title: IN BALLROOMS AND MANSIONS AROUND TOWN
description: For St. Clare's Dec. 2 - There will be reverential salutes and irreverent parodies of the Broadway theater in ''The Show That Money Can't Buy,'' the annual fund-raising and awards dinner for St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. Helen Hayes will present a humanitarian award to Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization. Cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by dinner and skits at the Pierre. Tickets for the black-tie evening $250, from Linda Greenough at 212-307-0735. Collegiate Benefit Dec. 4 - The Independent College Fund of New York has distributed more than $20 million in assistance to 32 member institutions and students since its founding in 1952. Fund-raising is its life blood, and a black-tie evening at Harkness House, 4 East 75th Street, will serve that purpose. There will be a viewing of American paintings, 1800 to 1895, along with Champagne at 6 P.M., followed by dinner and dancing. Tickets $175, from 212-744-2914. For the Red Cross Dec. 4 - Red Cross-sponsored shelters for the homeless will benefit from the premiere of the movie ''The Jewel of the Nile'' at the Sutton Theater, followed by a Moroccan supper party at Regine's. Tickets $200, from Rachel Trachten at 212-787-1000, extension 8111. Philharmonic Party Dec. 5 - The New York Philharmonic is holding its annual holiday party at the elegant Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street. Cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by singing by the University Glee Club and then dinner and dancing. Black tie. Tickets $175, from 212-580-8700, extension 377.

title: R. G. Douglas 3d Plans to Be Wed To Miss Trombly
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Trombly of Laconia, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Marie Trombly, to Robert Gordon Douglas 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas Jr. of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: 'THE MOST FAMOUS UNKNOWN IN THE WORLD' -- REMEMBERING DJUNA BARNES
description: ''YOU have to trust someone, Miss Barnes. Why not trust me?'' Only an author as aggravating as Djuna Barnes could have goaded me into making such a desperate plea, during a meeting in our publishing office. I was unaware I had nearly shouted these words until my assistant, in the outer room, repeated them to me. ''Do you think she trusts you now?'' she asked after Miss Barnes's departure. ''Did it work?'' Of course it didn't work. Nothing worked with Djuna Barnes, whose distrust of all book publishers seemed to be pathological, the product of her long and unhappy history with many companies here and abroad. She even rejected the word ''publishers''; they were ''printers'' to her. She was now almost 70 years old. She took advice only from her longtime friend and admirer T. S. Eliot, who happened to be her English publisher, and he told me that occasionally even his advice was flatly rejected.

title: Socially Neutral Spelling
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Most of Makeup
description: SOME WOMEN HAVE A compulsion about makeup products, rushing to the beauty counter to buy this new lipstick or that new lotion. Often, however, they invest more time, and money, than they have to - without necessarily reaping any beauty benefits. Using makeup wisely and economically is a matter of learning where to shop, when to splurge and how best to use the products that are purchased.

title: MASSACHUSETTS MIGHT BATTLE U.S. OVER SUBPOENAS OF LAWYERS
description: A new rule by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court that would discipline prosecutors for subpoenaing defense lawyers to testify against their clients without prior judicial approval could lead to a confrontation between the state and the Federal Justice Department, legal experts say.

title: ART
description: In terms of contemporary art, far more is happening now at the Brooklyn Museum than at any other museum in New York City. There is a small exhibition of paintings by Richard Diebenkorn on the lids of cigar boxes that continues through tomorrow.

title: COUNTRY FRENCH OF STELLAR QUALITY
description: CONSIDERING that Cafe du Bec Fin in Old Greenwich is one of the consistently fine restaurants in Fairfield County, it is not as widely known as it deserves to be. Yet six years after it opened, this tiny, country-French establishment continues to serve marvelous food in an effortless, low-key manner.

title: MAGICIAN PRIEST
description: Father Cyprian Murray, coordinator of preaching ministry for the Capuchin province of St. Mary, became enthralled with magic when he was 8 years old: ''I saw a movie, 'Fugitive Valley,' '' recalled the 47-year-old priest, who grew up in New Rochelle. ''It was a western, but there was this cowboy character who was also a magician. I went nuts. I asked my father to buy me a magic kit the very next day.''

title: Levitt Redux
description: Another housing community developed by Levitt Homes is rising on Long Island. Known as Woodcrest, it will number 110 houses on 51 acres in Coram, in Suffolk County.

title: Andrew Greenberg Weds Miss Sherry
description: Vivien Gail Sherry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Sherry of New York and Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Andrew Paul Greenberg, the son of William and Selma Greenberg of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Gunter Hirschberg, senior rabbi of Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, officiated at the Dag Hammarskjold Lounge in Columbia University's International Affairs Building.

title: ALABAMA FOOTBALL: SEA OF CHANGE, FEVER REMAINS
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, a man I knew said that if you wanted to poach a little game in Alabama, the best possible day would be the Saturday when Alabama and Auburn played football in Birmingham. On that afternoon, he said, every game warden in the state would be close to the radio following the game, and the woods would be yours. I never checked out the theory, but I feel sure it was valid.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ''THE STING OF DEATH'' AND OTHER STORIES. By Toshio Shimao. Translated by Kathryn Sparling. (Center for Japanese Studies, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Paper, $7.)

title: RULES FOR LAWYERS REVIEWED
description: CONNECTICUT lawyers who violate their profession's code of ethics would be disciplined in public under new rules being considered by the State Judicial Department.

title: The Role of the Nurse: Many-Faceted and Growing
description: The description of the development of Caring, the cancer support group started by a group of innovative, concerned nurses [About Long Island: ''From a Crisis, a Crusade Is Born,'' Nov. 3] fits in beautifully with the Health & Medicine: Employment Outlook supplement [''New Hats for Nurses''] that appeared the same day.

title: A GOOD SIGN: INSIDERS ARE STILL BUYING
description: One bullish sign for stocks, even after a two-month rise in prices, is that corporate officers and directors - the ''insiders'' who have an especially close view of business prospects - remain buyers of many of their own companies' shares. The Insiders, an advisory letter published in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., reported that recent insider buying has been as intense as it was prior to the market's big upswings in 1982 and 1984.

title: YOUNG FASHIONS BY A YOUNG DESIGNER
description: HE headed east right after his graduation from the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising in Los Angeles, where he was a scholarship student. After a week in New York, David Cameron met Michaele Vollbracht and was hired just in time to help stage a fashion show at the Beacon Theater. That was three and a half years ago. By February, he will be shipping the first styles made under his own name to stores all over the country. He will be 25 years old that month.

title: MANUEL OUT FOR 4 GAMES
description: The Giants, fearing that Lionel Manuel's injured left hamstring muscle would not heal in a week or two, placed the second-year wide receiver on injured reserve today.

title: G.O.P. IN HUDSON IS LOOKING TO '87 RACE
description: THE Hudson County Republican Party, flushed with almost unprecedented success in last month's Assembly elections, is already looking ahead to the 1986 elections and, especially, to those in 1987.

title: IN THE ALBANY CRUCIBLE, NEW SUBSIDIES FOR SHELTER
description: UNTIL its programs went into decline a decade and more ago, New York State was a major producer of housing, and since then it has been seeking a way back into the field. One way in the last few years has been the issuance of tax-exempt housing bonds, which were used to build mixed-income rentals and to increase the affordability of new and exisiting houses and condominiums through below-market mortgages offered by the State of New York Mortgage Agency. Now a new program enacted by the Legislature in its last session is about to put state tax revenues directly to work in the housing field - $50 million initially. When Governor Cuomo signed the bill in April, he said he expected contracts to be signed over a year's time that would bring about the ''rehabilitation and construction of over 3,800 units of housing in New York State.''

title: Lasting Legacy of Fruitcake
description: FRUITCAKES INSPIRE PASSIONATE responses. They are either loved or hated. And I suspect that the antifruitcakers associate them with the commercially made variety laden with poor quality glaceed fruits and not much else.

title: Now Do Better In '86
description: According to Mae West, that genuinely American philosopher, ''too much of a good thing is . . . wonderful.'' But too much summitry may not be. After Geneva's gratifyingly warm but nonetheless thin gruel, more substance is more important than more summits.

title: PARKWAY DESIGNS
description: State transportation officials, whose plan for doing away with ''signalized intersections'' on the Saw Mill River Parkway has met resistance in several communities adjoining the parkway, have announced that they have officially put their plans on paper for communities to look at.

title: TRAINING FOR FUTURE FACTORIES
description: THIRTEEN of the state's 19 two-year colleges are involved in a computerized-manufacturing program designed to train engineers and technicians for the factories of the future.

title: Students Offered 'Beer Pass' To Vote in Maryland Election
description: Fraternity and sorority members at the University of Maryland violated state election laws by promising ''beer passes'' to students who voted in the recent College Park elections, officials said Friday.

title: WHAT A MOUNTAIN IS
description: THE SOLACE OF OPEN SPACES By Gretel Ehrlich. 131 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95.

title: FOR FREE TV FORUMS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMY INQUIRY EMBARRASSES INTELLIGENCE UNITS
description: Two years after the Army opened an internal investigation involving some of its most covert operations, the inquiry's secrecy has been shattered and the reputation of some of the Army's most elite units has been tarnished.

title: MASKED BANDITS STEAL DONATIONS AT ST. PATRICK'S
description: Two armed men wearing ski masks entered the parish house of St. Patrick's Cathedral last night, handcuffed four ushers and escaped with money gathered in collection boxes earlier in the day, the police said.

title: Margot Murtaugh To Wed in March
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Robert S. Wilson of Berkeley Heights, N.J., and Paul A. Murtaugh of Mamaroneck, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Margot Thorington Murtaugh to John McCullough Snell, the son of Maxine P. Snell of Chapel Hill, N.C., and the late Dr. John L. Snell. A March wedding is planned.

title: Cecile Owens Is Bride
description: At Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, Conn., yesterday Cecile R. Owens and Frank Xavier Plattner 3d, graduates of the University of Vermont, were married by the Rev. Dana Kennedy. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Owens of Westport and the bridegroom the son of Mr. and Mrs. Plattner Jr. of Douglaston, Queens.

title: ATLANTIC CITY BEFORE IT WAS SWEPT BY THE SANDS OF TIME
description: WHEN friends and co-workers learn that I haven't been to any of the seashore casinos, some of them regard me with a strange air indeed. ''Not even to look?'' a few ask. Not even to stroll the Boardwalk, I tell them.

title: THE WORLD AT ONE'S FINGERTIPS
description: The holidays are a likely time for buying a complete home entertainment system combining both video and audio functions. After all, such a system is a magnificent gift for the entire family, a splendid acquisition suited to a festive season.

title: B. Traven's Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WINNIE: My Life in the Institution. By Jamie Pastor Bolnick. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Twenty years ago, a woman who had lived her life in a mental institution wrote a book to prove she wasn't retarded.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Christmas Stocking You would think only Santa would know what products will be in oversupply this Christmas. But Midge Ivie Tyner, chairman of Tradewell Industries in New York City, says she can usually make a good guess. Her company, which buys excess inventories and resells them to chains and discounters, thrives on the miscalculations of manufacturers and retilers.

title: REVISED 'LORD BYRON' RETURNS
description: ''Lord Byron is pretty good opera material, you know,'' Virgil Thomson said the other day. ''Don't forget that in addition to being a poet, he was also a genius, a lord, a millionaire and a beauty. He was world famous by the age of 21. With all that going for you, you have to misbehave every day, just to cut yourself down to size.''

title: BOMB LEFT AT COASTMOSQUE IS DISARMED BY POLICE SQUAD
description: A police explosives squad has safely disarmed a bomb found on the steps of a mosque, the authorities say.

title: SAM SHEPARD'S MYTHIC VISION OF THE FAMILY
description: Whatever else any great American playwright has done, each one has created, and in turn become identified with, a personal vision of the American family. If anything, the measure of achievement in American drama has been a writer's ability to place a vivid family portrait within a larger, societal frame - or, more to the point, to make the family represent not only the writer's inner life but a set of outer conditions. One thinks of Arthur Miller's men, hustlers who lived through one Great Depression and live in fear of another; of Tennessee Williams's women, cut loose with the fall of the plantation aristocracy and thrown into the cruel cities. O'Neill, Odets, Inge, Albee - all conjure images of the family at war with itself.

title: URSULINES AT 450
description: It may not have been as widely noted as the Extraordinary Synod of Bishops that was convened in Rome last week, but another event of some significance within Catholicism occurred there as well: the 450th anniversary of the founding of the Ursuline Order.

title: Beth Heffernen Bride Of Thomas E. Sucher
description: Beth Ann Heffernen and Thomas Edward Sucher were married yesterday at St. John Chrysostom Roman Catholic Church in Wallingford, Pa., by Msgr. Frederick J. Stevenson.

title: QUALITY AND PRICE COME TOGETHER IN THE MIDDLE
description: In audio, as elsewhere, the middle class is the traditional repository of recognized virtue. It can afford to be. The economics work in its favor. Consider the price structure of audio equipment. Down in the low-budget bracket, cost matters most, sometimes tempting designers to cut corners in ways that offend the knowing ear. Upward from there, performance rises with price - up to a point. Then the law of diminishing returns takes hold, and prices rise a lot faster than performance. That way, virtue as defined by cost/performance ratios is squeezed both from top and bottom and therefore concentrates in the middle. So if you're looking for the best values, that's where you find them.

title: DAVID BYRNE'S NEW FILM CELEBRATES THE ORDINARY
description: ''Suburban houses and tin sheds are often the objects of ridicule,'' says David Byrne, sitting rigidly upright in his chair at the thought of those who would mock such prosaic objects. In an office whose cool white walls are dotted with snapshots of sheds and houses and rooftops, he continues, ''When people think of a beautiful image, they think of the Grand Canyon or Yosemite. I'm saying you can take what's in your backyard, turn it around, and give it the respect it deserves as a beautiful object.''

title: PROPAGATING WOODY VARIETIES IN WINTER
description: AT one time or another, nearly every gardener has wanted to propagate woody plants for his own garden. With the many difficult-to-obtain varieties, this may be the best, if not the only, way to add them to the garden.

title: Miss Dorsey Wed To G. F. Robison
description: Liane R. Dorsey and Gregory F. Robison were married yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., where the Rev. Edward Johnston and the Rev. Jerome Mangan, a Roman Catholic priest, co-officiated. Mr. and Mrs. George K. Dorsey of Purchase, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Vernon V. Robison of Seattle are the parents of the couple.

title: Directing The Met Museum
description: As one who has been given great pleasure and inspiration from the Metropolitan Museum of Art for many, many years, I am grateful that the man who took as his field 15th- and 16th-century French, Dutch and Flemish paintings watches over that great institution. We are extremely fortunate to have Philippe de Montebello. MIRIAN O. ROSENGARTEN Princeton, N.J.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in Postings on Nov. 3 about a residential condominium to be built on East 86th Street in Manhattan misstated the name of the development and the number of units. It will be called the Channel Club and will have 165 apartments.

title: Diane Chaplin Is Wed To David M. Kelleher
description: The marriage of Diane Chaplin, a concert cellist, to David M. Kelleher, the administrative director of the Center for American Music, took place yesterday at the couple's home in Manhattan. The Rev. Paul Stambach, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: A CITY LOOKS UPWARD WITH GRATITUDE
description: A CHEERFUL gurgle from the faucet was one of the sounds of thankfulness last week as many New Yorkers, reveling in the city's announcement that rainfall had ended the seven-month drought emergency, let the water run while they brushed their teeth.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BAAA Written and illustrated by David Macaulay. 64 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. (All ages) IN David Macaulay's bleak book about the end of humankind, the world has gone not to the dogs but to the sheep. For when the last person vanishes, a flock of sheep wander in from a remote pasture and quickly acquire all the accouterments of civilization: frozen pizza, video cassette recorders, traffic jams, neuroses and crime. Indistinguishable from the species they have replaced, the sheep replicate the good life of modern man, and in the process become as greedy, as violent, as cannibalistic as their predecessors.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GO FLY A KITE

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I see a church with a machine gun, I cannot see the crucified Christ in that church.'' - Bishop Dario Castrillon Hoyos, of Pereira, Colombia, on the theology of liberation. [3:4.]

title: ZELDA FICHANDLER WINS DRAMA AWARD
description: Zelda Fichandler, co-founder and producing director of the Arena Stage in Washington, has been named this year's winner of the Common Wealth Award for distinguished service in the dramatic arts.

title: Biting the Hand
description: The excuses and extenuations advanced for the Israeli spying operation in the U.S. include: (1) The accused American volunteered, and was not recruited; (2) the information stolen had to do with Arab and Soviet capabilities endangering Israel, and should have been shared anyway; (3) no secret documents affecting U.S. security were sought; (4) evidence was developed showing U.S. spying on Israel, proving ''everybody did it''; (5) the accused spy, claiming ''the F.B.I. is after me,'' was turned away from the Israeli Embassy in Washington before his capture, and (5) everyone in high authority in Israel was kept in the dark, and all the fault belongs to an overly enthusiastic antiterrorist operative.

title: HISTORICAL SOCIETY TO OPEN ITS CHRISTMAS ANTIQUES BAZAAR
description: ALL decked out with garlands of greenery, the exhibit hall of the Greenwich Civic Center will provide a colorful setting for the 28th annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar next weekend. The show, sponsored by the Greenwich, Conn., Historical Society, will be open from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. Friday and from 11 A.M to 6 P.M. on Saturday and next Sunday. There will be 55 exhibits set up by antiques dealers from 11 states.

title: ONCE AGAIN, MUBARAK IS SECOND-GUESSED
description: Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, had barely weathered the embarrassment of the Achille Lauro affair when yet another band of Arab gunmen hijacked Egyptair Flight 648 last weekend. Once again, Mr. Mubarak's handling of the crisis could cause him trouble as he struggles with acute economic and political problems.

title: STUDENTS JOINING A STAR-STUDDED CAST
description: CHRISTMAS has come early this year for students at the Anglo-American School on West 89th Street. For over a month now, they have been thinking, painting and singing Christmas. Watercolor angels, snowflake posters and traditional carols have filled the halls of the private school as students prepared for their debut tomorrow night at Symphony Space in a staged reading of Dickens's ''Christmas Carol.''

title: RANGERS' RALLY FAILS AGAINST PENGUINS
description: On one night the Rangers play like the contenders they fancy themselves to be; on the next they don't.

title: She'll Stand Trial
description: A Municipal Court judge in Los Angeles last week ordered Cathy Evelyn Smith to stand trial on charges of murdering the comedian John Belushi by injecting him with heroin in March 1982. Rejecting a defense assertion that Miss Smith was only a ''lackey and a gofer''for the comedian, who ''wanted what he wanted when he wanted it,'' Judge James E. Nelson concluded: ''Surely Mr. Belushi issued the invitation to the dance.

title: AVIATION AN 18-BILLION BUSINESS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The three major airports and aviation-related business generated $18.9 billion in economic activity and 293,000 jobs in the New York metropolitan region in 1984, according to a report issued by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: LEAVE THE UNICORN MYTH UNSULLIED
description: THE unicorn in the garden is back again, and that bothers me. After having caused something of an uproar at Madison Square Garden, the ''unicorn'' showed up last month at the Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands as part of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus menagerie.

title: History Of a French Family
description: Like Mrs. Chautemps Samuels, I am a French-born American citizen (Letters, Nov. 10, in response to ''The French: Portrait of a Country Through a Family,'' by Francine du Plessix Gray, Oct. 13). A graduate of Saint-Cyr, I fought for liberte, egalite, fraternite in the same Free French forces of General de Gaulle for which Francine du Plessix Gray's father gave his life.

title: SEASONAL WARMTH AND THE NEDDIEST
description: Decorations are up on the giant tree in New York's Rockefeller Center. Store windows sparkle. Children are composing wish lists for Christmas and Hanukkah. Party invitations are going out and families are making plans for annual holiday gatherings. A festive spirit warms the city, as it does every year.

title: Gail Pilgrim Wed To Bruce Johnson
description: Gail Louise Pilgrim and Bruce Charles Johnson, both lawyers, were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel. The bridegroom's father, the Rev. Charles Earl Johnson of Asheville, N.C., performed the ceremony.

title: WHAT DO THEY WANT?
description: SOME AMERICAN MEN By Gloria Emerson. 315 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: SAFETY OF OIL TANKS STUDIED
description: THE Nassau County Fire Marshal's office says there is little chance that an oil spill last February, the worst in Nassau County's history, could recur.

title: Unfair View Of New Yorkers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Directing The Met Museum
description: Philippe de Montebello has certainly ''consolidated'' his position as director of the Metropolitan and as a potent social force in the art world (''The Fine Art of Directing the Met Museum,'' by James R. Mellow, Nov. 3). But he has not addressed some of the Met's consistent problems.

title: EAST MEETS WEST IN BEIJING
description: In the expansion of business and trade between China and the United States in recent years, bridge has played a small but significant role. The enthusiasm of the Chinese hierarchy for the game allows occasional social encounters among people who are far apart in almost all respects.

title: HALLEY'S COMET DEC. 1, 1985
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 1:31 P.M. today and set at 3:09 A.M. tomorrow.

title: WALL ST. REDISCOVERS THE THRIFT STOCKS
description: THE news this year on the thrift industry has hardly been encouraging to investors. Hundreds of insolvent savings and loans whose losses would total some $16 billion if assets were liquidated. Panicky efforts by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to recapitalize the depleted Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Billion-dollar California associations put under new management to work out their problems over an extended period of time. The litany could continue.

title: PILOT SAYS A SECOND HIJACKER SURVIVED STORMING OF AIRLINER
description: The pilot of the hijacked Egyptair jetliner said today that a second hijacker survived the storming of the aircraft in Malta and was being treated at a Maltese hospital for a nervous breakdown.

title: MORMON NANNIES IN DEMAND ON L.I.
description: SUNDAY services at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Plainview had just concluded. As parents rounded up their clans in the lobby, Kim McDonald, 18 years old, and Donna Christensen, 20, stood aimlessly for a moment.

title: Wedding in April For Blyth Steere
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Mowry Steere of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Blyth Steere to William Thomas Bailey 4th, a son of Mr. Bailey 3d of Excelsior, Minn., and Kathryn Mary Kiland of Minneapolis. An April wedding is planned.

title: NUTS AND BOLTS OF FASTENING TO STONE
description: A DO-it-yourselfer will often be faced with the task of fastening things to a solid masonry surface - for example, mounting shelf brackets or standards on a cement block wall, attaching studs or furring strips to a poured concrete foundation wall, or hanging a sign or mailbox against a brick wall.

title: WHAT IT TAKES: THE LIFE OF A C.E.O.
description: STANDING AROUND A BROAD OVAL table in a partially darkened room are seven men. They seem slightly anxious, as though they are guests waiting for a dinner party to begin. The room has burnished wood paneling, tasteful carpeting and nicely upholstered chairs, and the congregants are all in the proper attire of business: white shirts, sober suits, decidedly unraffish ties.

title: BUYING PORCELAIN IN CHINA
description: Ha Biyuan of the Shanghai Antique and Curio Store, which says it is China's largest antique center -smiled a little sadly. ''American visitors are keen to buy antique porcelain,'' he said, ''but many believe we sell antiques in sets. Most are one of a kind. All have a period, most a date mark. Some have an artist's name.''

title: HISTORY, UP AND DOWN
description: The Age of Reagan Second-term Presidents, so conventional wisdom runs, have their eyes on history. But in the remainder of Ronald Reagan's final term, the reverse will also be the case - a trained historian will be eyeing the President. Whatever the fruits of this experiment, the choice of Edmund Morris as witness is promising. He comes to the task with impressive credentials and without political baggage.

title: TAKING ON TERRORISM
description: Vice President Bush's Task Force on Combating Terrorism is expected to make its recommendations to President Reagan soon, completing a study that began this summer with the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet but one that has been subject to updating ever since with each new outrage of political violence. Ten ranking executives from print and electronic news organizations were invited the other day to meet with the Vice President and the panel's chairman, retired Adm.

title: THE FAMINE WORKERS
description: WHEN I LAST saw Hamid Bahamid, he was 4 years old and weighed 40 pounds. He was born in the Eritrean mountains across the border in Ethiopia; he will probably die in a hot tent in a refugee camp in the featureless desert of eastern Sudan.

title: EDISON COMPLEX HAILED FOR ITS SAFETY
description: THIRTY inspectors from the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration recently studied safety features at the Mobil Chemical Company's laboratory complex here as part of their own training in what to look for when they inspect the nation's work places.

title: Susan Gaeta To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Anthony R. Gaeta of Willowbrook, S.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lee Gaeta, to Timothy Michael Demkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Demkin of Riverhead, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: BHOPAL IS IN MIDST OF GRIM RECOVERY A YEAR AFTER LEAK
description: One year after a poison gas leak at the Union Carbide factory here, a major relief effort is reaching thousands of people while thousands more continue to have trouble breathing and working.

title: AT NIGHT, THE BOSS BECOMES A BARITONE
description: EVERY so often someone walks into a nightclub in Manhattan, looks at the baritone singing Gershwin or Cole Porter on stage and says, ''Oh my God!'' It's another instance of someone discovering the double life of Harvey Granat.

title: CRANSTON ARMING FOR TOUGH FIGHT
description: Preparing for what he says will be a tough re-election battle next year, Senator Alan Cranston is busy trying to make a political virtue out of being selected for defeat by the Republican right wing. Meanwhile, he is active doing one of the things he does best: raising money.

title: A WATCHFUL EYE TO CARE FOR HOMES IN THE COUNTRYSIDE
description: BEAR VAN ASCH VAN WYCK is a man of many roles. To begin with, he says he is a Dutch baron, a title he inherited from his maternal grandfather. He is also an artist, a teacher, a dealer of English antiques, and a budding breeder of English springer spaniels.

title: DRINKING AGE RISES TO 21 AMID DEBATE
description: ON Friday, Edmund Brett celebrated his 20th birthday with a drink. But starting today, he must wait until he reaches the age of 21 to be legally served a drink again in New York State, and that makes him angry.

title: MUSIC: KOTIK AND OLIVEROS IN AVANT- GUARDE PROGRAM
description: BOTH Petr Kotik and Pauline Oliveros use repetition to narrow and focus our attention, but their compositions at the Samaya Foundation on Leonard Street Friday night occupied separate worlds of experience.

title: FAIRFIELD THEATER SEEKS A 2D SEASON
description: AFTER its brief first season of four plays last winter, the Boston Post Road Stage Company in Fairfield seemed ready to continue for a second year. Then the founders of the professional theater, Rob and Ellen LaGamba, decided that it was more financially advantageous to pursue their acting careers in Florida, instead.

title: The 'Shrinking' Professor
description: I wonder how necessary or productive it really is to invest teachers with the heroic, larger-than-life stature Laurence Shames describes in his article ''First Encouragements'' (About Men, Oct. 27)? This image, alluring as it may sometimes seem, too often isolates the teacher from students. Mr. Shames's anger at Professor Greene for ''shrinking'' reveals an egotism far more troubling than any acknowledgement of his teacher's importance to him.

title: JULES VERNE'S COMET
description: To the Editor:

title: FREE AGENTS MAY BE LESS FREE TO MOVE
description: WHO said no one is interested in free agents? Why, five free agents have already signed, and they represent the greatest number of free agents who have signed in any November since 1979. In the intervening five Novembers, a total of nine signed. But - and that's a big BUT - the signing of those five probably says as much about the free-agent game, as clubs are playing it this year, as anything.

title: NORTH CAROLINA WINS, 73-62
description: With Kenny Smith and Brad Daugherty scoring 16 points each, North Carolina today defeated Purdue, 73-62, to move into the championship game of the eighth annual Great Alaska Shootout tournament.

title: SYRACUSE IS UPSET, 13-10
description: Mike Timko drove West Virginia 75 yards in less than a minute tonight and passed 5 yards for the winning touchdown to Grantis Bell with 36 seconds to play for a 13-10 upset of bowl-bound Syracuse.

title: Maura Finneran Becomes a Bride
description: Maura Agnes Finneran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thomas Finneran Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Bruce Platow, a son of Mrs. Charles W. Horsfall of Westport, Conn., and the late Raymond C. Platow. The Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan, assisted by the Rev. Charles Gonzalez, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church.

title: Scott Harris King, Mariner, to Marry Beryl Elizabeth Brown, an Architect
description: Beryl Elizabeth Brown, an architect, and Scott Harris King, a master mariner, plan to be married in June, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Archibald Hoadley Brown of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Boston, have announced.

title: 74TH APPEAL FOR NEEDIEST CASES FUND OPENS
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 74th annual appeal today to help the poor and downtrodden in the New York metropolitan area.

title: L. P. Boissiere Jr. to Wed Nicki Locker in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Locker of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nina Fran Locker to Lionel P. Boissiere Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boissiere of Chino, Calif. A March wedding is planned.

title: FOR THE 12-0 BEARS, DEFENSE MAULS WITH IMAGINATION
description: AMAZING facts about the Bears: 1. The defense has allowed just three touchdowns in the last seven games and none in the last 13 quarters. 2. When they beat the New England Patriots early in the season, 20-7, the Patriots had the ball on the Bears' side of the field for all of 21 seconds. 3. Seven players have intercepted three or more passes, and four have five or more sacks. 4. With three safeties, they are within one of tying the National Football League record for most in a season. 5. Through 12 weeks of play, their defense leads the league in - take a deep breath - fewest points allowed (127), fewest touchdowns allowed (15), fewest yards allowed (256.9 per game), fewest rushing yards allowed (82.3 per game), most sacks (50), most interceptions (30) and most interceptions returned for touchdowns (4). ''But we're not as good as we were last year.'' What? Who said that? Call the white coats. Is this guy serious?

title: LITERACY PROGRAM FOCUSES ON SEVERELY DISABLED ADULTS
description: HAL, Burt and Dean expend enormous amounts of energy each day in hiding a basic fact about themselves. Hal refuses to answer the phone at work, to avoid being forced to record a message. Burt rarely leaves familiar areas of the county, because he is not sure he can find his way back home. Ed keeps an ear to the radio to hear about current events.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IS IT merely politics, or is there a serious problem in Mercer County? ''It's politics, pure and simple,'' said Bill Mathesius, the County Executive and a Hopewell Township Republican. ''This is a bridge of convenience.''

title: PLANNING AHEAD FOR THE DESSERT COURSE OF INFORMAL DINNERS
description: BECAUSE they tend to be time-consuming, desserts are often overlooked in planning an informal dinner party. There is nothing wrong with serving cheese and fruit instead. But I have become so tired recently of playing Russian roulette with the fruit market, wasting time and money on gorgeous-looking ''gardener's prizes'' that turn out to be inedible, that I have gone back to making desserts again.

title: A WORDLESS, ANONYMOUS MEMORIAL
description: A century ago this week, across Lafayette Square from the White House, a Washington celebrity died by her own hand, and a masterpiece of sculpture found its occasion. Marian Hooper Adams was Washington's leading hostess of the day and one of the first American women to take a serious interest in photography. She was 42 years old.

title: SHIPPING STILL THRIVES HERE, BUT ITS FUTURE IS THREATENED
description: FROM the 10th floor of an old office building at the tip of Manhattan, men with binoculars keep watch on the blue-black waters of New York Harbor and see what few people ever get to see.

title: 'NUTCRACKER' GOING STRONG AT 93
description: It's ''Nutcracker'' time again, and once more the New York City Ballet will conjure up that enchanted world where a Christmas tree rises to astonishing heights, snowflakes dance and other wonders too numerous to mention follow one another without pause. It will materialize at the New York State Theater on Thursday night and continue through 38 performances ending Jan. 5.

title: BROOKLYN GIRL, 16 FOUND SLAIN
description: Homicide detectives yesterday investigated the slaying of a 16-year-old girl in her home in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Science Fiction Epic
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN VOICES WORRY ON SPIES OF ANY NATION
description: President Reagan said today that the United States would not hesitate to root out and prosecute the spies of any nation, letting the ''chips fall where they may.''

title: Time to Abolish Boards of Education?
description: I have taught in Smithtown for 23 years. Our new contract, a fair one, was finally ratified. Its history followed virtually the same scenario as the last number of contracts: negotiations, impasse, mediation, super-conciliator, picketing, job-action considerations, the whole time- and talent-consuming nine yards.

title: OFF-DUTY OFFICERS DOUBLING AS PRIVATE GUARDS, BUT SYSTEM DRAWS CRITICISM
description: A uniformed officer stood guard over construction workers repairing the sidewalk outside the Chapel Square Mall. Other police officers patrolled inside the mall. Still more patrolled the parking garage underneath.

title: Helen J. Crettier Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Helen Judith Crettier, a daughter of Mrs. Charles Rudolph Crettier of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Mr. Crettier, was married to Charles Cafritz Wilkes, the son of Mrs. William N. Cafritz of Bethesda, Md., and Charles L. Wilkes of Washington. The Rev. Gerald L. Lewis, assisted by the Rev. Frederick Hoesli, performed the ceremony.

title: About Men;   Electric Trains
description: MEN AND BOYS - INHERENTLY, IT seems - have always been fascinated by electric trains. Last Christmas, I rediscovered my own fascination with them when my mother and father surprised and delighted me with the set of Lionel trains that I had enjoyed when they were first given to me more than 25 years ago.

title: NYACK: A COMPLEX WORLD IN SILK
description: KIYOMI IWATA is an artist who uses silk only to defy its most obvious characteristics of softness and fragility. A representative selection of her recent works is on view through Dec. 22 at the Edward Hopper House here.

title: CHANNEL BASS PROVE ELUSIVE
description: IN the surf just south of here at the easternmost tip of Cape Hatteras, two of nature's most powerful ocean forces collide. The warm-water Gulf Stream and the frigid Labrador Current meet again and again on the watery battlefield of the ever-moving sand bars known as Diamond Shoals.

title: HOUSE VALUES SURGE IN THE OLDER AREAS OF NORTHERN QUEENS
description: PERHAPS not since the mid-1960's, when urban pioneers from Manhattan began reclaiming the long-neglected but architecturally distinctive houses of Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope, has an area of the city seen such a dramatic rise in real-estate values as have the older working-class neigh-borhoods of northern Queens. House prices in the area have doubled and in some cases tripled in the last three to four years, and interest in commercial properties also is booming.

title: NEW YORK CITES FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: LOSING BIDDER IN U.P.I DEAL IS SUIT TARGE
description: Another round in the battle over who is to acquire United Press International is scheduled to take place tomorrow when a Federal bankruptcy court in Washington holds a hearing on a request for a temporary restraining order aimed at a rejected suitor's attempts to replace the winning bidder.

title: CONTENDERS ASSESS MT. PLEASANT UPSET
description: VINCENT M. VALENTI of Valhalla, by self-proclaimation ''one of the exemplary pasta eaters in the world,'' has found a way to satisfy his doctor's demands that he shed some pounds: not by jogging around a track but by running for office.

title: FORMER ECONOMIST AT CORNELL
description: Melvin G. de Chazeau, an economist who was an authority on the steel and petroleum industries and a retired Cornell University professor, died Thursday at the Arlington (Va.) Hospital after a brief illness.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 10 on hotel barges in Europe gave an incorrect phone number for Continental Waterways of Boston. The correct number is 800-227-1281 for calls from outside Massachusetts.

title: STEAMBOAT IS A TEST FOR LIFELONG SAILOR
description: THE newest addition to Dr. Gifford B. Pinchot's household requires constant watching, balks stubbornly now and then and habitually emits ear-splitting belches. But Dr. Pinchot is clearly in love with his new steamboat, the Puffin.

title: U.S. ASSISTANCE REPORTED IN MALTA RAID
description: At least two American military officers provided technical assistance in Malta to the Egyptian commandos who stormed a hijacked Egyptian airliner last Sunday, according to sources in Washington and an official here who said he spoke with the Americans before the raid.

title: KEY GAMBINO WITNESS IS EXPECTED
description: When testimony resumes this week in the trial of Paul Castellano, the reputed head of the Gambino crime group, and nine others on charges of operating a car theft ring, the jury is expected to hear from the man prosecutors say often delivered Mr. Castellano's ''cut'' from the operation.

title: THOSE VCR'S ARE CAUSING SOMETHING MOMENTOUS
description: The basic facts of the VCR revolution are these: video cassette recorders are currently selling at the rate of one million a month. There are now more than 20 million VCR's in use and, by early 1986, it's estimated that one out of every three American homes will be equipped. Serving these customers are some 20,000 video cassette rental shops, or approximately one shop for every movie theater in the country.

title: ORCHESTRA WELCOMES A NEW MAESTRO
description: WHEN a new conductor faces an orchestra for the first time in rehearsal, the confrontation is similar to two animals meeting in the wild, said Michael Lankester, the new music director of the Hartford Symphony.

title: TOPICS
description: SURFCASTING on the outer beach at Fire Island seemed to me the perfect start to a fall day. I stood on the dunes watching as fishermen cast out.

title: THE JAPANESE ARE SLOWLY COMING TO FEAR BIG BROTHER
description: For most of their history, the Japanese have willingly told their Government just about anything it wanted to know, from the number of golf bags per household to how often they used a toothbrush.

title: MONUMENTS TO KEEPING FAITH
description: I GREW up in a family of strong traditions of storytelling and prayer, of keeping in touch with relatives, visiting them while they were alive and tending their graves when they were gone. Cemetery jaunts were frequent and loving ventures. We learned much about many of the other families besides our own as we passed the multitude of stones along the winding paths.

title: SHRIVER UPSET IN AUSTRALIA
description: Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden scored a shocking 3-6, 6-3, 6-2 victory over the fourth-seeded Pam Shriver of the United States in today's third round of the $1.5 million Australian Open Tennis Championships.

title: IMAGINE SHERLOCK AS A BOY...
description: The setting is Victorian London: streets teeming with horse-drawn carriages and hurrying figures in dark capes, venerable boys' schools with libraries dating back to the Middle Ages, characters with Dickensian names like Waxflatter and Cragwitch, Badcock and Bobster, Snelgrove and Mrs. Dribb.

title: CANAL CABLE RIDE? 'IT WOULD BE A GAS'
description: IN the 19th century, coal barges would get from New Jersey's Delaware and Raritan Canal to Pennsylvania's Delaware Canal (or vice versa) by being attached to a cable 15 feet above the water and floated across the Delaware River.

title: AT OLD BAILEY, POWDER PUFFS VS. HOBNAILS
description: When a rowdy soccer fan named Kevin Whitton was sentenced to life imprisonment the other day, Members of Parliament and editorial writers outdid one another in praise for the judge. When a former philosophy student named Nicholas Boyce got six years in jail, no one bothered to comment on the sentence.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WOLF OF SHADOWS By Whitley Strieber. 105 pp. New York: Sierra Club Books/ Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95. (Ages 5 to 9) NO matter how much we may wish to protect them, our children know they live under the shadow of a mushroom cloud.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: AMERICAN AVOCET Recurvirostra americana Size: 16 to 20 inches long.

title: COLLEGES ACT TO SOFTEN BLOW OF NEW LAW ON DRINKING
description: FOR the last time, students at Manhattanville College in Purchase crammed into The Laundry Room, the campus pub, for a night of dancing and drinking. The beer flowed and the music blared, but for many it was not a happy occasion.

title: Article 194942 -- No Title
description: Arnold Palmer, the oldest member of the foursome at age 56 but still the most popular, earned $45,000 on today's front nine of the Skins Game with birdies at the fourth and sixth holes at the Bear Creek Club.

title: OOMBARDI LETTERS
description: IN its passion for pre-eminence, Notre Dame has changed football coaches again. But in its quick hiring of Lou Holtz following Gerry Faust's resignation, how many interested coaches out there did it ignore? Twice, it develops now, Notre Dame ignored Vince Lombardi.

title: EXCLUSIVE NAVESINK GETS 2 CONDO PROJECTS
description: WHETHER it was the Lenni-Lenape Indians who gave the Navesink River its name, or, as one legend goes, it came about because the gentle waters would never sink a ship, the name has come to represent an unusually attractive section of New Jersey where the river meets the ocean.

title: BOY PLAYS ON GIRLS' TEAM
description: LIKE many 12-year-old boys, Jeremy Vail of Stafford Springs is absorbed with sports. Whatever the game -baseball, football, basketball and soccer, among others - Jeremy has probably played it.

title: BANKER REFLECTS ON A CAREER OF GROWTH
description: WHEN John E. Dowling was 35 years old, he was named head of the Westchester Federal Savings Bank in New Rochelle, the oldest savings bank in the county, founded in 1888. Now Mr. Dowling, who will be 63 on Christmas Day, has announced that he expects to retire as chairman and chief executive officer of the Westchester Financial Services Corporation and the Westchester Federal Savings Bank by year's end, or when the search for a new chief executive officer is completed.

title: SOPHISTICATED REGION-HOPPING
description: WITHOUT striving for urban chic, Barney's in Locust Valley has achieved a higher level of sophistication in a tastefully understated country setting than most of the hard-edged, high-energy spots that have opened on the Island recently.

title: A Whiff Of History
description: An archeologist of airspace might have spotted an indomitable little cloud of cigar smoke last week over the Manhattan parking lot between 49th and 50th Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues, where a consortium led by the Zeckendorf Company hopes to erect a $500 million housing and office complex.

title: 'CAROUSEL' IS BACK IN ALL ITS GLORY
description: THEATER talk has it that a big-time Broadway revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''Carousel'' is brewing. For maybe five minutes, rumors circulated that Stephen Sondheim, whose mentor was Oscar Hammerstein II, would direct such a revival either in New York or London.

title: INWOOD RESIDENTS GO 3 DAYS WITHOUT WATER
description: Hundreds of residents in the Inwood section of Manhattan have been without water since Wednesday night because of a water-main break, a spokesman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: SELF-PORTRAITS: 36 ARTISTS INVESTIGATE THE INNER SELF
description: AS a genre, artists' self-portraits are usually far more interesting than their portraits of others. The impulse to face oneself in the mirror and set down a record of the resulting encounter often has intriguing consequences, quite unlike the effect of portraying another person, for however intimate our connection or perceptive our insights, we remain outsiders to everyone but ourselves.

title: WHY THE LID IS ON PRICES, AT LAST
description: EACH month's inflation news suggests our new environment of low inflation has staying power. But how long can it continue? Right now, the dollar's decline since last winter is causing concern that inflation may reignite - a lower dollar could mean a rise in the price of imported raw materials and finished goods, and corresponding price increases in similar domestic products. This concern assumes that the dollar will continue to fall and that the inflationary response will be symmetrical to its response when the dollar was rising. Such symmetry has occurred in the past. But a symmetrical response is not likely this time, nor is the dollar likely to retrace its rise and give up the 87 percent it gained over the five-year period that ended last winter.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WORD OF HONOR. By Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $17.50.) This methodically paced novel - the genre is military courtroom drama - concerns a Vietnam War atrocity.

title: GROUPS TO SUE OVER STATE RULES ON 'HIGH RISK' SEX
description: A coalition of groups opposed to discrimination against homosexuals said yesterday that it would sue the state to strike down new rules that seek to slow the spread of AIDS by closing establishments that permit ''high risk'' sexual activity.

title: DEVILS OUTPLAYED LOSE TO CAPITALS, 6-2
description: Giveaways in their zone and an inability to kill penalties and get shots off on breaks were the primary reasons the Devils were defeated, 6-2, by the Washington Capitals tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: HIS BATTLE CRY WAS 'VALOR!'
description: COLLECTED STORIES By Tennessee Williams. With an introduction by Gore Vidal. 574 pp. New York: New Directions. $19.95.

title: HEMPSTEAD SEEKS TO CURB ASBESTOS
description: FEAR of lung cancer and other diseases believed to be linked to asbestos has prompted the Town of Hempstead to draft regulations that would allow close monitoring of any business using asbestos.

title: SAMSON AND MOLE
description: LONDON MATCH By Len Deighton. 407 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: BRAVE BUT HAPLESS PHYLLIS
description: THE HANDYMAN By Penelope Mortimer. 199 pp. New York: A Joan Kahn Book/St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: GOODE CALLS MARCH INFLAMATORY
description: The police arrested 34 demonstrators today as they marched into a mostly white neighborhood where demonstrations have been barred under a state of emergency declared because of protests against blacks moving in.

title: AT 50 THE DC-3 'GOONEY BIRD' IS STILL FLYING HIGH
description: When the National Aeronautic Association holds its annual Wright Brothers dinner Friday in Washington, gracing the head table will be a chunky, snub-nosed, 50-year-old guest of honor: a Douglas DC-3.

title: S. S. Birnkrant Marries Frann Tillman
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., last evening Frann Leigh Tillman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Tillman of Jericho, L.I., was married to Stephen Saul Birnkrant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwin M. Birnkrant of Pontiac, Mich. Rabbi Stanley Steinhart, assisted by Cantor Israel Goldstein, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Lynam Marries Michael McEneaney
description: Mary-Jane Therese Lynam, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Lynam of East Williston, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Anthony McEneaney, a son of Sylvia P. McEneaney of New York and the late Edward G. McEneaney. The Rev. Dennis J. Whelan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Aidan in Williston Park, L.I.

title: Holly Elizabeth Brown Becomes Bride in Rye
description: Holly Elizabeth Brown, a daughter of Mrs. Oran Gould Kirkpatrick Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Charles S. Brown of Utica, Mich., was married yesterday to William Robert Alexander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence E. Alexander of Hoffman Estates, Ill. The Rev. Penny L. Newell and the Rev. Howard B. Major 3d performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: THE SPLENDORS OF LALIQUE JEWELRY
description: Rene Lalique's jewelry -sculptural fantasies rooted in nature, rich in symbolism and medieval imagery -has been coveted by connoisseurs and known mostly through photographs by the public since it was crafted at the turn of the century. In ''Art Nouveau Jewelry by Rene Lalique,'' on view at the Walters Art Gallery here through Jan. 5, we see for the first time in this country many of Lalique's masterpieces in this medium, works that rank among the most splendid jewelry designs ever produced.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MY LOVE, MY LOVE: Or The Peasant Girl. By Rosa Guy. (Holt, $12.95.) This slim, deceptively simple novel takes its shape from Hans Christian Andersen's ''Little Mermaid.''

title: BACK ON HIS PEDESTAL
description: UNCOMMON CLAY The Life and Works of Augustus Saint Gaudens. By Burke Wilkinson. Photographs by David Finn. 428 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: EWING FOULS OUT
description: Through all of the miseries that have plagued the Knicks so far this season, there has been one hopeful constant: With Patrick Ewing on the court and playing well, they are capable of staying close to almost any team. But without him, forget it. Last night's encounter with the engimatic Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden effectively ended with 5 minutes 43 seconds remaining on the clock. That is when Ewing -who had more than held his own against the 76ers' indefatigable all-star center, Moses Malone - was charged with his sixth and final personal foul after an ill-fated attempt to stop the powerful forward Charles Barkley from driving to the basket on a fast break.

title: ITHACA ROUTS MONTCLAIR BY 50-28
description: Before the kickoff, today's playoff looked like an even match because Ithaca had won 9 of 10 games and Montclair State had taken 10 in a row after an opening loss to Wagner. But the game quickly became a mismatch as Ithaca won, 50-28, and advanced to the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III playoffs.

title: YES, TAX REFORM, BUT NOT VERY MUCH
description: TAX reform: The words conjure up the image of a modern-day Sisyphus, forever condemned to push weighty proposals up the hill, only to see hordes of well-heeled, oil company lobbyists hurl the nuggets back down to the Brookings Institution from which they were launched.

title: TREE HOUSE WINS IN ZONING APPEAL
description: AFTER months of uncertainty, a house has found a home in Lewisboro. By a vote of 3 to 1, the Lewisboro Zoning Board of Appeals has spared the tree house that James and Frances Pazereckas and their three children built in their backyard on Sabbathday Road.

title: HOWARD CHALLENGED FOR POST
description: TWO members of the Republican majority are struggling for the leadership post of the politically volatile Suffolk County Legislature, with another Republican and the Democratic minority likely to decide the outcome.

title: BUSES AID TOWN'S MERCHANTS
description: HOLIDAY shoppers in downtown Westport often have trouble finding a parking space, but merchants are attempting to remedy that problem by having their employees ride shuttle buses to and from work.

title: Anne E. Hartog Plans To Marry Roger Stark
description: The engagement of Anne Elise Hartog to Roger Douglas Stark has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jack B. Hartog of New York, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Ethel Stark of Hemet, Calif., and the late Frank Stark.

title: ALBANY PREPARES 2 NEW JOB PLANS
description: Governor Cuomo says he will seek to guarantee a job in private industry to every New York high school graduate, starting next year, to help stem the rising tide of dropouts.

title: NO LULL FOR LEGISLATIVE PANELS
description: EVEN though the General Assembly does not reconvene until Feb. 3, most legislative committees have been meeting weekly throughout the fall.

title: THEATER SHOWS PHOTOS, TOO
description: TEN years ago, Rocky Barry returned home to New Milford from Boston University with a film degree and a plan to put new life into the town's forgotten movie theater. The building had been boarded up for eight years, and Mr. Barry's father and a partner, who owned it, were planning to sell it to be used as a warehouse.

title: Marta A. Johnson To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Glenn M. Johnson of Tenafly, N.J., and Sun Valley, Idaho, have announced the engagement of their daughter Marta Ann Johnson to Matthew Bowditch Judson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Judson of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Nantucket, Mass. A March wedding is planned.

title: A NEW LENDER OF LAST RESORT
description: LAST year, the owner of the 30-acre lot that housed the Meredith Trailer Park, near Meredith, N.H., decided to sell the property. Thirteen families that lived there wanted to buy it. But they needed $42,000 - a sum not easily obtainable for people with modest incomes.

title: SEASON BRINGS 'NUTCRACKER'
description: FOR all family members, not just ballet lovers, one of the treats of Christmastime is ''The Nutcracker.'' So it has been ever since 1892, when Marius Petipa set Tchaikovsky's score into motion in St. Petersburg.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: I MADE A MISTAKE. Written and illustrated by Miriam Nerlove. Margaret K. McElderry/Atheneum. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8) A delightful retelling of the old jump-rope jingle about a little girl who keeps making ridiculous mistakes - ''I went to the bathroom to brush my hair, I made a mistake and brushed a bear.'' Once started, readers can make up their own verses. TUNNELS. By Sam and Beryl Epstein. Little, Brown. $14.95. (Ages 9 and up) A very informative book written in conversational style about all kinds of tunnels - for carrying water, connecting waterways, going through mud, through mountains, beneath cities and even for escape. Illustrated with photographs, charts and diagrams. A FARMER'S ALPHABET. Written and illustrated by Mary Azarian. David R. Godine. Paper, $7.95. (Ages 3 to 5) A new, smaller, paperback edition of a handsome alphabet book depicting farm life. The illustrations are distinctive woodcuts, and the frontispiece shows the artist herself at work. MO TO THE RESCUE. By Mary Pope Osborne. Illustrated by DyAnne DiSalvo-Ryan. Dial. $8.95.

title: Deer Complaints On Block Island
description: FOR years, residents of Block Island have complained about the deer that nibbled their vegetables and chomped their rose bushes.

title: Commons Backs British-Irish Pact By a Wide Margin
description: Britons really don't understand the Irish, Edward Heath, the former Prime Minister, conceded last week in the parliamentary debate on the new British-Irish accord for Northern Ireland. Mr. Heath's wry comments notwithstanding, the House of Commons accepted the pact, 473 to 47, overriding Northern Irish Unionists who insisted there was ''nothing in the agreement'' for the Protestant majority in the North.

title: THE $90 BILLION CHEATS
description: What the Government figures people are failing to pay in income tax has become known in Washington as the ''tax gap.'' The loss is estimated at $90 billion this year, and, as part of the tax overhaul drive, Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx is requesting a one-time, six-month amnesty from penalties for tax cheaters who come forward and pay up. Even with that, it is estimated that at least two-thirds would opt to stay hidden.

title: CO-OP REPORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Aeroplane in the Greenhouse As if his plays and books were not enough to carry his ideas and opinions to the world, George Bernard Shaw was a tireless writer of letters to newspapers. Many of them are collected in ''Agitations: Letters to the Press 1875-1950'' (Frederick Ungar), edited by Dan H. Laurence and James Rambeau. In this one, Shaw writes to The Times of London to defend his plays against the charge of too much talk.

title: Jean Peake Is Wed
description: Jean MacDougall Peake and Dr. John M. Hill, a staff physician for Executive Health Examiners in New York, were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Edward N. Maxwell performed the ceremony.

title: HIGH-TECH FILING, AND A TOUCH OF CLASS
description: ORGANIZATIONAL mania has hit the nation's automotive junkyards. Owners are filling weed- and rust-infested yards with gravel and asphalt, stacking auto frames neatly on huge metal shelves, and cataloguing their inventories on computer. Some even display their wares in carpeted showrooms.

title: CHINA YOUTH LEAGUE LEADER
description: An army veteran from a worker's family was elected today to head China's 48-million-member Communist Youth League, the New China News Agency reported. The new leader, Song Defu, replaced Hu Jintao, who became secretary of the Guizhou provincial party committee.

title: CABLE TV
description: Movie buffs can try a cluster of attic pearls this cable week, starting with ''We Live Again'' (1934), an adaptation of Tolstoy's ''Resurrection'' - Wednesday at 10 A.M. on Showtime. Sensitively played by Anna Sten, as a wronged servant girl, and Fredric March, as her princely seducer, this beautifully photographed drama shares the classy look of other pre-war Samuel Goldwyn productions like ''Dead End,'' ''These Three'' and ''Wuthering Heights.''

title: TOYS THE BIG KIDS ARE BUYING
description: ''IT used to be so simple,'' the man was saying. ''You'd get the wife a blouse. Maybe a necklace. I'd get my 15th pair of bedroom slippers. Now look at me.''

title: NOW SEEKS TO REKINDLE ENTHUSIASM OF PAST
description: AFTER a sea of empty chairs greeted panelists at a recent meeting of the Mid-Fairfield County chapter of the National Organization for Women, the president, Ruth Lyon, decided to poll members to see why attendance had been dropping off and what might be done to regenerate interest.

title: SETBACKS PLAGUE AMERICA'S CUP DEFENSE
description: Alan Bond and his Australian yacht racing syndicate have basked in the glory of winning the America's Cup for the last two years. But the high times appear to be giving way lately to a spate of unsettling circumstances.

title: Verbatim;   The Angolan Conflict
description: 'U.S. involvement in this conflict, whether direct or indirect, covert or overt, would damage our relations with governments throughout Africa and undermine fundamental U.S. policy objectives in southern Africa.' 101 members of Congress in a letter to President Reagan warning against aid to rebels fighting the Government of Angola.

title: GORBACHEV TRIES TO SHIFT THE ECONOMY INTO TOP GEAR
description: Going around Moscow is a joke that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is supposed to have told President Reagan during some casual fireside banter in Geneva 10 days ago. A philosophical listener calls a radio station to ask whether there can be a solution to an insoluble problem. The station responds: ''We don't reply to questions about agriculture.''

title: LONDON
description: If there is a time that a visitor can sense Jolly Old England in this sprawling capital, part ancient and part still going up, it's in December and January, when the nights are long and florists put pots of violets in their shop windows and the holiday lights have been strung since early November. The English celebrate the holidays with Dickensian zest and amazing staying power: Christmas trees in homes are decorated by the second week in December and stay up until Twelfth Night (Jan. 6), long after the last of the chocolates with which they are laden have been unwrapped and eaten. Many people manage to take a great deal of time off work during the holidays, and it's a good time to catch them in a friendly mood. Bear in mind, though, that museums and most restaurants are closed Dec. 24 to 26 and on Jan. 1 and theaters take a break on Christmas, so on those days visitors must check first before going anywhere.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE gymnasium at the State University of New York at Purchase is a far cry from field or forest. Fluorescent lights shine overhead; gymnastic equipment crowds the corners. From next door come the sounds of a bowling alley.

title: JAPAN'S POLIC GUARD AGAINST MORE RAIL SABOTAGE
description: Several thousand riot policemen and rail workers guarded train stations and other installations of the Japan National Railways today to prevent a recurrence of the sabotage that shut down 23 commuter lines on Friday.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE only agreement between two New Jersey counties to share a resource-recovery plant is in jeopardy, and its fate is in the hands of Robert E. Hughey, Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Carolynn Rockafellow Engaged To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fell Rockafellow of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolynn Hall Rockafellow to Francisco Javier Lopez-Balboa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Enrique Lopez-Balboa of Montclair, N.J.

title: SPANISH CIDER BY THE INCH
description: Sang a blackbird in an apple tree, He who cider does not drink, An Asturian cannot be. So goes an anonymous poem about the favored drink in the northern region of Spain known as Asturias. Indeed, hard dry apple cider - sidra - has been an integral part of the life and traditions of this mountainous, lushly green land since ancient times.

title: LEADERS IN ISRAEL APPARENTLY SPLIT IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: Israeli officials appear divided on how far to go in cooperating with the United States investigation of an American accused of spying for Israel, Government sources said today.

title: Delaware Girds For Bird Hazard
description: IT'S called an AN/TPQ-36 Fire Finder. It's an ominous-looking green hulk whose battlefield mission is to pinpoint enemy weapons.

title: CITY U. REVISING MEDICAL SCHOOL PLAN
description: The City University of New York is revising and strengthening its plan for a medical school after being denied provisional accreditation by the Liaison Committee on Medical Education.

title: Donna Beth Schlessel Is Wed to Carl Alan Muller
description: Donna Beth Schlessel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Schlessel of Great Neck, L.I., and Miami, and Carl Alan Muller, a son of Jeannette Muller of Hauppage, L.I., and the late Leo Muller, were married yesterday. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman and Cantor Benjamin Siegal officiated at Temple Israel in Great Neck.

title: '84 INCUMBENTS IN CONGRESS RECEIVED BULK OF PAC MONEY
description: Political contributions from special interests, which would be limited under a Senate proposal, went overwhelmingly to incumbents in last year's elections, particularly to House Democrats, a Government agency said today.

title: CITY OF MERCHANTS AND MARINERS
description: Even the low-key North Germans of Bremen will smile with pride when a visitor compares their Roland to the Statue of Liberty. Roland is a giant. A lot smaller than Liberty at 18 feet, but still strong and majestic, chiseled in stone, he has been standing in place on the Bremen market square for almost 600 years. A legendary figure of a medieval knight, the nephew of Charlemagne, he is the emblem of the city.

title: Four Proposals To Save Ground Water
description: The recent article ''Ground Water Is Focus of Concern'' [Nov. 10] has pointed up a problem that, while of increasing concern to all communities of northern Westchester, is not considered by those of us responsible for water systems in the town of Lewisboro to be adequately addressed by the Town Board, the Town Planning Board or the zoning authorities.

title: 'TIS THE 'SILLY SEASON' FOR TAX SHELTERS
description: IN THE tax-shelter business, November and December make up the prime selling season, sometimes pronounced ''silly season.'' Some deals that make questionable economic sense are prettily packaged to tempt taxpayers desperate for write-offs - and provide high fees to promoters. Still, investors who make the right moves now will benefit next April, when they file their 1985 income tax returns. The benefits of investing in a tax shelter with real economic potential may go beyond tax time, however, to bring you future income and capital gains. The prospectus will say for whom the investment is suitable: some shelters are set up for people with incomes as low as $30,000. A broker or financial planner can help locate specific offerings. But what types of shelters are really appropriate for the moderate investor, the one willing to put up $5,000, $10,000, even $25,000?

title: Star Warriors and Worriers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BUYER OFFERS TO SAVE GEORGIAN FROM EVICTION
description: A couple who offered to save a farmer from eviction by buying his property have backed out of the deal, but a new buyer has stepped forward, the farmer's lawyer says.

title: THE MAKING OF A MASTER
description: MIES VAN DER ROHE A Critical Biography. By Franz Schulze, in association with the Mies van der Rohe Archive of the Museum of Modern Art. Illustrated. 355 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $39.95.

title: THE OVERT FOLLY OF COVERT MEDDLING
description: Spies and secret agents, at least successful ones, are ''covert.'' Presidents are not. That banal distinction is necessary now that President Reagan openly proposes yet another ''secret'' but undeniable American intervention, this time in Africa.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Big Apple N.I.T., third-place game at 7 P.M., St. John's meeting Louisville, followed by the championship game at 9 P.M., Kansas vs. Duke, at Madison Square Garden, (Television - USA Network, 9 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 7 P.M.) Great Alaska Shootout, third-place game at 7 P.M., followed by the championship game at 9 P.M., from Anchorage.

title: FOCUS IS WIDENED ON SEX EDUCATION
description: Like most students at Olney High School, 16-year-old Janetta D. Greene gathers with friends each morning before 8 o'clock on the ornamental stone-and-concrete walkway leading to the school's main entrance.

title: HIGH-TECH TURKEYS
description: THE PENTAGON UNDERGROUND By Dina Rasor. 310 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.95.

title: Miss Bullock Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Bullock Jr. of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alicia Benedict Bullock, to Christopher B. Dow, the son of Anne Rindlaub Dow of Cambridge and Weston, Mass., and Frank B. Dow Jr. of Marblehead and Weston, Mass. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: PHOTO BOOK DEPICTS WESTPORT'S HISTORY
description: A PICNIC at Compo Beach in 1900, when women ate watermelon wearing long, gingham dresses and boater hats, a one-room schoolhouse with separate entrances for boys and girls, family outings by horse and wagon or trolley, tycoons and farm hands, landscape changed and unchanged, such are the scenes depicted by a new book, ''Westport . . . a Special Place.''

title: ROLLING OVER A GAIN
description: Question: I sold my apartment for $110,000 and have two years to buy another residence of the same or higher value to roll over the gain. Can I qualify for the rollover by buying an $80,000 house and putting $30,000 into repairs? If so, is there a deadline for the repairs? . . . M. G., East Hampton, L. I. Answer: For the purpose of rolling over a gain on a principal residence, the purchase price of the new house includes buying or building the house, rebuilding, capital improvements or additions undertaken within two years before or after the sale, according to Rod Young, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service. You must live in the home and the improvement costs must be incurred within the time limit.

title: 2 MONTHS AFTER GLORIA STILL A MESS
description: THE hurricane's fury was vented on Long Island for only a few short hours, but two months later thousands of people are still trying to pick up the pieces of their lives.

title: SCOPE OF VOCATIONAL COURSES CHANGING
description: AT Somers High School, building a house is part of the curriculum for some students. The curriculum at the Sound School in New Haven includes building boats, and students at Wethersfield High School spend their time making electronic instruments. Students at Haddam-Killingworth High School in Higganum, meanwhile, are preparing to put their skills to work on an airplane project.

title: LEADING ROLES IN RESTORATION
description: THE halls were dark and littered with debris, the floors full of holes. Where the roof had burned away, weeds grew freely, now watered by a misty rain. Slowly, a slim man in a trenchcoat made his way up the splintered staircase, pausing to shine his flashlight on the old ceiling beams.

title: NEW TWIST ON A CLASSIC HANDBAG
description: THANKS to a Milan handbag manufacturer, a fashion icon, or rather, something very like it, is enjoying a remarkable burst of popularity.

title: Harold F. Bloomer Jr. Weds Ann F. Donald
description: The marriage of Ann Freya Donald to Harold Franklin Bloomer Jr., a partner in the London office of the law firm of Morgan Lewis & Bockius, took place yesterday at St. Colomba's Church in London. The Rev. Dr. J. Fraser McClusky performed the Church of Scotland ceremony.

title: Robert Cantor Marries Margo Levine, Lawyer
description: Margo L. Levine, a daughter of Mrs. Sanford Levine of New York and the late Mr. Levine, and Robert L. Cantor, the son of Sol W. Cantor of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Hermina Rosenberg Cantor, were married yesterday. Rabbi Dennis N. Math performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel in New York.

title: 6 Officers Freed In Death of Michael Stewart
description: After the prosecution rested its case in the trial of six transit police officers charged in the death of Michael Stewart, defense attorneys announced that they would call no witnesses. ''You quit while you're ahead,'' Barry Agulnick, a defense lawyer, said at the time. ''As far as we're concerned, there is reasonable doubt in this case.''

title: LONE GUITARISTS: A RARE BREED SINGS ON
description: Where have all the folkies gone? Those lone troubadours, battered guitars in hand, have all but disappeared from television and radio; they have either learned to lead bands, a la Joni Mitchell and James Taylor, or been banished from major record labels. Yet as it has since its invention, the guitar still provides full accompaniment in portable form, and some songwriters find that it's all they need. Even in the era of cantilevered haircuts and digital sound sampling, solo songwriters are still with us on a circuit of coffeehouses, clubs and independent record labels; recent releases include albums by Greg Brown, Christine Lavin, Fred Small, Billy Bragg and Phranc.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN JUNK
description: PLEASE, do not call Kennie Andersen's business a junkyard. Andersen's Sales and Salvage Inc. in Greeley, Colo. is ''an automobile recycling shop,'' he insists.

title: BARRY MANILOW TAKES A FLING AT ACTING
description: When the singer and composer Barry Manilow performs on stage, he really knows how to tug at the heartstrings. As the fog machine goes on, the lights go down, and there he is in his white sequined tux at the white grand piano, warbling: ''I've never been so low on love . . . .'' If Barry Manilow were any cuter, he'd be illegal.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''For Texaco it's like sleeping with the sword of Damocles over you.'' Rosario Ilacqua, L. F. Rothschild analyst, on uncertainty at Texaco.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET IN 'BRAHMS-SCHOENBERG'
description: THE New York City Ballet's lovely new production of George Balanchine's ''Brahms-Schoenberg'' has a light and airy look that was enhanced by casting changes in Friday's performance at the New York State Theater.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, DECMEBER 1, 1985
description: International

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Night of the Generals Starring Peter O'Toole, Omar Sharif, Tom Courtenay; directed by Anatole Litvak, 1967 RCA/Columbia Home Video 146 minutes. $59.95 Based on a novel by Hans Helmut Kirst, a keen and ironic observer of military behavior, this murder mystery spans more than 20 years from wartime Warsaw and Paris to postwar Hamburg.

title: Amy Martin Is a Bride
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Amy Alexander Martin was married to Michael J. Raymond by the Rev. John W. Bishop.

title: UNION CARBIDE LEAK IN INDIA SAID TO POSELONG-TERM RISK
description: Medical studies conducted in the year since the chemical leak at the Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, India, indicate that the chemical responsible for the accident causes serious long-term health problems that were unknown before the disaster.

title: Karen Einbender to Marry Walter S. Smith Jr. in June
description: A June wedding is planned by Karen Ann Einbender and Walter S. Smith Jr., her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin H. Einbender of New York, have announced.

title: FIRST A STATE, THEN A NATION
description: ISRAEL The Partitioned State. A Political History Since 1900. By Amos Perlmutter. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title: DAUGHTER'S FUTURE SEEN IN RING
description: It is late December and my daughter is approaching her 16th birthday. A momentous occasion in any young life, this birthday calls for a special ritual in the lives of women in our family. On her 16th birthday, my mother received from her mother a ring: a small, square sapphire flanked on either side by two small, round, delicately cut diamonds, resting in a filigreed platinum setting. It had been my grandmother's engagement ring, presented with love by a young Hungarian soldier in 1902 in the old country.
