She had worn it across the sea, past the Statue of Liberty, across the country to San Francisco where they had settled and where my mother was born, a first-generation Californian.

title: REBELS CITE GAINS AGAINST PRETORIA
description: The leaders of the African National Congress say they believe they are finally within sight of their goal of abolishing apartheid in South Africa and setting up a black majority Government there.

title: RAIL LINE INTO HARTFORD IS PROPOSED
description: WALTER W. SIMMERS says he is not a ''train nut.'' He just wants to see commuter rail service between Vernon and Hartford. And if no one else will make it happen, he says he will.

title: An End To Anzus?
description: The United States drew closer last week to scrapping its military commitments to New Zealand under the 34-year-old Anzus pact, which links them and Australia in mutual defense against ''the common danger'' in the South Pacific.

title: CRACKING DOWN HARD, TEXAS STYLE
description: HOUSTON is not a comfortable place for an auto salvage dealer these days. At midnight on Dec. 31, the licenses of every one of the 150 yards expires. And there is a good chance that city officials will put yard owners through the wringer before those licenses will be renewed.

title: UP ABOVE BROOKLYN
description: CAUGHT By Jane Schwartz. 216 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: IN BROOKLYN, AN UNUSUAL OPERATIC COLLABORATION
description: Every fall, the avant-garde Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music presents at least one quasi-operatic collaborative project involving artists with strong reputations in separate mediums who come together in unexpected combinations. This year's major attraction of this sort is called ''The Birth of the Poet,'' and it will play for seven performances from Tuesday through next Sunday in BAM's Opera House.

title: WOMAN IS HONORED FOR VOLUNTEER WORK
description: ''ABSOLUTELY thrilling'' is how Pauline Flippin of New Rochelle described her volunteer work on the Purchase College Council of the State University of New York at Purchase. For her efforts, which go back to 1967 and the very beginnings of the council, she recently received the 1985 Distinguished Service Award of the Association of Council Members and College Trustees of the State University of New York.

title: Wedding Planned By Paula Wiener
description: Donald Etra, a partner in the Los Angeles office of the Chicago law firm of Sidley & Austin, and Paula Wiener, president of Belle Cadeaux, a manufacturer of leather goods in Los Angeles, plan to be married Dec. 28.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE BOURGEOIS EXPERIENCE: Victoria to Freud. Volume One: Education of the Senses, by Peter Gay. (Oxford University, $9.95.) This is the first in a projected work of at least five volumes exploring the inner world of the European and American middle classes from the 1820's to the start of World War I. The author has called it ''history informed by psychoanalysis.'' His initial volume focuses on Victorian sexuality. In 1984 Neil McKendrick commented here that ''this volume will delight the Freudians and serve as a new landmark in historical studies. In spite of - arguably, because of - its highly personal interpretations, it could well become a classic of its kind.'' THE WANDERERS, by Richard Price. (Penguin, $5.95.) The Wanderers are a largely Italian teen-age Bronx housing project gang of the early 1960's; in their unforgiving and violent world they confront adult posturings, sexual myths and realities and various fears. In 1974 our reviewer, Hubert Selby Jr., praised ''The Wanderers'' as an ''outstanding work of art,'' a ''superbly written book about coming of age in a section of the Bronx.'' In a second Richard Price novel, LADIES'

title: At 101, a New Life
description: The 101-year-old Mercantile Exchange Building in TriBeCa has been sold and the famous trading floor that once echoed to the shouts of commodity traders and more recently to avant garde music-and-light shows may soon become a fashion showcase.

title: BUTTERFISH BOOM ON EAST END
description: DURING the fall and early winter, butterfish by the millions swim in vast schools near the beaches between Shinnecock and Montauk Point. Yet the majority of these petite, silvery fish will wind up in rice bowls on tables in Japan.

title: SCULPTURE AND PHOTOGRAPHS AT WESLEYAN
description: PAUL MAGRIEL is a career-collector in the sense that he assembles works by others much as an artist puts together his own output for a show. Living with the collection as it accrues, he exhibits it when completed and then disposes of it to begin all over again.

title: Catherine Knapp and William Cargill, Executives, Marry in Southport, Conn.
description: Catherine Virginia Knapp, the daughter of Catherine B. Knapp of Cohasset, Mass., and Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Clarence E. Knapp, was married yesterday to William Burnell Cargill, a son of William S. Cargill of Marbella, Spain, and Mrs. Harris Russell of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Jenny Matheson performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport.

title: LEGISLATORS WEIGH TERM OF 4 YEARS
description: NOT for the first time, the Westchester Board of Legislators is thinking about extending its term from two to four years.

title: CAVS' FREE EXCELS AT NETS FALTER, 119-90
description: The game was still in its opening moments when World B. Free took a pass near the free-throw line and lifted it softly to the basket for a lay-in. It was a momentous occasion, but it was the only one the Nets would experience tonight.

title: EVERYBODY AIMS FOR CHAMPION
description: THE BLESSING of the spring has turned into the burden of the fall for the Villanova basketball team that won the N.C.A.A. basketball championship last March with players no one thought could do it. Now, in the same way that a younger brother is picked on by bullies who couldn't beat up his big brother, the Wildcats are starting to pay a guilt-by-association price for wearing the same uniforms.

title: BLAST KNOCKS OUT POWER IN MUCH OF LUXEMBOURG
description: A bomb explosion destroyed an electricity pylon in a Luxembourg suburb today, cutting off power to most of the capital, the police said.

title: DUKE AND KANSAS MATCH POTENT OFFENSES
description: Perhaps the most compelling question surrounding tonight's Big Apple National Invitational Tournament championship game at Madison Square Garden is whether Kansas and Duke can match the intensity of their semifinal games Friday night.

title: HELPING CHILDREN COPE WITH THE FEAR OF NUCLEAR WAR
description: SEVERAL mental-health professionals in the county have been speaking out recently about what they believe is a growing source of anxiety among children and teen-agers: the possibility that nuclear weapons will be used in their lifetime.

title: Students Protest Deng's Policies
description: Deng Xiaoping's efforts to push China into the 20th century have aroused opposition from aged colleagues with a nostalgia for more orthodox times. But last week, Mr. Deng had to take steps to halt a campaign against his ''open-door'' policies from a different quarter - university students who have been marching in Peking and other cities in recent weeks.

title: A STUDENT PAPER ON S.I. IS ALMOST 100 YEARS OLD
description: Borough President Ralph J. Lamberti of Staten Island and his recent Republican opponent, George Hart, were in for sharp questioning by a team of reporters last month.

title: THE CHURCH LOOKS BACK ON VATICAN II
description: THE bishops of the Roman Catholic church took turns last week giving Pope John Paul II their capsule summaries of the state of the church. The Pope had called them here to measure the impact of the Second Vatican Council and the reforms it generated two decades ago.

title: SOME CHILDREN'S CLASSICS WILL ENLIVEN HOLIDAY FARE
description: What's in store on cable this Christmas? Well, virtually every service will be paying its respects to the holiday. This month cable's two principal providers of family fare - Nickelodeon and the Disney Channel -move into high gear with a variety of children's programs that includes several noteworthy premieres.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Why do some cruise ships go right into port while others anchor out in the ocean and send passengers in by tender? - J. M., Queens Answer:The main reason some ships anchor offshore instead of going into port is that the draft - the depth of water that is displaced by these big vessels - makes it impossible for them to put into ports with relatively shallow water. In some busy cruise harbors, including Charlotte Amalie in St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands, some of the several ships calling on one day have to anchor offshore because there isn't room for them all.

title: RE-CREATING THE COUNTRY LOOK
description: THEY are the tabula rasa of the antiques world -dipped, stripped, bleached, waxed, assembled for export by English pickers and wholesalers and shipped to the United States by the container load.

title: Office Space With Sound Baffling
description: A new office building is rising on what its leasing agent described as ''the last parcel for office or industrial use'' next to the Westchester County Airport.

title: KEY U.S. LEGISLATORS FAVOR CUT IN LIBERIA AID
description: The chairmen of House and Senate subcommittees on Africa said this week that Congress should reduce or suspend United States aid to Liberia in response to reports of human rights violations after a coup attempt and a rigged presidential election.

title: PUN GOES TOO FAR
description: The way Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sees it, the only thing wrong with the little teddy bear holding a minature basketball net and wearing a uniform bearing the blue and gold Los Angeles Laker colors, is its name - Kareem Abdul Jabear. The pun, according to Abdul-Jabbar, who receives no royalites from the enterprise, violates his rights to exploit his own name and injures his marketability.

title: 12-ROUNDER FOR TITLE
description: The welterweight unification title bout between Donald Curry and Milton McCrory, set for next Friday night in Las Vegas, Nev., will be scheduled for 12 rounds as a result of a coin flip held there yesterday.

title: ARGENTINA COULD CASH IN ON ITS COMEBACK
description: Argentina has made so much economic progress, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said recently, that Argentines have virtually stopped shipping capital abroad for safekeeping. Thus Argentina, after the belt-tightening measures imposed by President Raul Alfonsin, is considered a likely beneficiary of the Reagan Administration's new ''Baker plan'' to assist third world debtors.

title: A PRIZEWINNER EXPLAINS WHY 8 WALLS ARE BETTER THAN 4
description: A FEW years ago, Keri Hulme, the winner of Britain's 1985 Booker Prize, almost abandoned hope of ever seeing her first novel, ''The Bone People,'' in print. Several New Zealand publishers had rejected it. They felt the 400-plus-page book about a woman living a hermitlike existence on the South Island beaches who befriends a boy unable to speak and his ornery foster father was too long, unwieldy and lacked the shape of a traditional novel. ''Which is why I was going to embalm the whole thing in a block of perspex,'' Miss Hulme writes in her introduction. To her rescue came three women who formed the Spiral Collective, an ad hoc publishing group, in order to bring out ''The Bone People'' and works by other female writers. Two printings, or 4,000 copies, sold out. It won the 1984 Pegasus Prize (sponsored by Mobil, with an agreement with Louisiana State University Press to publish the winner) and the New Zealand Book Award for 1984. And when it was nominated for the Booker, its British publisher, Hodder & Stoughton, threw a champagne party for everyone on the staff. ''They were very surprised,'' said Miss Hulme. ''I think they wondered, 'What are these colonials doing?' ''

title: TAX CREDITS FAVORED AS SPUR FOR LOWER-BUDGET HOUSING
description: In Baltimore's Franklin Square Historic District there is a graceful Italianate building with Queen Anne masonry that seems as if it might be a museum.

title: FLAMES DEFEAT ISLANDERS, 4-3
description: Jim Peplinski and Doug Risebrough scored second-period goals tonight to break a 2-2 tie and give the Calgary Flames their third straight victory, 4-3 over the Islanders.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH WILLIAM STYRON. Edited by James L. W. West 3d. (University Press of Mississippi, Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.) ''Conversations With William Styron'' is part of the University Press of Mississippi's series of collected interviews with modern writers.

title: NEVADA SETS ITS SIGHTS BEYOND THE HIGH-ROLLER
description: Normally, Nevadans enjoy a bit of a gamble. But these days they say it is too risky to place all their bets for prosperity on one industry. And so Nevada, which for half a century has depended on gaming for jobs and wealth, is struggling to attract new businesses. Already it has had some success.

title: BLIGHT THREATENS JERSEY BLUEBERRIES
description: Robert M. Reeves's blueberries are blighted and he does not know why.

title: DUSTING OFF THE VERDI CANON
description: The Germans, who can always be depended upon to invent a felicitous word, call it Auffuhrungspraxis. To the Italians, it is prassi esecutiva. In English, it is ''performance practice,'' or less formally, ''how they did it in those days.'' But, under whatever name, the subject is one that can generate tremendous heat and occasionally some light in musical circles. Within living memory, interest in how music of previous centuries should be performed did not greatly interest many people outside academic circles. Few musicians, even the most famous of them, concerned themselves with the problem. Pablo Casals, who was idolized by musicians and the public alike, is supposed to have remarked that all music should be performed as if it were Chopin. By that I suppose he meant look for the lyricism. He also once exhorted a cello student to play ''more like 'Schelomo,' '' by which he apparently meant with the kind of rhapsodic sentiment Bloch's piece exudes.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ABRAHAM LINCOLN lived his Presidential years in a state of depression. Richard M. Nixon's days were filled with hostility, bitterness and paranoia. And Jimmy Carter, although shaky after his unsuccessful re-election bid, never lost his basic strength of character.

title: NEW PRESCRIPTIONS FOR OLD AILMENTS
description: A GRAND STRATEGY FOR THE WEST The Anachronism of National Strategy in an Interdependent World. By Helmut Schmidt. With an introduction by William P. Bundy. 159 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $12.95.

title: IRAN'S FUTURE: DIFFERENT SORT OF AYATOLLAH
description: His face is featured on huge posters at airports, shops and offices throughout Iran. The posters are equal in size to those of Iran's leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who calls him ''the fruit of my life.''

title: Barbara E. Ernst to Marry Jeffrey Drew Prey Jan. 11
description: The engagement of Barbara Elizabeth Ernst and Jeffrey Drew Prey has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Herbert Ernst of Manhasset, L.I. A Jan. 11 wedding is planned.

title: Biographer's Dream
description: Until someone invents a time machine that works, Edmund Morris has probably the best working conditions a Presidential biographer could ask for. He will have extraordinary access to President Reagan, enough to allow the Pulitzer Prize-winning writer to capture, as he put it:

title: FROM U.P.S., FOR PHILADELPHIA
description: In what is hailed as a boost for the economy of the Greater Philadelphia area, the United Parcel Service is planning to build a new eastern regional hub for package sorting on Hog Island here.

title: REAGAN GETS A TAX BILL -- AND A DEADLINE
description: With Congress in recess, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, worked the telephone from his home in Chicago last week. His message to colleagues around the country, according to his staff, was this:

title: Dr. Susan Ascher Engaged to Marry Dr. Paul E. Kalb
description: Dr. Susan Michelle Ascher and Dr. Paul Edward Kalb plan to be married in May, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Floyd L. Ascher of Franklin Square, L.I., have announced. Dr. Kalb is a son of Carol Cohen of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Dr. Seymour Kalb.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PUTTERING ABOUT IN A SMALL LAND. By Philip K. Dick. (Academy Chicago, $16.95.) Written almost two decades ago, this book was in manuscript form when unearthed by Philip K. Dick's literary executors - a bad move on their part, since the novel was obviously nowhere near readiness for publication.

title: TUG-OF-WAR ON SUFFOLK BUDGET
description: BEHIND the public squabbling last week over Suffolk County's 1986 budget was a more significant and longer-range struggle between Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and an agency little known outside local government - the County Legislature's Budget Review Office.

title: Chelsea
description: To the Editor: In response to the letter from L. M., Salt Lake City (Q & A, Travel, Oct. 27), we would urge that anyone who wants to go to the Chelsea Flower Show, enroll in the Royal Horticultural Society, and attend the show on the private view day.

title: GROUP IS SEEKING TO HALT BISON HUNT IN MONTANA
description: An animal protection group based in New York has sought a Federal District Court order to stop the hunting of wild bison that wander out of Yellowstone National Park into Montana.

title: THE 'PEOPLE'S STAGE' GREETS ITS EIGHTH DECADE
description: The Folksbiene Theater, New York's oldest ensemble theater company, has entered its new season with some surprisingly springy steps for a septuagenarian that might be expected to be set in its ways, clinging loyally, even jealously, to Yiddish, its native tongue.

title: SEEKING CURES FOR AN EPIDEMIC OF ESPIONAGE
description: IT was a bittersweet week for the American intelligence community. In just nine days, three present or former employees of the Central Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency and the Defense Department have been arrested and charged with espionage.

title: The 'Shrinking' Professor
description: Meeting a former student who has become successful can be a depressing and embarrassing experience to an old teacher, who may be feeling bad about his own lack of achievements in his life. It may be better not to show up than to risk destroying his former student's illusions from the past. SCOTT E. WEBBER Stony Point, N.Y.

title: OLD STANDBYS GONE IN QUEBEC BOTE TOMORROW
description: Quebecers will vote Monday after a five-week election campaign that, remarkably, has made only sparse mention of the old mainstays of Quebec politics - protection of the French language and culture and greater political independence.

title: Paying Tribute To a Maverick
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WELCOME TO THE REALITIES OF CAMPAIGN FINANCES
description: To the Editor:

title: NASSAU C.C. EDGED
description: Lawrence Augilard returned a kickoff 95 yards for a touchdown and Flinn James made a 29-yard field goal to help Copiah-Lincoln, the host team, to an 18-17 victory today over Nassau Community College of Garden City, L.I., in the final of the East Bowl junior-college tournament.

title: 'RECYCLING' A HOSPITAL THAT WAS UNDERUSED
description: MORRISTOWN Memorial Hospital officially opened its Mount Kemble division here last month, and health experts say that the attractive facility shows how an old hospital can be ''recycled'' to meet other types of health needs.

title: Private Sector and Public Works
description: Chief among the Reagan Administration's means of shrinking government has been cutting money for public services. Also on the White House list has been pushing local governments to steer their business to private companies.

title: MICHIGAN DEFEATS GEORGIA TECH, 49-44
description: For the last seven summers, the Tipoff Classic committee has met here to choose a pair of outstanding teams for its annual game, which traditionally marks the beginning of the college basketball season.

title: CHILDREN'S IMAGES OF ALCOHOLISM SHOWN AT HIGH SCHOOLS
description: ALTHOUGH a picture by 9-year-old Rebecca of her mother won a place in an art show now touring the country, her mother knows nothing about it. Rebecca's mother is an alcoholic.

title: TWO REVIVALS HELP ILLUMINATE A CHOREOGRAPHIC PAST
description: ''You've got to travel more,'' Louis Johnson calls out across a sunny studio at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. ''Move into it quick. Move into the phrasing of it so that it doesn't become academic. Make it flow. And don't let it get too nice and comfortable. It has to have that animal thing.''

title: A VIEW OF JESUS' IMPACT ON CULTURE
description: AT Yale University last year, Prof. Jaroslav Pelikan delivered a series of lectures about Jesus Christ that gave him ''the opportunity I needed to write the book I always wanted to write,'' he said.

title: STRIKE DEADLINE IS EXTENDED FOR 9 MAJOR HOTELS IN BOSTON
description: Negotiators for 4,000 workers at nine hotels here agreed an hour before a midnight strike deadline to delay the walkout 24 hours, Mayor Raymond L. Flynn announced.

title: COLLEGES ADOPT NEW RULE ON ALCOHOL
description: MOST colleges on Long Island will put into effect today new policies prohibiting students under 21 years of age from consuming alcoholic beverages on campus.

title: ONE TOO MANY FOR THE MUSE
description: OWLED, sprung, jagged, buried, jingled, piffed, scrooded, spiflicated, squiffy, sozzled, bloated, corked, corned, polluted, ossified, embalmed, fried to the hat, slopped to the ears, lit up like the Commonwealth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TO ENGINEER IS HUMAN: The Role of Failure in Successful Design. By Henry Petroski. (St. Martins, $16.95.) Engineering, like all human endeavors, in-volves a chance of failure, and, as Henry Petroski writes in ''To Engineer Is Human,'' technological advances often come out of what we learn from failures.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: COMET WATCHING

title: CHAMBER WORKS SHOW VIGOR
description: The varied assortment of chamber works in a recent spate of European and American recordings proves once again, if proof is needed at this late date, that the genre is alive and perhaps in better health than it has ever been before.

title: RHODE ISLAND GAINS BY 35-27
description: Tom Ehrhardt threw for five touchdowns, including four to the tight end Tony DiMaggio, to lead Rhode Island to a 35-27 victory over Akron in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.

title: DOBBS FERRY GETS 38TH IN ROW
description: Dobbs Ferry set a Section I record for consecutive victories yesterday when it defeated Irvington, 17-0, in Section I's Class C Bowl Game at Memorial Field in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The victory was the 38th in a row for the Eagles, who led by 3 points at halftime.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 1, 1985 Fiction

title: TRIAL IN BRUTAL MURDER FILLS CAPITAL COURTROOM
description: The other Washington, the uneasy neighbor to the world of White House dinners, international conferences and marble memorials, only rarely comes into the public eye.

title: DRINKING AGE HOLDOUTS
description: At 12:01 this morning, New York became the 32d state to try to curb drinking by those under age 21. All states must do the same by Oct. 1 or lose Federal highway aid. Presumably all will do so, but 10 have taken the Government to court. New Yorkers ought to be especially concerned about the resistance of neighboring Vermont.

title: FIRST TREE OF HOLIDAY IS RECALLED
description: HENDRICK RODDMORE, the man believed to have put up the state's first Christmas tree, will be remembered by the Windsor Locks Historical Society later this week at the site of the 18th-century farm where the tree was reportedly erected.

title: Financial Counseling For Nassau Women
description: I read with interest the recent article ''L.I. Women Study Managing Money.'' How many Nassau County residents are aware that they can get low-cost financial conseling from a county-sponsored agency?

title: Hard Sailing In Submarines
description: After serving five years (and completing four deterrent patrols) as a nuclear-trained machinist's mate on a ballistic-missile submarine, I was disappointed to read yet another account of submarine life forward of the reactor compartment (''At Sea With 'The Silent Service,' '' by Richard Halloran, Nov. 3). It is too bad that Mr. Halloran did not give more attention to the highly trained men who work aft of the reactor compartment.

title: HOUSING BARRIERS PROVING HARD TO PULL DOWN
description: THERE is one area of race relations in the United States that rarely seems to change. It is housing and neighborhood segregation, a basic exclusion that is at the root of other important inequalities, in education and employment opportunity. Seemingly isolated developments in the last few days made the point again.

title: ALBANY ENJOYING A COMMERCIAL REVIVAL
description: AFTER nearly 30 years of decline, Albany is rebounding. New York's capital city is enjoying an unparalleled cycle of commercial investment and development. According to the city's Bureau of Economic Development, 426,800 square feet of commercial space is under construction or rehabilitation and the city has approved plans for an additional 625,000 square feet.

title: TRADE WITH EUROPE
description: Excerpts from an address by Lothar Spath, Premier of Baden-Wurttemberg, at the Konrad Adenauer Foundation in Washington on Nov. 18:

title: Hospice Care Given In Nursing Service
description: In response to the article entitled ''Hospice Benefit Is Target of Questions'' that appeared Oct. 27, we would like to take issue with a quote attributed to Rosemary Hurzeler, chief executive officer of the Connecticut Hospice.

title: BATTLE BREWING ON SALES TAX
description: A BATTLE is brewing in Albany and Nassau County over whether to retain the penny increase in the county sales tax that took effect in 1983 but is scheduled to expire at the end of next year.

title: NOT LAST, NOT LEAST
description: Apart from service to the abstract ideal of excellence, there is at least one good practical reason for the awarding of a brilliancy prize: The prospect of such an award keeps the otherwise talented players who are not having a good tournament from giving up and just willy-nilly tossing points to those in contention.

title: SUFFOLK MOVES TO EXPAND ITS OPEN-SPACE PROGRAM
description: FROM the sky it is difficult to distinguish the boundaries of the properties Suffolk County hopes to acquire in the latest chapter of the open-space program it established in 1964. Some are defined by the edge of a river or the contours of a wetland. Some are lost in the groves of pine trees.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FEAST OF LIGHTS

title: OPERA: 'PARADE,' TRIPLE BILL AT THE MET
description: WITH the triple bill known as ''Parade,'' the Metropolitan Opera has enjoyed one of its liveliest successes of recent years. The title is that of a slight ballet by Erik Satie, which serves as a curtain-raiser for ''Les Mamelles de Tiresias'' by Poulenc and ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges'' by Ravel. The trio returned to the repertory Friday evening, and though it is impossible to hear the third score played as well as it was by the Met orchestra without being newly bewitched, satisfaction was oddly elusive through most of the evening.

title: SERVICE ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 1, 1985 Fiction

title: SUMMIT: A MEETING OF PIGMENT AND SCULPTURAL MATERIAL
description: THE current offering at the Summit Art Center is an overview of painted sculpture and constructions entitled ''Interplay.''

title: ACTIVISTS COALITION AGREES ON PLATFORM
description: ARMED with a new consensus platform, organizers for the Legislative Electoral Action Program say their umbrella organization of 23 statewide lobbying groups is poised to influence Connecticut's 1986 elections.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN UPPER YORKVILLE
description: UPPER YORKVILLE is a neighborhood on the edge.

title: LITTLE SUCCESS IN CURBING SPREAD OF AIDS BY ADDICTS IS SEEN
description: The New York State Health Commissioner has told a Congressional committee that there has been ''precious little success'' in curbing the spread of AIDS through addicts who inject drugs. He said this ''may now harbor the greatest AIDS potential'' in the state.

title: HALFBACK SPOT FOR GIANTS BEOCMES A TWO-MAN JOB
description: In the Giants' 12 games this season, their halfback has averaged 25 carries for 99 1/2 yards. The Giants' other running backs combined have averaged 7 carries for 25 1/2 yards.

title: ITALIAN ACCENTS IN YONKERS
description: WITH plenty of Italy in its style and accent, Reggia Morelli is the kind of restaurant that can make diners forget they are on Central Avenue in Yonkers. In our review of this congenial place almost four years ago, we felt that only a little more care and polish could earn it a two-star rating. Recent visits indicate, however, that the restuarant is as good as it ever was. And in the case of its soups and pasta dishes, that is saying a lot.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Music Only: Scarlatti, Debussy, Ravel Starring Martha Argerich, Nelson Freire, Misha Maisky; directed by Frederic Rossif Sony Stereo 47 minutes. $39.95 This video cassette delivers what it promises - three-quarters of an hour of music, played by the pianists Martha Argerich and Nelson Freire and the cellist Misha Maisky.

title: 'MOONLIGHTING' DELIVERS WIT AND STYLE
description: With originality at a premium in weekly series, no one is likely to get excited over still another format involving a man and woman who work together as investigators while hints of romance bubble just below their professional surfaces. ''Remington Steele' or ''Scarecrow and Mrs. King'' will suffice nicely, thank you. Yet, this year's most inventive and sparkling new show, ''Moonlighting,'' turns out to feature two more of the same. Maddie Hayes is a former model who, ripped off by her managers, is forced to work in a detective agency she had been using as a tax shelter. Dave Addison is the wise-cracking lug who has been cavalierly minding the agency and now discovers that he actually has to find clients. Maddie and Dave are fortunate enough to be played by Cybill Shepherd and Bruce Willis. Their show can be seen Tuesday evenings at 9 on ABC.

title: RESORT FACES TEST ON PARKING
description: REPORTEDLY having shrugged off a $25 million offer from the Golden Nugget Hotel-Casino for her property, a woman who began the motel industry here 32 years ago has been blocking the hotel's application to operate a parcel of its land as a parking lot.

title: CHRISTMAS BAZAAR IN GREENWICH
description: ALL decked out with garlands of greenery, the exhibit hall of the Greenwich Civic Center will provide a colorful setting for the 28th annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar next weekend. The show, sponsored by the Greenwich Historical Society, will be open from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. Friday and from 11 A.M to 6 P.M. on Saturday and next Sunday. There will be 55 exhibits set up by antiques dealers from 11 states.

title: CATACOSINOS LASHES LILCO CRITICS
description: AFTER weeks of silence in the face of two proposals to take over the Long Island Lighting Company, William J. Catacosinos, the utility's chairman, struck back last week, in full-page newspaper advertisements and in testimony before a panel of state legislators.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SECRET GENERATIONS. By John Gardner. (Putnam, $17.95.) Every once in a while, a fragment of a decent spy novel peeks out from beneath the mound of cliches and unconvincing happenstance that make up ''The Secret Generations.''

title: Alisa Alpert, a Lawyer Weds Dr. K. S. Kaplan
description: Alisa Sue Alpert, an associate at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, was married last evening to Dr. Kenneth Scott Kaplan, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the New York University Medical Center. Rabbi Nathaniel Stampler performed the ceremony at the Hyatt Regency O'Hare in Chicago.

title: STATE FACES A CHALLENGE ON PENSION DIVESTITURE
description: NEW JERSEY'S pension-divestment law, which requires the state's pension funds to gradually sell off their investments in companies doing business with South Africa, is being challenged by this city's Mayor, Thomas G. Dunn.

title: AND NOW THIS MESSAGE
description: The moving sign suddenly advised a startled witness: ''Love Is Beautiful but Stupid,'' and he could not resist writing it down.

title: NEW CHOREOGRAPHERS STRETCH THE VERY DEFINITION OF DANCE
description: Kazuo Ohno looks like the Madwoman of Chaillot in his thrift-shop gowns and broad-brimmed hats. Michael Moschen, as he juggles glass balls above his head, molds his body into a sleek sculptural figure that recalls an Art Deco statue outside the Palais de Chaillot in Paris. These two performers, vastly different from each other, have raised similar questions about how dance should be defined. Neither is, strictly speaking, a dancer.

title: DARIEN PRODUCER SEEKS 'NEW LOOK'
description: HOW many Jane Bergeres are there, anyway? That question began circulating in Darien when Miss Bergere, the new executive producer of the Darien Dinner Theater, began her third career in October.

title: DEFENDANT IN SKIMMING CASE IS ORDERED TO TESTIFY
description: The Government, moving to shore up its case against eight people charged with illegally skimming $2 million from Las Vegas gambling casinos, has dropped charges against another defendant and won a court order compelling him to testify.

title: ANTI-TERRORISM CAN ALSO HAVE ITS PRICE
description: WHEN Arab gunmen collected passports from those aboard the Egyptair jetliner hijacked to Malta last weekend and selected Israelis and Americans to be shot, it was both a crime and an act of warfare. But more than an attack on particular passengers, it was meant primarily as an assault on the governments of Israel, the United States and Egypt, part of a campaign of international violence that has evolved into a purposeful, rational and calculated tool of policy, usually used by the weak against the powerful.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MADE IN AMERICA: His Own Story. By Peter Ueberroth, with Richard Levin and Amy Quinn. (Morrow, $17.95.) The man who headed the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee from 1979 to 1984 - and who is now the commissioner of baseball - here offers us a first-person chronology of the dry diplomacy and elaborate social gavotte that shaped the 1984 Summer Games.

title: WHEN SECRECY SEEMS MORE LIKE PROFESSIONAL COURTESY
description: A New York court's decision last week to release the record of pending charges against Roy M. Cohn was striking in itself, given the court's own rules governing confidentiality. It also was a reminder that when lawyers are accused of misconduct, rarely is the disposition -much less the record of proceedings - made public.

title: HERE BE MONSTERS
description: DREADFUL PLEASURES An Anatomy of Modern Horror. By James B. Twitchell. Illustrated. 353 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: SILENCING NOISE
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVELING EXHIBITS SHARE HISTORY
description: THE story of the Leatherman has intrigued Connecticut residents since the mid-1800's, when he roamed the countryside clad in leather from his neck to his feet. He spent 30 years walking a circuit from Middletown, along the shoreline and into New York State, covering 10 miles a day. He stopped only for food and drink and always at the same houses, never speaking to anyone.

title: Joe Niekro Deal Stirs Curiosity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MOVING ON POLITICALLY EXCEPTED TERRORISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AR'N'T I A WOMAN? Female Slaves in the Plantation South. By Deborah Gray White. (Norton, $18.95.) ''I have plowed, and planted, and gathered into barns, and no man could head me -and ar'n't I a woman?'' asked the former slave Sojourner Truth at an 1851 women's rights convention in Akron, Ohio.

title: Sheryl Bills, Senior Editor, Is Wed to John M. Heckler
description: Sheryl Jean Bills, a senior editor of USA Today and USA Weekend in Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to John Maguire Heckler, founder and chief executive officer of Boston Institutional Services, a stockbrokerage.

title: Child Inventor
description: THE assignment for extra credit in the fifth-grade class at the St. Francis Xavier School in Petoskey, Mich., was to write about an inventor. One pupil, Wendy Johnecheck, asked if she could forgo the writing and merely invent something instead.

title: ISRAELIS FEEL THE STING OF AUSTERITY
description: IN the bad old days of the Israeli economy, blue-collar laborers at the huge Osem noodle factory near Tel Aviv used to spend their morning coffee breaks lined up at the pay phone near the front gate. Inflation was so rampant that workers strained to stay in almost constant contact with their bankers and brokers to retain the value of their paychecks. They shifted funds from the stock market to money markets to dollar-linked bonds - day-by-day, even hour-by-hour.

title: ONE MAN'S DROSS, ANOTHER'S COLLECTION
description: EARLIER this year, Adele Green cleaned out her cluttered Bronx basement to make room for a sewing studio. She found ''a big cookie jar, an odd-looking salt and pepper shaker, so much stuff.''

title: LIGHT UP THE INDOOR GARDEN TO GROW WINTER SALADS
description: Our dining room is my lettuce patch. Not only lettuce, but arugula, mache, chives, basil and parsley thrive under lights. They grow in a floor-to-ceiling, custom-built fluorescent stand my wife dreamed up 30 years ago to brighten our winters with a garden by the table. She started with a heart-warming display of African violets, gloxinias, cyclamens, begonias, Jerusalem cherries, plumbago and miniature roses.

title: RAZING OF LANDMARK HOUSE IN PARAMUS WIDENS BERGEN RIFT l>By ALBERT J. PARISI
description: DEBRIS left in a bulldozer's wake here last month has raised more than a cloud of dust among Bergen County historians and local officials, and the dust has yet to settle, they say.

title: Patricia Pietchke Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Pietchke Jr. of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Louise Pietchke, to Donald Charles DeGraff, a son of Marjorie DeGraff of Sayville, L.I., and the late Richard DeGraff. Miss Pietchke, a cum laude graduate of Susquehanna University, is director of the Berlitz Language Center in Summit, N.J. Her fiance, who graduated from the University of Rhode Island, is a securities trader with Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cranbury $119,000 14 Marilyn Drive *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; *2* finished basement, 1-car attached garage, central air- conditioning; taxes $2,180. Mountainside $234,000 339 Short Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; *2* new kitchen with trash compactor and built-in toaster; *2* back porch, basement rec room; taxes $3,045. Prospect Park $118,000 118 North 14th Street *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; *2* basement workshop, porch, patio; taxes $1,739. Rahway $93,500 527 Albermarle Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2* living room with built-in bookcase, den, finished basement; taxes $1,937. Spotswood $131,500 6 Crestwood Court *2* 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old ranch; family room, den, deck; taxes $2,641. Woodbridge $87,500 402 Newport Court *2* 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old town-house condominium; *2* central air-conditioning, $65 monthly charges; taxes $1,579. OTHER AREAS Plainview, L.I. $150,000 58 Knickerbocker Road *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $2,200. Scarsdale, N.Y. $135,000 853 Scarsdale Road *2* 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year old ranch, living-room fireplace, *2* screened patio, terrace; taxes $2,657 Branford, Conn. $58,000 5 Bartholomew Road *2* 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old cottage; *2* beach rights, view of salt marshes; taxes $571.

title: BISHOP ASSAILS LIBERATION THEOLOGY
description: A prominent Roman Catholic bishop from Latin America harshly denounced the theology of liberation today, saying, ''When I see a church with a machine gun, I cannot see the crucified Christ in that church.''

title: Student Probation
description: IN a move to tighten academic standards, City College in New York put one of every three of its students - 3,604 - on probation last fall. The 34 percent rate was believed to be one of the highest in the country.

title: Party Leaders Get Dibs On Debates
description: Since 1976, the League of Women Voters has sponsored the Presidential debates that have become a staple of American election campaigns. Last week, though, a bipartisan commission recommended that in the future the two major political parties stage the confrontations.

title: 2 ROB THRUWAY RESTAURANT AND SHOOT AT STATE TROOPER
description: Two gunmen robbed a restaurant in a service area of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Rockland County, then shot at a state police sergeant who stopped their car for making a U-turn, officials said yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SOLOIST IN ENGLEWOOD Michael Ponti, the pianist, is about to begin a tour of the United States as soloist with the Southwest German Chamber Orchestra, performing Mozart and Bach concertos.

title: BEAR FANS' ROWDYISM CANCELS FLORIDA FLIGHT
description: United Airlines canceled a flight to Florida for 147 passengers after more than 50 Chicago Bears football fans passed around liquor and refused to take their seats before takeoff, authorities said today.

title: DANCE: ROD RODGERS AT CUBICULO
description: THERE was dancing again at ''the Cube'' on Friday night. The dancing was by the Rod Rodgers Dance Company, and it was accompanied by cheese, wine, nostalgia and rejoicing.

title: SCHOLARSHIP OBSCURES THE GENIUS OF DONATELLO
description: Donato di Niccolo di Betto Bardi, better known as Donatello, was the greatest sculptor in Europe in the 15th century and one of the three greatest Western sculptors since the early Renaissance.

title: CHALLENGE ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE
description: FRED MARSTON had hardly gotten off the M-15 bus at Chatham Square in Chinatown when Virginia Johnson buttonholed him, insisting that the bus stop was a public hazard because a newsstand restricted the exit of passengers.

title: CORRECTION
description: The investing column last Sunday misstated initial offering prices for shares of Rockefeller Center and American Savings Bank. Rockefeller Center was offered at $20; American Savings Bank went public at $12.50.

title: Loser Is Winning In Honduras
description: Voters in Honduras who wanted to mark their ballots in last weekend's presidential election had to agree to let themselves be marked. A dot on the finger with indelible ink supplied by the United States Embassy would prevent them voting more than once, or so the thinking went.

title: PATHS OF GREATER RESISTANCE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: After 14 months of violence in South Africa's black townships, the focus of protest in the country seemed to shift last week to more overt military action by the Government's exiled foes. The incidents were seen by some political analysts as evidence of an effort by the African National Congress to intensify its war against white minority rule and the system of apartheid.

title: MALTA IS CAUGHT IN ITS GEOPOLITICS
description: INHABITANTS of this tiny island country are fond of noting that its name comes from the Phoenecian word for ''haven.'' But Malta seemed none too hospitable last week as it dealt gingerly with the hijacked Egyptian plane. It was forced to accommodate the competing interests of Libya, an ally to the south; Egypt, Libya's enemy, and the United States and Western Europe, which together account for 70 percent of Malta's trade and 95 percent of the tourists it receives each year.

title: ROCKLAND PROSECUTOR: MAN ON THE GO
description: Kenneth Gribetz does not walk toward his office, he charges at it like a bull.

title: LEONARD SHERRIF AUCTION SCHEDULED
description: The Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries, Inc. will offer Part I of the Leonard Sheriff collection of 19th century stamps and covers on Dec. 11 and 12. The collection has been described by auctioneers as ''without a doubt the finest one man assemblage of its type to be offered at public auction in very many years.'' The auction will take place at the galleries, 160 East 56th Street, New York. It will begin on both days at 1 P.M.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Journey to the Center of the Earth Starring James Mason, Pat Boone, Arlene Dahl, Diane Baker; directed by Henry Levin, 1959 Playhouse Video, CBS/Fox Video 129 minutes. $59.98 It is to be cherished, marveled at and laughed at, this classic Cinemascope science-fiction adventure with its high-gloss 1950's production values and its corny special effects.

title: WEST GERMANY DEPORTS A SPANISH FINANCIER
description: Jose Maria Ruiz Mateos, a Spanish financier, was deported from West Germany today to face charges in Spain arising from the near collapse of the Rumasa business empire, the police said.

title: IN LONDON, TWO ACTRESSES SHINE
description: Didn't you find, as you watched those momentous meetings beamed back from Geneva, that your eyes sometimes drifted from the summiteers to the supporting teams around them? Didn't you momentarily wonder what was going on inside some of those conscientiously nondescript figures? If so, you're at one with Ronald Harwood, author of ''The Dresser'' and, as that tale of a great actor's factotum showed, a man with a special sympathy for the unnoticed sidekick. His new play ''Interpreters'' is about the human circuitry within two people who are supposed to be thought of only as decoding machines - a torrid and rather scandalous story of love and sexual betrayal among the translators.

title: COALITION SELECTS A CANDIDATE
description: About 6,000 youths and workers marched on the presidential palace today, and 700 people protested at the United States Embassy, both groups denouncing the planned special election on Feb. 7 as a ploy by what they called President Ferdinand E. Marcos's ''U.S. masters'' to improve his image.

title: BASEBALL'S TESTS FOR DRUGS STALLED
description: In the midst of an escalating dispute between owners and players over drug testing, club officials have indicated that virtually no testing of nonplaying major league personnel has been conducted under Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's mandatory drug-testing program.

title: New England Gray
description: I AM IN NEW ENGLAND for the gray. Everybody tells you to come before the gray sets in, but this is poor advice. In summer, the place is overrun by rich playboys and playgirls, their yachts and their favorite New York boutiques. If this is what you like, it is done much better in Nassau and on Columbus Avenue.

title: SUDANESE TOWN UNDER SIEGE
description: The 18,000 civilian residents of the Sudanese town of Kurmuk have abandoned the town, on the Ethiopian border, 370 miles southeast of Khartoum, for fear of an attack by the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, the official Sudan press agency said today. The agency said 4,000 guerrillas were laying siege to the town.

title: FORD PUTS ITS FUTURE ON THE LINE
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYS SOFTLY IN Lou Ross's fifth-floor office in the steel-and-glass headquarters of Ford Motor Company's North American Automotive Operations in Dearborn, Mich. It is in keeping with the professorial appearance of the man who manages the production and sales of all the company's cars and trucks in the United States and Canada.

title: FINDING THE HER IN HEROIC
description: MONUMENTS & MAIDENS The Allegory of the Female Form. By Marina Warner. Illustrated. 417 pp. New York: Atheneum. $25.

title: LIFE THROUGH THE APERTURE
description: AMERICAN IMAGES: PHOTOGRAPHY 1945-1980 (Barbican Art Gallery/Viking, Cloth, $35. Penguin Books, Paper, $16.95) appears to be a trick done with mirrors.

title: The Military Has a Traffic Jam
description: A post-mortem on the invasion of Grenada noted that American military forces had been hampered by poor communications; Army troops, for instance, had trouble telling Navy pilots about possible targets. Two years later, notwithstanding the $70 billion the Administration has spent so far to improve the Pentagon's vast communications network, the services continue to have trouble talking to one another and to their commanders in Washington.

title: FAUST STANDS BY HIS PLAYERS IN FAREWELL
description: The banner was behind the sideline where Gerry Faust stood for the final time as the coach of the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame. Its location on the east side of the Orange Bowl and the ''N1'' at the bottom would indicate support for the team in the gold helmets. The sign may have been behind the Irish, but it did not support their coach.

title: NEW PROPOSAL FOR WEST SIDE WATERFRON
description: The president of the Battery Park City Authority has asked Governor Cuomo to consider proposals to build parks, shopping centers and as many as 15,000 housing units along the deteriorated West Side waterfront between Chambers and 34th Streets.

title: THROUGH A GLASS, BEAUTIFULLY
description: WE have our own ''Window on the World.'' It is the huge picture window in the living room of our home on Long Island.

title: SCHOOL BOYCOTT IS ERASING DREAMS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Each morning, the father said, he washes and dresses and heads off to work, leaving behind a teen-age daughter whose fate for the day he will not know until evening.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEYOND THE HELIX: DNA and the Quest for Longevity. By Carol Kahn. (Times Books, $17.95.) Despite all our medical niceties, it is still practically impossible to live beyond the age of 110.

title: FOR HARRY BRIDGES, THE HEART OF UNIONISM STILL LIES WITH THE RANK AND FILE
description: Harry Bridges looked as frail as a bird. He was thin and bent and walked with a cane. His voice was weak. Emphysema.

title: PATERSON MAYOR PROPOSES CURFEW FOR CITY TROUBLED BY TEEN-AGERS' CRIMES
description: Late on a chilly Monday night hundreds of youths huddled on the street corners of this old industrial city, dancing to the beat blaring from box radios, drinking from bottles wrapped in brown bags, casually passing marijuana cigarettes.

title: 2 PIANISTS AND A TENOR ARE HEARD IN RECITALS
description: Leonid Kuzmin Leonid Kuzmin's piano recital last Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall was first class. On paper, the program made this listener a little wary; it was heavily weighted with showy, virtuosic fingerbusters: Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7, three etudes by Franz Liszt and Balakirev's fiendishly difficult ''Islamey.'' Fortunately, Mr. Kuzmin approached these works as music rather than sportive exercises; his playing throughout the evening was characterized by an even grade of tone from whispered pianissimo to the most clangorous of fortes, and by clarity, propulsion and - surprise -restraint.

title: LEFTISTS IN HAMBURG CLASH WITH THE POLICE
description: Hundreds of leftists protesting a two-day meeting of a rightist group clashed with the police today.

title: GANDHI INVITES ZIA TO SEE OPENING OF NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India said today that he had invited President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan to attend the inauguration of a nuclear power plant when he visits India next month.

title: A Responsibility To Players
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MERCHANDISING DR. RUTH
description: ''PEOPLE!'' YELLED an overwrought Bloomingdale's security guard. ''You got to buy the board game to see Dr. Ruth. And that's final!'' He urgently radioed for reenforcements in Stationery, where hordes of Dr. Ruth fans threatened to overrun his position.

title: Enhancing English Skills Through Latin Study
description: The article ''Rise in Latin Study Outpaces Teachers'' [Oct. 27] reflects the enormous interest generated by the growth in the teaching of Latin from grade school through the college level, which has been increasing steadily nationwide over the past decade and a half.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of the producers' change of plans, two entries in the Off Off Broadway listings today in The Guide, section 2A, are outdated. The musical ''Cheer!'' has been canceled. The production of ''Endgame'' at the Irish Arts Center has also been canceled.

title: NEW FROM BRITAIN
description: The British Royal Mint has announced the issuance by Britain of a brilliant uncirculated 1985-dated 5-pound gold coin. Like its proof counterpart, this version features the new coinage portrait of Britain's Queen Elizabeth II by London artist Raphael Maklouf. Its reverse carries the depiction of St. George slaying the dragon, a standard feature of British gold coins since 1817.

title: STORES NEAR REOPENED BRIDGE FEAR CUSTOMERS WON'T RETURN
description: IT is nearing the height of the Christmas shopping season, but Paulette O'Neill, a Mount Vernon merchant, is worried that business will not pick up. ''We're still living day to day,'' she said. ''I just paid this month's rent, and I don't know how I'm going to pay my other bills.''

title: RECALL FOR 11,000 SUBARUS
description: Subaru of America has issued a recall of 11,000 1985 XT Coupes on a voluntary basis for the owners, saying the cars may leak fuel after a rear-end accident. A rubber hose connecting the air vent on the fuel filler pipe to the fuel tank could be cut in an accident, company officials said Friday, adding that a fire could result. No accidents or injuries have been reported and no other Suburu models are affected.

title: A SHOWCASE FOR PALLADIO
description: Its central piazza looks like a set for an opera, its streets like an architectural collection, its museum like a grandee's house; it is close to Venice, but wholly different, the neighbor of Padua, but not demonstrably pious. Individual, assertive, yet infinitely refined, Vicenza, for centuries a part of the Venetian empire, has managed to retain its own character while influencing the rest of the world. If, today, much of English and American architecture looks the way it does, it is because of a genius from Vicenza.

title: Joan Markoff to Wed Andrew Lippa in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Markoff of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joan Carolyn Markoff to Andrew Mark Lippa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Lippa of East Meadow, L.I., and Lake Worth, Fla. The wedding is planned for May.

title: T. G. Reitz Weds Caroline Laccetti
description: Caroline Jeannette Laccetti, a daughter of Col. Joseph N. Laccetti, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Laccetti of Falls Church, Va., was married there yesterday to Thomas Gerard Reitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Reitz of Wantagh, L.I. The Rev. James C. Bruse performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church.

title: TV NETWORK LOSING VIEWERS
description: SINCE this past summer, the Trenton-based New Jersey Network has lost about a third of its out-of-state viewers because four cable-television companies in New York and Pennsylvania will no longer carry its signals.

title: CALLING ALL ANTS
description: FIRST FIGURE By Michael Palmer. 79 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Paper, $8.50. MICHAEL PALMER'S ''First Figure'' is his fifth volume of poetry, not counting chapbooks. One of our finest poets at the height of his power, he brings together and unifies tendencies that have divided poets into opposing factions. The epigraph from Paul Celan, ''Niemandes Stimme, wieder,'' announces the book's theme even by the fact that it is left in German - ''nobody's voice, again,'' in a language the reader may not understand. We are entering a meditation on language that will not stay within the range of comfort: ''Once I could not tell of it / and now I cannot speak at all.''

title: A BIT OF CAROLING TO OPEN THE HOLIDAY CONCERT SEASON
description: HOLIDAY concerts are beginning. Today at 4 P.M., Robert Regan will conduct the University of Bridgeport Concert Choir in Bach's ''Magnificat'' at the United Church of Christ. And at 8 P.M. Thursday at Yale University's Battell Chapel, the 76th annual Festival of Old Christmas Music continues a tradition, with caroling by the Yale Glee Club, the Freshman Chorus, the Carol Choir and the audience. Both concerts are free.

title: DANCE
description: Susanne Linke is the third choreographer from West Germany in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival. Unlike Pina Bausch, who has a large company, Miss Linke will present several solos danced by herself.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE OBEDIENT WIFE. By Julia O'Faolain. (Carroll & Graf, $17.95.) As the accomplished novelist Julia O'Faolain's sixth book begins, Carla Verdi - the Florentine wife of the title - waits in a rented Los Angeles house for her unfaithful husband's return from Italy.

title: NEW JERSEY'S STRUGGLE WITH FAIR HOUSING
description: FOR 15 years, New Jersey and its municipalities have been grappling over how to provide low-cost housing in the developing suburbs, where most new jobs are and where many people want to live. Most suburban communities, for their part, have tried to maintain traditional zoning, requiring large building lots and minimum house sizes. They did so, local officials have said, to preserve their communities' character. But such zoning also guaranteed that housing would be expensive, and thus many suburbs were closed to low-income and moderate-income people.

title: FIRE AT ARAB GROUP'S OFFICES IS TERMED SUSPICIOUS
description: Fire Department officials said today that they were investigating the cause of a fire Friday night that damaged the offices of the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee.

title: WILDERNESS RULING RAISES QUESTIONS ON WATER USE
description: A decision handed down by a Federal district judge could have far-reaching implications in determining who has jurisdiction over the use of water from rivers that run through lands designated as wilderness.

title: THE SPY WHO CAME IN FROM THE DIAMOND
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW IN SOUTH AFRICA: A 500,000-STRONG UNION
description: South African black union leaders meeting in Durban have formed the biggest labor federation in the country's history, grouping 500,000 workers in an organization billed as a potential major challenger to white minority rule.

title: Housatonic
description: To the Editor: Reading the article about the restored Housatonic Railroad (Travel, Oct. 6), as well as the article about the section of that line that now operates to Great Barrington (Travel, Sept. 9, 1984), I am horrified at the passage of years that made that section of line seem like an antique.

title: NEIGHBORLINESS FINDS A NEW HOME
description: I WAS 7 years old when we moved into our new neighborhood and will never forget the lady with the six children who found time to bake a pie and take it to my mother in a friendly ''welcome-to-the-neighborhood'' greeting. She and my mother became good friends. My brothers and I played with her children. We attended each other's birthday parties, stayed overnight at each other's houses and shared water sprinklers and lemonade stands.

title: WASTE-INCINERATOR SAFETY CHALLENGED
description: I GREW up in a family of strong traditions of storytelling and prayer, of keeping in touch with relatives, visiting them while they were alive and tending their graves when they were gone. Cemetery jaunts were frequent and loving ventures. We learned much about many of the other families besides our own as we passed the multitude of stones along the winding paths.

title: WHEN THE PC NEEDS SOUPING UP
description: NOWHERE does personal computing show its hobbyist origins to a greater extent than in its open architecture. The earliest personal computers - Altair, Cromemco, Imsai, South West Technical Products and the Sol - all allowed the tinker to purchase a very basic (crude by today's standards) machine and then add to it as funds and technology permitted.

title: MORATORIUM OVER, MALPRACTICE RATE RISE IS ASKED
description: New York State's five-month moratorium on increases in medical malpractice insurance rates expired yesterday without Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders reaching agreement on a long-term solution to the problem of rising rates.

title: HANDEL'S GIFTS POUR FORTH IN MANY FORMS
description: The fruits of the Handel tercentenary continue to pour forth from the record industry's cornucopia. They range from the best-known instrumental music to less familiar concertos and orchestral snippets to early cantatas to the late operas, oratorios and anthems.

title: How Japan Teaches Its Own History
description: The Japanese establishment - bent on avoiding defense cost in order to beat America in trade - should be most grateful to James Reston Jr. for his efforts to preserve the status quo in United States-Japanese relationships at any cost.

title: TRADE ISSUE HITS HOME IN A QUEENS COMMUNITY
description: On weekday mornings, Eddie Barbour leaves his home on 60th Place in Ridgewood, Queens, and heads for work in the ACD Knitting Mill eight blocks away.

title: SHOPPING THE GRAND BOULEVARDS, SAILING THE CARIBBEAN
description: Guide for Seekers of Parisian Chic From the grand couturiers of the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honore to the clothing shops of the Left Bank, the fashion trendsetters of Paris are among the features of a new, free guide to shopping available from the French Government Tourist Office.

title: OPERA: 'LIGHTHOUSE,' CHAMBER WORK
description: PETER MAXWELL DAVIES, the British composer whose ''Eight Songs for a Mad King'' is his best-known score outside his native land, tries for a similarly phantasmagoric theatrical effect in ''The Lighthouse,'' a chamber opera that had its New York premiere Friday night at Alice Tully Hall. Unfortunately, this fully staged performance looked rather amateurish, especially in its inept lighting, which did nothing at all to redeem a tiresomely jagged and atonal piece whose chief musical interest lay in the pointillistic orchestral score played by the Fires of London, the 12-musician group led by Mr. Davies.

title: A BADGE FOR EVERY BLOCK
description: Like any major city, Washington has its share of commonplace crime problems: robberies, murders, rapes, drugs.

title: JETS SEE FILM AND FEEL BETTER
description: Coach Joe Walton of the Jets, whose training is more football than Freud, used positive reinforcement today in making his players sit through the films of their awful Thanksgiving Day performance against the Detroit Lions.

title: LILCO BATTLING THE CLOCK FOR LOAN AID
description: THE financially strapped Long Island Lighting Company is pressing its case with state officials to borrow millions of dollars through low-interest tax-exempt bonds. But the utility is facing a New Year's Eve deadline because of proposed changes in the Federal tax laws that could derail the plan.

title: CONSUMER RATES
LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IT MAY be true that crime pays, but in this case not for the criminals. Grants totaling $164,400 have been awarded to 14 Nassau and Suffolk County crime prevention organizations, according to Margaret Chretien, a spokesman for the State Division of Criminal Justice.

title: How Japan Teaches Its Own History
description: As a Japanese, I am deeply skeptical of the current movement in Japan, led by Prime Minister Nakasone, to ''totally reevaluate'' postwar institutions, especially education (''How Japan Teaches Its Own History,'' by James Reston Jr., Oct. 27). At best, it can be characterized as extraordinarily naive.

title: Before Ferraro
description: To the Editor:

title: T.S. Eliot and Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: SUITS AGAINST SCHOOLS
description: Courts have repeatedly refused to hold school systems accountable when students contend that schools have failed to teach them, but the grounds for ''educational malpractice'' suits may be changing, according to Gershon M. Ratner, a long-term education activist. In an article in the Texas Law Review, Mr. Ratner suggests that research by social scientists over the last 13 years provides enough data to overcome some of the objections raised to such claims in the past.

title: TAKING CHILL OUT OF WINTER PHOTOS
description: COLD weather is one of the photographer's toughest adversaries. It affects photography across the board. Film becomes brittle and has to be handled carefully, moisture inside the camera can freeze mechanisms, a camera brought into the cold can become useless in seconds from fogging and batteries can be impaired.

title: WASHINGTON'S UMBRELLA FOR THE ARTS
description: Gary Crawford had a background in arts management and was between jobs. Phoebe Kilby, an urban planner, decided she wanted to change fields and work in the cultural arena. So they both headed for the offices of the Cultural Alliance of Greater Washington, which maintains an arts job bank.

title: Straws in the Wind
description: Sometimes you can tell how the political winds are blowing around here, not by reading the front pages but by watching the book notes.

title: Silenced Voices
description: Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the dissident physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, arrived in Moscow Tuesday to find that friends had left fresh flowers in the apartment she had not seen since she was banished a year ago last May. Little else was known about her activities since it had been reported that she would be allowed to seek medical treatment in the West on condition she agree to avoid the press.

title: A LONG AND WRETCHED VIGIL
description: ON THE PERIMETER By Caroline Blackwood. 117 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: CAMBRIDGE TO ASSESS RISK OF A SAFETY OF TERRORIST THREAT AT M.I.T. REACTOR
description: Spurred by fear of a nuclear accident and speculation about terrorism, the city of Cambridge is taking a closer look at a small nuclear reactor run by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: OFF THE TURNPIKE, SOME SURPRISES
description: THE business of the tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike has mesmerized us for so long that even now, with the tariff off and the bypass lanes completed, we can't leave it alone.

title: ROSA PARKS VISITS BOYCOTT SITE
description: Rosa Parks returned to Montgomery today for the 30th anniversary observation of her quiet refusal to yield a bus seat to a white man, an event often viewed as the start of the civil rights movement.

title: DENMARK EXPLORES ITS MUSICAL HERITAGE
description: As has happened in many countries in recent decades, the Danish musical world has been digging in its past to find something ''new.'' In other words, it has been hoping to uncover something worth resurrecting. This obviously accounts for the release of two albums on which can be heard symphonies by five Danish composers, works written anywhere from 1904 to 1955. One album of two disks contains symphonies by Louis Glass, Rudolph Simonsen, Hakon Borresen and Herman Sandby (Danacord DACO 139-140, monophonic). The recordings were made in the 1950's by the Danish Radio Symphony under Launy Grondahl and are slightly thick but bearable in sound. The other single-disk album is of more recent origin, made in the late 1970's, and includes two symphonies by Rued Langgaard (Danacord DACO 230). His Symphony No. 10 is led by Ole Schmidt and Symphony No. 14 by Michael Schonwandt. The Danish Radio Symphony is involved in both and the Danish Radio Choir in the latter.

title: WHY BE MORAL?
description: THE WORLD OF THOUGHT IN ANCIENT CHINA By Benjamin I. Schwartz. 490 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $27.50. ''THE Command of Heaven is not forever.'' This simple idea with far-reaching consequences was articulated in a court song commemorating the founding of the Chou dynasty in the middle of the 11th century B.C. It presumably was sung for centuries to remind Chou kings that their behavior still counted, just as the behavior of their ancestors counted, the founding kings who secured Heaven's revocable command to rule the world.

title: FENWICK IS STILL GOING STRONG
description: IT WAS the end of a long day, and Millicent Fenwick, picking up her tobacco pouch and pipe, settled into a chair and talked about her past in New Jersey, her present role in Rome and her future in government.

title: NOW BRITAIN MUST SHOW GOOD FAITH IN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME 'EXPERTS' ONLY OBSCURE PROBLEMS OF TEEN SUICIDE
description: ROLAND CARTIER, age 13, committed suicide in Putnam, Conn., last summer.

title: MAESTRO REVIVES OLD PRACTICE
description: TWO works concerned with the passage of time - Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' and Haydn's Symphony No. 101, ''The Clock'' - will be performed todayby the Plainfield Symphony.

title: Trudy Coplin Marries
description: Trudy Coplin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul S. Coplin of Elizabeth and West End, N.J., and Demetrios Kontopoulos, a son of Anastasia Kontopoulos of Fairfield, N.J., and the late Peter Kontopoulos, were married yesterday. Judge Jack Turret of the Family Court of the State of New York performed the ceremony at The Players in New York. The bride is an account supervisor at BBDO Advertising and the bridegroom the director of radio and television production at Hicks & Greist Advertising.

title: SWEDESBORO: POTPOURRI OF ERAS
description: IN THE center of the Gloucester County community of Swedesboro is a charming old inn that appears to have been suspended in time.

title: FRONT MEN USED IN GAS-TAX EVASION
description: One day in 1983, Mieczyslaw Szczepkowksi, a Polish immigrant who was barely literate in English, returned to his boarding house in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn with startling news for his landlady.

title: A MEDIA GIANT LOSES ITS SWAGGER
description: TIME INC.'S announcement 10 days ago that its magazine group would henceforth be run by a separate management team gave rise to some uncharacteristic Wall Street rumors - uncharacteristic for Time, that is. The company, the rumors went, might be preparing to sell its cable operations and use the cash to take its magazines private.

title: A CONFEDERACY OF GENIUSES
description: THE HISTORY OF SOUTHERN LITERATURE Edited by Louis D. Rubin Jr. with Blyden Jackson, Rayburn S. Moore, Lewis P. Simpson and Thomas Daniel Young. 626 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $29.95.

title: QUARRYING HISTORY IN JERUSALEM
description: Only in Jerusalem could a huge hole in the ground have historical significance for Christians, Moslems, Jews, Freemasons, devil worshipers and occasional treasure hunters.

title: IN SECURITY MOVE, MORE METAL DETECTORS ARE PLACED IN COURTS
description: THE installation of nine walk-through metal detectors at courthouses around the state is part of an effort by the State Judicial Department to upgrade courtroom security.

title: GRANDPARENTS, GRANDCHILDREN AND THE LAW
description: I THINK I will start a new group and call it the ''Right to Be Left Alone'' group. This group will be formed for the coming together of all those who feel their rights are being infringed upon by other ''Right to Run Your Life'' groups, to which has now been added, the ''Grandparents' Rights'' Group.

title: Lynda Wornom, A Curator, Weds Rev. Ross Wright
description: Lynda Elizabeth Wornom, assistant curator of the Herbert H. Lehman Papers at Columbia University, was married in New York yesterday to the Rev. Ross McGowan Wright. The ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church, where the bridegroom is assistant minister, was performed by the Rev. Harold Elliott Barrett, assisted by the Rev. John Yates.

title: Guarding Rights of Partners
description: FIRST-TIME home buyers often have difficulty coming up with cash for the down payment and closing costs, and this difficulty has been worsened by the recent period of sharply rising prices. About $25,000, for example, would be needed to meet the initial cash requirements for a $100,000 house, a modest property by today's standards.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PHILADELPHIA LIGHT DANCE A ''Flashlight Symphony'' was performed two years ago as an added attraction in an exhibition on light at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. It makes its third annual appearance at the museum Dec. 14.

title: ON THE PAIN OF FATHERHOOD AND BEING A GIANTS' FANATIC
description: ALL morning I'm nervous but ready. My pulse quickens just before I turn on the game. As the cameras zoom into Giants Stadium, I sit on the edge of the couch and become a screamer.

title: PENSION PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: AWARD FOR JACKSON
description: Bo Jackson, the triple-threat athlete who became the first running back in Auburn history to gain more than 4,000 yards, has been selected as the recipient of the 1985 Walter Camp Trophy as the country's outstanding college football player. The award will be presented Feb. 8 at Yale University, where Camp, captain of the 1878 team, served as player, player-coach and coach and created the first all-America team in 1879.

title: TO THE E.P.A., PUTTING FIRST THINGS FIRST CAN BE A PROBLEM
description: As Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Lee M. Thomas has a staggering list of problems to deal with. One of the toughest is trying to figure out which problems to deal with first.

title: CORPORATE TAKEOVER
description: Senator Jesse Helms was teased to the point of laughter the other night at a roast conducted by friends and fellow conservatives who noted that the North Carolina Republican had prevailed quite successfully beyond a harsh childhood that included a custody battle. ''He ended up staying wth his parents when they lost the case,'' said Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Removing Wine From L.I. Schools
description: IT was a very good 10 years for wine-tasting courses in the Great Neck, L.I., adult education program, but now times have changed.

title: STEWART DECISION IN, THE TRIAL GOES ON TRIAL
description: For nearly six months, Justice Jeffrey M. Atlas presided over the longest and perhaps most complicated criminal trial of the year in Manhattan, that of six transit police officers charged in the 1983 death of Michael Stewart.

title: A NURSERY SOLVES A SOCIAL NEED
description: ON Oct. 21, the Hempstead Nursery Cooperative received its first charges, 10 boys and girls between the ages of 2 and 4. The opening of the nursery, which is designed to give severely overburdened parents a brief respite from the care of young children, was the result of more than a year's planning by its parent agency, the Junior League of Long Island.

title: PARALEGAL DEGREE PROGRAM OFFERS NEW YORK PRISONERS HOPE
description: Each semester since he started law classes, Barry Harding's name has been a fixture on the dean's list at Bronx Community College. He has earned an A in every course he has taken.

title: GORBACHEV RETURNS STRONGER
description: On a quiet Sunday morning, the snow lies pure and white on the field that stretches from Boris Pasternak's grave to the weathered wooden villa where he spent so much of his life. It was here in this writers' village of Peredelkino that, in the Stalin years, Mr. Pasternak wrote ''Dr. Zhivago,'' dropping the manuscript sheet by sheet into his desk drawer, knowing the pages could never pass censorship.

title: STATE MAY BE THE SITE OF 3 U.S. PRISONS
description: A FEDERAL Bureau of Prisons official whose duty is to find potential institutional sites says that New Jersey, which has never had a Federal prison, could have three of them before the end of the decade.

title: Amy Marshall Is Wed
description: Holy Trinity Episcopal Church was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Amy Louise Marshall, a daughter of Mrs. Mortimer Marshall of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Marshall, an actor, to Richard Alan Bruck, a son of Mrs. Joseph Bruck of Levittown, L.I., and the late Mr. Bruck. The Rev. Robert Castle performed the ceremony.

title: CUOMO FAULTS PLAN TO RAISE FARMERS' REAL-ESTATE TAXES
description: Governor Cuomo has intervened in a dispute between farmers and the state, requesting the State Board of Equalization and Assessment to modify its proposed values for agricultural land for 1986, which would have raised real-estate taxes for farmers.

title: DISABLED ACTORS REACH OUT ON TV
description: ''Everything concerning the disabled shouldn't have to be so heavy-duty,'' remarked Italia Dito while maneuvering her wheelchair from a KTTV sound stage toward an adjacent lunchroom. ''That's why we wanted to try something different,'' she said. The unusual result of that effort can be seen tomorrow evening at 8:30 on WNEW/Channel 5, when the 33-year-old Miss Dito, as one of nine disabled performers, begins the half-hour of original ballads, comedy and dramatic revelations that make up the musical revue ''Who Parks in Those Spaces?''

title: JAZZ
description: This weekend, New Yorkers can catch up with three major forces in modern jazz - a composer-pianist, an ensemble and a collective. The pianist, Cecil Taylor, is playing a double bill with the ensemble, the World Saxophone Quartet, Friday and Saturday evenings at 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Carey Playhouse (718-636-4100). The Association for the Advancement of Creative Music, which has fostered new jazz since the 1960's, is holding a 20th-anniversary celebration Saturday night at 8 at Symphony Space (864-5400), with two trios, a quartet and a 16-piece orchestra of musicians who developed under the A.A.C.M. umbrella.

title: BREADTH OF PROBLEMS STIRS CALLS FOR ANOTHER SYNOD
description: Joseph Cardinal Malula of Zaire, one of the presidents of the extraordinary Synod of Bishops called to examine the results of the Second Vatican Council, said today that another meeting might be required to adequately examine the problems facing the church.

title: SILENCING NOISE
description: To the Editor:

title: PENSION PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO HONORS AFTER 38 YEARS
description: CONSIDERING the proliferation of music competitions, the fact that Cecilia Gniewek-Brauer, a pianist who is to perform at the North Merrick Public Library today, recently was a finalist in the Young Keyboard Artists Association International Piano Competition and Festival would hardly seem to be big news.

title: FOUNDER OF ASSOCIATED BLIND
description: Irving M. Selis, a blind newsdealer who devoted his life to helping the blind live independently and planned Selis Manor, the city's first apartment building designed exclusively for the blind, died of heart disease yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: THE TEAMSTERS' UNSAVORY REPUTATION IS ALSO AN ASSET
description: Civilian blue-collar and white-collar workers at Fort Sill, Okla., voted last month to oust their union, an A.F.L.-C.I.O., affiliate, and replace it with the teamsters.

title: SHOW AT KATONAH GALLERY EXAMINES 'VANGUARD' WORK
