description: THERE is one thing wrong with the premise of Jonathan Fineberg's exhibition, ''Rethinking the Avant-Garde,'' at the Katonah Gallery through Jan. 5: The avant-garde no longer exists and has not for some time. Instead of being derided for flying in the face of tradition, all art made today, no matter how far out, is applauded by a moneyed audience forever hungry for the new.

title: NOW, TEXACO FACES LOSS OF CONFIDENCE
description: Texaco's investors grew nervous after the company's president, Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., said it might consider bankruptcy proceedings as an ''extreme step'' because of the costs associated with the $10.53 billion judgment against it in the Pennzoil case. Until all appeals are exhausted, the big oil company could be forced to post a $12 billion bond and set aside interest costs amounting to as much as $3 million a day. Such huge expenses make investors jittery, especially because Texaco has about $8 billion in debt outstanding from its acquisition of Getty Oil - the acquisition that resulted in Pennzoil's suit.

title: FOR 'NUTCRACKER' CHILDREN, THE WORLD BECOMES TRANSFORMED
description: FOR holiday enthusiasts who prefer their sugarplums in balletic form, the state abounds in ''Nutcrackers.'' New Jersey's three major ballet companies, as well as many local groups, are polishing their bonbons and marzipan for performances that begin this week.

title: 25,000 RETURN TURKEYS AFTER A RECALL IN JERSEY
description: About 25,000 people returned their holiday turkeys to a New Jersey-based grocery chain in response to a recall, the company, Foodtown, reported yesterday.

title: COMMISSION CHIEF TAKES WORLD VIEW
description: EDWARD COHEN, the man usually credited with having created the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology, is modest, mild-mannered and preoccupied with ''weltanschauung'' - world view.

title: BALTIMORE TRAINS 26 WHO FAILED TEACHER TEST
description: Twenty-six public school teachers hired this year after they failed a simple writing test are attending special night classes to improve their skills.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE REAL THING
description: It was the Rembrandt with which no visitor to the great museum in West Brlin had ever had any trouble. It was the epitome not only of Rembrandt, as he was popularly considered, but of a chivalric tradition that lasted well into the 20th century. Here before the delighted visitor was the ''verray parfit gentil knight,'' first set before us by Geoffrey Chaucer in his ''Canterbury Tales,'' 600 years ago. Sumptuously painted, with gold in the helmet that could not be less than 24 karats and a face long kneaded by life but never defeated, it reassured the visitor that nobility in old age was an inalienable part of human nature.

title: JUDGE NOMINATION STIRS OPPOSITION
description: A major fight is developing in Congress over President Reagan's nomination of Jefferson Beauregard Sessions 3d, the United States Attorney in Mobile, Ala., to be a Federal district judge.

title: A SWEET JOB WITH SOUR NOTES
description: IN 1934 Tom Carvel, then just 26 years old, borrowed $15 from his future wife, Agnes, filled a battered vending truck with ice cream, and drove into the American dream. The truck broke down in Hartsdale, N.Y., but the dream never faltered.

title: Credit Welfare
description: INSTEAD of receiving food stamps, 3,600 eligible people in Reading, Pa., got plastic credit cards in an experiment designed to cut administrative costs and prevent the loss, theft and forgery of the paper coupons.

title: Article 193922 -- No Title
description: The Department of Education has awarded 10 grants worth a total of $54.4 million to set up centers for educational research and development at universities around the nation.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Todd Bergen, the Philadelphia center who refused to play this season, citing differences with the Flyers' head coach, Mike Keenan, has been traded to the Minnesota North Stars along with a Flyer defenseman, Ed Hospodar, in exchange for a defenseman, Dave Richter and a right wing, Bob Berglund. . . . Jerry Berndt, coach of the Penn team that has won or shared the Ivy League title the last four years, said he expected an interview this week for the Pitt job, opened last Monday by the dismissal of Foge Fazio. ''They contacted our athletic director for permission to talk to me,'' Berndt said.

title: LIFE CHOICES: WOMEN WHO RENT, MEN WHO OWN
description: THIS may or may not be a piece about real estate.

title: WE WHO LEFT IRELAND
description: EMIGRANTS AND EXILES Ireland and the Irish Exodus to North America. By Kerby A. Miller. 684 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35.

title: NEW EFFORT SEEKS TO INSURE QUALITY OF PSYCHIATRIC CARE
description: THE girl was clearly troubled.

title: COLD COMFORT FROM MY FREEZER
description: MY neighbors on the East End seem to be quite fond of me. My popularity with them may be due to my wit and charm, but realistically it is probably because I own a generator. During electrical outages, not uncommon in this territory, my freezer compartment becomes a haven for neighborhood perishables.

title: Myra Cohen Becomes Bride of a Rabbi
description: Myra Cohen, the director of radio and television marketing and production for the Consulate General of Israel in New York, was married yesterday to Rabbi Leon Klenicki, the director of the national interfaith affairs department of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in New York. Rabbi Irving Block performed the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York.

title: THE OLD WAY
description: ''Meadows is an appropriate name because right now it's just an open field,'' said Marion Innella, the sales director of Summerhill Meadows, a 39.6-acre complex of 175 town houses under construction in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: VIETNAM MEMORIAL TAKES TO THE ROAD
description: As an afternoon drizzle misted faces already streaked with tears, dozens of visitors knelt before the 250-foot-long wall of black of plexiglass and wood, touching the cold surface as they found familiar names.

title: Health-Services Guide Is Found Lacking
description: In the Westchester Journal of Oct. 27 appears an announcement of a ''health guide'' that is misleading. The ''Community Health and Medical Guide: A Comprehensive Resource Book of Health and Medical Services for Central Westchester'' is entirely paid advertisement; most physicians and other health professionals in central Westchester are unlisted because they did not pay to be listed.

title: SARAH CALDWELL: AFTER THE 'NIGHTMARE'
description: Sarah Caldwell is healthy and raring to go again -and so, she says, is her Opera Company of Boston.

title: BUILDING SKILLS TESTED IN SPACE
description: Crew members of the space shuttle Atlantis tended to housekeeping chores and routine experiments today as they prepared for an excursion outside the craft on Sunday.

title: On Language;   Only Foolin'
description: THE PRESIDENT OF the United States, discussing presummit maneuvering, told a group of wire-service reporters that the time had come to ''stop this futzing around.''

title: GUATEMALAN VOTERS WILL GET A CLEAR CHOICE
description: When Guatemalans vote for a civilian President Dec. 8, they will be choosing between two candidates with very different views on the crisis in Central America.

title: Soviet-American Destiny
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE waters of Long Island Sound lapped languidly at the luxuriant finger of land so aptly named Kings Point on a recent weekend, a rainy weekend that brought to mind sea passages in which a ship seemed a lonely plaything shrouded from more settled mankind in a closet of wet and cloud.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Bookstore With More Than Books Books Plus . . . now just east of the junction of Routes 100A and 100 in Hartsdale and the reincarnation of an Ossining store called Between the Lines, specializes in soft and hardcovers for children of all ages from activity books to classics, plus records and cassettes, hand-crafted wood puzzles and educational toys. A green parrot named Cuspy supervises and comments upon transactions.

title: JARUZELSKI VISITING LIBYA
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, flew to Libya today on the first stop of a three-country tour of North Africa. He will also visit Algeria and Tunisia.

title: December 1, 1985
The Big Spenders In City Politics
description: In his brief, unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic nomination for City Comptroller this year, State Senator Franz S. Leichter spoke often about the role of campaign contributions in city politics. The Manhattan Democrat believes that in return for big contributions, donors seek favorable action from the city on pet projects.

title: PHILADELPHIA NEIGHBORHOOD TORN BY RACIAL TENSION STARTS TO SIMMER DOWN
description: Gerald and Carol Fox have long been especially vulnerable to the slings of bigots. He is black and she is white. But they weren't terribly worried about moving into a house that needed fixing up in a white, working-class enclave of southwest Philadelphia two weeks ago.

title: EDISON LAB NEAR CENTENNIAL
description: IT WAS 98 years ago - Thanksgiving Day in 1887 - that Thomas Alva Edison moved into his new laboratory in this Essex County community.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Washington policymakers in this section on Nov. 17 incorrectly stated Douglas McMinn's former rank in the National Security Council. He was director for international affairs. The senior director for international economic affairs was Roger W. Robinson.

title: WHAT YOU PAY FOR IN FIRST CLASS
description: Many air travelers dream of flying first class.

title: AFGHANS CONTEST DETENTION IN U.S.
description: Three Afghans in a detention center in New York say they cannot understand why they are being held when the United States Government claims to support the struggle of rebels against the Soviet-backed Government in Afghanistan.

title: A NEW BOOK STUDIES JESUS' IMPACT ON CULTURE
description: AT Yale University last year, Prof. Jaroslav Pelikan delivered a series of lectures about Jesus Christ that gave him ''the opportunity I needed to write the book I always wanted to write,'' he said.

title: COACHES VANISH
description: ACADEMICIANS in colleges across the land have been dropping like flies lately. It's the season. As the fall semester winds down and their win columns look as bare as the trees, these academicians with whistles around their ample necks and thick playbooks under their arms either wait to be pushed from their practice-field towers, or they jump.

title: THE RECESSIONS WEREN'T WORTH IT
description: IF THERE is a conventional wisdom about the disinflation experience of the first half of the 1980's, it is that the back-to-back recessions of 1980 and 1981 and 1982 (and the falling oil and commodities prices and strong dollar that accompanied them) were the unpalatable but indispensable medicine that purged the economy of double-digit inflation.

title: TESTAVERDE LEADS MIAMI
description: The University of Miami Hurricanes, already assured of a trip to the Sugar Bowl on New Year's Day, finished their season in stunning fashion today. Scoring nearly every time they had the ball, they ended Gerry Faust's five years at Notre Dame by handing the Irish their fourth-worst defeat ever and their worst loss in 41 years. The final score: 58-7. For the Hurricanes, the victory was their 10th straight after a loss to Florida in their opening game. It gave them a 10-1 record, and enhanced the possibility that they could win the national championship with a victory over Tennessee in the Sugar Bowl, a loss by Penn State to Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl and a little luck in the final polls.

title: Spies Real and Unreal
description: What's going on here? Not only does the Government seem to be infested with spies; but they aren't even the kind of subversives good Americans have been taught to fear and loathe.

title: Guru's Rolls-Royces Sold
description: Bob Roethlisberger, a Dallas car dealer, paid more than $6 million Friday for 84 Rolls-Royce automobiles left behind by Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh when the guru left the country. Mr. Roethlisberger said he would haul them to Texas for auction Feb. 8-9.

title: Keeping Meter Well-Fed
description: Charging desperately down Madison Avenue, Milton C. Perlmutter was worried about an expired parking meter and trying to get to his car before a parking ticket, or a tow truck, did.

title: A Non-Medicaid National Health Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Volcker on Latin Debt
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said Washington would work with Latin America to achieve sustained growth and thus tackle the region's $360 billion debt problem.

title: Fire Destroys Oldest Theater
description: Fire destroyed a 145-year-old converted grist mill Saturday that housed the Hedgerow Theater, the nation's oldest repertory theater, officials said. The Hedgerow was the first theater to present repertory shows, changing plays every night.

title: A TRIBUTE TO INDIA'S ARTISANS
description: In a brief ritual, Rajeev Sethi put out three brass pots filled with mud -one from the Hudson River, one a mix of lime plaster, and one of earth from behind the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. It was part of an opening-night celebration of a museum exhibition conceived by Mr. Sethi of objects made in a collaboration between Western designers and Indian craftsmen.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS LOUISVILLE BY 86-79
description: For the second time in three nights, St. John's found itself playing at an accelerated pace against top-grade competition.

title: FAUST PONDERING HIS FOOTBALL FUTURE
description: The chartered airplane that would carry the Notre Dame football team back to South Bend, Ind., had developed mechanical problems, so the departure was delayed until midnight. The tropical sun, the possible consolation prize for lengthening a humiliating stay in south Florida, was fighting a losing battle with the clouds.

title: MYSTERY, FISHERIES AND LOVE
description: Rolf Neslund, who is 83 years old if he is still alive, got a big burst of publicity in 1978 when he crashed the freighter he was piloting into the West Seattle Bridge, wrecking its westbound lanes.

title: Shopper at Mall Is Shot In Attempted Robbery
description: A woman was shot during an attempted robbery in the parking lot of the Staten Island Mall yesterday, and the gunman was arrested after commandeering a car and crashing it into a telephone pole, the police said.

title: Enduring Legends
description: John V. McNally, the colorful and highly accomplished former football star known as Johnny Blood, was probably a subject of more on- and off-the-field legends than anyone else who ever played the game. But although most of the stories told about him were as true as they were implausible, McNally, who died last week at age 82, cheerfully debunked a number of them in his later years.

title: A COURT IN MANILA ACQUITS ALL 26 ACCUSED IN THE SLAYING OF AQUINO
description: A three-judge court today acquitted the armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, and all 25 other defendants of involvement in the August 1983 assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. President Ferdinand E. Marcos immediately accepted a request for reinstatement by General Ver, who has been on a leave of absence as chief of staff since accusations were brought against him in connection with the assassination.

title: Office Automation Rise Cited in 3Com Merger
description: L. William Krause, president of the 3Com Corporation, is an Army brat who grew up with a knowledge and love of military history.

title: PLIMPTON AND STYRON READ WORKS AT PEN SERIES
description: The sounds of Tchaikovsky reverberated throughout the Royale theater on Broadway last night, played by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. However, the Philharmonic was not in attendance - just one of its part-time members, George Plimpton, the author, editor and dilettante par excellence.

title: IN JEWISH-GENTILE MARRIAGES, CHILDREN OFTEN STRUGGLE TO REACH INNER PEACE
description: The gold medallion Leslie Goodman-Malamuth wears around her neck serves as an emblem of her lifelong struggle as the child of an interfaith marriage.

title: What's Wrong With Exporting Alaskan Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Effort Planned For Air Controllers
description: The labor union that originally organized the now-defunct union for air traffic controllers said Sunday it planned a new effort to organize controllers.

title: Dr. Claudia Plottel Weds Dr. L.E. Stam
description: Dr. Claudia Sarah Plottel, a second-year resident in internal medicine at the New York University Medical Center, was married last night to Dr. Lawrence Eric Stam, a nephrologist in private practice in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: TYSON, AT AGE 19, RUSHES TO FUFILL D'AMATO VISION
description: AT the end of a dirt road in Catskill, N.Y., the white 14-room Victorian house sits on a bluff overlooking the Hudson River and mountains in the distance.

title: Woman Is Killed In Machete Attack
description: A Queens woman died yesterday after being attacked with a machete in her apartment, and her stepfather was arrested, the police said.

title: Sherry Lynne Jetter Married to Dov E. Goldman
description: Sherry Lynne Jetter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Jetter of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday to Dov E. Goldman, a son of Judith A. Goldman of Westport, Conn., and Marvin Goldman of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Norman Lamm, president of Yeshiva University, performed the ceremony at the Sands in Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: SPORT OF NOBILITY COMMON EVENT IN GENESEE AREA
description: Here in the snow-carpeted farmland of the Genesee Valley, a sport of nobility has been recast as the winter amusement of teachers, gasoline station owners and country lawyers.

title: Prelate in El Salvador Criticizes Court System
description: Gregorio Rosa Chavez, the Auxiliary Archbishop of San Salvador, today criticized the country's judicial system and interrogation methods.

title: MALTESE SAYS 3 HIGH U.S. OFFICERS HELPED COORDINATE ASSAULT ON JET
description: American officials acknowledged today that three American military officers traveled on a C-130 aircraft to Malta with Egyptian commandos who carried out an assault on a hijacked Egyptair jetliner last Sunday.

title: PURCHASERS SEE GOOD 4TH QUARTER
description: The economy improved again in November, continuing the trend of the past two months, the nation's purchasing managers said yesterday in their latest monthly report.

title: HOLLYWOOD STARS HONOR PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan was honored tonight by friends and former colleagues in the entertainment industry at a black-tie affair for charity.

title: Mississippi Flooding Is a National Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: British Steel Chairman
description: Bob Scholey, deputy chairman of the British Steel Corporation for 13 years, will become chairman of the state-owned corporation next April, according to a Government announcement. Mr. Scholey, who is 64 years old, will succeed Sir Robert Haslam, who will become chairman of the National Coal Board. Sir Ronald Halstead, 58, will succeed Mr. Scholey as deputy chairman. Both appointments are for three years, Trade and Industry Secretary Leon Brittan said on Thursday.

title: Topics;   Proof Through the Night Light Hearted
description: Mayor Koch has a good idea when he talks of dimming city lights so New Yorkers can get a better view of Halley's Comet. Yet some star-gazing enthusiasts seem bent on fuzzing up what should be a purely practical issue.

title: Dog Saves Family and Dies
description: A family dog was credited with saving the lives of a woman and her two teen-age daughters from a fire in their home early Friday, but the animal did not survive, officials said.

title: Uganda Rebel Accuses Government in 2 Attacks
description: A Ugandan rebel leader accused Ugandan soldiers today of mounting an offensive against his guerrillas, but said a peace agreement still could be signed this week.

title: GIANTS LOSE TO BROWNS, 35-33, AS LATE KICK MISSES
description: The Giants and the Cleveland Browns had expected their game today to be a defensive struggle. Instead, it was a high-scoring, big-play battle that was decided on the final play.

title: 'Remember, Remember'
description: The Jews of Vilna were killed in the Nazi death camp at Sobibor, 90,000 of them, piled into mass graves. In January 1944 the Germans - fearing loss of the war and wanting to destroy the evidence of mass murder - ordered a Jewish work crew to dig up the bodies and burn them.

title: Q&A: Lee M. Thomas;   E.P.A.'s Next 15 Years
description: An executive order signed by President Nixon on Dec. 2, 1970, created, out of bits and pieces of other Federal departments, a new entity, the Environmental Protection Agency. The E.P.A. was born amid a growing public demand that something be done to halt accelerating degradation of the nation's air, water and land.

title: SHULTZ WELCOMES APOLOGY BY ISRAEL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States welcomed Israel's apology for the purported espionage activities of Jonathan Jay Pollard, a Navy counterintelligence analyst accused of spying for Israel.

title: Washington Watch;   Investment Insurer Hobbled
description: The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which provides political risk insurance to American companies, has been unable to issue new policies since Oct. 1 because Congress has been slow to renew its operating authority.

title: 2 Die in Shootings in India
description: Gunmen killed two people in separate attacks in Punjab State, where an increase in Sikh violence has caused Indian authorities to increase security, an Indian new agency reported today.

title: Maybe Polar Bears
description: Their 12-0 start has made the Bears a pre-playoff favorite to go all the way to the Super Bowl in New Orleans on Jan. 26. But before they are allowed to warm themselves inside the Superdome, they'll probably have to endure two open-air January dates in Chicago. So much for the incentive involved in trying to clinch the home field right through the conference championship.

title: Continued Testing Set for Picture Week
description: Despite marketplace rumors to the contrary, Picture Week (Time Inc.'s challenge to some of the more garish publications at supermarket checkout counters) will not be going into national distribution soon after the first of the year.

title: NBC'S 'JOHN AND YOKO: A LOVE STORY'
description: THE three-hour presentation of ''John and Yoko: A Love Story'' on NBC tonight at 8 could just as easily be called ''Yoko's Revenge.'' The influence of Yoko Ono on John Lennon and the Beatles, the most popular music group of the century, has long been a subject of debate. Some of the more unflattering interpretations can be found in such recent books as the best-selling ''The Love You Make'' by Peter Brown and Steven Gaines.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOD BLESS US, EVERY ONE Ready or not, we are now in the holiday season, when a nation bent on doing new things, and having new experiences most of the year, slows down and senses some old feelings. Very little associated with Christmas is more traditional here than Charles Dickens's story ''A Christmas Carol,'' which some think of as the single great Christmas myth of modern literature.

title: Bill Scott, Writer and Voice For 'Rocky and His Friends'
description: Bill Scott, the voice of the cartoon characters Bullwinkle the moose and Mountie Dudley Do-Right, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Tujunga. He was 65 years old.

title: Divestiture Revisited
description: In September, the Regents of the Smithsonian Institution decided to put off deciding whether it ought to divest itself of stocks in companies that do business in South Africa. On Thursday, a House committee is expected to approve a bill designed to force the Regents' hand.

title: FOR AILING YOUNGSTERS, SPECIAL DAY-CARE CENTERS
description: Once upon a time, working parents had to stay home when their children became ill. Then two women here who worried about working parents came up with an alternative - a day-care center for sick children.

title: OUTDOORS: PRIMITIVE MUZZLE-LOADING HINDERS HUNT
description: AMONG the ranks of those roaming the northeastern woodlands in quest of deer are many who choose to handicap themselves by using primitive weapons.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has there ever been a draw in a world heavyweight championship bout? If so, has the loser - the fighter who proved himself to be the equal of the champion - ever gone on to achieve the championship?

title: Tax Exempts Dominate Schedule
description: The Treasury market can look forward to a few weeks of light supply, because the Government is not expected to auction any new notes or bonds until the second half of the month. But it will again be a busy week for tax-exempt municipal financings.

title: Minimum Tax Called Threat
description: Momentous changes are afoot in the municipal bond market. Investors are faced with proposed revisions to Federal tax laws that would remove the tax-exempt status of many bonds issued after the end of the year, while local governments face stricter limits on the amount and kind of bonds they may sell.

title: FOR 1988, THEY'RE ADDING UP AND COUNTING DOWN
description: So far this year both Senators Edward M. Kennedy Jr. of Massachusetts and Gary Hart of Colorado have declined to cross the New Hampshire state line, as some lesser-known Democratic Presidential aspirants have eagerly done.

title: Washington Watch;   Issues for Trade Official
description: A former Senate aide, Paul Freedenberg, is about to become Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, a difficult position that has been unfilled for the last two years.

title: Casey Kurtti, Playwright, Is the Bride of Chris Silva
description: Casey Kurtti, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah Kurtti of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Chris Silva, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Silva of Hayward, Calif.

title: PACKERS 21, BUCS 0, SNOW 16
description: The Green Bay Packers beat the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, 21-0, today in one of the snowiest National Football League games ever. More than 36,000 fans stayed home.

title: Gypsum Chief's Bid Seen as Safeguard
description: John P. Hayes has spent his entire professional life at the National Gypsum Company, and has been its chairman and chief executive officer since 1982. Now, along with other top managers and outside investors, he wants to buy the company where he has worked for 38 years.

title: Surgeon General Calls Smoking an Addiction
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said today that despite assertions to the contrary by the cigarette industry, smoking is addictive and cigarette advertising should be outlawed.

title: EX-HEAD OF RUMASA IS JAILED IN SPAIN
description: Jose Maria Ruiz-Mateos, the fugitive head of a business empire expropriated by the Spanish Government, was jailed here early this morning after being extradited from West Germany.

title: Rams Are Routed by Saints
description: Morten Andersen kicked five field goals and Jack Del Rio, a rookie linebacker, led an inspired defense today as the New Orleans Saints whipped the Los Angeles Rams, 29-3.

title: Stock Plans By Maxxam
description: The Maxxam Group Inc. said that it intended to accept for payment all shares of the Pacific Lumber Company that had been validly tendered under Maxxam's offer.

title: PERES APOLOGIZES FOR ANY ESPIONAGE CONDUCTED ON U.S.
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres apologized today for Israeli espionage in the United States, ''to the extent that it did take place,'' and said the Israeli Government unit purportedly involved in the espionage would be dismantled ''if the allegations are confirmed.''

title: A COMPETITIVE 'SPORT,' HAROLD, TAKES THE STAGE
description: It was close, but in the end Yale squeaked past Northwestern Saturday by a score of 24 to 22.

title: Canada Posts Trade Deficit
description: Canada had a $1.48 billion foreign trade deficit in the third quarter of 1985, although economic growth as measured by gross national product edged up slightly during the period, Statistics Canada reported Friday.

title: Be It Ever So Humble
description: ''When I was at home I was in a better place,'' Shakespeare wrote in ''As You Like It,'' and someone of a similar bent, quoted by Robert Frost, said, ''Home is the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in.''

title: BRUINS SET BACK DEVILS
description: After shutout losses in their previous two games, the Boston Bruins took out their frustrations on the Devils tonight, defeating New Jersey, 4-2, at Boston Garden.

title: PRETORIA UNIONS BACK DIVESTMENT
description: The newly formed Congress of South African Trade Unions, the biggest labor federation in the country's history, said in its first policy statement today that it supported divestment by American and British companies of their South African holdings.

title: Profits Up in State For Savings Banks
description: State-chartered savings banks in New York are showing their healthiest results in several years, industry experts say, because of increased profitability in the third quarter.

title: 32 Killed, Many Hurt In Fighting in Colombia
description: Twenty-three leftist rebels, eight civilians and one police officer were killed in two major battles between leftist guerrillas and the army, the Government said today.

title: U.S.-China Investment
description: United States investment in China, led by American involvement in China's offshore oil industry, has reached $1 billion, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Philadelphia Police Ban Word
description: The police have been ordered to stop using the word ''Negro'' to describe blacks in written and oral reports. In one of his final acts as police commissioner, Gregore Sambor, who is white, ordered officers to use ''black'' in reports. ''The word Negro is considered improper by the black community and consequently unacceptable to the police department,'' said the directive read to officers this week.

title: Mets Open April 8 In Pittsburgh
description: The Mets, who set a club attendance record of 2,751,437 last season, will open their 1986 season on the road April 8 against the Pittsburgh Pirates in a 6:05 P.M. start. After another game in Pittsburgh and three in Philadelphia against the Phillies, the Mets will play their home opener April 14 at Shea Stadium in a day game against the St. Louis Cardinals, the National League champions.

title: Suzuki to Ship Vehicle to U.S.
description: The four-wheel-drive Samurai, a jeep-like utility vehicle developed 17 years ago for the third world, will be introduced in the United States by the Suzuki Motor Car Company of Japan.

title: Quinones Names Chief Of Panel on Standards
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones yesterday announced the appointment of Dr. Edmund Gordon, a psychologist at Yale University, as chairman of a new commission that is to determine minimum standards for New York City's public schools.

title: REDSKINS ROUTED BY THE 49'ERS, 35-8
description: The San Francisco 49ers, who got off to a slow start this season after having won the Super Bowl last January, played their way back into a leading position in the playoff picture today as they trounced the Washington Redskins, 35-8, at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: McEnroe Averts Third-Round Upset
description: John McEnroe survived an embarrassing ace before subduing Nduka Odizor today, and Pam Shriver was a surprise loser at the $1.5 million Australian Open.

title: Dolphins Set Sights on Bears
description: They have outscored their last three opponents, 104-3. They have the leading defense in the league, perhaps the league's best rusher ever in Walter Payton and an esprit de corps that would seem to compensate for any shortcomings. And their record is 12-0. ''Yeah, they're a good team,'' Dan Marino said today of the Chicago Bears, whom he and the Miami Dolphins face Monday night in the Orange Bowl. ''But they have their weaknesses.''

title: SPY SCANDAL LOOSE ENDS
description: Israel's explanations thus far of how one of its senior officials became involved with the spy suspect Jonathan Jay Pollard leave many important questions unanswered.

title: FAST-GROWING SUBURBS ACT TO LIMIT DEVELOPMENT
description: A wave of anti-growth sentiment is emerging in parts of the country, directed against a surge in the construction of office buildings, hotels and other commercial projects outside the centers of cities and in suburban areas.

title: IT'S DANIELSON TO THE RESCUE
description: Gary Danielson, an old quarterback with a battered body but an admirable attitude, figured that he gave the Giants 10 points today, but got back 14. ''So I came out ahead by 4,'' he said.

title: Wallflower of Sorts
description: When William J. Bennett was chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, he regularly found his mailbox full of invitations to social events given by museums and art galleries, various units of the Smithsonian, and other Washington cultural groups. But when he became Secretary of Education early this year, many of these organizations dropped him off their social lists.

title: Making Inroads
description: Since their nation has no domestic automobile industry, the only cars that Hungarians ever see on the road are imported models, and pretty tame imported models at that: sedans manufactured in the Soviet Union, East Germany and Poland, or perhaps a garden-variety BMW, Ford or Renault shipped in from the West.

title: RECITAL: HAESOON KOH SINGS
description: HAESOON KOH, a soprano from South Korea who has studied in New York and Brussels, sang a recital at Merkin Concert Hall, 167 West 67th Street, Saturday night that, to her benefit, might have been deferred for several years. Miss Koh has a strong upper register and a reasonable sense of pitch, but her gifts remain in an embryonic state.

title: Purloined Plans Lead to Arrest
description: The police in Plymouth, England, arrested a man yesterday in connection with an attempt to sell plans of the British 12-Meter keel to the New York Yacht Club's America's Cup syndicate. Because the man was expected to be charged today, the police refused to comment further.

title: STAGE: PIELMEIER'S 'BOYS OF WINTER'
description: IN ''The Boys of Winter,'' the new John Pielmeier play at the Biltmore, the audience is asked to empathize with seven marines who are spending Christmas week 1968 on a near-suicide mission in South Vietnam. Such are the play's inadequacies, however, that when the time comes for some of the men to die, we don't mourn for the characters but instead envy the capable actors impersonating them. The actors, after all, have the good fortune to be carried off stage, where they are free to ignore the rest of the play in favor of more stimulating cultural pursuits, like crossword puzzles or poker.

title: Brother James M. Kenny, 65; Former Treasurer of Fordham
description: Brother James M. Kenny, former financial vice president and treasurer of Fordham University, died of cancer Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at the university's Bronx campus.

title: Popular Photography Is Given New Leaders
description: CBS Magazines has brought in Neil R. Butwin, 52 years old, to be publisher of its Popular Photography.

title: HOSPITALS MOVE TO PREPAID CARE FOR NEW YORK
description: A major shift toward a form of prepaid group health care that has cut hospital costs and challenged traditional medical practices in other parts of the country is under way in New York City.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Union Sq. Can Have A Park and Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1985
description: International Israel apologized for its espionage in the United States ''to the extent that it did take place.'' The statement by Prime Minister Shimon Peres also said the Israeli Government unit purportedly involved in the espionage would be dismantled if the allegations were confirmed. [Page A1, Col. 6.]

title: Some in Inwood Still Lack Water
description: Hundreds of residents in Inwood spent their fourth day without water yesterday as city workers continued searching for the faulty water main that caused the problem.

title: Philadelphia Protesters Released After Arrest
description: The 34 people arrested Saturday for demonstrating in a racially tense neighborhood were released today pending a court hearing Dec. 20.

title: Election Winner: Raising Money to Offset Deficit
description: The winner of that contest, Councilwoman Carol Greitzer, is doing some unusual fund raising of her own.

title: Appeal on Education
description: The largest and most influential American companies operating in South Africa announced today that they had called on the Government to abolish its racially segregated education system.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 2, 1985: *2*MONDAY Albertson's Inc Collins Foods Intl Anderson Clayton Foxboro Co *2*TUESDAY Allegheny Intl Culbro Corp Allen Group Inc MCA Inc American Stores Southwest Gas Corp Bristol-Meyers Swank Inc *2*WEDNESDAY Alaska Air Group Inc Orion Capital Corp Bay State Gas Pennwalt Corp Beatrice Cos Peoples Energy Capital Holding Corp RCA Corp Corning Glass Works Univar Corp Federal Co URS Corp 1st UnRI EstEq&Mtg USF&G Corp Kidde Inc US Shoe Corp Louisville Gas & Elec Witco Corp Midcon Corp Wynn's Intl *2* THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys General Host Atlantic City Elec Co Illinois Power Boise Cascade Corp Kaiser Cement Brown Group Inc Lucky Stores Chrysler Corp SPS Technologies Engelhard Corp Sperry Corp Ex-Cell-O Corp Supermarkets Genl Flight Safety Intl Tektronix Inc Gearhart Indus *2*FRIDAY Chubb Corp Piedmont Natural Gas Federated Dept Stores Roper Corporation Gelco Corp Steego Corp

title: Berger Stone Adding Auto Dealers' Groups
description: Berger Stone & Partners, long involved with advertising for Chevrolet dealer associations, has just added two more of the dealers' groups to its client list, bringing the total to nine with billings of about $15 million.

title: Washington Watch;   'Junk Bond' Curb by Fed?
description: THE Federal Reserve Board, in a move that could severely curb certain corporate takeovers, seems poised to limit the use of an increasingly popular takeover financing tool.

title: Why Dissidents Need Detente
description: In this period of post-summit cordiality, many people are waiting anxiously to see if the civil words uttered at Geneva were aimed at winning public-relations points or will lead to real detente.

title: QUITTING A JOB GRACEFULLY
description: A FAVORITE work fantasy is that delicious moment when you have landed a wonderful new job and get to tell your old bosses exactly what you think of them.

title: St. Patrick's Theft Is Put at $7,000
description: Two gunmen who robbed four ushers in the parish house of St. Patrick's Cathedral Saturday night escaped with more than $7,000 the church had collected from worshipers, the police said yesterday.

title: Topics;   Proof Through the Night Wanted: Glitz
description: Glitz and glamour are coming back at last, we thought when we read that the new Marriott Marquis Hotel in New York's Times Square would bear the world's largest photograph on its too stony facade. The world's largest color snapshot might make up for losing the man who blew smoke rings for Camels . . . the enormous waterfall over Bond's clothing and, later, Pepsi Cola . . . the pot that poured coffee into a bottomless cup for Maxwell House . . . the Clydesdale horses galloping beneath an eagle that flapped and flexed its neon wings and claws for Budweiser.

title: PUBLIC SCHOOLS AVOID TEACHING RIGHT AND WRONG
description: At a time of increased pressure from top Federal officials and some educators and parents groups for public schools to teach moral values, many educators in the New York area say they deliberately avoid trying to tell students what is ethically right and wrong.

title: Housing Promise on Staten Island
description: Is unsubsidized housing impossibly expensive in New York City? Not on Staten Island. One- and two-family homes are rising even within a block or two of the depressed industrial strip along the island's North Shore. Some low-density apartments should also go up, but the city has moved, unwisely, to prevent their construction.

title: Bridge: New York's Tourney Scene Loses Two Notable Figures
description: Two notable figures on the New York bridge scene died recently at an early age.

title: U.S. Aide Joins Bear Stearns
description: Francis X. Lilly, the Labor Department's Solicitor, will join Bear Stearns Companies Inc. as an executive vice president in its Custodial Trust Company subsidiary next Monday, according to an announcement by the holding company.

title: HOSPITALS LURING PATIENTS BY MARKETING SERVICES
description: Hospitals in Minneapolis and St. Paul are advertising gourmet meals and rooms with big-screen television sets in a battle for patients that may tell something about the future of the nation's medical system.

title: Market Place;   Advisers Recall Stock Mistakes
description: EVERYONE loves to pick winners in the stock market, but professionals - like average investors - can go wrong. The smart ones learn to profit by this experience, turning lemons into lemonade, so to speak.

title: DAUGHERTY LEADS TAR HEELS TO TITLE
description: North Carolina got 21 points from Brad Daugherty in a 65-60 come-from-behind victory over Nevada-Las Vegas today in the championship game of the eighth annual Great Alaska Shootout tournament.

title: DUKE TOPS KANSAS, 92-86, IN N.I.T. FINAL
description: With the question of who's number one wide open after this weekend's games, Duke made a strong case for consideration last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Dec. 2, 1985 Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 1:20 P.M. today and set at 2:52 A.M. tomorrow.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Apple Bank for Savings has elected Jerome R. McDougal chairman and chief executive officer, effective March 31, 1986, upon the retirement of William R. Brennan.

title: UNUSUAL STRATEGY, INSTINCTS SERVE NUGGETS WELL
description: AT first glance, he looks out of place on a basketball court - out of pace with the bodies blazing about the floor around him, or merely miscast among the soaring, sweating, muscular men with whom he plays. He doesn't soar, appears never to sweat, and his lithe, 6-foot-7-inch figure seems to have been shaped not for this sometimes grueling sport, but for dance.

title: What's Wrong With Exporting Alaskan Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: McDonald's Eastern Carolina Co-Op to Fahlgren & Swink, Greensboro, N.C.

title: RIDE ON A B-%: NEW ROLE FOR WORKHORSE OF BATTLE
description: To train for a nuclear air strike against the Soviet Union, the B-52 bomber thundered down the icy runway and lifted off over the North Dakota prairie just as dawn broke.

title: THE LURE (AND THE LORE) OF ARGENTINA'S SUMMER
description: As the weather turns warm in South America, whatever the economic climate, one idea takes hold of most Argentines -it's time for the annual vacation.

title: PIANO: PETER SERKIN IN RECITAL
description: SUCH technical capacity as Peter Serkin displayed Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y, in the absence of a showman's will to dazzle, comes to full fruition only if the player has enough imaginative perception to shape and direct even the tiniest musical gestures - the rise and fall of a motivic germ, the latent directionality of an ostensibly static accompaniment. Many fine musicians are alive to this sort of thing, but I can think of no pianist whose fingers are more effortlessly, subtly responsive to it than Mr. Serkin's.

title: THEATER: 2D PLAY IN 'DARK AND MR. STONE' TRILOGY
description: WHEN last seen on the stage of La Mama, the great detective Edgar Stone, having just solved a murder in Boston, had been summoned to do likewise in Savannah. The second offering of Paul Foster's gaslight trilogy ''The Dark and Mr. Stone'' finds Stone rattling along in a railroad car on his way to Georgia, by courtesy of the electric lighting of Howard Thies that flickers in time to the railroad music of Alkiviades Steriopoulos at the keyboard in the audience.

title: Fox Film Goes Into the Black
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation Friday reported net income of $1 million on revenues of $174.4 million in the fourth quarter ended Aug. 31, in contrast to a loss of $73.8 million on revenues of $150.6 million in the corresponding period last year. The profit was Fox's first in 21 months.

title: CITY REPORTS 3 HOTELS HELP CHEATS GET WELFARE CHECKS
description: Three Manhattan hotels have been providing fraudulent addresses for poor and homeless people so they can qualify for welfare, city officials said yesterday.

title: Put a Lid on the Lobbies
description: At 2:25 P.M. tomorrow, Americans should know a lot more about their senators' views on taking money from special interests. That's about the time of the final vote on a bill to limit the flood of campaign contributions by PAC's, the political action committees that have sprung up on behalf of every imaginable interest.

title: Beirut Radio Reports Ambush of Israeli Patrol
description: Guerrillas ambushed an Israeli patrol in southern Lebanon today, killing or wounding five soldiers, the Beirut radio said. Meanwhile, rival militiamen again clashed in Beirut and in the mountains east of the capital.

title: NEW GROUP VOICES OPPOSITION
description: More than 80 chief executives of major American companies operating in South Africa have committed their companies to a new group's campaign to end apartheid, but the founders of the group have declined to say what steps were planned to follow through on their stand.

title: Bet That Felt Good
description: Really satisfying expressions of anger at the Federal Government are rare but not yet extinct. The other morning a commuter, driving into Georgetown over the Key Bridge, found himself alongside one of those clearly labeled interagency motor pool cars. Suddenly, a bridge-walker in the unmistakable motley of the Washington street-person darted through the traffic, thumped the Government car loudly on the hood with his fist and zipped back to the sidewalk, his protest complete.

title: Carter Aide in Senate Race
description: Hamilton Jordan, who was a top aide to President Carter, will run for the United States Senate in Georgia next year, despite the fact that he is undergoing treatment for cancer, The Atlanta Constitution reported in Monday's editions. The newspaper reported that Mr. Jordan, 41 years old, said he was ''free of disease'' and hoped to complete treatment for lymphatic cancer soon. He is the fourth announced candidate for the Democratic nomination to run against Senator Mack Mattingly, a Republican, in 1986.

title: Election Loser: So Busy It Seems as if He Won
description: David Rothenberg did not win election to the City Council. Nevertheless, he is busier than ever these days - so busy, in fact, that he thinks it is time he stepped down as executive director of the Fortune Society, which he has headed since its founding in 1967.

title: De Havilland Sale Reported
description: The Canadian Government will announce today that it will sell the state-owned de Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd. to the Boeing Company, the world's largest commercial aircraft manufacturer, Canadian Government sources said yesterday. The Government is expected to announce, in a news conference in Ottawa this afternoon, that it will sell the company for around $200 million (Canadian).

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1985
description: The Economy

title: WIDOW OF AQUINO HINTS ELECTION BID
description: Corazon Aquino, widow of the slain opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., promised a cheering crowd of 15,000 today that ''you will hear what you want to hear'' when she announces this week whether she will run for President.

title: Swiss Reject Plan to Bar Animal Experiments
description: Swiss voters today rejected a proposal to amend the nation's Constitution to outlaw most medical and drug experiments involving live animals.

title: Settlement Announced In Boston Hotel Talks
description: Negotiators reached a contract settlement early today that averted a walkout at nine of the city's hotels, according to Domenic Bozzotto, president of Local 26 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union.

title: BUSINESS PROTESTS ON APARTHEID GROW
description: In recent weeks, American business interests in South Africa have taken to increasingly vocal and public protests against the policies of the white minority Government.

title: FRITO-LAY'S GO-IT-ALONE PLOICY
description: At a time when the conventional wisdom among consumer products companies is that it is cheaper to buy an established national brand than try to develop one, Frito-Lay Inc. has not gotten the word.

title: Advertising;   Toil Helps Poppe Fill Billing Gap
description: EVEN if an advertising agency knows when it is assigned an account that the job is for a set period, it is still tough to depart at the appointed time. And unless new business is found to fill the gap, people have to be let go. That's the toughest.

title: TOON'S GRACE BELIES HIS SKILL
description: IT bothers Al Toon, who was brought up to use all his talents, that he can't do everything at once.

title: FOR SIXERS' ERVING, A SUPPORTING ROLE
description: In recent years, the only tangible sign that Julius Erving, the eminent Doctor, was not operating on the same level as he had during his incomparable past, was the distinguished hint of gray in his hair. Certainly, he was less dominant and acrobatic than he once was, and he was capable only rarely of taking command of a game for long and crucial stretches.

title: SEARS TRADE UNIT SHIFTS FOCUS
description: When Sears, Roebuck & Company set up Sears World Trade more than three years ago, officials at the new trading subsidiary boasted that they would go so far as to help Indonesia tap its timber resources and help China develop its pulp industry.

title: MANY CRIMES FOUND UNREPORTED
description: Two-thirds of America's crime victims do not call the police and victims are more likely to report car thefts than rapes or other types of assault, the Justice Department said today.

title: MUSIC: FIRES OF LONDON
description: IN the middle of its busy weekend at Alice Tully Hall, the Fires of London turned to two earlier pieces Saturday afternoon -''Le Jongleur de Notre Dame'' and ''Eight Songs for a Mad King.'' Both were composed - and conducted in these performances - by Peter Maxwell Davies, and each straddles the boundary lines of chamber opera, dramatic monologue, pageant and pantomime with considerable grace.

title: Pratt & Whitney Strike Is Begun by Machinists
description: Machinist union members began their first strike in 25 years against the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Company early today after turning down a three-year contract offer from the jet engine manufacturer on Sunday.

title: People
description: William T. Nicholson was named a senior vice president, chief financial officer, secretary and a trustee of the profit-sharing fund of Cunningham & Walsh.

title: Israeli Government Decides To Resume Talks With Egypt
description: The Israeli Government today approved the resumption of talks with Egypt on territorial disputes and other issues. The talks were cut off by Egypt after the Israeli air strike on Palestine Liberation Organization headquarters in Tunisia on Oct. 1.

title: Time to Redraw New York City School Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ONE is tempted to call this the year of the gorilla among children's picture books -in honor of Anthony Browne's ''Gorilla,'' the wittiest work I came across in my search. But a rabbit, a cat and a fox also did their turns. And so did some people, a few machines, 26 letters and several beguiling palettes of color.

title: DEMISE OF THE SGT. YORK: MODEL TURNS TO DUD
description: If a weapon can be said to have died of embarrassment, the antiaircraft gun called the Sergeant York did.

title: AS A HOLIDAY ENDS, TRAVEL'S HARSH REALITY SETS IN
description: At the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday afternoon, lines were long, tempers were short and the holiday weekend suddenly seemed more trouble than it was worth.

title: In Defense of a Vigorous U. S. Attorney
description: Pascal taught that the first rule of morality, and thus of public discourse about it, is to think clearly. In that spirit, here are a few thoughts about organized crime: The Mafia exists. It is not the creation of novelists or journalists. It has exacted a toll in misery that would shame the Inquisition and a toll in treasure that would embarrass the Pentagon. It consists not of dashing Robin Hoods or buffoons but of willful, disciplined men who have too long burdened all of us.

title: WEST EUROPEAN LEADERS MEET TODAY
description: Western European leaders will gather in Luxembourg on Monday amid growing doubts that they can overhaul the 10-nation European Economic Community before Spain and Portugal join next year.

title: House Tax Plan and Campus Employees
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are no more going to be passive. We have been passive for quite a number of years.

title: Collectors Have Their Day At a Lincoln Center Bazaar
description: At 6 o'clock yesterday morning, the line began forming at Lincoln Center. When the crowd was unleashed four and a half hours later, however, it was not to swoop down on the box office.

title: WOMEN AND MASOCHISM: DEBATE CONTINUES
description: ''Most of the behavior in women that has been labeled masochistic just isn't,'' said Dr. Paula J. Caplan. ''Women are not masochists, despite the belief that they are.''

title: MONDAY FOOTBALL
description: Football Dolphins vs. Chicago Bears, at Miami. The assistant coach, Buddy Ryan, has the Bears' defense on a roll. They have allowed only 3 points in the last 13 quarters and they have not allowed a point in the last nine.

title: MUSICAL FOCUSES ON DISABLED
description: ''WHO PARKS IN THOSE SPACES?'' is a cheerful, unpretentious half-hour musical performed by nine disabled people. If it lacks the polish of ''Tell Them I'm a Mermaid,'' its 1983 predecessor, it's still not half-bad as it is. The performers tell us about themselves, and because they're engaging we listen. Occasionally, we're moved. The program will be seen on Channel 5 at 8:30 tonight.

title: Stock Halt in Singapore
description: The Stock Exchange of Singapore announced today an indefinite suspension of trading to prevent panic selling after a major industrial venture was put into receivership Saturday.

title: TUMBLING, TWISTING ASTRONAUTS TURN STENUOUS TASKS INTO BALLET
description: Two astronauts stepped outside the orbiting shuttle Atlantis today for a second arduous construction exercise in the weightless vacuum of space.

title: DANCE: MERCE CUNNINGHAM 'EVENTS'
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM and his dancers are back on stage and all's well with the choreographic world. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company presented the first in a series of what Mr. Cunningham calls ''Events'' on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: U.S. WILL TRACE TOXIC SHOCK
description: Concerned that as many as 90 percent of the cases of toxic shock syndrome are not reported, researchers will conduct a study next year to try to determine how widespread the disease is.

title: KOHL OPPOSES NOBEL FOR RUSSIAN
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl joined a campaign today to prevent a Soviet doctor from receiving the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Church Report Says Policies Of Thatcher Hurt Poor People
description: A Church of England commission issued a report today criticizing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for policies it says helpthe rich at the expense of poor people living in decayed urban areas.

title: Yugoslavs Win Slalom In World Cup in Italy
description: Rok Petrovic and Bojan Krizaj scored a one-two triumph for Yugoslavia in today's World Cup of Alpine skiing slalom here as the heavy favorites, Marc Girardelli and Pirmin Zurbriggen, were disqualified for missing gates.

title: Pilot Reported Trouble Just Before Iowa Crash
description: A pilot reported ''severe turbulence'' just before his twin-engine plane crashed in a neighborhood, killing him and six members of a women's collegiate cross country team, according to transcripts of flight recordings released Friday.

title: GOAL OF PROPOSED PLANE IS 12-MINUTE COAST TRIP
description: So far just a gleam in the eyes of some engineers, a design for an airplane that could fly coast to coast in about 12 minutes is beginning to take shape, according to Government and industry sources.

title: The Cuomo Court
description: With the nomination of Stewart Hancock, New York's Governor Cuomo has now named six of the seven members of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal. A relatively new selection process has not produced scholars of the stature of Benjamin Cardozo, but it has created a panel of capable, moderate and broadly representative jurists without the unseemly clamor and expense of public politicking.

title: END OF PHONE CURBS SOUGHT
description: The seven Bell Telephone regional holding companies are mounting an intense campaign here to end Government restrictions on their ability to compete with the rest of the industry in businesses ranging from selling interstate long-distance services to manufacturing equipment.

title: BHOPAL FACTORY A YEAR LATER: SILENCE AND WEEDS
description: A black storage tank sits on a platform at the once-bustling Union Carbide pesticide factory here. Inside is about 13 tons of residue from a chemical reaction that spewed poison into the air and caused the worst industrial accident in history.

title: FOE OF POLAND'S GOVERNMENT GETS U.S. HUMANITIES HONOR
description: Leszek Kolakowski, an opponent of the Polish Government and an authority on Marxism, has been selected by the National Endowment for the Humanities to give its annual Jefferson Lecture in May.

title: Joint Effort Completed At Vietnam Crash Site
description: The United States and Vietnam completed their first joint excavation of an American warplane crash site today, but they said there were only slim hopes of identifying missing American servicemen from the unearthed bone fragments.

title: PRESSURE OF SKINS
description: AT the Skins Game, the golfers putt for big money while the spectators root for small money. Put up a few dollars and pick a player out of a hat. And on Saturday night, a man who had drawn Fuzzy Zoeller was talking to the 34-year-old touring pro who had failed to make a birdie on that day's nine holes.

title: Deana May Diamond Marries Seth Linfield
description: Deana May Diamond, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Diamond of Tulsa, Okla., was married there yesterday to Seth Douglas Linfield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Linfield of Brooklyn. Rabbis Sheldon Lewis and Charles Sherman officiated at Temple Israel.

title: ECONOMIC EFFECTS OF CAR LURES
description: The Chrysler Corporation's decision to end the year with yet another round of sales incentives clearly indicates Detroit's current preference for cutting prices rather than cutting production.

title: POPE VOWS TO BE OPEN TO SYNOD RESULTS
description: Pope John Paul II pledged today to remain open to the suggestions and conclusions of the Synod of Bishops being held in Rome.

title: Swiss Plan Silver Fixing
description: Switzerland's three biggest banks have disclosed plans to wrest silver trading business away from its traditional home in London.

title: United Arab Emirates to Build Big Naval Base to Protect Oil
description: The United Arab Emirates, one of the world's key oil-producing states, will build a large naval base to protect its offshore oil installations, a leading official said today.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 2, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHUCK YEAGER REACHES PUBLISHING STRATOSPHERE
description: When the White House phoned to invite the Yeagers to dinner with Prince Charles and the Princess of Wales, Chuck Yeager tendered his regrets because he was scheduled to hunt elk in Oregon that day.

title: Holbert and Unser Finish First at Daytona
description: Al Holbert and Al Unser Jr. combined today to win the season-ending three-hour International Motor Sports Association Camel GT race.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Giant Crew's 'No-Win Job'
description: THE job of an airline pilot was once described as ''hours of tedium, moments of terror,'' or words to that effect. The triumvirate that performs a crucial field-goal attempt in football could certainly apply to the same union as the cockpit crew on an airplane.

title: Washington Watch;   Briefcases
description: The Senate Energy Committee will consider on Thursday the nominations of Mary L. Walker as Assistant Secretary of Energy for Environment, Safety and Health, a newly revived post, and Donna R. Fitzpatrick as Assistant Secretary for Conservation and Renewable Energy.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 9
Official Wants to Cut Funds to Los Angeles
description: The Government's top immigration official in the West says he will explore whether Los Angeles can be cut off from receiving Federal funds after the City Council declared it a sanctuary for Central American political refugees.

title: Bomb in New Caledonia Destroys a Courtroom
description: A courtroom was destroyed here today in what the police said was the biggest bomb blast ever in this French territory.

title: HIGHER PURCHASE OFFER REPORTED BY COUNSEL FOR U.P.I.'S CREDITORS
description: The counsel for a committee representing United Press International's creditors said late yesterday that he had received a bid for the news agency ''significantly higher'' than the one the creditors' committee had aready endorsed.

title: The Inflation Option
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILIP LARKIN, POET AND LIBRARIAN, DIES AT 63
description: Philip Larkin, a reclusive librarian who was one of Britain's best-loved poets, died early today. He was 63 years old. He had lived for almost 30 years in Hull, a northeastern city sufficiently out of the way, he once noted, that importunate visiting Americans usually decided to bother someone else. He refused to give poetry readings, shunned interviews, and when asked by Kingsley Amis if he thought about becoming Poet Laureate, replied: ''I dream about that sometimes - and wake up screaming. With any luck they'll pass me over.''

title: CARBIDE A YEAR AFTER BHOPAL
description: As the Union Carbide Corporation passes the first anniversary of the accident at its pesticides plant in Bhopal, India, the company is shaken by giant lawsuits, the threat of a takeover and low employee morale.

title: TONE IS COOL AT U.S.-SOVIET LITERARY EXCHANGE
description: A group of American writers left Moscow today after talks with Soviet authors that touched on the role of homosexuality in literature and other subjects normally considered taboo in the Soviet Union.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP IN OCTOBER
description: Construction spending rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October as increased activity in residential building offset a big drop in construction of shopping centers, the Commerce Department said today.

title: 5 Minutes of France
description: It seemed like the perfect fix for the cravings of diehard Francophiles - a hot line set up by the French Consulate to provide French news in English for Americans.

title: NEC Raises Prices On Chips for U.S.
description: The NEC Corporation, Japan's top semiconductor maker, said it had raised prices 20 percent on memory chips sold in United States markets.

title: Follower of Manson Freed From U.S. Prison
description: A follower of the cult figure Charles Manson was released today from the Federal prison here after serving nearly 10 years for conspiring to send death threats to corporate officials.

title: ASTRONAUTS PREPARE TO COME HOME
description: Crew members of the space shuttle Atlantis, their seven-day orbital mission nearly behind them, said today that their flight had taken a significant step toward the establishment of a large space station.

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 27
description: The share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in August.

title: ITT Unit Offers Yield of 10.222%
description: The ITT Financial Corporation is offering $100 million of 10 1/8 percent senior notes due in 1996 at a price of 99 3/8, to yield 10.222 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: MCDONNELL WINS A 'STAR WARS' MISSILE CONTRACT
description: The McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Company was selected over the Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday to design a new ballistic missile to destroy incoming nuclear warheads, in the second major ''Star Wars'' contract awarded by the Pentagon in the last month.

title: MARIE WAIFE
description: Marie Waife, the last surviving child of Sholom Aleichem, the Yiddish writer, died Saturday at the Jewish Home for the Aged in New York. She was 94 years old.

title: RECALLING FAVORITE DECISIONS
description: The cases some Supreme Court Justices recall most fondly are not those that made the biggest headlines when the decisions came down.

title: Commodore Begins A Reorganization
description: Commodore International Ltd., the home computer maker that has suffered three consecutive quarterly losses, yesterday announced a reorganization of its top management.

title: REPORT FOR U.N. ASSAILS AFGHAN REGIME
description: Violations of human rights have become widespread in Afghanistan since Soviet forces joined the fighting there nearly six years ago, according to a report presented today to the United Nations.

title: PLAYOFF OUTLOOK A BIT CLEARER
description: With three weeks to go in the regular season, the playoff picture is relatively clear in both the National and American Conferences. Here is a closer look:

title: What the Weinberger Letter Actually Said
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,163,000 for the quarter and 9 months from expenses incurred in connection with a merger.

title: St. Lawrence Seaway Opens, But High Winds Shut It Again
description: The St. Lawrence Seaway reopened today when workers secured a lift bridge that had been rammed by a freighter, but winds of up to 94 miles per hour forced officials to halt shipping traffic soon afterward.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: NEW YORK is settling into the silly season. The other day, for instance, Marina Schiano, who used to be Calvin Klein's publicist, was in Bird Jungle (401 Bleecker Street, at West 11th Street). Although she wouldn't reveal what she'll be doing next professionally, Miss Schiano did let on what she might want for Christmas: a little brown bird wearing a striking orange neckband. Miss Schiano's companions, Giorgio Sant'Angelo, the designer, and Franco Rossellini, the director, were more interested in looking at a big-billed toucan. ''Toooo-can,'' Mr. Rossellini pronounced. ''It looks like Mrs. Vreeland, no?''

title: JUDGE ORDERS WILLIAMS TO BEGIN 10-YEAR SENTENCE IN BRIBERY PLOT
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the former teamster union president, Roy Williams, to begin serving a 10-year prison term for conspiracy to bribe a United States Senator.

title: 2 EARLY WORKS FOR FIRES OF LONDON
description: THE Fires of London and Peter Maxwell Davies played two works from the earliest years of their joint activity Sunday at Tully Hall, ''Miss Donnithorne's Maggot'' (1974) and ''Vesalii Icones'' (1969) - a fascinating conclusion to an engagement that has brought both disappointments and challenging rewards.

title: Not Trash or Books
description: The collections of the Library of Congress and the New York City Department of Sanitation rarely overlap. Still, Roger Liwer, the department's director of materials control, is coming from New York today to talk at a seminar for employees of the Copyright Services Office of the Library.

title: MORMON WRITINGS TRACED TO TEXAS
description: Papers supposedly written by a disaffected Mormon apostle in the 19th century have come to light in Texas and investigators are weighing the question of whether the papers had any connection to fatal bombings here in October.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,418,871 from payment of a life insurance policy of an executive.

title: Son Accused of Killing Mother in an Argument
description: A 37-year-old man was charged today with assault in the fatal beating of his mother after she refused to cook meatballs for him on Thanksgiving, the police said.

title: RODIME PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORLCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PARTI QUEBECOIS IS OUSTED AFTER 9 YEARS IN POWER
description: The Parti Quebecois, which once advocated at least partial independence from Canada, was overwhelmingly defeated tonight by the Liberal Party after nine years in office.

title: BARRY MANILOW STARS IN 'COPACABANA' ON CBS
description: BARRY MANILOW'S song ''Copacabana'' became a hit in 1978. Soon after, it was used for an elaborate nightclub production number in one of Mr. Manilow's television specials. Now, the lyric's scenario has been expanded into a two-hour television movie, supplemented with 10 new Manilow songs, which can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS. The result, impeccably directed by Waris Hussein for Dick Clark Productions, is a sweet salute to old-fashioned musicals, a kind of fond parody of everything from Carmen Miranda to ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue.''

title: NEW SCHOLARSHIP SHEDS LIGHT ON ORIGINS OF ETRUSCANS
description: RECENT excavations and interpretive work of scholars have pierced the shrouds that have enveloped the long-lost Etruscan civilization.

title: HAWKS' BIG MEN LEARN FROM ONE OF THE BEST
description: Several hours later, the Atlanta Hawks would beat the Knicks with the help of Dominique Wilkins's 35 points. It was last Tuesday afternoon, and the Hawks were going through their pre-game shootaround.

title: Citicorp, Morgan Backed on Underwriting
description: The Justice Department has asked the Federal Reserve Board to permit Citicorp and J.P. Morgan & Company to underwrite and sell certain securities, such as commercial paper, industrial revenue bonds and mortgage-backed securities.

title: U.S. TO PROPOSE RULES RESTRICTING 3 SUBSTANCES IN WORKPLACE
description: After years of consideration, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is to propose new workplace health standards soon on the use of three common substances that are suspected of causing cancer or other illnesses in humans.

title: ARAB-AMERICANS SEEK PROTECTION
description: Several organizations of Arab-Americans appealed today for protection by law-enforcement officials and ''Americans of good will'' against ''an increasing number of threats and attacks'' on leaders and offices of their groups.

title: Market Place;   Singapore's Chilling Effect
description: THE bull market in stocks has assumed global proportions this year, thanks partly to the infusion of cash from pension funds and other investors in the United States. But foreign markets felt a decided chill yesterday with the weekend announcement that the Singapore Stock Exchange -the largest in Asia after Japan and Hong Kong -had closed indefinitely.

title: Give Thanks for Those Holiday Fares
description: Some holiday air fares were truly remarkable: New York to Detroit or Raleigh for $29 . . . to Wichita or Jacksonville for $49 . . . to Tucson or San Francisco for $79. There was a catch, to be sure. Travelers had to leave on Thanksgiving Day or on Friday and return by Saturday. If they missed a flight, too bad; there were no refunds.

title: Winning Records
description: The victory over Mount Union of Ohio last Saturday was the 35th in a row by Augustana of Illinois, a Division III record by far. These are the longest winning streaks in college football history: DIVISIONS I-A AND I-AA Oklahoma (1953-57)47 Washington (1908-1439 Yale (1890-93)37 Yale (1887-89)37 Toledo (1969-71)35 DIVISION II Missouri Valley (1941-48)41 Hillsdale (Mich.) (1954-57)34 Wilkes (Pa.) (1965-69)32 Morgan State (Md.) (1965-68)32 East Texas State (1951-53)29 DIVISION III Augustana (Ill.) (1983-85)35 Dayton (1979-81)21 Plymouth (N.H.) State (1981-82)19 Lawrence (Wis.) (1980-81)18 Ithaca (N.Y.) (1979-80)18 California Lutheran (1974-75)18

title: U.S. SAYS WIFE IN SPY CASE HAD DATA FOR CHINA
description: When Anne Henderson-Pollard was arrested last month, she was planning to offer the Chinese a secret document that describes in detail what American intelligence knows about Peking's spying activities in this country, prosecutors asserted today.

title: Chess: San Francisco Tourney Won By Ramayrat of Philippines
description: Cris Ramayrat of the Philippines has captured first place in the San Francisco International Tournament with a 7-2 score. The 27-year-old international master was awarded $1,000.

title: Treaty With Turkey
description: For the first time since World War II, the United States and Turkey are to sign a bilateral economic treaty today.

title: City's Reservoirs Rise After Large Rainfalls
description: Recent rains have raised the levels of New York City's reservoirs to 66.8 percent of capacity, city environmental officials said yesterday.

title: MCNEIL STATUS STILL UNCERTAIN
description: It was another day of watching for the Jets' Freeman McNeil, who has not played since he sprained his right ankle in the opening quarter against the Patriots on Nov. 24.

title: Early Spring, Late Winter
description: Strange as it may sound, Rob S. Coleman of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is looking forward to the first deep freeze.

title: Advance Seen in Search for Blood Substitute
description: ALMOST 18 years ago scientists achieved the bizarre feat of keeping rats alive with virtually no blood at all in their veins. Until the animals produced more natural blood of their own, the oxygen-carrying function of blood was performed by an artificial liquid, a compound of a class called perfluorocarbons.

title: Pride Air Files For Chapter 11
description: Pride Air Inc., a fledgling airline founded by former strikers at Continental Airlines, filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy law today.

title: HOSTILE OFFER BY ARGYLL FOR DISTILLERS
description: In the largest takeover bid in British history, the Argyll Group offered $2.74 billion today for the Distillers Company, the world's leading maker of Scotch whisky, including the Johnnie Walker and Dewar's brands.

title: Managua Muzzles Human Rights Watchdog
description: To the Editor:

title: PRATT & WHITNEY STRIKE MAY WIDEN
description: Union machinists, who struck three of the four factories of Pratt & Whitney today, scheduled a new vote for Wednesday on extending the strike to the company's fourth and largest plant, here in East Hartford.

title: New Laws Hobble Spread of Space Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: TECHNOLOGY FOR COMMUNICAIONS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $230,000 for the quarter and $263,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $1,255,000 for the quarter and $1,529,000 for the year.

title: Children of Teen-Agers Need Legal Protection From Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXACO BID FOR DELAY IS REJECTED
description: A Texas judge yesterday denied the request by Texaco Inc. for a one-week delay in the hearing scheduled for Thursday to review the jury verdict that Texaco must pay the Pennzoil Company $10.53 billion.

title: New Executive At McCall
description: After a four-month search for a No. 2 man, Raymond Eyes, president and publisher of the McCall Publishing Company, has landed Robert J. Krefting, the 41-year-old former president of CBS Publications.

title: MURPHY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,339,001 and a gain of $3,125,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $1,714,571 and a gain of $1,082,627 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: 10-Year-Old Is Found Hiding in Closed Bank
description: Police officers and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, responding to a burglar alarm late Sunday night, found a 10-year-old boy hiding in the false ceiling of a closed Chemical Bank branch in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, authorities said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE letters reprinted in ''Public Philosopher'' represent a relatively small sampling of the 20,000 or so that Walter Lippmann is estimated to have written in the course of his long career. They add up to an impressively substantial volume, even so; and if they are almost exclusively limited to comment on politics and public affairs, John Morton Blum - who has performed his editorial duties with great skill - assures us that Lippmann's more intimate correspondence was of little interest to outsiders: he wasn't given to introspection when he wrote his letters, nor did he have one eye on posterity.

title: MCFARLANE REPORTED SET TO QUIT AS THE NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER
description: Speculation mounted today about the status of Robert C. McFarlane as a ranking White House official predicted that the President's national security adviser would resign shortly as a result of increased strains with Donald T. Regan, the chief of staff.

title: Norstar Bank Fills Top Management Jobs
description: The Norstar Bank of upstate New York, the rapidly expanding principal subsidiary of Norstar Bancorp Inc., yesterday announced two top management appointments.

title: TONE CHANGING FOR TEXAS BOOKS
description: Texas has long been the bete noire of textbook publishers. The influence religious fundamentalists here have exerted on content has caused teachers nationally to complain that publishers soft-pedal their treatment of evolution and other topics to sell their books in Texas, which has more public school children than any state except California.

title: SOVIET-BLOC LOANS SPLIT THE CABINET
description: President Reagan's Cabinet is divided over a legislative proposal that would make it easier for the President to stop commercial bank lending to Soviet-bloc countries.

title: Kent State Plans Memorial
description: More than 1,600 people have entered a competition, submitting designs for a memorial to the four students killed at a peace demonstration at Kent State University on May 4, 1970.
