title: Gold Coin Bill Passes
description: The House of Representatives today approved by voice vote legislation authorizing the first general-circulation gold coins in 53 years.

title: Blast Mars Opening Of European Meeting
description: The opening of a two-day summit meeting of the European Economic Community was disrupted today when a small bomb exploded less than a hundred yards from the building where the leaders are meeting. No one was hurt.

title: John Heckler Is Remarried
description: John Heckler, former husband of Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, was married Saturday to Sheryl Bills, a senior editor at the newspaper USA Today. The wedding at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., was the first for Miss Bills, who is 40 years old. Mr. Heckler, 57, is a lawyer and founder of Boston Institutional Services, a stock brokerage. The Hecklers' divorce after 32 years of marriage became final three weeks ago.

title: Keep Workplace Safety On OSHA's Shoulders
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: THE BIG APPLE CIRCUS
description: A DUSTY, antique circus wagon stops in the middle of the show's single ring, and a handful of performers step out, looking like a nomadic troupe of Picasso saltimbanques. In contrast to the hyberbolic proclamations of three-ring circuses, the Big Apple Circus is marked by its modesty and its restraint.

title: STAGE: 'EDWIN DROOD,' A MUSICAL BY HOLMES
description: IT'S easy to throw a festive party at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where the moon is full, the tickets are free and no one need rush to a cab. Holding that party in the more rarefied environment of the Imperial Theater is another matter. ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' the New York Shakespeare Festival musical of last summer, depends almost entirely on a picnic atmosphere to work its way with theatergoers. The main mystery posed by the Broadway arrival of ''Edwin Drood'' is whether the show's raucous, not to mention erratic, charms can retain their buoyancy indoors.

title: SEAHAWK OIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: THE DANCE: BUJONES IN DEBUT WITH BEJART
description: TWO guest artists, Eric Vu-An and Fernando Bujones, appeared with Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century on its closing night Sunday at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, and the results were very different.

title: The Chamber Specialists Of Queens
description: Queens musicians set what may have been a record Sunday as they bowed and plucked their way through 500 years of chamber music in seven hours.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
HEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: CALIFORNIA SUPERMARKET STRIKE DISRUPTS FOOD-BUYING HABITS
description: Southern California is so dotted with stores and laced with freeways that anyone dissatisfied with the local supermarket may easily take their business elsewhere, and many customers are now choosing discount drugstores that carry many of the same items.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 19
description: b-Net income Sales include leased departments.

title: Low Attendance Concern for N.I.T.
description: While the final figures haven't been released, preliminary indications are that the first preseason National Invitation Tournament was a bigger hit with participants than with the public. A healthy crowd of 14,225 showed up for Friday's semifinal doubleheader at Madison Square Garden as Duke edged St. John's, 71-70, and Kansas defeat Louisville, 83-78.

title: LOST CHANCES FOR GIANTS IN LAST MINUTE
description: In the final 45 seconds of Sunday's game here between the Giants and the Cleveland Browns, five things went wrong for the Giants. Coach Bill Parcells concluded today that the first four did not matter. The only one that counted, he said, was the missed field goal with 4 seconds left that allowed the Browns to win, 35-33.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART: SHOULD IT BE SCALED BACK?
description: Has the artificial heart caused such severe medical complications that it should be used only as a temporary device to keep patients alive until a human heart transplant can be arranged?

title: Heavy Mail For George Young
description: Let's see. The Jets and the Giants are both coming off losses. Freeman McNeil missed his last game with a sprained ankle and Phil Simms was hobbling with a sprained ankle at the end of Sunday's game.

title: Talking Business with Bailey of Conoco;   Optimism On Oil Outlook
description: Ralph E. Bailey, chairman and chief executive officer of Conoco Inc., sees some positive aspects in the oil industry's troubles. And looking a few years down the road, he is more confident of higher prices. With that in mind, the Du Pont subsidiary is continuing an aggressive exploration program.

title: VERDICT IN MANILA IS FAULTED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration, responding to the acquittal of Gen. Fabian C. Ver in the Aquino assassination trial in the Philippines, said in carefully worded statement today that the court decision was at variance with the findings of an independent investigation.

title: Support Urged For Debt Plan
description: Leaders of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund attempted to build support today for a plan by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker III to help debtor countries.

title: 3 IN NEWARK ARE ACCUSED OF PLOT TO SMUGGLE RADAR TUBES TO IRAN
description: United States customs agents arrested two Turkish citizens and a naturalized Canadian of Turkish origin in Newark last night on charges that they tried to buy up to $15 million worth of sensitive American military radar and other equipment with the intention of smuggling it to Iran.

title: Fay Joyce, 36, Is Dead; Ex-Reporter for Times
description: Fay S. Joyce, a former reporter for The New York Times and other newspapers, was found dead of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound yesterday at her apartment at 401 West 56th Street, the police reported. She was 36 years old.

title: TRAPPED GAS KILLS 2 IN QUEENS HOUSE
description: A retired Transit Authority worker and his wife were killed in their home in Queens yesterday by carbon monoxide gas that had accumulated from a furnace because of a blocked chimney, the police said.

title: AQUINO'S WIDOW SAYS SHE WILL RUN AGAINST MARCOS
description: Corazon Aquino declared her candidacy for President of the Philippines today, one day after a court acquitted all 26 defendants accused of involvement in the assassination two years ago of her husband, Benigno S. Aquino Jr. Saying that the country needs an ''unequivocal change'' from 20 years of rule by President Ferdinand E. Marcos, she said she was prepared to lead the opposition in elections scheduled for Feb. 7.

title: RANGERS ARE BEATEN AGAIN BY PENGUINS
description: There were changes and more experiments, but the curious spell gripping the Rangers continued last night.

title: SENATE DEBATES A BILL TO CURB POLITICAL ACTION COMMITTEES
description: The Senate began its first debate on campaign financing in eight years today with the leader of a drive to limit contributions from special interest groups urging colleagues to put conscience ahead of self-interest.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This proves that people can successfully reduce their cancer risk by quitting smoking or not taking up smoking.'' - Dr. Vincent T. DeVita Jr., director of the National Cancer Institute, on lung cancer report. [A1:1.]

title: RENT RISES AND TAX BILL: CONNECTION IS DISPUTED
description: Apartment dwellers could see a 15 percent increase in rents if Congress enacts the cutbacks in real estate tax benefits included in the House Ways and Means Committee's tax revision bill, spokesmen for landlords and builders said today.

title: Police Seek Help In Finding Officer
description: The Housing Authority police yesterday appealed to the public for help in finding a 27-year-old officer who disappeared nearly two weeks ago.

title: BROYLES'S SECRET PLAY THROWN FOR LOSS
description: Thanksgiving Weekend 1984 produced The Pass - Doug Flutie to Gerard Phelan. A year later, the same weekend has produced The Question. Blame it on the Heisman Trophy and Frank Broyles.

title: GIFTS FOR WOMEN: SENSIBLE TO SYBARITIC
description: The right holiday gift - where to start? The problem arises every year at this time, and it takes a certain amount of ingenuity - and often a certain amount of shopping - to come up with inspired solutions. Here are some suggestions, from the practical to the luxurious.

title: States Given Leeway Over U.S. on Dumps
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that states can conduct their own studies of proposed sites for nuclear waste dumps and that the Government has to pay for the tests.

title: CITY TO HALT WELFARE MAIL TO 3 HOTELS
description: Social Service officials said yesterday that they would stop mailing welfare checks to three Manhattan hotels that they said had provided scores of welfare recipients with fradulent addresses to obtain benefits.

title: Productivity Up in Quarter
description: The productivity of American business increased at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the third quarter, the Government reported today.

title: JORDAN SAYS HE IS NOW WELL AND WILL RUN FOR U.S. SENATE
description: Hamilton Jordan, the architect of the campaign that vaulted the nationally unknown Jimmy Carter into the Presidency in 1976, said today that he had sufficiently recovered from cancer to run for the United States Senate.

title: Leaving It All Behind
description: Among the perquisites being relinquished by Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, when he retires next year, is a new Capitol office with a sweeping view of the Mall, the Washington Monument and Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
Sly Williams Waived
description: The Boston Celtics have placed Sly Williams, the former Knick, on waivers. ''Sly did not fit into the Celtics' plans, and he did not fulfill the role that the Celtics had hoped he would,'' said John Volk, the Celtics' general manager.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $11,297 for the quarter and $27,630 for the 6 months.

title: NAVAL HOSPITAL TO END A PROGRAM IN CONTROVERSY OVER 2-SPECIALISTS
description: The commanding officer of the Bethesda Naval Hospital said today that he was terminating the hospital's 21-year-old training program for cardiothoracic surgeons because he no longer had anyone qualified to run it.

title: AIDES DON'T EXPECT BEGGS TO QUIT POST
description: Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that James M. Beggs, the agency's Administrator, was not expected to resign his post or relinquish any of his duties.

title: BANTAM TO PAY $250,000 FOR AMADO TRANSLATION
description: A gamble by a foreign publisher and author, who elected to have a Jorge Amado novel translated into English before selling it in the United States, paid off handsomely when Bantam Books offered $250,000 for the book. The amount in the negotiation, which was announced yesterday, is believed to be the most any American publisher has paid for the rights to publish a foreign novel in hardcover.

title: Yankees' Whitson Is Seeking Trade
description: Ed Whitson, the half of the Yankees' Baltimore brawl who hasn't lost his job, wants to leave the team. George Steinbrenner said yesterday that Whitson wants to be traded.

title: AMERICAN SURGERY CENTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $109,000 for the quarter and $451,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $21,207 from discontinued operations.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WIFE OF SAKHAROV ON A TRIP TO WEST
description: Yelena G. Bonner flew here from Moscow today at the start of a three-month trip to the West for medical treatment.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 3, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Music Series at 92d St. Y To Open With Mozart
description: A performance and discussion devoted to the works of Mozart will open a three-part music appreciation series Dec. 19 at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue.

title: AIRCRAFT MAKER SOLD TO BOEING
description: The Boeing Company, the world's largest commercial aircraft manufacturer, will purchase de Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd., the state-owned maker of small aircraft, for $155 million (Canadian) in cash and notes, the Canadian Government announced yesterday.

title: The Shameless Verdict in Manila
description: To nobody's surprise, a court in Manila has absolved 26 Filipinos accused of murdering Benigno Aquino, including the key defendant, Gen. Fabian Ver, now renamed to his former post as chief of staff. Worthless as law, the acquittal is a political act. It suggests, unmistakably, that those who risk their necks for President Ferdinand Marcos are legally untouchable.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Irving Jacoby Is Dead at 76; Producer of Documentaries
description: Irving Jacoby, a producer of documentary films, died Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Guilford, Conn.

title: MCENROE IS FINED
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden raced past Tim Wilkison, 7-6, 6-3, 6-3, today to advance to the quarterfinals of the Australian Open tennis championships at Kooyong.

title: MTS SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reactor Unit Revived After a Malfunction
description: The Unit 1 reactor at Three Mile Island was returned to 71 percent power production today after a malfunction that shut down the plant this weekend, releasing some radioactivity.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Jury Deadlocks in Suit Over Mount St. Helens
description: A jury today dismissed three of nine negligence suits against the the Weyerhaeuser Company stemming from the eruption of the Mount St. Helens volcano, but the plaintiffs said they would seek a new trial.

title: Bound for Gulf of Troubles
description: At first glance, the voyage of the Jason, sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution, looks as if there is a chance that not all passengers will survive.

title: ISRAEL REPORTED TO AGREE U.S. CAN INTERVIEW KEY AIDE
description: Israel will permit American law enforcement officials to interview the senior Israeli counterterrorism official said to have been responsible for operating an espionage operation in Washington, Government sources said today.

title: WITH HUNGER AS THE GOAD, HONDURANS SEIZE LAND
description: The tin-roofed shack is the same coffee-brown tone as the surrounding fields because it is made mainly of mud that was scooped from the same fields and then baked hard by the sun.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch last Wednesday on the background of Jonathan Jay Pollard, who is accused of spying for Israel, quoted Henry Delfiner as saying he remembered Mr. Pollard as ''a very bright young man.'' Mr. Delfiner, an assistant professor at Tufts University, says he was describing a different Jonathan Pollard, who received an undergraduate degree from Tufts in 1982, and that he never knew Jonathan Jay Pollard.

title: A TIME OF CRISIS FOR CARTELS
description: Throughout the 1970's, the industrialized nations found themselves at the mercy of third world cartels that sent prices soaring on a half-dozen commodities, including oil, cocoa and tin. ''A Cartel That Has World by the Throat,'' is how one headline described OPEC in 1979.

title: EDWARDS TAKES THE STAND AND DENIES FRAUD CHARGES
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana today left the defendant's chair where he has sat quietly rocking through 10 weeks of trial on Federal racketeering charges and took the witness stand in his own defense.

title: $140 Million Issue Sold for Harvard
description: The Massachusetts Health and Education Facilities Authority is selling $140 million of bonds on behalf of Harvard University, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: MORE COMPANIES FINDING SPACE IN MIDTOWN SOUTH
description: Manhattan real estate brokers call the Midtown South section ''the valley,'' implying that it is something less than the mountain-tall downtown and midtown sections that flank it. But this valley has 40 million square feet of commercial space - potentially more office space than Los Angeles, Boston or Dallas have in their entire central business districts.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the deadline for banks to register their brokerage businesses with the Securities and Exchange Commission incorrectly identified Kenneth Walsh. He is general counsel for the U.S. Trust Company of New York.

title: Advertising;   Reaching The Rich in Magazine
description: THE frequent attempts and frequent failures of magazine publishers to come up with a product that will appeal to the wealthy is almost laughable. Especially when those products look so much alike - the super-glossy heavy stock paper and the articles chosen to attract the right kind of free-spending advertisers. Travel. Art. Arty collectibles. Fine cars. Cover the logotypes and you wouldn't know which magazine you were reading.

title: MALTESE REPORTED TO HAVE BARRED ROLE FOR U.S. OFFICERS IN JET RAID
description: The Maltese Government prevented a United States general and two other senior American military officers from playing any role in the Egyptian commando assault on a hijacked Egyptair jet last Sunday, a Maltese source and officials in Washington said today.

title: MIME: ZWI KANAR
description: THAT mime, which is often regarded only as a pleasant diversion, can also express deeply serious themes was demonstrated by Zwi Kanar on Sunday afternoon at the Dramatis Personae Theater, 25 East Fourth Street. Mr. Kanar is a Polish-born, French-trained mime. He is also a survivor of six concentration camps.

title: Offerings From Chicago Total $405.5 Million
description: Authorities in Chicago yesterday began offering two separate bond issues totaling $405.5 million.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
WORK BEGINS ON WORLD'S LARGEST TELESCOPE
description: ON a plateau in New Mexico's mountain country, amid tumbleweeds and sagebrush and beneath an expansive Western sky, astronomers have begun to build the world's biggest radiotelescope. Their goal is to construct an array of dih-shaped antennas stretching 5,000 miles across the United States and its territories, with the farthest outposts in Hawaii and the Virgin Islands.

title: Popular Products For Holidays
description: WHAT is ''hot'' in the computer stores this holiday shopping season? Asked which items for the home and small business market they expected to be popular, dealers at the recent Comdex trade show in Las Vegas named a wide variety of hardware and software products. Some listed products that were already selling at a rapid clip, while others named new products that, by virtue of outstanding value or features, were expected to do well.

title: WEST GERMANY ARRESTS 2 AS SPIES
description: A 62-year-old West German man and his 34-year-old son have been jailed on suspicion of espionage for East Germany, the Federal prosecutor's office said today.

title: 23 Cited for Acts of Heroism
description: Thirteen Americans and nine Canadians, including a 13-year-old girl, were honored today for heroism by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.

title: Work Begins On Virology Laboratory
description: Work began today on a $20 million laboratory for research on the world's most deadly and dangerous viruses, according to officials of the national Centers for Disease Control.

title: NODAWAY VALLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TESTAVERDE BOUNCES BACK
description: Vinny Testaverde was watching Joe Montana talk on television the other day. The subject was the odd shape of a football, and the unpredictable directions it can take. ''He said the ball is shaped kind of funny,'' Testaverde said. ''Sometimes it bounces to you and sometimes it bounces away.''

title: CARDINAL URGES CHRISTIAN UNITY
description: Johannes Cardinal Willebrands, head of the Vatican Secretariat for Christian Unity, called today for greater efforts to bring Roman Catholics and other Christians together.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago share earnings were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed Sept. 11.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Dec. 3, 1985 Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 1:09 P.M. today and set at 2:35 A.M. tomorrow.

title: KEAN TO NAME HIS TOP COUNSEL STATE ATTORNEY
description: Governor Kean announced today that he would nominate W. Cary Edwards, his chief counsel, to be Attorney General when Mr. Kean's second term begins Jan. 21.

title: Article 198487 -- No Title
description: An armed gang of about 10 men kidnapped two Brinks employees from their homes early today, forced them to open the company's headquarters and looted an estimated $9.4 million from safes and strong boxes, the police said.

title: Topics;   Social Statistics; Unbelted
description: After New York's mandatory seatbelt law took effect a year ago, the number of riders buckling up rose to 69 percent.

title: 5 Family Members Die in Fire
description: Five family members died early today when fire spread through their house here.

title: People Cuts Fares to West
description: People Express Airlines Inc. said that it would reduce its fares between Newark and Los Angeles to $99, from the previous fare of $199 during peak hours and $149 during off-peak periods, effective today.

title: FRANZ PICK
description: Franz Pick, an international currency analyst, died of a brain tumor Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CARIBBEAN BEAT Monty Alexander's piano playing is exhilarating, uplifting, extremely rhythmical and sometimes electrifying. Reviewers have attributed this to his assertive style and his blending of Jamaican music, which he absorbed in his youth, with American jazz. He has performed in groups with musical luminaries like Milt Jackson, Ray Brown and Herb Ellis, and he turns up in all sorts of jazz combinations. And tonight his group opens at Carlos 1 (982-3260) billed as Monty Alexander and His Caribbean Band.

title: Tacoma Utility's $125.2 Million Sale
description: The Tacoma (Wash.) Department of Public Utilities Light Division is offering $125.2 million of revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: THATCHER GOVERNMENT UPSET OVER A CRITICAL CHURCH REPORT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government appeared today to have been sharply stung by a Church of England report that concluded that policies of the Conservative Government had contributed to ''severe and increasing deprivation'' in Britain's inner cities.

title: Pakistan Imposes a Curfew After Bludgeonings Spur Riot
description: Pakistani troops today imposed a night curfew in slum areas of Karachi after several thousand people rioted over the failure of the police to catch a group of mysterious killers who smash their victims' skulls with blunt objects.

title: MILITARY CONTRACTOR'S ROCKY RELATIONS WITH U.S.
description: The indictments yesterday of present or former executives of the General Dynamics Corporation are the latest in a series of similar problems for the nation's third-largest military contractor.

title: He Is A Risk
description: In a short-sighted bid to give the Soviet Union a black eye and win hosannas from conservative supporters, the Reagan Administration just might mess up one of its few remaining chances to effect positive change in Southern Africa.

title: Top Five Cities in U.S. By 2000 Are Projected
description: Los Angeles will grow to be the nation's most populous metropolitan area by the turn of the century, topping New York, while San Francisco will surpass the rest of the nation in personal income, new Government projections show.

title: Team Names Coach
description: David McWilliams, who turned the University of Texas defense into one of the most respected in the nation, was named the 11th head coach at Texas Tech. He replaced the popular Jerry Moore, who was dismissed two weeks ago. McWilliams is the fifth Texas Tech coach since 1970 and a protege of the former Longhorn coach, Darrell Royal. . . . Although the Oklahoma State football coach, Pat Jones, says he will meet this week with University of Pittsburgh officials to discuss the vacant coaching job there, Pitt representatives are staying mum on the issue. . . . The contract of Johnny Majors, the Tennessee coach, has been extended through 1991, ending rumors that Majors could return to Pitt.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bankeast Corp., Manchester, N.H., completed acquisition of First Citizens National Bank, Newport, N.H.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Net income

title: ABORTED JERSEY BANK ROBBERY IS TREATED AS A HOSTAGE CASE
description: Two gunmen broke into a small bank before it opened here this morning and terrorized four employees for about 10 minutes before shattering a ground-floor window and fleeing empty-handed, authorities said.

title: FILIPINO CALLS RULING 'BIG LIE'
description: A woman who testified in a recent trial in the Philippines that she saw Benigno S. Aquino Jr. shot by a man in uniform repeated her charge at a news conference in New York yesterday and said she had been threatened and offered bribes to keep her from telling her story.

title: CONVEST ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After provisions of $1,970,000 for the quarter and $8,127,000 for the 9 months for depreciation, depletion and amortization of oil and gas properties. c-Net loss d-After provisions of $6,184,000 for the quarter and $10,929,000 for the 9 months for depreciation, depletion and amortization of oil and gas properties. The share earnings for the latest quarter represent units. The results of operations for the 3 months ended Sept. 30, 1985, covers the period from the commencement of partnership operations on July 20.

title: CONGRESS STREET PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Comparable results for the full previous fiscal year are not available because the company was formed in March 1984.

title: Dunes Unit Rejects Golden Nugget Bid
description: The Dunes Hotels and Casinos Inc. said its wholly owned operating subsidy, the M and R Investment Company, had declined an unsolicited bid from Golden Nugget Inc., but said it was willing to open negotiations.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF MEETS WITH SENATE CRITIC
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, met today with Senator Jesse Helms, one of several conservative senators who have been accusing the C.I.A. of a possible ''pro-Soviet bias.''

title: U.S. Group's Study Asks Increase in Aid to Africa
description: A group of foreign policy specialists issued a set of proposals today for dealing with Africa's long-term economic problems. The plan calls for the United States to provide $3 billion a year in development funds.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch in some editions yesterday on United States acknowledgement that three American military men had traveled to Malta with the Egyptian commandos who stormed a hijacked airliner incorrectly identified the senior American officer. He is Maj. Gen. Robert Dudley Wiegand, who oversees United States military programs in Egypt.

title: MICHIGAN TROUNCES TENNESSEE, 87-52
description: Glen Rice, one of the nation's top freshmen, scored 10 points during a 27-10 first-half surge tonight that carried Michigan to an 87-52 victory over Tennessee.

title: Rams' Receiver Found
description: The wide receiver Bobby Duckworth of the Rams, missing since last Friday, has turned up in San Diego, according to his agent. The Rams had been unable to account for Duckworth, who didn't play in Sunday's loss to New Orleans. Jim Steiner, Duckworth's agent, said: ''It's an off-the-field problem that needs to be taken care of.''

title: American Honda Increases Prices
description: The American Honda Motor Company said that it was increasing the price of its 1986 automobiles by 4 percent, or an average of $403 a car, as a result of the falling value of the dollar.

title: REAGAN CAUTIONS ON EXCESSIVE SUMMIT HOPES
description: President Reagan said here today that his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev had opened the door to improved United States-Soviet relations by a crack, but not fully ajar.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Electronics Association, a trade group with headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., has named J.R. Iverson president and chief executive officer, succeeding E.E. Ferrey.

title: Making It
description: The extent to which this season's biggest pro football phenomenon has pierced the American consciousness is such that he now gets billing in a cartoon in The New Yorker. In the Dec. 2 issue, a child is seated between his parents at the dinner table, wearing a football jersey with No. 72 and glaring at the food on his plate. His mother is pointing at it and saying, ''I read that the Refrigerator eats tons of ratatouille.''

title: Harvard, I.B.M. In Joint Project
description: The Harvard Business School and the International Business Machines Corporation announced a four-year joint project to train scholars in information management.

title: SOME PARADOXES ON WHAT TO DO ABOUT ANGOLA
description: More than 100 House members sent President Reagan a letter last week urging him to continue his current policy of withholding overt aid for rebels battling the Government of Angola. Paradoxically, the letter writers are primarily liberal Democrats who often dissent from the Administration's foreign policy.

title: Life Imitates Art
description: The British actor Ian McKellan discloses how he gets his inspiration for the title role in ''Coriolanus'': ''Coriolanus was a great athlete who fought battles in public but hated the crowd who came to watch him and who felt superior to the people who provided him with stardom. I believe in Coriolanus because John McEnroe exists.''

title: FROM NAVY TO SPACE AGENCY, BEGGS HAS WORN MANY HATS
description: James Montgomery Beggs, an honor graduate of the United States Naval Academy who advanced from submarine service in the late 1940's to head the national space program in 1981, has long shuttled between Government and private industry.

title: Fraud Inquiry At Lloyd's
description: Britain's judicial authorities said today that they were investigating allegations of fraud at two Lloyd's of London insurance syndicates.

title: Chemistry Is Losing Its Identity
description: IS the science of chemistry fading away?

title: MOLECULE IS SHAPED LIKE A SOCCER BALL
description: CARBON atoms can be linked together in practically limitless combinations, and some chemists devote themselves to creating carbon molecules with highly unusual shapes. The latest of them, shaped like a soccer ball, has been named for the late Buckminster Fuller, developer of architectural designs based on the geodesic dome; it is called buckminsterfullerene.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL HOUSTON (NL) - Named Fred Stanley as vice president of baseball operations.

title: Yukica Sues
description: Joe Yukica, dismissed Friday as Dartmouth College football coach, has filed suit to get his job back. In his Grafton County Superior Court suit, Yukica asked that his dismissal be declared illegal, that he be allowed to complete the remaining one and a half years on his contract and that Dartmouth be restrained from hiring another coach for the 1986 season.

title: Debenture Sale By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced plans yesterday to sell $1.45 billion of new debentures Thursday at interest rates to be announced tomorrow.

title: The Real George Gipp
description: ''The Gipper would never quit until the final whistle,'' President Reagan said in a 1984 campaign speech, invoking once again the name of George Gipp, the legendary Notre Dame football player whose life he portrayed in the movie ''Knute Rockne - All American.''

title: Birch Trees Fight Back
description: Researchers in Alaska have found that the twigs of young birch trees produce in great volume a resin that makes them odious to snowshoe hares. They believe the interplay between voracious nibbling by hares and the ability of birch trees to regenerate shoots rich in the repellent may help account for the long-debated ''crashes'' of such hare populations at roughly 10-year intervals.

title: DOW DROPS BY 14.22, TO 1,457.91
description: An unexpected rise in interest rates together with normal profit taking sent the stock market to its steepest decline in nearly four months yesterday. Trading increased only moderately from Friday's post-holiday level.

title: Senator's Wife Has Surgery
description: Margaret Goldwater, wife of Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, underwent surgery Sunday for the amputation of her left leg because of circulatory problems, a spokesman said. Mrs. Goldwater, 76 years old, was in stable condition at Good Samaritan Hospital in Phoenix after the surgery.

title: STATES' BIDS TO LEAVE SOCIAL SECURITY TO BE HEARD
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Congress violated the Constitution in 1983 when it barred state and local governments from withdrawing their employees from the Social Security system.

title: Exam Is Weighed In Colombo Trial
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he was ''seriously thinking'' of ordering a pyschiatric examination of a defendant whose complaints of being sick have caused repeated delays in the racketeering trial of 11 reputed members of the Colombo crime organization.

title: Three Mezuzas in Space
description: Shirley Kagan and Brenda Bernstein of the ''In The Spirit'' gallery in New York City are disputing Representative Stephen J. Solarz's assertion that he has arranged for the first transportation of a mezuza into space. Mr. Solarz, a Brooklyn Democrat, said that, at his request, Representative Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat, agreed to take a mezuza with him on the space shuttle Dec. 18.

title: POLICE TAKE FEW FROM STREETS
description: As a record number of homeless people crowded into city shelters, the police were ordered last night to bring most of those left on the streets to shelters or hospitals.

title: Careers;   Guidelines On Starting A Business
description: SOME 600,000 people a year start businesses in the United States.

title: TOP NASA OFFICIAL INDICTED IN FRAUD ON WEAPONS COSTS
description: The Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was indicted today on charges of defrauding the Army on a weapons contract when he worked for General Dynamics.

title: A Critical Report on Asbestos Suits
description: A research group called yesterday for the creation of a national commission to propose overhauling the way the nation's judicial system deals with mass-injury claims from asbestos and other toxic substances.

title: MARINO STARS AS DOLPHINS STOP BEARS' STREAK AT 12
description: The Chicago Bears' quest for an undefeated season came to a resounding end tonight as the Miami Dolphins soundly beat them, 38-24.

title: Hard Disk on a Card Is a Marvel
description: BY now I have become a true hard disk devotee. A computer equipped with only floppies seems slow and cumbersome. Even having to load the disk operating system, or DOS, each time I power up, to awaken the electronic giant so that it will accept applications software such as a spreadsheet or a word-processing program, seems a real bother. I have become accustomed to simply switching on my hard disk system and having the computer do its own waking up exercises. After all, the computer is supposed to do the work, isn't it?

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After net LIFO charges of $145,000 for the quarter and $413,000 for the 9 months. c-After net LIFO charges of $134,000 for the quarter and $422,000 for the 9 months.

title: Knicks to Shuffle Lineup for Nuggets
description: Coach Hubie Brown of the Knicks, in an effort to get more offense from the lowest-scoring team in the National Basketball Association, has shaken up his starting lineup for tonight's game against the high-scoring Denver Nuggets at the Garden.

title: CYBER DIGITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are for the second quarter ended Sept. 30, 1985. Results for the current 6 months and the year-ago second quarter and 6 months are not available because the company went public in April 1984 and was still in the development stage in the first quarter of the latest fiscal year.

title: GRAY COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOREAN STUDENTS SEIZE U.S. OFFICE
description: Students armed with gasoline bombs took over an American office in the South Korean city of Kwangju today and held it for nine hours.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Plunge
description: Treasury bond prices fell sharply yesterday as traders were buffeted by selling from institutional portfolios and dismayed by reports that Congressional leaders were having a hard time agreeing on a proposal to reduce Federal budget deficits in future years.

title: 'ROCKY IV' A BIG SELLER AT BOX OFFICE
description: ''Rocky IV'' delivered a technical knockout at the nation's movie theaters over the Thanksgiving weekend. With ticket sales of $31,770,105 during the five-day period, ''Rocky IV'' easily surpassed last winter's blockbuster, ''Beverly Hills Cop,'' for the largest nonsummer opening in movie history.

title: Sending Team To Antarctica
description: GREENPEACE, the international organization of environmentalists, is sending an expedition to Antarctica. The purpose is partly to dramatize its effort to have that continent designated ''a world park for all humanity.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1985
description: International When Anne Henderson-Pollard was arrested last month, she was planning to offer the Chinese a secret document that describes in detail what American intelligence knows about Peking's espionage activities in this country, prosecutors charged. In a 23-page document, prosecutors contended that Mrs. Pollard was far more deeply involved in the espionage activities of her husband, Jonathan Jay Pollard, than previously indicated. [Page A1, Column 5.]

title: U.S. RULES OUT NEW NICARAGUA TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States had no intention of resuming direct negotiations with Nicaragua in the context of the peace initiative by Panama, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela.

title: CONOLOG CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
Of Wasps and New York
description: WHITE Anglo-Saxon Protestants invented America. They tamed the wilderness, built its steel mills, produced its assembly lines, founded its colleges, governed its people, grew and harvested its wheat, baked its apple pie, waved its flag, praised the Lord and passed the ammunition, and they still run most of its provinces. But they no longer dominate New York.

title: Bridge: Sometimes, Sure Winner Doesn't Need to Be Played
description: ''To travel hopefully,'' Robert Louis Stevenson declared, ''is a better thing than to arrive.'' This is seldom true in bridge, but there are some paradoxical situations in which the arrival can be distinctly unsatisfactory.

title: Topics;   Social Statistics; Bride Pride
description: The Sunday wedding and engagement announcements in The Times provide, over the years, a kind of social archeology; and the recent strata contain a dramatic showing about wives and work.

title: EDUCATING THE HANDICAPPED: A DECADE OF CHANGE
description: John J. McNeil, 15 years old, is legally blind and uses a wheelchair because of multiple handicaps that in another era would have kept children like him out of public school.

title: MILLER TELLS OF DEFICIT LIMIT IN REAGAN '87 BUDGET
description: President Reagan plans to propose a 1987 budget with a ''maximum'' deficit of $144 billion, President Reagan's budget director, James C. Miller 3d, said today. The figure is the same as the target required by the Senate's Gramm-Rudman-Hollings bill, now being debated in Congress, that would require a balanced budget by 1991.

title: A SUPER BOWL PAUSE FOR...THE FANS
description: Television screens will go dark for one minute during the Super Bowl pregame show Jan. 26 to allow football fans to make a run for the refrigerator or bathroom without missing any of the program, NBC Sports announced yesterday.

title: CHILD WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: The year-earlier results are pro forma.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Denver Nuggets, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. The Knicks did not stop off in Denver when they made a trip to the Coast earlier in the season, so this is the first meeting with the team that was first in the Midwest Division last season. The Knicks and the Nuggets split last season's games, each winning on its home court. Alex English of the Nuggets had 54 points in a game this season against Houston and has been averaging over 30 points a game. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.). Colleges: Fairleigh Dickinson at Maryland; Wagner at St. John's, 8 P.M. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 8 P.M.); Columbia at N.Y.U., 8:15 P.M. (Television -MSG, 10 P.M., tape. Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 8 P.M.); Seton Hall at Princeton (Radio - WSOU-FM, 89.5; 7:30 P.M.); Fairfield at Brown, 7:30 P.M.; Fordham at Hartford (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7:30 P.M.); Iona at Hofstra, 7:30 (Radio - WFAS-FM, 103.9; 7:30 P.M.); Medgar Evers at Baruch, 8 P.M. Boxing Tim Williams vs. Thomas (Mad Dog) Smith, at Atlantic City, Tropicana Hotel and Casino, middleweights, 10 rounds. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. Williams, the former Marine Corps champion from San Diego, has jumped off to a sensational start knocking out his first nine professional opponents. Smith, however, could provide some stiff competition. He is 15-2 with eight knockouts, but his second pro defeat was a six-round decision to Frank Tate, the Olympic gold medalist.

title: RECITAL: MIRIAM FRIED, VIOLIN
description: THE Bach sonatas and partitas for violin solo stand as an admonishment to the monument-builders of music who have come after him. With one stringed instrument, Bach creates -often by implication alone - a world of size, strength, breadth and depth that the instrumental armies of Berlioz or Mahler come nowhere near matching.

title: GRAPE GROWERS HOPING JUICE OFFSETS WINE SLUMP
description: At this time of year, as the winds off the Finger Lakes blow more briskly, Beverly and Monty Stamp are usually pruning row upon row of grape vines.

title: Gen. Heinz Hoffmann, Builder of Berlin Wall
description: Gen. Heinz Hoffmann, longtime Defense Minister of East Germany who in the 1960's was in charge of building the Berlin wall, died of heart failure today, the East German press agency reported.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Wisconsin Electric
description: The Wisconsin Electric Power Company said it would initiate a $600 million, six-year project to convert its Oak Creek Power plant to clean-coal technology in order to cut the emission of sulfur dioxide, from which acid rain is formed. It said the program called for a 50 percent reduction in emissions by 1993 despite a 64 percent increase in the generation of electricity. It said it would submit its plans to the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin for approval.

title: Blacks in Plains, Ga. Threaten Districting Suit
description: Blacks here in former President Carter's hometown won only two of three City Council seats in today's municipal election. Black leaders here had threatened to file a Federal lawsuit seeking to replace at-large elections with district voting if their candidates did not win all threeseats.

title: Trainer Suspended
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has suspended an Aqueduct trainer, Gasper Moschera, for 30 calendar days for failure to file the required certificate stipulating that certain of his stable help are covered by Workmen's Compensation insurance.

title: TOP BRASS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 3 More Markets For Sears Card
description: The credit card subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that it would introduce its Discover credit card in the Denver, Milwaukee and Albany-Schenectady-Troy areas on Dec. 29.

title: Rumasa Case Jailing Upheld
description: A Madrid court today upheld the imprisonment of Jose Maria Ruiz-Mateos in connection with the near-collapse of the Rumasa Group, Spain's largest private holding company, court officials said.

title: 3,000 IN A PROTEST AT BHOPAL PLANT
description: More than 3,000 people waving torches and shouting, ''Down with the killer!'' demonstrated tonight outside the Bhopal plant where a leak of deadly gas a year ago created the world's worst industrial accident.

title: The Joy of Teaching Writing
description: IT might have been called ''The Joy of Writing,'' or ''The Joy of Teaching.'' The new book by Lucy McCormick Calkins is all of that, even though it is more prosaically titled ''The Art of Teaching Writing'' (Heinemann Educational Books, $16).

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (MERIDIAN,FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A 'Star Wars' Cover-Up
description: The hyper-selling of ''Star Wars'' has gone far beyond the childish crayola spot aimed at the general public on TV, beyond the vague claim made to businessmen and allies by the program director, Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, of progress at an ''incredible pace.'' It has gone to the point of covering up scientific failure in a way that endangers the honesty of research.

title: Fond Farewell For a Coach
description: ''I guess it just goes back to the old adage. Nice guys do finish last.''

title: ENERGY CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HISTORY OF A TROUBLED GUN
description: The Sergeant York antiaircraft gun has often been cited by military critics as the best example of how not to buy weapons.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Special Session Set By Evening News
description: The president and directors of the Evening News Association have recommended that shareholders approve the proposed takeover by the Gannett Company at a special meeting Dec. 20. The special meeting was included in a proxy statement mailed to shareholders by Peter B. Clark, Evening News Association president and publisher of The Detroit News.

title: Man and Wife Killed as Plane Crashes in Jersey Sanctuary
description: A man and his wife were killed when a private plane on its way here from Sarasota, Fla., crashed in a state nature preserve, authorities said.

title: 2d Guilty Plea By Parr Head
description: Gregory Herbert, the 39-year-old president of the now-defunct Parr Securities Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to felony charges before Justice Felice Shea in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, the state's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, said yesterday. He said he would recommend a prison sentence.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Willie McCovey, who hit 521 home runs in 22 major-league seasons, and Minnie Minoso, who played in five decades, are among 14 first-year condidates for election to baseball's Hall of Fame. Results of the voting will be announced next month. . . . Fred Stanley, who played for the world champion Yankees during the 1977-78 seasons, was named vice president for baseball operations for the Houston Astros. . . . The Ohio boxing commission said yesterday it would review a request by Bethany Ann Torres for a professional license. The request by the 18-year-old, 125-pound featherweight is the first by a woman. . . . Alberto Juantorena of Cuba, winner of the gold medals in the 400 and 800 meters in the 1976 Olympics in Montreal, will be honored during the convention in Houston this week of The Athletics Congress.

title: He'll Oust Marxists
description: Jonas Savimbi helped liberate Angola from Portuguese colonialism in 1975. Now he's fighting to free Angola from Soviet- and Cuban-backed forces that seized the Government in the vacuum left by Portugal's withdrawal. America has a duty to assist the his struggle for Angolan freedom and independence.

title: LUNG CANCER IN WHITE MEN DECLINES IN U.S.
description: For the first time in at least 50 years, the incidence of lung cancer has dropped significantly for white men in the United States, the National Cancer Institute reported today.

title: Alexander's Posts a Loss
description: Alexander's Inc., one of the New York area's largest retailers, reported yesterday a loss of $874,000 in the first fiscal quarter ended October 19, against net income of $284,000, or 6 cents a share, in the same period last year. Sales declined 5.5 percent, to $108.7 million from $115 million.

title: DEVON RESOURCE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REVLON INC. AGREES TO PAY FORSTMANN
description: Forstmann Little & Company, the New York investment firm, said yesterday that Revlon Inc. would pay it $20 million in cash to settle a dispute arising from Forstmann's losing battle with Pantry Pride Inc. to take over the cosmetics and health care company.

title: Irish Police Chief Meets Counterpart From North
description: The police chiefs of Ireland and Northern Ireland met today for the first time in nearly three years to discuss security cooperation. It was the first such step taken under a British-Irish agreement last month on cooperation in the North.

title: Don't Meddle With Habeus Corpus
description: The ancient writ of habeas corpus, dating back to the Magna Carta as a means of challenging arbitrary imprisonment, is being challenged. Any reduction in its efficacy bodes ill.

title: Time to Tax Sales by Mail
description: People who shop from mail-order catalogues avoid about $1 billion a year in sales taxes. Anyone who lives in the 45 states and 7,000 localities that levy such taxes is supposed to pay them on almost every purchase, no matter where the seller is located. But a 1967 Supreme Court decision thwarts most collections across state boundaries. Federal legislation to overcome this barrier would obviously intrude on the states' independence, but it would do a lot for fairness.

title: AUSTRIA SETS UP SYSTEM TO YIELD NAZI-HELD ART
description: The Austrian Government yesterday released a list of more than 8,000 works of art, books, coins and medals that were confiscated from Jews by the Nazis during World War II, and announced the details of a process for returning the works to their owners and rightful heirs.

title: HOUSE G.O.P.'S OWN TAX PLAN
description: House Republican tax writers put the finishing touches on a legislative package today that would be more favorable to business than the tax measure the House Ways and Means Committee completed drafting last month.

title: Key Officer Resigns Two Posts at Norlin
description: The Norlin Corporation, the musical instrument and financial printing company that has been plagued with financial problems lately, said yesterday that Matthew A. Baxter had resigned as president and chief operating officer.

title: CUOMO EXPECTING NO MOVE TO SAVE 90 CENT TRANSIT FARE
description: Governor Cuomo and key Albany aides said yesterday that they did not foresee legislative action to save New York City's 90-cent subway and bus fare, making an increase to $1 on Jan. 1 a strong likelihood.

title: Oil Company Admits Fraud
description: A businessman who admitted today that his company had cheated hundreds of customers during home heating oil deliveries was ordered to make restitution of $50,000. The defendant, Edward Cohen of 8 John Street, Port Jefferson Station, pleaded guilty under a plea-bargaining agreement in State Supreme Court in Hauppauge to criminal possession of stolen property. Prosecutors said trucks from his concern, the E. C. C. Amber Oil Company in Copiague, had valves that fed some of the heating oil back into the trucks after meters registered delivery.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Conrail Urges Delay of Sale
description: Officials of the Consolidated Rail Corporation urged senators today to delay action on the proposed sale of the Government-owned railroad to the Norfolk Southern Corporation until the Justice Department finishes an antitrust analysis of the merger.

title: FOLK: GUTHRIE AND SEEGER
description: ''TWENTY years ago at this exact hour, I had just returned from picking up a pile of garbage,'' Arlo Guthrie recalled on Friday onstage at Carnegie Hall. ''Who knows? If I hadn't written a song about that garbage, I might not be here with you tonight.''

title: MUSIC: TENOR AND LUTANIST
description: SOMETIMES the simplest, sparest concerts are the most rewarding. On Sunday night, the tenor Nigel Rogers and the lutanist and guitarist Paul O'Dette shared the stage at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street), playing and singing works by John Dowland, Henry Purcell and Mauro Giuliani, among others, with sensitivity, intelligence and a warm musicality.

title: TWO BUILDINGS IN INWOOD STILL WITHOUT WATER
description: Water was restored to most of the Inwood section of Upper Manhattan yesterday, but at twin eight-story apartment buildings on West 217th Street, the dry spell continued.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1985
description: Markets

title: Guide for Young People
description: Need a job? A dentist? Drug counseling? Legal services?

title: Moderate Palestinian Is Slain in West Bank
description: A celebrated West Bank lawyer who advocated creation of a Palestinian state coexisting in peace with Israel was found stabbed to death tonight near his home in Ramallah, the Israeli television said.

title: Maj. Gen. William Hamilton, Ex-Artillery Commander, Dies
description: Maj. Gen. William Murray Hamilton, commanding general of the Eastern Antiaircraft Artillery Command during the Korean War, died of Parkinson's disease Sunday in the Barnwell Nursing Home, Valatie, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived in Old Chatham, N.Y.

title: Merchant Shoots Robbery Suspects
description: A lower Manhattan jewelry-store owner shot at least two of three holdup men last night, both of whom were later apprehended, the police reported.

title: RUMANIA WARNED OVER RIGHTS ISSUE
description: The Reagan Administration intends to warn Rumania that it is in jeopardy of losing its benefits in trade with the United States if it does not improve its human rights record, State Department officials said today.

title: A National Anniversary
description: On Dec. 7, 1835, with the opening of the 24th Congress as its competition, the National Theater raised its first curtain at a site on E Street facing Pennsylvania Avenue. The opening production was ''Man of the World,'' described as a pseudo-Restoration comedy featuring Scottish dialect.

title: In Salary, Koch Is Now Second to One
description: Detroit may be the ''pits'' to Mayor Koch, but it is going to pay its Mayor more than the Big Apple does.

title: SCIENTIST ASSAILS 'STAR WARS' PLAN
description: A scientist who resigned in protest from a Pentagon advisory group on the President's space-based missile defense program told a Congressional committee today that the United States could not have confidence that the computer software for a ''Star Wars'' defense would ever work.

title: Puerto Rico Sewer Unit Sets $320 Million Sale
description: The Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority is offering $320 million of revenue and refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9 percent for securities due in 2009 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Uganda Frees Ex-Amin Aide
description: Bob Astles, once an aide to the dictator Idi Amin, was freed today after six years in prison. Mr. Astles, a Briton who came to Uganda in 1949, was head of Mr. Amin's anti-corruption squad before the regime was deposed in 1979. He also held Ugandan citizenship but renounced it to obtain his release.

title: 2d-Largest Stock Issue
description: Bankers for the British communications company Cable and Wireless P.L.C. disclosed terms today for the second-largest stock flotation ever, with shares to be sold in Japan and Canada as well as Britain. The bankers aim to raise $:933 million, or $1.38 billion, making it the largest sale next to the flotation of a stake in British Telecom by the British Government last November for $:4 billion, or $5.9 billion. The merchant bankers Kleinwort Benson said the offer of 159 million shares would close Dec. 11.

title: Comparable Worth Is Rooted in U.S. History
description: To the Editor:

title: Hutton's Role In Takeovers
description: FOLKS on Wall Street who follow the ebb and flow of takeover rumors think a few things are a cinch to happen: General Electric will eventually use its sizable cash hoard to make an acquisition, Sperry sooner or later will find a merger partner, Pfizer will someday succeed in buying another drug company, and rumors about these and other companies will continue unabated.

title: FLORIDA ACCEPTS DRUG PLEAS IN KENNEDY CASE
description: Nineteen months after David A. Kennedy died of a drug overdose in a $250-a-night Palm Beach hotel room, the State of Florida has closed the cases of two bellhops accused of procuring cocaine for the 28-year old son of Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Electric Revenue Bonds Offered
description: The Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., is offering $125.5 million of electric revenue bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1985
description: Companies

title: HBO'S 'DOWN AND OUT'
description: ''DOWN AND OUT IN AMERICA'' is clear about its message: The system has failed, and the American dream has died. The Home Box Office documentary, directed and narrated by Lee Grant, tolerates no ambiguities, contradictions or complexities. It has seen the enemy, and it is us.

title: BILLS TRYING A SCRAMBLER
description: The last time Bruce Mathison faced the Jets, he now admits, he didn't know what he was doing.

title: THOUSANDS COMPLAIN TO CITY ON HEATING
description: Thousands of complaints about cold radiators and boilers were called in yesterday to the city's office for heat complaints as wintry winds blew in the coldest day of the season so far.

title: RANGEL RUNNING HARD TO BE DEMOCRATIC HOUSE WHIP
description: Morris Biller, the president of the American Postal Workers Union, stood before about 80 of his labor colleagues at a lunch today to present his union's first First-Class Leadership Award - an honor Mr. Biller invented specifically so he could bestow it on Representative Charles B. Rangel.

title: WITNESS DENIES UNION CHIEF WAS PAID FOR TEAMSTER LOAN
description: The reputed leader of organized crime in Cleveland testified Monday that he never told Government agents that Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, had received stolen gambling profits from casinos in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: The Bureaucracy;   Aid and Comfort For Whistleblowers
description: ''There's a definite whistleblower's community out there - and it's growing,'' said Ann Martino, who answers the local hot line (546-1200) in the spartan Capitol Hill office of the Coalition to Stop Government Waste.

title: No Punting Prize
description: Oh, if only Columbia's punting game had gone as well this season as its place-kicking.

title: COMMON MARKET CHANGES GET APPROVAL
description: After two days of difficult negotiations, a meeting of European leaders agreed early today on a package of modest but significant measures designed to strengthen the Common Market.

title: Rome Must Recognize Israel
description: There is something very wrong with the dialogue between Catholics and Jews. For 20 years now, even as the relationship was formalized and deepened, the Roman Catholic Church has used every tactic to avoid the issue that matters most to world Jewry -recognition of Israel. Even last week, at the synod in Rome, as the Church again denounced anti-Semitism the word ''Israel'' was never uttered.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SKATERS' WALTZ. By Philip Norman. 331 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $15.95. ONE of the things that distinguished ''Shout!,'' Philip Norman's collective biography of the Beatles, published in 1981, was his meticulous attention to detail. In that volume, exhaustive research, served up in dense, fact-filled prose, made for an informative, lively book - a book that lent the story of the Beatles' life and times a palpable weight and thrust. Now in ''The Skaters' Waltz,'' Mr. Norman tries to use a similar approach, in a novel, to evoke the vanished world of childhood in the 1940's and 50's.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report last Friday in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page incorrectly identified Josh Darden, a possible Democratic candidate for the House of Represenatives in Virginia's Norfolk district. He is a nephew of former Gov. Colgate W. Darden Jr.

title: WITNESS SAYS FAMILY PAID PRIEST IN ALIEN CASE
description: The Government's key witness in the trial of 11 people accused of smuggling Central American aliens into the United States testified today that the family of some of the aliens gave money to one of the defendants.

title: LONG FORCE-FEEDING OF SAKHAROV IN GORKY IS DEPICTED BY U.S. KIN
description: For 207 days of the last 18 months, Andrei D. Sakharov was separated from his wife and was being fed forcibly, his nose clamped shut to force him to open his mouth, relatives said today.

title: NOTE AND BOND PRICES HIGHER
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, with all of the gains coming during late afternoon trading.

title: Laurence Lafore Dies at 68; Was Novelist and Professor
description: Laurence Lafore, professor emeritus of history at the University of Iowa, died Nov. 24 at his home in Iowa City at the age of 68. He was the author of a dozen books, including five novels, and of numerous articles and reviews.

title: New Unocal President
description: The Unocal Corporation said today that Richard J. Stegemeier had been appointed president, succeeding Fred L. Hartley, who remains chairman and chief executive. Mr. Stegemeier, 57 years old, was also named chief operating officer at a directors meeting on Monday. He had been senior vice president, corporate development. He joined Unocal in 1951 and has also served as head of the science and technology division.

title: Pilot in Fatal Collision Says He Never Saw Other Copter
description: The pilot of one of two commuter helicopters maneuvering to land at a helipad says he never saw the other craft before they collided in flight, killing one person and injuring 10 others, according to a Federal official.

title: Jaruzelski to Hold Talks With Mitterrand
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, will hold talks with President Francois Mitterrand on Wednesday, a Government spokesman said today. It would be the Polish leader's first visit to a Western head of state.

title: English Archbishop Defends Report on Cities
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury hit back today at critics of a church report on urban problems that questioned Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies.

title: 6 Killed in Sri Lanka Blast
description: Five soldiers and a civilian were killed today in an explosion of a land mine planted by separatist Tamil guerrillas, a Defense Ministry spokesman said. Three soldiers were also wounded when the mine exploded under their vehicle in eastern Trincomalee. The blast was the latest attack on security forces by the guerrillas.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: School Bond Issue By Pennsylvania
description: The Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority, the financing arm for 235 school districts throughout the state, is offering $268.4 million of school lease revenue bonds to refund $335 million of similar bonds sold in 1984.

title: Quebec Retires the Quebecois
description: In an election remarkable for its calm, Quebecers on Monday deposed a provincial government long remarkable for its view that Quebec should pull out of Canada's Confederation. The defeat of the volatile Parti Quebecois by the Liberal Party won't end the debate about separatism. But the debate has lost its menacing rancor. Canada's union has survived a severe test. And in paradoxical ways, this cycle rounds out the career of Canada's and Quebec's creative and divisive leader, Pierre Trudeau.

title: Finding on Dumping
description: The Commerce Department has made a preliminary finding that the Japanese have sold one of the highest-volume semiconductors in the American market at deep discounts - as much as 94 percent - below the cost of production.

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,020,000 on the sale of a plant.

title: ANTARCTICA TREATY NATIONS THREATEN TO BOYCOTT U.N. DEBATES
description: Delegates from countries that administer Antarctica said today that they would boycott future debates on the future of the continent unless a group of developing countries abandons what the delegates described as a confrontational approach.

title: Averting More Chemical Tragedies
description: Two thousand people were asphyxiated by the chemical that escaped a year ago from the Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, India. At the time, the obviously lax training of the Indian staff and the excellent workplace safety record of America's chemical industry suggested that no such accident was likely in the United States. Now, that comforting inference seems far too complacent.

title: LAOTIANS CLOSE THE DOORS AND HAVE A CELEBRATION
description: Laos, a country given to secrecy, celebrated its 10th anniversary of Communist rule this week.

title: G.M.A.C. Sale Of $400 Million
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation yesterday offered $400 million of medium-term notes, equally divided between the domestic market and the Euromarket.

title: Workers at Bhopal Plant Agree to Settlement
description: The Indian subsidiary of Union Carbide today settled claims by workers laid off after the poison gas leak a year ago that killed more than 2,000 people.

title: OLIVER LUCK GETS ROLE WITH OILERS
description: The Houston Oilers hope to learn Wednesday whether Warren Moon is healthy enough to start at quarterback Sunday against the Giants in the Astrodome.

title: DANCE: SUSANNE LINKE OFFERS 4 SOLOS IN BROOKLYN
description: SUSANNE LINKE, who made her New York debut last night in a program of solos, is the last of three West German choreographers the Brooklyn Academy of Music is presenting in its current ''Next Wave'' Festival.

title: Williams Endorsed
description: Dick Williams, the manager of the San Diego Padres, got a vote of confidence from the club's owner, Joan Kroc, yesterday in the wake of published reports suggesting that her son-in-law, Ballard Smith, the team's president, and the general manager, Jack McKeon, were behind a Machiavellian plot to force Williams to accept a buyout of his contract. According to The San Diego Union, Williams was so upset by the recent dismissal of his friend, Ozzie Virgil, as the Padres' third-base coach, that he decided to accept a $250,000 buyout of the last year of his contract.

title: ANTI-IMPORT BILL SENT TO PRESIDENT, VETO EXPECTED
description: The House of Representatives passed and sent to President Reagan today a bill that would restrict imports of textiles, apparel and shoes.

title: Politics by the Carton
description: New Yorkers may soon be staring across their cereal bowls and coffee cups at the smiling faces of Governor Cuomo and United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: TANGO, SI! TALENT, IN WEST 47TH ST. STUDIO
description: It's all right, officer, it's only the tango.

title: The Sergeant York's First Victim
description: The Army's Sergeant York gun, the first major weapons program to be killed in two decades, could not hit anything in life. Now it has risen from the grave and shot a surprising victim, James Beggs, the Administrator of NASA. The Justice Department indicted him on Monday for defrauding the Army while overseeing work on the Sergeant York as a vice president of General Dynamics.

title: FARM CREDIT OVERHAUL IS APPROVED BY SENATE
description: The Senate tonight approved a rescue plan for the financially strained Farm Credit System, the nation's largest agricultural lender.

title: Numbers Night
description: C. W. Post's basketball team plays at home tonight against Dowling. Post has dubbed the evening ''400 Night,'' and for good reason.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Including a gain of $8,259,000 from the sale of 20 percent of the All American Gourmet Co. to the public in September for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $36,588,000 for the quarter and $39,856,000 for the 9 months and gains from the sales of businesses of $85,270,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: GIFTS FOR CHILDREN START WITH THE STARS
description: WHATEVER vision is dancing through children's heads this holiday season, it is not likely to be sugarplums, particularly with the range of items available to tempt the imagination sweetly. They include the colorful jack-in-the-box and the unearthly delights of a telescope with a down-to-earth price. Dolls are ever popular, maybe more so if they move to music. For music alone, there are records for young audiences. A festive sweater jacket or velvet dress may enhance holiday pleasures. 1.

title: Democracy Project Facing New Criticisms
description: The National Endowment for Democracy is a quasi-governmental foundation created by the Reagan Administration in 1983 to channel millions of Federal dollars into anti-Communist ''private diplomacy.''

title: Presidential Opposition
description: President Reagan decided today to oppose a legislative proposal that would make it easier for him to stop commercial bank lending to Soviet-bloc countries, according to an Administration official. The bill would amend the Export Administration Act to give the President discretionary authority to ''monitor and control'' commercial financial transactions with the East-bloc nations. Opponents argued that such a measure would cause relations with the Soviet Union to deteriorate after the President's successful summit conference with the Soviet party leader, Mikhail A. Gorbachev.

title: Table Manners
description: Following is a sampling of letters by students at Prospect Park School No. 1 in Prospect Park, N.J., written in response to an Oct. 16 article on table manners:

title: MARKET STEADIES, WITH DOW UP 1.15
description: The stock market broke its two-day skid, but just barely yesterday, as prices rose slightly on improved volume.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: RICHARD CURTIS gets into the elevator of a midtown office building with three other men, two of whom recognize one another. ''How you doing?'' one says to the other. ''Fine. What about you?'' ''Fine, just fine.''

title: ALEXANDER'S WILL CLOSE 58TH ST. FLAGSHIP STORE
description: Alexander's Inc. said yesterday that it planned to close its flagship store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue as part of a redevelopment of the blocklong site into what is expected to be an office and condominium complex.

title: 'Jerry's Girls' Opening Postponed by Injury
description: The opening of ''Jerry's Girls,'' which had been scheduled for Sunday, has been postponed because Dorothy Loudon, one of the stars, broke several bones in her toes at a performance last Friday evening.

title: CONTROVERSY AWAITS NEW GUATEMALA PRESIDENT
description: Among all the challenges that will face Guatemala's civilian President after his inauguration next month, perhaps the most difficult and sensitive is the one posed by relatives of those who have disappeared.

title: DUTCH AFFIRM A DECISION TO DROP 2 NATO NUCLEAR COMBAT TASKS
description: The Dutch Defense Minister said today that despite opposition from other NATO members, his Government planned to stick to a decision to end its obligation to carry out two specific tasks in the event of war.

title: European Takes Post At Banner Industries
description: Jeffrey Steiner has a home in London and offices in Paris, New York and now - Cleveland.

title: INACTION BY GOVERNOR WILL RESULT IN AN INCREASE IN FARES, KOCH SAYS
description: Mayor Koch attacked Governor Cuomo in unusually strong and personal terms yesterday for failing to take action to maintain the 90-cent bus and subway fare.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CBS SELLS BOOK DIVISION TO WEST GERMAN FIRM
description: Four months after putting a ''For Sale'' sign on the general books division of Holt, Rinehart & Winston, CBS announced yesterday that it had sold the division to the Holtzbrinck Group of Stuttgart, West Germany.

title: Seoul TV Pact Delayed
description: The signing of a contract between NBC and the South Korean Olympic Organizing Committee for American television rights to the 1988 Summer Games has been postoned because the two sides have not agreed on all the details, including the amount of compensation the network would be entitled to in the event of a cancellation or major boycott.

title: FANTASY GAME TO PLAY IN ARENA
description: Space warriors clad in high-tech costumes dash in and out of alcoves firing laser guns as red and green strobe lights flash warning signals in the sky. At the same time high-pitched synthesized music roars from all sides and a white mist engulfs the area, hiding some warriors from their opponents.

title: HOME ROBBER STRIKES AGAIN
description: An intruder entered a Park Avenue apartment Monday evening, tied up the four occupants and stole $32,000 in jewelry and cash, and the police said yesterday that they believed he was the same man who has committed 14 other Manhattan robberies and burglaries since August.

title: 2 AT SYNOD DEFEND LIBERATION IDEAS
description: Some bishops from Latin America strongly defended the teachings known as liberation theology today.

title: BENEFIT FOR 'BIG BEAR' OF 50'S BRINGS BITTERSWEET REUNION
description: The Big Four rode again here Monday night.

title: ARES-SERONO INTERNATIONAL HOLDING SA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All amounts are in United States dollars.

title: Rockland Won't Pay Orange All of the Brink's Trial Costs
description: Rockland County, which has been required to pay the $5 million bill for Brink's trial costs, said today that it would not pay part of the total, $140,000, that it still owed Orange County.

title: PORTUGAL'S VINHO VERDE MAKING GAINS ABROAD
description: The Portuguese drink it with gusto, but vinho verde, possibly the first wine exported from Portugal in the 15th century, is only now beginning to find a following abroad.

title: 157 TAKEN OFF STREETS
description: New York City housed 8,084 homeless people in its shelters early yesterday, the most in decades, the authorities said.

title: 3 Held Without Bail in a Plot To Export Radar Gear to Iran
description: Three Turkish natives accused of trying to export military radar equipment to Iran were ordered held without bail today.

title: CRIME GROUP'S ACTIVITIES DETAILED BY KEY WITNESS IN GAMBINO TRIAL
description: Dominick Montiglio, a key government witness in the trial of 10 reputed members of the Gambino crime ring on charges of stealing hundreds of cars, has painted a picture in court papers of his dealings in the upper ranks of organized crime.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EXPLANATIONS On two college campuses today, experts will present their views on the potent subjects of politics and art. Uptown at City College, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. will open this season's Presidential Lecture Series with a discussion of ''The Cycles of American Politics,'' the title of his next book. These cycles are the swings from the leadership by one party to the other (and from one philosophy to another - liberal to conservative, for example) that seem to occur every 20 to 30 years. The swings may also include the masses of voters who alternate between getting worked up about politics and laying back to rejuvenate. This program will begin at noon in Room 0/201 of City College's North Academic Center, at 138th Street and Convent Avenue.

title: MARGARET STRONG DE LARRAIN, 88
description: Margaret Strong de Larrain, a philanthropist and sole surviving granddaughter of John D. Rockefeller Sr., died Monday of a heart attack in Madrid. She was 88 years old.

title: Gender Problem
description: Woman's World, which describes itself as ''the woman's weekly,'' has sent a form letter to advertising and public-relations concerns, soliciting information for one of its columns.

title: FILM: 'YOUNG SHERLOCK,' SPIELBERG PRESENTATION
description: AT the end of a winter day in mid-Victorian London, Mr. Bobster, a prosperous businessman of a certain age, makes his way through the snowy streets, trailed by a menacing figure in a huge cloak of the sort that the Grim Reaper often wears to obscure its face. Mr. Bobster feels a slight sting on his cheek but, thinking nothing of it, goes into a restaurant where he prepares to dine on a fine roast pheasant.

title: Movement by Marino Confused Bears
description: The Chicago Bears hadn't seen anything like it in some time, a quarterback who could roll out and away from the pass rush to buy time. Joe Montana had done it with huge success last season in the conference championship game and with some degree of effectiveness this season in October.

title: Toyota Is Said To Pick Site
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's leading auto maker, has tentatively chosen farmland near Georgetown, Ky., for a $500 million auto assembly plant, sources said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Named Robert Howsam Jr. president and general manager of the Denver Bears of the American Association.

title: New Digital Machine Set
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the world's second-largest computer maker, is expected to formally announce a new top-of-the-line superminicomputer today, capable of processing between six and seven million instructions per second.

title: 'HIGH SCHOOL NARC,' AN 'AFTERNOON SPECIAL'
description: THE ''Afterschool Special'' program on ABC today at 4 P.M. confronts a sensitive issue and then seems to be singularly uneasy about the underlying message. ''High School Narc'' features Michael Knight as a youthful-looking 22-year-old police officer assigned to an undercover narcotics investigation. Andy, as he is called, is sent to a high school, where he will pose as a student while trying to discover the identity of a drug supplier. Only the principal knows about the police operation.

title: Widening Judges' Role Would Be Dangerous
