description: To the Editor:

title: A Player's Coach
description: Al Paul, the athletic director at Columbia University, has asked members of the football team to elect two or three players to serve on a comittee searching for a new head coach to replace Jim Garrett, who departed under fire last week. After a meeting with more than 100 players, Paul said he wanted to reassure the team, which has not won a game in more than two years, that the university was still committed to rebuilding the program.

title: G.M. Group Buys Fiat Unit Stake
description: A division of the General Motors Corporation, as expected, has purchased a minority share of the manufacturing tools subsidiary of Fiat, the big Italian autombile company. The Chevrolet-Pontiac-Canada Group of G.M. announced that it had bought 20 percent of Comau Productivity Systems Inc., the American subsidiary of Comau S.p.A., a unit of Fiat.

title: Absentee Votes to Decide Key West Mayoral Race
description: Tony Tarracino, a bartender and anti-development candidate, held a 33-vote lead over his opponent, Tom Sawyer, a banker, after the votes were counted in today's mayoral election.

title: Seaweed Shuts Reactors
description: Seaweed churned up by a storm clogged the filters of water-intake pipes at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, forcing closing of both its reactors until the debris is cleared away, officials said today. ''An unusually severe storm dug up kelp from the sea floor,'' said Dick Davin, a spokesman for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, which operates the plant.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Six Die in Pennsylvania As Deer Season Opens
description: Five people were fatally wounded and a sixth died of an apparent heart attack as hunters braved high winds, snow and cold on the opening day of Pennsylvania's two-week deer season.

title: BELLAMY TO BE AN OFFICER AT MORGAN STANLEY CO.
description: Carol Bellamy, lawyer, public official and candidate, is starting a new career: She is going to be an investment banker.

title: Another Kennedy
description: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d isn't the only member of his family who may be serving in the House of Representatives in 1987. On the same day that Joseph was saying in Boston that he would announce his House candidacy today, Democratic sources in Maryland were reporting that his sister, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, had decided to seek the Democratic nomination in that state's Second Congressional District north of Baltimore next year.

title: 5.5% Fall in House Sales Is Sharpest Since April
description: Housing sales fell 5.5 percent in October, the third consecutive decline and the sharpest drop since April, the Government reported today.

title: CHRISTMAS WITHOUT COOKING
description: IN this most transient of cities in a transient age, Christmas does not always find entire families reunited under one roof. The logistics notwithstanding, that roof might be one of Manhattan's dearly priced rabbit warrens, in which the laws of physics conspire against any sort of stylish celebration.

title: RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New Spy Charges Due For West Coast Suspect
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy communications specialist accused of espionage, is expected to be indicted next week on additional counts of espionage, his lawyer said today.

title: ST. JOHN'S TROUNCES WAGNER BY 85-55
description: After an exceptional start against exemplary competition, St. John's began a five-game journey through decidedly weaker competition last night with an 85-55 rout of Wagner at Alumni Hall.

title: HOSPITALS FOUND TO BE ILL-PREPARED FOR TOXIC SPILLS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Many hospitals in the New York metropolitan area, and particularly in the industrial corridor of northern New Jersey, are ill-equipped to treat victims of a major chemical accident, according to a new study and interviews with medical officials.

title: MANHATTAN HOTEL EMPLOYEE HELD IN KICKBACK OF WELFARE CHECKS
description: The desk manager of a Manhattan welfare hotel was arrested late Monday night on charges that he evicted a tenant and then forced him to give back most of his public-assistance rent checks, the District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau announced yesterday.

title: EDWARDS PARRIES U.S. PROSECUTOR'S ATTACKS ON HIS INTEGRITY
description: Gov. Edwin Edwards, the vanquisher of 15 Louisiana political opponents in 31 years, today began a climactic face-to-face duel for his honor and public integrity, this time with John Volz, the United States Attorney who is prosecuting him on racketeering charges.

title: DOUBLE-JEPARDY EXCEPTION IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that two states may prosecute a person for the same criminal act without violating the constitutional prohibition against double jeopardy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1985
description: International

title: BLOOD TEST FINDS STATE TROOPER IN FATAL CRASH WAS INTOXICATED
description: Blood tests on two state troopers killed when their patrol car crashed into a truck two weeks ago found that the trooper who was driving was legally intoxicated and the other had traces of cocaine in his body, the Westchester County Medical Examiner said today.

title: WINNIE MANDELA, DEFYING PRETORIA, VOWS VENGEANCE
description: Winnie Mandela, breaking an officially imposed silence, pledged vengeance today for the blood of fallen blacks at what she said was the first mass rally she had addressed in 25 years.

title: KNICKS DEFUSE NUGGETS
description: Doug Moe, the easy-going coach of the Denver Nuggets, doesn't spend much time scouting his opponents, unlike most other coaches. But even if he did, he would not have been prepared for what he saw last night.

title: MUSIC: TRIBUTE TO STERN
description: MONDAY evening's 14th annual Carnegie Hall concert of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation served, more even than most of these events, to call attention to the close ties between America's Jewish community, musical conservatories and concert life on the one hand, and young Israeli musical talent on the other. And, since the concert was designed as a belated celebration of Isaac Stern's 65th birthday, it called special attention to his role in forging this relationship.

title: TWO MARTHA'S VINEYARDS, EAST AND WEST COAST STYLE
description: THIS is a tale of two Martha's Vineyards. One, south of Cape Cod, is sandy and bathed by benign Eastern coastal crosswinds. The other, in the Far West, flourishes where eucalyptus blooms.

title: Expensive Ignorance on Birth Control
description: That New York State's network of family-planning clinics does good work is beyond dispute. It has had much to do with the 25 percent drop in the pregnancy rate among sexually active teen-agers between 1974 and 1980 - the biggest decrease in the nation. But it's also beyond dispute that the clinics don't reach everyone who needs help. Nearly 150,000 New York women have abortions every year.

title: 8 LATIN COUNTRIES CALL FOR U.S.-NICARAGUAN TALKS
description: Eight Latin American nations began a new diplomatic effort today to persuade the Reagan Administration to resume direct negotiations with Nicaragua.

title: LULU SMITH HOWARD
description: Lulu Smith Howard, a suffragist who was one of the first women to hold a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, died Thursday.

title: The Days of Snuff and Such
description: It is no exaggeration to say that United States Senators in the 1800's were up to snuff, and to chewing tobacco, as well.

title: THE FRENCH AT TABLE, FROM CELTS TO NOW
description: THE French take themselves quite seriously in the gastronomic realm, and never more so than in ''Les Francais et la Table,'' a retrospective of eating habits and customs from the Celts to the present day that opened at the Musee National des Arts et Traditions Populaires on Nov. 20. Cutlery, ceramics, glassware, metal pieces, paintings, prints and furniture are arranged both in showcases and in room settings to illustrate the evolution of dining a la francaise.

title: OCTOBER LEADING INDICATORS UP 0.3%
description: The Government's most closely watched barometer of future economic performance rose three-tenths of 1 percent in October, the sixth consecutive monthly advance, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Solzhenitsyn and Anti-Semitism: A Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 201262 -- No Title
description: Six months ago, when Samuel and Patricia Frustaci became the parents of America's first septuplets, the ebullient father said: ''It's a neat experience. Family life is great.'' But now, with four of the children dead and the survivors and their mother facing continuing medical problems, the family has sued the doctor and clinic who helped make the births possible.

title: INDIANA TRIUMPHS OVER NOTRE DAME
description: Steve Alford matched his career high of 32 points tonight as Indiana upset Notre Dame, 82-67.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE BACK AFTER NEARLY FLAWLESS MISSION
description: The space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here today, concluding a nearly flawless weeklong mission that included the first construction project in space and three successful satellite launchings.

title: EUGENIE LEVY ROBINSON
description: Eugenie Levy Robinson, the widow of Benjamin M. Robinson, died Monday at her home on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. Mrs. Robinson, who had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease, was 75 years old. She also had a home in St. James, Barbados, and was a former resident of White Plains.

title: A QUEBECER BACK ON TOP
description: The career of Robert Bourassa, the newly elected 52-year-old Premier of Quebec, has known its peaks and valleys.

title: VOYAGER 2 ADDS YET ANOTHER MYSTERY ABOUT DISTANT URANUS
description: Scientists monitoring Voyager 2 as it approaches distant Uranus reported yesterday that the most fascinating and puzzling observation so far might be what the spacecraft was not detecting. It is not finding any evidence that the giant planet has a magnetic field.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $6,527,463.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robin Roberts, who won 286 games in a 19-year major league career, including 234 in 14 seasons with the Philadelphia Phillies, has joined the Phillies as a minor league instructor. . . . According to Emanuel Steward, who is training Milton McCrory for Friday night's welterweight title bout against Don Curry, if McCrory wins, he would make one title defense before moving up to the junior-middleweight division, unless he got a fight with Sugar Ray Leonard. The retired Leonard, who has not indicated that his retirement is over, has been working with Shawn O'Sullivan of Canada, the 1984 Olympic silver medalist.

title: PPG Industries Sells Note Issues
description: PPG Industries is offering $100 million of 9 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at 99.58 to yield 9.60 percent, and $75 million of 10 1/8 percent notes due in 1995 at 99 1/2 to yield 10.205 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Judge Stays Execution Of a Murderer in Texas
description: A Federal District judge today blocked the execution of a condemned killer just 10 hours before he was to die by injection for murdering a jeweler in Beaumont, Tex.

title: Pratt & Whitney Union To Hold 2d Strike Vote
description: A Federal judge today cleared the way for a second strike vote at Pratt & Whitney's largest plant, setting the stage for the first statewide strike in 25 years against the world's largest jet engine maker.

title: WITH LATKES, POTATOES ARE JUST A POINT OF DEPARTURE
description: THE same restless taste that requires the surprise of pasta made with tomato or carrot dough, green peppercorn mustard and Brie flavored with mushrooms seems to be influencing some hallowed holiday foods. Nouvelle blue-corn latkes have yet to make their debut, but there are recipes for a number of variations on the traditional potato latke, the Eastern European Hanukkah pancake, that call for spinach, cheese, carrots and nuts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is our country. In the same way as you have had to bury our children today, so shall the blood of these heroes we buried today be avenged.''

title: Iran and Iraq Assaults
description: The official Iraqi News Agency said today that Iraqi warplanes had carried out a successful air raid on a naval target near the Iranian coast and that Iraqi troops had repelled an Iranian ground assault. The Teheran radio, meanwhile, said Iranian troops killed or wounded more than 100 Iraqi soldiers Monday night in a five-hour offensive along the central border.

title: Donald J. Trump: Stadium Builder
description: His plan to build the world's tallest building is yesterday's news. Today, Donald J. Trump is more concerned with sports stadiums -specifically the one the city and the state want built next to Shea Stadium in Flushing, Queens.

title: TAX PANEL APPROVES BILL, 28-8
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted, 28 to 8, today to adopt legislation that would make fundamental changes in the Federal income tax system.

title: HIGH BEEF PRICES EXPECTED TO REMAIN
description: BEEF prices have turned upward across the country, counter to the direction of food prices in general nationwide, as reported on Nov. 23.

title: American Drops Effort To Divorce Soviet Wife
description: An American who filed recently for divorce from his Soviet wife asked a court today to drop the proceedings, citing the expense and unwanted attention that the case brought him.

title: Mideast Diplomacy Can't Ignore Assad
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has once again maneuvered himself into the center of the Middle East peace equation and stands by ready to exercise his well-practiced veto powers. This is an unpleasant fact, but the other powers seeking peace ignore it at their own peril.

title: JOSEPH KENNEDY TO DECLARE FOR SEAT O'NEILL IS LEAVING
description: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d told other candidates today that he would announce his candidacy Wednesday for the Congressional seat to be vacated next year by Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House.

title: FERTILITY RATE DROPS EXCEPT FOR WOMEN 30 TO 34 YEARS OLD
description: The fertility rate in the United States dropped last year to the lowest level since the late 1970's, but the rate increased for women 30 to 34 years old, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: L.I. CENTER HONORS 3 FAMOUS LOCALS
description: Willem de Kooning has drawn inspiration for his paintings from Long Island's South Fork for more than 30 years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Amca International Corp., Hanover, N.H., said its Menck operating unit, Ellerau, West Germany, had received a contract to provide hydraulic offshore pile-driving hammers and related equipment from Micoperi Offshore S.p.A., Milan, Italy, for about $20 million.

title: Solzhenitsyn and Anti-Semitism: A Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Victory Claimed in War On Coast 'Killer Bees'
description: The first invasion of the United States by aggressive bees has been checked, state and Federal agricultural officials say.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS SUSPENDED BY U.S. ON NEW CONTRACTS
description: The Navy suspended the General Dynamics Corporation today from obtaining any new Government contracts, one day after the giant military contractor and four former or current executives were indicted on fraud charges.

title: JAPANESE RAISING CHIP PRICES
description: A number of Japanese semiconductor companies signaled today that they were increasing their dollar prices for all types of semiconductors by about 20 percent. They said the increase was intended to cover currency exchange losses caused by the recent appreciation of the yen against the dollar.

title: Chevron Unit
description: TheChevron Corporation said today that its Chevron U.S.A. Inc. unit has agreed to sell its holding in the Hill property, a section of the South Belridge oilfield, to the Celeron Oil and Gas Company, a unit of the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, for $395 million. The Hill property, located 40 miles west of Bakersfield, Calif., includes 130 producing wells on 502 acres and produces 5,100 barrels of crude oil a day, a Chevron spokesman said.

title: Bridge: Priest With Varied Career Is Standout at Card Table
description: Those who focus their lives largely on the microcosmic game of bridge cannot but admire those for whom card-playing is a small part of a multifaceted existence.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MORE and more people these days seem to be drinking less and less.

title: Pearl Harbor After 44 Years
description: On the day before he died on April 12, 1945, near the end of World War II, President Roosevelt wrote the following lines:

title: LATE GOAL BY JETS TIES ISLANDERS, 4-4
description: The Islanders, who have fallen into a pattern of squandering slim leads and then protecting ties in the overtime period, allowed the visiting Winnipeg Jets a 4-4 tie tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Consolation Prize For Lion Kicker
description: They may play on only the Division I-AA level, and even at that modest scale they may not have won a game in the last two years, but the Columbia Lions can boast at least one trapping of big-time college football: They are sending a player to a postseason all-star game.

title: Travels With Bush
description: The political career of George Bush has survived a number of crises over the years, but none quite like the Black Socks Scandal of 1985. It all began early last week when the Vice President was photographed in the White House welcoming a visitor in the absence of President Reagan.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: PERCHED behind a set of drums last weekend at Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J., Anton Fier grinned from ear to ear, looking gloriously at home. His hair tossing from side to side as he deftly battered his splash cymbals and rolled out propulsive snare-drum rhythms, he piloted his seven-piece all-star band through rock-and-roll songs ranging from his own collaborations with the guitarist Jody Harris and R.E.M.'s vocalist Michael Stipe to a revised version of Moby Grape's 1960's anthem ''Omaha.''

title: POLITICS, LOST BOOKS AND BUDGET WOES VEXING CHICAGO LIBRARY
description: On the top three floors of an old downtown warehouse, tucked away behind the Tribune Tower and the Equitable Building, is this city's central library.

title: COMBATING DEFLATION
description: The Government's most closely watched barometer of future economic performance rose three-tenths of 1 percent in October, the sixth consecutive monthly advance, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ITALIAN SAYS INTELLIGENCE SERVICE TRIED TO INFLUENCE AGCA TESTIMONY
description: An Italian racketeer turned state's evidence told a court here today that former officials of the Italian intelligence service, working with organized crime leaders, prompted the convicted assailant of Pope John Paul II to link the shooting in 1981 to Bulgaria.

title: Mental Patients Need Protection of Counsel
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 22 of the Arts and Leisure section Nov. 17 about self-destructive artists misattributed a psychoanalytic quotation cited by the artist Robert Motherwell. The source of the quote is ''Ego Psychology and the Problem of Adaptation'' by Heinz Hartmann.

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Soviet Jew Said to Get Permission to Emigrate
description: The World Jewish Congress said Monday that Eliahu Essas, a Soviet Jew who has been trying to emigrate since 1973, was being given an exit visa.

title: Ford or Bust
description: If you see Gerald R. Ford heading for the Senate chamber this afternoon, he is not back to preside over that body as he did, on occasion, when he was Vice President in the closing years of the Nixon Administration. Actually, he will be on his way to the ceremonial dedication of his own bust.

title: Dr. Stanley Zipser, 74, Dies; A Pediatrician and Professor
description: Dr. Stanley S. Zipser, a pediatrician and clinical associate professor of pediatrics at the Medical College of Cornell University, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old.

title: REAGAN SEEKING A REPLACEMENT FOR MCFARLANE
description: White House officials said today that the Administration was seeking a replacement for Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser.

title: THE GROWING CONRAN EMPIRE
description: Sir Terence Conran, one of Britain's great entrepreneurial success stories, is about to enlarge his retail and design empire, and the question now is whether he can continue to work his magic.

title: Table Manners
description: Following is a sampling of letters by students at Prospect Park School No. 1 in Prospect Park, N.J., written in response to an Oct. 16 article on table manners: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Table Manners
description: Following is a sampling of letters by students at Prospect Park School No. 1 in Prospect Park, N.J., written in response to an Oct. 16 article on table manners:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Mail-Order Exotica City residents can buy many interesting and exotic foods from specialty and ethnic food shops, but out-of-towners often have trouble finding items such as fresh puff pastry, fine olive oil or panforte, the richly spiced Italian Christmas torte that is full of nuts and dried fruits.

title: REPUTED CRIME-GROUP FIGURE
description: Aniello Dellacroce, who was recently charged as the underboss of the Gambino Mafia ''family,'' died Monday night at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 71 years old and had long been under treatment for cancer.

title: WINNING ONE FOR THE FLIPPER
description: He needed to win a big one. Not to prove that he could, but to remind everybody that he did.

title: Eric Cochrane, Expert On Italian Renaissance
description: Eric Cochrane, a leading authority on the late Italian Renaissance and a professor of history at the University of Chicago, died Friday at a hospital in Florence, after suffering a stroke two days earlier. He was 57 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: REAGAN TELLS LEADERS DEFICIT PLAN IS 'UNACCEPTABLE' ON MILITARY CUTS
description: President Reagan told Republican Congressional leaders today that both the Senate and House versions of legislation to balance the Federal budget could force ''unacceptable'' cuts in military spending.

title: TEXAS IN FIRST PLACE IN ADOPTIONS IN U.S.
description: Texas is leading the nation in adoptions, followed by California and New York, according to the first detailed statistics on adoptions published in a decade.

title: STAGE: 'JUST SO,' A MUSICAL
description: LED by his '' 'satiable curtiosity,'' the Elephant's Child asks the Kolokolo Bird what the Crocodile has for dinner and the Kolokolo Bird says with a mournful cry, ''Go to the banks of the great grey-green, greasy Limpopo River, all set about with fever-trees, and find out.'' In the years since Rudyard Kipling wrote those lines, generations of children have warmed to the onomatopoetic and alliterative language as they accompanied the Elephant's Child on his mission, which resulted, as you may remember, in the stretching of the elephant's nose.

title: Successor Named For Unilever Chief
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch consumer-products concern, announced yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Sir Kenneth Durham, will retire next May at the age of 61. He will be succeeded by Michael Angus, a vice chairman and member of the company's three-member special committee of top executives. Mr. Angus will also become a vice chairman of Unilever N.V., the Dutch part of the parent company.

title: Puerto Rico-Japan Pact
description: Governor Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico signed cooperation agreements today with Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. and the Nikko Securities Company to help more Japanese concerns invest in Puerto Rico. Takuzo Kusumi of Mitsubishi said that Mitsubishi would provide information on investment in Puerto Rico to Japanese concerns that have business relations with the bank. Toshihiko Yasui of Nikko Securities said Nikko, Japan's second-largest securities firm, had agreed to provide data to Japanese concerns through its 101 branch offices.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CARL KARCHER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 1
MacIntyre Resigns
description: He coached Vanderbilt to an 8-4 record and a trip to the Holiday Bowl in 1982, but for George MacIntyre and his cerebral Commodores, that turned out to be a fluke. Yesterday, after turning in his sixth losing season in seven years, the 46-year-old MacIntyre announced his resignation from the academically-stringent private university, suggesting that Vanderbilt's scholar-athletes were simply no match for the athlete-scholars in the powerful Southeastern Conference. ''The continuing rise in academic standards, both in admissions and in the retaining of student athletes,'' he said, was a big reason for the team's failure to keep winning.

title: G.E.C. OF BRITAIN IN A BID FOR PLESSEY
description: Britain's General Electric Company disclosed today that it had offered to buy the Plessey Company, a telecommunications and defense contractor, for about $1.7 billion.

title: SOHIO SETS CHARGE OF $1.86 BILLION
description: Joining the wave of restructuring that has coursed through the oil industry in recent years, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced a sweeping reorganization yesterday that will result in a $1.86 billion pretax charge against its fourth-quarter earnings.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE noted before that the cooking in my own kitchen varies from classic to home-style: from truffled sauces to a host of dishes made with bargain cuts of meat from my local supermarket. On special occasions I may regale my guests with foie gras cooked in brioche dough, while at other times I might offer something as simple as a hamburger (flamed with Cognac if I want to add a special touch).

title: Humana Picks Grey Agency
description: To compete for its combined advertising account, worth more than $20 million in billings, Humana Inc., the health care company based in Louisville, Ky., invited in four agencies, three already on its agency roster, and Grey Advertising.

title: Stop the Fare Beaters
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-TRUSTEE SAYS CHURCH AIDES LIED IN TOWER HEARING
description: A former trustee of St. Bartholomew's Church charged yesterday that church officials had ''intentionally misrepresented'' its finances in an effort to win support for construction of a skyscraper on its Park Avenue grounds.

title: Celtics Win Eighth in Row
description: Larry Bird scored 10 fourth-quarter points and Kevin McHale scored 29 points over all to lead the Boston Celtics to their eighth straight victory tonight, a 112-109 triumph over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Ian Smith Faces Inquiry By Zimbabwe Parliament
description: Parliament voted today to investigate reports that Ian Smith, the former Rhodesian Prime Minister, made derogatory statements about the Government and Zimbabwe's blacks while on a vacation abroad.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 4, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SENATE SKIRTS A VOTE ON LIMITING PAC FUNDS IN RACES FOR CONGRESS
description: The Senate avoided a vote today on a measure to limit the amount Congressional candidates could accept from political action committees, but not without going on record as endorsing the principle.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Boston Celtics, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. The Nets made up a 19-point deficit after three quarters in the teams' opening game of the season on Oct. 25, beating the Celtics, 113-109, in overtime after Micheal Ray Richardson sent the game into overtime with a shot at the buzzer.

title: McEnroe Ousted in Australia
description: Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia harnessed his power today to oust second-seeded John McEnroe, 2-6, 6-3, 1-6, 6-4, 6-0, in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open tennis championships.

title: AQUINO VERDICTS: PROTEST, NO PASSION
description: Demonstrators in separate small incidents today burned tires, honked horns and banged on lampposts, threw black confetti from windows and chanted, ''Killer! Killer!''

title: NATIONAL BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax recoveries of $302,000 for the quarter and $822,000 for the year. c-Including tax recoveries of $415,000 for the quarter and $750,000 for the year, a writedown of discontinued operations of $724,000 for the year and a gain of $675,000 for the year from the sale of scientific research tax credits.

title: Deere Income Declines 43.3%
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment, said today that net income for its fourth quarter dropped 43.3 percent, to $19.4 million, or 29 cents a share, from $34.2 million, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Georgia Burke, 107; Acted Character Roles
description: Georgia Burke, an actress who played character roles on Broadway from the 1920's until her retirement in the 1960's, died in the De Witt Nursing Home in Manhattan last Thursday. According to the records of the Actors Fund of America, she was 107 years old.

title: Ammirati & Puris Wins Chiquita Pops
description: Ammirati & Puris has emerged triumphant from a competition involving eight agencies to handle Chiquita Pops, from United Brands' Chiquita Brands.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
EXECUTIVES
description: * Beldoch Industries has appointed Mitchel Levine president of its Alberoy division, which makes junior knitwear and sportswear.

title: Complify Those Things
description: Axiom One: Tax simplification is good. ''What means good?'' Politicians believe voters desperately want tax simplification, will give heave-ho to politicians who resist tax simplification.

title: Postal Service Loss for Year Not Big Enough for Rate Rise
description: The Postal Service lost $251.5 million in the 1985 fiscal year, which ended in September, the Postmaster General said today.

title: Reagan Learns Virtue Of a Liberal Education
description: To the Editor:

title: COLOMBO WITNESS TESTIFIES ABOUT BRIBE ATTEMPT
description: A Federal agent testified yesterday that he was asked by an associate of the Colombo crime group in 1980 to destroy evidence in an extortion case in Brooklyn and to locate a Government witness, who would then be murdered.

title: American-Arab Unit's Chief Reports Identifying Bomber
description: The leader of an American-Arab organization said today he had identified for the Federal Bureau of Investigation a person he believed was responsible for four bombings, including a fatal attack California.

title: BAIL DENIED WIFE OS SPYING SUSPECT
description: A Federal magistrate denied bond today for Anne Henderson-Pollard after prosecutors asserted she might disclose national security secrets to hostile countries if the authorities released her.

title: Circulation Audit Issue
description: EARLIER this week The Des Moines Register became the second Gannett newspaper company to quit the Audit Bureau of Circulations, the 71-year-old body that authenticates the claims of publishers.

title: A Fund for Underdogs
description: L. Douglas Wilder, who defied predictions when he was elected Lieutenant Governor, has decided to raise money to help other underdogs seeking state or local office anywhere in the country. Some oddsmakers put Mr. Wilder's chances at 100 to 1 when he became the first major black candidate for statewide office here since Reconstruction. He is to decide which candidates merit aid.

title: ARMY SURGEON DEFENDS COMPETENCE AT HEARING
description: An Army surgeon who left the troubled Bethesda Naval Hospital recently after his surgical technique was criticized testified today that he was a ''very competent surgeon'' who was challenged by less-qualified subordinates.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results include pre-tax losses of $129.2 million for the latest year and $14.6 million for the previous year from manufacturing and marketing operations.

title: Linebackerspeak
description: The Philadelphia Eagles may have come up woefully short in losing to Minnesota after holding a 23-0 lead with eight minutes to play Sunday, but one of their linebackers, Anthony Griggs, was long on metaphors when asked his reaction: ''We were playing good, and a fuse blew. Somebody threw water in the fuse box and caused a short circuit.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $630,000 for the quarter and $1,745,000 for the year and a gain of $2,847,000 for the year from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Including a gain of $11,005,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Table Manners
description: Following is a sampling of letters by students at Prospect Park School No. 1 in Prospect Park, N.J., written in response to an Oct. 16 article on table manners:

title: People
description: Kenneth Angel has rejoined BBDO as senior vice president and management supervisor.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Israeli Unit Kills 5 Palestinians
description: Israeli soldiers today killed five Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon, an Israeli military spokesman said.

title: PACT IN INDIA ASSURES SOME, INFLAMES OTHERS
description: Last August Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi triumphantly announced a settlement in a bitter ethnic dispute that had cost thousands of lives in the northeastern state of Assam.

title: GATX-Airbus
description: A San Francisco-based company has agreed to buy 10 A320 European Airbus passenger jets in a deal worth more than $300 million, the aircraft's maker, Airbus Industrie, said. Under the contract, GATX Air has also taken an option to buy more A320's. Airbus Industrie, a consortium of French, West German, British and Spanish aircraft companies, did not disclose how many more jets were involved.

title: NEW WING AND NEW ART FOR MUSEUM IN RICHMOND
description: In a neighborhood of stately homes and equestrian statues of Civil War heroes, a building of bold contemporary design, containing one of the country's best collections of Pop and later contemporary art, will open to the public here Saturday.

title: YANKS ON TOP, METS ON RISE IN SALARIES
description: For the seventh time in the nine seasons of free agency, the Yankees had the highest average salary in 1985, a record $546,364. The Mets' average salary rose nearly 38 percent to $389,365, which took them from 20th place to 12th among the 26 major league teams. It also put them over the majors' average salary of $371,157.

title: CONVOY ATTACKED IN AFGHAN CLASH
description: Western diplomats said here today that Afghan guerrillas reportedly destroyed 16 fuel trucks in an attack on a Soviet convoy and that 15 civilians were killed when a bus was caught in the ambush.

title: 2 Yankees Honored
description: Two Yankee sluggers, Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield, got some postseason windfalls yesterday when they were cited for their outstanding fielding performances. In voting conducted by The Sporting News among coaches and managers, the two were named by the newspaper to the American League's Gold Glove team, and in accordance with provisions in their Yankee contracts, Winfield will get a $25,000 bonus and Mattingly will receive $15,000. Ron Guidry, the Yankee pitcher, and Keith Hernandez, the Met first baseman, also won Gold Glove awards, but their contracts contain no incentive clauses keyed to the award.

title: Radicals Say They Killed West Bank Lawyer
description: A radical Palestinian guerrilla group today took responsibility for the killing of a West Bank Arab lawyer and said all ''hirelings'' of Israel faced the same fate.

title: Ghana Greets Spy Suspect
description: Michael Agbotui Soussoudis, accused by the United States of spying for Ghana, arrived home to a hero's welcome today. About 5,000 singing and chanting Ghanaians carried placards accusing Washington of interfering in national affairs. Mr. Soussoudis was released in return for Accra's release of eight Ghanaians charged with spying for the United States.

title: Racing Resumes At Meadowlands
description: Racing resumed at the Meadowlands last night after officials worked through the day to assure safe track conditions for jockeys. The jockeys, who refused to ride after the second race Friday night, had forced the cancellation of Saturday's and Monday's cards because they found the track hazardous, first because of a washout caused by a week of rain, and then because of ice chunks that formed on the track after a sudden drop of temperatures Monday.

title: ALVARADO SAYS HE WILL NOT BE SHANKER'S AIDE
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the former Chancellor of the New York City public schools, has reversed his decision to accept a position as special assistant to the president of the American Federation of Teachers, union officials said yesterday.

title: WINE TALK
description: ''HOW do we convince our customers to hold on to our wines for five or six years, until they have had a chance to reach their peak?,'' asked Bernard Trimbach.

title: EXPELLED DOCTORS ACCUSE ETHIOPIA
description: A French medical organization has been ordered to end its relief work in Ethiopia, and today the group's president asserted that expulsion was the price for speaking out against Government policies that he said had killed 100,000 famine victims.

title: U.S. JUSTICES HEAR 2 CASES ON LIBEL
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether defendants in libel suits by private individuals may be penalized for making damaging allegations that have not been proved false.

title: RANGERS RECALL HANLON, DEMOTE SCOTT
description: Having taken a severe tumble in the space of a few days, the Rangers yesterday brought back their No. 1 goaltender of the last two years, Glen Hanlon, from the minor leagues, and sent down the rookie goalie Ron Scott.

title: Gulf Canada
description: Ultramar Canada Inc. said that it had agreed to buy Gulf Canada Ltd.'s refining and marketing fixed assets in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces for about $86.4 million. Gulf Canada has sold a number of its assets recently, following the purchase from Chevron Inc. last summer of a 60 percent stake in Gulf by Olympia & York Ltd., the company owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto. Ultramar, a unit of Ultramar P.L.C., a British company, said the sale would be completed on Jan. 8.

title: CATCHING OVEN SPILLS
description: THERE are few kitchen chores as tedious as cleaning an oven. The work can be minimized by placing a drip pan or sheets of aluminum foil under foods that tend to overflow during baking - fruit tarts, deep-dish pies, casseroles and so on. A specially designed pie pan does the same job.

title: Kaiser Aluminum
description: The British investor, Alan Clore, has joined a group of investors led by J. A. Frates in seeking control of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Clore has agreed to contribute ''at least $10 million'' to a new partnership with KACC Associates, based in Tulsa, Okla., and controlled by Mr. Frates. The new partnership holds 3.17 percent of Kaiser's shares outstanding.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 12:59 P.M. today and set at 2:19 A.M. tomorrow.

title: BUYING WINE IN BULK: CHOICES FOR HOLIDAY CHEER
description: AS the holiday entertaining season approaches, many consumers find themselves performing baffled pirouettes in the aisles of wine shops trying to stock up on quality wines at affordable prices for the season's social gatherings. Never before have there been so many new labels, new production regions and unfamiliar grape varieties from which to choose. At the same time, however, prices have rarely been better. With just a little forethought, then, consumers can spend like Scrooge on bargain wines by the case yet appear as munificent as St. Nick.

title: Theft 'Embarrassing' Police in Jersey Town
description: The police here were already worried about a rash of burglaries, but things really hit a low when someone broke into their headquarters and stole $240 in bail money.

title: UPTOWN AND DOWNTOWN, A BOUNTY OF HOME GIFTS
description: AT Christmastime, there is a touch of adventure in the air.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Stalking A Literary Stalker
description: The vault contains a peerless act of literary imagination whose entire opening paragraph is: ''Tom!''

title: WILTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE RISE OF REAGAN
description: In his appointment today of Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter as his national security adviser, President Reagan has cemented the power of Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, over the domestic and foreign policy apparatus of the White House, Administration officials said. By all accounts Mr. Regan's emergence as the most powerful figure in the Administration after the President will mark a faint but perceptible shift in White House operations.

title: World Cup Field Is Set
description: Scotland became the 24th and final team to qualify for soccer's quadrennial World Cup yesterday, when the Scots tied Australia, 0-0, in Melbourne. They had won the first game in Scotland, 2-0.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Connecticut Acts On Teacher Pay
description: The State Board of Education today approved a $19,300 starting salary for public-school teachers, beginning with the 1986-87 school year.

title: MARCOS VOICES SUPPORT FOR VER
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today he would retain Gen. Fabian C. Ver for some time as armed forces Chief of Staff, and the General told reporters, ''I am not retiring.''

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,080,000 for the quarter and $3,412,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,808,000 for the quarter and $7,274,000 for the year.

title: Required Reading;   It Isn't Easy
description: Excerpt from talk between President Reagan and students at Fallston High School, Fallston, Md., Dec. 4:

title: A Fund for Underdogs
description: L. Douglas Wilder, who defied predictions when he was elected Lieutenant Governor, has decided to raise money to help other underdogs seeking state or local office anywhere in the country. Some oddsmakers put Mr. Wilder's chances at 100 to 1 when he became the first major black candidate for statewide office here since Reconstruction.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FEW do-it-yourself projects can be completed without a hand saw of some kind, so nearly every tool kit should have one or more. The most widely used is the standard carpenter's wood-cutting saw. It is usually 24 to 26 inches long and has a springy metal blade permanently attached to a wood handle with a comfortable grip. Such saws come in two types: crosscut and rip.

title: DANCE: LINDA DIAMOND
description: THE Linda Diamond Dance Company opened its program on Tuesday at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street, with ''A Dancer's View of Calder's Universe,'' by Miss Diamond The suite of dances, performed by Miss Diamond and Tom Baird, offers a sensitive complement to the lines, shapes and energy of Alexander Calder's art, seen in projections on a white back screen.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $33,000 for the quarter and $1,120,000 for the 9 months and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $922,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $341,000 for the quarter and $682,000 for the 9 months.

title: Fieldcrest Buys Cannon Units
description: Fieldcrest Mills Inc. announced that it had purchased the bath and bedding operations of Cannon Mills for $250 million. The operations employ 12,900 workers in 12 plants and 14 sales offices, Cannon officials said.

title: THE ALLURE OF A CABLE SYSTEM
description: The investment was huge and the risks enormous as the operators of cable television systems built their businesses over the last 10 years. After laying out hundreds of millions of dollars to wire American homes, they were still at the mercy of fickle consumers and regulatory constraints.

title: CITY TO GIVE HISPANIC GROUPS $1 MILLION TO AID JOB TRAINING
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced the establishment of a $1 million job-training program to help disadvantaged Hispanic people in the city.

title: COURT HEARS 2 INTERPRETATIONS OF VOTING RIGHTS IN DISTRICTING CASE
description: The Reagan Administration and a civil rights lawyer argued before the Supreme Court today about whether the North Carolina Legislature had diluted black voting power in drawing legislative districts, in violation of the 1982 amendments to the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. When the teams met Nov. 7 in the Garden, the Bucks scored a 92-88 victory for the Knicks' seventh straight defeat and 19th over two seasons.

title: Thatcher Regrets Aide's Remark on Ireland
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that she regretted the wording of a Cabinet minister's declaration Tuesday that the British-Irish pact on Northern Ireland means there will ''never be a united Ireland.''

title: LIMITED IMPACT ON DYNAMICS IS SEEN
description: Defense industry officials and analysts said yesterday that General Dynamics' pivotal role as a military supplier would likely give the company tremendous protection over the next few months, keeping the Government's suspension of new contract awards from having more than a token financial impact on the company.

title: Farewell to Faust
description: Gerry Faust made an emotional goodbye last night at South Bend, Ind., to his five-season career as coach at Notre Dame. Faust, his voice trembling occasionally, spoke at the university's 66th football dinner.

title: Massachusetts Housing Bonds
description: The Massachusetts Housing Finance Authority is offering $122 million of multifamily mortgage revenue bonds, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: P.L.O. Aide in a Charge Against Mrs. Klinghoffer
description: Farouk Kaddoumi, an official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that there was no evidence that the hijackers of an Italian cruise ship were responsible for the death of Leon Klinghoffer, an American tourist.

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on May 3, 1985.

title: Higher Fares Will Make Hailing Taxis Easier
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVARD SECURITIES GROUP PLC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Revenue figures represent turnover. Results were translated at the rate of $1.47 equals one pound sterling.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the latest third quarter and 9 months reflect the acquisition of Lawson Co. from Sara Lee Corp. in September. Also, both periods reflect non-recurring charges of $681,899 related to interim financing costs related to the acquisition and a writedown of $150,000 to reduce the carrying value of marketable securities investment.

title: KOCH COMES OUT WITH 2D BOOK, 255 PAGES OF ANECDOTES, ADVICE AND INSULTS
description: Mayor Koch issued a compendium of anecdotes, homilies, advice and insults yesterday, all stitched together and released in the form of his second book.

title: Restore Trust to Defense Industry
description: The defense industry today is close to bankruptcy in terms of public trust and confidence. Many in Congress, the Pentagon, the judicial system, the press and the public at large appear to have determined that the industry is guilty of fraud, waste and abuse.

title: ARTHUR E. CRANE
description: Arthur E. Crane, a board member and retired vice president of the company that produces paper for United States currency, has died at the age of 71. Mr. Crane, who had worked for 44 years for Crane & Company, died Sunday after suffering an apparent heart attack at his home in Dalton.

title: CAPITAL THREATS STIR EVACUATIONS
description: Three Federal buildings were evacuated today after a man saying he represented the ''People's Liberation Army'' telephoned a series of bomb threats to 10 agencies, officials said.

title: 20th Century-Fox
description: The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation said that the previously announced purchase by Rupert Murdoch of half of TCF Holdings Inc., Fox's parent company, has been completed. Mr. Murdoch, who now owns all of TCF Holdings Inc., paid Marvin Davis and his family $325 million for the stake. Last month, Mr. Murdoch announced that he planned to combine the studio with six Metromedia Inc. television stations to form a new company, Fox Inc.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * John W. Palmer is joining Doyle Dane Bernbach/Detroit as a group senior vice president.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JACKSON POLLOCK (1912-1956) is very much alive again in the pages of this oral biography of the famous and controversial painter. Compiled and written by Jeffrey Potter, a friend of Pollock's who lived near him on the South Fork of Long Island, ''To a Violent Grave'' usefully supplements B. H. Friedman's admirable 1972 biography, ''Jackson Pollock: Energy Made Visible,'' which, as Mr. Friedman himself admits in these pages, failed to anticipate the enormous subsequent growth of Pollock's reputation.

title: RECITAL:Karin Hauschild
description: The soprano, Karin Hauschild, who made her New York debut Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, has presented recitals of art songs and chamber music throughout the Northeast, and sung important roles in several Mozart and Puccini operas.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avnet Inc., which makes computer products, has named its president, Leon Machiz, to the additional positions of vice chairman and chief operating officer.

title: New President Elected At Melville Corporation
description: The Melville Corporation, one of the nation's largest diversified specialty retailing concerns, said yesterday that Stanley P. Goldstein had been elected president and chief operating officer.

title: PLESSEY REJECTS BID OFFERED BY G.E.C.
description: The Plessey Company, a telecommunications and military contractor, today rejected the $1.7 billion takeover bid made yesterday by Britain's General Electric Company.

title: Intermountain Power In $625 Million Offering
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, which is constructing two coal-fired power plants in Utah to supply electricity to southern California, is offering $625 million of power system revenue bonds to refund bonds issued in 1981 and 1983 when interest rates were as high as 11 percent.

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: A TRIBUTE TO HARRY JAMES
description: ''YOU MADE ME LOVE YOU'' is called a tribute to the late Harry James, and it is. But without meaning to be, it's a memorial service for the big-band era as well. In a way, it's a little sad. Don't let that discourage you, however, because ''You Made Me Love You'' is also a very pleasant hour of television. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 10:35 tonight.

title: C.D., Fund Yields Are Stable
description: Rates paid on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed little or no change for the week ended yesterday. The lull in rates is now in its third week.

title: SUBWAY RIDERS PLEAD FOR DELAY IN FARE INCREASE AT M.T.A. HEARING
description: Exasperated subway riders took the microphone yesterday, one by one, to tell the Metropolitan Transportation Authority what they thought of the proposal to raise the transit fare. The fact that the microphone did not work very well was a symbol not lost on anyone.

title: Franciscans and Frugality
description: Last winter Harry Macklowe, a New York developer, demolished a midtown welfare hotel without a permit, to hasten more lucrative use of the property. He was caught in mid-demolition and sued by the city for $10 million.

title: U.S. WOMAN PROTESTS WITH 'MASS,' IN ST. PETER'S
description: An American woman walked up to an altar in St. Peter's Basilica today and simulated saying the holiest part of the mass to protest the Roman Catholic Church's exclusion of women from the priesthood.

title: U.S. MAY MOVE ANTI-HIJACKING EXPERTS
description: The United States is considering deployment of military anti-hijacking specialists overseas because of their failure to get to the scene quickly enough to aid in the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner to Malta and in the takeover of the Achille Lauro cruise ship, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: PRESIDENT URGING HOUSE TO APPROVE TAX-REVISION BILL
description: In the face of solid opposition from the Republican leadership in the House of Representatives, President Reagan ''strongly'' urged the House to pass tax-revision legislation next week and send the bill to the Senate.

title: THE FRAGRANT JASMINE
description: AS December's shadows lengthen, there's nothing so comforting as an undemanding house plant that flowers. And if that flower also happens to be jasmine, there's the added bonus of exquisite fragrance.

title: KEY WEST ELECTS BANKER AS MAYOR
description: A banker beat a barkeeper by just 52 votes today to become Mayor of this island city in a runoff election delayed by Hurricane Kate.

title: Spare Us
description: Representative Dennis M. Hertel, Democrat of Michigan, asks his colleagues in a letter, ''Can You Solve This Mystery?'' The mystery is the subject of a resolution, sponsored by Mr. Hertel, to designate the week of Jan. 5 as a special week.

title: UNBEATEN MICHIGAN TOPS YOUNGSTOWN
description: Gary Grant scored 12 points to pace a balanced Michigan attack tonight as the Wolverines defeated Youngstown State, 56-42.

title: NASA CHIEF TAKES LEAVE TO ANSWER FRAUD CHARGES
description: James M. Beggs, the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, took a leave of absence today to defend himself against charges that he attempted to defraud the Army while serving as an executive of the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: Holiday Fares: Airlines' View
description: Heavily promoted holiday fare discounts increased business but not as much as expected, spokesmen for some airlines said today. To get the discount, a traveler had to fly on Thanksgiving Day and make the return flight by Saturday night.

title: FAMILIES RESPOND TO NEEDIEST
description: Concern for the plight of the homeless, the hungry, the ill and the despairing has brought an outpouring of contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bonn and Ankara Set Exchange of Prisoners
description: Some 50 Turks jailed in West Germany will be returned to Turkey to complete their sentences, the Justice Ministry said today.

title: REAGAN APPOINTS ADMIRAL TO POST OF SECURITY CHIEF
description: President Reagan named Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter today to be the White House national security adviser, in a move the President said would allow ''continuity'' in foreign policy and national security issues.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net losses including tax credits of $750,830 for the quarter and $1,456,830 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $128,374.

title: Technology;   Tracking Stolen Cars
description: IT is no secret that electronics have played a major role in pulling better performance from today's automobiles. Nor is it any surprise that the microchip has found its way into everything from dashboards to suspension systems. But now, after a year of testing, a Massachusetts company has come to market with a unique application of the chip, one that promises a radical decrease in auto theft.

title: DEUTSCHE BANK BID FOR FLICK
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's largest bank, plans to buy the country's largest family-held industrial enterprise, the Flick group, the two companies said today.

title: Illinois Highway Refunding Begins
description: The Illinois State Toll Highway Authority is offering $163.6 million of toll highway refunding revenue bonds that were tentatively priced to yield a maximum of 9 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2009, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Advertising;   Doyle Dane Bernbach Buys Direct Response
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group (whose former last name was International) has acquired the seven-year-old Direct Response Group in Dallas, billing about $40 million. The acquisition was made for an undisclosed number of common shares.

title: The U.N.'s 30 Millionth
description: As the numbers dropped, the tension at the United Nations mounted.

title: MORISON RECEIVES 2-YEAR JAIL TERM
description: Samuel Loring Morison, a former civilian intelligence analyst for the Navy, was sentenced to two years in prison today for stealing classified documents and giving secret American satellite photographs of a Soviet aircraft carrier to a British military journal.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: Year-ago third quarter and 9 months net losses have been restated to reflect a change in the accounting method for certain vendor allowances.

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 15.

title: METS OFFER STAUB A NONPLAYING JOB
description: Rusty Staub has likely played his final game for the Mets, but Phil Niekro may still be pitching for the Yankees next season.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 5, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHIL OCHS TRIBUTE Of the many folk music personalities who reached maturity in the early 1960's, none carried the tradition of ''protest'' music with more dedication than Phil Ochs, who committed suicide in 1976 at the age of 35. Tonight at Folk City (130 West Third Street) the man who wrote ''There but for Fortune'' and the antiwar anthem ''I Ain't Marchin' Anymore,'' will be saluted by musicians who were either friends of the singer or were influenced by his music.

title: Jets Are Bothered By O'Brien's Sacks
description: The sack again reared its ugly head today on the Jets, especially as it applies to Ken O'Brien, the league's leading quarterback, who has been sacked a remarkable 54 times this season.

title: A Small Point
description: A period is being inserted and established in official documents right after the ''S'' in the name of the 33d President of the United States. When he was alive, he signed his name ''Harry S Truman,'' with no period, saying the ''S'' didn't really stand for anything.

title: Market Place;   High Tech's Midwest Stars
description: HIGH TECH generally conjures up visions of the Pacific Coast's Silicon Valley or New England's electronics corridor. Now analysts have identified another geographical focal point for high technology - the Middle West - and they have isolated a number of companies that have weathered the current computer industry slump, companies that they think have the potential for growth and profit.

title: Joseph Kennedy 2d Declares He Will Run for House Seat
description: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, who said he was ready for a ''long, hard battle,'' announced today that he would try to replace Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. in the House seat that was the first rung of John F. Kennedy's ladder to the Presidency. Mr. O'Neill, the House Speaker, is retiring next year.

title: Student Slain at Penn
description: The gagged and bound body of Meera Ananthakrishnan, a University of Pennsylvania graduate student from Madras, India, was found when her roommate returned from Thanksgiving break, officials said.

title: INQUIRY SAID TO BE SOUGHT IN E.P.A. CONFLICT
description: The House Judiciary Committee is expected to vote Thursday on whether to call for an independent investigation of allegations of wrongdoing by high Administration officials in Congressional inquiries into the Environmental Protection Agency three years ago, committee sources said today.

title: STADIUMS CHANGE, FRIENDSHIPS DON'T
description: Linda flew to Houston last night to spend the week with her friend Regina and Regina's family. On Sunday, both will go to the Giants-Oilers game in the Astrodome and will even sit together despite their opposite rooting interests.

title: Ray Williams Waived
description: Ray Williams, the veteran guard, was placed on waivers by the Atlanta Hawks to make room for Glenn (Doc) Rivers.

title: Jane's Reports Gains By Soviet in Aviation
description: Jane's, the military publisher, said today that the Soviet Union was narrowing the technology gap in aircraft.

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Americus Shareowner Service Corp. said the Americus Trust for Exxon shares has met requirements for its establishment and will begin trading on the American Stock Exchange today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Rebels Say They Killed 124 in Mozambique
description: Mozambican guerrillas said today that they killed at least 124 Mozambican and Zimbabwean soldiers and occupied two district capitals in four attacks near Beira on Monday.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in April.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''True tax reform is imperative. The first step must begin with a positive vote in the House of Representatives.''

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes gains of $1,820,000 for the quarter and $2,652,000 for the 9 months from the sales of partial equity interests in unconsolidated affiliates.

title: WESTPORT STRIVING TO RESTRAIN THE HANDS OF TIME
description: In the 1955 novel ''The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit,'' this town served as the archetypical ''bedroom community'' for striving young executives with jobs in the New York City and children in school.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $9,105,000 for the quarter and $9,291,000 for the 6 months.

title: Advertising;   New President Joins Altschiller Reitzfeld
description: J. Steve Davis, who resigned in June from Benton & Bowles, his only agency employer, has joined Altschiller Reitzfeld as president.

title: WEINBERGER OPEN TO PLAN TO REVAMP MILITARY
description: Under pressure from Congress, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he could accept changes in the structure of the armed forces, including proposals to strengthen the authority of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: New York's Wrong Approach to Better Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'POLITICS' SAMPLER
description: There are two occasions when one can engage in what used to be called the white lie. One is when you are getting rid of someone who is inadequate. I believe it is acceptable to tell them anything you want about how competent they are. And if you are asked to talk about that person publicly, I believe it is perfectly acceptable to make up laudatory statements and speak them straight-faced into the microphone. You are also allowed to say to a sick individual, ''No, you don't have cancer.''

title: HOME BEATALABASTER IN ORGANIC DESIGNS
description: CONSIDERING the naturalistic themes that she often uses in her jewelry, it's not surprising that Angela Cummings's new accessories have soft, smooth and organic forms.

title: 2 Students Shot In a Bronx School
description: Two students walking in the corridor of Junior High School 125 in the East Bronx were shot yesterday when a gun being handled by another student apparently went off accidentally, the police said.

title: CITY TO PROVIDE 630 MORE BEDS FOR HOMELESS
description: With the number of homeless people in city shelters increasing daily, the Koch administration promised a state judge yesterday that it would provide 630 additional beds within 10 days to relieve overcrowding.

title: Ross Ponders Offer
description: Bobby Ross, the Maryland coach, said yesterday he would make up his mind by today on whether to accept the job vacated by Lou Holtz at Minnesota. Ross, the former assistant coach for the Kansas City Chiefs, has been mentioned as a candidate for numerous coaching vacancies throughout the country.

title: PT COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NATO TALKS STRESS NONNUCLEAR ARMS
description: Officials of NATO said today that the Atlantic alliance had now reached a high degree of consensus on the need to renew efforts to build up its conventional forces.

title: Surgery for Islander
description: Ari Haanpaa, the Islanders' rookie forward who was already sidelined with a shoulder injury, had his appendix removed early yesterday morning and will not be permitted any physical activity for at least three weeks, an Islander spokeman said.

title: NETWORK DOCUMENTARIES AN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: Twenty-five years ago, Edward R. Murrow stood in his shirtsleeves in an open field and introduced ''Harvest of Shame,'' the network documentary that let millions of Americans see the hardships of migrant workers. The program had a national impact, and the power of the television documentary seemed secure.

title: Mary Kay Deal
description: Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. said it is now a private company.

title: SPAIN BACKS A.T.& T. VENTURE
description: More than two years of often tortuous negotiations involving the Reagan Administration and technological espionage all but ended here today when the Spanish Government approved a financial package for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to build a microchip plant.

title: STATE POLICE ACT TO TIGHTEN DISCIPLINE
description: Among law-enforcement experts, New York State's police force has been compared to the Marine Corps for its tough entrance requirements and stringent discipline.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MAPLE LEAFS OUTLAST DEFENSELESS DEVILS
description: The goals kept coming in rapid succession from both sides against poor defenses and even worse goaltending tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON STUDENT LOANS
description: The House today approved a $10.6 billion college aid bill that would tighten student loan requirements and raise the Federal Government's maximum Pell Grant for low-income students by $1,000 in the next six years.

title: Olympic Progress
description: The presidents of the Olympic committees of North and South Korea have agreed to meet in Lausanne, Switzerland, in early January for a new effort to reach agreement on the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, the International Olympic Committee reported. Fears had been expressed earlier that the scheduled second meeting on North Korea's demand to be co-host of the 1988 Games might never take place. But officials at I.O.C. headquarters here said Chong-Ha Kim, president of South Korea's National Olympic Committee, and Yu Sun Kim, president of North Korea's national committee, both advised Juan Antonio Samaranch of Spain, the president of the international committee, that they would attend the meeting planned Jan. 8 and 9.

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $552,000.

title: Dr. A. Louis McGarry Is Dead; Nassau County Psychiatrist
description: Dr. A. Louis McGarry, a psychiatrist who was medical director of the division of forensic services of the Nassau County Department of Mental Health, died of cancer Monday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 56 years old.

title: Mr. Option Three
description: Your Secretary of State thinks that Mr. Gorbachev, at the recent summit meeting, used formulations of language that revealed an unexpectedly flexible attitude about the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan; in fact, some American negotiators were certain that the new language could be incorporated into the conference's joint statement, providing a small breakthrough.

title: NETS LOSE AS DAWKINS IS EJECTED
description: There were 14 seconds left in the first half when Darryl Dawkins exploded in a burst of anger. But in that single moment, the Nets suddenly deflated. The game was virtually over.

title: Closing In
description: After being shut out Tuesday night by Winnipeg, Denis Potvin of the Islanders is still three points short of setting a career record for National Hockey League defensemen.

title: LATIN MEDIATORS REPORTED GLOOMY ON CENTRAL AMERICA PEACE EFFORT
description: The Contadora Group nations today struggled to keep alive their three-year-old peace effort among signs of a deepening rift between Nicaragua and three other Central American nations.

title: Pretoria Proposes Shift On Black Land Rights
description: The Government said today that it would propose next year that blacks be allowed to own land in urban areas for the first time in 72 years, but the change would not end restrictions on where they can live.

title: Hutton Stock Offering
description: The E. F. Hutton Group said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of three million shares of common stock. Hutton follows a number of securities companies that have taken steps to increase their capital this year. Because of competitive pressures, others are likely to follow, with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation reportedly considering acting soon.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: A STRUGGLE OF ATTRITION
description: After a mass funeral rally in Mamelodi, a black township near Pretoria, Winnie Mandela, the activist wife of the jailed anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela, told her followers on Tuesday that ''the solution of this country's problems lies in black hands.''

title: U.S. FUND GETS NEW BONN GRANT
description: The West German Government will provide a new grant, of $40 million, to the German Marshall Fund of the United States, a special envoy, Walther Leisler Kiep, announced today.

title: Advertising;   A How-To Bartending Videotape
description: A VERY special how-to videotape is coming on the market today in time for holiday giving. It is sight-and-sound translation of that longtime hard-cover favorite, the Mr. Boston Official Bartender's Guide, 10 million copies in print.

title: Portland Police Investigate Abortion Offices' Bomb Mail
description: The police are investigating the mailing of bombs to four offices where abortions are performed or birth-control information is provided.

title: The Battle for Safe Sex in the Baths
description: New York State's Public Health Council recently amended the sanitary code to require local officials to close facilities where ''high-risk sexual activity takes place.'' Mayor Koch has asked bathhouse owners to tell him what they've done to prohibit high risk sex at their facilities.

title: ALL AMERICAN GOURMET reports earnings for 16wks to Nov 3
description: b-Net loss c-After a tax benefit of $634,000. General Host Corp. owns 80 percent of All American Gourmet's outstanding shares following a recent public offering of 20 percent of the shares.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Hired Doug Rader, the former manager of Texas, as third-base coach.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a tax credit reversal of $177,000. c-After tax credits of $301,000 for the latest year and $1,275,000 for the earlier period.

title: STAGE: 1-ACT COMEDIES IN PUNCH LINE FESTIVAL
description: CONSIDERABLE talent is on display at the Intar Theater, where 5 of the 10 original plays chosen for Manhattan Punch Line's festival of one-act comedies opened this week.

title: 2 Acquitted In G.E. Case
description: A top General Electric Company official and a former high-ranking G.E. manager have been acquitted of charges of defrauding the Government of $800,000 on a nuclear warhead contract.

title: Cambodia, Not the Philippines, Worries Asean
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: WOODHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 28
UPHEAVAL, NO
description: Betty Webb had a complaint. She was trying to make good washcloths, but when she tried to hem them, the blade on her cutting machine chewed the fabric.

title: INTERIOR DESIGNERS GIVEN NEW AWARD
description: IN the movie business, the most celebrated performers receive Academy Awards. Accomplished stage actors and actresses are presented with Tonies. In the world of television, the highest honor is an Emmy. ''But,'' says Lester Dundes, publisher of Interior Design magazine, ''there has never been anything of that caliber to honor outstanding designers working in our field.''

title: 3-State House Vote On Money Bill
description: Following are the positions of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today approved an omnibus money bill to continue most Government programs for the rest of the fiscal year. The vote was 212 to 208.

title: 25.34 JUMP PUTS DOW AT 1,484.40
description: Stock prices exploded yesterday, under the pressure of demand that had been building for the last week.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Dec. 5, 1985 Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 12:48 P.M. today and set at 2:03 A.M. tomorrow.

title: EASING OF TRUST RULES IS PROPOSED TO REAGAN
description: The level of imports would become a statutory factor in determining whether a merger is unlawfully anti-competitive under a revamping of antitrust law that President Reagan's Cabinet has just recommended.

title: U.S. Asserts Hussein Wants Role for Syria in Peace Effort
description: A visiting State Department official said here today that King Hussein of Jordan wanted to include Syria in the Middle East process.

title: Bouncing Down The Long Road
description: To Joe Rhodes, a freelance writer from Shreveport, La., the road to the Final Four is more than just a figure of speech, and it is a very long road indeed. He has embarked on a college basketball odyssey that began three weeks ago, when Kentucky played host to the Czechoslovak national team, and will not end until after the last big weekend of the N.C.A.A. championship tournament. In between are appointments to see 150 games - an average of better than one a night, what with doubleheaders - on a journey that will crisscross the country for a total of 25,000 miles.

title: Harlem Dancers to Perform
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem Workshop Ensemble will perform in New York City on Dec. 19 at 12:15 P.M. in the Atrium at the Continental Insurance building, 180 Maiden Lane, at Front Street.

title: STUDIO GLASS PIONEERS OF THE 50'S HAVE A SHOW
description: ALTHOUGH Frances and Michael Higgins have been making glass for production for the table, for decoration and as jewelry since the late 1940's, until recently they were not widely recognized as forerunners of the American studio glass movement.

title: Soviet Official Demoted
description: The Soviet Union announced today that the Minister of Grain Procurement, Grigory S. Zolotukhin, would move to a less significant job in the reorganization of the country's agricultural and food supply industries. A decree in the Government daily newspaper Izvestia said Mr. Zolotukhin, 74 years old, would leave the job he had held since 1973 and become Minister of Bakery Products.

title: BLIND READERS FILE LAWSUIT OVER U.S. BAN ON BRAILLE PLAYBOY
description: A group of blind readers, complaining of what they called ''blatant, paternalistic censorship,'' filed a lawsuit today in Federal District Court here seeking to overturn a Congressional ban on publishing a Braille edition of Playboy magazine at the Government's expense.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.M.A. DUE TO SEEK CIGARETTE AD BAN
description: The American Medical Association is expected to call next week for a ban on all cigarette advertising.

title: Zimbabwe Leader Signs Accords With Moscow
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe reached agreement Tuesday with Soviet leaders on two accords aimed at improving relations, the official press agency tass said today.

title: Dance by Erick Hawkins
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company will perform from Dec. 17 to 21 at Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street. The company will perform ''Plains Daybreak,'' ''Agathlon'' and ''Hurrah!,'' all by Mr. Hawkins. Tickets are $20. Information and reservations: 255-6698 between 1 and 6 P.M.

title: STORE SALES DOWN BY 4.8% IN CITY
description: November sales at New York City's biggest retailers declined 4.8 percent from the same month last year, a spot-check found yesterday. It was the first solid evidence of the negative effect of the shortened Christmas shopping season, which began formally last Friday.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
IMPORTED CARS AT 32.4% AS DOMESTIC SALES FALL
description: Imported automobiles claimed a near-record 32.4 percent share of the American car market in November, as domestic sales continued to decline after the ending of a major incentive program on Oct. 1. The import share record of 32.8 percent was set during the worst of the industry's sales difficulties in August 1982.

title: Looking to the Future
description: A dispassionate observer of South Africa, if there were such a thing, would see one certainty in that turbulent land today: Real change is coming. When, no one can say. But there is a momentum in events, a sense that the abused black majority cannot forever be denied its place in the political life of the country.

title: Allied-Signal Unit
description: Charter Power Systems Inc. has agreed to buy the assets of Allied-Signal Inc.'s C&D Power Systems unit, a maker of storage batteries and chargers for industrial use.

title: Joseph R. Crowley Dies at 66; A Fordham Law School Dean
description: Joseph R. Crowley, associate dean and Cameron Professor of Law at Fordham University's School of Law, died of cancer Tuesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 66 years old. Mr. Crowley was a lifelong Yonkers resident and earned bachelor's and law degrees from Fordham.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES CASTELLANO IS THE SUCCESSOR TO GAMBINO
