description: A key prosecution witness in a Federal trial of 10 reputed members of the Gambino crime group identified Paul Castellano yesterday as the successor to the late Carlo Gambino as head of the organization.

title: STAGE: RICHARD LEWIS, COMIC
description: LIKE two generations of comedians before him, Richard Lewis bases much of his humor on the vocabulary of neurosis and psychic pain. But unlike his forerunners, his streak of good-natured machismo suggests an underlying ruggedness.

title: The Corporate Share of Tax Reform
description: The loudest opposition to the tax reform package voted by the House Ways and Means Committee comes from the business community. And the complaint is the same as the one some businesses hurled at President Reagan's original proposals: that the reforms are inimical to investment and growth. Is this criticism apt or just an effort to protect business tax advantages?

title: Chiles Better After Surgery
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, who is recovering from quadruple heart bypass surgery, got out of bed Tuesday, met briefly with his wife and aides and left the intensive care unit at Lakeland Regional Medical Center. A hospital spokesman said that the 55-year-old legislator was gaining strength and was in good spirits after the nearly four-hour operation Monday.

title: RELUCTANT CURRY A NATURAL FIGHTER
description: Donald Curry was only 12 years old when his trainer, Paul Reyes, discovered in a sparring session that he could no longer lay a glove on the youngster. ''It was,'' said the trainer, ''the last time I was in the ring with him. One of the other coaches tried, too. He gave up after half a round. Said to me, ''You're right. The guy's too fast.' ''

title: Bright Lights, Angry City
description: A blazing neon addition to the mid-Manhattan skyline was generating more heat than light yesterday as city officials sought to have the prominent new sign turned off.

title: NEW SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1985
description: International The new national security adviser who will replace Robert C. McFarlane at the White House will be Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, previously the deputy advisor. Admiral Poindexter was described by White House officials as smart, hard working and low-key. [Page A1, Column 1.] Bishops are in sharp disagreement over the form and substance of the final documents to be issued at the Synod in Rome. The pivotal question being debated is whether the Roman Catholic bishops should issue a statement of specific proposals to complement a pastoral message. [A1:3-4.] The French and Polish leaders met, generating protests in virtually all French political circles except the Communist Party. The 80-minute meeting between President Francois Mitterrand and Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, held at the general's request, was the first in a Western capital between the Polish leader and a Western head of state since Poland declared martial law in 1981. [A1:2.] A Polish priest was bound and beaten a second time this year, according to his mother, Teresa Zaleski. She said that the Rev. Tadeusz Zaleski, who was assaulted earlier this year because of his support for Solidarity, was attacked by three people who then ransacked his home. [A8:4.] Some U.S. anti-hijacking units may be deployed overseas. Administration officials said they were considering such action because of their failure to get specialists to the scene quickly enough to aid in last month's hijacking of an Egyptian airliner and in the takeover of the Achille Lauro cruise liner in October.

title: JAIL CRISIS ALMOST JAILS CHIEF OF TENNESSEE PRISON SYSTEM
description: The Tennessee prison chief was found in contempt of court Tuesday and sentenced to five days in jail, with all but five hours suspended, for not explaining why an inmate spent two and a half weeks too many behind bars.

title: DOLLAR SALES BY THE FED LARGER THAN SURMISED
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York intervened more heavily in foreign exchange markets in the latest three-month reporting period than at any time in the last five years, by selling $3.2 billion to help lower the currency's value, the bank said yesterday. The total of the Fed sales and the $7 billion sold by other central banks was larger than analysts had estimated.

title: People Express Has Europe Plans
description: People Express Airlines Inc., the Newark-based low-fare air carrier, wants to add service to Zurich or Frankfurt, Donald Burr, the company's chairman, said. Mr. Burr said he was trying to persuade Swiss aviation officials to drop objections to low-price flights.

title: Congress;   Inconsistency: Are You For It or Against?
description: In recent weeks both houses of Congress have passed legislation that would require a balanced budget within five years. But they have also adopted farm bills for the next four years that exceed the lawmakers' own budget targets by several billion dollars.

title: Columbia Honors 2 Scientists Today
description: Columbia University is awarding its 1985 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize to Dr. Mark Ptashne, a professor of biochemistry and molecular biology at Harvard University, and to Dr. Donald D. Brown, director of the department of embryology at the Carnegie Institute of Washington in Baltimore.

title: Springsteen Asks 3M to Keep Plant
description: The rock singer Bruce Springsteen and the country singer Willie Nelson asked executives of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company yesterday to reconsider a decision to shut down a plant in Mr. Springsteen's hometown that employs more than 350 people.

title: First Quaker Meeting House On L.I. Is Destroyed by Blaze
description: Fire destroyed a historic Quaker meeting house here today, officials said.

title: WIESEL TO BE HONORED FOR 3-VOLUME WORK
description: ''The man comes through every time,'' said Prof. Irving Abrahamson, editor of a new three-volume collection of the thoughts of Elie Wiesel, the author, teacher and memorialist of the Holocaust. ''Think of Bitburg. After he received the Congressional Gold Medal of Achievement last April from President Reagan, he appealed to the President to cancel his visit in May to the German cemetery because members of the S.S. were buried there. He said what he had to say before the world. When it counts, Elie Wiesel is not silent.''

title: JAZZ: WOODY HERMAN'S BAND
description: WOODY HERMAN, whose Thundering Herd is already wearing blue T-shirts proclaiming his 50th anniversary as a bandleader although that event will not occur until next November, has opened the two-week big band festival at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, with a four-night engagement, through tonight, that recaps four decades of his half-century in front of a big band and shows that he is still moving ahead.

title: Advertising;   Chesebrough-Pond's Moves Media Buying
description: You can bet there is weeping and gnashing of teeth these days at Ogilvy & Mather, the William Esty Company and Waring & LaRosa. And for good reason.

title: Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $250 million of 9 3/4 percent, five-year notes at a price of par, to yield 9.75 percent, or 59-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity. The notes, which are offered through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, are non-callable for three years, and are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

title: SELECTING A RUG BY A NAVAJO ARTIST
description: SINCE the time of the earliest settlers in the southwestern United States, Navajo weavings have been considered prized items. Eastern tourists traveling on the railroads encountered Navajo rugs in the curio shops. Later tourists drove through ''reservation country'' and bought rugs from the trading posts. In the 1940's many military men stationed in Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado saw and bought Navajo rugs and took them home. Such disparate personalities as Will Rogers and Frank Lloyd Wright have been Navajo aficionados. Today the soft colors and geometric designs of Navajo weavings have made them popular again as area rugs, bed coverings and wall hangings.

title: SINGAPORE STRAINED BY CRISIS IN STOCKS
description: The laissez-faire Government here is being forced to consider for the first time bailing out a private company for the sake of economic stability and its financial image.

title: HOUSE NARROWLY PASSES $480 BILLION CATCHALL BILL
description: The House of Representatives today narrowly approved a catchall appropriation bill that would cover most Government spending for the rest of the current fiscal year. The bill, approved by a vote of 212 to 208, now goes to the Senate, which is writing its own version.

title: THE NEW SKIPPER; JOHN MARLASN POINDEXTER
description: At a White House news conference today, Vice Admiral John M. Poindexter was asked if the press would ever see him again.

title: Lindbergh Leads
description: The fans who have voted so far for the starting teams in the National Hockey League's All-Star Game have given a wide lead to Pelle Lindbergh, who died in an auto accident a month ago, as the Wales Conference goaltender. The balloting began almost two weeks before the crash, but most of the votes for Lindbergh have been cast since his death, as a way of saluting his memory.

title: Brewers Get Green
description: David Green, the Giants' outfielder who was once a standout in the Milwaukee farm system, has been reacquired by the Brewers amid indications that his value may be slipping. As a minor-leaguer in 1980, Green was sent to St. Louis in the seven-player deal that brought Rollie Fingers, Pete Vuckovich and Ted Simmons to the Brewers.

title: HEAD OF DODD TO RETIRE
description: After more than 45 years in magazine and book publishing, Lewis W. Gillenson is retiring as president of Dodd, Mead & Company. The retirement, announced yesterday, will be effective Jan. 1.

title: FROM ISRAELI CARTOONIST, A CHATTY COMPUTER GAME
description: Some people think it was bound to happen sooner or later.

title: HANGERS FOR PLATES
description: HANGING plates for a decorative effect can be done in a number of ways. The Winterthur catalogue sells a brass plate hanger for $40, plus $5.95 for shipping. The 30-inch-long strip has two sets of adjustable hooks for plates from 5 1/2 inches to 12 1/2 inches in diameter, and there is a ring at the top for mounting the hanger to the wall. The plate hanger can be ordered from the Winterthur Museum and Gardens, Winterthur, Del. 19735; 800-556-4567 or 800-533-7723 in Virginia.

title: SOME WORKERS BAR STRIKE FOR A 2D TIME AT PRATT & WHITNEY
description: Hourly workers at Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group's plant here rejected a strike today for a second time, refusing to join workers at three other company plants already on strike.

title: Advertising;   Change at Raboy
description: Epstein Raboy Advertising, three years after the death of Mitchell Epstein, its chairman, has changed its name to Ephron, Raboy, Tsao & Kurnit to truly reflect the ownership and management: Erwin Ephron, executive vice president, marketing services; Richard Raboy, president and copywriter; Alex Tsao, executive vice president and creative director, and Shepard Kurnit, chairman.

title: OPERA: 'BIRTH OF A POET,' AVANT-GARDE
description: ''THE BIRTH OF THE POET,'' which opened in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House on Tuesday night and continues for seven performances in all through Sunday night as part of the Next Wave Festival, is a mess. It is a well-intentioned, neatly crafted mess, with often interesting contributions from the individual artists involved. But as a collaboration, it fails decisively, and was greeted by those who stuck it out to the end with a positive (negative?) barrage of boos. Given the half-century-old nose-thumbing Surrealist conventions of the staging, however, perhaps the evening's authors considered this antitriumph a triumph.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT JETS AFTER LEADING BY 6
description: The feature that made this game different from Ranger contests of late was that the Rangers did not need desperation, embarrassment, or Coach Ted Sator's dismay to goad them into scoring last night. They took a 6-0 lead midway through the game and went on to defeat the Winnipeg Jets, 7-4.

title: HOUSEHOLD CHORES: STILL NEVER DONE
description: DURING a cold November week in 1795, Martha Bullard of Hallowell, Me., listed among her household chores brewing beer, nursing a sick cow and scouring 35 skeins of wool in preparation for weaving. ''A woman's work is never done, as the song says,'' she wrote that week in her diary. ''And happy she whose strength holds out to the end of the rays.''

title: FACTORY ORDERS DROP 1.1%
description: Factory orders fell 1.1 percent in October, the third decline in the last four months and the biggest drop since July, the Government reported today.

title: BUSH-G.O.P. POLL STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: The first brouhaha among likely Republican Presidential candidates erupted today, provoked by a joint polling project of Vice President Bush and the national party on a public opinion poll.

title: NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL: THE PLUSES AND MINUSES
description: THE Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has long since established itself as the country's foremost forum for large-scale avant-garde performing art. It has given us (''us'' meaning both New York and, through its touring program, other cities) some genuine triumphs, including last season's revival of ''Einstein on the Beach'' and Pina Bausch's visits.

title: 2 SENATORS ASK A DELAY ON BUCKLEY NOMINATION
description: Connecticut's two Senators said today that they had asked the Senate leadership to hold up the nomination of James L. Buckley to the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE FIRST CHICAGO CORPORATION-Richard L. Thomas, president, bought and exercised option of 10,000 shares giving him directly a balance of 63,915 shares.

title: TEACHER IN SPACE FILES LESSON PLAN
description: Christa McAuliffe, who is scheduled to become the first teacher in space, today filed lesson plans that call for her to teach live from the space shuttle Challenger.

title: INVESTOR RISE TIED TO MUTUAL FUNDS
description: The number of individuals who invest in the stock market has risen 11 percent over the last two years, but the increase has come from individuals buying through mutual funds rather than trusting their own stock-picking abilities, according to a survey that the New York Stock Exchange released today at the annual meeting of the Securities Industry Association.

title: A Housing Plan of National Interest
description: If America has not altogether lost its zest for useful social experiment, Congress ought to leap at the modest mortgage subsidy fund for self-help housing programs inspired by Brooklyn's Nehemiah project. Representative Charles Schumer has prompted the House to write the program into its budget bill; the Senate now needs to accept the idea in conference.

title: L.B.J. Didn't Mandate Proportional Hiring
description: To the Editor:

title: 17 AIDS Bias Charges Filed In January Through October
description: Seventeen discrimination complaints involving AIDS were filed in the first 10 months of 1985 with the State Human Rights Division, compared with only six in the previous 15 months, officials said yesterday.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
BRENNAN FRIEND DENIES ANY PART IN BENCH BRIBES
description: The administrative judge of State Supreme Court in Queens testified yesterday that there was ''no truth'' to statements that he was involved in a conspiracy to accept bribes to fix criminal cases.

title: Long-Term Bond Prices Up
description: A late spurt of buying pushed prices of long-term Treasury bonds into the plus column yesterday. But the gains did not extend to the intermediate two- to five-year maturities or the bill market, both of which closed largely unchanged on the day.

title: Drinking for Freedom
description: It was billed as a ''drink-in'' and students were urged to ''protest prohibition at Columbia'' yesterday by drinking beer on the steps of Low Library, an activity forbidden by the university in the wake of this week's increase in the legal drinking age to 21 from 19.

title: Guatemala's History Augurs Ill for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Bozell & Jacobs Office Gets Commercial Trust
description: The Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey in Jersey City, which is the flagship bank of Commercial Bancshares of New Jersey, has decided to cast its lot with the Bozell & Jacobs Union, N.J., office.

title: That Cosmos Conflict
description: The management at the Cosmos Club is now suggesting that those members of the prestigious organization who are in favor of admitting women as members are subversives and should resign.

title: SUCCESSES SEEN IN EXPERIMENTAL CANCER THERAPY
description: An experimental therapy that turns white blood cells into roving cancer killers has shown evidence in a small number of tests on humans of destroying or significantly shrinking tumors even after the cancer has spread throughout the body, researchers at the National Cancer Institute report.

title: Shuttle Worker Dies in Fall
description: An iron worker fell to his death today while bolting a platform onto the 18th floor of a 285-foot launching building for the space shuttle. The body of the man, whose name was not immediately released, was transported to the Santa Barbara County coroner's office.

title: Sky Worker
description: Mychal Thompson of the Portland Trail Blazers, after meeting up for the first time with 7-foot-7-inch Manute Bol in Tuesday night's loss to Washington: ''I don't know why NASA spends all that money on the shuttle. All they've got to do is give Manute some tools and let him reach up and fix things.''

title: Money at the Opera
description: In a city obsessed with talk of a balanced budget, it is still rare to hear an official predict unequivocally that his operation will not spend more than it takes in. But that is what Martin Feinstein, general director of the Washington Opera, did yesterday.

title: MAVERICKS MAY FINALLY HAVE A BIG MAN
description: Since the Dallas Mavericks came into being as an expansion franchise for the 1981-82 season, management has searched endlessly for a better-than-average center. The Mavericks may have finally struck it rich with the acquisition from the Los Angeles Clippers 11 days ago of 7-foot-2-inch James Donaldson in a trade for 6-10 Kurt Nimphius.

title: Bridge: Argentine Teams Fared Well In the World Championships
description: The players from Argentina proved to be strong contenders in the recent world team championships in Sao Paulo, Brazil. In the qualifying stage their women's team was among the leaders throughout with good prospects of qualifying, but fell back on the final day to finish fifth in a field of eight.

title: NAVY EXTENDING DEADLINE ON BID TO BUILD 4 SUBS
description: The Navy today ''extended indefinitely'' a deadline for bids to build four nuclear-powered attack submarines in an effort to keep General Dynamics in the competition. A spokesman said that otherwise, the contract would have to be awarded on the basis of a bid from a single company, Newport News Shipbuilding.

title: BURROUGHS'S STRUGGLE AS NO. 2
description: W. Michael Blumenthal, chief executive of the Burroughs Corporation and former Secretary of the Treasury, is in the unenviable position of heading a $5 billion company that is considered small by its industry's standards. Burroughs is the nation's No. 2 manufacturer of mainframe computers. But its main competition is the International Business Machines Corporation, nearly 10 times its size.

title: MANHATTAN'S MANY DEPARTMENT STORES OFFER AN ARRAY OF GIFTS FOR THE HOME
description: WITH their many resources, Manhattan's department stores have the greatest variety of gifts for the home. Stores search worldwide for antique and contemporary items and, in addition, commission companies and craftsmen to design exclusive merchandise. As a boon for quick shopping, some stores also offer prewrapped gifts: A wide array of merchandise - glasses, decorative objects, kitchen accessories - is wrapped and ready to go.

title: Rochester Doctors Establish a Union
description: A group of Rochester doctors who say they are tired of being told how to practice medicine by bureaucrats announced today the creation of a statewide union for doctors and dentists.

title: Holders Approve Mesa Partnership
description: Stockholders of the Mesa Petroleum Company approved a proposal to reorganize the company into a master limited partnership valued at $850 million.

title: G.E. Realigns Management
description: In a reorganization aimed at reducing its layers of management, the General Electric Company said that it would discontinue its four-sector arrangement as of Jan. 1 and have its 21 businesses report directly to a four-man corporate executive office.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: CRAFTED by Indians, conceived by internationally known designers and displayed at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in New York, the furniture, clothing, shoes, toys and objects being exhibited through Feb. 23 in ''The Golden Eye'' hardly seem like the material of a trade show. The objects are not even for sale.

title: The Economy of the Homeless;   Children in a Sordid Sea
description: The Holland Hotel, in midtown New York, is used to shelter homeless welfare families at a cost to the nation, state and city of $60 per room per day. Some families stay for months, waiting for a permanent home. Some are engulfed by the surrounding sordidness, making the Holland like a kiddie park designed by Hogarth and the Marquis de Sade. Police cars stand at its door as dependably as limousines on Park Avenue. The tides of prostitution, drug and gun sales and thievery wash across its threshold. Particularly its children - sometimes predators, sometimes prey - need to be moved out.

title: PRODUCTION OPERATORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a net charge for the writedown on enhanced recovery project investments of $6,085,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After a net charge of $1,720,000 from the writeoff of acquisition costs in terminated projects.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Animal Trapping Is Disciplined and Regulated
description: To the Editor:

title: BLOCK RENEWS THE THREAT OF REAGAN FARM BILL VETO
description: The Reagan Administration threatened again today that President Reagan would veto the 1985 farm bill unless its cost to the Treasury was substantially cut.

title: 2 Pan Am Officers Get New Positions
description: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., a vice chairman at Pan American World Airways Inc., has been given the added position of chief operating officer in a reshuffling of top management at the loss-plagued carrier.

title: MITTERAND MEETS WITH JARUZELSKI
description: In a meeting with historical overtones and political risk, President Francois Mitterrand received the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, today.

title: C.A.O. DISPUTES RADIATION STUDY ON FIRST A-TESTS
description: An investigation by the General Accounting Office has challenged the contention of a Defense Department study that none of the 42,000 men participating at the first atomic tests after World War II were exposed to harmful levels of radiation.

title: LLOYD, NAVRATILOVA TO MEET FOR TITLE
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, the defending champion, scored a disputed 6-1, 7-6 triumph over Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany today to advance to the women's singles final of the Australian Open.

title: Amerada Hess Plans Charge
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said yesterday that it would take a special charge of about $500 million before taxes against its fourth-quarter earnings as a result of writing down the book value of some of its oceangoing fleet and marine transportation costs.

title: LEBANON TO FILE PROTEST WITH U.N. ON ISRAELI RAID
description: Lebanon decided today to file a complaint with the United Nations Security Council over a raid by Israeli troops in the south on Tuesday.

title: PENNSYLVANIA THEATER TO REBUILD
description: Efforts are under way to rebuild the historic Hedgerow Theater in Moylan, Pa., which was severely damaged by a fire early last Saturday. June Prager, the artistic director of the Hedgerow, said restoration of the theater would cost between $300,000 and $400,000 and would take about five months.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
CRADDOCK-TERRY SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $370,000 for the quarter and $1,020,000 for the year. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $3,950,000 for the quarter and $5,330,000 for the year which included a loss of $3,340,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: BISHOPS AT THE ROME SYNOD CLASH OVER ISSUING ITS PROPOSALS PUBLICLY
description: A major clash has broken out among Roman Catholic bishops at the extraordinary Synod here over the form and substance of the assembly's final documents.

title: BETSY ROSS SIGNATURE MAY GO ON DISPLAY
description: The only known surviving signature of Elizabeth Ross - better known as the flag-maker Betsy Ross - soon may be on public display in the house where she did her sewing.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Member of Graft Panel Is Named in Inquiry
description: A police inspector has resigned from a special commission studying police corruption after learning that his name had surfaced in a Federal investigation of graft, according to the acting police commissioner.

title: 3 IRANIANS , AT U.N., TELL OF TORTURE BY REVOLUTIONARY GUARDS
description: Three Iranians described today what they said was their torture at the hands of Revolutionary Guards and prison personnel in Iran.

title: PRIEST REPORTED BEATEN IN POLAND
description: A Polish priest assaulted earlier this year because of his support for Solidarity was bound and beaten again today by two men and a woman masquerading as medical officials, his mother said.

title: HERS
description: IF Raisa Gorbachev's high profile at the Geneva talks is any guide - reporters were agog at her charm, her clothes, her ability to take tea with Nancy Reagan without spilling the sugar - the Russians are about to adopt a Western custom as pernicious to Soviet women as Pepsi is to Soviet teeth. I mean, of course, our way of expecting wives to attend their husbands' business-related social gatherings.

title: CUOMO ORDERS LEGISLATURE TO MEET TUESDAY
description: Governor Cuomo, in an extraordinary action, tonight ordered members of the Legislature to return here Tuesday and convene a special session on issues ranging from low-cost housing to controls on rates for medical-malpractice insurance.

title: LOUISIANA GOVERNOR CLASHES WITH U.S. ATTORNEY
description: In a courtroom where the atmosphere during breaks seemed as socially animated as a country club before a tournament, a United States Attorney today continued his pursuit of the piece of evidence that might prove Gov. Edwin Edwards guilty of racketeering.

title: MUSIC: PHILADELPHIANS
description: ONE was sorry to read that Klaus Tennstedt had returned to Germany because of a throat ailment and therefore was unable to conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. But it was splendid to hear this marvelous, homegrown ensemble led, for once, by an American conductor, James DePreist, who is music director of the Oregon Symphony Orchestra and adviser to the Grand Rapids Symphony. Our major musical organizations remain defiantly (and provincially) Eurocentric - from the leaders they select to the repertory they perform. Not one of our ''Big Five'' orchestras is currently led by an American-born conductor, although there have been many fine potential candidates over the years.

title: Bathhouse Restrictions Voted in Los Angeles
description: Bathhouses must monitor sexual activities on their premises and expel any men engaging in oral or anal sex under rules voted Tuesday by the county Board of Supervisors.

title: THREE HORSES HURT AS AQUEDUCT SHIFTS
description: Three horses broke down in separate races at Aqueduct yesterday, and one of them, a 4-year-old colt named Magnetize, had to be humanely destroyed.

title: MILITARY JUDGE'S RULING MAY HALT COURT-MARTIAL IN SURGEON INQUIRY
description: A military judge ruled today that an admiral had improperly submitted charges to a general court-martial in the case of an officer involved in recruiting a heart surgeon who was later dismissed from Bethesda Naval Hospital.

title: NORTH AMERICAN SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: G.M. OFFERS NEW SALES INCENTIVE
description: The General Motors Corporation today announced a limited sales incentive plan, offering 8.5 percent financing on one line of compact cars.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After tax credits of $408,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,126,000, or 30 cents a share, for the 40 weeks. c-After tax credits of $374,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,009,000, or 27 cents a share, for the 9 months. d-After income of $663,000, or 17 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of changing to a different method of accounting for pre-opening expenses. The year-ago amounts have been restated to reflect an accounting change for pre-opening expenses.

title: CALENDAR: CRAFTS FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: Crafts in the Armory '85, 124 West 14th Street, 212-302-4904.

title: JAZZ: MONTY ALEXANDER
description: ALTHOUGH the pianist Monty Alexander was born and grew up in Kingston, Jamaica, and the Jamaican lilt that colors his speech can also be heard in his piano playing, he has not emphasized his Caribbean origins in his performances in recent years.

title: Clarence H. MacLachlan, 84, Ex-Publisher of Long Islander
description: Clarence H. MacLachlan, a former editor and publisher of The Long Islander, a weekly newspaper published in Huntington, L.I., died Friday at Huntington Hospital.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Joe Paterno's Morality Plays
description: The old philosopher of college football, Joe Paterno, had come to talk about Penn State's defense of its No. 1 ranking against Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl game. But his appearance yesterday on the 64th floor of Radio City, high atop the NBC studios, quickly created a series of morality plays concerning Miami's 58-7 rout of Notre Dame, the long proposed college football playoff, his grabbing of a Penn State player's facemask and Joe Yukica's ouster as the Dartmouth coach.

title: SENCER RESIGNS HEALTH POST TO WORK ON PROJECT IN OMAN
description: The City Health Commmissioner, Dr. David J. Sencer, has resigned to work in the Middle East on a health project in Oman, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: NEWSPAPER'S COVERAGE OF SEX-CRIME TRIALS SPLITS A TOWN IN WASHINGTON
description: A 16-year-old high school student who was raped here in March said later she felt she had been victimized three times -once by the rapist, once by testifying at the trial at which he was convicted and once in a 3,000-word account of the trial in The Shelton Mason County Journal.

title: U.S. TEAM PLANNING TRIP TO ISRAEL TO QUESTION OFFICIALS IN SPY CASE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that a team of Government officials would be likely to travel to Israel soon to question Israelis implicated in the espionage case against Jonathan Jay Pollard.

title: Army Reserves Called Ill Prepared for Battle
description: The Army's reserve units are ''much less ready'' than the active units to perform their missions, even though Army planning counts more and more on reserve troops, according to a report by the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Sued Firm in Chapter 11
description: The First American Mortgage Company, the Baltimore mortgage banking and brokerage firm that collapsed after a unit of the E. F. Hutton brokerage sued it on fraud charges, has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Isadore Smith Is Dead at 83; Gardening Expert and Author
description: Isadore L.L. Smith, a landscape architect, author and authority on early American gardens, died Saturday at the home of her sister in Tallahassee, Fla., after a long illness. She was 83 years old and lived in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Gas Leak in New Delhi Sends 340 to Hospitals
description: An acrid cloud of nontoxic gas leaked from a fertilizer plant and floated over a congested area of the New Delhi today, sending hundreds of residents fleeing in panic, the police said.

title: 'Boys of Winter' to Close
description: ''The Boys of Winter,'' the play by John Pielmeier about a company of marines on a secret mission in Vietnam, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Biltmore Theater. The drama, directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, will have run for nine regular performances and 31 previews.

title: BONNER EXAMINED BY ITALIAN DOCTOR
description: Pursued by Italian photographers, Yelena G. Bonner drove to this medieval Italian city today for the eye examination that brought her to Italy.

title: Polish Seaman Applies For Political Asylum
description: A Polish seaman applied for political asylum in the United States today, three days after he deserted his ship while it was unloading steel here.

title: SUPREME COURT UPHOLDS U.S. ON PROTECTING WETLAND AREAS
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously overturned a Federal appellate court decision that could have opened millions of acres of ecologically sensitive wetlands to commerical exploitation.

title: A SHOCKED BRITAIN LEARNS OF GROWING CHILD ABUSE
description: Jasmine Beckford was 4 years old when her stepfather beat her to death in July 1984.

title: Harold J. Lamm, 85, Founder Of Brokerage Firm, Is Dead
description: Harold J. Lamm, who founded a brokerage firm that for many years carried his name, died Monday at Greenwich Hospital after a long illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: NEW NATO OFFER ON TROOP CUT DUE
description: The United States and its allies will propose a compromise to the Soviet bloc on Thursday in an effort to achieve a breakthrough in the 12-year-old talks in Vienna on conventional force reductions, Administration officials said today.

title: Grateful Grads
description: For some time now, Crenshaw High School in Los Angeles has been turning out professional athletes by the bushel - people like Darryl Strawberry, Wendell Tyler, Ellis Valentine, Marques Johnson, Chris Brown. Crenshaw's kids get a lot out of the school's perennially strong sports program, and one recent episode suggests that they're not averse to giving something back.

title: Unlucky Horseshoes
description: Steve DeLine is a pretty fair place-kicker. As a junior at Colorado State this fall, he converted 12 of 19 field-goal attempts, including one for 60 yards. That was good enough to earn an honorable mention on the all-Western Athletic Conference team and start him thinking about how much better he might be as a senior next year.

title: ROSS, A J LOGISTICS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PLEASURES OF THE BELLE EPOQUE.

title: Union Weighs New Offer In Coast Grocery Strike
description: Negotiators for seven supermarket chains in southern California met with striking teamsters today after making their first new offer since the strike began a month ago.

title: Shuttle Crew Concludes Test For Mission to Start Dec. 18
description: With the space shuttle Atlantis back on Earth in good condition after a highly successful weeklong mission, the space shuttle Columbia's crew today ran through a smooth-running practice countdown to clear the way for a launching scheduled for Dec. 18. The shuttle is to land at the Kennedy Space Center here on Dec. 23.

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC NAMES PRESIDENT AS CHIEF ALSO
description: In 1972, when the United States Postal Service needed someone to run a $1 billion project to automate its bulk-mail delivery system, it picked Edgar S. Brower.

title: Super Feet
description: In last Sunday's game against New England, Rohn Stark of the Indianapolis Colts punted for the 300th time as a pro, the minimum necessary to be ranked among the National Football League's career leaders in average per attempt. Stark not only made the top 10, but zipped to the head of the class: Rohn Stark (300 punts)45.2 Sammy Baugh (338)45.1 Tommy Davis (511)44.7 Yale Lary (503)44.3 Horace Gillom (385)43.8 Jerry Norton (358)43.8 Don Chandler (660)43.5 Jerrel Wilson (1,072)43.0 Norm Van Brocklin (523)42.9 Danny Villanueva (488)42.8

title: WHITE OFFICERS SEEK MINORITY STATUS
description: Some police officers have asked to have their racial classification changed from white to black or Hispanic in an apparent effort to qualify for promotions to sergeant under a racial quota system, a police official said yesterday.

title: Truck Hits School Bus in Michigan and 4 Die
description: A tractor-trailer truck carrying a load of steel rammed the rear of a school bus carrying 23 children today, killing at least four people, the state police reported.

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
$200 Million Issue For State Schools
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $200 million of revenue bonds due 2005 on behalf of 13 colleges and universities in New York.

title: Woman Assaulted in Home
description: A woman was sexually assaulted and robbed by a man dressed as Santa Claus who had gained entry to the woman's home by telling her he was a firefighter, the police said today. An Eastchester police spokesman, Detective David Speidell, said the 24-year-old woman was home alone at about 4:45 P.M. Wednesday when the man knocked on her door and told her he was raising funds for the Eastchester Fire Department. When she let him inside, Detective Speidell said, the man drew a gun, attacked her, stole several pieces of jewelry and fled.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $145,000 for the latest first quarter and $42,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the disposal of SL Modern Creative and SL Electronics divisions and SL Homalite Corp. and also to reflect a 1985 pooling-of-interests. Share earnings reflect a 6 percent stock dividend paid Nov. 27, 1985.

title: PATH TO THE BASKET BECOMING PERILOUS
description: If recent trends continue, the so-called uncontested layup is destined to join the two-handed set shot as part of basketball memorabilia.

title: Bridge: New Team Event to Place A Premium on Flexibility
description: Three decades ago top-ranked teams tended to be flexible: partnerships could be switched to suit the convenience of the moment without loss of efficiency.

title: Third World's Biggest Problem Is Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Offering Call Warrants
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering, in the Eurobond market, 125,000 call warrants allowing the holder to buy a 10 percent issue of Merrill Lynch Euronotes due 1990, and 125,000 put warrants allowing the holder to sell 9 7/8 percent United States Treasury notes due 1990.

title: School Chief Gets Yonkers Extension
description: The Yonkers Board of Education has extended the contract of the Superintendent of Schools, Dr. Joan M. Raymond, through 1991 so she can oversee efforts to eliminate segregation in the public schools.

title: JETS ARE SUCCESSFUL WITH BIG TURNOVER
description: Perhaps it would not have been so bad staying with the Jets after all. Chuck Ramsey, the former punter, looked at the Jets' 9-4 record and their excellent chance of making the playoffs for the first time since the 1982 season and said he was surprised.

title: NEGOTIATORS AT IMPASSE ON BILL TO BALANCE BUDGET
description: House and Senate negotiators, who had hoped they were near agreement on a bill to mandate a balanced budget by 1991, hit a snag this evening.

title: NOVELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-After tax credits of $174,000 for the quarter and $374,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $225,000.

title: Harvard Professor Back After a Tenure Dispute
description: An expert on welfare state sociology has decided to return to the Harvard faculty more than five years after she accused the university of sex discrimination in denying her tenure.

title: ART: P.S. I SHOWS WORK OF 35 YOUNGER PAINTERS
description: Each year, the Institute for Art and Urban Resources, better known as P.S. 1, organizes an exhibition based on its National and International Studio Program. The current show, at the Clocktower, 108 Leonard Street, through Dec. 20, gave 23 American and 12 foreign artists a chance to display large work - up to 10 feet in any direction. It also provides a way of gauging the vitality of the program and considering the directions younger artists are following.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Association of Homes for the Aging, a Washington-based nonprofit organization, has appointed Ronald B. Stuckey treasurer.

title: V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis. The Knicks ended a 15-road-game losing streak that spanned two seasons when they beat the Pacers Nov. 27 at Market Square Arena. (Television -MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs. Houston Rockets, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television -WTBS, 10:35 P.M.) Colleges: St. John's vs. Columbia, 7 P.M., and Fairleigh Dickinson vs. Hofstra, 9 P.M., 11th annual Joe Lapchick Tournament, at St. John's University, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, Jamaica, opening round. St. John's has never lost in the first 10 years of its tournament. All 6,008 tickets are sold out for all St. John's home games. The consolation and final games are scheduled for tomorrow night at 7 and 9 P.M. (Television - Cablevision, Channel 22, 9 P.M. and 11 P.M., tapes of both games. Radio - WCBS 880, and WKCR-FM 89.9, 7 P.M.) Gonzaga vs. Howard, 6 P.M., and Iona vs. Lafayette, 8 P.M., eighth annual Iona Classic, at Mulcahy Center, New Rochelle, opening round. (Radio -WFAS-FM 103.9, 8 P.M.) Boxing Donald Curry vs. Milton McCrory, 12 rounds, for the undisputed world welterweight championship, at Las Vegas Hilton. Both are undefeated for this bout to unify the title for the first time since Sugar Ray Leonard retired in 1982 after eye surgery. Curry, from Fort Worth, is the International Boxing Federaton and World Boxing Association champion, with a 23-0 record and 18 knockouts. McCrory, the World Boxing Council champion from Detroit, is 27-0-1 with 22 knockouts.

title: BROADWAY
description: CHERYL CRAWFORD, whose producing credits over the last 55 years make the adjective ''illustrious'' seem an understatement, is returning to the New York theater scene next March, after an absence of almost a decade, as co-producer of ''So Long on Lonely Street,'' a play that caught her fancy down South last spring. The play is the first full-length work by Sandra Deer and is about an inheritance left by an unloved old woman - and those who are fighting for their share of it. A review in Variety last May when the production opened at Atlanta's Alliance Theater called it ''a funny and poignant comedy.''

title: ALICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FOR PUBLIC LIBRARY, DINNERS BY THE DOZEN
description: It is billed as ''The Night of One Hundred Dinners,'' but the actual count of festivities scheduled to benefit the New York Public Library next Tuesday evening is closer to 75 (some had to be canceled). Although most of the dinners will be given in New York City, other tables will be spread in a number of locations halfway around the world - from a condominium in Florham Park, N.J., to a rooftop attico in Venice, Italy. They include a Victorian greenhouse high above Manhattan, a Japanese teahouse in midtown and the New York City Transit Exhibit in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Advertising;   FCB Title Change
description: J. Hugh Duncan, 41, who as an executive vice president has been running the Foote, Cone & Belding office in Los Angeles, has now been retitled president of FCB/Southern California, which makes him additionally responsible for the FCB/Orange County office in Santa Ana, which deals with the Mazda account. He will continue to report, however, to the president of FCB/West.

title: Trio in Free Concert
description: The drummer Thurman Barker, the keyboardist Amina Claudine Myers and the saxophonist Joseph Jarman will play a free concert tonight at 8 o'clock in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, Third Avenue and Seventh Street (254-6374).

title: Weather Hinders Ski Circuit
description: The World Cup of skiing began in the Alps last weekend after a series of delays, cancellations and site changes because of lack of snow and warm temperatures.

title: PEALE PORTRAIT BRINGS RECORD PRICE AT AUCTION
description: Rembrandt Peale's sensitive, informal portrait of his younger brother, ''Rubens Peale With a Geranium'' (1801), sold for $4,070,000 to the National Gallery of Art yesterday, the highest price ever paid at auction for an American painting.

title: TERRORISM IN U.S. LOW AS ATTACKS ABROAD RISE
description: Even as terrorist attacks on Americans abroad increase, Federal law-enforcement officials say the incidence of such violence in the United States has remained low.

title: Brazil Reimbursement
description: The Brazilian Government decided Wednesday to reimburse foreign banks for 25 percent of the losses they suffered when three Brazilian banks failed last month. The National Economic Council made the decision in an afternoon meeting, two weeks after the central bank closed three private banks, including two of the country's largest. The decision calls for approximately $100 million in monetary reserves to reimburse international creditors who lent money to the Comind, Auxiliar and Maisonnave banks.

title: JMB REALTY TRUST CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including gains on the disposition of investment property of $934,098 for the latest year and $3,463,440 for the previous year.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Dec. 6, 1985 Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 12:38 P.M. today and set at 1:48 A.M. tomorrow.

title: HOUSE PANEL SUPPORTS DIVESTITURE BY SMITHSONIAN
description: A committee of the House of Representatives today voted to require the Smithsonian Institution to divest itself of any investments it has in companies that do business with South Africa as a protest against racial segregation there.

title: Smoking: A Partial Success Story
description: Two decades ago a landmark report from the Surgeon General declared that cigarette smoking was a major cause of lung cancer. That this warning did not fall on deaf ears is proved by a new report from the National Cancer Institute.

title: Peru Miners Seek Back Pay
description: The police forcibly dispersed 300 miners demonstrating outside the presidential palace today.

title: INQUIRY ON ATTACKS ON U.S. ARABS
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had ordered recent attacks on Arab-Americans to be investigated under the Civil Rights Act.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
'Suspicious' Judge Grants Bail in Case
description: A reputed member of the Luchese crime organization who was jailed for three months pending trial on racketeering charges was freed on $100,000 bail today by a Federal judge who said prosecutors did not prove the suspect was too dangerous to be released.

title: Frederick Boland, 81; Veteran Irish Diplomat
description: Frederick H. Boland, a former President of the United Nations General Assembly and one of Ireland's most distinguished diplomats, died Wednesday. He was 81.

title: 76ers Sign Carter
description: Butch Carter, a guard cut by the Knicks earlier this season, was signed by the Philadelphia 76ers to shore up the team's injury-riddled backcourt. To make room on the roster, the 76ers cut Voise Winter, a second-round draft pick. . . . David Thirdkill, who had been cut by the Celtics before the start of the season, was re-signed by Boston to replace Sly Williams, the former Knick, who was cut this week.

title: AUCTIONS
description: FIFTY years of works designed by major innovators - from Louis Comfort Tiffany's stained-glass lamps of 1900 through Piero Fornasetti's fool-the-eye furniture of the 1950's - will be auctioned tomorrow and next weekend at Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: Jackson Plans Latin March
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson will take part in a Christmas ''march for peace'' across Central America, mostly by bus, starting in Panama on Dec. 12, a Panamanian Government spokesman said today.

title: Loris Fortuna Dead; Italian Cabinet Aide
description: An Italian Cabinet minister, Loris Fortuna, who defied the Vatican by proposing and seeing through Italy's divorce law and sponsoring legislation making some abortions legal , died of cancer in a Rome hospital today, his family announced. He was 61 years old.

title: NEW '86 TOKEN PLANNED TO FOIL SLUG CHEATING
description: Will a new bus and subway token go into use next year? Definitely. In fact, it may happen twice. The Transit Authority plans to issue a new bull's-eye brass token with a round stainless-steel core about the end of February. The new token, however, is not connected with a possible fare increase.

title: GROUP BIDS FOR KAISER ALUMINUM
description: An investor group that owns 9.4 percent of the troubled Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation offered last night to buy the rest for a package of cash and securities that it valued at $20 a share, or nearly $800 million.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Panel Approves Funds For Police in 4 Nations
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, wary of human-rights abuses by security forces, today approved a restrictive one-year program to train civilian police in Central America to combat terrorism.

title: Italy's Prime Minister Receives Mrs. Bonner
description: Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, met with Prime Minister Bettino Craxi today and called the encounter an expression of respect for her husband.

title: Channel Will Buy Charter Oil Unit
description: Channel Refinery Inc., a company affiliated with Marc Rich, the commodities trader who is in Switzerland to avoid prosecution on tax evasion charges, has agreed to purchase the Charter Oil International Corporation.

title: HOWARD RODMAN
description: Howard Rodman, a motion picture and television writer, died Wednesday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles of complications following heart surgery. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. WILL RESUME REVIEWS OF ROLLS FOR DISABILITY AID
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would start again to review all 2.6 million people on the Social Security disability rolls to determine if they were entitled to continue receiving benefits.

title: WALL ST. VOLUME SURGES
description: In a session of wild price swings and frantic trading, the blue-chip-based Dow Jones industrial average made history yesterday by briefly piercing the 1,500 level before falling back abruptly. But many secondary shares moved higher, and, over all, more Big Board stocks rose than fell.

title: MAGNA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago results were restated to reflect accounting changes. The company is also listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. All results are in Canadian dollars.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Stocks Plunge In Singapore
description: Prices plunged in frantic selling on the Singapore and Kuala Lumpur stock exchanges today as trading reopened after a three-day halt.

title: A.T.&T. Denies Owing U.S. Taxes
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has asked the United States Tax Court to overturn a contention of the Internal Revenue Service that A.T.&T. owes back taxes of $102.2 million for 1976-77.

title: Cross-Endorsements Hurt the Party System
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Stranded Days On East River Island
description: A homeless man who dived into the East River near the United Nations on Thanksgiving Day was marooned for nearly a week on an uninhabited island, officials said yesterday.

title: Advertising;   Hasbro Aim: 2d Agency
description: HASBRO INC., which expects to emerge this year as the nation's leading toy and games company, is about to begin a search for a second ad agency.

title: IN FRANCE, STORM OVER POLE'S VISIT GOES ON
description: An unusual public disagreement between President Francois Mitterrand and his Prime Minister, Laurent Fabius, has created a political storm in France, with many commentators and officials asserting that the Socialist Government is deeply divided.

title: RABBIS GUILTY IN PROTEST ON SOVIET
description: Twenty-one rabbis were found guilty today of participating in illegal demonstrations last summer at the Soviet Embassy to protest treatment of Jews living in the Soviet Union.

title: 'BLEAK HOUSE,' BY CHARLES DICKENS
description: ALL too often, Charles Dickens is celebrated as the creator of colorful characters, almost always delightful even if they be villains. Sometimes lost in the process, though, is the fact that Dickens was a passionate reformer seriously caught up in an unending array of social causes. It is this side of his Victorian genius that is emphasized in the BBC's eight-part dramatization of ''Bleak House,'' one of the most excoriating treatises ever written on the subject of the law and lawyers. The series began on many Public Broadcasting Service stations last week, but Channel 13 will be showing the first two episodes together this Sunday beginning at 8 P.M.

title: Article 205754 -- No Title
description: A nearly two-century-old bottle of Chateau Lafite, believed to have been part of an order set aside for Thomas Jefferson, commanded $156,450 today at an auction here.

title: THE MARINES WANT YOU! JUST ASK SGT. COLOMBIA
description: Sgt. Charles Columbia, a Marine recruiter, had just landed at Hackensack High School and trained his sights on a target named Richard.

title: No Room at the Creche
description: The Community for Creative Non-Violence, a Washington group that seeks food and shelter for the poor, asked a Federal district judge yesterday to order the National Park Service to include in its 1985 Christmas pageant near the White House a Nativity scene that emphasizes the plight of the homeless.

title: 'Hodie' at St. Bart's
description: The St. Bartholomew's Choir and Choral Society, the New England Youth Orchestra and the resident choir of the American Boychoir School at Princeton, N.J., will perform Vaughan Williams's ''Hodie'' at St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 East 50th Street, at Park Avenue, Sunday afternoon at 4 o'clock.

title: SCULPTURE: TWO SHOWS OF SUGARMAN WORKS
description: GEORGE SUGARMAN began his career sedately enough under the influence of Cubism. Reproductions in the catalogue of the sculptor's 1982 retrospective, which was staged by the Joslyn Art Museum of Omaha, suggest an affinity between his wood carvings of the mid-1950's and those of Raoul Hague.

title: Advertising;   Desta Auto Agency
description: Desta of America (East), which will be the distributor of the Desta automobile that is being imported by Automotive Imports and Marketing of Phoenix, has selected Goldsmith & Ansorge of Red Bank, N.J., as its agency for advertising and public relations. The car, with models that will sell for as little as $4,990, is being put together in Greece with parts from Ford of Europe. But Desta headquarters are in West Germany.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE six-month-old Triplets, on Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, calls itself ''the small plate restaurant'' because dinner portions are smaller than traditional entrees yet larger than appetizers. ''This way you can have three entrees instead of one,'' our waiter explained.

title: SOVIET AFFIRMS THAT SPOUSES WILL GO
description: The Soviet Union has told nine separated family members of American citizens that they may leave the country for the United States, the State Department said today.

title: POLISH PRESS HAILS JARUZELSKI PARIS TRIP AS TRIUMPH
description: While Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's reception at Elysee Palace on Wednesday continued to shake France's governing Socialists, his meeting with President Francois Mitterrand was being hailed by the official press here as a major triumph for the Polish leader and his proclaimed policies of normalization.

title: Ted Turner, Peacemaker
description: Perhaps we all have been underestimating our homegrown sports moguls up to now. People used to titter when Donald Trump said he wanted to broker a nuclear-arms reduction, but since Ted Turner persuaded the Soviet Union to stage a jamboree called the Goodwill Games in Moscow next summer - with 129 hours to be shown on a network with which Turner has some slight affiliation - can detente be far behind?

title: TEXACO TELLS COURT IT'S FIGHTING FOR LIFE
description: Freshly armed with nationally known legal talent, Texaco Inc. pleaded for its life today before a Texas state judge who must decide whether to uphold a $10.53 billion jury award against the company.

title: D-DAY MERCHANT MARINERS WIN VETERAN'S STATUS
description: The Defense Department has granted veteran's status to about 1,000 merchant seamen who participated in the Allied invasion of Normandy, the Pentagon announced today.

title: KARPOV ASKS FOR CHESS TITLE REMATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov, who lost his world chess title to Gary Kasparov on Nov. 9, has asked for a rematch, the official news agency Tass said today.

title: IMPORTS BILL ILLUSTRATES DIFFICULTY OF PROTECTING JOBS
description: The import bill sent to President Reagan by the House this week illustrates the difficulties of trying to stem American job losses by reducing competition from foreign goods.

title: U.S. Agencies Will Buy Larger Home Mortgages
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and the Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday announced increases of 15.6 percent in the maximum size of one- to four-family home mortgages that they may buy.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes charges of $50,000 for the quarter and $177,800 for the year from the settlement of litigation. The results include pre-tax gains of $1,175,000 for the latest year and $56,000 for the earlier period related to land sales.

title: RESTAURANT
description: CHIKUBU is one of those inconspicuous midtown Japanese restaurants that I have passed dozens of times without paying much notice. Only when some Western friends who have kept it to themselves for years decided to break their code of silence, did I venture inside. First impressions were promising - at a long table in one of the two dining rooms were six tipsy Japanese businessmen, their silk ties askew and normally rigid expressions softened by saki. Judging by the gusto with which they were eating and drinking, I had high hopes.

title: Leakers Beware
description: Why are press associations hesitating to join the American Civil Liberties Union in appealing the two-year prison sentence of Samuel Loring Morison for leaking classified photos to Jane's Defense Weekly, a British magazine? This may be the clearest Government challenge to freedom of the press since the Pentagon Papers case in 1971.

title: How About an Ascot?
description: Jeremiah P. Shea, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of Delaware, may be in the market for one of those old-fashioned hand-tied bow ties that some men manage to get under the collars of pleated shirts when they don dinner-jackets.

title: U.S. Likely to Offer Itself For Afghan Peace Role
description: The United States is likely to formally advise the United Nations that it is willing to act as a guarantor of an Afghan peace settlement that includes a Soviet withdrawal, United States officials said today.

title: Maxxam Buys 60% Of Pacific Lumber
description: Maxxam Group Inc., led by the Houston investor Charles E. Hurwitz, announced that it had paid for the 13.1 million shares, or about 60 percent, of the Pacific Lumber Company that were tendered pursuant to its tender offer of $40 a share.

title: Leafs Send Flyers to Third Loss in Row
description: Wes Courtnall scored the first of his two goals in Toronto's four-goal outburst in the second period tonight as the Maple Leafs defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-3.

title: SCHOLARS BROADEN U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD
description: American and Soviet scholars signed an exchange agreement here today that they said would significantly expand academic cooperation.

title: Jazz: Piano, Cedar Walton
description: WIT, daring, elegance and a touch of the blues - the pianist Cedar Walton's trio can be counted on for those qualities through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street. With Ron Carter on bass and Billy Higgins on drums, the trio gives its own compositions and selected standards a treatment that's filled with rhythmic byplay and breezy harmonic sleight-of-hand.

title: A PUZZLING STAKE IN VIACOM
description: Wall Street is wondering what the J.M.B. Realty Company is up to.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO THE NEEDIEST SEEK TO SHARE LIFE'S BLESSINGS
description: The heartwarming traditions of the holiday season evoke a sense of well-being for many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who would like to share with others less fortunate.

title: Curb on Japan Is Postponed
description: President Reagan blocked immediate trade retaliation against Japan earlier this week after receiving a personal plea from Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising Column yesterday incorrectly identified the company marketing DeKuyper Cordials. It is the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation.

title: Trade Stirs Concern In Quebec
description: Robert Bourassa, the Premier-elect of Quebec, said Wednesday that he is nervous about a Canadian free trade pact with the United States.

title: Two West Bank Arabs Found Slain in Israel
description: The bodies of two Arabs who had been slain were found by Israeli police today in an orchard 15 miles west of here.

title: BEGGS, IN SPEECH TO NASA AIDES, HITS BACK
description: James M. Beggs, Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said today that ''outrageous'' and ''ridiculous'' charges against him were part of a growing adversarial climate that was threatening to make it ''almost impossible'' for the space and military industries to do their jobs.

title: Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Toronto-based farm equipment maker, said that it was ''actively discussing a comprehensive financial and operational restructuring plan'' with its lenders. The company said it was ''cautiously hopeful'' the restructuring could be completed in early 1986, but added that ''important parts of the plan have not yet been accepted.''

title: Boston Symphony
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Seiji Ozawa, will offer a program that includes the Sibelius Violin Concerto with Viktoria Mullova as soloist and excerpts from Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet'' at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8 o'clock. Tickets are $12 to $25. Information: (212) 874-2424.

title: Topics;   Blame-Mongers Self-Injuries
description: Blaming the victims is an old and dishonorable habit of terrorists. This week the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Polish Government gave fresh evidence of this cynicism in action.

title: British Committee Backs Tunnel Plan for Channel
description: Members of Parliament recommended tonight that Britain and France choose a tunnel rather than a bridge to link their countries across the English Channel.

title: Small Quake in Arkansas
description: A light earthquake, 3.9 on the Richter scale of ground motion, occurred today in northeast Arkansas, the United States Geological Survey said. The epicenter was about five miles southwest of Blytheville, Ark., near the southern end of the New Madrid Seismic Zone, an area in southeast Missouri and northeast Arkansas.

title: LASER IS SAID TO AID EYE AILMENT IN DIABETICS
description: A laser treatment that stops leakage in the retina of the eye can cut by half a type of vision loss that afflicts hundreds of thousands of diabetics, researchers said today.

title: TESDATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $362,000 for the quarter and $438,000 for the 9 months.

title: Benny Goodman at Yale
description: The clarinetist Benny Goodman will lead his new big band Sunday at 8 P.M. at Yale University's Woolsey Hall, Grove and College Streets, in New Haven.

title: Working Profile: Margaret D. Tutwiler;   The Political Key to the Treasury
description: Margaret D. Tutwiler would have you believe she moves her lips to read the hundred or so pages she gets each day of newspaper clippings on economic matters. She says she tells visiting chairmen of boards, ''I haven't a clue'' about their business or some of the provisions of the tax laws. She says she tells them, ''Talk to me like I'm a first-grader.''

title: LABATT, JOHN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 10
description: b-Including a tax credit of $450,000. c-Net losses.

title: A Job Well Done
description: For apprehending a rape suspect in Riverside Park last February, Police Officer Felecia V. Duke of the 26th Precinct in Manhattan has been named Police Officer of the Year by the Northeast Association of Police Women.

title: Serkin Recital Canceled
description: The pianist Rudolf Serkin's Carnegie Hall recital on Tuesday has been canceled because of Mr. Serkin's ''complete exhaustion,'' Lois Cohn, a concert hall spokesman, announced yesterday. The recital will be rescheduled for early next year and no refunds will be made until the new date is announced, she said.

title: Market Place;   Investors Told To Stay Alert
description: ALTHOUGH the stock market as a whole continues to penetrate new record levels, several analysts believe there are some industries and companies that now appear particularly vulnerable and due for correction.

title: U.S. Spending on Radiation Dangers Is Skewed
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Mirror In Paper Deal
description: The Times Mirror Company said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell an 80 percent interest in its Publishers Paper Company subsidiary to the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation of Alton, Ill., for about $150 million.

title: CADETS' COACH SAYS LONG DELAY WILL HELP NAVY
description: The late date for the Army-Navy game tomorrow in Philadelphia, a date that was dictated by CBS-TV, means three weeks have passed since the teams last played games Nov. 16.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS CUBAN ADVISERS ENGAGE IN COMBAT IN NICARAGUA
description: The State Department's top Latin America official said today that Cuban military advisers had become increasingly involved in combat operations against rebel forces in Nicaragua.

title: Yankee Deal for Dawson Off
description: The Yankees, who often do not announce moves they are making, announced yesterday a move they are not making. They said they have broken off talks with the Montreal Expos on a proposed trade in which they would have obtained Andre Dawson.

title: PANEL URGES SPECIAL COUNSEL IN DISPUTE OVER E.P.A. FILES
description: The House Judiciary Committee today released a 1,200-page report accusing former Justice Department lawyers of misconduct in the withholding of Environmental Protection Agency files from Congress in 1983.

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: Dallek Inc., an office furniture marketer, and Insurance Center, a division of Continental Insurance, to Drossman, Lehman, Marino.

title: Bloch and Bernstein
description: The Heritage Chamber Orchestra, founded in 1982 to offer music of Jewish content, will play music by Ernest Bloch, Leonard Bernstein and Paul Ben-Haim Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock at Alice Tully Hall.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EBONY, 40, VIEWED AS MORE THAN A MAGAZINE
description: Ebony magazine was born two years before blacks were allowed to play major league baseball, three years before President Truman's executive order to integrate the military, nine years before the Supreme Court outlawed segregation in public schools and 10 years before a Southern preacher named Martin Luther King Jr. came onto the civil rights scene.

title: FILM: 'RUNAWAY TRAIN,' FROM KONCHALOVSKY
description: AKIRA KUROSAWA wrote an early screenplay for ''Runaway Train,'' but he was probably not responsible for the film's references to Michael Jackson and Wayne Newton, or for the coarseness of a lot of its dialogue. Mr. Kurosawa's contribution, to a film whose screenplay is credited to Djordje Milicevic, Paul Zindel and Edward Bunker, can apparently be found in the crude energy and bravado of its central metaphor.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After special charges and writeoffs of $1,066,000 for the quarter and year.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THANKSGIVING was a new memory; the Christmas frenzy was just beginning to build, but summer was on the minds - and in the conversations - of the guests who congregated in Leonard Bernstein's apartment this week. The occasion was a cocktail-hour fund-raiser for the Tanglewood Music Center, the summer-school program for young musicians and composers in the Berkshires.

title: SHANLEY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CREATIVE COMPUTER APPLICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday on women and housework misstated a finding by Joann Vanek. She found that women without jobs outside the home spend more than 50 hours a week on housework; the others spend half that.

title: CRITICS SAY NEWLY FOUND POEM ISN'T SHAKESPEARE
description: ''Too bard to be true,'' The Economist magazine said this week, joining the ranks of skeptics who feel the recently discovered love lyric attributed to William Shakespeare is too awful to be genuine.

title: Anne Baxter Condition Is Reported as Critical
description: The actress Anne Baxter was reported in critical condition yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after having a stroke Wednesday. Miss Baxter, who is 62 years old, was walking on Madison Avenue when she became ill, according to Joyce Wagner, her spokesman.

title: AM Picks New President
description: AM International Inc., the Chicago business graphics equipment maker that emerged from bankruptcy reorganization last year, announced yesterday that Jerry O. Williams is its new president and chief operating officer.

title: U.S. EXPECTED TO REPORT CREATION OF 10 MILLION NEW JOBS SINCE '82
description: The Government is expected to report tomorrow that the United States has created 10 million new jobs since the current business expansion began in December 1982, a performance that has surpassed nearly all other industrial countries.

title: Upgrade School Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $447,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $357,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,657,000 and a loss for a provision on the disposal of discontinued operations of $9.3 million. Results are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 14 and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: REPORT TO CONGRESS SAYS MANILA WASTED U.S. MONEY
description: A preliminary Congressional report has found that more than $100 million in American military assistance to the Philippines has been wastefully spent and that the United States is limited in its ability to trace or influence how the funds are used, according to sources familiar with the report.

title: FOES OF MARCOS UNITE IN SUPPORT OF CORAZON AQUINO FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Opposition leaders said today that they had agreed to unite behind a single candidate to oppose President Ferdinand E. Marcos in elections scheduled for next year, and they indicated that the nominee would be Corazon C. Aquino, the widow of the assassinated opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. The opposition figures made it clear that Salvador H. Laurel, a former senator who had been the first opposition leader to announce his candidacy for President, had accepted the offer of the vice presidential spot on a ticket headed by Mrs. Aquino.

title: LOUIS E. ROUSSO
description: Louis E. Rousso, former chairman of the board of Russ Togs Inc., a New York sportswear company, died of complications after hip surgery Wednesday at the Jack Weiler Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. He was 87 years old and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: Weinberger Expects the U.S. To Have Laser Arms in 90's
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States might have the ability to deploy an antimissile shield using ground-based laser weapons as early as the mid-1990's.

title: Let the Stewart Jury's Verdict Close the Case
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1985
description: Markets

title: SIGNS POINT TO DISCORD IN TALKS ON FARM BILL
description: A conference committee's effort to resolve differences between the House and Senate versions of the 1985 farm bill got under way today amid promises from both sides to seek compromises.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: The 1985 results reflect operations for two months of its recently acquired Ridgeway Clock Co. unit.

title: BRONX JUDGE DIES AND 2D IS INJURED IN AUTO CRASH
description: Acting Supreme Court Justice Archie A. Gorfinkel of the Bronx was killed yesterday and a fellow judge was injured when a car driven by Justice Gorfinkel ran off the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Rockland County, hit a bridge abutment, bounced off a guard rail and rolled down an embankment to another highway 50 feet below, the New York state police said.

title: U.S., JOINING JORDAN, FAVORS A SYRIAN ROLE IN PEACE TALKS
description: The United States said today that it hoped Syria would join with Jordan and Israel in reviving Middle East peace talks.

title: SPECIAL SESSION IN ALBANY: POLITICAL MANEUVERING
description: When Governor Cuomo ordered on Wednesday that state lawmakers return to take up his legislative program, he was acting in the aftermath of a breakdown in the legislative process that both Democrats and Republicans say is a result of early maneuvering for the 1986 election.

title: MCCALLUM RUNS IN HIS FINALE AS MIDSHIPMAN
description: The ''Beat Army'' bedsheet banners are out at Bancroft Hall at the Naval Academy because this is Army-Navy week.

title: DANCE: AILEY TRIBUTE TO CHARLIE PARKER
description: ALVIN AILEY'S long-awaited tribute to the late jazz great Charlie Parker, ''For Bird -With Love,'' had its New York premiere at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's gala opening Wednesday night. It was worth the wait.

title: WINNIE MANDELA, 'EXTREMELY TIED,' ENTERS CLINIC
description: Winnie Mandela was admitted to a Johannesburg clinic Wednesday night and a clinic spokesman said today that she was ''extremely tired'' but not suffering from a serious condition.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE process of finding a star for ''Young Sherlock Holmes'' wasn't quite as laborious as Holmesian detective work, but it wasn't easy. Several thousand young actors - the exact number varies, depending upon whom you ask - were auditioned for the film's leading roles, and as the ranks of potential Holmeses and Watsons thinned, the candidates were auditioned in pairs. Nicholas Rowe, the 19-year-old British actor who eventually landed the title role, says that he was under consideration for about three months last year. He read with two Watsons before his teamwork with 15-year-old Alan Cox won both of them starring roles.

title: A TRIP TO THE COUNTRY TO BRING HOME A TREE
description: ONCE again it's time to head for the country to pick and cut your own Christmas tree instead of going down the street to the nearest store that sells trees already cut.

title: TENNIS LADY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Net losses.

title: REZONING FOR RESIDENTIAL: EAST SIDE BUILDER'S TACTIC
description: In the active Manhattan construction market of the mid-1980's, many builders have found and developed sites on the East Side. But only a handful risked the purchase of parcels in the East 30's, 60's or 70's that are zoned for manufacturing use and then won a zoning change for residential construction.

title: PISTONS RALLY PAST NETS
description: Isiah Thomas scored 17 of his game-high 28 points in the second half tonight, leading the Detroit Pistons to a 113-111 victory over the Nets.

title: CAPT CRAB'S TAKE-A-WAY reports earnings for Year to Aug 25
description: b-Includes a charge of about $1 million for fourth quarter adjustments, writeoffs and reserves.

title: Plan for Dumping Radon Soil Barred
description: A New Jersey proposal to dump 7,200 tons of radon-contaminated soil from Essex County at a Federal site has been barred by the Federal Energy Secretary, John S. Herrington. He said the state should find a suitable dump for the soil within its borders.

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $238,598 for the quarter and 6 months from the termination of a pension plan.

title: 'STAR WARS' GAIN SEEN WITH ALLIES
description: Two top Defense Department officials responsible for the Strategic Defense Initiative said today that European governments and corporations were growing more receptive to participation in research for the plan popularly known as ''Star Wars.'' But the officials cautioned that the work would be subject to a number of constraints by the United States Government.

title: AIR SAFETY UNIT WANTS CHANGES IN BOEING 747'S
