description: The National Transportation Safety Board yesterday recommended a series of changes for Boeing 747 jetliners to prevent structural breaks like those most experts believe led to the crash of a Japan Air Lines 747 in August.

title: Backlog Grows to 80 Ships At Site of Crash on Seaway
description: The St. Lawrence Seaway closed for more than 13 hours overnight while tugboats removed an Indian freighter that crashed into a bridge last week, officials said today.

title: Not-So-Vital Statistics on John G. Rowland
description: Representative John G. Rowland is not just another insurance-salesman-turned-lawmaker. At age 28, he is the youngest Congressman on Capitol Hill. Here are a some insights into the Connecticut Republican, as supplied by him:

title: THIRD WORLD A NEW FORCE AT THE SYNOD
description: One after another they have risen to speak, these representatives of Roman Catholic churches from countries like Malawi and the Sudan, Laos and Bangladesh.

title: LAWSUITS FILED IN OREGON ASK SHARE OF COMMUNE'S ASSETS
description: The dissolution of a commune founded in eastern Oregon by an Indian guru took a new turn today as two lawsuits were filed seeking a share of its assets.

title: Advertising;   CBS Magazines Restructures at Top
description: CBS Magazines yesterday announced a restructuring that follows the early retirement of three top executives and results in the mutually agreed upon resignation of a fourth.

title: Advertising;   Lincoln-Mercury Gets Minority Agency
description: Unlike the Ford division, its sister operation in the Ford Motor Company, Lincoln-Mercury has not had an independent specialty agency to do advertising for minority markets.

title: RESHAPING SOUTH FERRY: 8 PLANS BEFORE THE CITY
description: With the ink barely dry on the $455 million contract to replace the New York Coliseum with a massive office and apartment building, city officials are now evaluating another potential private development on an even more spectacular piece of public land: a 1.5-million-square-foot tower to go atop or beside the Staten Island Ferry terminal at the very tip of Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch in some editions yesterday on the resignation of Robert C. McFarlane as national security adviser incorrectly described his Marine Corps rank. He is a retired lieutenant colonel.

title: Physician Is Abducted And Released Unhurt
description: A Manhattan physician was abducted by three robbers as he sat in his car in front of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center at 8:30 A.M. on Wednesday, the police reported.

title: DEFIANCE PRECISION PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: Year-ago results are pro forma because the company went public on Oct. 17, 1985.

title: BLUES OR A BIG BAND, LISTENER'S CHOICE
description: THE blues is something more than a set of songs, a collection of licks or a musical form. To many of the greatest American musicians, it is a language - rich yet casual, suggestive yet direct. It can be high-flown or earthy, terse or rambling; it can be part of a vocabulary or a world in itself. And as with American English, the blues has all sorts of regional accents and personalized styles.

title: WAREHOUSE CLUB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEICHTER CITES 'ILLEGAL' ELECTION GIFTS
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter, who has criticized large contributions by business executives to Mayor Koch and other Board of Estimate members, yesterday released a list of politicians he said had received ''illegal'' campaign contributions.

title: PAUL F. CRUIKSHANK
description: Paul Fessenden Cruikshank, the headmaster of the Taft School in Watertown, Conn., for 27 years, died Wednesday at a nursing facility in Bloomfield, Conn. He was 86 years old and a resident of Middletown, Conn.

title: THEATER: 'A LIE OF THE MIND,' BY SAM SHEPARD
description: LATE in Act I in Sam Shepard's new three-act, four-hour play, ''A Lie of the Mind,'' a man named Jake (Harvey Keitel) stands at the edge of the California bedroom he grew up in, peering into an inky night. Behind Jake, picked out by a spotlight on his bed, is a small leather box containing the ashes of his father, an alcoholic Air Force pilot who had deserted his family. Ahead of Jake, far off in the mysterious distance and illuminated only by a high green moon, is a woman whose nude back beckons with the mesmerizing lure of a distant, flickering neon sign along a desolate Western highway. The woman is Jake's wife, Beth (Amanda Plummer), and she is literally a highway away, back at her own childhood home in Montana.

title: ERDMAN RETROSPECTIVE: 4 DECADES OF MOVEMENT
description: Jean Erdman is looking back on 43 years of choreography. This weekend, the Theater of the Open Eye, her mixed-media company, is offering a ''Jean Erdman Retrospective 1942-1985'' at Hunter College Playhouse, 695 Park Avenue, at 67th Street. Twelve works - ranging from her first major solo to two dances created last year - will be offered on two different programs. Individual pieces may vary stylistically, yet all spring from Miss Erdman's conviction that dance expresses shades of feeling that cannot be put into words.

title: Summit Interpreters Deserve Recognition
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. IS ACCUSED OF VIOLATING LAW
description: In a new attack on air pollution and acid rain, seven states, including New York and Connecticut, and four environmental groups filed a suit in New York yesterday charging the Environmental Protection Agency with violating the Clean Air Act.

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday A LITERARY READING Robertson Davies, the Canadian novelist, essayist and playwright, will appear tonight at the Writer's Voice, a literary series at the West Side Y.M.C.A. Arts Center. Mr. Davies is the author of more than two dozen books, including the Deptford Trilogy, which consists of ''Fifth Business,'' ''The Manticore'' and ''World of Wonders.'' His latest book, ''What's Bred in the Bone,'' has just been published. Mr. Davies will read from his works, talk about his writing, then answer questions from the audience. The program will be followed by a wine reception and sale of Mr. Davies's works. It all begins at 8 P.M. at 5 West 63d Street. Tickets are $8. Information: 787-6557.

title: Primus, Pares and Poindexter
description: Among the big fish who make waves in Washington, one of the biggest-looking is the national security adviser. What a ring of power the very title bears. The incumbent has instant access to the President, even at 3 in the morning. He sits astride the National Security Council and he seems, especially after the commanding way Henry Kissinger filled the job for Richard Nixon, the equal, or rival, of the Secretary of State.

title: Lloyd Gains Final
description: For the 67th time, Chris Evert Lloyd will be facing Martina Navratilova, and the Australian Open singles championship and the year's No. 1 ranking in women's tennis are at stake.

title: 1,500 Handbags Seized in L.I. Raid
description: Customs agents arrested six people and confiscated 1,500 counterfeit designer handbags at two factories in Bohemia, L.I., yesterday, according to a Customs Service spokesman.

title: Top of the Line
description: The University of Oklahoma nose guard, Tony Casillas, was named last night as the winner of the Lombardi Award, which annually goes to the player considered the nation's top collegiate lineman. Casillas, a 6-foot-3-inch, 280-pound senior from Tulsa, had 35 tackles and two quarterback sacks in seven games this year for the Sooners.

title: U.S. Spending on Radiation Dangers Is Skewed
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out Guide: Large Groups or Parties
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: Iraq Says Its Warplanes Had Busy Day Over Iran
description: Iraq said its planes flew 120 sorties against Iranian positions on the south-central war front today amid reports from both sides that Iran was preparing to mount a new ground offensive.

title: Jazz Artists in Solos
description: The pianists Danny Mixon, Kirk Lightsey, Carol Britto, Stanley Cowell, Larry Willis and Bob Neloms will play solos tonight at the Burgundy Cafe, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, at 82d Street (212-787-8300). There is a $10 cover charge.

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $170,000.

title: Southern Bell
description: The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company is offering $300 million of 10 3/4 percent debentures, due in 2025, at a price of 99.05 to yield 10.885 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The yield on the debentures, which are callable after five years and rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P., was about seven-tenths of a percetage point higher than for Treasury bonds due in 2012. Proceeds will be used to finance the redemption of $300 million of 12 7/8 percent debentures due in 2020.

title: Interior Nominee Is Criticized
description: President Reagan's nominee to a top Interior Department post was accused in a Senate confirmation hearing Wednesday of trying ''to gut the Federal strip-mining laws.''

title: MONEY DATA CITED
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell modestly yesterday as traders were made uneasy by rapid growth in the nation's basic money supply and an intense debate among economists about the direction of interest rates.

title: Gambino Witness Cross-Examined
description: A defense lawyer yesterday began cross-examining Dominick Montiglio, a key witness in the trial of the reputed head of the Gambino crime organization, Paul Castellano, and nine others on car theft and murder conspiracy charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: NATIONAL REVIEW, NOW 30, TAKES A BOW AT PLAZA
description: American conservatism celebrated itself last night with chicken pot pie and presidential accolades.

title: Gale Shuts Some Gulf Ports
description: A southerly gale closed several ports in the Persian Gulf today, knocked over trees and smothered some areas in sandstorms. Winds of 35 to 40 miles an hour were reported here and in Qatar.

title: U.S.-E.E.C. STEEL PACT IS CLEARED BY BRITAIN
description: The European Economic Community said today that Britain had lifted its objections to a proposed accord limiting the community's steel exports to the United States, clearing the way for the four-year pact to be approved by the Europeans.

title: DETECTOR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
K-V PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MACHINISTS PLAN 'SPOT' PICKETING IN EAST HARTFORD
description: Union machinists, who failed Wednesday for the second time to approve a strike at the main factory of Pratt & Whitney here, said today that their strike would continue at the company's three other plants in Connecticut.

title: Arts Academy Elects Diebenkorn, Salisbury
description: The American Academy of Arts and Letters has elected two new members, Richard Diebenkorn, painter, and Harrison E. Salisbury, journalist-historian, it was announced yesterday by Gunther Schuller, secretary of the organization.

title: BRIEFS
description: Biotech Research Laboratories Inc., Rockville, Md., said it had begun clinical evaluation of a new blood testing kit for acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: A South African Fights From Exile
description: In early November, Anthony Heard, the editor of The Cape Times, a South African newspaper, met with Oliver Tambo, the 68-year-old leader of the outlawed African National Congress, living in exile in north London. Mr. Tambo is what is known as a ''banned'' person, who may not, among other things, be quoted in South Africa, and Mr. Heard was arrested several days after the interview appeared. He faces the possibility of a three-year sentence. What follows is adapted from a longer text published Nov. 4 in The Cape Times.

title: SEAMAN FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
IPC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring net charge of $4,664,800 from the company's withdrawal from the business of selling PABX installations to the general business community. c-Net income.

title: Advertising;   People
description: Lawrence Dexheimer has been named chief operating officer of Ally & Gargano.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,819,000. c-After a tax credit of $1,781,000 and a special credit of $29,000.

title: Ginsberg Gets Visa
description: Soviet authorities, reversing an earlier decision, have extended the visit of Allen Ginsberg, the American poet, who came to the Soviet Union last month with a delegation of American writers. Mr. Ginsberg was informed Tuesday that he could remain in the Soviet Union for two weeks to lecture and conduct poetry readings.

title: Toward a Deluxe Home Away From Home
description: A Victorian mansion that served for many years as a dormitory where soldiers and sailors passing through town could stay overnight for 50 cents is getting a new life as a luxury inn that will charge up to $250 a night for accommodations.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 6, 1985
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on complaint by Angola.

title: Dulles Hub Planned For United Airlines
description: United Airlines, in a major East Coast expansion, announced that it would establish a hub at Dulles International Airport in Washington.

title: DEER IMPORTED INTO TEXAS IMPINGE ON LOCAL BREED
description: Wild deer and antelope from Asia, originally brought to Texas by ranchers as curiosities and for hunting, have escaped and are rapidly spreading over much of Texas.

title: Tremor Felt in Mexico City
description: An earth tremor, measured at 2.3 on the open-ended Richter scale, was felt in some parts of Mexico City early today. There were no reports of damage or injuries. An earthquake measuring 8.1 on the Richter scale killed at least 7,000 people in Mexico City on Sept. 19.

title: Music Behind Walls
description: The music was Mozart. The setting was somber.

title: CALIFORNIA HIGH COURT REBUFFS SAN DIEGO MAYOR
description: The California Supreme Court today rejected a request by Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego that it intervene in the criminal case against him.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BERNSTEIN AND 3 SYMPHONIES NO. 3
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN'S concert with the New York Philharmonic last night was a numerologist's delight, consisting of the third symphonies of three significant American composers. Three Thirds, beginning with Roy Harris's one-movement symphony from 1938, going on to William Schuman's more erudite 1941 composition and closing grandly with Aaron Copland's 1946 masterpiece. These works have long been catalogued together not only because they share a number but for their quality. Each represents the best a famous American achieved in the symphonic medium.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1985
description: International

title: BISHOPS WELCOME 2D DRAFT OF SYNOD MESSAGE
description: The bishops at the extraordinary Synod, who have been sharply at odds over the form and substance of the assembly's final documents, responded enthusiastically today to a new draft message to the world strongly endorsing the work of the Second Vatican Council and calling on Roman Catholics to fight for peace and social justice.

title: CLOSE VOTE ON TAX REVISION EXPECTED IN HOUSE
description: Democratic tax specialists in the House of Representatives spent today buttonholing colleagues to round up support for the tax-revision legislation the Ways and Means Committee approved this week.

title: PACIFICARE HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Harold J. Lamm, 85, Founder Of Brokerage Firm, Is Dead
description: Harold J. Lamm, who founded a brokerage firm that for many years carried his name, died Monday at Greenwich Hospital after a long illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: One Cheer for Europe
description: The European Community has finally decided to make a serious effort to pull itself together. The government heads at the Luxembourg summit conference this week who usually crow loudly when they've produced practically nothing are being untypically modest about their agreement.

title: ZAPATA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $500,000 and an extraordinary gain of $4.7 million from the exchange of stock for debentures. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7.3 million.

title: 2 Members of Radical Group Are Buried In Pennsylvania
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson served as a pallbearer, and relatives and friends chanted ''Long live John Africa!'' today as they buried the remains of the Philadelphia handyman who founded the radical group Move.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Boeing Contract
description: A Boeing Company division said it had signed a multimillion-dollar contract to purchase telephone switching systems from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The Boeing Computer Services division said the systems would be used to modernize telecommunications networks in Seattle, Wichita, Kan., Vienna, Va., and Philadelphia. The program's overall cost is estimated at $100 million.

title: ISRAEL ARRESTS 2 IN LAND FRAUD
description: A political furor broke out in Israel today over the arrest Wednesday of two Israeli officials accused of fraudulent Arab land sales to Jews in the occupied West Bank.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income of $19,859,000 for the quarter and $7,103,000 for the 9 months from equity in unremitted earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. and dividend income of $37,698,000 for the quarter and $112,947,000 for the 9 months from Du Pont. c-Including income of $25,412,000 for the quarter and $117,353,000 for the 9 months from equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont and dividend income of $37,051,000 for the quarter and $104,100,000 for the 9 months from Du Pont.

title: SOVIET COOL TO WESTERN PROPOSAL AT VIENNA TALKS ON TROOP CUTS
description: The likelihood of an early breakthrough in the 12-year-old talks here on reducing conventional forces seemed to recede today, after the Soviet bloc reacted with extreme reserve to a new proposal by the United States and its allies to end a longstanding deadlock.

title: I.B.M. Buys Site
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has agreed to buy Uniroyal Inc.'s Middlebury, Conn., headquarters building and other nearby properties, the two companies said. I.B.M. has no plans to occupy the property that includes three buildings and 1,400 acres of land, but will lease it to Uniroyal.

title: SCREEN: 'SPIES LIKE US'
description: A FUNNY thing, or rather a not very funny thing, happened to movie comedy several years ago. It became possible to make a blockbuster hit without benefit of much real humor, provided a few ''Saturday Night Live'' alumni were on hand to affect the right authority-baiting, devil-may-care poses. Merely putting Bill Murray in the Army (''Stripes'') or at camp (''Meatballs'') or on a golf course with Chevy Chase (''Caddyshack'') or on ghost patrol with Dan Aykroyd (''Ghostbusters'') became enough to make audiences laugh, or at least buy tickets. It was no longer vital to create full or interesting characters, let alone to sustain them for 90 minutes or more.

title: CIGARETTE MAKER WINS $5 MILLION IN TV LIBEL CASE
description: A Federal jury today awarded the manufacturer of Viceroy cigarettes $5.05 million in damages in a libel suit against CBS Inc. and a popular television commentator.

title: IOWA BANK SEEKS LOAN PACT
description: The Hawkeye Bancorporation, Iowa's largest bank holding company, announced today that farm loan problems had forced it to try to renegotiate its loan obligations and to cancel placement of $30 million in preferred stock.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Topics;   Blame-Mongers Toying With Transit
description: New York's politicians have for 80 years found it difficult to resist blaming each other whenever transit fares must be raised. Mayor Koch's latest attack on Governor Cuomo's refusal to propose taxes that might keep subway fares from reaching $1 is only the latest example of the habit.

title: Sutton Stays an Angel
description: The California Angels have reached an agreement with the pitcher Don Sutton for the 1986 season, with an option for 1987.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell slightly for the week ended Wednesday, dropping $179.5 million, to $208.87 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The decrease was a result of a $508.8 million decline in the assets of the 73 institutional funds, which now stand at $53.28 billion. The 87 broker-dealer funds rose $184.4 million, to $94.30 billion, while assets of the 192 general purpose funds increased $144.9 million, to $61.29 billion.

title: SUIT SAYS U.S. CURBED FILMS OVER IDEOLOGY
description: A group of 15 independent documentary film makers and production companies filed suit today in Federal District Court here, charging that the Federal Government had severely limited the distribution of their films abroad because of differences in political ideology.

title: SPINNING TOPS AND LATKES SET FOR HANUKKAH
description: With lighted candles, potato pancakes and spinning tops, Jews tomorrow night will begin their celebration of Hanukkah, the eight-day holiday that recalls the victory of the Maccabees and the liberation of the Holy Temple in Jerusalem in 165 B.C.

title: Quintet and Sextet
description: The violinist John Blake will lead a quintet and the pianist Stanley Cowell will lead a sextet, featuring Clifford Jordan on tenor saxophone, today at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall (247-7800). Tickets are $10.

title: Confessed Killer Awaits Execution in Nevada
description: Carroll E. Cole, a condemned murderer facing the last hours before his execution, talked with an investigator today about one of the 14 or 15 killings he says he committed for revenge against an abusive mother.

title: CONNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $294,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Giants Weak Covering Kicks
description: In this 8-5 season, with a playoff berth within reach, the Giants have generally played well on offense, defense, punting and punt coverage. Kickoff returns have been undistinguished. Kickoff coverage has been a problem.

title: STATES FOUND IN A LOCAL-FEDERAL VISE OVER SERVICES
description: For the first time the states are facing demands from both the Federal and local governments to expand public services, according to an analysis made public today by the Council of State Governments.

title: Advertising;   Addendum
description: Paul Spindler has established his own corporate and marketing communications concern, the Spindler Co., with headquarters in Los Angeles.

title: Maryland Keeps Ross
description: College football's round of musical coaches picked up tempo yesterday as Bobby Ross announced he had decided to stay at Maryland, Watson Brown announced he would leave Rice and return to Vanderbilt, John Gutekunst was picked to replace his former boss, Lou Holtz, at Minnesota and Mike Gottfried of Kansas emerged as the leading candidate to replace Foge Fazio at Pittsburgh. Ross, who had listened to overtures from both Minnesota and Pitt, said he had agreed in principle to accept a four-year Maryland contract and had engaged an agent to work out the details.

title: CANCER WARRIOR: RESEARCHER ROOTED IN SURGERY AND IMMUNOLOGY
description: The career of Dr. Steven A. Rosenberg, whose promising new approach to cancer treatment was announced this week, has combined training in two diverse fields, surgery and immunology, placing him in a strong position to exploit the body's immune system in fighting that disease.

title: Pennsylvania Court Upholds Abortion Law
description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the state's right to deny Medicaid funds for most abortions.

title: DOW INDUSTRIALS REACH 1,500 LEVEL BEFORE FALTERING
description: Amid the heaviest stock trading volume in more than a year, and the fourth-heaviest ever, the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday touched the 1,500 mark for the first time. It remained there briefly, until selling sent the popular average back below where it started the day, down 1.49 points, to 1,482.91.

title: Oscar Wilde's 'Earnest,' Starring Wendy Hiller
description: To write about the new television production of ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' means writing about Wendy Hiller. With her appearance about halfway through the opening act, hilarity enters. This is no criticism of the other performers; it is simply an acknowledgment that the part of Lady Bracknell, in accomplished hands, becomes the centerpiece of Oscar Wilde's supremely witty work about upper-class nitwits.

title: Open Sing of Handel
description: The Hebrew Arts School will celebrate Hanukkah with its seventh annual open sing of Handel's ''Judas Maccabaeus,'' on Sunday at 2 P.M., at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Whither the Whip
description: Nothing charges up the aggressive instincts of a politician like the opening of a newly elective office a notch above the one he or she now holds. When the next Congress convenes in 1987, for the first time the job of House Democratic whip, the third-ranking leadership post that was previously appointive by the Speaker, will be filled by election by all Democratic members, and campaign action is already at a high pitch.

title: SOUTHEAST-BARNETT
description: Florida's leading corporate bank, the Southeast Banking Corporation, and Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., the state's leading retail bank, announced they were breaking off the merger negotiations that had been announced Nov. 22.

title: 'Misa Flamenca'
description: The Spanish Dance Arts Company will present the premiere of ''Misa Flamenca'' (''Flamenco Mass''), a program of music and dance, on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street.

title: HARLEM ARMORY SELECTED AS SITE FOR NEW SHELTER
description: The state turned over the 369th Regiment Armory in Harlem to the city yesterday for use as a shelter for the homeless.

title: 1 Route to Triple Crown
description: Beginning next year, the only way a thoroughbred can be entered in a Triple Crown race is by being entered in all three races - the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes.

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY BUCKS
description: Some purists have criticized Don Nelson, the coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, for what he sometimes does in a basketball game - most notably when he pulls as many as three players away from the basket with their defenders and turns the game into a two-on-two contest. But in the fourth quarter last night at Madison Square Garden, he used a different strategy. It worked to perfection as the Knicks crumbled, were outscored by 25-14 and eventually lost, 105-95.

title: Court Leaves Jersey Mansion Owned by Libya Tax-Exempt
description: A mansion owned by Libya remains tax-exempt after a Federal appeals court refused to rehear the city's petition to put the property back on the tax rolls, according to the Englewood City Attorney.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is sad that an organization which began with such high hopes and to which this country has contributed so much in the past should have gone so wrong.

title: BRITAIN CONFIRMS ITS PLAN TO QUIT A 'HARMFULLY POLITICALIZED UNESCO
description: Britain, which 40 years ago was one of the key founders of Unesco, will withdraw from the 160-member organization at the end of this year, the Government told the House of Commons today.

title: SCREEN: SHEPARD'S 'FOOL FOR LOVE'
description: EDDIE, a tall, skinny, beat-up cowboy, and May, who has no particular calling in any direction, have been lovers since they were teen-agers. Eddie has a mean-streak down his back a yard wide, as well as a furious need for May that defines his love, which is as hopeless as it is careless.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN LOUISIANA GOVERNOR'S RACKETEERING TRIAL
description: After almost 10 weeks of testimony in the Federal racketeering trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards and seven co-defendants, defense lawyers rested their case this morning. Closing arguments are to begin Monday.

title: Ford Adopts Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would offer sales incentives on one line of subcompact cars, adopting a stance similar to that of the General Motors Corporation and avoiding the wider incentives being offered by Chrysler Corporation.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: Results for the latest fiscal year have been restated to reflect revisions in the provision for income taxes resulting from additional tax credits.

title: Advertising;   New Accounts Given To Dweck and Sweeney
description: Account announcements of interest are presented by Sweeney & Partners of Montvale, N.J., and Michael Dweck & Company of New York.

title: Occidental To Sell Stake
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it intends to sell its 20 percent stake in the Dallas-based Southland Corporation, the world's largest convenience-store operator, in a deal valued at about $394 million.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $55,095 for the quarter and $50,185 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after net from discontinued operations of $3,703 for the quarter and after loss from discontinued operations of $33,540 for the 6 months.

title: TRUMP CLEARED TO BUILD DOMED SPORTS STADIUM
description: New York State and New York City yesterday authorized Donald J. Trump to build a $286 million domed sports stadium next to Shea Stadium in Flushing, Queens, if he can attract a National Football League team to play there.

title: IN ASSAM'S PASTORAL SETTING, BLIND HATRED THRIVES
description: Tawny sheaves of rice dot the fields of the lush Brahmaputra River valley nowadays. But this season the people are also reaping a harvest of anguish, recrimination and fear.

title: CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM IS VOICED ABOUT TEST CANCER THERAPY
description: The report on a new experimental cancer treatment by scientists of the National Cancer Institute evoked cautious enthusiasm among research doctors yesterday and excitement among cancer patients and the general public.

title: BLUES OR BIG BAND, LISTENER'S CHOICE
description: WITH the help of a big-band festival that is bringing groups led by such famous stars as Buddy Rich, Woody Herman and Lionel Hampton to the Blue Note in the space of two weeks, more big bands are playing in New York this weekend than have appeared here simultaneously in years.

title: Dennis Brutus Reading
description: Dennis Brutus, the South African poet, will read from his work as part of an ''Arts in Celebration of Human Rights Day'' program tomorrow from 4:30 to 8 P.M. in the auditorium of the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street.

title: Third World's Debt Burden
description: IF the upsurge of confidence in the securities markets, founded on a belief in the stability of the American and world economy, is to be validated, the greatest threat to the financial system still needs to be solved. That threat remains the huge and still growing debt crisis confronting the developing countries and banks in the United States and elsewhere in the industrial world.

title: U.S. NATIONAL GUARD TO HELP HONDURAN ARMY BUILD ROAD
description: The United States and Honduras have agreed to begin a military engineering exercise next month that will involve construction of a 12.5-mile road, the Pentagon said today.

title: ACTING CHIEF FOR NASA
description: William R. Graham took over as Deputy Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration only two weeks ago, and so it is not surprising that few people in the agency know him or have much idea of what to expect, now that he has suddenly been put in charge of the civilian space program. He was named Acting Administrator, replacing James M. Beggs.

title: PATRIOTS LOOK TO HOME EDGE VS. LIONS
description: Besides their 9-4 records in the Eastern Division of the American Conference, the Jets, the Miami Dolphins and the New England Patriots have something else in common this season: They each had a game scheduled with the Detroit Lions. The Dolphins played them Oct. 27 and lost, 31-21. The Jets played them Nov. 28 and lost, 31-20.

title: JOYCE IS REPLACED BY SAUTER AT CBS NEWS
description: Edward M. Joyce, the president of CBS News, was replaced yesterday by the man who had preceded him in the job, Van Gordon Sauter, the network announced.

title: Crime Victim
description: The Queens Borough President's car is missing.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: WHAT do the 1980's have to offer in the way of large-scale public painting?

title: The Truth About Sakharov
description: The Kremlin's masters are ruthless but not dumb. They surely knew that the truth about their mistreatment of Andrei Sakharov would emerge if his wife, Yelena Bonner, were allowed to travel to the West. Thus the ugly story of forced feeding and faked telegrams has one compensation. It signifies a calculation that Miss Bonner's journey to Italy is less harmful to Soviet interests than her cruel detention in what the couple calls ''the black hole,'' the closed city of Gorky.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid on Nov. 21, 1984 and a 20 percent stock dividend paid on Nov. 21, 1985.

DOMINO EFFECT IN POLICE PROMOTIONS
description: To the Editor:

DOWU SLIPS 5.73 POINTS, TO 1,477.18
description: The stock market concluded a tumultuous week of trading on a sour note yesterday, as prices continued a slide that began late Thursday after the Dow Jones industrial average temporarily broke through the 1,500 mark for the first time ever.

DIVINYLS ROCK BAND
description: The Divinyls rock band from Australia will play its only United States concert tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tickets are $13.50; the set begins at 10:30 P.M.

title: 2 KILLED AND 12 HURT AS BLAST LEVELS A RESTAURANT
description: An explosion leveled a restaurant on the main street here Friday, killing two people, injuring at least 12 others, and leaving one person or more trapped beneath smoldering rubble for hours.

title: CROWN BOOKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SCHERING ACCUSES HUTTON
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation charged yesterday that E. F. Hutton & Company had engaged in securities fraud by using confidential information about the drug company for its own purposes.

description: Even the Police Department is not impervious.

title: NICHOLS, S. E. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REAGAN AND APATHY
description: The Chief of One-Liners had them laughing in Seattle the other day as he needled his detractors. ''And there are still some diehards,'' President Reagan said, ''who refuse to acknowledge that the changes we've made have had anything to do with America's dramatic progress in these last few years. They sort of remind me of the fellow who was asked which was worse, ignorance or apathy, and he said, 'I don't know, and I don't care.' ''

title: STEVENS, J.P. & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $4,250,000 for the quarter and $19,277,000 for the year and includes after-tax charges of $13,010,000 and $73,940,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, relating to the costs of restructuring the company. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $3,156,000 for the quarter and $10,841,000 for the year.

title: PORT AUTHORITY TO SPEND $2 BILLION AT CITY AIRPORTS

description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced a $6 million fine against Jaguar Cars Inc. today for marketing automobiles that failed to meet federally mandated fuel economy standards.

description: To the Editor:

title: QUARTET AT VANGUARD
description: The saxophonist George Adams and the pianist Don Pullen, both formerly with Charles Mingus, are leading a quartet tonight through tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: ANGOLA REBELS REPORT KILLING 28 CUBAN TROOPS IN CONVOY
description: Angolan rebels said today that they had ambushed a Cuban convoy, killing 28 Cuban soldiers and shooting down 2 Soviet-built helicopters in what the rebels called the first major battle of a new Government offensive in southern Angola.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs Portland Trail Blazers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. This is the final meeting of the season between the teams, In the other one, in Portland Nov. 19, the Nets captured their first road victory of the season. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:45 P.M. tape. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M. live.) Colleges: Kansas at North Carolina State. (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M.); Loyola (Chicago) at Notre Dame, (Television - ESPN, 4 P.M.); LeMoyne at Seton Hall, 8 P.M. (Radio - WSOU-FM 89.5, 8 P.M.); Medgar Evers at Stony Brook, 6 P.M.; Baruch at Staten Island, 7:30 P.M.; Rutgers at North Carolina; L.I.U. at Dayton; Wagner at Villanova; Bowling Green at Princeton; Army at St. Peter's; St. Joseph's at Fairfield; Manhattan at Holy Cross. Radio -WFAS-FM 103.9, Iona game only, live.) Football Army vs. Navy, at Philadelphia. The Air Force Academy has already won the Commander-in-Chief Trophy by beating both these teams. but there is no shortage of incentive for this 86th meeting. Navy leads the series, 40-38-7.

title: STATES' DRIVE ON PRICE FIXING
description: Calling the Reagan Administration's antitrust policy a ''betrayal of the consumer,'' the nation's 50 state attorneys general - Republicans and Democrats - today announced a drive to combat restraints on discounting and other ''vertical'' price fixing imposed by manufacturers and wholesalers on retailers.

description: b-Net loss

description: A Federal appeals court has ruled unconstitutional a 1984 law that lets the Government prevent people accused of drug trafficking from selling property while the charges are pending.

description: Storer Communications Inc. became a private company today after an investment firm had completed its $2.5 billion leveraged buyout of the broadcasting concern.

title: AIDS RISK TO UNBORN IS SEEN
description: Pregnant women infected with AIDS may run a risk as high as 65 percent of passing the infection to their unborn child, the Centers for Disease Control said Thursday in guidelines calling for testing of high-risk women who are or may become pregnant.

The results also include non-recurring income of $1,080,000 for the latest 3 months and $4,036,000 for the year- ago 9 months.

title: CREATING ORNAMENTS
description: Adults and children will have a chance to create their own Christmas tree ornaments from beads, foil, nutshells and straw at the Ukrainian Museum, 203 Second Avenue, between 12th and 13th Streets, today and tomorrow, from 2 to 4 P.M. The workshop, partly financed by the New York State Council on the Arts, costs $3.50 for nonmembers and $3 for members, students over 12 and the elderly.

title: TV: 'MIRACLE,' A TALE OF FLIGHT FROMN NAZIS
description: Caught up in pledge-week tactics to raise money, WNET/Channel 13 is putting its schedule through curious hoops. The premiere of ''Bleak House'' on Masterpiece Theater, for instance, was postponed one week, and the first two episodes are being presented tomorrow, beginning at 8 P.M. But consider poor ''Wonderworks,'' the award-winning family series put together by five stations outside of New York. Originally seen on Mondays, ''Wonderworks'' was shifted to Sundays by WNET earlier this season, but this week's showing will take place on Saturday - tonight at 7 o'clock, to be exact.

title: WALTER B. GIBSON, THE CREATOR OF 'THE SHADOW,' DEAT AT 88
description: Walter B. Gibson, who created ''The Shadow'' of pulp fiction in 1931 and turned out more than 300 novel-length stories on his exploits along with many other books, died early yesterday at Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 88 years old and a resident of nearby Eddyville.

description: You have to like the way Donald Regan has taken charge as White House chief of staff. He is a take-charge guy. He has put everybody on notice that a take-charge guy has now taken charge. He has sent them a message:

A NEW CABBAGE PATCH ARRIVES ON 5TH AVENUE
description: Two burly truckers sheepishly entered the pastel ''adoption room,'' the larger of the two deciding to stand so as not to smash to smithereens the delicate furniture.

description: A FEDERAL regulation that took effect in September requires that a third brake light be installed in all cars built after 1985. Even though the new regulation does not require the light on earlier models, automobile clubs are telling their members to install them.

The agreement ends rumors about Arnsparger returning to the National Football League as coach of the New Orleans Saints. . . . Keith Gilbertson, who served without pay this season as the offensive coordinator at Idaho, was named head coach, replacing Dennis Erickson, who resigned to coach Wyoming.

description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said that a lack of orders for steel rails will force it to curtail operations at its Monessen plant later this month.

title: VOUCHERS WOULD COVER MOST CATHOLIC SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Thayer to Stay In Jail for Now
description: Paul Thayer, the former No. 2 Pentagon official who pleaded guilty to obstructing justice in a stock trading deal, will stay in prison until at least next year, a Justice Department spokesman said today. Joe Krovisky, the Justice Department spokesman, said the United States Parole Commission decided Wednesday that Mr. Thayer would stay in prison until at least Dec. 12, 1986.

title: RULES ON COTTON DUST ARE EASED IN REVISION
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration Thursday issued revisions in the seven-year-old regulation that protects more than 170,000 workers in textile and other industries from the effects of cotton dust.

title: Electron Gun Improves TV Picture Tubes
description: An improvement in television picture tubes has been invented for the RCA Corporation.

title: NEWSPAPER IN ST. LOUIS SUSPENDS PUBLICATION
description: The St. Louis Globe-Democrat suspended publication tonight after a Federal bankruptcy judge said he would appoint a trustee to manage the newspaper's financial affairs.

title: MUSIC: REGGAE BY YABBY YOU
description: The reggae singer Yabby You, now playing his first concerts outside Jamaica, came to Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street, on Wednesday. Backed by the six-man Gladiators band, he sang reggae songs untouched by recent American pop styles - songs such as ''Fleeing From the City,'' which decries ''poverty and destruction, misery and corruption'' and says, ''We used to call one another brother.''

title: RETURNING TAX SOURCES TO LOCALITIES
description: An advisory commission of mayors, governors, legislators and other officials has recommended that Congress and the Reagan Administration consider repealing Federal aid programs worth billions of dollars and returning some tax sources to local governments.

title: CLAIMANT GROUP IN MANVILLE ACCORD
description: A representative of one of the key groups with asbestos-related claims against the Manville Corporation said yesterday that he had reached ''complete agreement'' with the company on a plan that would allow Manville to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $919,000.

description: The company said results for a year ago have been restated to reflect the acquisition in March 1985 of Car Systems Inc.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. This is more than a medallion engraved with a Star of David. What is on the other side, and what is the medallion's significance? 2. Two women, world figures banned from speaking in public, were in the news. Who are they and what were the circumstances in each case? 3. The most fascinating and puzzling observation from Voyager 2 as it approaches Uranus is what the the spacecraft is not detecting. Explain. 4. Four men, present and former officers of General Dynamics, were indicted on charges of defrauding the Army on a weapons contract. What weapon is it? 5. In the interest of unity, Salvador H. Laurel agreed to set aside his political ambitions, foregoing the goal for which he has worked the last two years. Who is he and what prompted his decision? 6. One of the nation's leading organizations is expected to call for a ban on cigarette advertising, despite constitutional questions. Identify the organization. 7. A recently published compendium of anecdotes, homilies, advice and insults is in the news. What is the reason? 8. A major retailer plans to close its flagship store, which, when it was built in 1965, was Manhattan's most expensive in 40 years. What store is it? 9. In addition to being the greatest runner, passer and kicker in his team's history, a hero of football lore smoked, drank and was a cardshark, a poolshark and the team's bookie.

title: WITH POETIC LICENSE
description: SELECTED POEMS. By John Ashbery. 349 pages. Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking. $22.95. ''The words are only speculation/ (From the Latin speculum, mirror),'' writes John Ashbery. ''They seek and cannot find the meaning of the music./ We see only postures of the dream.'' The lines are from Mr. Ashbery's dazzling masterwork ''Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror,'' and like so much of his verse, they address not only the situation at hand in a given poem, but also the overall condition of his art - his relation, as a poet, to the reality around him. In this case, the lines also uncannily describe the effect of reading Mr. Ashbery's poetry - an effect not unlike that produced by listening to a piece of avant-garde music. Certainly his elliptical work frequently defies conventional attempts to impute meaning - most are vague about time, place and characters, as though external reality were quite beside the point; many constantly shift point of view, as though the idea of fixed character, too, were outmoded. And yet its meditative, allusive beauty retains a powerful ability to entrance, goading the reader to re-examine his own relationship to the world.

title: DESTINATION MANILA
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has authorized an on-site inspection of preparations for the Presidential election to be held in the Philippines in February. The committee, in a bipartisan decision, is sending a team from the Center for Democracy, a Washington-based foundation associated with Boston University.

title: CONFESSED MURDERER OF 13 IS EXECUTED IN NEVADA
description: Carroll E. Cole, who confessed 13 killings he said were revenge against his abusive mother, was executed by lethal injection today after rejecting appeals because ''it would be unbearable to stay on here.''

title: BOGATA REBELS KILL 2 ON BUS
description: Leftist guerrillas hurled grenades and fired into an army bus in Bogota early today, killing two soldiers and wounding eight others, witnesses said. A joint command of several guerrilla groups took responsibilty for the attack in calls to local radio stations, saying the raid was in response to the killing two weeks ago of a rebel political chief.

title: PARTNERS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Avant-Rock Band
description: Mofungo, a Lower East Side avant-rock band, will perform tomorrow at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052). The band Fish and Roses will open at 10 P.M.; tickets are $6.

title: No Headline
description: Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn, singled out by the State Education Department last week as one of the two most ''deficient'' high schools in the city, is an institution teetering between its glorious past and a difficult present.

title: COMMITTEE BACKS PART OF FARM BILL
description: A conference committee working to resolve differences in the Senate and House farm bills today tentatively approved agricultural research and education programs that could cost up to $6.5 billion over the next five years. More controversial topics were put off until next week.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph accompanying a review in Weekend yesterday of the sculpture of George Sugarman was incorrectly placed on its right side side and the caption incorrectly the site where the work is on exhibit. The work, titled ''Waltz,'' is at the Robert Miller Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue at 56th Street.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS INVOLVED IN SECOND EXTENSION ON BIDS
description: The Air Force extended the deadline for bids on a contract to develop a new fighter plane today, thereby keeping open General Dynamics's chances of competing even though it has been suspended from receiving new Government contracts.

title: WHITE A YANKEE COACH
description: The Yankees, who a day earlier announced a trade they weren't making, made a trade yesterday and formally named Roy White first- base coach.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''No one is happy with the current system of physician payment.'' -Senator Bob Dole, describing medicare. [8:1.]

title: THE WINKLE, A USEFUL PLAY, IS SOMETIMES MISIDENTIFIED
description: A secondary squeeze in which the defense must choose between being end-played and allowing a ''useless'' card in the dummy to come back to life is known as a winkle. It is named for a twisted British shellfish that presents problems to the human consumer.

title: SILKWOOD EPILOGUE: FUEL-ROD DEBATE LINGERS ON
description: More than a decade after Karen Silkwood died, an epilogue to the dispute over nuclear safety issues she raised is unfolding at the Department of Energy's Hanford Nuclear Reservation here. In a remote spot in the shadow of the Rattlesnake Hills, the nuclear fuel rods that Miss Silkwood called defective are being used in the core of the world's most advanced reactor for testing such rods.

title: INDIA WANTS U.S. COURTS TO HANDLE BHOPAL CASES
description: The Government of India said yesterday that victims of the gas leak in Bhopal who are seeking compensation could not get a fair trial in their own country.

title: THESE JETS ARE BUILT FOR HARSH WEATHER
description: It was for cloudy, windy and cold days like today that Coach Joe Walton and his scouts designed the Jets. That may be the kind of weather they will face Sunday when they meet the Buffalo Bills in Orchard Park, N.Y. It is likely to be the weather the Jets wind up the season in, with two Giants Stadium games left, against the Chicago Bears and the Cleveland Browns.

title: 26-POINT FIRST HALF DOES IN THE KNICKS
description: Mindful that the weak Indiana Pacers were focusing their defense on the Knicks' frontline, Rory Sparrow, the playmaking guard, opened the contest tonight with an aggressive flurry that scored 5 quick points and helped give New York a 7-4 lead. But what followed for the Knicks was a horror as they suffered a crushing defeat to another of the worst teams in the league.

title: 30 LAWMAKERS URGE DELAY IN LASER WEAPON TEST
description: Thirty members of Congress yesterday sent a letter to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger urging him to postpone a $30 million test of an X-ray laser weapon because of reported flaws in the experiment's design.

title: CITY SHUTS A BATHHOUSE AS SITE OF 'UNSAFE SEX'
description: New York City obtained a court order yesterday to close the New St. Marks Baths in the East Village, in a continuing crackdown against places that permit ''high risk'' sexual activity linked to the spread of AIDS.

title: Measuring Lithium In Body
description: A METHOD of determining the amount of lithium in the brain and kidneys has been devised for the Department of Energy. The presence of the medication is disclosed by neutron radiation and examination of the breath.

title: NAVY SPY SUSPECT ACCUSES F.B.I.
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy radioman who is a friend of John A. Walker Jr., the confessed Soviet spy, testified in his own espionage case today that he had been subjected to ''psychological warfare'' by Federal agents who interviewed him before his arrest June 3.

title: BRITAIN SIGNS PACT ON RESEARCH ROLE IN U.S. 'STAR WARS'
description: Britain signed an accord today with the United States allowing it to take part in research on an American missile-defense system.

title: HOSPITAL RESIDENCIES IN SEARCH OF FUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTERY PARK CITY FISCAL PLAN APPROVED
description: The Board of Estimate has approved a plan that is expected to give New York City $3 billion from the Battery Park City development over the next 29 years.

title: HAPPY HOLY DAYS
description: Both Christian and Jewish holy days are to be celebrated Dec. 26-31 at the American Museum of National History. More than 70 groups comprising 600 performers will be on hand in the halls and exhibit rooms demonstrating how Americans of various faiths and ethnic back-grounds celebrate Christmas, the New Year and Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, which uses the lighting of candles to mark the rededication of the Temple in Jerusalem by Judas Maccabeus in 165 B.C.

title: Rogers Is Demoted
description: The Rangers recalled Mike Rogers last month to pack more offense into their attack, but yesterday they sent him packing. The 31-year-old center scored a goal in his first game after he was recalled from New Haven Nov. 13, but he had no goals in his last eight games.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE COMPANY (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHI BETA KAPPA AWARD
description: Phi Beta Kappa, the national honor society, named three winners of its 1985 award for outstanding books published in the United States in literature, science and social sciences. They are: ''The English Elegy: Studies in the Genre From Spenser to Yeats,'' by Peter M. Sacks, published by Johns Hopkins University Press; ''The Scientific Reinterpretation of Form,'' by Norma E. Emerton, published by Cornell University Press as part of the Cornell History of Science series, and ''The Crucible of Race,'' by Joel Williamson, published by Oxford University Press. Each of the authors is to receive $2,500.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $63,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $218,000, or 11 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company's 2,040 hourly workers in Sonoma County will return to full work schedules and full pay on Jan. 1 because of increased customer orders, the computer company has announced. Salaried and management employees will also be back on full schedules, but they will have to take wage reductions ranging from 5 percent to 10 percent until business conditions improve further. The divisions in Sonoma County, north of San Francisco, produce measurement equipment for engineering and scientific fields.

title: COCAINE CHARGE CLOUDS COMPANY CHIEF'S CAREER
description: The arrest on a cocaine possession charge of Terence J. Fox, a 47-year-old entrepreneur, socialite and the chairman of Iroquois Brands, has cast a cloud of uncertainty over the career of one of the New York area's more successful businessmen.

title: Ex-Referee Loses Plea
description: After Manny Sokol, a National Basketball Association referee, suffered a heart attack in November 1977, he received his full salary for the season, five years of disability payments, $10,000 in severance pay and a lump-sum distribution of his pension benefits.

title: JUDGE DELAYS RULING IN TEXACO CASE
description: After a brief morning session punctuated by impassioned legal arguments, a Texas state judge today delayed until at least Tuesday a decision on Texaco Inc.'s effort to disallow a $10.53 billion jury award against it.

title: REPUBLIC BANK CARVES NICHE
description: The Republic National Bank of New York is the nation's 30th-largest bank. But one would never know it from its operations.

title: No Headline
description: At the head of the procession will be the Coast Guard bark Eagle, tall and long and full of sails, leading the parade of tall ships in New York Harbor - 20 tall ships in all, from as far away as Venezuela, Oman and Indonesia.

title: SOME LIKE THEIR LUMPS IN MASHED POTATOES
description: An unscientific survey of 26 people proves that the vast majority prefer smooth mashed potatoes to those with lumps. Only four of those asked said they liked lumps and only one gave a rational explanation. ''With lumps,'' she said, ''I know they are real.''

title: MINNESOTA COURT RULES FETUS IS NOT A HUMAN
description: A fetus is not a human being under state law, the Minnesota Supreme Court said today in a decision that means a man who was accused of killing an 8 1/2-month-old fetus in an automobile accident cannot be charged in the death.

title: ISLANDER DEFENSE FAILS
description: The Islanders, visiting Quebec for the first and only time this season, were dealt a 7-3 loss by a team they don't consider any more gifted than themselves. The difference tonight was a quartet of power-play goals from the Nordiques and a mute protest from the Islanders, who never really attempted a come back from a 3-1 first-period deficit.

title: FIGHTING FOR THE MPEROR
description: At school on the morning of Dec. 8, 1941, the battle station bell of the flagship Mikasa pealed out, as it did every morning, for roll-call. The Mikasa had led the Japanese victory over the Russian Baltic fleet; the bell was yet one more daily reminder of the Japanese military traditions that my schoolmates and I lived to uphold. But that morning the bell had another resonance: at breakfast, my mother and brother and I had heard the news of our attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: FLAMEMASTER CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Stewart, an Ex-Justice, Hospitalized by Stroke
description: Potter Stewart, a retired Justice of the Supreme Court, was in critical condition in a New Hampshire hospital today after suffering a stroke, officials said.

title: BURYING BIAS, AND NOT JUST IN YONKERS
description: A Federal judge's ruling that officials in Yonkers, N.Y., ''illegally and intentionally'' maintained racially segregated public schools and housing is more than just another local school desegregation case. The finding, and the remedies that are soon to be determined, will echo through the country.

title: NAVRATILOVA CAPTURES TITLE
description: Martina Navratilova powered past the defending champion Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-2, 4-6, 6-2, today to win the women's singles title at the $1.5 million Australian Open tennis championship.

title: LEADER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a gain of $800,000 from payment of an insurance policy.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 19
NICARAGUA REBUTS U.S. ON CUBAN ROLE
description: A high-ranking Nicaraguan official denied today that Cuban military advisers were taking part in combat against anti-Government rebels, and he accused the Reagan Administration of seeking an excuse to expand its aid to the insurgents.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in October.

title: U.S. PLANS INQUIRY ON JAPANESE CHIPS
description: President Reagan has initiated an unfair trade complaint against the Japanese semiconductor industry, ordering an investigation into whether the Japanese have sold high-capacity memory chips, used in sophisticated computers and other electronic devices, in this country at prices below the cost of production.

title: LONG DISTANCE CALLING: IT'S TIME TO CHOOSE A LINE
description: Over the next few months, millions of New Yorkers will find light blue printed ballots in their mail boxes from New York Telephone asking them to vote for their favorite long distance phone company.

title: Laser Beams Used In Cancer Treatment
description: A team of eight Japanese inventors has patented a device that uses laser beam pulses to diagnose and treat cancer.

title: KEEP ADIRONDACK STATE PARK 'FOREVER WILD'
description: Governor Cuomo has a unique opportunity to establish national credentials as one concerned about the environment by supporting a bond issue of about $1.2 billion that will, among other goals, raise funds to preserve the Adirondack State Park. The future of the Adirondacks may depend on the size of the bond that Gov. Cuomo proposes in his Jan. 8 State of the State message to the Legislature.

title: ST. JOHN'S CRUSHES COLUMBIA
description: Walter Berry scored 29 points and Ron Rowan had 18 as St. John's routed Columbia, 80-58, in the first game of the 11th Lapchick Memorial Tournament last night.

title: SHUTTLE CREW CONCLUDES TEST FOR MISSION TO START DEC. 18
description: With the space shuttle Atlantis back on Earth in good condition after a highly successful weeklong mission, the space shuttle Columbia's crew ran through a smooth-running practice countdown Thursday to clear the way for a launching Dec. 18. The shuttle is to land at the Kennedy Space Center here Dec. 23.

title: CORRECTION
description: A music review in the Weekend section in some editions yesterday gave incorrect dates for two benefits to be held at the Burgundy Cafe, Amsterdam Avenue near 81st Street, to raise money to buy a piano now on loan there. The benefits will be held tomorrow and Monday at 6 P.M.

title: WAINWRIGHT TO PERFORM
description: The songwriter Loudon Wainwright 3d will perform today at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M. at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street (228-7880). Tickets are $9.

title: Savin Plans Major Shifts
description: The Savin Corporation reported today that it had canceled plans to introduce a high-speed photocopier, was investigating the possibility of a financial restructuring and that the company has a negative net worth. The actions came about three weeks after the Savin reported a third-quarter loss of $20.4 million and said it had taken a $50.7 million write-down on assets to settle a dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: RECITAL: SHARON ROBINSON, CELLIST
description: Sharon Robinson is a familiar figure on the New York music scene, but less as a solo cellist than as an erstwhile member of various chamber ensembles, most notably the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio. Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, she appeared for a recital, and within certain limits it turned out to be a most enjoyable occasion.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 15
SCREEN TEST FOR THE SENATE
description: Members of the United States Senate are dragging themselves, huffing and puffing, into the modern age of communications. Too slowly, they are recognizing that their floor proceedings should be televised.

title: U.S. MAY PRESS EFFORTS TO HELP LATIN GUERRILAS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States might take ''further steps'' on behalf of anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Right Spot, Right Time
description: It was a press agent's dream: a newspaper photograph of President Reagan standing next to Mayor Koch, with the President holding a copy of Mr. Koch's just-published second book.

title: Award for a Civic Leader
description: A prominent Democrat received an award from the nation's leading Republican.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
No Headline
description: Interest levels on fixed-rate home mortgages dropped to a four-year low between early October and early November, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: BENEFIT FOR AIDS RUN
description: Martha Raye, Cleo Laine, Don Scardino and John Herrera will be among the celebrities participating in ''Close Upon the Hour,'' an evening of music to benefit the American Run for the End of AIDS tomorrow at 7 P.M. in the Triplex Theater at Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street.

title: Cuomo Names Budget Aide
description: Dall For-sythe, a senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers' Investment Banking Group, has been appointed first deputy director of the State Budget Division by Governor Cuomo. He replaces Susan Tyler, who resigned. Mr. Forsythe, a 42-year-old Brooklyn resident, will assist the State Budget Director in writing the Governor's annual budget proposal and will oversee finances in the areas of health and human services. The post pays $82,425 a year, and Mr. Forsythe's appointment takes effect Jan. 1.

title: WHERE DREAMS ARE VALIDATED
description: It is a theater without stage or box office, where performances draw no notices and audiences, not actors, decide how the scenes will be played out.

title: DMI FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a charge of $2.2 million for the quarter and year for a provision for disposal costs and writedown of investment in a subsidiary. c-After a charge of $901,000 for the quarter and year related to a provision for a discontinued product line of a subsidiary.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AN ETHICS LESSON FOR NEW YORK
description: New York City's Board of Ethics seriously erred three years ago when it blessed a real estate deal between Ralph Lamberti, then Deputy Borough President of Staten Island, and Sanford Nalitt, a friend and real estate developer. The board, which advises on conflicts of interest, now admits its error but says Mr. Lamberti must share the blame because he was ''not candid'' about the deal.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON A PLAN TO END FEDERAL DEFICITS
description: House and Senate negotiators reached an ''agreement in principle'' today on legislation to require a balanced budget by 1991, ending a two-month struggle.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: TREASURY BONDS GET LATE LIFT
description: Although dealers and investors in fixed-income securities were mostly on the sidelines after lunch yesterday, there was sufficient pre-weekend short-covering throughout the day to keep prices firm. And when leaders of the Senate and House approved the main points in the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing bill late in the day, a flurry of buying converted losses of about 5/32d's on longer maturities into gains of about that size, but the bills market continued to show losses.

title: HANDEL'S 'JUDAS'
description: The Y Chamber Symphony, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, will present Handel's oratorio ''Judas Maccabaeus'' at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, today at 8 P.M. and tomorrow at 3 P.M. Soloists are Benita Valente, Kristina Carlson, Rockwell Blake and Jan Opalach; Amy Kaiser will conduct the Y Chamber Symphony Chorale. Tickets are $15 to $20. Information: 427-4410.

title: Celtics Lose First at Home
description: The reserves Jerome Kersey and Steve Colter each scored 22 points tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers became the first visiting team to win in Boston this season, ending the Celtics' nine-game streak with a 121-103 victory.

title: MAN TALK TO WOMEN SELLS COSMETICS
description: Wherever life takes him, Kip DiPaolo engages women in what is known in his line of work as ''warm chatter.'' Banks are the best places, he says, because of the long lines. ''Do you believe this line?'' he will say to a woman in a bank, moving on to the weather and other neutral topics before complimenting her on some aspect of her appearance and offering her a free facial.

title: Critic Is Criticized
description: Dale Brown, the Louisiana State basketball coach whose recruiting practices have been under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, has been outspoken in his criticism of N.C.A.A. investigators - a bit too outspoken, according to members of the L.S.U. Athletic Council. They chided Brown for denouncing the investigators with obscenities that were quoted in an with Sports Illustrated.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Spartan Spirit
description: Jim Horner, the coach of the undefeated Cherokee High School team in Marlton, N.J., said his son, Kyle, will play quarterback in the South Jersey Group 4 championship game against Pennsauken today despite a collapsed lung that a specialist said should have ended his football career.

title: DEVILS END THREE-GAME LOSING STREAK
description: A meeting among the Devils after the team had lost its previous three games lifted the players' spirits and may have helped them in tonight's game. The Devils played inspiring hockey at both ends of the ice, got excellent goatending from Glenn (Chico) Resch and ended their losing streak with a 4-1 victory over the Vancouver Canucks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: FLEISCHMANN BACKS OUT OF PARIS OPERA POST
description: Ernest Fleischmann, executive director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, announced yesterday that he had declined the position of artistic director and general administrator of the Paris Opera and would remain in his current post.

title: Large Numbers From Big Ten
description: It may have built a reputation for good football over the years, but in the development of players who went on to win national statistical championships, there has rarely been anything big about the Big Ten. From 1937, when the National Collegiate Athletic Association first posted detailed football statistics, through 1983, the conference's players won a mere 3 of 188 titles in total offense, passing, rushing and receiving.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IN ROME, THE BISHOPS CREATE THEIR OWN MYSTERY
description: They filed in one by one or in small groups, a collection of men in black punctuated by the bright red sashes and skullcaps of cardinals or the slightly more humble purple of bishops.

title: BUDGET CHIEF HINTS AT TRIMS IN '87 NONMILITARY SPENDING
description: President Reagan's chief budget officer hinted today that the Administration would make a new assault on nonmilitary spending next year in an attempt to shrink the budget deficit.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $743,000 for the quarter and $3,979,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary charges of $579,000 for the quarter and $2,723,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1985
description: Markets

title: PAPANDREOU SAYS THE VOTING IN CYPRUS CONCERNS GREECE
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said today that Greece considered its national interest to be involved in the outcome of the parliamentary elections in Cyprus on Sunday.

title: FOR MOST JAPANESE, PEARL HARBOR IS JUST A FOOTNOTE
description: The Japanese tourists come in the mornings, by the busload.

title: MOST TOXIC DUMPS FACING SHUTDOWN
description: More than two-thirds of the nation's toxic waste dumps have failed to qualify for permanent operating permits and must be closed, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIGHTING UP It's the season of longest nights and brightest lights. Hanukkah, the festival of lights, arrives this evening, and Christmas is not too far behind. Tomorrow, the special lights of the season begin twinkling along Park and Madison Avenues in an especially big and bright way, thanks to the efforts of the Avenue Association.

title: GOAL ACHIEVED
description: Vickie Maola and Drew Dusick, devout hockey fans, plan to be married on the ice of Civic Arena in Pittsburgh before tonight's game between the Penguins and the Devils.

title: SIDELINE FACTORS IN HEISMAN RACE
description: At approximately 5:55 P.M. today, after a program that will look back on the facts, figures and folklore surrounding the award, the Downtown Athletic Club will name the 51st winner of the Heisman Trophy before a national television audience. It is possible this will rank as the most suspenseful moment of the fall TV season since the opening episode of ''Dynasty'' revealed which characters survived the terrorist attack at Prince Michael's wedding. Unfortunately, just about everyone did, which is why ''Dynasty'' continues.

title: Martin Expecting To Manage Again
description: Billy Martin, the former manager of the Yankees, said today that he would decide next week after meeting with George Steinbrenner, the team's owner, what he would be doing next season. Martin added that one thing was clear:

title: HALLEY'S COMET Dec. 7, 1985
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 12:29 P.M. today and set at 1:33 A.M. tomorrow.

title: DENIS DE ROUGEMONT, FAMED SWISS WRITER
description: Denis de Rougemont, the noted Swiss writer who became a leading advocate of European unity, died today in a Geneva hospital after a long illness, sources close to his family said. He was 79 years old.

title: 'OPPORTUNITY ZONES,' ADVANCED BY NEW YORK STATE, OFFER MORE
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH RENTS THREATEN NON PROFIT ARTS
description: The real-estate boom in Manhattan is threatening to drive nonprofit arts groups out of the city or out of existence, according to a yearlong study commissioned by two city agencies.

title: EX-ITALY SPY CHIEF DENIES AGENCY LINK TO AGCA
description: A former Italian intelligence chief denied in court today that his agents had persuaded Mehmet Ali Agca to implicate Bulgaria in a plot to kill Pope John Paul II in May 1981.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1985
description: International

title: ARUTHUR ROTHSTEIN MEMORIAL
description: A memorial for Arthur Rothstein, the photojournalist and editor, will be held Monday at 3:30 P.M. at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. Mr. Rothstein died Nov. 11 at the age of 70.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17. 1. The medallion, designed to be worn by children of interfaith marriages, has an engraving of St. Christopher on the other side. 2. Under a vow of public silence, Yelena G. Bonner, a rights advocate who is the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, a leading Soviet dissident, left Moscow for a three-month trip to the West for medical treatment. In South Africa, Winnie Mandela, a foe of racial separation who is the wife of Nelson Mandela, long imprisoned black rights leader, broke an officially imposed silence, pledging vengeance for blacks killed by the police. 3. It has not detected any evidence that the planet has a magnetic field. 4. The Sergeant York antiaircraft gun, also known as Divad. 5. In the Philippines, Mr. Laurel, a former senator who had been the first opposition leader to announce his candidacy for the Presidency, accepted the offer of the vice-presidential spot on the ticket headed by Corazon C. Aquino, the widow of the assassinated opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. 6. The American Medical Association. 7. The book, ''Politics,'' is a new memoir by Mayor Koch. 8. Alexander's. 9. George Gipp of Notre Dame. 10. 1982. 11. In the first meeting in a Western capital between the Polish leader and a Western head of state since Poland cracked down on the Solidarity trade union and declared martial law in 1981, President Francois Mitterand received the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. 12.

title: CHURCHES' PARLEY ASSAILS PRETORIA
description: The World Council of Churches ended an emergency meeting on South Africa here today by adopting a resolution calling for increased church pressure and mandatory economic sanctions against the Pretoria Government.

title: GORDON LIPPITT, PSYCHOLOGIST AND PROFESSOR IN WASHINGTON
description: Gordon Leslie Lippitt, a behavioral psychologist and professor emeritus of behavior science in the School of Government and Business Administration at George Washington University, died of lung cancer Nov. 26 at a hospital in Bethesda, Md.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net income.

title: STIKE GOES ON DESPITE DIVISIONS IN UNION RANKS
description: As two dozen striking machinists took their turn marching in front of the Pratt & Whitney factory here today, Jimmy Mangum, the picket line captain, reminded them to attend a union meeting Saturday at a local elementary school.

title: Phillies Sign Maddox
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, who told 36-year-old Garry Maddox to try his luck in the free-agent draft, have re-signed him for one year at what is believed to be half the center fielder's $675,000 contract that expired after last season. The Phillies released Jerry Koosman to make room for Maddox on the club's 40-player roster. . . . The San Diego Padres said Dick Williams would return as manager next season.

title: Sideline View
description: Boomer Esiason, the Cincinnati quarterback, when asked what was uppermost in his mind about tomorrow's opponents, the Dallas Cowboys: ''Their cheerleaders.''

title: U.S. Neglect in the Pacific
description: This year may be remembered as the year the Pacific Ocean ceased to be America's lake. New Zealand refused port entry to a U.S. destroyer, Australia backed down from a commitment to help monitor an MX missile test and instability in the Philippines has raised questions about American bases there.

title: TRIO AT SWEET BASIL
description: The pianist Cedar Walton, the bassist Ron Carter and the drummer Billy Higgins are playing trios through tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, Bleecker Street, (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. today; 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minumum.

title: MANILA PANEL SUGGESTS TRIAL FOR PROTEST DEATHS
description: A civilian-military panel recommended today that a military captain, about 20 militiamen and soldiers and a mayor stand trial for the slayings of at least 21 demonstrators in the central Philippines in September.

title: Inventors Exposition Scheduled for Feb. 8-9
description: Preparations are being made for the National Inventors Exposition of 1986, to be held at the Patent and Trademark Office in Arlington, Va., on Feb. 8 and 9.

title: ARA MANUFACTURING CO OF DEL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary net loss of $465,000 on the extinguishment of debt. ARA Manufacturing is a subsidiary of Schick Inc.

title: GUNMEN SAID TO STEAL CHILEAN RIGHTS PAPERS
