description: Armed gunmen in Santiago, Chile, stormed into the office of the nation's leading human rights group and took documents that had been compiled for a United Nations investigation, group members said this week.

title: Group W Sale Field Reduced
description: In its final round of talks to sell its cable operation, Group W Cable, the Westinghouse Electric Company has decided to negotiate solely with the consortium that includes Time Inc., Tele-Communications Inc. and Comcast Communications, sources close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: BONNER AND POPE MEET BEFORE HER TRIP TO U.S.
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, had a private audience with Pope John Paul II tonight on the eve of her departure for the United States.

title: Japan Expansion Slows
description: Japan's economic expansion slowed to an inflation-adjusted six-tenths of 1 percent in the July-September quarter this year, down from a revised 1.4 percent in the April-June period.

title: CURRY STOPS MCCRORY IN 2ND
description: Donald Curry, who has sought to be counted among the elite of boxing, took a giant step toward that objective tonight when he scored a stunning knockout over Milton McCrory at 1:53 of the second round and became undisputed world welterweight champion.

title: WATERFOWL TRAPPED IN ICE AS COLD GRIPS ILLINOISE
description: Thousands of coots, apparently taken by surprise when a sudden blast of arctic cold swept through Illinois, have been frozen into a local lake and many will not survive, the authorites say.

title: SYSTEM & COMPUTER TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WAR OF THE DIGESTS
description: The Conservative Digest has decided to stop trying to look like Reader's Digest. The decision was made after lawyers for Reader's Digest threatened to take legal action to protect the singular look of that publication.

title: BOMB BLAST IN BELGIUM KILLS ONE
description: A bomb explosion at a Belgian court building killed a man and wounded two other people today, and officials reported other bombings at NATO fuel installations in Belgium and France.

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income. The company changed its fiscal year-end from one ending March 31 to April 30. Results for the latest periods are for the second quarter and 6 months ended Oct. 31, 1985. Year-ago results are for the second quarter and 6 months ended Sept. 30, 1984.

title: NO OPEC CHANGES ARE SEEN
description: OPEC'S Executive Council met today, prior to a full ministerial meeting Saturday, and apparently agreed not to seek changes in prices or output quotas.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE VOTES FOR LIMITS ON DEBT FINANCING OF TAKEOVERS
description: A divided Federal Reserve Board proposed today to curb debt-financing practices that have been widely used in the latest wave of corporate takeover bids.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
BUSINESS FLIERS PAY DEARLY FOR 'FREE MILES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 208287 -- No Title
description: Hanson Trust, a major British industrial group, began a $2.8 billion bid today for the Imperial Group, a brewing and tobacco conglomerate. The Hanson offer, the largest in British history, caps an extraordinary week of takeover activity here, bringing the value of bids made in the last five days to $9 billion.

title: Benefit for Writers' Center
description: The audience roared with laughter when Erica Jong entered the ring at the Big Apple Circus on the back of an elephant.

title: SAVING HOMELESS FROM THEMSELVES: A NEW POLICY CREATES NEW DISPUTES
description: A new policy toward the homeless, established last month by Mayor Koch the morning after a late night visit to Grand Central Terminal, has produced a surge in homeless people in city shelters, litigation and a controversy about the rights of the mentally ill.

title: VIACOM PURCHASING A CBS TV STATION
description: Viacom International, the diversified media company, has agreed to buy KMOX-TV, the CBS affiliate station in St. Louis, for $122.5 million.

title: A MEESE DEBATE
description: Among Washington lawyers and Government officials, no topic generates more heat these days than the views of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d on the Constitution. To add some light, possibly, the Center for National Policy and the law firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering will sponsor a debate Tuesday at the Georgetown Law Center between Laurence H. Tribe, of Harvard Law School, and Michael W. McConnell, of the University of Chicago Law School, on ''Intent v. Interpretation.'' The Center for National Policy, a Democratic-oriented research organization, says Mr. McConnell will support Mr. Meese's views.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A DRAFT OF THE BISHOPS' PASTORAL EXHORTATION
description: Following are excerpts from a draft text, obtained by The New York Times, of a pastoral exhortation from Roman Catholic bishops to the church. The letter was approved today in a slightly different form, which will be officially made public over the weekend.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY ASSAILS TERRORISM
description: The United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to condemn all acts of international terrorism as ''criminal.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Re-signed Garry Maddox, center fielder, to a one-year contract.

title: U.S. BISHOP CALLS SYNOD A SUCCESS, SAYING IT BACKS MORE AUTONOMY
description: Bishop James W. Malone, head of the United States Conference of Bishops, asserted today that the extraordinary Synod, now in its final hours, had been a resounding success and amounted to an endorsement of bishops' conferences as local voices of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: RARE CONCER OF AFRO-LATIN RITUAL MUSIC
description: New York City's musical life was enriched immeasurably in the early 1980's by a number of outstanding musicians who settled here after their exodus from Cuba. But some of the most gifted musical exiles, and the most widely respected within the Cuban community, have not been heard on concert stages or in nightclubs or recording studios.

title: One-Day Suspension
description: Steve Alford, the junior guard who is Indiana University's top player, averaging 28 points, has been suspended for today's game against Kentucky for allowing his photograph to be used in a sorority calendar that was sold to raise money for charity, according to Athletic Director Ralph Floyd, who said the school would abide by the ruling of the N.C.A.A. Eligibility Committee, ''Alford's picture appeared with 11 other students in a sorority project that was being sold to raise money for a girls' camp in Vancouver, Canada,'' Floyd said.

title: A DARK SIDE TO THE SUMMIT
description: We still don't know whether President Reagan pressed the Soviets on human rights at the recent summit meeting in Geneva. But if what happened at the summit to me and to the other defenders of those rights is any indication, there are reasons to doubt it.

title: BIRDSONG SEARCHING FOR TOUCH
description: In his mind, he knows something vital is missing. He can see the soft, arching jump shot that has been the staple of his game for eight professional seasons, and he can see the statistical sheet by which his success is invariably measured. But now, Otis Birdsong is not seeing his shots on the court. At least, not enough of them.

title: VOCAL ENSEMBLE
description: The Western Wind Vocal Ensemble will perform a program titled ''A Musical Celebration of Light'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine tonight at 7:30.

title: TRAINING IN RESCUE METHOD ENDS BECAUSE OF AIDS FEARS
description: A school district here is dropping training in cardiopulmonary resuscitation because of fear that high school students might be exposed to AIDS.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The latest third quarter and 9 months results included a pre-tax gain of $2.4 million from the sale and lease-back of headquarters facility.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHANGES SOUGHT IN DOCTORS' PAY UNDER MDICARE
description: Reagan Administration officials, members of Congress and private health policy experts called today for sweeping changes in the way the Federal Government pays physicians for treating elderly and disabled people under Medicare.

title: A SURGE IN CAMCORDER SALES
description: The home video camera is finally coming into its own.

title: THE DANCE: ALVIN AILEY PERFORMS 'ELEPHANT'
description: In ''How to Walk an Elephant,'' which had its New York premiere with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Thursday night at the City Center, Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane, the choreographers, include poses and movements that refer directly to George Balanchine's ballet, ''Serenade.''

title: JESUS AND MARY CHAIN
description: The Jesus and Mary Chain, a British rock band, will perform early tomorrow at about 12:30 A.M. at the World, 254 East Second Street (674-3348). Tickets are $12.50.

title: JOBLESS RATE DROPS TO 6.9% FROM 7%
description: The nation's overall unemployment rate edged down a tenth of a percentage point last month, to 6.9 percent of the labor force, the Government reported today.

title: Mark for Largent
description: When the Seahawks played host to Kansas City last Sunday, Steve Largent of Seattle tied a National Football League record for most seasons with at least 1,000 yards in receptions. Here are N.F.L. history's career leaders: Lance Alworth, San Diego7 Steve Largent, Seattle 7 Don Maynard, Jets5 Art Powell, Titans and Oakland5 Largent isn't done, either. Early next season, he should be zeroing in on another N.F.L. standard - most consecutive games with at least one reception. These are the leaders in that category: Harold Carmichael, Philadelphia127 Mel Gray, St. Louis 121 Steve Largent, Seattle120 Danny Abramowicz, N.O., S.F.105 Alfred Jenkins, Atlanta103

title: UNION REAFFIRMS DRUG-TESTING STANCE
description: With the drug-testing issue in dispute between baseball's club owners and players, the executive board of the Players Association spent much of its meeting time in Hawaii this week discussing the issue. Not unexpectedly, no agreement on testing emerged.

title: ROBERT C. STANLEY JR.
description: Robert C. Stanley Jr., a mining executive and state Republican Party official in New Jersey, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Middletown, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: ALBANY THEATER TO PLAY IN MOSCOW
description: An Albany theater's musical about Raggedy Ann dolls will be produced in Moscow next month as the first step in the newly renewed cultural exchange programs between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: VERMONT FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $108,164 from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. dividend. No per share figure for the previous fiscal year was reported because the company converted to stock ownership on Nov. 10, 1983.

title: NATIONAL HMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DISCIPLINE CONGREESS TO CUT THE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: COPING WITH COLLEGE COSTS
description: AT Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, alumni can pay for the entire tuition cost of their children who may enter Duquesne up to 18 years from now, with a single, fixed lump sum.

title: SCHUBERT SONG CYCLE ON CD
description: Concert promoters say they can no longer sell song recitals to their audiences, but the art song multiplies on records.

title: TESTIMONY BARRED IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
description: Defense lawyers have temporarily blocked the testimony of a key prosecution witness in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: MASSACHUSETTS PUBLIC OFFICIAL ADMITS HE TAPPED TREASURY
description: Sentencing is scheduled for Monday for the Norfolk County Treasurer, who pleaded guilty Wednesday to 40 counts of embezzlement, forgery and larceny.

title: PRODUCER SEEKS 'NEW LOOK'
description: HOW many Jane Bergeres are there, anyway? That question began circulating when Miss Bergere, the new executive producer of the Darien Dinner Theater in Connecticut, began her third career in October.

title: MICHAEL FRAYN: THE ENTERTAINING INTELLECT
description: ON A MONDAY NIGHT AT THE SAVOY Theater in London, Michael Frayn was settling into an orchestra seat to take another look at his comedy ''Noises Off.'' His long bony face wore its customary smile, but also a somewhat more anxious look than usual. Audiences on Monday evenings are notoriously thin and slow in Britain. ''Did you know,'' he confided, ''that the law in Germany forces manufacturers to admit which cars have been put together on Mondays? The workers make more errors, you see, and the parts go wrong more often.''

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHAT got Bruce Williams, the host on a financial talk show, into the broadcast business 10 years ago was, appropriately, a business venture.

title: AN UNLYRICAL LYRIC
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO PATHS TO CREATING LOW-COST HOUSING
description: THE State Economic Policy Council predicts that housing starts will increase next year by 12 percent to about 54,600 units, which it sees as a sign that New Jersey has rebounded vigorously from the housing-construction slump at the beginning of the decade.

title: 2 PLAYS DEPICT A TROUBLED HOLIDAY
description: THE Arena Players Repertory Company has filled its two theaters with seasonal fare about families in crisis on Christmas Eve. In its Main Stage theater is Sam and Bella Spewack's contrived situation comedy ''My Three Angels,'' which is set in the penal colony on Cayenne, French Guiana, in 1910.

title: SUPERSPRUCE
description: It may make you feel a little more holidayish to learn that the Refrigerator of Washington Christmas trees, a 54-foot white spruce for the west lawn of the Capitol, has arrived, is undergoing exterior decoration in place and will be ceremonially lit by assorted lawmakers at about dusk Wednesday. The Capitol tree does not always get the ink or air time accorded some competitors, but it dwarfs in bulk and stature both the 30-foot ''national'' tree on the Ellipse that the President customarily lights by pushing a button and the custom-decorated 20-foot tree in the Blue Room of the White House, which will receive its official press preview tomorrow.

title: JOYS ABOUND IN MODERN VIOLIN WORKS
description: Collectors on the lookout for unusual repertory would do well to investigate Artur Schnabel's Sonata for Solo Violin, an unusual, 47-minute work composed in 1919 and the latest installment in the violinist Paul Zukofsky's series of disks devoted to contemporary and barely heard music for his instrument (CP2/14, LP). Schnabel's public guise was, of course, that of a concert pianist - and, at that, a supreme interpreter of the Viennese and German classics who rarely ventured beyond Brahms. Although Schnabel biographies refer to his less public life as a composer (his entry in the New Grove, for instance, lists three symphonies, five string quartets, a piano concerto and several other chamber and orchestral works among his creations), few of his scores have been published or publicly performed.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The I.B.M. in G.N.P.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 8, 1985 Fiction

title: CASINOS OFFERING PRIZES AND PACKAGES AS WINTERTIME LURE
description: IN AN effort to do something about the annual winter doldrums, the hotel-casinos here are introducing special programs and packages.

title: ST. PETER'S FILLS WILL AND ARIEL DURANT CHAIR IN HUMANITIES
description: ''MY NEW teacher looked a bit ridiculous,'' the 13-year-old schoolgirl named Ariel wrote of her first impression of him.

title: WHEN BABY TALKS, A FATHER LISTENS
description: A FRIEND of mine believes that all American babies begin life speaking a dialect of Chinese, gradually progressing westward through Russian, Polish, and a host of European tongues until stumbling upon English sometime before their second birthday. Chinese babies, of course, are born with the innate ability to converse in English and gradually work their way east. At 15 months, my daughter seems poised somewhere west of Rome and east of Gibralter, possessed of half a dozen words in her mother tongue and an array of Latinate and Iberian-sounding expressions that defy orthography.

title: THE PAIN ISRAEL IS FEELING FOR SPYING BEHIND FRIENDLY LINES
description: When Jonathan Jay Pollard, a United States Navy intelligence analyst, was arrested on charges of spying for Israel, the unique relationship between the two countries was placed for a time under severe strain. Israel has acted - and wanted to be judged - like any other nation pursuing its own national interests. But Israel has also cultivated an intimate relationship with the United States and is thus precluded from behaving as if Washington were just another capital.

title: STUDY URGES NEW DIRECTION FOR ARMS CONTROL
description: President Reagan's plans for a spaced-based defense system could dangerously step up the arms race, according to a study published by the New York City Bar Association.

title: CUOMO ORDERS A SPECIAL SESSON OF THE LEGISLATURE
description: In what was regarded as an uncharacteristically good shove in the jostling for position before next year's statewide elections, Governor Cuomo flexed the powers of his office last week and ordered the Legislature back to work.

title: HIGHER TEACHER PAY GAINS
description: THE head of the state teachers organization is urging its 27,000 members to turn out at regional meetings around the state to demonstrate their support of a proposal that would establish a mandatory minimum salary of $19,300 for starting teachers.

title: DANCE: TIM WENGERD IN A PROGRAM OF SOLOS
description: TIM WENGERD is a distinctive dancer who fills the stage with his powerful presence. He is almost as distinctive a choreographer. And a program of his solos, performed by Mr. Wengerd on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, was a thought-provoking one.

title: FORD JOINS MINIVAN CARAVAN
description: THE third shoe has dropped, so to speak, and Ford's new Aerostar minivan hs arrived, taking its place with Chrysler's popular Voyager/Caravan twins and Chevrolet's recently introduced Astro.

title: EX-HEAD OF MEMPHIS DIOCESE
description: Bishop Carroll T. Dozier, retired head of the Roman Catholic Church's Memphis Diocese, died today after suffering a stroke Thursday. He was 74 years old.

title: TALK OF BETTER TIMES BELIED BY REALITY
description: As public officials and economists voice their opinions from high, comfortable offices, some of them tell us that the economy has substantially improved, the employment situation has improved, the plight of homeless and hungry people has improved, and ''we'' are better off now than ''we'' were a few years ago.

title: BENNY GOODMAN TO LEAD BAND IN YALE BENEFIT CONCERT
description: FOR the first time in New Haven in more than a decade, Benny Goodman will lead a 16-piece swing band in a concert tonight at 8 o'clock in Woolsey Hall at Yale University. The performance is to raise money for the Yale School of Music Scholarship Fund.

title: FACING DEATH WITH STRENGTH
description: THERE has been so much in the news lately concerning the right to die. As I hear Betty Rollin, author of the book, ''First You Cry,'' tell of assisting her dying mother to commit suicide, I think of my own experience with my mother, Celia Henson, who died in 1979.

title: TRYING 120 TASTES OF TAIWAN
description: THE only items that might be recognized on the menu of Foliage, one of several Taiwanese restaurants in Flushing, Queens, are fried rice and wonton soup. And do not expect the fried rice to be dark and laden with soy sauce, the way it is usually served.

title: PATRICE ELAINE BILZI TO WED MICHAEL THOMAS BICKFORD
description: Mr. and Mrs. August W. Bilzi of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patrice Elaine Bilzi to Michael Thomas Bickford, a son of Carol V. Bickford of New Providence, N.J., and Robert D. Bickford of Rochelle, Ill.

title: SPARKLING CRYSTAL FROM DARTINGTON
description: To buy Dartington Glass, the only clear crystal manufactured in England, you can go to Tiffany's in New York or to Crate and Barrel stores in Massachusetts. Or, you can combine a purchase with a visit to one of England's most scenic rural areas, driving through pink and green fields filled with sheep, to Torrington, in North Devon, where the glass is made.

title: DR. CYNTHIA A. PARADIES, INTERN, WED
description: Dr. Cynthia A. Paradies, a daughter of Anita Brunner Paradies and the late Russell Paradies of Hauppauge, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Suber S. Huang, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Pien-Chien Huang of Baltimore. The Rev. William H. Edwards performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: GOOD NEWS FOR CATHOLICS
description: A MERICAN Roman Catholics, accustomed to being critical of their church, were surprised indeed last week by the good news from Rome - the report that the Synod of Bishops may preserve many of the changes initiated 20 years ago by the Second Vatican Council.

title: A HOUSE WITH A HISTORY STANDS THE TEST OF TIME
description: I HAVE lived in this old house almost three decades - all my married life.

title: Put a Lid on the Lobbies, Cont.
description: Last Tuesday, for the first time in years, the United States Senate was about to stand up and be counted on the subject of controlling PAC's, the political action committees that pour out special-interest money to members of Congress. Which senators support even modest limits on all that special-interest peddling? There's still no way to tell, for no such vote took place. The senators ducked. They voted, in an 84-7 blur, in favor of embarrassed obfuscation.

title: BARBARA FORST IS MARRIED ONL.I. TO AN OPTOMETRIST
description: Barbara Terry Forst, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Forst of Lido Beach, L.I., was married in East Rockaway, L.I., yesterday to Dr. Brian Lewy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lewy of Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Amos Miller performed the ceremony at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Temple.

title: THE RETURN OF THE IMPORTANT HAT: ART FOR THE HEAD
description: THE hat has never completely gone out of style, but neither has it made much of an impact on the fashion scene in recent years. Once upon a time, there were hats being made that were truly distinctive.

title: FACULTY DEFENDS ACADEMIC CUSTOM
description: Faculty members at La Guardia Community College in Queens will vote tomorrow to replace a department chairman whose appointment led to the censure of the college's president by the City University Faculty Senate.

title: CANCER CARE BROADENS AIMS
description: AMY SCHINDLER's eyes still fill with tears when she thinks about her father, who died last July. But although she continues to feel grief of intermittent intensity, she now understands that the emotion is normal and appropriate.

title: Q AND A
description: Sharing the Equity Question: I want to sell an investment property next year and use the gains to build a new house with a friend who will use it as a primary residence. Can a single-family house be divided so that 50 percent can be considered an investment by one person, and thus be depreciated, while the other 50 percent is treated as a primary residence by another person? . . . W. P. B., Manhattan Answer: To protect tax benefits when you rent an investment property to a family member or a person who has an interest in it, you must enter into a shared-equity financing agreement as provided in Section 280A of the Internal Revenue Code, according to Rod Young, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service in Washington, D. C. This agreement should state that one of the parties intends to occupy the unit as a principal residence and is required to pay rent to the other party and that the second party is not entitled to occupy the premises as a residence. Both parties should have an undivided interest in the dwelling unit and the land for more than 50 years and the rent must be established in the agreement.

title: COAST GUARD ON L.I. FACES BUDGET CUT
description: A PROPOSED budget reduction for the Coast Guard could cause major problems on Long Island, which has a large number of recreational boats and fishing craft and where the Coast Guard is active in battling drug smuggling.

title: REPORT SEES AQUIFIER DEPLETION
description: A NEW report by the United States Geological Survey warns that ground water and aquifers in southwestern Nassau County and the Southwest Sewer District area in Suffolk County may be severely depleted in the next five years because of overdevelopment.

title: SOVIET ACKNOWLEDGES A FEW CASES OF AIDS
description: The existence of AIDS in the Soviet Union was officially acknowleged for the first time today, although a Soviet professor said the number of cases was less than ''the fingers on one's hand.''

title: DANCE: A SURVEY OF JEAN ERDMAN CHOREOGRAPHY SINCE '42
description: A SELECTION of Jean Erdman's choreography from 1942 through the present is on view this weekend at Hunter College Playhouse (68th Street and Park Avenue), with two final performances scheduled today at 2 and 5 P.M.

title: MITTERAND MEETS JARUZELSKI
description: A front-page headline in Le Monde last week seemed to sum up a nation's bewilderment in a single word: ''Why?'' Why indeed would President Francois Mitterrand agree to meet with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, a man who in many French minds has come to represent the repression of the Polish people?

title: HIGH NOON AT STEAMBOAT
description: A cowboy and his lady, on horses, push gently through stirrup-high snow, skis braced across their Western saddles. Visible through an early-morning mist and beyond a log barn are several ski slopes - as is the poster's only word: Steamboat.

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY BARBARA FLUM
description: Announcement has been made by A. Theodore Flum of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of his daughter Barbara Flum to Marc C. Stein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Zachary Stein of Wernersville, Pa. The wedding is planned for March 1.

title: BUDGET TURNS TO TRIMMING BUDGET
description: A COMMITTEE of the Westchester Board of Legislators cleared its first budget hurdle last week, increasing the proposed 1986 countywide levy by a relatively modest $118,980. Then it began work on a more demanding task - cutting more than $3 million from the same budget.

title: CRITICAL TIMES FOR WATERFRONT
description: FOR THE first time this century, people who live in this old waterfront city can see across the Hudson River from River Street.

title: RHODE ISLAND ROUTED
description: Furman got four touchdown passes from Bobby Lamb and took advantage of nine turnovers by Rhode Island (10-4) for a 59-15 Division I-AA quarterfinal victory today.

title: AMERICAN JOINS THE LOW-COST RANKS
description: DALLAS

title: MAXIM'S SOIREE - IN NEW YORK
description: ''I'm going to Maxim's, where fun and frolic beams . . . .''

title: DANCE TROUPE WITH MULTIMEDIA FLAIR
description: Dance in New York this month seems particularly illuminated by the rising star of Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane - a pair of choreographers whose work is accented by collaboration with a wide array of contemporary artists and composers.

title: MENTALLY ILL RISE IN CITY HOSPITALS
description: The number of mentally ill people taken to New York City's municipal hospitals for treatment has more than doubled in the last three years, while the number of those patients accepted by state mental hospitals has dropped 25 percent, according to the city's Comptroller.

title: BALANCE OF POWER, WIDE RECRUITING KEEP A.C.C. STRONG
description: JOHN SALLEY had proudly worn the baseball cap celebrating his team's Atlantic Coast Conference championship as he passed through an Atlanta hotel lobby and ascended a staircase. But as the Georgia Tech forward reached the room where a press conference was about to begin, he paused to bare his head.

title: 3 CATSKILLS HOTELS BUILDING VACATION HOUSES
description: HARVEY AND ELAINE JOSEPHSON, who live in Sayreville, N.J., recently bought a second home for summer and weekend vacations in Monticello, N.Y. One of the principal reasons they chose to buy where they did is Kutsher's Country Club, a year-round resort hotel where they and their three children had been vacationing guests for years.

title: Curry Establishes an Identity
description: Until he won the unified welterweight title Friday night with a second-round knockout of Milton McCrory, Donald Curry was a fighter who, although admired by the sport's cognescenti, went largely unappreciated by the casual boxing fan.

title: Shuler Earns Favored Status
description: Mickey Shuler's wife figured it out. Her insight is one reason why Shuler has turned into one of the most effective tight ends in the National Football League and why, after spending his first six years as just another body on the Jets, he has become their most productive receiver the last two seasons.

title: 20,000 YOUTHS AT RALLY PLEDGE TO BACK MARCOS
description: About 20,000 pro-Government youths rallied today in support of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and took an oath pledging their readiness to ''die for the country.''

title: FINDING FAULT WITH THE SHAKESPEARE FIND
description: To the Editor:

title: TAX BILL'S IMPACT ON GIVING ASSESSED
description: The tax proposal before Congress would benefit charities that rely on gifts from middle-income wage earners but could prove costly to universities, hospitals and cultural institutions that depend on large gifts from affluent Americans, according to lobbyists for nonprofit organizations.

title: Fashion View;   The New High C's
description: ITERNATIONAL FASHION IS A SEASONAL, OFTEN capricious, business. Every season for the past several years, certain styles have dominated and then receded. Designers in New York, Paris, Milan - and to a degree, London and Tokyo - struggling to anticipate what active women want, or will accept, have reacted with alacrity.

title: 2 CAREERS: SOCIAL WORK AND COMEDY
description: IT'S not that Stephen Young is particularly naive. But the author of ''The Wives of Marty Gladstone,'' a comedy that will have its world premiere Tuesday at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Suffolk, ''assumed I'd write a play and it'd get on Broadway.''

title: FIRE ON L.I. LEAVES A FEELING OF LOSS
description: Cars stop at the driveway next to the charred building to get a better view of the ruins. The motorists, many of whom are from nearby on the North Shore, stare silently at the blackened remains of what was once the Matinecock Meeting House.

title: FOND MEMORIES OF AN EARLY CUP
description: During the recent world team championships in Brazil, on Oct. 31, an unusual party was hosted by Nils Jensen, the Swedish President of the European Bridge League. The Halloween date was a coincidence: It was to mark the official 60th birthday of contract bridge.

title: WHEN DEPRESSION CALLS AT CHRISTMAS
description: JUST before Christmas a few years ago, Dr. Myrna M. Weissman, a professor of psychiatry and epidemiology at Yale's School of Medicine, received a call from a woman in despair. Through her tears, the woman told Dr. Weissman that her in-laws had arrived for the holidays with a gift of 10 pounds of shrimp.

title: Texas Man Is Arrested In Jetliner Bomb Plot
description: A man accused of trying to blow up a jetliner carrying his wife and three daughters to collect their insurance was arrested today in Nevada, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: SHAPING MYRIAD POSSIBILITIES FROM A UBIQUITOUS ELEMENT
description: In its endless metamorphoses, the element carbon has always excited wonder.

title: CABLE TV
description: The cable weeks holds some lesser-known film bargains. Take ''Vivacious Lady'' (1938), a very easy to take comedy with James Stewart and Ginger Rogers -Monday at noon on USA - about a college prof and his club- singer bride. And wait till you see Beulah Bondi dance the Big Apple. ''Rich, Young and Pretty'' (1951) is not a Grade A musical but it has a nice score and some personable players - Jane Powell, Vic Damone, Fernando Lamas and Danielle Darrieux. The highlights are a duet, ''I Can See You,'' and Miss Darrieux's charming ''C'est Fini.'' It's running Tuesday at 10 A.M. and Friday at 2 P.M. on Showtime.

title: No Headline
description: The Government is now requiring officials assigned in this country from East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria to book their travel arrangements within the United States through the State Department.

title: ROBERTA SCHOEN PLANS TO WED FREDERIC S. KESSLER
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Roberta Jane Schoen, the daughter of Marilyn V. Schoen of Morristown, N.J., and Albert Schoen of Dover, N.J., to Frederic Stuart Kessler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Kessler of Union, N.J. The wedding is planned for March. Miss Schoen, an environmental litigation paralegal at the Morristown law firm of Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch, graduated from Kean College and received a paralegal certificate from Upsala College.

title: Recycled Book Titles
description: To the Editor:

title: MEASURING FINGERS AND EYES
description: MARGARET SCHNEIDER, general manager of La Reserve, a plush Westchester hotel, used to worry about the vulnerability of the wine room. The room housed rare bottles and the hotel's electrical heart, yet security was no more elaborate than a key on a hook in the maitre d'hotel's office. No one had ever broken in, but it seemed too easy to do so.

title: Extension for Perkins
description: He may not be a Bear Bryant, but after three seasons, Ray Perkins has apparently passed minimum muster at Alabama. Perkins, who took over the Alabama football program when Bryant retired after the 1982 season, was given a three-year contract extension that will keep him at Alabama through 1990.

title: DON'T REMOVE TAX EXEMPTION ON NONPROFIT MEDICAL PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: SERVICE SECTOR STILL GROWING
description: As job growth in the service sector accelerated after the end of the latest recession, so did the debate about whether the United States is becoming a two-class nation socially and economically and a second-class country industrially. Last week's employment report is unlikely to help settle the dispute.

title: SIMPLE PLEASURES, OLD STANDBYS
description: SHADE Tree certainly has good intentions.

title: THE DAILY CHALLENGES OF LIVING IN SHADOWS
description: Food... shelter... medical care... basics that pose daily challenges for the poor and needy in the City of New York. Surrounded by wealth and middle-class comfort, the people who have been Impoverished by illness, economic discrimination and life circumstances struggle to feed themselves and their families, to find safe rooms in which to sleep, to treat illness before life is irrevocably threatened. Victims of contemporary urban life, the poor and th needy of the city are forced to live in shadows.

title: JAMEY S. WERTZ ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. McCann Jr. of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. McCann's daughter Jamey S. Wertz to Kevin Palmer Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent B. Murphy Jr. of Far Hills, N.J. The wedding is planned for March 22.

title: THE RISE, AND FALL AND RISE AGAIN OF WILLDURANT, TRUTH-SEEKER
description: NOV. 5 marked the 100th anniversary of the birth of Will Durant, the controversial philosopher and historian and the winner of a Pulitzer Prize and a Presidential Medal of Freedom. He died at age 96 on Nov. 7, 1981, just two weeks after the death of his wife and collaborator, Ariel.

title: New Agenda for the Women's Movement
description: I would like to respond on behalf of ''the young generation who take for granted the rights we won and who do not defend those rights. . . .''

title: DEFENSE SAYS KEY U.S. WITNESS TERRORIZED PERSICO
description: The defense in the Colombo crime-group racketeering trial charged last week that the Federal authorities abused the legal rights and ''played with the minds'' of Carmine Persico and other defendants during an undercover investigation half a dozen years ago.

title: EDUCATORS APPEAL FOR PUBLIC'S HELP
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones and two of his predecessors warned last week of eroding public confidence and interest in the public schools and urged civic organizations and individuals to play more active roles in public education.

title: BARNES FOUNDATION OFFERS A RARE ARRAY OF ART
description: DESPITE the plethora of paintings at the popular Renoir exhibition at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, visitors may notice they cannot find a number of their favorite Renoirs - perhaps the pert portrait of a ''Girl With Jumping Rope'' or the famous ''Artist's Family'' or the gritty ''Mussel Fishers at Berneval.''

title: POWERFUL PROCEDURE IN CANCER FIGHT
description: DURING nearly four hours of surgery, doctors at University Hospital here recently removed two large cancerous growths from a 59-year-old man.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Football Jets vs. Bills, at Orchard Park, N.Y. The Jets are on the road for the last time during the regular season. (Television -Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1 P.M.) Giants vs. Oilers, at Houston. Joe Morris, with 925 yards rushing, needs only 75 yards to become the second Giant 1,000-yarder behind Ron Johnson, who reached 1,000 yards twice. Butch Woolfolk, the former Giant, has 64 catches, the most by a running back in the Houston club's history, for 666 yards. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. WNEW 1130, 4 P.M.) Broncos vs. Los Angeles Raiders, at Denver. The Broncos are 18-2 in their last 20 games at Mile High Stadium and this game will be played before their 116th consecutive home sellout. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Chargers vs. Pittsburgh Steelers, at San Diego. The Steelers lead the series, 8-3, but have not won in San Diego since 1977. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. This is the second game in the home-and-home weekend series. (Television -MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7:20 P.M.) Track and Field M.A.C. Development Meet, at the 102d Engineers Armory, 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, 10 A.M. Jama Aden, who ran the 800 and 1,500 meters and captained the Somalian Olympic team at Los Angeles will run the 660 and the 2-mile. Other Events BASEBALL: Metros de San Juan vs.

title: MISS HALSEY HAS WEDDING
description: Mary Shaw Halsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Selden Halsey of Richmond, was married there yesterday to Robert Evan Marks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Harold Marks of Washington. The Rev. Don Raby Edwards performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Taking a Beating in Line Scalping Horowitz
description: A music lover we know got up at dawn two Mondays ago to buy tickets to the Dec. 15 Vladimir Horowitz concert. In recent years, the lines at Carnegie Hall for Mr. Horowitz's rare appearances have been like elongated kaffeeklatsches.

title: HOLIDAY PROGRAMS ABOUND THIS WEEK
description: WE seem to have hit the jackpot this week, with more than a dozen holiday concerts scheduled today in the county and even more during the week. Following is a sampling:

title: ACTORS MAKE LEARNING FUN
description: THE auditorium at the Memorial Boulevard Middle School in Bristol filled to capacity one recent afternoon with noisy seventh and eighth graders. Quickly they took their seats, and almost as quickly their chattering died down.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SCREEN FARCE TO HOLIDAY SONGS
description: Swan Lake A Royal Ballet production, featuring Natalia Makarova and Anthony Dowell; directed by John Michael Phillips, 1980 Thorn EMI/HBO Video 128 minutes. $39.95 One of ballet's great stories of love and enchantment is retold in a recording of a live performance by the Royal Ballet.

title: HOLIDAY TRADITION: A SORTAGE OF WORKERS
description: ''SO many jobs and so few people,'' is the lament of managers at retail stores, supermarkets and fast-food restaurants around the state. Despite aggressive recruiting efforts and offers of higher wages, merchandise discounts and flexible hours, many employers said they may be short-handed for the holidays.

title: BUT THAT'S GREENMAIL!
description: THE YEAR THEY SOLD WALL STREET By Tim Carrington. 245 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95 ''MAYDAY'' - killing off the New York Stock Exchange fixed-commission schedule in favor of negotiated rates - badly squeezed most retail-oriented brokerage firms. Many went out of business or merged. Then, as mutual funds, pension funds and insurance companies came to dominate the market, the average size of stock exchange transactions ballooned. Large blocks (10,000 shares and up) are half of total exchange volume, up from 5 per cent 20 years ago. A broker able to take a $10-million block of stock off a customer's hands into its own inventory, to distribute at leisure, can get the business away from one that offers to dribble the stock out for the customer over weeks or months. That, however, calls for substantial capital. To get it, some large brokerage houses floated their shares to the public or looked for merger partners.

title: JOYCE LINDOWER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At Congregation Ohr Torah in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday Joyce Sue Lindower and Steven Barry Warren Wolitzer were married by Rabbi Theodore Jungreis.

title: 1776 CAME EARLY IN THE CARIBBEES
description: The members of the colonial Legislature had gathered in the Assembly Hall, pistols in their belts and muskets stacked by the door, to vote defiance of the high-handed tax and trade policies of England's Parliament. These English settlers had, through decades of toil, cleared virgin forests and created the richest, most populous colony in the Americas. Over the years, however, they had grown a bit too independent-minded for the Motherland, and finally a fleet of gunships carrying English regulars had been dispatched to subdue them. Now cannons of that fleet were firing on their defenses, while the English infantrymen on board were donning armor in preparation to invade. Would these colonists declare war on England and fight for their freedom?

title: A GIFT A GARDENER WILL ENJOY
description: IF you are still looking for that perfect gift for the gardener on your holiday shopping list, look no further. The ideal gift is a membership in one of the botanical gardens or arboretums in the region. Why would one wish to consider such a gift? The benefits are many and varied.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: THE CHRISTMAS BOX. By Eve Merriam. Illustrated by David Small. Morrow. $11.75. (Ages 3 to 5) A happy Christmas story by the distinguished poet who explains how the presents for a large family somehow all fit into one long slim box.

title: ROBERT GRAVES, POET AND SCHOLAR, DIES AT 90
description: Robert Graves, the English poet, novelist and classical scholar, died yesterday at his home in Deya, a fishing village on the island of Majorca. He was 90 years old and had been living in seclusion since failing health stayed his pen 10 years ago.

title: CINCINNATIANS SEEK LEGACY OF CENTENNIAL
description: Ninety-seven years ago this city's gala centennial celebration came and went without leaving a permanent monument.

title: SETTING THE POST-SUMMIT TONE
description: IN THEIR ENTHUSIASM OVER the summit meeting in Geneva, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, have both proclaimed a fresh opening, a thaw in Soviet-American relations.

title: WHO HASN'T FAILED ONCE?
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING OUT IN OLD BOSTON
description: There can still be found in the city of Boston a few beetle-browed and venerable old restaurants down various side streets, that evoke memories of decades, even centuries past. While the charge has often been made that Boston is not a premier restaurant city - in spite of the fact that it has some superb fish restaurants, a variety of Italian restaurants (especially in the North End), and the fourth largest Chinatown in the country - surely it has among the most historical.

title: TOPICS
description: I WASN'T worried about the inside of the house because I realized they wouldn't care if there was dust on the furniture or fingerprints on the walls. Their main interest was the property, and I knew they had already been looking at it.

title: ENVOY TO MOSCOW, MR. ENVIRONMENT
description: IT may be a little bit after the fact, but following numerous trips to the Soviet Union, Nicholas A. Robinson of North Tarrytown is learning Russian. He started a course at Pace University in September, interrupting his studies for a week last month so he could make yet another Soviet sojourn, this time to Moscow and Leningrad.

title: Hungary
description: To the Editor: Paul Lewis's article on Hungary's Versailles (Travel, Oct. 13) brought back to me both pleasant and sad memories.

title: TV NEWS: WHEN EXPERIENCE TAKES OVER
description: How does television cover the news, and who says it's news, anyway? Coincidentally, two programs this week ask the questions, and even if their answers aren't definitive, it's good to know that someone is thinking about the subject. As Peter Jennings says on one of the programs, citing an ABC survey of young people, ''Nearly 70 percent consider television news their most important source of information.'' In fact, Mr. Jennings could have gone further. Ever since 1963, according to the Roper Organization, more people, young and otherwise, have said they get their news from television than anywhere else. Television images inform our thinking, but why those particular images? ''Making the News,'' an ABC ''Notebook Special,'' Wednesday afternoon at 4, says they arise from a journalistic collaboration. ''Race Against Prime Time,'' Tuesday night at 11 on Channel 13, says it's all more complicated than that. Each program, in its way, is pretty good.

title: A BANKER IS WED TOMISS STEPHENS IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Anne MacDonald Stephens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Stephens Jr. of Greensboro, N.C., was married there yesterday to William Burwell Harrison Jr., an executive vice president of Chemical Bank in New York and a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison of Rocky Mount, N.C. Msgr. William Pharr performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church.

title: IS THERE A WIZARD IN THE HOUSE?
description: Alexander Alekhine, who dominated the chess world from his victory over Jose Raul Capablanca in 1927 until his death in 1946, considered as a ''curious psychological weakness . . . the impression that I could always, or nearly always, when in a bad position, conjure up some unexpected combination to extricate me from my difficulties.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE l>By Barbara Delatiner
description: FEAST OF LIGHTS Today, the first day of Hanukkah, Jews throughout Long Island mark the ancient Feast of Lights. In Commack, at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Suffolk at 74 Hauppauge Road, festivities begin at 1 P.M. with a Family Hanukkah Party, complete with games, crafts projects, the storyteller Heather Forest, a sing-along led by Cantor Moishe Berger and, of course, a helping of potato latkes. Admission is $8.50 a family, $6.50 for members, with reduced fees for singles and senior citizens, and includes a chance to see ''Eight Artists for Eight Candles,'' a special art exhibition that runs through next Sunday. Call 462-9800 for information.

title: ALL UNQUIET ON THE WEST FRONT
description: An act of Government has turned up that is running well ahead of schedule, is costing less than the appropriated millions, has been free of spies, so far, and will look good when it is finished.

title: SPIRIT OF 1780
description: WHEN salvagers reported finding a sunken Revolutionary War frigate in New York's East River last September, they were elated. They said the 26-gun British frigate, H.M.S. Hussar, contained a payroll in gold now worth $576 million.

title: WORK-FORCE SHORTAGE WILL WORSEN
description: BUSINESSES in the state are begining to face a people crisis the way they did an energy crisis in the 1970's, and the result will be similar to what happened when the Arabs turned off the oil - a severe dislocation in the market.

title: HOUSING FOR THE AGED
description: Most recent development in Secaucus, N.J., where 85 percent of the town lies within the Hackensack Meadowlands Development District, has been upscale office, retail and residential projects.

title: A MOUSE THAT IS ROARING ABROAD
description: HISTORIAN Edward Crankshaw once said of the Hapsburgs that they differed from other monarchs because they literally owned their empire.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WORLD OF WINES In time for the holidays, Kevin Zraly, wine director of Windows on the World, high in Manhattan's World Trade Center, will fill you in on what's nouveau, what has aged gracefully, the latest industry trends and everything else a host should know as he or she inserts corkscrew (A) into bottleneck (B). Mr. Zraly will conduct a program at 7 P.M. Wednesday in the Mount Pleasant Library, at 350 Bedford Road, that includes wine tastings and a complimentary copy of his book, ''Windows on the World Complete Wine Course.''

title: No Team, No Dome
description: Stadiums should be built by towns that have teams to play in them. New York City no longer has a professional football team and the only way to get one seems to be to build a new domed stadium. So long as the two are kept in tandem, public approval of Donald Trump's domed stadium scheme appears justified.

title: 45 MINUTES FROM HONG KONG
description: Far from the madding crowd of Hong Kong, though only 45 minutes away by ferry, is the island of Peng Chau, where you won't find peace and quiet either. But this weather-beaten little island (Peng Chau seems to get particularly pummeled by the later summer typhoons) offers an unhampered look at traditional Chinese sea-village life. In addition it is famous among the Hong Kong Chinese for its fresh seafood and its hand-painted porcelain.

title: NEW LIFE FOR 'LITTLE SHOP'
description: Back in 1960 Roger Corman made a grade-Z movie, ''The Little Shop of Horrors,'' on a budget so low as to be barely visible. Now, 25 years on, an $18 million film is being made on the largest sound stage in the world (Pinewood's aptly-named 007) of the Off Broadway hit musical of the same name, with book and lyrics by Howard Ashman and music by Alan Menken. Once again a bespectacled Skid Row botanist buys a tiny plant that grows to man-eating proportions, a plant he feeds with human flesh in exchange for fame and fortune. And once again Ellen Greene, of the hourglass figure and lisping voice, plays his girlfriend Audrey, who, along with many others, is fed to this vegetable Dracula.

title: TOPICS
description: I NEVER thought I'd be starting my own business, what with all the risks, but I've come up with a venture that is sure to succeed, and I've got none other than Mayor Koch to thank. Mayor Koch plans to ban any car without at least one passenger from entering Manhattan by way of the East River and Harlem bridges during the rush hour.

title: Civilization
description: To the Editor: Your article ''Where Music Lives in London'' (Travel, Oct. 13) was excellent.

title: GORBACHEV'S MOST FAVORED NATIONS
description: For a man who snubbed the Kremlin only a few years ago, Prime Minister Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe was surprisingly accommodating last week during his first official visit to Moscow. He signed two trade and economic agreements and said nothing about old grudges that stemmed from Soviet support for his rival, Joshua Nkomo, during their long guerrilla war against white minority rule. ''We look to the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Mugabe said, ''for example, inspiration and, indeed, guidance.'' .

title: PERSPECTIVES: J-51 and 421a;   TAX BENEFITS AND REGULATED RENTS
description: IN 1969, Irving and Thelma Sherman bought a five-family house on East 11th Street and renovated it into three floor-throughs, a studio apartment and a duplex for themselves using tax benefits under the city's J-51 program.

title: New Agenda for the Women's Movement
description: Betty Friedan's poignant and timely article ''How to Get the Women's Movement Moving Again'' (Nov. 3), recognizes precisely the problems which have been crippling the movement for over half a decade. Not only does Mrs. Friedan accurately cite the causes of feminist apathy in America, but she gives feasible and promising solutions for our dormant ''evolution'' and offers us a Phase 2 strategy for a successful revival. PATRICIA CONHEENEY Ridgewood, N.J.

title: GUATEMALA TO ELECT PRESIDENT TODAY
description: Guatemalans turn out to vote Sunday to elect a new President, but their principal concern is not who will win, but whether the winner will be able to consolidate his government without military interference.

title: Teheran Car Bomb Kills 2
description: A car bomb exploded in front of a hospital in northern Teheran today, killing 2 people and wounding 18, officials and residents said. Iran's national press agency blamed ''agents of imperialism,'' an official term for opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GRACE IN THE WILDERNESS After the Liberation 1945-1948. By Aranka Siegal. 220 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 12 and up) ARANKA SIEGAL'S award-winning first book, ''Upon the Head of the Goat,'' detailed the harrowing story of the Davidowitz family's roundup by the Nazis and ended with four of the Hungarian Jewish children and their mother boarding a transport train for Auschwitz. This sequel begins with the liberation of Bergen-Belsen, which 15-year-old Piri Davidowitz and her sister Iboya have survived through luck and their deep, protective bond. What has happened between the train and the arrival of the Allied troops surfaces in an autobiography that reads more like fiction as the narrator recounts her postwar recovery and relocation to Sweden.

title: DAY-CARE WORKER HELD IN ASSAULTS ON CHILDREN
description: An employee of a day-care center in Maplewood, N.J., has been indicted for 229 offenses in connection with the sexual assault of 33 children between 3 and 6 years of age over a 6-month period.

title: LINDA POTTER TO WED TIMOTHY SHRIVER
description: The engagement of Linda Potter and Timothy Shriver has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Potter of New York and McLean, Va. Mr. Shriver is a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Sargent Shriver of Washington and Hyannisport, Mass.

title: TESTS DISTRIBUTED TO DETECT CANCER
description: A PROGRAM to aid in the early detection of colorectal cancer has been initiated by the Naugatuck Valley Health District, following studies showing that the rate of this cancer is increasing among residents of the district's six towns.

title: JULIE GABRIK IS MARRIED TOMICHAEL D. THOMAS
description: At the Basking Ridge (N.J.) Presbyterian Church yesterday Julie Ann Gabrik and Michael Dillon Thomas were married by the Rev. Dr. Calvin Jackson.

title: TRACKING THE WANDERING WHITE-TAIL
description: THEIR golden-brown autumn colors blend with the scrub, except for the ''white flag'' - the tail that gives them their name. As they graze, stepping ever so lightly, they are being watched.

title: 2 SOVIET EMIGRES TRY TO FIND A FOOTHOLD
description: SONYA K. - a shy, fragile woman of 32 years - shifted uneasily on the sofa in her Queens apartment recently as the moist, a salty night air drifted through the windows. She was groping for just the right words to describe how she and her mother, Liza felt on April 24, 1980, the day they received permission to leave the Soviet Union.

title: HELPING CHILDREN COPE AFTER SIEGE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: At the William Cullen Bryant Elementary School in West Philadelphia, students have been working on a different kind of writing assignment - one designed to help them get over the fright they felt after the police siege of the headquarters of the radical group Move last May.

title: CHASING THE GHOSTS OF IMAGINATION
description: Clutching a microphone with both hands, Steven Wright walks on stage as if he were Hamlet pacing the parapets of Elsinore. Crowned with frizzy hair that accentuates his beetling brow, the boyish, 29-year-old comedian projects a disposition that teeters between the antic and the poetic. Like Shakespeare's melancholy prince, Mr. Wright too is chasing a ghost - his own imagination - and he prowls with a frowning intensity as he summons the odd, unsettling and very funny images that appear to his mind's eye.

title: 42 YEARS, AND A STADIUM FULL OF BASEBALL MEMORIES
description: On Dec. 31, Lee MacPhail will retire after an association with baseball that began 42 years ago. The New York Times asked him to recount the highlights of his years of involvement with the game.

title: CHINA ON THE MOVE: WILL THE CHANGE LAST
description: FOR THOSE WHO KNEW the China of Mao Zedong, a shrill, implacable place where anything remotely Western was automatically suspect, the country is barely recognizable these days. Not even in the 19th century heyday of the Taipans and the missionaries and the foreign concessions was it as accessible to the outside world as it has become in the era of Deng Xiaoping.

title: SHARI FRIEDMAN IS WED
description: Shari T. Friedman, an associate director of on-air network operations for NBC-TV, and Dr. Joseph Y. Bistricer, an optometrist, were married yesterday at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Herschel Cohen performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irving Friedman of Bayside, Queens, and Sara Bistricer of Brooklyn and the late Bezalel Bistricer.

title: SHRUGGING OFF A THREAT TO CABLE
description: A recent Appeals Court decision that threatens to open cable television to unlimited competition would seem to cast a shadow on the industry's future, but not in the eyes of Wall Street. ''We have not changed any of our ratings,'' said John S. Reidy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., who said most of the leading cable stocks are trading at or near their historic highs.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ANYONE who lives or works in, or drives through, Morris County knows that its most obvious problem is traffic. Residential and commercial growth have clogged its major arteries.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PROCESS REMOVES LEAKED GASOLINE FROM WATER SUPPLY OF PRONVINCETOWN
description: When William Watts began missing gasoline from an underground storage tank at his service station in North Truro, he was sure a thief was stealing a few gallons after closing time. The police investigated, but found no one.

title: Too Heavy to Compete
description: When Lyle (Pooh) Burrell reported for his senior wrestling season at Mount Clemens High School in Michigan this year, he may have dreamed of becoming the Refrigerator of the sport. That's because Burrell, who had a 37-10-2 record as a husky-enough junior, reported to practice weighing 315 pounds.

title: HELENBETH REISS WED TO JOHN M. REYNOLDS
description: At Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Helenbeth Reiss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marc J. Reiss of Great Neck, was married to John Maynard Reynolds, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Maynard Reynolds of Arden Hills, Minn. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: POTVIN TIES ORR IN DEFEAT
description: Despite elaborate planning and a record-tying goal by Denis Potvin, the Islanders were beaten, 4-1, by the Quebec Nordiques tonight at Nassau Coliseum. There was a moment of elation when Potvin, who has labored since he was a teen-ager under the long shadow cast by Bobby Orr, slammed a blistering wrist shot into the net and tied Orr's 915-point National Hockey League record for defensemen. However, the thrill was short-lived, Potvin said after the game, because the rest of the evening produced nothing but frustration for his team.

title: Pearl Harbor Attack Recalled in Ceremony
description: Forty-four years after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, America remains determined that it ''will not again be caught unready,'' a Navy admiral said today at a ceremony marking the anniversary.

title: KATHERINE BIGGS WEDS
description: Katherine Lauren Biggs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Biggs of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jack Eldon Underwood Jr., a son of Mr. Underwood of Centralia, Wash., and Betty Lou Underwood of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. James Kavanagh performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont.

title: VIDEO ART: TELEVISION AS CANVAS
description: TECHNOLOGY affects art as it does so many other things.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Taking a Beating in Line L.I.R.R. Buck-Passing
description: The Long Island Rail Road! The very words long denoted the scourge of commuters and the bane of holiday travelers. Nowadays, the L.I.R.R. has finally achieved the improvements Nelson Rockefeller once promised, and the public takes them for granted. On-time performance has risen to 84 percent.

title: COAL TRADE TO MAKE A COMEBACK ON HUDSON RIVER
description: More than a century ago, the Hudson River was a major shipping artery for coal transported in barges through the Delaware and Hudson Canal across the Shawangunk Mountains from Pennsylvania and then downriver to New York City.

title: BUILDING INTEGRATED THEATER
description: HER ideals 'may seem corny,'' she concedes, but Carol Penney repeats them anyway in describing the Alliance Theater in New Haven. Through her conversation, she talks about ''crossing the color line,'' and ''filling a cultural gap,'' and ''breaking racial barriers'' and ''having a positive belief that people should be seen as people.''

title: SCULPTOR OF THE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE
description: Is it possible that at the turn of our century it was Augustus Saint-Gaudens, as much as any other single human being, who set the tone of New York City? For the answer to that question we need look no further than Grand Army Plaza in front of the Plaza Hotel. Rare is the New Yorker and rarer still the foreign visitor, who has not at least a subliminal acquaintance with the Sherman Monument that occupies so conspicuous a position at the southeastern corner of Central Park. Even those who have never heard of General Sherman are struck by the imperious old warrior as he sits upright on his horse and is guided forward, as if in a trance, by a beautiful young woman in the guise of Victory.

title: FACT OR OPINION KEY TO CBS APPEAL
description: The issue of whether a televised commentary involving the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation dealt with fact or opinion will be central to the appeal of a $5.05 million libel judgment against CBS Inc. and a Chicago television commentator, according to the defendants' attorney.

title: LOSS IS 14th STRAIGHT TO THE FLYERS
description: It is almost automatic: When the Flyers play the Rangers, they win - especially when the New Yorkers perform as they did this afternoon at the Spectrum.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SCREEN FARCE TO HOLIDAY SONGS
description: Gulliver's Travels Starring Richard Harris, Catherine Shell, Norman Shelley, Meredith Edwards; produced by Raymond Leblanc and Derek Horne, 1977 United Home Video 80 minutes. $24.95 (G) Can any screen adaptation of the Jonathan Swift classic conjure up images as vivid as the pictures in our own minds when we turn the pages of ''Gulliver's Travels''? Well, no, but this film, newly available on video cassette, tries its best.

title: A SIGNAL, OF SORTS, IS SENT TO DYNAMICS
description: In suspending General Dynamics from obtaining new Government contracts, the Pentagon intended to signal military contractors that it would not tolerate the types of cost overruns and fraud that it claims the company perpetrated on the Army when it developed the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun. That situation resulted in the indictments of three Dynamics executives, the company and NASA's administrator, himself an ex-official of Dynamics. But the message that came through this week was quite different. The Pentagon said Dynamics was suspended, all right, but a day later the Navy said it would delay awarding contracts on a submarine project, and possibly other projects, until the suspension was lifted. As a result Dynamics, which says it should never have been indicted, is expected to lose very little business.

title: 6 FOUND DEAD AFTER CONNECTICUT BLAST
description: Fire crews today pulled six bodies from the rubble of a three-story restaurant on Main Street that collapsed Friday in a fiery explosion that buried patrons and workers.

title: Wine View;   Hitting the Limit
description: A DECADE AGO, THE wine and spirits world was astonished - and delighted - by the way Americans seemed to be taking to wine. The number of wine drinkers was said to be doubling, and doubling again, and seers were predicting that by the end of the century America would rival some of the European wine-drinking countries in the amount of wine consumed.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SCREEN FARCE TO HOLIDAY SONGS
description: The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie Starring Fernando Rey, Stephane Audran, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Delphine Seyrig, Bulle Ogier, Paul Frankeur, Julien Bertheau; directed by Luis Bunuel, 1972 Media Home Entertainment 100 minutes. $59.95 Luis Bunuel's enchantingly funny, French comedy deserved every award it won in 1972, including the Oscar as best foreign-language film.

title: A FURRIER CARRIES ON THE TRADITION
description: ''I THINK of myself as being in the outerwear business,'' said Jeff Tepper of Roslyn Heights. And that he is. But some of his outerwear sells for $150,000.

title: BAKING: AROMATIC ACTIVITY FOR THE SEASON
description: THE holiday season is in full swing now. It is a fragrant time of year, perfumed by evergreens, of course, but also by the heady aroma of spice-scented baking. Ovens are kept busy nearly around the clock.

title: PAYING TWICE FOR THE SAME TRIP
description: Edith Zatz was irked. ''We booked a tour to Great Britain with our local travel agent,'' she said, ''and paid him in full - about $2,500.''

title: THE DANCE: WORK BY MARK MORRIS
description: IT is not simply his cleverness that makes Mark Morris worth watching. This young choreographer is interesting because of his willingness to try out many styles. One never knew what to expect next when the Mark Morris Dance Group performed Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 8, 1985 Fiction

title: AOTHER CUT AT SOCIAL SECURITY DISABILITY ROLLS
description: Past attempts by the Reagan Administration to review the medical status of people who draw Social Security disability checks prompted complaints that thousands were being removed from the rolls improperly. Last week, the Government said it would start next month a fresh round of pulse-takings, using new eligibility guidelines enacted by Congress last year.

title: Pitching Is the Prime Need As Officials Prepare to Meet
description: EVERYBODY in the world, Al Rosen said, ''is always looking for pitching. It's not that easy to get.'' Rosen, the new general manager of the San Francisco Giants and former front-office chief of the Houston Astros and the Yankees, basically is correct in his view that everybody always is looking for pitching. In fact, when officials of all 26 major league teams were asked what they would be looking for at this week's annual winter meetings in San Diego, only three failed to mention pitching.

title: 'TIPPLING' IS AN OLD TRADITION
description: THE wealthy 17th- and 18th- century families had punch bowls made of silver, of blown glass and of fine porcelain. The punch bowls were taken down from the shelves or off the sideboard and washed, dusted or polished for celebrations and parties. The basic early recipe for punch was spirits mixed with water, sugar, the juice of lemons or oranges and spices - perhaps cinnamon, nutmeg and sometimes a bay leaf.

title: FERTILITY RATE'S UPS AND DOWNS
description: The Census Bureau confirmed last week what experts on social trends - not to mention many new mothers - have talked about for years: More and more women in the United States are waiting longer to have babies. Although the overall fertility rate fell last year, the bureau reported, the rate continued to rise for women 30 to 34 years old.

title: COMPETING FOR TALENT WITH PRIVATE INDUSTRY
description: In mathematics and science, according to the National Science Foundation, the United States is in trouble.

title: A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: HELP THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: DAVID'S wife died the day after their eighth wedding anniversary, on a warm afternoon at the end of March. She called him at work, gasping for breath from an astham attack. When he reached their home in a housing project in the South Bronx, he knew that this was the end. She was 33 years old.

title: Antitrust Law
description: To the Editor:

title: NAVY STUNS ARMY IN 17-7 UPSET
description: The persistent power running of Napoleon McCallum and a defense that throttled the Cadets' wishbone offense brought Navy an upset victory over Army, 17-7, at Veterans Stadium today.

title: CUNY FINALLY HAS SOME ELBOW ROOM
description: When city officials announced plans for a new $118 million campus of Hostos Community College in the South Bronx, many people in the embattled borough applauded the project for what it might do to help stabilize the community.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR BLUE-LAW APPEAL
description: THE State Supreme Court has agreed to hear appeals by Ocean City and Paramus of an Appellate Division ruling last spring that overturned their Sunday blue laws.

title: COOKING
description: This has been a fine year for cookbooks. Name a topic, and somewhere in the huge pile there is sure to be at least one high-quality book that addresses it. Breathtaking picture books one would not dream of bringing into the kitchen vie with the more practical - and less expensive - for consideration. There is something for everyone - even people who don't cook.

title: TOW SONGWRITERS PREPARING REUNION
description: TWO former collaborators, who wrote hundreds of songs recorded by top popular singers, will have a professional reunion in Purchase next Sunday during the last of three performances of ''Pops '85,'' the Theater League of Westchester's third holiday songfest.

title: NEW DEMAND FOR SURF CLAMS
description: THE docks and bulkheads of Mattituck Inlet have been busy this fall as commercial fishing boats from all over Long Island compete for clams -Long Island Sound surf clams.

title: SAN FRANCISCO BALLET IN 'CINDERELLA' SPECIAL
description: MAGIC effects are scattered throughout ''San Francisco Ballet in 'Cinderella,' '' a ''Dance in America'' holiday special that airs as part of the Great Performances series on WNET-TV/Channel 13 today at 6:05 P.M. A puff of smoke transforms an ancient, ugly hag into a beautiful fairy. The hag disappears up the chimney of a cavernous fireplace in which a fire burns. The fairy flies up and across a night sky. A giant totters about the stage. But the greatest magic of this fairy-tale production, set to the haunting Prokofiev score, is its complete suitability for both adults and children.

title: About Men;   A Peace Walk
description: WHEN MY SON, TIM, WAS 10 years old, 12 years ago, he and I went hiking together. I was writing a book about the Ozark wilderness of the southern Middle West; the hike began in the morning at the head of a creek in Missouri's Mark Twain National Forest and ended in the evening well downstream with a scramble up a steep bluff and a weary five-mile walk out a dirt road back to our car. Along the way we talked, my son and I, skinny-dipped, ate tuna from a can and mandarin oranges, dodged a water snake. Most vividly, I remember convincing Tim to hone his survival skills by consuming a live ant; we joked about his guilelessness for years. I knew that child well: he was whole and not yet self-conscious. Only his stamina across 10 hours of hiking surprised me.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Trip Into the Past In Cross River Chattels is an antiques, collectibles and vintage clothing shop that opened two years ago in Cross River at the Amoco station on Route 35, well off the beaten track of holiday buying. Quality consignments are accepted and the tree ornaments are both new and old, locally made and imported.

title: On Teaching Writing: Replies Missed Point
description: Spirited as the responses were to ''On the Art of Teaching Writing'' (Opinion Page, Oct. 20), they missed the point: Barrington, Ill., represents one model for improving student writing that has gone beyond other programs by formally involving the community.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKING FARM BILL CHANGES
description: President Reagan today blamed past administrations for the crisis in American agriculture and called on Congress to overhaul the nation's farm policy and send him a farm bill ''I can sign.''

title: POETS AND COMPUTERS
description: 'One needs to be a practicing poet, and these scholars have no ear for poetry. A computer is no judge of what is poetry.

title: TIME TO GO
description: In 1953, the Bulova Watch Corporation built an Art Deco-style headquarters building and assembly plant in Jackson Heights, Queens. But now that much of the company's product is made overseas, the need for its industrial space has been sharply reduced.

title: GEORGE STREET'S 'CABARET' GETS TO THE PLAY'S NONMUSICAL CORE
description: THE best things about the George Street Playhouse production of the musical ''Cabaret'' are not musical. At times, one feels that the theater would be better served by a straight-on version of ''I Am a Camera,'' the John Van Druten play from which ''Cabaret'' was derived.

title: COLINIAL CHRISTMAS, CONTEMPORARY HOLLAND
description: When Holidays Weren't Festive Strange as it may seem in these days when so much warm tradition surrounds the celebration of Christmas, there was a time in America when taking the day off or enjoying a festive meal might earn the holidayer a fine. That was the period between 1659 and 1681 in Massachusetts, when the colony's laws mandated a 5-shilling levy against anyone who feasted or stopped work on a day when secular observances were offensive to Puritan beliefs and a celebratory meal was regarded as a ''wanton Bacchanalian feast.''

title: BROADER STATE ROLE SOUGHT IN AIDING GIFTED CHILD
description: ALTHOUGH the State Legislature has been debating a measure that would provide $9 million in local grants to identify and properly educate intellectually and academically gifted school-age children, the education of similarly gifted preschool children has, for the most part, been ignored by public schools, according to Jeanne Carlson, a specialist in teaching gifted children.

title: CENSORSHIP: WHAT NEXT?
description: I GREW up in a not-very-unusual suburb in what has become the much-mythologized decade of the 60's.

title: SIGHTS AND SOUNDS OF WAR ENGULF A UGANDA TORN BY INTERNAL STRIFE
description: Tonight there was laughter and dancing at the Hotel Diplomate here in the green hills of this city. But at the hotel's gate, there were young men with automatic rifles, and in the distance the rumble of artillery could be heard.

title: ROGER L. KRAKOFF, LISA A. KUHLMAN TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Kuhlman of Ladue, Mo., of the engagement of their daughter Lisa Anne Kuhlman to Roger Lawrence Krakoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Krakoff of Weston, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 7.

title: ELISA L. MAROTTA IS WED
description: Elisa L. Marotta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Marotta of Baldwin, L.I., was married there yesterday to Roberto C. Fini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Fini of Elmont, L.I. The Rev. Manerto Soriano performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Fini is a marketing officer for Citicorp Industrial Credit in Harrison, N.Y. Her father is a consultant for the Richmond Hill Savings Bank in Floral Park, L.I. Mr. Fini is president and his father is chairman of the LeFini Building Corporation in Bayside, Queens.

title: MARY PALLADINO WEDS MICHAEL E. SILVERSTEIN
description: The marriage of Mary Louise Palladino, an associate in the New York law firm of Chadbourne & Parke, to Michael Emanuel Silverstein, a candidate for a master's degree in psychology at New York University, took place yesterday at the Brooklyn Club in Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. H. Scott Matheney, Presbyterian chaplain at Columbia University, performed the ceremony.

title: 7 Die in India Bus Plunge
description: A crowded bus plunged into a ditch today, killing 7 people and injuring 60. The accident occurred near Nalanda in Bihar state, about 550 miles southeast of New Delhi in eastern India, the United News of India reported.

title: ROBYN M. TRACA IS THE BRIDE OF SCOTT M. BERMAN
description: Robyn Michele Traca, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Traca of Sunnyside, Queens, was married yesterday to Scott M. Berman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanford W. Berman of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Charles Simon performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (L.I.) Country Club.

title: WHEN TENANTS COSPONSOR THEIR CO-OP CONVERSION
description: LIKE other residents of ZIP code 10003, the tenants of 33 Fifth Avenue comprise that blend of the arts, academe and money that may be unique to central Greenwich Village. So when their building went up for sale a year ago, it was perhaps not surprising that the residents chose to band together and embarked on a real-estate transaction that itself may be unique to Manhattan both in its size and complexity.

title: NEW SERIES TAPES BERNSTEIN LIVE
description: Leonard Bernstein arrived elated at the reception room atop Avery Fisher Hall after a morning rehearsal the other day, on the eve of a performance with the New York Philharmonic of Mahler's Seventh Symphony.

title: ARCHITECTURE
description: THE explosion of architectural publishing - it seems as if the number of books on architecture increases geometrically from year to year -has brought with it a tendency to look with more intensity than ever before on the work of individual architects. Of the elaborate books suitable for gift-giving this year, relatively few are the broad, sweeping surveys of seasons past, and an unusual number are what were once called monographs, volumes devoted entirely to the work of one figure. Some are architects of other eras, no longer living; more of the subjects, however, are architects who are not only still alive but have barely reached the midpoint of their careers. Elaborate volumes of the sort that were once produced to memorialize long-departed architects are now becoming commonplace to celebrate those young enough to have the majority of their buildings ahead of them.

title: HISS HISS BANG BANG
description: STATE OF THE ART By Pauline Kael. 404 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $12.95. PAULINE KAEL, the feisty film critic of The New Yorker, rouses such passion that the publication of a new collection launches a bloody biennial rite, Kael-bashing. But she is no innocent.
