She writes taunting, contentious prose that she knows will jangle nerves, and she can be uncharitable about anyone's opinion but her own. Still, if pugnacity and crabbiness were sufficient provocation, nearly every critic could foment the rage Pauline Kael calls down. The hostility to her runs deeper because her criticism has always struck deeper. It strikes the very hearts of cultural supremacists.

title: WINNIE MANDELA ENDS HER SILENCE
description: For nearly a quarter of a century, while her husband, Nelson Mandela, a leader of the outlawed African National Congress, has been imprisoned in South Africa, Winnie Mandela has been silenced. Under the provisions of the latest order, she has been banished to a segregated black township and forbidden to meet with more than one person at a time.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS IN THE DOCK AGAIN
description: The Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun was consigned to the Pentagon's junk heap in August, but Government investigators have continued to sift through lingering allegations that the $1.8 billion program was shot through with conflicts of interest and inflated costs.

title: A NEW GAME FOR MANAGERS TO PLAY
description: AS THE football season gradually gives way to basketball, corporate managers would do well to consider the differences between these games. For just as football mirrors industrial structures of the past, basketball points the way to the corporate structure of the future.

title: TENSIONS IN SERVING ON A BOARD
description: IT is not easy to be a board member of a cooperative or condominium. At times, the pressures can become so intense that they bring on a severe case of burnout - no laughing matter, as anyone who has been through it will confirm.

title: 3d Death in Refinery Blast
description: Stan Lawrence, a 29-year-old worker burned in a hydrogen explosion, died Friday, bringing the death toll from the series of blasts at an Atlantic Richfield oil refinery Thursday to three. Five victims remained hospitalized in critical condition.

title: AMERICAN IN FINAL OF SOCCER
description: A senior midfielder, Fernando Iturbe, scored on a head ball in the 77th minute to give American University a 1-0 semifinal victory over Hartwick College today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: HEARING SET ON BURNING OF TOXICS
description: PLANS to dispose of hazardous wastes by incinerating them off the New Jersey coast took a small step backward and a large step forward in recent weeks. At-Sea Incineration, a company that once hoped to operate out of Port Newark, defaulted on a federally guaranteed loan and closed its New Jersey operations last month. A week later, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced plans to issue a permit to Chemical Waste Management Inc., an Illinois-based company, for a test burn off Cape May.

title: Giants Could Clinch Playoffs
description: While many of those following the National Football Conference playoff race are looking forward to the big game between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys next Sunday, the Giants are scheduled to play the Oilers this Sunday in the Astrodome. And, surprisingly, the Giants could clinch a playoff berth by winning.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH DEFENSE CONTRACTORS
description: OF ALL THE ILLS DISCOVERED IN THE AMERICAN defense industry in the last several years, surely the most troubling is the charge of shoddy workmanship. Coffee pots that cost $7,600, dogs that are boarded at taxpayer expense, and falsified time cards are the stuff of scandal. But the antitank missile that doesn't fire, the radio that suddenly goes silent, or the fighter plane's engine that flames out in midair - all because they were not properly made -can lose battles and get fighting men killed.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: The Parrot Solution BIRGIT R. DIFORIO was feeding her 18-month-old son, Stephen, lunch a couple of months ago when suddenly there came a tapping, as of someone gently rapping, rapping at her kitchen door. It was not Edgar Allan Poe's raven, but close: a bright green parrot was pecking at the kitchen window.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1984. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review.

title: Notable Paperbacks
description: This selective list of paperbacks was chosen from the New & Noteworthy column since the Christmas issue of 1984. It includes autobiography, biography, novels, stories, memoirs, essays, history, science, social science and poetry. ABORTION AND THE POLITICS OF MOTHERHOOD. By Kristin Luker. (University of California, $7.95.) The abortion conflict in America is viewed in this analysis as a battle largely between women of different economic classes and a different social outlook. THE ALBANY CYCLE. By William Kennedy. (Penguin, $17.85.) A boxed set of three novels - ''Legs'' (1975), ''Billy Phelan's Greatest Game'' (1978) and the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Ironweed'' (1983) - that are set in Albany in the late 1930's. AMERICAN DIPLOMACY. By George F. Kennan. (University of Chicago, $5.95.) A collection of the former diplomat's lectures on wars, foreign policy, the Far East, modern diplomacy and the Soviet Union. THE BALLAD OF TYPHOID MARY. By J. F. Federspiel. Translated by Joel Agee. (Ballantine, $3.50.) A fictional version of the life of a typhoid carrier who became an American legend - the 19th-century Swiss immigrant Maria Anna Caduff (a k a Mary Mallon). BLACK APOLLO OF SCIENCE: The Life of Ernest Everett Just. By Kenneth R. Manning.

title: WISCONSIN'S LICENSE PLATES WON'T SAY, 'EAT CHEESE OR DIE'
description: Wisconsin's appeal for suggestions for new license plates generated more than 46,000 reponses in less than a week, but the final five designs do not include the most novel proposals: cow-shaped tags and the slogan ''Eat Cheese or Die.''

title: A PHONE CALL TAKES AWAY HER MOTHER
description: I HAD been waiting for the phone call - hoping for it - but when it finally came, I felt devastated.

title: STATEN ISLAND AGENCY PROVIDES COUNSELING
description: Staten Island Family Service, the oldest nonsectarian counseling agency on Staten Island, has been carrying out its mandate of trying to preserve and strengthen the family unit for the last 66 years by providing counseling for families and individuals.

title: Editor of Dallas Times Herald Quits to Join Consulting Unit
description: Will Jarrett, editor of The Dallas Times Herald, resigned yesterday and the company will immediately begin a search for a new editor, according to Arthur E. Wible, the newspaper's publisher.

title: PROXY SHOWDOWN FOR LILCO
description: WHEN Long Island Lighting Company stockholders gather at a special meeting this week to elect members of the utility's board of directors, the results could prove decisive to the future of the Shoreham nuclear power plant and of the company itself.

title: ITHACA GAINS FINAL WITH A 34-0 ROMP
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 7 -

title: A GIANT STEP FORWARD FOR TECHNOLOGY
description: SINCE the dawn of history, the promise of beating swords into plowshares has been an integral part of human culture. Mankind's hunger for weapons can spawn valuable non-military technologies, as our recent experiences show. The Manhattan Project to develop the atom bomb gave birth to nuclear power, and the construction of the American intercontinental ballistic missile force greatly advanced the development of semiconductors, high-speed computers and space exploration.

title: ERIC RAYMAN IS WED TO SUSAN E. HORTON
description: Susan Emily Horton and Steven Eric Rayman were married last evening at the New York Academy of Art by Rabbi Emily Korzenik. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Horton of Lido Beach, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Rayman is a son of Dr. Norman N. Rayman of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Norma Rayman.

title: CHILDREN AND THE BOMB
description: IN RECENT YEARS, A number of studies by social scientists, doctors and teachers have told us that American children, in significant numbers, are worried about the nuclear bomb - its threat to their future and to the world's.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: ST. JOHN'S OVERRUNS F.D.U.
description: After watching St. John's rout its second opponent in two nights, Lou Carnesecca conceded last night that he hadn't expected to learn anything about his team this weekend.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1985
description: International

title: A CRACKDOWN IN CONNECTICUT CUTS HIGHWAY SPEEDING 29%
description: A yearlong crackdown on speeding on the state's major highways has slowed drivers but has not measurably reduced the number of accidents, state officials say.

title: LOW RENTS FOR COUNTY EMPLOYEES FAULTED
description: COUNTY employees whose rents in county-owned residences are far below market value face a rent increase of 38 percent under a proposal now being reviewed by county officials.

title: GARDENING
description: Gardeners have time now to take time out. They can afford the luxury of visiting other people's gardens or visiting them vicariously through beautiful pictures and elegant prose. The richness of this year's garden books could cause a moment or two of visual indigestion, but what does that matter? We have all winter to recover. Besides, such indulgence may teach us a trick or two or provide the inspiration to dig up the whole plot next spring and start all over again. VISIONS OF PARADISE: Themes and Variations on the Garden. Photographs by Marina Schinz. Text by Susan Littlefield. 272 pp. (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $39.95.) This beautiful book captures the textures, colors and even the ideas behind some of the Western world's best-loved gardens. The superb photographs are the work of the Swiss-born photographer Marina Schinz, who collaborated with the American landscape architect and writer Susan Littlefield. ''Clarity of garden style'' was the chief criterion for Miss Schinz as she traveled to California, New York, the District of Columbia, France, Italy and Britain in search of gardens that express a theme or fulfill a practical purpose. She has grouped her extraordinarily lush color photographs under 10 headings, ranging from the humble kitchen and cottage garden to the magnificent villa of Renaissance Italy, with stops along the way at the rose garden, the naturalized garden (a natural habitat with ''light botanical editing'') and that ''ultimate aesthetic achievement in garden design,'' the perennial border.

title: WHEN THE JOB LEAVES THE WORKER
description: WHEN, seemingly out of the blue, the head of your company announces, ''We're moving out of the area - come with us,'' what do you do?

title: Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN AIMS TO PROTECT JERSEY WILDLIFE REFUGE
description: A new master plan for the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge seeks to protect it from the rapid development of bordering communities and decrease the likelihood of flooding in the Passaic River Basin, according to Federal wildlife officials.

title: DR. RALPH I. DORFMAN
description: Dr. Ralph I. Dorfman, a retired president of Syntex Reasearch and a biochemist whose research on hormones and metabolism contributed to the development of oral contracetives, died of complications of Parkinson's disease at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View, Calif., on Nov. 18.

title: THE MOBSTERS WHO LURK BEHIND THE CORPORATE VEIL
description: Without using names, James M. Kossler, a supervisor in the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, recalled some time ago a man who entered the refuse business in New York State, mortgaging his home to buy a few garbage trucks. Before long, sugar was found in the gas tanks, Mr. Kossler said. Then someone tried to blow up a truck. One afternoon the phone rang, and a gruff voice described what the man's 10-year-old daughter was wearing that day. The voice warned that if the trucks were not sold, the girl would disappear. The business was shut down within hours.

title: CUDDLE UP, THEY'RE PLAYING OUR MOTET
description: It is difficult to keep up with science in our kaleidoscopic times, but we must not give up trying. With that thought in mind, I wish to direct your attention to a study published in the December issue of Psychology Today that should give heart to all hard-working musicians, many of whom may not fully realize the awesome power they hold over all of us. A Stanford University pharmacologist, we are told, analyzed responses of more than 250 people and found that 96 percent experienced thrills in response to music ''far exceeding the rate for an expected thriller, sexual activity.'' The respondents told Avram Goldstein, the inquiring pharmacologist, that ''musical passages'' elicited greater thrills than the following, in descending order by percentage:

title: THE HISTORY OF A FOUNDLING, CONT.
description: THE LATER ADVENTURES OF TOM JONES By Bob Coleman. 345 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: BALTIMORE DRIVERS PRAISE TUNNEL
description: FOR the first time in at least a decade, travelers on Interstate 95 did not have to spend much of their Thanksgiving weekend in Baltimore.

title: SAUGATUCK RIVER'S TROUT GET A NEW HOME
description: THANKS to Leon C. Hirsch and $50,000, the Saugatuck River near Westport is once again a suitable habitat for trout.

title: IN LIVERPOOL, IT'S HARD LEFT VS. SOFT LEFT
description: After backing off from a threat to lead this declining industrial port over a fiscal precipice into bankruptcy, the faction of the ''revolutionary'' left that dominates the Labor Party here is now battling with the national leadership for control of the party's local machinery.

title: LAURA LYNG, A CONSULTANT TO MARRY PETERM. GOOD
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Lyng of Clifton Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Anne Lyng to Peter Millner Good, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell H. Good of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: 25 WOUNDED BY BOMBS AT 2 PARIS DEPARTMENT STORES
description: Two explosions ripped through two of the largest department stores in Paris today, wounding more than 25 people, 8 of them seriously, fire and police officials said.

title: AN EXPENSIVE RAY OF HOPE ABOUT CANCER
description: Researchers at the National Cancer Institute announced last week that they had developed a promising - but extremely expensive - treatment that enhances the body's immune system so that it can attack some common forms of cancer.

title: FUR BEARERS STUDIED WITH TRAPPERS' AID
description: BIOLOGISTS from the state's Department of Environmental Protection have put out a call to trappers to save the carcasses of wild mink, river otters and coyotes for a biological study.

title: Utah Turkey Processor Closes as Inquiry Starts
description: A turkey processing plant suspected of using spoiled meat in processed products closed Friday, putting 250 people out of work, a spokesman said.

title: HISPANIC SURGE IS SEEN IN LOS ANGELES ELECTION
description: The last time Hispanic people here had one of their own on the City Council in this city founded by Spaniards, John F. Kennedy was in the White House and the first of the landmark modern civil rights laws was two years from enactment.

title: INDIAN HEALTH SERVICE CHIEF CRITICIZED ON AWARD
description: An inspector general's report has sharply criticized the director of the Federal Government's Indian Health Service over the awarding of $33,254 in agency scholarship money to his daughter.

title: AN OBSTACLE COURSE FOR INTRUDERS
description: ANYONE trying to sneak into the operations facility of Great American Federal Operations Center, a savings bank in National City, Calif., has to contend with an electronic obstacle course. Wired iron gates surround the employee parking and vehicle service areas, while closed-circuit televisions monitor activities. And an intruder trying to get into restricted areas without a current access card will set off an alarm at the guard's monitoring station.

title: HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: Over the last few years, the all-suite hotel catering to business travelers seeking the comforts of a small apartment has been gaining in popularity.

title: DOCTORS SEE NO REASON TO SCREEN PUPILS FOR AIDS
description: More than 250 school board members, administrators and nurses were told today that concerns about the dangers of spreading the AIDS virus through casual contact in the classroom were not based on scientific evidence.

title: KIANE BALK WED TO J.P. PALGUTA
description: The marriage of Diane Marie Balk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Balk of New York, to J. Paul Palguta, a son of Martha Palguta and the late Edward M. Palguta of Fort Wayne, Ind., took place yesterday at the Milner Chapel of the Second Presbyterian Church in Indianapolis. The Rev. Dr. Raymond A. Bowden performed the ceremony.

title: SAUDI ANTICIPATES OIL PRICE PLUNGE
description: Saudi Arabia said today that world oil prices could fall from their present level of about $28 a barrel to below $20 next year unless all oil producers cooperate with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in cutting back surplus production.

title: THE IVORY TRADE ENDANGERS A SPECIES
description: On the coast at Dar es Salaam, about 450 miles southeast of here, Gabriel Nguli carves ebony logs into willowy black swirls of grace and movement. He also works in white, but then he uses ivory, not wood.

title: PRIVATE SECONDARY SCHOOLS JOINING IN DEBATE ON PRETORIA INVESTMENTS
description: The debate over investing in South Africa, which has been waged on college campuses for several years, is spilling into private elementary and secondary schools.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SCREEN FARCE TO HOLIDAY SONGS
description: Madonna Live: The Virgin Tour Warner Music Video 50 minutes. $29.98 ''I was never elected homecoming queen, but I sure feel like one now,'' announces Madonna midway into this concert video filmed last May in her hometown of Detroit, during the national tour promoting her multi-platinum album ''Like a Virgin.''

title: STABLE HEATING COSTS EXPECTED IN NEW YORK
description: Barring an unexpected spell of very cold weather or an interruption in the worldwide flow of oil, residents of the New York metropolitan area should face heating bills comparable to those of last year, public and industry officials say.

title: ILLUSTRATOR'S SHOW: 'IMAGES OF AMERICA'
description: REMEMBER The Saturday Evening Post, at least in the large format that took up your whole lap? Or for that matter just Saturday evening, a quiet period that no longer seems to exist in the mid-1980's? These are not random trivial musings, for sharp tugs of nostalgia are at the heart of the retrospective of Stevan Dohanos, one of this country's foremost illustrators, at the New Britain Museum of American Art to Jan. 5.

title: ARE FIRES AT DUMP EXTICT
description: After nearly 30 years, the clouds of smoke and fumes that blanketed sections of the southern end of this Hudson County community are finally gone. But officials are concerned that the fire at the PJP landfill may erupt again as workmen dig into the mounds of decayed garbage.

title: Data Bank: December 8, 1985
FUNCTIONAL ILLITERACY IN THE AGE OF TECHNOLOGY
description: IN mathematics and science, according to the National Science Foundation, the United States is in trouble.

title: FOCUSING ON ELUSIVE CONCEPTS
description: IN photography there are concepts that are hard to comprehend and procedures that are difficult to apply even for serious students of the craft.

title: NO. 26 CARRIES THE BALL FOR ROBERT FROST
description: IN the casual history of this country, the years 1945 to 1949 have been given understandably scant attention. The nation was taking a vacation from the economic and military trauma of the previous 15 years and basked in the role of victor, flexing its economic muscles still further as if to show the world that the 30's were a fluke. Sandwiched between two wars, it was a time of Levittowns, ball point pens and fluid drive. The servicemen were home and they, and the economy, would wait for no man in busting loose.

title: PANEL QUESTIONS G.O.P. CHIEF ON ROLE IN A JERSEY CAMPAIGN
description: The State Senate Judiciary Committee is to meet Monday to continue its inquiry into allegations that Frank B. Holman, the New Jersey Republican chairman, threatened to block an Assembly candidate's appointment to the State Board of Education in order to force her to withdraw from last month's election.

title: What Regan Didn't Do
description: Q. Mr. Regan, I wondered about the White House changes, one in particular, and your role as chief of staff. A. Go ahead. Q. Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, denies that you were responsible for Bud McFarlane's resignation as chairman of the National Security Council, and says that the press has blamed you for every departure from the White House except the departure of the President's dog Lucky. Could we clear this up?

title: AFTER THE NEW WAVE, TAVERNIER
description: BERTRAND TAVERNIER COULD EASILY BE making a lot of people around him nervous. In the middle of shooting his new movie, ''Round Midnight'' - based on the life of the jazz pianist Bud Powell - his main actor, Dexter Gordon, in a classic case of life imitating art, is failing to show up on the set. Gordon, a noted black jazz saxophonist who has had his share of hard times and is now playing a jazz musician who is down and out and often drunk in Paris, is suffering from fatigue, possible illness and a probable hangover.

title: MUSIC: MESSIAEN WORK
description: OLIVIER MESSIAEN visited Utah's Bryce Canyon in 1972 and found there the kind of geological colossus worthy of his musical imagination. Bryce's fantastical minaret-like protrusions, its shifting light and shade and the birds that inhabit this natural wonder are reflected in the piece the French composer was afterward to write - ''Des canyons aux etoiles,'' which the Juilliard Contemporary Ensemble under Paul Zukofsky played at Alice Tully Hall Friday night.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: FUNCTIONAL-ART SALE Last year, more than 10,000 people attended the annual art exhibition and sale sponsored by the Essex County chapter of the National Council of Jewish Women. Even more are expected at this year's show, which opens today at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in West Orange.

title: A TOUCH OF FRANCE IN HO-HO-KUS
description: IN THE last few years, we've been pleased to see the New Jersey dining scene improving.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Words, words, words. Suddenly, it seems books of and about photography have developed an all-consuming passion for literature. A few years ago the ideal photography book was on the order of ''Walker Evans: First and Last'' (1978), which contained not a word of text except for the titles of the pictures. But the rage for having pages of solitary images surrounded by white borders has given way to a craving for personal history, anecdote and analysis. Blame it, if you must, on the success of Patricia Bosworth's chatty 1984 biography of Diane Arbus, which portrays photography at its most Dickensian. Now it is the photojournalists' turn: Robert Capa, Carl Mydans and W. Eugene Smith have all received the literary star treatment (their books were reviewed earlier in these pages). Ansel Adams, who was an entire constellation in his lifetime, has now written his autobiography. Needless to say, some of these photographers' lives warrant our attention more than others. Contrary to this trend, however, are the season's most intriguing entries, which focus on portraiture instead of personality.

title: THE BARREN LANDS
description: THE FEAR OF POPULATION DECLINE By Michael S. Teitelbaum and Jay M. Winter. 201 pp. San Diego: Academic Press/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $34. Paper, $19.95. FOR many years now, public attention - and debate - concerning the world's ''population problem'' has largely focused on overpopulation. Demographers and pundits note that the world's population is still rising at an unacceptably high rate of about 1.75 percent a year, or an increase by the year 2000 from 4.9 billion to 6.2 billion. This means that sometime early in the next century, the world will contain some 9 billion people. And more than three-quarters of them will be packed into the economically struggling states of the third world, which can least afford high population growth.

title: TRAVEL AND NATURE
description: My life as a reader can be numbered. I began as a 398.2; then I was a 920, and still later became an 820, an 813 and even a 822.33. Now, in my middle years, I am yet another number. A librarian asked me what kind of writing I do. I told her. She said, ''Why, you're a 910.'' In the Dewey Decimal system, 910 - geography and travel - is a nice number to be from. It's a shelf of journeys, peoples, places. It's not just the world, it's the world in motion. I'm happy in 910, happy to be in the realm of the 910's that follow. CHINA. By Hiroji Kubota. Illustrated. 204 pp. (Norton, $65.) It took the photographer Hiroji Kubota three years to get permission to photograph in China and seven years and 200,000 clicks of the shutter to collect this fine gathering of 186 color photographs. The pictures reveal China from the time when the current open-door policy was only a narrow slit to the now cavernous entrance provided the West, especially the United States. When historians look back to what may prove to be the most significant change of a national outlook in this century, Mr. Kubota's images will show China just crossing the threshold, just inviting the West in, timidly peeking out. He assigned himself all of China - one billion people, 3.7 million square miles and 55 minority nationalities. The book is especially full of China's minorities; at times the reader forgets the overwhelming majority presence of the Han Chinese, so rich are the photographs of the Kazakhs, the Uighurs, the Tibetans, the Mongolians. Mr. Kubota's approach is not that of the pure photojournalist.

title: Ridge Route Is Chosen For Appalachian Trail
description: National Park Service officials say the longest temporary stretch of the Appalachian Trail will be permanently located along a route favored by naturalists but opposed by local residents.

title: 2 Policemen Killed In Ulster Attack
description: Two policemen were killed tonight when guerrillas attacked an isolated village police station in Northern Ireland, the police said.

title: FEINSTEIN IS TRYING TO UNPAVE THE WAY
description: MORE than a decade ago, when she was still a junior member of the local Board of Supervisors, Dianne Feinstein looked up at a mile-long, elevated freeway on the edge of San Francisco Bay and said: ''I'm determined that that freeway come down, even if I have to become totally gray-haired in the process.''

title: WISHING FOR MILTON'S POWER AND TOLSTOY'S ZANINESS
description: The Book Review invited a number of well-known writers to think wishfully about the following topic: ''If Santa Claus were the muse, what would you ask for?'' We were invoking literary inspiration at large, and our writers - of poetry, novels, short stories, biography, history, essays, children's books, detective and science fiction and cookbooks - showed just how fanciful the holiday spirit can be. Scott Spencer Author of ''Endless Love'' Of course, Santa has never really cared for me. He's ignored my requests. I told him - ''Look, all I want for Christmas is my two front teeth,'' and I got Lincoln Logs instead.

title: A DECISION MADE ON INSTINCT SUCCEEDS
description: WHEN Dorothy Swegel arrived in White Plains for the first time on a rainy day in November 1968, her first reaction was shock.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, an article last Sunday about county residents involved in restoration projects incorrectly described the recent history of the former Towers Nursing Home in Manhattan. It has been empty for eight years.

title: EXHIBIT HONORS WAR VETERANS
description: A permanent stamp exhibit commemorates the contributions and sacrifices of the American armed services in Washington, D.C. It is located in a display case in the upper east wing of the memorial display area between the Tomb of the Unknowns and the Amphitheater. The exhibit, entitled ''to Honor Those Who Served'' was presented by Postmaster General Paul N. Carlin to Arlington National Cemetery during Veterans Day ceremonies.

title: SOLICITORS' PRACTICES ASSAILED BY L.I. VOLUNTEER FIRE UNITS
description: OFFICIALS of some volunteer fire departments on Long Island are angry over the use of outside solicitors to raise funds for some departments, charging that a few solicitors are operating outside the communities the departments serve.

title: Half of Americans Satisfied With U.S. Trends, Poll Finds
description: The number of Americans who are content with the way things are going in the United States is remaining essentially constant, while a growing number of people are personally satisfied, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: TENSE DAYS FOR PARTISAN AND REGIONAL INTERESTS
description: ALWAYS in the Capitol, when decisions are being made, the outcome is shaped by party conviction mixed with partisan politics, complicated by sectional rivalry. This week, those forces will be in play in a more heated way than in recent years.

title: A SMALL MUSEUM IN ESSEX COUNTY IS ONE FOR THE BOOKS
description: IT GALLED Henry Horowitz that there were so many museums of printing - a trade that dates only to the invention of movable type in the 15th century -but not of bookbinding, which is at least eight centuries older (the Encyclopedia Britannica dates the earliest surviving bound book to the seventh century). So he started his own. That was in 1974, and since then Mr. Horowitz has been adding steadily to his museum-library which occupies 3,000 square feet on the second floor of a building at 300 Fairfield Road in this Essex County community. On the first floor are the offices and workrooms of the A. Horowitz Company, which specializes in binding art and children's books.

title: MISS ISKANDAR IS BRIDE OF BRUCE W. MCENTEE
description: Shieny Iskandar, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. I. E. Kwet Iskandar of Jakarta, Indonesia, and Bruce Warren McEntee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Jennings McEntee of Garden City and Point O'Woods, L.I., and Mill Reef, Antigua, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dennis R. Odekirk performed the ceremony at St. James by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in La Jolla, Calif.

title: PENNSYLVANIA'S HIGHEST COURT RULES FOR PARENTS IN LAWSUITS ON STILLBIRTHS
description: The state Supreme Court, reversing three of its earlier rulings, has cleared the way for parents to sue physicians on behalf of stillborn children.

title: WAS ON HIGH COURT 23 YEARS
description: Potter Stewart, an Eisenhower Republican from Ohio who spent 23 years on the Supreme Court, died yesterday in a hospital in Hanover, N.H., where he had been admitted after suffering a stroke. He was 70 years old.

title: New Agenda for the Women's Movement
description: A feminist, at least as I perceive it, is a person who advocates the same rights for women as for men. As a father with hopes for his daughter, and as a husband of a professional woman, I realize that women still face obstacles that men do not.

title: STUFFING THE EXECUTIVE STOCKING
description: ARE you still stymied by certain names on your Christmas list? Perhaps your friend is a successful executive who just can't switch out of the business mode. Or maybe the friend has a humdrum job, but dreams of making a killing on Wall Street. Then, of course, the need may be closer to home: a gift to inspire an Operation Bootstrap program to shape up the family's finances next year.

title: FOSTERING COMMUNITY SPIRIT
description: THE Arts Council in Dobbs Ferry is suffering, the volunteer firemen are worried and the League of Women Voters hangs on by a thread.

title: HAMILTON WHO?
description: Hamilton Jordan, who helped propel ''Jimmy Who?'' to the Presidency in 1976, said last week that he had made a ''dramatic'' recovery from lymph cancer and would become the fourth announced candidate for the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Mack Mattingly, Republican of Georgia, next year.

title: JOB SECURITY KEY AT PRATT & WHITNEY
description: THE major demand on picket signs and in chants of more than 5,000 Pratt & Whitney workers who went on strike last week - job security rather than higher wages - has grown increasingly common in labor disputes.

title: CHILD'S VIEW OF CITY: FRESH AND COLORFUL
description: The Manhattan skyline - blocks of buildings and a burst of colors -floats serenely in a wide blue river. This is the New York City painted by Kelly Hernandez, a third-grader at Public School 90 in Queens.

title: PSYCHIATRIC NEEDS OF YOUTHS STUDIED
description: CONCERNED about the unmet psychological needs of children and adolescents, the Health Systems Agency of South-Central Connecticut has formed a special task force, the first of its kind in the state.

title: MARY TYLER MOORE: 'I'M NOT AN INNATELY FUNNY PERSON'
description: When ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' ended its celebrated, seven-season run on CBS in 1977, it was a victim not of poor ratings but of its star's professed desire for meatier acting challenges.

title: EAST HARLEM STUDENTS GET TASTE OF BROADWAY
description: To the frequent matinee-goer, there was nothing unusual about the performance yesterday afternoon of ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' except, perhaps, that some of the actors wore roller skates instead of shoes, and others wheeled around on skateboards.

title: Lie Detector Lies
description: Two million Americans each year are required to take lie-detector tests as a condition of employment. At least 50,000 are then denied jobs or promotions even though the results are unreliable. Now, after years of desultory debate, Congress appears convinced that this injustice is intolerable.

title: LOCAL HABITATIONS
description: THE VISITORS By Ronald Blythe. 239 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: OAKLAND
description: NESTLED along the banks of the Ramapo River with the profile of the Ramapo Mountains etched sharply against the sky, the Borough of Oakland stands as a rustic outpost in the northwestern corner of New Jersey.

title: TOKYO
description: Improbable though it may seem, Tokyo is a place to capture the Christmas spirit: That is, if Christmas for you means eye-opening store displays, high-tech gimcracks, ever-present recorded carols and enough tinsel to envelop a hundred Hollywoods. The season arrived a month ago, with the enormous Christmas ribbon and bow wrapped around the Mitsukoshi department store in the Ginza. While streets may be vibrant, it must be said that no spirituality is to be found. That will come at New Year's, which is a religious holiday and a time when most Japanese visit Shinto shrines.

title: ADJUNCT PROFESSORS AND L.I. COLLEGES
description: The article does not give the reader a full understanding of the role played by adjunct faculty at the Hofstra University School of Business. The percentage of teaching done by adjunct faculty is below 20 percent.

title: 6-YEAR BATTLE ON HEATING OIL BEARING FRUIT
description: ONE woman's six-year campaign to force New Jersey to adopt a standard for home heating oil that would prevent it from coagulating in cold weather appears to be making headway at last.

title: A NEW DIMENSION TO CELTIC SUCCESS
description: THE streams of smoke still curl up from his cigar when the game is in its final moments and his beloved Boston Celtics are comfortably ahead on points. When the night is over, he permits himself a smile born of satisfaction, even though he attends fewer games as the seasons go by and has not taken a courtside chair in almost 20 years.

title: THE DNACE: ANN LUDWIG COMPANY
description: ARIZONA may be the land of deserts, horses and herds of cattle in most New Yorkers' imaginations. There's madness in those dunes, however, to judge by a debut performance by the Tempe-based A. Ludwig Company: Dance Theater Collective, on Friday at the Nikolais-Louis DanceSpace.

title: Men's Style View;   Assimilation
description: THOUGH THERE have been times when designers and manufacturers have attempted sweeping alterations in the shape of men's clothing, this year has not been one of them. Rather, the most marked change in men's dressing patterns is one of attitude. Men seem to be taking a broader view of what is appropriate attire for the work place, thus freeing themselves - sometimes slightly, often more freely - from the cookie-cutter sameness of a corporate uniform.

title: A KENNEDY RUNS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The torch was passed to a new generation of Kennedys last week. Joseph P. Kennedy 2d announced that he would run for the Massachusetts Congressional seat once held by his uncle, John F. Kennedy.

title: Ezra Pound at 100
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION WOMEN AT WORK
description: The steady increase in the number of working women is making itself felt in one of the last refuges of male supremacy: the organized labor movement.

title: SUBTLE DELIGHT HAS ITS PRICE
description: Noted for bonhomie and other forms of expansiveness, Santa Claus seems like a fellow who likes to live it up a little. In anticipation of his visit, it might therefore be appropriate to move this continuing preholiday shopping list to the fancier precincts of audio where nothing is stinted and considerations of costs are not permitted to set limits to performance.

title: RECITAL: PETER ORTH, PIANO
description: PETER ORTH, who won the Naumburg piano competition in 1979, was clearly making a statement of elective affinities in his recital program Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall. The music he chose was not just Romantic, but Romantic in the grand, proclamatory sense -Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue; Brahms's Third Sonata, and the complete first book (''Switzerland'') of Liszt's ''Annees de Pelerinage.''

title: Hong Kong
description: To the Editor: Reading the articles on Hong Kong reawakened the excitement I felt when planning our trip to Hong Kong last year. It also, however, reminded me of some of the reality that impinged on my flights of fancy once we arrived in this fascinating city.

title: STRANGE RED HERING IN DEBATE ON ANGOLA
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLING ASBESTOS
description: IT was 1979, six years after Mountain View Mobile Home Estates had been built in Globe, Ariz., that a state health inspector found whitish fibers at the site, 90 miles southeast of Phoenix. The fibers were identified as asbestos, which health authorities have said can cause cancer of the lungs if inhaled.

title: SELF-PORTRAIT OF AN ART HISTORIAN AS A YOUNG MAN
description: I am sometimes asked how I became an art historian. The easiest answer is to say that I was born one, but the longer and more truthful answer is that I became an art historian when I was 13. I was brought up with works of art (Chinese mainly, with some unimportant Italian paintings that I still own), and art was a factor in both my parents' lives. My father took me from time to time to the Tate Gallery to look at Renoir's ''Parapluies'' (I disliked the picture then, and I have always disliked it since), and when I was 10 I helped my mother correct the proofs of what was, I think, the first book published in English on archaic Chinese jades.

title: BONNER ARRIVES IN U.S. FOR MEDICAL TREATMENT
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of the dissident Soviet physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, arrived in the United States today to seek medical treatment for a heart ailment.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PARADE BY TORCHLIGHT The sight of 2,000 flaming torches, lanterns, flashlights and candles moving down Old Saybrook Main Street in the annual Christmas Torchlight Parade and Muster is so spectacular that ''busloads of people start coming into town at 11 A.M.'' said Major William Reid, a retired Army officer who is in charge of organizing the event. The parade starts at 6 P.M. Saturday in front of the Liberty Savings Bank on Main Street.

title: AMERICAN AWAITS A SOVIET GIFT: HER HUSBAND
description: Gregory, 2 1/2 years old, listens carefully when his mother says that the father he has never met will be coming home from Leningrad in a few months. Sometimes, he runs to the front door expectantly.

title: A Triple for Banks
description: Willie Banks, the triple jumper who broke the world record earlier this year, achieved another triple yesterday, but this time it wasn't for distance. Banks, who was attending The Athletics Congress annual convention in Houston, won the Jesse Owens Award as the top American track and field athlete of 1985, the organization's Jim Thorpe Award as the year's best male field-event athlete, and was cited as the outstanding athlete of the year by Track & Field News.

title: SAWS MAY BUZZ IN PHILADELPHIA
description: OFFICIALS of the Philadelphia Commerce Department and the United States Forest Service have been talking for several months about a rather unusual project - establishing a sawmill as a community-based business venture to make lumber of dead or diseased city trees.

title: LAWYERS MOONLIGHT AS MAGISTRATES TO HELP CONNECTICUT'S JUDGES
description: In a typical work week, David Ertman spends four days tending to his law practice in New Haven and one day sitting in judgment on relatively minor cases in courts in New Haven or West Haven.

title: AMERICAN FARE AND STYLISH DECOR
description: THE latest Connecticut restaurant to jump aboard the bandwagon for American cooking is Sweetwater, in the center of Bethel.

title: PASSAIC DEFEATS RIDGEWOOD FOR TITLE
description: Sterling Henton threw a 50-yard touchdown pass to Mervin Curry late in the third quarter to send Passaic to a 24-19 victory over Ridgewood yesterday in the North Jersey Section 1 Group 4 championship at Hinchliffe Stadium in Paterson.

title: CALCULATORS IN EXAM DEBATED
description: THE State Board of Education is adding up the pluses and minuses of allowing eighth- grade students to use calculators when they take a statewide mathematics test next fall.

title: THE MAN WHO RESHAPED GEOMETRY
description: NEWTON NEVER SAID IT, NOR GALILEO, NOR FREUD. The historian of science I. Bernard Cohen scoured the annals of discovery for scientists who announced that their own work was revolutionary, but he could produce only this short list: Symmer, Marat, Lavoisier, von Liebig, Hamilton, Darwin, Virchow, Cantor, Einstein, Minkowski, von Laue, Wegener, Compton, Just, Watson and Benoit Mandelbrot. Sixteen visionaries and cranks - and on a bright windless day it is the latest and last-named who appears in Woods Hole, Mass., ready to propagate his particular revolution at a scientific lecture and clambake.

title: Thinking About Boxing
description: It was a great week for matchups on the tube. Army-Navy yesterday, Kareem and Akeem as well as Chris and Martina in one night, and a few nights earlier, the Bears and the Dolphins. And a few nights before that, ''Edith and Marcel.''

title: U.S. Attorney Quits Case On Philadelphia Radicals
description: The United States Attorney's office in Philadelphia has withdrawn from a criminal investigation of the confrontation between the police and the radical group Move. The office said it had been ''tainted'' by its closeness to the case.

title: THE DANCE: NEW YORK CITY BALLET IN 'NUTCRACKER'
description: ALTHOUGH the New York City Ballet often pleases people, they rarely show delight by gurgling and cooing. But on Thursday night as soon as the houselights dimmed gurgles and coos arose from the audience.

title: WATER PURITY
description: AFTER brief uncertainty over the amount of radioactive plutonium in New York City's water, the city announced in August that Federal tests made with ultrasensitive equipment showed but 0.1 femtocurie per liter -a trace considered normal.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Sohio had to take some medicine, but they covered the pill with enough sugar to sweeten the concoction.''

title: THE OTHER FOOT
description: THE writing assignment was a tough one: if you're a teacher, put yourself in the shoes of a student for one day. If you're a student, pretend to be a teacher. Beth Friedman, 27 years old and dressed from head to toe in cheerleading togs, chewed on her pencil and twirled her hair in distress. Nicole Luiso, 13, her hair silvered with stuff from a spray can, gave instructions:

title: NEW YORK PASTORAL
description: THE BRONX IN THE INNOCENT YEARS #1890-1925. By Lloyd Ultan and Gary Hermalyn. Illustrated. 164 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: HOLIDAY SHOPPING FEVER: WHAT'S HOT
description: FROM Cabbage Patch Kids dolls to Pet Rocks, every Christmas some products grab the attention and the dollars of the buying public.

title: SUSAN WEISSMAN TOMARRY IN JUNE
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Myrna Weissman of New York and New Haven and Dr. Sherman Weissman of New Haven of the engagement of their daughter Susan Weissman to Douglas Reifler, the son of Carolyn Bailey of Westlake Village, Calif., and Ronald Reifler of Claremont, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: ANITA COVINGTON PLANS TO MARRY IN FEBRUARY
description: Anita Flynt Covington and Steven McArthur Heller are engaged and plan to be married in February, it was announced by her parents, Anita Emmons Covington and Robert E. Covington Jr., both of Quitman, Miss. Mr. Heller's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Steven Heller of Dayton, Ohio.

title: 25 YEARS OF SIGHTS UNSEEN
description: HALLEY'S Comet is only one of many phenomena I have missed on Long Island. Not that I didn't try. I was out there at Parking Field 2 at the West End of Jones Beach the first night, along with the wife and Dorothy and Jerry and binoculars for all and a telescope and mittens and a Navy watch cap and a map of the heavens.

title: ATLANTA IS FINALLY FLOWING
description: REPAIR crews presented thousands of weary Atlanta commuters with an early Christmas present last week - they took down the construction barricades and opened some new lanes and a bridge over the intersection of Interstates 75 and 85 near downtown. Although the rest of the interchange is not scheduled to be finished until next year, the opening moved the city one step closer to the completion of a massive, $1.3 billion reconstruction of its 125-mile interstate highway network.

title: NUMBER OF OSPREYS ON INCREASE
description: A SURVEY of ospreys conducted before the birds left the state for warmer climes in October indicates that the population is at its highest point since the 1960's, when the pesticide DDT and shoreline development nearly decimated their numbers.

title: MELINDA WERBER TO WED IN APRIL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Werber of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melinda Hinckley Werber to John Charles Pettit, the son of Mrs. John J. Pettit of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Mr. Pettit. The wedding is planned for April.

title: Another Swim Record For Mitchell of Texas
description: Betsy Mitchell broke the American record in the 100-meter backstroke in the United States Open swimming championship preliminaries this morning and came back in the finals tonight to break her own mark with a time of 1 minute 1.79 seconds.

title: BUTING SECURITIES THAT THE 'ARBS' DUMP
description: THE heated pace of mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts has contributed to this year's record number of bonds, convertible bonds, preferred stock and other fixed-income instruments, many of which were issued to finance such deals. And at least one money manager is taking advantage of the ''inefficient market'' that often emerges when risk arbitragers establish spread positions using some of the new securities.

title: 50 OUTSTANDING CD RELEASES -- A SELECTIVE DISCOGRAPHY
description: Last spring, when there were only some 3,000 compact-disk releases, it still seemed possible for one person to offer a personal but still vaguely responsible survey of the available recordings and to provide a list of the 100 best of them. That list, qualified as ''a selective discography,'' appeared in this section on April 21.

title: HOLIDAY 'TIPPLING IS AN OLD TRADITION
description: THE wealthy 17th- and 18th- century families had punch bowls made of silver, of blown glass and of fine porcelain. The punch bowls were taken down from the shelves or off the sideboard and washed, dusted or polished for celebrations and parties. The basic early recipe for punch was spirits mixed with water, sugar, the juice of lemons or oranges and spices - perhaps cinnamon, nutmeg and sometimes a bay leaf.

title: INFANT DEATH RATE SAID TO BE TOO HIGH
description: ALTHOUGH the infant mortality rate in Connecticut has reached a plateau after years of decline, it is, state health officials say, still unacceptably high.

title: PUTTING INDUSTRY EVEN FURTHER BEHIND
description: IN the 1984 election, Ronald Reagan thrashed the Democrats for their flirtations with industrial policy. Today, he and his many supporters in the military industry are eagerly pushing the nation toward its grandest experiment yet in industrial planning - the Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as ''Star Wars.'' Unlike the Democratic versions, however, this policy will exacerbate our problems in international competition by diverting scarce resources and prized technical talent into arcane areas of research that lack commercial potential.

title: MARGARET CARROLL TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Carroll Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Duffus Carroll, to Stowe Holding Tattersall, a son of Mrs. Donald A. Pickering of Princeton, N.J., and the late Samuel L. Tattersall Jr. The wedding is planned for May.

title: SUITING UP IN BORROWED GEAR, WOMEN TAKE THE ICE
description: THE best player on the team is pregnant. ''Men's teams don't have that problem,'' joked Michael Bonelli, who coaches a woman's ice hockey team at the Harvey School skating rink in this northern Westchester town.

title: ROCKVILLE CENTRE PROPOSING AN OWNER-OCCUPANCY RULE
description: THE Village of Rockville Centre has proposed a zoning change that would require owners to live in new or converted two-family homes. Officials say it is designed to discourage the sale of existing two-family homes to absentee landlords.

title: 2 NIAGARA OFFICIALS GIVEN LEAVES
description: The Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority, one of the subjects of an F.B.I. investigation into possible corruption, has placed two of its top executives on indefinite leaves.

title: TARRYTOWN RETAIL SECTOR GETS A HELPING HAND
description: GENNARO FAIELLA says that he may have to wait until next year to get his Christmas wish - a revitalized Tarrytown business district.

title: Scholastic Incentive
description: The low graduation rate of major college athletes has become something of a national scandal, and now the College Football Association is trying to do something about it by honoring member schools that graduate at least 75 percent of their varsity football players within five years of matriculation. According to Chuck Neinas, the association's executive director, a survey of football players who entered the 63 member schools in 1979 found that three schools had achieved the 75 percent rate: the University of Virginia, Penn State and Notre Dame.

title: THE STAGE: GUARE CHRONICLE, 'WOMEN AND WATER'
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -

title: FREEDOM ,NECESSITY AND DOGS I HAVE KNOWN
description: WHEN an acquaintance asks what books have been important to me, I invariably surprise even myself by drawing a blank. I could answer - as I have on occasion, after some thought - ''The Brothers Karamazov'' or name some other classic work. But the true answer to the question, an answer I'm a little embarrassed to give after years spent acquiring a taste for high art, is that my important books were dog books, which I read from about my 7th to my 10th birthdays. I must have read scores of them, but I remember only a few by title: ''The Call of the Wild'' and ''White Fang'' by Jack London; ''Lad: A Dog'' and other collie books by Albert Payson Terhune; ''Big Red,'' ''Irish Red'' and the other setter stories of Jim Kjelgaard; and ''Wilderness Champion: The Story of a Great Hound'' by Joseph Lip-pincott.

title: MEG LOWENTHAL TO BE THE BRIDE OF SETH AKABAS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mort Lowenthal of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Meg Lowenthal to Seth A. Akabas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron L. Akabas of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: FAURE'S REQUIEM IN CHAMBER FORM
description: Musicology has devoted itself to a good deal of housecleaning in recent years, and apart from discovering numerous forgotten works by famous masters (not to mention forgotten masters themselves), scholars are now delivering up familiar scores in unfamiliar states, cleansed and shorn of later improvements made by other hands and sanctioned by tradition. Not every restoration is successful, but not all restoration rubs the paint off with the varnish. A case in point is Gabriel Faure's Requiem, the early chamber ensemble version of which was never published, and until now had not been performed since the composer's lifetime.

title: MAJOR CHANGES IN BUDGET BATTLES ARE SEEN IN PLAN TO END DEFICITS
description: Proposed legislation to require a balanced budget by 1991 would radically change the policy goals and political stakes in coming budget battles between the White House and Congress, according to several lawmakers.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT FROM BISHOPS AT SYNOD: 'MESSAGE TO THE PEOPLE OF GOD'
description: Following is the text, issued today by the Vatican, of the ''Message to the People of God'' from the Synod of Bishops:

title: CHILDREN MAKE ORIGAMI ORNAMENTS
description: CHRISTMAS arrived early in November at the Champion International Corporation in Stamford, when Darien schoolchildren decorated the trees in the company's greenhouse with origami ornaments.

title: New Agenda for the Women's Movement
description: For too long, Betty Friedan has looked to highly paid professional women as the source for a revitalized women's movement. She might well remember that the women's movement of the 1960's did not solely originate with professional women seeking careers.

title: New Agenda for the Women's Movement
description: By blaming yuppies and backlash fundamentalists for her movement's decline, Betty Friedan avoids the obvious: via mass women's magazines, she popularized a feminism that suited their readership: bored, middle-class housewives.

title: POLICE RULES ARE KEY TO DISPUTE ON OFFICER'S CHURCH VISITS
description: A police officer who wants to take his Sunday lunch break in church has spurred a labor dispute that turns on the question of a police chief's authority rather than any church-state issues, both sides say.

title: LEGISLATOR ASKING LAWYERS IN STATE TO RATE JUDGES
description: CONNECTICUT'S judges are being judged more closely themselves these days.

title: OSHA TAKES AIM AT 3 SUBSTANCES
description: The Reagan Administration announced last week its most extensive action to date on safety and health in the workplace. But union safety officials were not impressed.

title: ALBANY RULES CURB BUILDING NEAR STREAMS
description: Thirteen years after it got the assignment, a New York State agency is finishing work on regulations to limit development near protected rivers.

title: FATHER'S TRIAL OVER, BUT TRIALS CONTINUE
description: MONTCLAIR

title: CATHERINE CURRAN BECOMES ENGAGED TOMARRY THOMAS MCCARTHY SOUTHER
description: The engagement of Catherine Adele Curran to Thomas McCarthy Souther has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Curran of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Sea Girt, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Souther of Muttontown, L.I., and Stuart, Fla.

title: LEAGUE EXHIBITS 196 WORKS
description: AS one of the very few open exhibitions on Long Island, the Huntington Township Art League's annual members' show upholds a tradition established in this country by the Society of Independent Artists, formed in 1917 in reaction against the ultraconservative National Academy of Design and its exclusionary jurying practices.

title: SAHIBZADA KEMAL WED TO DR. MARY DI MAIO
description: Dr. Mary Di Maio, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dominick J. Di Maio of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to Sahibzada Mustafa Kemal, a son of Sahibzada Abdul Jabbar Khan and Begum Khan of Karachi, Pakistan. Msgr. Francis Murphy performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church.

title: LANDSCAPE DESIGNERS GIVE NATURE A HELPING HAND
description: The typical homeowner is more resistant to the idea of using a landscape designer than to using the services of an interior designer. I wasn't really sure why this should be so until the other night at a dinner party. No one at my table seemed to know what a landscape architect or designer does. They all had heard Frank Lloyd Wright's sardonic comment, ''A doctor can bury his mistakes, but an architect can only advise his clients to plant vines.'' They accepted the idea that erring architects would be eager to consult landscape architects in order not to multiply the errors, but beyond that, they were in the dark.

title: RESTRICTIONS ON CITY JUDGES WORRY MAYORS
description: MAYOR Ronald A. Blackwood of Mount Vernon is asking the state's judicial system for justice but he is not sure that he will receive it.

title: LINK TO GAMBLING?
description: COMPULSIVE gambling may be caused by the same biological deficiency linked to similar uncontrollable behavior in alcoholics and arsonists, according to a psychiatrist at the National Institute of Health.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 32 of the Arts and Leisure section today about compact-disk recordings misidentifies a classical work by the composer John Adams. The title is ''Harmonium.''

title: ADJUNCT PROFESSORS AND L.I. COLLEGES
description: As a professor at Nassau community College, as well as the secretary of the Nassau Community College Federation of Teachers, Local 3150, I found serious inaccuracies in ''Colleges Use More Adjuncts.'' The article seemed to favor the ''plight of the adjunct faculty union at N.C.C.'' at the expense of the union representing the full-time faculty and the institution itself.

title: COUNTERING DEPRESSION DURING HOLIDAYS
description: JUST before Christmas a few years ago, Dr. Myrna M. Weissman received a call from a woman in despair. Through her tears, the woman told Dr. Weissman that her in-laws had arrived for the holidays with a gift of 10 pounds of shrimp.

title: DIANE L. DIETZEN TOMARRY ANTHONY RHODES IN SPRING
description: Announcement has been made by Sandra Dietzen and David F. Dietzen of Austin, Tex., of the engagement of their daughter, Diane Louise Dietzen, to Anthony Lamont Belin Rhodes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Rhodes of Waverly, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title: Hemingway's Biographer
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SCREEN FARCE TO HOLIDAY SONGS
description: Carols for Christmas With the Royal College of Music Chamber Choir; arranged and conducted by David Willcocks; directed by Christopher Swann Thorn EMI/HBO Video 60 minutes. $39.95 This is a standard selection of carols, tastefully arranged, beautifully sung, and presented in tandem with appropriate seasonal works of art from the Metropolitan Museum's collection.

title: DRUNKEN-DRIVING SUITS WORRY JERSEY BARKEEPERS
description: Things have not been the same at the Melody Bar since the owners, Steve Flaks and Cal Levine, hung a 10-by-30-foot painting on the wall.

title: HOW THE LINEAR ACCELERATOR WORKS IN THERAPY
description: DOCTORS have been using radiation to destroy cancer cells since 1898, when they first inserted radioactive needles and glass tubes filled with radium powder into patients' bodies.

title: JORDAN, JOINING TREND, CURBS ISLAMIC MILITANTS
description: The Jordanian Government has begun imposing tight restrictions on Moslem fundamentalists, reflecting a growing tendency on the part of Arab Governments to suppress religious extremists.

title: WHY FARM SECURITIES ARE HOT ITEMS ON WALL STREET
description: PETER J. CARNEY is remarkably calm, even cheerful, considering that the Federal Farm Credit System is in such deep financial trouble.

title: FIRST AND TEN FOR DONALD TRUMP
description: Donald J. Trump, the developer, received permission last week from state and city officials to play ball in Queens; all he needs now is a team.

title: PAMELA J. TIMMERMAN TO WED J.R. MOUSSEAU
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Grove Timmerman of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Jane Timmerman to John Robert Mousseau, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Emile Mousseau of Thompson, Conn. A March wedding is planned.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE: BEST BOOKS 1985
description: The best books of the year, chosen by the editors of The Book Review from those published since last year's Christmas Books issue, comprise four volumes of fiction and seven of nonfiction. This year's list is shorter than last year's by two in each category.

title: SECOND THOUGHTS FROM HOME
description: The nomination of James L. Buckley to one of the nation's most important appellate courts, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, was placed on hold last week by the Senators from Mr. Buckley's home state, Connecticut. The Senators, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican, and Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, raised political and ideological objections to the nomination of Mr. Buckley, a resident of Sharon, Conn., who once served as a Republican-Conservative Senator from New York.

title: Food View;   A Year Of Surprises
description: NINETEEN-EIGHTY-FIVE took me by surprise. This is not easy for a food critic to admit - after all, we are supposed to be experts in our field. Yet looking back over these 12 months and, by my rough calculation, well over 400 restaurant meals, I must concede that my crystal ball was a bit foggy. In fact, I was fairly sure that the fervid pace of restaurant growth, in New York City as well as in other major cities, would begin to wane. And at the same time, near-fanatical public interest in the goings-on of chefs and competitive dining rooms, I believed, would decline to a more sober level.

title: TEXT OF FINAL REPORT ADOPTED BY SYNOD OF BISHOPS IN ROME
description: Following is the text of the final report adopted today by the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops. It was obtained and translated from the Latin by The New York Times.

title: 'LILLIPUTIAN LOLLAPALOOZA'
description: Since Hubert's Flea Circus vanished without a scratch some years ago from West 42d Street in New York City, most circuses moving around in the Northeast corridor have tended to be cumbrous affairs, devoted to traditional multi-ring bigness. Much too big for Howard Tibbals, of Oneida, Tenn., who has carved his own miniature circus of several thousand pieces on a scale that makes an elephant's trunk about the same size as a human nose.

title: DR. LUCY COLLINS WEDS HARRY DAVIDOW
description: The marriage of Dr. Lucy Emerson Collins and Harry Martin Davidow took place yesterday at the New York home of the bridegroom's brother and sister-in-law, Joel Davidow and Dr. Debra Miller. Acting Justice Frederic S. Berman of the State Supreme Court officiated.

title: ART
description: The good news this season is that there is a whole slew of new art books that are as rewarding to read as they are to look at. Anyone who thinks that is the normal state of affairs and undeserving of comment has only to visit the discount bookstores, where he will find pile upon pile of art books that were conceived in apathy and executed in squalor. Ours has been the age of the unnecessary art book, in which an oft-times recycled text finds its match in prehistoric black-and-white photographs and transparencies discolored by age or incompetence.

title: O FAITHFUL LISTENER, HARK, THE CHRISTMAS MUSIC SOUNDS
description: With the sounds of jangling jingle bells, cherubic choruses, crooning carols and oversweet renditions of ''Silent Night'' assaulting our ears in this season, those in search of superior specimens among the new Christmas albums can be promised some pleasant surprises.

title: A GUIDE FOR HOLIDAY SHOPPING
description: IS ANYONE looking for a Rolls-Royce limousine in clay? That is among the many unusual items available to holiday shoppers at craft galleries around the state.

title: NOISE NUISANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: LOBBYING GROUP SEEKS TAX REPEAL
description: Visitors to the downtown offices of Citizens for Limited Taxation catch on very quickly that this organization emphasizes substance, not style.

title: POP/IN THE CLUBS
description: Three years ago, Dixie Carter, the singer and actress best known for her roles in the TV series ''Filthy Rich'' and ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' made her local cabaret debut at Freddy's Supper Club and immediately established herself as a fresh, intriguing new singing personality. A performer with a broad comedic streak, Miss Carter is miles away from a conventional saloon singer.

title: WESTPORT CANCELS 'POWDER PUFF' GAMES
description: FOR years, one of the rites of late fall at many high schools has been the annual ''powder puff'' football game between female students.

title: Recent Sales
description: Edison $103,000 104 Merrywood Drive *2* 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old town-house condominium; *2* living-room fireplace, finished basement, $45 monthly charges; taxes $1,668. Fair Lawn $159,900 3-40 28th Street *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; *2* wine cellar, porch, central air-conditioning; taxes $2,398. title: Draco vs. Solon
description: The Great Budgetary Battle of '85 is coming to an end: The official dress of the U.S. Government for the next five years will be a straitjacket.

title: BURR TILLSTROM, PUPPETEER, DIES
description: Burr Tillstrom, the creator of the popular television show ''Kukla, Fran and Ollie,'' died Friday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: WHAT CUOMO SEEKS IN SPECIAL SESSION
description: When Governor Cuomo ordered a special session of the Legislature for next Tuesday, he set an agenda of six issues, all of which have been hotly debated among Democrats and Republicans for much of the year.

title: YULETIDE IN BRITAIN
description: Christmastime in England -the thought conjures up Dickensian images of singing carols in the snow, sipping wassail before a fire or eating roast chestnuts and Christmas pudding. But it's actually more likely to rain than snow in England on Christmas Day, and the snowy scenes described by Dickens in ''A Christmas Carol'' were something of a meteorological freak. But Christmas in Britain can promise all the other holiday trappings.

title: Adjunct Professors And L.I. Colleges
description: I regret to say that the Nov. 17 article ''Colleges Use More Adjuncts'' is thinly disguised propaganda for the Adjunct Faculty Association, a union that represents part-time faculty at Nassau Community College.

title: CHINA SPYING SUSPECT: A MAN OF MANY WORLDS
description: Larry Wu-Tai Chin entered Peking's Yenching University in 1940 when China was at a political crossroads. As Japanese armies occupied Peking and much of the country, many wondered whether to support the Communist insurgents.

title: Ex-Manson Follower Is Living in Vermont
description: A former follower of Charles Manson, the mass murderer, is living in Vermont after being released from a prison in West Virginia, according to Gov. Madeline M. Kunin of Vermont.

title: SOME IN CALIFORNIA PROTEST LOTTERY WINNERS
description: Not all the winners in California's two-month-old lottery have also won the public acclaim that usually accompanies such luck, and not all are being allowed to enjoy their new wealth in this country.

title: ARCHITECT LEAVES LEGACY IN 20 PARKS
description: Pastel plazas and Victorian gazebos - bits of sunshine in New York's drabber neighborhoods - are in large measure the legacy of one small bureau and one 33-year-old landscape architect.

title: SENATOR SAYS REPORT CLEARS SAFETY NOMINEE
description: John C. Danforth, chairman of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, has issued a report saying he is satisfied with Terrence M. Scanlon's denials of charges that he misused his office on the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Bo Wins the 'Eyesmen' Too
description: IN the film-weary eyes of the men who scout the campuses for National Football League teams, Bo Jackson, the Auburn running back, is by far the nation's most outstanding college player this season.

title: WHY TRUST CHINA NOW?
description: AS our intelligence agencies struggle with the implications of Larry Wu-Tai Chin's 20 years of top-level spying for China, across town at the State Department they're readying a celebration: The long-sought United States-China nuclear trade pact, under which we will give China technology and materials for nuclear power, is about to become a reality.

title: COURT HOLDS CLASSIFIED DATA TO A STRICTER LEGAL STANDARD
description: Judges must weigh possible harm to national security when they decide if classified material can be used in a trial, a Federal appellate court has ruled in an espionage case.

title: POLICE DISPATCHER SEEKS TRAINING FOR ALL
description: After six years on the job as a dispatcher for the East Hartford Police Department, John P. Lavoie is trying to organize fellow police, fire and ambulance dispatchers across the state into a professional association.

title: PARENTS AND CHILDREN LEARN TOGETHER
description: WHILE Wodenvel Randall is completing the work for her high school equivalency diploma and preparing for her next career move, her daughters are learning to be more independent and disciplined.

title: YELENA BONNER ARRIVES IN WEST FOR MEDICAL CARE
description: Yelena G. Bonner has broken out of the isolation that Soviet authorities had imposed to punish her and her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist. Last week, she was allowed to fly to Italy and the United States for treatment by eye and heart specialists.

title: ELLEN DEUTSCH MARRIES
description: Ellen Elizabeth Deutsch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans W. Deutsch of West Hartford, Conn., and Timothy Salo Hollister, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Hollister of Brooklyn, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. James L. Kidd and the Rev. Peter Grandy officiated at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: Australia Bowl To Wyoming
description: A crowd of 19,107 in V.F.L. Park, a stadium that seats 75,000 for Australian Rules Football, got a look at American college football tonight as the Wyoming defeated Texas-El Paso, 23-21, in the Australia Bowl.

title: THREAT LIES IN ARMS RACE, NOT FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: TIROZZI BACK IN THE CLASSROOM BOTH TO TEACH AND TO LEARN
description: WHEN State Education Commissioner Gerald N. Tirozzi visited a group of eighth graders at Eastford Elementary School last week and asked how many would like to be teachers, he was disappointed, but not surprised, by the response.

title: CHAMBER: JUBAL TRIO
description: THE Jubal Trio's Thursday evening performance at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, was distinguished by two elements: the world premiere of Miriam Gideon's limpid, lilting and good-humored ''Creature to Creature,'' a deftly wrought song cycle based on poems by Nancy Cardozo, and a strong performance of Harvey Sollberger's ''Life Study'' (1982), both works commissioned by the trio.

title: LAKERS GAIN IN STRENGTH
description: In Los Angeles, where the actor Jack Nicholson pulls down his shades and pulls up a chair every time the Lakers take the floor, it is business as usual. The defending National Basketball Association champions, who play before celebrities and sellouts almost nightly, are relishing a beginning not unlike those experienced by the Celtics in Boston. Only better.

title: THE F.C.C. IS EASING UP ON THE REINS
description: Following the lead of the rest of the Reagan Administration, the Federal agency that oversees the nation's airwaves has decided that it can best protect the public's interests by interfering as little as possible with broadcasters. Among other things, the Federal Communications Commission, a 50-year-old agency, has begun abolishing or weakening many rules that were designed to promote the more diverse ownership of radio and television stations and newspapers and to insure the financial fitness of broadcast license holders.

title: ATLANTIC DRAWS FROM ITS TREASURY OF POP
description: Ahmet Ertegun, founder of Atlantic records, was the son of a Turkish ambassador to the United States, a well-educated, owlishly dignified, unfailingly polite young man who spoke several languages fluently and dressed in conservative, impeccably tailored suits. He was hardly the sort of person one would expect to encounter on America's tough, competitive rhythm-and-blues scene in the late 1940's.

title: Home Design View;   Cultural Exchanges
description: MUCH ATTENTION is being accorded such controversial commissions as the American architect I. M. Pei's addition to the Louvre in Paris or the British architect James Stirling's Arthur M. Sackler Museum at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. In fact, however, it is no longer surprising that architects and decorators are regularly crisscrossing oceans and continents, whether for major buildings or smaller (and lucrative) residential projects. There is a new fascination, a special cachet, attached to that which is far away.

title: MOCK HEARING HELD IN CHERRY HILL ON SOVIET JEWISH POLICY
description: SPEAKERS at an unofficial Congressional hearing here last weekend painted a gloomy picture of life for ''refuseniks'' - Jews seeking to leave the Soviet Union.

title: Two Men Arrested in Killing
description: The police charged two cousins Friday with the slaying of a University of Pennsylvania student from India whose body was discovered Monday in her dormitory room. The two men, identified by the authorities as Charles Weatherbe, 25 years old, of Philadelphia, and George Stump, 18, of Harrisburg, were held without bail on charges of murder, robbery and related offenses in the fatal stabbing of Meera Ananthakrishnan, 24, on Nov. 28.

title: SAVORING RARE TREASURES FROM INDIA
description: The most ambitious of the Festival of India art events, ''India - Art and Culture: 1300-1900,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Jan. 5, makes it abundantly clear that the period decorative arts from this land of flowers and ferment are a mystery. The exhibition of 350 art works covers various media - sculpture, paintings, jewelry, textiles and metalwork - and lives up to its billing as the most extensive survey of later Indian art ever assembled. Enthusiasts realize that it is difficult, but not impossible, to acquire such works from dealers who specialize in this field.

title: PUTTING THE OLD TO GOOD USE
description: Last year a special development region known as the Reed-Putnam Design District was established in South Norwalk, Conn., to encourage, through loans and tax abatements, the reuse of old buildings in an aging industrial neighborhood on the Norwalk River.

title: ELDERLY IN JERSEY SEEN ON INCREASE
description: The number of elderly people in New Jersey will grow faster than any other age group by the end of the century, according to a study released by Governor Kean.

title: PROVIDENCE, R.I., ADDS APARTMENTS
description: WHAT do you do when your downtown streets are virtually deserted at night? If you're Mayor of Providence, you decide to bring people downtown to live.

title: JUDAICA: REWARDS AND PITFALLS
description: JUDAICA is not a field in which great numbers of people are assembling large private collections. According to Jay Weinstein, a vice president of Sotheby Parke Bernet Inc. in New York City and head of its Judaica department, ''there are no more than four or five major [private] collectors in the world.''

title: Alarm About Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Ezra Pound at 100
description: To the Editor:

title: DEAN OF NEW CITY U. MEDICAL SCHOOL RESIGNS
description: The dean of the new medical school at City University, which recently failed to win provisional accreditation, has resigned, according to officials at City College, the home campus for the school.

title: MARBLE STAINED? HERE'S HOW TO CLEAN IT
description: MARBLE is extremely durable and highly decorative, but it is quite porous and nowhere nearly as hard as it looks. It stains easily because it tends to absorb greasy liquids or foods dropped on it, and it can be easily marred by the mild acids found in many foods such as orange juice, tomato juice or lemon juice.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: COLONIAL CHRISTMAS, CONTEMPORARY HOLLAND
description: Parisian Shopping Convenience ''Will they have it at the airport duty-free shop the day I leave?''

title: AUTOMATED TICKET MACHINES DUE IN MASSAXHUSETTS LOTTERY
description: The Massachusetts Lottery Commission has signed a contract with a Texas company that manufactures automated ticket-selling machines.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: READING AND CRUNCHING ALTHOUGH libraries are supposed to be the quietest of places, in the West Babylon Public Library you kind of expect to hear the crunch from someone munching on a potato chip or two.

title: JAZZ
description: Jazz, rock and blues performers will gather on Monday at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue at 13th Street (242-1664) in a memorial concert for Big Joe Turner. The Kansas City blues singer, who died Nov. 24, showed generations of singers how to find joy, subtlety and swing in the most basic of blues.

title: WEIGHING THE RISKS AND RIGHTS OF HOMELESSNESS
description: When the friends of Gary Doe, one of New York City's estimated 50,000 homeless people, sought to retrieve him, they faced at least two problems - one logistical, one legal. They knew that even if they managed to track him down, they might be powerless under the law to force him to abandon his life on the streets.

title: REVENGE FUELS COLD WAR MOVIES OF THE 80'S
description: ''You can't squelch patriotism,'' Sylvester Stallone was quoted as saying late last spring when it became apparent that ''Rambo:

title: Nonprofit Corporations Are Seen as Hostages
description: New Jersey's 4,000 nonprofit corporations, as well as its physicians, are being held hostage to the insurance-industry crisis (''About Medical Malpractice Suits,'' by Hazel F. Gluck, the state's Commissioner of Insurance, Opinion Page, Nov. 10).

title: MISS DE LA BRUYERE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Jacqueline de La Bruyere, a daughter of Mrs. Frederic P. Herter of New York and Jean de La Bruyere of Beverly Hills, Calif., was married yesterday to Herve Farman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcel Farman of Paris. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: MT. KISCO BUS LINE LOSING ITS SUBSIDY
