description: WESTCHESTER County has notified Mount Kisco Bus Lines, which has been sharply criticized by two key members of the Board of Legislators, that it will not renew the company's subsidy contract that expires at the end of the year, Transportatiion Commissioner R. Raleigh D'Adamo said last week.

title: GOING BACK: BULGARIA, 20 YEARS LATER
description: I RETURNED WITH A certain uneasiness to Bulgaria, where I had served 20 years earlier as a correspondent. In part, my discomfort grew from memories of wretched hotel food, which invariably made me break out in boils, and the rather hostile attitude of Bulgarian officials functioning under a mandated policy of anti-Americanism. Primarily it was based on the fact that the People's Republic had issued a ukase barring me from the country for life. Twice.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The church by means of the Council did not wish to shut herself up within herself, or to refer to herself alone.

title: A LITERARY QUIZ (AND TO ALL, GOOD LUCK)
description: The great Western holiday of the winter solstice turns up once or twice, you might say, in the literature of the West. Identify author and title for the following excerpts. If the quizmaster had chosen to include ''He had a broad face and a little round belly, / That shook when he laughed, like a bowl full of jelly,'' the correct answer would be ''Clement Clarke Moore, 'A Visit From St. Nicholas.' '' Spelling and punctuation have been modernized, on occasion, with cunning and duplicitous intent. 1. The customary expedient of provincial girls and men in such circumstances is churchgoing. In an ordinary village or country town one can safely calculate that, either on Christmas-day or the Sunday contiguous, any native home for the holidays, who has not through age or ennui lost the appetite for seeing and being seen, will turn up in some pew or other, shining with hope, self-consciousness, and new clothes. Thus the congregation on Christmas morning is mostly a Tussaud collection of celebrities who have been born in the neigh-bourhood. 2. There were the Useful Presents: engulfing mufflers of the old coach days, and mittens made for giant sloths; zebra scarfs of a substance like silky gum that could be tug-o'-warred down to the galoshes; blinding tam-o'-shanters like patchwork tea cozies and bunny-suited busbies and balaclavas for victims of head-shrinking tribes; from aunts who always wore wool next to the skin there were mustached and rasping vests that made you wonder why the aunts had any skin left at all. 3.

title: A CONCERT MENU OF SENSATIONAL FARE
description: ONE of the most imaginative holiday concepts on today's busy music schedule - and seemingly the only one to note that Christmas is just one of the major holidays this month - is a gift to the community from the Trumbull Arts Commission.

title: A VICTORIAN CHRISTMAS AT GILLETTE CASTLE
description: GILLETTE CASTLE is glowing with holiday magic this month. The wood and granite castle, which overlooks the Connecticut River in Hadlyme, is a delightful architectural whimsy under any circumstances. But decorated for a Victorian Christmas such as its famous creator, the actor William Gillette, might have celebrated, it provides a special thrill.

title: CORAZON AQUINO CONCEDES DIFFICULTIES
description: CORAZON C. AQUINO describes herself as ''just a housewife,'' conceding that she has little political experience beyond preparing meals for the politicians who were friends of her husband. In announcing her candidacy for the presidency last week, the 52-year-old widow of Benigno S. Aquino, the assassinated opposition leader, said in an interview that it was the ''complete change'' she offered that was her greatest asset. ''I think that this is no longer a question of one politician versus another politician because people are just so fed up,'' she said. Does she have any political ideas other than those of her husband? ''Sometimes I wonder,'' she answered. ''I don't know. Maybe I do.'' The woman who seeks to become the first new President of the Philippines in two decades was born on Jan. 25, 1933, the sixth of eight children in the wealthy and politically active Cojuangco family in the province of Tarlac, 50 miles north of Manila. Her father and brother were congressmen and a grandfather was a senator. Her estranged cousin, Eduardo, is a powerful businessman with close ties to Mr. Marcos and is one of the leading contenders to become his running mate.

title: THE BIG ISSUE IS MARCOS AND 20 YEARS OF HIS RULE
description: ON the island of Cebu recently, President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda - to the delight of businessmen at a convention - harmonized in a chorus of a popular love song.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today, and an entry in the music listings of The Guide, section 2A, carry outdated information for Rudolf Serkin's recital at Carnegie Hall. The performance has been postponed indefinitely.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Monitoring Your Dreams There's pathos in the picture of a mother who is such an influential figure that she and her daughter have to exercise a mutual restraint in talking to each other. This is how Margaret Mead appears in ''With a Daughter's Eye'' (Washington Square) by Mary Catherine Bateson.

title: WROTE 'MOLLY BROWN' SCORE
description: Calvin Jackson, a pianist and composer who received an Academy Award nomination for the score of the movie ''The Unsinkable Molly Brown,'' has died at the age of 66.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ELECTRONIC SECURITY
description: THWARTING the bad guys may be the bane of the police, but it is a big boon for the fragmented group of nearly 2,000 companies that make up the growing security industry. The market for devices to help win the war against thieves, computer hackers, hijackers, terrorists, white-collar criminals, shoplifters and others with a less than honest bent is growing at an extraordinary pace.

title: OKLAHOMA WINS
description: Jamelle Holieway rushed for two touchdowns and threw for another to lead Oklahoma to a 35-13 rout of Southern Methodist today that kept the Sooners' hopes alive for a final No. 1 ranking. Oklahoma (10-1) will play No. 1 Penn State (11-0) in the Orange Bowl on Jan. 1.

title: PUTTING A PREMIUM ON CLASSROOM INNOVATION
description: IN mathematics and science, according to the National Science Foundation, the United States is in trouble.

title: Ezra Pound at 100
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Question:I plan to visit Iceland next spring and would like to know what there is do and see in a week. -E. L. D., Plainfield, Conn. Answer:Most visitors explore this 300-mile-long island by taking bus and plane tours. While rental cars are available, tourist officials discourage extensive driving by visitors because many of the roads are of gravel and are not well marked. A few tours outside Reykjavik, the capital, are available in April and May but the busy tour season gets under way in June, after the damage to roads caused by winter frosts has been repaired, and continues through September.

title: BATS, BALLS AND BUBBLE GUM
description: TOPPS BASEBALL CARDS The Complete Picture Collection: A 35 Year History, 1951-1985. By Frank Slocum. Introduction and card history by Sy Berger. Foreword by Willie Mays. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Warner Books. $79.95. THE BILL JAMES HISTORICAL BASEBALL ABSTRACT By Bill James. Illustrated. 645 pp. New York: Villard Books. $24.95. BASEBALL cards have long had a special place in the hearts of fans. Cards have been associated with bubble gum and youngsters since the early 1930's. Before learning to ride a two-wheeler, many children become adept at trading, flipping, matching or simply collecting baseball cards. But as long ago as the 1880's, cards were packaged with cigarettes, not gum, and prized by adults more than children. Indeed, the association of baseball cards with tobacco is responsible for the most valuable card of all, the Honus Wagner, distributed with Sweet Caporal cigarettes in 1910. The great Pittsburgh Pirate shortstop disliked cigarettes so much he insisted that the tobacco company recall and destroy all cards bearing his likeness; as a result, the few 1910 Wagners that remain now command $25,000 in mint condition.

title: A SPOOOF, OF COURSE
description: To The Editor:

title: CHICAGO GEARS UP FOR THE PRIMARIES
description: City, county and state politicians in Chicago are gearing up for the primary elections next March. But to win in 1986, candidates must first get past 1987.

title: JACKSON CAPTURES HEISMAN
description: The feeling was unlike any Bo Jackson had experienced during his four years at Auburn. Not even the prospect of a big game against Florida, Georgia or traditional rival Alabama had played on his mind like the business about winning the Heisman Trophy, Jackson said. On a football field at least, Jackson has some control over the outcome. But now, sitting in a room with dignitaries and members of the Downtown Athletic Club, he squirmed in his chair and heard his heart thumping as if it were being amplified by speakers.

title: STATE TO SET UP COMPUTERIZED FINGERPRINT SYSTEM
description: New York State plans to develop a computerized system for quickly identifying fingerprints found at crime scenes, according to the state's Criminal Justice Director, Lawrence T. Kurlander.

title: BROADWAY'S CLASSIC 'CHORUS LINE' MAKES
description: Turning a play into a movie is a little like translating a work of literature from one language to another. There are certain concepts, subtleties and innuendos that seem effortless in the original but are difficult to render in another idiom. So it was when ''A Chorus Line,'' that prize-winning, innovative, consummate piece of musical theater that has broken all records for longevity on Broadway, made the leap from stage to screen.

title: CONVICT-TURNED-DOCTOR PROVOKES PENNSYLVANIA LICENSE BATTLE
description: For 34 months, Timothy McCormick was number K1914, a convicted drug runner, one of hundreds of inmates who each year enter the century-old stone prison here with little hope for the future and a good chance of paying a return visit.

title: A CONDUCTOR WHO CHAMPIONS THE CAUSE OF HUNGARIAN MUSIC
description: Adam Fischer's schedule reads like something out of the movie ''If It's Tuesday, This Must Be Belgium.'' In the last 32 days, he has conducted 24 concerts, each in a different city, and he has paid the jet-age marathoner's price. One night last month the 35-year-old conductor walked onstage, bowed to the audience, raised his baton and realized he had forgotten what was on the program.

title: AIRPORTS AND JOBS
description: NEWARK International Airport and its resident aviation industries generate thousands of jobs and contribute billions of dollars a year to the regional economy, according to a new study.

title: BRITAIN WITHDRAWS FROM UNESCO
description: Britain made good last week its threat to withdraw from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, following in the footsteps of the United States for much the same reasons - dissatisfaction with what is seen as the agency's anti-Western bent and its inefficient management.

title: DANCE BUFFS CAN LEARN A LOT BY CURLING UP WITH A BOOK
description: Most people don't read the phone book page by page, but in these confessions of a dance-dictionary buff a certain case might be made for poring over the entries in reference volumes in a given field. The first justification is the fun of it all. For instance, looking through the 1986 edition of ''Dancing Times,'' a dictionary-calendar that Nancy Reynolds compiles so admirably every year, one learns under the May 21 entry that this date in 1959 is the time when ''Jerome Robbins, inspired by the famous ecdysiast, choreographs the musical 'Gypsy.' ''

title: On Language;   Zing 'em With Zugzwang
description: ''YOU CANNOT WRITE about world affairs without a Weltanschauung; you cannot practice literary criticism without an understanding of Zeit-geist; you cannot nibble your nails properly without Angst, and you cannot report on turmoil anywhere without Sturm und Drang.

title: THE U.N. ROUNDS UP MORE THAN THE USUAL SUSPECTS
description: Perhaps no activity of the United Nations has been more colored by politics in the last decade than its handling of human rights. The United States has long complained of a ''double standard,'' charging that the organization plays favorites, concentrating on violations in countries friendly to Washington while ignoring others.

title: ITALY'S TRUFFLED BOAR
description: Long before the Romans or even the Etruscans, Italians were wild for cinghiale, native boar. Ancient Greeks named an Italian island for its boar, the Isle of Kapros, now Capri. Imperial Romans doted on boar simmered in sauces of wine and honey, pepper, lovage, cumin, toasted almonds, dates and figs. Even today, Sardinians, Tuscans and Umbrians dispute the virtues of their wild pigs with the ferocity of the boar itself.

title: TWO YEARS FOR MORISON
description: Samuel Loring Morison's lawyers argued last week that their client -back in a Baltimore courtroom for sentencing - was not a spy and thus should not be dealt with harshly. But Federal District Judge Joseph H. Young rejected the lawyers' pleas for probation and sentenced Mr. Morison, convicted in October of giving spy-satellite photographs to a British military magazine, to two years in prison.

title: CRIME
description: The series featuring Detective Inspector Alfred Stanley Rosher continues with A DEATH IN IRISH TOWN by Jack S. Scott (St. Martin's, $12.95). Rosher is the Englishman who looks like a gorilla, acts like one and is as strong as one. A warehouse burns down in Rosher's jurisdiction, and the firemen discover a murder victim in the wreckage. The mystery, and it is not much of one, turns out to be connected with a trucking company and a smuggling operation.

title: NAPOLEON'S LAST QUARTERS
description: From October 1815 to May 1821, the island of St. Helena was world famous. On that isolated South Atlantic rock the deposed Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte passed the dreary years of his final exile. Watchful British troops camped there by the thousands, cannon bristled from every promontory, warships cruised offshore. When at last he died -of ulcers, cancer or arsenic poisoning - St. Helena's brief moment of glory faded.

title: A Sports Town Farther North
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: Newspaper in St. Louis Suspends Publication
description: The St. Louis Globe-Democrat suspended publication Friday night after a Federal bankruptcy judge said he would appoint a trustee to manage the newspaper's financial affairs.

title: THE ANNUAL AGONY OF SHOPPING DAYS
description: SOME people are so organized that they shop for Christmas all year long. Such people browse in leisurely fashion, cheerfully and methodically selecting the right gift for the right person. By the time the holiday season rolls around, their job is already done.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ONCE THERE WERE NO PANDAS A Chinese Legend. By Margaret Greaves. Illustrated by Beverley Gooding. Unpaged. New York: E. P. Dutton. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 8) WHEN PANDA CAME TO OUR HOUSE. Written and illustrated by Helen Zane Jensen. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 8) IF you have no brothers or sisters, or if you have too many brothers and sisters (which is less likely nowadays), giant pandas make exceptionally good private companions of fantasy. In these two new panda books, the very lovable natives of central China's high-mountain bamboo forests share the limelight with single girl children, one Chinese and one decidedly American.

title: A RESORT FOR ATHELETE AND ESTHETE
description: Only a week before, the hillsides of the Roaring Fork River Valley below Independence Pass were still a deep green summer quilt with wildflower patches in purple, lemon and burgundy, threaded by silvery streams. But autumn was in the bright yellow leaves of the aspen trees, whose shudderings turned the merest breeze to butterfly flights.

title: 'NUTCRACKER' SET BY 5 BALLET GROUPS
description: LIKE most 14-year-olds these days, Jennifer Gelfand has seen ''The Nutcracker,'' that perennial seasonal ballet favorite, more times than she can recall. But usually from backstage.

title: Short of the Best
description: As The Athletics Congress was handing out honors, it also found time to take one away.

title: U.S. SAYS CUBANS FIGHT IN NICARAGUA
description: The United States said last week that it has ''incontrovertible'' proof that Cuban advisers have been fighting alongside Sandinista troops against the Nicaraguan rebels and indicated it might take ''further steps'' to help the so-called contras. As evidence, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said that two Cuban pilots died when a rebel ground-to-air missile downed a Soviet-built MI-8 helicopter Monday near a large Sandinista base 60 miles inside Nicaragua.

title: CONCERT: A REQUIEM BY KOJIBA
description: BORN seven years after the horrible event, Tomiko Kojiba is nonetheless a survivor of Hiroshima. Miss Kojiba grew up there amid the lingering pain of that first atomic attack in 1945, and her requiem ''Hiroshima'' - written in 1979 and performed by the strings of the Boston Symphony at Carnegie Hall Thursday night -remembers its victims both dead and alive.

title: Syrian Stowaway's Bid For Asylun Is Weighed
description: The State Department will recommend next week whether a young Syrian stowaway who leaped into the Mississippi River and requested asylum can remain in the United States, according to the man's lawyer.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: OLD LONDON IN WESTERLY With the help of a set designer, a former church in Westerly, R.I., has been turned into a 19th-century English town. The metamorphosis, including a ''London Bridge'' for walking under and eight shops for browsing in, is a fund-raiser for the Center for the Arts, which is housed in the church at 119 High Street.

title: EMERY STRIKE: ANGER AND FEAR
description: FRANK CIARAMITARO has spent much of the last two months walking up and down outside the Emery Worldwide delivery service facility in Amityville along with some 75 co-workers.

title: 'DROOD' EVOKES THE MIRTH OF AN ENGLISH MUSIC HALL
description: The musical, ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' has moved from its summer quarters (the Delacorte Theater in Central Park) to its winter home (the Imperial Theater on Broadway), and therein lies a difference. What was a merry but meandering al fresco entertainment has been turned into an artfully engineered Victorian vehicle. While still giving only a nod to the essential Dickensian spirit and overlooking entirely the darker side of the narrative, the show is unabashed about its divergence from its source. It is ''suggested by'' rather than adapted from Charles Dickens's last and unfinished novel - about the disappearance and probable death of young Edwin Drood. Created in tandem by Rupert Holmes as author, composer and lyricist and Wilford Leach as director, the show pretends that a musicalization of the novel is being performed by a second-rate English acting company. The result is a play within a play, with the audience as active participants in finding a solution to the crime. For the Broadway version, the author and director have deepened the show's piquant English music hall flavor. At all costs, the new ''Drood'' is theatrical.

title: AS WE SAW CUBA
description: RESPONSE TO REVOLUTION The United States and the Cuban Revolution, 1959-1961. By Richard E. Welch Jr. 243 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $24. Paper, $9.95. SEVEN United States Presidents ago, Fidel Castro came to power in Cuba. This well-written book focuses on Washington's response to the Cuban revolution in the immediate aftermath of Mr. Castro's victory in Cuba in January 1959 until the consolidation of revolutionary rule after the defeat of the United States-backed exile invasion at the Bay of Pigs.

title: Going Bananas
description: THE WOMAN AHEAD of me in a supermarket checkout line wrote a check for three bananas. I was appalled.

title: Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE TELLS SYNOD VIEW ON VATICAN II
description: Pope John Paul II told the extraordinary Synod of Bishops in its final working session today that Roman Catholicism should welcome and pursue the opening to the modern world ushered in by the Second Vatican Council.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 67 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 67 food establishments cited for having violated the health code.

title: Murder Most Foul
description: William Safire is quite correct in concluding that ''vicious murder'' is a redundancy (''The Self-Clasping Squeeze,'' On Language, Nov. 10).

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: WHATEVER happened to the laptop computer? Two years ago, on my flight to Las Vegas for Comdex, the annual microcomputer trade show, every second or third passenger pulled out a portable, ostensibly to work, but more likely to demonstrate an ability to keep up with the latest fad. Last year, only a couple of these computers could be seen on the fold-down trays. This year, every one of them had been replaced by the more traditional mixed drink or beer.

title: ANOREXIA: IT'S NOT A NEW DISEASE
description: Before the 1970's, most people had never heard of anorexia nervosa. Since then this mysterious and frightening eating disorder, which afflicts primarily teen-age girls and young women who diet to the point of near starvation, has received a great deal of attention, creating the impression that it is a new phenomenon.

title: MUSIC: KELLAWAY, PIANO
description: ROGER KELLAWAY is a pianist who eludes any attempts at categorization. For the past 20 years he has moved readily between jazz, pop and classical music as a pianist, and as composer of such dissimilar works as the closing theme for the television show ''All in the Family,'' a variety of selections for tuba and pieces written for a quartet featuring Edgar Lustgarten, the late classical cellist.

title: New Agenda for the Women's Movement
description: Although Betty Friedan argues that strong forces are at work to strip the material gains now enjoyed by the female labor force, I believe it would be healthier for all to admit the revolution has achieved most of its original economic objectives. Until a new, disenfranchised female majority finds its voice, the first wave of the women's movement must acknowledge it is no longer a vital political force.

title: DAM SALE AND FEAR OF FLOODS
description: In the arcane world of water rights, among the dusty deeds that describe easements, allowable elevations and flowage rights, even a diligent state bureaucracy can lose track. Thus New Hampshire may have given permission for a dam that, some engineers contend, could flood farmlands and wash away the road to a county office complex.

title: HOAGY CARMICHAEL'S COLLECTION
description: The late Hoagy Carmichael, one of America's best known songwriters, also was a first-class coin collector. That fact will be dramatized next month when his fine collection is sold at auction in Los Angeles. Mr. Carmichael's coins figure to bring upwards of a half million dollars according to Mark Goldberg, a vice president of Superior Stamp & Coin Company Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., the company that is staging the auction.

title: Maintaining College Sports
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Singer at the Wheel
description: Christopher Cross, the pop singer, is the latest celebrity to try his hand at auto racing.

title: BLACK THEATER THRIVING IN NEW BRUNSWICK
description: Eight years ago, two Rutgers University classmates took over a former garment factory in the decaying downtown of this city of 40,000. Their plan was to create a professional theater devoted to black drama, the sort of enterprise difficult enough to sustain in a metropolis.

title: Jetliner Engine Fails
description: An Eastern Airlines jetliner bound for Barbados made an emergency landing Friday evening when an engine spouted sparks and smoke shortly after takeoff from Miami International Airport, officials said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S 'POLITICAL BAROMETER'
description: PART OF MY SOUL WENT WITH HIM By Winnie Mandela. Edited by Anne Benjamin. Adapted by Mary Benson. 164 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $5.95. THE name Mandela has been the symbol of the black liberation struggle in South Africa for more than a generation. Nelson Mandela, who is 67 years old and still unbowed after 21 years in prison, became prominent in the 1940's as a young leader of the African National Congress - the oldest black protest organization in South Africa. He spurred the organization to a radical course of mass civil disobedience and later sabotage. In 1958, six years before he was sentenced to life imprisonment, he married Winnie Madikizela, a young social worker who became a leader and symbol of defiance in her own right.

title: USING HEIRLOOM PLANTS TO TASTE HISTORY
description: TO the casual observer, it looks like a large and ambitious country garden. Fall crops of lettuce and cabbage are growing in neatly tended plots and several varieties of winter wheat are just beginning to come up through the earth. Wood stakes are in place for a grape arbor, tiny apple trees flourish under the protection of a wood-slat screen, and a few holly-hocks and bachelor buttons, reminders of the summer, grow in small beds nearby.

title: STUDY TELLS OF ROLE OF CHRONIC JUVENILE CRIMINALS
description: A researcher who tracked the criminal history of every person born in 1958 who lived in Philadelphia from 1968 to 1975 says his study shows the juvenile justice system is too soft on the chronic offender.

title: WAKING UP TO THE GLUT ECONOMY
description: IN London, an eerie silence hangs over the tin trading ring at the Metal Exchange; trading has been halted because there are simply not enough buyers for the vast quantities of tin that producers in faraway Malaysia keep turning out. In America's farm belt, more than a million bushels of this year's record corn crop went directly into storage, piling up on top of last year's surplus. In corporate America, such blue chips as General Motors, Warner-Lambert and Standard Oil of Ohio are reeling from lackluster demand for their products. They have been forced to cut prices, lay off thousands of workers and write off billions of dollars in redundant production capacity.

title: CUTTING CORNERS ON NUCLEAR SAFETY
description: WHEN a nuclear plant costs 10 times more than it was supposed to, or when a reactor is broken down more than it runs, fairness - and several public utility commissions - dictate that the utility's stockholders, not ratepayers, should absorb the extra costs. In fact, 15 states have ''incentive'' rate programs covering about 35 reactors that let the utilities earn more if their nuclear plants operate reliably, and less if they are shut down for refueling and repairs for long periods.

title: N.F.L. Sides Meet For Informal Talks
description: With the expiration of the current collective bargaining agreement more than a year away, negotiators for the National Football League owners and players have begun to meet on an informal basis to exchange ideas and identify issues that will be discussed over the months to come.

title: STATE U. EMPLOYEES ASSAIL STALLED TALKS
description: HUNDREDS of employees from the three State University of New York campuses on Long Island have demonstrated recently to protest their stalled contract negotiations.

title: Gunmen Kill 11 in Pakistan
description: At least 11 people were killed and 10 wounded when gunmen in the Baluchistan region of western Pakistan opened fire on a bus that had ignored their order to stop. The police said today that six people were arrested after the shooting Friday at Dera Murad Jamali, about 250 miles north of Karachi. Bandits in Baluchistan and Sind Provinces frequently attack buses, trucks, cars and trains, but the raids have decreased since the authorities increased security.

title: A RETURN TO THE TRADITIONAL TOYS
description: WHILE the most popular gifts of last Christmas were futuristic electronic items, this year has been marked by a swing back to more traditional toys, such as model trains, dolls and telescopes.

title: Alexis Leads Syracuse to Easy Victory Over Navy
description: Wendell Alexis scored a game-high 23 points tonight to power Syracuse to an 89-67 victory over Navy in the championship of the Carrier Classic Basketball Tournament.

title: CATERPILLAR PLANS TO INCREASE AUTOMATION AND CUT JOBS BY 20 %
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the world's largest maker of earth-moving equipment, will install advanced automated machinery in all its plants and reduce its worldwide work force by about 20 percent in the next five years, company officials said yesterday.

title: Latin Peace Effort Halted, Official Says
description: The Contadora group has suspended negotiations on a peace agreement for Central America for five months at Nicaragua's request, Colombia's Foreign Minister, Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, said today.

title: Ezra Pound at 100
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WITH an avalanche of books to serve as reference, tutor, guru and confidante for both the experienced and the aspiring, this could be the best holiday ever for the writer in all of us.

title: ALL WERE BIG AND SOME WERE BRIGHT
description: IN PERSON: The Great Entertainers. By Martin Gottfried. Illustrated. 264 pp. (Abrams, $49.50.) A few words, by way of preface: if you possess a coffee table, this book has no place on it. Martin Gottfried's ''In Person'' is not a coffeetable book. If you possess a copy of the book and insist upon its having a place - just keep it within reach. It's wonderful. Whatever else he may consider this work to be - he calls it ''an appreciation of the peculiarly American variety turn and of the solo entertainer'' - Mr. Gottfried, a widely published drama critic and author, has written a Celebration.

title: PARISHIONERS SEE AIDS PERIL IN COMMUNION
description: Responding to parishioners' fears about getting AIDS from communion cups, America's Roman Catholic bishops are telling pastors to stick with their regular services but be ready to offer alternatives.

title: PLAYING FIELDS OF IOWA
description: GENTLEMEN ON THE PRAIRIE By Curtis Harnack. Illustrated. 254 pp. Ames: Iowa State University Press. $19.95.

title: THWARTING THEIVES WITH TINY TAGS
description: WHEN a customer tried to walk out of a Pic-A-Flick video store with tapes in his socks, pants and sleeves, proprietor Mary Woods decided to do something about shoplifting. ''Some of the tapes were going out of here wholesale,'' she recalled.

title: HOW A COWARD COMEDY WAS BORN
description: In an introduction to ''Hay Fever'' written in 1934, almost 10 years after the play was first seen in London, Noel Coward noted that ''from the professional standpoint, 'Hay Fever' is far and away one of the most difficult plays to perform that I have ever encountered. To begin with it has no plot at all, and remarkably little action. Its general effectiveness therefore depends upon expert technique from each and every member of the cast.''

title: MANILA OPPOSITION TO MARCOS SPLITS
description: A fragile unity among opposition factions collapsed today minutes before a news conference that had been called to announce a common ticket to oppose President Ferdinand E. Marcos in elections next year.

title: LOVE WITHOUT END: A MAN AND HIS LP's
description: I love records. Long-playing records, that is - those vinyl platters that turn precisely 33Y times a minute, tracked by a diamond needle that translates them into music. I recall the shivering awe I felt as a child, watching my parents' records spin and listening to the magical sounds pour from the speakers.

title: SYNOD BISHOPS GET POPE'S APPROVAL TO ISSUE REPORT
description: Roman Catholic bishops today approved a report on their deliberations at the two-week extraordinary Synod here that calls for specific actions to help remedy problems that have arisen since the Second Vatican Council. Pope John Paul II, breaking with recent practice, agreed to publish the document.

title: PLAYING OUT THE GAME AS DEATH AWAITS
description: PEOPLE you love die. It is not fair, it is not equitable, it certainly is not negotiable. You can't change it, so you have to live with it. Letting go doesn't come naturally. I should know.

title: NEW YORK, WATER UP, PLANS FOR NEXT DROUGHT
description: After months of water restrictions and days of constant monitoring, the bounty of water in New York's reservoir areas since Hurricane Gloria has returned the city's water system to a degree of normalcy.

title: A LAKE WOBEGON CHRISTMAS -- SUCH WERE THE JOYS
description: WHEN I was a boy and lived in Lake Wobegon with my family and my dog Buster, Christmas arrived in our house at the last minute. Other families got their trees up and strung them with lights a week or two early, and night after night I stood barefoot on the cold bedroom floor, looking out the window, studying other people's happiness. Their Christmas was correct, according to Good Housekeeping magazine, Perry Como's Christmas special and a glossy book that Aunt Marie sent us, called ''Christmas Ideals.'' It featured color photographs of tremendously happy people in fabulous homes resplendent with lights and music and love, in greens and reds as deep and shiny as Jell-O desserts. Standing in the dark, admiring the windows along our street, I imagined how happy those families were as they cheerfully completed the many joyful tasks of the season: baking, decorating, wrapping, singing, dancing, being nice to each other, etc. Our home was more like Little Benny's miserable hovel in ''The Christmas Gruel: A True Story of an Orphan in the East London Slums,'' a gift from my mother. The pictures in that book were drawings - Benny begging for pennies, Benny huddled in a heap of rags in the snow, etc. The book was supposed to make me grateful for my blessings, I guess, but to me, it was autobiography.

title: MCFARLANE QUITS, IS REPLACED BY HIS DEPUTY
description: President Reagan lost his national security adviser last week for reasons that apparently had little to do with security or the quality of advice. The adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, resigned after two years in the post and was replaced by his deputy, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter.

title: Knick Shooting Hits the Bottom
description: Just moments after the Knicks had endured a shocking 107-83 trouncing Friday night by the hardly overwhelming Indiana Pacers - a defeat that was arguably one of the most embarrassing in the franchise's history - Coach Hubie Brown stood in a quiet corridor at Market Squate Arena in Indianapolis speaking softly.

title: YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC JEALOUSLY GUARDS ITS GAINS
description: This country, a leader in the group of 77 nations that demands a ''new international economic order'' on behalf of the developing countries, has a north-south problem of its own. The republics of Slovenia and Croatia are the developed north, and people there say they feel that their less developed brothers are milking them.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Goldome in this section on Nov. 10 misstated the savings bank's charter. Goldome switched to a Federal charter from a state charter in October 1983.

title: CONCERT GALA SET
description: THIS town's Unity Concerts will celebrate its 65th birthday Tuesday with a gala concert featuring the Cleveland Orchestra under its music director, Cristoph von Dohnanyi, preconcert cocktail parties in private homes and a post-concert champagne supper at The Class Reunion, a local restaurant.

title: FUTURE BANKER
description: Carol Bellamy, who will roll down her sleeves as City Council President on Dec. 31, announced last week that she would roll them up again on Jan. 1 as a vice president in the tax-exempt securities division of Morgan Stanley & Company Inc., investment bankers.

title: DR. SENCER STEPS DOWN
description: Several members of the Koch Administration have been shown the door in recent weeks, but last week it was the Mayor's turn to regret a departure. Mr. Koch announced that Dr. David J. Sencer, the City Health Commissioner, had resigned to join a Boston consulting firm, where his first assignment would be to develop a five-year plan for improving children's health services in Oman.

title: WNYC SOUNDS FOREIGN NOTE
description: Seeing the world in a grain of sand is one thing, but bringing the world to a television screen on a programming budget of $1.5 million a year may be a heftier challenge. Yet this is one of the principal endeavors of WNYC, the public broadcasting facility owned by New York City, whose limited funds and heady aspirations have led it more and more in a specific direction: to serve as a conduit for programs of a distinctly international flavor that are otherwise unavailable on New York television. WNYC feeds into Channel 3 on both of Manhattan's cable franchises, and is seen on several suburban systems.

title: PLAZA TO PARKING LOT
description: African Art Auction Dec. 9 - African art - carvings jewelry, masks and metal objects -will be auctioned at the Phelps Stokes Fund, 10 East 87th Street, from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. to benefit the African Student Aid Fund. Auction prices will be in the $100-to-$3,000 range, with other items on sale from $25 up. The fund makes low-cost loans to needy African students studying in this country. Refreshments; no admission charge. Evening at the Plaza Dec. 9 - On the bill at the Pyramid Ball at the Plaza: Henny Youngman with his one-liners and Astrud Gilberto, known for ''The Girl from Ipanema,'' with her songs. John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and chief executive officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, will be the host for the evening, a benefit for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International, and William A. Shea, senior partner in the law firm Shea & Gould, will be honored. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M., dinner at 7:30 P.M. and entertainment at 9 P.M. Tickets, $300, from 212-695-5981. Parking Lot Soiree Dec. 10 - If ballrooms are not your cup of tea, here's a change of pace: The cars will be cleared from a parking lot on 21st Street near Fifth Avenue and a heated tent erected so that 500 formally attired guests can dine, listen to Maureen McGovern, Karen Akers and others, and bid on Christmas trees decorated by Elizabeth Taylor, Joan Collins, Andy Warhol and other celebrities. This Night of 100 Trees is the fourth annual benefit for the New York Special Olympics, which has sponsored sports training and competitive events for 30,000 children with disabilities.

title: China and Nicaragua Open Diplomatic Ties
description: China and Nicaragua announced the establishment of diplomatic relations today, with Peking vowing to support Managua's ''just struggle to safeguard national independence.''

title: IN VERMONT-FGROWN TURKEYS, WHITE MEAT, DARK (AND INK)
description: For the turkey farmers of Vermont, it was as if the Grinch had stolen Thanksgiving.

title: Devils Win, 5-1, End Penguin String
description: Greg Adams and Peter McNab scored goals 38 seconds apart in the second period as the New Jersey Devils ended the Pittsburgh Penguins' five-game winning streak tonight with a 5-1 victory.

title: THE LAST DAYS OF THE 90-CENT FARE
description: While the fate of New York City's 90-cent bus and subway fare will not be determined officially until Friday, the handwriting was on the wall last week - and no amount of graffiti could obscure its meaning. Governor Cuomo and state legislative leaders said they did not foresee any action in Albany to save the fare, making it all but certain that, come Jan. 1, a bus or subway ride will cost at least $1.

title: Thousands Attend South Africa Funeral
description: Thousands of mourners attended a funeral for 11 riot victims today and heard the leader of a new black union federation threaten a boycott of rent and tax payments to press the campaign for black rights.

title: Chronicle of an Arctic Canoe Trip
description: WILDERNESS rivers tug at canoeists, and in recent years many have discovered that it is possible, with proper planning, to embrace successfully an adventure that once was an impossible dream.

title: LAURA ABRAMS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Abrams of Waldwick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Jean Abrams to David Mark Emert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Emert of Coral Springs, Fla., and New York.

title: DELAWARE DAY TO BE THE SIT OF BIRD ZONE
description: The Governors of New Jersey and Delaware have signed an agreement to create a migratory-bird protection zone along the Delaware Bay.

title: Hong Kong
description: To the Editor: As a veteran of many shopping expeditions to Hong Kong, I would like to add some important information to the advice given by Marcia Seligson in ''Hong Kong, Made to Order'' (Travel, Oct. 27).

title: FRIENDS, LOVERS, CHILDREN: OF GETTING AND GIVING BOOKS
description: I REACH to send books for Christmas. With odd black marks on white paper, I can send someone I love on an excursion in time and place, deliver immediate enchantment. My husband brought me to England, where the writing really began; then I watched as he read, for the first time, Gabriel Garcia Marquez's ''One Hundred Years of Solitude.'' We walk along Wimpole Street. We look at faces. Is this person from ''The Magus'' or ''The Deptford Trilogy''? We go across Marylebone Road and into Regent's Park.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: NEW JERSEYANS donate more money to charities during the holiday season than at any other time of the year - more than $1 billion, according to some estimates - but all of those who are looking for money are not well intentioned.

title: PARTI QUIEBECOIS LOSES POWER
description: For nine years, the Parti Quebecois kept the rest of Canada on edge by its prickly rule of the largely French-speaking province. Last week, with its goal of independence all but abandoned and its disillusioned followers torn by dissension, the party was turned out by the Quebec electorate, which restored the Liberals to power.

title: ART
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters on Broadway at 155th Street is not the easiest place in town to get to. Moreover, institutional memorial exhibitions are often perfunctory.

title: MELANIE AND DR. LISA R. HIRSCHHORN PLAN THEIR MARRIAGES FOR NEXT YEAR
description: Dr. Lisa Hirschhorn and Bennett B. Goldberg plan to marry in June and her older sister, Melanie Hirschhorn, plans to marry George M. Vetter 3d in September. The future brides are daughters of Dr. Kurt Hirschhorn and Dr. Rochelle Hirschhorn of New York and Wellfleet, Mass., who have announced their engagements.

title: Rendering of town houses near Brown's Hotel, Loch Sheldrake IN THIS TOWN, FEW VIEWS ARE FOREVER
description: NEW YORKERS, who are fairly starved for contact with nature, pay dearly for apartments with a bit of sunshine or views of a park or water. But in their excitement over the scenery, buyers and tenants often do not question whether future development could destroy their light or view. Many times, it does.

title: NETS TOP BLAZERS, 118-106
description: The night was full of personal triumph for Micheal Ray Richardson and full of disappointment for Otis Birdsong. In the aftermath, Richardson talked about surviving the rough stretches of an early season, but Birdsong barely talked.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In some copies of The Guide today, a theater listing gives an outdated opening date for ''Jerry's Girls.'' Performances have been suspended until Dec. 13, and the musical is now scheduled to open in the week of Dec. 15.

title: ALVARADO BOWS OUT
description: Protests by New York City members of the American Federation of Teachers last week blocked the appointment of Anthony J. Alvarado, former Chancellor of the New York City public schools, as special assistant to Albert Shanker, president of both the national union and its New York chapter, the United Federation of Teachers.

title: DOCTORS' OFFICES WIN ARCHITECTURE PRIZE
description: THE design for the interior of a suite of doctors' offices has won the top prize in this year's competition for the Archi Awards of the Long Island chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

title: SPAIN TAKES HARD LOOK AT ITS PLACE IN NATO
description: Campaigns for a scheduled referendum in March on the question of whether Spain should stay in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have gone into full swing.

title: EDBERG TOPS LENDL IN AUSTRALIA UPSET
description: Stefan Edberg, a Swedish teen-ager, scored a stunning 6-7, 7-5, 6-1, 4-6, 9-7 semifinal triumph over top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia in the Australian Open tennis championships today.

title: Ezra Pound at 100
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mosaic of Memories In Strawberry Fields
description: In Strawberry Fields, Mick Davis reached through the crowd at the sidewalk mosaic and tossed a small sprig from his Christmas tree to the tile surface.

title: CHESTER LEE SHAW
description: Chester Lee Shaw, a journalist for five decades who served as editorial director of Newsweek magazine, died Saturday.

title: A SYNOD BALANCE SHEET
description: If there is a single emotion that united all factions today at the close of the extraordinary Synod of Roman Catholic Bishops here, it was one of relief.

title: A Little Incentive
description: A visitor to Los Angeles on Saturday morning rushed from the airport to the nearby campus of Loyola-Marymount for his appointment with the Laker center Kareem Abdul-Jabbar only to find that the gymnasium where the team, which is off to the best start in franchise history with a 17-2 record, was supposed to be holding practice dark, quiet and very empty.

title: WEICKER REITERATES HE IS NOT CANDIDATE IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced yesterday, ''once and for all,'' that he would not be a Republican candidate for Governor of Connecticut next year.

title: Police Seeking 3 Men In Synagogue Beating
description: The police are investigating an attack on a synagogue official who was beaten and burned with a chemical Saturday when he refused turn over its sacred scrolls to three intruders.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football 49ers vs. Los Angeles Rams, at San Francisco. The Rams got off to a 7-0 start, but their streak was snapped by the 49ers in their first meeting of the season, a 28-14 loss.

title: McConnell Takes Pro Squash Final
description: Alicia McConnell of Brooklyn Heights turned back the challenge of Sue Cogswell of England yesterday to take the first Women's United States Pro squash hardball championships at the Uptown Racquet Club in Manhattan. The scores were 15-11, 15-13, 17-18, 15-13.

title: INCO'S HARSH ENVIRONMENT
description: In its heyday three decades ago, Inco Ltd. produced 85 percent of the world's supply of nickel, setting the price almost as a matter of divine right.

title: Topics;   Subsidies, Substitutes On Dasher!
description: The Postal Service has turned to Federal Express for help with the Christmas crunch. Ho, ho, ho, say those irritated by slow delivery.

title: DEBATE ON BANK'S ENTRY INTO INSURANCE RESUMES
description: With both sides confident of victory and the arguing likely to be fierce, bankers and insurance executives will debate once again this week whether state-chartered commercial banks in New York should be permitted to enter the insurance business.

title: Another Actor in Politics
description: Fred Grandy, who won television note as Purser Gopher Smith aboard ''The Love Boat,'' is making his transition from entertainment to politics official. Tomorrow, at two events in Sioux City, Iowa, and one in Des Moines, the 37-year-old actor will announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for the Sixth Congressional District, in Iowa's northwestern quadrant.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Nancy Alloggiamento made president and chief executive and Melvin Fauer, named chairman of Sussman & Sugar, a book-advertising subsidiary of Ogilvy & Mather.

title: India Arrests 11 Protesters
description: The police arrested 11 people in Ahmadabad today and stepped up security in Gujarat state on the eve of a strike against the state's minorities policy, the Press Trust of India reported. The news agency said that those arrested had vowed to continue a campaign against the reservation of jobs and school and college seats for poor classes and castes.

title: Political Malpractice
description: The exploding cost of insuring against medical malpractice hurls doctors into fierce combat with lawyers. Now it also locks New York's Governor Cuomo and Senate Republicans into an acrimonious election-year standoff. The special session of the Legislature tomorrow looks more like an occasion for posturing than substantive work. It is the Governor who needs to move first toward a compromise.

title: Well, They Round Up Pelicans, Don't They?
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics;   For Jesse Jackson, a Campaign to Stay Visible
description: The young man had waited patiently for a chance at the microphone, and now he was trying to ask the Rev. Jesse Jackson a question.

title: COWBOYS ROUTED BY BENGALS, 50-24
description: Three weeks ago, the Dallas Cowboys were buried, 44-0, by the Chicago Bears. They came back and won the next two weeks and brought a 9-4 record here, andwere buried again today by the Bengals.

title: 9 EXILES TO GET HUMAN RIGHTS AWARDS
description: Poets from the Soviet Union, South Africa, Cuba and Chile, painters from Poland and Tibet and cultural advocates from the Philippines and Haiti are to be honored today as human rights exiles who have contributed to the cultural life of New York City.

title: Hutton Denies Schering Story
description: E. F. Hutton & Company yesterday denied that it had used confidential information about the Schering-Plough Corporation for its own purposes.

title: 6 ALIENS FLEE DETENTION CENTER
description: Six inmates escaped and two others were injured and captured yesterday at a Federal immigration center in Lower Manhattan, the police said.

title: DEATH OF EX-JUSTICE STEWART IS LAID TO EFFECTS OF STROKE
description: Former Associate Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court died of complications of a stroke that included pneumonia, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: East German Guard Flees
description: A 23-year-old East German border guard escaped over the heavily protected frontier into the West German state of Bavaria, the police said today. The soldier, in uniform but carrying no weapons, apparently escaped detection by fellow guards on Saturday. A police statement gave no details.

title: FOR STUDENT AND SCHOOL, ADMISSION PROVES A RICH SOURCE OF EVER-MOUNTING ANXIETY
description: Leading a tour of high school students and their parents around Wesleyan College, David Silverberg took a deep breath and began to enumerate his school's charms.

title: PACKERS OUTPLAYED BY DOLPHINS, 34-24
description: Dan Marino passed for 345 yards and five touchdowns, including two in the fourth quarter, as the Miami Dolphins held off a furious second-half rally by Green Bay today and defeated the Packers, 34-24.

title: Austrian First In Cup Slalom
description: Roswitha Steiner of Austria today won the women's Alpine World Cup slalom race and moved into a tie for first place in the standing.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   'Audibility,' New Work By Yoshi Wada
description: In the last 15 years, Yoshi Wada, the Japanese-born sculptor-turned-experimental musician, has evolved a style of meditational trance music played on exotic homemade ''pipe horns,'' similar to Alpine horns but using electrically generated power. More recently, Mr. Wada has begun working with bagpipes and reeds.

title: MARINES RELIVE WITHDRAWAL FROM BATTLE IN NORTH KOREA
description: Former marines who survived the costly withdrawal from the Chosin Reservoir in North Korea held their first national reunion in 35 years last week, to remember lost buddies and meet a new generation of marines.

title: Futures/Options;   Volatile Times In Oil Trading
description: MINISTERS of the OPEC countries met in Geneva over the weekend and decided on a ''new'' strategy that, in effect, permits the cash-strapped producers to carry on with their present practice of selling just about all the crude they can, even if it has to be at cut-rate prices. If anything, the decision adds to the gloom in the oil patch and confirms the deterioration of OPEC's ability to keep prices high.

title: Medicare Reform is Coming
description: On Jan. 1, New York becomes one of the last states to join the prospective payment system based on diagnostic related groups for hospital Medicare reimbursements. Although the system has been in effect elsewhere for several years, most people seem never to have heard of it. Its consequences for health care costs and patient care are still largely unknown. But the payment system and diagnostic groups represent perhaps a revolution in the campaign to reduce costs in all medical programs. It would be a foolish patient who remained ignorant of their provisions.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A dispatch from Rome yesterday about the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops was accompanied by a translation of the Synod's final report.

title: SOUTH ASIA SETS UP A REGIONAL PANEL
description: Leaders of seven South Asian nations, meeting together for the first time, set up a new association today for regional cooperation and pledged not to interfere in each other's internal affairs.

title: Steel Price Rise At Bethlehem
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, said Friday that it plans what amounts to a price increase of $30 a ton for certain structural steel products on Feb. 2.

title: OUTDOORS: BUYING A USEFUL GIFT
description: PURCHASING a gift for a longtime hunter or angler is a risky endeavor, because he usually has more gear and outdoor clothing than he needs, or else has zeroed-in on a specific item which, at the moment, he deems indispensible to his efforts afield.

title: THE DANCE: MARY ANTHONY TROUPE
description: DANCE doesn't seem to take much stock of its wise elders. Among those veterans is Mary Anthony, one of the city's most highly respected modern dance teachers. And a performance by the new Mary Anthony Dance Theater/Phoenix on Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, Claremont Avenue and 120th Street, suggested that Miss Anthony still has much to tell us after 42 years in dance.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline Saturday on an article about Jaguar Cars Inc. misstated the amount the company has been fined for failing to meet federally mandated fuel economy standards. It was $6 million.

title: PARIS BLASTS LAID TO AN INDIVIDUAL
description: Crude incendiary devices are believed to have caused the explosions at two Paris department stores that wounded 39 people, a spokesman for the Interior Ministry said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1985
description: International

title: Watch May Be Counterfeit But the Spirit Is Genuine
description: Suddenly, a sharp ripple zigzagged through the swollen but slow tides of pedestrians on Fifth Avenue.

title: Drama Festival in New Home
description: Leading figures from the worlds of entertainment and politics helped dedicate the Alabama Shakespeare Festival's new home Saturday in a theater that Olivia de Havilland called ''magnificent.''

title: The Urge To Intervene
description: The New Globalism, it could be called. It is the most important conceptual movement in American foreign policy in years. It comes from the source of so much Reagan Administration thinking, the ideological right.

title: SLUMPING BIRDSONG IS SCORELESS AGAIN
description: Players grumble. In professional basketball, it can happen nightly. One player gets too few minutes on the court, another gets none at all. In the lockerroom afterward, they try to mask their frustration. Yet it always shows.

title: Not Monkeying Around
description: Business - of the monkey variety - was prominent on the agenda of Deputy Mayor Alair A. Townsend during her recent visit to China.

title: Rabbi H. N. Brockman Is Wed to Elin Schoen
description: At Congregation Keneseth Israel in Allentown, Pa., yesterday Elin Schoen, a freelance writer and photographer, was married to Rabbi Herbert N. Brockman.

title: GLOBAL FIGHT ON CHILD ABUSE URGED AT PARLEY
description: Representatives at a conference on child abuse and neglect, citing a growing number of reported cases in industrialized countries, have called for a new international effort to fight the practice.

title: ABORTION CLINICS ARE TARGETS AGAIN
description: Violence against abortion clinics, widely thought to have abated this year after the conviction of bombers in the Washington area and in Pensacola, Fla., has intensified recently. And the latest incidents appear to be the first in which the target was human life.

title: Mexico GATT Bid Called Bold Move
description: The decision late last month by Mexico's president to formally seek membership in the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs is one of the boldest economic policy moves in Mexico in several decades, diplomats and private economists say.

title: Atom Plant Shuts Down
description: The Unit 1 nuclear reactor at the Limerick Generating Station shut down automatically today when an apparent electronic malfuction caused the plant to produce more power than planned, a utility spokesman said. No radiation was released, said Ron Harper of the Philadelphia Electric Company. The reactor shut down safely with no problems, and the utility expected to restart the unit Monday, he said.

title: NEW WAVE HASN'T HIT
description: THIS isn't something the New York Islanders are going to like to hear, but they are beginning to resemble an earlier championship team that fell on hard times, the New York Yankees, circa 1965-66.

title: Singapore Stocks Gain
description: The Singapore and Kuala Lumpur stock markets made a partial recovery on Friday, but remained nervous with big investors keeping well clear of the battered trading floors.

title: FRAUD IS TOP ISSUE AS GUYANA VOTES
description: The people of Guyana, who have experienced years of economic hardship and authoritarian rule, will vote for a President Monday, ending a campaign in which the central question has been whether the voting would be rigged.

title: Rohatyn Warns Of Transit Crisis
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority needs increased revenue from taxes and higher fares to avert a crisis that could rival the fiscal troubles that New York City faced in the 1970's, Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of a state commission studying the agency, warned yesterday.

title: U.C.L.A. Reaches Soccer Final
description: U.C.L.A. defeated Evansville, 3-1, today in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament.

title: A Leader's Exhortation To Securities Industry
description: The annual meeting of the Securities Industry Association is an occasion for Wall Street's commanders to enjoy a sunny week in Florida. And since most firms are racking up soaring profits, the gathering last week was a convivial affair. Raymond A. Mason was one of the few industry leaders, though, with some darker preoccupations.

title: U.S. JUDICIAL-SELECTION METHOD COMPARES POORLY WITH CUOMO'S
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SIGHTS, SOUNDS, SCENTS AND SALES OF CHRISTMAS DRAW THRONGS TO CITY
description: Shop windows glittered with chrome, gold and cut glass. Aromas of evergreen and roasted chestnuts filled the air. Bells pealed on corners and in cathedral towers. Great throngs crowded the stores and avenues.

title: MUSIC: BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: THE Boston Symphony Orchestra's Friday-night concert at Avery Fisher Hall, under the direction of Seiji Ozawa, found this celebrated ensemble playing at or near its current best.

title: Arens Returns to Israel After Meetings in U.S.
description: Moshe Arens, Minister Without Portfolio, returned to Jerusalem today from a confidential mission to Washington on behalf of Prime Minister Shimon Peres, the Israeli radio said.

title: Washington Watch;   Selling Off Government Loans
description: The budget-balancing law that Congress and the White House appear likely to settle on this week has already set off a search for ways to ease the pain of the draconian deficit reductions it orders.

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * WNYC radio and TV stations to Doyle Graf Mabley.

title: Other Eras, Other Arms, Other Summits
description: To the Editor:

title: Marceau Collapses on Tour in Russia
description: The French mime Marcel Marceau, who collapsed while on tour in the Soviet Union, underwent intestinal surgery at a Moscow hospital where he was listed in serious condition in an intensive care unit, French and Soviet sources said Saturday.

title: Frates Fight Likely On Kaiser Rejection
description: Joseph C. Frates is a rich Oklahoma investor who in the past has preferred to make money as quietly and as privately as possible. For the time being, those rules have changed.

title: BLAST IN DURBAN WOUNDS 8 PEOPLE
description: A bomb exploded today at a post office in Durban, wounding eight people, three of them children.

title: BENEFIT CONCERT PLANNED AS TRIBUTE TO TURNER
description: Big Joe Turner sang about love and trouble and moving on - the classic subjects of the blues - in a voice as big as his 6 foot 2 inch, 250-pound frame. When he died Nov. 24 at the age of 74, he left an indelible imprint on American music and thousands of dollars in personal debts and hospital bills.

title: STAGE: 'TOULOUSE-LAUTREC'
description: JEFF WANSHEL'S new play, ''Times and Appetites of Toulouse-Lautrec,'' questions if it is possible to dramatize the life of an artist without showing any of his art on stage. The answer is a firm no, unless the playwright is better able than Mr. Wanshel to conjure the spirit of the artist in words and images. The show opened yesterday at the American Place Theater.

title: OPERA: THOMSON'S 'BYRON'
description: VIRGIL THOMSON is widely considered to have composed the two greatest American operas - ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' (1934) and ''The Mother of Us All'' (1947) - although America's major opera houses still haven't heard the news.

title: R.S.V.P.'s Flowing
description: The chairman of the Congressional Arts Caucus gets no extra compensation but is invited to a lot of exclusive exhibition previews and often meets art world celebrities. Presumably that's why candidates for the job are lining up a year early to succeed Representative Thomas J. Downey of New York. He is not eligible to continue as chairman beyond January 1987, and two of his Democratic colleagues, Representatives Ted Weiss of Manhattan and Bob Carr of Michigan, are already out soliciting support for the caucus chairmanship in the next Congress.

title: RAIDERS TOP BRONCOS ON OVERTIME KICK
description: The Los Angeles Raiders moved into strong position today to win the Western Division of the American Conference with their second overtime victory of the season over the Denver Broncos.

title: 'JUNK' BOND RULE DRAWS PICKENS' IRE
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, yesterday sharply attacked the Federal Reserve Board's proposed rule that would restrict the sale of high-yield securities for use in financing hostile takeovers.

title: Susan Elman, Lawyer, Wed to Joseph Ronson
description: Susan Elman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Elman of New York, was married yesterday to Joseph S. Ronson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Ronson of Dumont, N.J. Rabbi A. Stanley Dreyfus performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in New York.

title: Slow Finish
description: That there is no such thing in horse racing as a sure thing is a lesson that many bettors have to learn the hard way. That, as it turns out, is the very way that some people on the other side of the parimutuel windows have been learning the same lesson this year. They are the investors in International Thoroughbred Breeders Inc., which spent $130 million to build one of the nation's most modern and comfortable racing plants: the new Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N.J., just across the Delaware River from Philadelphia.

title: LAST STOP FOR COAST-TO-COAST SLEEPER CAR
description: It was the night sky over Arizona that stayed with Belinda Johnson, broad and clear and filled with stars. Mark Espie remembered the persistence of Texas as his train hurtled onward, but the geography stayed the same. ''Texas takes a long time,'' he said. And both remember a peculiar state of mind, being immersed in the country but removed from its cares in the cocoon of a transcontinental sleeping car.

title: 3 Ghanaians Charged With Arms-Export Plot
description: Federal Customs Service agents today arrested three Ghanaians on charges that they conspired to buy missiles, antiaircraft guns and other weapons for a guerrilla group in their African nation.

title: Pinching Pennies
description: Readers of stock market reporting are all aware that vaporous rumors of malaise in a given industry or company can have major impact on Wall Street. In much the same way, Washington listens closely for tentative evidence of uncertainty in any major sector of the economy.

title: RUMASA'S EX-CHIEF KEEPS SPAIN EDGY
description: Jose Maria Ruiz-Mateos, extradited from West Germany a week ago on charges related to the expropriation of his business empire, has been sitting without bail in a high security prison here.

title: QUALITY AND TRADITION IN HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR MEN
description: Hanukkah began Saturday night, but the Feast of Lights lasts eight days, so there's still time to shop. And Christmas isn't that far away. So give in to giving -you probably have no choice anyway. If you defy commercialism and instant obsolescence by choosing presents with an eye for quality, let the gifts you give to men be as traditional as the season. Seek classics that never go out of style and rarely go out of stock. Here are suggestions that should suit the new mood for old standards.

title: PANEL'S TRAPDOOR: STIFF MINIMUM TAX
description: The tax bill that goes to the House floor this week was originally supposed to be a wholesale cleanup of special tax breaks. Yet, the bill left open plenty of opportunities for individuals and corporations to take advantage of many of the deductions and other preferences that are the heart of tax shelter deals.

title: OPERA: VINEYARD SHOP PRESENTS 'GIANNI DI PARIGI'
description: IN its search for original material, the Vineyard Opera Shop has followed with profit the byways of the Donizetti repertory. Its latest production - which opened Friday night at the Susan Bloch Theater, 307 West 26th Street, and runs through Dec. 22 - is ''Gianni di Parigi.'' By the Vineyard's calculations, it has not been performed since 1846.

title: SCHOOLBOY STAR: FIT TO PLAY, BUT WHERE?
description: THE gym at Far Rockaway High School is one of the oldest in the city. Yellow brick walls stand a few feet from the backlines of the narrow basketball court. A running track, the kind you find at a Y.M.C.A., circles above the court. The scoreboard has so many lights burned out that it is usually impossible to tell what the score is.

title: Advertising;   Magazine to Welcome People to New Homes
description: Beginning next June, families moving into new homes in 25 major markets will receive a handy magazine and guide from a local utility that will inform them about the area and coming events. A quarterly, it will appropriately be named Changing Homes. The people behind it are expecting to distribute 6.2 million copies the first year and add 10 markets the second.

title: Justice Stewart's Legacy
description: It would have been presumptuous or devious in almost any other public official, but Potter Stewart once asked President Nixon not to name him Chief Justice. He later explained that he had promised himself on reaching the Court in 1958 never to lust for higher office.

title: Nuclear Plant Workers Arrested in Drug Case
description: Three security guards at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant and one former guard have been arrested as a result of an 11-month investigation of cocaine sales, the authorities said.

title: STORM KING ART CENTER GIVEN 2 PARCELS OF LAND
description: The Storm King Art Center, one of the world's largest centers for the display of monumental outdoor sculpture, announced yesterday two major gifts of land to its 250-acre property in Mountainville, N.Y., about 65 miles north of Manhattan in the Hudson River Valley.

title: Victim of the Malta Hijacking Moved to Minnesota Hospital
description: Jackie Nink Pflug, a special education teacher who was shot in the head by the hijackers of an Egyptair jetliner last month, was transferred Saturday night to the University of Minnesota Hospitals.

title: DOLE SAYS PLAN ON DEFICIT IS NO PANACEA
description: The latest compromise on a plan to balance the Federal budget by 1991 is not a panacea and could be eventually altered by Congress if flaws develop, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1985
description: International

title: EXPERTS SEE BENEFIT IN CATERPILLAR PLAN
description: Investment analysts today praised the Caterpillar Tractor Company's statement this weekend that it would spend $600 million to install more automation in nine plants over the next four years as part of its efforts to cut costs.

title: NORTHERN CORNER OF MINNESOTA DRIFTS CLOSER TO U.S.   ANGLE INLET, Minn., Dec. 8 (AP) -
description: If not for a map-making error two centuries ago, this 150-square-mile tract of bogs and woods would not be part of the United States.

title: FREE AGENTS' DESTINY UNCLEAR
description: As club officials fought the fog and gathered today for baseball's annual winter meetings, free agents continued to try to work their way through the fog the owners have created in an apparent effort to regain control of player movement.

title: POPE ASKS BISHOPS TO HELP IMPROVE PEOPLE'S LIVES
description: Pope John Paul II, in a mass and homily to mark the close of a two-week extraordinary Synod of Bishops, exhorted the bishops today to promote the church's vision of improved ''human life on earth.''

title: Donna Jakubovitz Marries Donald Spector, Executive
description: The marriage of Donna Jakubovitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Jakubovitz of New York, to Donald Spector, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Spector of Hollis Hills, Queens, took place yesterday at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Israel Miller performed the ceremony assisted by Rabbis Stanley Platek and Abraham Kelman, the bridegroom's uncle.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the tiredest I have ever been in my life.'' - Corazon C. Aquino, after breakup of alliance against President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philipines. [A8:6.]

title: Tin Halt Is Extended
description: The London Metal Exchange on Friday extended its suspension of tin trading until Dec. 16 to give the International Tin Council and its creditors more time to resolve a six-week crisis. Michael Brown, the exchange's chief executive, said the exchange would decide at a meeting on Monday when the tin market should reopen.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 9, 1985: *2*MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Secs IntercoInc Burroughs Corp Tidewater Inc Dayco Corp Tribune Co *2*TUESDAY Cross (AT) & Co Intl Flavors&Fragrnces Esterline Corp Oklahoma Gas and Elec Fleetwood Entpr Premier Industrial Fluor Corp Toro Co Hi-Shear Indus Tri-Continental Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Fairchild Indus Ponderosa Inc General Re Corp Soo Line Corp Harper & Row So New England Tel Heinz (HJ) Co Wolverine Worldwide Nicor Inc Zapata Corp *2*THURSDAY Apache Corp Deere & Co Basix Corp Hallwood Group Inc Big Three Industries Trinity Indus *2*FRIDAY Abbott Laboratories National Fuel Gas Bay Financial Corp Pueblo Intl Inc Holiday Corp United Cable Television Hospital Corp Amer Varian Associates Mony Mtge Investors *2*SATURDAY Helmerich & Payne

title: DAY-CARE WORKER GUILTY OF SEX CRIMES
description: A former worker at a Bronx day-care center was convicted yesterday of 23 counts of rape, sodomy and sexual abuse of children in his care.

title: REALITY GOES OUT OF BOUNDS AS LIFE IN UGANDA UNRAVELS
description: Khaki-clad soldiers carrying AK-47's used to pitch their tents on the fifth green of the golf course here. As one Ugandan said, ''It was difficult to play through.''

title: TO CALIFORNIA: WISH WE WERE THERE
description: To begin with, the avocados are bruised and mushy. For that matter, so are the strawberries. And the supermarkets have a lot of nerve passing off those withered green things as artichokes.

title: PHILADELPHIA FETE FOR OFFICIALS? JUST SHOWING off
description: Inside the Old Original Bookbinder's seafood house Friday night, a trainload of Senators and Representatives, spouses and children up from Washington, lobster bibs in place, were just getting down to business.

title: New Zealand Chooses Discretion in Ship Ban
description: American warships refused entry to New Zealand ports under proposed legislation because they might be carrying nuclear weapons will not be publicly identified, Deputy Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer said today.

title: SOME MARK SEASON BY GIVING TO THE NEEDIEST
description: In place of exchanging gifts, sending greeting cards or buying new Christmas decorations this holiday season, many donors are contributing to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A.M.A. to Debate AIDS Test
description: All couples should be tested for exposure to AIDS virus before being granted marriage licenses, according to a resolution to be considered this week by American Medical Association leaders.

title: G.O.P. LEADER SAYS CUOMO WILL FAIL IN SPECIAL SESSION
description: The leader of the State Senate's Republican majority said this weekend that he expected passage of only one bill out of the six that Governor Cuomo has ordered the Legislature to take up this week in a special session.

title: Acid Spill in Osaka Hospitalizes 80 People
description: More than 80 people were treated at hospitals early today for effects of fumes after 1,820 gallons of dilute hydrochloric acid leaked at a plant in Osaka, a police official said.

title: Head of Argyll Viewed As Successful Strategist
description: James G. Gulliver, chairman of the Argyll Group and the man behind the largest takeover bid in British history, is highly regarded by London financial analysts.

title: SIX RECEIVE KENNEDY CENTER HONORS
description: Well-known figures from the worlds of opera, theater, film, music and dance converged on Washington this weekend for a two-day celebration marking the achievements of six Americans in the performing arts.

title: CENTER-LEFT PARTY LEADS IN GUATEMALA
description: The leader of the center-left Christian Democratic Party, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, took an early lead as vote counting began in Guatemala's presidential race today.

title: LASTING POVERTY FOUND IN CAPITAL
description: Poverty among blacks here has remained stable despite a decade of accelerating economic prosperity in Washington, according to a report released today by a regional research group.

title: Bridge: 'Team Olympiad' Tops List Of Books for Holiday Gifts
description: Those who wish to give their bridge-playing friends a book for Christmas have a wide selection available. The leading choice for serious players is no doubt ''The Seventh World Team Olympiad.'' (189 pages, paperback; $13.95 from the American Contract Bridge League, Box 161192, Memphis, Tenn. 38186.) Other items worth considering include:

title: Toni Glassman Weds Physician
description: Toni Glassman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Glassman of Glen Head, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. James A. Taterka, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Taterka of New York. Rabbi Joan Friedman performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: Advertising;   10 Awards Recognize Creative Use of Media
description: The seventh annual New York Marketing and Media Week, conducted by Marketing and Media Decisions Magazine, came to a close at a luncheon Friday at which the winners of the first Creative Media Awards were honored. The awards for creative media use are the idea of George Mahrlig, media services director of Campbell Soup.

title: Reagan's New Power
description: The forced balanced-budget scheme on which the House and Senate have agreed may well enable President Reagan to complete a task he has already started, the dismantling of New Deal Government. Yet this ill-conceived legislation reflects one false and one dubious assumption - first, that the deficit was caused by overspending; second, that the public demands deficit reduction.

title: The Sour Ploy of the Sugar Lobby
description: Quotas that limit America's sugar imports have had the effect of tripling the price of sugar for consumers. Yet this protectionism is backfiring on domestic growers because the main consumers, commercial buyers, are switching to cheaper corn sweeteners. So the sugar lobby has pressed Congress for even tighter quotas that would further raise supermarket bills and impoverish efficient sugar exporters in Latin America. Only a House-Senate conference committee can stop this madness.

title: HOUSE VOTE HOLDS KEY TO CHANGE
description: After more than a year of writing and rewriting tax legislation, of speechmaking, lobbying and political horse trading in the Treasury Department, the White House and Congress, the question of tax revision will come down to one 15-minute vote in the House of Representatives this week.

title: MAN ON MOVE FINALLY ARRIVES
description: AS part of his public introduction at Notre Dame, the present stop in his career as a coach, Lou Holtz was sure to include his physical and scholarly resume, a list of his most nonflattering characteristics and achievements: 5 feet 10 inches. 152 pounds. Speaks with lisp. Appears afflicted with combination of beriberi and scurvy. Ranked 234 in a high-school class of 278. His self-deprecating list was sure to create chuckles, but it also carried a message.

title: Playoffs Still Puzzle For Many in N.F.L.
description: They are still alive and hoping, which is all the Washington Redskins could have hoped for yesterday afternoon. They could have done the Giants a favor by losing, but the Redskins kept alive their playoff chances by beating the Philadelphia Eagles, 17-12.

title: TRADE GAP WITH JAPAN IS EXPECTED TO GROW
description: Despite a higher-valued yen and new moves by Japan to open its markets, the trade deficit between the United States and Japan is expected by many analysts to continue rising, sharpening frictions between the two countries.

title: 'LOVE IS NEVER SILENT,' ON DEAFNESS IN A FAMILY
