description: WE have come to expect certain values in a ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' production: fine actors, lavish sets with scrupulous attention to detail, and what must be called, until a better phrase comes along, family entertainment. We get all this in ''Love Is Never Silent'' on NBC at 9 P.M. tonight.

title: TREASURY AWAITS DEBT CEILING ACTION
description: Today's regular auction of new Treasury bills due in three and six months was postponed late Friday, because Congress had not yet passed legislation to increase the Federal debt ceiling.

title: DANCE: NEW AND OLD ERDMAN WORKS
description: THE series of retrospective concerts of choreography by Jean Erdman continued with a varied program on Saturday night at Hunter College Playhouse (68th Street and Park Avenue). A dance from 1944 and a dance from last summer proved particularly interesting.

title: Knight Defends N.C.A.A. Action
description: Coach Bob Knight today defended the regulation that forced a one-game suspension of his Indiana basketball team's leading scorer, but he said regard should have been given to Steve Alford's intent in allowing his picture to be used in a sorority calendar.

title: Washington Watch;   1986 Economic Report Preview
description: THE Council of Economic Advisers is well along on its principal year-end chore, writing the annual Economic Report of the President. Its chairman, Beryl W. Sprinkel, lugged first drafts of the report to his vacation home in Punta Gorda, Fla., last week. He had a lot of work. One chapter, on agriculture, ran about 100 pages, or more than twice the length the report can accommodate.

title: Bonner Unable to Book Phone Calls to Sakharov
description: Yelena G. Bonner is growing increasingly concerned about her husband, the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, after trying in vain today to book a telephone call to him, her son said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 'WOMEN IN POLICING' A policeman's lot is not a happy one, as Gilbert and Sullivan wrote in a ditty, and a policewoman's lot was often in years past much harder than that of the male of the species. The story of the women who joined our own police force in the last 90 years is told in an exhibit that has just opened at Police Headquarters, at 1 Police Plaza, just east of the Municipal Building at the east end of Chambers Street.

title: U.S. Judicial-Selection Method Compares Poorly With
description: To the Editor:

title: ICAHN SAID TO WEIGH SHIFT IN BID
description: Carl C. Icahn and his financial advisers made an intense effort over the weekend to put together from $800 million to $1 billion in financing to enable the New York-based investor to buy out the remaining shareholders of Trans World Airlines, according to sources involved in the effort.

title: OPEC PLANS TO END OIL-PRICE DEFENSE TO CAPTURE SALES
description: OPEC oil ministers agreed today on a change in market strategy that could lead to a new oil-price war and bring lower world prices next year.

title: LATIN PEACE MEETINGS SUSPENDED
description: The Contadora group has suspended negotiations on a peace agreement for Central America for five months at Nicaragua's request, Colombia's Foreign Minister says.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Racial Quotas Hurt Blacks and the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: FREE OFFER SETS TRAP;6 BITE BAIT
description: Sheriff Frank Hackett of Kennebec County, Me., figured he had a problem. There were 400 people in the county who had been named in arrest warrants in the last decade for failing to appear in court on charges ranging from drunken driving to rape and robbery. And his county was too big for him to go out looking for them all.

title: Bitter Irony in a Russian Writer's Secret Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: WILANDER UPSET BY EDBERG IN FINAL
description: Stefan Edberg of Sweden captured his first Grand Slam title by defeating his countryman, Mats Wilander, in the men's singles final of the $1.5 million Australian Tennis Open Championships.

title: JETS ROUT BILLS, 27-7
description: All the elements that have elevated the Jets into a division race were back in place today against a perfect foil, the Buffalo Bills.

title: Cambodian Refugees Seem Overlooked
description: For all the talk here about refugees in Afghanistan, Africa and elsewhere, official Washington seems to have a bureaucratic blind spot for the plight of more than 230,000 homeless refugees from Cambodia living in impoverished border refugee camps in Thailand.

title: SWISS FORESTS ARE DEPLATED FURTHER BY PLLUTION
description: A new report by the Swiss national forestry office indicates that damage and disease caused by acid rain and other forms of air pollution are continuing unabated in the country's forests despite antipollution measures.

title: Topics;   Subsidies, Substitutes Out of Bounder
description: President Reagan's Christmas present to his wife is a King Charles spaniel named Rex. Rex is handsome, well-mannered and oblivious to the whirr of the helicopter and the roar of the crowd.

title: Other Eras, Other Arms, Other Summits
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTOR SAYS A PATIENT DIED FROM EXPERIMENTAL CANCER TREATMENT
description: A new experimental cancer treatment that generated widespread publicity and enthusiasm when it was announced last week has killed one of the patients receiving it, the National Cancer Institute's top surgeon said today.

title: Chez Harriman
description: If you have a large gracious home in Georgetown and are seriously concerned about the future of the Democratic Party and its candidates, it's very easy to find yourself in the midst of a heavy social schedule, whether or not the World Bank is in town. Take Pamela C. Harriman, the former New York Governor's wife, who is chairman of Democrats for the 80's, an upscale Washington political action committee.

title: 96 YARDS TO HISTORY
description: WHILE the Jets searched for their longest words to describe the longest touchdown pass play in the franchise's history, Hank Bullough, the Buffalo Bills' coach, turned a cliche into a classic.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arthur Young, the accounting and management consulting firm, appointed Robert Owen national director of industry competence.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 9, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: JAMES O. WATSON
description: Dr. James O. Watson, who helped found Doctors Hospital North and served as president of the American College of Osteopathic Surgery, died at the hospital Saturday, apparently of a heart attack.

title: NEW FORM OF CANCER SEEN IN AFRICAN AIDS PATIENTS
description: A rare cancer, Kaposi's sarcoma, has changed rapidly in Africa and is now playing a disturbing role in the worldwide epidemic of AIDS. The cancer is believed to be striking young Africans at a significantly higher rate than ever before.

title: PUGET SOUND FERRIES FACING BUDGET WOES AND ANGRY RIDERS
description: The Washington State Ferry System, one of the world's most beautiful commuter routes, is facing hard times.

title: 3 DIE
description: Three people were killed when their car was struck by a southbound Amtrak passenger train at a crossing in this northern Dutchess County community this afternoon, the police said.

title: 'LENNON REMEMBERED'
description: FIVE years after John Lennon was murdered, television has taken notice of the Beatles' founder - with last week's ''John and Yoko: A Love Story,'' the weekend's showings of ''Magical Mystery Tour'' and ''Yellow Submarine'' and, last and definitely least, ''John Lennon Remembered'' tonight at 9 on Channel 5.

title: EFFECT OF LIMITING MILITARY BUDGET IS GAUGED
description: Constraints on Pentagon spending for the next five years may reduce the conventional military capabilities of the United States by one quarter to one third, according to a new analysis by Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies.

title: ATTACKS ON 13 JEWISH STORES STILL UNSOLVED IN BROOKLYN
description: The facts of the case are simple: on the night of Friday, Nov. 8, or early the next morning, windows at 13 Jewish-owned stores in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn were smashed. Two weeks later rocks were thrown through the windows of five more Jewish-owned stores in Borough Park and neighboring Flatbush. Nothing was taken from any of the stores. No messages were left.

title: OH COMRADE, CAN I BORROW YOUR RAMBO CASSETTE?
description: The Russian host, a nonconformist writer, flipped on his television, slipped a cassette into the Japanese video player and pressed the play button.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which teams did Roman Gabriel play for in the National Football League and did he ever appear in the Super Bowl with any of them? Does he hold any league records?

title: Zoffany Captures Hollywood Turf
description: Zoffany, dismissed at odds of 21-1, made a late charge at Hollywood Park today to take the $500,000 Hollywood Turf Cup by 2 1/2 lengths from Win, the New York-bred gelding.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FROM THE RUINS OF THE REICH:

title: Washington Watch;   Prospects for World Bank Job
description: Movement toward filling A. W. Clausen's job as president of the World Bank continues at a snail's pace. Mr. Clausen does not depart until June, but people in the international banking community here say Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d needs someone on board to help him develop his new developing-country debt policy.

title: CARROLL'S 'ALICE,' ON CBS
description: APPARENTLY, Lewis Carroll's ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' has to be tackled by adapters simply because, like Mount Everest, it's there. There have been movie versions of the children's classic, ranging from a 1933 Paramount effort to a Disney animation in 1951. For the stage, a traditional approach was taken by Eva Le Gallienne while Andre Gregory directed an avant-garde interpretation. And at least one television version, made in Britain, managed to squeeze Sir John Gielgud into the cast. Not one of these efforts, it should be added, was entirely successful in capturing the special flavor and multileveled experience of the book.

title: FARE WAR CASUALITIES: TRAVEL AGENTS
description: As the air-fare war rages in the skies over the Eastern seaboard, the casualties mount at Estelle Lessack's agency, Travel Trends.

title: Package of Prison Bills Voted By Legislature in Tennessee
description: Spurred by a Federal judge's order barring new admissions to the state prisons, the Tennessee Legislature has approved a package of prison bills that includes earlier paroles and money for more space.

title: ALABAMA IS ORDERED TO DESEGREGATE COLLEGES
description: A Federal district judge has labeled Auburn University the most segregated campus in Alabama and given Gov. George C. Wallace until mid-February to devise a plan to remove remnants of segregation from Alabama universities.

title: F.A.A. Threatens Airport
description: Maintenance funds for San Francisco International Airport may be cut off if local officials do not allow Boeing 707 jetliners to land at the airport, the Federal Aviation Administration says. Engine noise exceeds the allowable decibel level set by the airport commission. The airport's director, Louis Turpen, said Saturday that the airport had recently settled lawsuits brought by residents complaining of noise.

title: SAUDIS REPORT PROGRESS IN EFFORTS TO END 5-YEAR-OLD IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: Saudi Arabia is making progress in its efforts to end the Iraq-Iran war and insure good relations between Teheran and its Arab neighbors, the official Saudi radio said today.

title: Advertising;   Colgate Shuffles Accounts
description: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE, which went from four to three worldwide agencies two years ago, announced on Friday a redistribution of advertising assignments that affects all three agencies.

title: MARCOS FOES TRY TO RESOLVE RIFT BEFORE DEADLINE
description: A tenuous unity among political opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has unexpectedly broken down, and it was unclear today whether the breach could be healed.

title: Peking Calls for Easing Of High-Tech Curbs
description: China said today that it hoped the United States would stop considering it a ''potential adversary'' and further ease restrictions on the transfer of high technology.

title: Market Place;   Chartist Offers Stock Choices
description: IS the party over for the stock market? That is the question many investors are asking when they consider that the Dow Jones industrial average last Thursday touched the 1,500 mark for the first time and then quickly backtracked amid the heaviest trading volume in more than a year.

title: GAF SAID TO BE RAISING FUNDING FOR CARBIDE BID
description: The GAF Corporation has begun an effort to raise large amounts of financing from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment banking firm, according to Wall Street sources who believe that those efforts may indicate that GAF is close to making a bid for at least controlling interest in the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Police Seek Prisoner Who Fled Airplane
description: Police searched from helicopters and with dogs today for a prisoner wearing leg irons and handcuffs who jumped from an airplane moments after it landed here Saturday.

title: RANGERS TOP FLYERS, FINALLY
description: This was a night when the Rangers were expected to cower, when they were supposedly spent from the rigors of the day before. But against all the trends and self-doubt, the Rangers somehow rose up at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: GAS PIPE LEAK AT SITE OF BLAST IN CONNECTICUT
description: Authorities today discovered a leak in a gas pipe leading into a restaurant that was leveled in a fiery explosion Friday, killing a cook, a waitress and four customers.

title: Abraham Adler, 83, Is Dead; Co-Founder of an Art Gallery
description: Abraham M. Adler, co-founder of the Hirschl and Adler art gallery, died of a heart attack Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JEWISH TERRORISTS FREED BY ISRAELI
description: President Chaim Herzog of Israel has commuted the prison sentences of two members of the Jewish terrorist underground who had been convicted of plotting to blow up one of Islam's holiest shrines, Mr. Herzog's office confirmed today.

title: Amy Pasco Is a Bride
description: The wedding of Amy Gale Pasco, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Pasco of West Hartford, Conn., to Dr. Martin Ira Baskin, an internist at the Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn and a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Baskin of Little Neck, Queens, took place yesterday. Rabbi Jody Cohen performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Israel in West Hartford.

title: 200,000 Candles Recalled
description: A gift wholesaler has recalled 200,000 candles and candle holders after learning the products might be a fire hazard.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Robert Battey, Cellist, In New York Debut
description: The cellist Robert Battey, who made his New York debut Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, studied with Janos Starker and Bernard Greenhouse. He is currently a member of the Volker String Quartet, in residence at the University of Missouri in Kansas City.

title: CHRISTMAS AT HOME: THE PERILS
description: ''I'll be home for Christmas,''

title: An Avenue of Lights Continues a Tradition
description: With thousands of tiny lights sparkling like diamonds, a prestigious stretch of Park Avenue was set aglow last night for the holidays.

title: Topics;   Subsidies, Substitutes; Costly Tax Cut
description: Responding to the public outcry over delayed income tax refunds last year, President Reagan agreed to a modest increase in the 1986 budget for more Internal Revenue Service staff. Now, however, he's sending the opposite signal and risking another debacle next April 15.

title: CORRECTION
description: A short news item on an auto race at Daytona Beach, Fla., in SportsMonday Dec. 2 incorrectly stated Al Holbert's accomplishment in winning the race. He tied the season record for Camel GT victories.

title: Advertising;   Hall of Fame Adds 3 Names
description: This year's three additions to the Advertising Hall of Fame of the American Advertising Federation include neither copywriter nor art director. But there are two space peddlers and one agency internationalist.

title: MUSIC: DIXIE CARTER, SINGER
description: FEW cabaret singers have the dramatic mobility of Dixie Carter, the superb singing actress and comedian who began her nightclub career only recently, after making her name as a television actress. The singer, who returned to Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street) for a two-week engagement that will end Saturday, projects the broad emotionality of a soulful clown in performances that combine theatricalized singing with broad physical caricature.

title: Cleveland Mayor Attacks Deficit-Reducing Plan
description: Mayor George V. Voinovich of Cleveland called on Federal leaders today to reduce the national deficit by raising taxes instead of cutting programs.

title: A BANK TELLER'S DIPLOMATIC JOB
description: THEY blow cigar smoke in Eleanora Ribaudo's face, and she turns the other cheek. They accuse her of cheating them, and she wishes them a nice day. But it was too much when her own employer, Citibank, threw a party last month for some of its tellers and hired a comedian who joked about tellers being reluctant to tell strangers what they did for a living. ''I was really shocked,'' Miss Ribaudo said. ''I'm not ashamed to be a teller.''

title: One Man's Long Fight With the Government
description: Raymond H. Swentek's older brother died in 1948 when his Navy bomber crashed into the side of a Canadian mountain. Almost 40 years later, Mr. Swentek is still trying to get the Navy to bring back the remains.

title: West Virginia Telethon Raises Flood Donation
description: Organizers of the West Virginia Flood Relief Telethon said today donations for the victims of last month's floods had neared $1 million.

title: 7-Year Study Is Urged On Women as Priests
description: Priests for Equality, a group of American priests, has called for the Roman Catholic Church in the United States to enter seven years of prayer, reflection and experimentation aimed at determining how women will be ordained.

title: NEW YORK CONSIDERS BUILDING PUBLIC SHOWERS FOR HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city was considering building public showers or bathhouses for the homeless as part of an effort to make shelters for the homeless ''more humane and cost-effective.''

title: Catching Up
description: * The plane crash that killed four members and two coaches of the Iowa State women's cross-country team two weeks ago came 15 years to the month after history's worst air disaster involving a collegiate sports team. A plane carrying the Marshall University football squad crashed on November 14, 1970, and the program has just recently recovered from the tragedy.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 12:11 P.M. today and set at 1:04 A.M. tomorrow.

title: PRESIDENT'S PARTY MAKES A STRONG SHOWING IN GREEK CYPRIOT VOTE
description: President Spyros Kyprianou's party appeared this morning to be winning enough votes in Parliamentary elections to defeat an opposition effort to force his resignation over his handling of negotiations to reunite the island.

title: On Target
description: Tim Foley of Georgia Southern is a place-kicker whose body gives him a certain resemblance to the guy who sits at the end of the bar at Cheers. His head coach, Erk Russell, calls him chubby, and Foley admits that he likes a beer now and then to help him unwind from on-field tension.

title: STATE ROLES GROW IN AID TO BUSINESS
description: In their efforts to provide more jobs, many state and local officials are becoming so deeply involved in business activity that it is difficult to tell where government ends and private business begins.

title: BUDGET PLAN STIRS RATE HOPES
description: Bond market participants hope that the Congressional budget plan announced late Friday will lead to lower interest rates, but many expect that developments in the economy will prevent a quick drop in rates. House and Senate conferees reached an agreement on reducing Federal budget deficits.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN THE MOOD The Forbes Magazine Galleries, which opened last March with spectacularly designed exhibits on the ground floor of 62 Fifth Avenue, near 12th Street, will soon observe their first Christmas. They are a must stop for those in search of something not likely to be seen elsewhere, particularly those with children in tow.

title: LONG PASS PLAY IS KEY JET TACTIC
description: For Joe Namath at the end, it was merely a memory. For Richard Todd it never was a fully realized dream. But for 25-year-old Ken O'Brien and today's Jets, it is a reality: the long pass is back. No one in recent games is throwing it more regularly and with such dramatic results.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Sea Turtles Fly South
description: Four sea turtles that failed to migrate south to Florida have made the journey by airliner, arriving this week in Fort Lauderdale from Atlantic City. Weakened by the cold and undernourished, the turles had washed ashore on Long Island and had been shipped to the Marine Mammal Stranding Center in Brigantine, N.J., for treatment.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $159,300. c-Net loss.

title: MISUNDERSTANDING ON KICKOFF PROVES COSTLY FOR THE BRONCOS
description: A misunderstanding between Coach Dan Reeves of the Broncos and Barney Chavous, the team captain, might have gone a long way in helping the Los Angeles Raiders beat the Broncos in overtime Sunday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Burlington Northern Inc., Seattle, said it had extended its tender offer for Southland Royalty Co. stock through tomorrow. It has bought about 39 million shares, or 91 percent, of Southland at $17 a share.

title: Consumers Power To Take Write-Off
description: The Consumers Power Company said today that it would take a charge of $490 million against fourth-quarter earnings in a partial write-off of its uncompleted Midland nuclear power plant. The company said, however, that it was still looking into ways to complete at least part of the plant, which has cost $4.1 billion so far.

title: SIX ARRESTED ON CHILD PORNOGRAPHY CHARGES
description: Six men, including a teacher at Harvard University and an engineer for a military contractor, were arrested today after they were indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of sexually exploiting children by mailing or receiving child pornography.

title: BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net loss of $1,262,842 for the quarter and year related to the disposal of a drilling rig and certain oil and gas properties. c-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 1-for-5 reverse stock split paid in October.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RANGERS OBTAIN KINGS' MACLELLAN
description: The Rangers made two major trades yesterday that fulfilled one of their biggest needs. In a three-way deal, they acquired the big, high-scoring left wing, Brian MacLellan, from the Los Angeles Kings.

title: South African Asks Asylum
description: A South African who contends he was forced to kill innocent blacks as a draftee in the army under his Government's apartheid policies has asked for political asylum in the United States. ''Even if I were thrown in jail in America, it would be better than staying in South Africa,'' said the South African, Bernard Butler-Smith, 27 years old.

title: CARTWRIGHT'S X-RAYS BRING GOOD NEWS
description: At 10:30 yesterday morning, Bill Cartwright, wearing a jacket over his blue Knick warmup suit, parked his blue Mercedes in a garage opposite 150 East 77th Street. The 7-foot-1-inch center was headed for the offices of 77th Street Radiology to have the broken bone in his left foot X-rayed.

title: GUEST SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bond Prices Advance Sharply
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday as traders and investors began to anticipate that two of the bond markets worst enemies - huge Federal budget deficits and high inflation -are at major turning points and may be less of a threat in the future.

title: Chess: Interpolis International Play Results in a Three-Way Tie
description: The ninth Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, ended in a tie for first place among Tony Miles of Britain, Robert Huebner of West Germany and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland.

title: 4 DEAD IN RAMPAGE IN AN IOWA TOWN
description: A farmer who was apparently distraught over his finances killed the president of his bank today and is believed to have slain a neighbor and his own wife before he killed himself, the authorities said.

title: General Dynamics Elects a Chairman
description: Stanley C. Pace has been in tough spots before. During his 39th combat mission as a B-24 pilot and flight leader in World War II, his plane was shot down and he spent nine months in a German hospital and a prisoner-of-war camp.

title: Searle Will Retain Sweetener Product
description: G. D. Searle & Company, a unit of the Monsanto Company, will retain its low-calorie sweetener Equal and continue marketing it through the Nutrasweet division, the parent company said.

title: FILM: ATTENBOROUGH'S 'CHORUS LINE'
description: EVERYONE was convinced that ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' could never be tamed for the screen, but Mike Nichols turned it into a group triumph for himself, Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton. Though it was generally agreed that ''Hair'' would not work as a film, Milos Forman transformed it into one of the most original pieces of musical cinema of the last 20 years.

title: LORIMAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: POLAND UNDER BLACK LIGHT. By Janusz Anderman. Translated by Nina Taylor and Andrew Short. 131 pages. Readers International. $12.50. ''WHEN did it happen?

title: HEADED DOLLAR SAVINGS BANK
description: Henry G. Waltemade, a real-estate executive and former president of the Dollar Savings Bank of New York, died Sunday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: COLOMBO-TRIAL DEFENSE COMPLAINS ABOUT PRESSURE
description: The defense in the Colombo crime-group racketeering trial accused the Government yesterday of setting up a ''crime supermarket'' during the investigation of the case and pressuring people to use it against their better judgment.

title: Hill Holliday London And Local Shop Merge
description: The London office of Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos of Boston has merged with Aspect Advertising Ltd., an indigenous London shop, to form Aspect Hill Holliday with billings of about $28 million.

title: CUOMO SHIFTS ON TOXIC-SUBSTANCE BILL
description: Governor Cuomo, in an effort to break a deadlock over his agenda for a special legislative session that begins Tuesday, today agreed to a key item that had been sought by Republicans.

title: Dr. Sencer's Contribution
description: Throughout the AIDS crisis New York City has kept its head, often leading the country in resisting panic and devising humane responses to the novel problems of the feared disease. In large measure, that's because of the city's outstanding Health Commissioner, Dr. David Sencer, who is leaving office after four years.

title: Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores said it is considering selling its Holt Renfrew & Company, a chain of 15 high-fashion stores based in Canada, in order to concentrate on its domestic subsidiaries. Carter Hawley, which operates six department store divisions and four specialty retailers, including Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman-Marcus, said it had retained Salomon Brothers to consider any transaction. Holt Renfrew accounted for about 3 percent of Carter Hawley's $3.7 billion in sales in 1984, the spokesman said.

title: Crocker National Officer Takes Posts at Seafirst
description: Richard M. Rosenberg, vice chairman of Crocker National Bank, was named president and chief operating officer of the Seafirst Corporation, a division of the BankAmerica Corporation, effective Jan. 1.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption and an article on Oct. 31 about the collaboration between the singer Al Green and Willie Mitchell, a pop record producer, misidentified an automobile owned by Mr. Mitchell. It was a 1950 Chevrolet.

title: Piedmont-Empire
description: The Transportation Department gave tentative approval to the proposed acquisition by Piedmont Aviation of Empire Airlines, a commuter carrier that primarily serves the New York State area. The department said the purchase of Empire would not harm competition, although Piedmont Airlines and its commuter unit, Henson Aviation, compete with Empire in 12 cities.

title: M.T.A.'S BOARD GETS FISCAL PLAN WITH A $1 FARE
description: The finance committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority sent proposals to the M.T.A. board yesterday that would raise bus and subway fares by 10 cents, tolls on some major bridges and tunnels by 25 cents and commuter railroad fares by 11 percent.

title: State Mortgage Agency In $200 Million Offering
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which finances low-interest home mortgages by selling tax-exempt bonds, is offering $200 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 8 5/8 percent for interest-bearing bonds due in 2011, according to prices announced yesterday by underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: An Age Theme
description: One of Washington's most prestigious old boys' clubs is the United States Association of Former Members of Congress. It has 630 members, including some women, and it has several programs to keep the former Representatives and Senators busy and an annual dinner where current members of Congress join the alumni to eat, drink, sing and tell jokes.

title: More Bullying on Campus
description: Accuracy in Academia, the new organization that will be sending students and other volunteers into classrooms at some 110 American colleges and universities to monitor their teachings for ''liberal bias,'' is an idea whose time should never have come.

title: A CELEBRATION OF ROYAL INDIA'S FASHIONS
description: The women looked elegant, even stately, as they climbed the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night for a gala evening that included a preview of the newest exhibition in the galleries of the Costume Institute. Wisely deciding not to compete with the shimmering metallic and vibrantly colored clothes of the exhibit, called ''Costumes of Royal India,'' the majority of the guests wore black, but not your basic little black dress, to be sure.

title: CARTERS BECOMING CO-AUTHORS
description: Since his defeat by Ronald Reagan in 1980, Jimmy Carter has written one best-selling book about politics and another about the Middle East, while Rosalynn Carter has written a No. 1 best seller tracing their extraordinary journey from Plains, Ga., to the White House. Now the former President and First Lady are pooling their talents on a book for Random House about how to make the most of the second part of one's life.

title: BONN TRADES SPIES IN DEAL WITH EAST
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said today that East and West Germany conducted an exchange of imprisoned agents five days ago.

title: JOHN VASSOS
description: John Vassos, a retired industrial designer, illustrator and artist who designed the exterior of the RCA Corporation's first television set, died Friday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 87 years old.

title: ALCOA SETS WRITE-OFF, SHUTDOWNS
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would take an after-tax charge against earnings of $175 million in the current quarter to permanently shut a fourth of its production capacity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1985
description: International

title: Indians Win Court Battle Over Occupied Land
description: Indians who have occupied Federal land in the Black Hills since 1981 won a court battle today in their effort to set up a permanent religious community.

title: RIVERSIDE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains from the early extinguishment of debt of $1,408,000 for the quarter and $1,453,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $52,000. There were no share earnings for the latest third quarter because net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: NOT A FRIEND OF GENERALS
description: Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, who emerged today as the overwhelming civilian winner of Guatemala's presidential election, carries the hopes of his countrymen as no leader has in more than three decades.

title: National Press Club Honors Flora Lewis, Times Columnist
description: Flora Lewis, foreign affairs columnist of The New York Times, tonight received the National Press Club's 13th annual Fourth Estate Award for ''a lifetime of contributions to American journalism.''

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden. The last time they played was Friday at Indianapolis and the Pacers played like world champions, beating the Knicks, 107-83. Indiana, which had lost 9 of its last 10 going into that game, led by 30 at the half. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; 7:20 P.M.). Nets vs. Sacramento Kings, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Nets ended a seven-game sojourn through the West on Nov. 24 with a 118-103 victory over the Kings in Sacramento as Otis Birdsong scored 21 points. (Television -SportsChannel, 11:45 P.M. tape. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.). Bucks vs. Seattle SuperSonics (Television WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Colleges: Delaware State at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M. Clark at Yale, 7:30 P.M. Connecticut at Fairfield, 7:30 P.M. Iona at Louisville, 7 P.M. (Television, ESPN, 7 P.M.). Coppin State at Brooklyn, 7:30 P.M. Lehman at Hunter, 8 P.M. Auburn at Alabama-Birmingham (Television, ESPN, 9 P.M.) Boxing Prince Mamah Mohammed vs. J. B. Williamson, at Inglewood, Calif., The Forum, for vacant World Boxing Council light-heavyweight championship, 12 rounds. This is for a third of the undisputed title abandoned by Michael Spinks after he beat Larry Holmes for the heavyweight crown. Mohammed, 32-1-2 with 16 knockouts, and Williamson, 21-1 with 8 knockouts, are rated No. 2 and No. 3, respectively, by the W.B.C. Johnny (Bump City) Bumphus vs. Allan Clarke, at Atlantic City, Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, welterweights, 10 rounds.

title: Advertising;   Selling Chanel's New Scent
description: TOMORROW, department stores in 13 major markets with the exclusive right to sell the new Chanel Coco Parfum will begin advertising the product on TV with commercials supplied by Chanel Inc.

title: Pepsico Purchase
description: Pepsico Inc. said it agreed to buy the soft-drink business of MEI Corporation, its third-largest independent bottler, for $590 million. The transaction must still be approved by the companies' boards and MEI shareholders. MEI had 1984 operating income from its beverage business of $79.7 million, on sales of $564 million.

title: UNIFAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TOFU TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 9.

title: METS SEEK TO LIMIT LENGTH OF CONTRACTS
description: The Mets said today that they had notified their players of tighter new policies that would limit contracts to no more than three years and eliminate incentive bonuses for on-the-field performances.

title: GTE Unit Fills New Key Post
description: GTE Government Systems, a subsidiary of the GTE Corporation, announced yesterday that it had established a new Tactical Services Division to produce a military cellular telephone system for the Army, and said that Armen Der Marderosian had been named vice president and general manager of the division.

title: Office Building Backs Eurobonds
description: The Equitable-Lord Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of Lord Securities, is offering about $205.8 million of Eurobonds backed by a midtown Manhattan office building.

title: 'AMERICAN ALMANAC': WAITING GAME AT NBC
description: From the time NBC commissioned a new program called ''American Almanac'' from its news division last February, network executives have tried to leave no doubt that this time, after 13 tries, NBC meant to have a news magazine succeed. Grant Tinker, chairman of NBC, vowed that the network would stand by the program forever.

title: Dr. Z.A. Piotrowski, Rorschach Test
description: Dr. Zygmunt A. Piotrowski, a psychologist and expert on the use of the Rorschach test, died at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia on Nov. 28. He was 81 years old.

title: Stop the Presses
description: The first annual No News Is News Award goes to the Public Affairs Office of the Office of the United States Trade Representative, for a release marked ''Not For Immediate Release,'' announcing the ''first annual U.S.T.R. Press Holiday Party'' on Dec. 17.

title: Stickers Will Alert Firefighters to Children
description: In the suburbs, bright, reflective decals affixed to children's bedroom windows direct firefighters in their rescue efforts.

title: A TINY COLOR PRINTER AT A SURPRISINGLY LOW PRICE
description: THE holiday season is filled with color, so what better choice of gifts for your computer than a color printer?

title: Opportunity Is Knocking for Giants
description: Next Sunday's game in Dallas against the Cowboys may be the most significant for the Giants since two decades ago, when their heroes were named Tittle and Gifford and Huff rather than Simms and Morris and Taylor.

title: Exchange Plan
description: That sports can - and should - be utilized to bring people of differing lands to a closer understanding of each other is an ethos that gets a lot of lip service, but Alberto Juantorena and Fred Newhouse are hoping that their own endeavor won't end there.

title: INNER-CITY FUND HAILS PHILANTHROPIST
description: Decades ago Milton Petrie joined the ranks of America's self-made millionaires. Last night he was honored for the fortunes he has given away.

title: Soskin, Now of JWT, Plans Move to SFN
description: David H. Soskin, who founded David Soskin Associates, a direct marketing agency, which he sold to J. Walter Thompson in 1978, is joining the SFN Companies of Chicago as a senior vice president on Jan. 8.

title: Business and the Law;   Golden Chutes Under Attack
description: AFTER long accepting golden parachutes, state courts are beginning to frown upon them. Thus, when the board of the Beatrice Companies voted last month to award $24 million in golden parachutes to six corporate executives, many shareholders rushed into court to try to shoot those parachutes down. They were encouraged by recent actions in other state courts.

title: TOP JUSTICES TAKE A CASE ON EXECUTION
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states may constitutionally execute prisoners who say they have become insane without giving them a chance to prove it in court.

title: MICHAEL P. MANDARINO
description: Michael P. Mandarino, a former Philadelphia Eagles football player and team physician and one of the first surgeons to use plastics in repairing broken bones, is dead at the age of 64.

title: Investment Counselor Gets Term of 80 Years
description: A former investment counselor convicted of swindling investors out of millions of dollars was sentenced today to 80 years in prison and fined $352,000.

title: JAPANESE PUZZLE: THE VENDING MACHINE MURDERS
description: Haruo Otsu was a typical victim.

title: WESTERN-WORLD TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: New Faces Join Hallowed Group
description: In 1969, the centennial of college football, the list of schools that had won the most games over the years was topped by Yale, Princeton, Harvard and Penn. A decade and a half later, that Ivy League bloc has been pierced by Michigan and Notre Dame, and the ancient leaders that sprang from the sport's cradle are now facing additional threats.

title: 3 Hostages Overpower Captor in Philadelphia
description: A gunman was overpowered today by three teen-agers at a high school where he had taken six people hostage, demanding that President Reagan resign, the police said.

title: FAMILIES IN FLUSHING TRY CABLE - AND IT'S FREE
description: Downstairs at 43-54 149th Street in Flushing, Queens, Patricia A. Favorito and her cousin, Douglas, were engrossed in a videotape of the movie ''Creature.'' A teen-ager was about to be horribly murdered.

title: DECOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $37,000 for the quarter and $270,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Jersey Smoking Law Starts
description: Smoking in grocery stores became illegal in New Jersey today with violators subject to a $25 fine. The law applies to any food store of more than 4,000 square feet, including most of the large chain stores.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Wallich Due to Return
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that it expected Henry C. Wallich, one of its seven board members, to return to work shortly after an absence that began in mid-October. ''Mr. Wallich is ailing,'' a spokesman said.

title: Sudan Officials Expect To See More Ethiopians
description: Sudanese officials expect another 200,000 Ethiopian refugees to flood across the border from Tigre province after another poor harvest there.

title: Angola's Leader Re-elected
description: The ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola today re-elected President Jose Eduardo dos Santos to a second five-year term, the official press agency Angop reported from the Angolan capital of Luanda. Mr. Dos Santos took over as President of Angola after the death of Agostinho Neto in 1979.

title: Rising Cost Estimates On Nine Mile Point 2
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AND THE BIG FOOTBALL WINNER IS...CBS
description: Allegedly, the idea survives in some remote corners of the sporting kingdom that how you play the game is more important than the final score. It is not clear just where such thoughts exist, or who holds them, but one thing is certain -they are not found in the land of television sports.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Free Woman Charged in Spy Case
description: A Federal judge today turned down a third request by Anne Henderson-Pollard to be freed on bond while awaiting trial on charges of obtaining classified documents.

title: 2 Arrested in Robbery Of a Couple in Queens
description: An elderly couple were robbed early yesterday by two or three men who broke into their home in Forest Hills, Queens. Several hours later, two men were arrested at a Marine Midland bank branch in Forest Hills trying to cash a check stolen from the couple.

title: Musician's Home Burns
description: Fire today destroyed the home of Phil Woods, a Grammy Award-winning jazz musician, but he and three other people, alerted by a new smoke detector, escaped, the authorities said. Earlier this year, the Phil Woods Quartet staged two benefit concerts to help the Fire Department raise money.

title: ARREST IN VANDALISM IN BROOKLYN
description: A suspect was arrested yesterday in the smashing of windows last month in Jewish-owned stores in Borough Park and neighboring Flatbush, the police said.

title: Market Place;   OPEC's Impact On Stocks
description: WALL STREET is taking a a positive view of the latest meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Ending three days of talks in Geneva, OPEC ministers vowed yesterday to defend their share of the world oil market.

title: BARBARA WALTERS TALKS WITH THREE PERFORMERS
description: THE guests, so to speak, on tonight's ''Barbara Walters Special'' are three performers in successful network series, or as Miss Walters puts it, three people ''who in spite of having been down have never been out.'' The program can be seen at 10 o'clock on Channel 7.

title: SUNSTAR FOODS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $481,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $461,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,119,000.

title: THE VALIDITY OF STUDENT DRUG TESTING
description: In the last year or two, compulsory testing for drug use has started taking root - and winning judicial acceptance - in some sectors of American business, sport and government.

title: AGENT CRITICIZES SHORT PACTS
description: While teams pursued trades for such players as Jim Rice, Andre Dawson and Britt Burns, a player agent predicted today that clubs that strictly follow the new hard-line policy of offering contracts of no more than three years would fall on hard times.

title: Iron Men
description: A couple of veterans named Dave were on the job yet again over the weekend, extending their respective pro leagues' longest current streaks in consecutive games played. These are the leaders among active players in the National Basketball Association: Dave Corzine, Chicago446 Bill Laimbeer, Detroit422 James Donaldson, Dallas371 Eddie Johnson, Sacramento275 Michael Cooper, L.A. Lakers274 And in the National Football League: Dave Dalby, L.A. Raiders203 Jan Stenerud, Minnesota200 Charlie Joiner, San Diego179 Mark Moseley, Washington161

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
35 Years With the Met
description: All the world was on stage Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: People
description: Ivan Becker and Sheron Davis have been named senior vice presidents at Batten Barton Durstine & Osborn.

title: G.&W. Profits Are Up 23.6%
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 23.6 percent, to $70.7 million, or $1.01 a share, from $57.2 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: COMTREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
On Pearl Harbor
description: There was not much public remembering of Pearl Harbor around the capital on Saturday, the 44th anniversary of Japan's attack on the United States.

title: Bonn to Help Chip Project
description: The West German Government, dropping earlier reservations, today approved a Dutch-German plan to develop a new generation of powerful computer memory chips as part of an aggressive effort to challenge Japanese and American domination of the semiconductor field.

title: Elmira Bears Wickenden, 95; Awarded Presidential Medal
description: Elmira Bears Wickenden, who received the Presidential Medal for Merit for her work in recruiting nurses in World War II, died Nov. 30 at the Mount St. Antonio Gardens retirement community in Pomona, Calif. She was 95 years old and had lived for many years in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: THE RETAIL WAR IN LOS ANGELES: A 4-WAY FIGHT
description: For a modest $170,000, Robinson's offers a specially tailored Christmas gift: a first-class flight to Leningrad and a week's stay while Russian furriers design your own sable fur coat.

title: Half a Fire Test Is Worse Than None
description: The Commerce Department's National Bureau of Standards is widely respected for its materials testing and is now energetically studying structural fires involving toxic smoke. Why then should New York duplicate a fraction of this effort by requiring manufacturers to test the toxicity of materials to be used in the state?

title: MARKET REACTION STRONG AMID DOUBTS ON OPEC
description: The threat by OPEC oil ministers to wage a price war to protect a fixed share of the world market reverberated through the commodity and stock exchanges yesterday.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $16.7 million. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $25 million. Revenues figures include revenue of unconsolidated finance subsidiary of $382.6 million for the latest first quarter and $335.5 million for the year-ago first quarter.

title: AUTO UNION BATTLES UPHILL IN JAPANESE PLANT IN OHIO
description: As hundreds of automobile workers attend to the Honda assembly line here, many of them wear buttons with the emblem of the United Automobile Workers cut in half by a diagonal red slash.

title: BURLEIGH GRIMES, EX-PITCHER AND HALL OF FAME MEMBER
description: Burleigh Grimes, a Hall of Fame pitcher whose career as player, manager and coach spanned six decades, died of cancer in Wisconsin last Friday at the age of 92.

title: JOHN (JAKE) NEVIN
description: John (Jake) Nevin, the head trainer for the Villanova basketball team, died today at his home.

title: COMMUNIST PARTY A LOSER IN CYPRUS
description: As vote-counting continued today in Sunday's Greek Cypriot parliamentary elections, the Communist Party appeared to be the principal loser.

title: KICKING OFF 'A CHORUS LINE'
description: An extraordinary gathering of performers and the powerful made last night's premiere of the film ''A Chorus Line'' at Radio City Music Hall a star-studded, double-barreled charity extravaganza. Thousands filled the Avenue of the Americas, attracted by klieg lights and lines of limousines.

title: PULLMAN-PEABODY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2,774,000 for the quarter and $4,824,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $978,000. d-After a tax credit of $4,880,000. Results for the latest periods do not include the operations of Peabody International Corp., which was merged with the company effective Oct. 25. Results for fiscal 1985 include REDM Industries, acquired Oct. 1, 1984.

title: 8 Israeli Soldiers Die In Fire at Barracks
description: Eight Israeli soldiers died today in a fire of unknown origin that destroyed their barracks on a military base in the occupied West Bank, officials said. Seven men were hospitalized.

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Careers;   New Twist In Video Interviews
description: FOR job seekers and companies hunting employees, video interviewing is growing popular.

title: 14 Pleas of Not Guilty Entered in Belushi Death
description: The woman accused of second-degree murder in the death of the comedian John Belushi after a drug overdose pleaded not guilty today.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including tax credits of $650,000 for the quarter and $1,180,000 for the 9 months, a pretax LIFO inventory credit of $144,000 for the quarter and a pretax LIFO inventory charge of $661,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after pretax LIFO inventory charges of $465,000 for the quarter and $1,550,000 for the 9 months.

title: Marcos Says Gen. Ver May Quit Before Vote
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the armed forces chief, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, may retire before a scheduled Feb. 7 presidential election, a presidential palace press release said.

title: Coach Responds
description: The Texas A&M football coach, Jackie Sherrill, said yesterday that a lengthy story in The Dallas Times Herald that said the school violated National Collegiate Athletic Association regulations contained ''numerous errors,'' then he abruptly canceled a news conference to discuss the matter. Sherrill had announced he would meet with reporters today to respond to The Times Herald's reports that A&M athletes received thousands of dollars in benefits from school coaches and boosters.

title: CEZAR INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to July 31
WAGNER NAMED TO EDUCATION BOARD
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named Robert F. Wagner Jr., his unsuccessful choice for Schools Chancellor three years ago, to serve on the Board of Education.

title: UNION CARBIDE IS TARGET OF TAKEOVER BID BY GAF
description: The troubled Union Carbide Corporation has become the latest target in Wall Street's series of takeover battles.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net income The year-ago figures include profit on the sale of real estate of $367,568.

title: CARBIDE CALLED RISKY TARGET
description: On its face, the Union Carbide Corporation appears to be a poor target for the takeover proposed yesterday by the GAF Corporation and its chairman, Samuel J. Heyman, according to Wall Street analysts.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Cambridge, Mass., on Nov. 5 about confidential C.I.A. financing for Prof. Nadav Safran, director of Harvard's Center for Middle Eastern Studies, incompletely reported remarks by two of his staff members, Barbro Ek and Dennis N. Skiotis. Both said they had known about C.I.A. support for a book Professor Safran was writing, but they also said in interviews that they opposed the financing and left the center before the C.I.A.'s role became public in October.

title: OFFICER SAYS MAN GOETZ SHOT TOLD HIM OF A ROBBERY PLAN
description: A policeman who arrived at the scene moments after Bernhard Goetz shot four young men on a Manhattan subway train last year said last night that one of the men had told him, ''We were going to rob him, but he shot us first.''

title: Hot Spot
description: ''Quite possibly the best retail location in all the world,'' read an advertisement in the Sunday real-estate section.

title: Using Trees to Restore Farm Land
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT PUSHES FOR TAX BILL
description: President Reagan increased the pressure on Republicans in the House of Representatives today to vote for a Democratic tax revision bill this week, and for the first time many legislators said they thought the measure would pass.

title: Boston Drops Plan to Dump Sludge in the Sea Off Jersey
description: Massachusetts and New Jersey legislators today ended their feud over whether Boston should be allowed to dump its sewage sludge off the New Jersey coast.

title: 2 Stocks Are Sharp Gainers
description: Shares of United Energy Resources Inc. and the Midcon Corporation rose sharply on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in what Wall Street analysts termed unusual trading, just days before stockholders vote on a merger proposal involving the two companies.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A Test For Journalism
description: The South African Government sought to justify the orders it issued Nov. 2 to keep reporters and photographers away from scenes of violence with the claim that their presence provoked the violence.

title: Computer Design Risks Are Seen for Engineers
description: THE days when engineers solved design problems at the drafting table with pencil, compass and slide rule are long gone. Today's engineers sit at computer terminals and use special computer programs that allow them to generate in a day designs that used to take months to produce.

title: DOW UP TO RECORD 1,497.02
description: Stock prices pushed ahead again yesterday to record levels as investors cheered the prospects of lower energy costs, hoping they could have a positive effect on the nation's already improving economy. Trading was heavy.

title: CENTRIST WINS BIG IN GUATEMALA VOTE
description: The Christian Democratic leader, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, swept to election today as Guatemala's first civilian President in 15 years.

title: U.N. ADOPTS RESOLUTION ON TERROR
description: The General Assembly unanimously adopted a landmark resolution today that condemns all acts of terrorism as ''criminal.''

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $163,000.

title: THE STAGE: 'BEEN TAKEN' OPENS
description: EACH spring the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual one-act play Marathon demonstrates the vitality of the short theatrical form. Increasingly, if unintentionally, that vitality is demonstrated in the autumn, too -for it's then that past Marathon successes are often remounted in expanded versions that seem inferior to the original one-act works. Neither Shirley Lauro's ''Open Admissions'' nor Shel Silverstein's ''Lady or the Tiger'' gained much more than padding once enlarged for commercial runs. The syndrome continues with Roger Hedden's ''Been Taken,'' a 1984 Marathon standout that the Ensemble Studio itself has now restaged as an inflated full-length attraction.

title: OPERA: ROSSINI'S 'ITALIANA IN ALGERI,' AT THE MET
description: YES, that was Marilyn Horne appearing last night in the title role in ''L'Italiana in Algeri,'' but it took a double-take or two to confirm the fact. The season's first performance of Rossini's comedy found the world's foremost contralto in what must be termed startlingly good form, not only offering her usual quota of prodigious vocalism but looking considerably slimmer than we have ever seen her. From some angles it might have been Elizabeth Taylor in one of her periods of fasting and abstinence.

title: Putting It On Paper: Turning Point
description: PRINTER technology is at a turning point. Dot-matrix and daisywheel printers, which are referred to as impact printers because they make images by physically hammering ink onto the paper, are rapidly approaching their technological limits for speed and print quality. To satisfy their needs for faster and fancier printing, personal computer users are increasingly turning to printing processes that make images on paper without impact, using ink sprays, heat, laser beams and other light sources, magnetic pulses and still more exotic mechanisms.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IN a dimly lighted garage behind the Silvercup Bakery sign in Long Island City, the influential Japanese designer Rei Kawakubo showed her Comme des Garcons collection for spring and summer. The setting in Queens was the ground floor of the International Design Center, New York, and it seemed that all of the city's fashion avant-garde were there. ''You could tell from the 59th Street bridge who was coming,'' said Frances Grill, head of Click Models. ''They were all wearing black.'' Miss Kawakubo's models still wear combat boots, but the once dour designer has changed her stance. Now her wild shapes are mixed with sexy silhouettes, and her mannequins drew wide smiles with women's hats shaped like shrimp toast, dresses in peach and pink and linen men's wear that seemed to be inspired by the zoot suit. Even the weather changed to suit the refreshing mood. As the audience boarded buses for their return to Manhattan, the season's first snowfall sprinkled the dark night white.

title: Twists in New York State's Medicaid Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Triumph By 6-4
description: The rookie defenseman Craig Wolanin scored his first National Hockey League goal to snap a 4-4 tie in the third period, and the Devils went on to a 6-4 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: A SANTA OF SORTS JOINS WHITE HOUSE TOUR
description: Nancy Reagan, with the help of Larry Hagman, better known as J. R. in the television series ''Dallas,'' conducted a tour today of the White House, decorated for the holidays.

title: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago results are pro forma because the company went public in May.

title: SENATORS' 3-MONTH BULK MAILING COSTS DISCLOSED
description: Senators facing re-election campaigns in 1986 were reported today to be among the heaviest users of Government-paid mailings to their constituents.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 17
MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $16.8 million in connection with business realignments. c-Net income.
