description: c-Net income including a gain of $701,700 on the sale of real estate and a tax credit of $140,000.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 10, 1985
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. on Nicaragua.

title: CROWN ROTATIONAL MOLDED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MANVILLE PLAN TO BE QUESTIONED
description: Some representatives of asbestos victims with claims against the Manville Corporation today planned to question the adequacy of a proposal that would allow the company to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings and begin paying billions of dollars in compensation to the victims, lawyers and others involved in the case said yesterday.

title: PROVINCETOWN-BOSTON AIRINE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORPORATE TAX LOBBYING INTENSIFIES
description: The American business community mobilized its forces today for a final lobbying assault on Capitol Hill before this week's House vote on the Ways and Means Comittee's tax-overhaul bill.

title: BOONTON ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $85,236. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in June 1985.

title: Insurance Review Plans To Accept Advertising
description: After 45 years without it, Insurance Review, a monthly of the Insurance Information Institute, has decided to join the crowd and accept advertising.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The right-hander Mark Ross was purchased by the Cardinals from the Astros yesterday in the first deal of baseball's winter meetings. The 28-year-old Ross split the 1985 season between Houston and Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. . . . The Toronto Blue Jays hired two scouts, Gordon Lakey and David Blume, and named Steve Mingori pitching coach at Syracuse of the International League.

title: Top Indonesian Rebels Surrender to Neighbor
description: The top leaders of a separatist movement seeking independence for the Indonesian province of West Irian have surrendered to Papua New Guinea authorities, the Government said today.

title: Heavy Ticket Sales For New Shepard Play
description: Sam Shepard's new drama, ''A Lie of the Mind,'' sold more than $100,000 in tickets in the three-day period after its opening last Thursday. That total is exceptionally large for an Off Broadway show.

title: SKATERS TEST ICE AT A NEW RINK ON THE EAST SIDE
description: One by one, four young girls glided onto the ice, twirling and cutting figure-eights to the sound of classical music, and moments later it was official -the third outdoor skating rink in Manhattan was open.

title: H J HEINZ COMPANY OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October.

title: ARON STEUER, SERVED AS APPELLATE JUSTICE IN NEW YORK COURT
description: Aron Steuer, a former justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, died Saturday at his home in New York City. He was 87 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Advanced Polymer Systems Inc., Redwood City, Calif., has elected Helen C. Leong chairman.

title: Chemical Bank Loses Trusteeship
description: Chemical Bank has been dismissed as trustee for nearly $2.4 billion in pension money it had managed for the New York City Teachers Retirement System, the system said.

title: G.M.A.C. Issue Biggest of Kind
description: Officials at the First Boston Corporation said yesterday that they expected to offer later this week a $524 million issue of bonds for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation backed by automobile loan receivables. The financing exceeds the total amount of all previous bonds backed by automobile and lease receivables and marks the first such financing by an automobile finance company.

title: Japan's Bond Rules Irk U.S.
description: The United States criticized Japan for failing to move quickly enough to ease restrictions on its capital markets as financial talks ended today.

title: Embassy Row;   Canadians Await Pennsylvania Avenue 844.8,0,96.8,4.1 > <
description: When the next President of the United States takes office in January 1989 and travels by motorcade from the Capitol to the White House, Allan Gotlieb expects to have one of Washington's best views of the inaugural parade.

title: November Snow Cover-Mark
description: Snow cover set a record for November in North America, Europe and Asia last month, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced today. Snow covered 6 million square miles of North America, topping the 5.1 million record set in November 1973, the agency said. Satellite photographs showed snow covering 9.2 million square miles of Europe and Asia, breaking the record set of 7.8 million, also set in November 1973.

title: Iran-Iraq Peace Effort Fails
description: Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi Foreign Minister, said today that his Government had failed to persuade Iran to end its five-year-old war against Iraq, the Saudi press agency reported from Riyadh, the Saudi capital. Prince Saud met there for three days with the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati.

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $49,843 for the quarter and $131,630 for the 6 months.

title: PROPOSAL ON FAILED BROKERAGE
description: The Commodity Exchange said yesterday that it would try to end a complicated legal wrangle by agreeing to provide $4.1 million to repay customers of the Volume Investors Corporation, a small brokerage firm whose accounts at the Comex were frozen last March when it went into receivership.

title: G.E.C. Stand On Plessey
description: The General Electric Company said it would pursue its hostile bid for the Plessey Company, offering more than 160 pence a share, or about $:1.18 billion - equal to $1.75 billion - in cash and stock for the rival British communications operation. A statement from G.E.C.'s merchant bankers, S.G. Warburg & Company, said the offer values Plessey at about 14 times its earnings for the year ended Sept. 27, 1985.

title: RECITAL: RUTH GEIGER, PIANO
description: RUTH GEIGER is a solid, serious and technically accomplished pianist; her Saturday night recital at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street) had much to recommend it.

title: MICROSCOPES PEER EVER DEEPER INTO SMALL WORLD
description: SINCE the 17th century, when Anton van Leeuwenhoek's microscope first discovered the teeming world of bacteria, protozoa and other microorganisms, every advance in the ability to see objects on smaller and smaller scales has led to fundamental increases in the understanding of living and physical processes.

title: Superpowers Ignore The Iran-Iraq War
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SUMS UP CASE AGAINST LOUISIANA'S GOVERNOR
description: A Federal prosecutor led the jury through a summary of the evidence against Gov. Edwin W. Edwards today, trying to persuade them that the Government had proved its racketeering case against him and his co-defendants.

title: Soviet Toys of Death
description: A powerful antiwar poster that Americans saw everywhere in 1970 showed bodies heaped in the Vietnamese village of My Lai. The caption was terse, taken from an inquiry into that massacre perpetrated by Americans: ''Q. And babies? A. And babies.''

title: ALTIUS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: No comparable year-ago results are available due to a change in the fiscal year-end.

title: Heinz Net Up 7.5% in Quarter
description: The H.J. Heinz Company said today that its net income was $74.9 million, or 55 cents a share, in the second quarter, up 7.5 percent from $69.7 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Required Reading;   Presidential Speeches
description: Excerpt from remarks by Andor C. Klay upon receiving the Abraham Lincoln Award of the American Hungarian Federation, Nov. 24:

title: JOHNNY CASH SPECIAL
description: IF Sylvester Stallone can pad out ''Rocky IV'' with ''flashback'' clips from his previous ''Rocky'' movies, I suppose Johnny Cash can play the same recycling game in ''The 10th Anniversary Johnny Cash Christmas Special.'' If nothing else, it's cost efficient.

title: DANIEL J. MOONEY
description: Daniel J. Mooney, president of Standard Lubricants Inc., died suddenly Friday at his office in the Bronx.

title: ANOTHER VOLCANO SURVIVOR
description: A 75-year-old woman was rescued in Armero over the weekend after being trapped in her house for 24 days by mud that inundated the town after the eruption of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano, the town's Mayor said today.

title: ESALEN WRESTLES WITH A STAID PRESENT
description: THE hills across the coastal highway from Esalen Institute are bleak now, charred by a forest fire last year, and the winter rains are carving gullies into the bare soil. But the Esalen grounds themselves are as green as ever; at dusk men and women still gather to digest the events of the day while they soak in the candle-lit baths at the hot springs overlooking the Pacific.

title: OPPOSITION LEADER ROUGHED UP AS GUYANA VOTES
description: As this South American nation voted in presidential elections today, the leading opposition figure charged that he and a British journalist had been roughed up at a polling place and forced at gunpoint to drive to a police station.

title: Lendl Suspended
description: The United States Open champion, Ivan Lendl, has been suspended for 42 days for exceeding the allowable amount of fines during one year, the Men's International Professional Tennis Council announced yesterday.

title: Cost-Cutting, Roman Style
description: Cutting corners on government contracts is a practice that may date at least to the first century A.D., according to archeologists who have been studying the ruins of a monumental Roman arch.

title: In Remembrance of Real Money
description: In five Administrations, from Harry S. Truman's to Richard M. Nixon's, William McChesney Martin was probably the most influential economic policymaker in Washington and the embodiment of a now-vanished rectitude in American finance.

title: XEBEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ODD FOSSIL MAY BE A CLUE TO MAMAL EVOLUTION
description: IN a discovery that could change thinking about early mammal evolution, scientists have found the fossil jaw of a platypus-like animal that lived 110 million years ago in Australia. The specimen represents the oldest known mammal of the monotreme subclass and is about 85 million years older than any previous fossil mammals found in Australia.

title: A PIONEER OF FREE SPEECH IS SALUTED
description: Two hundred and fifty years ago, John Peter Zenger, an impoverished publisher of a weekly newspaper in New York, was charged with the crime of criticizing the British colonial governor, and was thrown into jail. The celebrated trial that followed, in which he was exonerated, is universally regarded as a landmark in the history of American free speech.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET TO SHARE INSIGHTS ON COMPUTERS
description: A MEETING of American and Soviet educational computer experts has produced an agreement to exchange specialists involved in the improvement of elementary and secondary education.

title: RAMS TOP 49ERS, GET PLAYOFF SPOT
description: The Los Angeles Rams clinched at least a wild-card berth in the playoffs and came within one victory of clinching their division title by defeating the San Francisco 49ers, 27-20, tonight.

title: WITH FOES OF MARCOS DIVIDED, EX-SENATOR REGISTERS TO RUN
description: Salvador H. Laurel registered today as a candidate for president of the Philippines, rejecting a last-minute offer from Corazon Aquino for a compromise that might have allowed them to run on a joint ticket.

title: FINALCO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kentucky Auto Plant
description: Toyota officials have confirmed that their multimillion-dollar automobile assembly plant will be built in Kentucky, state officials said today.

title: STUDY WARNS U.S. SUFFERS FROM EROSION OF TALENT AT THE TOP
description: The Federal Government is suffering a steady erosion of talent at the top, and the system Presidents use to pick agency officials must be revised to guarantee that the nation has leaders of quality, a study concluded today.

title: After OPEC
description: It's official: Once-mighty OPEC has abandoned its struggle to prop up oil prices. If members expand output as much as oil analysts anticipate, the price of a barrel could soon fall by as much as $10 from the current $28 OPEC benchmark.

title: SCHEIB, EARL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Baldrige Asks Soviet Trade
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said here today that the United States would intensify its promotion of American goods in the Soviet Union to foster increased trade.

title: MILITARY BUDGET STALLS PROPOSAL TO TRIM DEFICIT
description: Top House and Senate negotiators sought today to resolve White House objections that a bill to require a balanced budget would hit the Pentagon too hard.

title: A Weinberger Lament
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger made it clear last month that he felt strongly about not accompanying President Reagan to the Geneva summit meeting.

title: Simone DesMarais-Brewer Weds C. E. Walsh 3d
description: Simone DesMarais-Brewer, the executive director of the North Country Community College Association in Saranac Lake, N.Y., and Charles E. Walsh 3d, a lawyer in Lake Placid, N.Y., were married yesterday at San Francisco City Hall.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ENDS A CASE AGAINST 12
description: Charges of treason against 12 prominent opponents of the South African Government were dropped today by the prosecution. Four others still face charges in the case.

title: IN AFRICA, PROBLEMS CHANGE BUT THE FRUSTRATIONS GO ON
description: IT was 20 years ago and I was an epidemiologist leading an immunization campaign in West Africa. The refrigerators aboard the trucks we drove carrying vaccines to villages at the edge of the Sahara would not work in the 100-degree heat. When an official of the sponsoring Agency for International Development in Washington learned about this, he suggested that we park the trucks in the shade.

title: Berbick's Deadline
description: The Canadian Professional Boxing Federation has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Trevor Berbick to defend his Canadian heavyweight title against No. 1-ranked Ken Lakusta of Edmonton. Berbick's last title defense was in September 1983, when he knocked out Lakusta in the 10th round.

title: REAGAN TO SEEK TALKS ON FREER CANADA TRADE
description: President Reagan is preparing to notify Congress on Tuesday that he wants to begin negotiating a liberalized trade agreement with Canada in the new year, Administration officials said today.

title: BONN AND ITS MANY ENEMIES WITHIN: SPY SCANDALS BARE ITS VULNERABILITY
description: An undulating wall of cement, steel and barbed wire separates West and East Germany, but for Communist spies the frontier is the most penetrable in a divided Europe.

title: A Scientific Leap
description: The job of White House science adviser is expected to be assumed, temporarily, by Erich Bloch, the director of the National Science Foundation. He is to replace George A. Keyworth 2d, who is leaving to start a consulting concern.

title: YALE SAID TO PICK BENNO SCHMIDT AS PRESIDENT
description: Benno C. Schmidt Jr., dean of the Columbia University Law School, is expected to be named today to succeed A. Bartlett Giamatti next year as the president of Yale University, sources close to the search said last night.

title: Philadelphia Bonds Tentatively Priced
description: The $249 million issue of water and sewer revenue bonds of Philadelphia was tentatively priced yesterday by underwriters led by Smith Barney, Yields for interest-bearing bonds ranged from 6 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.50 percent in 1989 and from 8.40 percent in 1996 to 9.10 percent in 2004. Zero coupon bonds, which pay no interest, were offered with yields ranging from 7 3/4 percent for bonds held to maturity in 1990 to 8.60 percent for bonds due in 1995.

title: ROCK: JOHN COUGAR MELLENCAMP
description: JOHN COUGAR MELLENCAMP seemed a little nervous on Sunday at Brendan Byrne Arena in the New Jersey Meadowlands, and no wonder. Two nights earlier, at Madison Square Garden, his sound system malfunctioned partway through the concert; although he finished the show, Mr. Mellencamp offered to give refunds to all ticketholders (through the Garden box office), which could cost him $300,000.

title: RESERVE OIL & MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,793. c-Net income after an extraordinary loss of $59,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $3,105,000 for the year. Year-ago results include operations of two Canadian subsidiaries sold in May and July 1984.

title: ARGENTINE COURT FINDS FIVE GUILTY FOR JUNTA ROLES
description: A civilian court today found five former military leaders guilty of crimes committed during a campaign against leftist guerrillas in the 1970's in which more than 9,000 people disappeared. Four other former military leaders were acquitted.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SETON HALL ROLLS OVER MANHATTAN, 114-61
description: After an embarrassing loss to Columbia last month, Seton Hall supporters, who had spent the summer making optimistic predictions, were beginning to reconsider.

title: Prosecutors' Actions Are Weakening the Public Defender System
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BATTLE, AQUINO FINDS, RECASTS HER AS THE LEADER
description: Though opposition unity collapsed Sunday, and with it her best hope of defeating President Ferdinand E. Marcos in elections expected in February, Corazon C. Aquino says she takes pride in one aspect of the day's events: She became a leader.

title: Beware (a Little) Falling Meteorites
description: A FALLING meteorite may not one of the major hazards of modern life, but a person can be struck by one. Scientists in Canada have even calculated the magnitude of the risk.

title: FARM PANEL VOTES SWEEPING CHANGES FOR SOIL PROGRAM
description: A conference committee working to reconcile the Senate and House versions of the 1985 farm bill today tentatively approved the most sweeping changes in the 50-year history of the nation's soil conservation program.

title: Edison's Own Commodity-Standard Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The trial is an historical event almost without precedent in Latin America and the world.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $575,761 on the sale of property. Results for the latest year have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Concord Natural Gas Corp. in September. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the method of accounting for pooling- of-interests.

title: Walter Payton's 11 Miles
description: In the hours before the Chicago Bears' game in Miami a week ago, Walter Payton was walking through a hotel lobby. As an elevator door suddenly opened and several passengers emerged, a middle-aged businessman stepped away, accidentally bumping into the Bears' running back. ''Excuse me,'' Walter Payton said. Justifying his Sweetness nickname, he smiled and moved on through the lobby. But having recognized the famous football player, the middle-aged businessman seemed honored to have collided, even if ever so gently, with the leading rusher in National Football League history.

title: Case Against Turkey Is Dropped in Accord
description: Five West European countries that accused Turkey in the European Court of Human Rights of torturing political prisoners and other abuses have agreed to drop the case after Turkey promised to speed up its return to democracy, it was announced today.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUDY HAILS EFFECT OF MEXICANS ON CALIFORNIA
description: A new study of the impact of Mexican immigrants on California concludes such immigration ''has probably been an economic asset'' to the state and says no ''immigration crisis'' exists here.

title: JACK H. SKIRBALL
description: Jack H. Skirball, an ordained rabbi who became a motion-picture producer, died Sunday at his home in Century City, Calif. He was 89 years old.

title: Proposal to T.W.A.
description: The directors of Trans World Airlines are weighing a proposal by the investor Carl C. Icahn to offer less cash in his $24-a-share bid to buy out the remaining stockholders, sources close to the financing effort said. Mr. Icahn would offer about $15 a share in cash and the rest in preferred stock, compared with $19.50 in cash offered originally. He made the proposal to the board late Sunday night in an effort to make it easier to get financing of $800 million to $1 billion. A source said the board took no action.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 12:02 P.M. today and set at 12:51 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Dr. Clara Lynch, 103; Led Cancer Research
description: Dr. Clara J. Lynch, a leader in the study of cancer and aging, died Dec. 8 at a nursing home in Arlington, Va. She was 103 years old.

title: PROTEST ON ANTI-SAKHAROV LETTER CLOUDS NOBEL CEREMONY IN OSLO
description: A dispute swirled today on the eve of the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize ceremony over criticism of the personal physician of Soviet leaders for having signed a joint letter in 1973 denouncing Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: CSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $544,000 for the quarter and $3,894,000 for the 9 months and a nonrecurring gain of $4.8 million for the 9 months on the sale of warehouse property and two leaseholds. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $394,000. d-Net loss after a loss of $899,000 from discontinued operations. Results for the latest periods include revenue from Rapidforms Inc., acquired in January 1985.

title: CARE OF ELDERLY CITED IN GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Concern for the growing number of elderly people who are without a home or who are ill and lack the means to care for themselves was expressed by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: SONEX RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is still in the development stage and as a result did not report revenue.

title: A CITY WITH LOTS LOOKS FOR MORE, IN PARTICULAR SLEEP-OVER TOURISTS
description: While its reputation as a good place to live has blossomed, this city has yet to cultivate a strong appeal for out-of-town visitors.

title: Frates Lifts Stake
description: A group led by Oklahoma investor Joseph C. Frates has raised its stake in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, a company it wants to acquire, to 10.48 percent from 9.4 percent, a group spokesman said.

title: CABLE TV COMES TO QUEENS IN A TEST TWO DECADES AFTER MANHATTAN GOT IT
description: After years of delay, and two decades after service began in Manhattan, cable television has arrived in the other boroughs - or at least in about 25 homes in Flushing, Queens.

title: SUGAR PLUM AND FRIENDS
description: THE glitter from the little tree covered his hands with bits of silver, frosted his right cheek and lodged in an eyebrow. Before long, he was rubbing his eye, accidentally ornamenting the lid and lashes. He was so annoyed with the Sugar Plum Fairy he didn't notice.

title: Bridge: Trump Club in Manhattan Has Range of Table Games
description: As one might expect, bridge clubs in general devote themselves to one activity, and other games are normally taboo. One of the rare exceptions is the Trump Club, 227 East 56th Street in Manhattan, which provides chess, Scrabble, backgammon, gin rummy and other indoor games. (For information, call (212) 319-0430.) Duplicate bridge games are scheduled Mondays and Wednesdays at 12:30 P.M. During one of them, the proprietor, Jeff Bayone, noted an imaginative defensive play by Gloria Spitalnik. She held the East cards and opened one club.

title: The Free-Market Blather Behind Takeovers
description: That insightful comedian Henny Youngman once remarked:

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON STATE REGULATION
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a challenge to the powers of a state utility commission to regulate the price of electric power in ways the Federal Government says interfere with its own regulatory regime.

title: COONEY IS ARRESTED IN BAR INCIDENT
description: The heavyweight boxer Gerry Cooney was arrested early this morning on a disorderly conduct charge that grew out of an incident at a hotel bar.

title: Koch Advisers Reject Plan to Show Comet
description: Dimming New York City's lights to make Halley's comet more visible would be ''a waste of time,'' one of Mayor Koch's science advisers said yesterday.

title: CRAFT HOUSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1985
description: Companies

title: Breeders' Cup to Move
description: Directors of the Breeders' Cup voted unanimously today to move the 1987 series of championship races worth $10 million from Churchill Downs in Louisville to California.

title: FOR A CHANGE, COOPERATION RULED THE DAY
description: AN annual conference that brings together educators from public and nonpublic schools in New York City took on new importance last week in light of the increasing strains between the two sectors.

title: SOLIDARITY FAULTS A VISIT BY BRANDT
description: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt, chairman of the West German Social Democratic Party, ended a visit here today amid criticism from the Government's political opponents that he had shunned them while lending his stature and support to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader. Polish officials were reflecting jubilantly on a week of diplomacy that began with General Jaruzelski's meeting with President Francois Mitterrand of France and ended with Mr. Brandt's visit. The two events were being cited by the Polish press as evidence that the West's policy of isolating Poland had collapsed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Friday from Stateline, Nev., about a report on Federal-state relations by the Council of State Governments, misstated one finding. The report said that although Republicans under President Reagan had achieved extraordinary success nationally, they gained no political realignment of the kind that Democrats won under Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOME foods, like watercress, radishes, shrimp and crab, possess dominant flavors.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Annual Caviar War What would Christmas in New York be without the annual Macy's-Zabar's caviar standoff? Murray Klein of Zabar's, the food emporium at 2245 Broadway (80th Street), fired the opening shot last week when he dropped the price of Zabar's prime beluga caviar from $180 a 14-ounce ''pound'' (for unclear reasons, ''pounds'' of caviar always have only 14 ounces) to $175. Steven Fass, director of Macy's Cellar, the food-filled vault below the Herald Square department store, promptly responded by dropping his price on beluga to $168.95.

title: BOSTON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Italian Is in New York, Investigating Papal Plot
description: A Italian judge investigating the purported conspiracy to assassinate Pope John Paul II came to New York yesterday to interrogate a former Italian secret service agent who is in Federal custody here.

title: Governing Party Ahead In Guyana's Elections
description: The Socialist Party, which has governed Guyana for 21 years, took a lead of 6 to 1 tonight in presidential elections in which opposition leaders are charging fraud and interference.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: IT'S A MATTER OF 'PRINCIPLE' FOR COACH FIGHTING OUSTER
description: Although his could be a landmark case, Joseph M. Yukica, the plaintiff, has no particular interest in being a landmark himself. He merely wants to continue coaching football, his vocation of 32 years that Ted Leland, the Dartmouth College athletic director, attempted to terminate the day after Thanksgiving.

title: SHELTER'S CLOSING UPHELD ON APPEAL
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia cleared the way today for the Reagan Administration to close an 800-bed shelter for the homeless in the nation's capital.

title: JUDGE RULES OUT SETTING BAIL FOR SUSPECT IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: A Federal district judge refused to release Ronald William Pelton from jail today, finding that the former employee of the National Security Agency, who faces espionage charges, was likely to flee and was a danger to the community.

title: Former Official Pleads Guilty
description: A former deputy Mayor of the District of Columbia who served as a close adviser to Mayor Marion Barry Jr. pleaded guilty today to charges of defrauding the city of $190,000. The former official, Ivanhoe Donaldson, who ran Mr. Barry's successful 1974 campaign for the City Council and engineered both of Mr. Barry's mayoral campaigns, is scheduled to be sentenced Jan. 27. He faces a possible maximum of 23 years in prison and a $340,000 fine on the charges that he ''systematically stole money'' from a city account used for administering unemployment funds.

title: LANDMARKS PANEL SETS GUIDELINES ON THEATERS
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday sought to resolve nearly four years of dispute by approving guidelines intended to preserve the city's theaters without impeding the staging of shows.

title: GAME ENTRANT SEES A PRIZE IN THE CARDS, BUT SPONSER BALKS
description: A 23-year-old man who says he figured out the pattern of a contest sponsored by the Beatrice Companies contends the corporation owes him $20 million, but Beatrice disputes him and says it has called off the contest.

title: MARCOS PICKS MAVERICK FOR HIS TICKET
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today named a former Foreign Minister and sometime critic, Arturo M. Tolentino, as his vice presidential running mate.

title: London Paper Misses Issue After 20 Balk at Wage Pact
description: The Guardian failed to appear today because about 20 editorial assistants refused a 9 percent increase accepted by the rest of their union, the management said.

title: WALTON SEES HIMSELF IN DITKA
description: Joe Walton talked today about Mike Ditka, and Walton was, in a sense, talking about himself.

title: A FOOD HARVEST FOR THE HUNGARY
description: Second Harvest is making sure that $300 million worth of edible food that might otherwise have been dumped will be distributed to the hungry this year.

title: A NEW MARY TYLER MOORE
description: NOT just a grand old name, Mary - spelled out, that's Mary Tyler Moore - is a national treasure. She has succeeded in the movies (''Ordinary People'') and on stage (''Whose Life Is It Anyway?''), but she has positively triumphed on television. ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' was, and on reruns still is, the kind of situation comedy that critics invariably point to when they pontificate about the medium's potential. A terrific cast, bright scripts, sparkling direction -the series had it all, usurping most of the light-comedy territory that for years had been the province of Broadway.

title: NEW SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1985
description: International Oil prices tumbled in tumultuous trading as traders reacted to the mounting perception that OPEC would fulfill its threat to wage a price war against other petroleum-producing countries to protect a fixed share of the market. The price of crude oil for January delivery fell a remarkable $2.28, to $25.23 a barrel, after dropping $1.23 on Monday. Less than a month ago, by contrast, a comparable contract was trading at about $29. [Page A1, Column 2.] Countries should use all types of aid, including covert assistance, to advance their diplomatic goals, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz. In a major speech in London, Mr. Shultz sought to persuade the Western allies to support the approach being followed by Washington in such countries as Afghanistan, Nicaragua and now Angola. [A1:3.] The Nobel Peace Prize was presented to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, a Boston-based organization headed by two cardiologists, one American and the other Russian. The Oslo ceremony took place amid a controversy over the fact that the Russian, Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, had joined in signing a 1973 letter denouncing Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and dissident. [A10:5-6.] Ferdinand E. Marcos was nominated by acclamation to be his party's Presidential candidate in Philippine elections set for February. President Marcos was expected to name his vice presidential running mate in his acceptance speech today. [A3:4-6.] National A bill to require a balanced budget by 1991 advanced in Congress when House and Senate conferees agreed on a compromise.

title: G.O.P. GOVERNORS LOOK TO POST-REAGAN VICTORIES
description: While the debate in Washington intensified over tax revision and budget deficits, the nation's Republican governors have spent two days here congratulating one another on their policy innovations for dealing with state and local concerns.

title: Museum of Natural History Gets 21,327 Carats . . .
description: The Topaz as Big as a Cantaloupe.

title: The Aquino Case Acquittal Verdict Was a Purely Judicial Act
description: To the Editor:

title: GAF PLANS BIG SELLOFF AT CARBIDE
description: The GAF Corporation told its stockholders yesterday that if it succeeded in taking over the Union Carbide Corporation, it would sell off close to half the company.

title: ON A QUEST FOR ULTIMATE MOLE SAUCE
description: THIS country can be as mysterious as it is enchanting. So in a quest for the ultimate mole (pronounced MOH-leh), the king of sauces in Mexican cooking, it came as no surprise to discover a hall of a thousand mirrors with a secret in every corner. Mole is not the thick, bittersweet, chocolate sauce so familiar to American aficionados of Mexican food. Rather, it is as individual as the uncounted Mexican mothers who for generations have passed their recipes to their children.

title: PROVINCETOWN-BOSTON AIRINE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a provision for losses on the disposition of assets of $2,024,866, a gain from the reversal of pension plan accrual of $563,287 and a gain on the renegotiation of leases of $79,053. c-Net income.

title: G.I.'s Going to War Games
description: Nearly 20,000 G.I.'s and 300,000 tons of equipment will be sent temporarily to Western Europe in January and February in an annual exercise to demonstrate the resolve and ability of the Americans to honor NATO commitments in a crisis, the Defense Department said today. The troops and equipment for the so-called Reforger exercise, for Return of Forces to Germany, will be ferried to Europe on ships and aircraft.

title: How Powerful Is as Powerful Does
description: He does not hold elective office, nor is he a political appointee. And she is not a leading lobbyist, lawyer or leading society figure. But Richard and Gail Berendzen, a couple with no obvious claim to the sort of power that runs this town, have nevertheless become one of the capital's power couples.

title: NOMINEE TELLS OF PLANS FOR LONG-TERM HEALTH CARE
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, President Reagan's nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services, today offered proposals to help finance health care for people with catastrophic illnesses and people who need long-term care.

title: Economic Scene;   Trade Talks: Threats Persist
description: THE Reagan Administration has finally got agreement on the new round of trade talks it has been seeking for the last two years. On Thanksgiving Day, the 90 members of the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs agreed to start formal preparations for opening multilateral trade negotiations next September.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: MBI BUSINESS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
President of Gould Chosen to Be Chief
description: James F. McDonald, president and chief operating officer of Gould Inc., has been named to succeed William T. Ylvisaker as chief executive officer of the diversified electronics company.

title: Treasury Seeks Role As Market Regulator
description: The Treasury Department proposed legislation yesterday that would make it the primary regulator for the market in Government securities.

title: Yankee Publishing Buys Alaska Magazine
description: The Yankee Publishing Company of Dublin, N.H., already the home of six publications, has just reached an agreement to acquire its seventh. And it has taken quite a reach.

title: AN ERROLL GARNER TROVE
description: ERROLL GARNER left behind many hours of unreleased recordings when he died on Jan. 2, 1977. But after nine years, none have been released. All are still stored in vaults, mute and unheard. Even an album called ''Erroll Garner Plays Gershwin and Kern,'' a set of recordings made by the pianist between 1964 and 1968, which has been available in Europe for a decade, was issued in the United States for the first time only a few weeks ago on the Emarcy label.

title: 2-Year Subway Plan Would Delay a Fare Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidential Debates Need an Honest Broker
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS SCORE A SLOPPY VICTORY
description: Dave Wohl was considered an expert on offense, having been tutored in Los Angeles and spending three seasons on the bench of the Lakers, basketball's prototypical running team.

title: MUSIC: AT CARNEGIE HALL, HUNGARIAN SYMPHONY
description: THE Hungarian State Symphony's visit to Carnegie Hall Sunday night was a lovely surprise. So many of the Central European orchestras that pass through town on tour bring only average talents to painfully familiar repertory. This group is a splendid ensemble, and if its program on Sunday was not a totally original one, it did offer a strong and convincing theme - Hungarian music played by Hungarians.

title: DENIED 3D CONSPIRACY TRIAL, MAYOR OF SAN DIEGO RESIGNS
description: After two trials and a conviction on charges that he financed his 1983 campaign illegally, Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego resigned his office today.

title: PUBLISHING: HARD TIMES END FOR EDMUND MORRIS
description: MANY people know that Random House agreed to pay Edmund Morris $3 million for his forthcoming biography of Ronald Reagan, but what is not well known is that Mr. Morris had to scramble for a long time to make a living as a writer.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN the late 19th century almost all the vineyards of France were devastated by the spread of the phylloxera louse. It was 20 years before a solution to the problem was found: the grafting of French vines on American, phylloxera-resistant roots. The new vines grew quickly in France's sunny south and more slowly in the northerly regions of Bordeaux and Burgundy, where the country's greatest wines were made.

title: Classical Station Wins Battle to Stay on the Air
description: A Massachusetts broadcaster who has fought for 11 years to keep his one-man classical radio station on the air won his battle with the F.C.C. today and had his license renewed.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing John Meekins vs. Martin Quiroz, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, at Resorts International Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8:30 P.M. Meekins, from New York, is 9-0 with 8 knockouts.

title: CHEWY COOKIE MARKET FALTERS
description: Stan Livingston of McFarland, Wis., tried those chewy home-style cookies that the likes of Procter & Gamble, Nabisco, Frito-Lay and Keebler have been touting. But Dr. Livingston, a 32-year-old physician and a longtime connoisseur of the homemade chocolate chip cookie, was not impressed.

title: People
description: * David Berger has been promoted to executive vice president of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, Chicago.

title: PARIS FEARS BLASTS MAY DETER TOURIST DOLLARS
description: The French Government and businesses are fretting that the bombings last weekend at two large department stores could depress sales during what officials say could be the most profitable December ever for France.

title: BREAKS UP AN UNAUTHORIZED VIGIL
description: The Soviet Government marked International Human Rights Day today with news conferences, articles and statements hailing Soviet accomplishments and accusing the West of rights violations. An unauthorized attempt by several people to stage a silent vigil in a Moscow square was disrupted by the police.

title: DANCE: JONES AND ZANE AT THE JOYCE
description: BILL T. JONES and Arnie Zane are among the leading younger modern dance choreographers working today in this country. They have persistently mined the vein of postmodernist mixed media dance, particularly in their use of verbal material. They began working together in 1973, and their collaboration has become a fusion of sensibilities as rare as the interest inherent in their partnering of each other in the dances - Mr. Jones being tall, intense, and black; Mr. Zane being short, a little zany and white.

title: British End Participation In Ethiopian Food Airlift
description: Britain's Royal Air Force ended a 13-month emergency food airlift operation in Ethiopia today, saying conditions had improved markedly since the flights began.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
D'Arcy's Budweiser Campaign
description: OUTSIDE the brewery there are few people to whom the new Budweiser advertising means as much as it does to Clayton E. Wilhite and Albert Lerman.

title: David Barnett, 78, Composer, Pianist, Author and Teacher
description: David Barnett, a pianist, composer and member of the music faculty at Wellesley College for 30 years, died Saturday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 78 years old. Mr. Barnett was born in New York, studied at the Juilliard School and made his debut as a pianist at Carnegie Hall in 1928, performing regularly for the next few years in the United States and Europe.

title: Market Place;   Utility Stocks In Year Ahead
description: UTILITY companies and individuals alike have benefited from the Economic Recovery Act of 1981, which granted special tax provisions for dividends reinvested by shareholders. But this tax break is to expire at year-end.

title: JOHN WOODRING: 'STARTING OVER'
description: For 14 weeks, John Woodring was no longer part of the New York Jets, and he had the walking papers to prove it.

title: SHULTZ BACKS AID TO FOES OF SOVIET
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that members of the Atlantic alliance should not shrink from using all kinds of aid, including covert assistance, to advance their diplomatic goals.

title: DANCE: RITHA DEVI FROM INDIA
description: RITHA DEVI offered a selection of pieces with familiar and unusual themes on Saturday night at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street, in a program of dances in the Odissi and Kuchipudi styles. It was in the most dramatic of these pieces that Miss Devi shone brightest.

title: FARM CREDIT LEGISLATION IS APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a plan to assist the financially troubled Farm Credit System, a nationwide farmer-owned lending system that holds a third of the nation's $214 billion of farm debt.

title: Abortion Clinic Is Bombed
description: A bomb exploded in the bathroom of a Manhattan abortion clinic yesterday, starting a small fire but causing no injuries, the police said.

title: Illegal Home Workers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: U.S. Recommends Denial Of Asylum for Syrian
description: The State Department recommended Monday that asylum be denied to a Syrian ship stowaway who jumped handcuffed into the Mississippi River last week, one of his lawyers said.

title: STATER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Results are for 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and 14 weeks and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: U.A.W. Chief Chosen To Run for Re-election
description: The president of the United Automobile Workers, Owen F. Bieber, and most other top officers have been nominated for re-election at the convention next June, the union said today.

title: Gray Hair Syndrome
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: After the Israeli Spy Case
description: The arrest of Jonathan Jay Pollard, an American Government employee charged with selling unauthorized information to Israel, was a sobering and unpleasant event. Israel's American friends are sorry and even angry about what happened. Our support for Israel and its people will not change. Our belief in Israel's essential mission and our pride in its achievements are not diminished, but Israel must not test that support by actions that may harm the United States.

title: PRESERVING OPEN WINE
description: ONE of modern technology's most significant recent contributions to enology has been the wine-preservation machine, which makes it easier for restaurants and bars to serve fine wines by the glass. These machines preserve the wine after the bottle is opened by placing a layer of nitrogen gas over the surface of the liquid. The most common of these devices has up to eight spigots connected to long tubes that are inserted into wine bottles; the bottles, in turn, are sealed in an airtight box. When the spigot is turned on, wine comes out through the tube and nitrogen fills the space left in the bottle. Without oxygen in the bottle, the wine stays fresh for days. This is particularly useful with older red wines that oxidize quickly after they are opened as well as with fragile whites. The commercial wine-preservation machines, which hold up to eight bottles, are too large and expensive for home use.

title: Syrian Prime Minister In Jordan for Meetings
description: Prime Minister Abdel-Raouf al-Kassem of Syria arrived in Jordan today on a three-day visit amid speculation that he is carrying an invitation to King Hussein.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene: the Oak Room of the Algonquin, where Harvey Phillips hears one self-satisfied man at an adjoining table say to another: ''I taped over the 13th and 14th episodes of 'Berlin Alexanderplatz' with Astaire and Rogers in 'The Gay Divorcee,' and you know what? I'm glad!''

title: Bill Wambsganss Dies at 91; Made a Triple Play in Series
description: William Adolph Wambsganss, one of the two remaining members of the 1920 world champion Cleveland Indians, died Sunday in Lakewood Hospital. He was 91 years old.

title: Uniworld Gets Coors Account
description: The Uniworld Group, a black-owned agency that specializes in advertising to minority communities, has landed the Adolph Coors Company account just a week after it won the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln-Mercury division.

title: Chasing a Record
description: Jim Horner, the coach of the undefeated football team at Cherokee High School in Marlton, N.J., raised a few eyebrows when he let it be known that his son, Kyle, would be trying to equal the regional season record of 23 touchdown passes in last Saturday's South Jersey championship game against Pennsauken. Kyle, who was two short of the mark, had suffered a collapsed lung twice within the previous three weeks, the first time spontaneously, in his sleep, and the second when a tube that had been inserted into the lung was removed. He had also been told by a medical specialist that if he played football again, there was a good chance he would die.

title: CONFEREES ADOPT PLAN TO BALANCE U.S. BUDGET BY '91
description: House and Senate conferees tonight approved a bill designed to shrink the Federal budget year by year and lead to a balanced budget by 1991.

title: A Demolition Derby
description: Just like any other consumer, the Department of Transportation went from one automobile dealer to another, trying to get the best price for a specific model and bargaining when necessary. Now that the department has bought 8 cars and is nearing deals on 16 more, it can gear up for the next move: destroying them.

title: Another Record for Dow: 1,499.20
description: An exciting session on Wall Street yesterday failed to reach a dramatic conclusion. Despite late gains that for a time propelled the Dow Jones industrial average over the 1,500 level, prices finished only slightly higher than they began.

title: Cowboys Aren't Giants' Favorite Team
description: The Giants don't hate the Dallas Cowboys. At the same time, they are not likely to share an evening at Carnegie Hall or exchange Christmas cards.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Saturday about high rent's effect on the arts misidentified the school at which Suzanne Farrell and Patricia McBride trained. It was the School of American Ballet.

title: Convictions Overturned In Georgia Killing of 6
description: Saying that even ''an obviously guilty defendant'' has the right to a fair trial, a Federal appeals court has thrown out the convictions of three men in the murders of six members of a family.

description: Companies

title: CONSTITUTIONAL SCHOLAR

Schmidt Jr. But yesterday, a day Mr. Schmidt described as ''emotionally wrenching,'' there were at least two such occasions.

title: Bruce Slovin Married To Francesca Cernia
description: Francesca Cernia and Bruce Slovin were married yesterday by Acting Justice Harold Tompkins of the State Supreme Court at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Atlas.

title: ISLANDERS RALLY PAST PENGUINS
description: The Islanders, playing host to Pittsburgh for the first time this season, used tonight's 7-4 victory to bolster team confidence and save face in the division standings. The Islanders entered tonight's game clinging to fourth place in the Patrick Division, one point ahead of Pittsburgh and the Devils. Knowing they could fall into last place if their four-game nonwinning streak continued through this home-and-home series with Pittsburgh, the Islanders won their first game since Nov. 29 in Winnipeg with a three-goal rally in the third period.

title: FILM: 'KIM PHUC' AND 'SANCTUARY' IN DOUBLE BILL
description: MANY a movie maker with a message has succumbed to the notion that a virtuous cause can pardon esthetic sins. Two variations on this agitprop fallacy open today as a double bill at Film Forum.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $867,624 for the latest quarter and $768,278 for the year-ago quarter.

title: Mileage Muddle
description: Players of the Phoenix Suns have refused to sign autographs on promotional items for the National Basketball Association because the club would not allow them to claim mileage under airline promotion programs. Rick Robey, the Sun's representative to the National Basketball Players Association, said that the action was taken ''on the advice of the head of our union.''

title: Shearson Handles World Bank Issues
description: The World Bank yesterday announced a $200 million Euromarket offering of 15-year notes and a worldwide offering of zero coupon bonds maturing in 2000 through 2016 with a face amount of $500 million.

title: HOUSE PASSES $10 BILLION MEASURE TO BOLSTER TOXIC WASTER PROGRAM
description: The House of Representatives today easily passed a bill to expand the toxic waste cleanup program to $10 billion over the next five years and to put more teeth into the law. The vote was 391 to 33.

title: TEXACO MUST PAY $11 BILLION AWARD, TEXAS COURT RULES
description: A Texas state judge today upheld a jury verdict requiring Texaco Inc. to pay $10.53 billion in damages, plus interest, to the Pennzoil Company for interfering with Pennzoil's agreement to acquire the Getty Oil Company in 1984.

title: Monsanto Retirements
description: The Monsanto Company said today that early retirement had been accepted by 2,340 salaried employees, which is about 60 percent of the workers who were offered special incentives to retire early by the St. Louis-based chemical company.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 11:54 A.M. today and set at 12:38 A.M. tomorrow.

title: 7 ROBBERS INVADE ERASMUS CLASS
description: Seven teen-agers took over a social studies classroom at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn yesterday morning and robbed a teacher's assistant and three students of $65 and some jewelry, the police said.

title: South Africa Debt Freeze
description: The South African Government said today that it had extended until March 31 its freeze on repaying loans to Western banks.

title: MacLellan Is Impressive
description: With the arrival of Brian MacLellan this morning at their practice headquarters, the Rangers suddenly viewed themselves with greater self-esteem.

description: ''In the 1980's and beyond, most likely we will never see a world in a total state of peace - or a state of total war.

title: Ratio for Chips Rose in Month
description: In the second indication in a month that the semiconductor industry may be rebounding, the Semiconductor Industry Association said yesterday that the book-to-bill ratio rose in November to 0.90, the highest level since September 1984.

title: Plessey Rejects Offer by G.E.C.
description: The Plessey Company, a telecommunications concern, today rejected a $1.74 billion takeover bid by the General Electric Company of Britain as unwelcome and inadequate. G.E.C., which is Britain's biggest electronics company and is not related to the American company of the same name, announced its formal bid late Monday after first disclosing its interest in Plessey a week ago.

title: Call That a Miracle?
description: I recently bought a VCR so I could go to my Thursday night bowling club again.

description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it would repurchase a 13.6-million-share block of its stock for $596 million, or about $43.75 a share.

description: Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the machine tool and robot manufacturer, said yesterday that Clifford R. Meyer, its president and chief operating officer, will retire at the end of the year due to illness.

description: Republicans who control the State Senate tonight turned down five of the six programs that Governor Cuomo had summoned legislators to vote on in a special session that began this morning.

The locals marvel at the winery built from a converted barn that includes a two-story apartment where, they jest, Mr. Wiemer sits on high contemplating the gleaming steel tanks below that hoard his highly regarded wines.

title: Nudist's Conviction Upheld
description: A state appeals court yesterday upheld the conviction of a 38-year-old computer analyst from New Rochelle, N.Y., for sunbathing nude in Jacob A. Riis Park in Queens in the summer of 1984. The panel of four judges in the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court rejected the argument of the defendant, Robert Hollman, that his arrest denied him his First Amendment right to freedom of expression. He was convicted by Judge Daniel W. Joy in Queens Civil Court and fined $140.

title: 'MR. PREVIN COMES TO TOWN'
description: ON Channel 13 tonight at 10 o'clock, Andre Previn makes a circuitous return to his childhood home in ''Mr. Previn Comes to Town'' - and to his new job there as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

description: They tried to shoot and they missed. They tried to run and they turned the ball over. So it went last night at Madison Square Garden as the Knicks and the Indiana Pacers seemed to be trying hard to get down to each others' levels.

title: Comings and Goings

A former Indiana University basketball star, Landon Turner, partly paralyzed from a 1981 automobile accident, signed an out-of-court settlement, details of which were not disclosed. . . . Jane Blalock, who rebounded from back problems to finish seventh on the Ladies Professional Golf Association money list this year with $192,426, accepted Golf Digest's award as the female comeback player of the year. . . . The former Pittsburgh football coach, Foge Fazio, has talked with Lou Holtz about joining the new Notre Dame coach's staff, according to The South Bend Tribune. Meanwhile, Notre Dame's former coach, Gerry Faust, was interviewed for the vacant coaching job at Marshall University in West Virginia.

title: Guilty Plea in Jet-Parts Case
description: A former Navy employee pleaded guilty to charges that he stole and smuggled parts for fighter aircraft to Iran, the United States Attorney's Office announced today. The prosecutors also said the defendant, Daniel Gerard Wheeler of Leominster, Mass., agreed to testify against seven codefendants. Mr. Wheeler could get a sentence of up to 17 years in prison and a $600,000 fine.

title: DENG ANSWERS STUDENTS WITH A RALLY OF HIS OWN
description: The Communist Party had marshaled 4,000 shivering high school students into Tiananmen Square for a ceremony designed to shore up support for the Government's ''open door'' economic policies.
