title: STAGE: 'BLOOD KNOT,' WITH FUGARD AND MOKAE
description: THE most persistent sound in Athol Fugard's ''Blood Knot'' is the harsh ringing of a windup alarm clock, blaring insistently into the tranquillity of a tin-roofed hovel. The clock is the means by which the shack's occupants, two mixed-race brothers in South Africa, mark the passing of their dreary, unvaried days. But the ring also has a piercing urgency, as if it were sounding an alarm far beyond the walls of the shabby setting. One might say - even if the playwright never explicitly does - that it is history's alarm, warning of a time bomb soon to go off. Such is the sad saga of South Africa that Mr. Fugard's warning is perhaps even more pressing now than it was when the playwright first unveiled ''Blood Knot'' in 1961.

title: Real Estate;   Catering To Small Offices
description: IN a city of skyscrapers, where talk of putting up the world's tallest building is taken seriously, almost no one pays attention to small buildings and the tenants who occupy them.

title: NOBEL PRIZE GIVEN TO GROUP OF DOCTORS DESPITE PROTESTS
description: The 1985 Nobel Peace Prize was presented today to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, a Boston-based organization headed by two cardiologists, one American, the other Russian.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF WARNS ARABS OF DANGER
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that Arab-Americans had entered a ''zone of danger'' and were targets of violence by a group seeking to harm ''enemies of Israel.''

title: FILM: 'JEWEL OF THE NILE'
description: THERE'S nothing in ''The Jewel of the Nile'' that wasn't funnier or more fanciful in ''Romancing the Stone,'' although that earlier film was by no means any landmark in the annals of armchair adventure. Derivative as it was, ''Romancing the Stone'' did have a certain spunk, thanks to its contrast between the workaday life of Joan Wilder, romance novelist (played so gamely by Kathleen Turner), and the far-flung adventures into which the screenplay propelled her.

title: BAYLOR DEAL REPORTED NEARER
description: One of the most prolonged trade discussions in recent years could finally be reaching fruition. But even if the Yankees and the Chicago White Sox conclude the deal, Don Baylor might not approve it.

title: FORMER NEW YORKERS AND VISITORS TO CITY GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Former New Yorkers and people who have visited the city are remembering the city's homeless, hungry and ill this holiday season by sending contributions from across the country to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON MAJOR WORK IN WELFARE HOTEL
description: Facing heavy penalties, the owners and operators of the Holland Hotel, a welfare hotel near Times Square, have agreed to renovate the building completely over the next six months.

title: Houston Controversy
description: The dismissal of Hugh Campbell as coach of the Oilers hasn't quite cleared the air in Houston. The team's general manager, Ladd Herzeg, said yesterday that hiring Campbell as head coach was the worst mistake of his professional career, but Joe Faragalli, the offensive coordinator, said Herzeg disposed of the wrong man when he dismissed Campbell Monday for what he labeled the team's ''erratic offensive scheme.''

title: Evicted Tenant Is Charged
description: A woman who had been evicted from an apartment building has been arrested for investigation of murder in a fire that killed four tenants, the police said today. The woman, 26-year-old Brenda Denise Cooper, was arrested Friday in Long Beach. The fire left more than 50 residents of the 16-unit building homeless.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $371,000. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,453,000 on the disposal of certain operating units. d-Including a gain from discontinued operations of $453,000.

title: STOCKINGS AND THEIR STUFFERS
OPEC'S THREAT SENDS OIL PRICES DOWN SHARPLY
description: Oil prices collapsed yesterday in tumultuous trading.

title: ARGENTINES VARY IN THEIR REACTION
description: Argentines reacted in sharply different ways today to a court decision on Monday that found five former members of military juntas guilty and acquitted four other former officers of responsibility for the disappearance of thousands of people during a campaign in the 1970's against leftist guerrillas.

title: Albany's Burning, Albany's Burning
description: Special sessions of the New York State Legislature are usually for emergencies. Not the one starting today. Only one of the six items that Governor Cuomo now demands action on requires urgent attention - the need to forestall further increases in medical malpractice insurance premiums. But more important than whether the Governor has presented true emergencies is whether the merits of the other bills justify decisions now. One does, and the Governor is right to press it. The others are a different story.

title: HOWARD J. DIRKES Sr.
description: Howard J. Dirkes Sr., retired president of the Long Island Savings Bank of Syosset, L.I., died Monday at New York Hospital.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3,464,000 from the resolution of litigation.

title: Chicago's Lions Thrown for Loss
description: Chicago fans have come to expect almost anything when Bears and Lions get together, but few were prepared for what a handful of Scrooges wrought during the recent weekend.

title: PBS Plans Commercials On Network Programs
description: Public television is preparing to promote its ''TV Worth Watching'' slogan in commercials aired on such programs as ''Dynasty,'' ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''Miami Vice.'' The ads, which will be tested on WXXI in Rochester and WGTE in Toledo, Ohio, beginning next month, will discuss the value of such programs as ''Masterpiece Theater'' and ''Great Performances.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch from Oslo yesterday about controversy over the Nobel Peace Prize misstated the date on which the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia published a 1973 letter denouncing Andrei D. Sakharov. The correct date was Sept. 2.

title: DEATHS ON THE IOWA PRAIRIE: 4 NEW VICTIMS OF ECONOMY
description: When the radio news flashed across the snow-covered prairies Monday for the noon meal, it carried a bulletin that John Hughes, president of the Hills Bank and Trust Company, had been shot and killed. One farmer just outside this town of 550 people turned to his wife and said, ''I wonder if it was Dale Burr.'' It was. Mr. Burr, a 63-year-old farmer whose financial troubles were about to claim his land, his machinery, his stored grains and his beloved quarterhorses, went on a killing rampage, shooting three people to death before committing suicide on a lonely road near his home.

title: Suit by Motorola
description: The Motorola Corporation has filed a $30 million Federal lawsuit charging patent infringement by the Mostek Corporation and asking that the United Technologies Corporation's sale of Mostek to a French company be annulled. The suit contends that Mostek and United used Motorola's 68000 microchip technology without paying fees and then Mostek was sold to Thomson-CSF of France to prevent Motorola from recovering damages.

title: MALLE'S 'GOD'S COUNTYRY' IN MINNESOTA
description: WHAT lurks in Glencoe, Minn.? Who lives there?

title: BOSTON DOCTOR 'UPSET' OVER SAKHAROV LETTER
description: A member of International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, which received the Nobel Peace Prize this year, said today that he was ''upset'' about the revelation that the group's Soviet co-founder had signed a letter in 1973 denouncing Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: Chester Weidenburner Dies; Ex-Judge and U.S. Attorney
description: Chester Weidenburner, a former New Jersey Superior Court judge and United States Attorney, died Sunday at the Elizabeth (N.J.) General Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Linden, N.J.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHEN it comes to drinking socially, for many people the problem is not cutting out alcohol but cutting down. Though not uncontrollable alcohol addicts, these individuals often find themselves drinking more than is desirable with regard to their health, weight, driving ability and occupational and social prowess. Rather than swear off alcohol entirely, they choose a more moderate course of drinking less and enjoying it more.

title: KEY GAMBINO TRIAL WITNESS ADMITS LYING TO JURY
description: The key prosecution witness against Paul Castellano, the reputed leader of the Gambino crime ''family,'' admitted yesterday that he first gave prosecutors details linking the defendant to a car-theft ring and two murders only a week before his trial began.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Traded Steve Bedrosian, pitcher, and Milt Thompson, minor-league outfielder, to Philadelphia for Ozzie Virgil, catcher, and Pete Smith, minor-league pitcher.

title: Head of Nuclear Panel Plans to Retire in June
description: Nunzio J. Palladino, chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, announced today that he had asked President Reagan not to reappoint him when his term expires June 30.

title: MICHEL SEES TAX BILL PASSING
description: The House Republican leader conceded today that the tax revision bill backed by most Democrats would pass this week despite strong opposition from Republicans.

title: Looking for Work?
description: Do you agree with the proposition that ''in today's complex and pluralistic society, absolute truths and values are no longer valid''? How about this one: ''The United States and the Soviet Union possess nuclear weapons for essentially the same purpose: the preservation of world peace and stability.'' If you were applying for a staff position in the House of Representatives through the Republican Study Committee Job Bank, your chances of being hired could hang on whether you answered yes or no to these and 39 other statements.

title: Drastic Device
description: After Tim Kempton played his best game of the young basketball season in Notre Dame's victory over Oregon, Coach Digger Phelps said: ''Coming out for the second half, he tripped over a cheerleader and got really mad. If that's what it takes, I may have one of my assistants sucker-punch him.''

title: Frigitronics Offer
description: Charles C. Johnston, a Massachusetts investor who holds 9.8 percent of Frigitronics Inc., proposed today to acquire the remaining shares for $24 a share in cash and $10.50 in debt securities.

title: Wide Impact Seen on Texaco
description: A judge's decision yesterday to uphold the full $11.1 billion judgment against Texaco Inc. was greeted with shock by analysts, who said the ruling would have a dramatic impact on the future of the nation's third-largest oil company.

title: DRUG TESTS BY JERSEY SCHOOL ARE RULED UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: A school board's policy requiring all students at a Bergen County high school to be tested for drugs was ruled unconstitutional today.

title: 8TH GRADER HELD AFTER CUSTODIAN IS SHOT TO DEATH
description: A 13-year-old student armed with a semiautomatic rifle shot and killed a custodian today at Portland Junior High School and injured the principal and a secretary, the state police said.

title: Why No Belts on School Buses?
description: Seat belts have been standard equipment in automobiles for so long that most children can't remember when cars came without them. Not so with school buses, in which many children spend more travel time than in the family car. The inconsistency demands correction.

title: NEW CHARGES ARE BROUGHT IN NAVY SPY CASE
description: A Federal grand jury today returned a new indictment against Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy chief petty officer who is charged with espionage.

title: DELACORTE, 92, AND WIFE MUGGED IN THEIR BELOVED CENTRAL PARK
description: George T. Delacorte, the 92-year-old philanthropist who has expressed his lifelong love for New York City with such gifts as the Delacorte Theater and the bronze Alice in Wonderland statue in Central Park, was robbed in the park yesterday.

title: . . . and Bestows Clothes Upon Koch
description: Meanwhile, two less valuable objects from the museum were finding their way to City Hall.

title: Jewelry Is Missing at Carlyle
description: Jewelry valued at $40,000 was reported missing yesterday from the room at the Carlyle Hotel of Joseph Verner Reed, the United States representative to the United Nations Economic and Social Council. The police said Mr. Reed, a former United States Ambassador to Morocco, reported the loss after discovering it Monday at 7:30 P.M. at the hotel, at 35 East 76th Street.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Tip's Tune
description: When the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., retires from Congress a year from now, with him will pass a ritual that Senator Bob Dole, for one, says he will not miss. Hailing his old friend on his 73d birthday on Monday, Senator Dole, a Kansas Republican, said in a floor speech:

title: CARDINALS TRADE ANDUJAR TO A'S
description: Joaquin Andujar, the tempestuous pitcher who won 41 games in the last two years for the St. Louis Cardinals, was traded to the Oakland A's tonight in a blockbuster deal that shattered the calm of baseball's winter meetings.

title: Presidential Debates Need an Honest Broker
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribune Company In 2 Big Asset Sales
description: In two divestitures that will raise $413.5 million, the Tribune Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell The Los Angeles Daily News and nine of the company's 15 cable television systems. The proceeds will be used to reduce debt, some of which was incurred in the recent $510 million purchase of KTLA-TV, an independent television station in Los Angeles.

title: Presidential Debates Need an Honest Broker
description: To the Editor:

title: Post-Summitry: Extend Testing Moratorium
description: To the Editor:

title: Son of Andropov Replaced in Athens Post
description: Igor Y. Andropov, son of the late Soviet leader Yuri V. Andropov, will not return to his post as Ambassador to Greece, the Greek Foreign Ministry said today.

title: BREWING COMES BACK TO THE WEST SIDE
description: IT has been a long, occasionally frustrating journey for the polished copper brew pots of the Stuttgarter Hofbrau from West Germany to their new home on the West Side of New York. But just after Christmas, New Amsterdam Amber Beer will begin bubbling in those kettles and the city will again have a major brewery in an area in which its beer industry once flourished.

title: U.S. ELECTS SWISS TO HEAD REFUGEE AGENCY
description: The General Assembly today unanimously elected a 47-year-old Swiss national, Jean-Pierre Hocke, to the post of United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: Racz Gets Account
description: Racz & Dessimoz Associates of New York has been named to handle the account of Teledyne Acoustic Research of Canton, Mass. The job had been split between Mullen Advertising of Beverley Farms, Mass., and Schmalen & Berger & Company of Boston. Billings are estimated at $1 million.

title: McEnroe to Marry
description: John McEnroe, whose relationahip with the actress Tatum O'Neal has been the focus of attention and speculation in recent weeks, said that Miss O'Neal is pregnant and that they plan to be married.

title: Sweet Nothings
description: The crowd of reporters and lobbyists was so large one day last week that it overflowed the hearing room where the Senate Agriculture Committee was preparing the final draft of the farm bill. So an audio report of committee deliberations was piped into an empty room two floors below in the Russell Senate Office Building.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $639,000 for the latest first quarter and $200,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: ENTREPRENEURS: THE NEW HEROES
description: DURING the 1960's, names like the Chicago Seven, Che Guevara and Angela Davis fired the imaginations of a generation of college students. But now, a growing number of undergraduates draw inspiration from John D. Rockefeller, Andrew Carnegie and Steven P. Jobs.

title: Contractor Says Crew Avoided Gas Pipelines
description: The construction workers digging at the site of an explosion that killed six people Friday stayed at least five feet from natural-gas pipes, according to the contractor supervising the job.

title: Bridge: A Generation Gap Emerges In Simple vs. Complex Bids
description: In bridge, as sometimes in life, the old tend to favor simplicity, while the young seem to favor complexity. In bidding styles, for example, the younger experts embrace sophisticated bidding methods, while their elders persevere with the simple styles of yesteryear.

title: Buyback Rumors Lift RCA Stock
description: The RCA Corporation's stock rose sharply yesterday in extremely heavy trading on rumors that the company would soon announce a major financial restructuring.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Celotex Corp., Tampa, Fla., a building materials subsidiary of the Jim Walter Corp., has named William G. Lees president of the Celotex Building Products division and Gilberto Aleman president of the Celotex Roofing Products division.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ REMARKS ON AID TO REBELS
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's speech today to the Pilgrims Society here:

title: WNYC to Inaugurate New Studios Today
description: Public radio station WNYC will begin broadcasting today from its new $3.3 million studios in the Municipal Building.

title: DEFENSE RESTS AT TRIAL IN SEATTLE OF 10 LINKED TO NEO-NAZI GROUP
description: The defense rested today in the three-month racketeering trial of 10 members of a white supremacist group, the Order, and prosecutors began presenting rebuttal witnesses against the only defendant who testified on his own behalf.

title: William Gomberg, 74; Professor at Wharton
description: William Gomberg, emeritus professor of management at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School and an expert in labor-management relations, died of cancer Sunday. He was 74 years old.

title: MILITARY SALES TO MANILA SCRUTINIZED
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating whether high-ranking Philippine officials may have received payments in connection with more than $100 million in military contracts financed by the Pentagon, according to businessmen and Reagan Administration officials.

title: CONSUMER DEBT RISES
description: Americans took on $6.63 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in October, down sharply from the record debt growth of September, the Government reported today.

title: Justice Reborn in Argentina
description: Formal justice played little role in Jorge Videla's dictatorship in Argentina. Those who offended his regime were abducted, tortured or murdered. In the new Argentina of President Raul Alfonsin, justice is back. After a fair trial, Mr. Videla, along with Adm. Emilio Massera, was sentenced to spend the rest of his life in prison. Three other military collaborators drew lesser sentences.

title: Thorn Unit Sold
description: The management of Thorn-EMI's entertainment division bought the unit for $159 million, using help from American and Australian backers to outbid two Israeli movie entrepreneurs. The bid by Yoram Globus and Menachem Golan was about $144 million, British newspapers reported. The management group's bid was backed by clients of Bear, Stearns & Company of the United States and by Alan Bond, an Australian.

title: Long-Term Rates Drop Again
description: Long-term interest rates continued to decline to new lows for the year yesterday, as Treasury bond prices rose more than 1/2 point in active trading.

title: BRITAIN PLANS TO GIVE POLICE POWER TO CURB VIOLENT ACTS OR THREATS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government plans to give the police new powers to deal with demonstrators, strikers, riotous soccer fans, racist bullies and anyone whose use of ''threatening'' language in public might inspire fear.

title: CHRISTMAS BREAKFAST YIELDS A TROVE OF GIFTS
description: A CHRISTMAS breakfast can be as magical as the holiday itself, a special treat that is festive without being formal (pajamas and dressing gowns are welcome at this table), a buffet whose elements are chosen with as much care as Christmas presents but whose preparation does not sour the spirit of the cook.

title: REAL-ESTATE STEERING ON L.I. CHARGED
description: The New York State Attorney General's office filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday charging that four real-estate companies in Nassau County promoted housing segregation by steering black home buyers to areas with large black populations, while showing whites of similar incomes homes in virtually all-white areas.

title: F.C.C. Alters Character Rules for Station Owners
description: The Federal Communications Commission today changed its rules for evaluating the character of broadcast station owners and applicants to hold licenses.

title: SCHMIDT, NAMED YALE CHIEF, LOOKS TO 'CHALLENGE'
description: Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the dean of the Columbia University Law School, was introduced as the 20th president of Yale University today and used the occasion to appeal for a merging of scholarship with the ''special challenge'' of social responsibility.

title: CHINESE IN U.S.: QUESTION OF LOYALTIES
description: Several years ago a Chinese-American working for Union Carbide in Peking was approached by a senior Chinese official with a proposal.

title: Books: For Collectors
description: COLLECTORS of period decorative arts will find this year's crop of books covers an impressive range of styles and materials, from antiquities through Art Deco, from Peruvian feather capes to Art Nouveau tiaras.

title: Broker Is Resentenced In Slaying After Crash
description: An investment broker convicted last year of murder for killing a passenger in a car that struck the Ferrari he was driving was resentenced yesterday to serve 4 to 12 years for manslaughter.

title: F.C.C. Acts to Subsidize Phone Service for Some
description: The Federal Communications Commission today unaminously adopted a local telephone service subsidy plan aimed at helping millions of low-income households maintain basic telephone service.

title: NEW HIPS FOR THE HOLIDAYS, IN AN OFFICE VISIT
description: It's Christmas time in the city. Children gaze wide-eyed into store windows, the aroma of roasting chestnuts and sidewalk Christmas tree lots fill the air, Santas ring bells on street corners and Dr. Elliot's office becomes as busy as Santa's own workshop.

title: National Security Assistant Is Promoted to No.2 Post
description: President Reagan has promoted Donald R. Fortier to the No. 2 job on the National Security Council, the White House announced today.

title: REAGAN TEMPERS HIS VIEW ON SOVIET
description: President Reagan said today that Soviet-American relations would continue to feel the impact of human rights issues. But in his annual speech marking International Human Rights Day, he abandoned the harsh tone with which he has previously denounced rights violations by the Soviet Union.

title: ARE SCHOOLS OVERLOOKING THE PARENTS?
description: JUDY THOMAS knows both sides of the parent-teacher equation. She is the mother of a high school sophomore and a lobbyist for the New York State Parent-Teacher Association. Sometimes, she said, the roles conflict in surprising ways.

title: Baltimore Loses Plea
description: A lawsuit in which the City of Baltimore has tried to bring the Colts back from Indianapolis through condemnation has been thrown out by a Federal District judge, Walter E. Black Jr. The Federal judge granted the request of the Colts' owner, Robert Irsay, for an immediate decision without a trial, dismissing a civil suit filed by city officials in 1984.

title: A.M.A. VOTES TO SEEK TOTAL BAN ON ADVERTISING TOBACCO PRODUCTS
description: The American Medical Association today called for a complete ban on the advertising and promotion of all tobacco products.

title: JOHN J. DUGAN
description: John J. Dugan, who worked in the picture and news departments of The New York Times for 50 years, died yesterday at his home in Bayonne, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MET OPERA: 'L'ITALIANA IN ALGERI'
description: YES, that was Marilyn Horne appearing last night in the title role in ''L'Italiana in Algeri,'' but it took a double-take or two to confirm the fact. The season's first performance of Rossini's comedy found the world's foremost contralto in what must be termed startlingly good form, not only offering her usual quota of prodigious vocalism but also looking considerably slimmer than we have ever seen her. From some angles it might have been Elizabeth Taylor in one of her periods of fasting and abstinence.

title: IONA IS DEFEATED BY LOUISVILLE, 88-75
description: Pervis Ellison, a freshman center, scored 15 of his 19 points in the second half to lead Louisville to an 88-75 victory over Iona.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STAYING WELL Our American forebears, in the course of establishing, heroically, a new society, suffered from many ailments, some imported, some domestic, all more or less serious in a country where, at the time of the American Revolution, it is believed 80 percent of the doctors were self-taught. A house call to Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street, corner of Broad Street (425-1778), will show you how early Americans coped with what ailed them.

title: DEVELCON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Spreading Stardust in Europe
description: For Americans, the Strategic Defense Initiative sprang unannounced from their President's head. For Europeans, this concept of building some kind of an electronic shield against Soviet missiles poses excruciating choices. After months of argument, Britain has agreed to participate in the research, and other European countries will probably do so shortly.

title: EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
The Chief Justice Is Calling
description: It's not often that the Chief Justice of the United States emerges from the silent portals of the Supreme Court to call on the American people for help, but Warren E. Burger is calling on us now.

title: To Avoid a Bhopal in the U.S.
description: In the year since the world's worst industrial accident, in Bhopal, India, which killed more than 2,000 people and injured tens of thousands, there has been much talk but little action about how to avert similar catastrophes.

title: UGANDANS SAID TO PLAN TREATY
description: Uganda's military Government and its guerrilla rivals are to sign a peace agreement Friday intended to reunite the war-divided country, President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya announced today.

title: A GORBACHEV TRADE WARNING
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told 400 American business executives today that while the Geneva summit meeting had opened the way to better Soviet-American relations, trade would remain limited until Washington lifted ''political obstacles.''

title: Working Profile:William H. Axtman;   Like a Wallflower At the Lobbyists' Waltz
description: In 1888, eight decades after Fulton first steered his steamboat without benefit of Government regulation, a Federal official from the Navy showed up to monitor a meeting of executives from the nation's booming boiler-making industry. It has been ''Uncle'' this and ''Uncle'' that ever since, according to William H. Axtman, the industry's current lobbyist, who finally yielded in 1972 and moved his headquarters from Newark down here to the amorphous Government zone called Inside the Beltway.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 11, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FIREFIGHTERS BARRED FROM POSTING CROSS AS HOLIDAY DISPLAY
description: Volunteer firefighters in Cos Cob have been forbidden to display a wooden cross on their firehouse during this Christmas season, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: The Children Are Gone
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: HIGH COURT RULES IN INFORMER CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that incriminating statements an undercover informer elicited from an indicted defendant may not be used to convict that defendant of the crime charged in the indictment.

title: NEW ZEALAND SUBMITS BILL TO BAN NUCLEAR-ARMED SHIPS AND PLANES
description: The Government, in a measure that could further strain relations with the United States, introduced legislation today to ban nuclear-armed ships and aircraft from New Zealand.

title: Weinberger On Navy Bids
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, in a special policy statement released today, said the Navy might have to forgo competitive bidding on a submarine contract if the General Dynamics Corporation cannot prove quickly that it is a responsible contractor.

title: LCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THAT BOWLING ALLEY ON THE TIBER: Tales of a Director. By Michelangelo Antonioni. Translated from the Italian by William Arrowsmith. 208 pages. Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: Cyclops Deal
description: The Cyclops Corporation said it had reached an agreement with company managers and outside investors to sell its steel and construction businesses, the bulk of its operations, for $20.50 a share, or about $200 million. The company identified the buyers as the Hillman Company of Pittsburgh and a management team including William H. Knoell, president and chief executive, and James F. Will, executive vice president.

title: Texaco's 'Poison Pill'
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that its board of directors had approved a plan intended to make it prohibitively expensive for any unwanted suitor to take over the company.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ACTION IS URGED TO AVERT GLOBAL CLIMATE SHIFT
description: A group of senators and scientists today called for national and international action to avert a predicted warming of the earth's climate resulting from a buildup of carbon dioxide and other man-made gases in the atmosphere.

title: Orlando Yields Range to 8.90%
description: The Orlando Utility Commission is offering $562 million of water and electric revenue bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets with yields as high as 8.90 percent for 8 1/2 percent bonds due in 2009 at a price of 96.

title: TEXACO'S BEST HOPE MAY BE SETTLEMENT
description: Legal experts said yesterday that while Texaco Inc. has three avenues of defense in court, its best hope of escaping the $10.53 billion judgment against it would be an out-of-court settlement.

title: 3 Die in Pennsylvania In Coal Mine Cave-In
description: A cave-in occurred at a coal mine today while miners were blasting, killing three men who were trapped more than half a mile underground, officials said.

title: JAZZ: A.A.C.M. CONCERT
description: THE Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, founded in Chicago in 1965, is a cooperative organization that has aimed to foster musical creativity regardless of idiom or style. The works members present at their concerts may be improvisational, largely notated, bluesy, abstract, even theatrical - the only requirement is that they be original.

title: Eastern Proposal
description: Eastern Airlines says it will seek deep cuts in wages, vacation time and sick leave from its pilots because of increased competition.

title: EX-U.S. SAFETY BOARD OFFICIAL
description: Francis H. McAdams, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board for 16 years, died yesterday while jogging near his home in Washington. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. TAPS ITS OIL RESERVES
description: In the first comprehensive test of the country's ability to tap its vast oil stockpile in an emergency, a Texas refiner today began to take delivery on a shipment of crude oil from the Government's strategic petroleum reserve.

title: 'SZCZECIN' DRAMATIZES POLISH STRIKE
description: ''THREE DAYS IN SZCZECIN'' is a docudrama, a form so treacherous that a case may be made for never using it for anything more recent than the Battle of Hastings. Still, done intelligently it does have its uses, and ''Three Days in Szczecin'' gives us one: Information is imparted, more or less painlessly. The 90-minute docudrama is on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: THEATER: SHELLEY'S CREATURE
description: BEFORE the horror of the monster movie ''Frankenstein,'' there was, of course, Mary Shelley's mordant novel about ''the new Prometheus.'' For its second show this season, the City Stage Company has gone back to the original book, as dramatized by Laurence Maslon. ''Frankenstein'' is running in repertory with Ibsen's ''Brand,'' and the pairing of plays is no coincidence; each deals with a man who would be God.

title: CSX PLANS TO WRITE OFF $954 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: The CSX Corporation, the nation's leading coal-hauling railroad, announced yesterday that it would take a write-off of nearly $1 billion against fourth-quarter earnings as part of a major corporate realignment program.

title: DESIGNATED HITTER WILL REMAIN AS IS
description: Baseball's club owners decided today not to heal the great schism of the last dozen years: The designated hitter will continue to bat for the pitcher in the American League next season but not in the National League.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Green Bay Packers signed Vince Ferragamo for the rest of this season and all of next year. Ferragamo, 31 years old, was waived Dec. 4 by the Buffalo Bills after starting the first nine games of the season. . . . Brian Bosworth of Oklahoma was voted the winner of the first Butkus Award, which honors the best college linebacker, by the Athletic Club of Orlando.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JURORS POSE CRUCIAL TEST OF ODDS FACING FLAMBOYANT EDWARDS
description: After 10 weeks of testimony and two days of lawyers telling them what it meant, the jurors in the Federal racketeering trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards were finally led into seclusion Tuesday night. They looked rather like a troop of tired horses.

title: 12.50 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,511.70
description: Helped by a string of developments that could aid businesses for years to come, the Dow Jones industrial average demolished the stubborn 1,500 barrier yesterday in the fifth-busiest session in Wall Street history.

title: Gorbachev and Jefferson
description: As he finished talking about human rights at the White House on Tuesday, President Reagan mentioned Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Thomas Jefferson.

title: THEATER: 'LEMON SKY' BY LANFORD WILSON
description: ''I'VE been trying to tell this story, to get it down, for a long time,'' says Alan, the protagonist and narrator of Lanford Wilson's ''Lemon Sky.'' The story may be one of the oldest going - that of father and son - but the storyteller knows that it is far from easy to tell. In Mr. Wilson's fine play, briefly seen Off Broadway in 1970 and now given exquisite new life by the Second Stage, Alan (Jeff Daniels) is constantly interrupting his own sentences with irrelevant asides, annotating others' lines, replaying scenes as if they were film loops and questioning the recollections of his fellow characters. Even so, the facts can't be pinned down. As Alan concedes upon failing to reconcile different versions of a distant domestic anecdote, maybe ''it doesn't matter anymore'' who said what to whom during childhood. The real question is, how does one grow up?

title: 24 AT JERSEY A-PLANT EXPOSED TO :LIGHT' DOSE OF RADIATION
description: Twenty-four workers were exposed to small amounts of radioactive gases at the Oyster Creek nuclear power facility in southern New Jersey yesterday after electricity to a ventilation system was interrupted, the utility reported.

title: ISLANDERS TIED BY PENGUINS
description: The Islanders failed to complete a sweep of their home-and-home series against the division rival Penguins and settled instead for a 4-4 tie at the Civic Center tonight.

title: Proposal Criticized By Boxing Figures
description: Within hours of the New Jersey State Commission of Investigation's recommendation yesterday that professional boxing be abolished in the state, leading figures in the sport were challenging the validity of the commission's findings, the competence of its judgment and the wisdom of its recommendations.

title: RADILLO ACCUSES KOCH OF RACISM IN HIS CRITICISM
description: Herman Badillo said yesterday that ''beneath the surface'' of a ''personal attack'' on him in Mayor Koch's latest book ''lies a grave character defect'' that threatens the Mayor's ability to govern New York City.

title: Burley Tobacco Crop
description: The 1985 burley tobacco harvest is estimated at 616 million pounds, down 14 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said today. Production is down in all burley states this year except Missouri, the department's Crop Reporting Board said.

title: DANGER OF UNFAIRNESS IN MASSIVE TAX REFORMS
description: To the Editor:

title: The '85 Farm Bill Will Hurt Exports
description: The 1985 farm bill is likely to be one of the biggest Federal handouts in history. It may also mean that by 1989 the United States will be importing more food than it exports.

title: PENZOIL MAY SETTLE FOR ASSET DEAL
description: Indicating that the Pennzoil Company wants to avoid a prolonged court fight, J. Hugh Liedtke, the company's chairman and chief executive, said today that he would consider a transfer of assets by Texaco Inc. to Pennzoil to settle the $11.1 billion judgment entered against Texaco Tuesday.

title: AT NBC NETWORK, MOOD IS RELAXED
description: Industry analysts and NBC News executives said last night that they did not expect the General Electric Company's acquisition of the RCA Corporation to have a major impact on the management of NBC News or the television network.

title: Gottfried to Pitt
description: Pitt will name Mike Gottfried as its football coach today, United Press International reported last night, citing ''sources close to the negotiations.'' Gottfried, the present coach at Kansas, will be given a five-year contract by Pitt, the news agency said.

title: Hartford Raises Bid for Provident
description: The Hartford National Corporation and the Provident Institution for Savings said the price Hartford agreed to pay for Provident's 3.75 million shares had been raised to $23.25 a share, from $21 a share. The merger modification also calls for Hartford to pay holders an additional 17 cents a share for each month following March 31, 1986, if the deal is not closed by that time, they said.

title: Passer Comes Out of the Blue
description: Earl Harvey almost chose to remain at home in Fayetteville, N.C., and take a job bagging groceries this fall. Instead, after some hesitation, he decided on a sheepskin and the pigskin, and the only thing he bagged all autumn was opposing defenses: In the season just concluded, he became the first freshman in N.C.A.A. history to pass for 3,000 yards.

title: A Stunning Win, or Loss, for the Poor
description: Silently, while hundreds of lobbyists have clamored for this loophole or that special interest, an immense victory for millions of poor people has been germinating in the House Ways and Means Committee. Any minute now - assuming the President corrals enough Republican votes to undo yesterday's parliamentary setback - the House will vote on the committee's tax bill. While there are many reasons to vote yes, here is the best one:

title: 3-State House Vote On Tax Legislation
description: Following are the positions of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today defeated procedures for considering tax revision. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to consider the two tax bills, and a ''no'' vote was a vote not to consider them; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: Canada Movie Aid Is Urged
description: A Government-appointed study has recommended that only Canadian companies be allowed to distribute films and videotapes in Canada. The recommendation, if adopted, could cost American film distributors millions of dollars in lost revenues, and was one of several tough proposals to shore up Canada's struggling film industry.

title: TROOPS PATROL IN WEST BEIRUT
description: A joint force of Lebanese Army soldiers and policemen was deployed in West Beirut today in a new attempt to end the rule of the militia groups in the mainly Moslem area.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 12, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FALSIFIED DEGREES GROWING PROBLEM
description: Two Congressional panels asserted today that more than 500,000 Americans had obtained false credentials or diplomas in fields ranging from medicine to architecture to zoology.

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $22,252 for the quarter and $127,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $6,615 for the quarter and $57,755 for the 9 months.

title: MEI Head, After Sale, Sees New Investments
description: Carl R. Pohlad, the Minneapolis financier who is chairman of the MEI Corporation, one of the nation's leading beverage companies, has a lot more money to play with now than he did last week. But Mr. Pohlad, who in the past has been involved in investment forays with Irwin L. Jacobs, a longtime friend, said yesterday that he had not yet thought about what to do with the windfall.

title: Man Who Killed Ill Wife Is Given Year's Work
description: An 85-year-old man who shot and killed his seriously ill wife was sentenced Tuesday to a year of community service at a food bank.

title: Conference on Soviet Jewry Reaches Out
description: For many years, American activity in behalf of Jews in the Soviet Union has been largely centered in places like New York and Los Angeles, where there are large Jewish populations.

title: RESCUERS DID NOT RESPOND TO CALL FROM A YACHT SINKING OFF JERSEY
description: The crew of a yacht that sank in Delaware Bay Friday transmitted a distress message that rescue units did not respond to, the Coast Guard said yesterday.

title: MINORITY DOCTORS OFTEN SERVE POOR
description: Doctors who are members of minority groups were more likely to care for poor and minority patients and to practice in areas where medical services were scarce than were white physicians trained at the same time, the early 1970's, , a new study concludes.

title: Gov. Sinner Out of Hospital
description: Gov. George A. Sinner was released today from a hospital where he spent six days for treatment of a bleeding ulcer that doctors attributed to stress and his use of aspirin for chronic headaches. Mr. Sinner, 57 years old, left St. Alexius Medical Center accompanied by his wife, two aides and a nurse. ''I'll have to cool my heels,'' he said.

title: BUSH, IN QUEST OF CONSERVATIVES, PAYS HOMAGE TO MEMORY OF LOEB
description: Vice President Bush, in his most visible effort to court Republican conservatives, paid homage tonight to the memory of William Loeb, one of their heroes and one of his harshest political tormentors.

title: 10 Olympians Honored
description: Ten athletes, including four gold medalists from the 1984 Olympics, are to be inducted into the United States Olympic Hall of Fame today.

title: Sea-Land Plan To Block Bid
description: The Sea-Land Corporation yesterday adopted a shareholder rights plan aimed at fending off a hostile takeover bid from Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor whose $25-a-share proposal to acquire the company was rejected last month by the company.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,866,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $33,000,000. d-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $5,637,000 and an extraordinary net credit of $1,898,000.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Liberian Leader Lifts Curfew and Frees 14
description: President Samuel Doe lifted a month-old curfew today and ordered the release of 14 people, including opposition politicians, who were arrested after an abortive coup on Nov. 12.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Computer Consoles Inc., Rochester, said it expected to release about 200 employees in mid-January and eliminate 130 more through attrition by the end of June. The company said it was also shifting its headquarters to Waltham, Mass.

title: University of California Aide Leaps to Death From Bridge
description: Donald L. Reidhaar, chief attorney for the University of California, jumped to his death from the Golden Gate Bridge Tuesday, the university said today.

title: CHEMICAL PLANT ACCUSED OF CONCEALING DEATHS
description: A labor coalition today accused Rohm & Haas, a chemical concern, of trying to cover up the cancer deaths of four employees exposed to what scientists at one point called the most potent carcinogen known.

title: CUOMO TRIES TO SALVAGE LEGISLATION
description: Governor Cuomo tried today to resurrect the legislative package that the State Senate rejected in a brief special session on Tuesday The Governor invited the Legislature's leaders to a meeting on the issues - with medical malpractice insurance at the top of the list - in the hope of calling legislators back to Albany for another try.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses of $162,000 for the quarter and $540,000 for the 9 months from an unconsolidated subsidiary. c-Including a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $23,877,000.

title: Angolan Rebels Expect Government Offensive
description: Angolan and Cuban troops appear to be preparing for another offensive against South African-backed guerrillas in Angola, a guerrilla spokesman said today.

title: $15.2 Billion Sale Of Bills Set Today
description: The Treasury announced yesterday afternoon plans to auction $15.2 billion of Treasury bills today that would normally have been sold last Monday. Bids for the $7.6 billion of new three-month bills and an equal amount of six-month bills will be accepted only at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and must be submitted by 10 A.M.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Allan McKay, pitcher.

title: Market Place;   Biotechnology: Wide Swings
description: THE biotechnology group is tiny compared with such prominent sectors of the stock market as oils, computers or paper companies. But several events have sent biotechnology issues soaring to record prices - and later pulling back - this month.

title: HOME BEAT
description: A CERAMICIST, Martine Vermeulen makes lovely things that she sells in a shop-studio.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Perhaps the single most pivotal factor in the commission's determination that boxing should be abolished is its investigative conclusion that not even the sturdiest of statutory controls will reduce the brutality of the sport to any significant degree.

title: To Your Holiday Health
description: On the first day of Christmas, your true love might give to you an executive physical examination ($250), a lunch at an upscale restaurant ($100), an eyeglass screwdriver ($1), stop-smoking lec-tures ($150), a pony ride ($5) or luxurious in-patient treatment for your new baby, your spouse and you ($3,000). These are all available through a holiday gift catalogue of the Washington Healthcare Corporation, an organization of several hospitals in the capital area, telephone (202) 541-5787.

title: BENNETT SOLICITS LETTERS ON CURBING DROPOUTS
description: William J. Bennett, the Federal Secretary of Education, said yesterday that motivating students was essential to solving the dropout problem and invited the public to send him letters describing successful efforts.

title: Brennan Case Goes to Jurors
description: The jury in the trial of Justice William C. Brennan of State Supreme Court in Queens began deliberating yesterday whether the judge had violated Federal racketeering laws.

title: A NOTE IN FOND DEFENSE OF THE APPOGGIATURA
description: WHAT is an appoggiatura and why does it matter?

title: Waterman Resigns at McKinsey
description: Robert H. Waterman Jr., co-author with Thomas J. Peters of the best seller ''In Search of Excellence,'' resigned yesterday from McKinsey & Company to write books and start his own consulting firm.

title: WOMAN IN THE NEWS: CORAZONE AQUINO THE TICKET OF 2 THAT SEEKS TO TOPPLE MARCOS
description: Corazon C. Aquino, who will face President Ferdinand E. Marcos in elections set for February, says her advisers keep telling her to stop referring to herself as ''just an ordinary housewife.''

title: CONTROVERSY ABOUT TOYS, TV VIOLENCE
description: TWELVE parents sat in a circle during the first ''He-Man Workshop'' at the Christ Church Day School in Manhattan and voiced their concerns - and confusions - about the state of children's television entertainment.

title: Drug Test Ban To Be Appealed
description: A lawyer for the Henry P. Becton Regional High School in East Rutherford said the school board would appeal a State Superior Court judge's ruling that struck down a policy requiring students to submit to drug tests.

title: U.S. AND ITS ALLIES AGREE TO TEST SOVIET ON ARMS
description: The United States and its NATO allies agreed today to seek an early test next month of the stated Soviet willingness to negotiate a separate accord on medium-range missiles.

title: LEO HONIG
description: Leo Honig, chairman emeritus of the Anglo Fabrics Company, which operates woolen and worsted mills, and former chairman of Johanna Farms of Flemington, N. J., died of cancer Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 92 years old and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: REAGAN LOSES KEY TAX VOTE
description: In a striking setback for President Reagan, the House of Representatives voted today to block consideration of tax revision legislation, the top legislative priority of the President's second term.

title: Choice of Temperatures On the West Side
description: Forget the zoning issues, complicated though they may be. The most perplexing thing about the new rooftop Hitachi sign near Columbus Circle is its temperature reading.

title: STORE DECORATING SERVICES: WHAT THEY OFFER
description: VIVIAN and Martin Lorber live in a four-bedroom house on a Florida beach. Thea and Terence Nolan live in a two-bedroom apartment on Manhattan's East Side. Susan Schulman lives with her family in a 13-room town house on the West Side. And Jane Nielsen lives in a one-bedroom apartment with a spectacular river view from downtown Manhattan. Their living styles and their homes are all different, but they have one thing in common: They were decorated by the interior design services of Manhattan department stores.

title: ROCHESTER COMMUNITY SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Pactel Waiver Gets U.S. Backing
description: The Justice Department has recommended that a Federal judge grant a waiver allowing Pacific Telesis to purchase Communications Industries.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: COAST MUSEUM ACQUIRES 'EARTHWORK'
description: A major ''earthwork'' sculpture from the late 1960's - ''Double Negative,'' a 1,500-foot-long groove cut into a mesa in the Nevada desert by the artist Michael Heizer - has been acquired by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, it was announced yesterday.

title: BUCKNELL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $1,110,000, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,732,000, or 37 cents a share, for the 6 months; includes a gain of $2,648,000, or 56 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, from sale of an excess building and a gain of $1,172,000, or 25 cents a share, for the 6 months from sale and leaseback of a manufacturing facility. c-After equity in earnings of Raymark Corp. of $11,000 for the quarter and $280,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $4,524,000 on sale of Raymark stock for the quarter and 6 months.

description: b-Including tax credits of $120,927 for the latest year and $221,737 for the previous year.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Economy

title: Pavarotti in Concert
description: ''Pavarotti Plus,'' a concert of arias and ensembles with Luciano Pavarotti, Kathleen Battle and others will be given at Avery Fisher Hall on Jan. 6. Remaining tickets will go on sale Sunday at the box office, or may be charged by phone at 874-6770.

title: IMEX MEDICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Wives and Business
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Intelligence Community Resists Quality Control
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN LOSES KEY TAX VOTE
description: One of the most abrupt Congressional setbacks of Ronald Reagan's Presidency left startled White House officials trying to figure out where they went wrong and making plans late today to salvage some form of tax revision, the major legislative priority of Mr. Reagan's second term.

title: NEGOTIATORS ON FARM BILL SAY ACCORD MAY BREAK DEADLOCK
description: House and Senate negotiators say they have come up with a compromise that could break an impasse on income support for wheat, grain and corn farmers.

title: 8th Grader Faces 5 Years in Slaying
description: A 13-year-old eighth-grade student, accused of killing a custodian at Portland Junior High School on Tuesday and injuring the principal and a secretary with a semiautomatic rifle, faces a maximum of five years in a state school for delinquents, law enforcement officials said today.

title: TESTS OF NEW ARMOR VEHICLE REBUT CRITICISM, ARMY SAYS
description: The Army said today that recent tests showed its new armored fighting vehicle was less vulnerable to Soviet anti-tank weapons than critics had alleged but that additional improvements costing as much as $480 million would have to be made.

title: ADI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Nets, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. This is the first meeting between the teams this season.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses of $50,100,000 for the quarter and $43,680,000 for the year from discontinued operations and extraordinary charges of $9,719,000 for the quarter and $16,361,000 for the year from the writedown of assets and restructuring costs. c-After income of $3,053,000, or 4 cents a share, from discontinued operations. d-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $11,368,000, or 14 cents a share. The 1984 amounts have been restated to reflect the oil and gas segment as discontinued operations.

title: YALE GETS A NEW BUIDLING DATED 1894
description: YALE'S computers needed more space. The new home planned for them, a genteel Romanesque revival structure of red brick built in 1894 had arched windows and 16-foot ceilings, but not enough floor space for the Computer Science Department, which was expanding.

title: LOW-PAYING JOBS FORESEEN FOR MOST WORKING WOMEN
description: Despite recent progress, most American women who are employed will continue to work in largely low-paying occupations dominated by women for the foreseeable future, a panel formed by the National Academy of Sciences has concluded.

title: Banc One Terms
description: The Banc One Corporation said it had agreed to acquire KYNB Bancshares, a closely held bank holding company whose subsidiary has assets of $260 million, for an undisclosed number of new shares and the First Crawfordsville Financial Corporation, whose banking subsidiary has $125 million in assets, for $21.9 million of new shares.

title: Always The Bridesmaid
description: Ethel Kennedy's son Joe is running for the Massachusetts seat once held by his uncle, and her daughter Kathleen is thinking of running for Congress in Maryland. The Kennedy clan is making its generational move, and it is nice to see the familiar grins on the new faces.

title: Required Reading;   'TIL DEBT DO US PART
description: Excerpts from ''Til Debt Do Us Part: Who Wins, Who Loses and Who Pays for the International Debt Crisis,'' a new study by Alfred J. Watkins, economic policy consultant to the Roosevelt Center for American Policy Studies, based in Washington:

title: Halley's Hot Line
description: Beginning today, prospective comet watchers can call (212) 769-3299, the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium hot line, and hear an avuncular voice say:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1985
description: International

title: CONCERT: HERITAGE ORCHESTRA
description: THE Heritage Chamber Orchestra is a new organization dedicated to the propogation of Jewish orchestral music, and its inaugural concert at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon more than proved the assertion that there is a repertory worth propogating.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STRUGGLES AT THE NEW 'SATURDAY NIGHT'
description: When ''Saturday Night Live'' made its season debut last month, most of the reviews were scathing. The first show featured several sketches widely condemned as tasteless and witless, such as one in which President Kennedy, assisted by his brother Robert, murders Marilyn Monroe, and another in which a homosexual actor and a female star who is an intravenous drug user are afraid of catching AIDS from each other in a kissing scene. ''This was comedy the way Hiroshima was comedy,'' pronounced one critic. ''Bad taste, nothing! This is bad humanity.'' Another advised, ''Fold up the tent and let the series die.''

title: HANOVER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $579,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,577,000, or 58 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Businessman Dies In a Plane Crash
description: A twin-engine airplane crashed while approaching the Chemung County Airport today, killing the pilot, who was a Binghamton businessman and brigadier general in the Army Reserve, authorities said.

title: Committee Backs Dr. Bowen
description: The Senate Finance Committee today unanimously approved President Reagan's nomination of Dr. Otis R. Bowen as Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services. If confirmed by the Senate, Dr. Bowen would succeed Margaret M. Heckler. Mrs. Heckler is leaving the post to become Ambassador to Ireland. Dr. Bowen, a physician for 44 years, served eight years as Governor of Indiana.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FACE OF THE CITY New York has even more faces than Lon Chaney, the man of a thousand faces, and these countenances of the city keep showing up at the Municipal Art Society, which has three galleries in which to show them off at its landmark Urban Center headquarters, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street (935-3960).

title: POP: SADE AT RADIO CITY
description: SADE, the Nigerian-born English pop star, may have grown up ''in a miserable seaside town,'' as she told her Radio City Music Hall audience on Tuesday. But the singer and lyricist, who was making her New York City concert debut performing with an excellent 10-man pop-jazz band, exuded the cool, composed regality of someone groomed in palatial splendor.

title: TENNESSEE GOVERNOR SIGNS 6 BILLS AIMED AT REFORMING STATE PRISONS
description: Gov. Lamar Alexander today signed into law six bills designed to reform Tennessee's troubled prison system, and the Attorney General advised a Federal judge that the state had regained control of its penal institutions.

title: ENHANCING A FIREPLACE
description: USED in Colonial days to protect masonry against deterioration from extreme heat and to radiate more warmth to a room, firebacks are both decorative and useful. The Country Iron Foundry in Paoli, Pa., carries reproduction firebacks in 12 American and French designs.

title: The Family-Planning Ploy
description: The spirit of the Kemp-Hatch amendment opposing Congressional funding of family planning services reveals the conservative alliance's ultimate strategy. Although defeated in committee by a substitute bill that must still pass the House - Kemp-Hatch could be revived - its ban on Federal funds for any family planning clinic that offers abortion counseling shows the aim of the Fundamentalists, Roman Catholic conservatives and President Reagan. They wish to attack birth control and voluntary sterilization, the foundation of a woman's right to control her childbearing. Their eventual target is to wipe out the women's movement.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Tuesday about William McChesney Martin, the former Federal Reserve chairman, erroneously described the rarity of Government buildings named for living people. The General Services Administration says that a cursory check shows about 20 Federal Government buildings in various states named for people still living, including former Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. of New Jersey and former Senator and Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: Millions Found Wasted On Tests for Disability
description: Congressional investigators have found the Social Security Administration may have wasted up to $166 million over the last two years through unnecessary medical tests on patients who applied for disability aid.

title: Technology;   A Future Role For Scramjets
description: TREMENDOUS progress in the design of a new class of jet engines - known as scramjets - is propelling the fantasy of a hypersonic plane out of the Twilight Zone toward reality.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: New Rules For Lloyd's
description: Lloyd's of London, the group of insurance companies whose reputation has been tarnished by a scandal, has announced new rules intended to put its ''accounting house in order.''

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Cyprus Write-Off
description: Cyprus Minerals Company said it would take an after-tax charge on earnings of $425 million in the fourth quarter in a write-off of its investment in the Thompson Creek molybdenum mine in Challis, Idaho, and some copper and coal assets. The action, taken because of poor business conditions, will reduce its net worth to $805 million, or $30.66 a share, from $1.2 billion, or $46.82 a share.

title: Toward Economic Justice
description: President Reagan has chosen J. William Middendorf 2d as chairman of a group to advocate more private enterprise in Central American and Caribbean countries so as to help them reduce their considerable national debts. Mr. Middendorf will retain his post as Ambassador to the European Economic Community, in Brussels. The executive director of the group of 12 American business and labor offcials is expected to be a Washington-based businessman, Bruce L. Mazzie, a 48-year-old native of New Jersey.

title: HEARINGS OPENED ON MARCOS ASSETS
description: A House subcommittee began hearings today into allegations that President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, have accumulated extensive real estate and other holdings in the United States. The hearings today were closed.

title: BKW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TROUBLED FARMERS: DEBTS AND GUNS
description: A financially troubled farmer who walked into his small town bank near here Monday and shot the bank president dead had no problem driving off again into the blowing snow: The Hills Bank and Trust Company, with more than $200 million in assets, had no security guard.

title: HOMELESS FAMILIES STAYING IN OFFICES
description: Homeless families with children have been forced to spend the night in city welfare offices in the last three months because there was no room for them in the shelters or welfare hotels, according to city records.

title: U.S. TEAM IN ISRAEL OVER SPYING CASE
description: A team of American investigators arrived in Israel today to question two Israeli diplomats and a senior counterterrorism official who have been linked to an espionage operation in Washington.

title: PHILIPPINE OPPOSITION WORKS OUT AGREEMENT FOR A UNIFIED TICKET
description: One hour before the expiration of a midnight filing deadline, the Philippine opposition reached a compromise tonight and agreed that Corazon C. Aquino would run for President with her chief rival, Salvador H. Laurel, as her running mate.

title: MISSISSIPPI BEGINS ANALYZING ITS RACIST CONSTITUTION OF 1890
description: A 350-member biracial commission today began a study of Mississippi's 1890 Constitution, which was designed primarily to keep blacks out of the state political process.

title: RANGERS SET BACK DEVILS
description: In a game marked by conservative play from both teams, the Rangers took a 3-0 lead and held on for a 4-2 victory over the Devils tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: DANCE: A NEW 'LAMENT' BY ALVIN AILEY TROUPE
description: ''THERE'S something strange going on,'' Brother John Sellers, the gospel and blues singer, has frequently warned us as part of one of Alvin Ailey's dance pieces. And there is definitely something strange going on in Louis Johnson's ''Lament.'' Created in 1953, the work was introduced in a revised - souped up -version Tuesday night by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: PRESSURE ON TEXACO FOR ACCORD
description: Texaco Inc. found itself yesterday under mounting financial pressure from credit markets, bankers and suppliers to reach a settlement in its high-stakes legal battle with the Pennzoil Company.

title: PARIS RESTAURANT AWARD
description: Members of the French culinary establishment tonight awarded Papa Maya, a Texas-Mexican restaurant on Rue Rambuteau in Les Halles, the Plat Vermeil, or Gold-Plated Dish, award for foreign food and the Golden Fork award for excellent cuisine.

title: Petro-Lewis Plans
description: Officials of the Petro-Lewis Corporation announced they would lay off 85 more employees in an effort toward restructuring, but said plans to liquidate the financially troubled oil company had fizzled.

title: P.S. on No. 1's
description: A postscript to the age-old headache in deciding whether to hold on to a first-round selection or use it as bait in a trade for a veteran star: Of the 28 players from the N.B.A. on the opening-day rosters of teams in the Continental Basketball Association, eight are former first-rounders. They range from Freeman Williams, the eighth player taken in 1978 (by Boston) to Stewart Granger and Michael Young, the 24th players chosen, by the Cleveland Cavaliers (1983) and the Celtics (1984), respectively.

title: REAGAN WIDENS USE OF LIE TESTING ON TOP ADMINISTRATION OFFICIALS
description: Attempting to deal with espionage and disclosures of information, President Reagan has ordered a more widespread use of mandatory polygraph, or lie-detector, testing of Administration officials with access to highly sensitive security material, the White House announced today.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $411,000 from a distribution of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: SALVADOR LAUREL THE TICKET OF 2 THAT SEEKS TO TOPPLE MARCOS
description: In a way, Salvador H. Laurel has been preparing all his life to run for President, a fact that made his concession to Corazon C. Aquino tonight all the more difficult.

title: YANKEES ACQUIRE ROENICKE
description: The Yankees finally sought Don Baylor's permission to trade him to the Chicago White Sox, they completed trades tonight for Gary Roenicke, an Orioles' outfielder, and Mike Fischlin, an Indians' infielder.

title: Advertising;   New Chairman At Doremus
description: On Jan. 1, Curtis R. Troeger will become chairman and chief executive officer of Doremus & Company, a subsidiary of BBDO International.

title: DOUBTS ON GASOLINE PRICE CUTS
description: When OPEC announced its oil embargo in 1973, the price at the gasoline pumps here quickly followed the steep rise in the cost of crude oil.

title: REAGAN LOSES KEY TAX VOTE
description: In an effort to balance the budget after 24 deficits in 25 years, Congress tonight approved legislation aimed at shrinking the deficit to zero by 1991.

title: Hispanic Assemblyman Wins Los Angeles Post
description: State Assemblyman Richard Alatorre won an easy victory Tuesday in a special election that saw the first Hispanic candidate elected to the City Council in nearly a quarter of a century.

title: World Bank Rate
description: Another cut in the interest rate charged to poor countries by the World Bank will go into effect Jan. 1, a bank official said today. The official, who requested anonymity, estimated that the current rate of 8.82 percent might drop to 8.6 percent. The official said the amount has not officially been set for the rates, which are reviewed every six months.

title: POP: BUSTER POINDEXTER
description: BUSTER POINDEXTER, the fictional bandleader who is an alter ego of the rock singer David Johansen, represents one performer's ingenious solution to the problem of how to transcend pop music's cult of personality. While the musical interests of rock performers often range far beyond their signature styles, public exploration of those interests risks tampering with a popular known quantity.

title: A FRENCH SUPERSTAR'S MINIMALIST FURNITURE
description: HE is 36 years old and is by most accounts the current superstar on the French design scene. His name is Philippe Starck and his minimal, linear furniture and spare, contemporary interiors are nearly as recognizable as he is himself - a charming hulk of a man, usually dressed in a black or gray T-shirt and with more than a morning-after growth of stubble dotting a serious, rectangular face. Even when he calls on President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Office Is Robbed
description: Two men, one armed with a shotgun, held up the office of the Union Settlement Federal Credit Union at 237 East 104th Street yesterday and escaped with $50,000, the police said.

title: Trade Deficit Sets Record
description: The United States foreign trade deficit soared to a record $33.1 billion from July through September, as American farm sales slowed to their lowest pace in more than six years, the Government said today.

title: INSURERS SAY AIDS MAY COST BILLIONS IN CLAIMS IN 2 YEARS
description: If the AIDS epidemic continues unabated, the nation's insurance industry could be paying billions in benefits in two years, an industry official warned Tuesday.

title: Italy Jails Arab Over Arms
description: An Italian court today sentenced an Arab who said he was a supporter of the Palestine Liberation Organization to a 14-year jail term for illegal possession of arms and explosives. The man, Omar Saadat Salem, 39 years old, was arrested here two weeks ago.

title: ACIDIC POLLUTION MAY BE ON THE RISE
description: After a long decline, emissions of the major pollutants that cause acid rain may have started to rise again, according to the Environmental Protection Agency's preliminary data for last year.

title: DeLorean Loses Custody of Children
description: The divorce battle between John DeLorean and Cristina Ferrare ended in a split decision today, with the former auto maker losing custody of their children, but winning a fight to deny his former wife a large share in his estimated $20 million fortune.

title: Governor's Libel Suit Reinstated in Dakota
description: Gov. William J. Janklow's $24 million libel suit over a book that included an assertion that he once raped an Indian babysitter was reinstated by the South Dakota Supreme Court today.

title: HOW SENATE VOTED ON BUDGET PLAN
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate adopted legislation to raise the debt limit. The measure also includes a provision designed to eliminate Federal deficits by 1991.

title: UNESCO WORKERS STRIKE OVER DISMISSALS
description: Large numbers of employees of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization held a work stoppage today to demand changes in the agency's policy on dismissing employees.

title: JORDANIAN PLANS TO VISIT DAMASCUS
description: King Hussein of Jordan has accepted an invitation to visit an old enemy, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, in Damascus.

title: Bomb Damages Church Where St. Francis Died
description: A bomb exploded today in a chapel of a basilica where St. Francis of Assisi died in 1226, damaging frescoes but causing no injuries, the police said.

title: POLLUTION THREATENS RESIDENTS NEAR GREAT LAKES, STUDY SAYS
description: Growing evidence indicates people living around the Great Lakes are exposed to and accumulate ''appreciably more'' toxic chemicals than other North Americans, a United States-Canadian study has found.

title: GRIDCOMM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DANGER OF UNFAIRNESS IN MASSIVE TAX REFORMS
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PLAYOFF POSSIBILITIES: A JIGSAW PUZZLE
description: This is exactly what the National Football League had in mind when it devised the tiebreaking procedure to determine playoff teams: Chaos.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $57 million after-tax provision for restructuring North American Tire operations for the quarter and year and extraordinary tax credits of $4 million and $9 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $5 million for the quarter and $13 million for the year and a gain of $26 million from the sale of discontinued operations for the year. The latest fourth quarter and fiscal year results also include credits of $10 million and $16 million, respectively, for adjustments to prior years' estimated tax liabilities. The prior year net also includes an $11 million gain from the sale of the company's Brazilian rubber plantation.

title: From Stage to Screen
description: After playing a matinee and an evening performance of ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' a troupe trooped up to the Thalia to see ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood.''

title: Becker Accepts Draft
description: Boris Becker of West Germany said he would make himself eligible to be drafted into military service.

title: Gretzky Gets 7 Assists
description: Wayne Gretzky matched his National Hockey League record for assists in a game with seven tonight in leading the Edmonton Oilers to a 12-9 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: SWEEPING STATE MOVE ON MERGERS
description: A bill passed by the Legislature Tuesday night in an effort to protect New York corporations from some hostile takeovers is the most sweeping legislation of its kind in any state.

title: On Kaleidoscopes
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: EVENTS: BROOKLYN CHRISTMAS
description: Christmas Decorations, Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street, 718-624-0890.

title: Patterson Returns To His Old Position
description: For 15 games this year - the last two exhibitions and the first 13 of the regular season - Elvis Patterson started at left cornerback for the Giants. He played aggressively and, usually, well; certainly better than expected from a free agent who played little as a rookie last year.

title: Politics;   Whither Charles S. Robb?
description: Eight years ago, when Charles S. Robb moved to Richmond to serve first as Lieutenant Governor of Virginia, then as Governor, he was best known as Lyndon B. Johnson's son-in-law, a former Marine captain who had married the President's daughter, Lynda Bird, then gone off to the war in Vietnam.

title: Equally Tragic Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: Guru's Commune-City Held Unconstitutional
description: The commune-city of Rajneeshpuram, created and now being disbanded by followers of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, was an unconstitutional merging of church and state, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: Swiss Broker Ordered to Give Documents to U.S.
description: The Swiss Federal Court ruled that Ellis A.G., a Zurich broker, must supply documents requested by the United States Justice Department that relate to an insider trading investigation, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

title: PIONEERS THAT GREW UP TOGETHER INTO GIANTS
description: The merger agreement announced last night by the General Electric Company and the RCA Corporation would rejoin two companies that fueled each other's growth from the closing days of World War I and then diverged as each became giants of burgeoning communications, space technology and electronics industries.

title: BRITISH AND IRISH HOLD FIRST TALKS UNDER PACT WHILE PROTESTERS RAGE
description: British and Irish Cabinet ministers held their first meeting on the affairs of Northern Ireland in Belfast today behind barbed wire and massed policemen, who held off furious Protestant demonstrators.

title: G.E. WILL PURCHASE RCA IN A CASH DEAL WORTH $6.3 BILLION
description: The General Electric Company agreed yesterday to acquire the RCA Corporation, owner of the NBC television network and a leading defense and consumer electronics company, in a cash deal worth nearly $6.3 billion.

title: TREND IS GROWING FOR LOW SCORING
description: For years a cherished pro basketball statistic was keeping an opponent from scoring 100 points. That statistic, perhaps more than any other, symbolized good defense. But in the last several seasons, failure of a team to reach 100 points is becoming more common.

title: Intermountain Power In $806 Million Offering
description: The Intermountain Power Agency is offering $806 million of electric revenue bonds through Goldman, Sachs & Company to refund bonds previously issued in 1981 and 1983.

title: Election Due in July, Uganda's Leader Says
description: Uganda's military ruler, Gen. Tito Okello, announced that elections would be held next July, a year after President Milton Obote was ousted in a coup, the Uganda radio said today.

title: Advertising;   London Merger
description: Wells Rich Greene in London has merged with Holmes Knight Ritchie, to form Holmes Knight Ritchie/ WRG, in which W.R.G., the American partner, is a minority owner. Richard Knight, founder of the British agency, will be chairman of the combined operation, which has billings of some $43 million.

title: HERS
description: RECENTLY I found myself in midtown and decided to take a walk through Bryant Park, the intransigently shabby square of struggling greenery and overflowing trash baskets that sits beside the 42d Street library. It was my favorite sort of day, one of those mild, misty, romantic last afternoons of fall, and I strolled along enjoying a mood of pleasurable melancholy. But not for long.
