Distracted by one of the park's resident drug dealers, who invited me to take off my clothes, and by another, who wanted to know why I wasn't smiling, I looked around and noticed an interesting thing. In Bryant Park on this lovely gray afternoon were perhaps 50 men, strolling, ambling, striding along eating hot dogs, sitting on benches and reading the paper or trading illegal substances as though they had all the time in the world - and 3 women, all walking quickly and grimly, as I was now doing, as though late for an appointment with the dentist.

title: JERSEY PANEL RECOMMENDS A BAN ON BOXING
description: The State Commission of Investigation recommended today that professional boxing be outlawed in New Jersey, calling it ''legal savagery'' and saying it ''has no place in a civilized culture.''

title: Advertising;   A.M.A.'s Assault on Tobacco
description: THE reaction in adland to the demand by the American Medical Association for the end of all promotion for tobacco products was an almost universal condemnation based on First Amendment rights. And some of the comments were not unlike those voiced when the Congressionally dictated broadcast advertising ban against cigarettes went into effect after the Super Bowl game in 1971.

title: Coffee Declines Sharply Following Recent Rally
description: Coffee futures prices dropped sharply in New York today after a recent rally as traders assessed the impact of a potentially large release of stockpiled coffee. There were also rumors that the Brazilian drought has not damaged next year's crop as badly as expected.

title: Iroquois Rejection
description: Iroquois Brands Ltd., the maker of liquor, specialty foods and vitamins, said Terence J. Fox, chairman and chief executive, and his family had rejected an offer for their stake in the company, which would total 29 percent after the exercise of options. The offer was for $42.50 a share, or a total of $11.3 million. Mr. Fox called the offer inadequate and said he would prefer that any offer be extended to all shareholders.

title: 44 PEOPLE, BANK AND 2 BUSINESSES INDICTED ON FEDERAL DRUG CHARGES
description: Forty-four people, a Texas bank and two companies in the Cayman Islands have been indicted in connection with a drug ring that is said to have brought 250,000 pounds of marijuana into the United States from Mexico, it was announced today.

title: REV. J. BENJAMIN FELL, LEADER OF OLYMPICS HELD AT LAKE PLACID
description: The Rev. J. Bernard Fell, president of the Lake Placid Olympic Organizing Committee, died of cancer Tuesday at the Medical Center of Vermont in Burlington. He was 63 years old and lived in Northfield, Vt.

title: New Chance in Guatemala
description: For Guatemala, now comes the hard part. The military, in power for most of 31 years, has honored its promise to permit the free election of a civilian president.

title: Excerpts From Jersey Report on Boxing
description: Following are excerpts from the report on boxing issued yesterday by the New Jersey State Commission of Investigation:

title: Bridge: The Latest Project for Sharif Blends Two of His Interests
description: >A world-famous personality arrived in Manhattan Tuesday intending to combine two of his major interests. The actor who became a star in ''Lawrence of Arabia'' more than two decades ago and completed his 56th movie, by one count, in Spain earlier this week is to spend today making a videotape entitled ''Play Bridge with Omar Sharif.''

title: COLOMBIA'S FUTURE: MORE VIOLENCE?
description: On a summer's day last year, while children painted white doves on sidewalks and artists sang poems to peace, Colombians of all ages crowded downtown Bogota to celebrate a cease-fire between the army and leftist guerrillas.

title: Transactions
description: MONDAY BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Traded Steve Bedrosian, pitcher, and Milt Thompson, minor-league outfielder, to Philadelphia for Ozzie Virgil, catcher, and Pete Smith, minor-league pitcher.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
34 Are Reported Dead In Fighting in Salvador
description: Nineteen rebels and 15 soldiers were reported killed today in battles north and east of San Salvador.

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FUNDS GAIN
description: The average yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were held in check during the week ended yesterday. Meanwhile, yields on money market mutual funds showed some upward movement, led by gains at mutual funds that deal only in Treasury securities.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH most homeowners know well why insulation is needed in the attic or under the roof to cut energy costs (for cooling as well as for heating), many are not aware of the importance of adequate ventilation on the outer side of the barrier in closed-off attic spaces and crawl spaces. Many are also not certain why vapor barriers are needed (in addition to ventilation) to fight condensation - or, for that matter, why condensation can be a problem at all.

title: Pipeline Rule On Transport
description: Government regulators, in the face of resistance by pipelines to becoming transporters rather than wholesalers of natural gas, have voted to allow the companies to keep moving low-cost supplies to certain buyers through the winter.

title: DANGER OF UNFAIRNESS IN MASSIVE TAX REFORMS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW MUCH GIANT PROGRESS?
description: For the first time in more than two decades, the Giants have won nine games in two successive seasons. That's progress. It's also continuity. But just how much progress and how much continuity will be determined Sunday when the Giants go against the Dallas Cowboys in Texas Stadium with first place in the National Conference East at stake.

title: DAPPER TEXAS JUDGE FOR A HISTORIC CASE
description: Until Tuesday, when he affirmed the largest civil damages award in American history, Solomon J. Casseb Jr. was not known in Texas legal circles for any particular ruling from the bench.

title: NEW YORK CITY WARNED ON THE AIDS COST BURDEN
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan warned yesterday that by the end of the decade the city could be forced to spend $500 million on AIDS a year and was not preparing for the financial burden.

title: N.F.L. Disavows Merger
description: National Football League owners today approved a resolution avowing that the N.F.L. has no interest in merging with the United States Football League or settling the U.S.F.L.'s $1.2 billion antitrust suit against the N.F.L.

title: YALE, ITS HOUSE PUT IN ORDER, GETS READY TO SET NEW GOALS
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, who is in his eighth and final year as president of Yale University, sat in a stiff armchair in his Woodbridge Hall office one recent morning and considered his legacy to the 284-year old institution.

title: Rockwell Suspension Lifted
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, suspended as a Pentagon contractor on Oct. 31 because of a guilty plea to fraud charges, has regained the right to receive contracts by promising management improvements and creating the post of internal ombudsman, the Air Force said today.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The figures for both periods include the results of Surface Science Laboratories Inc., acquired in January and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: RUSSIAN LAUREATE FIGHTS 'STAR WARS'
description: Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, the Soviet co-founder of the doctors' group that won the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize, today criticized the concept of a space-based missile defense as ''one more step toward nuclear war.''

title: VOZNESENSKY MUSICAL SET FOR SPRING
description: Andrei Voznesensky, whose reputation as an international poet has gained him entrance even to the White House, has said he expects to be heard from in another form next spring - as the lyricist for an Off Broadway rock musical that first played out of town (in Off Off Moscow).

title: Conferees Back Funds For Public Broadcasting
description: House and Senate conferees today agreed on an authorization for public broadcasting through fiscal year 1990 and included the financing proposal in the budget reconciliation bill.

title: LIFE IN AMERICA AFTER THE REVOLUTION
description: Samuel Colton never approved of ''the notions of equality that were spreading in New England.'' He and his family lived comfortably in their Longmeadow, Mass., home, and as Tories, they disdained the American Revolution, which threatened their way of life.

title: PROGRAM TEACHES ART TO OLD AT HOME
description: JENNY SMITH pointed at the brightly colored afghan stretched across her living room sofa. ''I loved to crochet,'' the 94-year-old woman said, reflecting on her handiwork. ''I used to make beautiful things: blankets, dolls, hanger covers. You name it, I made it.''

title: 'Crazy Horse' Libel Suit Reinstated in S. Dakota
description: The State Supreme Court of South Dakota reinstated yesterday a $15-million lawsuit by Gov. William Janklow of South Dakota against the author Peter Matthiessen, Viking Penguin and several South Dakota booksellers. At issue are statements in ''The Spirit of Crazy Horse,'' a book about the American Indian Movement organization by Mr. Matthiessen.

title: ST. JOHN'S OUTPLAYS MARIST
description: Walter Berry scored 16 points and had 15 rebounds as St. John's extended its winning streak to five games with a 62-48 victory over Marist last night at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Pan-Electric Industries
description: Tan Koon Swan, a Malaysian politician and millionaire, signed an interim rescue agreement for Pan-Electric Industries, the troubled company that had triggered a crisis on the Singapore and Kuala Lumpur stock markets. Mr. Tan holds a substantial interest in the company.

title: SPIRIT OF THE SEASON IS INSPIRING DONORS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: The meaning of the holiday season and the spirit of giving to those who are less fortunate are expressed by many contributors to the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: House Approves Legislation On Self-Rule for Micronesia
description: The House of Representatives today passed by voice vote a compact that would give residents of Micronesia and the Marshall Islands control over their own affairs, except for defense.

title: GUYANA PRESIDENT SAYS HE IS VICTOR
description: President Desmond Hoyte claimed an ''overwhelming'' victory today in the elections here and said he was ''catagorically denying'' widespread charges of fraud and voter interference.

title: THE URGE TO INTERVENE
description: Look up the word ''conservative'' in the dictionary, and you find such adjectives as cautious, moderate, prudent. Now think what today's self-styled conservatives want to do with American foreign policy. You will understand how an old political tradition has been transformed into something radical and strange.

title: American Can
description: The Atalanta/Sosnoff Capital Corporation, headed by the New York investor Martin Sosnoff, said that it had increased its stake in the American Can Company from 5.4 percent, to 7.1 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

title: KENTUCKY SITE PICKED BY TOYOTA
description: Top officials of the Toyota Motor Corporation said today that they do not intend to grant advance union recognition at the assembly plant that Toyota will build about 12 miles north of here. However, they stopped short of saying they would oppose organizing efforts.

title: RYMER COMPANY reports earnings for Year to Oct 26
description: b-Including tax credits of $4,248,000 in the latest fiscal year and $3,300,000 for earlier period.

title: F.A.A. Order Grounds Commuter Aircraft
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the grounding from commercial service today of a twin-engine commuter aircraft, the Fairchild-Saab 340, because of recurrent engine failures that are believed to be linked to icing problems.

title: JETS AND BEARS SHARE RESPECT
description: The Chicago Bears are making it sound like Super Bowl XIX 1/2.

title: On the Dispute Front
description: A group of former Ambassadors has formed the International Council for Dispute Resolution and already, according to one of them, there are clients. The idea, said William J. vanden Heuvel, is not to replace lawyers but to help clients, such as countries or large companies, avoid some litigation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Travel Related Services Co., a subsidiary of the American Express Co., has named Diane Shaib senior vice president of consumer card marketing for its Payment Systems division, succeeding John Sutphen.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   A Merciful Day With Sister Elizabeth
description: A few weeks before his own death, the Rev. Vincent Pulicano, who founded Manhattan's Cabrini Hospice, said of the dying, ''They want their own bed, the bed they have been sleeping in for 30, 40, 45 years; the same pictures on the walls; to hear the same noises of children on the street, to see their loved ones.'' So, too, do the five seriously ill people Sister Elizabeth Mullane, who's with the Nursing Sisters Home Visiting Service, saw on her Brooklyn rounds one day last week. If they're in their own beds, looking at the same pictures on the walls, it's because of the home health care provided by visiting nurses like her.

title: CORRECTION
description: The ''About New York'' column yesterday, discussing cosmetic surgery, imprecisely described a conversation in the waiting room of Dr. Elliot Jacobs, a plastic surgeon, about a woman who suffered complications after a buttocks lift. The column did not intend to suggest that the operation had been performed by Dr. Jacobs.

title: OIL PRICES CLIMB AFTER TWO-DAY DESCENT
description: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products recovered somewhat yesterday from their drastic two-day plunge, and stocks of some major oil companies showed modest gains for the first time this week.

title: HAJI-SHEIKH FEELS CHILL OF INACTIVITY
description: The hours are not bad, since there is no work to be done at night.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PREPARING FOR POWER: America's Elite Boarding Schools. By Peter W. Cookson Jr. and Caroline Hodges Persell. 260 pages. Basic Books. $19.95. THE observation that inspired this book is not terribly startling. Like many other sociologists have done - professionals and amateurs alike - Peter W. Cookson Jr. and Caroline Hodges Persell noticed that when youngsters go into the elite boarding schools of America, they tend to be the children of rich and powerful parents. And when they come out of those schools, they are better prepared to take the place of those parents.

title: AIDS VIRUS INFECTS BRAIN, STUDIES SAY
description: The virus that causes AIDS can also produce meningitis, an acute infection of the membranes that line the brain and spinal cord, according to reports published yesterday.

title: CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split announced yesterday.

title: Mamma Leone's to Move
description: Part tourist attraction, part kitsch, with its excesses of decor and dining, Mamma Leone's Ristorante has been an institution in the theater district for 63 years. But it will soon be leaving its home at 239 West 48th Street.

title: 3-State House Vote On Budget Plan
description: Following were the positions of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House approved legislation to raise the national debt limit and balance the Federal budget.

title: U.S. Apologizes in Arrest Of a Chinese Student
description: The State Department expressed regret to China today because of the failure of the campus police in Berkeley, Calif., to notify the Chinese Consulate General of the arrest of a Chinese student.

title: A HOLIDAY TOUR AT DYCKMAN HOUSE
description: Two holiday events are scheduled on Sunday at the historic Dyckman House at 204th Street and Broadway in the Inwood section of Manhattan.

title: Pearlman Leaving Treasury Tax Post
description: Ronald A. Pearlman, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy, said yesterday that he would leave the department on Dec. 20 to return to private law practice in St. Louis.

title: U.S. Bill Rates Drop Sharply
description: Treasury bill rates fell sharply yesterday as short-term interest rates began to share in the euphoria of the long-term bond market where yields have fallen by nearly a percentage point since late October.

title: Shad Dubious Of Fed Plan
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the restrictions proposed by the Federal Reserve Board on using so-called junk bonds for financing hostile takeover would have little impact.

title: RUSSIAN WHO MADE NAVY A GLOBAL FORCE IS RETIRED
description: Adm. Sergei G. Gorshkov, the man responsible for building the modern Soviet Navy, has been replaced as the naval commander in chief by his chief of staff, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: STEWART IS EULOGIZED AS A JURIST OF DISTINCTION
description: Family, friends, lawyers and high officials bade an affectionate farewell today to one of Washington's best-loved men of power.

title: FERRARO BARS SENATE RACE IN '86
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro declared yesterday that she would not be a candidate for the United States Senate next year, because of a continuing Justice Department investigation of her 1978 Congressional campaign finances and subsequent financial reports as a member of the House.

title: TOLLS LIFTED, I-95'S POPULARITY GROWS
description: In the two months since the toll barriers were removed from the Connecticut Turnpike, traffic has increased by as much as one-third, state surveys show.

title: AVERY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a tax credit of $398,000 and an extraordinary gain of $468,000 on the termination of a pension plan.

title: Margaret Goldwater Dies at 76
description: Margaret (Peggy) Goldwater, wife of Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, died today at Good Samaritan Medical Center after suffering circulation problems that forced the amputation of her left leg. She was 76 years old.

title: INTERNATIONAL INFORMATION NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: No comparable year-ago results are available because the company went public in December 1984.

title: EXERCISING IN PAIRS EASES THE BOREDOM
description: THEY want earnestly to exercise, to lift weights, to work out on body-conditioning equipment, to punch and dance their way through aerobics, to run, but they won't - or can't - unless they have a partner, a buddy. For some New Yorkers, the companion provides rrthe motivation necessary to exercise regularly or makes the exercise session more palatable and less lonely. For others a companion gives the competitive edge to workouts that only a partner can provide.

title: GIFT IDEAS FOR YARD AND SILL
description: WHEN it comes to choosing gifts for garden enthusiasts, there is a surprisingly wide assortment available in the city's shops. It does not matter if the ''garden'' is a window sill, a tiny terrace, a yard or a country retreat, there are practical as well as whimsical possibilities for the green thumb, indoors and out.

title: AGENCY OF CONGRESS OPPOSES FUNDS FOR A NERVE GAS BOMB
description: The General Accounting Office said Tuesday that despite new information supplied by the Pentagon, it still took the view that a nerve gas bomb under development was beset by technical problems and that there was no need for Congress to appropriate funds for the weapon this year.

title: QUARTZ ENGINEERING & MATERIALS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $25,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $17,000 for the quarter and $52,000 for the year.

title: GUATEMALA DEMOCRATS OF THE PAST MEET THE FUTURE
description: The 83-year-old former President, probably the most popular leader this country has ever had, said he had not expected to live to see civilian rule re-established in Guatemala.

title: Odom Is Arrested
description: John (Blue Moon), the former pitcher for the Oakland A's, was arrested yesterday in Fountain Valley, Calif., for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon. The police said Odom threatened to kill his wife and held her at gunpoint with a shotgun Tuesday night in their apartment in Fountain Valley, about 35 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles.

title: Mazda Price Rise
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation will raise its 1986 car and truck prices by an average of 4.8 percent because of the continued increase in the value of the Japanese yen, the auto maker said. The price increase, announced in a statement, would begin Tuesday with cars and trucks shipped to dealers in mid-Eastern and Western states and on Jan. 1 with shipments to dealers in Eastern and Southeastern states. Imported goods are more expensive when the dollar is worth less.

title: New Grant Established For Interdisciplinary Art
description: A new arts grant, established by the National Endowment for the Arts and the Rockefeller Foundation, will be awarded annually to cultural organizations around the country that specialize in assisting artists who work in interdisciplinary fields, it was announced today by the sponsors. This year's grant, which amounts to close to $200,000, will be distributed to seven arts organizations, each of which will receive $28,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Nov. 25 from Santa Fe, N.M., about efforts to save native plants from extinction in the United States and Canada, incorrectly described Talavaya Center, a Santa Fe preservation organization. It receives no Federal aid.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: Market Place;   How to Choose A Newsletter
description: CHARLES ALLMON, publisher of the Growth Stock Outlook in Chevy Chase, Md., usually writes a stock market commentary on the front page of his twice-monthly service. But he recently sounded a warning on what he sees as a potential danger for people who might be tempted to subscribe to some investment newsletters, particularly in a period of soaring stock prices.

title: COMPUTERLAND TO GO PUBLIC IN AGREEMENT ON SUIT
description: The Computerland Corporation, the nation's largest computer retailer, will go public as part of a partial settlement of a dispute over its ownership, the parties involved said today.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Developer to Buy First Federal Stake
description: First Federal of Michigan said Jerome L. Schostak, a Detroit developer, had agreed to buy all 1.1 million of its shares owned by Craig Hall, a Dallas real estate investor, for an undisclosed amount.

title: AXELROD SEEKS TO REINSTATE CASE ON GROSS
description: The State Health Commissioner recommended yesterday that charges of professional misconduct be reinstated against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the city's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL PUTS MISSILES AT 20
description: A Nicaraguan rebel leader said this week that the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, the largest of the groups trying to overthrow the Government in Managua, had obtained ''about 20'' portable SA-7 antiaircraft missiles, which he said were purchased this year.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JETS VS. BEARS: CLASH OF PERSONALITIES
description: If a team's personality is reflected by how players see themselves, then the Jets and Bears are looking in different mirrors. Yet they have developed two of the most powerful clubs in the league, and their clash Saturday at Giants Stadium will be one of the most closely watched games this season.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE spirits of a star-studded gallery of black entertainers will arrive on Broadway next month with a musical revue called ''Uptown . . . It's Hot,'' a celebration of the contributions of artists ranging from Lena Horne, Cab Calloway, Ella Fitzgerald, Duke Ellington and Count Basie to Chuck Berry, Fats Domino, Stevie Wonder and Tina Turner.

title: 'Contras' Are on the Right Track
description: Public opinion in the United States has a passion for ''balance'' - for believing that both sides in any conflict are at fault and blaming both in equal measure. In the case of the Central American conflict, this is leading many people astray.

title: Hospital Aides Blamed In Illnesses of 26 Babies
description: Officials at a hospital where bacterial infections in the newborn intensive care unit have killed one baby and made 25 others ill say that the infections were probably spread by doctors and nurses who failed to wash their hands.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 13, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING EXPORT TO ISRAEL
description: Federal authorities are investigating the possible illegal export to Israel of plans and technology for making tank cannon barrels, Government officials said today.

title: Colombia Set To Sign Loan
description: Colombia, which has avoided the debt crisis that has gripped much of Latin America, will sign a $1 billion syndicated loan agreement next Tuesday with a group of 160 international commercial banks, Chemical Bank, chairman of the loan committee, said yesterday.

title: THE DANCE: TOBY ARMOUR
description: TOBY ARMOUR ingeniously combined dance with speech in ''Angry Minute Dance Plays'' on Tuesday night at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street. Her sketches lasted more than a minute.

title: OPERA: 'FEUERSNOT,' STRAUSS ONE-ACT
description: ''FEUERSNOT,'' Richard Strauss's second opera, is a surprisingly patchy effort by a man who would go on to compose 13 more operas, including half a dozen of the most popular in the repertory. Although he wrote this one-act piece at age 36 when he was already a mature artist renowned for his tone poems, it sounds like a young composer still thrashing about, trying to settle on his own style and purpose. ''Feuersnot,'' whose performance on Wednesday evening at the Manhattan School of Music was believed to be its New York City premiere, is nonetheless fascinating as a case study in artistic bravado and career-building.

title: Potlatch Amends Its Voting Rules
description: The Potlatch Corporation's stockholders approved an amendment to the company's bylaws that gives four votes a share to all current holders of the company's stock. Anyone buying stock after today will have one vote a share until they have held their shares for four years or longer.

title: Big Stakes in the Philippines
description: Judging only by the big print, there is hopeful news from the Philippines. President Marcos may lose the snap election he has been forced to call for Feb. 7. Hours before the filing deadline, a bickering opposition agreed to a single slate, teaming the personable but untested Corazon Aquino with the seasoned but wily Salvador Laurel.

title: A Broadway Benefit For Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center announced yesterday that it would hold a gala evening at Avery Fisher Hall on April 14 called ''Broadway Applauds Lincoln Center.'' Theater artists, a 100-voice chorus and the 60 musicians of the Broadway Symphony will offer music, dance and comedy.

title: Bowen Confirmed by Senate
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the country doctor who became a popular tax-reducing Governor of Indiana, easily won Senate confirmation today as Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: V.A. Reduces Interest Rate
description: The Government said today it would lower the maximum interest rate on federally backed Veterans Administration mortgages to 10.5 percent from 11 percent.

title: Symphony and Steel
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic will join with a Caribbean steel band, the Iscott Casablanca, in performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M. The Philharmonic will be directed by Tania Leon and the 30-member Iscott Casablanca, from Trinidad and Tobago, by G. A. (Tony) Prospect.

title: Toyota in Canada
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it would build a $400 million (Canadian) plant in Cambridge, Ontario, to make a 1.6-liter-engine type of passenger car by 1988. The plant will be the company's first car manufacturing facility in Canada and will employ about 1,000 workers when peak production of 50,000 units is achieved, Toyota said. On Wednesday, the company announced plans to invest $800 million in a car plant in Kentucky.

title: Fatal Accident in Mine Is 2d in 2 Days in Area
description: An explosion rocked a coal mine tonight, killing one miner and injuring his son-in-law.

title: BONNER PHONES SAKHAROV, BUT THE LINE IS JAMMED
description: Yelena G. Bonner reached her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, by telephone today at his place of banishment in Gorky.

title: BRADSHAW BROUGHT RCA BACK
description: For Thornton F. Bradshaw, who has led RCA for the last five years, the acquisition by the General Electric Company is a personal as well as a professional turning point. Mr. Bradshaw, who is 68 years old, said yesterday that he would retire when the deal is completed next year and become a consultant to the company.

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEW FLOOD OF IMPORTS: EUROPEAN CHEFS
description: ''You only have food where you have money,'' said Gerard Pangaud, ''and there is no more money in France. The money is here, in New York. That is why New York is becoming a world center for food.''

title: Marini Loses an Eye
description: Hector Marini, the 27-year-old right wing who was the first Devils player to be selected to the National Hockey League All-Star Team, lost his left eye in surgery Tuesday at the Midwest Eye Institute at Indianapolis Methodist Hospital. The eye was stuck by a shot from a teammate of Marini's as they played Dec. 5 for the Fort Wayne Komets, a Devils farm team in the International Hockey League, against the Indianapolis Checkers. The team physician for the Checkers, Dr. Joseph Randolph, said Dr. Stephen Johnson removed the eye because Marini had lost all sight in it.

title: BUSINES DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1985
description: Companies G.E. said it could take a year to complete its merger with RCA. The comment sent RCA shares skidding by $4.25 a share, to $59.25, well below the $66.50 offering price. Trading was extremely heavy as investors, unwilling to tie up their money that long, sold the stock. G.E. said it would take time to arrange $4 billion or more of financing and to get regulatory approvals for the merger. [Page D10.] Grant Tinker, the head of NBC, said the resources of the merged company could speed the network's progress, including the possible development of a 24-hour cable news operation. [D10.] The Big Board is investigating trading in RCA and G.E. stocks before the merger was announced. [D11.] It took just 36 days h for G.E. and RCA to forge their multibillion-dollar merger, beginning with a meeting of the chairmen of G.E. and RCA at the Upper East Side apartment of Felix Rohatyn. [A1.] GAF sweetened the terms of its bid for Union Carbide by offering $68 a share in cash for all outstanding shares and by no longer requiring that Carbide's board approve the deal. [D1.] Oppenheimer & Company officers are discussing buying the investment banking and brokerage house back from Mercantile Holdings of London, according to sources close to both companies. [D1.] Nippon Oil delayed plans to explore some Texaco oilfields because of Texaco's legal battle with Pennzoil. The action symbolized the concern felt by Texaco's lenders, suppliers and partners.

title: The Deck-the-Hill Gang
description: At the 1981 Christmas party of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, a group of staff members for Senator Charles H. Percy, then the chairman, performed a series of satirical political songs they had adapted to familiar tunes. The theatrical octet that evolved from this casual beginning, the Capitol Steps, will celebrate its fourth anniversary tomorrow in performance at the Bread Oven, a Pennsylvania Avenue restaurant where the group has been appearing recently.

title: Mack Trucks Chairman
description: John B. Curcio, 51-year-old president and chief executive officer of Mack Trucks Inc., was elected yesterday to the additional position of chairman. He succeeds Alfred W. Pelletier, 64, who is retiring.

title: Princeton Revue
description: ''No. 96 Untitled,'' a musical-comedy revue, will be presented by the Triangle Club of Princeton University tonight at 8 at Hunter College, Lexington Avenue and 68th Street.

title: G.E.'S DEMANDING CHAIRMAN
description: In four years as the chairman of the General Electric Company, John F. Welch Jr. has become known simultaneously as one of the nation's toughest executives, as an intellectually astute manager and as a man more inclined to demand action immediately than wait for a second opinion.

title: Odetta at Festival
description: A festival of crafts and music, featuring the folksinger Odetta, will take place this weekend and next at Martin Luther King Jr.

title: 46 COMMUNITY GARDENS WIN PARNIS HONORS
description: A trellis surrounded by a variety of fruit trees and flower and vegetable gardens now graces a lot that was once a garbage dump and a haven for drug addicts.

title: 'Terrorist' as a Name for a Weaker Political Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleveland Orchestra
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi will lead the Cleveland Orchestra in two concerts at Carnegie Hall this weekend.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
King's Cousin Fined in Spain
description: A Spanish court gave the Duke of Cadiz, Alfonso de Borbon, cousin of King Juan Carlos, a suspended six-month jail sentence today for negligence in a car accident in which his 11-year-old son died. Court officials said the Duke was stripped of his driver's license for one year and ordered to pay compensation to his former wife and his other son, Luis Alfonso, who was seriously injured in the 1984 crash.

title: ...OTTAWA'S BARGAINER IS READY FOR AMERICANS
description: Sol Simon Reisman, 66, who will lead Canada's trade talks with the United States next spring, has more than 30 years' experience as an Ottawa bureaucrat and a reputation as a tough, no-nonsense negotiater.

title: Cauthen Treated
description: Steve Cauthen, the jockey who in 1977 won 487 races at the age of 17, is completing a three-week program at a Cincinnati hospital for alcohol dependency. His father, George (Tex) Cauthen, said his son quit drinking about three months ago. Cauthen returned to his hometown of Walton, Ky., near Cincinnati, last month from England, where he has been racing in recent years.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS DISMISSED OF MICHIGAN MEDICAL STUDENT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that it was constitutional for the University of Michigan to dismiss a medical student without giving him a second chance to pass an important examination.

title: INSTEAD OF THE BAND AND BANNERS, ALL-NIGHT CHAPELS AT FT. CAMPBELL
description: The banners had been hung in the post gymnasium and the division band was prepared to play at a ceremony welcoming 250 members of the 101st Airborne back from almost six months in Sinai.

title: U.S. TO SELL PETROLEUM LEASES OFF ALASKA IN '86
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel announced today that he would conduct a sale of offshore oil and gas leases next month for Alaska's Bristol Bay, one of the world's richest fisheries and spawning grounds.

title: FILM: 'ONLY EMPTINESS,' THE ARGENTINE MISSING
description: MARTA FRANCESE DE BETTINI is not the kind of woman to be intimidated by the film crew that's come into her richly furnished Madrid apartment to interview her. Dressed in what appears to be a simple, extremely expensive couture suit, with some appropriately understated jewelry, she has the mien and bearing of an aristocrat. She could be the subject of a Town & Country article on how the Old Manners are surviving in the ''new'' Spain.

title: The Ambassadorship Bout
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is embroiled in another round of the never-ending bout between the White House and Foggy Bottom over ambassadorships. He would like President Reagan to reassign Reginald Bartholomew, who has been Ambassador to Lebanon for more than two years now, as Ambassador to Turkey.

title: Keep Staten Island a Home Where Wild Pheasants Can Roam
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the pressure on Texaco Inc. to seek an out-of-court settlement with the Pennzoil Company incorrectly described Texaco's ability to pay a large bill from Saudi Arabia. The company has adequate funds to make the payment.

title: SCREEN: 'CLUE,' FROM GAME TO FILM
description: LIKE the board game on which it is based, the movie ''Clue'' is most fun in its early stages.

title: 20 Cars Vandalized In Westchester
description: More than 20 automobiles were vandalized early Wednesday in a raid on a neighborhood here, the police said today. It was the third attack of vandalism within several blocks over the last five weeks.

title: ALLENDE WIDOW STARTS U.S. TOUR
description: Hortensia de Allende, the widow of the Chilean President who died in a 1973 coup, began a speaking tour here today after being allowed to come to the United States despite initial Government objections.

title: Guitar at Neither/Nor
description: The electric guitarist Sonny Sharrock will lead his jazz quartet tomorrow, with sets at 10 P.M. and midnight, at Neither/Nor, 703 East Sixth Street (475-5758). Tickets are $5.

title: Drinking, Driving And Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Max Lovell, Lawyer Who Held Key Posts in Amateur Sports
description: Max J. Lovell, a Manhattan lawyer who was long associated with collegiate sports and Olympic activities, died Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: ART: PASSION OF PICASSO, AT BEADLESTON GALLERY
description: AMONG the many, many little-known or previously unknown works of art that have been set before us since a substantial part of the Picasso estate was distributed among the artist's heirs, the most consistently rewarding to date have been those from the holdings of Picasso's granddaughter Marina.

title: NETS NEVER TRAIL IN BEATING KNICKS
description: Micheal Ray Richardson may have expressed the Knicks' plight best last night after he helped the Nets rout them, 108-85, in Madison Square Garden.

title: ANNE BAXTER IS DEAD AT 62; ACTRESS WON OSCAR IN 1946
description: Anne Baxter, the Academy Award-winning actress widely known for her role as the scheming, social-climbing young actress Eve Harrington in the movie ''All About Eve,'' died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital, where she had been taken Dec. 4 after suffering a stroke. She was 62 years old and lived in Easton, Conn., and in West Hollywood, Calif.

title: PAGEANTS, JAZZ, PUPPETS AND OTHER PRESENTATIONS
description: Today American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 81st Street. ''The Star of Christmas'' show, illustrating how the sky above Bethlehem appeared on the day of Jesus' birth. Admission: $3, adults; $2, children. Through Jan. 1. Information on show times: 873-8828.

title: SMUGGLER WITNESS SAYS HE KEPT CASH
description: The key witness in a Federal trial charging alien smuggling testified today that the Government allowed him to keep $1,500 given to him by professional smugglers in unrelated cases in 1983.

title: Will A.M.A. Act on Liquor Ads?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Unwanted Street Scenes Hansom Mayhem
description: To see a hansom cab marooned in Manhattan's legendary traffic is to suffer for the horse. To be driving in that legendary traffic, and to have to maneuver around a 19th-century holdover as well as cars and pedestrians is to suffer - period. Early last Sunday night a car and a horse finally crossed paths in midtown New York.

title: Roy Cohn's Too-Special Case
description: For many months Roy Cohn, a New York lawyer long associated with controversy, argued that judges and lawyers were making him the special target of spurious charges of misconduct. Now his case has indeed become special.

title: AT JUNIOR HIGH, ATTEMPT TO DEAL WITH SHOOTINGS
description: As Portland Junior High School reopened today, students and teachers struggled to come to terms with the shootings Tuesday in which an eighth grader killed a custodian.

title: OFFICIALS ARE WARY ON THE CAUSE OF THE CRASH
description: Officials declined tonight to say whether the DC-8 jetliner that crashed here with 250 American soldiers and 8 crew members this morning had undergone de-icing before taking off in a freezing drizzle.

title: C.G.E. Talks Stop
description: The French Government has called off talks between one of its state-owned companies and the Swedish company L. M. Ericsson until it decides whether to go ahead with a deal involving the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Industry and Trade Minister, Edith Cresson, said. Speaking to reporters, the minister said the Government had given ''the green light'' to state-owned Compagnie Generale d'Electricite to negotiate further with A.T.&T. and repeated her desire to see the initial deal improved.

title: Mississippi Queen In Collision With Tug
description: The steamer Mississippi Queen collided with a tugboat at dusk today and was run aground to keep from sinking, but no injuries were reported among the stern-wheeler's 431 passengers and crew, officials said.

title: Hot Streaks
description: The San Francisco 49ers' collapse in the final minutes was not the only rare occurrence in the game last Monday night. When the Los Angeles Rams blocked an extra-point attempt, they ended a string of 150 point-after conversions by Ray Wersching, the ninth-longest such streak in A.F.L./N.F.L. history. The top 10: Tommy Davis (1959-65)234 Jim Turner (1967-74)221 George Blanda (1967-71)201 Fred Cox (1968-74)199 Bruce Gossett (1965-70)171 George Blanda (1951-56)156 Jan Stenerud (1968-73)155 Mike Clark (1965-69)151 Ray Wersching (1982-85)150 Tom Brooker (1962-65)149

title: Israeli Films
description: Screenings of ''A Lens on Israel'' will open a film series on Sunday at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: Mapco Buys Stock
description: Mapco Inc., an oil and gas company, said it had bought about 6.5 million shares of its common stock for about $304.3 million in cash, or $44 a share, from Peter Kiewit Sons Inc., the Omaha-based construction and natural resources company. It said the repurchase represents about 24.5 percent of the 28.2 million shares outstanding. The company said its action in reducing the number of shares outstanding would result in improved future per-share earnings ''in the range of 15 to 20 percent.''

title: G.I.'S KEPT WATCH IN SINAI
description: The 250 American soldiers killed in the plane crash in Newfoundland today were members of an international peacekeeping force deployed in Sinai in 1982, after Egypt made peace with Israel.

title: HANDEL'S 'MESSIAH' AND OTHER CHRISTMAS ORATORIOS
description: Tomorrow Bruno Walter Auditorium, New York Public Library, Lincoln Center. Bach's ''Magnificat'' and Cantata No. 140; Riverdale Chorale Society. At 2 P.M. Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Staged production of Schutz's oratorio ''Christmas Story''; the Grande Bande of New York, Early Music Foundation's BoyQuireand members of the Court Dance Company of New York; Frederick Renz, director. At 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $10 and $15. Information: 749-6600 or 977-9020.

title: Claude E. Boillot Dies; Suez Canal Co. Official
description: Claude E. Boillot, former United States representative of the Suez Canal Company, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS: 'MESSIAH,' AND MORE
description: IT used to be that music in New York around Christmastime amounted to a ''Messiah'' or two, plus various events - mostly carols and the like - in the churches.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $141,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TAKEOVER ISSUES CLIMB
description: The stock market ended mostly higher yesterday, bolstered by sharp gains in some rumored takeover targets.

title: Man Shoots an Officer Before Killing Himself
description: A man with a gun barricaded himself in an apartment on the West Side yesterday and, when the police arrived, shot an officer in the hand through the door. Six hours later, the police broke in and found the man dead, apparently of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

title: YANKEES GET BURNS IN TRADE FOR COWLEY AND HASSEY
description: The Yankees and the Chicago White Sox, after prolonged talks, finally consummated a deal today, but it did not include Don Baylor. The Yankees, however, did acquire Britt Burns, the left-handed pitcher they had been seeking for two months.

title: U.S. Embassy in Soviet To Cut Russian Staff
description: The State Department said today that Americans would replace substantial numbers of Soviet citizens working at the United States Embassy in Moscow.

title: Land Mine Wounds South African Soldier
description: A South African troop carrier struck a land mine today near the border with Zimbabwe. A soldier was slightly wounded in the explosion, the sixth such blast in two weeks.

title: LTV Plant Ruling
description: The Justice Department reversed itself today and said it would accept an employee buyout of the LTV Corporation's steel plant in Gadsden, Ala.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ART: 'STRUCTURES,' EXHIBITION AT WHITE COLUMNS
description: ''STRUCTURES'' is an indication of the continuing value of alternative spaces. The exhibition - at White Columns, 325 Spring Street, through Jan. 4 - reflects the current artistic interest in pictorial and sculptural constructions. Although the painted reliefs by Steven Diamond and the painted freestanding sculptures by James Cole and Joanne Lowenthal may not be fully mature, each of the artists - as well as Tom Fellner, whose paintings are on exhibit in the gallery's White Room - is thoughtful and serious.

title: U.S. Demands Eviction At Washington Shelter
description: Federal guards posted eviction notices today at an abandoned Government building occupied as a shelter by hundreds of homeless people.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Panel Approves Nomination Of C.I.A. Aide to U.S. Bench
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Stanley Sporkin, general counsel to the Central Intelligence Agency, to be a Federal district judge here.

title: NATO WILL SHARE SOME ARMS WORK
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization, in an effort to cut defense costs, announced formal agreement today on a plan for cooperation in development of new conventional weapons systems.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IF you fear that Italian food in New York is becoming a bit precious, what with all those cute Frisbee-sized pizzas, pastel raviolis and vegetables in every color of the spectrum except green, then you might want to venture to the Williamsburg-Greenpoint section of Brooklyn to visit Crisci's - ''A Tradition Since 1902.''

title: Keep Staten Island a Home Where Wild Pheasants Can Roam
description: To the Editor:

title: LUXURY HOUSING IS BUILT ON RIM OF GARMENT AREA
description: A large condominium tower is rising on the easterly blockfront of the Avenue of the Americas between 36th and 37th Streets, just north of Herald Square and Macy's and on the eastern fringe of the garment district. It is a location where no developer has ever tried to sell expensive apartments before, and it is a prime example of a relatively new phenomenon in the New York housing market.

title: COOPER LASERSONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring pre-tax gain of $5,442,000 for the quarter and year on the licensing of a product line. c-Net loss.

title: Newman at West End
description: The saxophonist David (Fathead) Newman will lead a quintet featuring Curtis Fuller on trombone, tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9:30, and 11 P.M. and 12:30 and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: FUTURE FOR BUDGET LAW: A POLITICAL BALANCING ACT
description: In enacting a law requiring the elimination of Federal budget deficits over a period of five years, Congress and President Reagan may have found a solution to the nation's economic conundrum of the 1980's. Budget deficits are widely blamed for much of what ails both the American and world economies, from the jobs lost in American factories to the debts of Argentina.

title: Dining Out Guide: Brunch
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE LUXEMBOURG, #200 West 70th Street (873-7411) -

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Gunmen Rob French Train
description: Masked gunmen stopped a mail train near here today and took 91 sacks of coins worth the equivalent of $100,000 belonging to the Bank of France, the police said.

title: RETAIL SALES UP IN NOVEMBER
description: Retail sales rebounded in November from their record decline the month before, but the modest 1.1 percent increase still left many analysts questioning just how good a Christmas season merchants could expect this year.

title: 'MY COUSIN RACHEL,' ON THE 'MYSTERY!' SERIES
description: When selected for the Grand Masters Award by the Mystery Writers of America, Daphne du Maurier cautioned in her acceptance letter: ''Do remember that I am not a crime writer in the true sense of the word.'' What she meant becomes obvious when considering ''My Cousin Rachel,'' a novel that she quite accurately described as ''a study in jealousy and not in crime.'' That work, like her ''Rebecca,'' was made into a movie - in 1952. That version starred Olivia de Havilland and Richard Burton. Now, a four-part British adaptation has been acquired for the public television series ''Mystery!'' The first two episodes can be seen beginning tonight on some public television stations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday THE SOUNDS OF SPAIN He is known only as Sabicas, but when he plays guitar he is known as a master of flamenco, the tremulous, darting music of the Spanish gypsies. Tonight, Sabicas offers one of his rare New York performances, at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, where he gave the first solo flamenco guitar recital in the United States 37 years ago. Since then, he has played in concert halls around the world and recorded more than 50 albums. Although Sabicas, who is 68 years old, lives in New York City, he has not given a concert here in more than two years. Tickets are $11.50 and $14.50. Information: 362-0290.

title: 258 ON U.S. TROOP FLIGHT DIE AS PLANE CRASHES IN GANDER ON WAY HOME FROM MIDEAST
description: A chartered jetliner crashed on takeoff at the international airport here today, killing all 258 people reported aboard, all but eight of them American soldiers headed home for Christmas.

title: Ruland Out 6 Weeks
description: Jeff Ruland, the Washington Bullets' center, suffered a broken ankle Wednesday against the Pistons and will be sidelined six weeks. . . . Dennis Johnson, the Celtics' guard, has a hyperextended left thumb, and will sit out tomorrow's game at Cleveland. . . . Alvan Adams, the forward for the Suns, suffered a torn calf muscle against the Warriors and will be sidelined a week. . . . Walter Davis, the Phoenix Suns' leading scorer, missed last night's game against the Lakers at Los Angeles because of ''personal problems,'' a team spokesman, Tom Ambrose, announced. Davis was ''in the hands of league counselors,'' Ambrose said. . . . Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, who has been sidelined since October with a broken foot, will remain in a cast an additional two weeks.An examination revealed the bone in the left foot had not healed yet, said Dr. John Hefferon, the team's physician.

title: TINKER, NBC'S CHAIRMAN, 'DELIGHTED' WITH MERGER
description: Grant Tinker, the chairman of NBC and the man credited with engineering NBC's current ratings success, said yesterday that he was ''delighted'' by the proposed merger of NBC's parent company, RCA, and the General Electric Company.

title: OPPENHEIMER'S OFFICERS SAID TO DISCUSS BUYOUT
description: Oppenheimer & Company, investment bankers and brokers, is expected to announce as early as today that discussions are under way with its parent, Mercantile Holdings Ltd., London, concerning the purchase of Oppenheimer by its officers, according to sources close to both companies.

title: KOCH PICKS A SUPPORTER FOR CHIEF HOUSING POST
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named Emanuel P. Popolizio, a former city housing official and a longtime political ally, to be the chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

title: FOR TRADE EXPERT, CANADIANS NEXT...
description: The man who will head an American negotiating team in high-stakes trade talks with Canada next spring has already tackled some of the thorniest issues in the realm of international commerce.

title: G.E. SAYS MERGER MAY TAKE A YEAR
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it could take as long as a year to complete its merger with the RCA Corporation. The comment sent RCA shares plummeting in tumultuous trading on the New York Stock Exchange, as investors evidently chose to cash in their RCA holdings now.

title: Noise Is a Hazardous Waste of Air Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   A.& G. Parting Ways With Sun Banks Client
description: Ally & Gargano, a publicly held company, announced yesterday that it and its Sun Banks of Florida client, based in Orlando, had agreed to go their separate ways.

title: No Comment on Talks
description: The American Embassy and Israeli Government spokesmen refused today to give any details on the interviews of Israelis in the Pollard case, the nature of the discussions or the Israeli individuals involved.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Living Section on Wednesday describing a culinary gift for Christmas misidentified the tea kettle shown. It costs $29.95 and is available in red, black or white at all Conran's stores.

title: 8.374% Top Yield For M.A.C. Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation of the City of New York is offering $123.7 million of bonds with a maximum yield 8.374 percent for securities due in 2008, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: New Squad
description: A few weeks ago, the management of the Chicago Bears decided that ''the concept of cheerleading has outlived its time'' and that this year would therefore be the final one for the Honey Bears, 38 young women who have performed at Soldier Field for the last eight seasons. The Bears' play this fall may have contributed to a judgment that they no longer needed help from the sidelines, but there was at least one indication that their fans disagreed: In a local radio poll, listeners voted by a margin of 3 to 1 that the cheerleaders should stay.

title: CUOMO SETS OWN STUDY OF HOMELESS
description: Governor Cuomo ordered inspectors sent to New York City today to look into charges that families with children were being forced to spend the night in welfare offices.

title: Cardinal Prepares Document About Theology of Liberation
description: Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, head of the Vatican watchdog body on Roman Catholic faith and morals, said today that his department was preparing a new document on the theology of liberation.

title: Burford Trial Postponed
description: The trial of Anne McGill Burford on charges of public drunkenness was postponed for a second time today. Her lawyer said the new date for Mrs. Burford, former chief of the Environmental Protection Agency, was Feb. 7. She had been scheduled to appear Friday. Mrs. Burford was arrested at the Arlington County Jail on charges of being drunk and disorderly after her husband was taken there on drunken driving charges.

title: USE OF VACCINE IS URGED TO CURB HEPATITIS PERIL
description: New York's public school staff members who supervise mentally retarded children carrying the hepatitis B virus face a small increased risk of infection with the disease agent, according to a new study.

title: PLOVER IS DECLARED AN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: The piping plover, a shore bird once common on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and along the Great Lakes, has been declared an endangered and threatened species by the Federal Government.

title: Wallace Looks to a 5th Term
description: Governor George C. Wallace said tonight that he was very interested in seeking a fifth term in 1986.

title: Football Player Dies
description: Rob McIntyre, a 22-year-old senior defensive tackle at Indiana State, died Wednesday at the university's medical center in Terre Haute from a pulmonary hemorrhage while undergoing exploratory surgery after a weeklong illness, a university spokesman, Tom James, said. McIntyre's illness appeared to be pneumonia, doctors said.

title: Urban Group's New Head
description: The New York Urban Coalition got a new chairman yesterday - Dr. Stephen R. Aiello, chairman of the City Youth Bureau, former president of the Board of Education and senior vice president of Burston-Marsteller, the public-relations concern.

title: Unavoidable Runaway
description: He's not the first basketball coach whose urgings from the bench went unheeded by his team, but Jim Dismuke wants everybody to know he tried his best. Dismuke, the coach of the girls' team at St. Mary's High School in Medford, Ore., says he did everything he could in a game against Rogue River High on Tuesday night, but nothing seemed to work. ''I kept telling them to 'back off, back off,' '' he says.

title: Naumburg Prize Given In Clarinet Competition
description: The Walter W. Naumburg Clarinet Competition - billed as the first major competition in the United States for that instrument - was won yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall by Charles Neidich.

title: PIANO: BORIS BERMAN RECITAL
description: IT'S hard to think of two more dissimilar composers than Shostakovich and Brahms. The smirking irony we find in much of the Russian composer's music is antithetical to the formal, intensely serious, musical world of Brahms.

title: Malta Charges Suspect In Airliner Hijacking
description: The only surviving suspect in the hijacking of the Egyptair Boeing 737 forced to Malta last month was formally charged today with 16 counts of hijacking, murder and assault.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The line between video cassettes and movie theaters will blur a little more next month when CBS-Fox Video begins a $2 million advertising campaign for its cassette of ''Return of the Jedi,'' almost certain to be the largest marketing campaign in the short history of home video.

title: Promotion Plan Seen at A.M.C.
description: The American Motors Corporation is preparing to promote its top officers, according to A.M.C. officials who spoke on the condition that they not be named.

title: 'CASTOFFS' ARE GETTING RESPECT
description: It has become almost a cliche for a team to see itself as a band of walk-ons, someone else's rejects.

title: Fire Guts a Calcutta Market
description: Troops were called in today to help put out a fire that swept through Calcutta's oldest market, destroying about 250 shops.

title: THEATER: 'HAY FEVER,' NOEL COWARD COMEDY
description: IN the unlikely event that you stop laughing and start thinking at the sparkling new Broadway revival of ''Hay Fever,'' you may notice that Noel Coward's comedy has skin-deep characters, little plot, no emotional weight or redeeming social value and very few lines that sound funny out of context. All of which goes to show that some plays defy the laws of theatrical gravity. In this now 60-year-old jape, Coward demonstrates that pure fluff also rises: ''Hay Fever'' is a classic spun out of the thinnest and most dizzying of air.

title: AFTER ALL HOPE IS GONE, THE SEARCH GOES ON
description: Even after any rational expectations of finding survivors had been given up, the search continued into the night.

title: AQUINO VOWS JUSTICE FOR VICTIMS
description: Corazon Aquino vowed today, on her first presidential campaign tour, to obtain justice for her slain husband and ''all the victims'' of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Tens of thousands of Filipinos cheered her.

title: CONSUMERS' AIDE BACKED IN SENATE
description: The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation voted 9 to 7 today to approve the nomination of Terrence M. Scanlon as chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Unicef Says It Is Saving A Million Lives a Year
description: Unicef says in its annual report that its efforts to improve health care for children are saving more than a million lives a year.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $47,000 for the latest quarter and $3,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: LAWMAKERS CHALLENGE SCOPE OF BUDGET MEASURE
description: The legislation President Reagan signed today requiring a balanced Federal budget within five years shifts power toward the executive branch and away from the legislative branch, according to lawmakers from both parties.

title: Eisenhower Saw It As the Lesser Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitworth Pleads Not Guilty To 4 New Espionage Charges
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy chief petty officer, pleaded not guilty today to four new espionage charges based on information believed to have been supplied by his former Navy friend, John A. Walker Jr., who has confessed to being a spy.

title: 3 YEARS IN OFFICE, BANGLADESH RULER SEEKS MANDATE
description: Nearly three years after seizing power in a coup, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad has yet to succeed in arranging an election to legitimize his rule, according to politicians and diplomats here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have suffered a tragic loss that will be everlasting, and our hearts go out to the families and loved ones of these soldiers.'' - Maj. Gen. Burton P. Patrick, commander of the 101st Airborne Division. [A1:4.]

title: Bridge: Several Computer Programs Able to Bid, Play and Defend
description: While computers have become sophisticated chess players, teaching them to play bridge seems to be more difficult.

title: JUSTICE INVESTMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to give effect to a 10 percent stock dividend in September 1985.

title: STUDY FINDS HEART ATTACK RISKS EASE RAPIDLY AFTER SMOKER QUITS
description: Smokers' unusually high risk of heart attacks eases rapidly when they quit, a new study has found, and the risk almost disappears if they stay away from cigarettes for two years.

title: Bernard King To Meet Press
description: Bernard King, who has been under a self-imposed silence since March 23, when he suffered torn ligaments in his right knee in a game against the Kings in Kansas City, Mo., has called a news conference for Monday at 11 A.M. at Madison Square Garden.

title: Winter Storm Hits Texas And Threatens Midwest
description: Ice-coated roads in Texas yesterday caused scores of traffic accidents and forced school closings as a storm swept out of the southern Rockies on a path that curved northward toward the lower Middle West.

title: SOME CONTRIBUTORS PUT ASIDE OWN ILLS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Many people who are disabled or ill but feel more fortunate than others this holiday season are among the contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: PARADYNE IS INDICTED ON CONSPIRACY CHARGES
description: The Paradyne Corporation, eight current and former executives and a former official of the Social Security Administration were indicted today on charges of conspiring to defraud Social Security in an $84 million computer contract.

title: Advertising;   McCann's Newest Operation
description: A SPECIAL kind of agency-within-an-agency has been established by Robert L. James, chairman and chief executive of McCann-Erickson. The new unit, named Ira Madris, Bruce Nelson & Colleagues, for reasons that will soon become obvious, may appear at first to be just another creative boutique, of which the woods are full. This, however, is not the case. Instead of a pyramid-stacked management typical of most of today's companies and ad agencies, the Madris-Nelson operation will be laid out horizontally with top-level creative teams all working directly with the very top managements of very special client companies.

title: Fire Ruins House of Blacks Who Were Targets of Protest
description: Fire broke out tonight in a home formerly occupied by a black couple who were targets of protests by whites three weeks ago, the authorities said.

title: U.N. RELIEF AGENCY IN A FISCAL PLIGHT
description: The new director of a United Nations agency providing care for nearly two million Palestinian refugees has warned that his agency faces the worst financial crisis of its history and that further cutbacks in services will bring increased instability in the Middle East.

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL ON BUDGET BILL
description: Here is the roll-call vote of 271 to 154 by which the House of Representatives approved legislation Wednesday aimed at balancing Federal budgets by the fiscal year 1991 and raising the national debt limit to more than $2 trillion. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the legislation. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 118 Democrats and 153 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 130 Democrats and 24 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are no vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Biotechnica Diagnostics, Cambridge, Mass., a subsidiary of Biotechnica International Inc., has named Richard L. Dalton president.

title: MICHIGAN'S RELLFORD PACES EASY VICTORY
description: Richard Rellford scored 17 points, and Antoine Joubert had 14 tonight as unbeaten Michigan defeated Central Michigan, 82-61.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: GAF OFFERS CASH FOR ALL OF CARBIDE
description: The GAF Corporation yesterday sweetened the terms of its bid to take over the troubled Union Carbide Corporation by offering to pay $68 in cash for all outstanding shares without approval of Carbide's board.

title: Jefferies Group Officer to Quit
description: Ronald A. Alghini, president and chief operating officer of the Jefferies Group and Jefferies & Company, its main subsidiary, said he would resign from both companies effective Jan. 2 to pursue other business interests.

title: Cause of Gas Leak Sought at A-Plant
description: Officials of the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant in southern New Jersey said yesterday that they were inspecting the plant's filtration system to determine how radioactive gases had leaked into a building during a power failure on Wednesday. The leak exposed 24 workers to small amounts of the gases.

title: City in Georgia Cancels Parade to Keep Klan Out
description: The City Council has voted to cancel Friday's Christmas parade rather than allow the Ku Klux Klan to participate. City officials had said earlier that they could not turn down the Klan's request to enter a float because the group met all legal requirements.

title: Judge Says Government Withholds Torture Data
description: A Federal judge hearing a lawsuit on behalf of illegal Salvadoran aliens today accused Government lawyers of withholding details of torture and killings in the Central American country.

title: AUBURN, TARGET OF COURT WRATH, SAYS IT'S TRYING TO DESEGREGATE
description: Last Saturday, the same day that a Federal district judge declared that Auburn University was the most racially segregated school in Alabama, crowds of students, black and white, gathered at the edge of campus here, spilling into the streets.

title: Iran Conditionally Backs U.N. Meeting on War
description: Said Rajaie-Khorassani, the Iranian delegate, said today that he would attend a Security Council meeting on the Iran-Iraq war if the Council were to adopt the position voiced by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations.

title: Advertising;   New Leader for ABC's Consumer Magazines
description: James A. Casella, 37 years old, has been named president of ABC Consumer Magazines, one of 10 operating divisions of ABC Publishing.

title: A TEXACO DEAL HALTED BY NIPPON
description: The Nippon Oil Company said yesterday that it would delay a planned exploration of some of Texaco Inc.'s United States oilfields until Texaco's legal battle with the Pennzoil Company was resolved.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL AMERICAN LEAGUE - Appointed Peter Bavasi, the president of the Cleveland Indians, to baseball's executive council. Named Marty Springstead chief supervisor of umpires for the league.

title: CANDIDATES STUDY RACE IN SAN DIEGO
description: The resignation of Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego leaves the biggest state's second-largest city with a field of possible successors.

title: Q&A: Dr. C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General;   Of Strong Prescriptions
description: In voting to seek a ban on cigarette advertising this week, the American Medical Association echoed a call made a year ago by Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States.

title: ART: ROY LICHTENSTEIN AND HIS IRONY WITHIN IRONY
description: ROY LICHTENSTEIN'S career as an ironist seems to have begun inadvertently with his World War II service in the Army, which he entered as a private and emerged from, three years later, as a private first class. It may also include his phases in the 1950's, first as a painter of Wild West scenes and later as an Abstract Expressionist. But there's no question that the career took flight in 1962, when the artist first displayed his comic strip paintings, or that it remains airborne today, some 70 solo shows later, not to mention countless appearances in groups.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $3,514,000 resulting from a 20 percent reduction in the company's workforce and a writeoff of selected equipment and inventory. c-Net income after net from discontinued operations of $70,000 for the quarter and $722,000 for the year. d-After a gain of $3,055,000 on the sale of an investment in Applied Solar Energy Corp.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Indiana Pacers vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Indianapolis. Tuesday night, the Pacers were limited to 64 points in a loss to the Knicks, the fourth-lowest total since introduction of the shot clock in the 1954-55 season.

title: A CALENDAR OF MUSIC FOR THE CHRISTMAS SEASON
description: Following is a selection of the musical presentations planned for the Christmas season in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. Today Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West 57th Street. Buxtehude's ''Neugeboren Kinderlein'' and Saint-Saens's Christmas Oratorio; Paul Liljestrand, organist and choirmaster. At 7:30 P.M. Information: 975-0170. Helmsley Palace Hotel, 455 Madison Avenue, at 50th Street. International carols; John Motley Singers. At noon.

title: CONDEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to July 31
HUSBAND HELD IN STABBING DEATHS OF WIFE AND 3 DAUGHTERS IN JERSEY
description: A woman and her three young daughters were found stabbed to death in their home here today and authorities charged the woman's husband with the killings.

title: CONFEREES WOULD GIVE TAXPAYERS A BRAEK ON SUGAR
description: House and Senate negotiators reached a tentative compromise today on income supports for farmers growing wheat, corn and feed grain, but they were unable to agree on other key provisions of the 1985 farm bill.

title: U.S. SAID TO LIMIT INFORMATION FLOW TO ISRAEL AGENCIES
description: A senior Defense Department official said today that the United States had reduced its sharing of intelligence information with Israel since Jonathan Jay Pollard, an American Navy analyst, was arrested Nov. 21 on charges of espionage.

title: FOR FAMILY SHELTERS, ONE-ROOM SCHOOLS
description: The homeless children in the city's family shelters spend their days in one room, and now, many of them learn in one room as well.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FDR: THE NEW YORK YEARS 1928-1933.

title: JERSEY PUBLIC BROADCASTING CHIEF RESIGNS, CHARGING BOARD PRESSURE
description: The executive director of the New Jersey Public Broadcasting Authority resigned today amid charges that the Kean administration had become unhappy with the network's news coverage and had pressured the authority to remove him.

title: IN PARIS, A TASTE FOR 'TEX-MEX' AND 'CHIENS CHAUDS'
description: The honor just paid to an American restaurant in Paris reflects the growing popularity in France of American food and the proliferation of American-style restaurants here. Throughout Paris, young French people are lining up for ''les hamburgers,'' ''les chiens chauds'' (hot dogs) and a wide variety of other American dishes.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHEN Maxwell's Plum opened in 1965, its flamboyant Art Nouveau decor and buoyant bar scene represented the apotheosis of that much-maligned yet much-frequented institution known as the singles bar. The food had its ups and downs, yet no one made much of a fuss - most patrons really came to graze in its verdant social pasture.

title: David Murray Quartet
description: The tenor saxophonist David Murray and his quartet - John Hicks on piano, Fred Hopkins on bass, Ed Blackwell on drums - is performing tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: BINGO ISSUE PITS CREEK INDIANS AGAINST OKLAHOMA
description: The proud and ancient Creek Indian Nation, which once owned millions of acres in Oklahoma, is making a 20th-century stand against the white man on a sand bar along the banks of the Arkansas River near downtown Tulsa.

title: 3 STRAINS OF FLU ARE CIRCULATING THROUGH NATION
description: With the onset of colder weather, all three strains of influenza that caused the flu in the past now are circulating in the United States, the national Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Unwanted Street Scenes Prezlock
description: On his last visit to New York, President Reagan brought rush-hour traffic in Manhattan to its knees. The new version of gridlock was called ''Prezlock.''

title: THERE'S A WHOLE WORLD OF DANCE DOWN THERE BELOW 23D ST.
description: THE New York City Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker'' is now installed at the New York State Theater. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is doing its own celebrating a few blocks away at City Center. And Anna Sokolow and her glowing Players' Project company are performing uptown at the Theater of the Riverside Church. But dancegoers do not have to go north of 23d Street to enjoy a rich panoply of dance this weekend, because new, provocative and exhilarating works will be performed all over downtown New York.

title: THE STAGE: A REVIVAL OF HELLMAN'S 'FOREST'
description: LILLIAN HELLMAN wrote ''Another Part of the Forest'' in 1946 to explain how the Hubbard clan, as mean a bunch as ever inhabited the Gothic South, got to where we found them in ''The Little Foxes.'' The play is currently enjoying a workmanlike revival at the Equity Library Theater.

title: Japan Wants Airline Talks
description: The United States and Japan must hold talks before Tokyo can rule on a United Airlines request to take over trans-Pacific routes from Pan American World Airways, a Transport Ministry official said today. However, the official said the issue was not linked with Tokyo's broader dissatisfaction over its civil aviation agreement with Washington.

title: Ford Develops New Sports Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company said it was developing a ''premium performance sports car'' to be sold in the late 1980's as well as a new ''small, lower-priced sporty car.''

title: Skier Suffers Head Injury
description: Christina Putz, a 19-year-old Austrian skier, suffered a life-threatening head injury and was in a coma today after crashing at more than 60 miles per hour during the first women's World Cup downhill race of the season.

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Restaurant Associates to Smith/ Greenland for Charlie Brown's restaurants.

title: HOW SENATE VOTED ON BUDGET PLAN
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate adopted legislation Wednesday to raise the debt limit. The measure also includes a provision designed to eliminate Federal deficits by 1991.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THOUSANDS of model trains from the Henry Ford Museum, Woody Allen's Phantom V Rolls-Royce, a 1937 motorcycle ridden by Steve McQueen in ''The Cincinnati Kid'' and A. M. Cassandre's famous poster ''Nord Express'' will be offered by Guernsey's this weekend in an auction of transportion collectibles at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street. They may be viewed today from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. and will be auctioned tomorrow at 10 A.M. and Sunday at 11 A.M.

title: Prices of Oil Products Continuing to Recover
description: Prices of oil products continued their moderate recovery yesterday from the plunges that were brought on earlier this week by the threat of an oil price war.

title: Solti Conducts 'Falstaff' For 'Great Performances'
description: Verdi's second comic opera - and his only successful one - waited until the composer's 80th year to be written. ''Falstaff'' is also his last work for the stage. And although we have a right to expect its sophistication and subtlety, the exuberant energy always comes as a surprise. Verdi here once again celebrates Shakespeare -with the Falstaff of ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' and 'Henry IV'' plays brought together in a three-act libretto by Arrigo Boito.

title: Home Loan Bank Post
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had approved the appointment of Richard F. Syron as the next president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Boston. He will succeed Raymond Elliott on Jan. 1. Mr. Syron is now a senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.

title: JUDGE IN QUEENS IS FOUND GUILTY IN BRIBERY TRIAL
description: Justice William C. Brennan of State Supreme Court in Queens was found guilty by a Federal jury yesterday of taking bribes.

title: Manville Plan Approval
