description: A committee representing thousands of asbestos victims who have made health-related claims against the Manville Corporation has given preliminary approval to a plan that would allow the company to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings and begin paying billions in compensation. Some lawyers, however, said they would continue their opposition. The plan calls for establishment of a $2.5 billion fund to pay health claims, and a fund of at least $125 million to pay property damage claims.

title: Article 223231 -- No Title
description: Almost $34 million in drug-related assets have been seized in connection with the indictment of 44 people, a bank and two companies on charges of operating drug and money-laundering rings, Charles Lewis, an assistant United States Attorney said today.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
New Rules, Same Old Deficit
description: Congress has now passed and the President has signed a law that yet again postpones their responsibility to tame the budget deficit. The latest deficit-reduction scheme may be unconstitutional and is certainly irrational, but it is law. It imposes on Congress and President the very duty they've been ducking for four years. But in its clumsy and cowardly way, this gimmick may finally force President Reagan to choose between his military buildup and raising taxes to pay for it.

title: SOME RATES DROP; FED EASING IS SEEN
description: Short-term interest rates moved lower yesterday as some analysts grew more confident that the Federal Reserve has taken at least a small step toward an easier monetary policy.

title: MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including gain of $133,082,000 on the sale of its operating divisions. The company sold its operating divisions in January 1985. Results for the year ended Sept. 30, 1985, basically reflect the gain on that sale.

title: AIRLINE WAS PENALIZED IN '84 INSPECTION
description: Arrow Air, whose plane crashed in Newfoundland yesterday, was one of 16 airlines receiving significant penalties after a Government inspection of 327 American carriers in early 1984.

title: BUDGET-BALANCING BILL IS SIGNED IN SECLUSION
description: President Reagan, the consummate master of White House ceremonies, chose today to sign one of the most important laws of his Presidency, the five-year deficit-cutting mandate, without the usual multipenned pomp and circumstance.

title: Advertising;   Bob Evans Farm Unit To Ted Bates Subsidiary
description: The Chicago office of Campbell-Mithun, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, has been appointed agency for the restaurant division of Bob Evans Farms in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Same Man, Different Jobs
description: In one of the more pointed anecdotes in his new book ''Politics,'' Mayor Koch relates how, because he was ''unconventional,'' he had refused a request by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin that the Mayor reappoint his brother, Dr. Gurston D. Goldin, to the Board of Higher Education.

title: PENNSYLVANIA GOVERNOR SAYS HE WON'T TRY FOR SENATE SEAT
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh ended weeks of suspense today by announcing he would not challenge his fellow Republican, the incumbent Senator Arlen Specter, for his seat next year.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Brooklyn Plan Blocked
description: An effort to bring baseball back to Brooklyn in the form of a minor league team was apparently blocked, or at least threatened, yesterday by the Mets, who invoked their territorial rights against the project. ''The Mets raised the issue in the National League meeting,'' said Al Harazin, executive vice president of the Mets.

title: Pick a Poll, Any Poll
description: These days, it seems, there is no such thing as an out-of-season political poll. Anxious Presidential candidates begin running even before it is known who will be running in the next off-year elections.

title: Crew on the Plane
description: Following is a list of crew members aboard the Arrow Airlines chartered plane that crashed today in Gander, Newfoundland, as made public by the airline, which is based here.

title: THE STAGE: 'PRIDE AND PREJUDICE'
description: In his dramatization of ''Pride and Prejudice,'' David Pownall has jettisoned two of the five Bennet daughters, and, along with them, he has sacrificed an equal share of the novel's sense and sensibility. Though he has not lampooned the original, the result is more a variation than a true adaptation.

title: Big Board Will Study Trading in RCA Stock
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would investigate the trading in shares of the RCA Corporation and the General Electric Company before the announcement by the two concerns Wednesday night that they had agreed to a merger.

title: The Survival Question
description: A Federal appeals court here has made a foreign policy decision on a technicality that highlights the peculiar means some conservatives are using to force their view of morality on the rest of the world.

title: Christmas in Brooklyn
description: The lighting ceremonies are not as elaborate as the one in Rockefeller Center, but when the Christmas displays are turned on in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Canarsie and Bensonhurst the results are the same - admiring approval.

title: RESTAURANT INSPECTIONS FAIL TO FOLLOW LAW, GOLDIN SAYS
description: One of every three restaurants in New York City is not inspected each year as required by law, and even when restaurants are inspected regularly, serious health violations are often missed, the City Comptroller charged yesterday.

title: Politics;   Whither the Women's Movement?
description: Notwithstanding Geraldine A. Ferraro's announcement Wednesday that she will not seek a Senate seat from New York next year, the women's political movement has entered its ''unremarkable'' phase, activists say, and that, they add, is real progress.

title: 2 MEN SEIZED IN GUNPOINT THEFT OF COLLECTIONS FROM ST. PATRICK'S
description: Two men have been arrested and accused of being the gunmen who handcuffed four ushers in the parish house of St. Patrick's Cathedral on Nov. 30 and stole $7,000 that had been gathered in collection boxes, the police said yesterday.

title: ITALY INDICTS EX-AIDE IN 1980 BOMBING
description: A former Italian intelligence official being held in jail in New York City has been indicted with others in Italy on a new charge of ''masterminding'' the 1980 bombing of the Bologna train station that killed 85 people.

title: CONGRESS ADOPTS STOPGAP MEASURE ON U.S. SPENDING
description: The House and Senate, deadlocked over Federal spending in 1986, tonight adopted a stopgap money bill to keep the Government running through Monday.

title: BUDGET CHIEF LISTS PROPOSED '87 CUTS
description: James C. Miller 3d, director of the Office of Management and Budget, today presented members of President Reagan's Cabinet with a long list of proposals to cut domestic spending and eliminate programs in the fiscal year 1987, which begins next Oct. 1.

title: KUWAIT SPURNS ANGLICAN ENVOY ON U.S. HOSTAGES
description: Efforts by a special envoy of the Church of England to bring about the release of a group of Americans held hostage in Lebanon have been hampered by Kuwait's refusal to deal with him, according to Arab diplomats.

title: Cause for Amusement
description: Commissioner Harry Usher of the United States Football League said he was ''amused'' by the National Football League owners' resolution Wednesday avowing no interest in merging with the U.S.F.L. or settling the U.S.F.L.'s $1.2 billion antitrust suit against the N.F.L. ''Frankly, the resolution really has no significance to the U.S.F.L.,'' Usher said in a statement. ''We are eager to try our lawsuit, and we believe a substantial verdict will be awarded by the court in favor of the U.S.F.L., and against the N.F.L. and its member clubs.''

title: Train Kills Pedestrian on L.I.
description: A pedestrian was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train today, disrupting evening rush-hour service for 40 minutes and causing extensive delays, the railroad said. Don Malone, a railroad spokesman, said the pedestrian, whose identity was not immediately determined, was struck and killed at 4:48 P.M. by an eastbound train just east of the Mineola station.

title: U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON THE ENVIRONMENT APPROVED IN GENEVA
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev approved a broad, detailed agreement on environmental protection at their meeting in Geneva last month, Administration officials said today.

title: DOLPHIN DOMINANCE A HURDLE FOR PATRIOTS
description: Given the turnover rate of personnel in the National Football League -most players have come and gone in five years or so - the domination of one team by another is not always easy to explain. It does, however, lead to generalizations, like the following:

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in October.

title: Coming and Goings
description: The National Football League said the St. Louis Cardinals could not wear all-maroon socks, calling them a violation of the uniform code. The socks were ordered by the team's owner, Bill Bidwill, and were worn last Sunday against the Saints. Bidwill had been irritated that players had been using white tape to cover most of the red in the old half-maroon, half-white socks. . . . The Redskins signed 33-year-old Steve Bartkowski, who threw for 23,468 yards in 11 seasons with the Atlanta Falcons, for the remainder of the season.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased slightly for the week ended Wednesday, falling $350.5 million, to $208.49 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds fell $525.9 million, to $60.76 billion, while assets of the 73 institutional funds dropped $24 million, to $53.26 billion. Assets of the 87 broker-dealer funds edged up by $199.4 million, to $94.47 billion.

title: SUNSTAR FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $16,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $95,000.

title: CONCERT: MARLOWE TRIBUTE
description: THE tribute to Sylvia Marlowe presented Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall came on the fourth anniversary of the American harpsichordist's death, and succeeded in the way all such occasions must hope to do - it made one think warmly of, and want to learn more about, what must have been a very remarkable woman.

title: REAGAN'S TAX EFFORT STALLS
description: President Reagan was apparently unable today to swing enough Republican votes in the House of Representatives to salvage his tax-revision legislation.

title: HOUSE PANEL ON MARCOS CHARGES TWO
description: A House subcommittee today cited for contempt of Congress two New York men who refused to answer questions on purported holdings in the United States of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda.

title: Giants Fear Injury May Bench Adams
description: With a division title virtually at stake when they meet the Cowboys in Dallas Sunday, a problem has arisen with the Giants' offense.

title: WALKING THE CITY'S SHORELINE
description: On a recent Sunday, after a week full of wet days, it mercifully did not rain. But a fog lingered along the banks of the Hudson River, obscuring the hillsides and cityscapes from the view on the George Washington Bridge.

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $4,157,000 from the surrender of $15,211,000 of the company's 8 percent convertible debentures. c-Net income The company said that its latest year results are after a net gain of $7,422,000 from the sale of the company's Antiviral and HLA product lines. The gain from the product lines' sale in the latest fourth quarter was $6,809,000.

title: DANCE: JONES AND ZANE
description: BILL T. JONES and Arnie Zane, who used to perform together in dances they co-choreographed, have recently moved into ensemble works for an expanded company of their own - and the results, as seen Wednesday night, are interestingly varied.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $571,000, or 6 cents a share, on sale of real estate.

title: SETTING DOWN THE SCALES OF JUSTICE
description: In 50 years as a town justice, nothing much happened, according to J. Aubrey Smith: ''Mostly speeding tickets, 95 percent, I'd say.'' The biggest sentence he ever gave was one year - only once. The biggest wedding he officiated at was 200 people - only once.

title: RECITAL: GYORGY SANDOR
description: GYORGY SANDOR - best known, perhaps, for his pioneering early recordings of the piano works of Bartok and Prokofiev - is not so common a figure on the New York recital stage as he once was. His Monday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall therefore offered an unusual opportunity to hear Mr. Sandor in several idioms: music of the Baroque (works by Bach, Handel and Scarlatti); the Romantic era (Beethoven's Sonata in D major, Schumann's ''Symphonic Etudes'' and Liszt's ''Mephisto Waltz''), and two very different strains of 20th-century music (the folkish, cultivated barbarism of Bartok and Kodaly and the wafting poetry of Debussy).

title: LILCO REJECTS CLOSING SHOREHAM
description: Shareholders of the Long Island Lighting Company voted today to repudiate a bid to abandon the Shoreham nuclear power plant and to make the company a public power authority, according to Lilco officials.

title: SANDGATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The company said revenue and net income increased primarily as a result of the merger of Anglo American Auto Auctions Inc. into a subsidiary of Sandgate on Sept. 3. The merger was effective Aug. 3 for accounting purposes.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for a 5-for-4 stock split effective Sept. 6, 1985. The company changed its fiscal year-end from Aug. 31 to July 31.

title: ASSOCIATES CORP OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reagan's Policy: 'A Blind Alley'
description: Once again, the Reagan Administration is beating the drums over Nicaragua and the alleged Cuban involvement there. It is a familiar refrain, but it may say more about our failed policy than about the threat in Central America.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1985
description: International

title: FED WEIGHS A PENALTY
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that the central bank was considering the imposition of a new, heavier penalty against financial institutions whose computer failures force them to seek exceptionally large short-term loans from the Fed.

title: CONFESSION OF A SECRET FAN
description: The Bears are coming, the Bears are coming. Just the nickname, Monsters of the Midway, makes it feel as if Bulldog Turner, Dick Butkus, Ed Sprinkle, Ed O'Bradovich and Bronko Nagurski himself were going to bust into New Jersey tomorrow and start giving what-for.

title: JG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods include operations of Goldblatt department stores, the Milgram Kagan Corp. and Susses Group Ltd.

title: BOOK OFFICIAL RETIRING AFTER 6-DECADE CAREER
description: When F. H. Landshoff retires today from Harry Abrams Inc. at age 84, he will leave behind a book publishing legacy that spans two continents and more than 60 years.

title: Economic Scene;   Why Stocks Are Booming
description: AT a time when the ''real'' economy of productivity, production and construction is plodding along, the stock market is racing ahead, setting records. The Dow Jones industrials sailed over the 1,500 barrier this week, with frenetic trading given an extra lift by the news that the General Electric Company had agreed to acquire the RCA Corporation for nearly $6.3 billion, which would make it the biggest industrial takeover to date outside the oil industry.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: HERMIONE GINGOLD sat in a plump armchair in the middle of Milton Goldman's living room on Sutton Place and presided over a birthday party in her honor. Miss Gingold herself steadfastly refused to disclose which birthday she was observing, but the irrepressible Mr. Goldman was telling everyone that it was No. 88.

title: Hotel Rating
description: On his 61st birthday, the thoughts of Edward I. Koch, the 105th Mayor of New York, turned to Caesar - Caesar salad, that is.

title: An American Dilemma
description: George Shultz told a London audience the other day that Western nations should use whatever means necessary, including covert military aid, to support anti-Communist forces in such places as Angola, Afghanistan, Cambodia and Nicaragua. But conspicuously missing from the Secretary of State's list was the Philippines.

title: A LARGE CAR-LOAN ISSUE
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering the largest issue ever of securities backed by car loans, and is the first finance affiliate of a car manufacturer to enter the new market. A $524.7 million issue 8.45 percent pass-through securities was offered yesterday by the First Boston Corporation at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 8.71 percent on a semiannual yield basis.

title: THE G.E.-RCA MERGER: FORGING A MEGADEAL
description: It took just 36 days for the General Electric Company and the RCA Corporation to forge their multibillion-dollar merger.

title: Pitt Chooses Gottfried
description: Mike Gottfried signed a five-year contract yesterday to be the football coach at Pitt, whose season records fell to 3-7-1 in 1984 and 5-5-1 this season after nine consecutive bowl-game appearances.

title: Suspect Ruled Incompetent
description: A woman charged with killing three people and wounding seven in a rampage at a suburban Philadelphia mall was declared mentally incompetent today to stand trial for murder. A Delaware County judge ruled the woman, Sylvia Seegrist, 25 years old, was incompetent when a court-appointed psychiatrist pronounced her unable to participate or assist in her own defense.

title: FRED J. LEARY Jr.
description: Fred J. Leary Jr., a retired executive vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, died of cancer Wednesday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: SCHLUMBERGER PLANS $485 MILLION CHARGE
description: Schlumberger Ltd., in a major break with the way it has done things in the past, yesterday announced a $485 million charge against earnings and a stock repurchase program.

title: A CHANCE TO SAMPLE EMERGING NEW BANDS
description: THE New Year is still a couple of weeks off. This weekend, however, listeners can get a jump on jazz, funk and rock, circa 1986. At Jazztrack tomorrow, the trombonist Craig Harris will introduce an all-star quintet that he hopes will stay together for some time. At Danceteria, the two-night New York Funk Festival will present eight bands tonight and tomorrow. And tomorrow at Irving Plaza, four up-and-coming rock groups will play a bargain-priced benefit to buy new equipment for WNYU, 89.1 FM, a valuable outlet for independent rock music.

title: Concerts to Aid A.N.C.
description: Three concerts to benefit the African National Congress, the outlawed black nationalist movement in South Africa, will take place this weekend at Aaron Davis Hall of the City College of New York, 134th Street at Convent Avenue (690-4100). Tonight, there will be reggae by Seakou Sundiata and the Kou, jazz by the Sedition Ensemble and South African songs by Sechaba.

title: TORRES CRITICIZES JERSEY STUDY
description: Jose Torres, the commissioner of the New York State Athletic Commission, yesterday criticized a recommendation by the New Jersey State Commission of Investigation that professional boxing be outlawed in that state.

title: Advertising;   TBWA Gets Sonecor
description: TBWA Advertising in New York has been appointed agency for Sonecor, a division of the Southern New England Telephone Company that is involved in telephone systems for business. There were originally 11 agencies in the competition, and that was cut to three. The previous agency was Posey & Quest in Greenwich, Conn.

title: REAGAN ADVISER ON LATIN SWING
description: Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, President Reagan's new national security adviser, made a swing through Central America today, including a stop here to plead with the Honduran military to permit the transit of aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: WESTERN STEER MOM 'N' POPS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
BRIEFS
description: * Avondale Industries said the Navy had ordered two additional landing ship docks, worth $300 million, from its shipyards division.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 11:37 A.M. today and set at 12:14 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Icahn and T.W.A. Still Negotiating
description: Carl C. Icahn and the Trans World Airlines interim board of directors are still in negotiations on Mr. Icahn's proposal to restructure his offer to shareholders to make it easier for him to get up to $1 billion in financing, sources close to the financing said yesterday.

title: PENTAGON AIDE WARNS OF AGING OF MILITARY PLANS
description: A Pentagon analyst told a Presidential commission today that weapon costs were increasing at such a rate that the military would have fewer and older weapons in the future.

title: Ready for Drop-In Guests
description: Heading to Europe during the holidays, three travelers from the South are having a hard time making a connection at Kennedy International Airport. So they may spend a night in the city next week.

title: SAMUEL ROSS BALLIN IS DEAD: BANKRUPTCY LAWYERS' 'DEAN'
description: Samuel Ross Ballin, a leading bankruptcy lawyer who helped assemble the midtown property for Rockefeller Center in the early 1930's, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday night at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HORIZON AIR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: On Giving Sanctuary
description: The United States has a right and duty to protect its borders. It may prosecute all violators including those like the Sanctuary movement who claim a moral motive for smuggling in aliens from Central America. That's exactly the claim in the trial now under way in Arizona. Regrettably, this case is clouded by the Government's insensitive and probably unnecessary infiltration of a church with a wired informant.

title: OCCIDENTAL HEAD SEEKS SOVIET DEAL
description: The American industrialist Armand Hammer said that he was negotiating to join two multibillion-dollar Soviet coal slurry projects and to sell the Kremlin oil drilling equipment for Arctic conditions.

title: AFTER THE GAMES, A REAL BATTLEFIELD
description: International sports competitions routinely produce intense feelings of rivalry, but at the Southeast Asian Games, which got under way in Bangkok, Thailand, this week, the most intense rivalry is not among the various national teams but among the members of a single team - a disparate group of athletes representing the divided nation of Cambodia.

title: U.C.L.A. SEEKS SOCCER TITLE
description: Coach Sigi Schmid of U.C.L.A. was convinced his soccer team was serious about the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs when the five seniors on the team went to the first playoff game dressed like executives.

title: Saving Is a Habit To Teach and Reward
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. One hour before the expiration of a midnight filing deadline, the Philippine opposition agreed that Corazon C. Aquino would run for President with her chief rival, Salvador H. Laurel, as her running mate. 2. 24. 1991. 3.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chrysler Corp., Detroit, said suggested retail prices on 1986 model Mitsubishi imports would be an average of 2.9 percent higher than prices of 1985 models.

title: ST. BARTHOLOMEW SKYSCRAPER SUIT DISMISSED
description: A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a lawsuit brought by parishioners who want to block St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church from building an office tower on its Park Avenue grounds.

title: GAF SEEMS READY TO LIFT CARBIDE BID
description: The GAF Corporation indicated yesterday that it might be willing to raise its $68-a-share bid for the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: CLUES ARE SOUGHT TO CRASH THAT KILLED 256 IN GANDER
description: Searchers combed the snow-dusted woods near the international airport here today, recovering bodies and searching for clues to the jetliner crash Thursday that killed a 248 American soldiers going home from the Middle East.

title: AMTRAK ACCIDENT LAID TO BEAVERS
description: Federal investigators have concluded that the collapse of a series of beaver dams caused the flash flood that undermined a section of track in Vermont last year resulting in the derailment of an Amtrak train. Five people died in the derailment and 26 were seriously injured.

title: Vatican Ties Would Solve None of Israel's Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 11:30 A.M. today and set at 12:02 A.M. tomorrow.

title: CITY RUNOFF IN PRIMARIES IS UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the validity of the state law that provides for primary-runoff elections in citywide races in New York City.

title: VICTIMS OF THE AIRLINE CRASH IN NEWFOUNDLAND
description: Following is a list of those aboard the Arrow Air charter jet that crashed Thursday in Gander, Newfoundland. The list of passengers was provided to United Press International by the Defense Department, which was withholding other names pending notification of relatives. The crew list, transmitted by The Associated Press, was provided by the airline, which is based in Miami. The cockpit crew members were from the Miami area; the cabin crew members were from the New York area.

title: DEVICES TO DETECT LETHAL GAS
description: EARLIER this month, a retired Transit Authority worker and his wife were killed in their Queens home, victims of carbon monoxide gas that seeped in through the furnace because of a blocked chimney.

title: Working Profile:Antonio Ortiz Mena;   Banker, Mediator, Economic Peace-Keeper
description: The re-election last month of Antonio Ortiz Mena as president of the Inter-American Development Bank marked one of the rare times that the United States and the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua have agreed on anything.

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KOPPERS TO TAKE 4TH-PERIOD CHARGE
description: The Koppers Company said it planned a $100 million charge in the fourth quarter and a redeployment of $160 million from the sale of assets.

title: If You Understand Pizza, You Understand Subway Fares
description: In 1975, when I first visited New York City, the transit fare was 35 cents for service that, in my experience, ran from indifferent to poor. By 1978, when I returned, the transit fare had increased to 50 cents. It also seemed to me that service had deteriorated.

title: Sahl-Salzman Retrospective
description: The Cubiculo Theater, 414 West 51st Street, will present a 10-year retrospective of music-theater works by Michael Sahl and Eric Salzman tonight at 8.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. These two became one at the last moment. Explain. 2. After (20/22/24) Federal budget deficits in 25 years, President Reagan signed legislation aimed at reducing the deficit to zero in (1987/1989/ 1991/1993). 3. ''After they took my money they could have said, 'Thanks for building that statue.' '' Who made the remark, to what statue was he referring, and what were the circumstances? 4. The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles plans to organize airplane trips for visitors who wish to see a new acquisition, ''Double Negative,'' by the sculptor Michael Heizer. Why is that necessary? 5. In Argentina, five defendants were found guilty in trials that recorded a first in Latin America. Why were the trials unusual and what was noteworthy about one of the defendants? 6. The Mayor of a city resigned after a judge refused to grant him a third trial on charges of illegal campaign financing. Name the city. 7. ''There was only one factor in this decision,'' Geraldine A. Ferraro said. What was the decision and what was the factor? 8. ''No truly viable social or economic benefits can be derived from such legal savagery,'' said a report by a State Commission of Investigation. What state is it and what did the report recommend? 9. For the first time, a restaurant in Paris that specializes in American cuisine has received the Plat Vermeil, or Gold-Plated Dish, award for foreign food and the Golden Fork award for excellent cuisine.

title: NAVY REJECTS DYNAMICS BID
description: The Navy has rejected a contract bid from the General Dynamics Corporation to develop a combat system for attack submarines, Navy officials and a Congressional office said today. In addition, they said the program had run into significant cost and mismanagement problems.

title: KNICK FANS SHOW THEIR IMPATIENCE
description: The more than 10,000 fans who bought season tickets and the hundreds more who bought tickets on an individual-game basis to be a part of the Patrick Ewing era seem to have begun to turn on the Knicks.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF GROSS CASE
description: A series of four articles in The New York Times reported that, according to pathologists in the Medical Examiner's office and elsewhere, the Chief Medical Examiner had produced misleading or inaccurate autopsy findings on people who died in police custody. The Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, denied the charges. The articles also found that, in the view of many lawyers and doctors, the office had so deteriorated that they could no longer trust its findings.

title: Eyeful Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: MARIS IN HOSPITAL
description: Roger Maris, diagnosed two years ago as suffering from lymphatic cancer but said to have been in remission earlier this year, was being treated yesterday at M. D. Anderson Hospital and Tumor Institute in Houston. The family of the former Yankee slugger requested that information about his condition be withheld, a hospital spokesman, Joan Baird, said.

title: Cage Door Is Blamed In Fatal Jaguar Attack
description: A 200-pound jaguar pushed open a motorized automatic door on its holding cage before attacking and killing a 30-year-old zookeeper, city investigators said today.

title: The Talk of Cape Vincent;   MEMORY OF TEENAGERS' DEATHS LINGERS IN A TINY VILLAGE
description: In a simple burial ground, where snow-flecked gravestones face the wintry gray St. Lawrence River, lie the teen-age victims of an auto accident. This tiny village finds their deaths difficult to forget.

title: COMEBACK SET
description: The two gigantic football helmets created by a Chicago sculptor as a salute to the Bears' big season will go back on display at the city's Art Institute, though not on the heads of the bronze lions outside the museum.

title: 4 KILLED IN S.I. HOUSE FIRE
description: A woman and three children were killed yesterday in a fire in their Staten Island home.

title: The 'Strong Pass' Systems Provoke Wide Controversy
description: A controversy raging in other continents has left the bridge players of North America virtually unaffected. It concerns the plethora of ''strong pass'' systems, which have gained some expert adherents, mainly in Europe, Australia and New Zealand.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 2
description: b-Includes an unusual charge of $21,363,000 to cover costs associated with a major restructuring of the organization. c-Net income

title: DEC. 1-10 CAR SALES OFF 12.6%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles in the Dec. 1-10 period were down 12.6 percent from last year, the manufacturers reported here today. The decline came despite a new round of sales incentive programs offered by most of the car companies.

title: ARTS GROUP TO HONOR EDUCATORS
description: Four New York City teachers and principals and four cultural organizations will receive awards from distinguished New Yorkers for helping to introduce children in the school system to the arts.

title: CHECKING BRAIN'S STATUS DURING HEART SURGERY
description: Erwin R. John, director of brain research laboratories at the New York University Medical Center, was granted a patent this week for a system that, during open-heart surgery, detects brain waves, observes the blood flow and temperature, and displays the information to the surgical team.

title: JEWS ARE CAUTIOUS AFTER SOVIET VISIT
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, the president of the World Jewish Congress, spoke candidly today about his talks with the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, but he refused to say anything about the three days he spent in Moscow before his arrival here.

title: PETTIBONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $36,125,000 for the quarter and $39,430,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,658,000 for the quarter and $9,040,000 for the 6 months.

title: No Shultz Comment On Lie-Testing Order
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz refused to comment today when asked about President Reagan's executive order requiring polygraph, or lie-detector, testing for high officials, inluding Cabinet officers.

title: A.M. NAMES NEW CHAIRMAN
description: The American Motors Corporation announced a series of executive changes yesterday, including the unexpected election of a new chairman, Pierre Semerena, who is a former vice president of Renault, the French auto maker that owns 46 percent of A.M.C.

title: INVENTORIES ROSE 0.5% IN OCTOBER
description: Business inventories rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest increase in a year, while sales were falling sharply, the Government reported today.

title: HATING THE BEARS
description: For years Highpockets has observed the Chicago Bears with a sharp eye, but one not devoid of a lot of ill will and a glimmer of envy. Highpockets lives in Chicago and remains a Chicago Cardinal fan, a rather forlorn undertaking given that there are no Chicago Cardinals.

title: CARSON NOW ENTHUSIASTIC ABOUT GIANTS
description: In his 10 seasons with the Giants, Harry Carson has seen the good and the bad, mostly the bad. On Sunday, he hopes to see the good.

title: CYPRUS SETS LIFE TERMS FOR 3 KILLERS OF ISRAELIS
description: A Briton and two Palestinians were convicted today of murdering three Israelis aboard a yacht in a Cyprus marina in September. They were sentenced to life in prison.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: OSTRACISM OF POLAND: THE WEST'S UNITY UNRAVELS
description: When Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski met this month with President Francois Mitterrand of France and later with Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, it did not necessarily mark a clear-cut end to Poland's status as a pariah in Europe. But it certainly reflected sharp divisions in a policy of ostracism that Western democracies agreed on after the Polish leader imposed martial law four years ago today.

title: EXPERTS LACK SOLID CLUES ON CAUSE OF CRASH
description: Safety specialists were still without solid clues yesterday on what caused the crash of a chartered jetliner in Gander, Newfoundland, on Thursday that killed 256 people, most of them American soldiers returning from peacekeeping duty in the Middle East.

title: A Gain for the Latin Media
description: Without fanfare, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights has struck a decisive blow against a practice prevalent in Latin America: the compulsory licensing of journalists by governments. This decision, involving Costa Rica, deserves close attention because it is the first time that any international court has considered the free press provisions of the Inter-American Declaration of Human Rights and because its ruling ought to have an important impact on 10 other Latin American countries with similar laws restricting journalists.

title: DISPUTES BOG DOWN HEARING ON HOLDINGS SAID TO BE MARCOSES'
description: A House subcommittee looking at purported holdings in the United States of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, bogged down today amid partisan disputes and conflicting statements during public and closed sessions.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 'Cats' Stage Crew Stars in Short Film
description: Students, teachers and city officials are among those who will see on film what goes on behind the stage during a performance of ''Cats'' at screenings of ''Broadway Backstage!'' on Monday at the Winter Garden Theater, Broadway and 50th Street.

title: BRAZIL LOAN TALKS STALL
description: Brazilian banking officials and representatives of the 700 banks holding most of the country's $104 billion foreign debt said yesterday, after concluding two days of talks, that negotiations in New York on the restructuring of loans due this year and next had been adjourned until Wednesday to allow the Brazilians to return home for previously scheduled commitments, a banking source said.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Isla All-Stars vs. Metro All-Stars, Puerto Rico Winter League All-Star Game, at Bayamon. (Television - Channel 41, 12:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7:20 P.M.) Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:45 P.M. tape. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Colleges: St. John's at U.C.L.A., 3:45 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 3:45 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 3:45 P.M.); Brooklyn at Syracuse, 8 P.M.; City College at Staten Island, 7:30 P.M.; Rider at St. Francis (Brooklyn), 3 P.M.; Seton Hall at St. Peter's, 8 P.M. (Radio -WSOU-FM 89.5, 8 P.M.); Wagner at Hofstra, 2 P.M.; Princeton vs. LaSalle at the Spectrum, 1 P.M.; Pittsburgh at West Virginia (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.); Kentucky at Kansas (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.); New York Tech at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M.; Southampton at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M.; Holy Cross at Boston College, 2 P.M.; Dartmouth at Fairfield, 7:30 P.M.; Iona at Duquesne, 8 P.M.; Harvard at Manhattan, 8 P.M.; Allegheny at New York University, 4 P.M.; Women: Seton Hall at St. John's, 2 P.M. Football Jets vs. Chicago Bears, at Giants Stadium, 12:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 2, 12:30 P.M. Radio -WABC 660, 12:30 P.M.) Broncos vs. Kansas City Chiefs, at Denver. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 3:45 P.M.) College Bowl Game: Fresno State vs.

title: THE NEEDIEST RECEIVE GIFTS AS MEMORIALS
description: The recollection of loved ones and their concern for the homeless and needy during the holiday season is cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Uganda Undone
description: Uganda is disintegrating. As Edward Gargan reported in The Times, civil order in the onetime pearl of Africa has broken down.

title: STOCKS SURGE: DOW UP 23.97
description: Wall Street yesterday wrapped up the busiest week in its history with a record-setting flourish.

title: HOW THE VARIOUS COMPANIES DIFFER
description: To choose a long distance telephone company, a consumer must first weed out the companies that do not match his or her calling patterns. Then, a comparison must be made of the rates various companies charge for the phone calls the consumer makes most often.

title: EXCAVATING DISHES OF THE 60'S
description: The invitation to the black-tie dinner read ''Deja Vu.'' The three hosts were professionals in the food business. So it took no great powers of deduction to figure out that the menu would look back, perhaps at some of those forgotten blockbusters such as beef Wellington and veal Orloff.

title: SINAI FORCE HALTS USE OF AIRLINE
description: The international peacekeeping force that is deployed in Sinai will not use Arrow Air for a coming scheduled flight of American troops, a State Department official said today.

title: MORRIS ON MOVE
description: If Joe Morris gets into the end zone at Dallas tomorrow, he'll set a record for most touchdowns by a New York player in a single A.F.L. or N.F.L. season. The best such years: Gene Roberts (Giants, 1949)17 Joe Morris (Giants, 1985)17 Art Powell (Titans, 1960)14 Don Maynard (Jets, 1965)14 Homer Jones (Giants, 1967)14 Emerson Boozer (Jets, 1972)14 Ron Johnson (Giants, 1972)14 Emerson Boozer (Jets, 1967)13 Bill Paschal (Giants, 1943)12 Del Shofner (Giants, 1962)12 Ron Johnson (Giants, 1970)12 The league record, though, appears to be out of Morris's reach. These are history's leaders: John Riggins (Washington, 1983)24 O. J. Simpson (Buffalo, 1975)23 Gale Sayers (Chicago, 1965)22 Chuck Foreman (Minnesota, 1975)22

title: UNESCO WORKERS END 4-DAY HUNGER STRIKE
description: Seven Unesco staff members ended a four-day hunger strike today after the organization yielded to demands for a joint committee to negotiate job cuts.

title: What, Reagan Worry?
description: Although President Reagan's helpers were expected to worry through the weekend trying to gain support for tax-revision legislation, the President himself was not visibly upset. Most White House watchers scoffed at a report that the President was ''steamed'' by the House refusal on Wednesday to take up the tax legislation.

title: ROYAL MARINES AND SCOTS TO MARCH AT THE GARDEN
description: ''I shall be very sad to leave the band,'' Trevor Attwood said, wiping away an imaginary tear that trickled from one eye down onto his sandy mustache. Bandmaster Attwood is a cornetist in Her Majesty's Royal Marines Band, which will appear with the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders in a performance of regal British pageantry tomorrow afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 14
STEWART & STEVENSON SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax writedowns of $23.8 million for the quarter and $24.2 million for the 9 months from the sale of a drilling rig and on the value of its assets. c-Net income

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL KANSAS CITY (AL) - Named Frank Funk pitching coach at Omaha of the American Association.

title: ISRAEL SAYS U.S. SUPPORTED GUN DEAL
description: Israel said today that the United States Government had cooperated in the export of technology for producing tank cannon barrels. It denied involvement in any illegal scheme to export the technology without proper licenses.

title: Klan Cancels Parade Plan
description: Members of the Ku Klux Klan, faced with the warnings of the police and the disappointment of a town that had canceled its Christmas parade, have scrapped plans to display their float anyway. ''There will be no parade, there will be no float,'' said Dan Carver, leader of the racist group in Georgia. The Town Council voted to cancel tonight's parade after the Klan insisted on participating, but leaders had said they would go ahead and roll their float, bearing eight robed men and wishing the town ''Merry Christmas From the Klan,'' along the parade route.

title: FAMILY SHGELTER ADDED BY CITY AT A SCHOOL SITE
description: The city announced yesterday that it was opening a fifth shelter for homeless families and sending homeless families with sick children to a specially designated hotel in Queens.

title: How Students Learn What's Right and Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-RCA HOLDER SUES IT, G.E
description: A former RCA Corporation shareholder filed a class action lawsuit in a Manhattan Federal District Court yesterday against the General Electric Company and RCA for not disclosing earlier than they did on Wednesday that they had agreed to a merger.

title: MANDELA BOOK IS BANNED
description: The Government today banned the autobiography of Winnie Mandela, wife of the imprisoned black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, saying the book was ''found to be undesirable.''

title: WARD 5B: A MODEL OF CARE FOR AIDS
description: Even sitting exhausted in a chair in his room at San Francisco General Hospital, John Lere can still talk about how he likes to raid the communal refrigerator at night. Talking between breaths from an oxygen mask, he likes to joke that his primary care nurse, Charles Cloniger, is ''like having Mom at home.''

title: Article 226495 -- No Title
description: Judge Larry Margolis of the United States Court of Claims says the Yurok Indians are entitled to $23.8 million because timber revenue was paid to another tribe living on the same Humboldt County reservation.

title: FRENCH SUE U.S. OVER AIDS VIRUS DISCOVERY
description: Intensifying a bitter dispute over who first established the cause of AIDS, officials of the Pasteur Institute, a leading French research organization, announced today that it had sued the United States Government.

title: MAN HELD FOR SLAYING FAMILY CALLED MODEL FATHER
description: Over the summer, Dennis Beardsley installed an above-ground swimming pool and a swing set in his backyard for his daughters, 5-year-old Katherine and 4-year-old Jennifer.

title: U.S. OFFERS TO BE GUARANTOR OF AN ACCORD IN AFGHANISTAN
description: The United States today announced its readiness to serve as a guarantor of a peace settlement in Afghanistan that would include both a withdrawal of Soviet troops and an end to American aid to the rebels.

title: HOUSING AGENCY: DEPRESSION'S CHILD
description: Born in the the Depression, when mortgage defaults were widespread and credit was scarce, the Federal Housing Administration has emerged as one of the pillars of the housing finance industry.

title: MOTOROLA SETTLES
description: Motorola Inc. said it had settled a patent infringement suit that it had filed against the United Technologies Corporation and a United subsidiary, the Mostek Corporation. Motorola had charged in a complaint filed Nov. 21 in Federal District Court in Dallas that Mostek and United used Motorola's 68,000 microchip technology without paying Motorola a fee. No further details were disclosed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CARVINGS Holiday or not, there is always a celebratory mood at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street (581-2474), an atmosphere created by the things it displays, things that recall the traditional American esthetic.

title: Pope's Peace Message Sees 'Abyss' of Inequality
description: Pope John Paul II issued his annual message on world peace today, calling for dialogue between the United States and the Soviet Union, action to eliminate the inequality between rich and poor nations and respect for human rights.

title: Lincoln Skated on Thin Constitutional Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: Democracy Is Real in Honduras
description: To the Editor:

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: The company said the share earnings of 37 cents, compared with 36 cents, do not reflect a previously declared 3-for-2 stock split payable Dec. 27, but after adjustment for the split share earnings for the first quarter were 25 cents versus 24 cents.

title: DANES AND PRETORIA CURB
description: The Danish Parliament urged the Government today to end all trade with South Africa to protest that country's racial policies, backing a union boycott that has already brought most trade to a halt.

title: THE SELLING OF TOY 'CONCEPTS'
description: He is simply ''the most powerful man in the universe.'' Coming out of nowhere just three years ago, he is He-Man, the centerpiece of Mattel Inc.'s Masters of the Universe army of action toys, and one of the hottest-selling items for the third Christmas season in a row.

title: FOUR-LEGGED INVESTMENTS
description: LEONARD FEIGENBAUM, a financial planner at Drimal-Brudner Financial Services in New York, and four friends invested $2,000 each in a harness racing horse 10 years ago. They lost money on that deal, but Mr. Feigenbaum became enamored with this form of investing and is now a partner in five standardbreds, the trotting and pacing horses used in harness racing. ''You're chasing a dream,'' he said. ''If I pay my bills every year and have some fun, that's good enough.''

title: MAN SENTENCED TO 120 YEARS AFTER ADMITTING TO 2 MURDERS
description: A former insurance salesman who was accused of murdering six young women, was sentenced to 120 years in prison today for two of those slayings.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON
description: Anderson Clayton & Company and the Unilever Group said that they had signed definitive agreements for Unilever to buy Anderson Clayton's Brazilian and Mexican interests for $112.5 million.

title: WHAT TEXACO OWES PENNZOIL
description: It started as soap opera. Did giant Texaco unfairly grab Getty Oil after Getty had agreed to sell much of its reserves to little Pennzoil? Did Texaco, of White Plains, N.Y., make a fatal error in allowing the case to be tried by a good ol' jury in Houston? Would Burgess Meredith play Pennzoil's down-home lawyer in prime time? But now the tale has become a sad farce. The jury awarded Pennzoil $11.1 billion, by any conceivable reckoning at least 18 times the damage it suffered. If this bizarre decision stands, the nation's third-largest oil company could be forced into bankruptcy and its shareholders stripped of most of their investment. It is up to the appeals courts to repair this injustice.

title: U.S. ENTERING A NEW PHASE IN BATTLE ON WESTERN WATER
description: Utah residents voted overwhelmingly last month to spend $335 million to help finish a federally planned system of dams and canals on the Colorado River after being warned that if they did not California would some day ''raid'' Utah's water resources.

title: EAST-WEST TIES 'ENCOURAGING,' NATO SAYS
description: The NATO allies, in a communique at the end of their two-day winter meeting here, said today that they were encouraged by recent East-West developments.

title: TAKING MEDICINE THROUGH THE SKIN
description: An electrically powered applicator that passes medicine through the skin into the bloodstream was patented this week by Dan Sibalis.

title: BAYLOR TRADE TALKS OFF
description: The Yankees' prolonged effort to trade Don Baylor ended today, at least for now, when Jerry Kapstein, Baylor's agent, and the White Sox broke off talks designed to secure Baylor's permission for a trade.

title: Man Here Has a Comet Problem
description: Please don't think me blase when I say the approach of Halley's comet does not make my pulse flutter. It is a simple case of disillusion. A few years ago I got terribly worked up about another comet and had my heart broken when it failed to show up.

title: The Prosperity of '29
description: In July 1929, I landed a temporary job as a runner for the brokerage firm of Samuel Ungerleider & Company. A senior at Morris High School in the Bronx, I knew virtually nothing about the geography of the financial district and even less about the logistics of the market. This was a state of innocence that, I later discovered, I shared with millions of other Americans who were then maniacally buying and selling stocks and bonds from sea to shining sea.

title: 4 Killed as Militias Clash in Beirut
description: Four people were killed and nine wounded today as Christian and Moslem militiamen continued battling with tanks across Beirut's dividing Green Line, officials said.

title: LEGISLATOR QUESTIONS DECISIONS BY OFFICIAL ON GRAZING PERMITS
description: A Congressman says the director of the Bureau of Land Management has broken a 1981 promise to avoid making decisions affecting cattle-grazing permits his family holds.

title: BILL RATES CONTINUE TO DECLINE
description: Treasury bill and other short-term rates fell further yesterday as the credit markets again waited in vain for the Federal Reserve to cut its discount rate to financial institutions. The rate on the current 90-day bills, for example, fell seven basis points, to 6.78 percent, its lowest level since late September, when the major industrial nations moved to reduce the dollar's value.

title: PREGAME RITUALS FACE A BIG TEST
description: In those mad, players-only moments before game time against the Chicago Bears on Saturday, Coach Joe Walton will not go into the Jets' locker room.

title: CROWD FOILS CUBAN KIDNAPPING
description: Four Cuban Embassy employees tried to kidnap a former Cuban official here today but were foiled when about 30 bystanders intervened, the police said.

title: LIGHTING UP THE BEAUMONT
description: For the first time in its turbulent recent history, harmony radiated from the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Looking forward to the opening next Friday of its first production, rather than back at four years of darkness and discord, the directors of the theater threw an elaborate party for 410 on the stage Thursday night.

title: BONUS TO KEEP OFFICERS UREGED
description: The city should pay bonuses to veteran police officers who agree to stay on the force instead of retiring, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: MAYS, J. W. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $95,988 from a refund of real estate taxes for prior years. c-Including a gain of $5,872 from a refund of real estate taxes for prior years and a charge of $25,000 representing a writedown of contingency liability on vendor claims in Chapter 11 proceedings. Sales figures include sales from leased departments.

title: PRODUCER PRICE INDEX RISES SHARPLY
description: The Producer Price Index, a major inflation gauge that tends to herald changes at the retail level, rose sharply in November for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.

title: THE ARTIST AS HEROINE
description: THE HISTORY OF THE UNIVERSE. By Jennifer Bartlett. 197 pages. Moyer Bell Limited/Nimbus Books. $15.95. Filled with bright, nimble images of trees, houses and oceans, Jennifer Bartlett's paintings - from the earlier, minimalistic work through the later, more realistic period - have often demonstrated a distinct narrative impulse, an instinct for storytelling and autobiographical revelation that persists in the viewer's mind, however abstract or unexpected the overall creation. It comes as no great surprise, then, that Miss Bartlett has also written a novel - titled, with typical ambition and expansiveness, ''The History of the Universe.''

title: HOME STATE INDICTMENTS
description: A state grand jury today indicted Marvin L. Warner, the former owner of the failed Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati, on charges of financial wrongdoing. He was charged with 45 counts of willful misapplication of funds, 4 counts of securities violations and a count of theft by deception.

title: BIBLE OF U.S. DAIRY FARMERS MARKS CENTURY OF CRUSADING
description: Gordon Berg, a terse dairy farmer in Brownsville, Wis., says he has two bibles. The first is the Holy Bible and the other is Hoard's Dairyman.

title: 3 Teen-agers Charged In Trolley Derailment
description: Three 15-year-old boys who said they hurled rocks and chunks of concrete onto a train track to see how far they could throw them were arrested for causing a trolley derailment that injured 59 people, police said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1985
description: The Economy

title: DIRECT ACTION MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A LOOK AT THE NEW CROP OF TINY VIDEO CAMERAS
description: Christmas shoppers - those undeterred by a four-figure price tag, at any rate - have an opportunity to participate in the home-movie revolution currently in progress, due to the availability of a new, miniature video camera. Sony, Kodak, Canon and General Electric, among others, are offering compact 8-millimeter camera-recorders that are far smaller and lighter than anything previously available.

title: IAN STEWART, 47, DIES: HELPED FOUND 'STONES'
description: Ian Stewart, the pianist who was a founding member of the Rolling Stones, died of a heart attack Thursday in his doctor's office in London. He was 47 years old.

title: M.T.A. CITES DEFICIT
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to raise bus and subway fares to $1, tolls on major bridges and tunnels to $1.75 and commuter railroad fares by 11 percent. The increases take effect Jan. 1.

title: Protest in San Francisco Ties Up City Hall Toilets
description: City workers found themselves unable to use the restrooms in City Hall for 15 minutes today as residents lobbied for more public facilities.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT IN 0.4% GAIN
description: Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in November following two months of declines.

title: CORRECTION
description: Christmastime music schedules in Weekend yesterday carried incorrect time listings for three programs:

title: NEW COACH NAMED
description: The University of Kansas promoted Bob Valesente to head football coach yesterday, less than 48 hours after his predecessor, Mike Gottfried, took the head coaching position at the Univerity of Pittsburgh. Valesente, 45, joined Gottfried's staff at Kansas in April 1984 as quarterback coach.

title: STATE PANEL SEES MEDICAL LAPSES IN 9 GROSS CASES
description: The state's charges against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, accuse him of improperly failing to determine that the deaths of four people in police custody were homicides. He also deviated from standard professional practice in five other cases, according to the charges.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1985
description: International

title: LOSS SEEN BY HUTTON IN QUARTER
description: The E. F. Hutton Group disclosed yesterday that it lost $7 million during October and November and would take one-time charges totaling $24 million before taxes in December. That meant, it said, that the brokerage firm would probably report a loss in the fourth quarter.

title: Amputee Loses Lawsuit Against Cigarette Maker
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed an amputee's $55 million lawsuit against the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, ruling that the amputee, Floyd Roysdon, had failed to prove the company's cigarettes were more dangerous than a customer should expect.

title: FARM BILL CONFEREES MOVE TOWARD AN ACCORD
description: Senate and House negotiators made progress today toward finishing the 1985 farm bill, one of three major bills awaiting final passage before Congress adjourns for the year.

title: U.S.-SOVIET ART EXCHANGE PLANNED
description: An exchange of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces by American and Soviet museums was announced today, the first major cultural agreement to come from last month's Geneva summit.

title: LAKERS HALTED
description: Wayne Cooper scored a career-high 32 points tonight as Denver stopped the Los Angeles Lakers' eight-game winning streak with a 124-120 victory. The Lakers, now 19-3, have lost twice here to the Nuggets (16-8). The Nuggets never trailed in the second half, but it was not until Alex English hit two free throws with five seconds left that the victory was secure.

title: Kohl's Coalition Partner Cool to 'Star Wars'
description: The junior partner in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition Government said today that talks with Washington about possible German participation in research on a missile-defense system should focus solely on broad technical questions of industrial and scientific cooperation.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES SELLING OFF F.H.A. TO PRIVATE BIDDER
description: President Reagan's draft budget for the fiscal year 1987 contains a proposal to sell the Federal Housing Administration to ''private bidders'' by the end of 1989.

title: YUANKS AND METS DISAPPOINTED
description: The Yankees and the Mets went home today still pursuing trades that were not made at baseball's winter meetings during a week in which 29 players were swapped in 13 deals.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have not specifically and categorically ruled out anything at this time.'' - Peter Boag, Canadian investigating crash of U.S. troop flight in Newfoundland. [1:3.]

title: U.C.L.A. READY FOR ST. JOHN'S
description: It was about this time last season that Walt Hazzard, in just his second month as head basketball coach at U.C.L.A., brought his young Bruins to Madison Square Garden for a game against powerful, nationally ranked St. John's.

title: Rome Via Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-THEATRICAL MANAGER
description: James Awe, a longtime theatrical company manager, died of cardio-pulmonary arrest Wednesday after being struck by two cars while walking on an upper Manhattan street. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago net income reflects an increase of $2,198,000, or 20 cents a share, from the DISC tax credit.

title: FOR SHANKER AND UNION, CELBRATION TONIGHT ENDS ERA
description: Albert Shanker remembers spending the early days of the United Federation of Teachers on East 23d Street ''in a loft building with rats in it,'' stuffing envelopes ''and calling for picket lines and demonstrations where frequently only 12 active people would show up.''

title: PENTAGON SEEKING PRIVATE HEALTH CARE FOR DEPENDENTS AND RETIREES
description: The Defense Department has decided to invite hospital chains and large insurance companies to bid on a contract to provide health care off military bases for military dependents and retirees, a Pentagon health official said today.

title: A CHAIR FOR MAKEUP
description: A makeup chair, which enables the occupant to see reflections of hair and clothing in two mirrors, has been patented by Luther G. Simjian, president of Command Automation Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rotation of the chair aims one mirror attached to a rod that extends upward from the seat, and a fixed mirror is on the wall.

title: LONG DISTANCE LINES: MAKING RIGHT CHOICE
description: Choosing a long distance telephone company is not a life-or-death decision. Everybody's entitled to a mistake, perhaps two. They can be corrected. Fast.

title: ISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
SNAG IN REBEL AID SAID TO WORRY U.S.
description: The Honduran Government's resistance to channeling United States aid to Nicaraguan rebels was the focus of a report to President Reagan today from his new national security adviser, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, according to Administration officials.

title: MALTESE AGREE ON A HARD ISSUE, NOT ON A SOFT DRINK
description: On this sunny speck of an island in the Mediterranean, the color a Maltese wears and the beverage he drinks betray more than esthetic preferences: they are political statements.

title: RUSSIANS AND CHINESE TO EXCHANGE VISITS
description: The Soviet and Chinese Foreign Ministers will exchange visits next year in a further effort to broaden talks between the two nations, according to Soviet officials here.

title: IN ARGENTINA, A CULTURAL RENAISSANCE
description: The Italian director Lina Wertmuller talked about film in one room while Argentine novelists discussed literature in the next. On the same evening, a new political play had a premiere.

title: SOME BIG NEWS
description: Manager Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals, when asked by a sportswriter whether the Mets were the team to beat next year: ''Were you out of the country? We won 101 games. Don't you think that makes us the team to beat? You must be from New York. The people in New York don't realize they lost yet.''

title: LEARJET DELAYS CONSOLIDATION
description: Officials of the Gates Learjet Corporation said that they had postponed their planned consolidation of manufacturing operations and had appointed a former Learjet president to re-evaluate it. The company said it would consolidate its manufacturing in Wichita during its regular Christmas holiday shutdown.

title: A LOST ALBUM OF PHOTOS IN THE SNOWS OF GANDER
description: Through most of the day ambulances and army trucks slowly bumped their way up a dirt service road from the thick woods on the shore of Gander Lake to a hangar on the edge of the airport grounds.

title: TEXT OF STAT CHARGES AGAINST MEDICAL EXAMINER
description: Following is the text of the case-by-case charges by the New York State Board for Professional Medical Conduct against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: JAPAN IS SAID TO PLAN END TO CAR RESTRAINTS
description: Japan plans to end its restraints on auto exports to the United States after they expire this spring, according to several press reports here, but Japanese Government officials said today that no decision has yet been made.

title: SENATE VOTES TO SETTLE CLAIMS ON CHIPPEWA LANDS
description: The Senate today voted 58 to 35 for a bill that would settle decades of dispute over ownership of land once set aside for the White Earth Band Chippewa Indian Reservation in northern Minnesota.

title: THE SPACE SHUTTLE'S SUCCESSOR
description: AN aerospace vehicle that is expected to be used in the year 2000 and thereafter was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The craft is planned as the successor to the space shuttle.

title: DAVISUNDER TREATMENT
description: Two days after matching his career scoring high with 43 points against Golden State, Walter Davis has been placed on the National Basketball Association's suspended list by the Phoenix Suns after entering a southern California center for treatment for drug and/or alcohol abuse. The 31-year-old Davis, a five-time all-star who was leading the Suns in scoring this season will be out a minimum of four weeks. General Manager Jerry Colangelo would not reveal the location of the clinic, but said it had treated several major league baseball players and at least two N.B.A. players - Quintin Dailey of the Chicago Bulls and John Lucas of the Houston Rockets.

title: TREATING BLOOD PLASMA TO CURB AIDS VIRUS
description: A method of treating blood plasma fractions to reduce the effect of viruses has been interpreted as offering advantages in preventing transmission of AIDS-related viruses to patients such as those suffering from hemophilia.

title: STRAWBERRY VOWS TO STAY HEALTHY
description: It happens almost every afternoon after lunch: Darryl Strawberry gets into his car in the Los Angeles suburb of La Verne and drives 20 minutes to Brookside Park in Pasadena. And there, in the shadow of the Rose Bowl, in the company of Eric Davis of the Cincinnati Reds and Chris Brown of the San Francisco Giants, he starts swinging at baseballs and testing the most damaged and most important thumb in the history of the Mets.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Dec. 2 from Bhopal, India, about the Union Carbide factory there misidentified a company official who was released on bail after the gas leak at the factory a year ago. It was J. Mukund who was freed (along with S. P. Choudhary). Brij Shukla is chief investigator for the Indian Central Bureau of Investigation, not an arrested official.

title: PRICES ON COFFEE SPURT DESPITE RISE IN QUOTAS
description: Prices of coffee futures rose sharply today despite a move by an international marketing agency to expand export quotas for the world trade. Coffee prices set life-of-contract highs and were mostly up the limit of 6 cents a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

title: When Presidents Need To Be Above the Crowd
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL CLEANUP OF OIL SPILL IN HILLS OF PENNSYLVANIA PUTS RESIDENTS AT ODDS
description: When Elizabeth Morrison turned on the faucet in her basement laundry room, a spark set off an explosion that knocked her out of her shoes, flinging her more than 10 feet across the room.

title: TEXACO'S RATINGS CUT
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had downgraded its ratings on Texaco Inc.'s bonds and commercial paper in light of the uncertainty over the outcome of Texaco's legal battle with the Pennzoil Company. The action by S.&P. follows the decision on Wednesday by Moody's Investors Service to lower Texaco's credit ratings and means that Texaco's debt is now rated as below investment grade by both major ratings services.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Novt 3
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $127,000. c-Including a tax credit of $527,000.

title: BOON FOR MUSEUMS SEEN
description: In addition to making possible exchanges of exhibitions such as in the agreement announced yesterday on collections of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art, the resumption of Soviet-American cultural exchanges is likely to benefit the museum world in another way: Loans of individual key paintings from the Soviet Union can once again take their place in major retrospectives of the painters in the West who were bought by Russian collectors before 1914.

title: FREE BUSES TO ICE RINKS
description: Ice skaters may now ignore the wind-chill factor, the safety factor and the taxicab factor, if those have deterred them from getting to their sport.

title: JUDGE RULES FOR YUKICA
description: A judge said today that Dartmouth had breached the contract of Joe Yukica when it dismissed him as football coach.

title: YOGI WISDOM
description: Yogi Berra, talking to Al Campanis at the baseball meetings in San Diego, recalls a minor league playoff series in which they once opposed each other: ''You wouldn't have won it if we'd beaten you.''

title: KOCH POPS OUT CORK AND AWKWARD QUIP
description: Several hundred cases of New York State wine were being donated to Mayor Koch to serve at official city functions, and the Mayor popped the cork on a bottle of champagne at City Hall.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: ENSEMBLE 13
description: The clear highlight of the German chamber music group Ensemble 13's Wednesday night concert at Cooper Union was a performance of Arvo Part's ''Tabula Rasa.''

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GORMAN GETS CUP POST
description: The United States Tennis Association has confirmed that Tom Gorman has been selected to succeed Arthur Ashe as captain of the nation's Davis Cup team.

title: THE HEIMLICH MANEUVER SAVES A PROPONENT
description: Since 1971, when Dr. Frank Field, the newsman, demonstrated the Heimlich maneuver on television with Dr. Henry J. Heimlich, he has been an advocate of the technique that saves people from choking to death.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED ON ABUSE CHARGES IN PRISON CASE
description: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today in the case of seven defendants being tried on charges of abusing prison inmates in a 1983 disburbance. The action came after jurors said they could not reach a verdict on civil rights charges against four people in the case.

title: SKIER STILL IN COMA
description: Christine Putz of Innsbruck, Austria, remained in a coma at Les Sablons Hospital near Grenoble, France, yesterday, a day after her crash in a World Cup downhill skiing competition, race officials reported. The 19-year-old skier hit her head twice in the fall, which occurred about two-thirds of the way down a course normally raced by men. Because of insufficient snow, the women had to switch to the men's course for most of the run.

title: SPINKS TRIOUMPHS
description: Leon Spinks, the former world heavyweight champion, stopped Kevin (Kip) Kane at 1:37 of the eighth round last night to win the vacant World Boxing Council Continental Americas heavyweight title at Felt Forum.

title: BUDGET ACCORDS ON THE MILITARY AND ON TOBACCO
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed tonight on a 1986 Pentagon budget of $298.7 billion and approved limited production of chemical weapons beginning next year, ending a 16-year ban.

title: WINNING IS ACADEMIC AT AUGUSTANA
description: Shortly after practice earlier this week, Lynn Thomsen, Augustana College's all-conference defensive tackle, tried to explain how his classmates feel about their football team.

title: BAVARO'S ANKLE SPRAINED
description: Mark Bavaro, the Giants' starting tight end, suffered a sprained right ankle today when he stepped on the foot of another player in practice. Though X-rays were negative, Coach Bill Parcells placed Bavaro on the injury list as questionable, which meant he had a 50-50 chance to play Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A Team in Trouble
description: It was an impressive new Democratic consulting team that came together last April: Patrick Caddell, the polltaker for President Carter; Robert Shrum, speechwriter for Senator Edward M. Kennedy Jr. of Massachusetts, and David Doak, a political manager who helped engineer the successful gubernatorial strategies of Charles S. Robb and Gerald L. Baliles in Virginia. They presented themselves as a full-service company to corporate and political clients, offering polling, media buying, campaign strategy and the production of television advertising in one package, an approach Mr. Doak said would ''revolutionize'' the consulting business.

title: Fizz in These Bones Yet
description: The Punchline of the Week Award goes to Representative Claude Pepper, the Florida Democrat, who delivered it at a hear-ing on fraudulent mail-order degrees. Mr. Pepper, 85 years old, who received a law degree from Harvard in 1924, said he received a degree last month from a place calling itself Union University in Los Angeles. To get it he paid $1,810 and submitted a book report on ''The Power of Positive Thinking.'' The degree was a Ph.D. in psychology, he said, adding, ''I can now be called Doctor Pepper.''

title: FREEDOM REJECTS $670 MILLION BID
description: Freedom Newspapers Inc., which operates 29 newspapers and 4 television stations, has rejected a $108-a-share bid, or a total of $670 million, for two-thirds of the company. The company also said it intends to defend itself against the possibility of Harry Hoiles selling his stock publicly. Mr. Hoiles, who has made two previous bids for the stock this year, controls one-third of the company.

title: MILLER SETS MARK, DRAWS EJECTION
description: Cheryl Miller broke the school career basketball scoring record for men and women tonight and finished with 22 points for the game as fourth-ranked Southern California defeated 11th-ranked Tennessee, 85-77, at the Los Angeles Sports Arena.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Bob Gutkowski, president of the Madison Square Garden cable television operation, has been named to supervise the Garden's boxing program. John Condon is stepping down after six years as president of boxing at the Garden. . . . The Islanders reduced their roster to 23 players by returning Bob Bassen, a center, and Neal Coulter, a right wing, to the Springfield (Mass.) farm team in the American Hockey League. Bassen had a goal and an assist in eight games, and Coulter had three goals and four assists in 16 games. . . . Danny Ainge, the Celtic guard who would have been eligible for free agency after this season, has signed a new contract with Boston, reportedly for six years.

title: HONEYWELL'S STOCK JUMPS
description: Honeywell Inc.'s stock jumped $13.25 a share yesterday morning, reaching $86.50 at one point, on rumors that management was considering a leveraged buyout.

title: Flimflam on Central America
description: As the Reagan Administration completes its fifth year, there is no sign that it is persuading critics of its policies in Central America to accept its version of what is happening in that troubled region.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on Monday from Georgetown, Guyana, about election preparations misattributed an American assessment of ''fraud and intimidation'' in Guyanese elections over the last two decades. The source was not the United States Embassy but a State Department report on human rights issued in 1984.

title: SECURITY DISMISSAL BOARDS PROPOSED FOR U.S.
description: The Office of Personnel Management is seeking to revive a long dormant procedure to summarily dismiss Federal employees suspected of threatening national security.

title: A School Where Jobs Are Part of the Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIAN HEALTH AIDE REINSTATED
description: The director of the Indian Health Service has been reinstated after a five-and-a-half-month suspension imposed because of questions about possible favoritism in the handling of his daughter's application for a scholarship from the agency.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MACHINISTS REACH TENTATIVE PACT IN THE STRIKE AT PRATT & WHITNEY
description: Negotiators for striking machinists reached a tentative agreement with the management of Pratt & Whitney yesterday and scheduled a vote for tomorrow that could end a two-week strike at three Connecticut factories of the jet engine manufacturer, a union spokesman said.

title: PRESIDENT STILL SEEKS TAX VOTES
description: Despite fresh efforts today by the White House and Republican Congressional leaders to break the impasse blocking House consideration of a major tax bill, President Reagan was apparently still unable to promise enough Republican votes to win passage of the bill.

title: Foggy Bottom Wins One
description: The State Department is on the verge of winning a long struggle to upgrade two jobs it considers vital to arms control and intelligence: director of the Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs, now held by H. Allen Holmes, and director of the Bureau of Intelligence and Research, now held by Morton I. Abramowitz.

title: A FLURRY FROM CONGRESS HAS REAGAN WOBBLING
description: IT was not a good week for President Reagan on Capitol Hill. As the frenzy to end the 1985 session accelerated, Republicans ambushed a package of tax revisions that Mr. Reagan considers the centerpiece of his domestic program and prevented it from reaching the House floor for debate. There was still some chance that enough Republicans would switch their votes to revive the measure this week, before Congress recesses for the year, but that would not erase the stark image of a President embarrassed by members of his own party.

title: MEN'S POWER, WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: ''Today's Woman: Running in Place'' is right on point per its fundamental thesis that the world at large demands that women be better than men before being accepted as equals.

title: THEATER SURVIVES IN SHADOW OF CASINOS
description: GETTING a serious regional theater going anywhere is chancy. Sustaining one in a resort area - especially one just 10 miles from Atlantic City -may seem, to some, a foolish fantasy.

title: SHAKESPEARE'S NEW POEM: A SCHOLAR'S CLUES AND CONCLUSIONS
description: ON the evening of Nov. 14, while I was routinely checking references in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, I came across an item I did not recognize, a poem attributed to William Shakespeare, with the first line ''Shall I die?
