Shall I fly?'' I asked for the manuscript to be fetched and late the next morning I went back to check it. I found the literary equivalent of Sleeping Beauty, a nameless poem awakening from the ancient sheets in which it had lain undisturbed for centuries, a poem without a critical history.

title: BUSH'S VOODOO POLITICS
description: Of all the horses at the starting gate for the l988 Presidential race, Vice President Bush probably has the best track record. But he may be jumping the gun. None of them can match his experience in the White House, in the Congress, in business, in diplomacy as Ambassador to China and the United Nations, or in the subterranean world where he worked as head of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: SOLDIERS ON CHARTEREDJET THAT CRASHED AT GANDER
description: Following is a list of soldiers aboard the Arrow Air charter jet that crashed Thursday in Gander, Newfoundland, as made public today by the Defense Department, which was withholding other names pending notification of relatives: ABRAMS, Mark Edward, Pfc, Rhodell, W. Va. ALEXANDER, Herbert, Pfc., Ponchatoula, La.

title: FUEL CELL INSTALLED IN PRINCETON
description: AN EXPERIMENTAL fuel cell similar to the encapsulated portable energy source used in the space shuttle program has been put into service at Princeton University.

title: SLEEPWRITING AND GLAD CAFES
description: SOMETHING should be done to make the work of American writers easier. We know how difficult it is; they've told us. In ''How to Write While You Sleep'' (Writer's Digest Books), Elizabeth Irvin Ross has some helpful suggestions. ''If you're a writer,'' she says, ''that means you can 'write' while you sleep.'' You can use your dream time to ''make your writing more descriptive,'' for researchers have discovered ''that you can hear, smell, touch, and taste in your dreams; often, you dream in color.''

title: NEW EAGLEGTON UNIT WILL STUDY SCHOOLS
description: A GROUP of researchers and analysts at Rutgers University's Eagleton Institute of Politics has won a $6.5 million Federal grant for a new center to tackle some of the thorniest issues growing out of state and local actions to improve public schools.

title: A POWERFUL COLOR PORTRAIT OF CHINA
description: IN his book ''The Decisive Moment,''

title: CORRECTION
description: Picture captions accompanying an article on part-time magistrates in Connecticut last Sunday were transposed. David Ertman was shown at the top; Edward J. Berns below.

title: PUBLIC RADIO OFFERS LIVE CONCERT SERIES
description: CONNECTICUT PUBLIC RADIO has introduced a new program devoted to the music of performing groups based in the state, as well as visiting ensembles.

title: LAST-MINUTE 'SAVES' ON THE OPERA STAGE
description: For all the temperament and intrigue that one associates with the opera world, there do exist some reassuring stories of last-minute rescues of one singer by another. Enrico Caruso, turning his back to a Philadelphia audience, once sang Colline's coat song from ''La Boheme'' for an indisposed Andres de Segurola; this most celebrated tenor later recorded Puccini's popular bass aria. A 1984 Metropolitan Opera performance of Offenbach's ''Tales of Hoffmann'' featured Kenneth Riegel in the orchestra pit, singing the tenor role, while a hoarse William Lewis acted out the part on stage. ''It was like singing with Charlie McCarthy,'' the soprano Catherine Malfitano said after the ordeal was over. (Ironically, Mr. Lewis was himself a substitute for an ailing Neil Shicoff.) And - as if the story of the Richard Strauss-Hugo von Hofmannsthal symbolic opera ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' weren't already difficult to follow - a Nov. 24 performance of the work at the Zurich Opernhaus featured the same woman singing two leading roles, simultaneously.

title: OPPORTUNITIES FOR EDUCATION
description: A rights debate has been mounting on two parallel fronts: caring for the homeless, and curbing the transmission of AIDS.

title: THEY LAUGHED WHEN SHE STOOD UP
description: I'M NOT MAKING THIS UP, YOU KNOW The Autobiography of the Queen of Musical Parody. By Anna Russell. Edited by Janet Vickers. Illustrated. 246 pp. New York: Continuum. $17.95.

title: LEESA KELLY MARRIES TIMOTHY DONNER
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Leesa Ray Kelly, a daughter of Mrs. Raymond N. Kelly of Washington, Pa., and the late Mr. Kelly, was married to Timothy Elting Donner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Donner of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: Mullin's Rocky Start
description: He's a rookie trying to make it in the National Basketball Association 3,000 miles from home, and for Chris Mullin, the former St. John's star now playing for the Golden State Warriors, it has not been easy. Mullin, who missed training camp while contract negotiations dragged on through the exhibition season, has been shooting 44 percent from the floor, 11 perentage points below his average at St. John's, and well below his own and the Warriors' expectations.

title: CONCORD'S 'SILLY PROBLEM': SNACK TAX
description: These days a customer in a sandwich shop who orders a ham on rye and a can of soda pays a 7 percent tax on the food but none on the drink. But if the same soda is in a cup he is taxed for both, according to the Commissioner of Revenue Administration.

title: A CHILDREN'S SUMMIT MEETING
description: The participants at this summit were much younger than those in Geneva. The friendly banter was about homework, school and sports. But the aspirations were the same - peace and an end to the nuclear arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: STATUE OF LIBERTY: The First Hundred Years. By Christian Blanchet and Bertrand Dard. English-language version by Bernard A. Weisberger. (American Heritage/Houghton Mifflin, $29.95.) LIBERTY: The Statue and the American Dream. By Leslie Allen (The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation/Summit Books, $32.95.) The tumultuous celebration next July 4 for the centennial rededication of the Statue of Liberty promises to make the adjective ''momentous'' emerge as an understatement. The same might be said for the sheer tonnage of books, films and assorted mementos the lady in New York Harbor is inspiring. If these two handsome, profusely illustrated volumes are gauges of what is to come, they augur well for high-quality birthday gifts. Bernard A. Weisberger's ''Statue of Liberty,'' based on a French version of the book by Christian Blanchet and Bertrand Dard, may well be one of the best in its treatment of the statue itself. As much picture as it is text, it offers a bright biography of this extraordinary figure, conceived during a dinner party by a group of influential republicans, as a gift of France in the name of liberty. We learn about its construction according to the most modern techniques applied by Frederic-Auguste Bartholdi, who created a genuine modern colossus. Although it was in a classic, old mold that many felt lacked artistic innovative genius, it has seized the imagination of the world. The story tells of the fund-raising, the commercialism, the idealism, the subsequent neglect that surrounded the statue during the 100 years since it was erected.

title: SEX-CASE DEFENSE ASSAILS THERAPISTS
description: For nearly two months, in a nearly deserted courtroom, the teachers and administrators accused of sexually abusing scores of children at a pre-school in nearby Manhattan Beach have presented an unusual defense.

title: LOOKING ASKANCE AT NEW VIEW OF WHITE HOUSE
description: The $100 million Metropolitan Square office complex, with its intimate views of the White House, is nearing completion. But preservationists are not giving up their fight and have asked the Supreme Court for a hearing.

title: GEESE INCREASE AS DUCKS DWINDLE
description: WILD ducks have become victims of Long Island's rapid development, but those same conditions have enabled the wild goose population to rise, according to wildlife experts.

title: Article 220785 -- No Title
description: DURING a lunch hour one day recently, when most bank lobbies in Hartford were jammed with people, the lobby at Financial Federal Savings Bank at 100 Constitution Plaza was nearly deserted.

title: Orwell Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: ACORPORATE-CAMPUS SYMBIOSIS
description: THE annual meetings of major college and university associations are dedicated to the theme of corporate-college partnerships, and well they should.

title: U.S. FIGHTING ORDER ON VDT'S
description: An arbitrator has ruled that the Labor Department violated the rights of a handicapped employee whose impaired vision made it difficult for her to use a computer monitoring terminal. The department is appealing the decision.

title: CUREPHOBIA
description: Two recent guests on NBC's ''Today'' show, a dentist and a psychologist, talked with straight faces about a new disease, ''dentalphobia.''

title: DIFFERENT WAYS TO CUT THE TIES THAT BIND
description: I look forward to reading the Long Island Weekly section every Sunday, but I was rather disturbed by Arlene Levine's recent ''Cutting the Ties That Bind'' [Opinion Page] .

title: JEFFERSON LAP DESK IS SOLD FOR $55,000
description: Thomas Jefferson's lap desk, on view at the White House for 23 years until last June, was sold Wednesday for $55,000 to Daniel Jordan, director of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation, which runs Monticello, the Jefferson mansion. Mr. Jordan, who made the purchase at Phillips, Son & Neale, said he represented both Monticello and the diplomatic reception rooms of the State Department, which would share the cost of the desk and its ownership.

title: PHONE USERS TO GET CHOICE OF SERVICES
description: THE users of 60,000 telephone lines in Stamford are to become the first in the state to be offered a choice of interstate long-distance companies, a process that is to begin this month when the Southern New England Telephone Company sends the users notifications in their telephone bills.

title: GUIDELINES FOR PICKING A CHRISTMAS TREE
description: ONCE again, it is time to select the family Christmas tree. This can be a pleasant outing for the family, assuming that everyone will agree on what constitutes the right tree. But it is not uncommon for it to be a source of family discord with every tree on the lot either being too short or too tall, too fat or too skinny to please everyone. Perhaps a few guidelines will be helpful in making the right choice.

title: INDIA'S NORTHEAST SEEMS LIKE A WORLD OF ITS OWN
description: When wildlife authorities transferred five rhinoceroses from a sanctuary in Assam to another part of India, people here were outraged. They called it yet another act of exploitation and highhandedness by the central Government. In remote northeastern India, almost everything New Delhi does is suspect.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: GONGORA. Illustrated by Pablo Picasso. Poetry by Luis de Gongora y Argote. Translated by Alan S. Trueblood. (Braziller, $50.) An artist of astounding versatility, Picasso often turned his talents to literary collaboration.

title: FROZEN ASSETS
description: COMPANY OF ADVENTURERS Volume One. By Peter C. Newman. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: Viking. $25. ONE long evening long ago in northern Canada an unhappy man named James Isham smashed a blood-bloated mosquito onto the page of his personal journal, right next to an anguished entry about the insect swarms that dominate summer life in that part of the world to this day.

title: UPSTATE INNS IN THE GRAND MANNER
description: In 1885, a newly married Cincinnati society figure asked one of the favored architects of the day to design a castle, with turrets, a gabled porte-cochere, and finely carved wood paneling for many private and public rooms. Her fantasy, in deep red Medina stone, still stands guard, poised among ancient firs and white oaks over Seneca Lake in Geneva, N.Y.

title: Divestiture Suit Called Personal One
description: In the Dec. 1 article on the state's divestiture law, Mayor Thomas G. Dunn of Elizabeth was quoted as having said that a suit seeking to void the law would be filed ''in my behalf and that of the city . . .'' For him to do so would be in direct conflict with Elizabeth city ordinances.

title: A MAYOR RESIGNS
description: Roger Hedgecock was supposed to spend the next two years as San Diego's Mayor.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS ARE BRIEFED ON AIDS
description: EDUCATING teen-agers - not barring elementary school AIDS victims from the classroom - is the way to stop the spread of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in schools, a panel of medical experts told a conference of nearly 300 school board members and nurses.

title: '86 HOPES UP FOR PENNSYLVANIA G.O.P.
description: With a United States Senate seat at stake and a new governor guaranteed, Pennsylvania faces a big political year in 1986. But three of the biggest developments have come in 1985, one of them this week, and all three appear to offer strong encouragement to the state's historically moderate, pragmatic Republican Party.

title: NEW ENGLAND VALLEY LURING ARTISANS
description: Josh Simpson relishes his high perch on the crest of a hill in Shelburne Falls, where he arrived with his wife a decade ago and turned a barn into his glass-blowing studio. ''You can see the thunder clouds coming out of the valley,'' he says, ''and you feel on top of the world.''

title: ONE-BRAND SYSTEMS SOLVE THE SHOPPING QUANDARY
description: This week everyone is too rushed to spend the hours it takes to pick stereo components. But that's no reason to forgo good sound - if that's what you have set your heart on. Even if you can't take much time to shop, you can still get it all together for the holidays. Just get a one-brand system.

title: 'THE HANDS OF ANGER, FRUSTRATION, HUMILIATION'
description: DALE Burr, a 63-year-old farmer in Hills, Iowa, whose financial difficulties threatened to take his land, livestock, machinery and his grain, which had been ''sealed,'' or put up as collateral for a Government loan, went on a rampage Monday, killing his wife, a bank president and a neighbor before committing suicide on a lonely road near his home.

title: NATIONAL STRATEGY TO PREVENT AND CONTROL AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE US ACCEPTS TOO MANY REFUGEES
description: America's golden door has always been open to refugees. The widespread interest in the ultimately unsuccessful effort of the Ukrainian seaman Miroslav Medved to defect to the United States shows how eager Americans are to offer sanctuary.

title: Canadian Official in India
description: Foreign Minister Joe Clark of Canada arrived today for talks with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and other officials. The talks are expected to center on a treaty that would allow India to extradite Sikh separatists living in Canada. Trade will also be discussed during Mr. Clark's six-day stay, officials said.

title: OPEC COMES TO GRIPS WITH A BUYER'S MARKET
description: Leaders of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said last week in Geneva that they were willing to risk an all-out price war, a desperate move, to check the steep decline in sales and revenues of recent years. Since 1979, the world has needed less oil than the producing countries wanted to sell, and the resulting glut has weighed heavily on the revenues of most of OPEC's 13 members. Some, such as Nigeria, are in deep financial trouble, while others, such as Saudi Arabia, are eating into enormous treasuries piled up during the 1970's.

title: PROFESSOR PRESSES BID TO GAIN FILES
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., sitting in a ''clean room'' on Capitol Hill, read through the classified file that the Central Intelligence Agency has kept for a quarter of a century on a Columbia University professor. When he had finished, he emerged to say the Government owed the professor an apology for labeling him a security risk.

title: KUROSAWA DIRECTS A CINEMATIC 'LEAR'
description: ''What has always troubled me about 'King Lear' is that Shakespeare gives his characters no past. We are plunged directly into the agonies of their present dilemmas without knowing how they came to this point.'' Unexpected criticism of the Bard from an unlikely source, but the thought takes on greater meaning as Akira Kurosawa pursues it in discussing ''Ran,'' his newest film, which has been called an adaptation of ''King Lear.'' ''How did Lear acquire the power that, as an old man, he abuses with such disastrous effects? Without knowing his past, I've never really understood the ferocity of his daughters' response to Lear's feeble attempts to shed his royal power. In 'Ran' I've tried to give Lear a history. I try to make clear that his power must rest upon a lifetime of bloodthirsty savagery. Forced to confront the consequences of his misdeeds, he is driven mad. But only by confronting his evil head on can he transcend it and begin to struggle again toward virtue.''

title: CHANGING HOME LOCKS: THE KEY IS TO KNOW YOUR DOOR
description: EXCEPT for occasional lubrication and tightening a loose set screw now and then, there is little the do-it-yourselfer can do to repair a worn out or broken door lock. In most cases, it is simpler to replace the lock - a fairly simple job for any home handyman.

title: PROSPECT OF PRIVATELY RUN PRISONS DIVIDES PENNSYLVANIA LEGISLATORS
description: The Pennsylvania House and Senate have both approved bills that would bar, at least for one year, the incarceration of felons in privately run prisons.

title: Lost Overboard
description: No one is an ''expert'' at surviving overboard except those who have done so.

title: NEW FOCUS ON THE OLD
description: ON A RECENT MORNING, in a small converted room in New York's Mount Sinai Medical Center, its oxygen outlets and nurses' call buttons still in place, a group of medical professionals sit around a metal table. The gathering is comprised of three postresidency fellows, a psychiatrist, three medical students, two social workers, two nurses, a pharmacologist and a physical therapist. As they do every week, they are discussing patients in the hospital's geriatrics evaluation unit.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 15, 1985 Fiction

title: GROWTH IN FINANCE JOBS SLACKENS IN MANHATTAN
description: The pace of job growth in the Manhattan financial industry, which had been the fastest-growing one in New York City, slowed dramatically in 1984, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: MUSIC: CHARLES DUTOIT CONDUCTS THE PHILHARMONIC
description: CHARLES DUTOIT, who began two weeks of guest-conducting with the New York Philharmonic Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, has made a lively reputation with his recordings, mostly with his Montreal Symphony. Now, he is beginning to appear more and more frequently with major orchestras in live concerts, and Thursday's program revealed a slightly different Dutoit than the one we've heard on disks.

title: AMERICAN MUSIC'S THE NEW WORLD LABEL'S SPECIALTY
description: It has been a decade since New World Records sent its first 10 disks into the world, and in that time, the label has proved that American music - new and old -can be a marketable commodity. Oddly enough, proving that proposition was not New World's original intention; in fact, the idea of offering the records on the retail market was an afterthought. When the label was incorporated, in June 1975, its aim was to produce a 100-disk anthology of American music, in honor of the Bicentennial year, and then to distribute 10,000 copies of the set to libraries, schools and government radio stations. Most of the anthology was to comprise original productions, but these were to be supplemented with licensed recordings, where pertinent or historically desirable. And because the recording and production costs were to be covered by a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, 70 percent of the sets could be distributed free, with the other 30 percent to be sold to schools and libraries at cost.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''This is one time politics must be put aside on both sides of the aisle.''

title: CABLE TV
description: Charles Dickens is well represented in cable films this pre-Christmas week, even as the author's spirit hovers over Broadway (''The Mystery of Edwin Drood'') and regular television (''A Christmas Carol'' and ''The Old Curiosity Shop,'' as cited elsewhere in the daily listings of The Guide).

title: Soccer Title To U.C.L.A.
description: U.C.L.A. captured the N.C.A.A. Division I soccer championship tonight but needed the longest game in collegiate history to outlast American University, 1-0.

title: Professionals
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: GLASS-MORAN 'JUNIPERI TREE,' IN CAMBRIDGE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 11 -Operas keep pouring forth from Philip Glass, but ''The Juniper Tree,'' which opened Wednesday night at the American Repertory Theater here and continues in repertory, with alternating casts, through Feb. 20, is a Glass opera with a difference. It also happens to be both charming and chilling, a children's opera for thinking children (also known as ''adults'').

title: ROMAN EMPIRE WITH ONE-LINERS
description: ''A FUNNY Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' the musical currently receiving a rousing production by the Long Island Stage, was a major turning point on two fronts when it opened on Broadway in 1962.

title: ABUSED WIFE TRIES TO START A NEW LIFE
description: FOR seven years, Mrs. R. fought the urge to walk away from her husband and the home they shared. It was not a happy place. In it, she had endured incessant verbal abuse that had eroded her self-confidence and withstood the increasing physical attacks her husband inflicted on her.

title: CAROLINA POTTERY, SHAPED BY TRADITION
description: In the pastoral South, bluegrass, barbecue and moonshine represent a style of living from the past, but the ground on which they were founded yields material of an even older Southern tradition: pottery making. Potteries reach from Marshall, Tex., to Georgia, from Mississippi's Gulf Coast to Waco, Ky., but nowhere in the United States does one area support so many master potters as the region around Seagrove in the heart of North Carolina. Here some potteries have been in operation since the 1700's, and they continue to serve as strong reminders of the past.

title: JAIL: WHO GOES, FOR HOW LONG?
description: CONFRONTING CRIME An American Challenge. By Elliott Currie. 326 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95. PAST OR FUTURE CRIMES Deservedness and Dangerousness in the Sentencing of Criminals. By Andrew von Hirsch. 220 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. $25.

title: A REPORTER ON THE TRAIL OF HER OWN LIFE
description: ''MAYBE we should call this book 'A Quiet Obsession,' '' said Doris McMillon of Great Neck. ''I was obsessed.''

title: WATERFOWL DECOYS A VANISHING ART
description: OLD, rare and superbly crafted waterfowl decoys are luring well-heeled collectors as effectively as they once tolled the wild birds they were fashioned to deceive.

title: 'HUMANITIES' MAY CHANGE BUT NOT THE NEED TO MASTER LANGUAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: PAMELA LEIGH OSWALD TO WED DR. DAVID NEIL LOUIS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Oswald of New York and Red Hook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Leigh Oswald, to Dr. David Neil Louis, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sydney Louis of Woodbury, L.I., and Hawley, Pa.

title: JOHN YOUNG AND BARBARA FAST-BISSELL, EXECUTIVES, ARE MARRIED AT ST. BART'S
description: Barbara Hoge Fast-Bissell, a daughter of Mrs. William Bradford Bissell and a stepdaughter of Dr. Bissell of Bellport and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to John Christopher Young, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Frederick Young of Sea Cliff, L.I. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: DIRECTORS FEEL THE LEGAL HEAT
description: IT used to be that everyone wanted to be a corporate director. The job required little more than meeting with colleagues once every few months. It was an easy way to get instant prestige and an extra couple of thousand dollars a month.

title: A NOVELIST SINGS A DIFFERENT TUNE
description: I NEVER PLANNED, OR even wanted, to write librettos. If someone had asked me, ''What are the requirements for being a librettist,'' I would have answered, ''Well, you would need to know a lot of technical things about music, and it would certainly help if you lived in another cen-tury, when audiences and producers were more hospitable to new operas.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption on page 23 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in The Guide, section 2A, carry outdated information on ''Enemy Mine.'' It will open on Friday at the Criterion, Gotham Cinema, Bay Cinema and U.A. 85th Street East.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Investing column in this section on Dec. 1 misstated the former name of the Crossland Savings Bank.

title: A.M.A. WANTS TO BAN ALL ADS FOR TOBACCO
description: The national movement against smoking shifted into a higher gear last week when the American Medical Association called for a blanket ban on the advertising of all tobacco products. The association's House of Delegates, meeting in Washington, voted overwhelmingly to push for legislation that would make it illegal to advertise cigarettes, cigars, chewing tobacco, snuff or any other tobacco product in ''any form of media.''

title: How Greenwich Meets Needs of the Aged
description: UNTIL she needed a series of operations a few years ago, 78-year-old Bertha Gazco had been able to manage the stairs and housekeeping in the two-family house in which she lived in Greenwich.

title: Shopping, the Last of It
description: A resourceful Washington merchant has devised a system to benefit rather than penalize the last-minute Christmas shopper.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS DETAIN REPORTERS
description: The police today briefly detained several reporters and television crew members who had been covering the funeral of victims of unrest.

title: BARGAINING TO BEGIN ON DEFINING JOBS
description: THE state may soon change its view of clerical workers - from the stenographers who take dictation to the administrative assistants who help run government offices.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BALLET IN HACKETTSTOWN The Ballet America Concert Dancers, the touring company of the Joffrey Ballet, will appear this evening at Centenary College in Hackettstown.

title: ELIZABETH HEARD WEDS PETER DONALD
description: Elizabeth Corbett Heard and Peter Gordon Donald were married yesterday in the chapel of St. George's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Thomas F. Pike. Mrs. Donald is a daughter of Col. Richard Townsend Heard, U.S.A., retired, of San Antonio and Virginia Lynch Heard of Center Sandwich, N.H. Mr. Donald is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Dunn Donald of New York.

title: CONSIDERING ALL INTERESTS
description: A rights debate has been mounting on two parallel fronts: caring for the homeless, and curbing the transmission of AIDS.

title: EWING'S LATE SPURT TOPPLES THE SPURS
description: For 23 games the Knicks and their fans had waited for Patrick Ewing to rise up and take control of a game down the stretch. Last night it happened and the Knicks defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 108-98, at Madison Square Garden.

title: A U.S. OFFER ON AFGHANISTAN
description: The United States made a formal offer last week that implied it would stop helping the rebels in Afghanistan - if Moscow agrees to withdraw the thousands of Soviet troops that have been fighting there since December 1979. The American offer, in the form of a guarantee of noninterference to be given by Pakistan, was sent to the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: The Mississippi
description: To the Editor: Hal Goodman (''Huck's River Revisited,'' Travel, Oct. 20) must have missed crossing the Mississippi River by ferry, which we've found gets one closer to the romantic river he was seeking.

title: TRENTON PANEL SUBPOENAS GENERAL AND E.P.A. AIDE ON POLLUTION BY MILITARY
description: THE commanding general of Fort Monmouth and the chief official of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for the New York-New Jersey region have been subpoenaed to appear here Tuesday before a special legislative committee investigating toxic and radioactive pollution at military installations in New Jersey.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THERE is plenty of gingerbread for Christmas in Plainfield. Not the kind to eat, but the kind to feast the eye upon. It decorates Victorian-style homes much the way the lacy icing decorates the spicy cookies (which is how the architectural term evolved): Fancy, ornamental carved woodwork along eave lines, under roof lines and on porch brackets.

title: WHEN ALL'S SAID AND DONE, THE VOICE SOUNDS JUST LIKE MOM
description: ''O.K., Mom, now we'll tape the message for your answering machine.

title: A SPECIAL 'OLD BLUE' IS RETURNING TO YALE
description: BY his own admission, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., has a lot to learn about Yale University during the next six months.

title: SHARING WHILE PARTYING
description: Arthurian Evenings Dec. 15, 18, 19, 20, 21 and 22 - They are the evenings of ''Madrigal,'' a spectacular Christmas feast, King Arthur style. There will be jugglers, mimes, strolling minstrels, a chorus of 26 to sing ancient songs accompanied by a 14-piece chamber orchestra and a lavish six-course dinner starting with a hearty flagon of wassail such as the Knights of the Round Table might have enjoyed. The festivities start at 8 P.M. each evening in the spacious dining hall, suitably bedecked as a medieval hall, of the Trinity School, 139 West 91st Street at Amsterdam Avenue. The evenings will benefit Covenant House in New York, founded 17 years ago as a haven for homeless and runaway youngsters. Tickets, $50, from 212-877-1684. Colombia Benefit Dec. 17 - In response to the volcano catastrophe in Colombia, a group of New Yorkers headed by Anne Eisenhower and Pilar Crespi, both of whom have spent years in the South American country, formed New York for Colombia to raise money for the American Red Cross Relief Action in Colombia to aid thousands of refugees. To meet some concerned New Yorkers and help the relief work, come to Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, for cocktails, 6 to 8:30 P.M. Tickets, $100, from 212-288-3390 Downtown Party Dec. 17 - The New York Art Theater Institute is a seven-year-old Off Off Broadway group that mixes visual and performing artists and that has, in addition to presenting avante-garde productions, gained a reputation for throwing some dazzling parties.

title: RETIRED DANCERS GET ADVICE
description: IN THE world of dance, time passes quickly, and many performers must retire from the stage around the age of 35 and search for a new career. For most, the transition is long and difficult.

title: CHRISTMAS AROUND THE WORLD
description: Although Americans are the most prolific users of Christmas stamps, other nations issue holiday stamps for use with greeting cards and letters. For some small nations, sales of such stamps to collectors represents a more significant source of revenue than that derived from sale for postal use.

title: JOHN ALLEN, THE COUNTY'S NEW SOCIAL SERVICES COMMISSIONER
description: THERE is an old saying that if you just stay in one place long enough, eventually everything will pass before your eyes. John J. Allen has been with the county's Department of Social Services for 37 years - only two less than the department itself has existed as a countywide agency - and he has seen all five of its commissioners come and go. Last week Mr. Allen was appointed to be its sixth.

title: CORRECTION
description: ''Who Lives Where,'' a map of New York City's ethnic makeup in the World of New York section on Nov. 3, incorrectly designated a strip of land in the East River. The strip, shown adjacent to the Upper East Side, should have been labeled Roosevelt Island. Although no ethnic group strongly predominates, the island should have been colored green, purple, brown and pale yellow (''Irish,'' ''European-Descended Jews,'' ''Other Europeans'' and ''Black, U.S.-Born'').

title: CORRECTION
description: The Food column in the Dec. 1 issue of this magazine misstated the amount of one ingredient used in Sylvia's fruitcake. The recipe calls for 8 ounces of walnut halves.

title: YALE'S NEW PRESIDENT VIEWS ITS FUTURE AND HIS
description: YALE University last week appointed Benno C. Schmidt Jr. as its 20th president, reclaiming him from Columbia University, where he was dean of the law school. Mr. Schmidt, 43, will succeed A. Bartlett Giamatti, who will step down in June after eight years as president. A graduate of Yale College and Yale Law School, Mr. Schmidt has spent the last 16 years as a member of the law faculty at Columbia, becoming dean last year. At Yale he will preside over more than 10,000 students, 2,200 faculty members, 5,600 other employees and a budget of $400 million. In an interview last week with Edward B. Fiske, education editor for The New York Times, Mr. Schmidt discussed his new job. Excerpts follow. --------------------------------Question. Do scholars think about being the president of an institution, of switching to the administrative?

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: THE GREEK WORLD: Classical, Byzantine and Modern. Edited by Robert Browning. (Thames & Hudson, $60.) A. A. Long, one of the contributors to this book, admits in his chapter that ''even a potted account of Greek philosophy from Thales to Aristotle would be quite impossible here.''

title: OPPOSITION IS VOWED ON PLAN FOR THE SALE OF HOUSING AGENCY
description: Opponents of a plan under which the Reagan Administration would sell the Federal Housing Administration to private bidders and cut housing subsidies in the 1987 fiscal year vowed today to fight the proposal in Congress.

title: 'STAR WARS' ADVANCES: THE PLAN VS. THE REALITY
description: More than two and a half years after President Reagan broached the idea of a space-based defense, many Administration experts and critics alike remain uncertain about the consequences of such a defense for nuclear strategy and arms control. Yet almost all in the Government are going along with the program and, as a result, it has moved forward significantly in the past six months.

title: BELINDA BUCK TO BE A BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Austin Buck of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Belinda Therese Buck to Morton Henrik Kielland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Halfdan Kielland of Oslo. A May wedding is planned.

title: SAURA'S NEW FILM RETURNS TO FLAMENCO
description: Carlos Saura, the lone wolf of Spanish cinema, and Antonio Gades, the great flamenco dancer and choreographer, were filming the last scene of their latest collaboration, ''Love, the Magician.''

title: IS HOME CARE WORTH THE PRICE (WHATEVER THAT IS)?
description: At his Senate confirmation hearing last week, Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the new Secretary of Health and Human Services, described home health care as ''the fastest growing component of Medicare,'' the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled.

title: Learning to Keep Count
description: I do not believe that the political-science professor was being ''absurdly quantitative'' when he listed the number of books he had worked on, rather than their content.

title: ONE MORE SURVIVOR
description: More than 23,000 people in and around the town of Armero, Colombia, died last month after the eruption of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano, but Maria Rosa Echeverri survived, trapped for 24 days by the mud that had engulfed her home.

title: DEPRESSING CONTRAST AT HOLIDAY TIME
description: For most of us, the holiday season is a joyous time of hopes and dreams.

title: DANCE: AILEY COMPANY IN AN ALL-AILEY PROGRAM
description: ALTHOUGH the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has a varied repertory, it occasionally devotes programs entirely to works by Alvin Ailey, its director. What made Thursday night's all-Ailey program unusual was the fact that Mr. Ailey served as commentator. It was one of several special events that the company is offering this season at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: U.S. PRODS ISRAEL FOR SPYING DATA
description: The Reagan Administration leaned on Israel last week to satisfy United States demands for evidence in the case of Jonathan Jay Pollard, an American Navy analyst accused of spying for Israel. American investigators met in Israel with Foreign Ministry and intelligence officials.

title: SCORES HURT, 11 SERIOUSLY, ON SKI LIFT IN COLORADO
description: A chairlift cable at a ski resort jolted violently today, throwing scores of skiers as far as 40 feet to the ground and seriously injuring at least 11.

title: DELAYS AFFLICT LUXURY HOMES AT ST. ANDREW'S
description: ''WE thought we were giving them everything anybody could want,'' said Stuart Polly, gesturing toward a bathroom as large as an ordinary living room, with its built-in towel warmers and hair dryer, its steam room and its wall-to-wall bathtub, so large it requires a commercial-sized water heater.

title: HOUSING QUESTIONS IN HEWLETT
description: A GROUP of Hewlett residents say they support a plan to demolish two rows of garages near their homes, but they are wary about replacing the garages with a dozen condominium town houses.

title: PEKING SAFETY IMPRESSES A NEW YORK OFFICER
description: Pickpockets, bicycle thieves and traffic accidents are the main concerns of Peking's Public Security Bureau, according to its director.

title: MAXINE SULLIVAN: 50 YEARS A SINGER AND STILL GROWING
description: The precise point of departure for the 50th anniversary that Maxine Sullivan is currently celebrating seems a bit uncertain. Does the anniversary stem from her appearance at an after-hours club in Pittsburgh wonderously named The Benjamin Harrison Literary Society? Members of Chick Webb's orchestra heard her there in 1934 and, according to the jazz historian Chris Albertson, two members of the band - the bassist John Kirby and the pianist Cliff Jackson - remembered her so favorably that each later married her.

title: MICHIGANMAY LIMIT RACE AS FACTOR IN ADOPTIONS
description: The State of Michigan has apparently decided that it will no longer make race a primary factor in considering the placement of children for foster care or adoption.

title: THE ALLURE OF 'SINGLE STATE' MUNICIPALS
description: DEMAND for municipal bond funds has grown dramatically in 1985 as investors have sought to nail down higher net income than they could get from Treasury and corporate issues. In New York and other high-tax states, residents reached for even better equivalent yields by investing in so-called single-state funds, which restrict their investments to provide income free of state and local as well as Federal taxes. Many single-state investments were recently paying 8.25 percent to 8.75 percent tax-free - relatively high, compared with the approximately 11 percent taxable return on corporate bonds or 10 percent from Treasuries.

title: FOR ROBERT KLEIN, REAL LIFE IS A LAUGHING MATTER
description: There is a strange transformation occurring in the life of Robert Klein. When he leaves his home in the morning, he no longer ''goes down,'' as in down the elevator or the down the stairs of the vertical abodes in New York City better known as apartment buildings. Now he ''goes out,'' as in the great outdoors, better known as Westchester County.

title: ART BOOKS: TREATS FOR EYES AND MIND
description: ART books, as much a sign of Christmas as the Rockefeller Center tree, can be ornate, excessively lavish and sometimes unmanageable, but some also offer delight to the eye and mind.

title: DEVILS TROUNCED BY NORDIQUES, 9-3
description: Michel Goulet scored four goals and Brent Ashton added three to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 9-3 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: SAM SHEPARD REVISITS THE AMERICAN HEARTLAND
description: In Sam Shepard's exhilarating new play, ''A Lie of the Mind,'' two families are divided against themselves and armed against each other. One family, on stage right, is Californian, fatherless and matriarchal. The other, stage left, is nomadic, Montanan and patriarchal. It would be no leap of the imagination to suggest that, as in a western movie, the Californians are homesteaders, the others are hunters. However, Shepard's new western story is not really a tale of rivalry on the range, but of interior domestic violence, the damage that one does to filial, fraternal and marital bonds - and the love that lingers in the air after the havoc has run its natural course.

title: PARKS TOOPEN INC COMET HUNT
description: New York City will set aside one clear night in January for stargazing and comet-hunting in four city parks, but even so, scientists warn that the prospects of observing Halley's comet from the city are dim at best.

title: ICING TRAIN ADS IN PHILADELPHIA
description: THE transit agency that serves Philadelphia and beyond was feeling so good about recent improvements that it opened an advertising campaign to give out the news. But last week, bad weather froze switches on tracks and iced power lines, and some trains ran 90 minutes late.

title: SOMETHING OLD, SOMETHING NEW
description: MONTE CRISTO in Great River is an Italian-Continental restaurant of old-fashioned standard issue with many new ideas grafted onto it. It is overdecorated in dark wood with stained-glass lamps, bric-a-brac pinned or placed on every surface and hanging plastic plants. Imitation flowers are tucked into bud vases on each table, and ''Old Blue Eyes'' croons through the sound system.

title: Hasselbeck Is Activated
description: The Giants, concerned about injuries to two key players, activated Don Hasselbeck and Lee Rouson today for Sunday's game here against the Dallas Cowboys. To make room, the Giants placed Mark Haynes and Jeff Hostetler on injured reserve.

title: Chile Extends Emergency Decrees
description: The military Government today extended its emergency powers to restrict civil liberties and press freedom for 90 days.

title: Verse That Affirms
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AUTOPSIES SET FOR CRASH VICTIMS
description: The bodies of 248 American soldiers and 8 crew members killed in the crash of a DC-8 jetliner will be sent to Delaware for autopsies beginning Monday, Canadian and United States officials said today.

title: BASEBALL WORLD REMEMBERS THE COURAGE OF MARRIS
description: As the baseball world mourned his death yesterday at the age of 51, Roger Maris, the former Yankee slugger who hit a record 61 home runs in 1961, was remembered as a multitalented player whose home run record eclipsed his other skills. He was also recalled as a loyal and unassuming friend who had dealt with the cancer that would claim his life in the same way he had handled the pressures of chasing Babe Ruth's home run record - with quiet courage.

title: CAN CONGRESS WALK AND CHEW GUM?
description: Can Congress Walk and Chew Gum? No way, people wise to the ways of Washington said last January. Congress can't possibly cope with the budget deficit and tax reform in the same year. They were right. As Shaw once said, to be cynical may be a sin but it is rarely mistaken.

title: About Men;   Rocking After Hours
description: WHO SAYS YOU can't have it all?'' asks the beer commercial. ''Who says you can't have pin stripes and rock 'n' roll?''

title: A Little-Known Allergy
description: IT CAN STRIKE ANYWHERE: THE EARS, THE neck, even the thighs of women who still wear garter belts with metal stocking holders.

title: FOUR VOICES IN THE MAKING
description: THE CHRISTMAS WIFE By Helen Norris. 136 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $11.95. HONEYMOON By Merrill Joan Gerber. 126 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $11.95. TENTACLES OF UNREASON By Joan Givner. 134 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $11.95. GETTING TO KNOW THE WEATHER By Pamela Painter. 117 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $11.95.

title: BRITAIN THROUGH BOOKS, RUSSIA BY BOAT
description: In Footsteps of Great Writers With a cast of characters running from Joseph Addison and Harrison Ainsworth to William Butler Yeats and Charlotte M. Yonge -not to mention Charles Dickens, Thomas Hardy and William Shakespeare - literature provides the theme for the latest addition to the Blue Guide series.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: THE ARCTIC WORLD. By Fred Bruemmer. (Sierra Club, $39.95.) Although the Arctic is an immense multinational, circumpolar portion of our globe, its uneven southern boundaries zigzag across latitudes so that, for example, while Irkutsk, Siberia, very definitely feels Arctic, Berlin, at the same latitude, doesn't.

title: A HOMECOMING TURNS INTO TRAGEDY
description: The banners had been hung in the Fort Campbell, Ky., gym. The base band was prepared to play. But last week's welcome for members of the 101st Airborne Division returning from a five-month peacekeeping stint in the Middle East turned into a wake. A chartered jetliner carrying the 248 soldiers and a crew of eight crashed in the Newfoundland woods Thursday, killing everyone aboard. It was the worst crash in Canadian history and brought the aviation death toll in 1985 to 1,948, the worst year on record.

title: ANOTHER SETBACK FOR PROSECUTION IN CASE AGAINST GAMBINO GROUP
description: The case against Paul Castellano, the reputed head of the Gambino crime organization, appeared full of unanswered questions last week after five days of testimony by the man billed as the prosecution's star witness.

title: NEW COMPETITOR FOR HAMPTON JITNEY
description: AFTER an eight-month legal struggle, the Montauk Bus Company began service last Monday between the East End and Manhattan on routes currently serviced by Hampton Jitney.

title: GERMANY'S DIVISION IS 'INHUMAN,' SHULTZ DECLARES ON VISIT TO BERLIN
description: On the eve of his first visit to Eastern Europe as Secretary of State, George P. Shultz today attacked the postwar division of Berlin and Germany as ''unnatural and inhuman.''

title: MARCOS PREDICTS HAVOC IF HELOSES VOTE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today accused his election opponent, Corazon Aquino, of being influenced by both Communist ''reds'' and American ''whites,'' and he warned that 10 years of bloodshed would follow an Aquino victory.

title: ENJOYING THE PLAYTHINGS OF YESTERYEAR
description: Toys from the attic of the Museum of the City of New York - tin wagons, a cast-iron circus, French china-head dolls, a Mickey Mouse bank - have moved to midtown for the holidays and are on view in the lobby of the Paine Webber Building, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (at 51st Street), through Feb. 3.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Pleasantville Shop Gives Film New Look Cousins Audio-Video Center of Pleasantville opened 42 years ago, long before the invention or prevalence in most homes of much of its present stock - video cameras, recorders, tapes and cassettes, big-screen color television sets, stereo equipment, answering machines, microwave ovens, portable AM/FM stereo cassette radios and headphone radios for AM/FM or stereo cassette.

title: 'DOLLY' IN DARIEN: A PRODUCTION WITH A FEW HIGH POINTS
description: On opening night at the Darien Dinner Theater last Sunday, ''Hello, Dolly!'' was introduced as ''America's favorite musical.'' Such a sweeping statement, arguable even with the best of ''Dollys,'' is hardly supported by the tentative staging in Darien.

title: 69 Suspects in Philadelphia Charged in Credit Card Fraud
description: Dozens of people have been charged in a credit card fraud scheme that netted about $500,000 in merchandise, the district attorney's office said.

title: CONRAIL SALE HANGS ON ANTITRUST ISSUE
description: THE success of the Norfolk Southern Corporation's bid for the Federal Government's controlling interest in Conrail, the freight-only carrier, hinges in large measure on its getting Department of Justice approval.

title: JUDGE ORDERS ROCKWELL TODONATE TO CHARITIES
description: Rockwell International Inc. has been ordered to give $200,000 to charities in the Dallas area by a Federal district judge who said the ''poor, helpless and unsophisticated'' were the real victims of the military contractor's overcharges.

title: WAS CUBA PART OF CHINA?
description: CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS By Gianni Granzotto. Translated by Stephen Sartarelli. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $18.95.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: IT GETS HARDER AND harder to avoid entertainment overload. At our house, for instance, you get a minimum of four entertainments in the short journey from the front door to the kitchen, which is in the back of the house.

title: RIVAL CYPRIOT CHIEFS VOICE PESSIMISM ON PACT
description: President Spyros Kyprianou and Rauf Denktash, the leaders of the Greek and Turkish parts of Cyprus, expressed deep pessimism this week about the chances of reaching an agreement to reunite this divided island.

title: Data Bank;   December 15, 1985
New & Noteworthy
description: WASHINGTON DESPATCHES 1941-1945: Weekly Political Reports From the British Embassy, edited by H. G. Nicholas. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) Serving as a diplomat during World War II, the British philosopher Isaiah Berlin wrote most of these reports from Washington, and he has also contributed an introduction to this collection. It begins with the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and ends shortly after the Japanese surrender. In 1981 in these pages, John Kenneth Galbraith said, ''There will never be a better, more luminous view of how things looked at that time.'' A FANATIC HEART: Selected Stories, by Edna O'Brien. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Last year our reviewer, Mary Gordon, wrote that ''Edna O'Brien tells the Irish woman's inside story. She has - as only the finest writers can - created a world; she speaks in a voice identifiably and only hers. . . .

title: Q & A
description: Question:Is there a shopping guidebook that specializes in where and what to buy in Europe? - G. L., Hewlett, N.Y. Answer:Shoppers who want a book that makes a general survey, without much detail, of shopping in 17 countries may get some help from ''Fielding's Selective Shopping Guide to Europe'' ($5.95). But the most thorough and knowledgeable information is found in a few books limited to one city or country. Among these are the Gault and Millau guides called ''The Best of Paris'' ($14.95), ''The Best of London'' ($12.95) and ''The Best of Italy'' ($13.95), all published by Crown. These books assess the quality of hotels and restaurants as well as stores.

title: 14-0 STREAK ENDED IN 51-7 ROUT
description: The defense forced eight turnovers and Kevin Sweeney passed for three touchdowns today as Fresno State routed Bowling Green, 51-7, in the California Bowl, which matched two unbeaten teams.

title: COLLEGIAN AT 8
description: JENNY CUTLER was 8 years old and complaining of boredom in public elementary school in Auburn, Me., when her parents hit on a solution. They enrolled her in the University of Maine at Augusta.

title: BRAVO THRIVES ON CULTURE
description: Marking a significant anniversary by presenting a festival of films by the director Michael Powell and the screenwriter Emeric Pressburger - whose collaborations include such winning works as ''The Red Shoes'' and ''Black Narcissus'' - will probably seem a lesser entry in the world of promotion. But the fact that Bravo turned to these films to begin its sixth year of operation this week is an indication that such seemingly uncommercial fare has a lively constituency on this very viable service.

title: A MAY WEDDING FOR JULIE ROGERS
description: The engagement of Julie Babineau Rogers to Lyman Greenleaf Bullard Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bullard of Andover, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Courtenay Rogers of New Canaan, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: MY LITTLE GRASS CONDO
description: Eighteenth-century navigators to the Pacific Islands sent home glowing accounts of idyllic scenes and engaging people, and thereby established a lasting image of the islands as a paradise. If those adventurers could return today, they would be unable to recognize places they discovered, and in many cases named. Even during my own years in the Pacific, the changes have been dramatic, and in some ways sad.

title: Riggins Wants to Stay
description: At the age of 36 he is the National Football League's oldest running back, he hasn't had his old power this season and his one-year contract is coming to an end with no prospect of extension. But don't talk to John Riggins about retiring.

title: WHEN A LANDSLIDE IS NOT A MANDATE
description: Even with a landslide victory in last week's presidential election, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo must tread a fine line. He recognizes what he has called ''the tremendous injustices'' in Guatemalan life. Yet he is also aware that his freedom to do something about them will be restricted not only by the country's faltering economy but also by the desire of some traditionally powerful people - particularly military officers, conservative businessmen and large landowners - to maintain a system that has brought them wealth and influence.

title: Legal Rights In Illegal Sublets
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M.'s CHIEF COUNSEL: ELMER W. JOHNSON;   LIMITING THE AUTO GIANT'S LIABILITY
description: ELMER W. JOHNSON, the top lawyer for the General Motors Corporation, is no stuffy, single-minded corporate counsel. He once prefaced a speech to some G.M. employees with a blaring trumpet solo. He preached a sermon on economics and God's justice at the University of Chicago's Rockefeller Memorial Chapel. His reading taste runs to Plato and John Stuart Mill; his writings carry such titles as ''Corporate Leadership and the Judeo-Christian Vision.''

title: PLEA ACCORD OVERTURNED IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has unanimously ruled that a plea agreement in which defendants pledge not to testify on behalf of co-defendants is unconstitutional.

title: Learning To Keep Count
description: The ''About Men'' column has become increasingly a forum for showing off (''Keeping Count,'' by Zick Rubin, Nov. 3).

title: JULIA HARRIS WED TO E. Z. HUGHES
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Crawford Harris of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward Zeller Hughes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bantley Hughes of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Joseph R. Gatto performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn.

title: SOME OLD FAVORITES IN YONKKERS
description: THOSE who believe that the quest for inventiveness, evident in the work of so many of today's savvy chefs, has reached absurd dimensions, need only dine at Villa Savone to be reassured that places grinding out the old familiar numbers, such as linguine with white clam sauce, spaghetti with meat sauce, veal parmigiana, chicken cacciatore, spumoni and tortoni, still thrive. There's nothing subtle about these renditions of old favorites at Villa Savone, where they are concocted with no more or less skill than one can find in other restaurants of this kind around the county. Exciting the food is not, but some diners will find its familiarity comfortable.

title: AUSTRIAN CAPTURES DOWNHILL
description: Peter Wirnsberger gave Austria its first downhill victory of the ski season in a men's World Cup race today.

title: THE MAGNIFICENT MEMORY RESIDENTS
description: LOOKING back as the year draws to a close, one of the most memorable things about 1985 in the personal computing world is memory itself. There is more of it, and it is used differently than had been expected. Most of the publicity concerned extended memory boards, which allowed the working memory of I.B.M. PC's and compatibles to be expanded beyond the 640K barrier.

title: NAVY SAYS HOUSING IS PROBLEM ON S.I.
description: American sailors can brave the open seas, but they cannot weather the New York City housing market, the Navy has concluded.

title: MORE OFFICIALS WILL FACE MORE POLYGRAPH TESTS
description: News leaks and other unauthorized disclosures of Government secrets have been a major concern for most of the Oval Office's recent occupants. White House officials confirmed last week that President Reagan, whose Administration has stalked leakers more vigorously than most, had ordered a more widespread use of lie-detector tests among officials who have access to highly sensitive security material.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Wages Will Weaken The new year's wage increases will not exactly have workers breaking out the champagne.

title: FLAMENCO GUITAR: SABICAS
description: LISTENING to Sabicas play flamenco music at Town Hall Friday night was impressive as much for the restraint as the flamboyance. Indeed, this is an art of guitar playing that thrives on control and proportion.

title: HARMONY, ELEGANCE IN THE EXURBS
description: MAXIME RIBERWA has weathered the difficulties that go with the territory when one opens an exurban restaurant and has emerged with a harmonious establishment. The homey, provincial dining rooms are at once elegant and comfortable. Heavy swag draperies, what must be a totem of elephant miniatures and a magnificently tall and stately flower arrangement helped fill the space attractively. Impeccably appointed tables bear green frosted-glass bowls like melted tallow in which deep pink and purple daisies float. Service is helpful, efficient and courteous, and the food an inspired balance of classic French cuisine sparked by nouvelle touches.

title: JENNIFER BITMAN TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Doris Sumerson of Philadelphia and Dr. Kenneth L. Bitman of Paoli, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Leigh Bitman to Adam Bela Liptak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bela G. Liptak of Stamford, Conn. A June wedding is planned. Miss Bitman, an apprentice artist with the MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour of the Public Broadcasting Service, graduated cum laude from Yale College, as did her fiance, a first-year student at the Yale Law School.

title: DANCE
description: Erick Hawkins makes dances that are, at their best, informed by a kind of poetic serenity especially welcome in the maelstrom activities of the holiday season. And the Erick Hawkins Dance Company will perform ''Plains Daybreak,'' one of Mr. Hawkins's loveliest and most serene dances, when it appears at Playhouse 46 from Tuesday through Saturday.

title: SEOUL IS PESSIMISTIC ABOUT BETTER TIES WITH NORTH
description: After more than a year of unusually steady and even amicable negotiations, South Korean officials say no substantive progress has been made with North Korea on possible two-way trade and large-scale exchanges of war-separated families.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Dumont
description: Mrs. Rene Marquet Dumont of Los Angeles has announced the engagement of her daughter Suzanne Renee Dumont to William Craik Hellendale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hellendale of Riverside, Conn. The wedding is planned for May 31.

title: Movement at the Alexander's Site
description: WITH its announcement this month that it would close its flagship store on Lexington Avenue and 58th Street as part of a blocklong redevelopment plan, Alexander's Inc., gave public expression to its long-assumed intention to extract greater value from one of its major assets, the ownership of choice East Side real estate.

title: PLAN FOR A STUDENT TRIP TO NICARAGUA DRAWS FIRE
description: PLANS for a student trip to Nicaragua during the coming winter recess to help peasants harvest a coffee-bean crop have generated criticism from Stockton State College officials and faculty members and conservative community factions here.

title: AVEDON TAKES A DARK VIEW OF THE WEST
description: In the photographs of the late Ansel Adams, the American West is composed of majestic landscapes that express the nobility of the human spirit. Everything is primeval, pure, just as it left God's hands. A younger generation of photographers has challenged this view of the West with pictures that include beer cans, tract houses and shopping malls, peopled either by slack-jawed, dull-eyed Philistines unworthy of the landscape they inhabit, or (the more radical version) puzzled, frightened victims of forces that have despoiled them along with the countryside.

title: P.L.O. SEEN AT ODDS OVER PEACE POLICYU
description: An argument has been going on within the Palestine Liberation Organization about whether it ought to make concessions in order to push the Middle East peace process forward, according to sources close to the Palestinians.

title: THE MAGIC TOUCH: IT WORKS ON THINGS THAT NEED FIXING NOT JUST ON PEOPLE
description: I'm a firm believer in ''laying on of hands.'' Once exclusively the province of evangelical preachers, its supporters say it is now a common from of therapy in some quarters.

title: School in Rhode Island Restricts Toilet Visits
description: Veterans High School is seeking to improve students' grades by cutting down on going to the bathroom.

title: CONDOS TAKE ROOT ON THE NORTH FORK
description: While residential development on Long Island's South Fork moved along at a fast clip throughout the 1970's, the Island's North Fork was largly overlooked by builders of waterfront condominium projects. Now such North Fork Villages as Greenport and Southhold are witnessing some of the East End's newest residential projects.

title: In the Midi
description: To the Editor: Hugh Leonard's ''Idling through the Midi'' invited envy.

title: Nativity Scene in Providence Moved to Avoid Legal Clash
description: A Knights of Columbus group has erected its traditional public Nativity scene, but across the street from City Hall instead of on the municipal building's steps, where it had been for four years.

title: How We See Each Other
description: As one who has spent considerable time in the last 15 years dealing with business colleagues in the Soviet Union, I felt the articles ''The View From America'' by David K. Shipler and ''The View From Russia'' by Serge Schmemann (Nov. 10), held an accurate mirror to the thoughts and feelings of the public in both countries. But, in my opinion, when we focus on what people think and feel today, we lose sight of why they feel and think as they do.

title: ISRAEL BARS ARAB GROUP FROM VISIT TO ARAFAT
description: Israeli military Government officials informed prominent West Bank Arabs today they may not travel to Jordan next week for a planned meeting with leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: LUCY KLINGENSTEIN TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Klingenstein of Rye, N.Y., and Abaco, the Bahamas, have announced the engagement of their daughter Lucy Lowe Klingenstein to Scott Alan Butterworth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Butterworth of Cheshire, Conn. A June 7 wedding is planned.

title: NOW, CHRISTMAS PAST
description: IN 1876, John B. Trevor, a well-to-do New York City stockbroker, built an imposing mansion along the banks of the Hudson River in Yonkers. Called Glenview, the mansion, designed in an eclectic melange of architectural styles, was used primarily as a summer residence. From time to time, however, the Trevor family would spend Christmas there, and decorated it lavishly with greenery and ornaments in the fashion of the time.

title: N.A.A.C.P. LEADERS EXAMINE CHANGE IN PRIORITIES
description: For the first time in at least eight years, leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People met privately in New York City this weekend to undertake a wide reassessment of the organization's goals and tactics.

title: 5 NEW WORKS JOIN COOKING BOOKSHELF
description: AN ECLECTIC quintet of recent cookbooks might be just what is needed for that last-minute Christmas gift. In addition, they contain ideas for food gifts to make and for elegant holiday-entertaining dishes.

title: RARE TIMEPIECES FEATURED IN EXHIBIT
description: ALMOST invariably, ''art is long and time is fleeting'', but one of the exceptions has to be the exhibit of clocks made and used throughout the Connecticut River Valley in the early 18th and 19th centuries, and now treasured by the collectors who still use them in the 20th century.

title: MUSICAL OFFERINGS FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: CHURCHES and concert halls are again preparing Christmas music for audiences whose appetite for it seems to be growing.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: RICHARD B. SELLERS, a former chairman and chief executive officer of Johnson & Johnson and a prime mover in the decade-old revitalization of New Brunswick, will step down Jan. 1 from volunteer positions as chairman of the New Brunswick Development Corporation and the New Brunswick Cultural Center Inc.

title: NO COMET TERRORS THIS TIME AROUND
description: To the Editor:

title: EDUCATORS ASSESS STATE'S SCHOOL SURVEY
description: AS the county's elementary and secondary schools hurried to meet today's state deadline for making public their academic scorecards, Westchester educators expressed concern that the results could be misinterpreted.

title: LORI BEZYACK ENGAGED TO BE WED TO A BANKER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Bezyack of Head of the Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Christine Bezyack, to Michael Robert Lyons, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Lyons of Nesconset, L.I.

title: PERSONAL TRAINERS BRING PHYSICAL FITNESS HOME
description: AMERICANS spent over $1.2 billion on home-exercise equipment in 1984, according to industry officials, indicating a growing trend to working out at home. But it is not only the lure of specialized machines that keeps people exercising closer to the hearth, but the rising popularity of personal trainers.

title: CINEMA DOODLES
description: THAT BOWLING ALLEY ON THE TIBER Tales of a Director. By Michelangelo Antonioni. Translated by William Arrowsmith. 208 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: FARM PACKAGE WINS APPROVAL FROM CONFEREES
description: House and Senate negotiators tonight reached agreement on the 1985 farm bill, ending eight days of deliberations.

title: COMET BRIGHTNESS TOPS EXPECTATIONS
description: Halley's comet is growing brighter, and from recent observations scientists believe it may put on a more spectacular show than had been predicted.

title: KINGSBRIDGE HEIGHTS
description: RESIDENTS of Kingsbridge Heights, perched on the hills of the northwest Bronx, lived through a frightening time in the 1970's and early 80's.

title: FAMILIAR PROBLEM FOR PINELLA
description: POOR Lou Piniella. He is more than two months away from the first spring training of his managerial career, and already the Yankees have a solid nucleus of unhappy players who could ignite the type of turmoil the Yankees have become accustomed to in the George Steinbrenner years. Britt Burns, the new No. 2 starting pitcher, said he eagerly looked forward to playing for the Yankees, but a substantial number of other players on the team as it is currently constituted could erupt from the opening day of spring camp.

title: Wisconsin Acts to Curb Harassing of Professors
description: People who attend classes at the University of Wisconsin to ferret out professors they regard as leftist could face a two-year jail sentence under a bill introduced Friday in the State Assembly.

title: A LATIN TEACHER'S THREE GIFTS
description: I RECEIVED three gifts this week and the common thread in the giving was the spontaneity of 12-year-olds. The first gift came yesterday from Marta. I was finishing lunch in my classroom, when Marta and a friend appeared in the doorway. ''You're five minutes early,'' I said. ''Does this mean you just can't wait to get to Latin class?''

title: The Sandwich Eater II
description: THE LAST TIME the world in general heard from R. J. Murray, he had missed the shot of a lifetime at a four-point buck because he was deeply involved in a turkey sandwich.

title: PTROTECTION FOR PRO-ARAB AMERICANS
description: It's taken too long for the rising violence against supporters of Arab causes in the United States to get the attention it deserves. In this year alone, bombings and other terrorist acts directed against ''enemies of Israel'' have killed two persons and injured many more.

title: NORTH AMERICA NEEDS FREE TRADE ZONE
description: NEWS reports that President Reagan wishes to begin negotiations on lowering tariffs and non-tariff barriers between the United States and Canada are welcome indeed. Less welcome is the persistent undercurrent of thought in Canada that reduced trade barriers will mean the destruction of our country's heritage and customs. The overriding fact is that the major North American economies need to establish a commercial union similar to the European Economic Community if they are to compete with Europe and the nations of the Pacific Rim.

title: LOBSTER INCREASE IS TAPERING OFF
description: A DRAMATIC increase in the lobster catch in Long Island Sound from 1982 through 1984 - almost double the catch of previous years - has now begun to decline, scientists say.

title: FLOWER MERCHANTS FIGHTING TO PRESERVE AN OASIS OF GREENERY IN MANHATTAN
description: On and around the Avenue of the Americas from 26th to 28th Street, amid an oasis of palms, ficus trees, yucca plants and other greenery, Manhattan's flower and plant merchants say they are fighting a battle on several fronts.

title: SUBWAY PING-PONG
description: Inevitably, Mayor Koch's demand that Governor Cuomo hold New York's subway fare at 90 cents prompted the Governor to return the favor. Pointing to the city's vaunted budget ''surplus,'' Mr. Cuomo suggested a quick investment underground.

title: SUSAN BELGARD TO WED ROBERT JAY GUMENICK
description: Susan Belgard, the chief of appeals and civil enforcement for the New York State Organized Crime Task Force in White Plains, and Robert Jay Gumenick, an associate in the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, plan to be married in February. Sam Rosenfeld of Jacksonville, Fla., has announced his daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Gumenick of Flushing, Queens.

title: FISHERMEN FIGHT RISE BY INSURERS
description: Arthur Ochse, the captain of the 90-foot scallop boat Dianne and Maureen, has fought icy weather, rough seas and the uncertainties of bringing in a good catch for 15 years.

title: DEAD LANGUAGE SPEAKS UP
description: ABC ET CETERA The Life & Times of the Roman Alphabet. By Alexander Humez and Nicholas Humez. 274 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $17.50.

title: EXPERTS DIVIDED ON UNION MEMBERSHIP
description: FIGURES that show trade-union membership declining precipitously in the state have been the object of a continuing debate between the leader of a major union organization and the Rutgers University economist who compiled the data.

title: LINDA LICAMELI IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. August M. Licameli of Fairview, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Linda Diane Licameli to Robert Wieczorek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wieczorek of East Falmouth, Mass.

title: RITA JENKINS WEDS JOHN SHELDON CLARK
description: Marguerite Martin Jenkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Nelson Jenkins of Warrenton, Va., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesteray to John Sheldon Clark, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Martin Clark Jr. of New York, Oyster Bay, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Larry Johnson performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Jenkins home in Warrenton.

title: AIRLINE CONFIRMS JET HAD PROBLEMS BEFORE CRASH
description: Arrow Air officials confirmed today that the chartered DC-8 that crashed in Gander, Newfoundland, killing all 256 people aboard, had mechanical difficulties earlier this year and had been forced to abort two takeoffs in the past six months.

title: THE RISING PRICE UNDERGROUND
description: While the quality of service on New York City's subways and buses may not be rising noticeably, beginning Jan. 1 the price of a ride will increase. After weeks of hearings, occasional demonstrations and almost nonstop finger-pointing, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Friday formally raised the price of a bus and subway token to $1.

title: SECOND WIND
description: ''We'll describe our return to Plains, the fact that I'm a relatively young ex-President, how we made decisions about the dozens of opportunities available, how we changed disappointment into gratifying prospects.'' Jimmy Carter the former President, explaining the theme of a book he and hs wife, Rosalynn, are writing about starting a new career after leaving the White House.

title: LEADERSHIP SCHOOL IS 30
description: FOR three decades, the Union Leadership Academy, part of the Institute of Management and Labor Relations in the labor education department at Rutgers University, has been nurturing union leadership through special classes for union members.

title: Lafcadio Hearn
description: To the Editor: Reading Michael Shapiro's affectionate story ''A Japanese Tribute to an Adopted Son'' (Travel, Nov. 10) was a delightful and exhilarating experience.

title: AUGUSTANA TAKES TITLE AND 37TH IN ROW
description: Augustana overpowered Ithaca, 20-7, today in the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III championship for an unprecedented third consecutive season and extend college football's longest current winning streak.

title: Weather For Bears
description: IN weather more suitable to a freezer than a Refrigerator, the Jets learned why the Chicago Bears are the National Football League's best team.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: THE STORY OF THE DANCING FROG. Written and illustrated by Quentin Blake. Knopf. $9.95. (Ages 5 to 9) A wildly funny tale, so improbable as to be called a ''shaggy frog'' story, about Gertrude and her pet frog, who had a long and glorious dancing career, traveled widely and became an international celebrity.

title: BALLANTINE HOUSE: VICTORIAN GEM
description: THE Newark Museum's Ballantine House, one of the state's most resplendent Victorian residential restorations, has been awarded National Historic Landmark status by the Department of the Interior.

title: ARCHDIOCESE SERVES HAITIANS
description: ''BON SOIR,'' the Rev.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the Style page last Sunday with an article about the return of important hats incorrectly described a hat and muff shown at the top of the page. They were made of stenciled calfskin, not the skin of a leopard, which is an endangered animal.

title: HELPING LIBRARIES MEET THEIR NEEDS
description: Thank you for the fine article, ''Libraries Run Out of Space for Books'' [Nov. 17] . As you probably will remember, Ridgefield had an anonymous donor who gave $1 million for a new library addition, with certain provisions involving money from the town for its upkeep and other details.

title: Antitrust
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLIDAY LIGHTS DRAW POLICE VETO
description: A trucker who calls himself ''Santy Claus'' on his citizens' band radio says he usually draws chuckles and friendly waves when he decorates his 18-wheel tractor-trailer with Christmas lights, but a Maryland police officer was not amused and gave him a $20 ticket.

title: 30 Drown in Indonesia
description: Thirty people drowned when a ferry capsized after hitting a tree in a river in central Sumatra, the police said today. About 80 people were rescued after the sinking in the Indragiri River on Tuesday.

title: MRS. AQUINO CUTS A DEAL IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: She may be a neophyte politician, but Corazon C. Aquino handled herself like an old pol last week. Three days after her unity ticket opposing President Ferdinand E. Marcos fell apart, and moments before the midnight filing deadline for candidates, the widow of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. -and, it is widely held, his successor as Mr. Marcos's strongest foe - convinced her chief rival in the Philippine opposition camp, Salvador H. Laurel, to climb back on her Presidential ticket as running mate.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: UNDERSEA LIFE. By Joseph S. Levine and Jeffrey L. Rotman. (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $24.95.) Marine ecology is a boundlessly fascinating subject, big and wild enough to touch on all the key questions.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: THE BAYEUX TAPESTRY. Introduced by David M. Wilson. (Knopf, $75.) Whoever designed the Bayeux tapestry nine centuries ago was one of the greatest narrators ever to tell a story. In pictures and words this embroidered linen strip 20 inches high and 230 feet long tells the story of the conquest of England by William of Normandy in 1066 so gracefully and clearly that few accounts of any historical event can match the swiftness of its narrative or its power over one's emotions. As a viewer watches the story unfold, the rich and tumultuous life of 11th-century nobles and their armies fills the imagination and when the Battle of Hastings finally comes into view the action becomes startlingly dramatic. The epic elevation and dignity of this great work lift the spirit; vanquished and conquerors alike move with energy one can feel across the centuries, they fight without treachery and their nobility endows the final battle with tragic grandeur. Brilliant photographs made several years ago when the tapestry was removed from its casing in its Bayeux museum for cleaning have been assembled in 146 consecutive pages by Sir David Wilson in a magnificent book that displays the tapestry in greater clarity, at times, than one can see it in the museum. Sir David, the director of the British Museum, also provides clear, brief commentaries on the events depicted in the tapestry as well as on the people and action in each picture. His appendixes on society, customs and buildings of the era convey his enormous learning with engaging good humor.

title: Pro-Rally Racing Seeks Exposure
description: In Carson City, Nev., last Sunday, the Sports Car Club of America's Pro-Rally season ended as it in 9 of the last 11 years - with John Buffum winning the driver's championship.

title: WEDDING IN APRIL FOR DR. WALLACE
description: Announcement has been made by Jean Wallace of Syracuse of the engagement of her daughter Dr. Deborah N. Wallace to Dr. Arthur L Goldner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Goldner of Nashville. The wedding is planned for April 20.

title: STORY-TELLING IS TRIBUTE TO STUDENT OF THE AGED
description: Somehow Moish Sacks always manages to come up with a minyan -the minimum 10 men required by Jewish law - for Saturday morning services at the Intervale Avenue Jewish Center in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.

title: DANCE: SOKOLOW GROUP IN A SUITE SET TO IVES
description: ANNA SOKOLOW delves into pain to cathartic effect in her best-known dances. Madness, chill alienation and the coruscating loneliness of urban life are her special provinces. But few have depicted these worlds with such sharp focus and simplicity. And a performance by Miss Sokolow's Players' Project on Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church offered a shining example of her art in ''Scenes From the Music of Charles Ives.''
