title: CANCER-FIGHTERS TURN TO INTERLUEKIN-2
description: Over the years, new treatments for cancer have raised hopes time and again as scientists struggled to conquer the baffling, often fatal disease. Just as frequently, the hopes have crashed into disappointment as the treatments underwent broader testing.

title: THE 74TH APPEAL/REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases fund was established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of the The Times. That year 117 contributors donated a total of $3,630.88 to be distributed among three private social-service agencies.

title: ETRUSCAN TOWN DRAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: FLUTE, CELLO AND PIANO
description: Gary Schocker In Francis Poulenc's flute sonata, there is a little four-note upbeat figure that recurs throughout the first movement, and sometimes it seems to take repeated tries before the little riff will flow on into the melody. At the 92d St. Y Tuesday night, Gary Schocker played those upbeats as though trying out different tones of voice, or different ways of beginning a sentence, before he could get on to the main thought of it. Ah, that's it, one imagined his flute to be saying as it pursued the tune.

title: WHEN THE TEACHER IS AWAY
description: A head, (uncombed), attached to a T-shirt (Van Halen), appeared in the doorway and stared at me in astonishment. Silently I stared back, unschooled in the ritual.

title: A SCHOOL BOARD ON L.I. DROPS PLAN REQUIRING PUBLIC SERVICE
description: An experimental program that required high school students to do 120 hours of community service work in order to graduate has been dropped by the Islip Board of Education after protests from parents.

title: LOOK FOR MORRIS IN THE END ZONE
description: SOMETIMES the other team simply can't find Joe Morris. With good reason. Morris, as described by George Young, the Giants' general manager, stands ''5-foot-7 and a freckle.'' And when Morris, the Giants' halfback, lines up for a play, he hunkers behind the starting offensive line of Bill Ard, who stands 6 feet 3 inches and weighs 270 pounds; Brad Benson, 6-3, 270; Chris Godfrey, 6-3, 265; Bart Oates, 6-3, 267; and Karl Nelson, 6-6, 285.

title: SIMONE PRAVER IS A BRIDE
description: At Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., last evening Simone Maria Praver and Michael Hugh Raus, 1985 graduates of the American University, were married by Rabbi Robert S. Widom. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Praver of Great Neck and the bridegroom a son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Raus of Louisville, Ky.

title: TRIAL SET TO OPEN ON POLLING AT VOTING PLACES
description: The news media and the State of Washington will square off in court next week over how far the state can go in regulating the polling of voters as they leave the voting place and then making early projections of winners.

title: INEZ REKSTEN PLANS TO BE WED IN JUNE
description: Rolf Reksten and Dine Beate Hoyer Reksten, both of Estoril, Portugal, have announced the engagement of their daughter Inez Reksten to Federico Guglielmo Maria Mennella, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Mennella of Milan. A June wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES SELLING THE F. H. A.
description: As the Federal Housing Administration celebrated its 50th anniversary last year, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., said the program, which has provided mortgage insurance for more than 51 million home buyers, had helped ''people realize the American dream.'' A dream of the Reagan Administration has been to sharply decrease the number of services provided by Washington, so the White House may ask Congress for authority to put the agency on the block.

title: ROSES IN JANUARY
description: Pasadena, as everyone knows, is inhabited mainly by white-haired old ladies who drive electric cars; Raymond Chandler said it was ''a place for old people and their parents.'' The Rose Parade and the Rose Bowl Game are held there, and Cal Tech is also in Pasadena. It never rains and it's a good place to retire, especially if you're a millionaire. So much for the cliches.

title: A PREDECESSOR SCOURGE
description: To the Editor:

title: On Drug Tests And Contracts
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: FALLOUT FROM OIL'S DECLINE
description: If there was a cloud in the silver lining of last week's lower oil prices, one had to look no further than the precious metals markets to find it. ''These markets have been poor performers all year,'' said Walter L. Emery, director of research at the Commodity Research Bureau, ''but what really put the whammy on them was the OPEC meeting.''

title: MEDALS FOR MARK TWAIN
description: Mark Twain, one of America's best-known and best-loved literary figures, is the subject of two impressive and unusual medals issued to commemorate the 150th anniversary of his birth. Both are bronze, both weigh nearly a pound and both have offbeat shapes.

title: Daily Telegraph of London Sold to Canadian
description: After 57 years of ownership by the Berry family, control of The Daily Telegraph, a morning newspaper, has gone to Conrad Black, a Canadian financier.

title: JUDGE BLAMES AIR CONTROLLER IN FATAL JERSEY CRASH
description: A Federal judge has ruled that an air-traffic controller's ''momentary lapse'' was the primary cause of a midair collision in which two people were killed in 1982.

title: HYSTERIA IS BEHIND THE DRIVE TO BAR AIDS VICTIMS FROM SCHOOLS
description: IT IS certainly understandable that some residents of New Jersey have demanded that public schools exclude children who may have AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome).

title: BUDGET ACCORD FOR '86 ALLOTS $298 BILLION TO THE PENTAGON
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed Friday night on a 1986 Pentagon budget of $298.7 billion and approved limited production of chemical weapons beginning next year, ending a 16-year ban.

title: SIGNS OF PROBLEMS AMID THE PROGRESS
description: THE 1980's have been boom years for women's intercollegiate athletics. The number of women participating on sports teams has continued a dramatic rise that began in the early 1970's. But some daughters of this athletic revolution are less than ecstatic over the good news. They say that the advances women have made are being offset by the decrease in influence they are asserting over female athletes and their programs.

title: Iraq Reports Air Raids On Iran and Ship in Gulfn
description: Iraq said its warplanes hit power and oil pumping stations in Iran today and attacked a ship in the Persian Gulf on Friday night.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BOARD GAMES FOR ADULTS
description: A YEAR ago, Ann Benson, Robin Landerman and their husbands were sitting around, playing ''Trivial Pursuit.'' Miss Benson, who runs a small design and product development company, cannot remember who won the game. But she can remember leaving her dining room filled with brie, good wine and a sense of creativity. ''I said, we can do this. We can create a game.''

title: Lobbying Effort
description: After coaching high school football for 43 years, Gordon Wood decided it was time to call it a career. The 71-year-old coaching legend, who has won more games (405) than any other coach on any level of the sport, announced his retirement from Brownwood High School in Texas, where he spent 26 of his 43 seasons.

title: GIVE GUATEMALA A CHANCE
description: It isn't often that we hear good news from Guatemala. But the results of the election last week are exactly that - a glimpse of what may be the first genuine democratic opening in that tortured country since the Central Intelligence Agency toppled its last legitimate Government, in 1954.

title: DAIMLER RACES INTO HIGH TECH
description: TWO years ago, when Werner Breitschwerdt took over the chairmanship at Daimler-Benz, he had each of the company's management board members write a strategy paper for Daimler's growth into the next century. Then, in a closed session, the papers were distilled into a master blueprint.

title: NEW DEPARTURES FOR TWO MAJOR DIRECTORS
description: Steven Spielberg was pacing his midtown Manhattan hotel room, cracking walnuts.

title: THE BISHOPS' SILENCE WAS ALSO REVEALING
description: SOME Roman Catholics hoped and others feared that the Extraordinary Synod of Roman Catholic Bishops that closed last weekend would clarify the church's stand on the many matters dividing Catholics around the world. In the end, though, the Synod's final report was at least as notable for what it avoided as for what it confronted.

title: ONE EXPERT'S ETIQUETTE IS NOT ANOTHER'S
description: Hamilton Brill of Greenwich Village arrived at an East Side Christmas party last year, tossed his raincoat atop a six-layer pile on a king-size bed and headed for the wassail bowl. Hours later, after making his farewells, Mr. Brill discovered that someone had apparently departed in his raincoat, a Burberry copy, leaving behind a bonafide Burberry.

title: POLICING BY TV
description: WHEN Charleston, W. Va., announced plans to use television surveillance in a redeveloped downtown plaza to deter crime, some residents objected. They said in August 1984 that the cameras would intrude on their privacy.

title: PAINTER, FORGER, MISER, SPY
description: WHAT'S BRED IN THE BONE By Robertson Davies. 436 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $17.95.

title: ELAYNA R. ZAKIM PLANNING TO MARRY DAVID KIRSCHTEL
description: The engagement of Elayna Rachel Zakim to David Kirschtel has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Zakim of Wayne, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: FINDING FUN IN MURDER AND MAYHEM
description: ''MURDER is the hot category,'' says Roy L. DeVries, president of Just Games, a company in Garden City, L.I. ''This is the year that everybody is going nuts with ideas for murder games.''

title: MELANIE G. NORTHROP TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Melanie Gay Northrop of Cambridge, Mass., and Daniel Edward Forman of Washington have announced their plans to be married in June.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: THE EPIC OF LIFE: The Balinese Journey of the Soul. By Idanna Pucci. (Alfred van der Marck/Harper & Row, $60.) Balinese arts have been illustrated in large-size books throughout our century, but never has a particular visual creation from Bali been more beautifully captured than in this stunning volume. Classic court paintings there portrayed gods, heroes, demons and comic servants. The paintings were stored and then shown on occasions determined by taboos that helped regulate the iconography's power. One exception to this rule is this vibrant set of paintings, which illustrates the ''Bhima Swarga,'' the Balinese folk tale that describes a hero's journey into the afterlife. Set in the ceiling of the royal pavilion in Klungkung, a former royal capital, these fixed, painted surfaces became a monument to the legal system established after Klungkung fell to the Dutch in 1908. The panels depict Bhima, that most approachable high-born protagonist in the ''Mahabharata,'' witnessing punishments that characterize the Hindu hell: ordeals by fire, boiling, anal and genital mutilations and horrific battles. Along with the few remaining relics of Klungkung's once expansive palace area, the work has been preserved, occasionally restored and added to Bali's principal tourist sites. Idanna Pucci, a widely traveled freelance writer who has lived in Indonesia, organized this stately volume around splendid photographs, most of which were taken by Hans Hoefer, a publisher and photographer who lives in Singapore, before recent applications of acrylic paints to the panels. The book isolates individual scenes in extraordinarily subtle colors set off against surrounding panels left in black and white.

title: A PATRON IS MUGGED
description: George T. Delacorte, the 92-year-old philanthropist, has delighted millions of children and adults with his gifts to Central Park, including the Delacorte Theater, the animated clock at the Children's Zoo and the Alice in Wonderland statue on the Conservatory Water. One morning last week two young men approached Mr. Delacorte and his wife, Valerie, as they were strolling near the zoo. Mrs. Delacorte, 66, suffered a superficial wound on one hand as the two men choked her and took her mink coat. Mr. Delacorte gave them the $200 he had in his wallet. He said he had walked in the park every day for 60 years, but had never before been the victim of a crime in New York.

title: Egypt Indicts Four Libyans In Plot to Kill Libyan Exiles
description: Four Libyans were indicted today on charges of plotting to kill Libyan exiles in Egypt.

title: 37% IN POLL SAY AIDS ALTERED THEIR ATTITUDE TO HOMOSEXUALS
description: One-third of American adults say they are less favorably disposed toward homosexuals as a result of the AIDS epidemic, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: PLEASE READ FROM LEFT TO RIGHT BUT DO SO AT YOUR OWN RISK!
description: SOMETHING has been puzzling me for months, and I think, to my dismay, I have just realized the answer. The cake and muffin mixes I have been using for so long have suddenly changed their directions. I used to tear open the bags and heap the mix into bowls with the appropriate eggs and water, and then think no more of it. The results were fine. Now, I am carefully instructed all over the box to cut open the plastic bags specifically with scissors (capitalized and often underlined). So what was wrong with slashing them with a knife, or ripping them apart with my own little fingers, I asked myself. Then, what I perceive as the horrible truth, dawned on me. I bet some careless housewife (I hate the term ''homemaker'') slashed her hand with a knife instead of the plastic bag, or shredded the plastic bag with her fingers so some pieces of it fell into the mix. Naturally, she promptly sued the manufacturer for making faulty plastic bags. Why else would the manufacturer care how we opened the bag? I have decided that we have all gone mad on the subject of product liability. I want to reinstitute the idea of user competence and user liability.

title: A SELF-STYLED NATURALIST AS AN ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCE
description: In 1930, guests at Mohonk Mountain House were sick of boiled potatoes for breakfast. So young Daniel Smiley was directed by his dad to come up with a refrigeration system that could store more fresh foods for their family hotel.

title: IS THERE A WAY OUT OF McKINLEY'S NIGHTMARE
description: The case-study method of teaching business requires students to study a corporation and suggest ways to solve its problems. This article takes the same approach, but with a twist: The subject is Texaco, and the ''students'' are businessmen, lawyers and other outsiders with ideas on what Texaco should do next. WITH his craggy looks and southern drawl, John K. McKinley, Texaco Inc.'s chief executive, has often been compared to the late President Lyndon B. Johnson. These days, the comparison goes well beyond their looks.

title: POLISH SEAMN GIVEN ASYLUM AFTER CLEVELAND SHORE LEAVE
description: A Polish seaman who failed to return to his freighter after shore leaver in this Lake Erie port has been granted political asylum.

title: MINORITY GAIN MIGHT BRING COLLEGES CASH
description: CONNECTICUT state colleges and universities that enroll and graduate more minority students would be eligible for cash incentives under a $2.6 million, five-year plan before the Board of Governors for Higher Education.

title: STATE WEIGHS TOXIC-CLEANUP LIABILITY
description: TWO bills designed to reduce the liability of contractors cleaning up hazardous-waste sites have begun to move through the Legislature.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: THE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF SUPERHEROES. By Jeff Rovin. (Facts on File, $29.95.) In his introduction to this exhaustive listing of the hyperactive characters who have been a colorful part of the American scene for half a century, Jeff Rovin indicates that the superhero is not exactly a new boy on the block. Perhaps the first recorded superhero is in the Babylonian epic of Gilgamesh, circa 2000 B.C. Gilgamesh was the King of Erech, part god, part human. Other mythological old boys Mr. Rovin mentions are Neph, a ram-headed Egyptian; Husheng, a Persian monster-slayer, and Rama, an Indian archer and warrior. ''In the earliest days, we called them 'gods,' '' writes Mr. Rovin, a comic-book editor and television consultant. The true superhero, Mr. Rovin says, must have at least one superpower, must be ''neither vindictive nor selfish'' and ''must function like the secretary-general of the United Nations, working for the good of everyone.'' Merlin, Ulysses and John Henry fail to make the grade. Moses doesn't qualify because ''he stretched forth his hand over the sea [and] there remained not so much as one'' Egyptian, while ''the Lone Ranger never killed a soul'' and ''is a saint.''

title: SEASON BRINGS AN OUTPURING OF MUSICAL OFFERINGS FOR THE HOLIDAY
description: TRADITIONALLY, the Christmas season has been a time of musical celebration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1985
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: SAVORING THE FRUITS OF SICILY'S PAST
description: Nine centuries have passed since the Norman knights drove the Arabs out of Sicily, yet just as the discerning eye can see traces of the Saracen occupation still lingering in the red domes and the Moorish arches of Palermo's Arab-Norman churches and palaces, so the discerning palate can detect the exotic flavors that the Arabs introduced into Palermo's cooking. A meal of local dishes can convey much about the city's history and the curious mingling of Eastern and Western cultures that sets it apart, in its cuisine as well as its architecture, from anything to be found on the Italian mainland.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: DENTISTRY: An Illustrated History. By Malvin E. Ring. (Abrams, $67.50 until June 1; $75 thereafter.) The colorful history of dentistry, from prehistoric times to the mid-20th century, is beautifully depicted in these lavishly illustrated and well-produced photographs.

title: TOPICS
description: ONE by one they closed, almost unnoticed, replaced by nationally recognizable franchises.

title: INDIANS SEPARATE MYTH FROM HISTORY
description: THE children were told an Indian was coming, and soon, Howling Wolf appeared in the classroom, wearing a headdress of brightly colored feathers.

title: BUSH FORGIVES AN OLD TORMENTOR
description: No one was meaner to George Bush in his 1980 campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination than William Loeb, the conservative publisher of The Manchester Union Leader in New Hampshire. Mr. Loeb, who died in 1981, called Mr. Bush a ''hypocrite'' and a ''spoon-fed little rich kid,'' among other things.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Football Giants vs. Dallas Cowboys, at Irving, Tex. Both teams are in the running for the playoffs and possibly a division title. A Rafael Septien 31-yard field goal gave the Cowboys a 30-29 victory over the Giants on Oct. 6. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 1 P.M.) Redskins vs. Cincinnati Bengals, at Washington. Both teams still have playoff chances. The Redskins have won six straight games against American Conference opponents. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Raiders vs. Seattle Seahawks, at Los Angeles. The Raiders can win their second division title in three years by winning just one of their last two games, but Seattle needs this victory to stay in the playoff picture. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Pittsburgh Penguins, at Madison Square Garden. On radio, Dave Maloney, the former Ranger defenseman, will make his debut as a color analyst, substituting for Sal Messina, who is working the cable television show. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) Devils vs. St. Louis Blues, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. In 10 games since they put on their Devils suits, New Jersey has not been able to beat the Blues. Their last home victory over St. Louis was in Colorado Jan. 18, 1982. ( Radio -WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) Black Hawks vs. Detroit Red Wings, at Chicago (Television -ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Soccer World Cup Draw, at Mexico City. The six seeded teams have already been named: Italy, the defending champion; Mexico, the host country; Brazil, a three-time champion, France, Poland and West Germany. Today, the 18 other teams will be sorted and placed into groups of four, headed by the seeded teams to begin round-robin play in the tournament next May.

title: Man Accused of Posing As Doctor in a Scheme
description: A Canadian here posed as a doctor and charged 700 people up to $2,000 each for medicinal herbs while urging them to discard their prescription medicines, state police officials say.

title: Q AND A
description: Return of the Tenant Question: In April 1984, when my employers offered me a two-year assignment out of state, I obtained written approval of my landlord to sublet my rent-stabilized apartment. I intend to return to my job in Manhattan and to my apartment. The building has been sold and the new owner, who is trying to convert the building to a co-op, refuses to renew my lease. Am I entitled to a renewal? . . . G. B. H., Stamford, Conn. Answer: Yes, according to Thomas Viola, assistant commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. The 1983 Omnibus Housing Act says that when an apartment is sublet, the prime tenant retains the right to a renewal lease and the rights and status of a tenant in occupancy. File a complaint of failure to offer a lease renewal at the district rent office for your apartment. An Unfinished Row Question: There is a row of new town houses on East 67th Street between Second and Third Avenues that have never been completed. Who owns them and when will they be sold? . . . D. D. D., Manhattan Answer: The 11 granite-clad town houses were designed by Eli Attia and developed by Sheldon H. Solow.

title: How We See Each Other
description: The articles on how the United States and the Soviet Union see each other point up only too clearly how much of our culture is created by the press and the fact that if something does not exist in the popular media it does not exist.

title: ANAWARI FEELS RESTLESS
description: KARAN By B. Wongar. 248 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $16.95.

title: A JAZZMAN'S ART AND ANGST INSPIRE A CHOREOGRAPHER
description: ''For Bird - With Love,'' which the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is currently presenting at the City Center, is a highly emotional, profound work inspired by the life and music of the late jazz alto-saxophonist Charlie ''Bird'' Parker. Mr. Ailey has called it one of his ''artist in torment'' pieces. And it does, in fact, fall into the category of Ailey works in which the protagonist - usually subject to an untimely death -is a performing artist whose achievement parallels a personal or physical disintegration. The question raised is whether the creativity or success - not always the same - has been attained at the expense of happiness, sanity and even life itself. Or, more disturbingly, has the suffering been vital to the artistry?

title: Hitting Stride
description: Mary Decker Slaney and Willie Banks have been named by a 10-member media panel as the United States Olympic Committee's 1985 Sportswoman and Sportsman of the year. Mrs. Slaney, who was knocked out of the Olympic 3,000-meter race in the famous collision with Zola Budd, rebounded to set two world records and six American records this year. Banks won 21 of 25 meets this year and set a world record for the event.

title: Dishing the Full Plate
description: STRESSED OUT?

title: JETS ARE STOPPED, 19-6, BY BEARS, COMPLICATING THEIR PLAYOFF HOPES
description: The Chicago Bears, the wind and the fumble sent the Jets to a 19-6 defeat today, sidetracking them in their struggle to make the National Football League playoffs.

title: WAR ERUPTS OVER THE PEACE PRIZE
description: When the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War won the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize in October, sources close to the selection committee called the choice ''a safe one.'' But that seemed far from the case last week when the group's co-founders - Bernard Lown of the United States and Yevgeny I. Chazov of the Soviet Union - arrived in Norway to accept the award.

title: THE POLLACK TOUCH
description: ''I HAD A FARM IN AFRICA, AT THE foot of the Ngong Hills'' - that famous opening sentence of Isak Dinesen's ''Out of Africa'' has daunted some of the most enterprising of modern film makers. Orson Welles, who made an hourlong film of Dinesen's ''The Immortal Story,'' never realized his hopes of adapting her classic African memoir. Nor did David Lean's thoughts of filming the book ever materialize. In the early 1970's, Nicolas Roeg thought of directing a film with Julie Christie as the Danish-born author and Ryan O'Neal as the Swedish Baron whom she married. But if the book, which Dinesen's biographer Judith Thurman has called ''a landscape from the air,'' has a keen sense of character and place that have made it alluring from the film maker's standpoint, it also has an uneventfulness that has kept it well out of reach. So it eluded them all.

title: NEW PERIL FOR CHILDREN: LEAD POISONING
description: THE 3-year-old girl was in the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow several months ago, under treatment for a blood disorder. But doctors noticed some surprising symptoms, including anemia. On a hunch, they checked and diagnosed the child as having yet another problem - lead poisoning.

title: ENCOUNTERING HALLEY'S COMET FOR THE SECOND TIME
description: There is plenty of publicity about Halley's comet this time around, but it is all calm and scientific, nothing like the forewarnings and dire predictions that preceded its last appearance in 1910.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: CADILLAC. Photographs by Stephen Salmieri, hand-painted by Sydnie Michele Salmieri. Text by Owen Edwards. (Rizzoli, $50.) Consider the front view - or the face - of the 1955 Cadillac Fleetwood. The hood comes forward like the bulging forehead of a beluga whale. Slow, deep curves connect this forehead to fenders containing two hooded, saturnine eyes. A silver tusk juts from either side of the grinning, heavily chromed grill. Zoomorphic indeed. And this orgy of curved surfaces renders the aerodynamically sound boxes we drive today bland and soulless. In ''Cadillac,'' the Brooklyn-born photographer, Stephen Salmieri, displays the results of a 12-year search that took him and his wife, Sydnie Michele Salmieri, coast to coast through junkyards, ghettoes, deserts, auto shows, amusement parks and funeral homes in a pilgrimage for these living rooms on wheels. If your soul soars when you gaze on the winged, pachyderm sleekness of a '59 Cadillac -those vast fins, each attended by two bullet-shaped taillights - these 80 or so portraits, along with Owen Edwards's quirky, on-the-mark essay, may constitute nirvana for you. Some purists may balk at the colors Mrs. Salmieri used in hand-painting the black-and-white photographs - some of them never were and probably never will be available in Cadillacs - but the effect she achieves is mildly and pleasantly surrealistic. Mr. Edwards's essay is emphatically not just dressing. He peels back the layers of the American psyche and analyzes our love of the horseless carriage. He invokes the ghost of Harley Earl - the General Motors designer responsible for fins and grinning grills - and gets Keats, poltergeists and the Holy Grail into the discussion in meaningful ways.

title: BIG BROWN BAT
description: Eptesius fuscus Size: Four to five inches long; weighs one-half to five-eighths of an ounce.

title: A KILLING BY THE ROADSIDE
description: IT happened in an instant. The sleek, fragile doe leaped across the road, her fawn following. The mother made it to the other side; the fawn didn't - his graceful sprint brutally interrupted by the fender of a car that sped on, unconcerned.

title: No Headline
description: An article in The Week in Review last Sunday about the downing of a Nicaraguan transport helicopter misstated the official American description of the weapon used. Eliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American affairs, testified Dec. 5 that anti-Sandinista guerrillas had shot the helicopter down with a hand-held Soviet-made SA-7 antiaircraft missile.

title: Koreans Are Jailed for Sit-In
description: A Seoul court today sentenced three textile workers to two years in prison for leading a factory sit-in to demand the release of arrested union leaders, court officials said. A fourth union member was imprisoned for 18 months, and eight others received suspended sentences of one year each.

title: POP: A HOLLY NEAR BLEND
description: HOLLY NEAR traces her musical roots to a rural childhood, many hours of which were spent listening to records by Yma Sumac, Edith Piaf and Judy Garland, among other exotic voices. Miss Near, who is a dedicated feminist, leftist and humanitarian, also belongs to the folk tradition of Woody Guthrie and the Weavers.

title: KANSAS SMOTHERS KENTUCKY, 83-66
description: Danny Manning led Kansas to an 83-66 victory tonight over Kentucky.

title: SMART MACHINES GET SMARTER
description: NEARLY two decades after the first screening of ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' the specter of HAL, the omniscient but soulless computer, still haunts programmers in artificial intelligence laboratories.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: Your readers may be interested in the following example of honesty and efficiency in Japan:

title: A DISSERVICE TO FORMER GOVERNOR
description: I read with interest the article ''Plan to Name Turnpike for Lodge'' [Nov. 24] . Although the late John Davis Lodge may have been instrumental in seeing the turnpike built, naming it for him now would be a disservice.

title: SYRACUSE ROUTS BROOKLYN BY 102-61
description: Sparked by 15 points each from the freshman guard Sherman Douglas and the senior Rafael Addison, Syracuse easily defeated Brooklyn College, 102-61, to run its unbeaten string this season to six games.

title: JEAN D. ZIELINSKI, TEACHER, IS WED TO BRUCE MONACO
description: The marriage of Jean Denis Zielinski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walt Thomas Zielinski of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., to Bruce Gerard Monaco, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert N. Monaco of Jamaica Estates, Queens, took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Edward Beck performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Convent of the Sacred Heart Chapel.

title: 'MAMA' IS REMEMBERED
description: ''BUT most of all, I remember Mama.''

title: SARAH PEYTON GARDNER TO WED IN MAY
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Underhill Gardner of South Dartmouth, Mass., and Tuftonboro, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Peyton Gardner to Charles Seth Cunningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Cunningham Jr. of Bedford Village, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: BRUINS SET BACK RANGERS
description: The ice does not allow much room to move freely. The curves of the rink are unique. And the goaltender has to watch for pucks ricocheting haphazardly. The charm of playing hockey at the Boston Garden can be rather haunting to the visiting team.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: To contain something nutritious, something a reader might absorb and then remember in a tiny subliminal fantasy flash just before falling asleep, say, or on a crowded subway during rush hour, even the most lavish and expensive volume of color photographs must also be a real book. Here is a satisfying selection from this year's crop of travel books. Scottish Symphony Photographs by Michael Ruetz. Illustrated. 158 pages. New York Graphic Society. $50.

title: A FANCIFUL SHOW OF CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IN one display case is the first edition of a 1947 book called ''Atomics for the Millions,'' which contains illustrations by a high-school artist named Maurice Sendak. In another is an autographed first edition of Louisa May Alcott's ''Hospital Sketches'' from 1863, her second book and the first to put her on the literary map.

title: AN OVERBEARING PRODUCTION SWALLOWS UP THIS 'FIGARO'
description: Considering Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's reputation as a shrewd man of the theater, it is hard to understand how his new production of ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' for the Metropolian Opera could go askew in so many ways, large and small. Mr. Ponnelle, who not only directed but designed sets and costumes for the Met's first new staging of Mozart's opera in a decade, made several miscalculations, the most glaring being his overbearing and carefully decayed scenery, by now a Ponnelle trademark, if not cliche, in the three Mozart works he has produced for this company. The scale of the production, with its use of the full cavernous depths of the Metropolitan stage for key scenes, is such that the opera's human, conversational aspects are diminished if not lost. The singing itself is often swallowed up, not so damagingly as to volume as in expressive nuance. There is, I submit, something beetle-browed and obtuse about the notion that the Countess should begin her wistful ''Porgi amor'' while seated on a bed so far from the audience that she might as well be in another opera for all the connection she makes with her listeners.

title: WHEN SAFETY BECOMES AN ISSUE
description: First, in June, it was the hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 after it left Athens. Then it was the earthquake in Mexico; hurricanes in the Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico; the hijacking of the cruise liner Achille Lauro off Alexandria, Egypt; the volcanic eruption in Colombia, and the hijacking of an Egyptian airliner and the commando storming of the plane on Malta.

title: SOLE PRIORITY FOR MANY IS BASIC SURVIVAL
description: At midpoint in the 1980's, the gap between New Yorkers who have and those who have not stretches wide between stark contrasts. The erosion of our middle-class economic base, which began at its lowest levels 15 years ago, has now reached into the once-solid core of our working people, nowhere more evidently than in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Lost Overboard
description: I lived every bit of the tale of Richard Appaldo, as he hung on to life for three days in the sea (''One Man's Victory at Sea,'' by Fred Waitzkin, Nov. 10). I salute all those who aided in his rescue. They deserve a medal of honor. IRVING M. ZELLER Jamaica, Queens

title: WELCOME NEWS FOR HISPANOPHILES
description: A SPANISH restaurant in Connecticut, indeed in Norwalk, is certainly an idea whose time has come. To a Hispanophile, it is especially good news.

title: NEW YORK CITY LOBBYIST IS VETERAN AT PERSUASION
description: As a young Marine Corps veteran fresh from the Korean War, James Brenner decided to become a lawyer because he ''thought it was an interesting career, and that it gave you a lot of options.''

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPOSERS BLAZE NEW VOCAL TRAIL
description: The human voice is the most intensely emotional of all musical instruments - the one most capable of refined and subtle expressive inflections and the one that cuts closest to our deepest feelings. It therefore comes as no surprise that lovers of particular kinds of singing develop fanatically intense identifications with those styles, and find it difficult to accept emotional validity in other styles, or to appreciate the technical achievements of a method of singing that contradicts the vocal verities they hold dear.

title: TV NEWS OUTLOOK RAISING CONCERNS
description: THE officials from the Long Island Coalition for Fair Broadcasting were bathed in television lights. Their news conference to denounce what they considered the lack of local television coverage by New York City stations was well attended by representatives of the very medium they were discussing.

title: AN EARLY SWIM BACK TO MAINE
description: EVERY winter it was the same thing: Andre the seal would be picked up in Rockport, Me., by Harry Goodridge and driven to the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium in Mystic, Conn.

title: BELAGA ANNOUNCES CONDIDACY FOR GOVERNOR IN CONNECTICUT
description: Julie D. Belaga, the deputy Republican leader in the State House of Representatives, formally announced today that she was running for governor.

title: A 'CHOOSY' ACTRESS IS MATCHED WITH A SHAVIAN DRAMA
description: Since Uta Hagen is one of the glories of the American theater and since she turns up infrequently in large public performance spaces, she is subject to a tiresome litany of questions. ''Uta,'' her friends demand, ''why are you so choosy?'' Even worse are colleagues who will watch her do a finely wrought workshop job of acting at the school she runs with her husband and then stun her with, ''Uta, isn't it a shame you're not working?'' Mention the need for ''high visibility'' at your peril; the Hagen idea of theater is at odds with convention. Forty-eight years after she first walked on stage, she still sees that actor's art as a sacred gift, one that can, if need be, shed a pure light in the corner of a small room before an audience of two, neither of whom paid for the seat.

title: POSTER DRIVE AIMS TO FIND FUGITIVES
description: For the last three months, larger-than-life photographs of convicted felons and felony suspects have glared from the backs of many New York City buses. Each poster carries the message: ''Have you seen me? It could mean $100 to you.''

title: HOLOCAUST SURVIVOR STRIVES FOR SURVIVAL IN MANHATTAN
description: IN his 61 years, Mr. F. managed to live through the Holocaust, adapt to life in a foreign country and survive two openheart operations.

title: HELP FOR GAMBLERS
description: THE director of New Jersey's Sports and Exposition Authority, which runs the Meadowlands Race Track in East Rutherford, said that ''the authority feels it has a social responsiblity to help those who may develop a problem gambling on the horses.''

title: MORE DATA FOUND ON AIDS IN AFRICA
description: Researchers have found more corroborating evidence that AIDS is spreading in Africa to pose substantial risks to newborn infants and to affect about as many women as men, primarily by heterosexual intercourse.

title: DAWKINS EJECTED AS NETS WIN
description: Darryl Dawkins shoved his belongings into a duffel bag and walked quickly toward the door that led out of the Nets' lockerroom. He had not yet thought about a suspension.

title: Air Fares
description: To the Editor: The other day, my seat companion paid but one third of the fare I paid for a flight from New York to San Francisco and return. He paid $358.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGET FOR 1987 SEEKING MEDICARE SAVINGS
description: The Office of Management and Budget is proposing to reduce Medicare physician fees, restrict Federal payment for home health services and cut spending on AIDS as part of President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1987.

title: CALIFORNIA PANEL APPROVES REVISED TEXTBOOKS
description: The California Board of Education has adopted seventh- and eighth-grade science textbooks that include stronger discussions of the theory of evolution.

title: VERDI INTERPRETATIONS YIELD MYRIAD PLEASURES
description: ''Don Carlos'' is Verdi's most daring opera: The complexity of the personal relationships, their intertwining with the destinies of nations and with the political ideals that fired the composer's heart, passed anything that he had attempted before. The great re-examination of Verdi over the past three decades has raised the standing of ''Carlos'' dramatically - and also unearthed multiple problems concerning its performance.

title: BOSTON REALTORS ACTING TO DETECT HOUSING BIAS
description: The technique of detecting housing discrimination by sending a black couple and a white couple posing as customers to the same real estate agent was pioneered by civil rights groups, but starting next year, realtors in Boston will be using the test on one another.

title: NEW WATER-USE AGENDA LEADS TO A DISPUTE
description: A PLAN to split the state into seven water resource management areas and identify future supply sources for each has won praise from water companies and planners, but some people have questioned the priorities within the plan.

title: CARLOS ROMULO OF PHILIPPINES, A FOUNDER OF U.N., DIES AT 86
description: Carlos P. Romulo, the eloquent Filipino diplomat who was a leading spokesman for newly independent third world countries in the early years of the United Nations, died today. He was 86 years old. As a co-founder of the United Nations in 1945, Mr. Romulo succeeded in having its charter explicitly endorse the independence of colonized countries. He lived on to become one of the last survivors of the charter's 51 signers.

title: JERSEY PANEL CALLS BOXING 'SAVAGERY'
description: It wasn't a knockout punch, but the words hit like uppercuts: Professional boxing is ''legal savagery'' and ''one-on-one brutality'' that ''has no place in a civilized culture.''

title: YEARS OF REPUBLICAN FRUSTRATION UNDERLAY HOUSE REVOLT
description: President Reagan's startling setback on a tax vote in the House of Representatives this week resulted from Republican legislators' mounting frustration at being treated like extras in the political theater and from a lack of political leadership in the White House, according to lawmakers, Administration officials and political analysts.

title: WHY MILITARY CONTRACTING IS CORRUPT
description: SO MUCH evidence has come out about misconduct and mismanagement in defense contracts, over such a long period, without an appropriate response from the Government, that the public is growing progressively more outraged and cynical. People are asking, ''Do defense contractors work for the Government or is it the other way around?''

title: EVEN GRAZ CAN CUT LOOSE
description: ''Beyond the Sound of Music'' was the motto of recent presentations in New York and Los Angeles by avant-garde actors, writers, musicians, choreographers, film makers and other talent from Austria. They wanted to show that their country's cultural reality today is not all Mozart and Mahler, waltzes and yodeling.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BLACKBERRIES IN THE DARK By Mavis Jukes. Illustrated by Thomas B. Allen. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95 (Ages 8 to 12) IN a complicated world where children often land at the bottom of the heap it is comforting to find a book about a child who participates in decisions and who makes crucial connections about events and emotions. ''Blackberries in the Dark,'' by Mavis Jukes, a Newbery Honor Book author, while sometimes overly subtle and flat, deals with some important issues, among them loss, loneliness and the need for tradition.

title: IN REM NO MORE
description: Perhaps there is nothing of less use to New York City than its 10,000 vacant in rem lots throughout the five boroughs, on which it collects no taxes.

title: ALFONSIN'S ONE-MAN SHOW
description: ONE RECENT MORNING, President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina sat in a cramped, book-lined study at the 93-acre presidential compound in a suburb of Buenos Aires to talk about his first two years in office. The 58-year-old leader was thinner and more relaxed than he was a year ago. Up at 7 A.M., he had already read the newspapers and held a long meeting with Dante Caputo, his Foreign Minister. Technicians worked outside setting up cameras for the arrival of some foreign guests. Mr. Alfonsin, who answers questions briefly rather than taking the opportunity to launch into a monologue, was unruffled by the activity. He spoke in the soft tone of his provincial hometown of Chascomus, rather than in the harsh, distinct accent of the capital with which most Argentines speak.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS U.C.L.A
description: During the introductions before today's game between U.C.L.A. and St. John's, the Bruin fans greeted the St. John's players by shouting, ''Who cares?'' after each name. When Walter Berry was introduced, the crowd roared, ''Who's he?''

title: JERSEY LEGISLATURE PASSES BILL TO CUT BACK CHEMICAL LEAKS
description: The State Legislature has passed a bill aimed at preventing chemical leaks at manufacturing plants, and Governor Kean has said he will sign it.

title: POP MUSIC
description: One of the most appealingly endearing albums of recent weeks puts the eclectic, sometimes zany, encyclopedically knowledgeable and impulsively enthusiastic rock band NRBQ to work as backing group, cheerleaders, and song-finders for Skeeter Davis, an extraordinary country-pop singer who faded from popularity some years ago and has been seldom seen since.

title: MRS. FERRARO DECLINES TO RUN AGAINST D'AMATO
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro threw open the race for the Democratic nomination to oppose United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato with a single word last week: No.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: FOR the second year running, Christmastime has an extra special meaning for Thomas P. Chagaris, a Park Ridge resident who throws a Christmas party for poor and handicapped youngsters.

title: STATES ARE URGED TO COMPETE IN FILLING TEACHER VACANCIES
description: States should start raiding one another's schools to fill a growing number of teaching vacancies, the president of the Educational Testing Service told a conference of educators and state officials here.

title: There's Hope For Columbia
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BLUE ANGELS WORK TO STAY ON TOP
description: LOUIS KERN, coach of the women's basketball team of the College of New Rochelle, knows the price a team often pays for being No. 1: ''Everyone is out to knock you off,'' he says.

title: PANEL URGES SITE IN YAPHANK FOR BURYING L.I. WASTE ASH
description: A board created by the State Legislature has recommended a 230-acre site in Yaphank, L.I., for the burial of ash from garbage incineration in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WINTER BIRD COUNT In 1899, Frank M. Chapman, known as the dean of American ornithologists, started the first winter bird count in 25 Northeastern sites. His purpose was to provide an alternative to the Christmas Side Hunt, an event in which shooters competed to kill the largest number of wild birds and animals on Christmas Day.

title: A Very Special Soprano
description: Bernard Holland's article on the soprano Kathleen Battle gives an interesting picture of the study of classical singing by Americans here and abroad (''A Very Special Soprano,'' Nov. 17). His statement that ''America has become the voice-teaching center of the world'' is a troubling one.

title: THE DICKENS SPIRIT GLOWS IN 'BLEAK HOUSE'
description: Over the past 14 years of watching public television's Masterpiece Theater, one of my more consistent diversions has been in trying to figure out what Alistair Cooke, host for the series, really thinks about the shows he is introducing with such unflappable urbanity. The key, I've decided, is rather simple. When Mr. Cooke is pleased, he gives the viewer all sorts of historical and social details to amplify each episode. When lukewarm or downright miffed, he restricts himself to a bare-bones recapitulation of the plot up to that point. Using this makeshift yardstick, it seems clear that Mr. Cooke is not too fond of ''Bleak House,'' the eight-part dramatization that will be reaching Episode Three on WNET/Channel 13 tonight at 9.

title: ADVANCE TO GO -- OR TO THE BRONX
description: PLAYERS of the new ''Beverly Hills: The Golden Triangle'' board game can pretend-shop to their hearts' content. And players of the new ''Vegas: The Game'' can be pseudo-high rollers as long as their luck holds out. But players of ''NYC: The Big Apple'' get to make real changes in their city - S. Alden Inc., in Kansas City, Kan., which owns the game, donates $2 of the $35 purchase price to the Ellis Island Foundation.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 15, 1985 Fiction

title: Broadcast TV
description: The recent two-part biography of Laurence Oliver presented on public television's Great Performances may have left the impression that the actor had already reached the end of a distinguished career. In fact, those interviews were recorded in 1982, before Olivier was to appear in, among other things, Granada TV's extraordinary production of ''King Lear.'' Originally presented in syndication on commercial TV, ''Lear'' will be broadcast Wednesday on Channel 13 at 9 P.M.

title: OLD INFRASTRUCTURE A CONCERN IN BLAST
description: THE explosion that leveled the River Restaurant in Derby is giving investigators a view of 18th-century construction practices and focusing attention on the aging infrastructure of old cities like Derby.

title: HOW SCULPTURE FREED ITSELF FROM THE PAST
description: The most important development of this relatively uneventful fall art season has been the re-emergence of sculpture. In the past few years there have been signs of sculptural vitality but they were not spectacular, they did not point in any one direction and they did not flash from the most visible galleries.

title: CHECKPOINTS OFFER A SOBERING LESSION
description: WITH red and blue lights flashing in the night, nine Westchester County police cars, led by a large blue van, drove down the Saw Mill River Parkway. Reaching a spot on the Cross County Parkway, they set up a sobriety checkpoint.

title: U.S. AND GUYANA: WARMER TIES ARE EXPECTED
description: With the election of Desmond Hoyte as President of Guyana, Western diplomats say they expect to see an improvement in the country's sometimes contentious and distant relations with the United States.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gerry Faust, the former Notre Dame football coach, is reportedly a candidate for the head coaching job at Rice following the resignation of Watson Brown, who takes over at Vanderbilt. . . John McKay will leave his post as president of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers at the end of the season, according to a report in The Orlando Sentinel.

title: FAST MEAN COWS AND SLOW MEAN COWS
description: THE GRASSHOPPER TRAP By Patrick F. McManus. 214 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $13.95.

title: Five Given Prison Sentences In Fatal Ohio Fireworks Blast
description: Five men have been sentenced to prison for their roles in an explosion at an illegal fireworks factory in Beaver Township May 20 that killed nine workers.

title: INSIDE THE PALESTINIAN BUNKER
description: UNDER SIEGE P.L.O. Decisionmaking During the 1982 War. By Rashid Khalidi. 241 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $25.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: KING ISLAND CHRISTMAS By Jean Rogers. Illustrated by Rie Munoz. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow. $11.75 (Ages 5 to 8) THE DONKEY'S DREAM By Barbara Helen Berger. Unpaged. New York: Philomel. $12.95 (Ages 5 to 8) THAT mysterious thing, the spirit of Christmas, is brought heartily to life in ''King Island Christmas.'' There are no Christmas trees in this book, no Santa Claus, no reindeer, no Christ Child, but plenty of Yuletide cheer just the same.

title: JANE A. SCHWITTER PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Schwitter of New York and Amagansett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ann Schwitter, to David Fleming Bekard Ruppe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Francis Ruppe of Wilmington, Del., and Dorset, Vt.

title: In the Midi
description: To the Editor: ''Idling Through the Midi'' (Travel, Nov. 10) expressed our enthusiastic feelings about our recent voyage on the Blue Line's Talisman II from Marseillan to Castelnaudary. A previous marvelous experience on the Burgundy Canal aboard the Princess (the QE II of barges) with its pampering staff sparked our interest in Riquet's beautiful waterway.

title: GIANTS FOCUS ON PASSING GAMES
description: In many pro football games, the key is what the quarterbacks do. In Sunday's big game between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys in Texas Stadium, the key may be how much of a chance the quarterbacks get to do what they do.

title: A 'PANIC TO PLEASE'
description: FORGIVE ME By Cathleen Crowell Webb and Marie Chapian. Illustrated. 220 pp. Old Tappan, N.J.: Fleming H. Revell Company. $15.95.

title: THE 'ELVES' OF WALL STREET ARE STILL BULLISH
description: AMONG the stock market's technical analysts, who ponder chart patterns and other, more archane, clues to predict the future course of prices, perhaps none has a wider audience than Robert J. Nurock, the bearded 48-year-old president of Investor's Analysis Inc., in Paoli, Pa.

title: Louisiana Governor's Lawyer Asks Judge to Dismiss Juror
description: Defense attorneys asked the judge in the Federal racketeering and fraud trial of Gov. Edwin Edwards and four associates to dismiss a juror who gave a thumbs-down gesture today on his way to deliberations.

title: TRAVELING TO TOKYO VIA KHABAROVSK
description: A remarkable bridge odyssey was undertaken recently by a group of young Hungarian players: Peter Lakator, Laszlo Szilagyi, Daniel Vikor, Geza Homonnay, Eva Csibi and Geza Szappanos. Their story was reported to this department by Gabor Salgo of Budapest, who serves as a link between the players of Eastern Europe and the international bridge fraternity.

title: TOWNS AND SCHOOLS FINDING INSURANCE SCARCE AND COSTLY
description: WHEN John S. Whearty, the Superintendent of Schools in Mount Pleasant, purchased liability insurance for his district this year, he discovered that the rates had increased by 100 percent while the policy's coverage had decreased by 60 percent, to $6 million from $15 million.

title: F.B.I. VARIED TACTICS IN COLOMBO CASE
description: The first phase of the Colombo crime-group racketeering trial ended in Federal District Court in Manhattan last week with a demonstration that, even in a highly sophisticated case involving thousands of hours of electronic surveillance, there is still a place for shoe leather.

title: BUY A GAME, WIN A HOME
description: EVER since ''Monopoly'' took hold, games players have been used to the idea of buying and selling real estate. But a game in which a player can win a genuine $300,000 condominium? And get real coupons for such things as two free nights at a Miami Beach hotel, membership to an Atlantic City hotel dinner club, and discounts on food, magazines and electronic equipment?

title: THE HOLIDAY SEASON BRINGS AN OUTPOURING OF MUSICAL OFFERINGS
description: P.M. Tickets: Adults, $5; college students and the elderly, $3. Information: (201) 725-3420. Englewood John Harms Plaza - ''Festival of Christmas Music'' for choir, double brass quartet, percussion and organ. Pro Arte Chorale: Patricia Handy, conductor; Bob McGrath, narrator. Music from Gabrieli to Stravinsky; Daniel Pinkham's ''Christmas Cantata'' and carols with audience participation. 3 P.M. Tickets: Adults, $13; students and the elderly, $9.50. Information: (201) 445-9052. Glassboro Glassboro State College - Glassboro State College Concert Choir with brass, hand bells and chamber orchestra. Clarence Miller, conductor; Lawrence DePasquali, organist and pianist. Bach's Cantata No. 140. Free. 3 P.M. Information:(609) 863-5000. Hackensack Harrison Williams Senior Citizens Center - Bergen County Freeholders' Senior Citizens Concert: International winter songs and traditional Christmas music. Dennis DeSantis, conductor; Garah Landes, piano accompanist. New Jersey Chorale. Free. 2 P.M. Information: (201) 943-8498. Irvington Irvington High School - Christmas concert of Baroque music, madrigals and selections from Handel's ''Messiah.'' Irvington Symphony Orchestra and Chorus: James Sadewhite, conductor. 3 P.M. Free. Information: (201) 748-1194. Lakewood Georgian Court College - Georgian Court Wind Ensemble Christmas Concert. Works by Goldman, Wagner, Cole Porter, Lang, Ford and Werle. 3 P.M. Tickets: Adults, $3; students and the elderly, $2. Information: (201) 364-4666. Mendham Delbarton School - Christmas concert: Corelli's ''Christmas Concerto'' and works by Leopold Mozart and Leroy Anderson and traditional carols. Schola Cantorum, Wind Ensemble and Abbey Orchestra: Roy Horton, conductor. 3 P.M. Donations accepted. Information: (201) 538-3231.

title: ON NORTH FORK, THE WINDMILLS WHIRL ANEW
description: IN simpler times, windmills that pumped water dotted the fields and farms of Long Island's North Fork.

title: 5 Seized in Philadelphia Near Racially Tense Area
description: Five members of an antiracism group were arrested today as they shouted over bullhorns near a neighborhood placed under a state of emergency because of racial tensions, officials said.

title: THERE'S MORE THAN ONE OREGANO TO GROW AND SAVOR
description: Oregano is a typical essence found in the oils of many different genera. It is to pizza as basil is to pesto, a flavoring central to Italian food. But there has been some confusion among gardeners about the many kinds of plants known as oregano.

title: SIX ENDANGERED FERRETS ARE UNDER STRICT GUARD
description: In a nondescript modern building here at the University of Wyoming are what may be the last six healthy black-footed ferrets in the world.

title: FIREFIGHTERS CITE TOXIC SMOKE PERIL
description: EXPRESSING concern over the health effects of toxic smoke in fires, Westchester firefighters last week urged the state to establish a ''toxicity data bank'' that would contain information on the toxicity of smoke from certain building materials in a fire. But spokesmen for building-materials manufacturers and others argued against the measure, saying it was costly, premature and even dangerous.

title: ASPIRIN WARNING ON A YOUTH ILNESS EXPECTED
description: Sometime in early spring, a Federal regulation is expected to go into effect that will require all packages of aspirin or medicines containing aspirin to carry a warning about a childhood disease.

title: ROGERMARIS IS DEAD AT 51 SET RECORD FOR HOME RUNS
description: Roger Maris, who held the major league record for the most home runs in a single season, died yesterday at M. D. Anderson Hospital and Tumor Institute in Houston after a two-year bout with cancer, hospital officials said. He was 51 years old.

title: JAMIE OSTROFF TO MARRY JONATHAN BRUCE JAMES
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ostroff of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jamie Sue Ostroff, to Jonathan Bruce James, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald James of Fort Lee, N.J. The wedding is planned for June.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: White Christmas Starring Bing Crosby, Danny Kaye, Rosemary Clooney, Vera-Ellen; directed by Michael Curtiz, 1954 Paramount Home Video 120 minutes. $24.95 This assembly-line package was the biggest box-office grosser of 1954.

title: JAMES POPE, RETIRED ENDITOR OF LOUISVILLE COURIER-JOURNAL
description: James S. Pope, the retired executive editor of The Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times and former president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, died Friday after a long illness. He was 85 years old and had lived in Panama City, Fla., since he retired in 1962.

title: CYNTHIA SHENKER WED TO JAMES J. CAMPBELL
description: Cynthia Dee Shenker, a legislative lawyer, and James J. Campbell, director of the New York State Assembly task force on the disabled, were married yesterday at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Rabbi Bernard Bloom officiated. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Shenker of Pomona, N.Y. A graduate of Cornell University with a law degree from the Western New England Law School, she is an associate counsel to Daniel B. Walsh, majority leader of the State Assembly.

title: WHY WE LOVE THEM: BECAUSE THEY'RE THE GIANTS
description: FOR the first time in 22 years us Giant fans are sleeping better.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever Directed by Don Mischer MGM/UA Home Video 130 minutes. $29.95 Motown's 25th-anniversary special, which won an Emmy for best variety show of 1983, is a sprawling, sentimental ''family'' affair that catches fire every time Michael Jackson comes into view. Today, even in the wake of the Michael Jackson mania that this show helped to whip up, the performer's boyish ferocity as he whirls and moon-walks through ''Billie Jean'' remains spellbinding.

title: SMALL SCREENS BREED SMALL MOVIES
description: In the 1950's, movie makers attempted to fight television competition by offering the public an alternative - new techniques with trademarked names like Cinerama, CinemaScope, VistaVision, WarnerSuperScope, Todd-AO. Each was designed to fill the ever-bigger theater screens with images of a depth, a clarity and a density of information impossible on a television set. In fact, VistaVision and Todd-AO did pretty much what they promised, and even the various 'scopes created a healthy new awareness of the shape of the screen and its relation to motion picture narratives.

title: MISS WILSON HAS WEDDING
description: St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Larkin Wilson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Wilson of New York, to George Walton Taliaferro Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Taliaferro of Harrisonburg, Va. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: PRETORIA FREES 12 DISSIDENTS
description: Twelve prominent opponents of the South Africa Government, forbidden to speak out while they stood charged with treason, could rejoice without reprisal last week. After four months of trial, the prosecution said there were legal errors in its case and dropped the charges.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: COUTURE: The Great Designers. By Caroline Rennolds Milbank. (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $65.) This book is as opulent as its ultimate subject - haut-couturier clothing.

title: 'HANSEL AND GRETEL' TOUR SET
description: GLASSBORO

title: WINTER WEDDING FOR ANNE UPSON
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Barnard Upson of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Anne English Upson to John Winthrop Marcus, the son of Ruth Alland Marcus of New York and Morey Marcus of Pound Ridge, N.Y. A February wedding is planned. The future bride, a director of programming for CBS/Fox Video in New York, graduated from the Low-Heywood School in Stamford, Conn., Bradford Junior College and the University of Arizona.

title: GUATEMALA'S PRESIDENT-ELECT TAKES TO ROAD
description: The new President-elect, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, began a quick tour of Central American capitals today, the first in a series of trips he plans to take before assuming the presidency next month. He will spend much of the five weeks before he takes office traveling in Latin America and Europe, according to aides.

title: SHULTZ HEADS FOR THE OTHER SIDE OF EUROPE
description: THE Reagan Administration is showing renewed interest in Eastern Europe, spurred by last month's Reagan-Gorbachev meeting and the knowledge that a thaw in Soviet-American relations often produces openings as Moscow's allies make the most of Russian smiles. After stopping in this Western enclave, Secretary of State George P. Shultz planned to visit Rumania and Hungary today and tomorrow. He was to spend a day in Yugoslavia before returning to Washington.

title: SWEPT UP BY THE GRABLE LOOK
description: ELABORATE, sculptured hairdos are back for evening. Some, carefully curled variations of Betty Grable's upswept style, should be familiar to a lot of former G.I.'s. The heiress Barbara Hutton helped popularize the style, too.

title: SCHOOL DRUG TEST IS RULED ILLEGAL
description: Drug and alcohol abuse are medical problems, officials of the Henry P. Becton Regional High School in New Jersey contended last summer when they decided to screen all students for signs of such abuse. But a State Superior Court judge ruled last week that drug abuse is also a criminal matter, and that the proposed drug test therefore violated constitutional protections against illegal search and seizure and against invasions of privacy.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Sam Heyman has sunk his teeth into a very big animal that is worth a lot. The question is: Is the animal going to bite him back?''

title: THE NAVY'S BRASH LEADER
description: ZIPPERED INTO AN orange flight suit, John F. Lehman Jr. struts the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Coral Sea with a proprietary air. Already, the visiting Navy Secretary has interrogated the vessel's officers on the state of its aging bulwarks and boilers. He has gone on the ship's closed-circuit television to solicit reaction to his latest initiatives, a Navy-wide order commanding that paperwork be cut in half and a message shortening the time sailors and pilots spend at sea. He has made the rounds of the pilots' ready rooms, like a politician working a favorite precinct, bantering knowledgeably about the status of pay bonuses, training programs and new weapons, and curling his lip contemptuously at the ''petty bureaucrats'' on Capitol Hill and ''lounge lizards in the Pentagon'' who make his job difficult.

title: HOW SECLUSION MAY HELP IN AN ATHLETE'S RECOVERY
description: BERNARD KING, the basketball star, has secluded himself since injuring his knee last March. Until now he has not given interviews and has not appeared at the games with his team, the New York Knicks, and we sports fans miss him like a son. Although I have never spoken to Bernard, I can understand how the normal rehabilitation process for a seriously injured athlete might reqire his seclusion.

title: THE GONE WILL NOT SOON BE FORGOTTEN
description: THE trial of Argentina's former military rulers ended last week when five of the nine defendants were convicted of human rights abuses. Their sentences ranged from life in prison to four-and-a-half years. But the verdict, which followed an eight-month trial during which more than 1,000 witnesses testified against men who ran Argentina for seven years, seems unlikely to end the argument over their reign or the anguish remaining in its wake.

title: Sons Confess in Death Of Mexican Diplomat
description: The Mexican Ambassador, Horacio Flores de la Pena, said today that the son and stepson of a Mexican diplomat slain here had confessed to the killing.

title: FUND TO FIGHT INFANT MORTALITY IN 10 CITIES CALLED INSUFFICIENT
description: IN October, the state's Department of Health began its $1.8 million Healthy Mothers-Healthy Babies campaign to reduce infant mortality in 10 of New Jersey's largest cities, but a group of health-care professionals and community representatives believes more effort is needed.

title: A CHANGE WEIGHED IN AIDING HOMELESS
description: COUNTY officials are considering whether to adopt a policy to force the homeless into shelters when the temperature drops below freezing.

title: LAUTREC NEVER LOOKED BETTER
description: A spirit of mischief is abroad in New York City, and its headquarters are in the Museum of Modern Art, where through Jan. 26 we can see a mammoth exhibition of prints by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec (1864-1901) together with one or two major paintings to bulk out the package. People are rolling up in almost unmanageable numbers to see this show, and they come away delighted with the spirit of mischief and surprised, in many cases, by the unexpected delicacy and refinement of Lautrec's workmanship.

title: NOBEL PRIZE OUTCRY: PANEL SURPRISED
description: The room, quiet and green in tone, contains an oval wooden table, six upholstered chairs and a crystal chandelier. On the discreetly flowered walls are 69 small framed black and white photographs of the men and women who have won the Nobel Peace Prize since it was first awarded in 1901.

title: THE YAWN OF COURAGE
description: The evil economic empire called OPEC, which brought the world a decade of inflation and high interest rates, finds its power to gouge imperiled by oversupply.

title: SOME ENGLISH RITUAL FARE FOR CHRISTMAS
description: WHEN I was a child, Christmas was the most important day of the year. Because my father was in the foreign service we were usually abroad for the holiday. Celebrating it became a way of reminding ourselves of home. It engendered yearnings for an English world that has all but vanished now - of the nursery, gongs for meals, heavy puddings and brisk walks - a world more familiar to the viewers of Masterpiece Theater than to many English people today.

title: ISLIP MOVING AGAINST GRAFFITI
description: ISLIP TOWN is stepping up its battle against graffiti.

title: 'DOLLY' MISSES THE MARK
description: AT the Darien Dinner Theater opening night last Sunday, ''Hello, Dolly!'' was introduced as ''America's favorite musical.'' Such a sweeping statement, arguable enough even with the best of ''Dollys,'' is hardly supported by the tentative staging in Darien.

title: Mondale, All of Him
description: You may have crossed Walter F. Mondale off your current list of consuming interests, but the Minnesota Historical Society hasn't. Four operatives from that group were over at the National Archives last week, poring over the papers of the former Senator and Vice President, which is a somewhat bigger job than you might have thought.

title: MISS MINOR TO MARRY HAIGH SCOTT REINIGER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lance Cabell Minor Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Gail Minor to Haigh Scott Reiniger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Haigh McDiarmid Reiniger of Boston.

title: TWO ON THE AISLE IN TOKYO
description: Some years ago, one rainy day in Copenhagen, I went to see a Woody Allen movie, in English with Danish subtitles. Though it was midafternoon the theater was fairly full; but I had the unnerving experience of being the only one in the large house who laughed (and I laughed a lot). Either the creator of the titles had missed the humor or the Danes were just being melancholy. Some years before, I had had the same experience in reverse, seeing a comic play in Shiraz. The Iranian audience rocked with laughter while I, knowing no Farsi, sat there unsmiling. But not discontent. For the true theater lover, some enjoyment can be found in any performance: in the bravura of the acting (which you can follow without any distraction by the text), in the alien body language, even in the sometimes unpredictable reactions of the audience.

title: POLICE TIE EAST SIDE ROBBERTY TO 16 REPORTED SINCE AUGUST
description: An armed man who entered the unlocked fifth-floor balcony door of an Upper East Side apartment Friday night and bound and robbed the 25-year-old resident has been linked by the police to 16 previous robberies in Manhattan over the last four months.

title: CRACKS IN APARTHEID'S WALL
description: South Africa's biggest political trial in two decades came to a sudden end the other day when the Government's treason case against 12 black and Asian dissidents collapsed. With a grain of sense, the Pretoria regime will now free the four remaining defendants.

title: NANCY L. MAJOR BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Nancy Lauren Major, a credit analyst with Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and Todd Cranston Morgan, a commercial lender for Credit Suisse, both in New York, were married yesterday. The ceremony at the Thompson Memorial Chapel at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., was performed by the the Rev. Carol Pepper, chaplain to the college and a United Church of Christ minister.

title: PIANO: OLEG MAISENBEG
description: OLEG MAISENBERG'S pianism combines the flash and glitter of the Russian virtuoso tradition with a distinctly personal sensitivity and analytic intelligence. His Thursday evening concert at the Metropolitan Museum was a rewarding one.

title: CAVEATS IN A CO-OP PURCHASE
description: MEDICAL professionals such as physicians, dentists and therapists are increasingly discovering that to obtain desirable space in New York City, they must buy rather than lease.

title: BARBARA SCHIFFMAN TO WED GARY COHEN IN SEPTEMBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schiffman of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Schiffman, to Gary Ronald Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry L. Cohen of Tenafly, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: NORTH DAKOTA ST. WINS FINAL
description: Jeff Bentrim rushed for two touchdowns and passed for another today as North Dakota State routed North Alabama, 35-7, for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division II title in the Palm Bowl.

title: ON DEFENDING LE FRANCAIS: A WORD WAR
description: A private group here has stepped up the longstanding effort to keep English words out of the French language by suing those who break this country's laws about linguistic purity.

title: LEARNING-DISABLED STUDENTS TAKE TO COMPUTERS
description: A GROUP of learning-disabled pupils in East Hampton is finding the computer a key to academic achievement.

title: Higher Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnegie Hall Gets $2.5 Million Gift
description: Sanford I. Weill, co-chairman of the Campaign for Carnegie Hall's renovation and restoration, and his wife, Joan, will donate $2.5 million to the campaign. It is the largest individual gift to Carnegie Hall since Andrew Carnegie built the landmark concert hall in 1891.

title: The Giants Need Timeout Coach
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STATE SUIT AGAINST CAVEL ENDS IN SETTLEMENT
description: The New York State Attorney General has dropped a lawsuit charging that the Carvel Corporation forced its franchises to buy their supplies solely from the company at inflated prices.

title: MILES EXPANDING
description: Earlier this year, Miles Laboratories Inc., the pharmaceutical concern, purchased from the community of West Haven, Conn., a 30-acre piece of property adjacent to its 50-acre research and manufacturing facility on Morgan Lane. The acquisition, which gave the company control of the land bounded by Interstate 95, Heffernan Drive, Morgan Lane and the Oyster River, was the first step toward the creation of a complex that will be the focus of the company's research on pharmaceuticals in North America.

title: SAM ROBERTS OF TIMES TO GET PETER KIHSS REPORTING AWARD
description: Sam Roberts, a reporter for The New York Times, has been named by the Fund for the City of New York as the recipient of the second annual Peter Kihss Award for excellence in reporting about New York City government.

title: OFFICE GROWTH
description: In the last 10 years Morris County, N.J., has emerged as a major office center. The Parsippany-Troy Hills area has been particularly attractive to developers, in part, because of its proximity to both east-west and north-south highways, including Route 80 and Interstate 287.

title: ANNETTE E. KLUSS TO MARRY FEB. 15
description: Annette Elizabeth Kluss, an appraiser and cataloguer of Japanese works of art and an auctioneer at Sotheby's in New York, plans to be married Feb. 15 to Paul H. Alvarez, chairman and chief executive officer of Ketchum Public Relations in New York. The future bride is a daughter of Doree Gongwer Kluss of Mamaroneck, N.Y., who has announced her engagement, and the late Wilfred M. Kluss of Stamford, Conn.

title: REAGAN URGES ARMS AID FOR NICARAGUA REBELS
description: President Reagan, preparing to seek renewed military assistance next year for Nicaraguan rebels, denounced the Nicaraguan leadership today as ''thugs'' whose military units are increasingly dominated by Cuban military personnel.

title: ANDERSON IS PUSHED BUT DOESN'T BUDGE
description: White-haired, smiling, courtly in speech and manner, Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton looks like a man who would rather talk than fight. Amiable negotiation has, in fact, been his style as majority leader of the Republican-controlled New York State Senate during the equally conciliatory Mario M. Cuomo's three years in the Governor's office.

title: NEW YORK DINING BY DESIGN
description: If there is anything that unites the current generation of restaurants in Manhattan - more than the food they serve, more than the kind of people they attract, more than their often gargantuan size -it is that virtually all of them have been created on the assumption that a restaurant is a work of design as much as it is a place for preparing and serving food.

title: OWNING A PIECE OF HARVARD SQUARE
description: IN New York they sell miniatures of the Statue of Liberty; in San Francisco, it's cable cars. And in Cambridge, Mass., there's now a ceramic replica of the kiosk in Harvard Square.

title: Soviet Fills Vacancy In Its Finance Ministry
description: Boris I. Gostev, a former aide to Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, has been appointed Finance Minister, the official press agency Tass said today.

title: RAISES FOR JERSEY AIDES URGED
description: A panel appointed by Governor Kean has recommended substantial pay increases for the Governor, state judges, Cabinet officers and legislators.

title: 2d IN NATIONS, 2d ON CAMPUS
description: The University of Michigan's basketball team is ranked No. 2 in the news-agency polls. Closer to home, that status is appropriate in another way as well.

title: KEAN OFFERS HUDSON TRANSIT PLAN
description: Governor Kean today outlined an $825 million transportation improvement plan for the Hudson River waterfront that would link the 25 major housing and commercial projects that are on the drawing boards.

title: JUDGE CONVICTED OF TAKING BRIBES
description: A Federal jury last week found Justice William C. Brennan of State Supreme Court in Queens guilty of accepting bribes to fix court cases. At his sentencing, scheduled for Feb. 3, Justice Brennan will face maximum prison terms of 20 years on the most serious charges.

title: 'MESSIAH' EVER NEW TO DAVID RANDOLPH
description: DAVID RANDOLPH, music director and conductor of the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, has led his ensemble in Handel's complete ''Messiah'' 105 times - ''probably more than any other conductor,'' he says.

title: 21 SENSORS IN STATE SET FOR FLOOD DATA
description: IN two weeks, officials hope to begin receiving the first computerized readings from a new statewide automated flood-warning system.

title: AMY E. SMITHLINE TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Smithline of White Plains of the engagement of their daughter, Amy Elizabeth Smithline, to Robert Jonathan Strauch, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Berish Strauch of New Rochelle, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May. Miss Smithline, an alumna of Northwestern University, and her fiance are fourth-year students at Northwestern's School of Medicine and the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, respectively.

title: BEHIND EVWERY PIANIST LURKS AN UNHERALDED HERO
description: Some years ago, a music critic at a debut panned every aspect of the pianist's performance, finishing the poor fellow off with the indictment, ''Mr. X actually made the piano seem out of tune.'' This coup de grace assumed a general understanding that in recital, no piano could possibly be out of tune. As such, it paid tribute to the technicians who attend at least part of every concert where a piano is featured, hovering over the instrument as a doctor hovers over a moribund patient, checking each key for pitch, weight, response and voicing - the piano's vital signs.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: WINTER BIRD COUNT In 1899, Frank M. Chapman, known as the dean of American ornithologists, started the first winter bird count at 25 Northeastern sites. He wanted to provide an alternative to the Christmas Side Hunt, in which shooters competed to kill the largest number of wild birds and animals on Christmas Day.

title: WALL STREET'S ENDANGERED SPECIES
