description: EVEN by current standards, it was an exceptionally busy week for the investment bankers and Wall Street lawyers who have grown flush with fees for ar-ranging multibillion-dollar mergers and hostile takeover bids. And while some experts said the economy could absorb the effects of such deals with little trouble, others - including Government officials - warned of trouble ahead and stepped up efforts to curb the takeover trend.

title: THE POLITICAL PERILS OF MORE U.S. TRADE
description: MANY Americans, including recent Presidents, have been surprised to learn than their leading trading partner is not Japan but the phlegmatic, sub-Arctic country to the north. In fact, a single Canadian province, Ontario, does more business with the United States than does Japan, and, at $20 billion, America's 1984 trade deficit with Canada exceeded on a per capita basis its trade deficit with Japan.

title: IN DEFENSE OF PURPLE PROSE
description: A WORD is its uses, as William H. Gass shows in his rollicking conspectus, ''On Being Blue,'' although he might have ogled ''purple'' as well. Purple does seep into his bluebook, however, here tinting some ''spent body like a bruise,'' there leaving a ''lavender thumb''-print of ''broken veins.'' In fact, as well as being a book on the uses of ''blue'' - in talk, literature and the dictionary - ''On Being Blue'' is a prime, up-to-date example of purple prose, not so much a patch as it is a pyramid, a pandemonium, a seething nuclear pile of words.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: NORMANDIE: Queen of the Seas. By Bruno Foucart, Charles Offrey, Francois Robichon and Claude Villers. (Vendome, $50.) Fifty years ago the glittering, record-breaking Normandie first tied up at New York's Pier 88.

title: DAUGHTER'S GONE, MEMORIES LINGER
description: ''AH, peace and quiet,'' he said when his youngest girl left for college.

title: TRADITION IN WORDS
description: THIS is a story about a woman who tells stories, a woman named Peninnah. Peninnah's Lithuanian grandmother was also named Peninnah. The name means Pearl, and it comes from the Old Testament.

title: INVENTING THE AFRIKANER PAST
description: THE POLITICAL MYTHOLOGY OF APARTHEID By Leonard Thompson. 293 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22.50.

title: U.S. AGENCY ACCUSED OF IMPROPRIETY ON SHOREHAM
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee has charged the Federal Emergency Management Agency with improperly hiring a management consultant to help conduct a controversial test of emergency plans for the Shoreham nuclear power station.

title: THE STAGE: 'NUNSENSE,' A MUSICAL
description: IF you forget the featherweight plot and watch the five winning actresses dressed as nuns do their vaudeville turns in ''Nunsense,'' a new musical comedy at the Cherry Lane Theater, after a while it becomes habit-forming. That pun is the property of Dan Goggin, the show's writer-director, who uses it in the first number and again in the final reprise, ''Nunsense Is Habit-Forming.''

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Nutcracker A Royal Ballet production, featuring Lesley Collier and Anthony Dowell; directed by John Vernon, 1985 Thorn EMI/HBO Video tk minutes.

title: THEATER GROUP ADDRESSES THE DEAF
description: MARK TWAIN'S Captain Stormfield, and tales of some wriggling crabs and a man who turns outer space green are being performed this month in Connecticut -and in India and Nepal, too.

title: STARTING A NEW TRADITION
description: A STROLL THROUGH THE woods or, simpler still, a trip to the corner grocery store can reap a host of untraditional, as well as inexpensive, alternatives to the ubiquitous amaryllis or poinsettia plants or boughs of white pine and balsam that customarily fill the house each Christmas.

title: BEARS GET A TASTE OF PLAYOFF WEATHER
description: The temperatures were numbing. The winds were swirling. For a while, it snowed. Chicago weather. The Bears didn't exactly love it. But they didn't mind it, either. ''It'll be colder in Chicago in January,'' Jim McMahon, the Bears' quarterback, said today after he and his teammates had beaten the Jets, 19-6. ''Hopefully, we'll have a bunch more games there.''

title: A 1920's ARCHITECTURAL TOUR
description: When Los Angeles was a raucous boomtown in the 1920's, Pasadena was an affluent suburb surrounded by citrus groves and filled with the families of businessmen from the Middle West and the East Coast, many of whom had discovered the community as a winter resort and later moved there permanently. Although Pasadena's gentry ''had been established by brand names such as Heinz's Pickles, Smith Brothers' Cough Drops and Chalmer's Underwear,'' Anita Loos once wrote, many of these same families pursued culture in all its forms - including architecture.

title: GRADING PUPILS: D IS DO BETTER
description: No A's for effort, or even C's or D's are allowed these days in the city's public schools under a new grading system in which only academic performance can be used to evaluate students.

title: ANN MCDONOUGH MARRIED
description: Ann Folan McDonough, a daughter of Margaret McDonough of Baltimore and the late Robert McDonough, was married yesterday to John Mitchell Gilpin, a son of Kenneth N. Gilpin Jr. of Boyce, Va., and the late Lucy M. Gilpin. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Swanson performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The bride, a graduate of Towson State University, and her husband, a graduate of Harvard College, are actors.

title: GAIL LAPIDUS MARRIED TO LAURENCE DOBOSH
description: Gail Felicia Lapidus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Lapidus of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there last evening to Laurence Daryl Dobosh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Dobosh of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Amiel Wohl and Cantor Helaine Reps officiated at Temple Israel.

title: MEN'S POWER, WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: ''Today's Woman: Running in Place'' [Opinion Page, Nov. 17] described the obstacles and hidden mines women face as individuals in running the male-powered gauntlet of office politics. When the focus is on women's responsibilities as individuals, we lose sight of the larger field in which the politics of sex discrimination is played.

title: LET YOUR FINGERS DO THE SHOPPING FOR LINES
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital for Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW STRAIN OF V.D. ON RISE
description: A PENICILLIN-RESISTANT strain of gonorrhea is showing up in increasing numbers in Connecticut, according to state health officials.

title: FAMILY HOLIDAY PROGRAMS
description: THERE are enough programs planned in the county to satisfy the most ardent Yuletide celebrant, and many of them have been designed with the whole family's entertainment in mind.

title: ISLANDERS TIE BLUES, 2-2, ON GOAL BY BRENT SUTTER
description: This wasn't the way they wanted it to happen, but the Islanders made it two in a row tonight at Nassau Coliseum: they skated to a 2-2 tie with St. Louis on the heels of a 4-4 tie at Pittsburgh Wednesday.

title: RULE ON LEAD IN PIPES IGNORED
description: ONE of the greatest stumbling blocks to curbing lead poisoning on Long Island is the lax enforcement of county laws banning lead-solder use in home plumbing, according to engineers and building officials.

title: JOHN CHARLES JORDAN JR. WED TO SARAH ARMSTRONG
description: Sarah Lyon Armstrong and John Charles Jordan Jr. were married yesterday at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Robert MacLennan performed the ceremony.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Muddling Through After her mischievous ''Domestic Manners of the Americans'' came out in 1832, Fanny Trollope turned her attention to Parisians, who were a bit more satisfying to her rather sophisticated tastes. Here, in ''Paris and the Parisians'' (Hippocrene), she describes the conversational strategy of French-English encounters.

title: CONSUMER RATES
NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 36 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 36 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: SHANKER TO RETIRE AS HEAD OF LOCAL ON JAN. 1
description: Albert Shanker said yesterday that he would retire as president of the United Federation of Teachers on Jan. 1 after leading the New York City teachers union for 21 often-tumultuous years.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BIG ORCHESTRA SOUND If it's true that bigger is better, then today and tomorrow should be banner days at the C. W. Post Center's Tilles Concert Theater since three major orchestras are holding forth on the premises in Brookville. For starters, the Cleveland Orchestra, under Christoph von Dohnanyi's baton, performs Mozart, Zemlinsky and Brahms in a 2:30 P.M. matinee today. Call Friends of the Arts at 922-0061 for information. Then, the Long Island Philharmonic, with Christopher Keene conducting and Nathan Milstein as violin soloist, take over at 7:30 P.M. with a program featuring Bruch and Mozart's ''Requiem.'' Call 293-2222 for reservations.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ART GALLERY OPENING A new art gallery, organized by The Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson and the Cabrini Nursing Home of Dobbs Ferry, opens at 2:30 P.M. today in a first-floor corridor of the home, at 115 Broadway.

title: APARTHEID ADDED AS A SCHOOL TOPIC
description: Public school students in social-studies classes throughout the city participated in a ''teach-in'' on apartheid last week, part of a new, long-term effort by the Board of Education to add course material on racism in South Africa to the social-studies curriculum.

title: How We See Each Other
description: One should not accept too quickly the statements in Serge Schmemann's analysis of the Russian view of America to the effect that ''Soviet perceptions of America are for the most part as young as the Soviet state.'' From 1960 until my retirement in 1985, I was the area specialist (Russia and the Soviet Union) in the European Division of the Library of Congress.

title: ARE THOSE FICTIONAL DOCTORS BAD FOR THE VIEWER'S HEALTH?
description: While filming ''Spellbound,'' Alfred Hitchcock hired a prominent psychiatrist to advise on medical aspects of the script. When the doctor complained to the director that he was ignoring her suggestions, Hitchcock replied: ''My dear, this is motion-picture drama, not a psychoanalysis.''

title: BARBADOS IN TWO STAGES
description: The British have left their mark on Barbados. The language is English, the sport is cricket, the driving is on the left, politics is taken very seriously. Barbadians are proud of their hard-won struggle for national independence. But on this most easterly of Caribbean isles, politics gets a special spin.

title: JANE G. STODDARD PLANS TO WED JUNE 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hudson G. Stoddard of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Gillan Stoddard, to Brian Douglas Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Williams of Middletown, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 7.

title: EL SALVADOR BARS A VISIT BY REBELS
description: The Salvadoran Government refused to allow leftist guerrilla representatives to attend a conference here today dedicated to finding a negotiated end to the country's six-year-old civil war.

title: U.S. ENDORSES COVERT AID TO ANGOLA REBELS
description: The Reagan Administration, under pressure from conservatives to openly support Jonas Savimbi's Angolan insurgents, has added the threat of secret military aid to American diplomacy in southern Africa. In London last week, Secretary of State George P. Shultz endorsed ''covert action'' to supplement diplomacy.

title: BRONCOS WIN, 14-13, WITH LATE SCORE
description: John Elway, after having thrown five interceptions, completed three key passes in the closing minutes, and Sammy Winder dived 1 yard for a touchdown as the Denver Broncos kept their playoff hopes alive with a 14-13 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs today.

title: Caviar, the Chinese Variety
description: White House spokesmen aren't exactly trumpeting the news, but the new caviar imported from northern China is winning acceptability at the highest levels of the Reagan Administration. Last month at the state dinner the President gave for the Prince and Princess of Wales at the White House, the 88 guests consumed 4 kilograms, or about 9 pounds, of the product, and an additional supply has been ordered for a private party the President and Mrs. Reagan are planning for Dec. 23.

title: THE RIGHT WAY TO DEAL WITH GAMBITS
description: Accepting a gambit may be the preferred way of defeating it, as the world champion Wilhelm Steinitz asserted a century ago, but not all gambits can be successfully countered in the same way.

title: CHEROKEES INSTALL FIRST WOMAN AS CHIEF OF MAJOR AMERICNA INDIAN TRIBE
description: AThe daughter of a full-blooded Cherokee father and a white mother was installed today as the first woman to be chief of a major American Indian tribe.

title: HUNTINGTON FIGHT CONTINUING OVER TITUS POND
description: WHEN the Huntington Town Board voted unanimously late last month to condemn Titus Mill Pond and to acquire the 39-acre property through New York State's eminent-domain procedure, it was thought that more than 200 years of territorial disputes involving the parcel might have been brought to a conclusion.

title: NEW SHUTTLE LAUNCHING PAD
description: A second shuttle launching pad was dedicated at the Kennedy Space Center Friday, a key element in plans for 14 shuttle missions in 1986.

title: PASADENA
description: The Tournament of Roses parade will glide onto Colorado Boulevard with an extra charge of local pride on Jan. 1 as the city of Pasadena enters its centennial year.

title: THE HOMELESS OF LOS ANGELES MAKE THEIR NUMBERS FELT
description: The winter headaches of snow removal, potholes and subsidizing heating bills for the poor do not burden the leaders of the nation's second-largest city. But one year-round problem here more than makes up the deficit, local officials say. Los Angeles has more homeless people than any other city in the nation, according to figures of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, and the city says the problem is getting worse.

title: A THAI OUTPOST ON THE DELAWARE
description: FOR many people, the names Siam and Thailand conjure up different images. The old Siam (the ancient name for Thailand) brings visions of an exotic and elegant way of life, typified by sinuous, graceful dancers, gentle people and a whole fairytale world of ''Anna and the King of Siam.'' But for those who were once stationed in the East, Thailand's capital city of Bangkok was often the site for ''R and R'' - ''rest and rehabilitation'' - and all that the term implies.

title: Seoul Imprisons 3 for Sit-In
description: A Seoul court imprisoned three textile workers for two years today for leading a factory sit-in to demand the release of arrested union leaders, court officials said. They were among 35 workers and students charged with organizing illegal assemblies. The workers were also demanding the abolition of what they called repressive labor laws that virtually ban strikes.

title: RIDING THE WAVE OF GROWTH IN ROBOTICS
description: HE never took a vacation or a sick day. But after 10 years on the job - a nasty one, grinding stainless steel pipes for sinks - his company retired him anyway.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: EXHIBITIONS IN STAMFORD AND HARTFORD
description: RALSTON CRAWFORD (1906-1978) is best known as an abstract painter who went against the grain by painting compositions of quirky geometry when abstract expressionism was the favored mode. His paintings, along with his prints and a selection of photographs, form a major exhibition currently at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City.

title: NEW ASSAULT ON COCAINE PLEDGE BY U.S. DRUG CHIEF IN NEW YORK
description: In response to changing patterns of drug abuse, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has embarked on a new agenda in New York and stepped up the pursuit of organizations trafficking in cocaine, according to the newly appointed head of the agency's largest district office.

title: Photo of canadian soldiers taking part in military maneuvers in Alberta last spring (AP) CANADIANS DEBATE A FEEBLE MILITARY: ITS ONE STRENGTH IS ITS NATO ALLIES
description: When the Canadian armed forces held their largest maneuvers in several decades in Alberta last May and June, they fielded all the tanks they had in the country - a total of 18.

title: TEETH, WONDER WOMAN AND THE SOUL OF BALI
description: THE NOBLE HORSE. By Monique and Hans D. Dossenbach. (G. K. Hall & Company, $75.) This lush, oversized 448-page horse treasury is an ideal decoration, better seen than read.

title: New Federalism, Again
description: White House officials have told several governors that President Reagan intends to renew his ''new federalism'' drive next year, again calling for less Federal involvement in the states' affairs.

title: The Italians
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's article on the Italian disdain for Rome and its citizens, ''Why Italians Think They Hate Romans'' (Travel, Nov. 24), reminded me of a comment I heard many years ago while studying in Bologna.

title: WILL H.M.O.'S CARE FOR THOSE MOST ILL?
description: The article of Nov. 10 in which health maintenance organizations are discussed [''New Health Plans Moving Onto Island''] addresses health-care issues from the perspective of business. Health care has had, of necessity, to become increasingly business oriented, and personnel and consumers are the chess pieces in this game of medical economics.

title: IN THIS 'FLOWER SHOW,' A ROSE IS A ROSE IS A CAMERA
description: IF ''Flower Show,'' the title of the current exhibition at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, conjures up visions of a horticultural extravaganza in the galleries, the subtitle, ''Photographs From the J. Paul Getty Museum,'' advises that this is no garden club event.

title: Groups and People in History
description: To the Editor:

title: INSTEAD OF DESPAIR, A WARM GREETING
description: Today, most New Yorkers know that there are children and families in our city without hope, who are desperately in need. Families haunted by hunger, living in housing that is unsafe, dilapidated, devoid of light, heat, water and fit only for the superabundance for rodents that share their wretched quarters.

title: PROSECUTORS, PREJUDICE AND HANDPICKED JURIES
description: Some prosecutors think they can increase the odds of convicting a black defendant by removing blacks from the jury. And others believe they stand a better chance of convicting an accused murderer if they can purge the jury of opponents of the death penalty.

title: AN ORDER FOR CHANGE AT AUBURN
description: On the campus of Auburn University in Alabama, white students outnumber blacks, 16,500 to 651. A Montgomery branch campus and agricultural extension programs administered by Auburn in other parts of the state duplicate the curricula at neighboring schools that are predominantly black.

title: EIMICKE BARS EVICTING RELATIVES OF ORIGINAL TENANTS
description: WILLIAM B. EIMICKE, THE NEW YORK State Director of Housing, issued an emergency order last week barring landlords from using a recent Court of Appeals decision to evict relatives of tenants who have died or moved away.

title: Problems Facing Female Athletes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: NEW JERSEY and Delaware have joined forces to protect habitats important to migratory shore birds, a move that ornithologists hope will be emulated by other jurisdictions along the birds' annual route.

title: YOUNG ADULTS MUST ORGANIZE FOR STRENGTH
description: IF I were young and had a cause, it would be to organize those between the ages of 18 and 27.

title: JERRY HERMAN, FROM 'DOLLY' TO 'LA CARE'
description: It all began with Ethel Merman. Jerry Herman was in his early teens when his parents took him to see ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' on Broadway, and he fell in love.

title: Regatta to Mark Anniversary
description: The celebration next year of the 100th birthday of the Statue of Liberty has spawned a one-design sailboat regatta that claims its own share of New York history.

title: WINTER AT THE DOOR, RUMANIA CLOSES DOWN EARLY
description: After a warm fall, winter is closing in on this city, creating a visible reflex of apprehension in the population.

title: LATIN MILITARY PUT ONNOTICE BY JUNTA TRIAL
description: The guilty verdicts handed down this week to five former Argentine military rulers will influence Latin America for years to come, according to political and military leaders and commentators in the region.

title: REMEMBERNG A MASTER SPY AT HOME
description: A LONG ISLAND spy who contrived to conceal his identity for a century and a half is being remembered this year.

title: BIDEN SEES NO IMPROPRIETY IN TEAMSTER CASE
description: The ranking Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee says he is convinced that senior officials in the Justice Department and Federal Bureau of Investigation were not involved in wrongdoing in their handling of Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: ONTHE LOG PILE OF MEMORIES
description: ANOTHER winter is approaching and the string is running out. For 17 winters I have been burning wood in the fireplace, and not a single stick have I paid for.

title: SALE OF R.C.A. TO G.E. WILL REUNITE GIANTS
description: The sale of RCA was not entirely a surprise, given the popularity of broadcasting companies and the recurrent rumors of the possible purchase of NBC. But the price - $6.3 billion - and the buyer - G.E. - raised some eyebrows. G.E. had, however, said ite was looking for acquisitions to solidify its position in electronics. The G.E.-RCA deal, the larges non-oil merger in history, was put together quickly and quietly, but enough word leaked out that the stock price jumped more than $10 on the day of the announcement. Despite the overall euphoria and praise for the deal, a class-action suit said the companies should have disclosed the talks earlier, instead of allowing the rumor mill to run up the stock price.

title: PAUL MANSHIP IN A REVIVAL OF SORTS AT THE HUDSON MUSEUM
description: THE double-barreled title, with a colon between the barrels, is a rhetorical device that few exhibition curators can resist. ''Paul Manship: Changing Taste in America,'' however, is a title that really needs its second barrel, as visitors to the Hudson River Museum soon find out.

title: BUBBLY SELECTIONS FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: THE more than four-fold rise in sparkling-wine sales seen in the United States in the last 15 years has been accompanied by a marked increase in the number of products available at retail outlets. In fact, it is not unusual for even the most modest area shops to stock bottles of bubbly from New York State, California, Italy, Spain and France - with little-known brands offering consumers some of the best bargains.

title: Food;   A Dish Of Sicilian History
description: IF THERE IS ONE recipe that sums up what is best and most interesting in Sicilian cookery, it is surely pasta with wild fennel and sardines, a dish so subtle, mysterious and harmonious that I consider it one of the triumphs of the blending of disparate ingredients. Pasta con le sarde plays the soft texture and saline flavor of Mediterranean sardines against the slightly bitter and musty taste of wild green fennel from the Sicilian mountains. The play is further enhanced by the addition of sweet dried grapes from the lowland orchards, pine nuts from the forests, a little saffron (a touch of Moorish Spain), all combined with fine Sicilian olive oil, then presented to the diner against the soothing backdrop of a pasta.

title: THOSE NO-FRILLS VCR'S DELIVER THE ESSENTIALS
description: At this point, most of us are racing Santa to the chimney, but there's still time to pick up a VCR. Lots of people are, with the number of buyers doubling year after year.

title: Happy Ending
description: To the Editor: To the stories of lost wallets, snatched bags and travelers' woes, I would like to add one that had a happy ending. Stepping from a crowded bus in Rome's Piazza Venezia, I knew at once that I had had a wallet lifted. I carry one for money, the other for identification cards and my green card as a permanent resident of the United States; the latter had been taken.

title: TEXAS ADOPTS STRINGENT RULES ON RIGHTS OF POOR AT HOSPITALS
description: The Texas Health Department today approved stringent new regulations designed to prevent private hospitals from sending seriously ill patients whom they consider poor financial risks to public hospitals.

title: MUSICAL OFFERINGS FOR CHRISTMAS
description: PREPARATIONS are again under way for presenting the evocative music of Christmas in Westchester's churches and halls. For the 50th year, a group of Bronxville church choirs is rehearsing diligently for its ecumenical Creche Pageant, performed in all weather on the lawn of the Reformed Church at Pondfield Road, at 5:30 P.M. Christmas Eve.

title: Non-Rajneeshee Leaders Lake Over Ex-Commune
description: A new administration has replaced the all-Rajneeshee town government whose members resigned when the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh left the United States after pleading guilty to charges of immigration fraud.

title: THERE'S ROOM FOR NEGOTIATION ON A BROKER'S FEE
description: ASK any real-estate broker in the metropolitan region what his fee is for selling a home or an apartment and the answer, almost invariably, will be ''6 percent.'' Pose the same question to the New York State Association of Realtors and the answer is that commissions are ''always negotiated,'' in compliance with Federal antitrust laws that prohibit price-fixing.

title: A CHARMING 'OLIVER,' WITH A MESSAGE
description: AS its holiday offering, Theater Three in Port Jefferson is presenting ''Oliver,'' the musical by Lionel Bart based on Charles Dickens's novel ''Oliver Twist.''

title: ONE LANGUAGE, HIGHLY DIVISIBLE
description: DICTIONARY OF AMERICAN REGIONAL ENGLISH Volume One. Introduction and A-C. Chief Editor, Frederic G. Cassidy. 903 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $49.95; $60 after Dec. 31.

title: AT LAST, S.I. TELEPORT GETS ITS FIRST TENANT
description: WASYL LEW sits at his desk in a modified mobile home in the Bloomfield section of Staten Island and waits for the future to arrive. Mr. Lew, the president of the tiny Catholic Telecommunications Network of America, came here in October with his 18 employees, who share two other trailers in the alternately dusty and muddy corner of what will eventually be a parking lot.

title: TRAVEL BY AIR BROUGHT PROSPERITY TO GANDER
description: More than 20 years before there was a town of Gander, there was an airport here.

title: CAFFEINE IS FOUND OF HELP IN SIDS
description: THE search at St. Peter's Medical Center here for help in the fight against SIDS (sudden infant death syndrome) has led to the discovery that a familiar drug, caffeine, can be safely used in the battle.

title: REPORT WARNS CITY TO ANTICIPATE U.S. AID CUT AND TRIM SPENDING
description: The State Financial Control Board, citing expected cuts in Federal aid, has called on the city to begin modestly curtailing expenses to reduce the need for sharper spending cuts next year.

title: TWICE-IN-A LIFETIME VIEWER REJOICES AT HALLEY'S RETURN
description: AT THE age of 80, Philip J. Del Vecchio admits without hesitation that he is a two-timer, and his wife, Teresa, says it was bound to happen.

title: SHOREHAM DRILL: PLANNING THE DETAILS
description: DESPITE the objections of Suffolk County and New York State, Federal officials moved ahead last week with plans for an emergency preparedness test for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: CUOMO CALLS FOR USING $1 BILLION FROM M.A.C. TO HELP CITY TRANSIT
description: Governor Cuomo called yesterday for using $1 billion of Municipal Assistance Corporation money to help avert an economic crisis for mass transit in New York City. He also proposed creating a panel to monitor mass-transit spending in the metropolitan area.

title: No Headline
description: THE traffic is stop-and-creep on the rain-wet Long Island Expressway, but for once I don't mind. For one thing, I am not behind the wheel. For another, I am of two minds about the evening that lies ahead, and one of those minds would just as soon not arrive. And for a third, I am poring over my high school yearbook, getting in the mood for my 20-year class reunion.

title: Opportunity for a Gift
description: When a senator organizes a fund-raiser with no political beneficiary, that's news. When it's a Jewish Senator and the fund-raising involves Christmas, the story gets even more interesting.

title: CARLOS P. ROMULO OF PHILIPPINES DIES
description: Carlos P. Romulo, the eloquent Filipino diplomat who was a leading spokesman for newly independent third world countries in the early years of the United Nations, died yesterday in Manila. He was 86 years old.

title: 6 WORKERS FOR CITY HONORED
description: In the commotion and congestion that is New York City, it is a wonder to many that anything gets done at all. To most city residents, as an urban specialist, William H. Whyte, once noted, ''simply coping with New York'' is considered an act of heroism.

title: THE TOWNSPEOPLE OF GANDER GRIEVE FOR G.I.'S AS THEY WOULD THEIR OWN
description: The driving snow had abated but a bitter wind rattled the flags flying at half-staff when Gander's townspeople turned out this afternoon to mourn the 256 Americans killed in the air disaster Thursday.

title: Let American Textile Workers Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers Should Not Testify Against Clients
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale of Stake Set by Curtiss
description: The Curtiss Wright Corporation and its subsidiaries said they had decided to sell the 3,981,000 shares, or 16.3 percent, of the stock they held in the Western Union Corporation. Curtiss Wright also said it was rescinding a share purchase ''standstill'' arrangement between the two begun in November 1983.

title: Shaklee Fight Ousts Chief
description: J. Gary Shansby, who helped build the Shaklee Corporation into a major direct sales company, resigned as chairman and chief executive this weekend in a dispute with directors, the company said today.

title: A 'Fire-Sale Price' Irks The Head of Sea-Land
description: In the years he served as vice chairman of R. J. Reynolds Industries and, earlier, when he held the same post at the General Foods Corporation, Joseph F. Abely Jr. was involved in a corporate takeover or two. But what is happening now is outside his experience.

title: CARNEGIE HALL ANNOUNCES DEPARTURE OF DIRECTOR
description: Carnegie Hall yesterday announced that Seymour Rosen, joint managing director of the hall since July 1982, would leave his post effective Feb. 1. He will be replaced by Judith Arron, who has been manager of the Cincinnati Symphony for the last 10 years.

title: Israelis Question U.S. On Gun Deal Charges
description: Israel demanded today that the United States explain its charges that Israel had illegally acquired defense technology, and said at least one of the purchases had been financed and approved by the Defense Department.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TREE IN THE FOREST The Gotham Book Mart is in itself a touch of old New York, a survivor of the days when bookstores were repositories of books old and new rather than cut-price, best-seller merchandising marts. The shop's little sign in front of 41 West 47th Street, depicting a man with a line and the slogan ''Wise Men Fish Here,'' sets it off from the gesticulating hubbub of the jewelry district around it.

title: For Free Subways
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS ASSAIL PLAN FOR F.H.A.
description: Economists, mortgage bankers and other housing industry analysts yesterday sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's plan to sell the Federal Housing Administration to private bidders by the end of 1989.

title: Sex Offender Granted Parole After 3 Years of 15-Year Term
description: An obese sex offender whose brief release from prison because of weight-related ailments prompted national outrage in 1982 is to be paroled Tuesday after serving 3 years of a 15-year sentence.

title: 32 Missing on Mexican Ship
description: Rescue workers battling high seas searched today for 32 workers missing from a Government oil company boat that sank in the Gulf of Mexico. A company spokesman said 39 of the 71 people aboard were rescued Saturday after the boat, the Huichol, sank in winds up to 60 miles an hour.

title: MIAMI CULTURES FIND RAPPORT AFTER A GENERATION OF CLASHES
description: A Spanish-language television station signs off for the night with a ''buenos noches.'' Then the studio technicians, all young people of Hispanic origin, discuss the next day's schedule. In English.

title: CUOMO TO SEEK FEDERAL INQUIRY ON FUEL PRICING
description: Governor Cuomo will ask the Federal Justice Department today to investigate what state consumer officials are calling unusual recent increases in heating oil prices on Long Island, his office has announced.

title: BRITISH TREASURE HOUSES
description: ''TREASURE HOUSES OF BRITAIN'' shows us the stateliest of the stately homes and the bric-a-brac within. No one has thrown anything away in years. We get paintings, porcelain, furniture, glasses, ewers, salvers, statues, books, bowls, tapestries, drapes, carvings, even turtle skulls, whimsically nailed to a wall. Meanwhile, everyone is extremely polite and a little self-conscious. The program, the first of a three-part series, will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: POLICE, MARSHALS AND CHICKEN LURE FUGITIVES INTO CUSTODY
description: The police and Federal marshals, one marshal dressed as a chicken, arrested 100 fugitives who had been lured to a brunch today with promises of free tickets to a Washington Redskins-Cincinnati Bengals football game.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 11:15 A.M. today and set at 11:40 P.M. tomorrow.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: An obituary of Riggs Stephenson last month pointed out that Stephenson was not in the Hall of Fame even though he was a .336 hitter in his major-league career. Did any player have a higher average among those not enshrined?

title: SAUTER DISCUSSES CBS NEWS ROLE
description: Van Gordon Sauter, who began his second tour as president of CBS News last week, spent part of his first few days back on the job talking with staff members about the importance of documentaries.

title: Wall Street Christmas Bonuses: Bullish
description: As the curtain falls on one of its best years ever, Wall Street is rewarding the people who made it all possible with the financial world's traditional present: the Christmas bonus.

title: Futures/Options;   Brazil Drought Buoys Coffee
description: SHARPLY rising prices, heavy volume and traders' confusion have made coffee futures the liveliest trading commodity recently.

title: A LOST WEEKEND
description: IN completing a lost weekend, the Giants were unable to do what the Jets were unable to do - win a big game that would have simplified their status in the Super Bowl XX playoffs. And when somebody mentioned to Phil Simms after the 28-21 loss to the Dallas Cowboys yesterday that ''people say the Giants don't win the big game,'' the blond quarterback's face flushed in anger.

title: Roger Maris: No Asterisk
description: THERE are two misconceptions about Roger Maris that should be cleared up in the wake of his death Saturday at the age of 51. The first is that he was some kind of baseball mediocrity who just happened to hit 61 homers in 1961, and the second is that he was some kind of asocial being, vastly different from the other Yankees in the clubhouse.

title: NEW ZEALAND MIGHT EXPEL AGENTS
description: New Zealand said today it would consider sending two French secret service agents jailed for their part in the sinking of the Rainbow Warrior, but only if France guaranteed to keep them in jail.

title: A Good Choice for Refugees
description: Few jobs are harder, or more heartbreaking, than that of United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The incumbent is steward of the hapless millions dislocated by invasions, civil wars and rebellions.

title: INDONESIANS HOPE TO SETTLE DISPUTES IN TIMOR AND IRIAN JAYA
description: Forty years after their country declared its independence from the Dutch, Indonesians say they are making progress in defusing two ''time bombs'' left behind by colonial powers.

title: A FRESH THRUST BY SHISEIDO
description: Every so often, Victor Harris, the president of Max Factor's Japanese subsidiary, is pressed by his American supervisors to attack the weaknesses of the Japanese cosmetics giant, Shiseido. But he says: ''I've spent a career examining their weaknesses, and you're not going to find any major ones.''

title: Bridge: Some Computer Programs Are Top-Flight Insurance
description: Although programs that enable home computers to bid, play and defend random deals are still open to considerable improvement, others that provide a limited number of planned deals for instructional purposes are of high caliber.

title: FOR A SHINING MOMENT A YEAR, TUBAS GET SPOTLIGHT
description: ''Is this some sort of tradition?'' asked Malcolm Blair, an Englishman, peering down into the skating rink at Rockefeller Center yesterday. ''I'm from Brooklyn,'' replied Lila Wood, ''I have no idea what this could be.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cameron Iron Works Inc., a Houston-based company that makes oil and gas drilling and production tools, has elected Philip J. Burguieres president and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: Ahrne Thorne, Editor Of Anarchist Journal
description: Ahrne Thorne, a Yiddish writer and the last editor of the defunct New York anarchist journal Freie Arbeiter Stimme (Free Voice of Labor), died of cancer Friday at his home in the Bronx. He was 80 years old.

title: Portuguese Vote In Local Elections
description: Early returns from local elections throughout Portugal today indicated that the Social Democratic Party of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva would retain control of Lisbon and Oporto, the country's two largest cities.

title: KNICKS AWAIT KING'S WORD
description: After Patrick Ewing turned the final two minutes of Saturday night's game against the San Antonio Spurs into a showcase and a 108-98 Knick victory, the rookie was asked about Bernard King's news conference, scheduled for today.

title: DOCTORS LEARNING TO DIAGNOSE ALCOHOLISM
description: The 21-year-old college student was failing her courses and feeling depressed. She dropped out of school and consulted a psychiatrist. ''He said, 'No cause to worry' - I was just suffering from adolescent problems and from the fact that I had been small as a child,'' the woman said the other day. ''I told him that I was drinking and taking drugs - marijuana, LSD - but he didn't want to discuss that at all.''

title: RANCHERS AND INDIANS OPPOSE A PRAIRIE PRESERVE
description: Lee Holcombe, a rancher, was reared in the Osage country, close to the round flint hills and the bluestem grass that grows belly-high to a horse.

title: LED SOUTHERN PACIFIC RAILROAD
description: Donald J. Russell, who as head of the Southern Pacific Company turned the railroad into one of the nation's leading transportation conglomerates, died late Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in San Francisco after a brief illness. He was 85 years old.

title: FLIGHTS OVER FOREST SHOW POLLUTION DAMAGE
description: Scientists flying over the Green Mountains have discovered extensive forest damage that they attribute to air pollution, including acid rain. And they say their techniques can be used to monitor the health of remote forest areas.

title: OF SNEAKERS, HAIRCUTS AND SELECTING COLLEGS
description: Lauren Markoe, a senior at Bronx High School of Science, struck Amherst from her list of colleges because it flunked the sneaker test.

title: Fighting Back
description: Just 18 months after losing his right foot in a motorcycle accident, Craig Bodzianowski, a cruiser-weight boxer, returned to the ring Saturday night and scored a second-round knockout over Francis Sargent before a cheering, sold-out crowd of 2,750 in Palos Heights, Ill.

title: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIA PUT NEW MISSILES CLOSE TO LEBANON
description: Israel announced today that, in the last three weeks, Syria had stationed a variety of surface-to-air missiles along its border with Lebanon. Israel said the deployment seriously threatened regular Israeli reconnaissance missions over Lebanon.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Nov. 28, about lobbying for men's causes, misidentified the group in which Dan Logan serves as executive director. It is Free Men.

title: FORCE OF JETLINER CRASH AT GANDER COMPLICATES INVESTIGATORS' WORK
description: Investigators looking into the cause of the crash of the DC-8 charter jetliner here Thursday morning said today that the catastrophic nature of the accident was making the task both difficult and time-consuming.

title: Advertising;   15-Second TV Spots Examined
description: THE Advertising Research Foundation finished a two-day workshop Friday by devoting the entire day to the exploration of the controversial 15-second TV commercial.

title: 1,600 Drug Punishments Overturned by Military
description: The Army and Air Force have overturned disciplinary actions against more than 1,600 service members because in 1982 and 1983 military laboratories mishandled tests designed to detect drug use.

title: F.D.I.C. Delay on Moves
description: Regulatory officials expect the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to approve a six-month delay today of a rule requiring that the agency disclose disciplinary actions that it takes against banks.

title: PENNZOIL CASE CHILLS ADVISERS
description: The $10.53 billion civil judgment awarded to the Pennzoil Company for the manner in which Texaco Inc. outbid it for the Getty Oil Company last year has sent subtle but perceptible shudders through the high-stakes world of mergers and acquisitions advisers.

title: A GENTLE REBELLION AGAINST THE NECKTIE
description: In a modest and gentle rebellion against this country's sartorial traditions, many Frenchmen have more or less given up that slender sign of conventional formality, the tie.

title: Logophobia
description: To the Editor:

title: D'AMATO DRAWS PRAISE IN FERRARO'S OLD DISTRICT
description: At the invitation of Representative Thomas J. Manton, a Democrat, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, held a town hall meeting yesterday in the Queens district represented until last year by another Democrat, Geraldine A. Ferraro.

title: LONGEST GAME TO U.C.L.A.
description: The stress and strain of 166 minutes 5 seconds of soccer showed on the face of the U.C.L.A. defender Paul Caligiuri, despite the locker-room celebration going on round him Saturday night. Minutes before, the Bruins had won their first National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I soccer championship, defeating American University, 1-0, in the longest soccer game in collegiate history.

title: The Goetz Incident And Mine
description: Nearly a year has passed since Dec. 22, 1984, when Bernard Goetz shot four teen-agers in a subway after one of them, he said, demanded money from him. For a time, Mr. Goetz was lauded as a hero, then denounced as deranged and ultimately indicted.

title: From Legal-Rights Post To Homosexual Rights
description: In the arena of legal-rights advocacy, Thomas B. Stoddard will be able to jump from the frying pan without leaving his office building.

title: SYRIA RECEIVES UNDISCLOSED NUMBER OF NAVAL CRAFT FROM RUSSIANS
description: Syria has taken delivery of an undisclosed number of Soviet-built naval vessels as part of what its state-controlled news organizations called Syria's strategy of establishing military parity with Israel.

title: Velasquez Takes 54th Stakes in '85
description: Jane's Dilemma led all the way for an easy 10 1/2-length victory in the $83,700 Gallant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. It was the 54th stakes victory this year for the jockey Jorge Velasquez, equaling the record held by Chris McCarron for most stakes winners in one year.

title: SCIENCE SHOWMANSHIP: A DEEP 'STAR WARS' RIFT
description: A deep rift has divided the leading scientists at work on President Reagan's antimissile defense plan.

title: INTERNATIONAL STUDY ON SPACE OVER POLES IS SCHEDULED FOR '86
description: A space mission to gather data about the regions over the earth's poles, using as many as eight satellites, will be conducted from next March through June.

title: U.S. RHODES SCHOLARS INCLUDE 32 STUDENTS FROM 21 COLLEGES
description: A champion skier with one leg, the co-captain of the Ohio State University football team and a science student with varsity letters in four sports are among the 32 Americans who have won Rhodes scholarships for study at Oxford University in England.

title: CHARLES W. BACHMAN
description: Charles W. Bachman, one of Michigan State University's most successful football coaches, died Saturday in Port Charlotte, Fla.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you move up missiles to a point which, it is true, is located inside Syria, but whose range of kill-sphere covers Lebanon, that affects our freedom of flight in Lebanon to a significant degree.'' - Lieut. Gen. Moshe Levy, Israel's Chief of Staff. [A1:3.]

title: Soviet Coal Minister Is Replaced By a Deputy
description: Boris F. Bratchenko, the Soviet coal industry minister, has been replaced after 20 years in office, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: TAXI MEDALLION COST PUSHED TO $100,000 BY HEAVY DEMAND
description: A taxi medallion has been sold for $100,000, a record for the price of these taxi licenses, which once cost $10.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Salary Rise For Graduates
description: College graduates in 1986 can expect a starting salary about 4 percent higher, on average, than their counterparts received in 1985, according to a new study by Northwestern University.

title: RAIDERS WIN AND CLINCH DIVISION TITLE
description: In a fierce game between bitter rivals, the Los Angeles Raiders, on the strength of their defense, clinched the American Football Conference Western Division title today with a 13-3 victory over the Seattle Seahawks at the Los Angeles Coliseum.

title: Passing the Legislative Buck on Plant Shutdowns
description: To the Editor:

title: BLUES BEAT DEVILS WITH ONE SECOND LEFT
description: Officials in the National Hockey League do not usually call penalties late in a tight game, but they did tonight and it cost the Devils.

title: Catherine de Hueck Doherty, Charity Worker, Is Dead at 89
description: Catherine de Hueck Doherty, founder of the now-defunct Friendship House in Harlem, which distributed food and clothes to the needy, died of a heart ailment Saturday at the Madonna House in Combermere, Ontario, where she lived. She was 89 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: POLITICS. By Edward I. Koch. With William Rauch. 255 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. IN a ''Last Word'' that he wrote especially for the paperback edition of his best-selling autobiography, ''Mayor,'' Edward I. Koch complained, albeit obliquely, about those critics who reviewed the author himself instead of the book he had written.

title: A 'Benefactors' Benefit Lives Up to Title
description: In 1933, at the urging of Albert Einstein, the International Rescue Committee was founded to help refugees from Hitler's Germany. In 1985, it is aiding refugees from Afghanistan, Ethiopia, Iran, Poland and other countries.

title: Views of Business Economists
description: The National Association of Business Economists is publishing a forecast today that shows little promise for the President's positions on economic issues. The latest survey of 300 of the association's 4,000 members said that 62 percent wanted the tax system revised but believed that the President would not get a law this year, as he once wanted, and only 22 percent expect one next year.

title: Lisa Kurtz Marries
description: At Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday Lisa Shari Kurtz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kurtz of Oceanside, L.I., was married to Dr. Jeffrey Haberman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Haberman of New York.

title: Tasty Incentive
description: It may not cause Bobby Knight to change his own techniques, but some sports research at little Spalding University in Louisville, Ky., has found that when it comes to motivating basketball players, nothing can compare with Froot Loops.

title: Advertising;   Ted Bates Dismisses Chief Creative Officer
description: Michael L. Becker, the 45-year-old chief creative officer of Ted Bates Advertising/New York, has been let go by the company, apparently because during negotiations for a new contract he asked to broaden his company role.

title: Banchetto Musicale
description: The Banchetto Musicale will present Handel's ''Messiah'' tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall.

title: A U.S. AGENCY BATTLES PRECIOUS METAL FRAUDS
description: The phone rings. The smooth voice on the other end addresses you by your first name and asks, ''Are you interested in the best investment in the world?'' The sales pitch has begun. The caller is touting silver or another precious metal that he predicts will soon rise in price, producing a killing for those lucky investors who can establish big positions with a small down payment. The trouble is, however, that they rarely do make a killing - or even hold onto their initial stake.

title: Meritor Financial Names a New Chief
description: The Meritor Financial Group, which will serve as a holding company for seven financial service companies, including PSFS of Philadelphia, the nation's oldest and largest savings bank, announced that Frederick S. Hammer had been named chairman and chief executive officer.

title: MEXICAN OIL-PRICE FLEXIBILITY SEEN
description: Mexico, faced with the prospect of a substantial drop in worldwide oil prices that could severely stress its economy, plans to remain flexible in its own oil pricing and maintain its daily export output, officials say.

title: COAST GROUP PICKS GILLIAM'S 'BRAZIL' AS BEST FILM
description: ''Brazil,'' a movie that Universal Pictures has called overlong and unsatisfying and has up to now refused to release, was chosen best movie of the year Saturday by the Los Angeles Film Critics Association.

title: BAKER'S DEBT PLAN GETS LATIN SCRUTINY
description: Latin America's leading debtor nations are expected to renew their campaign for lower interest payments when they meet Monday in Montevideo, Uruguay, to analyze the Baker Plan.

title: THIS SEASON'S COMPUTER WAR
description: To demonstrate the stunning capability of its new Amiga computer, Commodore often displays on its screen a surprisingly realistic picture of a colorful bouncing ball. So it was a deliberate challenge when, at a recent trade show, rival Atari placed its new 520 ST computer beside the Amiga - and displayed on its screen a virtually identical bouncing ball.

title: OUTDOORS: HUNTING HAND WARMERS AND WATERFOWL
description: ALTHOUGH grizzled gunners are prone to ramble on about the many perfectly executed waterfowl hunts they have experienced, failing memory or a desire to imbue the past with a magic it only half possessed is leading them astray.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline yesterday on an article about the Federal racketeering trial of Carmine Persico and nine other reputed leaders of the Colombo crime group misidentified the agency whose operatives testified in the trial's first phase. They were from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Columbia Back in Service
description: The space shuttle Columbia, the flagship of the fleet, is scheduled for its first flight in more than two years this week, carrying a seven-man crew that includes a Congressman from Florida and the first Hispanic American astronaut. The launching of America's first reusable spacecraft, which has undergone an 18-month overhaul, is scheduled for 7 o'clock Wednesday morning.

title: V.S. PRITCHETT, IN STEP WITH THE YEARS, WRITES ON
description: ''I shall never be as old as I was between 20 and 30,'' V. S. Pritchett wrote when, having reached the reasonably ripe age of 70, he was starting to accustom himself to the notion that old age might be upon him.

title: YESHIVA GIVES DEGREES TO BUSH AND SIX OTHERS
description: Vice President Bush, Israel's Ambassador to the United States and five business and community leaders yesterday received honorary degrees from Yeshiva University, the oldest and largest university under Jewish auspices in the United States.

title: BIBLE STUDY FIGHT IN CAROLINA TOWN
description: The family of a woman who challenged the legality of Bible study in the Dunn public schools has left town after what family members describe as weeks of harassing telephone calls and attacks published in the local newspaper.

title: Buy One, Create 23 More
description: It's hard for the current generation of bureaucrats to believe that Washington functioned at all in the primitive days before the photocopier. But along with its effortless multiplication of paper, the photocopier has brought substantial legal problems to a city where communication not infrequently becomes a substitute for action.

title: Fresh Clues Sought on Rates
description: Signs that the Federal Reserve has adopted a slightly more generous monetary policy helped reduce short- and long-term interest rates last week by a quarter percentage point or more.

title: IN ONE MARKET, CLINIQUE OUTDOES JAPANESE GIANT
description: In the chic Seibu department store in the Shibuya neighborhood of Tokyo, Clinique, the American cosmetics company, boasts two counters in the front of the store. Slightly to the rear of Clinique is the one counter allotted to Shiseido.

title: EUROPEANS SHUNNING SPOTLIGHT
description: Once again, Western Europe is being urged to serve as the locomotive of the world's economy, but its governments are balking, seared by the problems that followed the last time Europe accepted the global leadership role.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline in the Business People column on Wednesday about changes at Cincinnati Milacron Inc. incorrectly stated that a new president had been named. Donald G. Shively, who is executive vice president, will assume the responsibilities of the president, Clifford R. Meyer, when he retires, but not the title.

title: At the Latin Debt Hospital
description: The high occupancy rate in the Latin American debt hospital continues. Argentina has left the emergency room, but another debtor, Mexico, is showing symptoms that it may have to return unless it gets a massive injection of funds to pay interest. These two countries plus Brazil account for two-thirds of the nearly $400 million Latin American external debt, of which about $280 million are owed to international commercial banks, 40 per cent of them in the United States.

title: LEMIEUX LEADS PENGUINS PAST RANGERS
description: He commanded the Rangers' attention, and logically so. With a deft sweep of his stick and with a delicate pass under the most extreme pressure, Mario Lemieux altered the tempo of the game last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: CONCERT: 8 COMPOSERS IN NEW-MUSIC PROGRAM
description: PHOENIX, a new new-music group, made its formal debut at Christ and St. Stephen's Church (120 West 69th Street) Thursday night. There were eight composers, most of them young and less known, but also on the program was ''Failing'' by Tom Johnson - a relative patriarch of the avant-garde movement - and some piano music by Otto Luening, at 85 years of age a true one. Mr. Luening gave a little talk after intermission, urging listeners to support not only the emerging composer but the submerging one as well. This audience was kept busy doing both.

title: Miss de Marinis Bride Of Richard Brockhume
description: Lisa Gerette de Marinis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. M. Joseph de Marinis of Bronxville, N.Y., and Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Brockhume, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Brockhume of London. The Rev. Jack H. Haney performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Trianon Room at the Carlyle Hotel in New York.

title: SHULTZ, IN RUMANIA, WARNS CHIEF ON TREATMENT OF CHRISTIAN SECTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met here with President Nicolae Ceausescu today and told him that Rumania's treatment of some of its Christian sects could cause it to lose its preferential trade status in the United States, a senior American official said.

title: Mitterrand Defends His Economic Record
description: President Francois Mitterrand declared tonight that France under his Socialist Party was winning the battle for modernization and against inflation.

title: Punjab Leader Elected President of Sikh Party
description: Chief Minister Surjit Singh Barnala of Punjab State, a moderate, was unanimously elected today as president of the Akali Dal, the main Sikh political party.

title: THOUGHTS ABOUT MARIS
description: In retrospect, the American League executive vice president Bob Fishel believes he could have done a better job for Roger Maris during their days with the Yankees.

title: CITICORP, TO DECENTRALIZE, PLANS QUEENS COMPLEX
description: The largest office building complex ever built in the boroughs outside of Manhattan has been proposed by Citicorp for its own use at a largely vacant site in Queens, just a subway stop from the bank's main operations in midtown Manhattan.

title: Pieces Fall From Plane Onto House Near Boston
description: A jetliner from London with 254 passengers and a crew of 17 aboard lost two wing-flap sections as it approached Logan International Airport today.

title: BATTERED PASS, FAILED PUNT LEAD TO GIANT LOSS
description: The Dallas Cowboys had their chances today and made the most of them. They scored two touchdowns within 46 seconds after a freakish interception and an aborted Giant punt. The Giants had their chances and did not make the most of them.

title: STAGE: 'MRS. WARREN,' AT THE ROUNDABOUT
description: ''YOU are stronger than all England,'' says an awed Vivie Warren to her mother, a former prostitute turned high-class madam, in ''Mrs. Warren's Profession.'' After watching Uta Hagen play the title character of this early (1894) and once-notorious Shaw play, one may wonder why Vivie didn't throw in Europe, North America and Asia as well. Handsome and caustic - her whisky-and-cigarettes voice usually on the verge of a contemptuous snicker or an unimpeachable command - Miss Hagen blasts through her role with such intense concentration that her fellow actors might well be tempted to run for cover. Some of them, in fact, might be better off if they did.

title: JEWISH GROUP SUPPORTS CLAIMS AGAINST FLICK
description: A Jewish organization is supporting a demand that Deutsche Bank A.G., which is in the process of buying the giant Flick concern, be required to indemnify former Jewish wartime slave laborers forced to work in Flick's factories.

title: DANCE: MIN TANAKA PERFORMS A 2-PART SOLO
description: THERE was never any question about Min Tanaka's skill in ''Form of the Sky,'' the two-part solo he offered Wednesday night at La Mama Annex, 74A East Fourth Street. The Japanese dancer was always in full control, even when portraying people who were out of control, and his gestures were meticulously timed.

title: CARBIDE REJECTS BID FROM GAF
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, calling a $68-a-share bid by the GAF Corporation ''grossly inadequate and unfair,'' said last night that its board had rejected that offer and had authorized a program to repurchase 35 percent of its stock for a package of cash and notes that it valued at $85 a share.

title: ANGOLA EXTOLS CUBAN AND SOVIET TIES
description: If the statements heard at a party congress here last week are any indication, then Angola is not about to lessen its ties to the Soviet Union or ease out some 30,000 Cuban troops helping to fight a 10-year-old bush war against anti-Communist guerrillas.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: USING STRUGGLE AS CASH, TENANTS BUY A BUILDING
description: The residents of 90-102 Hamilton Place in upper Manhattan celebrated the holidays early this year: they gave themselves homes for Christmas and a housewarming party Saturday night.

title: Lobbying Cost Of Tax Battle
description: WIN or lose, compromise or delay, the struggle over the tax system has proven one of history's biggest moments in lobbying, publishing and analysis.

title: MUSIC: MONKS' CHANTS
description: EIGHT Tantric Buddhist monks from the Gyume monastery - founded in Tibet in 1433 and relocated to India in 1959, following the Chinese invasion of Tibet - performed Wednesday and Thursday at the Samaya Foundation, 75 Leonard Street in TriBeCa.

title: Whither Dust Jackets
description: Speaking of the Library of Congress, have you ever wondered what the Library of Congress does with the dust jackets of all those books it acquires? Well, it used to collect them, but officials recently transferred 167,000 dust jackets to the Rochester Institute of Technology in New York State, which will use them as ''a resource for students as well as scholars of typography, book design, the history of the book and popular culture,'' according to the library.

title: SLEEPLESS NIGHTS FOR HOMELESS IN WELFARE OFFICES
description: Maryanne Jiminez did not want to stay in a shelter for the homeless Friday night. She could have but she did not. Instead, she spent the night in a corner of a welfare office in the Bronx, and by choice.

title: BANGLADESH TO LIFT BAN ON RALLIES
description: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad told the nation today that his martial-law Government would lift a 10-month ban on opposition political demonstrations Jan. 1.

title: POLISH POLICE BLOCK A MEMORIAL SERVICE
description: Hundreds of policemen today blocked several thousand people, including Lech Walesa, from holding a memorial service for workers killed in rioting along the Baltic Coast in 1970.

title: LAND MINE KILLS 6 IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The South African Army reported tonight that six people were killed and five people seriously wounded when a light truck set off a land mine close to the border with Zimbabwe.

title: Better With Age
description: When A. J. Foyt turned 50 earlier this year, there were suggestions that he might be getting too old to drive a racing car. Clearly, the critics had never heard of a Southerner named Harvey Templeton.

title: Ban Boxing III
description: As recently as March 1984, New Jersey's State Commission of Investigation was promoting reforms it hoped could civilize professional boxing. Now the commission has reached the grim conclusion that reform won't do. ''Not even the sturdiest of statutory controls will reduce the brutality of the sport to any significant degree,'' it says. That and the involvement of organized crime lead to an inescapable conclusion: Boxing ought to be outlawed in New Jersey. It is up to Governor Kean and the Legislature to follow through.

title: FAVORITE TOYS: WHY SO SPECIAL?
description: TO the person who has a soft, furry toy owl, Morgan's parents are frantic to find you. If anyone has a very small, very cuddly toy cat, Jenna's mom and dad would love to know where you bought it. The same goes for the owners of teddy bears, striped giraffes and woolen baby blankets with ribbon trim. Parents often panic as the objects to which their youngsters cling wear out.

title: Centre Street Role for Papp
description: Unbeknown to the theatrical world in which he usually plays so public a role, Joseph Papp staged a special production of ''King Lear'' last Friday.

title: I.M.F. SAYS BANKS BACK BAKER PLAN
description: Commercial banks holding 90 percent of loans to developing countries have thrown their support behind an American proposal that they increase their lending to the third world by $20 billion over three years as their contribution to easing the debt crisis.

title: AQUINO SAYS IF SHE IS ELECTED MARCOS FACES A MURDER TRIAL
description: The opposition candidate for president, Corazon C. Aquino, said today that if she is elected next Feb. 7 she will probably put President Ferdinand E. Marcos on trial for the murder of her husband.

title: The Wrong Beat for American Cops
description: The Reagan Administration's Central American counterterrorism bill repackages a dubious idea derived from a flawed premise. It would earmark $54 million for hardware and training for police in El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Panama and Costa Rica. The hope is to turn bad cops into good cops under the tutelage of Uncle Sam.

title: U.S. TESTS CITIZENS NEAR BOMB PLANT
description: For the first time in the 42-year history of the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, where plutonium has been manufactured for nuclear bombs since the days of the Manhattan Project, the Federal Government is offering radiation tests that may eventually be given to 1,500 people living within 10 miles of the reservation's eastern boundary.

title: Tass Criticizes Shultz For Berlin Statements
description: The Soviet press agency Tass accused Secretary of State George P. Shultz today of using anti-Soviet rhetoric and contradicting the agreements of the summit meeting last month.

title: BUSY TIME AT LINE FOR FRAUD REPORTS
description: If the six-year program called Defense Hot Line is any measure, the nation's taxpayers have become ever more aroused by ''horror stories'' of waste, fraud and abuse in Pentagon spending. In the most recent six-month period, the program received 5,000 phone calls and letters of complaint, a jump of 30 percent over the previous period.

title: INVESTIGATIONS BEGIN OVER COLORADO SKI ACCIDENT
description: Engineers and inspectors went to a ski resort in the central Rocky Mountains today, looking for why a chairlift inspected only weeks before had failed, catapulting skiers to the ground and injuring dozens.

title: Advertising;   D.D.B. Unit Gets President
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group announced Friday that Peter Falcone, 49, had been promoted to president of D.D.B./New York, of which he was formerly vice chairman and director of corporate development. The president's title comes from Barry E. Loughrane, who continues as president and chief executive of the Group, which is what counts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1985
description: International Israel said Syria has stationed a variety of surface-to-air missiles along its border with Lebanon, seriously threatening the regular Israeli reconnaissance missions over Lebanese territory. Israeli military sources said Syria's move was a ''dangerous change in the status quo.'' [Page A1, Column 3.]

title: Moores for Washington
description: George Ablah, the art collector from Wichita, Kan., who lent 25 Henry Moore sculptures to New York City last year, has sent three large Moores to the National Gallery of Art in Washington on a longterm loan. This was arranged in conjunction with the museum's exhibition ''The Treasure Houses of Britain.'' The sculptures, in bronze, have been installed in a garden adjoining the East Building.

title: TOWN GATHERS IN MOURNING SOLDIERS LOST IN PLANE CRASH
description: With the chorus of ''The Battle Hymn of the Republic'' rising to church rafters, the 248 soldiers killed in an airplane crash in Newfoundland were honored here today at a memorial service attended by some families of the victims.

title: 8,000 TURN OUT FOR DISTRIBUTION OF SURPLUS FOOD
description: The lines outside the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center yesterday stretched around the block, as people waited in the windy cold as long as two hours for white plastic bags of free food.

title: RETAILERS AWAIT SHOPPING TREND
description: The 1985 Christmas shopping season, now slightly past its mid-point, does not yet show a clear pattern, a survey finds. Retailers in six major cities report results ranging widely from ''sluggish'' to gains of about 10 percent over last year.

title: Advertising;   A New Book Review Based in Washington
description: Next month will mark the debut of the Washington Book Review, a monthly, whose editor is Alexander Burnham, former managing editor of Dodd, Mead & Company, book publishers.

title: PLAYOFF POSSIBILITIES CLEARER
description: There is far less chaos about the approaching National Football League playoffs today than a week ago, but making sense of the situation still requires a mind for mathematics and a healthy dose of patience. The possibilities continue to run rampant.

title: USING SATELLITES TO REACH VOTERS IN THE OUT THERE
description: The ranks of believers are growing. They speak of the technology with shining eyes and expansive tones, like those who have seen the future and decided it not only works, it's also affordable.

title: China Agrees to Buy French and British Gear
description: China has agreed in principle to buy French reactors and British turbines worth more than $1.5 billion for its first nuclear power plant, officials said today.

title: Florida Rights Official Rules for AIDS Victim
description: The state's top human rights officer has ruled that AIDS is a handicap, and that discriminating against its victims violates the state disability law, an AIDS victim's attorney says.

title: Catching Up
description: Denny McLain, the last major-league pitcher to win 30 games in a season, has not been much heard from since April, when he was sentenced to 23 years' imprisonment for racketeering, extortion, conspiracy and drug trafficking. What's new? Well, nothing special, according to officials at the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta.

title: State Governments Need Mail-Sale Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Executives Promoted In A. O. Smith Changes
description: Robert J. O'Toole, senior vice president of the A. O. Smith Corporation, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Milwaukee-based diversified maker of auto and industrial products.

title: FARM BILL: ITS IMPACT
description: Eleven months ago, when the Reagan Administration introduced a farm bill that proposed to trim farmers' incomes, reduce Government expenditures and produce a long-term policy that would tie agricultural production to a free market, House and Senate leaders condemned the idea as ''dead on arrival.''

title: KOCH QUESTIONS A PLAN FOR M.A.C. TRANSIT AID
description: Mayor Koch yesterday questioned a proposal by Governor Cuomo to use $1 billion in Municipal Assistance Corporation funds to help avert a crisis in mass transit.

title: Refinery Blast Toll Reaches 5
description: Two more have workers died of burns they suffered in an explosion and fire at the Arco Refinery in Carson Dec. 5, bringing the death toll from the accident to five, the authorities said Saturday. Eugene Martinez, 37 years old, died Friday and Carl New, 47, died Saturday at Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center, a spokesman said. The explosion remains under investigation.

title: CONCERT: CLEVELANDERS
description: WITH each succeeding visit to New York, the Cleveland Orchestra underlines the absolute rightness of its affiliation with Christoph von Dohnanyi. Mr. Dohnanyi became the orchestra's music director last season, and it is pleasing indeed to hear this collective instrument -so finely tuned by George Szell and so well-maintained by Lorin Maazel -now directed toward the seriousness of musical purpose its new conductor offers.

title: 'LETTER TO THREE WIVES'
description: MORE than 35 years ago, back in the late 1940's, Joseph L. Mankiewicz, gearing up for the 1950 major film classic ''All About Eve,'' wrote and directed a minor classic called ''A Letter to Three Wives.'' That has now been updated for a television movie, which can be seen on NBC at 9 this evening. The tampering has been considerably less than inspired.

title: THE DANCE: ALVIN AILEY
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater packs a distinctive wallop. The performers surge through funny and sad depictions of life with a warmth and commitment that are uniquely their own. The fact that they can dance, too, was made clearer than ever on Friday in a performance of Billy Wilson's ''Concerto in F'' at City Center, where the company is installed through Dec. 29.

title: The Fed's Fear of Takeovers
description: When corporations threatened by takeovers call for restraints on mergers, their motives are suspect. When the Federal Reserve, guardian of the nation's financial system, sounds the alarm, it's time to take a hard look.

title: 1-ROOM FURN. HSE., EXCEL. LOC.
description: Pastry chefs at the American Festival Cafe, which adjoins the skating rink at Rockefeller Center, have erected a handsome, playhouse-size gingerbread house. It's 6 feet by 6 feet, nearly 8 feet tall and has windows on 3 sides.

title: REAGAN TO PRESS G.O.P. ON TAX BILL IN PARLEY TODAY
description: Congressional leaders today looked to a trip by President Reagan to Capitol Hill on Monday as the last chance to salvage his tax overhaul program.

title: Fiasco in the House
description: Ronald Reagan is one of the most popular Presidents in history.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST TRY TO BRIGHTEN CHILDREN'S LIVES
description: Bringing some measure of joy and happiness to children who are ill, homeless or without a family to share the holiday season is the hope of many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: REDSKINS SURVIVE WITH 27-24 VICTORY
description: The Washington Redskins survived five fumbles and three disallowed touchdowns today to defeat the Cincinnati Bengals, 27-24, and keep alive their slim chances of qualifying for the National Football League playoffs.

title: FURTHER DROP SEEN IN MORTGAGE RATES
description: Interest rate levels on home mortgages, which have declined in recent weeks, are expected to drop further - perhaps as much as one percentage point - in the new year, bankers and economists say.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Dolphins vs. New England Patriots, at Miami. The Patriots, who have not won in the Orange Bowl since 1966, can capture the American Conference East title with a victory.

title: The Sore Winners
description: Few intellectual movements in this country have won so much political influence so fast. The neoconservatives, the sect of one-time liberals who turned right, see their ideas on the march in American foreign and military policy. Their views proliferate in the journals. The President of the United States says they inspire him.

title: Gen. Istvan Olah Dies at 59; Hungary's Defense Minister
description: Hungary's new Defense Minister, Gen. Istvan Olah, died today, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported from Budapest. He was 59 years old.

title: BROWNS TAKE LEAD IN A.F.C. CENTRAL
description: Bernie Kosar passed for three touchdowns and ran for another today as the Cleveland Browns beat the Houston Oilers, 28-21, to take a one-game lead in the Central Division of the American Conference over Cincinnati and Pittsburgh.

title: Magazines in Braille
description: Now that a group of blind readers and their organizations have gone to court to kill the 1985 Congressional killing of money to print Playboy in Braille, you might like to learn what other suspect magazines the Library of Congress is still circulating in Braille editions.

title: Texas Coaches Fight New Rule on Grades
description: High school coaches in Texas, angered by the state rule that keeps students who have failed courses out of extracurricular activities, have formed a political action committee and they say that Gov. Mark White is not likely to win their endorsement.

title: Stenmark Victory First in 21 Months
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden skied to a record 80th World Cup victory today in a giant slalom.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 16, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: UPDIKE AND WOODY ALLEN END SERIES
description: Norman Mailer recited three of his poems last night, Woody Allen parodied Kafka as well as an assortment of mystery writers from Raymond Chandler to Mickey Spillane, and John Updike waxed poetic about New York, in which he last lived in 1957.

title: ITALY LIKES WORLD CUP DRAW
description: Italy, the defending champion, will meet Bulgaria in the opening game of the 1986 World Cup tournament here next May 31, officials determined today in a public drawing.

title: Poland Debt Payment
description: Poland has repaid its commercial bankers about $250 million, the first repayment of principal under a rescheduling of debt due in 1981, banking sources said Friday.

title: Market Place;   Oil Service Stocks Lag
description: THE stock market threw a grand party last week, as the Dow Jones industrial average soared 58.03 points to a record closing at 1,535.21. But the oil service and drilling contingent was notably absent from the guest list.

title: WALTON PROUD OF PROGRESS THIS SEASON
description: There has been an undercurrent of seething pride to Joe Walton all season, a season in which his Jets have been grudgingly accepted as a playoff contender. And today, after the 19-6 loss to the Bears and before the regular-season finale, Walton decided it was time to give his version of how far the club has come.

title: Article 227732 -- No Title
description: The Treasury has scheduled auctions this week of notes due in two and four-years, as well as bills due in three, six, and 12 months. The financings total $40.7 billion, but after paying for maturing securities, will raise only about $6.1 billion of new cash to finance the Federal budget deficit.

title: POLITICIANS' WISH LIST
description: Asked about their Christmas wish lists, a sampling of the nation's leaders came forth with a mixture of diplomatic, economic and legislative goals, along with a few personal things. Here are their Christmas wishes:

title: 3 Fires in Midwest Kill 9 Children and 6 Adults
description: Fires killed 15 people in three Middle West cities yesterday, including a suburban Chicago blaze that claimed the lives of six children, one at a nursing home near Detroit that left six dead and 27 injured, and one in Dayton, Ohio, in which three young boys died, the authorities said.

title: IN TERROR RAID'S AFTERMATH, COLOMBIA ELITE RALLIES TO CHIEF
description: At the height of the worst crisis of his Government last month, President Belisario Betancur finally decided to play the most powerful political card at his disposal.

title: Advertising;   N.A.D. Calls a Foul On Air Jordan Shoe Ad
description: The TV commercial proclaimed that Nike had developed a revolutionary new basketball shoe and that ''on Oct. 18 the N.B.A. threw them out of the game.''

title: Advertising;   Women's Day Rates
