description: A Federal jury today found George A. Sawyer, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy, not guilty of unlawfully concealing job-hunting contacts with a big military supplier while he was overseeing the buildup of the fleet.

title: CHINA'S CATHOLICS RESTORE A CHURCH IN PEKING
description: The independent Chinese Catholic Church has restored a large 19th-century church in Peking, in time for use before Christmas, an Italian religious news agency said today.

title: IN PERIGORD, A FUROR OVER FOIE GRAS
description: THE valleys of the Perigord, a region in central France long synonymous with culinary splendor, are usually a portrait in tranquillity, the rolling hills dotted by vineyards and some 1,800 chateaus.

description: The Rumanian Defense Minister, Col. Gen. Constantin Olteanu, has been relieved of his duties, the official Rumanian press agency said today.

The company said the offer to Alexander Syndicate Management, the independent managing agent of syndicates 126 and 127, was to settle claims following the discovery of wrongdoing by former executives of the Howden Group, acquired by Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. of the United States in 1982.

description: On an island so electronically innocent that it has but one television station and less than 20 hours of programming per week, I am assembling my own word-processing system.

The notes were priced to yield 16 basis points above the six-month Treasury bill, 12 basis points above a one-year Treasury note, and 16 basis points over a five-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

description: A top Pennzoil Company official said yesterday that the company had not yet held any serious settlement negotiations with Texaco Inc., more than a week after a Texas judge entered a $10.53 billion award against Texaco.

title: Beaux-Arts Benefit
description: Ten-month-old Grace Wilentz was supposed to be a killer bee. But crawling about the ballroom in her bright jumpsuit and pink wings, she looked more like a sugarplum fairy.

title: COMPUTER DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
GANGLAND KILLING LURES GAWKERS TO 46TH ST.
description: ''Is this the spot?'' Janet D'Amico asked as she joined the crowd.

title: San Diego Vote to Be Feb. 25
description: City Council members voted unanimously Monday to set a special mayoral election for Feb. 25, with a runoff election to coincide with the statewide primary on June 3 if a candidate fails to carry 50 percent of the vote. The election is being held to replace Roger Hedgecock, who was convicted of conspiracy and perjury and resigned last week before being sentenced.

title: GAMBINO 'CAPTAIN' SEEN IN CENTRAL ROLE IN STRIFE
description: John Gotti, a fastidious, well-groomed 45-year-old resident of Queens, is believed by law-enforcement officials to be a central figure in an internal fight for leadership of the Gambino crime family.

title: GUATEMALAN WARY ON U.S. ARMS HELP
description: The President-elect of Guatemala said today that he wanted strong United States backing for democratic development in his country but had no immediate desire for military aid.

title: F.T.C. SET TO REJECT SPA REFUND RULES
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission recommended today that the agency drop a proposal to protect consumers in contracts with health spas. The commission generally follows the recommendations of its staff in such matters, and it is expected to adopt the recommendation when it meets Wednesday.

title: A FRENCH CHEF'S COUP IN PALM BEACH
description: Today, just 30 hours before a benefit at his new Palm Beach restaurant, Le Relais a Mougins at the Palm Court hotel, Andre Surmain watched as workers stood on the newly installed Vulcan gas ranges in his kitchen and lustily walloped the overhead stainless-steel exhaust hood with hammers.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 18, 1985
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meeting requested by the United States for discussion of hostage-taking - 11:30 A.M.

title: LATIN AMERICA DEBTORS URGE LOAN RATE CUT
description: Latin America's leading debtor nations today proposed a set of ''emergency measures,'' including new loans and the reduction of interest rates, to permit a resumption of economic growth in the region.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: A PAINTER whose first one-man show in New York runs through Saturday at the Mary Boone Gallery, 417 West Broadway, may be better known to music-lovers than to the art world. The prestigious gallery, which has represented David Salle and Julian Schnabel, has a show of eight large, boldly colored canvases by Don Van Vliet, the composer, saxophonist and harmonica player who has been making records since the 1960's as Captain Beefheart. The style of such paintings as ''Eye Whine'' and ''Gum at the Bottom of the Grocery'' will be familiar to owners of the albums ''Shiny Beast (Bat Chain Puller),'' ''Ice Cream for Crow'' or ''Doc at the Radar Station,'' which have Van Vliet covers.

title: TREASURY CONSIDERING PLAN TO AID THRIFT INDUSTRY
description: The Treasury is developing a rescue plan for the ailing thrift industry that would include inviting large non-banking organizations, such as Sears, Roebuck & Company, to buy scores of insolvent savings and loan associations and then convert them into commercial banks, a senior Treasury official said today.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in September.

title: Surfeit of Reindeer Song
description: The morning announcer at radio station WLLR was placed on an indefinite suspension with pay today after playing the song ''Grandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer'' 27 times in less than three and a half hours. The station manager, Larry Rosmilso, said the announcer, Jack Daniels, had continued to play the song in defiance of orders.

title: Progress on New York City School Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Guilty and 2 Acquitted In Killing in the Capital
description: Six of 10 defendants in the trial for the murder of a mother of six face up to life in prison after being convicted of savagely beating her in an alley while a crowd watched.

title: NETS SPUTTER IN SECOND HALF AND LOSE
description: In the relative quiet of the lockerroom, Darryl Dawkins and Micheal Ray Richardson pondered their missed free throws. They had been crucial to the outcome, both players finally agreed, but they were merely footnotes in the postgame thoughts of Dave Wohl, the Nets' first-year coach.

title: Time Out For Christmas
description: In the last weeks of the Old Year, Congress and the President have been fussing with one another -not much peace or even good will. And there has been a lot of casual talk around here that Ronald Reagan may now be a lame duck or standby President.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 11:01 A.M. today and set at 11:20 P.M. tomorrow.

title: STABBINGS REPORTED
description: Scores of inmates took control of two wings of the Oklahoma State Penitentiary tonight, breaking windows, stabbing three guards and seizing seven others as hostages, the authorities said.

title: ASSAM STATE ELECTION IS CLOSE
description: Elections in the state of Assam headed toward a close finish today, with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party hoping to retain power through a coalition.

title: Mass for Maris At St. Patrick's
description: The Yankees announced yesterday that John Cardinal O'Connor would offer a special memorial mass for Roger Maris at St. Patrick's Cathedral next Monday at 1 P.M. Maris, who hit 61 home runs in 1961 for the Yankees, died of cancer at age 51 last Saturday.

title: AFTER 30 YEARS, GUATEMALA TESTS DEMOCRACY
description: Just five years ago, Francisco Villagran Kramer resigned his post as Vice President of Guatemala and fled the country.

title: U.S. and Britain Assailed Over Curbs on Press
description: The International Press Institute accused United States and British leaders today of ''double standards'' in calling for curbs on press coverage, particularly of terrorist attacks.

title: NORTH CAROLINE (8-0) TRIUMPHS OVER JACKSONVILLE BY 69-65
description: Jeff Lebo's 15-foot jumper gave North Carolina the lead with 1 minute 57 seconds remaining, and Kenny Smith added a pair of free throws with 11 seconds to go as the top-ranked Tar Heels held off Jacksonville, 69-65, tonight.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch in some copies yesterday about changes in flight arrival and departure time slots listed the four affected airports incorrectly. National Airport in Washington is one of them; Newark International Airport is not.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Net income

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I ADMIT that I love preparing and eating pork chops, largely because I am addicted to the basic flavor of the meat and because there are so many ways to cook them.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Nice Numbers
description: A couple of weeks ago Iowa became the 35th team in college basketball history to have won 1,000 games, and Monday night, with a victory over Florida State, Alabama became No. 36.

title: Hunter Sentenced
description: Dave Hunter, a forward with the Edmonton Oilers, has been sentenced to four months in jail for his third impaired driving conviction.

title: Military's Holiday Fare
description: There may be no place like home for the holidays, but the Defense Department says members of the armed services who cannot make it home this year can once again look forward to a traditional Christmas dinner, courtesy of Uncle Sam.

title: MOVE ON HOSTAGES DUE TODAY AT U.N.
description: The Security Council is expected to adopt a landmark resolution Wednesday that ''condemns unequivocally all acts of hostage-taking and abduction'' and calls for the ''immediate, safe release of all hostages and abducted persons.''

title: CHEF'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-After a charge of $51,585 for the quarter and 9 months related to the sale of a restaurant.

title: BOND PRICES STRONG AGAIN
description: Bond prices shot up again yesterday amid widespread expectations that the recent erosion of interest rates would continue well into 1986. Indeed, as investors rushed to lock in current yields, long-term bond prices climbed almost a point, with the Government bonds with the longest maturities trading at their highest levels since early 1980.

title: SKIING RHODES SCHOLAR TELLS OF UPHILL BATTLE
description: At one time in Bonnie Saint John's life of 21 years she was, in her own words, ''a fragile, handicapped girl sitting by a window'' losing herself in books to escape the taunts of children who called her Wooden Leg.

title: DRAFT OF REAGAN BUDGET FOR 1987 SEES END TO I.C.C. AFTER 100 YEARS
description: President Reagan's draft budget for the fiscal year 1987 would reduce the staff of the Social Security Administration, abolish the Interstate Commerce Commission and end Federal support for the agricultural Extension Service.

title: News Corp. Earnings Up
description: The News Corporation, the international media organization controlled by Rupert Murdoch, says its third-quarter profit more than doubled.

title: RADIX VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income. Revenue figures represent gross billings.

title: CHRISTMAS CRIME: DETERRING A GRINCH THAT STOLE A TREE
description: THERE are certain items that you would never think to protect. Garbage cans, although of practical value to everyone, have a minimal theft rate. (When it comes to garbage, apparently, everyone wants his or her personal can.) The same with pets. Leave the beagle chained to the parking meter in front of the Grand Union all day long and he would probably still be there, moaning, at the end of the day.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income

title: Economic Scene;   A Rush to Own TV Properties
description: WHEN the American Broadcasting Companies agreed last March to be acquired by Capital Cities Communications, it was the first time that one of the nation's three major television networks changed hands since Leonard H. Goldenson's United Paramount Theaters merged with a fledgling network to create the modern ABC in 1953. Yet 1985 was not out before the RCA Corporation, parent of NBC, agreed to be acquired by the General Electric Company. And CBS Inc., owner of the the third network, has been afflicted all year by Ted Turner's unwelcome takeover bid or the fiscal wounds it left. Meanwhile, in the side ring, several of the nation's biggest television stations and station groups were being bought and sold like the hot commodities they have become.

title: Boesky-Lorimar
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, said he had bought 5.7 percent of Lorimar Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Boesky said that he had bought the shares ''in connection with merger arbitrage and other investment activities.'' Between Oct. 7 and Dec. 12, Mr. Boesky bought 438,200 Lorimar shares on the open market for prices ranging from $33.125 to $44.50 a share. Lorimar is a television program production company, based in Culver City, Calif.

title: JEM RECORDS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: DR. MARIA ROSLER GITTER
description: Dr. Maria Rosler Gitter, a psychotherapist who was an early protegee of Dr. Alfred Adler, the founder of the school of individual psychology, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85 years old.

title: FOR PARENTS OF PREGNANT CHILDREN, NEW LIABILITY
description: The state that pioneered the open primary, income taxes and unemployment compensation has now devised a novel approach for addressing teen-age pregnancy. A wide-ranging law adopted unanimously by the State Legislature last month provides for sex education in public schools, grants for programs to counsel teen-agers, abortions without the necessity of parental consent and the establishment of a state adoption center.

title: DEVILS ROUT FLYERS BY 7-4
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have been the dominant team in past encounters with the Devils, but tonight's meeting belonged to New Jersey from the opening shot.

title: TOUR OF ART FROM SOVIET TO INCLUDE MET MUSEUM
description: An exchange of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art between American and Soviet museums scheduled for next year has been expanded to include an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, it was announced today.

title: ARROW AIR WON BID AFTER U.S. SOUGHT COMPETITION
description: A spokesman for the Sinai Peacekeeping Force said today that the decision to suspend a contract with Arrow Air was made after the airline said it would be unable to fulfill its contract to rotate American soldiers from the United States for members of the force on duty in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: CONCRETE CONTRACTORS TELL OF PAYOFFS TO A UNION LEADER FOR LABOR PEACE
description: Two concrete contractors testified yesterday that they had been forced to pay thousands of dollars in return for labor peace to Ralph Scopo, who retired last April after seven years as president of the Cement & Concrete Workers District Council of the Laborers International Union.

title: PENTAGON DENIES IT'S RESPONSIBLE FOR SAFETY OF PLANE THAT CRASHED
description: A senior Air Force general said today that the Department of Defense was ''not technically responsible'' for the chartering, safety or operation of the Arrow Air plane in which 248 American soldiers died in a crash last week.

title: REFUND ORDERED
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the city's Rent Guidelines Board illegally allowed landlords to charge tenants of rent-stabilized apartments millions of dollars in fees.

title: Give Matching Funds For Antismoking Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Wall Street bonuses incorrectly described a change in salary policy several years ago at Merrill Lynch. Although salaried employees no longer receive year-end bonuses, their annual raises are larger than before.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a gain equal to 6 cents a share from the sale of land. Year-ago 6 months results reflect a charge resulting from a work stoppage.

title: ISLANDERS' SCORERS FIND THE NET AGAIN
description: The Islanders, who have recently been plagued by erratic play and an absent-minded defense, were a rejuvenated team tonight as they beat the Buffalo Sabres, 7-3, at Nassau Coliseum. Their penalty-killing unit, which had allowed recent opponents carte blanche, gave a flawless performance, shutting Buffalo down on all five chances.

title: U.S. ASKS MALTA FOR SUSPECT
description: The State Department said today that it had asked Malta to extradite a man believed to be the only surviving hijacker of an Egyptair plane that was forced down in Malta last month.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
California Panel Grants Sirhan a Parole Hearing
description: The state reversed itself today and granted a new parole hearing to Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, who assassinated Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York in 1968.

title: Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had revised its retirement security program, effective Jan. 1, for nonunion salaried employees, and it expects to save at least $30 million annually. Bethlehem said the program will freeze pension benefit amounts of current salaried employees as of Dec. 31 and initiate a new defined contribution plan.

title: 'The Color Purple'
description: SWEETNESS and stridency exist side by side in Alice Walker's ''Color Purple,'' a book whose great virtue is the conversational immediacy that lets its characters spring to life on the page. In Steven Spielberg's film version, which opens today at the Beekman and other theaters, the characters are also big and vibrant, but beyond that they resemble Miss Walker's barely at all. Mr. Spielberg has looked on the sunny side of Miss Walker's novel, fashioning a grand, multi-hanky entertainment that is as pretty and lavish as the book is plain. If the book is set in the harsh, impoverished atmosphere of rural Georgia, the movie unfolds in a cozy, comfortable, flower-filled wonderland.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYINGS ON COAST SENTENCED IN CANADIAN CRIME
description: Charles Ng, a former United States marine who is wanted in connection with a series of grisly California deaths, was found not guilty today on an unrelated Canadian charge of attempted murder. But he was convicted of robbery and assault and was given a four-and-a-half-year sentence.

title: The Word From Reagan
description: The unarguable political record shows that for 50 years the party that has won or retained control of the White House in a Presidential year has lost seats in the House of Representatives in the next off-year election.

title: SPORTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Faulty Weld Is Blamed For Ski Lift Accident
description: A faulty weld on a main pulley caused a ski lift accident at the Keystone resort that injured 49 people, but the flaw might not have been detectable even with the most sensitive equipment, a state engineer said today.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Net income.

title: YEVTUSHENKO PLAYS REBEL AGAIN, CALLING FOR OPEN SOVIET LITERATURE
description: The session was a closed one, but even so the poet's strong words against distortion of history, against censorship, self-flattery, silence and privilege in the world of letters were strikingly bold.

title: SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING SCHEDULED FOR TODAY POSTPONED 24 HOURS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today postponed the launching of the space shuttle Columbia by 24 hours because tired ground crew workers had fallen behind in their countdown tasks.

title: LESS ILLNESS FOUND IN BEER DRINKERS
description: Beer drinkers appear to be substantially healthier then either nondrinkers or wine and liquor drinkers, according to the largest study yet conducted of health differences among people who drink different kinds of alcoholic beverages.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Midcon Falls $1.50 a Share
description: Stock of the Midcon Corporation slipped $1.50 a share yesterday, to $61.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said the drop reflected Wall Street's belief that the $62.50-a-share bid made for Midcon on Monday will fail.

title: Advertising;   Pursuing Clients for An Agency
description: LEE ANN MORGAN is very successful at completing cold calls to top executives in advertiser companies, a claim many agency and media folk would like to be able to make for themselves.

title: Dow Is Down 8.60 After Seesaw Day
description: Trading remained heavy yesterday on Wall Street, but this time the stock market was going in reverse, with prices suffering their biggest single-day decline in two weeks.

title: CALIBRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Year-ago revenue was from discontinued operations and accordingly not separately reported. c-Including a gain of $1,938,338 from debt restructuring. d-Net loss.

title: PLAN IS SOUGHT TO COORDINATE JERSEY HUDSON DEVELOPMENT
description: Officials of a leading civic group called today for the creation of a commission to draft a comprehensive plan for development along the the Hudson River in New Jersey.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today's long-awaited striving for change to the better in our country gives us profound hopes that self-flattery will be forever rejected, and that non-concealment will become the norm of civic behavior.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about Kareem Abdul-Jabbar dealt with his successes and setbacks as a 38-year-old basketball star.

title: 'IT'S WRONG!' SHULTZ SAYS OF TERRORISM
description: The news conference here today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Raif Dizdarevic was marked by an unusual outburst by Mr. Shultz. Here is some of what the two officials said.

title: Comings and Going
description: For the third time in four years, a Duke soccer player has won soccer's equivalent of football's Heisman Trophy. Tom Kain of Wall, N.J., was named the winner of the 1985 Hermann Trophy yesterday, succeeding Joe Ulrich and Mike Jeffries, the 1982 and 1983 winners. The senior forward, a three-time all-America selection and 1984 Olympic team member, is the Blue Devils' career-record holder in goals (51), assists (45) and total points (147). . . . Vida Blue, who had an 8-8 record with the Giants last season after being suspended for the 1984 season because of drug possession while with Kansas City, has signed a new one-year contract with San Francisco in which he voluntarily agreed to undergo drug testing even after his probation ends next March. . . . Akron University has called a news conference today, and radio station WAKR is saying it is to announce that Gerry Faust, the former Notre Dame coach, will take over at the Division 1-AA school, replacing Jim Denison.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES IMPORT BILL
description: President Reagan tonight vetoed a bill to limit imports of textiles and shoes on the ground that it would impose unacceptable ''economic and human costs'' and invite foreign retaliation.

title: MANY ANONYMOUS DONATIONS MADE TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: Many anonymous contributors are helping to aid the hungry, homeless and ill by donating to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: New Publisher Of Newsday
description: Newsday, the newspaper based on Long Island, said yesterday that Robert M. Johnson would become its publisher and chief executive, succeeding David Laventhol, who becomes chairman.

title: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Results of the latest fourth quarter reflect year-end inventory writedowns equivalent to about 13 cents a share.

title: DAVID SHULA: HARD WORKER WITH THE CORRECT LINEAGE
description: The game ended in the Orange Bowl at 12:08 A.M. today. David Shula made it home by 2 A.M.; less than six hours later he was sitting at his desk at the Miami Dolphins' complex, charting each play of their 30-27 victory over the New England Patriots. Not even his father/boss, Don Shula, had checked in yet.

title: GIFTS FOR THE WINE LOVER
description: BLESSED are the gift givers with a wine fan on their list this year. The best gift for a wine person is, of course, wine. After that, wine books.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SPORTS WEDNESDAY
description: Basketball Nets vs. Utah Jazz, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The only regular-season game in the Meadowlands for the Jazz and Adrian Dantley, who leads the league in scoring with a 30.4-point average.

title: SIFTING THE SCHOOLYARD FOR BITS OF HISTORY
description: EIGHTY third-grade students have embarked on an archeological dig in the backyard of the Dalton School, 51 East 91st Street. Absorbed in mud, sand and clay from sneakers to faces, the students have been excavating surprises hidden in a wooden box about the size of a shipping crate, with one clear plastic side. Through it, four layers of earth, containing the remnants of four distinct eras, are clearly visible.

title: THE SCREEN: 'BRAZIL,' FROM TERRY GILLIAM
description: TERRY GILLIAM'S ''Brazil,'' a jaunty, wittily observed vision of an extremely bleak future, is a superb example of the power of comedy to underscore serious ideas, even solemn ones. ''Brazil,'' which was not scheduled for 1985 release until the Los Angeles Film Critics Association voted it best film of the year, was slated, as of yesterday, to open on Dec. 25 for one week in order to qualify for Academy Awards consideration. However, the opening was suddenly advanced, and it began its weeklong engagement today at Loew's New York Twin. It is scheduled to reopen on Feb. 14.

title: JORDAN OF GEORGIA LOOKS O BATTLE FOR SENATE SEAT
description: ''I'm the underdog,'' asserted Hamilton Jordan, adding that he was referring to his candidacy for the United States Senate in Georgia and not his battle with cancer.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COMMONPLACE BOOK. By E. M. Forster. Edited by Philip Gardner. 372 pages. Stanford University Press. $35.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bridge: A Lead of the 'Unbid Minor' Pays Off for New York Pair
description: A traditional guideline with considerable merit calls for the lead of the ''unbid major'' against three no-trump. The declarer, however, will often be expecting that lead and be well prepared for it.

title: HOUSE VOTE ON TAX DEBATE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 258 to 168 by which the House of Representatives today approved procedural rules for considering the Ways and Means Committee's tax-revision bill. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to consider the legislation. A ''no'' vote was a vote not to consider it. Voting ''yes'' were 188 Democrats and 70 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 58 Democrats and 110 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. A ''present'' denotes those who voted they were present at the time of the vote but did not vote ''yes'' or ''no'' on the issue. There are 435 members of the House.

title: Detroit Convention Center Expansion
description: Among the projects being undertaken to revive the downtown area of Detroit is the expansion of the Cobo Hall Convention Center. To finance the project, the city is selling $180 million of tax-exempt convention facility limited tax revenue bonds.

title: QUINCY CO-OPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: There were no per share figures reported since the company converted to a stock form last month.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $44,000. c-Net income including a tax credit of $119,000. Results for the latest first quarter reflect an increase in the provision for doubtful accounts of $1.5 million.

title: SPEC'S MUSIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Phillips, Pecten in China
description: The Phillips Petroleum International Corporation and the Pecten Orient Company have signed a contract with China for offshore oil exploration rights in the South China Sea.

title: SPEX GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PIERCE, S S CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
U.S. WANTS LAST 6 WILD CONDORS CAPTURED TO PREVENT EXTINCTION
description: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service today proposed that the last six North American condors remaining in the wild be captured immediately and placed in zoos.

title: Kareem and Patrick Meet
description: An older man who invented the sky hook and has learned to enjoy the spotlight, and a younger one who uses the sky hook but hasn't found the knack yet were present in Madison Square Garden last night as the Knicks extended the Los Angeles Lakers before losing, 105-99. Shortly after being named Sports Illustrated magazine's Sportsman of the Year, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar took the court against Patrick Ewing. Abdul-Jabbar had attributed his latest award to his making ''an effort to be appreciated'' as well as ''a token of appreciation for what I've done for the sport.''

title: MONEY BILL AVERTS AGENCY SHUTDOWNS
description: Congress today passed a stopgap bill to finance key Federal departments through Thursday, averting a partial shutdown of the Government. The measure will give House and Senate conferees time to try to reach a new agreement on a catchall appropriation bill for the rest of the fiscal year 1986.

title: Lilly-Hybritech
description: Eli Lilly & Company said it had increased its offer for Hybritech Inc. to $374 million, from $335 million.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL BASED ON TALES BY O. HENRY
description: THINK of O. Henry and you think of surprise endings, which is to say, his tales lose something at a second reading. And if you should decide to do a musical based mainly on ''The Gift of the Magi,'' you have to assume that much of the audience will know before the box office opens what is going to become of the young wife's beautiful hair and the young husband's treasured pocket watch.

title: COMBINING METALS FOR IMPROVED POTS
description: IMPROVEMENTS in pots and pans continue at an impressive rate. While stainless steel has always been desirable to the home cook for its ease of cleaning and durability, it suffers one serious drawback: it does not conduct heat as well as copper and aluminum.

title: REDRAWING THE ECONOMIC MAP
description: On Friday, the Commerce Department will announce the results of a long and secret project that will change the world as we know it, or at least many details of the economy for the last 30 years and more.

title: DIVI HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MARTY, a 17-year-old high school senior, is a hard act for his younger sister to follow. He's maintained a 3.5 scholastic average while serving as class president, playing racquetball, lifting weights and taking a center-stage role in the life of his high school. His college interviewers were suitably impressed with his academic, leadership and athletic achievements, but when they learned that Marty also spends four hours of every day in treatment for cystic fibrosis, they were astounded by all that he has managed to accomplish.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $34,950,000. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July.

title: CASTING 'HAY FEVER' WAS 'LIKE LOVE'
description: Casting the hit revival of Noel Coward's ''Hay Fever'' was a little like catching spring fever, said Brian Murray, the show's director - a little like seeing all of a person's attributes, then being tickled in the heart with a touch that says ''this someone is the perfect one.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A SINGULAR ART The one-person show, the most precarious hit-or-miss venture a performer can undertake on stage, is nothing new to show business. It has been a lure in English-speaking theater at least since 1747, when Samuel Foote, in England, tired of waiting for a job and went on solo, imitating fellow actors and celebrities of the time; it went well and he made a full run of his one shot.

title: Continental to Halt Aid From 28 Banks
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, taking another step toward financial recovery, said today that it would disband the network of banks that helped furnish it with a ''safety net'' to survive the liquidity crisis it suffered in May 1984. At one point, Continental was borrowing as much as $4.1 billion a day from the 28 banks.

title: Guru's Foundation Seized
description: All property of the Rajneesh Foundation in India has been taken over by the Government to recover $3 million in taxes, a Deputy Finance Minister told Parliament today. Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the Indian guru who had established a commune in Oregon, returned to India Nov. 17 after pleading guilty to violating United States immigration laws and receiving a suspended sentence. He left India four years ago after the Government revoked the tax exempt status of his commune in Poona, in western India.

title: Japan Air Ruling
description: The Japanese Cabinet abolished the rulings that originally divided Japan's international and domestic airline routes, the Transport Ministry said. This effectively ends the Japan Air Line Company's monopoly on international service, it said, noting that there are now seven Japanese airlines, and all want part of that market. All Nippon Airways has already applied for a Tokyo-Guam route, to start on March 3, and is expected to seek a Tokyo-Los Angeles route.

title: A State-Tax Outreach Program
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ IS ANGERED AT YUGOSLAV VIEW ABOUT TERRORISM
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz pounded a table in anger today after the Yugoslav Foreign Minister responded to a question about the hijacking of an Italian cruise ship by Palestinian terrorists in October.

title: BITBURG REMEMBERS, BUT THE BITTERNESS IS FADING
description: It is difficult to find traces of the controversy that catapulted this town on the Luxembourg frontier to the center of world attention eight months ago.

title: New Momentum in the Selling of Government
description: Governor Cuomo says, ''It is not government's obligation to provide services, but to see that they're provided.''

title: U.S.-MEXICAN DRUG EFFORTS SAID TO PROGRESS
description: The Attorneys General of the United States and Mexico, ending a two-day meeting here, reported new progress in their cooperative efforts to control drug trafficking across the border. The meeting followed by just five days the cracking of what officials said was a major drug-smuggling ring.

title: PROSPECTIVE BUYER OF U.P.I. CLEARS ANOTHER COURT HURDLE
description: Lawyers for Mario Vazquez Rana, the Mexican newspaper publisher trying to acquire United Press International, filed an amendment in bankruptcy court yesterday to a purchase agreement for the news service, clearing the way for the next step in the acquisition process.

title: ALTHEA RUDD TRUAX
description: Althea Rudd Truax, a life trustee of Hartley House and the widow of R. Hawley Truax, the former chairman of The New Yorker, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Abortion Bombers' Christmas Message
description: The Christmas season is many things to many people. To America's domestic terrorists it is, as it was last year, prime time to escalate the battle against a woman's legal right to a safe abortion.

title: UGANDA FACTIONS SIGN ACCORD ON PEACE
description: The Ugandan military Government and rebel leaders signed a peace accord today in a festive ceremony, but there was little confidence that stability would return quickly to their troubled country.

title: 7 Performing Artists To Get Mayor's Awards
description: Seven individuals in the performing arts are to receive the Mayor's Awards of Honor for Arts and Culture.

title: DANCE: PHYLLIS ROSE TROUPE
description: VARIETY is not enough. The Phyllis Rose Dance Company presented works by seven choreographers on Saturday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y, 344 East 14th Street. They were certainly varied. Yet they were also insubstantial.

title: Man, 26, Guilty In Youth's Killing
description: A 26-year-old man was convicted yesterday of murder in the shooting of a high-school honor student four years ago outside a Manhattan doughnut shop owned by the victim's father.

title: STAGE: 'TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN'
description: CAROL HALL'S ''To Whom It May Concern'' is a Christian musical for secular humanists. The show, which is playing at St. Stephen's Church (122 West 69th Street), takes the gospel musical tradition of ''Godspell'' and ''Salvation'' and turns it sideways by having everyday characters, strategically situated in a church congregation, rise up and testify to their spiritual uncertainty. Their anecdotes are interwoven with a score whose music boasts a strong country-gospel flavor and lyrics that shy away from expressing religious faith.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1985
description: The Economy

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No year-ago revenue figure is available because no shipments were made in the year-ago first quarter.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Sent Leo Hernandez, outfielder, to the Yankees to complete a trade made last week.

title: EWING AND ABDUL-JABBAR: FIRST MEETING A STANDOFF
description: It was a memorable night - the first meeting between Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the 38-year-old center who is in the twilight of a brilliant career, and Patrick Ewing, who is just beginning a career that has already been marked for greatness.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HAL ROACH STUDIOS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRISON CROWDING IN SOUTH LEADS TO TESTS OF OTHER PUNISHMENTS
description: Five young men - three burglars, an arsonist and a car thief - arrived at the Dodge Correctional Institute two hours southeast of here by car last month with long hair, designer jeans, tattoos and an attitude of independent swagger.

title: PLEA SAYS JUDGES USURP JURY ROLE
description: Federal appeals courts overturned jury verdicts on issues of fact in nearly half of all civil cases decided in the last year, according to a statistical study by law students at Yale University.

title: Comedy Benefit to Aid Coalition for Homeless
description: A weeklong series of comedy performances to benefit nonprofit organizations in the city continues today at 9 P.M. at the Comic Strip, 1568 Second Avenue, near 81st Street.

title: T.W.A. Studies New Icahn Bid
description: The board of Trans World Airlines will consider a revised acquisition offer from Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, in the next few days, sources involved in the offer said yesterday. The bid provides less cash per share and more preferred stock, but will still be valued at $24 a share.

title: Another Test of Truth for the Army
description: Another major weapons program seems to be in serious technical trouble. It's the Army's $13 billion program to buy an armored troop carrier known as the Bradley Fighting Vehicle. With almost 2,000 Bradleys already produced, the Army has discovered they are extremely flammable when hit by a standard Soviet antitank round.

title: Topics;   Reconstructions Sell Justice
description: American corporations are breathless to take each other over; and the Reagan Administration is breathless to sell off pieces of the Government, like the Federal Housing Administration, to the private sector. In this atmosphere, what could be more natural than the American Civil Liberties Union's proposal to buy the Justice Department?

title: RECITAL: BARBARA HENDRICKS
description: BARBARA HENDRICKS'S recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night was both relaxed and elegant. The songs were by Mozart, Brahms, Debussy and Montsalvatge, and in all of them there was a refusal to oversell or overstate.

title: Advertising;   A 2d Playboy Account Won by Smith Burke
description: Smith Burke & Azzam of Baltimore, which in October got Playboy's trade advertising account, now has its consumer business as well.

title: EXPERT SAYS CRIME FAMILY CHIEFS SANCTIONED SLAYING OF CASTELLANO
description: New York State's top expert on organized crime said yesterday that he believed that the slaying of Paul Castellano, the reputed chief of the nation's most powerful Mafia group, the Gambino family, had been sanctioned by the heads of New York City's four other crime families.

title: SENATORS SEE MODIFIED BILL, HARD FIGHT
description: The Senate is likely to adopt a tax-revision measure of its own next year, but it will probably be more favorable to business than the bill passed by the House tonight, and it could well raise additional revenues to help reduce the Federal deficit, Senate leaders said tonight.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO CITE 2 FOR CONTEMPT IN MARCOS INQUIRY
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted overwhelmingly today to proceed with contempt citations against two New York real estate figures who last week refused to answer a subcommittee's questions regarding their contacts with President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines.

title: Colombia Says It Found More Mass Graves
description: The authorities said today that they had found more bodies buried in mass graves in a southern area where guerrillas are active, bringing to at least 64 the total number of bodies exhumed in less than a week.

title: SEARING THE ROAST: AN UNEVEN HISTORY OF UNCERTAIN BENEFITS
description: WITH fall fading into memory and the winter feasts upon us, cooks face an age-old problem: how to insure that the holiday roast turns out to be the succulent centerpiece of the meal, rather than a mere dry substratum for gravy or sauces.

title: SCREEN: CHABROL'S 'HORSE OF PRIDE'
description: CLAUDE CHABROL'S ''Horse of Pride,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is most interesting for being so completely uncharacteristic of the French director who made such sophisticated melodramas as ''Les Biches,'' ''Le Boucher'' and ''La Femme Infidele.''

title: There the Poor Go, Failing the Government Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeal Is Planned In Arson Murders
description: The Westchester County District Attorney said today that he ''very definitely'' would appeal a ruling that overturned the murder and arson conviction of a Connecticut man for a discotheque fire that killed 24 people in 1974.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pessimism About Ulster
description: Acclaimed on both sides of the Irish Sea and both sides of the Atlantic when it was signed five weeks ago, the Anglo-Irish agreement has hit its first rocks. Some of them were trivial, but they are symptoms of the profound and maybe insoluble difficulties facing this latest attempt to unravel the Ulster knot by giving Dublin a symbolic, advisory role in the affairs of Northern Ireland.

title: Bright Side
description: Jerry Glanville, who lost Sunday in his debut as interim coach of the Houston Oilers, explains why he feels well off even if he isn't reappointed after the season: ''I've got one of the best coach's wives in the business, a great son and a dog that still hunts. I've got a car that's down to 36 more payments, and I belong to a hell of a church.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: SUIT ON BOOKS GIVES LOOK AT HASIDIM
description: Each morning for the last two weeks, an old yellow school bus with ''Machne Yisrael Day Camp'' painted on its side has arrived at the Federal Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn. Its doors open, and out comes a swarm of men dressed in the distinctive clothing of the Lubavitcher Hasidim.

title: Fleeting Wealth
description: ''You added funds. . .November 13. . .$60,000,050.00.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bell & Howell Co., Skokie, Ill., which makes information systems, said it expects fourth-quarter earnings to fall below last year's $7,708,000, or 73 cents a share. The company also said it had completed buying University Microfilms International from Xerox Corp. for $100 million.

title: SALES SOARING FOR TONGUE-TWISTING SINGLE-MALT SCOTCHES
description: ''FIRST you have to learn to pronounce them,'' said Daniel S. Beck, bar manager for Keens on West 36th Street, where 40 single-malt Scotches are stocked at the bar. Bunnahabhain (pronounced BOON-na-hah-ven), Glenmorangie (glen-MORE-an-gee), Laphroaig (lah-FROYG) and Auchentoshan (AWKH-en-tosh-an) do not exactly trip off the tongue, but the taste certainly seems to, if the growth of the market is anything to judge by.

title: Why Some People Stop Going to the Movies
description: To the Editor:

title: Threatt Activated
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have activated Sedale Threatt, who had been on the injured list since Dec. 4 with a pulled abdominal muscle, even though he is not yet ready to play.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Net losses.

title: The Homeless and the Night Visitors
description: The time: last Saturday night. The place: the South Bronx. Governor Cuomo of New York proceeds discreetly toward a welfare office in search of evidence that Mayor Koch's administration is letting homeless families sleep on chairs and floors. His car phone rings. Hold everything, an aide advises. The Mayor is already there.

title: IN POST-TITO YUGOSLAVIA, POLITICAL UNITY CRUMBLES
description: Three hundred households in Serbia canceled electric service in November. With an 80 percent rate of inflation this year and a 73 percent rise in the cost of living, the residents could no longer afford it.

title: Israeli Authorities Deny Entry To University on West Bank
description: Israeli occupation authorities today closed An-Najah University in the West Bank city of Nablus to prevent a symposium on armed struggle against Israel, military officials said.

title: GAMBINO TRIAL IS UNFOLDING HALTINGLY
description: The case against Paul Castellano and nine other reputed members of the Gambino crime family has unfolded unevenly and haltingly in the last 10 weeks, as the prosecutors have sought to link Mr. Castellano directly to a stolen-car ring and 25 murders.

title: Topics;   Reconstructions Marshall Plans
description: The disrepair of what used to be called the Atlantic community is a subject that glazes eyes on this side of the ocean. Americans regard solidarity with European democracies as a given, forgetting who gave it: the generation that fought in World War II.

title: INQUIRY CONFIRMS DAMAGE TO THRUST DEVICE IN ENGINE OF JET THAT CRASHED
description: Investigators here confirmed today that a right-hand thrust reverser was found in damaged condition in the wreckage of the chartered DC-8 airliner that crashed here Thursday morning. But they gave no indication of what caused the damage and said it was too early to attach significance to the thrust device.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $314,000 for the quarter and $358,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary gain of $202,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $219,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a loss from discontinued operations of an affiliate of $1,049,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: UAL Discounts
description: United Airlines said it would offer special discount fares through the New Year's holiday. United said the one-way fares would be $10 lower than its announced discount fares to be offered on Dec. 26, 27 and 28. The fares, which apply to flights made Dec. 31 through Jan. 3, will be $39 for flights up to 500 miles long, $59 for flights of 501 to 1,500 miles and $89 for flights over 1,500 miles.

title: RAPID-AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After net of $1,866,000 from operations which were sold. c-After a gain of $69,766,000 on sale of Lerner Stores Corp. and an extraordinary charge of $4,003,000 on note and debentures purchases. d-Net loss after net of $7,672,000 from operations sold and a loss of $18,240,000 on note and debenture purchases. Sales for both year-ago periods were restated to exclude sales of Lerner Stores Corp.

title: Daniels Ruled Eligible
description: Lloyd Daniels, Andrew Jackson High School's star basketball player, yesterday was declared eligible to play by Joe Varone, chairman of the Public Schools Athletic League's eligibility committee. Varone, who said his decision was final, ruled on Daniels, an 18-year-old junior who is attending his fourth high school in less than two years, after two P.S.A.L. coaches had protested their games with Jackson because Daniels was in the lineup.

title: OFFICIALS PREPARE AGAIN TO SHUT OFF OPERATIONS
description: With a wink and a smile, the White House today issued another of its periodic warnings that the Government might suddenly have to be shut down for lack of funds.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL HISTORY, 'IN THE HOUSE OF BLUES'
description: A YOUNG woman named Melody inherits a long-deserted blues club in Harlem in David Charles's ''In the House of Blues'' at the New Federal Theater, and is burdened with a rather labored premise for pointing up some highlights of blues history.

title: ENTERTAINMENT MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings are adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split effective on Dec. 21, 1984.

title: 12TH BODY IS FOUND IN GAS BLAST
description: City officials investigating Monday's explosion at a gas company office here said today that a worker's error in removing a propane tank valve might have prompted the blast.

title: Kosar May Be Obstacle For Jets
description: In the Jets' path to the playoffs, Bernie Kosar, a curly haired 22-year-old who could still be playing college football, may be the stumbling block.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
New Polaroid Chief Fits Tough Mold
description: For only the third time in 48 years, the Polaroid Corporation has a new boss.

title: OFFICIAL ELECTION TALLY SHOWS EVEN BIGGER MARGIN FOR KOCH
description: Mayor Koch polled slightly more votes than the unofficial count in the mayoral election, while City Council President Carol Bellamy received considerably fewer, according to the official count released yesterday by the City Board of Elections.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $1,519,381, or $1.28 a share, on the disposition of rental properties, mortgages and investments and a provision for possible losses of $315,000. c-Including a gain of $1,383,746, or $1.09 a share, on the disposition of rental properties, mortgages and investments and a provision for possible losses of $433,169. Results for both years reflect Gould Investors Trust's proportionate interest in BRT Realty Trust.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: 2 Brooklyn Takeout Shops Skaffles Catering is an attractive, new Brooklyn takeout shop at 645 Vanderbilt Avenue (Prospect Place), not far from Grand Army Plaza. Michael Ayoub, the young chef-proprietor, had a restaurant called Skaffles in the Bay Ridge section of the borough for a number of years. When he decided to expand the catering side of his business, he said, he found this handsome old space, a former drugstore with polished dark walnut cabinets and glass-fronted cases. It seemed ideal for a takeout shop, and that is what it has become.

title: Conviction Upset In Officer's Case
description: The assault conviction of an off-duty police officer after a dispute at a Brooklyn abortion clinic last March was overturned yesterday by Criminal Court Judge Alfred Murray.

title: TAX REVISION BILL WINS PASSAGE IN THE HOUSE ON SHIFT IN G.O.P. VOTES
description: After months of fierce lobbying and delicate political manuevering, the House of Representatives approved legislation tonight that would make the most extensive changes in the Federal income tax system in more than 40 years.

title: Change of Scene For Tar Heels
description: Already in the habit of conducting practice behind closed doors, Dean Smith takes it a step further this afternoon: behind bars.

title: Time to Do Something About Carriage Horses
description: To the Editor:

title: New Affection
description: She has a penchant for climbing out of the stands to plant kisses on the cheeks of baseball stars, and now Morganna Roberts, the exotic dancer known as the Kissing Bandit, has an entire team to embrace. She is a new owner of the Utica Blue Sox, the New York-Penn League club that has not been known to let an opportunity for publicity go unexploited. (Its manager last season was Ken Brett, the former major leaguer who got the job on the strength of his appearance in a beer commercial that disparaged the team's hometown.) Miss Roberts became one of the team's 20 limited partners - another is A. J. Duhe, the former Dolphin linebacker - when the general partner, Greg Larson, a sportswriter for The Florida Times-Union, interviewed her during an engagement in Jacksonville last month and happened to mention his connection with the Blue Sox. Bob Fowler, the managing partner, whose group paid $70,000 for the franchise before the 1985 season, declined to say yesterday how much Miss Roberts and her husband had paid for their minority share, but insisted that she had been given no consideration for her potential publicity value.

title: Ho, Ho, Ho
description: A strong contender for the 1985 Insensitivity Award in Christmas News Releases comes from the J. E. Robert Companies of Alexandria, Va., a real estate consulting concern, which predicts a new national record in mortgage foreclosures and repossessions of homes for the year now closing.

title: HEYMAN OF GAF: TOUGHT TENACIOUS
description: Samuel J. Heyman earned his stripes as a corporate takeover artist in the long and bitter battle for the GAF Corporation. Now, two years later, he is going after much bigger prey and the battle is getting even rougher.

title: RESPECTABILITY AND CRIME: PRIVATE LIFE AND VIOLENT DEATH OF PAUL CASTELLANO
description: In his highly stylized death, Paul C. Castellano finally played out the popular expectations about a man who, law-enforcement officials said, was the boss of America's most powerful crime organization.

title: MIDDIE GOES OUT WITH CLASS
description: Virginia McCallum, in brown wool jacket and rust-colored dress, sat on a folding chair in Memorial Hall on the Naval Academy campus and held a white midshipmen's hat in her lap.

title: CARBIDE STOCK RISE CONTINUES
description: Amid the battle for control of the Union Carbide Corporation, the shares of the beleaguered chemical giant continued to rise today as investors wrestled with the decision of whether or not and to whom they might sell their shares.

title: Rating Raised On City Bonds
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday raised its rating on New York City general obligation bonds to Baa-1 from Baa.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Minnesota Group Takes Over Farm Loan Office in Protest
description: Farmers demanding an immediate moratorium on foreclosures took over a regional farm loan office today and held it for seven hours until they were promised meetings with state officials.

title: Body Found Under Bar Floor
description: A body found in a trunk cemented beneath the floor of a bar here Monday has been identified as that of a Bronx man missing six years, the Nassau County police said today.

title: AIDS Questions Allowed by Jersey
description: Health insurers in New Jersey will soon be allowed to ask policy applicants whether they have ever suffered from or received treatment for AIDS or related diseases, state officials said today.

title: BENGALS ARE HELPING STEELERS
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers, preparing for their game against the Giants here Saturday, are receiving help from an unexpected source - the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Visitors From Luxembourg
description: Crown Prince Henri of Luxembourg passed through Washington the other day, but with little of the commotion that attended the Prince and Princess of Wales last month when they visited the capital for the National Gallery of Art's exhibition, ''The Treasure Houses of Britain.''

title: Ulster By-Elections Due As a Protest Gesture
description: Protestant members of Parliament from Northern Ireland won the right today to run in an election early next year as part of a protest over a British-Irish accord to cooperate on the future of the province.

title: ONTARIO ANNOUNCES PROGRAM TO SHARPLY CURTAIL ACID RAIN
description: Ontario Province in Canada, in a step that would significantly reduce acid rain in New York State and New England, announced a program today to curtail sulfur dioxide pollution sharply.

title: UNION VOTE AT HONDA PLANT POSTPONED AFTER U.A.W. FILES CHARGE
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ''indefinitely postponed'' a union representation vote scheduled for Thursday at an Ohio Honda motors plant after the United Automobile Workers formally charged the company with an unfair labor practice.

title: HOUSING STARTS ARE DOWN 12.2%
description: Housing construction plunged 12.2 percent in November, the sharpest drop in six months, according to a report released today by the Commerce Department. Analysts were divided on the reasons for the steep decline.

title: CBS CANCELLATION JEOPARDIZES 'AMERICA'
description: ''America,'' a hybrid program of entertainment and information, arrived this fall with a budget of $22 million and the backing of some of the most successful companies in television, including Paramount Television, Post-Newsweek stations and CBS. Its aim was to break the hold of game shows and old network reruns in the afternoon and, in the process, alter the economics of syndication.

title: KINGS ROAD ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ABORTION-CLINIC CASE IS LOST BY ALBANY CATHOLIC DIOCESE
description: New York State's highest court, reversing two lower courts, yesterday rejected attempts by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany to block two abortion clinics from opening.

title: CELEBRATE! THIS TIME LET BUBBLY BE THE BEST
description: THERE is a little restaurant on the west side of the Place de la Madeleine in Paris called Caviar Caspia.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Kellogg Officer Plans to Retire
description: Walter T. Redmond, vice chairman and chief administrative officer of the Kellogg Company, has announced plans to retire at the end of the year, after more than 37 years of service.

title: 7th Ave. Dickens
description: Crowds ''ooh'' and ''aah'' at Christmas windows on Fifth Avenue. But serious window aficionados are doing their viewing on Seventh Avenue between 16th and 17th Streets at an acidic contrast from the sugarplum-and-Santa ones in midtown.

title: Mets on the Mend
description: Three members of the Mets who underwent surgery last season gave a report on their conditions at a Shea Stadium gathering yesterday. Doug Sisk and Bruce Berenyi, right-handed pitchers, and Mookie Wilson, the center fielder, said their rehabilitation and recovery was right on schedule.

title: Capital's Michelangelo Tackles George Meany
description: The Washington area will soon get its ninth piece of public sculpture by the Long Island artist Robert Berks, a distinction perhaps never achieved by any other person, almost certainly by no other living artist.

title: ROCKING WITH AMERICA
description: AMERICA, America - it's turning into a rock-and-roll hook. Between John Cougar Mellencamp's 1983 hit ''Pink Houses,'' with its chorus of ''ain't that America,'' and Bruce Springsteen's multimillion-selling 1984 album, ''Born in the U.S.A.'' there has been a flood of songs that refer to ''The State of Our Union'' (which is the title of a new album by the Long Ryders).

title: YUGOSLAVS OF TWO MINDS ON BATTLING TERRORISM
description: Yugoslavia, a country that never knew a period free of terrorism, has, in the view of United States Government specialists and some Yugoslav officials, maintained dual attitudes over the years toward terrorists.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $33,000 for the quarter and $255,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $171,000 for the quarter and $776,000 for the 9 months.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically offers a selection of such questions, with today's group concentrating on people - and things - that are missing.

title: MAYOR RESTORES DR. GROSS TO JOB, CITING FAIRNESS
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, whose conduct as the New York City Chief Medical Examiner has been the subject of city and state inquiries for almost a year, was returned to office yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Africa Common Market
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia said today that he envisions the birth of a 20-nation African common market in seven years. Mr. Kaunda, who led the British colony of Northern Rhodesia to independence as Zambia in 1964, said the aim of the community - representing 150 million of Africa's 500 million people -would be ''to free ourselves economically'' from former European colonial powers. He spoke at the opening of the fourth summit talks of the Preferential Trade Area for Eastern and Southern African States.

title: TELEPHONE SPECIALISTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: New Regulations Will Improve Hospital-Subsidization Program
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO MAKES VISIT TO HOMELESS
description: Shortly after midnight this morning, Governor Cuomo visited a Manhattan welfare office where homeless families were spending the night.

title: CNL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEVELOPER TOLD JURY HE ORDERED ILLEGAL DEMOLITION
description: A major New York City developer testified before a Manhattan grand jury earlier this year that he had ordered the demolition of four buildings on West 44th Street in January even though he was aware that no permit had been issued for the work, according to grand-jury minutes that have been made public.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE CELTIC TOUCH There is no mistaking with any other the music that emanates from the glens and lochs on the European rim of the Atlantic. Joyful or mournful, the music has its distinctive lilt, the sort of soul that some of the greatest authors in the English language have brought with them out of a Celtic past.

title: CONGRESS VOTES SWEEPING CHANGE IN GOVERNMENT SUPPORT FOR FARMS
description: Congress today approved two measures that together form the most sweeping alteration in Government farm policy since the Depression.

title: GANDHI'S PARTY LOSES IN ASSAM
description: In a political setback for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, the governing Congress Party was defeated in elections held Monday in the troubled northeastern state of Assam, according to returns tonight.

title: YEVTUSHENKO TALK IS HEAVILY EDITED
description: The Soviet literary weekly today published a heavily censored version of a recent speech by the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko that had called for candor and openess in Soviet literature.

title: JERSEY CITY TRAVEL AGENT IS SEIZED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE EXPLOSIVES
description: The owner of a Jersey City travel agency was arrested today and charged with conspiring to smuggle 150 pounds of explosives to a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, a customs agent said.

title: INSURER-MANAGEMENT LIABILITY RIFT SEEN GROWNING
description: A Delaware court's approval this month of a settlement between the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York and several insurance companies seems likely to aggravate a growing problem for American business, according to experts in the field. The problem is the cost and availability of liability insurance for directors and officers.

title: PETRA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: PERSONAL COMPUTER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: How to Make PAC's Work for Everybody
description: To the Editor:

title: IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 KLANSMEN AND 2 OTHERS PLEAD GUILTY IN CAROLINA
description: Two Ku Klux Klan leaders and two other people have pleaded guilty to Federal civil rights charges in a series of cross-burnings intended to harass interracial couples.

title: AT NO CHARGE, USEFUL SKI DATA
description: For just the price of a postcard or a telephone call, skiers can get free publications with solid and useful information.

title: UNIONISTS SAYS CHEMICAL PLANT IN LOUISIANA POSES HAZARDS
description: A major labor coalition has accused the BASF corporation, a large West German chemical concern, of operating a Louisiana chemical plant in a manner that endangers the lives of workers and people in the community.

title: LEVITT CONSIDERS SENATE RACE
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the American Stock Exchange, met with Democratic senators today to discuss whether he should try to unseat New York's Republican Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, next year.

title: DELAY IS SOUGHT FOR SOME PROVISIONS
description: In a postscript to Tuesday night's passage of a sweeping tax revision bill, the House of Representatives has asked senior House and Senate tax writers to pledge that some of the provisions will not be retroactive to Jan. 1, if a tax bill becomes law in 1986.

title: Advertising;   Witter's Campaign For Savers
description: THE people at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., which has been part of Sears Roebuck & Company since 1981, feel that the other brokerages are missing the boat by making advertising that seems to be talking only to the high and mighty, when there are lots of other folks around who could use a broker for help with savings.

title: NEW SNAG IN TURNER'S MGM DEAL
description: Another effort by Ted Turner to raise funds for the purchase of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company apparently fell through today, with Mr. Turner's company announcing that it was not able to agree on the sale of certain assets to Viacom International Inc.

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ENGINEERED SUPPORT SYSEMS reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
THE DANCE: HAWKINS COMPANY
description: THE Erick Hawkins Dance Company has returned for a brief season through Saturday afternoon at Playhouse 46. The three Hawkins works on view gained surprisingly strongly from the intimate setting.

title: ALBANY G.O.P. OFFERS A PLAN TO CUT TAXES
description: The State Senate's Republican leadership today proposed a broad tax-cut plan that it said would save taxpayers $3.9 billion over five years.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RANGERS FALL FLAT AFTER LEADING, 3-0
description: The Rangers' offense hummed along, out of character and a step ahead of the Buffalo Sabres. But that lasted for only half the night.

title: HERALD CENTER HOPES HOLIDAY CAN END LULL
description: As the holiday shopping pace intensified this week, curious throngs gathered outside the sparkling 34th Street tower that is Herald Center. They watched as clowns juggled, a break dancer cavorted and a young woman blew bubbles in the front window of the city's first vertical shopping center devoted exclusively to retailing. However, few in the sidewalk audience seemed to head inside to shop.

title: VETERANS OF PAIN, AFGHAN CHILDREN GET HELP IN U.S.
description: The four children, in traditional Afghan garb, stood tired and bewildered amid the holiday crowds that filled the arrival hall of Kennedy International Airport. ''Who are those children?'' strangers kept asking, struck by their strangers kept asking, struck by their exotic dress and a somber dignity that seemed beyond their years.

title: Grace Shares
description: W. R. Grace & Company said its planned repurchase of 26 percent of its shares held by the Flick Group of West Germany might ''impair the company's ability to pay dividends in the future.'' W. R. Grace disclosed the imformation in an amended registration statement for 2.5 million common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission. W. R. Grace is offering the shares to raise part of the $597.8 million needed to purchase the shares from the Flick Group. The company's net income was down to $102.2 million for the first nine months of 1985, compared with $141.6 million for the first nine months of 1984.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $173,000 for the quarter and year and after a $8.9 million charge for litigation settlements and an after-tax gain of $1.3 million on the sale of assets for the quarter and year. c-After a tax credit of $456,000.

title: MISTRIAL RULED IN EDWARDS FRAUD CASE
description: A Federal district judge today declared a mistrial in the fraud and racketeering case against Gov. Edwin W. Edwards and four co-defendants after the jurors failed to agree on a verdict.

title: ALAN H. KEMPNER, PUBLISHING OFFICAL AND A BROKER, DIES
description: Alan H. Kempner, a stockbroker, publishing executive and philanthropist, died Tuesday at his home in Purchase, N.Y. He was 88 years old.

title: PINE AND SIMPLE
description: THEY happen to be nice, useful, simple items that are American-made of pine with a clear lacquer finish, available through Selections, a new mail-order concern owned by Evelyn Della Corte, below left, and Carmen Sugerman.

title: HOW THE SENATE VOTED ON FARM BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed the 1985 farm bill and sent it to President Reagan.

title: U.S. Ends Plan on Health Spas
description: The Federal Trade Commission voted unanimously today to drop regulations on the health spa industry that had been pending for a decade.

title: CONFEREES COMPROMISE ON AN '86 SPENDING BILL
description: House and Senate conferees agreed this evening on a compromise on a catchall appropriations bill for the rest of the 1986 fiscal year, one of the last hurdles to ending the 1985 session of Congress.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $75,000 for the latest quarter and $80,000 for the year-ago period.

title: UNIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a consolidation of earnings from Unimed's two-thirds ownership of Andos Chemical Co. c-Net loss.

title: CRITIC'S VOTE 'PRIZZI'S HONOR' BEST FILM
description: ''Prizzi's Honor,'' John Huston's black comedy about a hit man and a hit woman who fall in love, was voted the best film of 1985 by the New York Film Critics Circle yesterday. The group, voting its 51st annual awards, also chose Mr. Huston as best director.

title: NEW GROUP OF U.S. SOLDIERS LEAVES SINAI FORCE FOR HOME
description: A contingent of about 250 American soldiers who had completed a six-month tour of duty with the multinational peacekeeping force in the Sinai Peninsula left Cairo today to return to their base in the United States amid tight security and a news blackout.

title: DEBT-LADEN BRAZIL SEEKS $2.5 BILLION
description: Brazil, whose $104 billion of foreign debts make it the biggest debtor among the developing countries, is seeking $2.5 billion of new loans from multilateral development banks and additional credits from commercial banks, Brazil's Minister of Planning, Joao Sayad, said here today.

title: LANDMARK MANSION IN NEWARK
description: JOHN BALLANTINE, the son of the founder of the renowned Newark brewery, became president of the company in 1883 and thought he should have a house that fit his position. Completed in 1885 in the then-tranquil and elegant section of Washington Park, the Ballantine House combined Renaissance, Georgian and Romanesque styles in an excess of Victorian opulence.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: 'TANGO ARGENTINO,' THE SEASON'S IMPROBABLE HIT
description: Even on Broadway, where musicals about felines and female impersonators can become hits, ''Tango Argentino'' arrived in October as the longest of shots. Here was a show, after all, that violated the Broadway dictum that musicals be elaborate, expensive and stocked with supple young bodies. ''Tango Argentino'' wasn't even in English.

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GERALD'S PARTY. By Robert Coover. 316 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: EX-FUND-RAISER AT CANCER SOCIETY INDICTED IN $4 MILLION TAX FRAUD
description: The former head of fund raising for the American Cancer Society's New York City branch was indicted yesterday for masterminding a scheme that enabled contributors to take nearly $4 million in illegal tax deductions.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. World B. Free, the free spirit and high scorer from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, makes his first visit to the Garden this season.

title: Soviet Bloc Accord
description: The Soviet Union and nine Communist allies today began a 15-year cooperative program to upgrade their economies in a bid to close the technology gap with the West.

title: NUMEREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Travels With Reagan
description: White House officials raised the possibility yesterday that President Reagan might travel to other Asian and Pacific nations after attending the May 4-6 economic summit in Tokyo. The officials said a White House team would go to Tokyo in January to make Mr. Reagan's summit arrangements and to look into a possible extension of the trip.

title: BRITAIN'S WALL STREET FACES TIGHTER CONTROL
description: The City of London, Britain's Wall Street, has been buffeted recently by a series of been buffeted recently by a series of fraud cases, tarnishing the reputation of Europe's leading money center and putting pressure on the Government to strengthen the policing of London's financial district.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Cyprus Unification Initiative
description: The United States began talks today with Greek and Turkish officials in Cyprus in a new attempt to aid negotiations aimed at reunification of the two communities there, officials said. James Wilkinson, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for South European Afairs, arrived Tuesday after visits to Athens and Ankara. Mr. Wilkinson met with President Spyros Kyprianou and said said he was preparing to visit later today with Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Muscovites Warned on Firs
description: This city's forest administration warned today that residents could be jailed for a year if they cut down fir trees in the forests outside the Soviet capital for New Year's festivities. Residents say it is common to see people hurrying home with small fir trees cut from Moscow's woods. Parents decorate the trees with toys and fruit for children to find on the morning of January 1.

title: 5 Subpoenaed in Philadelphia
description: Five people have been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury about a fire last Thursday at the former home of a black couple in a predominately white neighborhood.

title: Fire Kills 6 in Illinois Family
description: A fire apparently started by faulty Christmas tree lights swept through a house early today, killing six members of a family and critically injuring a seventh, the authorities said.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 22
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $238,483, or 1 cent a share.

title: Gold Coin Bill Is Signed
description: President Reagan signed legislation Tuesday authorizing the minting and sale of general-circulation gold coins for the first time in 53 years. There will be four gold bullion coins - $50, $25, $10 and $5. The selling prices will fluctuate with the gold market and will not be tied to the nominal dollar designation on the coin, which is intended in large part to attract investors and collectors.

title: GLITTERY FASHIONS FOR FESTIVE EVENINGS, NOW AND LATER
description: SPARE moments during the day are spent shopping for gifts. Evenings are a melange of parties, gift-wrapping and home decorating. Almost two weeks remain before New Year's Eve and, of course, there's nothing to wear to the parties in between.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $20,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: VATICAN TO ALLOW INDULGENCES BY TV
description: The Vatican, in an unusual shift in Roman Catholic devotional practice, said today that Catholics who follow the Pope's annual Christmas benediction on television or radio will partake for the first time in the plenary indulgence reserved until now for those who were physically present at the service.

title: REAGAN DENIES CUT WILL HIT MILITARY
description: President Reagan, pledging to maintain the nation's military buildup, said today that balancing the Federal budget by 1991 would require deep cutbacks of what he called ''wasteful and unnecessary'' domestic programs.

title: Mack Layoffs
description: Mack Trucks will furlough 200 workers and will temporarily shut down operations at its manufacturing plant here, according to a company spokesman. The layoffs, scheduled for Friday, will be for an indefinite period, Bill McCullough said. The furlough will bring to 700 the number of workers idled at the truck maker's Hagerstown plant since spring.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,287,000 for the quarter and $4,040,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $336,000 for the quarter and $2,930,000 for the 9 months. The latest results also include loss provisions of $12,241,000 for the quarter and $16,872,000 for the 9 months on the sale of drilling rigs.

title: KING INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
