description: b-Including tax credits of $35,416 for the quarter and $83,116 for the 6 months. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $72,839 for the quarter and $246,557 for the 6 months and tax credits of $62,200 for the quarter and $168,200 for the 6 months.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Best Yet to Come
description: Coach Denny Crum, on the potential of his Louisville basketball team: ''I think we've got most of our future ahead of us.''

title: FEDERAL JURY HEARS TAPES ON LABOR PAYOFFS
description: A Federal jury heard secretly recorded conversations yesterday in which Ralph Scopo, a former concrete workers union president who is accused of extortion, told a contractor that paying Mr. Scopo guaranteed ''peace of mind.''

title: Cecil W. Kenyon Dies; An Early Female Pilot
description: Cecil W. Kenyon, one of America's first female aviators, died last Thursday, of complications from a stroke, at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. She was 80 years old and lived in Lyme, Conn.

title: MARVIN WEBSTER TO QUIT BASKETBALL
description: After missing all of last season and the first 25 games of this one because of hepatitis, Marvin Webster yesterday left professional basketball for good.

title: CONOLOG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2-Week Cleanup Likely For Mississippi Oil Spill
description: The Coast Guard set up a command post today and began planning a two-week cleanup of a major oil spill in the Mississippi River caused when an oil barge struck a railroad bridge.

title: CALENDAR: HOLIDAY TOURS AND FLOWERS
description: A Surreal Christmas: Things Are Not Always What They Seem, Muriel Karasik Gallery, 1094 Madison Avenue, at 82d Street, 212-535-7851.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Named Tony Torchia manager of New Britain in the Eastern League.

title: Iowa Land Values Fell 30.2% In Last Year, Survey Reports
description: The average price of an acre of Iowa farm land plummeted 30.2 percent this year, the sharpest decline since the Great Depression, according to a survey by Iowa State University made public today.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.N. UNANIMOUSLY CONDEMNS HOSTAGE-TAKING
description: The Security Council adopted a resolution today that condemns ''all acts of hostage-taking and abduction'' and calls for the immediate, safe release of all hostages and abducted people.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loses after losses from discontinued operations of $170,930 for the quarter and $667,500 for the year and a loss of $435,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $36,331 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: GAMBINO FIGURE STANDS ACCUSED IN ASSAULT CASE
description: John Gotti, who is believed by law-enforcement officials to be seeking control of the Gambino organized-crime family, and his son, John Jr., have been accused of assault in separate incidents in Queens in the last 14 months, according to court records.

title: Advertising;   Smithsonian Will Add Air & Space Magazine
description: The Smithsonian Institution, which publishes the successful Smithsonian magazine, will be adding a second title in the spring, Air & Space, the official publication of its National Air & Space Museum.

title: HOUSE ROLL CALL ON FARM BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 325 to 96 by which the House of Representatives today approved the farm bill. A ''yes'' vote is a vote for the bill. A ''no'' vote was against the bill. Voting ''yes'' were 194 Democrats and 131 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 49 Democrats and 47 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are 435 members of the House.

title: PAY-O-MATIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: DOHNANYI LEADS CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: CHRISTOPH VON DOHNANYI'S concert with the Cleveland Orchestra in Carnegie Hall Saturday evening began with that exquisite meditative gem, ''The Unanswered Question'' of Ives. Its calm assertion of the unchanging (muted string ensemble, offstage), punctuated but not shattered by the shrill querulousness of flutes and the pensive musings of the trumpet, still hung in the air as the orchestra stole into the fevered world of Schoenberg's monodrama ''Erwartung,'' where nothing is unchanging and all calm is shattered.

title: Robert A. Magowan, 82, Dies
description: Robert A. Magowan, former chairman, president and chief executive officer of Safeway Stores Inc. of Oakland, Calif., died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: TELECALC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $35,000 for the quarter and $157,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUESPhiladelphia Issue For Airport
description: Philadelphia is offering $95.6 million of airport revenue bonds, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: MET OPERA: 'L'ITALIANA'
description: FOR reasons best known to the Metropolitan Opera, Ernesto Palacio, a tenor with a far greater international and recordings reputation than Douglas Ahlstedt, is the ''cover'' for Mr. Ahlstedt as Lindoro in this season's revival of Rossini's ''Italiana in Algeri.'' Monday night Mr. Palacio, who has recorded this role with Marilyn Horne, the star of the Met's cast, made his company debut, singing his only scheduled performance of the season.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FARADYNE ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ohio Boy Is Near Death After 40 Minutes in Pond
description: A 9-year-old boy trapped under freezing water for more than 40 minutes was in critical condition today as doctors kept him in a drug-induced coma to forestall brain damage.

title: CORRECTION
description: A movie review of ''The Color Purple'' yesterday gave the film's rating incorrectly. It is PG-13.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CARBIDE AND GAF STOCK UP SHARPLY
description: The shares of the Union Carbide Corporation and the GAF Corporation rose sharply today amid widespread rumors that GAF was preparing to increase its $68-a-share tender offer for Carbide.

title: NETS CONTAIN JAZZ, 113-98
description: They won the game, and that alone brought a smile of satisfaction to Dave Wohl. But the schism between the Net coach and his unpredictable leader, Micheal Ray Richardson, may have grown a bit wider tonight.

title: JUDGE SETS DEADLINE FOR YONKERS TO SUBMIT PLAN FOR DESEGREGATION
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the City of Yonkers and the Board of Education to submit by Feb. 17 proposals to desegregate the city's public schools and public housing.

title: Ferry Carrying 177 Sinks In Philippines; 53 Saved
description: A ferry carrying at least 177 people from Manila to a southern Philippine island sank Wednesday, and the United States Navy said it was able to rescue as many as 50 survivors.

title: Technology;   Preparing Food For Microwave
description: PRODUCERS of food for microwave ovens have gone a long way in recent years to satisfy the growing number of fast-paced and finicky eaters' demands for a quicker way to prepare meals at home.

title: TALK BY YEVTUSHENKO IN ITS ENTIRETY
description: Following is the text of a speech given last week by Yevgeny Yevtushenko to a congress of Russian writers, as translated by The New York Times. The material in italics, between brackets, was omitted from the version published today by Literaturnaya Gazeta, a Moscow weekly.

title: FOUNDATION DONATES $100,000 TO HELP NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: A donation of $100,000 from the Willard T. C. Johnson Foundation to help feed the poor and the homeless has been made to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: OBSTACLES TO PHILIPPINE VOTE DESCRIBED
description: A bipartisan team of American electoral experts reported today that there were still many technical and political questions to be resolved before free and fair presidential elections could be assured in the Philippines on Feb. 7.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Fall
description: The long advance in Treasury securities prices came to a halt yesterday. But the price declines, while sizable, reflected technical and seasonal factors more than any change in basic sentiment, according to credit market analysts.

title: POLICE SEEK GANG-SLAYING WITNESSES
description: A combined force of about 50 police detectives and F.B.I. agents searched yesterday for witnesses and clues in the slayings of the organized-crime leader Paul Castellano and a chief aide, but officials acknowledged little progress in solving the murders.

title: Deceptive Good News on Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 19, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee Against Apartheid - 10:30 A.M.

title: Big Road Trip
description: Where can the antithesis of the Robeson team be found? Maybe at Christ the King High School in Middle Village, Queens.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 9
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $173,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the 9 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $3,163,000.

title: BORDER FIGHT WAGED ON CIVIL WAR BATTLE SITE
description: A point of high ground along the Mississippi where Confederate cannon once shelled Union warships has become the landlocked site of a border conflict between lawyers battling over oil and gas royalties.

title: Texaco Lending Snags Seen
description: Texaco Inc.'s attempt to raise $1.7 billion in much-needed short-term financing ran into snags yesterday, as the company and some of its banks could not agree on the interest rates to be paid for the money, according to banking sources.

title: MONEY DOESN'T HELP WINGS
description: The Detroit Red Wings, floundering this season despite the hiring of several expensive free agents last summer, are giving credence to the cliche that ''many a truth is told in jest.''

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-The company did not have year- ago sales because it was in a development stage.

title: The Fairness Issue
description: The tax bill passed by the House of Representatives confounds many predictions, mine included. The existing tax code is a premise of life for so many interests in this country that real reform looked impossible but the House bill is real reform.

title: Counting Out
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, never stopped smiling and exchanging pleasantries with the guests at the annual White House Christmas press party the other night. And there was some indication that the Handshaker in Chief was keeping a private count as he stood on the receiving line. As the wife of one reporter shook his hand and moved along, the President turned to Mrs. Reagan and said, ''That's 250.''

title: MINNESOTA WOMAN GETS JARVIK HEART
description: Surgeons late Wednesday for the first time began implanting an artificial heart in a woman to keep her alive until a human donor heart can be found. The doctors at Abbott-Northwestern Hospital were using a version of the Jarvik-7 artificial heart that is 30 percent smaller than the plastic-and-metal pump used in men, Tom Horner, a hospital spokesman, said.

title: APPLE SEES RECORD NET IN QUARTER
description: Apple Computer Inc., in an announcement that surprised Wall Street, said today that it expects record earnings in the current quarter, despite a drop in revenues.

title: NEW PHILADELPHIA POLICE HEAD CHOSEN FROM OUTSIDE THE RANKS
description: Kevin M. Tucker, a Brooklyn native who was the agent in charge of the United States Secret Service office here for seven years until his retirement last June, was appointed today as Philadelphia's Police Commissioner as of Jan. 1.

title: 7 HOSTAGES RELEASED UNHARMED AS OKLAHOMA PRISON RIOT ENDS
description: About 80 inmates who rebelled against conditions at the Oklahoma State Prison, stabbing three guards and taking seven hostages, released seven guards at midday today in exchange for a meeting with prison officials in front of a group of reporters.

title: Monsanto Expects Loss
description: The Monsanto Company said it expected to report a loss from operations in the fourth quarter.

title: Anti-Takeover Plan by Busch
description: In an anti-takeover move, the Anheuser-Busch Companies said its board had adopted a plan to distribute preferred share purchase rights to shareholders. The Anheuser-Busch chairman, August A. Busch, said in a statement, ''We have not been, nor do we expect to become involved in any discussions that could affect in any way our independence.''

title: French Site Chosen For Disney Park
description: The French Government signed a letter of intent with Walt Disney Productions today for the construction of a vast amusement park and vacation center in Marne-la-Vallee, 15 miles east of Paris.

title: SENSATIONAL KILLINGS FILL CRIME FAMILIES' HISTORY
description: The fatal shooting of Paul Castellano, the head of the Gambino crime family, was the latest in a long series of sensational killings involving warfare between competing factions of organized crime.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: Protect Plays, Not Just Theaters
description: New York's three dozen legitimate Broadway theaters are the jewels of its cultural life, but putting them in a landmark lockbox will not automatically safeguard their value. The Board of Estimate should take great care today in reviewing the first of the theater landmark proposals.

title: A Violent Climate in the American Family
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd., the international banking arm of the American Express Co., has elected its vice chairman and treasurer, Robert A. Savage, to the additional post of chief operating officer.

title: City Federal Plans Management Shifts
description: City Federal Savings and Loan, the nation's 12th-largest savings and loan association, yesterday announced a number of changes among its top management. The association, the principal sub= The association, the principal subsidiary of Cityfed Financial Corporation of Palm Beach, Fla., said that Gilbert G. Roessner, its chairman since January 1978, will step down from that position at the end of the year. Mr. Roessner, who is 67 years old, will remain chairman and chief executive of the holding company and as a member of City Federal's board, the association said.

title: Weighing In
description: Fat reports are nothing new on Capitol Hill, but the most recent one issued by the House Judiciary Committee seems remarkable in several ways. The report, on the 1982 Environmental Pro-tection Agency scandals, has 39 words in its title, 44 pages in its index and a total volume of 1,282 pages. It weighs about 11 pounds, and, according to experts familiar with its contents, contains not much new.

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain from the sale of assets of $457,000 for the quarter and year.

title: SALIVA DISCOUNTED AS AN AIDS THREAT
description: The AIDS virus was detected in the saliva of only one of 71 homosexual men known to be infected with the disease, according to a new report. Scientists said the finding should help allay public fears that acquired immune deficiency syndrome could spread through casual social contact.

title: 6-11 ST. JOHN'S SUB GOES WEST TO GROW
description: When St. John's played U.C.L.A here last Saturday afternoon, the Redmen were cheered by perhaps the biggest fan at Pauley Pavilion: the 6-foot-11-inch, 210-pound Rob Cornegy.

title: THEATER: 'SHOW CAUSE'
description: DECADES of racial segregation in the Army and Navy ended in 1948 with President Truman's Executive Order 9981 directing ''equality of opportunity for all persons in the armed services.'' This directive ignites the action in Stephen Taylor's two-act courtroom drama, ''Appear and Show Cause.'' It is based on a story Mr. Taylor and Leon H. Gildin wrote in 1978 about a 1951 incident in the offices of the Judge Advocate General, United States Army Headquarters, in Stuttgart, West Germany.

title: WITH MINI-SERIES, VIDAL RETURNS TO TV WRITING
description: Gore Vidal, writing for television for the first time in 25 years, has produced the script for a four-hour mini-series, ''Dress Gray,'' based on the best-selling novel by Lucian K. Truscott 4th about homosexuality, corruption and murder at West Point during the Vietnam era. The film, which stars Alec Baldwin, Hal Holbrook, Lloyd Bridges and Eddie Albert, will be broadcast by NBC in March.

title: MAFIA INFILTRATION OF BUSINESS COSTING CONSUMERS MILLIONS
description: New Yorkers pay more for what they eat and where they live and work because of organized crime's grip on legitimate businesses, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: DEL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Net income.

title: A VIOLENT CLIMATE IN THE AMERICAN FAMILY
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ ENDS VISIT TO EAST EUROPE
description: After a quick introductory visit to Eastern Europe, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he believes ''there is a lot of potential motion'' for change in that area, but it will be ''a slow, subtle and difficult process.''

title: New Spoleto Festival Head
description: The Spoleto U.S.A. Festival in Charleston, S.C., has announced that Nigel Redden will be its general manager. Mr. Redden now heads the dance program for the National Endowment for the Arts. He will replace Carmen Kovens, who has served as acting general manager since the resignation last July of Philip Semark. The 10th annual Spoleto U.S.A. Festival will take place from May 23 to June 8.

title: TAX BILL REVISION LIKELY IN SENATE, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: Administration officials said today that they expected the Senate to approve a tax-revision measure next year with greater incentives for business investment than those contained in the bill approved Tuesday night by the House of Representatives.

title: $296 Million Bond Issue For an L.I. Waste Unit
description: The Industrial Development Agency of Hempstead, L.I., is selling $296 million of fixed-rate, convertible resource recovery revenue bonds for an American Re-Fule of Hempstead solid waste disposal project. American Re-Fule is a partnership between wholly owned subsidiaries of Browning-Ferris Industries and Air Products and Chemicals Inc.

title: THEATER: 'JERRY'S GIRLS,' A MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT
description: IN shows dating from his biggest hit, ''Hello, Dolly!'' (1964), to his latest one, ''La Cage aux Folles'' (1983), the songwriter Jerry Herman has stood up proudly and often effectively for the tuneful, extravagant, unabashedly old-fashioned Broadway musical. But not this year. At ''Jerry's Girls,'' the new Broadway ''entertainment'' purporting to pay tribute to its namesake's song catalogue, one is less likely to recall the high spirits of ''Dolly'' or the opulence of ''Mame'' than the screechiness and tackiness of such latter-day Broadway revues as ''Leader of the Pack'' and ''Peg.'' The only thing that ''Jerry's Girls'' has in common with a bona fide Jerry Herman musical is that it occupies the St. James, the theater where Dolly once promised she'd never go away again.

title: Orlando, Fla., Bottler Recalls 10 Soft Drinks
description: A Coca-Cola bottling company has withdrawn about 10,000 cans of soft drinks from store shelves because of contamination from a nontoxic lubricant, a health official said Tuesday.

title: MORE JUDGES AND COURT AIDES INDICTED IN CHICAGO
description: Twenty-two men, including three current or former judges of the Cook County Circuit Court, were indicted today on charges of racketeering, mail fraud, extortion and tax violations.

title: WALL BRACKETS FOR TV
description: NUMEROUS brackets exist for attaching television sets and stereo speakers to walls or ceilings. Television Rental, 55-02 Broadway, Woodside, N.Y. 11377 (718-458-2211 or 516-483-1211), rents television sets but also sells a number of different TV brackets. Model 1700 is made of brown steel (which can be spray-painted in another color). It can hold television sets from 12 inches to 21 inches wide and up to 100 pounds in weight. The unit has a fixed 15-degree tilt for a standard 8-foot ceiling. It sells for $79.95.

title: Samantha Smith Statue
description: A model of a statue of Samantha Smith was unveiled at a shopping center Tuesday, less than four months after the 13-year-old peace advocate was killed in a plane crash. The statue, showing Samantha holding a dove while a small bear sits at her feet, was sponsored by the Auburn Mall. The cost of casting the statue in bronze will be financed by public donations. Gov. Joseph E. Brennan and 300 others attended the brief unveiling ceremonies.

title: MARTIN LAWRENCE LTD EDIIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHOT IN BAR ROBBERY
description: An Essex County sheriff's officer who was shot during a November robbery attempt at a Newark tavern died today at University Hospital, a sheriff's spokesman said.

title: HOW TEXACO LOST COURT FIGHT
description: A month ago, Texaco Inc. was one of the nation's strongest companies. Today, the oil giant is reeling and on the ropes.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $211,000 for the quarter and $320,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $258,000 for the quarter and $279,000 for the 6 months.

title: LOUISVILLE OUTLASTS INDIANA
description: Milt Wagner, the senior guard who has struggled this season, scored 22 points tonight, including Louisville's final 10 of the game, to lead the Cardinals to a 65-63 victory over Indiana.

title: A.T.& T. SEEKS RATE CUT FOR SOME FOREIGN CALLS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today to approve a 10.1 percent reduction in the company's long-distance telephone rates for calls to 33 of the nearly 250 countries and territories the company serves.

title: HUSSEIN CALLED DISCOURAGED BY ARMS-SALE CURBS
description: King Hussein of Jordan was reported today to have told American officials recently that the conditions imposed by Congress on a sale of arms to his country had undermined his confidence in the United States and its ability to bring about productive peace negotiations in the Middle East.

title: Market Place;   Western Union Merger Gossip
description: A FEW weeks ago the band of speculators who prowl Wall Street thought they had the troubled Western Union Corporation figured out. Here was a company that has struggled for more than a year to get a stable line of credit, and was doing a good job of cutting its expenses in hopes of improving its profit levels.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Two by Land
description: If Earnest Byner of the Cleveland Browns can run for 99 yards against the Jets next Sunday, then he and Kevin Mack will become only the third tandem of 1,000-yard rushers on the same team in the history of the National Football League. The first such duo was Larry Csonka (1,117 yards) and Mercury Morris (1,000) of the 1972 Miami Dolphins, and the second was Franco Harris (1,128) and Rocky Bleier (1,036) of the 1976 Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: MANILA COURT SAID TO UPHOLD ELECTION
description: The Philippines Supreme Court voted 7 to 5 today to allow early presidential elections to proceed as scheduled on Feb. 7, according to three of the judges.

title: Bashing the Yobbos
description: In the country that Americans like to think of as the citadel of civility, politics ain't beanbag.

title: JETS BENCH MCELROY
description: The Jets attempted to solve their problem of yielding too many sacks by benching Reggie McElroy today and replacing him with Ted Banker at left tackle.

title: STATE OF SIEGE IS LIFTED IN BOLIVA
description: Bolivia today lifted the state of siege imposed Sept. 19 by President Victor Paz Estenssoro to halt a 15-day protest strike by workers that crippled the Bolivian economy.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
T.W.A.'S TALKS STILL SNAGGED
description: Trans World Airlines tried on several fronts yesterday to overcome its takeover stalemate but came up empty-handed. Some of those involved said the airline, which is losing money at a rapid rate, could find itself in severe financial difficulties if the matter is not resolved soon.

title: SHL SYSTEMHOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Reflects a non-recurring gain of $437,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: MERCHANTSBANK OF BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $167,000 for the quarter and $305,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $21,000 for the quarter and $146,000 for the 6 months.

title: Foundation to Aid Mentally Ill
description: The Federal Government and a private foundation joined today in offering eight large cities money to help provide services for chronically mentally ill patients discharged from mental hospitals, many of whom become homeless.

title: A PROGRAM TO TRAIN 20 GARDENING BUFFS
description: For city dwellers who know the difference between a rhododendron and a philodendron and have some time to do volunteer work, the Cooperative Extension Division of Cornell University is offering a chance for free horticultural training.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HOMEOWNERS in many parts of the nation have already had a good taste of how storms can leave their families without power, heat, telephones and sometimes even without water. And storms can leave roads impassable, so that you cannot get to local stores for needed provisions -even if the stores are open.

title: EWING ISN'T THE ONLY ROOKIE
description: Although Patrick Ewing entered the National Basketball Association as one of the most heralded rookies in many years, Jerry West, the Los Angeles Lakers' general manager, believes Xavier McDaniel has a chance to win rookie-of-the-year honors.

title: Bad for New York
description: America is now a nation governed by clerks and computers. In perhaps the greatest abdication since the Duke of Windsor chose Wallace Simpson over the throne, Congress last week turned the power of the purse over to the Federal bureaucracy by passing the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction plan. The consequences for New York State will be harsh.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes gain of $3 million, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of three hospitals.

title: Niekro Near Accord
description: The agent for Phil Niekro said yesterday that he expected to reach agreement with the Yankees on a one-year contract for the 46-year-old free-agent right-hander within the next three weeks. ''Phil will not accept the Yankees' offer of arbitration, and we don't have an agreement,'' Bruce Church, the agent, said by telephone from his office in Atlanta.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1985
description: International Bonn's interest in ''Star Wars'' was confirmed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition. It announced that Economics Minister Martin Bangemann would go to Washington next month to negotiate over a role for West German industry in a space-based missile defense system. [Page A12, Column 4.]

title: After the Tax Triumph
description: Tax reform lives. After the President's last-minute foray to the Capitol for Republican support, the House rescued it from last week's grave. No one knows what the result will be after the Senate takes its turn next year; what matters today is that the House has voted to keep the bill rolling.

title: HCW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Travels With McFarlane
description: Word is circulating in Washington that the President's departing national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, will join Kissinger Associates Inc., the consulting concern headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Christmas Message From Reagan to U.S.
description: Following is a text of President Reagan's 1985 Christmas message:

title: Dow Falls 2.07 as Volume Slackens
description: The stock market, depressed in late trading by a number of sell programs, eased yesterday as volume slackened a bit.

title: Advertising;   Mullen's New Client
description: Mullen Advertising and Public Relations, one of the bigger agencies in Beverly Farms, Mass., has been tagged to do advertising for Analog Devices, a Norwood, Mass., manufacturer of linear integrated circuits and testing, measurement and control equipment for industry. The billings, previously handled by Giardini/Russell, will be about $1.5 million.

title: 23 Police Officers Hurt In Protests by Basques
description: Twenty-three policemen and several demonstrators were hurt today as a wave of violent protests against the death of a Basque arrested by the paramilitary Civil Guard swept northern Spain, officials said.

title: Jury Convicts 2 More In Killing in the Capital
description: The jury in the trial for the murder of a mother of six convicted two defendants today two days after returning guilty verdicts against six others.

title: Aid for Targets Of Takeover
description: The Senate passed a bill today that would make it easier for companies that are targets of hostile takeover bids or proxy fights to communicate with their shareholders.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
Scofflaws' Nemesis
description: Elsewhere on the traffic front, the man scofflaws would love to hate, were it not for his relative anonymity, is stepping down.

title: FOR A CRAFTSMANLIKE JOB WHEN GLUING FURNITURE
description: It is a rare household where a dab of glue here and there would not be welcome. Whether you own fine furniture or pieces of more modest pedigree, a basic understanding of repairing wood furniture can be helpful.

title: GOVERNOR'S MANSION IS GETTING A NEW LOOK
description: For Matilda Cuomo, the first indication that the 41-room, 19th-century Governor's Mansion in Albany needed renovation was in the kitchen. ''There was no counter space and no commercial dishwasher,'' she says. ''I saw how the staff was struggling, ''I saw how the staff was struggling, and it wasn't efficient. They were working under a handicap.'' She soon noticed other deficiencies: Leaky windows caused drafts, there was no convenient men's room for the public and no central air-conditioning.

title: Those Nixon Tapes
description: A lawsuit seeking to hasten the public release of all tapes and documents of Richard M. Nixon's White House was filed yesterday in Federal court in Washington.

title: House Panel Tax Review
description: A House Ways and Means subcommittee is looking into the use of an investment tax deferral technique that permits delayed payment of taxes on capital gains by several years.

title: TEACHERS LECTURE KEAN ABOUT THE FRUSTRATION AND JOY IN THE CLASSROOM
description: For a few hours today, 15 public-school teachers had Governor Kean as a student. The subject was education policy.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including tax credits of $78,000 for the quarter and $117,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: TAX BILL: UPHILL BATTLE AHEAD IN SENATE
description: Although he won a considerable victory in gaining passsage of a tax-revising measure in the House of Representatives Tuesday night, President Reagan may have made it harder, perhaps a great deal harder, to achieve a tax revision of the sort he has long sought.

title: Allen Submits New Bid for Conrail
description: Allen & Company, a Wall Street investment firm eliminated last year from the bidding for the Consolidated Rail Corporation, has submitted a new $1.4 billion offer for the Government's 85 percent interest in the railroad.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 10:54 A.M. today and set at 11:10 P.M. tomorrow.

title: 3 Workers Die in Collapse Of Los Angeles Building
description: A steel beam crashed several floors through an office building under construction near a downtown freeway today, collapsing the structure and killing three workers, officials said.

title: G.M.A.C. Tests Financing Plan
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financial subsidiary of the giant auto maker, today introduced a pilot financing program that is intended to lower a new-car buyer's monthly payment with a balloon payment at the end of the contract. Initially, the plan will be offered in southeastern Michigan only.

title: Bridge: Risks of 'Sandwich' Bidding Tend to Outweigh Rewards
description: Bidding ''in sandwich'' is a term used in Europe, and a very appropriate one, for entering the auction against two active opponents.

title: Advertising;   Fisher-Price Drops Waring
description: The ghost of Ebenezer Scrooge walked the hallways of Waring & LaRosa last night very much at home in the gloom that followed the loss of more than $11 million in, of all things, toy billings.

title: MUSIC: CHRISTMAS PLAY
description: DEMONS, a dragon, two fools and a shipwreck all but upstage Mary and Joseph in ''La Cantata dei Pastori'' (''Shepherds' Cantata''), which was presented Sunday at St. Ann's Church in Brooklyn by the Italian music-theater troupe I Giullari di Piazza. The Christmas play was written in the 17th century and has been performed each year around Naples, evolving through the years. It uses folk music, some dating back to the 15th century, and figures from commedia dell'arte. On Sunday it also included fire-eating, juggling and prestidigitation between scenes.

title: Public Employee Union Wins Ohio Labor Vote
description: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees emerged today as the winner of a 20-month drive to unionize 42,500 state workers.

title: NUMBERS DIALED ON 3,400 PHONES FOUND RECORDED BY U.S. IN A YEAR
description: A Congressional survey has found data indicating that Federal law-enforcement agencies installed secret electronic devices to record telephone numbers that were dialed from 3,400 telephones in a recent 12-month period.

title: THE STAGE: 'JOIN',' COLLEGE FRATERNITY ANTICS
description: ''JONIN','' a first full-length play by Gerard Brown, is enveloped in a curtain of deja vu. The setting is a dormitory in a black university that resembles Howard (from which the author graduated in 1975). However, the events are not far removed from those one has experienced in earlier plays and movies about academia. The play seems neither pertinent nor particularly contemporary.

title: GENETIC ENGINEERING reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
EX-NAVY OFFICIAL FREED IN CONFLICT-OF-INTEREST CASE
description: A Federal jury on Tuesday found George A. Sawyer, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy, not guilty of unlawfully concealing job-hunting contacts with a big military supplier while he was overseeing the buildup of the fleet.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $601,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $538,000 from discontinued operations. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,904,000 which includes a gain of $3.3 million on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: BOARD TO LET QUINONES'S CONTRACT RUN UNTIL 1987
description: In what was described as a symbolic ''vote of confidence,'' the Board of Education yesterday announced that the contract of Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones would be extended for one year.

title: TEL ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: STATE SEEKS TO BLOCK MUSEUM'S MOVE
description: In the first legal move to prevent the Museum of the American Indian from leaving New York, Attorney General Robert Abrams has filed a motion in State Supreme Court asking that the museum's petition to relocate in Texas be dismissed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1985
description: The Economy

title: NOISE POLLUTION IN THE N.F.L.
description: Noise pollution is the National Football League's loudest problem. Home-team fans, sometimes aroused by arm-waving players, are disrupting games more than ever before. Their decibels drown out a visiting-team quarterback's voice when he's calling signals for a crucial play, thereby interfering with that team's right to operate its offense. And that's wrong. When fans buy a ticket, they purchase the right to cheer or to boo, but not a right to prevent a visiting team from playing the game.

title: AIR AGENCY ORDERS WIDE INSPECTIONS OF REPAIR SHOPS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered an unusually broad inspection of jet engine repair facilities operated by major airlines and by independent overhaul companies.

title: 'WOZA ALBERT!,' SOUTH AFRICAN PLAY
description: UNDER the umbrella heading of ''Channel Crossings,''

title: GRAND ENTRANCES THAT ARE IN THE SPIRIT OF CHRISTMAS
description: INNOVATIVE Christmas decorations by experts - tulips next to miniature topiary trees on a mantel, or unusual color schemes, such as magenta and bronze ribbons knotted in a swag of juniper - are easily adapted to any home. Some deftly blend new and classic imagery and might well become decorating traditions for this season of hearth and home.

title: SHEDDING LIGHT ON DARK-DAY BLUES
description: AT 5:30 on winter mornings, when most other homes in Gaithersburg, Md., are still dark, six powerful fluorescent lights are glowing in Susan Nicholson's recreation room as she bounces steadily on a small trampoline. She is not only exercising but also recharging what she calls ''my solar batteries'' under high-intensity, full-spectrum lights that mimic the sun's rays.

title: HOMECRAFTERS WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes charge of $5 million as a provision for unusual inventory losses expected to be incurred in closing 11 warehouse stores for the quarter and 9 months.

title: UNITED WAY PUTS '85 RECEIPTS AT $2.23 BILLION
description: Americans are giving $2.33 billion to the United Way this year, a record that caps the charity's best three years in more than a quarter century, officials estimated today.

title: Sudan Minister Resigns
description: The Sudan's Finance Minister, Abdel Magied, resigned today after the nation's 15-man civilian Cabinet failed to ratify a draft agreement with the International Monetary Fund, the official press agency reported.

title: Advertising;   Zale Fills Post
description: The Dallas-based Zale Corporation, which has changed from a manufacturing to a marketing thrust, has appointed Michael C. Barlerin, formerly of Doyle Dane Bernbach, New York, to be senior vice president, corporate marketing. Zale has 1,450 retail jewelry outlets and a $60 million promotion budget. The Bloom Agency does its advertising.

title: Pepperell Gets New President
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc., the Georgia-based textile manufacturer, has named Donald J. Keller as president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 15.

title: KOENIG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chrysler Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that on Friday it would stop production at its Warren, Mich., truck assembly plant for three months for modernization.

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $62,000.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: POLLING AT VOTING PLACES UPHELD BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A state law banning the polling of voters within 300 feet of a voting place is unconstitutional, a Federal district judge ruled today in a challenge of the law that was brought by two newspapers and the nation's three major television networks.

title: FUND DRIVE LAGS ON KING HOLIDAY
description: The first observance of the national holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will be marked around the country Jan. 20 with an ambitious schedule of events. But the Federal commission set up to organize the holiday celebration says it has fallen far short of its original fund-raising goals.

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HOLIDAY GREENERY: CARE AND HANDLING
description: FOR those who are decorating their homes with live plants and cut greenery, here are a few practical reminders and tips for a safe holiday.

title: NO HEART SURGERY NOW FOR BONNER
description: Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, does not require surgery to correct her heart problems and will be treated with drugs and ordered to stop smoking, doctors said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Nov. 30 about George A. Keyworth's decision to resign as President Reagan's science adviser misstated the history of the adviser's position. It was established in 1957 under President Eisenhower, abolished by President Nixon and re-established as a statutory office in 1976 by President Ford.

title: WOOD HEATING: WORDS OF CAUTION
description: Wood has achieved a solid place in America's winter heating budget in recent years, but wood-burning equipment was implicated in an estimated 140,000 home fires in 1983, according to Terrence M. Scanlon, chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Even Blowouts Can't Slow Them
description: Alexander Hamilton Vocational High School, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, closed its doors last June and then reopened in September as the Paul Robeson High School of Business and Technology. The transformation may have meant a better academic atmosphere, but basketball has been another matter. So far in its first season, Robeson has played four games and lost them all - by the combined score of 358-65.

title: Security Plus
description: Their new identification cards will literally unlock doors for employees of Dow Jones & Company. But the cards have an alarming side effect.

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: There are no share earnings figures because net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He's been through the fires of hell. How long do you keep the guy roasting?'' - Mayor Koch referring to Dr. Gross. [A1:2.]

title: ISRAEL AND IVORY COAST PLAN TIES
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres flew to Geneva early today for an unannounced meeting with President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast, after which the two leaders announced their intention to restore diplomatic relations.

title: Mishap at Three Mile Island
description: A mishap at the Unit 2 reactor of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant here delayed cleanup of the reactor for several hours but did not cause an emergency, a plant spokesman said Monday. A canister being loaded with radioactive fuel debris fell about a foot into the reactor on Saturday, according to the spokesman, Gordon Tomb. He said the canister was retrieved and steps would be taken to make sure the canisters were properly locked into place in the future.

title: CONGRESSMAN SET TO GO UP IN SPACE SHUTTLE TODAY
description: The countdown went smoothly today for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia on Thursday. Among the seven crew members is Representative Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat who heads the House subcommittee that oversees the budget of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Plain-English Software A Project for 2 Brothers
description: When the Gross brothers sit down to work on their personal computers, they ''talk'' to the machines in plain English.

title: Faust Hired by Akron
description: Gerry Faust, the former Notre Dame coach, took over today as coach at Akron, a Division I-AA school with a developing football program.

title: BONN SAYS IT SEEKS 'STAR WARS' ROLE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition announced today that it would negotiate with the United States over a role for West German industry in the so-called ''Star Wars'' missile defense program.

title: 5 GIANTS, 4 JETS GOING TO PRO BOWL
description: For anyone unaware that the Giants of today are better than the Giants of recent years, the Pro Bowl voting announced today should remove doubts. Five Giants were named to the National Conference's 41-player team for the all-star game Feb. 2 in Honolulu.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: TELCO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit equal to 8 cents a share.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
CHARTER AIRLINES CARRY MANY MILITARY TRAVELERS
description: The same day an Arrow Air chartered plane crashed in Newfoundland, three other Arrow Air flights carried 272 American military passengers in and out of Diego Garcia, an island site of a United States naval and air base in the Indian Ocean.

title: UTAH FINDS UNCERTAINTY IN HIGH-TECH INDUSTRIES
description: More than a decade ago Utah's political, business and academic leaders began a drive to create a high-technology center here in the shadow of the Wasatch Mountains.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CSI TELE-MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income after net losses from discontinued operations of $22,798 for the quarter and $41,427 for the 6 months and extraordinary tax credits of $84,200 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 6 months.

title: Slippery When Syruped
description: Well after breakfast time, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway was slathered in maple syrup late yesterday afternoon after a tank trunk sprang a leak not far from the Grand Central Parkway.

title: CHECKROBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-There are no year-ago results because the company was formed in April and went public in October. The company is in the development stage so it had no operating revenue.

title: EX-ARMY DOCTOR DENIED NEW TRIAL IN SLAYING OF WIFE AND DAUGHTERS
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the conviction of Jeffrey MacDonald, a former Army physician who was found guilty of the 1970 murder of his wife and two daughters.

title: CABARET: ANNETTE SANDERS, SINGER, OPENS AT FREDDY'S
description: LIKE most singers who have spent long periods in the isolated world of recording studios performing commercial jingles, Annette Sanders seemed to be going through transition problems when she opened this week at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, and found herself facing a live audience.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Three Polish Activists Are Reported Detained
description: Three prominent opposition activists were detained by the police in Warsaw today after their apartments were searched, family members and associates said.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NUGGET OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sonat to Take Pretax Charge
description: Sonat Inc. said it would take a pretax charge of $300 million against fourth-quarter results because of uncertainties surrounding the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's order on open access to natural gas transportation systems and continued softness in oil and natural gas prices. It said the after-tax amount was $170 million.

title: Key Receiver Lost
description: Hassan Jones, a senior wide receiver at Florida State who was a key figure for the team all season, has been declared ineligible to play in the Gator Bowl Dec. 30 against Oklahoma State because he violated National Collegiate Athletic Association regulations on complimentary tickets. Under N.C.A.A. rules, only relatives and fellow students can have a player's complimentary tickets. Jones gave 12 tickets for the Nov. 30 game against Florida to people who were neither related to him nor students at Florida State.

title: Quickly: Save 623,000 Jobs
description: In the waning minutes of the session, Congress needs to turn its attention briefly but quickly to the targeted jobs tax credit, which otherwise will expire on Dec. 31, needlessly killing the jobs of 623,000 disadvantaged Americans.

title: STANWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: BAYSWATER REALTY & CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HERS
description: WHEN my friend Beth said she was seriously thinking of sending her 10-year-old daughter to a girls' high school, my first reaction was ''Poor Rosa!'' My entire precollege education took place at a school from which boys were banished after third grade, and I was one miserable teen-ager. ''I don't even know any boys to say hello on the street!'' I would rage, while my parents tried to look as though they could see why this might be a cause for sorrow.

title: Oliver May Head F.T.C.
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Daniel Oliver to be a member of the Federal Trade Commission and designate him chairman once he is confirmed by the Senate, the White House announced today. Mr. Oliver, who would succeed James Miller 3d, has been general counsel at the Agriculture Department since 1983. Mr. Miller became President Reagan's budget director earlier this year. From 1981 to 1983, Mr. Oliver was general counsel at the Education Department. From 1973 to 1976, he was executive editor of The National Review magazine. Mr. Oliver practiced law in New York City from 1976 to 1979.

title: Mice Leap to Death On the Golan Heights
description: Hundreds of field mice are killing themselves by jumping from cliffs on the Golan Heights in what Israeli scientists say is the rodents' instinctive way of solving an overpopulation problem.

title: Don't Tamper With the F.H.A.'s Success
description: It's doubtful that even the Reagan Administration really intends to press for abolition of Federal agencies like the Interstate Commerce Commission or Agricultural Extension Service. Draconian measures are usefully leaked at budget-writing time, if only to make more modest cuts later seem reasonable. But the talk of ''privatizing'' the Federal Housing Administration may be enticing enough to merit a closer look. The foreseen benefits of selling that agency do not seem to justify the risks.

title: Former Algerian Leader Is Accused of Fraud
description: Former President Ahmed Ben Bella was accused of fraud today, two days after starting a campaign for the liberalization of the country's one-party political system at a news conference in London.

title: IBM Japan
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and IBM Japan Ltd. announced they had set up an equal joint telecommunications and information processing venture.

title: Where's the Belt Law For School Buses?
description: To the Editor:

title: LAST-MINUTE DECOR FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: IF you have yet to find time to make your home festive, there are florists around town geared to provide stylish last-minute trimmings.

title: Expect Chaos
description: As chairman of the House Budget Committee during the 1985 budget negotiations, I learned how difficult it is substantively and politically to reduce Federal budget deficits. No one would be happier to learn of a magic formula to painlessly solve the problem.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Commercial Airplane Co., Seattle, a unit of Boeing Co., said three airplane companies had ordered a total of five Boeing 747's with a combined value of more than $490 million. The airplanes are scheduled for delivery in September 1986.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Politics;   Biden: Something About '88 Keeps Beckoning
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware says he has no doubt that he has the winning Democratic message for 1988 and that he can deliver it as well as or better than most other Democratic Presidential hopefuls.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FIRST CONTINENTAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WITNESS TELLS OF MEETING ON HEROIN SALE
description: A key witness told the jury in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial yesterday that he had seen four defendants participating in a Mafia meeting about a large shipment of heroin.

title: SHULTZ SAYS HE WAS ANGRY 'FOR AMERICAN PEOPLE'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that when he erupted in anger at remarks by the Yugoslav Foreign Minister on Tuesday, ''I was very much really speaking for the American people.''

title: Pitt Loses a Coach
description: Roy Chipman, weary of reports that the University of Pittsburgh improperly recruited players, resigned as basketball coach of the school effective at the end of the season. Chipman said at a news conference in Pittsburgh that he would ''never coach basketball another day after this season ends'' because ''it's not that important, because I want to do something else with my life.''

title: BARBARA FIRESTONE
description: Barbara Firestone, wife of Leonard K. Firestone, the industrialist and former Ambassador to Belgium, died of cancer Tuesday at her home, a family spokesman said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Two of Roger Maris's former Yankee teammates, Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford, will be among the pallbearers at Maris's funeral today in Fargo, N.D. The other pallbearers will include Mike Shannon, a former teammate of Maris with the St. Louis Cardinals; the Cardinal manager, Whitey Herzog; two former Yankee teammates, Clete Boyer and Bill Skowron, and Bob Allison, a former Twins outfielder. A prayer service for Maris was held in Fargo last night. . . . Paul Boutilier of the Islanders will undergo a brain scan today at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital to determine why he has double vision in his left eye each time he is hit hit hard. . . . John (Blue Moon) Odom, a former major league pitcher, pleaded innocent to five misdemeanor assault charges at his arraignment in Westminster, Calif.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $8,400,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and $26,900,000, or 71 cents a share, for the 40 weeks. c-After tax credits of $10,920,000, or 29 cents a share, for the quarter and $23,850,000, or 63 cents a share, for the 40 weeks and includes gains on the sale of marketable investment securities of $13,883,000, or 37 cents a share, for the quarter and $19,061,000, or 51 cents a share, for the 40 weeks. d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $135 million, or $3.59 a share, related to the reversion of surplus pension funds to the company.

title: JEC LASERS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $128,000. c-Net loss.

title: Article 235405 -- No Title
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities will give $14.9 million in conditional grants to 41 United States colleges and cultural organizations for research, faculty endowments and historic renovations, officials said today.

title: HOW KUROSAWA'S 'RAN' MISSED A SHOT AT OSCAR
description: Akira Kurosawa's widely acclaimed film ''Ran'' will not be nominated for an Academy Award as Best Foreign Film, and the story of how it came to be left out is one of good intentions and missed opportunities.

title: Brown-Bagging It
description: Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, opened his briefing for reporters Wednesday on a poignant if somewhat self-serving note. Clearly hoping to shame domestic correspondents, he reported that he had finally received one Christmas present from the press corps: a bottle of vodka and a tin of caviar from Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: 85 of 200 Rescued After Manila Ferry Sinks
description: United States Navy helicopters and sailors rescued more than 70 survivors of a capsized ferry boat from the South China Sea today, bringing to 85 the number of people saved, officials said.

title: AGENCY PROPOSES FUND OF STOCKS IN 3D WORLD
description: The directors of the International Finance Corporation, an agency of the World Bank, are expected next month to approve creation of a mutual fund that will invest in securities of companies listed on third world stock exchanges, a spokesman said today.

title: HOME-FIELD EDGE FACTOR IN LAST WEEK
description: The most important residual of winning consistently, besides making the playoffs, is getting the home-field advantage for one or more playoff games.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Carbide Suit Delayed
description: A United States District Court judge in New York today put off until Dec. 24 further consideration of a suit by the GAF Corporation that seeks to block the Union Carbide Corporation's stock repurchase plan. The Carbide plan is designed to rebuff GAF, which has offered $68 a share for all Carbide's stock.

title: Developer Is Wanted On Charge of Assault
description: The police said a 13-count arrest warrant was issued today for a building developer that charges him with assaulting two photographers and stealing their cameras and equipment. The developer is rebuilding 61 houses destroyed in a confrontation between the police and the radical group Move.

title: ANADITE INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest fourth quarter and year reflect a pretax charge of $2,668,000 for the writedown of assets. Year-ago results include a pretax gain of $1,190,000 on a government waiver of previously accrued rental obligations.

title: APARTHEID'S RULES LEAVE A BLACK FAMILY SUNDERED
description: The letter came not long ago to this village and preparations for celebration began immediately. Sainah Zitha's husband was coming home.

title: Reds Trade 4 For Gullickson
description: The Cincinnati Reds today obtained the right-handed pitcher Bill Gullickson from the Montreal Expos in a six-player trade that sent the pitcher Jay Tibbs to the Expos.

title: FAULTY PUMP IN ROCKET ABORTS SPACE SHUTTLE LIFTOFF
description: A hydraulic pump in a booster rocket attached to the space shuttle Columbia failed today, stopping the countdown just seconds before liftoff and delaying the mission until early next year.

title: Military Contractor Accused
description: A military contractor and three employees have been charged with fraud in the manufacture and testing of semiconductors for military and other uses, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

title: Chief Executive Elected at Charter
description: The Charter Company, the energy conglomerate that sought protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in April 1984, said yesterday that D. Thomas Moody has been elected president and chief executive, effective Dec. 31.

title: Addendum
description: Sullivan & Hone, a strategic marketing and new product development firm, opened in Great Neck. L.I., by John W. Sullivan and Francis J. Hone Jr.

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
RESTAURANTS
description: IT is always refreshing to see a relatively unfamiliar cuisine appear in New York, such as the spicy and spirited fare of the West Indies at Lola, a stylish new restaurant in the blossoming Madison Square neighborhood. This rakish, pastel-washed establishment is the creation of Eugene Fracchia, former owner of Pesca, and the Jamaican-born Yvonne (Lola) Bell. The menu is only about half Jamaican - Mr. Fracchia asserts his own ethnicity via a handful of Italian dishes.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $117,854.

title: TENNESSEE REPORTS MEETING PRISON AIM AHEAD OF DEADLINE
description: The State of Tennessee has complied with a judge's order to reduce the population of its prison system, and the goal has been reached two weeks ahead of the deadline, the Corrections Commissioner has reported.

title: Bridge: The Player of the Year Title Rides on a New York Event
description: As usually happens, the Greater New York Bridge Association's Player of the Year title will be decided at the last tournament, the Winter Regionals beginning tomorrow at the Sheraton Centre, Seventh Avenue and 53d Street.

title: Czechoslovak Fete
description: The foods and music of Czechoslavakia will be featured at a traditional Christmas celebration on Sunday at 12:30 P.M. at St. John Nepomucene Church, First Avenue and 66th Street. Admission is $7 ($3 for those under 12.) Information: 254-6862 or 734-4613.

title: Court Urged to Return Rubin Carter to Prison
description: Prosecutors have petitioned a Federal appeals court to return Rubin (Hurricane) Carter to prison. A judge ordered Mr. Carter's release last month on the ground that his conviction in a 1966 triple murder had been based on racism.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: IT has been a year of struggle and triumph for Barbara Cook, who is playing her first New York club engagement in nearly three years at the newly renovated and enlarged Michael's Pub. The project that has kept the singer from performing more frequently in cabarets has been the creation of a Broadway-bound one-woman show that is still only half-finished.

title: Test for West Side Mettle
description: The Apple Bank sign read 11:12.

title: Trenton Urged to Run Motor Vehicle Offices
description: The State Commission of Investigation recommended today that the state take over operation of Division of Motor Vehicle agencies and end the traditional political patronage system used to appoint agents.

title: CENTRAL MAINE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There were no share earnings in the latest 9 months after preferred dividend requirements.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Bail Accord Reached In Molestation Case
description: A defendant accused of child molestation who was jailed without bail for 21 months was granted $1 million bail Wednesday under an agreement that limits her contact with children.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Synthetic Fuels Corporation Drops Effort on Shale Grants
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation, which Congress has voted to abolish, decided today not to try to make last-minute aid awards to two shale oil projects in Colorado and Utah.

title: Britain's Finance Bill
description: The British Government introduced legislation today aimed at reforming business practices in the City of London, the nation's financial center.

title: MUSEUM DECISION IS DEFERRED
description: After a lengthy hearing yesterday afternoon in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Justice Martin B. Stecher reserved decision on two motions relating to the Museum of the American Indian's petition to relocate in Texas. One was a motion by Attorney General Robert B. Abrams to dismiss the museum's petition.

title: Cards Fined, Player Says
description: According to Joe Bostic, a guard for the St. Louis Cardinals and the team's union representative, most Cardinal players have been fined $1,000 each for refusing to take drug tests as part of their end-of-season physical exams.

title: JEWISH MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: The Hebrew Arts School's Winter Festival of Jewish Music will begin Sunday at 8 P.M., with a program by the composer-pianist Jack Gottlieb tracing the roots of some American popular music to their origins in Yiddish songs and liturgical music.

title: A DIVISIVE JUNK BOND DEBATE
description: Corporate America is finally getting back at the raiders.

title: Bermuda Banning Farrakhan
description: Louis Farrakhan, leader of a Black Muslim faction, has been banned by Bermuda's black-led government because of fears that a speech scheduled for Dec. 27 would incite unrest on the racially mixed island.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday A PAUL WINTER SOLSTICE Tomorrow brings the shortest day and the longest night of the year, and once again the Paul Winter Consort will celebrate the winter solstice with three concerts at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The mystical music of wolves, whales and a canyon wren will complement the Paul Winter ensemble at 8 tonight and Saturday, but Saturday night's performance is already sold out. Because of the demand for tickets, a special matinee has been added at 2 P.M on Saturday; it will have its climax as the winter solstice actually arrives at 5:08 P.M. Tickets are $12 and $20, with children under 12 admitted at half-price for the afternoon performance only. The cathedral is at West 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Information: 662-2133.

title: Boy Pulled From Pond Dies of Heart Failure
description: A 9-year-old boy died at Children's Hospital without regaining consciousness today, two days after he was pulled from an icy pond where he was under water for 45 minutes.

title: Coffee Rises Sharply On Earthquake Rumor
description: Coffee futures prices soared yesterday on a false rumor that an earthquake in Colombia had damaged growing areas there.

title: TAX DEBATE MIGHT FORESHADOW '86 CAMPAIGN
description: When President Reagan first advanced the idea of tax reivision, Republican strategists maintained that it could become a political magnet attracting Democratic voters away from their traditional loyalties.

title: CAROLIN MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
YOUNG FANS TARGET OF ANTIDRUG BOOK
description: Although the issue of testing major league baseball players for drug use remains unresolved, the head of the players union said yesterday that the organization will begin its own campaign to curb drug use - among children.

title: THE DANCE: BILL T. JONES IN SOLOS
description: BILL T. JONES presented a tour de force of a performance Wednesday in two hours of solo dancing at the Joyce Theater. One early piece, one later one and four works created this year offered a view of Mr. Jones that was provocative, though perhaps not entirely in the way he meant it to be.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE success story of the week is undoubtedly that of Terry Gilliam's ''Brazil,'' which as of last Friday was not going to be released by Universal Pictures. On Saturday it was voted best film of 1985 by the Los Angeles Film Critics, to whom it had been shown in a private screening. By Monday a decision had been reached to open the film in New York as speedily as possible and play it for a week so that it could qualify for further awards. The film's producer, Arnon Milchan, was then awakened in the middle of the night with a call telling him no theater would be available. But by midday Tuesday, Loew's New York Twin had been persuaded to jettison ''Rocky IV'' and make room for the last of the year-end contenders.

title: KEY POINT IN TEXACO CASE TODAY
description: Texaco Inc. is scheduled to go into a Federal court today to argue for protection from the Pennzoil Company that Texaco maintains is essential to its functioning as a going concern.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Hardly Missed
description: So how badly did the Chicago Bears miss Todd Bell, the strong safety who went to the Pro Bowl last season and then held out all of this year in a contract dispute? Not very badly, it would appear. When the rosters for this season's Pro Bowl were announced the other day, one of those named was Dave Duerson, Bell's replacement.

title: The Yiddish Theater Takes on The New Yorker
description: With temperatures in the 20's, yesterday was not the best day for picketing. But actors and others from the Yiddish theater marched in front of The New Yorker, at 24 West 43d Street, to protest the magazine's refusal to list Yiddish shows in its ''Goings on About Town'' section.

title: WOMAN HIJACKS HELICOPTER TO FREE 3 AT SOUTH CAROLINA PRISON
description: A young woman who said she was chartering a helicopter to go sightseeing drew a gun on the pilot and forced him to land in the yard of a state prison near here today. Three inmates scrambled aboard and were flown to freedom.

title: Yes, By Kahanism
description: Is Meir Kahane a serious threat to Israeli democracy? Or is he merely an ugly blemish?

title: U.S. CITES BROAD SMOKING HEALTH RISK
description: The Surgeon General of the United States said today that cigarette smoking represented a greater health threat to most American workers than do workplace hazards.

title: State's Power Enough To 2013, Study Finds
description: New York State residents can get all the electricity they need until at least 2013 without building more large power plants and without opening the completed $4.5 billion Shoreham nuclear plant, according to a state report released today.

title: Schembechler Speaks
description: Bo Schembechler, the University of Michigan football coach, yesterday criticized the University of Akron president, William Muse, for replacing Coach Jim Dennison with former Notre Dame Coach Gerry Faust.

title: The Momentum of a Vague Vision
description: The ''Star Wars'' missile defense program is moving steadily forward. Hundreds of research contracts have been let. Important technical advances have already been claimed. The Russians seem desperate to stop the program. Star Wars is building a constituency.

title: NOW, SEXY BRIEFS FOR MEN
description: Hannah Kaplan spends her day surrounded by men's underwear. As owner of Underworld, a nine-month-old boutique on West 72d Street, her world is one of silk briefs and satin boxer shorts, combed cotton nightshirts and cashmere socks.

title: Connecticut Issue
description: The Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority is offering $91.7 million of bonds for a solid waste disposal and energy generating project with a maximum yield of 8.702 percent for bonds due in 2004 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 7 percent for bonds due in 1990 to 7.90 percent in 1995 and 8.40 percent in 2001. The bonds are rated A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

title: Winning Moves
description: In the 40-year history of the National Basketball Association, only 14 players have won league championships with more than one franchise. Now Bill Walton of the Boston Celtics and Maurice Lucas of the Los Angeles Lakers, both of whom played for the Portland Trail Blazers' 1977 title team, are front-running candidates to join that group.

title: TECHNICAL EQUITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,070,000 on the sale of a unit for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: Japan and Germany Urged to Grow
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development urged West Germany and Japan today to expand their economies faster, warning that unless they do there is little chance of reducing high unemployment levels in industrial countries or of cutting America's trade deficit.

title: Sikorsky Plan For Westland
description: Britain's financially troubled Westland Helicopters went ahead today with the announcement of an American-led plan to rescue the company, despite opposition from the Defense Ministry and arms manufacturers.

title: THE THEATER: 'REAL SHOW IN JACKSON'
description: THE New York premiere of ''And They Dance Real Slow in Jackson'' moves real slow at the Hudson Guild Theater. It's a doleful ''Our Town,'' populated by some exceptionally unpleasant and excruciatingly uninteresting people. ''There ain't really nothin' here,'' says a character about Jackson, Ind. That seems about right. The central figure in Jim Leonard Jr.'s play is Elizabeth Ann Willow, a young victim of cerebral palsy (Susan Wands in a wheelchair and braces). Why Elizabeth Ann stopped speaking in her mid-20's is the question the play asks and, in a manner of speaking, answers. The heroine makes it plain that she aspires to soar, but she gets no help from anyone, including the playwright.

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 22
description: b-Including a tax credit of $761,000 for the quarter and 9 months and a charge of $5.1 million for the 9 months related to plant consolidations.

title: 2 Italians in Bulgaria In Papal Shooting Case
description: The judge and a prosecutor in the Rome trial over the shooting of the Pope arrived in Sofia today to question two Bulgarian defendants.

title: PLAN ON SELLING F.H.A. IS SAID TO BE REVERSED
description: After extensive criticism from the real estate and construction industries, the Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to withdraw its proposal to sell the Federal Housing Administration to private investors by 1990, Administration officials said today.

title: PLAYWRIGHT REKINDLES TORCH OF NIGERIAN THEATER
description: J. P. Clark leaned against the edge of the stage, his hands pushing against its rough painted planks, his attention riveted by the two actresses rehearsing before him in the half-dark theater. ''Cut! Cut!'' he commanded. ''You are too civilized!'' he said, pointing to one of the two women. ''You are too tame. I want it rough! You are a busybody woman. You are a gossip, a woman around town. ''All right. Cue!'' And the two women began again, rehearsing a scene from Mr. Clark's most recent work, ''Return to Dear Native Land,'' a play that recounts the experiences of a forcibly retired Nigerian civil servant who decides to leave the capital and return to his native village.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Caroling in the Village
description: An evening of caroling through the streets of Greenwich Village tonight begins at 7:30 at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 487 Hudson Street, between Grove and Christopher Streets. Members of the West Village Chorale will lead the carolers on the 90-minute walk. Information: 989-2141.

title: Education for the Disabled Benefits Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: KEAN URGES NEW STRATEGY FOR G.O.P.
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey came here today to offer his landslide re-election victory this year as proof that Republicans can vastly improve their political standing by reaching out to black voters.

title: ROSS COSMETICS DISTRIBUTION CENTERS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
FARAH MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a gain of $7,440,000, or $1.26 a share, from the settlement of litigation.

title: STAGE: 'BEACH HOUSE' AT CIRCLE REPERTORY
description: PRESUMABLY with the holiday spirit in mind, the Circle Repertory Company has chosen to bring its audience a warm, if half-baked, theatrical chestnut. ''The Beach House,'' by Nancy Donohue, is a play about a divorced middle-aged father and troubled adolescent son whose disheveled household needs only the perfect female stranger, bearing love and a vacuum cleaner, to set it right. In different variations - ''The Courtship of Eddie's Father,'' ''A Hole in the Head,'' ''A Thousand Clowns'' - this formula has provided pleasure in the past, and with stars like George Grizzard and Swoosie Kurtz at its disposal, there's no reason why Miss Donohue's slightly updated version shouldn't amiably pass an audience's time now.

title: CRECH PUT UP IN SCARSDALE BY VICTORS IN COURT STRUGGLE
description: The Scarsdale creche was restored today after a five-year absence to Boniface Circle, a tiny public park in the center of this suburban village, culminating a legal struggle over constitutional rights that reached the United States Supreme Court.

title: PRESIDENT WILL SIGN FARM BILLS
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that President Reagan would sign the 1985 farm policy bill and a second bill to assist the troubled Farm Credit System early next week.

title: PROPERTY MARKET HELPS PACE
description: ''MY whole adult life has been in real estate advertising,'' said Milton F. Bagley, the new president of Pace Advertising.

title: Project in Jersey City
description: A $150.3 million tax-exempt bond sale to finance the first phase of housing for Newport City on the Jersey City waterfront was completed this week through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FILM: GERALDINE PAGE IN 'A TRIP TO BOUNTIFUL'
description: IT'S 1947. Carrie Watts is a well-meaning, loving old woman but, as her son, Ludie, and daughter-in-law, Jessie Mae, know from years of experience, living with Carrie in a tiny Houston apartment is no picnic. It's more like a Balkan truce.

title: PETER BOGDANOVICH PETITIONS FOR BANKRUPTCY HELP
description: Peter Bogdanovich, who directed such films as ''Paper Moon,'' ''The Last Picture Show'' and ''Mask,'' has filed for protection under Chapter 7 of Federal bankruptcy laws, William Peiffer, his business manager, said.

title: Market Place;   The Lagging Texas Banks
description: BANK stocks, by and large, have been outstanding market performers this year, thanks to good fundamentals, rising profits and merger activity reflecting the expanding frontiers of interstate banking. The exception has been most banks in Texas, where share prices have trended downward.

title: Oppenheimer Buyout Terms
description: Officials of Oppenheimer Holdings Inc. said yesterday that they would buy 82 percent of their brokerage company from its British parent, Mercantile Holdings Ltd., for $150 million in cash and securities. The British company will retain ownership of Oppenheimer's mutual fund group, which constitutes the bulk of the assets not involved in the deal.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW ARMS OFFER MADE BY MOSCOW
description: The Soviet Union offered today to permit the United States some on-site inspection of nuclear test ranges in return for American participation in a test moratorium.

title: VANBIESBROUCK TAKING ROLE AS RANGER LEADER
description: He learned early last year how to put on the smile. It was to show his teammates that he could take their small jokes smoothly. But John Vanbiesbrouck felt the acid between the lines.

title: REAGAN HEARS AIDS HAS NO. 1 PRIORITY
description: President Reagan was told today that the Government was waging ''an unprecedented effort'' to seek a vaccine for AIDS and that finding methods to counteract the disease was ''the No. 1 priority'' of health officials.

title: 'AMERICA' IS CANCELED
description: The syndicated television program ''America,'' an expensive and ambitious effort to add a mix of information and entertainment to afternoon television, was canceled yesterday because so many stations were dropping the program.

title: FILM: KUROSAWA'S 'RAN'
