description: ''Ran'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared Sept. 27 in The New York Times. The film opens today at Cinema 1, Third Avenue at 60th Street.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1985
description: International

title: Sonatas by Bach
description: Elaine Comparone and Ani Kavafian will perform Bach's six sonatas for harpsichord and violin at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. Tickets are $10. Information: 362-8719.

title: BOARDING SCHOOL EXPELS 7 AFTER RAPE REPORT
description: Seven boys have been expelled from a private boarding school after the local police received a complaint that a student had been raped.

title: NEW BREED SAID TO EMERGE IN ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Years ago, John Franzese is reputed to have done for the Mafia what William Levitt did for would-be homeowners from New York City. Both offered their constituencies the opportunity to put down new roots on Long Island.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $409.4 million, to $208.85 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: A Bach Oratorio
description: The St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra, under the direction of David Randolph, will perform Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio'' at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

title: CUOMO BACKS PROPOSAL TO HOUSE 2,000 FAMILIES
description: The Cuomo administration has given its enthusiastic support to a plan to use private funds to build emergency housing for 2,000 homeless families in New York City.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Economic Scene;   Painful Moves In Steel Go On
description: EVENTS this week have again demonstrated that the steel industry's often painful efforts to become more competitive in order to survive are far from over:

title: Off to Vienna
description: President Reagan has decided to name Ronald S. Lauder, a 41-year-old son of Estee Lauder, the cosmetics manufacturer, as Ambassador to Austria. He has served as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for European and NATO policy since 1983.

title: ETHIOPIAN AID CHIEF SAID TO SEEK ASYLUM IN U.S.
description: The head of the Ethiopian Government's famine relief program, Dawit Wolde Giorgis, was reported yesterday to be seeking asylum in the United States.

title: Minneapolis Sets $70.2 Million Offer
description: Minneapolis is offering $70.2 million of general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 8 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2014, through underwriters led by the Continental Illinois National Bank.

title: THEATER: 'TIME OF YOUR LIFE'
description: WILLIAM SAROYAN was well aware of the mutability of ''The Time of Your Life'' (in revival at the Mirror Repertory Company). Though it is a microcosm of Saroyan country, where sentiment is a constant and where anyone walking through the saloon's swinging door can turn out to be a talented hoofer, pianist or Irish tenor, the play easily takes on various shadings. In a period of nostalgic yearning to go ''back to the future,'' ''The Time of Your Life'' is a breath of fresh idealism.

title: MACY BID CUT $2, TO $68 A SHARE
description: The management of R.H. Macy & Company said yesterday that it was lowering its offer to buy the retailer in a leveraged buyout to $68 a share in cash from $70 a share.

title: Suspect in Bomb Threats
description: A drifter was charged with making more than 50 false bomb threats to Federal and city government buildings in the last two weeks, the District of Columbia police said today. The suspect, identified as Paul Louis Waltz, 33 years old, was arrested Wednesday night near the Smithsonian Mall. The police said they had not determined a ''rational'' motive for the calls.

title: Bellamy Farewell
description: Carol Bellamy said it with Shakespeare.

title: AUCTIONS
description: HENRY MILLER'S original typescript of ''Tropic of Cancer,'' one of the most influential novels of the 20th century, will be auctioned in February at Sotheby's. This typed 926-page version, completed in Paris in 1932-33, is considered as important as a hand-written manuscript, because Miller always wrote directly on the typewriter.

title: BUSINESSES PLAN LESS SPENDING IN '86
description: In what may be an ominous sign for the economy, a Government survey predicted today that American businesses will cut back on investment spending by 1 percent in 1986.

title: JETS' RECORD SLIPS WITH THEIR RUNNERS
description: The Jets' running game, led by Freeman McNeil, is no longer the plowing force it was earlier this season. And the Jets will need to run Sunday against the Cleveland Browns if the wind whips Giants Stadium the way it did when the Jets played the Chicago Bears last Saturday.

title: THEATER OWNERS ASK BOARD TO DELAY LANDMARK STATUS
description: Broadway theater owners and producers last night made a last-minute plea to reverse the designation of three theaters as city landmarks and postpone action for a year on other theaters as well.

title: Quincy's Steak House Moves to Henderson
description: Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., has become the agency for Quincy's Family Steak House, which operates 214 restaurants in seven Southeastern states.

title: A SACKFUL OF HOLIDAY MAGIC TO SHARE WITH CHILDREN
description: AN excited 3-year-old stood up on his seat at a recent performance of ''The Nutcracker'' at Lincoln Center as the curtain rose, and cried out, ''Where is Clara?'' ''Where is Clara?'' The 3-year-old, who was attending his first live performance, had learned the story and characters by heart from his parents and he was eager, as were all the youngsters around him, to see the dancers spring magically to life on the big stage.

title: ART: TRAYLOR DRAWINGS IN SHOWS AT 2 GALLERIES
description: BILL TRAYLOR'S story is pathetically short for a man who lived to be 93. It's been told many times, but it nonetheless bears recapitulation, because the shows now at the Hirschl & Adler Modern and Luise Ross galleries mark only the fourth New York appearance in 43 years by this artist - three of them since 1979. Besides, he's the real thing.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''THERE I was in Boulder, Colo., with the people so in awe of me. Me, a butcher's son,'' said John Reed, O.B.E., sipping at a glass of soda water. ''Then after two months they put me in a convoy, I mean a convoy to the airport. I was a parade, for Heaven's sake!''

title: Money Isn't Economics
description: In Washington, the malaise comes from indecision, a lack of sense of direction in the big international issues. In New York it is financial frenzy, but with the same fear of uncontrolled drift.

title: The Sock Saga, Part II
description: Faithful readers may recall an exploration in this space a fortnight ago of whether Vice President Bush had tried to keep up a sagging sock with a rubber band, despite his Ivy League background. Photographic evidence was disputed by Mr. Bush, who said the White House picture showed a stripe, not an improvised garter, above his ankle.

title: ART: 8 ARTISTS IN 'BETWEEN DRAWING AND SCULPTURE'
description: ''BETWEEN DRAWING AND SCULPTURE'' has a good deal to say about the steps leading to the creation of a work of art.

title: People
description: Michael J. Faulkner named senior vice president at Brouillard Communications, a division of J. Walter Thompson.

title: Roger Maris Comes Home
description: The townspeople and visitors from around the area and those from far away filled the pews, while others stood quietly against the wall of St. Mary's Cathedral here at noon yesterday.

title: JEWEL ACQUISITION
description: ''The Brazilian Princess,'' at 21,327 carats (9 1/2 pounds) the world's largest cut gem, was displayed by Dr. George Harlow, curator of the Mineral Sciences department at the American Museum of Natural History. The near-flawless light blue topaz, found in Brazil 25 years ago in the form of a 75-pound crystal, was delivered to the museum yesterday. It is a gift from an anonymous donor.

title: CONGRESS REACHES IMPASSE ON PLAN TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: The House and the Senate deadlocked early today over a small provision in a three-year, $74 billion deficit-reducing package. This could mean the entire proposal will die as the 99th Congress moves to end its 1985 session.

title: Dawkins Is Fined
description: Darryl Dawkins, the 6-foot-11-inch Nets center, was fined $2,000 yesterday for his fight with Steve Stipanovich, the Indiana Pacer center, during a game Saturday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: IRATE BASQUES SEEK ANSWERS FOR A DEATH
description: The unexplained death of a Basque after the police detained him has renewed friction in Spain's Basque region.

title: Aguirre Clashes With His Coach
description: Mark Aguirre of the Dallas Mavericks refused to re-enter a game tonight against the Atlanta Hawks after a second-quarter incident in which he said he was benched by Coach Dick Motta for coming to the aid of an opponent.

title: FLORENCE ANDERSON
description: Florence Anderson, who was the corporate secretary of the Carnegie Corporation of New York from 1954 to 1975, died of a heart attack Monday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. She was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: What Women Do at Home Is Also Work
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 PROTESTS, 2 PROSECUTORIAL STRATEGIES
description: In the last year more than 2,000 protesters have been arrested at demonstrations outside the South African Embassy, but not one has been prosecuted.

title: S.I. BUILDER BOTHERED BY UTILITY DELAYS
description: It is safe to say that Lucy Conti is the only former graduate student in English at Harvard who is in the home-building business on Staten Island. She decided to go the way of her father, who built houses in Winnepeg, Manitoba, after getting her construction experience building and renovating commercial structures.

title: Romulo Is Buried
description: FormerForeign Minister Carlos P. Romulo was buried today after eulogies from President Ferdinand E. Marcos and representatives of seven foreign governments. More than 1,500 mourners filed into the Cultural Center of the Philippines for funeral services that included a one-minute standing ovation for Mr. Romulo, who died Sunday at the age of 86.

title: U.S. WON'T GO ALONG
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would not join the Soviet moratorium.

title: SOUTH AFRICA RAIDS ANGOLA ANEW
description: South African television said today that the army had mounted a raid into Angola for the third time in recent months, killing at least six Namibian guerrillas and capturing weapons.

title: LAWYER IN '71 FOILED PRISON ESCAPE GAINS IN COURT
description: A judge has dismissed three of five murder counts against Stephen M. Bingham, a lawyer who was charged in a foiled 1971 prison escape from San Quentin prison that left six people dead.

title: THREE ECONOMISTS TELL WHY
description: There is a story told here about the time, 10 years ago, when only three people were out of work in all of Switzerland. All three were sought out by reporters for interviews, but just one would consent and only on condition that his name not be used.

title: E.G. FREEHAFER, LIBRARY DIRECTOR
description: Edward G. Freehafer, director of the New York Public Library from 1954 until 1971, died, of complications from a spinal operation, on Monday at Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Cooperstown.

title: FLYERS REGAIN FORM
description: The Philadelphia Flyers maintained their composure after trailing twice by two goals and completely outplayed the Devils in the last period tonight for a 6-3 triumph at the Spectrum.

title: Requiem at Christmas
description: Nearly 20 years ago in Rappahannock County, Virginia, I built a four-acre pond - perhaps the single most constructive act of my life. The pond improved worn-out land and gave it a new ecology, stopped erosion, guarded against drought, beautified a barren little valley and provided immeasurable recreational values for my family and friends - not to mention habitat for a beaver, then an endangered species in Virginia.

title: Dining Out Guide: Friends In for the Holidays
description: Following is a special guide by food writers of The New York Times suggesting restaurants to take friends who are in for the holidays. THE RIVER CAFE, #1 Water Street, Brooklyn (at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge), (718) 522-5200. The island of Manhattan never looks more magical than during the holiday season, and there is no better place to take it all in than from the River Cafe in Brooklyn.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chuck Long, the Iowa quarterback, was named winner of the Maxwell Award as college football player of the year for 1985. . . . Howard Cosell, who had a year remaining on his contract and who had been scheduled to broadcast the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes and the Tournament of Champions Tennis Classic next year, has asked to be released from those commitments, and ABC Sports has agreed. He will continue to work on ABC's Radio Network.

title: MARTIAL RISKS: AGE, RELIGION
description: Even though society has become far more tolerant in the past 15 years of interfaith marriages and of wide disparities in the ages of spouses, these differences can still create serious problems between the partners themselves. This was the finding of a recent study conducted by sociologists at Brigham Young Unversity in Provo, Utah, and a new report by a psychologist in Berkeley, Calif.

title: HRUDLEY GETS A CHANCE TO REVIVE ISLANDERS
description: Kelly Hrudey sat on the bench as the Islanders' dynasty years hit a zenith in the 1983 playoffs. He sat there again as they waned in 1984. Finally in 1985, the year that confirmed that the dynasty had ended, he emerged as the goalie Bill Smith's successor, and a new generation of Islanders began picking up the pieces of the legacy.

title: A 25-SHOW BINGE ON BROADWAY
description: In a season notable for excess, Broadway offers the ultimate theater binge. In the 14-day period from Sunday through Jan. 4, the inveterate theatergoer can see all 25 Broadway shows.

title: A Wrangle In the Bronx
description: A seemingly clever legal maneuver to help George Steinbrenner avoid a lawsuit has backfired, creating what has turned out to be a tempest in a legal teapot.

title: The Dotted Line
description: Only three of 15 free agents whose clubs offered salary arbitration accepted the offers by the deadline of midnight last night. Danny Darwin of Milwaukee, Richie Hebner of the Chicago Cubs and Tony Perez of Cincinnati agreed to arbitration, meaning they are considered signed, with their salaries to be determined by an arbitrator.

title: Walking a Policy Tightrope on South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN ELECTROMEDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including tax credits of $6,000 for the latest period and $40,000 for the year-ago period.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes $270 million in special charges for the writedown and disposal of selected assets for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Donna Wood Tribute
description: Donna Wood, who retired from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater this season, will be honored in a performance tonight at City Center.

title: BOMBINGS IN SALVADOR APPEAR TO 'BEND THE RULES'
description: The Salvadoran Air Force has attacked at least five villages in rebel-held regions in recent months in what appears to be a violation of Government regulations prohibiting air raids on civilian-occupied areas, according to villagers and evidence of bombing seen by reporters.

title: Paradyne Forms 2 Posts
description: The Paradyne Corporation, a computer maker based in Largo, Fla., said yesterday that it had created two new management positions to strengthen the company's daily operations.

title: GROSS, BACK IN OFFICE, NAMES A DEPUTY FOR ADMINISTRATION
description: A deputy administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration was appointed yesterday to administer the Chief Medical Examiner's office.

title: CHERRY BOWL: YOUNG BUT RICH
description: The importance of corporate sponsorship in support of sports events is delineated by the Cherry Bowl, a game at an unlikely place, Pontiac, Mich., on an unlikely date, four days before Christmas.

title: A BLIND AND DEAF INFANT'S SHORT LIFE ON THE ROLLS OF NEW YORK'S HOMELESS
description: Shamal Jackson was 8 months old and weighed only 7 pounds when he died last May in Beth Israel Medical Center, the luckless baby of a homeless family.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: Simmons Raises Stake in Sea-Land
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, disclosed yesterday that he had increased his stake in the Sea-Land Corporation to 34.8 percent, from 26.2 percent, and that he intended to seek control of the transportation company ''through stock ownership.''

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MTV's Founder Named To Two Key Positions
description: Robert W. Pittman, the young programming executive who thought that rock music videos would work on television and started MTV, the music cable television channel, was named president and chief executive of MTV Networks Inc. yesterday.

title: BABOON HEART IMPLANT IN BABY FAE IN 1984 ASSAILED AS 'WISHFUL THINKING'
description: An attempt 14 months ago to save a dying infant by giving her a baboon heart was doomed to failure and the outlook of her surgical team was tainted by ''wishful thinking,'' according to a new medical review of the case.

title: WORLD DISASTERS INSPIRE GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: An awarenss of a world in need -famine in Africa, earthquakes in Mexico and volcanic eruptions in Colombia - has been cited by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Diner's Journal
description: WHAT Else Is New Department -Union Bank of Switzerland has just published the results of an international survey that compares, among other things, the average price of a restaurant meal in 49 major cities. New York City came out highest in the continental United States and near the top worldwide, edged out only by Tokyo.

title: RADIOACTIVE WASTE BILL PASSES
description: Congress today passed legislation ending a threat by three states to begin shutting down the nation's ony dumps for radioactive waste.

title: 'MUST DOS' FOR CHINESE: 1. FOLLOW ALL THE LISTS
description: If you are a young man about town in China these days it can mean a lot to have the ''three highs.'' If you have got the ''eight big things,'' so much the better.

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
College Volunteerism Lives On in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan-Pakistani Talks Recess on U.N. Plan
description: Afghanistan and Pakistan suspended their latest round of peace talks today to study new United Nations proposals aimed at fixing a timetable for withdrawal of Soviet troops backing the Afghan Government.

title: ANDY WILLIAMS SPECIAL
description: SO far, we've had Perry Como in Hawaii, Johnny Cash at the Grand Ole Opry and Kenny Rogers and Dolly Parton together on scattered locations, just to mention a few of the Christmas specials on television in the last couple of weeks. Grouches may have reached a saturation point as far as seasonal caroling is concerned, but the music keeps playing as producers continue to seek out appropriate settings for the performances.

title: A CHRISTMAS PIED PIPER ON AVENUE C
description: Joseph Pupello was working in his garden plot on Ninth Street and Avenue C one day late last summer when a little boy named Junior stopped by to investigate Mr. Pupello's peach tree. Junior left, then returned to show the tree to several friends. It wasn't an uncommon occurrence. And Mr. Pupello found himself thinking once more about the often aimless lives of the ''Juniors'' of the Lower East Side, where he grew up, still lives and now directs and choreographs for the Manhattan Performance Ensemble.

title: HOSTAGES SEIZED AT FRENCH TRIAL
description: An armed man described as a Palestinian guerrilla burst into a courtroom here today and, together with four defendants on trial for robbery, took the judge, jurors and a number of trial observers as hostages.

title: AN ARMY THAT MARCHES ON MUSIC AND PRAYER
description: You tend to rush by them in the frenzy of holiday shopping: Uniformed bell-ringers and horn-blowers standing round a kettle for contributions. Perhaps you throw in a dollar - Salvation Army, good cause. Eye contact is not likely, let alone stopping to wonder who these people are.

title: CONTRACTOR SAYS HEAD OF UNION MADE THREAT
description: A building contractor testified yesterday that Ralph Scopo, a former concrete workers' union president who is accused of extortion, told him in 1981 that he would have to ''go down to Little Italy and sit with three or four guys with thick necks'' if he did not pay off Mr. Scopo.

title: PHILIPPINE ELECTIONS GET SUPREME COURT APRROVAL
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a presidential election set for Feb. 7 should go ahead despite doubts about its constitutionality. But opposition politicians said they still believed President Ferdinand E. Marcos had several other options for stopping the election should he fear he might lose.

title: Black Shoppers Boycott Ordinance on Parks
description: Many black shoppers are boycotting merchants and cutting into Christmas business in this predominantly white Detroit suburb to protest an ordinance that bars nonresidents from most town parks.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income after a loss of $169,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESTORS SBI reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $5,643,000, or $1.99 a share, for the latest year and $501,000, or 17 cents a share, for the previous year.

title: American Express
description: The American Express Company said it plans to increase the capital of two units, American Express Bank Ltd. and IDS/American Express Inc. The bank would get $175 million to develop business opportunities and IDS would get $65 million to expand its financial planning business.

title: Plan to Relax Antitrust Laws
description: White House officials said today that President Reagan would accept a Cabinet recommendation that the Administration ask Congress to soften Federal antitrust law in ways intended to make American industry more competitive in international markets.

title: JUDGE IN JERSEY, CITING RACE BIAS, VOIDS FIREFIGHTERS' PROMOTION TEST
description: A Federal District Court judge today ruled invalid promotional examinations for the ranks of fire captain and fire lieutenant that were given by the New Jersey Civil Service Commission in 12 major municipalities.

title: MICROAGE INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Protest in West Germany
description: The police arrested 23 anti-nuclear protesters and impounded a dog that bit an officer at a demonstration today at the site where the first West German plant for reprocessing nuclear waste is to be built.

title: Met Opera Association Elects New President
description: Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey was elected president of the Metropolitan Opera Association at a board meeting at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. She is the first woman to hold the post.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 10:47 A.M. today and set at 11:01 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Jailed Irish Guerrilla Begins Hunger Strike
description: An Irish guerrilla jailed for murder refused food today, beginning what is expected to be a new wave of hunger strikes in this British province.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
EDUCATOR IN '44 TEXAS DISPUTE
description: Homer Price Rainey, who was ousted as president of the University of Texas in 1944 after protesting actions by the Board of Regents that he said limited academic freedom, died yesterday in Boulder, Colo., where he made his home. He was 89 years old.

title: Richard Pryor Interviewed On 'Only in America'
description: Because the comedian and actor Richard Pryor's abuse of drugs and other details of his life have been well publicized, and because stars have turned their excesses and other defects into a lucrative confessional industry, there is little in the way of novelty or interest in the interview with Mr. Pryor to be broadcast tomorrow on Channel 2 at 7:30 P.M.

title: OPEN AIR MARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 17
description: The company notes that results for the latest periods included six supermarkets acquired in April 1985.

title: TRAIN ENGINEERS IN TENTATIVE PACT
description: The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers reached a tentative settlement with the nation's major railroads Wednesday on a contract providing 25,000 union members with pay increases averaging 10.5 percent over two and a half years.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 7.

title: Senate Agrees To Tax Delay
description: The Senate agreed today that any changes in the nation's tax laws resulting from pending legislation should take effect no earlier than Jan. 1, 1987. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, one of the main sponsors of the nonbinding resolution, said he was ''concerned that a chilling effect would take place in our economy'' causing the loss of ''tens of thousands of jobs'' as businesses and taxpayers delay crucial economic decisions until Congress completes action on tax revision.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1985
description: Companies

title: ALLIES PLEASED BY SHULTZ VISIT TO EAST EUROPE
description: Senior officials in several Western European countries have privately welcomed Secretary of State George P. Shultz's nine-day trip to three Eastern European countries as a step toward a more active and differentiated American approach to the area.

title: 9 LINKED TO MAFIA ARE ACCUSED OF BILKING LEGITIMATE BUSINESSES
description: Nine reputed Mafia members were indicted yesterday in a complex conspiracy that involved infiltrating legitimate businesses, including some of the most established corporations in the United States, and defrauding them of millions of dollars.

title: Dow Up 1.49 as 'Witching Hour' Nears
description: The stock market yesterday ended its two-day decline, but just barely, as investors anxious over today's expiration of index options and futures bid prices up only a bit.

title: CONCERT: COMPOSERS LEAGUE
description: IN any potpourri contemporary-music concert, the mind and ear search for thematic connections that aren't there, straining under the onslaught of sometimes interesting but otherwise unrelated works. That grumbled, the concert of new British and American music presented Tuesday night at Symphony Space by the Chamber Players of the League/ISCM (International Society of Contemporary Music) had much to offer. No one program could hope to survey either country, or suggest plausible similarities and dissimilarities. But as a grab bag, there was much to grab.

title: SHULTZ DEPLORES FORCING OFFICIALS TO TAKE LIE TESTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he had ''grave reservations'' about polygraph tests and would resign ''the minute in this Government I am told that I'm not trusted.''

title: Rangers Trade Rogers
description: The Rangers traded the center Mike Rogers to the Edmonton Oilers yesterday for Larry Melnyk, a defenseman, and Todd Strueby, a left wing.

title: KNICKS CAN'T STOP TURPIN
description: After Tuesday's game in which Patrick Ewing more than held his own against Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, last night's matchup against Mel Turpin, the 6-foot-11-inch Cleveland Cavalier center, figured to be easier for Ewing.

title: Stenerud to Retire
description: He was one of the early soccer-style place-kickers, and in 19 professional seasons he has 373 field goals, more than any other player in National Football League history.

title: Siemens Fined
description: The European Commission said that it had fined Siemens A.G. of West Germany and a Japanese supplier $840,000 for monopolizing the European machine-tool control market.

title: What the Soviet Poet Said
description: Whatever his merits as a poet, Yevgeny Yevtushenko's political ear is highly developed. A brilliant polemicist, he expresses the ideals of the Soviet Union's post-Stalin generation at shrewdly calculated moments of opportunity. When he and other writers dare to escalate their cry for freer speech, they stage a political event of major importance.

title: Shultz Names a Committee To Advise on South Africa
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today announced the appointment of a 12-member committee to advise him on policy toward South Africa. It is headed by Frank Cary, former I.B.M. chairman, and William T. Coleman, former Transportation Secretary.

title: CONVENTION CENTER GETS 'LABOR CRAZE'
description: The dean of the Fordham University School of Law was chosen yesterday as the impartial arbitrator for labor disputes at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Upjohn in Filing On Baldness Cure
description: The Upjohn Company asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve sale of Regaine Topical Solution, a formula that the company believes cures baldness in some men.

title: Students in Peking Protest Army Presence on Campus
description: About 1,500 students, defying Government warnings, demonstrated at Agricultural University against the housing of an Army unit on campus, lax security and bad food, a campus official said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WILLIAM MARSHAL. The Flower of Chivalry. By Georges Duby. Translated from the French by Richard Howard. 155 pages. Pantheon. $15.95 WILLIAM MARSHAL was born around the year 1145, the son and grandson of men who had been household officials - marshals, in fact - at the Plantagenet court. If his name means little or nothing today, except to students of the period, he was a person of great importance in his time. A staunch supporter of Henry II and his heirs, he rose from his relatively obscure origins to become first a celebrated knight, and then one of the most powerful noblemen in the realm.

title: Giants Accenting the Positive
description: Had the Giants beaten the Dallas Cowboys last Sunday, they would have clinched a wild-card playoff berth and all but clinched their division title. In that case, the game here Saturday against the Pittsburgh Steelers would have meant much less.

title: The Tax-Exempt Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Houston Rockets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Nets' second and final game against the Rockets and the only regular-season visit to the Meadowlands for Houston's twin towers of Akeem Olajuwon and Ralph Sampson. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7:30 P.M.) Cleveland Cavaliers vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Richfield, Ohio. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Colleges: Staten Island at Lehman, 8 P.M.; John Jay vs. Baruch, at Xavier High School, 30 West 16th Street, 4 P.M.; Virginia Commonwealth vs. Richmond and Virginia vs. Old Dominion, Times-Dispatch Tournament, opening round, at Richmond. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M.) Football Seahawks vs. Denver Broncos, at Seattle. The Broncos (10-5) need a victory to have a chance at a wild-card playoff berth; the Seahawks (8-7) are out of contention. A Bronco loss would insure a playoff spot for the Jets. (Television -Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:50 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Islanders, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. Their fourth meeting this season, and the Islanders lead the season series, 2-1. The teams play again tomorrow night in Nassau Coliseum. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 7:30 P.M.) Tennis Sweden vs. West Germany, Davis Cup final, at Munich, opening-round singles. Mats Wilander, the French Open champion, was drawn yesterday to play Michael Westphal of West Germany as Sweden begins defense of its title in the three-of-five-match series. The second singles will match West Germany's Boris Becker, the Wimbledon champion, and Stefan Edberg, the Australian Open champion.

title: Why Cuomo Named Titone to Appeals Seat
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: KENNEDY, CITING SENATE GOALS, RULES OUT '88 PRESIDENTIAL BID
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for President in a bitter contest in 1980, announced this evening that he would not try again in 1988.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Announced that Geoff Zahn and Ken Forsch, pitchers, will not be offered new contracts. Reached a three-year agreement with the Palm Springs Angels.

title: TROOPS WELCOME SWITCH TO U.S. JETS FOR TRIP HOME
description: Some of the American soldiers who returned from the Middle East peacekeeping unit today expressed relief at having been flown home on Air Force cargo planes instead of on a chartered jet like the one that crashed in Newfoundland last week, killing 248 fellow soldiers.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $117,000.

title: U.S. SAYS CAR CRASH SHOWS SANDINISTA ARMS FLOW
description: The Reagan Administration said today that a recent traffic accident in Honduras had turned up strong evidence that cars with secret compartments were being used to move military supplies from Nicaragua to Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: MURDER CONVICTION REVERSED
description: The state's top court overturned a murder conviction today because the prosecutor in the case asked the chief defense witness why he would not swear to God to tell the truth.

title: ALBANY HIGH COURT LETS MALLS RESTRICT LEAFLETING
description: Shopping malls are not public places where citizens are free to distribute politically related pamphlets as they please, the state's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: Money & Politics Inc. Is Gunning for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On Presidential Elections;   Debates Shouldn't Be Campaign Mantras
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue figures represent gross revenues.

title: A RISE IS CRIME THREATENS BEIRUT'S FRAGILE CALM
description: Militiamen are off the streets, the resumption of public bus service has added to traffic snarls and although West Beirut is the Moslem part of the Lebanese capital, Christmas shopping there is brisk. But at the same time in West Beirut, the latest security plan is seriously challenged by a rising crime wave and continuing factional tensions.

title: A BALL WHERE ONLY THE PEOPLE WERE REAL
description: It was with difficulty that Donald Sanders made himself heard over the rustling of plastic.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Hospital Is Approved On Heart Transplants
description: The heart-transplant program at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan was approved yesterday by the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council.

title: FEDERATED GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
REDLAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a $439,000 extraordinary gain.

title: BIG BOARD AND AMEX SHORT INTEREST SET RECORDS
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest soared 14.9 percent, or 39.1 million shares, in the month ended Dec. 13, to a record 301.9 million shares. The previous high of 262.8 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 220.7 million shares.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Including a pretax gain fo $2,304,000 for the quarter and year on the sale of a building and a tax credit of $1,661,000 for the quarter and year.

title: SCREEN: 'ENEMY MINE'
description: THIS season's ''Dune'' is ''Enemy Mine,'' a costly, awful-looking science-fiction epic with one of the weirdest story lines ever to hit the screen. The poster for ''Enemy Mine'' may look slightly facetious, what with Dennis Quaid locked in a profile shot with what appears to be a giant lizard, as the man and the lizard exchange confrontational stares. However, this image is completely in earnest. What's worse, it represents the movie perfectly. There is indeed a lizardlike character in the movie, played by Louis Gossett Jr., who has what is unquestionably one of the most thankless roles in movie history. Not only does Mr. Gossett spend the entire film wrapped in scales, but he must also die in childbirth, which can hardly have been an easy thing for an actor to do.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT will be a combination of the old and the new this summer when the spanking new Marquis Theater in the Marriott Marquis Hotel opens with a musical featuring ''The Lambeth Walk,'' a hit song and dance of the late 1930's.

title: U.S. AND ISRAEL FAIL TO ISSUE STATEMENT ON SPY CASE
description: A last-minute hitch late Thursday night prevented American investigators and Israeli officials from issuing a joint communique effectively closing the Washington spy scandal case and expressing the United States' full satisfaction with Israeli cooperation, senior Israeli Government sources said today.

title: Chrysler Discloses Spending Plans
description: The Chrysler Corporation will spend $3.4 billion on new-product programs in 1986, a record amount, Lee A. Iacocca, the company's chairman, said in a statement. Mr. Iacocca also said he expected final 1985 figures to show that the company had sold more than two million cars and trucks in North America and increased its market share to 12.2 percent, from 11.4 percent in 1984.

title: Poll Indicates Majority Favor Quarantine for AIDS Victims
description: A majority of Americans favor the quarantine of AIDS patients, and some would embrace measures as drastic as using tattoos to mark those with the deadly disorder, according to a poll published today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Burlington Northern Inc., Seattle, has appointed Christopher T. Bayley president and chief executive of the Glacier Park Co., which manages its U.S. real estate operations.

title: Rates Slip in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday in quiet trading, as credit market participants waited for clear signs of the Federal Reserve's intentions and today's estimate of gross national product for the fourth quarter.

title: The Reason for Everything
description: Once in a while an ailment comes along that sorts out your life, clarifies mysteries and leaves you feeling better about yourself. More often than not it is self-diagnosed.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EXCERPTS FROM COURT OF APPEALS OPINIONS ON PASSING PAMPHLETS IN MALLS
description: Following are excerpts from the majority decision and the dissenting opinion of the New York State Court of Appeals in the ruling permitting shopping malls to enforce limits on distributing politically oriented pamphlets.

title: Hinton's Snapshots
description: When he wasn't playing bass during his 50-year career, the jazz musician Milt Hinton was snapping photographs of colleagues.

title: CHRISTMAS TREASURES JUST AROUND THE CORNER
description: THERE are tiny tin soldiers on Fifth Avenue and towering puppets in the World Trade Center, herbal wreaths in Fort Tryon and pink poinsettias in the Bronx. If you've already seen ''The Magnificent Christmas Spectacular'' at Radio City, the traditional tree at Rockefeller Center and ''The Nutcracker'' at the New York State Theater, rest assured that there are still many enclaves of Christmas cheer to be found in the city.

title: 7 Suburbs of Chicago Sued by U.S. on Rights
description: The Justice Department filed a suit today against seven nearly all-white Chicago suburbs, charging they had imposed discriminatory residency requirements on job applicants to keep blacks out of municipal jobs.

title: DOHR IS REJECTED BY A BAR PANEL
description: Bernardine Dohrn, the 43-year-old former leader of the Weather Underground, has been rejected for admission to the New York bar, her lawyer said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Chevron Finishes Deal on Stations
description: Completing a previously announced deal, the Chevron Corporation and Cumberland Farms Inc. signed an agreement under which Cumberland will buy 500 company-owned Gulf and Chevron service stations in 10 states in the Northeast and Middle Atlantic regions. Cumberland, a convenience store chain based in Canton, Mass., will also acquire supply contracts for 3,400 independently owned Gulf and Chevron stations, and 20 distribution terminals in those states.

title: Yes, by Liberal Jews
description: As I review the year since 26,000 Israelis voted that I be their Knesset representative, I am overwhelmed, even as the polls show a dramatic increase in my strength, by the sheer magnitude of the frenzied hatred of the liberal-intellectual mob. Old witch hunters never die. They return in the form of Israeli and American Jewish liberals, news media people, politicians, intellectuals, Reform rabbis and presidents of Jewish organizations.

title: Antifertility Hormone Found
description: The discovery of a hormone that inhibits fertility may lead to a male birth control pill and perhaps give a clue to some unexplained cases of infertility, a scientist said today.

title: FIRST WOMAN RECEIVES AN ARTIFICIAL HEART IMPLANT
description: Mary Lund of Kensington, Minn., became the first woman to receive an artificial heart early today.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and after a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $7,615,000 from the sale of the company's Englewood Cliffs, N.J., property.

title: SERVAMATIC SOLAR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: AVON TO SELL MALLINCKRODT
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Mallinckrodt division to the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation for $675 million, thus virtually completing its divestiture program.

title: STOCKING STUFFER
description: A copy of the tax bill is snugly tucked into the bright red Christmas stocking hanging in the office of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who managed to guide the tax measure through the House this week.

title: PROSECUTOR WEIGHING NEW TRIAL FOR EDWARDS
description: A Federal prosecutor said today that he would probably seek to retry Gov. Edwin W. Edwards on racketeering and fraud charges in spite of his failure to convince most jurors of his guilt in the first trial.

title: JUDGE BARS U.S. PLEA FOR SECRECY IN SUIT OVER BUDGET OFFICE DELAY
description: A Federal judge has rejected an effort by the Reagan Administration to bar public distribution of a legal complaint that asserts the Office of Management and Budget unlawfully delayed the issuing of environmental rules.

title: LOSS FOR CURTISS-WRIGHT
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation has sold its remaining 3.9 million shares of the Western Union Corporation in a transaction that Curtiss-Wright said would result in a $53 million after-tax loss in the fourth quarter.

title: FRENCH APPEALS COURT RULING DELAYS BARBIE TRIAL
description: France's highest appeals court today overturned a lower-court ruling that prevented Klaus Barbie from being charged with some crimes committed during the Nazi occupation of France. The decision in effect postponed the trial of Mr. Barbie, a former Nazi SS captain, until after the French parliamentary elections in March.

title: Franzese Gives Up To Florida Aides
description: Michael J. Franzese, a reputed Mafia member who was indicted Thursday on Federal racketeering charges, surrended to law-enforcement officials in Florida late yesterday afternoon, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: 4 Vacant Buildings To Become Shelter
description: The city has sold four vacant apartment buildings in Harlem to a community group that will turn them into emergency shelter for 100 homeless families, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: BIG MEN STAND OUT AS NETS TRIUMPH
description: The Nets presented their own version of the Houston Rockets' twin towers tonight.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We end the year on a rather dismal note. We have done very little to reduce the deficit.

title: AIM TELEPHONES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $79,000 for the quarter and $111,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $28,000 for the quarter and $56,000 for the 9 months.

title: DON'T TELL THE NEWSPAPERS YOUR AGE
description: ''How old would you be if you didn't know how old you were?''

title: Long-Term Treatment By Implanted Drugs
description: A safe and efficient controlled drug release system is the subject of patent 4,559,054, granted this week to Dr. Stephen D. Bruck, a medical scientist in Rockville, Md.

title: THE FRONTIER OF DEATH
description: THE SERPENT & THE RAINBOW. By Wade Davis. 297 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. It's immediately clear that Wade Davis, the author of ''The Serpent & the Rainbow'' - an account of his research in Haiti - fancies himself some kind of real-life Indiana Jones. He makes a point of interrupting his narrative to tell us that he went to see ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' at a local movie theater in Haiti; and the ''about the author'' note accompanying his book does its best to play up the parallels. ''During his many expeditions,'' the note from Simon & Schuster reads, Mr. Davis ''was initiated into secret rites and ceremonies traditionally off-limits to whites; was caught in gunfire between soldiers and guerrillas; was mistaken for a Dutch gunrunner; he ate a lunch of fresh termites with warriors in loincloths; got lost among the Jivaro, the famed headhunters; flew an aging wreck of a DC-3 over the Andes when the pilot was hung over. He has survived high fevers, hepatitis, malaria and pains, ills, and diseases barely known in the so-called civilized world.''

title: Arrest Warrant Issued In Copter Prison Escape
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today charged Joyce L. Bailey, a former textile worker, with air piracy and extended a search nationwide for her and three convicts she lifted from a prison yard with a helicopter.

title: THEATER RETURNS TO LINCOLN CENTER
description: Theater officially returns to Lincoln Center on Monday, ending eight years of almost complete darkness, with two works by one of the most familiar and renowned contemporary playwrights, David Mamet.

title: GUNMEN RELEASE HOSTAGES UNHARMED IN FRANCE
description: Three gunmen who turned a robbery trial into a 34-hour hostage drama here surrendered to the police tonight.

title: Cabbage Patch in Brooklyn
description: A box addressed to the administrator of the pediatric department arrived the other day at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center at Linden Boulevard and Rockaway Parkway in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. It was filled with 72 original Cabbage Patch Kids.

title: MANY CONTRIBUTING TO THE NEEDIEST CITE THEIR DESIRE TO SHARE
description: A desire to share their good fortune to help ease the plight of the homeless, the hungry, the ill and the despairing has brought an outpouring of contributions to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: British Plan Would Strip Drug Offenders of Gains
description: The British Government today published details of proposed legislation to strip drug traffickers of their fortunes in Britain and overseas.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Reading, Writing, Sharing
description: In the aging classrooms of Notre Dame Academy here, a few blocks from the Capitol, dozens of elementary school students gather two nights a week to improve their reading, math and vocabulary skills with the help of an unlikely group of volunteer tutors.

title: CONGRESS LEAVES WITH NO MEASURE ON CUTTING DEFICIT
description: A weary and depleted Congress ended its 1985 session this evening after failing to approve a three-year, $74 billion deficit-reducing package.

title: Man Held in Phone Threats
description: Paul L. Waltz, 33 years old, has been charged with making telephone bomb threats this month that caused thousands of Federal workers to be evacuated, although no bombs were found, the authorities said today.

title: AS STAMFORD RIDERS SHIVER, NEW STATION AWAITS REPAIRS
description: With a 15-ton sculpture planned for the new railroad station here, a city engineer tested the floor beams to make sure they could support such monumental artwork.

title: New Job ReportedFor Andropov's Son
description: The son of Yuri V. Andropov, the former Soviet leader, has been appointed an ambassador at large and will work with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, a ministry official said.

title: Swiss Triumphs In Giant Slalom
description: Ending a four-year dry spell, Joel Gaspoz of Switzerland won a World Cup giant slalom ski race today.

title: VERDICT IS UPHELD IN NASSAU CASE
description: A Federal judge has upheld a jury's verdict that the Nassau County Republican Committee violated the constitutional rights of county workers by requiring them to contribute 1 percent of their salaries to get promotions and raises.

title: KISCLOSURES IN SUIT DRAW REBUKE
description: A lawyer who admitted disclosing information about Senator Paul Laxalt's libel case against McClatchy Newspapers has been chastised by a Federal magistrate who said she was becoming concerned about a fair trial.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Announced that Milt Wilcox, pitcher, will not be offered a contract for the 1986 season.

title: LIMA, UNDER SIEGE, SETS ITS SIGHTS ON KIDNAPPERS
description: With a .357 Magnum revolver in his shoulder-holster and a shotgun on his desk, Edgard Rivera sat in front of two television monitors watching clients enter his weapons store.

title: EX-AIDE TO STEELWORKER UNION
description: Meyer Bernstein, a former director of international affairs for the United Steelworkers of America, drowned Dec. 10 on a visit to Miami Beach, according to Dade County officials. He was 71 years old and lived in Brussels, Belgium.

title: SAMUEL J. BOYLE 3d EX-EDITOR FOR THE PHILADELPHIA BULLETIN
description: Samuel J. Boyle 3d, a newspaper reporter and editor in Philadelphia, died today at a hospital where he had undergone surgery for removal of a cancerous tumor. He was 65 years old.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,028,000 for the quarter and 6 months. Results for the latest periods include operations of a subsidiary which was consolidated as of June 1. Results for year-ago periods have not been adjusted.

title: BOND PRICES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, after the Federal Reserve temporarily bought securities and added reserves to the banking system for the second consecutive day. The Fed's actions heightened speculation that the central bank would soon announce a cut in the discount rate it charges on loans to financial institutions.

title: CUBAN DEFECTOR DISCUSSES FUNDS
description: A Cuban defector who was the target of a Cuban kidnapping attempt here said in a published interview today that he collected nearly $500,000 in ''commissions'' in his Government job before fleeing Cuba.

title: American Airlines Reduces Fares
description: American Airlines, in a move to stimulate traffic in the January doldrums, said yesterday that it would cut fares by up to 74 percent from regular coach fares for travel between Jan. 8 and Feb. 10. The discount fares, which have several restrictions, basically restore the so-called ultimate super saver fares to the levels of a year ago, when they were first introduced.

title: COLOMBO JURY HEARS TAPE OF '83 CONVERSATION ABOUT PAYMENTS
description: A Federal jury yesterday heard a taped conversation in which Ralph Scopo, a former union leader accused of extorting money from contractors, discussed payments with reputed leaders of the Colombo crime organization.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1985
description: International

title: LIFETIME COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $290,900 for the quarter and year. c-Including tax credits of $70,953 for the quarter and $244,953 for the year.

title: A Street That Never Was
description: How do you get to Verrazano Street?

title: THE SELLING OF CARS TO WOMEN
description: Ford has tried wine and cheese parties. Chevrolet established a special marketing committee and advertising strategy. A Toyota dealer in California set up a special office to handle inquiries and complaints. All to draw women into their showrooms to buy their cars.

title: THRIFT UNIT BRANCH PLAN
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board proposed today to give interstate branching powers to savings and loan associations that buy insolvent savings institutions.

title: Kurri: 4 Goals; Gretzky: 6 Assists
description: Jari Kurri scored four goals, including two short-handed, and Wayne Gretzky had six assists to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 9-4 victory over Los Angeles tonight.

title: A Warnaco Buyout Backed
description: Warnaco Inc., one of the nation's largest apparel companies, said yesterday that its independent directors had approved a merger proposal from RLL Inc., a group of private investors headed by Warnaco's senior management.

title: JUDGE ROGER ROBB OF U.S. APPEALS COURT DIES
description: Judge Roger Robb, an appointee of President Nixon who served 13 years on the United States Court of Appeals here, died at his home Thursday. He was 78 years old.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bridge;   Play in the Winter Regional Begins in New York Today
description: The last tournament of the year for enthusiasts in the New York metropolitan area begins today at the Sheraton Centre, 53d Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: THE ARCTIC DIVISION
description: They try to pretend that it's not that cold. But they know it is.

title: GIANTS' FATE MAY BE DECIDED
description: The Giants will play their last regular-season game Saturday, and if things go wrong it could be their last game of the season, period.

title: Hockey Crackdown
description: Wielding a big stick of his own, the National Hockey League's executive vice president, Brian O'Neill, handed out three suspensions for stick-swinging yesterday that totaled 20 games. Glenn Anderson, the Edmonton Oiler wing, was assessed an eight-game suspension, effective immediately.

title: M.T.A. VOTES FREE RIDES FOR HOLIDAY
description: In an effort to keep drunken drivers off the road, rides on subways, buses and Staten Island and Metro-North trains will be free on New Year's Eve, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority decided yesterday.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS CORPORATION-HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ISRAELIS DROP SPY UNIT, U.S. SAYS
description: The State Department said today that Israel had dismantled the unit that directed the activities of Jonathan Jay Pollard, a United States Navy analyst accused of stealing hundreds of pages of classified documents.

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
'THE MUSE' BY BRANCUSI RETURNS TO GUGGENHEIM
description: ''The Muse,'' a marble sculpture by Brancusi that was removed from the Guggenheim Museum by deputy sheriffs under court order 14 years ago, is now back in the museum's possession - this time, for keeps. The museum, which had lost a legal wrangle over ownership of the work, had to pay more than $2 million to reacquire it. But that hasn't dampened the elation of Thomas M. Messer, the Guggenheim's director, who kept track of ''The Muse'' and moved quickly when it came up for sale.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a housing plan for the homeless misstated Leonard N. Stern's relationship to The Village Voice. Mr. Stern owns it; David Schneiderman is publisher and editor in chief.

title: PLANE IN GANDER CRASH WAS IN 3 EARLIER INCIDENTS
description: The DC-8 jetliner that crashed in Newfoundland last week was involved in an incident four years ago in which problems with the cabin-pressure system forced the pilot to make a rapid descent for an unscheduled landing in Denver.

title: FOUNDER OF APPAREL CONCERN
description: Jack M. Ruby, an apparel industry leader and former chairman of Jaymar-Ruby Inc., died Wednesday in a nursing home in Michigan City, Ind. He was 93 years old.

title: NEW SECRETARY FIGHTS MEDICARE CUTS
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the new Secretary of Health and Human Services, has in his first days on the job moved toward a major confrontation with the Office of Management and Budget over proposals to cut Medicare and other domestic social programs.

title: BECKER'S VICTORY TIES SERIES
description: Boris Becker defeated Stefan Edberg, 6-3, 3-6, 7-5, 8-6, tonight to enable West Germany to salvage a split of their opening singles matches against Sweden after the first day of the Davis Cup tennis final.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Marshall University has hired George Chaump as its new head football coach, getting him to leave his post at Indiana University of Pennsylvania after four years. Chaump, who compiled a 24-16-1 record at the Pennsylvania school, was hired for four years to replace Stan Parrish, who left for Kansas State. . . . The Yankees have assigned the contracts of Keith Smith, an infielder, and Alfonso Pulido, a pitcher, to their top farm club at Columbus, Ohio, and reduced their roster to 38 players. Both were with the Clippers last season, Smith hitting .241 and Pulido posting an 11-8 record. . . . A state appeals court in New Orleans has cleared the way for a new trial for John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane basketball star accused of taking money to shave points in two games last season. , . . Freddie Solomon, the San Francisco 49er wide receiver, says he will retire after the season.

title: EDWARDS A. G. & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods reflect costs for indirect computer conversion and additional provision for doubtful accounts.

title: 21 Followers of Guru Face Conpiracy Charges
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted 21 followers of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh on conspiracy charges, accusing them of illegally tapping telephone lines and planting microphones in rooms at the guru's Oregon commune.

title: No Need to Send Out a Call For Snowplowers
description: Our valiant snowplowers were at their annual Sanitation Department Snow Operations office Christmas party yesterday afternoon when, on hearing the weather forecast, Commissioner Norman Steisel declared a snow alert.

title: MINERS CALL END TO COAL WALKOUT
description: The president of the United Mine Workers of America announced today the end of the union's 15-month strike against the A. T. Massey Coal Company, one of the longest and most bitter labor disputes in the union's history.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect subsequent stock dividends.

title: 3 Men Indicted In Cathedral Theft
description: Three men, including a former custodial employee of St. Patrick's Cathedral, were indicted yesterday for the Nov. 30 robbery at the cathedral in which $7,000 was stolen.

title: LAXALT'S AFFAIRS IN NEVADA COMING UNDER CLOSE SCRUTINY IN HIS LIBEL SUIT
description: Senator Paul Laxalt's affairs are coming under close scrutiny as part of the pretrial process in a $250 million libel suit the Nevada Senator has brought against McClatchy Newspapers.

title: ARTHUR W. J. BEENEY
description: Arthur W. J. Beeney, former executive director of the Beekman-Downtown Hospital, died of emphysema Dec. 12 at Imperial Point Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in Davie, Fla.

title: 6 Seek RefugeAt Embassy in Albania
description: Six Albanian brothers and sisters have taken refuge in the Italian Embassy in Tirana, the Albanian capital, and an Italian newspaper said today that they had threatened to take poison if they are turned over to the Communist authorities.

title: FED POLICY STABLE LAST MONTH
description: The Federal Reserve's chief monetary policy-making body, led by the chairman, Paul A. Volcker, voted last month for no change in policy, the Fed reported today. However, one Fed governor, Martha Seger, dissented, recommending an easier policy, a summary of the Nov. 4-5 meeting said.

title: STRESS ON THE JOB BECOMES BIG BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Return of Dr. Gross
description: Mayor Koch insists that ''fairness'' and the ''best interests'' of New York City dictate sending Dr. Elliot Gross back to work as Chief Medical Examiner. The Mayor is not persuasive.

title: SUCCESSFOR BEARS OFF THE FIELD TOO
description: We are the Bears Shufflin' Crew Shufflin' on down, doing it for you. We're not here to start no trouble, We're just here to do the Super Bowl shuffle.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ONLY THE BRITISH The British have a history of making movies that make audiences laugh. This weekend, a series of more than 50 British film comedies and musicals, from the late 1920's to the 1980's, starts at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: TAR HEELS WIN, 89-55
description: The guard Ranzino smith scored 15 points and sparked an 18-0 run midway through the first half tonight as North Carolina beat Stanford, 89-55.

title: Iraq Said to Ask U.N. To Stop Attack by Iran
description: Iraq reportedly asked the United Nations today to help stop an expected Iranian offensive, while Iran's President criticized Moscow and said there could be no peace with Iraq's current leaders.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1985
description: The Economy

title: KENNEDY MOVE SAID TO BOOST CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo has emerged as a major contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination following Senator Edward M. Kennedy's decision not to run, state and national politicians said yesterday.

title: CHAMBER: KEITH JARRET
description: Keith Jarrett was the principal guest of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, accompanying the clarinetist Richard Stolzman in a most stylish and persuasive performance of a Bach sonata (BWV 1028), originally for viola da gamba, and presenting a new piece of his own.

title: 'Nature Stops Experimenting and Creates a Man'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Splitting the M.A.C. Difference
description: The sole original purpose of New York State's Municipal Assistance Corporation, spawned in the 1975 fiscal crisis, was to stave off New York City's creditors when its own paper was as unwelcome as a jury summons. The cash to service the M.A.C.'s own bonds comes from taxes collected in New York City, especially sales taxes.

title: REQUIEM FOR THE DIME
description: Raising the subway fare from 90 cents to $1 will provoke the ire of millions of disgruntled commuters. But what no one has stopped to consider is that it will also seriously limit our contact with dimes.

title: KAPPA NETWORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New TV Pact for N.B.A.
description: The National Basketball Association and the CBS network reached agreement yesterday on a new four-year television contract worth $173 million. The pact, which takes effect next season, almost doubles the $88 million, four-year pact that will end after this season.

title: Police Station Shelled In Northern Ireland
description: Guerrillas fired mortar shells at a village police station near the border with the Irish Republic late Thursday night, slightly wounding six people and damaging the station and scores of houses, the police said today.

title: CARBIDE SAYS INDIANS ALTERED BHOPAL DESIGN
description: The Union Carbide Corporation asserted yesterday that Indian companies and officials had changed its design for the ill-fated pesticide plant in Bhopal, India, and that Carbide itself had little control over the plant's construction or operation even though it was the majority owner.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BHOPAL LEAK NOT SABOTAGE, REPORT SAYS
description: Indian Government scientists, in a report issued today, declared that the Bhopal toxic gas leak last year was caused by a complex chemical reaction that could not have resulted from sabotage.

title: To Get Beyond Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE ACTS TO MOLIFY SHULTZ ON LIE DETECTORS
description: The White House appeared today to modify its policy on polygraph, or lie detector, tests for Government officials in an effort to satisfy the concerns of Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: DANCE: KATHRYN POSIN PRESENTS 3 PREMIERES
description: Kathryn Posin remains a choreographer harder to type than most -she can turn out a formalist piece to Minimalist music and strive for social commentary by way of rock or disco music. Her vocabulary, nonetheless, remains decidedly in the mainstream modern-dance tradition, a virtue rather than a failing.

title: Venture Capital Club Benefits
description: GREGORY A. GORDON, a physician in Santa Fe, N.M., bought $10,000 worth of stock in a company called the Newman Communications Corporation in the spring of 1984 for 25 cents a share. Now the shares are selling for more than $4.

title: MONEY TO BURN?
description: Chestnuts roasting on an open fire is a matter of no particular interest to the Treasury Department's Office of Currency Standards. And Jack Frost nipping at your nose is only seasonal bother, compared to the accidental burning of paper money in fireplaces and stoves, which increases at this time of year and is the business of the currency office.

title: NO SHOWBOAT, MILLER RUNS AT FULL SPEED
description: For some, there is a temptation to see Cheryl Miller as a media princess rather than a dominant, innovative force in women's basketball.

title: COURT TELLS YUKICA TO COACH, FOR NOW
description: A state court in New Hampshire yesterday issued an order temporarily setting aside the dismissal of Joe Yukica as the head football coach at Dartmouth.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Europe Security Talks Yield Some Optimism
description: The eighth session of the 35-nation European Security Conference ended today with both the Soviet and United States representatives saying they were optimistic about reaching an agreement.

title: CRASH VICTIMS' CHILDREN TO GET TOYS
description: Americares, a Connecticut-based foundation that has helped earthquake victims in Mexico and refugees in Afghanistan, has organized a shipment of toys to the children of soldiers killed Dec. 12 in the crash of a chartered aircraft in Newfoundland.

title: POTVIN BREAKS ORR'S RECORD IN TIE
description: Nearly every time he has touched the puck here over the years, he has been razzed. The fans even organize chants to jeer him in absentia when he is playing in another arena. But last night, Denis Potvin experienced one of the finest moments of his career at, of all places, Madison Square Garden.

title: TV: WESTMINSTER CHRISTMAS
description: Getting away from some of the flashier television routines of the season, WNEW/Channel 5, is presenting another in a series of annual holiday specials tomorrow at 9 P.M. Last year, the program originated from St. Patrick's Cathedral in Dublin. This year, it is ''Christmas From Westminster,'' the Roman Catholic cathedral for London.

title: SPARRING WITH SPEAKES
description: Usually toward the end of the daily White House press briefings, reporters and the chief spokesman, Larry M. Speakes, engage in a period of free-volley. Some of the exchanges are funny, some are crude.

title: TAX BILL STIRS PLANNING FLURRY
description: As 1985 draws to a close, tax advisers are urging clients to take advantage of many of the tax benefits that would be cut back under the tax overhaul bill approved by the House of Representatives this week.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 10:41 A.M. today and set at 10:52 P.M. tomorrow.

title: PENNZOIL, TEXACO IN TALKS
description: A Federal court hearing was abruptly adjourned yesterday after lawyers for Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company disclosed that they were holding negotiations to settle their multibillion-dollar legal struggle.

title: THERESA GOELL, 84 ARCHEOLOGIST KNOWN FOR WORK IN TURKEY
description: Theresa M. Goell, an archeologist who uncovered the tomb of Antiocus I in Turkey, died Wednesday after a long illness at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DOW EASES BY 0.92
description: In a wild session topped off by frantic last-minute trading, the stock market closed mixed yesterday, with investors hoarding secondary stocks and shunning the blue chips.

title: STREET PEDDLING: BEWARE
description: MORE unlicensed peddlers are clogging the streets of Manhattan and shopping strips in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens this year than in past years, according to the Police Department.

title: Memorial Mourners
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, Mayor Koch and Commissioner Peter Ueberroth will be among the dignitaries attending Monday's special memorial mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral for Roger Maris, the former Yankee slugger who died of cancer last Saturday and was buried in his hometown of Fargo, N.D., on Thursday. The mass, to which the public has been invited, will be said by John Cardinal O'Connor and the eulogy will be delivered by Howard Cosell, the sports broadcaster. The Maris family will attend, as will the former baseball commissioner Bowie Kuhn; the American League president, Bobby Brown; the new Yankee manager, Lou Piniella, and Phil Rizzuto and Whitey Ford, former Yankee players.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ultrashort Light Pulses In Telecommunications
description: Scientists for AT&T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., have patented a telecommunications system that can send ultrashort light pulses for long distances through glass fibers without dispersing.

title: JERSEY DAIRY TO SELL MILK ON S.I.
description: One of New Jersey's largest milk dealers was given permission by New York State today to begin selling milk in part of New York City.

title: Ford Aerospace
description: The Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, said it had received a $200 million contract to build two communications satellites for the Space Communications Corporation. The designs of the two satellites will be based on the Intelsat 5 series, Ford said. According to Ford, Space Communications was formed earlier this year by the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation after Japan enacted a deregulation law that allowed private companies to compete for domestic communications services.

title: Black Santa, White Santa
description: This is a tale of two Santas - one white and one black.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Cherry Bowl football game between Syracuse and Maryland incompletely listed television coverage. In the New York area the game, starting at 1 P.M. today, will be seen on WPIX (Channel 11) as well as the cable stations of USA Network.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SOVIET PRESSES U.S. TO JOIN MORATORIUM ON A-TESTS
description: The Soviet Union pressed the United States today to join a moratorium on all nuclear testing, contending that its offer to permit on-site inspection of test ranges satisfied Reagan Administration concerns about monitoring a ban.

title: Girl, 3, Climbs Slope To Bring Help to Mother
description: A 3-year-old girl whose mother lay injured after a vehicle accident climbed a steep embankment and attracted the attention of a motorist to save the woman's life, officials said.

title: FIRE KILLS 2 AT FAUCHON, ELITE PARIS FOOD STORE
description: A fire today swept through the upper floors of Fauchon, the renowned luxury food store, killing the owner and her daughter and injuring at least 11 people.

title: GETTING THE INVITATION IS BECOMING HALF THE FUN
description: Received any good invitations lately? Any really good invitations?

title: JETS SAY THEY WANT TO EARN THEIR BERTH
description: Forget tonight's Denver-Seattle game, Coach Joe Walton told his Jets today. The important game is their own, against the Browns Sunday at Giants Stadium.

title: ESPIONAGE SUSPECT ARRESTED BY F.B.I.
description: Federal agents arrested a print shop worker here Friday night on charges of trying to sell classified materials to the Soviet Union, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced early today.

title: BOARD ACTS TO EVICT ARTISTS OCCUPYING BROOKLYN LOFTS
description: The Board of Estimate, after three years of study, moved yesterday to force more than 100 artists out of illegally occupied manufacturing lofts in two Brooklyn neighborhoods.

title: BRONCOS WIN, KEEP PLAYOFF HOPES ALIVE
description: The Denver Broncos kept their playoff hopes alive tonight with a 27-24 victory over the Seattle Seahawks after trailing by 17-0 in the second quarter.

title: HOPEFUL NOTE
description: Coach Hank Bullough, on his 2-13 Buffalo Bills: ''We keep beating ourselves, but we're getting better at it.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18. 1. A gunman who said he was a Palestinian guerrilla burst into a courtroom in Nantes, France, and, with the aid of defendants, chained the judge to a chair and took about 35 people hostage. 2.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GREETINGS AND ZINGERS
description: Truly satisfying revenge is rarely achieved and almost never acknowledged in the Washington bureaucracy. But both sides seemed to win in the exchange of Christmas greetings and zingers between the Environmental Protection Agency and Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP SHARP 0.6%
description: The Consumer Price Index, the Government's most widely followed inflation gauge, jumped six-tenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest rise in almost two years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Settlement in Fire At Park in Jersey
description: The family of a teen-ager killed in a fire last year at the Great Adventure amusement park will be paid $2.5 million in a settlement with the company that owns the park.

title: New, Bigger Edition Of 'Patent It Yourself'
description: David Pressman, a San Francisco patent attorney, has revised his book, ''Patent It Yourself,'' and it is being published by Nolo Press of Berkeley, Calif.

title: THOSE MEGAWATT MIRACLES OF THE CHRISTMAS SEASON
description: Bedlam is served. Dinner in the Guarinos' kitchen at this time of year is accompanied by workers scurrying through with hammers and electrical wire, people screaming such things as ''Where's the hay for the manger,'' Santa adjusting his beard and a rather more somber man popping his head in the back door to say that someone has died again.

title: SUNDAY, BORING SUNDAY
description: Professional football is in a rut.

title: CONTRACTOR GUILTY IN DEMOLITION OF 44TH STREET BUILDINGS AT NIGHT
description: A Brooklyn contractor was convicted of reckless endangerment yesterday for his role in the late-night demolition of four buildings on West 44th Street in January.

title: KENNEDY SEES HIS HOPE FOR PRESIDENCY FADING
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that with his decision not to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988, ''It would certainly appear that the chance to gain the Presidency has been removed from my future.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of crafts fairs in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect address for a Tibetan exhibition and sale. It takes place today and tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the East Side Community Center, 330 East 45th Street.

title: RABBI PHILIP BERNSTEIN: HELPED DISPLACED JEWS
description: Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein, who helped in the resettlement of hundreds of thousands of displaced European Jews after World War II, died Dec. 3 of heart failure. He was 84 years old and lived in Brighton, N.Y.

title: The Nation Weekly Sold
description: The Nation magazine, the oldest weekly in the country, was sold yesterday by Nation Enterprises, the limited partnership that has owned it for the last eight years. The magazine was bought by the Nation Company, a new partnership formed by the magazine's editor, Victor S. Navasky; its publisher, Hamilton Fish 3d, and Arthur Carter, the founder and publisher of The Litchfield County Times, a weekly newspaper in northwestern Connecticut.

title: LOW-PAYING JOBS GO BEGGING AT SUBURBAN SHOPPING MALLS
description: Help-wanted signs have become standard features this holiday season in the windows of many stores and restaurants in suburban shopping malls in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: WHAT A LIVING WILL DOES NOT PROTECT YOU AGAINS
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENCY SAYS SOLVENT IS SAFE FOR PROCESSING COFFEE
description: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed permitting the continued use of a chemical to remove caffeine from coffee although the chemical has been found to be a possible cause of cancer.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a gain of $300,000 from a lawsuit decision.

title: LAKERS WIN BY 128-116
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 13 of his 29 points in the pivotal third quarter as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 128-116, tonight.

title: IN SPITE OF LAW, HALF NOT USING AUTO SEAT BELTS
description: More than half of the state's motorists are not complying with New York's year-old seat-belt law, officials said today as they began a campaign to get more people to buckle up.

title: OPERA: 'FIGARO' CAST CHANGES
description: The Metropolitan Opera introduced four newcomers into its new Jean-Pierre Ponnelle production of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' on Wednesday night, among them the two principal male characters.

title: DOCUGRAPHIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Patents;   Creating A Text by Computer
description: A HUSBAND-AND-WIFE team of inventors has devised a method of creating a text by utilizing a computer.
