title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued toy, fashion, and non-apparel specialty retailing operations separately.

title: Beatrice Buyout
description: The Beatrice Companies said that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the investment firm, had sent it copies of commitment letters from banks and a letter from another investment concern, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., confirming that they would provide about $6.6 billion in financing for the leveraged buyout of Beatrice. Beatrice said the financing was subject to the execution of a definitive agreement.

title: PANEL URGES CONTINUING ARTIFICIAL-HEART PROGRAM
description: A Federal advisory panel today recommended that experiments to implant permanent artificial hearts in a small number of patients be allowed to continue with only minor medical and administrative changes.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: GAF Bid Is Questioned
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it had asked the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System for confirmation that the GAF Corporation intended to use margin stock to back the financing it receives in its tender offer for Carbide.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (Television -MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7 P.M.) Nets vs. Indiana Pacers at Indianapolis, 6 P.M. (Television - Channels 23, 50, 52 and 58, 6 P.M. live, SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. tape.) #76ers vs. Boston Celtics, at Philadelphia (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Colleges: Georgetown at DePaul. (Television - Channel 4, 3:30 P.M.); West Virginia at Virginia Tech (Television -ESPN, 7 P.M. live); Medgar Evers at Ramapo, 2 P.M.; Niagara at St. John's, 8 P.M. (Radio - WCBS 880, 8 P.M.); Queens at St. Francis, 7:30 P.M.; Maryland Eastern Shore at Brooklyn, 7:30 P.M.; St. Bonaventure at Syracuse, 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WNYE-FM 7:30 P.M.); Minnesota at Connecticut; Fordham vs. LaSalle, 3 P.M., at the Palestra (Radio - WFUV-FM 90.7, 3 P.M.); Dominican at Hofstra, 2 P.M.; Lafayette at Manhattan, 8 P.M.; Marist at St. Peter's, 8 P.M.; L.I.U. at Rutgers, 2 P.M. (Radio - WCTC 1450 and WRSU-FM 88.7, 2 P.M.); Pace at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M.; Women: Fordham at St. John's, 2 P.M. Boxing Mark Breland vs. Hedgemon Robertson, welterweights; Evander Holyfield vs. Anthony Davis, cruiserweights, and Tyrell Biggs vs. Tony Anthony, heavyweights, eight-round co-features, at Virginia Beach, Va. (Television - Channel 7, 4 P.M.) Football Giants vs. Pittsburgh Steelers, at Giants Stadium, 12:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 4, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 12:30 P.M.) Cardinals vs. Washington Redskins, at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 3:45 P.M.) Colleges: Furman vs.

title: NIGERIA REPORTS ARREST OF COUP PLOTTERS
description: Nigeria has foiled a plot to depose its four-month-old military Government, and many military officers have been arrested, the Defense Minister said today.

title: Dispatching Animals And Protecting Pelts
description: To the Editor:

title: Against the Tax Bill and Local Interest
description: Narrow regional interest dictated a lot of votes against the big tax-revision bill that the House has finally approved. Oil-state representatives, for example, had no trouble voting their constituents' interest in trying to defeat the bill. What's considerably more troubling is why similar parochialism didn't also dictate votes for the bill. We have in mind 12 New York and 2 New Jersey Republicans who voted against the measure.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: Net income for the latest year includes a restated gain of $1,765,000, or $1.01 a share, on the sale of land and buildings by the company's English subsidiary. Year-ago net income includes $525,000, or 29 cents a share, due to the reversal of deferred taxes provided in prior years on the undistributed earnings of the company DISC which, as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1984, are tax-free.

title: New York Energy Board Saw Lilco Bond Plan as a Bad Gamble
description: To the Editor:

title: The Broken Chain of Command
description: It was moving to watch President and Mrs. Reagan comforting the relatives of the Gander air-crash victims. The Commander in Chief went in person to Fort Campbell to accept responsibility for his troops and to share the burden of sorrow. Maddeningly, the tragedy evoked a quite different reaction at the Defense Department.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $654,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $7,489,000, or $1.35 a share, for the year from sale of securities.

title: Emhart Purchase
description: The Emhart Corporation said it had concluded its purchase of Allegheny International Inc.'s True Temper operations for $102 million.

title: ECONOMY GROWING AT SLUGGISH PACE
description: The Government said today that the economy appears to be growing at the tepid pace of 3.2 percent from October through December and 2.4 percent for the whole year, the smallest gain since 1982.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said it would raise its Jeep prices by an average of $157, or 1.2 percent, in January.

title: Parent Race Designation Upheld in Louisiana
description: The state's requirement that birth certificates include the race of a child's parents was held constitutional today by the Louisiana Court of Appeal for the Fourth Circuit.

title: ETHIOPIAN, IN U.S., DENIES ASKING FOR ASYLUM
description: The head of the Ethiopian Government's famine relief program, Dawit Wolde Georgis, yesterday denied reports that he was seeking asylum in the United States.

title: 9 SOUTH AFRICANS SAID TO DIE IN RAID
description: Nine people identified as South African refugees were shot and killed early today when raiders, said to have come from South Africa, attacked two homes in Maseru, the capital of neighboring Lesotho.

title: Bulgarian Denies Role In Shooting of Pope
description: A Bulgarian accused of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II denied today that he was ever part of such a plot.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: GOOD SIGN
description: In preparing the Clemson media guide for tonight's Independence Bowl game against Minnesota, Tim Bourret, the Tigers' associate sports information director, lent support to the axiom that there is no such thing as an irrelevant football statistic. What Bourret's research uncovered is that during Danny Ford's tenure as the head coach, he has a record of 50-12-2 when his wife, Deborah, is not pregnant, but only 8-8 when she is. Mrs. Ford, who two months ago gave birth to the couple's fourth child, is not now expecting. Clemson is a 4-point favorite over Minnesota.

title: U.S. PHONE UNIT WINS JAPAN ORDER
description: In the midst of continuing trade tensions over the Japanese telecommunications market, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation yesterday awarded a $250 million contract to an American subsidiary of Northern Telecom Ltd. for computerized switching equipment to route domestic telephone calls in Japan.

title: TURN THE SUBWAY INTO A PARK
description: It is a fallen subway system and the dime won't make a difference.

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,115,000. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $298,000. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: NEW YORK-JERSEY COSTS RISE 0.8%
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the largest monthly increase since January 1984, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: JUDGE SENDS LANDLORD TO JAIL FOR FAILING TO PROVIDE HEAT
description: The landlord of a seven-unit apartment building in the Bronx was sent to jail yesterday for failing to provide heat or hot water to his tenants, city officials said. He was the first landlord to be jailed this winter for failing to provide tenants with heat.

title: Tennstedt to Miss Concerts
description: Klaus Tennstedt, who was to have conducted a series of concerts with the New York Philharmonic, will not appear because of illness.

title: THOUSANDS PAY TRIBUTE TO SOLDIERS KILLED IN JET
description: Standing at attention on a snowy parade ground, 17,000 troops paid homage today to the 248 American soldiers killed in the crash of a chartered airliner in Gander, Newfoundland, a week ago.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 16
description: b-After a one-time charge of $2.6 million from the cost of insurance coverage.

title: TWO SHOPS ADD SPICE TO CITY'S FOOD SCENE
description: Even a city that has a food shop on every block can make room for two more when they are top of the line. The latest additions are especially noteworthy because of the people behind them.

title: KENNEDY REPORTEDLY BOWED OUT BECAUSE HE FORESAW '88 DEFEAT
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy decided to remove himself from the 1988 Democratic Presidential race because he believed he could not win the election and because he wanted to clear the field for the next generation of Kennedys, according to political associates.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: ROCK AND ROLL: KISS IN CONCERT AT THE GARDEN
description: Before there was punk-rock, Kiss was putting out what might be called junk-rock - loud, pummeling songs with lyrics about antisocial behavior. A decade and 20 albums later, Kiss is still blasting away, minus the makeup that concealed its members' faces through the 1970's.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET IS GIVING LIBYA BIG NEW MISSLE
description: The Soviet Union has provided SA-5 long-range ground-to-air missiles to Libya that would pose a threat to aircraft in disputed areas of the Mediterranean, the State Department said today.

title: Assam Said to Plan To Deport Bangladeshis
description: The man elected the next Chief Minister of the state of Assam in northeastern India said today that his party planned to expel thousands of immigrants who came here illegally from neighboring Bangladesh.

title: HOW TO SHARE TRANSIT COSTS: THOSE WHO BENEFIT MUST PAY
description: May I suggest a way to avoid the perennial chaos arising out of transit deficits that will occur again in the years unless the transit fare is taken out of politics?

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including income of $25,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $255,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Middle South Chief in Posts
description: Middle South Utilities Inc., the nation's fifth-largest electric and gas utility company, said yesterday that Edwin Lupberger, its acting chief executive, had been elected chairman and president.

title: No Pact for Kingman
description: The Oakland A's decided not to pick up the contract of the veteran slugger Dave Kingman. He hit .238 with 30 home runs and 91 runs batted in this year.

title: Icahn's T.W.A. Bid Reportedly Revised
description: Carl C. Icahn and negotiators for the board of Trans World Airlines have agreed on a restructuring of Mr. Icahn's offer for the airline, sharply reducing the cash portion, a source involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Aguirre Suspended
description: Mark Aguirre, the Dallas Mavericks' star forward, was suspended for two games as the result of a heated exchange with Coach Dick Motta over an incident Thursday in which Aguirre helped an opposing player from the Atlanta Hawks after a fall. ''A player under stress is going to say some things he shouldn't say.

title: STAGE: A MUSICAL TALE, 'WIND IN THE WILLOWS'
description: For almost 80 years, the Kenneth Grahame book ''The Wind in the Willows'' has been one of the delights of childhood. It is a story about nature and civilization, in which tiny animals are made to stand up for mankind's foibles in a lyrical world as delicate as the ''soft thin whispering'' of reeds.

title: THE AMERICANIZATION OF THATCHER STRAINS HER TIES ABROAD
description: It is not a barb that is likely to bother her, but on three distinct issues in only two weeks Margaret Thatcher has been accused, with varying degrees of invective, of putting Britain in a subservient, ''me-too'' position in its relations with Ronald Reagan's America. In each case, it is alleged, she has chosen to reinforce the waning ''special relationship'' with Washington at the cost of appearing insensitive to the reactions of Britain's partners in Western Europe.

title: NICARAGUAN WON'T END CURBS AS ASKED BY 80 IN CONGRESS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that he would not lift Nicaragua's state of emergency despite an appeal that he said he recently received from more than 80 members of the United States Congress.

title: BRITAIN BRACES FOR A FINANCIAL FREE-FOR-ALL
description: IN his oak-paneled office adorned with Victorian prints of English gentlemen hunting and fishing, Somerset Gibbs was complaining good-naturedly about the boom times in his trade - headhunting for clients in the City of London, Britain's Wall Street.

title: SUFFOLK ABANDONS SEAT-BELT LAW FOR SCHOOL BUSES
description: A Suffolk County law requiring the use of seat belts on school buses has been abandoned in a consent decree settling legal challenges by three Suffolk school districts.

title: FOR PORTRAIT ARTIST, TRUTH IS IN THE EYES
description: FOR the portrait artist Herbert Abrams, the most prestigious commission of his career was the official White House portrait of President Jimmy Carter. That was, that is, until he was asked to paint the portrait of Clement Conger - the man in charge of recommending painters to Presidents for the last 16 years.

title: SINGULAR CELEBRATIONS OF CHRISTMAS
description: IN Litchfield, at the white clapboard colonial home of Victoria and James Sansing, wax candles create soft, beckoning halos in each window, grapevine wreaths are woven with bright ribbons, and a swag of greenery is draped over the entrance.

title: AND BACK IN COURT
description: Federal prosecutors obtained yet another indictment of reputed Mafia members last week.

title: No Headline
description: An article last week on neonatal programs was unclear about the status of Dr. Thomas Hegyi. He is still at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch.

title: Last Benefits of 1985
description: Party With a Heart Dec. 22 - From 8 P.M. on, there will be a party at the Area nightclub, 157 Hudson Street, below Canal Street. The evening will benefit the Heart Association, with the New York Health and Racquet Club matching all funds collected. Tickets, $20 at the door, with cash bar. Information: 212-683-9800. Gifts for Children Dec. 23 - Each year the Hyatt Hotels, now 95 around the world, hold Christmas parties that the chain calls collectively ''the world's largest office party.'' In New York, the Grand Hyatt's party from 3 to 6 P.M. will be held in its Empire State Ballroom to benefit the Leukemia Society of America and the Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children. There will be entertainment and celebrity bartenders ranging from a Penthouse model to chief executive officers of major corporations. Admission is $10 at the door plus a toy, wrapped or unwrapped. Reservations may also be made from 212-679-1939. Benefits for Many Dec. 27 - The Waldorf-Astoria ballroom will resound to the differing beats of entertainers from Italy (Alberto Rocchi), the Philippines (Carmen Patena) and the United States (Peggi Blu and Blu Pearl). Cocktails at 6 P.M. precede the performances, which will be followed by dinner. The evening aids the Police Foundation of New York, the Play School Association and the Ad Hoc Committee for the Filipino Community Center. Tickets for the black-tie event, $150, from 212-751-7257 or 212-302-4139. Dinner, Dancing, TV Dec. 28 - The United Negro College Fund, which sponsors 43 traditionally black colleges and universities as well as 45,000 needy students each year, is holding its annual television fund-raising telethon, ''The Lou Rawls Parade of Stars.''

title: Stakes Record
description: Jorge Velasquez yesterday broke the record Chris McCarron established last year for most stakes winners ridden in a year. Velasquez scored his 55th such victory aboard Tatt Stable's Love That Mac in the $68,100 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: WILD DAY OF SOLVING CITY ISSUES
description: It was midnight at the Board of Estimate. Artists from Brooklyn were sleeping on the sturdy wooden benches in City Hall. Theater owners were arguing with a Deputy Mayor behind closed doors. The zoning maps were out. A union president was talking about pay equity, to anyone who would listen.

title: TALKING PORTRAITS THE NATURAL WAY
description: MAKING a good portrait by available light is like landing a trout with a fly rod - it takes skill fused with determination. To catch a personality naturally, in its own light, without flash or flood intruding, is a technique that can lead to great satisfaction and outstanding pictures.

title: Trading Up
description: To the Editor:

title: 19 ARTISTS' COLONIES GET $207,500 IN GRANTS
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has awarded 15 grants totaling $207,500 for artist-residency programs at artists' colonies across the country.

title: Swedes Take Lead in Cup
description: Mats Wilander and Joakim Nystrom routed Boris Becker and Andreas Maurer, 6-4, 6-2, 6-1, today, giving the defending champion, Sweden, a 2-1 lead over West Germany in the three-of-five Davis Cup tennis final. Sweden can retain the cup with a victory in either one of Sunday's final two singles matches, Wilander versus Becker and Sweden's Stefan Edberg against Michael Westphal.

title: DANCE: AILEY OFFERS 'PIGS AND FISHES
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is best known for its high-energy, popular modern dance performing. But its real eclecticism was evident in a program the company presented Thursday at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Three choreographers known for their sleek, often cool pure dance pieces were represented in a new-dance program that featured two of the Ailey Company's most interesting repertory pieces.

title: THE UNDERWORLD HITS AND RUNS ON 42nd STREET
description: In New York, Boston and Kansas City, Federal prosecutors have begun what they describe as the Government's largest crackdown yet on organized crime. In New York alone, the reputed leaders of the region's five major organized-crime factions, along with dozens of associates, are on trial or under indictment.

title: 'AND YOU CAN'T BE AFRICAN'
description: NATIVES AND STRANGERS By Louisa Dawkins. 404 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: STABLING HORSES IN SUBURBS
description: AS pressure for higher-density residential development reaches ever deeper into the countryside, property owners who keep horses and use informal networks of equestrian trails are finding their cherished rights coming into conflict with those of neighbors.

title: NEWARK TRYING TO TREAT THE SICK AND HOMELESS
description: ''A YEAR ago, I had a $70,000 house,'' said a bearded man named Woody as he sat in a makeshift clinic in a shelter for the homeless here. He had an eagle tattooed on his arm, 7 cents in his pocket and a left leg swollen to twice its normal size.

title: Debra Steinhardt Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Debra Ann Steinhardt, a trader for the 44 Wall Street Group, an investment holding company, and Michael Bruce Lakow, a third-year student at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, took place last evening at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. officiated. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Steinhardt of White Plains and Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Lakow of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: A Different Bohemia
description: Having now moved to St. Louis, my wife and I remember with glee the snappy performances of Ann Magnuson as Barbie and the Heftones or as master of ceremonies of Bingo Night in the basement of a Ukrainian church on St. Marks Place (known then as Club 57). Though not artists ourselves, many of our friends were, and our life in the East Village (circa 1979-83) was typically bohemian, if not a part of the institution itself.

title: CONGRESS PACKS AND LEAVES, BUT THE BATTLE WILL CONTINUE
description: CONGRESS had not even adjourned for the holidays -it did that a couple of days later, in the midst of the capital's first snowstorm this winter - when President Reagan made it clear that 1986 is going to be a year of intense political combat.

title: DEAR RICH-AND-FAMOUS
description: PUBLIC PHILOSOPHER Selected Letters of Walter Lippmann. Edited by John Morton Blum. 652 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $29.95.

title: F.B.I. HOLDS ANOTHER SPY SUSPECT, EMPLOYEE OF HOUSE TRANSCRIBERS
description: An employee of a company that transcribes secret sessions in the House of Representatives has been charged with spying for the Soviet Union after offering to sell an undercover agent secret documents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: WHOSE COMPUTER REVOLUTION IS THIS, ANYHOW?
description: BRAVE NEW WORKPLACE By Robert Howard. 224 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95.

title: 'RUDOLPH' GETS REFURBISHED
description: In 1939, Robert L. May wondered if a certain red-nosed reindeer should be named Rudolph, Reginald or Rollo.

title: DANCE: RICHAR BULL
description: SINCE people who are told to relax often tighten up instead, it was not surprising that when the members of the Richard Bull Dance Theater talked about spontaneity they appeared constrained. They did their talking in ''Recursions,'' a work created and performed by Richard Bull, Peentz Dubble and Cynthia Novack that was offered Thursday night at the Warren Street Performance Loft, 46 Warren Street.

title: Decline and Fall Of Teaching History
description: Diane Ravitch is right on target when she states that ignorance or indifference about studying our past is cause for concern (''Decline and Fall of Teaching History,'' Nov. 17). But placing the blame for this sad situation on a new social-studies curriculum or boring textbooks or poor pupil reading skills or on the dropping of state requirements for history courses flies in the face of her own statistics.

title: THE WELLBORN MAVERICK
description: OUTSIDE THE MAGIC CIRCLE The Autobiography of Virginia Foster Durr. Edited by Hollinger F. Barnard. With a foreword by Studs Terkel. Illustrated. 360 pp. University: The University of Alabama Press. $24.50.

title: TOYS: LOVABLE AND COLLECTIBLE
description: SOME toys that are built to last actually do, in fact long enough to leave behind their roles as childhood playthings.

title: Ann Pendelton Dillon Wed to Mark Skarbek
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Ann Pendelton Dillon, a daughter of Ann Worden Dillon of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Dr. Thomas F. Dillon of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Mark Peter Skarbek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Skarbek of Doylestown, Pa.

title: SUBURBS STRUGGLE WITH RISE IN THE HOMELESS
description: The suburbs, cities and towns around New York City are struggling with a growing problem of homelessness that is fast overwhelming local support programs, according to officials and advocates for the homeless in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: WHEN SPORT SHATTERS MYTHS, EVERYONE CAN WIN
description: SITTING in the marble Japanese bath with hot water gurgling and steam rising around me, I struggled to get a grasp on my rudimentary knowledge of German. At the secluded Nihon Aerobics Center, one hour outside Tokyo, the postworkout soak in the huge baths complex was as much a part of training as the run I'd just taken with my Soviet counterpart, Igor Lotorev. Igor had just spoken expansively about the joy he finds in his daily runs in the forests near his home in Kiev. ''But, how,'' he asked, ''do you run in New York City?''

title: GIFTS THAT MONEY COULD NOT BUY
description: ONE year, John lost his job a few months before Christmas. We couldn't possibly afford to buy presents; we had no money for anything but the bare necessities. I could hardly eke out a few small gifts for the children.

title: Art
description: Many claims have been made for the preeminence of Augustus Saint-Gaudens, the late-19th-century American sculptor perhaps best known to New Yorkers for his monument to General Sherman in the Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn. The retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, through Jan. 26, enables us to understand how these claims could have been made.

title: THE HOME SCREEN VS. A MOVIE HOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK MOSES IN A SEA OF RED INK
description: THE MARCUS GARVEY AND UNIVERSAL NEGRO IMPROVEMENT ASSOCIATION PAPERS Volume Four: 1 September 1921-2 September 1922. Edited by Robert A. Hill with Emory J. Tolbert and Deborah Forczek. Illustrated. 1,125 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $65.

title: WHILE THE OIL IS HOT
description: To the Editor:

title: MASSACHUSETTS DEBATES PLANS TO AID MENTALLY ILL
description: Massachusetts officials are proposing the most dramatic changes in the state's mental health system since they began moving patients out of institutions 20 years ago.

title: AROUND THE GARDNE
description: This Week:

title: A TIMELY HALT TO THE RAIDERS' SHELL GAME
description: WEBSTER'S Ninth New Collegiate Dictionary defines ''shell game'' in part as ''the substitution of something of little or no value for a valuable item.'' It is an old game, one that has appeared and reappeared in different manifestations on street corners - and even on The Street.

title: LINES THAT DVIDE TOWNS AND THE RACES
description: When John Van Buren, a black professor of education at Hofstra University, is asked if he can name a black friend who lives in a predominantly white part of Long Island, he cannot think of one. Professor Van Buren himself lives on a block in Hempstead Village that was half white when he and his family moved there 22 years ago and today is virtually all black.

title: SOVIET UNION
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: SANTA'S HELPERS IN NEW YORK ANSWER LETTERS
description: In this season of holiday mirth, stories of benevolence abound: the doctor who performs a free operation, the charity that serves turkey to needy families, the Christmas tree salesman who gives away trees.

title: BASHIN' THE REDS
description: You can fool all of the people some of the time, some of the people all of the time, but you can't fool Madison Avenue, ever. While the rest of us were watching President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev cozy up in Geneva, TV advertisers, keeping their eyes firmly on the evil empire, were introducing a new technique: Red-bashing. Miller Lite beer was first. Miller usually employs aging sports personalities as its spokesmen. Now they're showing an emigre Soviet comedian, surrounded by new capitalist pals at a bar, telling us he loves America and the wonderful things he's found here, including unopened mail. ''Also,'' he says, ''in America you can always find a party. In Russia, Party always finds you.''

title: HIDDEN STRUGGLE
description: According to a chronicle of the United States championship in Estes Park, Colo., Grandmaster Lev Alburt of New York had almost as easy a time winning this year as he did last year. But in this kind of competition, bare round-by-round results can be deceptive.

title: EISENHOWER AND THE MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL COMPLEX
description: To the Editor:

title: CORELLI AND BARTOK ON THE VIOLIN FRONTIER
description: Consider this study in contrast. Arcangelo Corelli (1653-1713), hailed during his lifetime as the ''new Orpheus'' and the ''Christopher Columbus of music,'' died highly revered and wealthy. Bela Bartok (1881-1945), barely recognized, let alone revered, in his lifetime, died frustrated and penniless. Poles - and centuries - apart, these two nevertheless have much in common: both created enduring works for the violin and both expanded the frontiers of the violinist's art. Current releases illuminate their accomplishments alongside other landmarks in the violin repertory.

title: GECKOS, PORCH LIGHTS AND SIGHING GARDENS
description: SECULAR LOVE By Michael Ondaatje. 126 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95. ELEGY ON INDEPENDENCE DAY By Arthur Smith. 50 pp. Pennsylvania: University of Pittsburgh Press. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $6.95. THE TRIUMPH OF ACHILLES By Louise Gluck. 60 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $13.50.

title: PHILADELPHIA PICKS AN OUTSIDER TO LEAD ITS POLICE
description: Putting an outsider in charge might or might not lead to a bright new image for the Philadelphia Police. But in a department that was the target of a broad Federal corruption investigation even before it accidentally gutted a substantial section of a thriving, mostly black neighborhood May 13, a fresh face almost certainly cannot make matters worse.

title: HIGH TECHNOLOGY IS SPURRING RACE TO RETOOL IN THE MIDWEST
description: Lynn Conway, who spent more than 15 years designing computerized systems in California, sold her $500,000 house in Palo Alto not long ago. She moved to the industrial Middle West because, she says, ''this is where the technological action is going to be for the next 20 years.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No Research for Pablo ''I do not seek; I find'' is one of Picasso's most famous remarks. In ''Patterns of Intention'' (Yale University) by Michael Baxandall, Picasso rejects the idea of painting as research.

title: VARIETY IS THE SPICE OF PARIS
description: IN PARIS, ONE DESIGNER MAKES CLOTHES so clinging that no curve or undulation is overlooked. Another garbs women in dresses so discreet that even the most alluring of them tend to blend into the background. And when the shows for spring 1986 are over, at a glittering gala in the Paris Opera House televised so that millions of world viewers are watching, both designers receive top awards for contributing to the city's fashion creativity.

title: WINTER: A SEASON WITH A PURPOSE TO FULFILL
description: FOR some it is a season that starts on Labor Day and ends at Memorial Day, which, although admittedly long, is still shorter than Byron's somewhat jaundiced view of:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BLOOD SEED. By Andrew Ward. (Viking, $17.95.) A rare Indian perspective on the last 100 years of the British raj is provided in this entertaining adventure novel, purportedly the memoir of Balbeer Rao, orphaned son of a Rajput widow.

title: OYSTER INDUSTRY FIGHTS FOR LIFE
description: THE current oyster harvest has been cut by as much as 75 percent, oystermen say, by a new infestation of the same Asian parasite that virtually wiped out the shellfish in 1958.

title: THE SEASON'S LISTS TEST ENDURANCE
description: ALTHOUGH I am an avid list-maker throughout most of the year, I find that the task of making and implementing all the necessary Christmas lists requires patience beyond human endurance.

title: Street Fashion;   IT'S A YOU-HAUL CHRISTMAS
description: Not all good things come in small packages, at least not for a good many New Yorkers. Judging by the size, and number, of this year's Christmas shopping bags, big is better, at least sometimes.

title: Providing Aid Can Preserve Dignity
description: Within each of us is a measure of human dignity. But for too many people, misfortune and circumstance strip away that dignity.

title: ST. JOHN'S CRUSHES NIAGARA, 104-61
description: Motivated by last season's embarrassing upset loss to Niagara, St. John's registered a smashing 104-61 victory over the Purple Eagles last night at Alumni Hall.

title: SOMETIMES IT'S THE LITTLE THINGS THAT MEAN A LOT
description: Even trivia - as devotees of parlor games will tell you - has its charm and sometimes turns out not to be so trivial at all. In audio, for example, all those little gizmos for keeping records clean and tape decks healthy are downright essential. Besides, they make splendid stocking stuffers for sound buffs - a timely consideration just days before Christmas.

title: A RARITY AMONG STEAKHOUSES
description: DAR TIFFANY, a steakhouse of unusual design, opened in Greenvale a little less than two years ago. It was a two-star steakhouse then, and several return visits recently clearly indicate that the quality has held up. It rates two stars again.

title: HOMES FOR RETIREMENT
description: MAny of the inland communites in Ocean County, N.J., which offer close proximity to the beach without the prices that usually come with living at the water's edge, are drawing the increasing interest of retirement-age couples. And in recent years, developers have been creating retirement communities to house such couples.

title: L.I.R.R. STATION PLAN ASSAILED
description: PLANS by the Long Island Rail Road to build four modern train stations in Suffolk County as part of its electrification project on the Main Line have met with a lukewarm response from commuters and opposition from some railroad workers.

title: Tough Coach, Good Mother
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AN OFFER THE U.S. COULD REFUSE
description: The Soviet Union held out some bait to the United States last week in the hope of getting it to join a moratorium on atomic testing. But the Reagan Administration, while interested, did not bite.

title: HOTELS JOIN THE FREQUENT-FLIER GAME
description: All you have to do is spend eight nights - not necessarily consecutively but whenever you choose - at any of 17 hotels in the United States. In return, you receive a free round-trip economy ticket on American Airlines or Pan American World Airways between the United States and Europe. Spend 16 nights and you win two tickets, and so on. But you must complete your stays by next Sept. 1, and your travel must be between Oct. 1, 1986, and May 1, 1987.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last week about Texaco misstated the time that the law firm of Fulbright & Jaworski joined the Texaco defense in the Pennzoil suit. Fulbright & Jaworski joined after the jury verdict this month.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday reporting the death Dec. 3 of Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein of Brighton, N.Y., who helped in the resettlement of displaced European Jews after World War II, contained an incorrect reference. Rabbi Bernstein, formerly president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis and chairman of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, did not hold the position of executive director of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.

title: BLIND BEGGARS AND INCESTUOUS PASSIONS
description: A SIMPLE STORY By S. Y. Agnon. Translated and with an afterword by Hillel Halkin. 246 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $14.95.

title: THE ROCKY ROAD TO HOLIDAY TRADITION
description: LAST year while we were trimming the Christmas tree, my daughter, then a high-minded 13-year-old, asked, ''Why do we have to have these tacky ornaments every year? Why can't we do it all in gold, with little white lights?''

title: TO GET OFF WELFARE: PRIVATE JOB TRAINING
description: A NEW program to find work for welfare recipients in Hartford and New Britain differs from others because it is not being operated by a social service agency.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''You will watch the damnedest array of filibusters you can ever imagine on every single issue. Oil and gas, real estate - go through the whole stack, because our rules allow that.''

title: DEVILS LOSE TO WHALERS,7-6
description: The Devils had several uninspired moments here tonight, but none of them matched their lethargy during 17 seconds in the middle period.

title: NEW HAVEN'S BIT OF INDIA IMPROVES
description: DON'T let the conventional facade deter you. You pull off exit 59 of the Merritt Parkway in New Haven and arrive at the proper address, expecting an Indian restaurant. But a colonnaded ''colonial'' motel greets your eye. Steady on!

title: A June Wedding For Miss Stallfort
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Robert Stallfort of Elverson, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Elizabeth Stallfort, to Harrison Frazier Caner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Z. Caner of Seattle. A June wedding is planned.

title: Anne Savarese, Medical Student, Weds Physician
description: Anne Morrow Savarese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Savarese of Saddle River, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dr. Harry J. Bigham Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bigham of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. Edward F. Kavin performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel.

title: JAPANESE AGREE FOR THE FIRST TIME TO GIVE U.S. TRADE CONCESSIONS
description: Japan has agreed to $260 million in trade concessions and other measures to compensate the United States for ''unfair'' trade practices, the Reagan Administration announced today.

title: CHATEAUS IN ALL DIRECTIONS
description: For the visitor to France, the Routes de Beaute offer not only an intimate view of chateau life in centuries past but also the experience of how the owners of these historic homes -and their guests - live today. The Roads of Beauty were organized by La Demeure Historique, a nonprofit organization founded in 1924 to locate, catalogue and increase public awareness of privately owned buildings of historical or artistic interest all over France. The properties include chateaus and cathedrals, abbeys and monasteries, parks and gardens.

title: FRANCE
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: MARYLAND DEFEATS SYRACUSE, 35-18, BY EXPLOITING MISTAKES
description: Maryland, which began the season aiming for the top ranking in the final polls but will have to settle for less, ended its season today with an impressive 35-18 victory over Syracuse in the Cherry Bowl.

title: BIGGER GUNS ALONG THE SYRIAN BORDER
description: ISRAEL and Syria settled last week into a new phase of belligerent coexistence. Israel announced that Syria had moved up Soviet-built missiles in a ''dangerous'' challenge to Israeli air surveillance of Lebanon. The missiles are deployed on the Syrian side of the Lebanese border, however, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said they would not be worth fighting over unless Syria launched ''an aggressive act.''

title: PHILADELPHIA FALLS SHORT OF PROMISE TO REBUILD NEIGHBORHOOD BY CHRISTMAS
description: As 61 homes in West Philadelphia lay smoldering last May, reduced to stark shells by what has since come to be known as the Move incident, Mayor W. Wilson Goode set a goal: replace all the houses by Christmas at no cost to the owners.

title: ASSESSMENT UNIT DROPS PLAN TO RAISE FARM LAND VALUES
description: A state board, under pressure from top politicians, has dropped a plan to raise some agricultural land values for tax purposes.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: JOHN REED IN 'IOLANTHE'

title: THE LATEST WRINKLE IN NETWORKING
description: THERE is still a lot of talk about local area networks, or LAN's. But, as in the case of electronic mail, for the most part, the manufacturers have been doing the talking, the consumers have not been buying. To a large extent, the consumer reticence has been due to the high price commanded by a LAN. At $1,000 plus per computer, the cost of networking can be difficult to justify.

title: Tax Reform
description: To the Editor Professor Nordhaus, in ''Yes, Tax Reform, but Not Very Much'' (Forum, Dec. 1), speaks like a true economist. The results of the House Ways and Means Committee's tax reform bill are plugged into the appropriate models, analyzed, and found wanting.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SHOWTIME FOR THE YOUNG The children's musical ''Cinderella'' is returning to New Brunswick's George Street Playhouse for four days of matinees, starting Thursday.

title: A MODEST REVIVAL IN BUSINESS ETHICS?
description: AS A liberal minister, I have often preached against the amoral tendencies of giant corporations and the tyranny of the profit motive which, if taken alone, can lead to the destruction of the environment and the debasement of individuals. Nevertheless, perhaps buoyed with the optimism of the season, I have noticed a revival of sorts, little heralded but perhaps significant, going on in the business community. At least some management decisions are being made with reference not only to profits but also to values.

title: ALFRED RIZZO
description: The pianist Alfred Rizzo, who played Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, studied at the Oberlin Conservatory, the Juilliard School and the State University of New York at Stony Brook. While at Oberlin, he won the Rudolf Serkin Award; during the 1984-85 academic year, he returned to Oberlin as a visiting assistant professor of piano.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TOMIE DEPAOLA'S MOTHER GOOSE Illustrated by Tomie dePaola. 127 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95. (Ages 3 to 7) THE new edition of ''Mother Goose'' by Tomie dePaola is a mutedly colorful, well-designed and rich sampling of 200-plus rhymes and songs of childhood. Its selections, leaning heavily toward those emphasizing domestic animals - cows, pigs, ducks, hens, geese, cats and dogs - make this a Mother Goose decidedly aimed at the younger range of listeners. (It also results in an unavoidable sameness to some of the pictures, particularly in the early part.) The rhymes are told complete in most instances, with the texts taken from Iona and Peter Opie, the folklore specialists in Britain. The book includes such nontraditional rhymes as ''Three little ghostesses, / Sitting on postesses'' and '' 'I went up one pair of stairs.' 'Just like me.' '' (This ends with, '' 'And there I saw a monkey.' 'Just like me.' '') Here, as elsewhere in a markedly successful 20-year career in children's picture books, Mr. dePaola provides ingratiating, cheerful and intelligent illustrations, albeit perhaps too bland. His ''Mother Goose'' cuts a commendably wide ethnic swath with black, Hispanic, Oriental and gypsy characters taking full part in the verse happenings. Rhymes about time and weather are illustrated together inventively.

title: KENNEDY BOWS TO A NEW GENERATION
description: ''Well, here I don't go again,'' Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts said last week as he set out to explain for the fourth time why he would not be seeking his party's Presidential nomination. This time, however, even the 53-year-old head of the nation's most celebrated political family acknowledged that his announcement had a different ring to it.

title: CHAMBER OF COMMERCE SAYS IT'S CARRYING ON
description: An article about Point Pleasant Beach (Nov. 24) said that the Greater Point Pleasant Area Chamber of Commerce ''went broke and closed its doors.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: UP TO 1,400 garbage trucks converge on the Edgeboro Landfill in East Brunswick each day. They carry the refuse of 102 New Jersey towns, as well as some from out of state.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Dec. 15 about the disputed Metropolitan Square construction site in downtown Washington incorrectly identified Anne Sellin. She was zoning chairman of the Dupont Circle Citizens Association from 1975 to 1983 but no longer is a member of the association.

title: TAKING STEPS TOWARD A LIFE OF STABILITY
description: THE boxes are the first things a visitor sees when entering Mrs. G's apartment. At the top of a rickety staircase, they wait in the shadows, piled high with her belongings - testimony to the chaos she has endured.

title: LANDLORD WITH AN IDEA FOR THE HOMELESS
description: LARRY C. SMYJ walked through a large apartment in one of the five buildings he owns in Yonkers, a building in which he has lived nearly all his life. Blue-eyed and fair-skinned, he looks younger than his 31 years and, dressed as usual in jeans, a sweatshirt and sneakers, all dotted with white paint (much of his time is spent renovating apartments), he looks nothing like what most people imagine when they think of landlords.

title: Importing People
description: PLAGUED by shortages of high school science and mathematics teachers, Georgia education officials tried an unusual solution last year: importing West Germans.

title: SUMMATIONS UNDER WAY IN A RACKETEERING TRIAL
description: Summations are under way in the racketeering trial of 10 men charged with ''skimming millions of dollars'' from several bars and restaurants in New York City.

title: PENNSYLVANIANS CELEBRATE A ROAD
description: ONE thousand red, green and white balloons soared skyward like a collective sigh of relief last week as the final stretch of Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania was opened to traffic, 25 years after construction of the highway began.

title: A SURRENDER IN FRANCE
description: In yet another hostage incident, a gunman interrupted a trial of four suspected robbers in Nantes, France, last week, seizing the presiding judge and more than 30 people in the courtroom.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them. Leaving aside the Philippines, Christianity has had little impact on Southeast Asia, with its strong Buddhist, Hindu and Moslem cultures.

title: WHERE ALL THOSE HOLIDAY PLANTS ARE GROWN
description: When Joel Poinsett introduced a flame red flower to this country in 1825, little did he know what he started. While serving as this country's first ambassador to Mexico from 1825-29, Joel Poinsett was more than impressed with a native plant he found blooming there in December.

title: RETURNING TO CHURCH
description: JUST BEFORE CHRISTMAS OF 1980, I WAS SITTING IN THE Sevens, a neighborhood bar on Beacon Hill (don't all these stories of revelation begin in bars?), when a housepainter named Tony remarked out of the blue that he wanted to find a place to go to mass on Christmas Eve. I didn't say anything, but a thought came into my mind, as swift and unexpected as it was unfamiliar: I'd like to do that, too.

title: SALVADOR REBELS TRYING TO UNIFY IN MARXIST PARTY
description: The top military leaders of the Salvadoran guerrilla movement say that they are trying to unite in a single Marxist-Leninist political party.

title: ARCHAIC LAWS LET PROPERTY OUTWEIGH A TOWN'S PEOPLE
description: TWENTY-THREE years after the United States Supreme Court enunciated the principle of ''one man, one vote'' in Baker v. Carr, New Jersey continues to cling to an election procedure in which property, not residency, is the key criterion and in which the amount of influence that citizens wield is not equal, but proportional to the amount of property they own.

description: Weeks This Last On Week Fiction Weeks List 1 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. Exercises to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.''

title: CHRISTMAS IS BETTER WITHOUT SANTA
description: MY husband and I didn't set out to be a curiosity - a family that whole-heartedly celebrates Christmas without Santa Claus. The decision came as we prepared for Christmas when our son was 18 months old.

title: ALTERNATIVES TO RICH HOLIDAY FARE
description: WHEN the rich fare of the holidays becomes excessive, sometimes an Oriental meal can provide the light relief that soothes body and soul. There is news about three Oriental restaurants; in fact, make that four, since two of them, Kyoto and Szechuan East, occupy the same premises (one-half is Japanese and the other, Chinese). But more about that later.

title: RECORDINGS TRACK SCANDINAVIAN MUSIC
description: The music of Scandinavia and Finland (technically not a part of Scandinavia, although many of its people speak Swedish) has a few well-known figures: the Norwegian Edvard Grieg, the Finnish Jan Sibelius and, to a lesser extent, the Danish Carl Nielsen. Beyond that, it is pretty much uncharted territory for most Americans. The Scandinavians, however, are responsible promoters of their music through recordings, and a motley batch of recent (or fairly recent) issues give a good idea of what has gone and is going on with their composers.

title: APPAREL CENTER
description: The first major manufacturing center to be established for apparel industry companies outside Manhattan will soon open in the South Bronx in a former printing plant for stocks and bonds.

title: SLUDGE BILL IS CALLED GOOD START
description: IN THE first step toward ending the practice of dumping sewage sludge off the northern New Jersey coastline, the House of Representatives passed legislation recently to phase out the site and restore it.

title: THE MAKING OF A BEST SELLLER, 1906
description: THE story of Upton Sinclair and ''The Jungle'' has receded so far into the back pages of American literary history that it was a bit surprising to see the tale resurrected, if only as a television statistician's ad-lib during a major league baseball All-Star Game. As the game played itself out in a flurry of home runs and fielding errors, a commentator introduced one of those statistics that serve not so much to enlighten as to divert - a televised version of the newspaper sidebar. The script was altogether routine: citation of the baseball statistic from 1906 (''most home runs in an All-Star Game''); transition to author and best seller (''the same year a man named Upton Sinclair published a book called 'The Jungle' ''); tie-in about novelist and hitter having had a good year. Pause. Next pitch. Sinclair's cameo appearance was pretty inconsequential - not unlike other instances since the Bicentennial in which little-known episodes in American history are rendered as a series of ''spots'' on commercial television. But the episode roughly coincided with the purchase of the New York Mets in 1980 by an investment group headed by Doubleday & Company, the parent company of the house that originally published ''The Jungle.'' That acquisition, of course, was only part of a larger pattern of the last 20 years best described in Thomas Whiteside's ''Blockbuster Complex: Conglomerates, Show Business, and Book Publishing'' (1981) - the diversification of independent houses like Doubleday into entertainment industries; the transfer of once-privately owned publishing houses to multinational conglom-erates (I.T.T., Gult & Western, M.C.A.); the new emphasis on orchestrating books and Hollywood ''concepts'' through million-dollar auctions and promotional tours.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'COPPERFIELD' TO TOSCANINI
description: Puccini's 'Boheme' A Metropolitan Opera production featuring Jose Carreras, Teresa Stratas, Renata Scotto, Robert Stilwell, James Morris; conducted by James Levine Paramount Home Video 127 minutes. $59.95 Puccini's bittersweet exaltation of Bohemian life, with its combination of joy and sorrow, idyllic love and brutal poverty, comes to vibrant life in this videotaped ''La Boheme'' recorded in early 1982, preserving Franco Zeffirelli's lavish and epical staging.

title: Michele R. Manis Married to David J. Kaufmann
description: Michele Raye Manis, the daughter of Harry Manis of Irvington, N.Y., and the late Edith S. Manis, and David J. Kaufmann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Kaufmann of Larchmont, N.Y., were married last evening in the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y. Cantor Robert Abelson performed the ceremony.

title: CHRISTMAS (WITHOUT COMMERCIAL INTERRUPTION)
description: JOY to the world! It is snowing big fat flakes, the sky is steely gray, the streets are alive with Christmas shoppers. They rush and bustle about, toting bags filled with tempting packages and goodies to eat.

title: A ZANY TROUPE PARODIES THE YEAR
description: It is either an unusual example of revisionist history or an extreme case of wishful thinking. For in ''Not Necessarily the Year in Review,'' the cast of HBO's monthly series ''Not Necessarily the News'' offers its own version of the major events of 1985 with an interpretation that is decidedly novel. The half-hour program began its run on the premium service this weekend and will be shown tomorrow at 11:30 A.M., Friday evening at 7:30 and twice more through the year's end.

title: THE DOCTOR'S DIPLOMA
description: LEARNING TO HEAL The Development of American Medical Education By Kenneth M Ludmerer. 346 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95.

title: GEORGIA SOUTHERN WINS
description: Tracy Ham passed 13 yards for a touchdown to Frankie Johnson with 10 seconds left to give Georgia Southern a 44-42 victory over Furman for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA championship today.

title: DR. BOWEN'S DEBUT
description: For a number of reasons, those who watch such things in Washington have been paying particular attention to the early days of Dr. Otis R. Bowen as Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: PETER SHAFFER CREATES ANOTHER ENVIOUS OUTSIDER
description: Whatever else Peter Shaffer may lack, it isn't courage, it isn't derring-do. His plays traverse the centuries and the globe, raising questions that have perplexed minds from Job to Samuel Beckett. Two civilizations, two theologies, Christian and Inca, confront each other against a backdrop of the Andes in ''The Royal Hunt of the Sun.'' The composer Salieri challenges God to a bout of metaphysical fisticuffs in the more recent ''Amadeus,'' incidentally destroying Mozart in the process. And now here's ''Yonadab,'' transporting us simultaneously to 1000 B.C., Israel, King David's court and (perhaps the most exotic location of all) the hyped-up debating chamber the play's author carries in his head. Several times in the past, one has felt that Peter Shaffer deserves a special medal for a sort of majestic recklessness in the field; and that's also the case this month, at the National Theater.

title: MIRIAM RAMOS
description: The pianist Miriam Ramos, who made her New York debut Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, studied in Brazil, Paris and London. She is currently a professor at the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro.

title: Miss Essrog Sets Date for Marriage To Jay Balakirsky
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Seymour Essrog of Randallstown, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah-Jo Essrog, to Jay Balakirsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Balakirsky of Potomac, Md. The wedding is scheduled for March 23.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ''THE NUTCRACKER'' - it's a holiday classic. On Saturday, there will be some noticeable differences, however, when the mouse king and toy soldiers do battle on stage at the Academic Arts Theater of Westchester Community College in Valhalla. Unlike more traditional versions, this production, presented by the Westchester County Historical Society and called ''A Colonial Nutcracker,'' takes place in Westchester and incorportes Colonial history into its story.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 22, 1985 Fiction

title: Foucault and Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: MURDER IS MORE THAN A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: The execution of Paul Castellano, reputed boss of America's most powerful La Cosa Nostra family, makes for grim entertainment. Students of underworld pathology and writers of Godfather fictions are consulted for explanations.

title: IT'S NOT ONLY THE HITS THAT HELP DEFINE THE YEAR
description: Before the 10 best films of 1985 are discussed next Sunday, there's still time to consider some of the other movies that, though they won't get on many top-10 lists, even as runners-up, are notable as footnotes to the year. Such movies help to define the season as much as do the blockbusters. With a couple of exceptions, these films weren't especially popular. However, for one reason and another, they stick in the memory, which, considering the immediately forgettable quality of most of the year's releases, is not something to be dismissed. In no particular order of importance, they are:

title: WINTER DREAMS - FISHING SEASON AND CHERRY BLOSSOMS
description: Anglers' Inspiration In Vermont At a time of year when northern winds howl and lakes freeze over, most fly fishermen can only dream of the return of warm weather and the resumption of the immemorial contest of angler and fish. For the devoted fisherman, however, there is consolation of sorts in the form of the American Museum of Fly Fishing.

title: CAMPAIGNS SET TO ALERT DRIVERS TO SEAT BELT LAW
description: CONNECTICUT motorists who are not already aware of the new law requiring the use of seat belts beginning New Year's Day will be reminded through advertising campaigns by the state as well as private groups.

title: SOUTHPORT
description: THE ritual of buying a house in Southport is to tell a local real-estate broker what you need, then go home and wait for the phone to ring. It may take a few weeks, more likely several months, quite possibly a year. For the turnover is slow in this almost completely developed enclave, particularly in the historic district and adjacent waterfront, where prices start at about $500,000 and go up to $1.7 million.

title: WAVE OF PROTESTS SWEEPS OVER HAITI
description: Thousands of people have taken to the streets in half a dozen towns and cities around this impoverished country in the last few weeks, challenging as never before the family dictatorship that has ruled Haiti with an iron hand for nearly 30 years.

title: White Clothes Stolen From East Side Shop
description: A thief who broke into a Madison Avenue women's clothing shop after Friday night's snowfall stole only white clothes, the police said yesterday.

title: Of Money and Friends
description: The Senate Stationery Room does a booming Christmas business selling lawmakers and staff workers an assortment of low-priced pens and other office supplies suitable as gifts. As evidence of why the United States is running a trade deficit, the official Senate mug sold there costs $14.40 for a set of four in a box that announces: ''Made in Taiwan, Republic of China.''

title: MANY IN CONGRESS SAY SESSION OF '86 WAS UNPRODUCTIVE
description: The Congressional session that limped to a close Friday was one of the least productive and most frustrating in recent memory, many members of Congress from both parties say. They complain that Congress repeatedly missed deadlines and got mired in deadlock until it was forced to the point of crisis.

title: Susan Feldbau Plans To Be Wed to Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Best of Holliswood, Queens, and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of her daughter Susan Mala Feldbau to Charles H. Baker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Baker of Westport, Conn.

title: Anne Garrels Engaged To James V. Lawrence
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Garrels Jr. of Stuart, Fla., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Anne Longworth Garrels, to James Vinton Lawrence, a son of Barbara C. Lawrence of New York and Norfolk, Conn., and the late James F. Lawrence. Miss Garrels is the daughter also of the late Valerie S. Garrels.

title: R.O.T.C. PROGRAM IS THRIVING AT YONKERS HIGH SCHOOL
description: I may have been the uniform that initially attracted some of the 150 students at Yonkers High School to the Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps. But much more than that compels them to rise at 7 A.M. each school day to attend morning drills, face authority and endure admonition in front of their peers without flinching.

title: PARIS BOOKS
description: To the Editor: The article on English-language bookshops in Paris leaves out one of my favorites - Librairie St.-Augustin on Boulevard Haussmann.

title: DR. WILLIAM A. BRISCOE
description: Dr. William A. Briscoe, the retired head of the pulmonary division of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: TAX-EXEMPT TROUBLEMAKERS
description: DESTROYING DEMOCRACY How Government Funds Partisan Politics. By James T. Bennett and Thomas J. DiLorenzo. 561 pp. Washington: Cato Institute. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $11.95.

title: A TIDY PROFIT
description: It was business acumen, not inside information obtained illegally, that enabled Thomas C. Reed to invest $3,000 and, in two days of options trading, make a profit of $427,000, a Federal jury in Manhattan decided last week. Mr. Reed, who was Secretary of the Air Force under President Ford, was appointed a special assistant to President Reagan for national security affairs in 1982.

title: IS TRUMP'S LATEST PROPOSAL JUST A CASTLE IN THE AIR?
description: Not since the world gasped at Philip Johnson and John Burgee's plan for the A.T.& T. Building in 1978 has an unbuilt project been as talked about as Donald Trump's new proposal to put a 150-story condominium tower on Manhattan's Upper West Side. The Trump tower, which would be the centerpiece of Television City, a massive apartment, office and studio complex designed for Mr. Trump by the architect Helmut Jahn, has made the network news, numerous national magazines and a lot of the international press - not bad for a project that is years away from being built, if it gets built at all.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MY DISCOVERY OF AMERICA. By Farley Mowat. (Atlantic Monthly, $12.95.) When the Canadian writer Farley Mowat was barred from entering the United States last April, he wondered, naturally enough, why. Mr. Mowat's frequently hilarious book chronicles his quest to get a sensible answer from the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The author of ''Never Cry Wolf'' learned he and thousands of others are blacklisted under the McCarran-Walter Act of 1952, a law intended to keep Communists and anarchists out of the country. Given no further explanation from immigration officials, Mr. Mowat examined his conscience. Was the problem his book ''The Siberians''? On reflection he admitted he had ''treated the Soviets as human beings essentially like us.'' Or was it ''Sea of Slaughter,'' which condemned the butchery of wildlife along the United States and Canadian coasts? Neither, an anonymous immigration official finally explained. Mr. Mowat, he said, was a serious espionage risk and a threat to our armed forces. According to a 1968 newspaper clipping in a Government file, the author - no stranger to bluster - had said he took potshots with a .22 at United States bombers flying over Newfoundland. The way Mr. Mowat tells it now, the planes were visible only with binoculars - decidedly out of range for a rifle commonly used to hunt squirrels. Since he believed the aircraft carried hydrogen bombs, Mr. Mowat says he had even less reason to shoot. After he was refused entry and the Government was lambasted in newspapers across the nation, officials rigged an escape hatch for themselves: they would ''parole'' Mr. Mowat.

title: IN GERMANY, HALLS DECKED ROYALLY
description: I have spent Christmas at home and Christmas abroad: exuberant boyhood holidays in Ohio, subdued wartime holidays in Vietnam and Nigeria, gala grown-up holidays in Sicily and Devon and the South of France. But I have never had quite as perfect a Christmas as the one my wife and I spent last year in an obscure corner of Germany.

title: Yugoslav Takes Slalom
description: Rok Petrovic of Yugoslavia scored his second slalom victory of the season today, mastering a hard-packed, iced-over track on which only 30 of the 84 skiers qualified for the second heat, and only 18 finished the race.

title: RESPONDING TO A FALSE ALARM ON DEBT
description: IN adopting the Williams bill, the 1968 law that established the basic Federal regulations for tender offers, Congress made clear that it was Federal policy to proceed without ''tipping the balance of regulation, either in favor of management or the person making the bid.'' Now, however, the Federal Reserve Board has proposed a change in its ''margin requirements'' that would provide for extensive new Fed intrusion in the tender-offer process, with significant adverse consequences to bidders.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL AT LAST CONDEMNS HOSTAGE-TAKING
description: The United Nations Security Council, after ducking the issue for years, voted unanimously last week to condemn hostage-taking. Earlier attempts to deplore terrorism ran afoul of third world and Communist sympathy for self-described liberation movements and insistence on including ''state terrorism'' - a reference to punitive Israeli raids in Arab territory and United States support for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: NETS DEFEAT PACERS BY 102-98
description: The last time Darryl Dawkins and Steve Stipanovich faced each other, they were involved in a brawl, were ejected from the game and were fined a total of $2,750.

title: PORTRAIT OF A JAPANESE WOMAN AND HER LIFE IN JAZZ
description: ''Silk Screen,'' a three-part series, wants to examine the impact of Asian culture on Western life and vice versa, although this, thank goodness, is not as forbidding as it sounds. As a rule, films about cultural transference are also films about cultural collision. Someone or something loses. ''Silk Screen,'' at least in its opening presentation -''Jazz Is My Native Language,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight - is more interesting than that. If nothing else, the first program suggests that the series is only an excuse to join three films about Asians or Asian-Americans that are also made by Asians or Asian-Americans, and that in a category like this there is considerable room for maneuver. ''Jazz Is My Native Language'' is not about the impact of one culture on another; it is about a woman, her life and her music, and it is really pretty good.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: For Partying Times And Other Times Harris Restaurant Supply in Port Chester is both a wholesaler and a retailer at wholesale prices of commercial and home supplies for cooking, serving, partying and cleaning up afterward - everything from a corncob holder for 15 cents or a 10-inch candle for 35 cents to a Garland six-burner stove with grill, broiler, two full-size ovens and a price tag of $1,495. All sales are cash and carry - checks and credit cards cannot be accepted.

title: PIANISTS OF THE PAST WORK THEIR MAGIC IN REISSUES
description: Two pianists of the past, both great but as dissimilar as they could be, were Alfred Cortot (1877-1962) and Ignaz Friedman (1882-1948). What they had in common - the characteristic 19th-century singing line, the ability to organize bass lines and bring out inner voices so carefully notated by the composers and so carefully ignored today - was far outweighed by their differences.

title: Winslow Homer Show Set for National Gallery
description: The National Gallery of Art will observe the 150th anniversary of the birth of Winslow Homer with an exhibition of 100 watercolors by the American artist next spring.

title: ROOM WITH VIEW - AND NO PEOPLE
description: I HAVE A NICE LIVING ROOM. YOU SHOULD COME sit in it some day. You will undoubtedly be alone when you do, because no one ever sits in the living room. (Unless we have company. Otherwise, never.) We talk a lot about the fact that no one ever sits in the living room. It makes us all sad. The living room is the prettiest room in the apartment. It has a fireplace and moldings. It has a slice of a view of the river. It is a cheerful room furnished in light colors. The couches in it were recently cleaned by men with small machines. It always looks neat and tidy. That's because no one ever uses it, I know that, but still. You should see it. I already said that, but I mean it.

title: A JOB QUOTA CASE GOES TO TRIAL
description: For the first time, the Justice Department took the campaign against what it considers employment quotas to Federal trial last week, supporting white firefighters and members of the Engineering Department of Birmingham, Ala., who argue that they were improperly passed over for promotion in favor of blacks. Not for the first time, the administration of Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. is arguing that it is merely following the goals and timetables arrived at through a consent decree under President Carter.

title: FOR ADULT COLLECTORS, TRAINS REKINDLE THE MEMORIES OF YOUTH
description: IT was not until Christmas morning when he was 12 years old that John R. Pavlick learned why his family had been eating spaghetti every night for a week. His mother, he recalled recently, had been saving money from the family's food budget to buy a new locomotive for his model train set.

title: PAT DENNING: COACH AND TEACHER MEET IN A PIONEER
description: SHORTLY after practice one day last week, Willie Little, the head basketball coach at the University of Illinois at Chicago, recalled the first time he saw his assistant coach, Pat Denning, in action. ''I watched Pat run a team in the Abe Saperstein summer league a few years ago,'' Little said. And how did she do? ''To tell you the truth, it took so long to get over the initial shock that I didn't spend much time observing coaching technique,'' Little said with a smile.

title: FOR CLASSROOM MONITORING FROM RIGHT AND LEFT
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music
description: ''Messiahs'' to the left of us, ''Messiahs'' to the right of us, into the valley of Christmas ride we all. Handel's great oratorio may be only partly about Christmas, but along with the ''Nutcrackers'' and the carol sings, Christmas it has come to represent.

title: A Different Bohemia
description: It is ironic that a photo of a political mural project called ''The Struggle Continues/La Lucha Continua'' should be used in an article on the new Lower East Side bohemia, which attempts to deny that this artistic direction exists.

title: JUNIOR TENNIS IN SPOTLIGHT
description: ALL over Long Island, youngsters are flailing away at tennis balls, dreaming, perhaps, of inheriting the mantles of John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors, while parents and coaches watch anxiously from the sidelines.

title: NORWAY
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.:

title: A Motherless Goddess
description: To the Editor:

title: A VALUABLE RETURN ON 'JUNK MAIL'
description: DIRECT mail sales - orders from catalogues, fliers and the like - were among the few reasons for retail euphoria this year. Numerous retailers say that their direct mail sales were up as much as 40 percent over past years, and they are expanding and revamping their catalogues at a heady pace. ''The number of households buying through direct mail keeps growing,'' said Paul Leblang, Saks Fifth Avenue's senior vice president for marketing. ''The old opprobrium, 'junk mail,' seems to be fading away.''

title: FINDER'S KEEPER
description: A ''keeper,'' in newspaper parlance, is a story held, or kept, for publication at a time it can have the most political effect. This too-careful timing of news is not as nefarious as the ''roorback,'' or unanswerable election-eve smear, but in the U.S. is frowned on as advocacy journalism.

title: LET'S KEEP SALT II
description: Had it been ratified by the Senate, the second strategic arms limitation accord would expire on Dec. 31. Fortunately, SALT II's provisions are still being adhered to by the United States and the Soviet Union, and each side has pledged not to ''undercut'' its terms so long as the other side shows equal restraint. I believe that continuation of the ''no undercut'' policy remains very much in our nation's security interest.

title: Recent Sales
description: Irvington $67,000 391 Chapman Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, older colonial, *2* new vinyl siding and roof, recently painted interior, taxes $1,436. Linden $135,000 20 Beriant Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old split level, *2* attached garage, fenced yard, den, taxes $1,318. Livingston $317.500 3 Sandalwood Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level, *2* sunken living room with mirrored walls, central air- conditioning, taxes $3,998. Mercerville $79,000 3441 Quakerbridge Road *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod, *2* 3-car garage, full basement, taxes $1,200. Mountainside $160,000 1354 Stoney Brook Lane *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old colonial, *2* family room, pation, attic fan, taxes $2,047. Wayne $123,900 26 Leonard Terrace *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch, *2* wall-to-wall carpeting, 2-car attached garage, taxes $1,580. OTHER AREAS Port Chester, N.Y. $163,500 12 Irenhyl Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 55-year-old frame colonial, *2* dining room, den, modern kitchen, taxes $2,543. Clinton, Conn. $72,000 33 Ironworks Road *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 21-year-old raised ranch, *2* large screen porch, family room, wood stove, $1,175. Massapequa Park, L.I. $183,000 267 Linden Street *2* 7-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old split level; *2* pool, circular drive, deck, pation, aluminum siding, taxes $3,700.

title: Friends Of the Clumsy
description: David Binder's magnificent piece on klutz omits one significant ramification: the effect we have on our companions (''Brotherhood of the Inept,'' About Men, Nov. 24).

title: Kiley Gets Authority To Sell Flxible Buses
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has authorized the agency's chairman to sell the 850 Grumman Flxible buses that were taken out of service in February 1984 either in large or small numbers or as scrap for parts.

title: WHOSE APARTMENT AFTER THE BREAKUP?
description: IN the last few years, New York City has become the kind of town where estranged couples encounter such difficulty finding attractive, affordable accommodations that breaking up is becoming harder and harder to do.

title: BUENOS AIRES
description: To the Editor: Lydia Chavez's article, ''What's Doing in Buenos Aires'' (Travel, Oct. 20), was indeed timely since my wife and I left that very day for Buenos Aires.

title: Research Talent
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST SIDE FAMILIES BRIGHTEN SEASON FOR WOMEN AT SHELTER
description: By day the gymnasium at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association's building echoes with the noise and laughter of children in an after-school program. After nightfall, when the children have gone home, 19 beds are lined up side by side and the gym is turned into an overnight shelter for homeless women.

title: Marc Rosenberg to Wed Amy B. Cohen in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Cohen of Springfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Beth Cohen to Marc Andrew Rosenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Curt M. Rosenberg of Hillside, N.J. The wedding is planned for August.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TERRY and Marilyn, who live in Bellmore, like to humor our friends from Hollis, Hal and Judy. So if Hal and Judy want to do something outlandish, like going to England for a few days - well, Terry and Marilyn go along.

title: PRESS MARCOS FOR REFORMS NOW
description: From a distance, the prospect of a democratic transition of power in the Philippines has never looked better. In truth, however, an opposition victory in the elections scheduled for Feb. 7 would be a small miracle - and with the opposition may also go the last real hope of democratic change.

title: CORRECTION
description: A graph on Dec. 8 recording New York's weather in November showed incorrect figures for the normal and actual mean temperatures. The normal mean was 47.2 degrees and the actual mean was 50.1 degrees.

title: About Men;   Being Santa
description: I LOOK FORWARD TO Christmas every year because it enables me to be Santa Claus. Unlike many men who play Santa just for the money or to be the life of the party, I feel as if I actually become Santa Claus in appearance, conversation, mannerisms and in the real sense of enjoyment I derive. Granted, there is a certain amount of ego gratification involved. I look in people's faces and feel really good about their responses to me.

title: TOKEN PUZZLE: 8 MILLION ARE MISSING
description: ABOUT eight million Connecticut Turnpike tokens are still out there, enriching the state and puzzling officials. Out of 10.187 million tokens in circulation, 2.059 million have been redeemed or are on their way back to the State Transportation Department.

title: MUSEUM EXHIBITION SHOWS BRONX JEWS IN HALCY ON DECADES BETWEEN WARS
description: THEY came to the Bronx by subway, to the highlands of the city from the Lower East Side, and within a half-century many of them left, most by automobile, for the greener pastures of suburbia. The story of what went on during that lively interim is the theme of ''Between the Wars: The Bronx Express, a Portrait of the Jewish Bronx.''

title: REDSKINS DEFEAT CARDS
description: George Rogers ran for a club-record 205 yards and a touchdown and Mark Moseley kicked two field goals, helping the Washington Redskins keep their National Football League playoff hopes alive with a 27-16 victory today over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: SUPERLUNARIAN FOLLIES
description: THE CAT WHO WALKS THROUGH WALLS A Comedy of Manners. By Robert A. Heinlein. 382 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: KEEPNG THE STATE ON THE LEADING EDGE
description: THE inaugural meeting of the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology on Oct. 26 signified the culmination of a four-year effort to place New Jersey in a national leadership role in stimulating economic development through advanced technology.

title: America's Own Nut
description: PECANS ARE ONE OF THE most versatile and compelling of shelled nutmeats, and one of the most interesting historically.

title: Decline and Fall of Teaching History
description: Diane Ravitch fails to convince the reader that history has fared any worse than other disciplines in our schools.

title: TAX POLITICS: HOW REAGAN WOOED THE G.O.P.
description: The Jets were losing 10 to 3 and the President was behind 1 to 0 when the phone rang in Representative Guy V. Molinari's house on Staten Island last weekend.

title: A Hemisphere Of Difference
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHINA
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.
