title: THE BUSINESS OF CORPORATE PHILANTHROPY
description: WHEN it comes to giving, some Westchester corporations are perceived as Santa Clauses and others as Scrooges by the many nonprofit organizations that, in the wake of Federal cutbacks, are scrambling for funds from the private sector. Corporations and individuals are asked to support a growing number of human services, arts and educational agencies - $100 billion is sought annually nationwide - because of reductions in public funds. Faced with so many outstretched hands, how do the county's corporations make philanthropic decisions?

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CHRISTMAS THEATER The Spinning Wheel Inn in Redding will hold its sixth annual Christmas Theater Banquet at 4:30 and 7:30 P.M. today, 7 P.M. Monday and at 4:30 Christmas Eve.

title: MEXICO
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: PARTIES PLAN TALKS TO SETTLE HOSPITAL SUIT
description: THE director of security at the County Medical Center in Valhalla has accused officials of the center of having ''neutralized'' him in his job in retaliation for going to Hospitals Commissoner Bernard M. Weinstein with ''allegations of corrupt, improper and wasteful practices'' at the center.

title: SOVIET HAS SUPPLIED A DANGEROUS MISSILE TO LIBYA, U.S. SAYS
description: The Soviet Union has provided SA-5 long-range ground-to-air missiles to Libya that would pose a threat to aircraft in disputed areas of the Mediterranean, according to the State Department.

title: STAGE: REVISED VERSION OF 'BOOM BOOM ROOM'
description: YOU can see it coming from the moment the characters start tearing one another's hearts out, since they are friends and couples and family. Although a dozen years separate the two plays, a theatergoer can hear sounds in David Rabe's ''In the Boom Boom Room'' that reverberate later in ''Hurlyburly.'' As metaphors about the way things are in Mr. Rabe's America, the titles are blood relatives.

title: AMID 1985 TURMOIL, McENROE FINDS SOME PEACE
description: IT is early morning. Much too early, it seems, for John McEnroe. He is standing, tall and slender with his uncombed curly locks blowing in the breeze, in the middle of the tarmac here at the airport in this tiny, remote town on the eastern coast of Lower California. He says nothing. But his look - tiny eyes squinting in the sunlight above an angular, unshaven jaw and a thin half-smile -conveyed much more about his state of mind last Saturday than any words could have. Clearly, McEnroe would rather have remained in bed.

title: Linda A. Simpson and John Ettinger, Lawyers at Davis Polk, Plan to Marry
description: Judge Arthur J. Simpson Jr. and Mrs. Simpson of Oradell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Linda Ann Simpson to John Riche Ettinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Austen A. Ettinger of New York.

title: WHY TODAY'S ORCHESTRAS ARE ADRIFT
description: The symphony orchestra in America, outwardly gleaming and efficient, is inwardly adrift. Buffeted by a generation of unprecedented change, the institution that once stood as the unquestioned pinnacle of musical activity has emerged with its cultural identity fundamentally altered.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMALGAMATION! Race, Sex, and Rhetoric in the Nineteenth-Century American Novel. By James Kinney. (Greenwood, Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $12.95.) James Kinney's subject is race relations - in both the social and sexual senses. Mr. Kinney, who teaches English at Virginia Commonwealth University, traces the ways in which novelists from 1792 to 1914 dramatized miscegenation and participated in the struggle over slavery and racism.

title: Alison C. Corvington To Wed Paul Dickard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mark A. Corvington of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Claudia Corvington, to Paul A. Dickard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene C. Dickard of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The wedding is planned for April 19.

title: CRIME
description: Nat Hentoff, who has written about jazz, politics and the social problems affecting New York City, has also written mysteries. The first was ''Blues for Charlie Darwin,'' and it introduced a New York Police Department lieutenant named Noah Green. Now Green is back in THE MAN FROM INTERNAL AFFAIRS (Mysterious Press, $15.95).

title: BETHLEHEM FIGHTS CHRISTMAS THEIVES
description: THE municipal golf courses in Bethlehem, Pa., which lose about a half-dozen evergreens a year to Christmas tree poachers, have borrowed a tactic used by many state highway departments. For the first time, said John Schweder, director of parks and public property, the city has sprayed the trees with a chemical so foul-smelling that no one could keep them indoors.

title: A LESSON LEARNED ON THE IMPORTANCE OF HAVING WATER
description: ''THE worst thing that could ever happen is to be without water,'' said the neighbor who welcomed us to Pound Ridge 22 years ago.

title: SOLVING THE CASE OF THE ROYAL CHAIR
description: This is the story of an exquisitely carved and gilded French chair with an impressive past which was found recently worn, faded and darkened with dust in the New Jersey warehouse of the New-York Historical Society.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: THIS WEEK:

title: Miss Deglin Is Wed
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday, Kane Elizabeth Deglin and Michael Vincent Lippe were married by the Rev. Justin Hennessey. Mrs. Lippe is a daughter of Theodore L. Deglin, who heads his own public relations concern, and Mrs. Deglin of New York. Mr. Lippe, the sales manager of New York Fabrics, is a son of Mrs. William T. Lippe of New York and the late Mr. Lippe, who was the national sales manager for Seagram Distillers.

title: DANCE HELPS AUTISTIC CHILDREN
description: THE children and their dance teacher bounce a yellow balloon between them; its lightness captivates the children.

title: THE SMALL FARMER VS. SOME BIG NUMBERS
description: From the start, perhaps nothing was more central to Capitol Hill's year-long debate over Federal farm policy than the matter of whether that policy would be determined by lawmakers concerned with preserving rural culture or by those pushing to make tough economic choices.

title: PERPETUAL REPLAY
description: Many of the most striking photographs in LIFE IN SPORTS (Harper & Row, $29.95) have appeared in Life magazine. Gjon Mili's photograph of a 1939 cockfight (shot at 1/100,000 of a second), George Silk's thrilling photo essay of the 1962 America's Cup race and Arthur Rickerby's violent images of football and lacrosse are unforgettable.

title: Miss Zimmerman Planning to Wed R. I. Wishnick 2d
description: The engagement of Karla Zimmerman to Robert I. Wishnick 2d has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Manuel Zimmerman of New Rochelle, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Wishnick of Scarsdale, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: Walesa Says He Faces Slander Indictment
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, said today that he had been told he would be indicted on charges of slandering the authorities during general elections in October.

title: Vincenzo Taramelli
description: Of the three pianists who made formal New York debuts this week, Vincenzo Taramelli, who played Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, selected the most interesting program. He devoted the first half of his concert to 20th-century arrangements of baroque works, and closed the evening with some relatively unfamiliar compositions by Scriabin and Rachmaninoff.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: GETTING TO KNOW THE GENERAL, by Graham Greene. (Pocket Books, $3.95.) After the death in 1981 of the Panamanian leader, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Graham Greene wrote this memoir about the general who had become his good friend. Last year Alan Riding wrote in The Book Review that ''from a literary point of view, this book is perhaps not among his most memorable - he has conceded he found it difficult to write. But from a human point of view, it is compellingly compassionate.'' BLUE JUNIATA: A LIFE. Collected and New Poems, by Malcolm Cowley. (Elisabeth Sifton/Penguin, $7.95.) In 1929 Malcolm Cowley first published this volume of poems; in 1968 he reissued it, with what our reviewer, Kenneth Burke, called ''several superb additions.'' Mr. Burke added: ''To go through the whole sequence of these poems is to follow, in Cowley the poet, the embodiment of the trends that are treated by Cowley in his role as historian of the literary situations characteristic of our times. . . . All told, the collection is expert, and poignantly relevant.'' HISTORICAL CONSCIOUSNESS: Or the Remembered Past, by John Lukacs. (Schocken, $13.95.) The 300-to-400-year evolution of historical consciousness is at least as important as the scientific revolution in the view of John Lukacs. The development of our understanding of history is the subject of this 1968 book critics called long-winded and confusing as well as insightful, fascinating and important. Mr. Lukacs has written a new introduction and conclusion for this edition.

title: GETTING IT RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: DISSONANCE IN THE COSMIC HARMONY
description: THE BURNING FOREST Essays on Chinese Culture and Politics. By Simon Leys. 257 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An opera review last Sunday for ''The Juniper Tree,'' at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., misidentified the conductor. He is Richard Pittman.

title: PROPOSAL FOR TRAIL RUNS INTO OPPOSITION
description: PLANS for a 30-mile pathway envisioned as a mini-Appalachian Trail for equestrians, bird watchers and cross-country skiers in East Hampton have run into opposition from property owners along the way.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ON EXTENDED WINGS. By Diane Ackerman. (Atheneum, $16.95.) The reader soars with Diane Ackerman as she learns to fly and ultimately earns her private pilot's license.

title: Christmas Tradition Leads Suspects to Jail
description: Police officers disguised as merrymakers carrying out the Puerto Rican tradition of wee-hour Christmas visits seized 52 robbery and petty crime suspects, the newspaper El Mundo reported today.

title: F.A.A. TO CHECK JET REPAIR SHOPS
description: With commercial aviation's deadliest year nearing its end, the Government announced last week that its inspectors would soon be fanning out among the jet-engine repair shops maintained by 14 major airlines and 6 independent overhaulers.

title: A BATTLE FOR AIRPORT RIDERS
description: LONG ISLANDERS have become used to heavy competition for their travel dollars from local and national airlines. Now, with the holiday travel season in high gear, the competition to provide ground transportation to and from the airport has become equally hot.

title: GOLDEN OLDIES: SOME SHADES OF CHRISTMAS PAST
description: THE temptation is to seize the new: the latest technical wizardry in computers, the hottest marketing scheme in dolls. But Christmas, more than any other holiday, seems to be a time to indulge in the past.

title: WORKING FOR THAT SECOND TEDDY BEAR
description: EACH December, John and Karin Pieper take their two sons to the kitchen gadgets section of Fortunoff's on Long Island to buy Christmas gifts. One year, the couple recalls, the boys bought their father a set of reindeer-tipped swizzle sticks; their mother got two cookie cutters, one shaped like a ship, the other a whale.

title: STATE TOLD TO PLAN FOR WASTE FACILITY
description: THOUGH Connecticut does not appear at the moment to need a major new facility to handle hazardous waste, the planning for one should begin, according to the head of a statewide panel.

title: 21 APPROACHES TO ABSTRACT ART
description: ''ABSTRACT Painting Redefined,'' an exhibition of canvases by 21 contemporary artists, now at the Fine Arts Center Gallery of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, sets itself no small task. Its ambition is, in the words of Cie Goulet, the artist responsible for the selection, ''the taking of work into fresh new territory.''

title: IS IT REALLY SHAKESPEARE?
description: GARY TAYLOR, an Oxford scholar at 32, who as an American has a stronger claim to be taken seriously as a Shakespeare scholar than any of his British colleagues, has just discovered what he believes to be a previously unknown poem by the great and enigmatic Will. I am not being ironic when I relate his nationality to his presumed scholarship, since America has the time and the money to spend on Shakespeare studies, while we in Britain have good-humoredly relinquished them to American brains and American computers. If Gary Taylor asserts that the poem in question - which has turned up in the Bodleian Library at Oxford in a volume dated 1630 - is by Shakespeare, then we are inclined to take seriously his American instinct, poetic ear and background of Shakespearean know-how. Nevertheless, I do not think that the poem (published in full in last Sunday's Book Review, with an essay by Mr. Taylor) is by Shakespeare.

title: A GO-AHEAD FOR PHILLIPPINE VOTING
description: DOUBTS that there might not be a Philippine presidential election Feb. 7 -and they have been widespread - were eased to a large extent last week by the Supreme Court. The court voted 7 to 5 in favor of ''letting the people decide'' whether to put an end to 20 years of authoritarian rule by Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: PANETTONE IS MILAN'S YULETIDE TREAT
description: The first signs of Christmas in Milan are the stacks of trapezoidal boxes, wrapped in blue, cream, white, gold and beige, that crowd the aisles and display windows of coffee shops, pastry shops and confectioners from early November to early January. A traditional Yuletide sweet bread, made with flour, eggs, leavening, butter, sugar, raisins and cedro -the candied rind of a large Sicilian lemon -Milan's panettone is a close cousin to Verona's star-shaped pandoro and Genoa's fennel-flavored pandolce. Unlike these, which are still primarily known locally, panettone has become, for many non-Italians, the symbol of Christmas in Italy.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'COPPERFIELD' TO TOSCANINI
description: David Copperfield Starring Freddie Bartholomew, Frank Lawton, W. C. Fields, Lionel Barrymore, Edna May Oliver, Jessie Ralph, Madge Evans, Lewis Stone, Roland Young, Basil Rathbone, Maureen O'Sullivan; directed by George Cukor, 1935 MGM/UA Home Video 131 minutes. $24.95 Charles Dickens called ''David Copperfield'' his ''favorite child.''

title: Scott E. Herman Weds Kimberly Jane Markel
description: Kimberly Jane Markel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O. Markel of Loveland, Colo., was married yesterday to Scott Edward Herman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Herman of Washington. The Rev. Edward Gaffney performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: 'TALLEST' RUNNER
description: AFTER a quick appearance on network television in the Giants' locker room, Joe Morris hunched down as if he had taken a handoff and hurried 20 yards toward where the showers were steaming. During the week he is the most pleasant of men, but after a game Joe Morris is usually too ''wrapped up'' to talk to notebooks and microphones. But after having rushed for 202 yards in yesterday's 28-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers that assured the Giants of the home site in next weekend's National Conference wild-card game, Joe Morris agreed to meet the news media.

title: A CHRISTMAS TREE SETS THE MOOD
description: THE thin light of early morning woke me that Christmas day of 1967. I knew I would not have long to wait before my three children - Janie, 12 years old; Julie, 7, and Matthew, 4 - would be up and clamoring for the wrapped presents beneath the splendidly decorated Christmas tree. I knew there would be presents under the tree for me, too, but I already had the present I wanted most. My mother, who had been ill all year, was feeling well again and was coming with my father for Christmas dinner.

title: Frown From Washington Square
description: To the Editor:

title: GERMANY
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: TRUE CONSERVATISM
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORT OF CASH, ICAHN ALTERS T.W.A. DEAL
description: Carl C. Icahn revised his offer to buy T.W.A. to $11 a share in cash and $13 in preferred stock. He was unable to obtain the financing to honor his original offer of $19.50 a share in cash and $4.50 in preferred stock, and it was beginning to look as if the T.W.A.'s board would have to look for another buyer. One possibility was a $22-a-share cash offer from Frank Lorenzo of Texas Air, whose earlier bids for T.W.A. were overtaken by Mr. Icahn. . Mr. Icahn's new deal leaves enough cash to help the airline through the transition period. The board has not yet approved the deal, but it is well known that the airline's directors are anxious to close. The reason: Only after Mr. Icahn takes control would union concessions take effect to help stem mounting losses.

title: PROSPECTS
description: REIT's Rise Again Real Estate Investment Trusts - which allow small investors to buy shares in a portfolio of real-estate or mortgage holdings, or both - have had a roller-coaster existence since they were introduced in the 1960's. But now REIT assets are climbing once more. At about $16 billion this year - up from $12 billion in 1984 - they may reach $18 billion in 1986.

title: MINORITY GRANTS APPROVED
description: Cash incentives totaling $2.6 million over five years and a program modeled after Upward Bound have been approved by the Board of Governors for Higher Education to encourage the recruitment and retention of minority students and staff at Connecticut state colleges and universities.

title: Romantic Link Seen In Helicopter Escape
description: The woman accused of hijacking a helicopter to pluck three convicts from a high-security prison had met one of the inmates and visited him several times, apparently developing a romantic attachment, an investigator said today.

title: JOINT U.S. AND SWEDISH ISSUE IN PLANNED
description: The United States Postal Service and the Swedish Post Office will release stamp collecting issues on Jan. 23. The United States offering will be a booklet containing two identical panes of four 22-cent stamps each. The Swedish issue, also in booklet form, will contain a single pane of four stamps.

title: HOLIDAY TRAVELERS ADVISED ON TRAFFIC TROUBLE SPOTS
description: WEATHER, highway accidents and the seasonal whims of shoppers all play a part in determining holiday traffic patterns for the next four days, but special problems already are being anticipated by traffic experts in some parts of the state.

title: FORUM THEATER'S 'COMPANY'
description: IN a Forum Theater Group press release, ''Company,'' the 1970 Stephen Sondheim musical, is announced almost as an apologia (and erroneously listed as a 1972 show).

title: THREE HOURS PASS SWIFTLY IN A NEW 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'
description: There is no doubt about it:

title: Steelhead Trout Has Zealous Fans
description: SOME anglers don't know when to call it quits, and among their ranks are those who even now are ignoring snow and cold to fish some of Lake Ontario's tributaries in New York State for steelhead trout.

title: DR. GROSS GETS HIS JOB BACK
description: The on-again, off-again career of Dr. Elliot M. Gross was on again last week. Mayor Koch decided to allow Dr. Gross to return to his post as the city's Chief Medical Examiner and to remain there unless charges of gross negligence or incompetence filed by the State Health Department are reinstated and upheld.

title: BETTER SERVICE FOR HARRIED SHOPPERS
description: IT is axiomatic among merchants that no store, however large, is physically equipped to cope with the huge throngs of shoppers who flood the aisles each day during the Christmas shopping season. But every year, retailers try to somehow hone the logistics to accomplish the impossible.

title: BRAZIL
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: Olympic Medalists Sweep Four Bouts
description: Four American boxing medalists from the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics continued their progress through the professional ranks with clear-cut victories here today.

title: ARTISTS PRESENT HOLIDAY WRAPPING OF A DIFFERENT SORT
description: AS a way of promoting and celebrating the arts in their city, some New Haven artists have wrapped several exterior floors of a building with more than 3,000 yards of material, including several large, red and blue spinnakers.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ESTIVITY PACKAGE Arrowwood, on Anderson Hill Road in Rye Brook suggests a way to drink and not drive New Year's Eve, with an all-inclusive overnight package for $316 a couple. Included are a six-course dinner with champagne in the grand ballroom, dancing to a live orchestra from 9 P.M. to 2 A.M., buffet breakfast served at 1 A.M., overnight accommodations, New Year's day brunch, and unlimited use of the heated indoor-outdoor pool, indoor tennis courts and complete health and sports facilities.

title: PARIS BOOKS
description: To the Editor: Jonathan Baumbach's article on English bookstores in Paris (''Paris Has Plenty to Read - in English,'' Travel, Nov. 24) provides a good introduction to an aspect of Paris few American visitors take the trouble to explore.

title: Chase T. Rogers Becomes a Bride
description: Chase Theodora Rogers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Rogers of Greenwich, Conn., and Pinehurst, N.C., was married yesterday to Lieut. Edward Vincent O'Hanlan, U.S.N.R., of the Judge Advocate General's Corps, a son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Treacy O'Hanlan of Waynesboro, Va.

title: G.E.-RCA MERGER WOULD BE A REUNION
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 COLLEGES OMITTED IN COMPUTER ARTICLE
description: The fine Dec. 1 article on factories of the future and the North/Central CIM (Computer Integrated Manufacturing) Center at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark omitted the names of three colleges in the CIM consortium.

title: THE CITY RETAILERS' CHARITY CHRISTMAS
description: THE flurry of excitement that usually accompanies the Christmas shopping season was not as evident this year. But the shopping period has not been without some suspense.

title: PRESIDENT BARS A TAX INCREASE
description: President Reagan said today that ''my veto pen is inked up and ready to go'' if Congress attempts to raise taxes to reduce the Government's budget deficits.

title: OMENS FOR G.O.P. IN CONTEST
description: THE struggle for the post of Presiding Officer of the Suffolk County Legislature portends a more significant and serious development than the momentary embarrassment of Suffolk Republican leaders, local politicians said last week.

title: NEW CLUSTER PLANNED FOR ROOSEVELT I.
description: Five new residential towers containing more than 1,100 apartments are planned for the western shore of Roosevelt Island, across from the East Side of Manhattan.

title: GROUP CAB RIDES BECOME A YORK AVE. CUSTOM
description: Beginning at about 7 A.M. on York Avenue at 72d Street and at 79th Street, as many as 40 taxis are lined up, waiting for customers going to the financial district - and turning down passengers who want to go elsewhere.

title: A NOT-SO-JOLLY TALE
description: SO THERE was a Santa Claus, after all. Too bad. Too many people had sworn there wasn't. Some of them were important people. Now they looked foolish. While nobody likes to look foolish, important people absolutely hate it.

title: MUSIC: ALEXANDER QUARTET
description: OF the ingredients that go into making a string quartet, the balancing of talent is perhaps the most excruciatingly difficult to manage. The Alexander String Quartet, which played at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night, seems happily to have settled on just the right musicians.

title: MR. SHULTZ'S BALKAN SALVOS
description: George Shultz's wrath in Belgrade expressed America's frustration with terrorism. The Secretary of State was justifiably provoked when his Yugoslav hosts offered a mealy excuse for failing to hold the presumed plotter of the Achille Lauro hijacking. Traveling through Eastern Europe, Mr. Shultz was also right to hold Rumania accountable for the mistreatment of its people, notably a non-conforming Christian minority.

title: Susan Stoddard Jacobsen Is the Bride Of John Colby Kean 3d on Long Island
description: Susan Stoddard Jacobsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valdemar F. Jacobsen of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Sea Island, Ga., was married yesterday to John Colby Kean 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kean Jr. of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. William Rogers performed the ceremony at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I.

title: OPERA: FIRST 'LOHENGRIN' OF METROPOLITAN SEASON
description: WHAT was admirable about this season's first performance Friday night of Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' at the Metropolitan Opera was so admirable that it made one angry about what was mediocre or worse.

title: Final Curtain
description: FOR 21 years, in the teeth of wavering audiences and steady deficits, the show went on at the Bristol Valley Playhouse. The founders, George and Mary Sherwood, dug into their own pockets to meet expenses, and a bit of Americana - summer stock - survived in Naples, N.Y.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'COPPERFIELD' TO TOSCANINI
description: Scenes From the Big Chair Featuring Tears for Fears RCA/Columbia Musicvision 75 minutes. $29.95 The British quintet Tears for Fears has refined a plaintively appealing style of pop-rock that borrows rhythmic ideas from the Talking Heads, a chiming oracular mood from U2 and lyric inspiration from the primal-scream theorist Arthur Janov, by way of John Lennon.

title: ANOTHER 'MAY DAY' WORRIES THE MARKET
description: THE stock market - already distorted by various institutional buy and sell programs related to options and futures - may step up to a new level of volatility as a result of a recent decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Last month, the S.E.C. ruled that investors who have accounts of at least $500,000 could negotiate ''incentive'' fees with registered investment advisers. Many professionals are concerned that the change could result in extra price swings, especially at the end of the year, as money managers increase their trading in an attempt to improve the performances of the stocks they manage.

title: JETS HAVE RARE CHANCE TODAY
description: A playoff appearance has been so rare for the Jets in the 26 seasons of the franchise that Sunday's game against the Cleveland Browns marks only the second time they can earn a postseason berth by winning their final game of the regular season.

title: LUXURY GALORE IN NEW RIVIERA
description: BACK when we were kids, learning to tell which car was which, Buick was the place to start. There were those portholes in the fenders for one thing. There was that distinctive hood ornament for another. And there was the Riviera, the first of the ''hardtop convertibles,'' later known simply as hardtop coupes.

title: INSIDERS RECALL BIRTH OF FREE AGENCY 10 YEARS AGO
description: ''The grievances of Messersmith and McNally are sustained. There is no contractual bond between these players and the Los Angeles and the Montreal clubs, respectively. Absent such a contract, their clubs had no right or power, under the Basic Agreement, the uniform player contract or the Major League Rules to reserve their services for their exclusive use for any period beyond the 'renewal year' in the contracts which these players had heretofore signed with their clubs.'' WITH these words, written 10 years ago tomorrow, Peter Seitz, then baseball's impartial arbitrator, created the free agency that dramatically and irrevocably changed the sport. After Seitz created free agency, free agency created millionaires, agents and unhappiness among owners, but it also produced unprecedented popularity for baseball.

title: MUSIC: DUTOIT AND THE PHILHARMONIC
description: LAST week, in Charles Dutoit's first program of the season with the New York Philharmonic, he offered much to admire but fell short of the finest of the many records that have established his international reputation. In this week's program, heard Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, he easily matched his recorded best. The orchestra simply played much better for him, and one wonders why: the alchemy of that particular evening? a full week of working together, smoothing things out? more rehearsal time? music with which Mr. Dutoit felt more comfortable?

title: BANKING ON THE BIOTECH BUSINESS
description: FROM THE OUTSIDE, THE SQUAT GRAY building by the railroad tracks seems ordinary enough. But inside, security pads requiring coded keys are by every door, and stairs made from a single, reinforced piece of steel lead to the explosion-proof control room. Much like the observation balcony of an operating theater, the control room overlooks an area in which stands a Rube Goldberg-like maze of green, blue, red, white and orange pipes leading to and from a 1,500-liter fermenting vat.

title: JAPAN
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: HERE COMES THE SEVERN BORE
description: Tom Higgs and I were chugging down the Gloucester and Sharpness Canal in a pre-autumn gale when, tiring of the wet and cold, I went below and occupied myself with the canal boat's tidy bookshelf. A volume entitled ''The Severn Bore'' by F. W. Rowbotham caught my eye. Marveling at the author's confidence, I took it down. The book fell open at an astonishing photograph showing a wall of water six or seven feet high, suspended, as it appeared, between the banks of a river.

title: John T. Sargent Weds Elizabeth Kelly
description: Elizabeth Nichols Kelly, the fiction and books editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, was married yesterday to John Turner Sargent, the chairman of the executive committee of Doubleday & Company in New York. The Rev. Robert A. Nunn of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's Manhattan apartment.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: Edward D'Elia to Be Wed To Robin E. Luca in May
description: Robin Elise Luca and Edward D'Elia, both 1984 graduates of St. John's Law School, plan to be married in May, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Adolfo F. Luca of Brooklyn, have announced.

title: Support on Privacy Urged by Physician
description: Your article on Dec. 1 (''New Effort Seeks to Insure Quality of Psychiatric Care) explores but one of many new ventures developing in our county, state and the nation to influence the way health care is delivered. Many corporations, home-based here, are experimenting with pre-admission certification, concurrent review and other cost-cutting measures for all of medicine, not just psychiatry.

title: IN A HURRY
description: Harry Macklowe, a New York developer involved in the late-night demolition of four buildings on West 44th Street in January, told a grand jury that he had ordered the structures razed even though he knew that no permit had been issued for the work. The admission was contained in testimony released last week during the trial of the demolition company, Mitron Associates, and its owner, Eddie Garofalo, on charges of reckless endangerment (they were found guilty on Friday).

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md. (Television - Channel 9, 6 P.M.) College: St. Mary's (Md.) at Adelphi, 7:30 P.M.; Holy Cross at Hartford, 7:30 P.M.; Women: Hofstra at St. Francis. Football Jets vs. Cleveland Browns, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. The Jets are after a division title and/or a playoff spot. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1 P.M.) #49ers vs. Dallas Cowboys, at San Francisco. The defending Super Bowl champions need this victory to have a chance at the playoffs. The Cowboys have already clinched the National Conference East title, but need a victory for the home-field advantage in the second round of the playoffs. (Television -Channel 2, 4 P.M.) College Bowl Game: Arkansas vs. Arizona State, Holiday Bowl, at San Diego. (Television - Channel 11 and USA Network, 8 P.M.) Hockey Devils vs. Minnesota North Stars, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) Sabres vs. Boston Bruins, at Buffalo. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M. live.) Tennis Davis Cup final, at Munich, West Germany. In the reverse singles format, the players from Friday's opening round swap opponents for the final two matches. If Mats Wilander beats Boris Becker or Stefan Edberg beats Michael Westphal, Sweden, which leads, 2-1, will capture the cup. (Television - ESPN, 9 A.M. live.) Other Events BASEBALL: Metros de San Juan vs. Lobos de Arecibo, Puerto Rico Winter League game of the week at San Juan.

title: L.I. CHURCHES REVIVE PRACTICE OF TITHING
description: DON'T look for church bazaars at St. Hugh's in Huntington these days.

title: More Penny Stamms Needed in County
description: When I read Wei Wei C. Huang's letter to the editor (''Preferred Treatment of Foreign Guests,'' Nov. 24) I felt an urge to defend Penny Stamm. I thought to myself, ''How many of us, despite our busy schedules, would make an effort to share our home with a friend from afar?'' Penny Stamm treated her ''friend from China'' like a member of her family, and gave him the simple pleasure of being able to feel at home.

title: A PARTNERSHIP WITH SHAW
description: ANY producer casting a George Bernard Shaw play, or looking for a director for one, is likely to say, ''Get Jerome Kilty.'' It is hard to think of anyone more identified with the work or the character of Shaw than Mr. Kilty, the actor and director who lives in Weston.

title: SCHOOL HELPS PERPETUATE CHINA'S CULTURE
description: WHEN the Mid-Jersey Chinese School was established 22 years ago, its handful of students met in a private home. Today, school officials do not advertise because the 228 students in the Saturday program are outgrowing the building here.

title: RUTGERS TROUNCES LONG ISLAND, 82-67
description: The freshman forward Anthony Duckett led five Rutgers players in double figures with a career-best 20 points today as the Scarlet Knights defeated Long Island University, 82-67.

title: ISRAELI, TIED TO SPYING IN U.S., SAID TO LOSE JOB
description: Rafael Eitan, the man who is said to have masterminded the Israeli espionage operation in Washington, has been removed from his post as the head of an intelligence gathering unit in the Ministry of Defense and is expected to retire quietly in the near future, Israeli officials said today.

title: There Are Reasons Grandparents Act
description: I read the article ''Grandparents, Grandchildren and the Law'' [Dec. 1] . When at first I read it, I was angry at what I considered a biased attack on grandparents. After rereading the article, I feel perhaps you are under some personal pressure that has made you very bitter.

title: CASINOS HERE FAIL TO ECLIPSE NEVADA'S
description: ANALYSTS and casino executives expected 1984 to be the year that the young casino industry here would exceed $2 billion in revenues, surpass the Las Vegas area and lay claim to the title of national gambling capital.

title: Correcting Myth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STATE AIDES OPTIMISTIC ON NEW SUPERFUND
description: THE House version of the Superfund reauthorization bill, passed on Dec. 10, contains several provisions that will directly help New Jersey's hazardous-waste cleanup efforts, according to state officials.

title: FOR NEW OFFICERS, SCHOOL'S OUT
description: AS they marched proudly into the large auditorium, the 98 graduates displayed a marked change from the awkward recruits who had assembled 26 weeks earlier.

title: A BUSINESSMAN PUTS TINY NATION IN HIS PORTFOLIO
description: THERE'S a little outpost of a little country on 42d Street and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and perhaps its foremost representative in the United States is a Berlin-born businessman who lives in the old carriage couse in Southampton that was once home to the best-selling author Irwin Shaw.

title: EXPERIMENTAL DANCE IS NOT ALWAYS AIDED BY TRAPPINGS
description: This month's debut by Susanne Linke, a dancer and choreographer from West Germany, constituted the last dance entry in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival - an event that prompts some reflections not only on the German choreographers in the festival but also on the whole series.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED IN EDWARDS CASE
description: Louisiana politics is never dull. But, the state's citizens agree, it has not been so entertaining for decades as it has been in the three terms of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards.

title: CORRECTION
description: An illustration with an article on artificial intelligence appeared without a credit line. The illustrator was Brad Hamann.

title: The Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: WRITERS SAY YEVTUSHENKO SPEECH REFLECTED A HOPEFUL MOOD
description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko's recent call for candor and openness in literature was more than a solitary appeal by an aging rebel, according to the poet's colleagues.

title: U.S. TO KEEP F.H.A. FOR NOW
description: Few proposals for reducing fiscal flab have had as stormy a reception as the notion of budget director James C. Miller 3d, disclosed a week ago, that the Government help make ends meet by unloading the Federal Housing Administration. Last week, after protests by, among others, influential members of Congress, the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the real estate and construction industries, the Office of Management and Budget pulled back its plan.

title: Helen K. Davlin To Wed in April
description: Mrs. Thomas Allen Ennis of New York and Hobe Sound, Fla., and Andrew Davlin Jr. of Pismo Beach, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Helen Kingsley Davlin to William G. Reardon, a son of Mrs. Frederick A. Reardon of Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Reardon. The wedding is planned for April.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ALTHOUGH her books evoke other times and places, they are grounded in reality, says the novelist Belva Plain.

title: Debra L. Newman Weds
description: Debra Lynn Newman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Newman of New York, and Dr. Jeffrey Neal Solowey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Solowey of Dix Hills, L.I., were married yesterday at the Plaza Hotel in New York by Rabbi Balfour Brickner. The bride is a candidate for a doctorate in clinical psychology at Fordham University and a program coordinator at Christ Church in Jersey City. Dr. Solowey is a psychologist at the Eastchester (N.Y.) High School. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: BIG SUR
description: To the Editor: Your article on Deetjen's Inn at Big Sur (Travel, Nov. 10) revived memories of many weekends I spent there in the late 60's, when it was still a rustic hideaway.

title: MINNESOTA PREVAILS
description: The sophomore Rickey Foggie ran and passed Minnesota into position for Chip Lohmiller's game-tying 19-yard field goal and Valdez Baylor's 1-yard dive in the final 11 minutes as the Golden Gophers defeated Clemson, 20-13, in the Independence Bowl tonight.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SAFE HOUSES. By Lynne Alexander. (Atheneum, $13.95.) The title of Lynne Alexander's first novel refers to both the real safe houses that sheltered refugees in World War II and the more elaborate safe houses of the imagination.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Difficult as it was, this session is going to look very easy compared to next year.'' - Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania, discussing Congress. [1:4.]

title: WASTE-CLEANUP VOTE
description: Governor Cuomo plans to ask the Legislature next month to approve for placement on the ballot in November a referendum question on spending at least $700 million to clean up hazardous waste, according to state officials.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are almost as many ways of shopping for Christmas as there are shoppers, but Tom Corcoran may have one of the most unusual. He does a friend a favor, he saves himself a lot of work, he lies a little and all in all, his system is a combination of completely painless and almost painless. In an unliteral sense, it makes the season a breeze.

title: Freedom of Dance
description: THE United States Supreme Court has held that when a nude dancer performs in public, the performer is exercising freedom of speech, and so the dancing is protected by the First Amendment. But when a Staten Island cabaret owner tried to invoke this defense to keep city officials from closing his dance floor for patrons, the State Appellate Division balked.

title: U.S. AGAIN ASSERTS THAT SOVIET BROKE ARMS AGREEMENTS
description: A Presidential report to Congress on Soviet compliance with arms-control treaties has presented new charges against Moscow and modified some earlier allegations in the light of recently acquired evidence.

title: SQUEEZING SALES INTO FEWER DAYS
description: THE one good thing that could be said about the short Christmas selling season is that it did not come as a surprise. Retailers had ample time to realize that there were only 26 shopping days this year, and to map their strategies accordingly.

title: UNBEATEN GEORGETOWN HANDS DePAUL FIRST DEFEAT
description: Reggie Williams scored a game-high 30 points as Georgetown survived a rugged and sometimes ragged challenge from DePaul to post an 85-70 triumph today in a match of unbeaten teams.

title: A 'NONESENSE' SHOW
description: At the Somerstown Gallery, a renovated three-story country house in the Historic Preservation District of Somers, a new show is devoted to the works of the famous Victorian-era artist and writer Edward Lear. Entitled ''How Pleasant to Know Mr. Lear,'' the exhibition features six rooms devoted to his particular light-hearted brand of humor.

title: A Different Bohemia
description: As an artist, in the more conventional sense of the word, I read Maureen Dowd's article with great dismay.

title: SUITS CHALLENGE USE OF MOTELS FOR HOMELESS
description: WESTCHESTER's practice of housing homeless families in motels is being challenged in lawsuits filed on behalf of two homeless mothers and their children.

title: WELCOMING THE HOLY SEASON
description: CHRISTMAS, AND THE FOUR WEEKS OF ADVENT PRECEDING THIS great feast are infused with special meaning at the Abbey of Regina Laudis. For it was in a town called Bethlehem, nestled in the rolling hills of Connecticut, that a handful of Benedictine nuns found a new home after traveling from a war-ravaged France 40 years ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1985
description: International

title: CEMENTING ALLIED'S LOOSE ENDS
description: BEHIND Michael D. Dingman's desk on the 16th floor of the Seagram Building in midtown Manhattan hangs a still life on loan from the Whitney Museum. The painting, Niles Spencer's ''The Green Table,'' could hardly be more serene. But its calming influence is lost on Mr. Dingman, a man who has never been interested in slowing down.

title: PROTECTIVE CUSTODY
description: California condors, the world's largest, and some would say ugliest, flying birds, once roamed western North America. Today the flock is down to 27, and the West is no longer their oyster. Six fly the skies over Ventura; the remaining 21 are earthbound at the San Diego and Los Angeles zoos.

title: New Castle Now Mandates Its Esthetics
description: THE Town of New Castle has given itself sweeping new powers to mandate the kind of architectural style, lighting, landscaping, building and paving materials and commercial signs in renovations and new construction - even before a builder comes along with plans for a property.

title: MARYLAND VOTERS WILL GET A CHANCE IN 1986 TO WEIGH VALUE OF INTEGRITY
description: Seven years after a slate promising reform swept into power in Maryland, some political analysts are wondering whether a reputation for integrity is an asset for candidates running in next year's state elections.

title: AT THE POPE'S RIGHT HAND
description: THE RATZINGER REPORT An Exclusive Interview on the State of the Church. By Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger with Vittorio Messori. Translated by Salvator Attanasio and Graham Harrison. 197 pp. San Francisco: Ignatius Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: Of Money and Enemies
description: High Frontier, an organization whose sole purpose is to get President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' missile-defense system installed in space, does not deal in understatement or innuendo. In its current fund-raising mailing, the organization names its enemies and tells the public how to defeat them.

title: YOUNG PERFORMERS HAVE THEIR DAY
description: FOR a dozen years, Heida Herrmanns watched over the Young Artists Competition sponsored by Performers of Connecticut, the organization she helped found in 1972. She saw it grow from a strictly southern Connecticut operation to a statewide talent search, then to one encompassing all of New England, until finally, last year, the doors were opened to competitors from all over the country.

title: WINNING SQUAD
description: The sedate intellectual effort required at the card-table does not usually appeal to men of action, but there are exceptions. Three years ago Colin Simpson, an officer of the Special Branch of London's police, made headlines when he shot an Arab gunman who had just inflicted a near-fatal wound on Israel's ambassador to Britain. Four weeks ago he made news in a quieter way as a member of a British team that won a major international bridge event.

title: WHERE WATCHING TV IS LIKE WATCHING HISTORY
description: Robert Batscha has unusual fantasies. ''Imagine if we had television coverage of some of the great events of previous centuries,'' he says excitedly. ''I would have loved to have seen a television interview with George Washington or Abraham Lincoln. Imagine television coverage of the signing of the Declaration of Independence!''

title: MERCHANTS COMPLAIN SOUTH STREET SEAPORT HAS YET TO ESTABLISH ITS IDENTITY
description: In its first Christmas season as a completed development, the South Street Seaport seems to be suffering from an identity conflict.

title: FRANK ABOUT MAIL
description: ''I would have to think a long, long time to come up with a more embarrassing example of the waste of the taxpayers' money,'' says Senator Charles Mathias. He was referring to the $144 million that members of Congress expect to spend this year on Government-paid newsletters and other mailings to constituents.

title: Elaine J. Young Plans To Be Married in April
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Louis Young of Franklin Lakes, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Elaine Joan Young to Glenn Marshall Bradford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lloyd Bradford of Wyckoff, N.J. The wedding is planned for April.

title: 76ers' LATE RALLY DEFEATS CELTICS
description: Maurice Cheeks scored a season-high 26 points and the 76ers' defense spearheaded a strong fourth quarter tonight as Philadelphia defeated the Boston Celtics, 108-102.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FREDERICK'S FABLES A Leo Lionni Treasury of Favorite Stories. Written and illustrated by Leo Lionni. Introduction by Bruno Bettelheim. 132 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 8) LEO LIONNI is a modern master of the picture book. Beginning with ''Little Blue and Little Yellow,'' in 1959, he has been an outstanding innovator. A distinguished art director and graphic artist, he is a minimalist for preschoolers. His influence has been pervasive in the field, traceable through the efforts of William Steig, Eric Carle, Elizabeth Cleaver and Robert Kraus, among many others. The little ''parables'' Mr. Lionni writes and illustrates generally concern misfits who, with just the right touch of imagination, transcend their sorry circumstances. The publication of ''Frederick's Fables,'' an anthology of 13 of his best-known picture books issued between 1960 and 1983, should be a cause for celebration.

title: Wet Question
description: NOT since the 1930's had there been a bar or liquor store in Castile, N.Y., about 50 miles southeast of Buffalo. But last month Castile planned to vote again on whether to remain one of the state's 18 dry towns.

title: CONSUMER RATES
'ARCTIC VISIONS,' THE ART OF THE INUIT, AT THE MONTCLAIR MUSEUM
description: ''ARCTIC VISIONS,'' a sampling of Eskimo art at the Montclair Art Museum, is grounds for either optimism or dismay. It all depends on the viewer's willingness to accept art as a substitute for real life, since that essentially is what it has become for the Eskimo.

title: SMETANA'S 'LIBUSE IN A RARE HEARING
description: Czechoslovakia's national opera will come to town on March 13, when Eve Queler will conduct the Opera Orchestra of New York in what is said to be the American premiere of Smetana's ''Libuse'' at Carnegie Hall.

title: WOMMEN WIN ONE AT OLD NASSAU
description: One of the last bastions of male camaraderie in the Ivy League lost its first line of defense last week.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:The train ride from Denver to Ogden, which used to be made on the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad, is one I have long wanted to take. Is it still possible to do the same trip with Amtrak on the way to San Francisco? - I. B., Hartland, Vt. Answer:It is still possible to take this route (which railroad enthusiasts describe as one of the most scenic mountain runs in the United States) from Denver to Salt Lake City on the way to San Francisco. But to complete the journey to Ogden, Utah, about 35 miles north of Salt Lake City, requires a break in the trip.

title: Aiding a Good Cause
description: As the two principal corporate takeover specialists in New York, the law firms of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz can generally be found on opposite sides of most courtrooms or bargaining tables.

title: Speech! Speech!
description: A public figure who finds himself on the platform with William F. Buckley Jr. can feel a little uneasy in the presence of the erudite and sharp-tongued conservative. But that didn't seem to perturb Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., when he appeared with Mr. Buckley the other day at commencement exercises at the University of South Carolina, delivering remarks that some might consider Buckleyesque, or even perhaps a gentle parody of their subject.

title: LAW PROFESSORS FAULTED FOR LACK OF PUBLISHING
description: FOR at least 60 years, critics have complained about the low scholarly output of America's law schools. Now, an article in the latest issue of the Journal of Legal Education has provided legal academia's detractors with still more ammunition.

title: ALIENATING AFFECTIONS
description: ESTRANGEMENT America and the World. Edited by Sanford J. Ungar. 347 pp. New York: A Carnegie Endowment Book/ Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 40 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSEST
description: he New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 40 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Dickerson Slowed
description: Eric Dickerson, the Ram running back who began the regular season as a holdout, may be ending it as a heldout.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NUCLEAR DEBATE: Deterrence and the Lapse of Faith. By Robert W. Tucker. (Holmes & Meier, Cloth, $24.50. Paper, $9.95.) Do we need to be reminded of how confused we are about nuclear weapons and the odds and ends of deterrence? Yes, in this case, we do.

title: Foucault and Pleasure
description: To the Editor:

title: IN EMPIRE STYLE
description: Before the area was designated a historic district by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, some of the graceful town houses in Chelsea, on Manhattan's West Side, were stripped of their detail in modernization efforts.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'COPPERFIELD' TO TOSCANINI
description: I Am a Camera Starring Julie Harris, Laurence Harvey, Shelley Winters; directed by Henry Cornelius, 1955 Monterey Home Video 99 minutes. $59.95 (PG) After it was a novel and a Broadway play and before it became the Broadway musical and Hollywood Academy Award-winner known as ''Cabaret,'' Christopher Isherwood's account of life in prewar Berlin was transformed into a movie drawn from the John van Druten stage adaptation.

title: KOKOSCHKA'S EARLY PORTRAITS SUM UP A WHOLE SOCIETY
description: Among the exhibitions of the fall season, none has carried a heavier load of nostalgia for this visitor than the little show called ''Oskar Kokoschka: The Early Years, 1907-1924'' at the Serge Sabarsky Gallery, 987 Madison Avenue at 77th Street. Kokoschka will always have his place in historical terms as an honored veteran of the Viennese art world before 1914, but for those who also remember him as a vibrant and ever-provocative presence in the room, the opportunity of seeing a large group of his early portraits is irresistible.

title: THE MEANINGS OF 'DUALITY' IN ART
description: SIGNIFICANT numbers of artists have discovered that being part of the late 20th century also means being in touch with one's cultural tradition.

title: Miss Chafee to Wed John Nassikas 3d
description: Senator and Mrs. John H. Chafee of Potowomut, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Georgia de Forest Chafee, to John Nicholas Nassikas 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Nassikas of McLean, Va., and Dunbarton, N.H. A June wedding is planned.

title: TRIBOROUGH AUTHORITY LIMITING TOKEN SALES
description: Because of evidence of ''very serious'' hoarding in recent days, discount rolls of Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority tokens will no longer be sold until the 25-cent fare increase takes effect Jan. 1, according to the authority. Tokens will be sold only singly or in single round-trips until then.

title: Donna Marie Flotteron To Marry Kevin Cahill
description: Mr. and Mrs. James J. Flotteron of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Marie Flotteron, to Kevin Thomas Cahill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Cahill of Hampton, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN'S MAN FOR EDUCATION
description: IN HIS YOUTH, WILLIAM J. BENNETT PLAYED OFFEN-sive tackle on his college football team, and the burly professor-turned-public-servant is fond of using occasional metaphors from his favorite sport. In the world of politics, he once told a young colleague, there are no referees to make sure that you get your turn on offense: ''If you don't act as if you had the ball, if you don't put yourself on the offensive, setting the terms of debate around your agency, then you're on the defensive. And that's no place to be.''

title: Communication Needed In Grandchild Cases
description: I would like to respond to the article by Barbara Lewandowski, ''Grandparents, Grandchildren and the Law.''

title: TO BE YOUNG AND GIFTED -- AND BORED
description: ELAINE PAGELS, a religion professor at Princeton, has fond memories of the classes for the gifted that she took as a child. ''I would have been bored to death without the advanced classes,'' said Miss Pagels, a recipient of a MacArthur Foundation fellowship and an award-winning writer.

title: SALE WILL SPOTLIGHT RARE GOLD COINS
description: The 1986 auction season will open with a glittering sale of United States gold coins.

title: THIS TIME, SHULTZ HAS THE LAST WORD
description: GEORGE P. SHULTZ demonstrated again last week that on matters of principle, the normally easygoing Secretary of State can turn into an implacable adversary. In Belgrade, at the end of a nine-day European trip that included Hungary and Rumania, Mr. Shultz erupted in anger at a joint news conference with the Yugoslav Foreign Minister, Raif Dizdarevic.

title: CLINTON FRETS OVER THAT GLEAM IN DEVELOPERS' EYES
description: FOR years, the name Hell's Kitchen has conjured up images of seedy tenement buildings and violence by gangs of street fighters.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM 'COPPERFIELD' TO TOSCANINI
description: Toscanini: The Maestro Documentary featuring 1943 concert performance of Verdi's ''Hymn of the Nations,'' starring Jan Peerce, tenor; with James Levine, Alexander Scourby, Walfredo Toscanini; produced, directed and edited by Peter Rosen, 1985 Video Arts International 74 minutes. $49.95 This cassette consists of an hour-long documentary about Arturo Toscanini's life, with an addendum of the conductor's edition of Verdi's pot-boiler patriotic cantata, made for a wartime propaganda film.

title: THE BIRTH OF JEWISH ART
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling to Supply Help to the Helpless
description: Our agency serves annually more than 2,000 children and their families struggling with inadequate housing, child neglect and abuse, family violence and the heartbreaking hopelessness that results from overwhelming deprivation.

title: Kathryn Maney To Wed Feb. 22
description: Kathryn Claire Maney, a second vice president in the corporate finance division of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York, and James Charles Cowles, a Smith Barney first vice president, plan to be married Feb. 22.

title: Friends Of the Clumsy
description: Clumsy, my foot. It's just as offensive to glorify ineptness in men as it is to indulge dumbness in women. David Binder keeps mentioning ''the inability to recognize'' and ''not being able to discern.''

title: Wendell Willis, T. P. Livingston To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Wendell Willis to Thomas P. Livingston has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Willis Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Seal Harbor, Me., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald G. Livingston of Morristown, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: NAME THAT DOG
description: CANINE NOMENCLATURE is taking a turn toward the human. More and more, we are giving dogs the names we used to reserve for people.

title: A FIGHT TO KEEP THE DIRT IN RED DIRT ROAD
description: RED DIRT ROAD, a wide red dirt path that winds its way for one and a half miles through some of the lushest, hilliest terrain in East Hampton, is different things to different people.

title: CAVALLI WAS FINE, BRING ON PUCCINI
description: What Raymond Leppard really wants to conduct is ''La Boheme.''

title: MALLS MAY SAY NO TO PAMPHLETEERS
description: New York State's highest court ruled 5 to 2 last week that the New York Constitution permits a shopping mall to enforce a blanket policy against distributing handbills.

title: Dr. R. I. Thomas Weds Dr. Alexander
description: Dr. Nanette Laurie Alexander, a resident in medicine at Harlem Hospital, and Dr. Rogelio Isaac Thomas, a resident in internal medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital, were married yesterday at the Bethany Baptist Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. William Augustus Jones Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: WHAT'S FUELING YELLOW FREIGHT
description: THE sprawling terminal, built on 57 acres near the intersection of I-70 and I-435 on the outskirts of town, is surrounded by hundreds of trucks. Some are huge tractor trailers; others are vans. All carry the insignia of Yellow Freight System Inc.

title: Love, Concern For His Men
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GERALDINE PAGE REVELS IN A FILM ODYSSEY
description: In a dark bus station in Harrison, Tex., an old woman who is trying to return to a place called Bountiful vows she will reach her destination no matter what. ''I will go on,'' says Carrie Watts stubbornly. ''I will walk those 12 miles if I have to.''

title: 259 EDICTS LATER, HISTORIC U.N. SESSION ENDS
description: When the General Assembly President, Jaime de Pinies of Spain, pounded his gavel for the last time this week and the words ''Happy Holidays'' lighted up a giant electronic voting board in the Assembly chamber, diplomats from every political bloc burst into applause. At last, the historic 40th session was over.

title: ON TELLING AN EYESORE FROM RUINS OF HISTORIC SIGNIFICANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Holly Russell Marries Jack Rosenthal
description: Holly Russell, a copy writer for Grey Advertising, and Jack Rosenthal, deputy editorial page editor of The New York Times, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan by Rabbi David Posner.

title: HE PLAYS 30 ROLES IN 'CHRISTMAS CAROL'
description: SINCE Charles Dickens published ''A Christmas Carol'' in 1843, its characters have become holiday traditions. A few years after it was written, Dickens himself gave the first public reading of his work, and the retelling of this tale about a man who rediscovers the spirit of Christmas within himself has become almost an annual obligation.

title: A Question of Value
description: It was Polonius in Shakespeare's Hamlet who said, ''Who steals my purse steals trash.'' The question before Justice Budd G. Goodman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan recently was whether filching such trash - specifically, two pieces of scrap paper - amounts to robbery under state law.

title: A HIT TV SHOW SPAWNS A HIT ALBUM
description: The runaway success of ''Music From the Television Series 'Miami Vice,' '' (MCA-6150), which has sold more than three million albums in less than three months, sharply illustrates the changing relationship between popular records and television. By using rock videos in a dramatic context, the series has demonstrated, even more convincingly than MTV, the power of video to promote records. An extended version of Jan Hammer's theme song for the series recently became a No. 1 single, and Glenn Frey's ''You Belong to the City,'' which was also specially written for the series, reached No. 2. Where soundtracks from hit movies have regularly sold in the millions, ''Miami Vice'' is the first album of music from a television series to reach No. 1 on Billboard's album chart since Henry Mancini's ''Music From Peter Gunn'' did the trick in 1959.

title: Article 243802 -- No Title
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has approved the $939 million, final phase of a five-year, capital-expenditure plan intended to help get the bus and subway system back into acceptable condition.

title: KATZENBACH CHAIR AT YALE
description: The Yale Law School, with a gift of $1.9 million from I.B.M. and 121 individuals, will create an endowed professorship in honor of Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a senior vice president of I.B.M. and a former United States Attorney General.

title: Q AND A
description: Rent-Increase Exemptions Question: I am a senior citizen renting in a building that is being converted to a co-op. I receive a rent increase exemption because I have a low income. If my apartment is sold to a speculator, will I still receive the exemption? . . . P. S. W., Riverdale, N.Y. Answer: Yes, so long as you continue to qualify. New York State law says that any tenant in a noneviction plan, and elderly and disabled tenants in eviction plans, shall continue to be subject to programs that regulate rentals or occupancy, according to Jane Rosenberg, assistant attorney general in the Attorney General's Real Estate Financing Bureau.

title: Seeking Assistance
description: Memphis State and Youngstown State have recruited major college assistants to take over their sagging football programs.

title: Encouraging Sign
description: Mike Rogers, who came to the Rangers in 1981 after two 105-point seasons with the Hartford Whalers, never lived up his potential in New York.

title: COUNTY WORKS ON PACKAGE FOR ALBANY DELEGATION
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke is preparing a list of resolutions for the New Year that he wants the county's representatives in Albany to put into effect when the legislative session begins next month. Although Mr. O'Rourke has in the past criticized the performance of Westchester's 13-member state delegation, he said last week that he was adopting a positive attitude.

title: DONNA REED ILL WITH CANCER
description: Donna Reed, the star of ''The Donna Reed Show'' of the 1950's and 1960's who recently filled in as matriarch of the Ewing clan in the television show ''Dallas,'' has been hospitalized with pancreatic cancer, Harry Flynn, her press agent, said Friday. Miss Reed, 64 years old, won an Oscar in 1953 for best supporting actress in ''From Here To Eternity.''

title: Gail Bradley Plans to Wed Dean G. Klewsaat in June
description: A June wedding is planned by Gail S. Bradley and Dean G. Klewsaat, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Bradley of Milltown, N.J., have announced. Mr. Klewsaat, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Juergen H. Klewsaat of Watchung, N.J., is a senior research and development technician at Colgate-Palmolive Research and Development in Piscataway, N.J., where his fiancee is a research technician.

title: THE CONCRETE MEETS THE ABSTRACT IN A GROUP SHOW
description: TODAY'S most successful art often blends recognizable elements with the strong visual principles developed during decades of powerful abstraction.

title: UGANDA TRIES TO AWAKEN FROM ITS NIGHTMARISH PAST
description: There is an undeniable lushness to this land, where the soil is fertile and the climate magnificent. Here, in a nation Winston Churchill once called ''the pearl of Africa,'' the promise of an independent Africa perhaps seemed greatest.

title: 7 Rebels Reported Killed In Clash in Sri Lanka
description: Security sources said seven Tamil separatist guerrillas were killed and a soldier was wounded in a gun battle Friday at Ariyalai in northern Sri Lanka, the national news agency reported today.

title: A Different Bohemia
description: Maureen Dowd's article ''A Different Bohemia'' (Nov. 17) is an interesting update on the commercialization of New York's art scene. But she tends to turn things upside down in revealing ways.

title: Kidney Machine AidsWoman in Heart Case
description: The first woman to receive an artificial heart was hooked to a machine today to help her kidneys, and doctors said she was not improving as quickly as doctors had hoped.

title: DISAGREEING, BUT IN A COMMON TONGUE
description: A CLUMSY attempt by four Cuban Embassy employees to kidnap a Cuban defector on a Madrid street has jolted relations between Spain and Fidel Castro. Two dozen passersby thwarted the kidnappers, Spain expelled them and diplomatic notes were angrily exchanged.

title: Briton Held in Lebanon Is Said to Issue Message
description: A British official of the United Nations, kidnapped in West Beirut nine months ago, has reportedly issued a message to the British Government to release a number of Arabs and Moslems who are prisoners in British jails in return for his freedom.

title: FARMER AND FAMILY, ON THE BRINK, FACING A MEAGER CHRISTMAS;
description: For the young Gladbach family, the evening was much like the farming season, a time of contrasting scenes and moods.

title: 'DEFINITIVE' MANTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mabeth Wilson to Marry Daniel S. Hudson in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce B. Wilson of St. Davids, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mabeth MacFarland Wilson to Daniel Scott Hudson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Hudson of Woodstock, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: DATA BANK

In percent#6.9#4.3#3.6 Producer Price IndexNov.#3 Mos.#12 Mos. title: MODERATE PANEL PUSHES FOR MORE WELFARE AID
description: A broad coalition of moderate leaders in both major political parties has concluded that Federal budget cuts will be so severe over the next few years that big changes must be made in the way the Government operates or there will be serious inequities and disruptions in services.

title: 247 PUPILS, 77 NATIONS IN 1 SCHOOL
description: The game was called four-square, and the place was a playground on a quiet street in Queens.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: COE HALL CHRISTMAS It doesn't take long to create a tradition; would you believe eight years? That's all it has taken Friends of the Arts to make ''Christmas at Coe Hall'' part of the holiday schedule. And today's the day the Great Hall of the Coe mansion, with its high vaulted ceilings and leaded glass windows (and appropriate seasonal decorations) goes back in time for a concert of 16th-century music. Dressed in the proper gear and playing brass and double-reed instruments of the era, the Hopewell Renaissance Band does the musical honors with a program that includes works by Josquin des Prez and Michael Praetorius. The concert, followed by a reception, is at 2:30 P.M. at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. Tickets are $7.50.

title: MUSIC: CELTIC TRADITION
description: WITH a new lineup, the Boys of the Lough remain one of the finest bands in Celtic traditional music. Christy Moore on uillean pipes and John Coakley on piano and guitar have joined the fiddler Aly Bain, the flutist Cathal McConnell and the cittern (long-necked mandolin) and concertina player Dave Richardson.

title: Fast Track
description: Shola Lynch won the girls' 1,000-yard run yesterday in 2 minutes 39.2 seconds at the 32d annual Bishop Loughlin indoor interscholastic games at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: EVEN SPECIAL PARENTS NEED HELP WITH SPECIAL CHILDREN
description: MRS. R never stopped asking herself why she had given birth to a disabled child - until she found the answer.

title: Comings and Goings
description: James Edwards, the Phoenix Suns' center, will be out indefinitely because of two bone spurs on his right ankle. . . . Jiro Watanabe of Japan, the World Boxing Council super-flyweight champion, will defend his title against the top-ranked contender, Gilberto Roman of Mexico, in March with the date and site to be chosen. . . . Eamonn Coghlan, Sydney Maree and Steve Scott will lead the field for the mile race at the United States Olympic Invitational meet at the Meadowlands Feb. 8. . . . Dave Hampton, a former Atlanta Falcons running back, was ordered to pay $43,000 in restitution to a mortgage lender and to perform 300 hours of community service after pleading guilty to forging a mortgage agreement.

title: ENGLAND
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: AUSTIN STREET SPAWNS A DEVELOPER
description: WHEN oldtimers in the Forest Hills section of Queens speak of going to ''the village'' to shop they are probably referring to Austin Street. Its mock-Tudor architecture has sustained its village-like character even as prosperity has brought change. The English flavor is especially prevalent in the quarter-mile stretch from Continental Avenue, or 71st Avenue, eastward to Ascan Avenue.

title: Miss Davis Weds R. E. Massengill
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Akron, Ohio, yesterday Susan Lynn Davis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Davis of Akron, was married to Robert Endres Massengill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton E. Massengill of Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George E. Ross, assisted by the Rev. Martha J. Everhard, the bride's aunt.

title: NOW, FOR LONELY COMMUTERS, CLUBS ON WHEELS
description: In October 1983 Ruth Guillou saw the man of her dreams at a stoplight.

title: A NEW FASHION ON FIFTH AVENUE
description: Van Cleef & Arpels Inc., the Fifth Avenue jewelry store, last week joined the growing list of fashionable retailers accused of violating tax laws to please purchasers of big-ticket items. Claude Arpels, the company president, and Al Schwartz, the controller, were indicted on charges of conspiring to help customers evade city and state sales taxes on more than $4.9 million worth of jewelry.

title: A TALE OF THREE TOWNS
description: NOT long ago, shoppers in this country's smaller towns and cities were the stepchildren of national retailing. At Christmas, they squirmed in the clutches of a few dowdy retailers who offered limited selections and fixed prices.

title: IT'S GOOD NEWS YOU WATN? TRY THE ELMER TIMES
description: On Sunday afternoons, Helen Richards, correspondent for The Elmer Times, starts phoning for news in Daretown and Aldine.

title: WHEN BIRD TOOK FLIGHT
description: SWING TO BOP An Oral History of the Transition in Jazz in the 1940s. By Ira Gitler. Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50.

title: CHRISTMAS POINSETTIAS: A NATURAL DISPLAY
description: THE poinsettia, which is native to Mexico, was first cultivated near Taxco and was prized by Montezuma, the Aztec king. As the result of its brilliant red color, it was considered to be a symbol of purity. The Indians also used the red bracts as a source of red dye.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE OUT-HAUL. By Alannah Hopkin. (Hamish Hamilton/David & Charles, $16.95.) Despite a century of troubles in Ireland, documented powerfully by Yeats, O'Casey, Bernard MacLaverty and Benedict Kiely, the myth of the Brigadoon-like Irish village still hovers over the landscape.

title: FOR ARTS GROUPS IN MANHATTAN, THE LEASE IS THE THING
description: When Joseph Papp founded the New York Shakespeare Festival 30 years ago, he paid no rent for its home, a church cellar on the Lower East Side. Twelve years later, when he moved the organization to new quarters in the East Village, the cost of the space was not much higher. But if the festival were looking for a home today, he maintains, he could not afford to open, at least not in Manhattan.

title: 'Shocking' Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz
description: The drummer Art Blakey and the trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie, two veterans who have left a strong personal stamp on jazz, will both be on New York bandstands with their groups this weekend. Mr. Gillespie, who is now 68 years old, and Mr. Blakey, who is 66, were playing together 41 years ago in Billy Eckstine's big be-bop band, the first of its kind. Both had come out of the big band world of the 1930's - Mr. Blakey was with Fletcher Henderson's orchestra and Mr. Gillespie played in Teddy Hill's band and was with Cab Calloway for two years.

title: U.S. BACKS SOME DAMAGE AWARDS OVER ZONING
description: The Justice Department, in a significant shift, has urged the Supreme Court to rule that state and local governments must sometimes pay landowners damages for zoning and other land-use restrictions that diminish the value of property.

title: A REAL CHRISTMAS CALLS FOR A REAL TREE
description: JUST about this time every year, I hear the argument from my family. At issue are the merits of a real tree over an artificial one.

title: PAPERS OF SUB'S INVENTOR DONATED
description: IN A letter to Thomas A. Edison in 1904, John Philip Holland, the Irish-born inventor credited with developing the first modern submarine, stated the purpose of his life's work.

title: A SALUTE IN VERSE TO AN ISLAND DIVERSE: SEASON'S GREETINGS
description: SEASON'S greetings to Whitman's Paumanok, Long Island From th east River to Montauk's open, sandy strand.

title: LIVING ON A LANDFILL
description: When Gateway Plaza, the first apartment project in Battery Park City, was just a thought in the minds of its planners, no one knew whether New Yorkers would want to live on 92 acres of landfill at the tip of Manhattan. But since that project opened in 1982 the public's enthusiastic response has demonstrated that there is a demand for both rental and owner-occupied housing there.

title: Eleni Pournaras Plans To Wed an Executive
description: Announcement has been made by Irene Pournaras of Hamden, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter Eleni Alexandra Pournaras to Albert Gallatin Blakey 4th, a son of Gretchen Vedder Blakey of Hellam, Pa., and Mr. Blakey 3d of York, Pa.

title: REPUBLICANS SEEK CUOMO CHALLENGER
description: Four years ago there were at least three Republicans interested in running for governor, and the Republican state chairman at the time, George L. Clark Jr., was asked by some candidates not to interfere in the competition.

title: THE HOME SCREEN VS. A MOVIE HOUSE
description: To the Editor: It was with interest that I read Vincent Canby's recent articles on VCR's. As a well-established critic and film-goer in New York City, he unavoidably misses a few of the virtues of VCR's that a serious film watcher in ''the provinces'' can more readily appreciate.

title: RESCUING TURTLES OFF LONG ISLAND
description: THE Kemp's Ridley turtle is threatened enough in its natural breeding ground - it nests in Mexico -without being in the wrong place at the wrong time. That is why the appearance of more than two dozen of the endangered sea turtles on Long Island beaches in the last few weeks has prompted intensive rescue efforts and some head-scratching.

title: EARLY DRIVE SET TONE FOR GIANTS
description: One by one, they talked about that first drive, ''the confidence builder,'' as Bart Oates, the center, called it.

title: Calendars
description: Horse Shows Friday through Sunday - Old Salem Farm, North Salem, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information (914) 669-5610.

title: Pamela Ann Wood Wed
description: At the United Church of Christ in North Hampton, N.H., yesterday Pamela Ann Wood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Wood of North Hampton, was married to David Thomas Arthur, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Arthur of Hingham, Mass. The Rev. William McConnell performed the ceremony. The bride attended Sweet Briar College. Mr. Arthur is a senior at Washington and Lee University.

title: DANCE: AILEY TROUPE 'IN THE BLACK TRADITION
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater offered another of its special events of the season on Tuesday night at the City Center Theater. The program, called ''In the Black Tradition,'' which is to be repeated at 3 today, consisted of four works derived from black American history, and the commentator was Judith Jamison, a former leading dancer of the company who also achieved acclaim on Broadway in ''Sophisticated Ladies'' and who remains active as a teacher and choreographer.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE STORY OF SIRIO. By Ferdinando Camon. Translated by Cassandra Bertea. (Marlboro Press, Paper, $8.) ''The Story of Sirio'' traces the sentimental education of its title character, the heir to an automobile fortune in an unnamed Italian city.

title: Transactions
