description: FOOTBALL DETROIT (NFC) - Placed Mark Nichols, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Activated Duane Galloway, cornerback, from injured reserve.

title: CHAMPION AXMAN GROWS TREES NOW
description: LAST summer, Boonville, N.Y., honored him by naming a day after him, and Jewett City hung a banner that said, ''Home of Dave Geer - World Champion Woodchopper.''

title: THE UNTHINKABLE WAS UNPRINTABLE
description: BEYOND BELIEF The American Press and the Coming of the Holocaust, 1933-1945. By Deborah E. Lipstadt. 370 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: 'AT WOR,' A PEG FOR THREENEW ROCHELLE FACULTY PAINTERS
description: ATITLE such as ''At Work'' leads an observer to expect an exhibition that explores the artistic process in a thoroughgoing manner. For example, it might include a printmaker who shows us his etching plates or lithography stone, or a sculptor who exhibits his specialized tools. The journey from initial idea to finished work might be made to seem exciting and enlightening.

title: AGENT, TURNING 80, HONORED BY STARS
description: ON Christmas Day, Johnny Pransky of Fort Lee will be 80 years old. Still spry, wiry and with a sparkle in his eyes, he was the guest of honor last Sunday at a celebration at the Montammy Golf Club here.

title: 'STAR WARS'
description: To the Editor:

title: YULETIDE SPIRIT AFFECTS PETS, TOO
description: NO matter how much the children may plead for a puppy at Christmas, this is not the time, all the humane societies agree, to introduce a new pet into your home. If the holidays are overwhelming for children, they are more so for a little animal suddenly taken from its litter mates. When the excitement of the holidays has passed, and if you still think a pet is a good idea, then is the time to get one.

title: MANDELA TAKEN FROM HER HOME IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Armed white policemen forcibly removed Winnie Mandela, the South African black activist, from her home in this segregated township today after she refused to accept renewed and relaxed restrictions on her movements, family friends and lawyers said.

title: SPAIN
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: PROSECUTION ENDS CASE IN NURSING HOME TRIAL
description: Patients at a nursing home were left lying in filth for hours and there were shortages of food and medicine, witnesses have testified at a trial in which the nursing home is charged with murder by neglect in the death of an elderly woman.

title: APPLYING PLASTIC LAMINATE: LITTLE THINGS COUNT
description: WHETHER it is used to resurface an old table or counter top, or to finish off a new cabinet or storage unit, plastic laminate has become increasingly popular with do-it-yourselfers, cabinetmakers and furniture manufacturers.

title: PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS FAIL TO REPORT PATIENT CRIMES, STATE PANEL SAYS
description: Directors of state psychiatric centers are breaking the law by failing to report possible crimes among patients to the police, a state commission has concluded.

title: SOVIET LETTERS
description: 'Today's long-awaited striving for change for the better in our country gives us profound hopes that self-flattery will be forever rejected, and that nonconcealment will become the norm of civic behavior. We, men of letters, will not be worth a penny if we simply report and laud the social transformations taking place independently of us.' Yevgeny Yevtushenko Soviet poet, at a congress of Russian writers

title: HOW THE INTANGIBLE GIFT OF A WISE MAN BROUGHT HOLIDAY JOY TO A FAMILY
description: CHRISTMAS is a time when we give and receive material gifts. The Wise Men gave items of value: gold, frankincense and myrrh. We continue that tradition today by placing under the Christmas tree brightly wrapped packages containing sweaters, neckties, jewelry and toys for those whom we love.

title: A LIBRARY OF TOYS REFITTED FOR DISABLED
description: APRIL POWERS, a bright-eyed 7-year-old with a trusting smile, was growing impatient with the adults standing around her wheelchair, just chatting.

title: Lesson to Be Learned From Budget Process
description: I read, with great interest, your articles [''O'Rourke Blames Aid Cuts for Need to Raise Taxes,'' Nov. 17; ''Board Seeks to Trim Rise in Property Tax,'' Nov. 24] about the County Executive's proposed 1986 county budget. The 1986 proposal suggests a 50 percent solid-waste tax hike and an 11 percent tax increase in the county budget.

title: NEW UHF STATION STARTS UP AMID HUDSON VALLEY GROWTH
description: A new television station, WTZA-TV (Channel 62), went on the air this week in the Hudson Valley, with a signal that reached as far north as Hudson Falls, some 40 miles north of Albany, and as far south as New York City.

title: AN OIL TOWN LOOKS FOR A NEW MEANS OF SUPPORT
description: Carolyn Fielder, an interior decorator, has fond memories of the great oil boom that gripped this energy capital until fairly recently. Petroleum companies came to her with unlimited budgets. ''They just said make it wonderful,'' she recalled wistfully. ''It was real fun.'' Now her firm, Campbell Design, has lost nearly all its commercial accounts. With the sudden collapse of the boom, many office projects have been canceled; one of her clients cannot afford even to replace its threadbare carpets.

title: The Muse in the Mead Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR 'HOLLY CITY,' CHRISTMAS IS OVER
description: AMONG the commercial traditions of the Pine Barrens, sand mining and boat building are not what they used to be and burning wood to produce charcoal is a thing of the past.

title: Cable TV
description: The altruistic theme of ''Magnificent Obsession'' (1954) seems apt for the season, especially on a leisurely Sunday - 4:55 P.M. over WTBS - with many cable viewers contemplating Christmas at midweek. Cynics will find the film sentimental and obvious, as a romantic drama about a stricken widow and a reformed playboy. But the story is well handled, with a handsome production, a good performance by young Rock Hudson in his first major role and a beautiful one by Jane Wyman that steadies the whole enterprise. Try it, for a little Yuletide inspiration with love-story flavoring.

title: TRUMP TO OPERATE JERSEY ANCHORAGE
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, has leased a New Jersey-owned marina adjacent to his Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino here.

title: CANADA
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: RATE REQUEST BY LILCO SEEKING A SIGNAL
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company cannot collect $1.4 billion of the cost of the Shoreham nuclear power plant from its customers because Lilco mismanaged the $4.5 billion project, the State Public Service Commission said last week in a long-awaited order.

title: Father Who Shot Ill Girl Gets Life Sentence
description: Charles Leroy Griffith, who said he was insane when he fatally shot his comatose 3-year-old daughter in her hospital crib June 28, has been sentenced to life in prison for the killing.

title: BONNER ADDRESSES SYNAGOGUE CROWD
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet human rights activist, went to a synagogue here today and expressed her hope that Jews in the Soviet Union will be allowed to join their families abroad.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN BY RANGERS, 5-4
description: The Islanders played catchup hockey from the end of the first period until a dramatic two-minute flurry at the close of the game, but succeeded only in losing by the closest of margins as they were defeated by the Rangers, 5-4, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: 4 KILLED IN BLAST AT AN ITALIAN OIL DEPOT
description: An explosion ripped through a petroleum storage depot in this port city early today, killing at least 4 people, injuring more than 160, forcing the evacuation of as many as 2,000 residents and touching off an oil-fed fire that raged into the night.

title: STILL GUILTY
description: Fifteen years ago, Jeffrey MacDonald's wife, Collette, and their two young daughters, Kimberly, 5, and Kristen, 2, were stabbed and bludgeoned to death in their home at Fort Bragg, N.C. Ever since, Dr. MacDonald, who was an Army physician in 1970, has been attempting to prove he did not commit the murders. He lost another round in that prolonged legal battle last week, when a Federal appeals court upheld his 1979 murder conviction.

title: A SWEET DEAL FOR NEW HIRES
description: ATTRACTING housewives, actors and students to work part-time in stores - not to mention bright, young college graduates willing to make retailing a career - is one of the prime concerns (some say nightmares) that retailers must face during the Christmas season. The merchants need to expand their staffs to handle the shopper bulge. Yet the relatively low pay, long hours and hectic pace are not exactly drawing cards.

title: Decline and Fall Of Teaching History
description: In secondary schools, the history curriculum is its own self-destruct mechanism. In one year, students in their early teens are expected to know the cultural and political history of India, Africa, Asia, the Middle East and the Soviet Union; the causes and effects of the Renaissance, Reformation, Industrial Revolution, Imperialism, Colonialism, and World Wars I and II, Korea, Vietnam and concepts such as detente, cold war, balance of power, spheres of influence.

title: CITY, ORDERED TO SHUT DEPOT, SAYS SNOWPLOWING IN QUEENS MAY LAG
description: A court order to close a Sanitation Department depot in a Queens park has led the agency to warn that there could be delays in plowing out northeastern Queens after large snowfalls in the next three years.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: THE TRUTH ABOUT SANTA CLAUS. By James Cross Giblin. Thomas Y. Crowell. $11.50. (Ages 8 to 12) If, having grasped the truth, you would seriously like to know how a man's deeds eventually led to holiday traditions, which then turned into commerce, here's the book.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MYTH OF WOMEN'S MASOCHISM. By Paula J. Caplan. (Dutton, $16.95.) Paula J. Caplan, a clinical and research psychologist, has written a useful compendium on a subject central to contemporary feminism.

title: POLICE SUSPECT ARSONIST CAUSED FIRE AT ELITE PARIS FOOD STORE
description: The police said today that they suspected that the fire Friday at Fauchon, the renowned luxury food store, was the work of an arsonist. The fire killed the owner and her daughter and injured 11 other people.

title: SMALL INVESTORS ARE DOING IT TOGETHER
description: Wall Street has never provided a very stable haven for the small investor, the one who buys a few shares on the basis of a tip from a friend or a shoeshine boy. But at least until a few years ago, the little guy had a lot of company. A stampede was likely to include many other independent buyers, who influenced the direction of the market only when they acted or reacted in droves.

title: Anne K. Giaever Becomes a Bride
description: Anne Kari Giaever, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ivar Giaever of Schenectady, N.Y., was married yesterday to Marc Anthony Meyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Meyer of Colorado Springs, Colo. Judge Louise Smith of the Schenectady Municipal Court officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: DRUG RING REPORTEDLY SMASHED
description: The United States and the Netherlands have smashed a drug ring that sought to ship heroin and hashish to America in exchange for cash and cocaine, according to the Justice Department.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO OUR VANGUARD?
description: In thinking about this year's Next Wave Festival - the prestigious, trendy avant-garde showcase at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -the question arose recently as to whether the downtown vanguard creative scene in general and music in particular are in a lull.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HISTORY OF THE UNIVERSE. By Jennifer Bartlett. (Moyer Bell/Nimbus Books, Mount Kisco, N.Y., $15.95.) For those interested in the universe of the well-known painter Jennifer Bartlett, her apparently autobiographical novel may well prove irresistible.

title: LA MAM TAKES A BREAK FROM THE AVANT-GARDE
description: In the adaptable environment of La Mama Annex, Andrei Serban re-fought ''The Trojan Wars,'' Peter Brook sent the audience figuratively flying on a Persian carpet of a spectacle entitled ''The Conference of the Birds,'' and, last year, Ping Chong offered his sleekly modern ''Nosferatu.'' Earlier this season, in the same space, Tadeusz Kantor led his ensemble through a symbolic re-enactment of his life and times in 20th-century Poland.

title: MANSION OFFERS A SETTING OF BEAUTY
description: IN an elegant Lewisboro mansion flanked by a dramatic stone silo, Rene Chardain, the owner and chef, has created one of the most beautiful restaurants in the county, with its serene, regal blue dining rooms and well-spaced, prettily appointed tables. Fresh flowers, heavy linens, elegant china and tapestried chairs, as comfortable as they are beautiful, further enhance the luxurious interior.

title: ITALY
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them. As the headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church, Rome is a city in which Christmas should be an important holiday. And in many ways it is, reflected notably at St. Peter's and in the creches that pop up all around the city. The shopping districts around Via Condotti get dressed up, a mixture of the quietly tasteful and the garish.

title: A DIOCESE FAILS TO BLOCK 2 CLINICS
description: New York State's highest court rejected last week a suit by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany that had sought to prevent the State Health Department from issuing permits for two abortion clinics. The decision by the State Court of Appeals overturned two lower-court rulings that would have required the department to conduct a more thorough investigation of the need for the clinics, one in Albany, the other in nearby Hudson.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CLARA'S HEART. By Joseph Olshan. (Belvedere/ Arbor House, $15.95.) Near the end of this impressive novel, Clara Mayfield, a middle-aged black Jamaican working for a wealthy family in suburban New York, makes a bleak generalization about her new home: ''Americans always seem to be looking for a change. . . . Car is old after two years, a dress no longer the style, so you pitch them away.

title: Phot of Glenn Close with Sam Waterston (NYT/Jim Wilson) IS GLENN CLOSE THE IDEAL HEROINE?
description: For a time, Glenn Close burned so bright, and her successes piled up so steadily, that it seemed she could do no wrong. As Oscar, Emmy and Tony nominations cascaded, critics proclaimed the actress incandescent, intelligent, polished and dazzlingly versatile. Then came ''Maxie.'' The movie marked Miss Close's attempt to veer away from the strong and silent earth mothers she had portrayed in movies such as ''The World According to Garp,'' ''The Big Chill'' and ''The Natural'' and try a character who was funny and slightly peculiar.

title: TEACHING PEOPLE TO BE BETTER PARENTS
description: ''Hands-On Experiences in Handling of Children'' [About Long Island, Nov. 17] described the comprehensive child study program at Herricks Senior High School. Parenting is an integral part of the home economics curriculum.

title: Reviewer Missed Mark On Avant-Garde
description: I am complimented that William Zimmer, in his Dec. 1 review of my exhibition ''Rethinking the Avant-Garde'' (Katonah Gallery) thinks there is only ''one thing wrong'' with it. I am however disappointed that -in six columns - he never got around to addressing any of the substantive issues in the catalogue or show. Instead of responding to my ''rethinking'' of what it means to be avant-garde in a consumer society, he trotted out the cliche of ''being derided for flying in the face of tradition'' as his definition of avant-garde and repeated the current conceit that we can have no avant-garde with ''a moneyed audience, forever hungry for the new.''

title: A NIGHT AT SHELTERS IN NEWARK
description: ONE-fourth of the nation's homeless may have acute medical problems, experts say, and an even greater percentage may have chronic conditions or physical disabilities that make it difficult for them to work.

title: Miss Gilbert Has Wedding
description: Elizabeth A. Gilbert, a daughter of Drs. James Bryson Gilbert and Enid Fischer Gilbert of Madison, Wis., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Mark L. Bono, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Bono of New Bedford, Mass.

title: Oklahoma Indians Win Injunction in Bingo Case
description: A Federal district judge has issued a permanent injunction barring the Oklahoma Tax Commission and the Tulsa County District Attorney's office from controlling and taxing operators of a high-stakes bingo game run by the Muscogee Creek Indian Nation here.

title: Mary Shelley's Longings
description: To the Editor:

title: YOU CAN HELP YOUTH NOW FOR LESS
description: ''ALL of us kids' lives would've gone down the drain if we didn't get help. I'll always remember the dedicated people who were there when we needed them.'' This is from a former student at Educage, the alternative school sponsored for many years by the Cage Teen Center in White Plains From an employee of College Careers, another group in White Plains that offers an opportunity for higher education to disadvantaged young people: ''At a time when most people turned their backs on me, you gave me a chance.''

title: OLD GARDEN FIT LIKE A COMFORTABLE SHOE
description: WE once heard an old gentleman, when complaining bitterly about the round structure called Madison Square Garden atop Penn Station, wind up a long tirade by describing the old Garden up Eighth Avenue at 50th Street as an ''arena with a soul.'' Now, we have no doubt, in an abstract view of the case, that he was right, for doubtless no arena without a soul can be described as a genial place.

title: HORS D'OUEVRES TO ACCOMPANY HOLIDAYS
description: THE holiday season is the time for champagne. More of the luxury sparkler is sold in December than at any other time of year. Although the term champagne should refer only to those bubbly bottlings that come from a small region in France east of Paris, it has come to mean the entire category of sparkling wines.

title: WALLACE P. ANDERSON
description: Wallace P. (Mad Bear) Anderson, a longtime champion of Indian rights, died Friday after a long illness.

title: HOLIDAY TRADITIONS IN HOMES OF YORE
description: CHRISTMAS was not celebrated in colonial Connecticut, a stronghold of Puritanism. Declaring a holiday and observing the Yuletide by bringing in decorative evergreens, having a festive dinner and giving presents was considered pagan. But by the 19th century in the towns and cities, if not as yet in all rural areas, this attitude changed.

title: Gretchen Frank Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Gretchen Rees Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Armin C. Frank Jr., of Philadephia and Stowe, Vt., to Francis James Carey 3d, a son of Mrs. Richard D. Sears of Aiken, S.C., and Mr. Carey of Ambler, Pa., took place yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Fort Washington, Pa. The Rev. James R. Nicoll 3d, assisted by the Rev. Richard Hawkins, performed the ceremony.

title: TESTIMONY IN POPE CASE ENDS IN SOFIA
description: An Italian court trying to determine whether Bulgaria conspired to assassinate Pope John Paul II returned this week to the city where such a plot was supposedly devised.

title: A MYSTERY SOLVED: TALE OF THE MISSING PHOTO
description: It is a cover-up of Himalayan proportions. An American mountain-climbing team wanted to do something monumental to honor the General Assembly's 40th session. So last May the team, sponsored by the United Nations, braved glacial cold and howling winds to put the blue and white United Nations flag at the summit of Mount Everest.

title: VERMONT
description: After some tentative starts, the ski season along the winding State Route 100, which runs up the spine of Vermont, got under way this month following a substantial snowfall. The state has close to 30 ski centers, which attract hundreds of thousands ofvisitors. But the slopes provide only a glimpse of the attractions of Vermont, which for many travelers, whether skiers or not, is at its most charming in winter. Straddling Route 100 and the back roads branching off to the small towns that comprise the heart of the state, visitors find a host of craft shops, factory outlets, restaurants and farms. They also discover antiques shops and auctions, art exhibits, local festivals and fresh maple and apple products.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SANTA'S workshop may be in the North Pole, but social service agencies, hospitals and other organizations that provide presents for needy children look toward Rahway State Prison, not the pole.

title: Juliana Reiss Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter G. Reiss of Westport, Conn., and Lake Placid, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Juliana Cecelia Reiss to Roger Kingsley Smith, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard W. Smith of New Haven and Lake Placid. The wedding is planned for June 7.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: PULLING THE PLUG ''HI, I'm the Lottery Express and I make it quick and easy. . .''

title: TAKING DELIGHT IN HIS FAULTS
description: POLITICS By Edward I. Koch with William Rauch. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: ISRAEL
description: This is a special season in much of the world. In some countries Christmas is the centerpiece of the celebration, in others New Year's or Twelfth Night. Following are reports from 15 Times correspondents and bureaus on how the holidays are celebrated in their areas, and tips on how a visitor can join in - or cope with - them.

title: Joe Klecko: Moving Fast
description: EIGHT days ago against the Chicago Bears, at a moment when most eyes were certainly on the ball about to be snapped, Joe Klecko propelled his burly 260-pound body a few feet to the right in one nimble sequence. He was therefore hunkered in when Walter Payton came a-running with the football, and was able to slam Payton to the frozen chemical floor.

title: Stephanie Baranof Wed
description: Stephanie L. Baranof, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Baranof of East Hills, L.I., and Harry A. DeMell, the son of Marcia Fine of Manhattan and the late Paul DeMell of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, were married yesterday. Rabbi Robert Orkand, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Lisa A. Doyle Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. James L. Doyle of Salem, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Doyle, to Peter Eaton Gardiner, a son of Robert M. Gardiner of Far Hills, N.J., and Janet Eaton Glover of Hanover, N.H. The wedding is planned for May. Miss Doyle, an associate product manager for the Gillette Company in Boston, graduated from the Phillips Academy and cum laude from Harvard University.

title: TEANECK SCHOOL BOARD PRAISED FOR ACTIONS
description: The Dec. 8 article ''Broader State Role Sought in Aiding Gifted Child'' was a welcome contribution to an ongoing and much-needed debate on ways to foster gifted preschool children.

title: FRANCE'S BITTER BRAND OF ETHNIC POLITICS
description: It was more than 100 years ago that a nationalistic textbook writer began to mold the minds of generations of French schoolchildren by starting a history of France with the phrase, ''Our ancestors the Gauls.'' Though black children in France's African and Caribbean colonies learned from the same textbook about some historic blood tie with the ancient Celtic race that lived in this country, France is now witnessing a renewal of a kind of nativist sentiment, a fear that Gallic blood is being diluted by Arab, black and other non-European immigration.

title: Anna Kavan, Englishwoman
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CALIFORNIA'S TOP JUDGE, THE TRIALS OF A CAMPAIGN
description: In a single evening recently, lawyers, businessmen and Hollywood entertainers contributed $280,000 to the re-election campaign of Rose Elizabeth Bird, the Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court. That day, the first of a planned wave of thousands of video cassettes containing what Miss Bird's supporters characterize as ''vicious'' attacks were distributed to California voters by one of four conservative groups vowing to prevent her return to the bench.

title: NEW SUPPORT FROW AFRICA AS W.H.O. PLANS EFFORT ON AIDS
description: In an important change of attitude, major African countries have started to become more open about AIDS, and officials of the World Health Organization, in an expression of mounting concern, say they plan a new push to control the global epidemic of the usually fatal disease.

title: GOOD NEWS AND BAD FOR GHANDI
description: It was much quieter on the Western front last week for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India, but there was some static from the northeast.

title: PRIVATE GROUP TO ACQUIRE PUBLIC-HOUSING COMPLEX
description: THE New Rochelle Neighborhood Revitalization Corporation, a nonprofit private organization, has announced plans to acquire from the city three public housing buildings containing 180 apartment units. The arrangement, involving a total cost of about $4.5 million, will be financed by a bond issue to be floated in the spring and by a grant for renovations from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: MUSEUM TRACES RELIGIOUS 'AWAKENINGS' ON L.I.
description: IF a history museum is supposed to help people see where they have been so they can understand why they are here and where they are going, the Suffolk County Historical Society Museum in Riverhead has come up with a relevant learning experience in its new exhibition.

title: KNICKS TOP PISTONS, 112-110
description: His teammates call him The Animal because of the havoc he can -and often does - create on a basketball court, and because of the great quantities of food he has been known to devour.

title: MORRIS PUTS GIANTS IN PLAYOFFS WITH 3 TOUCHDOWNS
description: The Giants are in the playoffs. They made it today, in their final game of the National Football League's regular season, by handing the Pittsburgh Steelers sound beatings on offense and defense and winning, 28-10.

title: On Welfare
description: Excerpts from a paper by Robert Lerman, a professor at Brandeis University, one winner of a recent contest in which the Institute for Socioeconomic Studies, in White Plains, asked for essays proposing sweeping welfare reforms:

title: THE FARMERS BEAT THE PRESIDENT
description: The Reagan Administration wanted this post-election year to be the time for sweeping reform of farm policy. It wanted to abolish the vast welfare system for the agriculture industry and force it to submit to market disciplines, leaving only a safety net for the minority of poor farmers. The drive has failed; the President is beaten. Congress would only trim and patch the system and has committed the nation to five more years of hugely expensive and inefficient programs.

title: Russian Asks French Refuge
description: Officials said today that a Soviet seaman from the grain carrier Ivan Pokrovsky jumped overboard here on Friday and was seeking political asylum. He was aided by passers-by as he emerged from the water. An inquiry is being held to confirm his identity and intentions, the officials said.

title: E.P.A. PLANS TO DROP 8 SITES FROM LIST OF WORST DUMPS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has announced plans to drop eight hazardous waste sites, including one in Upper Freehold, N.J., from its priority list of dumps requiring quick cleanup action.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SAM SHEPARD. By Don Shewey. (Dell, Paper, $3.95.) With cover copy that reads ''The Life, the Loves, Behind the Legend of a True American Original,'' this book at first glance seems like just another slapdash celebrity biography.

title: CLOSE U.S.-ISRAEL RETLATIONSHIP MAKES KEEPING SECRETS HARD
description: The relationship between Israel and the United States has become so intimate that many American officials are convinced of Israel's ability, on a routine basis, to obtain sensitive information about this country's secret weapons, advanced technology and internal policy deliberations in Washington.

title: FROM NEW YORK, BANKING BY PHONE
description: A NEW YORK CITY bank has gained a foothold in the Connecticut market with a bank-by-mail program, but the State Banking Department is considering whether the service violates interstate banking laws.

title: IN HIS TIME AND IN HISTORY
description: JESUS AND JUDAISM By E. P. Sanders. 444 pp. Philadelphia: Fortress Press. $19.95. JESUS THROUGH THE CENTURIES His Place in the History of Culture. By Jaroslav Pelikan. Illustrated. 270 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22.50. ONE of the most remarkable features of E. P. Sanders' latest contribution to the study of Christian origins is that it lacks a subtitle. In effect, the author claims to be presenting a total picture of an extremely complex topic. The wonder is that to a large degree he has succeeded. I would be surprised if ''Jesus and Judaism'' does not turn out to be the most significant book of the decade in its field. For Mr. Sanders, who is the Dean Ireland's Professor of Exegesis of Holy Scripture in the University of Oxford, the task confronting historians of earliest Christianity is easily defined - how to characterize Jesus' intentions and His relationship to His Jewish contemporaries. That Jesus was executed by the Romans no one doubts. But to what extent, if any, did His death result from some opposition by Him to the Judaism of His day?

title: HAVES, HAVE-NOTS AND GEORGICA POND
description: I cannot help but comment on the Georgica Pond flap [''Dispute Roils Georgica Pond,'' Nov. 3] . It's really a question of the advantaged wanting their advantages.

title: MUSIC: BRUCE PURSE LEADS AN 11-PIECE BAND
description: FOR the last six weeks an exuberantly brassy and strongly rhythmic big band has been taking shape at Mikell's.

title: Spaniards Pick the Winners In Lottery Worth $406 Million
description: Spain's Christmas lottery, advertised as the world's largest, paid tax-exempt prizes Saturday that totaled 63 billion pesetas, the equivalent of $406 million.

title: SETBACK SEEN FOR POLICY
description: China said this week that the 1985 grain harvest was likely to be about 53 million tons less than the record crop of 407 million tons last year.

title: Boeing Deal Scrutinized
description: The Canadian Government said it would form a parliamentary committee to examine Boeing's planned acquisition of de Havilland Aircraft of Canada.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: Florida Sinkhole Absorbs A House and a Carport
description: A 70-foot-wide sinkhole continued growing today after swallowing a house and carport and forcing evacuation of four homes here, officials said.

title: Just in Time
description: Kit Waller Tollerson will always be No. 10,000 in his parents' hearts.

title: Von Bulow Asserts He Plans To Move to Europe Next Year
description: Claus von Bulow, who was acquitted in June of twice trying to kill his wife, says he intends to leave the United States early next year and take up permanent residence in Europe.

title: 9-WEEK ALIEN TRIAL STILL HEARING FIRST WITNESS
description: As the trial of 11 church workers charged with transporting illegal aliens reached the end of its ninth week Friday, the first witness for the Government was still on the stand under cross-examination.

title: Turner Pessimism On MGM
description: Turner Broadcasting System has suggested that its heavy borrowing to acquire the MGM/UA Entertainment Company could cripple its ability to run MGM as a major movie studio.

title: HOLYFIELD IMPRESSIVE AS VICTOR
description: Blood was spread on the dressing room floor of Pavilion Convention Center in Virginia Beach. A single drop stained a white leather boxing shoe a few feet from where Anthony Davis sat in a folding chair after his battering by Evander Holyfield.

title: BEAN MESHES MAN, MACHINE
description: Each year, some 2.5 million people who are outdoors enthusiasts - or just want to look the part - make a pilgrimage to L. L. Bean Inc.'s famous retail store, a landmark in this small Maine town. With visions of down vests, chamois shirts and rubber-bottomed Maine hunting shoes dancing in their heads, most probably do not even notice the sprawling, metal-skinned building that stands unidentified off Route 1, just about a half-mile down the road from Bean's store.

title: GANGS VS. ASPIRATIONS IN A MUSICAL 'PROJECT'
description: The Cabrini-Green public housing complex has long been synonymous here with unrelenting poverty and murderous street gangs. But now residents are offering what they say is a fuller picture of life there in ''Project,'' a musical documentary at the University of Illinois's Chicago campus.

title: VIGOR WINS NEW LIFE FOR FIREARMS AGENCY
description: Four years ago it was perhaps the most obscure of large Federal agencies, an outfit with an ungainly name and almost no influential friends. In fact, it was a law-enforcement agency that even President Reagan did not like, and had proposed to abolish.

title: O'Neill Sees No Tax-Bill Veto
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, predicted today that President Reagan would not veto a tax-revision measure if one reaches his desk sometime next year.

title: Tests of Heart Patient Produce Few Answers
description: An artificial heart patient here was on kidney dialysis today, and X-rays failed to determine what has caused her to be slow to respond to stimulus, hospital officials said.

title: Bridge: Rosmarin and Beers Vie In Knockout Team Final
description: Teams led by Michael Rosmarin of New York City and David Beers of Cromwell, Conn., contested the final of the Knockout Team Championship at the Winter Regionals of the Greater New York Bridge Association at the Sheraton Centre hotel in Manhattan last night.

title: GROUP EXAMINES SELECTION OF MINORITY JUDGES
description: Women, blacks and Hispanic people are more often chosen for the bench where judgeships are filled by appointment rather than election, a nonpartisan court-monitoring group says.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: BEARS UPSET DITKA IN VICTORY
description: Coach Mike Ditka was annoyed today even though his Chicago Bears romped to a 37-17 triumph over the Detroit Lions, equaling the National Football League record with 15 victories in 16 games. Ditka was critical because the offense generated only one of Chicago's four touchdowns.

title: ROLE OF RACER SATISFIES NEWMAN'S COMPETITIVE SIDE
description: NOT many champion race-car drivers are recognized so readily, especially when they're far from the rumble of the race course and hoofing it along Fifth Avenue. But this one is different. He catches the eye and the response is quick: ''Yes, yes, I know him! He's the one on the bottle of that salad dressing!''

title: Miller Scores 39 As U.S.C. Romps
description: Cheryl Miller scored 39 points and pulled down 24 rebounds as Southern California routed Oregon State, 117-55, today.

title: MIAMI, AT 7-0, REGISTERS SEASON'S STRONGEST FINISH
description: For all their wondrous achievements, appliances and a 15-1 record that was unmatched by any other team in the National Football League, the Chicago Bears did not finish the regular season as the league's hottest team.

title: U.S. Contract To Lockheed
description: The Air Force awarded a contract of nearly $2.1 billion to the Lockheed Corporation on Friday for giant C5-B cargo planes.

title: Inmates in Copter Escape Are Seen in Alabama
description: Three escaped prisoners and the woman the authorities say hijacked a helicopter to help them break out of a South Carolina prison last week stole a car at gunpoint in Alabama today, the authorities said. They said the inmates bragged about their escape and vowed they would not be taken alive.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 10:28 A.M. today and set at 10:34 P.M. tomorrow.

title: 2 Teams Might Use Planned Stadium
description: The chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation said yesterday that he would be willing to let two professional football teams play in a domed sports stadium planned for Queens.

title: FARM MEASURE'S AMBITIOUS GOALS MATCH ITS HIGH COSTS, EXPERTS SAY
description: The farm bill now on President Reagan's desk, the costliest in history, is an expensive gamble that America's agricultural troubles can be cured with lower prices and bigger Government paychecks, its defenders and its critics say.

title: IT'S WISE, WARY AND FULL OF PAIN, BUT CAPITAL CITY CAN STILL BE SURPRISED BY JOY
description: At this season, it is wise to be wary in a city where secrets flurry about in great whispery drifts. The capital's corps of polygraph technicians, who say they can detect who has been bad or good have been given fresh visions of sugar plums: Thousands more Government workers may be subject to occasional lie detector tests under an intensified policy against espionage and news disclosures that has been a matter of controversy and subsequent qualification at the White house.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: Muhammad Loses In Split Decision
description: Slobodan Kacar of Yugoslavia won the vacant International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight championship with a 15-round split decision over Eddie Mustafa Muhammad of the United States Saturday night.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   India Salutes American Justice
description: India, suing in America for the victims of the Bhopal disaster, has told the court its citizens cannot get justice in India. That's a breathtaking statement, however necessary to maintain the lawsuit against Union Carbide in the United States. The chemical company has moved to dismiss India's suit and may prevail if courts here are persuaded that India's own courts can do the job.

title: Nuclear Test in Nevada Is Delayed by Weather
description: A nuclear weapons test reportedly linked to President Reagan's plan for a space-based defense against missile attacks was postponed for the third time today because of weather conditions, the Department of Energy said.

title: It's Back to Work for Parcells
description: What does a football coach do on a Sunday when his team is not playing? He watches a football game, as Bill Parcells did today in the middle of a normal working day.

title: MANDATE TO END DEFICIT: REAGAN'S BUDGET CHALLENGE
description: In the holiday euphoria enveloping the White House, President Reagan's triumph last week in salvaging a tax overhaul plan was an especially happy gift from Congress. But White House aides say that with the focus of the new year shifting to preparation of a budget plan to cut the deficit, Mr. Reagan and his staff confront wrenching and far-reaching choices.

title: 'Contras' in Human-Rights Clothing
description: To the Editor:

title: 'BETWEEN THE DARKNESS AND THE DAWN' ON NBC
description: JUST in time to qualify as a candidate for worst television movie of the year, ''Between the Darkness and the Dawn'' is being slipped into the NBC schedule tonight at 9. Elizabeth Montgomery, who made her television debut in 1953 as an ingenue on her father's series, ''Robert Montgomery Presents,'' tries to play a 37-year-old woman awakening from a coma that has lasted 20 years.

title: Washington Watch;   Mexico's Debt Crisis
description: Momentum toward a resolution of Mexico's re-emergent debt crisis seems to be building. Jesus Silva Herzog, the country's Finance Minister, flew here last week straight from the meeting of the 11-member Catagena Group of Latin debtors in Monevideo, Uruguay, where participants urged their many creditors to cut interest rates.

title: POSSIBLE VIOLATION OF SECURITY RULES IN SPY CASE CITED
description: The company that employed a deliveryman accused of trying to sell secret documents to the Soviet Union appears to have violated Government rules requiring thorough destruction of classified material, a senior Federal official said today.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Dessoff Choirs Perform Motets and Respighi
description: The Advent and Christmas seasons were the subjects of the Dessoff Choirs' concert at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, and the program ranged from Renaissance motets to music by Respighi. The motets by Schutz, Dering, Byrd and Giovanni Gabrieli - all beautiful works - elicited the finest performances of the evening.

title: SOUR END FOR THE CARDINALS
description: Coach Jim Hanifan, dismissed with his entire staff late Saturday as coach of the St. Louis Cardinals, acknowledged today that his team was a major disappointment this year.

title: Soda Cans for Subways
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Britain Urges Release Of Journalist in Lebanon
description: Britain appealed today for kidnappers to release Alec Collett, a British journalist held in Lebanon, but said it would not make a deal for his freedom.

title: Cocaine and a Dead Bear
description: A 175-pound black bear apparently died of an overdose of cocaine after discovering a batch of the drug, the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said today. The cocaine was apparently dropped from a plane piloted by Andrew Thornton, a convicted drug smuggler who died Sept. 11 in Knoxville, Tenn., because he was carrying too heavy a load while parachuting. The bureau said the bear was found Friday in northern Georgia among 40 opened plastic containers with traces of cocaine.

title: Basques Protest in Spain
description: Thousands of Basque nationalists demonstrated today in this northern Spanish city to protest the death of a Basque who disappeared while in Civil Guard custody and whose body was found in a river. Tens of thousands took part in another protest march Saturday night in San Sebastian.

title: Dr. Herbert Hyman, 67, Dies; Expert on Science of Polling
description: Dr. Herbert H. Hyman, a professor emeritus at Wesleyan University and an early contributor to the science of polling, died Wednesday in Canton, China, where he had been visiting. He had suffered a heart attack four days before.

title: WALLACE P. ANDERSON
description: Wallace P. (Mad Bear) Anderson, a longtime champion of Indian rights, died Friday after a long illness.

title: ARKANSAS PREVAILS BY 18-17
description: A freshman, Kendall Trainor, kicked a 37-yard field goal with 21 seconds remaining tonight to give Arkansas a 18-17 Holiday Bowl victory over Arizona State.

title: 49ers Win; Craig Sets Mark
description: Roger Craig helped the San Francisco 49ers into the playoffs today when he scored on a 4-yard run in a 31-16 comeback victory over the Dallas Cowboys and he made history in the process.

title: Laurie Melissa Fleischer Weds Fred Gary Danzig
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Laurie Melissa Fleischer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray S. Fleischer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married to Fred Gary Danzig, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin E. Danzig of North Merrick, L.I., and Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Dovid Goldwasser performed the ceremony.

title: COMPANIES HAVE GIFT LISTS, TOO
description: TWENTY-TWO sets of hurricane lamps have been ordered, and the shopper has moved on to the next item on her Christmas list: gifts with $150 price tags.

title: POLICE ESTABLISHING CHECKPOINTS TO FIND INTOXICATED DRIVERS
description: The police are setting up checkpoints throughout the city through New Year's Day to catch intoxicated drivers, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: TEXAS RANCHERS EARN EXTRA CASH FROM HUNTERS
description: The deer-hunting season is in full swing now and Henry Louis Welge has scarcely had time to look at the 100 Herefords that roam his range here.

title: Unity on G.O.P Agendas
description: Republican House members, fractionated by ideology and bruised in their tax revision dispute with President Reagan, have decided to open the 1986 election year with an exercise in unification. The Baltimore Conference on issues, which has been conducted for the last two years by the militantly right-wing Conservative Opportunity Society, is going to be expanded next month to include legislators from two more moderate House G.O.P. caucuses, the Wednesday Group and the 92 Group, as well as the current Republican freshman class.

title: Treasury Sales Reduced by Holiday
description: The Treasury will auction $15.2 billion of three- and six-month bills today. Aside from the Treasury's regular weekly bill sales, the list of new fixed-income securities offerings will be shortened by the Christmas holiday on Wednesday.

title: CITY, IN SHIFT, TO MAKE BLOOD TEST FOR AIDS VIRUS MORE WIDELY AVAILABLE
description: In a major policy change, New York City has decided to make the blood test for the AIDS virus more widely available by permitting local hospitals to administer it.

title: But Can They Maintain Quality in Health Care?
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 LATIN NATIONS CREATE UNIFIED LOBBY ON DEBT
description: Latin America's five largest debtor nations will for the first time act as a bloc in lobbying foreign governments and banks to accept the region's latest ''emergency'' debt proposals, financial experts said.

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Bridal Originals to AC&R Advertising for its gowns.

title: LIBERIAN REJECTS U.S. LINKAGE OF AID AND RIGHTS
description: Liberia's Foreign Minister declared this week that any move to link United States military aid to Liberian political guarantees would be an ''unethical'' intrusion into this country's affairs.

title: Shari Wyner Is Bride of Richard Narva
description: Shari Mae Wyner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay S. Wyner of Sands Point, L.I., was married there yesterday to Richard Lawrence Narva, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton I. Narva of Brookline, Mass. Rabbis Martin S. Rozenberg and Eli M. Pilchik with Cantor Jacob Yaron performed the ceremony at the Community Synagogue.

title: ABC-Capital Cities Tie
description: The Federal Communications Commission has refused to block the merger of ABC and Capital Cities Communications Inc., despite a request that a Federal court review the F.C.C.'s approval of the deal. Anthony R. Martin-Trigona has asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to review the approval because ''novel issues are presented which have not been considered by the commission or the courts, such as waivers of signal overlaps'' and ''control of a network through various devices.''

title: 40 Years Since Patton Died
description: Belgian veterans who fought under Gen. George S. Patton commemorated over the weekend the 40th anniversary of the death of the World War II commander. The American general died Dec. 21, 1945, in a highway accident in West Germany. A memorial service Saturday at General Patton's tomb at the Hamm military cemetery was attended by Defense Minister Marc Fischbach of Luxembourg and Jean Gerard, the United States Ambassador.

title: A Defense Pact With Israel Now
description: This is a good time for the United States and Israel to start moving more seriously toward a formal defense pact.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday in some copies of the Sports section with an article about the Knicks game misidentified a New York player. He was Gerald Wilkins.

title: BUT CAN THEY MAINTAIN QUALITY IN HEALTH CARE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Neal A. Brooks Exchanges Vows With Felice Medwin
description: The marriage of Felice Ilene Medwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Medwin of New York, to Neal A. Brooks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Norton Brooks of Phoenix, took place yesterday.

title: S.&P. Cuts Rating Of Bond Insurer
description: Buyers of tax-exempt bonds were reminded Friday that insurance policies covering bond interest and principal are only as good as the company issuing the guarantee.

title: JETS BEAT BROWNS, 37-10, FOR WILD-CARD BERTH
description: The Jets chased the ghosts of collapses past, who started to hover over the winter sky today when it looked as if the playoffs might slip away.

title: Blast Kills 17 At Polish Coal Mine
description: A gas explosion tore through a coal mine near Katowice in southern Poland today, killing at least 17 miners and injuring eight others, the official news agency P.A.P. said.

title: IN STUDENT INTERVIEWS, PRESSURE'S ON TO SHINE
description: The interview got off to a shaky start.

title: Character and Power
description: Something strange and wonderful happened in Washington last week. In that city of rootless ambition, of Snopeses dealing for place and power, character triumphed. A man stood against the degrading of our political life, and he won.

title: Remark Recanted by Boxer
description: The loser of a boxing match against a fighter trying to make a comeback following the amputation of his right foot said today that he was misunderstood when he said he ''threw the fight.''

title: Washington Watch;   Pressure for Monetary Overhaul
description: Whether governments will attempt to overhaul the world's monetary system remains a question, but pressure keeps building on the periphery. Following the meeting that Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, and Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, put on here last month, the Swiss Finance Ministry and an association of Swiss bankers have been quietly planning one in Lugano, Switzerland, from May 27 to 29.

title: THE JETS KEEP GOING
description: THE last time Joe Fields went to a Super Bowl, four years ago, he realized he was not enjoying himself. He turned to his neighbor in the next seat and discovered that Joe Klecko was not having a good time, either.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme Electric Corp., Olean, N.Y., which makes power conversion equipment, has elected James W. McLaughlin chairman and G. Wayne Hawk president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 2.

title: N. CAROLINA ROUTS THE CITADEL, 104-51
description: Kenny Smith and Ranzino Smith scored 16 points each today to lead a balanced attack as North Carolina crushed The Citadel, 104-51.

title: Reliance Group to Get Another Savvy Investor
description: Stephen M. Peck, a well-known Wall Street investor, is about to join forces with another savvy financier: Saul P. Steinberg, chairman and chief executive of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

title: PANEL ON POLICY TO PICK A LEADER
description: A committee to select a new president of the Council on Foreign Relations will recommend the appointment of Peter Tarnoff at a board meeting today, council members and officials said yesterday.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: KINGDOM OF SIAM IS RUNNING OUT OF SIAMESE CATS
description: There was a cat show in Bangkok - a novelty here where pets rarely promenade in public - and during the proceedings some bad news slipped out.

title: JETS' MCELROY IS BACK
description: The Jets made a change in their offensive line today, Ted Banker replacing Reggie McElroy at left tackle. The purpose was obvious: to provide better protection for Ken O'Brien, the quarterback who had been sacked 59 times in 15 games.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: U.C.L.A., which won Rose Bowl games in 1983 and 1984 and the Fiesta Bowl in 1985, will have an opportunity in next week's Rose Bowl to win a fourth straight New Year's Day bowl game. Has this feat ever been accomplished?

title: Bonner Says Remarks Did Not Break Promise
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the Soviet human rights activist, does not believe her remarks at a synagogue here on Saturday violated a pledge not to talk to reporters while she is in the West for medical treatment, her daughter said today.

title: MIDCON'S DIRECTORS REJECT BID
description: The Midcon Corporation rejected yesterday an unfriendly bid for $2.71 billion made last week by a partnership formed by Wagner & Brown and Freeport-McMoran Inc. and offered to acquire up to 10 million shares of its own stock as a defensive measure.

title: BRISK SALES SPUR HOPES OF RETAILERS
description: Shoppers poured out in droves to fill stores around the country in the final weekend before Christmas, giving retailers what some called their biggest weekend of the year.

title: TEXACO BATTLE: A CRITICAL JUNCTURE
description: Having signaled in a Federal District Court on Friday that they are negotiating a settlement of their high-stakes legal and financial battle, Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company find themselves at a critical juncture of the nearly two-year-old case.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CREATIVE FUND-RAISING GROWS AS YEAR NEARS END
description: The card from New York University's School of Law pictured a blind-folded but smiling Justice sharing a pedestal with a mean-eyed tax-collector whose pockets, collar and cuffs are stuffed with dollar bills. The message to 8,500 alumni: ''This year you could feel good about where your money goes . . . which one will get it?''

title: CRITIC ON PLANNING PANEL BEING REPLACED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch has decided not to reappoint a leading critic of city development policies to the City Planning Commission, and the decision has set off charges that the administration is seeking to stifle dissent.

title: Nancy Leviine Marries
description: Nancy Ellen Levine, a daughter of Mrs. Edward R. Levine of Arlington, Mass., and the late Mr. Levine, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Dr. William Henry Armstrong Jr., the son of Mrs. Armstrong of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Armstrong. The Rev. Kenneth Reid-Brown performed the Unitarian ceremony in the chapel at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The bride is an alumna of Northeastern University. Dr. Armstrong, a professor of chemistry at the University of California at Berkeley, graduated from Bucknell University and received his doctorate from Stanford University.

title: Catching Up
description: * Marc Buoniconti, the 19-year-old Citadel linebacker who was left paralyzed when he made a tackle against East Tennessee State in October, was moved from intensive care to a regular room at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami two weeks ago. As a result of an operation to remove pressure from his spinal cord, the youth can now be propped up in a sitting position without discomfort.

title: BEHIND THE RADIO COWBOY'S PERSONA
description: Paul Aaron was born and raised in Leonia, N. J., the son of a doctor and a social worker. He attended the Stockbridge Academy prep school, received a bachelor's degree from Emerson College and a master's from Columbia University. He has wiry black hair and wears glasses. This is the resume of a cowboy. For Mr. Aaron is better known as his alter ego, the creator and host of ''Cowboy Joe's Radio Ranch,'' an eight-year-old show of western swing music, cattleman lore and rodeo news on the Columbia University station, WKCR-FM, 89.9. As Cowboy Joe, Mr. Aaron's curriculum vitae includes the Wrangler Award from the National Cowboy Hall of Fame and Western Heritage Center, a certificate of appreciation from the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association and designation as an Honorary Cowboy by the State of Wyoming. ''It's their Oscar,'' Mr. Aaron said. And this is no lark, improbable as it seems. ''Cowboy Joe's Radio Ranch'' reaches a substantial and loyal audience each Sunday from noon to 2 P.M. - ''High noon, the perfect time,'' Mr. Aaron says - and until recently was syndicated through National Public Radio as far afield as Buffalo, Houston, Rhinelander, Wis., and Laramie, Wyo.

title: STAGE: 'THE ROBERT KLEIN SHOW'
description: ROBERT KLEIN is a seasoned prizefighter in the world of stand-up comedy.

title: CHANGE NOTED IN MAN HELD IN KILLINGS
description: The man accused of killing his wife and three daughters had been losing weight in the weeks before the crime and sleeping fitfully, his lawyers say.

title: AS CHRISTMAS DRAWS NEAR, STORES ARE ASWARM
description: It was mobbed at Macy's, swarming at Saks. There were long lines at Lord & Taylor and Zabar's was a zoo.

title: Janet E. Lewis Wed To Sidney Leon Getz
description: Janet Ellen Lewis and Sidney Leon Getz were married yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Washington by Rabbi Joshua O. Haberman.

title: SWEDEN RETAINS DAVIS CUP TITLE
description: Stefan Edberg resisted a stubborn challenge from Michael Westphal of West Germany today to win the final singles match and give Sweden a 3-2 victory in the 1985 Davis Cup final.

title: Strike Delays Channel Traffic
description: English Channel traffic was tied up today by bad weather and a 10-day-old strike by ferry pilots who shepherd British passenger and cargo ships into France. Although not all pilots were striking, officials said, about 100 freight trucks were backed up, with delays averaging seven to eight hours.

title: THEATER: 'BENEFACTORS,' BY FRAYN
description: WHEN last heard from, in the uproarious ''Noises Off,'' the English playwright Michael Frayn was demonstrating how the clockwork machinery of farce falls crazily apart when careless actors lose their props, drink too much and tumble down stairs. ''Benefactors,'' Mr. Frayn's equally dazzling new play at the Atkinson, would seem a complete departure: It's a comedy only in the darkest sense.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   A Piano Recital By Meral Guneyman
description: Meral Guneyman's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening offered us an imposing technique, a delicate feel for timbre and very often, a tendency to hurry on just when the music asked for more time. Still she is an excellent pianist and a good musician, one suited especially well for the Debussy ''Images'' (here the three from Book II) and the three ''Transcendental Etudes'' - all of which came at the end of her program.

title: Solstice Song
description: The shortest day is done, my friends, the shortest day is done. Blow winds and crack your cheeks, the shortest day is done.

title: Next Steps in Rail Deregulation
description: When Congress relaxed price controls for freight railroads in 1980, it sought an artful balance. It wanted to give railroads incentives to rebuild their collapsing systems. But it wanted also to protect shippers from being gouged by rail monopolies. Some of these shippers now complain that the balance has tilted in favor of railroads, and they make a good case. If deregulation is to work for everyone, the reforms of 1980 need fine tuning.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Jimmy Heath Quartet Plays at Carlos 1
description: Since the Modern Jazz Quartet reactivated itself a few years ago and Percy Heath returned to his post as the group's bassist, what had briefly been the Heath Brothers Quartet has become the Jimmy Heath Quartet under the sole leadership of the saxophonist and arranger. With Stafford James on bass and two veterans of the Heath Brothers group - the guitarist Tony Purrone and the drummer Akira Tana - there is now a stronger emphasis on Jimmy Heath's roles as both soloist and writer in the quartet's work at Carlos 1, where it played through yesterday.

title: Nets' Centers Play Key Role
description: The Nets, whose play had been generally erratic through the first six weeks of the season, are on a formidable streak. They meet the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena with seven victories in their last eight games, with a 12-2 record at home and with their newest weapon: the two-headed center.

title: Advertising;   Manhattan Hotline For Diners
description: ''WHAT we're doing is starting a new medium,'' said Bruce Kallenberg, a former stockbroker, as he sat in his cramped office last week. In the next room at 201 East 56th Street, the electronic equipment he hopes will make him rich was warm, with little red lights shining brightly, indicating a readiness for action.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: HOW ONE CORRESPONDENT ENDED RULE ON CREDENTIALS
description: All that Norma Greenaway, a Washington correspondent for Canadian Press, Canada's major news service, wanted were White House press credentials. But she was unwilling to pay the price.

title: Rabbi P. E. Schechter Is Wed to Rabbi Rolle
description: The marriage of Rabbi Elizabeth Rolle, associate rabbi of the Jewish Community Center in White Plains, and Rabbi Philip E. Schechter of Temple Shaari Emeth of Englishtown, N.J., took place yesterday at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony, in which seven other rabbis and a cantor participated.

title: Sprucing at Shea
description: Jet fans, most of whom remain New York residents, trekked to New Jersey again yesterday to see their team struggle for a playoff spot. They tailgated, they hollered, they whooped. At the park that had been left behind, meanwhile, there was only stillness.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1985
description: International

title: FOLK MUSIC: TOM PAXTON
description: IN Tom Paxton's recent song, ''Yuppies in the Sky,'' a ghostly band of young upwardly mobile consumers, togged out in running shoes and stereo headphones, wafts down a desolate Columbus Avenue of the future where the boutiques and salad bars have all been shuttered. Brandishing credit cards, the well-dressed spirits send up a plaintive cry, ''Condos for sale! Condos to buy!,'' to the strains of the old Vaughn Monroe hit ''Riders in the Sky.''

title: AQUINO SPEAKS AT POLICE MASSACRE SITE
description: Tens of thousands of villagers lined country roads and gathered in town squares today as Corazon C. Aquino brought her presidential campaign to Negros Island, a sugar-producing area in the southern Philippines.

title: A New Chairman For Middle South
description: Edwin Lupberger has been named chairman and president of Middle South Utilities Inc., the nation's fifth-largest electric and gas utility.

title: A CHURCH, CHICKENS AND SPIES
description: Philadelphians like to remind visitors that they have more history on any given block than most municipalities have in their city limits.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: EXPERT CITES GAINS AGAINST MAFIA
description: New York State's top expert on organized crime said yesterday that efforts to crack down on the Mafia were making major progress and within a decade could transform the underworld organization into something ''you will not recognize.''

title: Lisa Diaz Is the Bride Of Michael C. Nash Jr.
description: Lisa Maria Diaz, a division manager of financial services institutions for American Express International in Hong Kong, and Michael Charles Nash Jr., a vice president and general manager of travel related services for American Express International in Seoul, South Korea, were married yesterday. The Rev. James R. Steele performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: South Korea Debt Rises
description: South Korea's outstanding foreign debt totaled $46.3 billion at the end of November, as against $46.1 bilion at the end of October and $42.4 bilion at the end of November 1984, officials of the Economic Planning Board told reporters. They gave no further details.

title: PARENTS OF ASTHMATICS OFFER HELPING HANDS
description: Miki Jaeger glanced around the roomful of parents and voiced the silent fear they all had shared. ''Especially at the beginning, whenever he would have an asthma attack, I'd have the fear that he would die,'' she said of her son, Adam.

title: Tokyo Allows New Brokers
description: The Ministry of Finance has given formal permission to six foreign securities companies, including three subsidiaries of foreign banks, to open branches here, a ministry official said Friday.

title: Patriots Win for Playoff Berth
description: Craig James rushed for a career-high 142 yards and tiptoed along the sideline for an 11-yard, fourth-quarter touchdown, as the New England Patriots captured an American Conference wild-card playoff berth today with a 34-23 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: China Oil Project
description: The state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation has signed a contract with a consortium of three foreign oil companies for oil exploration in the Pearl River basin, a spokesman for one of the companies said Saturday. Harold R. Allison, a vice president of Texaco Inc., said the consortium consists of AGIP (Overseas) Ltd., Chevron Overseas Petroleum Ltd. and Texaco Petroleum Maatschappij (Nederland) B.V. The consortium would explore an area about 170 miles southeast of Canton, in the Pearl River basin, Mr. Allison said. It is the fourth contract to be signed in a second round of bidding for offshore exploration rights.

title: Advertising;   JJ Gross Joins Kufeld In Real Estate Venture
description: J.J. Gross, president of JJ Gross & Company, has joined with David Kufeld to set up a separate agency to specialize in real estate advertising called the Kufeld Organization.

title: MACHINE TOOL OUTLOOK BRIGHTENS IN GERMANY
description: West Germany's powerful machine tool industry, long the world leader, has been having its headaches in recent years.

title: Trucks and Buses Recalled
description: The Ford Motor Company is recalling about 57,000 1984 and 1985-model medium-duty trucks and school buses equipped with hydraulic brakes to check for faulty brake systems. A company spokesman, Jim Bright, said Friday that about 5,900 of the affected vehicles are based on the B-series chassis.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GALLERY HOP The Whitney Museum of American Art's branch in the Philip Morris Building, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, opposite Grand Central Terminal (878-2550), almost always, it seems, has an exhibition that is guaranteed to catch the public eye, a show that is well laid out with good explanatory material.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * John Mariucci has been named executive vice president and board member at Doyle Dane Bernbach/New York.

title: Democratic Contenders
description: With Senator Edward F. Kennedy out of the running, handicappers of the 1988 Democratic Presidential sweepstakes will be focusing more sharply on runners heretofore back in the pack, say, for instance, Gov. Bruce Babbitt. Close associates of the Arizonan report he is quietly preparing to become an active national player about the end of his term a year from now.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In our view, sending these people back to El Salvador or to Guatemala is the same thing as putting Jews on a boxcar bound for Dachau., We claim what we are doing is based not only on religious conviction but the deepest values of our United States traditions of being a place of refuge, a place to where persecuted people can come.'' - Rev. Peter J. Sammon, pastor of St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco. [A1:4.]

title: Washington Watch;   Ominous Start For I.R.S.
description: OVERHAULING the Internal Revenue Service's tax-collection procedures appears subject to the same fits and starts as the President's campaign to overhaul the tax system.

title: Advertising;   A Switch by Publisher
description: Margaret Byrne Heimbold is leaving her position as publisher of American Film magazine to assume a similar role at Historic Preservation and Preservation News, the former a six-a-year magazine and the latter a monthly tabloid. The headquarters are in Washington.

title: AID TO ALIENS SAID TO SPUR ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION
description: Federal officials say a spreading campaign by religious groups to designate American cities as sanctuaries for illegal aliens has stimulated a new flow of immigrants from Central America.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST EXPRESS WISH TO AID THE CITY'S HOMELESS
description: At a time of rejoicing and family reunions, many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund express the wish to help those who are alone, homeless and in need of care this holiday season.

title: U.S. AIDES FIND HOPE AS SOVIET URGES TEST BAN
description: Although the Reagan Administration has publicly rejected the Soviet Union's proposal for a moratorium on nuclear testing, some Administration officials say they still see the Soviet move as a potentially positive development.

title: The Harvard Club Weighs Expansion
description: Another McKim, Mead & White building, the Harvard Club at 27 West 44th Street, may be getting a new look that is meant to respect the old.

title: The Secretary and the Fear Machines
description: Secretary of State George Shultz would be the last Cabinet member ever suspected of the kind of disloyalty that requires a lie detector test. Yet he was the first to question his President's order to subject thousands more Government employees to polygraph examinations.

title: DANCE: AILEY TRIBUTE TO DONNA WOOD
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater honored Donna Wood on Friday night at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street. It was a wonderful occasion.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington on Sunday about the ability of Israel to obtain sensitive information about American weapons, technology and policy incorrectly stated the damage caused by an Israeli air and sea attack in 1967 on the Liberty, an American spy ship in the Mediterranean. The ship was badly damaged but was able to reach port in Malta.

title: MISTAKE INTO MAGIC
description: WHEN he needed surgical reconstruction of his left knee two years ago, nobody knew if Kurt Sohn would play for the Jets again. But yesterday the 28-year-old wide receiver out of Fordham, turning a bobbled ball into a surprise touchdown, turned the Jets toward the Super Bowl XX wild-card playoffs at Giants Stadium with ''New York, New York'' as its theme song.

title: IN L.A., TWO CULTURES MEET AT MIDFIELD
description: IN any other National Football League territory, a Monday night contest between two local teams would whip the citizenry into an internecine frenzy.

title: STAGE: 'SPECTACULAR,' A DOWNTOWN BENEFIT
description: THERE used to be a custom in some English towns of raising money for the local women's institutes by holding an annual performance that could only be described as the village follies. Everybody got a chance to perform, and the results were often good-naturedly hilarious. Such was the atmosphere at ''The Downtown Christmas Spectacular!'' on Friday at Performance Space 122. Presented by the Manhattan Performing Ensemble, ''The Downtown Christmas Spectacular!'' was held to raise money for STEP C, a new program designed to provide training at city arts schools for needy children on the Lower East Side.

title: O'Connor, at Service, Honors Crash Victims
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, celebrating mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, prayed for the 256 soldiers and crew members killed in a plane crash in Gander, Newfoundland, telling relatives and friends of the servicemen that he shared their grief and pain.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DATING YOUR MOM. By Ian Frazier. 123 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. THERE are flowers and pink ribbons on the cover of Ian Frazier's first book, ''Dating Your Mom.'' The ambiance is redolent of sentimental Mother's Day cards and barbershop quartets singing ''I want a girl just like the girl that married dear old Dad.''

title: A STATE-OF-THE-ART CHALLENGER ALARMS FLEET STREET
description: Eddie Shah works from an office that is about three miles away from Fleet Street, the natural habitat of English newspapers.

title: RIFT SEEN IN CAMBODIA GUERRILLA FORCE
description: A power struggle within the major non-Communist guerrilla group fighting the Vietnamese in Cambodia has burst into the open in the last few days, threatening to weaken the guerrilla cause, diplomats say, just as Hanoi is preparing its annual dry-season offensive against them.

title: BOND BUYING SPREE CONTINUES
description: Bond investors resumed their buying spree late last week on renewed expectations of still lower interest rates. While bond investors rushed to lock in existing yields, Treasury bills came under selling pressure from domestic and foreign holders, causing rates to move up smartly on Thursday and Friday as well.

title: BRIGHT LIGHTS DIM NEIGHBORS' SMILES
description: As dusk turns to dark, the traffic northward on Trascontinental Drive toward Lake Ponchartrain thickens. Bumper to bumper, it plods camel-like toward the growing illumination of a distant star, which blurs the darkness with electric light.

title: Sugar Competition Takes Many Forms
description: To the Editor:

title: SEASONAL TIPPING PROBLEMS
description: WHEN money changes hands in the form of the holiday tip, the underlying message may be something other than season's greetings.

title: DEVILS FALL, 8-3, TO STARS
description: The Devils did not have to worry about a letdown after taking a lead tonight because they never had one.

title: STATE PAROLE VIOLATORS CROWD JAILS, CITY SAYS
description: With both the New York State and city penal systems bulging with record numbers of inmates, a major legal dispute has erupted over the jailing of state parole violators.

title: $10 Million Winner In Lotto Drawing
description: Someone who bought a Lotto ticket in Queens won $10 million in the latest drawing, state lottery officials said yesterday.

title: TEXANS IN MIDCON BID BEGAN WITH HANDSHAKE
description: Some oil industry analysts say that the $2.7 billion offer made last week by WB Partners for the Midcon Corporation is too low. If that is the case, raising the ante should not prove too difficult for Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, two of the richest oilmen in Texas.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. When the two teams met Nov. 30 at Richfield, Ohio, the Cavaliers won, 119-90. (Television - SportsChannel, 11:15 P.M., tape.) Colleges: Monmouth at St. John's, 8 P.M. (Television - Cablevision Channel 22, 11 P.M. tape. Radio -WCBS, 880; 8 P.M., live). Columbia at Fordham, 8 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; and WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.). Marist at Fairfield, 8 P.M. Arkansas-Little Rock at Providence, 8 P.M. Rutgers at Princeton, 7:30 P.M. St. Peter's at Fairleigh Dickinson, 8 P.M. York at Medgar Evers, 8 P.M. Football Los Angeles Rams vs. Los Angeles Raiders, at Anaheim, Calif. This is the final Monday night game and the final regular-season game. This is the Raiders' first trip to Anaheim. Both teams clinched divisional titles, the Raiders in the A.F.C. West and the Rams in the N.F.C. West. Eric Dickerson, with 1,136 yards this season, is the third Ram in the 5,000-yard club, joining Lawrence McCutcheon (with 6,186) and Dick Bass (5,417). (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 9 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Detroit Red Wings, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Their first meeting this season. The Red Wings won two of three games last season, both at Detroit. (Television - MSG network, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 930; 7:30 P.M.) Islanders vs. Whalers, at Hartford, 7:35 P.M. This is their first meeting of the season, but the Whalers will be at Nassau Coliseum for a rematch Thursday.

title: GETTING 'MESSIES' TO CLEAN UP
description: Sandra Felton admits it. She's a messie.

title: Acid Rain Falls and Falls
description: Nearly one year ago, President Reagan and the Canadian Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney, appointed representatives to craft recommendations for controlling acid rain. This week, Canada announced a program aimed at reducing sulfur emissions from Ontario -the source of most of Canada's pollution - by two-thirds. The Reagan Administration continues to do nothing.

title: A Boon for Wetlands
description: The otherwise costly and extravagant 1985 farm bill marks a welcome turn in Federal conservation policy. It contains provisions to protect wetlands and erosion-prone land, thus enriching wildlife habitats and saving the taxpayers some money.

title: WINNIE MANDELA JAILED FOR RETURN TO SOWETO HOME
description: The South African police arrested Winnie Mandela today after she defied a ban imposed Saturday forbidding her to enter Soweto. Her lawyers said she had been taken to jail in Krugersdorp, southwest of Johannesburg.
