title: REAGAN BACKS SALE OF POWER SYSTEMS
description: President Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1987 contains a proposal to sell the Bonneville Power Administration and three similar agencies, Federal officials said today. The agencies provide electric power to millions of people living in Western, Southwestern and Southeastern states.

title: AIDS: BELLEVUE TRIES TO COPE WITH DISEASE IT CANNOT CURE
description: The AIDS epidemic has transformed Bellevue Hospital Center to such an extent that the fatal disorder of the immune system is now the municipal hospital's single most common medical diagnosis.

title: Doctors in the Dock?
description: Sometime next year, after long investigation, New York District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau may submit to a grand jury charges that a family physician and certain doctors and nurses at a New York hospital were criminally negligent in the death of Libby Zion, aged 18, last March 5.

title: Secrets of the Constitutional Bicentennial
description: To the Editor:

title: AMID MARXISM, RELIGION GAINS GROUND IN ANGOLA
description: On Karl Marx Street, a rich chorus of African voices brought passers-by a lilting refrain: ''God gives you love, God gives you peace, shalom, shalom.''

title: Market Place;   Holiday List For Wall St.
description: ON Wall Street, this is the season when brokerage firms and advisory services make out lists of favorite stocks, in hopes that Santa will deliver during the coming year, instead of on Christmas morning.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SUIT BY WHITES CHARGING BIAS IN BIRMINGHAM
description: A Federal district judge who dismissed a discrimation case against the city of Birmingham says the city did not discriminate against white firefighters when it promoted blacks the complainants said were less qualified than white candidates.

title: Shaping Up
description: Capitol Hill tends to be the home of long working hours, little sleep, heavy smoking, irregular diet and vigorous off-duty partying. As a result, any Senate office that becomes known as an oasis of health and physical fitness attracts considerable attention.

title: G.M. Purchase Of Hughes
description: The General Motors Corporation completed the purchase Friday of Hughes Aircraft, adding space technology and substantial military interests to the assets of the world's largest auto manufacturer.

title: Ruling on 17 Activists Is Delayed in Turkey
description: A Turkish court has delayed its decision on the appeal of a case against 17 prominent Turkish citizens imprisoned since 1982 on political charges, citing a lack of information, according to a human rights monitoring group.

title: Boy, 10, Dies in HospitalAfter 2 Hours Under Ice
description: Jeffrey Goodale, 10 years old, who spent two hours under the ice of a lake on Martha's Vineyard, died today despite efforts by doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: A MISCELLANY OF HOLIDAY BUSINESS CUSTOMS AROUND THE WORLD
description: With Christmas and New Year's falling on a Wednesday this year, most American office and factory workers will not have as much time off as usual for their traditional celebrations. But for many parts of the world, where one- and two-week vacations at this time of the year are becoming standard, the midweek holidays will make little difference.

title: ISLANDER COACH EXASPERATED
description: The weekend's Islander-Ranger series, dominated by the Rangers with a 2-2 tie at Madison Square Garden Friday and a 5-4 victory at Nassau Coliseum Saturday, was encouraging for Coach Ted Sator of the Rangers and disappointing to his counterpart, Al Arbour.

title: Libya Rejects Protests Over Its New Missiles
description: Libya today dismissed American protests over its reported acquisition of Soviet SAM-5 long-range antiaircraft missiles and accused the United States of creating an ''atmosphere of terror.''

title: RADIO SHOW STIRS LISTENERS TO COLLECT FOOD AND CLOTHING FOR THE HOMELESS
description: That Jesus was born homeless, sheltered in a stable, was one symbol that emerged over a weekend of symbols as hundreds of people gathered at 20 sites in the New York City area to help the homeless at Christmas.

title: Advertising;   Hicks & Greist Loses Heath, but Wins Hood
description: Another account departing from a New York agency is L. S. Heath & Sons of Robinson, Ill., which has had its confections served by Hicks & Greist in Gotham.

title: Instant Announcer
description: Because he liked basketball, and because he also liked Rhonda Woodruff, who played guard for the women's team at Walters State Community College in Morristown, Tenn., Darren Allen used to hang around the gym while the Lady Senators practiced.

title: U.S. DISTRESSED BY PERU, BUT EAGER TO AVOID CLASH
description: Despite continuing distress over Peru's new nationalist tone and radical economic policies, the United States seems anxious to avoid an open clash with the country's five-month-old Government, according to local and foreign officials.

title: CONCLUSION OF 'RIVER JOURNEYS' SERIES
description: THE BBC series ''River Journeys,'' which began in New Guinea last month and has flowed through Southeast Asia, Africa and Brazil, concludes tonight in Australia, as Russell Braddon, an Australian writer, guides us along the Murray, his country's pre-eminent river. His journey can be seen at 10 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: FOR CONNECTICUT, A SURPRISE START
description: The start of the Big East season is more than a week away, but already there has been surprising movement from teams that were expected to be a stride off the pace this season.

title: MAILER EARNS PRAISE FOR PEN EFFORTS
description: The 48th International PEN Congress, which opens in New York next month, will be the first such congress in the United States in 20 years and may be the largest gathering ever of foreign writers on American shores.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   French Songs Of the 20th Century
description: As most Francophiles know, the Montparnasse section of Paris became a hotbed and hangout of artists shortly after the turn of the century and remained a locale of intense artistic life for a goodly number of years. Thus, it is entirely reasonable that the Jewish Museum is offering an exhibition entitled ''The Circle of Montparnasse: Jewish Artists in Paris 1905-1945.''

title: What the Homeless Need Are Decent Emergency Quarters
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVOYS SEE SIGNS OF KREMLIN RIFTS
description: Western diplomats here say there are indications of divisions in the Soviet leadership on foreign and domestic policies.

title: WALKER'S CAREER ADVANCES BY LEAPS
description: THE NICKNAME was inevitable. They had to call Kenny Walker ''Sky.''

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Daniel Lentz Ensemble At Carnegie Hall
description: Little bits of music and words pile up in complicated ways in the compositions of Daniel Lentz, who brought his ensemble to Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday. Mr. Lentz controlled a multitrack tape recorder, on which he layered and replayed the sounds made by the musicians onstage. This method was used for three very diverse pieces - the 45-minute ''Coyote Dances,'' the 20-minute ''Bacchus'' and the seven-minute ''On the Leopard Altar.'' ''Bacchus'' was a theatrical showpiece. Jessica Lowe, David Kuehn, Brad Ellis and Mariliz Romano sat, formally dressed, inside an acoustically isolated capsule at a table laden with glasses and wine bottles. They sang fragments of sentences about the pleasures of wine while tapping, rubbing or blowing on the glasses and bottles, which were retuned by drinking the wine in them. Through Mr. Lentz's multitracking, the sounds and text fragments built up until the full quotations were heard. It was wry, delicate music. One sentence was delivered entirely in whispers, against lightly tapped glasses; the second used the quiet hooting of blown bottles against rippling, gamelan-flavored arpeggios and sustained voices; the third used percolating rhythms and percussively articulated consonants. ''On the Leopard Altar'' set a gory text sweetly. Six short, consonant ''songs'' accompanied by simple keyboard chords fit together in a rippling chorale, with a playback as each piece was added; Miss Lowe lighted a candle before she began each song. ''Coyote Dances,'' a world premiere, was less theatrical. Three busy synthesizer players played short riffs that built up into twinkling and then, fairly quickly, propulsive chords.

title: Tass Calls U.S. Report On Arms Pacts a Fraud
description: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that a United States Presidential report accusing the Soviet Union of violating arms control treaties was ''a propaganda fraud'' filled with ''hackneyed inventions.''

title: Saving Ladies' Mile
description: ''When we saw the cornice come down on that building,'' Anthony C. Wood said, ''many people's hearts skipped a beat.''

title: Dolphins Take Division Title
description: Dan Marino threw two touchdown passes to Bruce Hardy today as the Dolphins routed the Buffalo Bills, 28-0, to win the American Conference Eastern Division title.

title: Growing Respect
description: They don't call him Fatty anymore, but it's not because Raymond Smith is especially leaner at the age of 18 than he was as a 300-pound, 6-foot sixth-grader cowering at home to avoid the taunts of his classmates. It's because he went out for football last year and promptly began acquiring the confidence and respect due a 6-foot-7-inch, 430-pound tackle who could take out half the defensive line with a single block.

title: Advertising;   Agency for Tower Air
description: Biederman & Company has become the first ad agency for Tower Air, which flies its 747 aircraft primarily out of Kennedy International Airport and has regular service to Brussels and Tel Aviv. It also does charter work as well as worldwide ferrying of military personnel under a Defense Department contract. The agency says that the three-year-old carrier will be spending more than $1 million for advertising.

title: Sears Denies Stock Plans
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company today denied reports that it would repurchase a large amount of its stock or spin off or sell certain assets in order to increase the value of its stock.

title: KNICKS OVERCOME BULLETS BY 100-93
description: It is rare that two halves of a basketball game are so different. Indeed, about the only similarity between the first and second halves of the game between the Knicks and the Washington Bullets at the Capital Centre tonight was that each lasted 24 minutes.

title: PENN THAL
description: Penn Thal, a former Cambodian diplomat who became a leader of the anti-Vietnamese resistance on the Thai-Cambodian border, died Wednesday in Peking, according to officials of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. He was 51 years old.

title: Club Med in China
description: Two villas at the Imperial Summer Palace in Peking will become the first Club Med vacation resort in China, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Beatrice Plans To Sell Assets
description: The Beatrice Companies said today that it planned to sell off at least $1.45 billion in assets to finance its planned leveraged buyout with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: Are You There?
description: Most of Washington takes seriously the case of the public servant arrested for spying for Israel.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Topics;   Truth in Packaging Tampering With Twain
description: Mark Twain started ''Huckleberry Finn'' in 1876 and took almost a decade to finish it. During that time he also wrote, among other things, ''Life on the Mississippi,'' which he padded out with a chapter about rafting that he'd originally written as part of Huck's adventures.

title: MUSIC: 'MESSIAH' IN BROOKLYN
description: SATURDAY night's performance of Handel's ''Messiah'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was distinguished mainly by the transparent playing of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra and the conducting of its music director, Lukas Foss. Mr. Foss opted for brisk, propulsive tempos, yet the most notable qualities of his interpretation were lyricism and an abiding gentility. There was little drama, in the traditional sense; instead one found a musical meditation characterized by sustained tenderness and awe.

title: 3M WORKERS CAMPAIGN TO KEEP PLANT
description: George Kaffl knew something was wrong when he walked into the company cafeteria just before midnight and saw the plant manager.

title: BRIEFS
description: Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., finished selling its Western Auto Supply Co. subsidiary to Wesray Automotive Inc., an affiliate of Wesray Capital Corp., for more than $300 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article on companies' gift giving misstated the price of a sterling silver necklace sold by Tiffany & Company. It is $1,200.

title: Philippine-I.M.F. Pact
description: The Philippine Government announced International Monetary Fund approval of further draw-downs from a standby credit of 615 million special drawing rights.

title: Jeweler Charged With Tax Evasion
description: A jeweler was arrested yesterday on charges that he had evaded taxes on more than $1 million in sales over three years.

title: Solstice Salute
description: Paul Winter, whose jazz group has had a loving relationship with the Earth, welcomed winter last weekend with music combined with the taped voices of wolves, whales and other creatures.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Dismissed Eddie LeBaron, executive vice president.

title: FRIES ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net lo9sses.

title: New Plan Seeks Phone Rate Rises
description: The New York Telephone Company today proposed a new system of rate increases that would allow it to raise customers' bills twice a year in 1986 and in 1987 to pay for higher operating costs.

title: HOLIDAY SPIRIT PROMPTS GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST
description: Contributions large and small, all given in the spirit of the holiday season, have been received by the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ATTRACTING TOP-NOTCH TEACHERS
description: CONGRESS last week appropriated $10 million to finance a new scheme to encourage talented high school students to become teachers. In Washington fiscal terms, a mere $10 million is hardly considered real money, and so the new legislation, known as the Talented Teacher Act, is in danger of being overlooked. But to judge that measure by its price tag would be to pass up one of the most promising opportunities to give muscle to the recent surfeit of plans for school reform.

title: Kuwait Inquiry
description: Kuwait has ended an official inquiry into insider trading in the $2.5 billion takeover of the Santa Fe International Corporation, a United States oil drilling company, the Kuwait press agency Kuna said.

title: HIGH-TECH OPENINGS EXPECTED
description: THE future of the troubled high-tech industry looks a little brighter for 1986, according to some management recruiters who specialize in high tech. That indicates some job opportunities.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago 6 months results reflect a reduction equal to 26 cents a share from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 16
description: b-After a charge of $3,750,000 for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks from a plant closing expense, tax benefits of $2,440,000 for the 12 weeks and $1,544,000 for the 24 weeks, an extraordinary charge of $109,000 for the 12 weeks and an extraordinary credit of $670,000 for the 24 weeks. c-Including extraordinary credits of $869,000 for the 12 weeks and $1,308,000 for the 24 weeks.

title: Dinkins's Top Aides
description: Being ''painfully aware that blacks, Hispanics and women are underrepresented in our government,'' David N. Dinkins, soon to take office as Manhattan Borough President, has appointed a Hispanic woman as deputy borough president.

title: OPTIMISM ON RATES FOR 1986
description: Two of the bond market's worst enemies - huge Federal budget deficits and the specter of higher inflation -haunted investors for much of this year. But lately their fears have subsided enough so that interest rates could start 1986 at the lowest levels in six years.

title: CHOIRBOYS ON FIFTH AVE.
description: THE boys made 120 tuna, ham and cheese sandwiches, packed them in brown paper bags with cups of soup and homemade cookies, and trooped the bitterly cold streets, handing the food out to the homeless they found huddled in atria and subway stations.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Man Forces a Nurse To Let His Father Die
description: A man who held a pistol to a nurse's throat and ordered her to disconnect his comatose father's life support system had promised his father ''not to let him linger,'' relatives said.

title: PUFFIN COLONY RESTORED IN GULF OF MAINE
description: TWENTY pairs of Atlantic puffins, the penguinlike birds with sad clown eyes, have nested this year on Eastern Egg Rock, a seven-acre island in Maine. It is the largest number nesting there since the colony of puffins was reestablished in 1981, according to Dr. Stephen W. Kress, director of the Fratercula Fund of the National Audubon Society.

title: Business and the Law;   Tobacco Ads: Curbs Legal?
description: WOULD it be unconstitutional to bar the Marlboro man from billboards and newspaper advertisements?

title: CENSORSHIP TO BE A TOPIC OF PEN CONGRESS PANEL
description: The opening session of the 48th International PEN Congress, which convenes in New York next month, will include such major writers as Mario Vargas Llosa of Peru, Kobo Abe of Japan, Nadine Gordimer of South Africa, Gunter Grass of West Germany and John Updike and E. L. Doctorow of the United States. In morning and afternoon sessions on Jan. 13 they will discuss ''How Does the State Imagine.''

title: Dow Slides By 14.22, To 1,528.78
description: The holidays reached Wall Street early, causing a sharp decline in volume yesterday. Stock prices also fell sharply.

title: Penguin Impasse
description: Weekend negotiations that were supposed to produce a new contract for the Pittsburgh Penguins' center, Mario Lemieux, have instead resulted in a stalement, and a Jan. 10 deadline has been set for the team to make a new proposal. ''I'm not happy with their offer,'' Lemieux said. The Penguins are trying to sign Lemieux, the National Hockey League's second-leading scorer for most of the season, to a four-year contract that wuld include an option year.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Novt 2
'Wind in Willows' Closes
description: ''Wind in the Willows,'' the musical based on Kenneth Grahame's stories about the adventures of a community of riverbank inhabitants, closed after the matinee Sunday at the Nederlander Theater. The play, staged by Tony Stevens, ran for four regular performances and 27 previews.

title: Coach Contacted
description: Jerry Berndt, who coached Penn to the Ivy League football title or a share of it in each of the last four seasons, said yesterday that Rice had interviewed him as a candidate for its vacant head-coaching job.

title: FRANCE AND GREENPEACE ANNOUNCE PACT
description: France and the environmentalist group Greenpeace agreed today to negotiate the amount of damages the Government owes the group for sinking its flagship, both sides said.

title: A Quiet Week's Busy Start
description: LIKE a kid displaying holiday gifts, Leo Greenland, the silver-tongued chairman of 27-year-old Smith/Greenland, opened the agency's main conference room early yesterday to display two moderately new top executives, a newish marketing method, a new commercial (with a guest star) and a couple of new assignments.

title: CONSUMER NOMINEE STALLED IN SENATE
description: The nomination of Terrence M. Scanlon as chairman of the Consumer Products Safety Commission was stalled just before the Senate ended its 1985 session Friday, with Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, leading the effort to block confirmation.

title: Topics;   Truth in Packaging Now Map the Trains
description: New York's subway authorities have done a wonderful thing, no doubt about it. Riders arriving at, say, West Fourth Street, no longer need hope there's somebody on the platform or in the token booth who knows the way to the New School.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amtrak has appointed Henry Rogers Moore executive vice president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 9. He replaces Thomas P. Hackney Jr., who will retire.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
REYNOLDS WINS SUIT ON SMOKER AND HIS DEATH
description: A state jury today rejected the theory that smoking is addictive and that the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company should be held liable for the lung cancer death of a Santa Barbara man in 1982.

title: SENATE PANEL URGES OVERHAUL OF POLICIES ON CLASSIFYING DATA
description: After a year in which 11 Americans were charged with spying, the Senate Intelligence Committee called today for wide streamlining of the way the Government protects its secrets from spying and unauthorized disclosures of sensitive information.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 16
Lilco Issue Sold
description: The New York State Energy Research and Development Authority sold $150 million of tax-exempt bonds on behalf of the Long Island Lighting Company through an underwriting group headed by Salomon Brothers. The issue consists of 30-year variable rate bonds with a 6.5 percent coupon, priced at par.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PROTOCOL COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $243,000.

title: AIRBUS GROUP ACTS TO MOLLIFY U.S.
description: Britain, France and Germany want to hold joint talks with top Reagan Administration trade officials early next year in an effort to convince them they are not subsidizing the European Airbus, the passenger aircraft that the three countries build jointly.

title: Holiday Closings
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed tomorrow for Christmas.

title: BOMB AT A RESORT IN SOUTH AFRICA KILLS SIX WHITES
description: At least six whites, three of them children, were killed today when a bomb planted beside a garbage can exploded among pre-Christmas shoppers at a mall in this white resort south of Durban.

title: Be Fair to Mail-Order Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: REVISING OF PACTS RULED TO VIOLATE CITY CHARTER
description: A state judge has ruled that the way the Board of Estimate routinely revises agreements on franchises, contracts and development plans violates the City Charter.

title: RAMS ARE BEATEN BY RAIDERS, 16-6
description: Marcus Allen ran for 123 yards to win the National Football League rushing title, and Chris Bahr kicked three field goals tonight as the Los Angeles Raiders scored a 16-6 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

title: TV MINISTER CALLS HIS RESORT 'BAIT' FOR CHRISTIANITY
description: The traffic begins to back up along Route 21 at dusk; buses, vans and cars bound for the annual display of Christmas lights at Heritage USA, a sprawling resort complex founded here as an evangelistic venture by the television minister Jim Bakker.

title: RICHARDSON LEADS NETS TO 4TH STRAIGHT
description: A week ago, they seemed on the edge of an emotional breakup. But the widening gap that began to separate Dave Wohl and Micheal Ray Richardson over a two-day period has slowly closed.

title: RANGERS ROUT RED WINGS
description: When the Rangers scored for the 10th time against the Detroit Red Wings last night at the Garden, their players on the bench pumped their sticks, and their fans, unaccustomed to plenty, stood and stayed standing. The Red Wing players, embarrassed again, stared at the ice.

title: Prof. Ignace Gelb, Authority On Ancient Languages, Dies
description: Ignace J. Gelb, professor emeritus at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, an authority on the development of writing, died of leukemia in Chicago Sunday. He was 78 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: ARGENTINE CHRISTMAS: LETTUCE AND BATHING SUITS
description: Up and down the main downtown pedestrian mall here, the city has put up one-story metal structures for Christmas - sculptures, for want of a better term. They are decorated with snowflakes, pine trees and the names of local companies.

title: Market Place;   Last-Minute Tax Tactics
description: IN the five trading days remaining this year, stock market investors still have time to consider a variety of tax strategies.

title: NBC TO USE SUPER BOWL TO PLAY UP NEWS ANCHOR
description: For football fans, next month's Super Bowl is the climax of a long season. For advertisers, it's an expensive method of selling cars, soap and beer. And for NBC News, the Super Bowl is a way to give Tom Brokaw, the anchor of the No. 2-rated ''Nightly News,'' the kind of exposure the network believes he needs in the competition for evening viewers.

title: SAUL, B F REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $843,000 for the quarter and year from early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $136,000 for the year from sale of property.

title: 4,000-Year-Old Pot
description: Archeologists digging south of St. Augustine, Fla., have uncovered what they believe is the oldest ceramic pot ever discovered on the North American continent. They said it was molded as long ago as 4,000 years.

title: THEATER: HEINER MULLER'S 'QUARTET'
description: DRAWN from the 18th-century novel ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' Heiner Muller's ''Quartet'' is a dense, four-character dialogue to be played by two actors, dealing in philosophical terms with forbidden games of decadence and depravity. The novel, which was also the basis for the Roger Vadim film of the same title, is epistolary - letters sent back and forth between the Marquise de Merteuil and the Vicomte de Valmont, describing in graphic detail the interwoven crosscurrents of their seductions.

title: Challenger Is Moved to Launching Pad
description: The space shuttle Challenger has been hauled to a newly modified Apollo moon rocket launching pad to prepare for a January mission with a New Hampshire schoolteacher aboard.

title: AT LUNCH, CHURCH YOUTHS LEARN A LESSON IN SHARING
description: In the basement of St. George's Episcopal Church at 11:15 A.M. yesterday, 9-year-old Sky A. Berdahl inspected the neat row of brown lunch bags, poked his nose into a half-empty one, and in his best imitation of a bellow announced, ''We need more sandwiches!''

title: U.S. ARMS REPORT IS CALLED BIASED
description: President Reagan's report on purported Soviet arms control violations came under fire today from private experts.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Ranking Christmas On the Stress Scale
description: You've probably seen the ''Life Stress Scale,'' which assigns points to various experiences (being fired, 47 points; sex difficulties, 39) and thus allows you to calculate how messed up you are at any given time. Score more than 150 and you're a candidate for a stroke or a psychiatrist's couch.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $65,000 and a charge of $341,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Including extraordinary gains of $265,000 for the quarter and $3,647,000 for the year. d-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,566,000 and a tax credit of $1,183,000. e-Net loss.

title: Balking at Tests
description: Players for the Green Bay Packers had the option of taking drug tests at their postseason physicals yesterday, but their player representative, James Lofton, said that the players would refrain. ''We're not going to take them,'' Lofton told The Milwaukee Sentinel.

title: VIOLENCE TO JOURNALISTS FOUND TO RISE
description: Violence against journalists increased dramatically worldwide in 1985, and the result was more self-censorship and intimidation of news organizations, according to Leonard R. Sussman, exeutive director of Freedom House, a watchdog organization based in New York.

title: NEW FIND IS LINKED TO EVENTS TO EXODUS
description: PROBING 20 feet into the soil of the Nile delta, American scientists have found tiny glass fragments from a volcano that they say could lend support to a theory linking a volcanic eruption to the seemingly miraculous events associated with the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS HUGE FARM BILL, BUT RELUCTANTLY
description: Saying he sought to ''help put America's farmers back in a competitive position in world markets,'' President Reagan today signed the costliest farm bill in the nation's history.

title: Exxon, Hunt Link
description: The Exxon Corporation has aquired 49 percent of the Hunt Oil Company's interest in a production sharing agreement with Yemen, which includes the Alif oilfield. Hunt said it had established a joint venture with Exxon to produce and transport oil from the Alif field, which has just been declared commercial with an estimated 400 million barrels of recoverable oil reserves. A subsidiary of the Dallas-based Hunt Oil acquired a concession in Yemen's Marib-Jawf area in 1981.

title: PARTNERS IN MIDCON BID ARRANGE FOR FINANCING
description: The partnership formed by Wagner & Brown and Freeport-McMoran Inc. to acquire the Midcon Corporation said yesterday that it had secured commitments to finance the full $1.25 billion in high-yield, high-risk securities it wants to use as part of the purchase price.

title: Stores' Deposits Stolen in Brooklyn
description: A burglar broke into the night deposit box of a Brooklyn bank and stole as much as $500,000 in weekend receipts from stores in the Bay Ridge section, the police said yesterday.

title: 2 EXECUTIVES LOSE THEIR JOBS
description: The end of a season always brings with it a change in personnel, as owners conclude that dismissing coaches and general managers is more convenient and less expensive than dumping high-salaried players.

title: Off for the Season
description: From the Queens County courthouse comes a Christmas story -Walter R. Christmas's story.

title: Security Pacific Gets PX Business
description: Security Pacific Bankcard USA said it had won a contract to process credit-card transactions at 791 Army and Air Force post exchanges in the United States as well as 35 Navy stores in California, Washington and Nevada. The division of the Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, did not disclose the contract's value, but a spokesman, Mary Trigg, said it would be one of largest merchant accounts at the bank.

title: NO ANONYMOUS LETTERS IN SPY CASE
description: A Federal district judge refused today to allow prosecutors in the espionage case against Jerry A. Whitworth to introduce anonymous letters sent to the Federal Bureau of Investigation that purport to outline a spy ring.

title: Soviet Protest to Britain
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today protested the British Government's decision to join in research for the United States space-based missile defense program known as ''Star Wars.'' Britain signed a memorandum with the United States on Dec. 6 agreeing to join in the research.

title: Complications In Horse's Injury
description: Veterinarians today continued to try to clear up a blood clot in the broken leg of Stephan's Odyssey, the son of Danzig, who finished second in the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes.

title: BUDGET CUT WOULD DELAY U.S. SPACE STATION PROGRAM
description: The White House will seek to cut $480 million of the $580 million that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration wants in the next fiscal year to develop a space station, an industry magazine said today.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. Steel Is Censured
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured the United States Steel Corporation today for improper practices as transfer agent for its own shares from 1983 to 1985.

title: U.S. PROTESTS TO PRETORIA OVER ARREST OF MANDELA
description: The State Department said today that the United States had protested to the South African Government over the arrest of Winnie Mandela on Sunday.

title: IN SALVADOR REBEL ZONE: A LIFE OF WAR AND WANT
description: The peasants of this farming hamlet celebrated their annual festival of the Virgin of Remedies in a small adobe house. They said they would have held the ceremony in their crumbling village church except for the fact that it was destroyed by the Salvadoran Army two years ago.

title: Ethiopian Defection Denied
description: Berhanu Dinka, the Ethiopian delegate, denied today that Dawit Wolde Georgis, head of Ethiopian famine relief, had defected to the United States.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY A SHARP 0.6%
description: Americans' personal income rose in November at the fastest clip in seven months, while consumer spending rebounded from a steep plunge the month before, the Government reported today.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 5
IDLENESS FRUSTRATES GIANTS' MANUEL
description: The Sunday before last, the Giants were playing the Cowboys in Texas in a game they could have won but did not. For the Giants' players there, the frustration was unending. For Lionel Manuel, it was worse.

title: Angry Atlantan's Computer Ties Up Falwell's Phone Line
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 23 (AP) -

title: U.S. to Pay Chicago For Desegregation Costs
description: A Federal district judge who chastised the Government for paying too little of the cost of desegregating Chicago's public schools today ordered the Department of Education to give the city up to $88 million.

title: STAGE: LINCOLN CENTER PRESENTS 2 ONE-ACTS
description: IN smart contrast to its ill-fated predecessors, Lincoln Center's newest theatrical regime is starting out small, attempting to walk before it runs. There are no plans to try to reoccupy that black hole of New York's dramatic universe, the Vivian Beaumont, until next season. Instead, the fledgling company's artistic director, Gregory Mosher, has reopened the neighboring, intimate Newhouse Theater, and done so with his own theatrical specialty - a bill of one-act plays, ''Prairie du Chien'' and ''The Shawl,'' by his longtime Chicago colleague David Mamet.

title: Sky Marshals on Iran Jet Kill Would-Be Hijacker in Incident
description: Iranian sky marshals foiled an attempt to hijack an Iran Air jetliner on a domestic flight today, killing one of the would-be hijackers in a struggle aboard the plane, the Teheran radio reported.

title: Third-World Population Bomb Alive and Ticking
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF MISS JANE MARPLE. By Anne Hart. 161 pages.

title: TAX EVASION RAIDS IN INDIA STIR DEBATE
description: A wave of arrests of prominent business executives and other wealthy people on tax evasion charges has shaken the Indian business community and stirred a new debate over the country's huge ''black economy'' of illicit and underground business activities.

title: Norway Pays $614,000 For Grieg Manuscripts
description: The Government of Norway has announced the purchase for $614,000 in New York of a large number of musical manuscripts, autographs and letters by the Norwegian composer Edvard Grieg. This collection contains music of 29 Grieg works covering 800 pages of manuscript paper and also includes 375 of Grieg's letters on 1,300 pages.

title: STATE TO PROPOSE CENTERS FOR AIDS
description: New York State plans to create a system of hospital-based AIDS centers that will emphasize hospice care and home services, rather than long hospital stays.

title: Michelle Stacey, an Editor, Is Wed to David Schonauer
description: Michelle Stacey, a senior associate editor of Savvy magazine, and David Schonauer, the managing editor of American Photographer magazine, were married yesterday.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Eight-Hour Concert Of 'Architectural' Music
description: The year's shortest day contained one of its longest concerts. About 6 o'clock Saturday night, the composer Phill Niblock turned on the tape recorder and movie projector in the Experimental Intermedia Foundation and began an eight-hour program of his own music.

title: SUSPECTS IN HELICOPTER JAILBREAK ARE CAUGHT AT GEORGIA REST STOP
description: After swearing Sunday that they would never be taken alive, three escaped convicts and the woman believed to have plucked them from a prison yard by helicopter last week were found asleep in a stolen car this morning.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available.* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WHY THEY FIGHT: REBELS TELL THEIR STORIES
description: This village and dozens of others like it are among the places where El Salvador's revolution began over a decade ago.

title: CAREERCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $88,496.

title: Gorbachev Receives Chinese
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today received Li Peng, a Chinese Deputy Prime Minister, who was stopping over on his way home from a visit to Czechoslovakia and Rumania. It was the highest-level meeting between the two countries since July, when another Chinese Deputy Prime Minister, Yao Yilin, was in Moscow.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including gains of $12,869 for the quarter and $286,803 for the 6 months on the sale of land.

title: GANDER CRASH PUTS SPOTLIGHT ON AVIATION GROUP AND ITS REGULATORY CLASHES
description: The operator of the chartered American troop plane that crashed in Canada Dec. 12 is part of a large family-held aviation empire that has been involved in several government inquiries and lawsuits over safety and management issues in the last dozen years.

title: Ex-Councilman Gets Prison Term
description: A former New York City Councilman, Joseph Savino Jr. of the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday to an 18-month prison term for illegally possessing a machine gun and three pistols equipped with silencers.

title: Don't Believe In Trust
description: Especially at this holiday season come again the questions of what to believe about others. Is Mikhail Gorbachev sincere? Can we ever really trust the Russians?

title: POUND PUPPIES: PET OF THE YEAR
description: They are cute, excessively cute, soft and easily cuddled, and virtually every small child in New York, perhaps in the United States, seems to want one this Christmas. They are this year's toy fad, this year's Cabbage Patch Kids. Well, actually they're not kids, but dogs - Pound Puppies they're called.

title: U.S. Deficit Still Increasing
description: The Federal Government suffered a $33.39 billion deficit last month, 23 percent higher than the $27.09 billion October deficit, the Treasury Department said today.

title: AMTRAK TRIMMING SCHEDULES ON SOME OF ITS MAJOR ROUTES
description: Amtrak will reduce passenger-train service on some major routes beginning Jan. 12 because of cuts in Federal funds, officials said today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: YOU won't hear a pin drop on Seventh Avenue this week because designers have already dropped all their pins in favor of wrapping paper and ribbon. Some have turned their backs on all of that and simply left town for the holidays. Perry Ellis is in Virginia and Michaele Vollbracht in Kansas. It may be hard to believe at times, but designers have families and hometowns, too.

description: Passenger and freight traffic across the English Channel was reported back to normal today after French navigators for the Sealink company ended their 10-day strike on Sunday night. The navigators' demands concerned wages and vacations. Details of the settlement were not available.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $72,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: SAN FRANCISCO APPROVES BILL TO DESIGNATE IT A SANCTUARY
description: The Board of Supervisors voted 8 to 3 today to adopt a resolution declaring the city a sanctuary for refugees from the Central American countries.

title: Malls as a Marketplace for Ideas
description: New York's highest court holds that the state Constitution does not entitle citizens to pass out leaflets in privately owned shopping malls. That's a permissible but regrettable reading of New York's bill of rights. The Court of Appeals was free, so far as the United States Supreme Court was concerned, to render a more expansive interpretation that would have enlarged freedom of expression at no significant cost to private property rights.

title: NO QUICK ACCORD SEEN IN TEXACO-PENNZOIL TALK
description: Representatives of Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company are expected to meet again today to continue negotiations aimed at settling their multibillion-dollar legal dispute.

title: CHRISTMAS LIGHTS ORDERED DARK
description: The Louisiana State Supreme Court today ordered Al Copeland to turn off his 250,000 Christmas lights and then ordered a warrant for his arrest.

title: THE REAL REASON FOR CHRISTMAS
description: Ever try to keep Christmas holy? It is a job-and-a-half, but at St. Agnes Cathedral Elementary School, Sister Kathy Carlin, the principal, does not consider that grounds for caving in.

title: Goodbye, Charle
description: When he arrived at the Seattle Seahawks' headquarters yesterday, he was Charle Young, tight end. When he drove away in a shiny new Rolls-Royce after announcing his retirement, he was C. Edward Young, contractor and car importer.

title: Offer Is Submitted For St. Louis Paper
description: The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, the bankrupt newspaper that ceased publication Dec. 6, could resume publishing in early January under the ownership of two local businessmen, according to the bankruptcy trustee appointed to the case.

title: Bridge: Team Scores a Slim Victory In Greater New York Final
description: A foursome headed by Michael Rosmarin of New York City gained a narrow victory Sunday night in the final of the Knockout Team Championship at the Greater New York Regionals at the Sheraton Centre, at Seventh Avenue and 53d Street in Manhattan.

title: Bradley the Lobbyist
description: Senator Bill Bradley played an unusual role, for a Senator, in the recent melodrama and intrigue over the passage of tax-revision legislation that so titillated the fans of Government and politics in the capital.

title: MCELREAVY COLUMBIA COACH
description: Larry McElreavy's longtime ambition to be a head coach in the Ivy League was achieved yesterday with Columbia's announcement that he had been appointed coach of the Lions.

title: Argentine Will Appeal Acquittal of 4 Officers
description: A Government prosecutor said today that he would appeal a civilian court's decision this month to acquit four former military rulers on charges of extensive human rights abuses.

title: U.S. SAYS 'SHOCKING' CONDITIONS FOLLOW RESETTLEMENT IN ETHIOPIA
description: An American foreign aid official said today that the United States had accounts from witnesses of ''shocking'' conditions in two resettlement villages in Gojjam Province in western Ethiopia, suggesting ''a vast human tragedy of historical proportions.''

title: Giants Unsure on Watts
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said today he was unsure whether Ted Watts, a reserve cornerback, would be ready to play against the San Francisco Giants here Sunday in aNational Football League wild-card game. Watts injured his left knee in Saturday's 28-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers, the game that put the Giants into the playoffs.

title: AS HEMS RISE, SHORTS RETURN
description: This may be the time when shorts make it back into the mainstream of fashion. There hardly exists a designer in Milan, Paris or New York who does not feature some type of shorts for spring.

title: Grand Old Tradition Of Interventionism
description: To the Editor:

title: ARABS PRESS ARAFAT ON U.N. MEASURE
description: Yasir Arafat is coming under increasing pressure from politically moderate Arabs to accept a United Nations resolution that calls for recognition of Israel's right to exist. The alternative, he is being told, is to be dropped from the Middle East peace initiative being pressed by King Hussein of Jordan.

title: DANTE MAGNANI
description: Dante Magnani, a National Football League halfback and a member of the ''Monsters of the Midway'' Chicago Bear teams of the 1940's, has died of heart failure. He was 68 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend on Friday listing extra theater performances over the holidays misstated the schedule for ''Doubles.'' There will not be a matinee on Jan. 3.

title: 19th-Century Support for Thesis of Palestine-Depopulation Book
description: To the Editor:

title: COURTS HAVE SILENT DAYS DURING CHRISTMAS WEEK
description: On any given day, there are about 125 trials under way in Manhattan's sprawling criminal and civil court system, court officials say. Yesterday, there was one. Where crowded corridors and congested calendars are the rule, there was silence. Where jury rooms are ordinarily packed, the seats were empty.

title: L.I. Man Pleads Not Guilty In Multimillion Dollar Fraud
description: Michael Franzese, who prosecutors say operated a multimillion dollar scheme to defraud banks, oil companies, car manufacturers and state governments, pleaded not guilty today in Federal court here.

title: Investigation Should Precede a Malpractice Suit
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOY TIME Anyone taking the kids to marvel at the midtown tinsel around Rockefeller Center this week will be well rewarded with a drop-in, a block north, at the headquarters of Paine Webber at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52d Street. The reward is not so much surcease from walking and weather as it is in the shape of 500 eye-catching playthings on display in the new Paine Webber Art Gallery in the lobby. Unlike the amorphous, space-filling nature of so many lobby galleries, this one stands apart from the financial business of the building and has the feeling of visiting any separate gallery.

title: Kasparov Refuses Karpov a Rematch
description: Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, said today that he would not grant a rematch to the man he defeated for the title, Anatoly Karpov.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 10:22 A.M. today and set at 10:25 P.M. tomorrow.

title: CONGRESS RESISTING NEW AID FOR NICARAGUA'S INSURGENTS
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to sound out Congress about the prospects for restoring military aid to Nicaraguan rebels have drawn negative responses over the last several weeks, according to some key legislators.

title: THE SPRINGSTEEN BOWL
description: It seems so long ago by now, like a memory from a simpler time, but it was only last Sept. 12 that New York was levitated by Baseball Thursday, a Met game at Shea in the afternoon, a Yankee game at the Stadium at night, and pilgrims making their Chaucerian way from Queens to the Bronx.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax charge of $75,000. c-Net income including tax credits of $217,000 for the quarter and $470,000 for the 6 months.

title: STATES SHIFT TOWARD INCENTIVES
description: AFTER several years of ordering public schools and colleges to meet minimum standards of student achievement, state education policy makers around the country are turning to programs that reward schools and teachers for doing better than the minimum.

title: 7.9% G.M. LOAN RATE EXPECTED
description: The General Motors Corporation will offer a 7.9 percent interest rate later this week as an incentive to increase flagging car sales, auto industry sources reported today.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FOR VERRAZANO, ONE-WAY TOLLS
description: The people who run the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge announced today that, under orders from the Federal Government, they would begin collecting tolls in only one direction on the bridge on or about April 1.

title: St. Patrick's Filled To Honor a Slugger
description: Amid the Christmas wreaths hanging on the tall white columns along the nave and the bright poinsettias placed on the altar, a mass was said in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon for Roger Maris.

title: Research From Afar On South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: A JUDGE APPROVES USE OF F.B.I. TAPES IN DONOVAN TRIAL
description: A state judge in the Bronx yesterday approved the use of secretly recorded tapes in the larceny and fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and nine other men.

title: TALKS BY FRANCE FAIL IN LEBANON
description: Efforts by a French Government team here to win the freedom of four Frenchmen held by Moslem extremists ended in failure today, the negotiators said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Saturday about Klaus Tennstedt's cancellation of appearances with the New York Philharmonic misstated the arrangement for exchanging tickets. They may be exchanged for other New York Philharmonic tickets now on sale at Avery Fisher Hall, subject to availability.

title: Papal Aide to Meet With P.O.W.'s in Iran
description: Pope John Paul II, acting on a request from the Government of Iran, sent an envoy to Teheran today with a Christmas ''message of prayer and human solidarity'' for Iraqi prisoners of war.

title: ST. JOHN'S WINS
description: After watching St. John's begin its season with inspired performances against stiff competition, the benefits of playing a tough early schedule became obvious.

title: QUEST FOR DRUG AGAINST AIDS MAKES PROGRESS
description: IN many laboratories here and abroad, scientists are working urgently to find drugs that will work against the deadly virus that causes AIDS.

title: DAISY'S DINOSAUR TRAITS
description: PRINTER technology is evolving rapidly. And just as in the evolution of life, some species of printers are having a tough time of it.

title: EIL INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Carbide Rating Is Cut
description: The rating on $1.7 billion of Union Carbide Corporation debt was lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which also hinted at further reductions.

title: Games for Sale, Playboy Says
description: Eight-year-old Games magazine, which Playboy Enterprises acquired late in 1979, is on the block, according to Christie Hefner, president of Playboy Enterprises.

title: MANY TO HOSPITAL
description: A twin-engine plane on a landing approach in heavy fog plunged through the roof of a shopping mall crowded with Christmas shoppers tonight, the authorities said. An undetermined number of people were injured but there were no immediate reports of fatalities.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: Scully Suggests a Switch
description: Vin Scully, the sports broadcaster, suggests a movie based on the Pittsburgh cocaine trials: ''They could call it 'From Here to Immunity.' ''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1985
description: International

title: Klecko Says Walton Improved Jets
description: The Jets started to win, Joe Klecko said today, ''after Joe Walton got rid of cocky people, militant people, and got just people who will work.''

title: PENTAGIN'S FRUITCAKE: QUITE RICH, OF COURSE
description: Christmas, says Senator Sam Nunn, is the time for sharing old family recipes, such as the Pentagon Fruitcake, Military Specification MIL-F-1499F.

title: Among the Dolls and Toys
description: Snow-covered doll houses of the type that sat beneath the tree on Victorian Christmas mornings make the Washington Dolls' House and Toy Museum one of the most enchanting of holiday treasures in the capital.

title: A WEDDING THAT WASN'T
description: There are some of us who feel we were left at the altar by ABC's ''Wide World of Sports'' last Saturday. The program featured the 1984 United States Olympic boxers Mark Breland, Tyrell Biggs, Evander Holyfield and Meldrick Taylor, each of whom continued serving their apprenticeships as professionals without incident. Pernell Whitaker, another Olympian, was initially on the card, but withdrew well in advance because of a broken bone in his foot.

title: Military Security Guard Is Approved for Aquino
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos approved military security today for Corazon C. Aquino, his opponent in the Feb. 7 special presidential election.

title: In Turkey, a Gain for Rights
description: The human rights climate in Turkey seems to be getting better, slowly. America and the rest of Europe should of course welcome this progress, tentative as it is, but we should also keep up the scrutiny and pressure that spurred it in the first place.

title: In the Name of Sanity, Tax Oil
description: America, running a $200 billion deficit for the fourth consecutive year, desperately needs to reorder its finances. Congress knows that and so does the President: They've just committed themselves by law to cut the deficit $55 billion next year and eliminate it entirely by 1991. Now the opportunity to take a long stride toward that goal is enhanced by the collapse of OPEC, the oil cartel. The way to do it is to tax imported oil.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results include an approximate gain of $4.9 million, or 60 cents a share, from the sale of the company's seed business in the United States.

title: Church's to Close 100 Restaurants
description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc. said that it was closing about 100 of its fried-chicken restaurants in a move that would reduce first-quarter earnings between 11 cents and 15 cents a share. J. David Bamberger, chairman and chief executive, said that most of the restaurants are geographically remote and difficult to market.

title: Fed Bank on Coast Names President
description: Robert T. Parry, chief economist with the Security Pacific Corporation, will succeed John Balles as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, upon Mr. Balles's retirement in February.

title: 'ANNIE OAKLEY' ON CABLE
description: SHELLEY DUVALL, the actress turned executive producer, has been winning awards for her cable-TV series called ''Faerie Tale Theater,'' an uneven but often imaginative updating of traditional children's stories. Now she is bringing forth ''Shelley Duvall's Tall Tales and Legends,'' taken from the files of American folklore and given the same sort of contemporary, winking spin. The first production, which can be seen on the pay-cable service Showtime tonight at 7 o'clock, is ''Annie Oakley.'' It is unlikely to win any awards.

title: When Professors Are Not Accurate
description: Izvestia and Secretary of Education William J. Bennett have something in common. They think Accuracy in Academia is a bad idea but for different reasons.

title: 2 GAS-STATION OPERATORS INDICTED IN A SCHEME TO EVADE SALES TAXES
description: Two gasoline-station owners were indicted yesterday on charges of defrauding New York State of nearly $9 million in sales taxes by underreporting sales.

title: Selling Iowa
description: When Gov. Terry Branstad travels to Pasadena, Calif., to watch Iowa play U.C.L.A. in the Rose Bowl, he will take with him a message about Iowa's economic-development efforts. Yesterday he unveiled lapel stickers that the Iowa Development Commission had prepared.

title: Pfizer Stock Drop
description: Pfizer Inc.'s stock dove yesterday after a report appeared in London linking the company's anti-arthritic drug, Feldene, to 77 deaths in Britain over five years. The stock declined $2.875, to $50.125, and was the second-busiest issue on the New York Stock Exchange as nearly 2.5 million shares changed hands. Pfizer defended the drug, saying the articles were sensationalized and contained nothing new.

title: LINEAR INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He loves children and he never dies.'' - Chad Scanga, 4 years old, of Lower Burrell, Pa., responding to poll question about whether he believes in Santa Claus. [A1:1.]

title: Dollar Declines a Bit While Gold Is Mixed
description: The dollar was down just a bit against all major currencies in very quiet pre-Christmas trading yesterday.

title: SUDDEN BLIZZARDS: SCIENTISTS TRY TO TAKE SURPRISE OUT OF WINTER
description: FOR the 30 million people in the populous zone from Boston to Washington, the season of sudden blizzards is about to begin, with its threat of paralyzed cities, stranded motorists and deaths by freezing. Now, in what is said to be the largest operation of its kind ever undertaken, an effort is being made to learn more precisely what causes these storms and how to predict them better.

title: Oppenheimer Officers Share Parallel Paths
description: Stephen Robert and Nathan Gantcher were born within a month of each other, grew up in small towns outside Boston, attended college in New England and in 1968 joined Oppenheimer & Company, the brokerage house.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Newell Head Is Appointed
description: The Newell Companies, a group of houseware and hardware concerns based in Freeport, Ill., said yesterday that William P. Sovey will become president, effective Jan. 1.

title: CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $60,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a net loss of $4,097,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Buchanan's Window
description: When Patrick J. Buchanan became White House director of communications last February, he was given ample power, but his office, near the Oval Office, had no window.

title: Bone Analyzer
description: An instrument developed to help scientists combat the bone loss that occurs during long space flights may aid in treating bone fractures and bone-weakening diseases such as osteoporosis, according to an announcement by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Fordham Wins On Late Foul Shots
description: Eric Brooks made three free throws within the last 34 seconds to break a 41-41 tie, and Fordham held on to edge Columbia, 44-43, last night at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: IN A TALK, CUOMO JOKES, REFLECTS AND LOOKS TO '86
description: The state tax cuts proposed last week by Republicans are ''a good idea,'' Governor Cuomo said today.

title: DR. LEWIS B. POSNER
description: Dr. Lewis B. Posner, the former head of the prenatal clinic at Harlem Hospital, died Sunday at the Frances Schervier Home and Hospital in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 83 years old and lived in Riverdale.

title: MODEL TRAINS ARRIVE AT THE TERMINAL
description: During the last few weeks before Christmas, I spent considerable time pondering the subject of model trains. My 6-year-old son, Revell, had been talking of nothing but ''lectric'' trains all year. Although he was really too young for them, it had become increasingly obvious that his father was ready for one.

title: COUNCIL ON FOREIGN RELATIONS APPOINTS PRESIDENT
description: The Council on Foreign Relations, one of the nation's most influential private groups for the study of international affairs, named a former diplomat as its new president yesterday.

title: AID FOR HOMELESS OFFERED BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo has proposed a program to provide new housing for homeless families in New York City.

title: MEGATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BALLET: 'THE NUTCRACKER'
description: THE Eglevsky Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker,'' performed Saturday night at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College in the Bronx, is a version that does honor to this holiday classic. Michael Vernon, the company's resident choreographer, tells the story in dance and a staging that are notably lively, simple and tasteful. The sets - by Robert Olson, for the prologue, and Howard Jones, for the first and second acts - are pretty, with a Christmas tree that grows with extra magic, and a second act backdrop that makes the Land of Sweets a pleasantly airy place.

title: IN PARK WHERE RHINOCEROS ROAMS, RANGERS STALK POACHERS
description: At dusk, a pinpoint of light shines from inside the forest. Slowly the light gets closer to reveal a jeep full of hunters, returning to camp with their quarry.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $15,337,000 for the quarter and $18,044,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $1,511,000 for the quarter and $4,994,000 for the 9 months.

title: Westchester Sets '86 Spending Plan
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators approved a $716.9 million budget for 1986 tonight, trimming nearly $4.5 million from the one proposed five weeks ago by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: Ex-Civil Guard General Slain in Northern Spain
description: A retired Civil Guard general was slain today in Pamplona, and the police said they suspected Basque terrorists.

title: CONCERT: Y SYMPHONY IN A DAVID STOCK PIECE
description: FROM a standpoint of programming, Gerard Schwarz is the most responsible and thoughtful music director of any mainstream musical organization in Manhattan. Sunday afternoon's Y Chamber Symphony concert at the 92d Street Y was as usual: well balanced and full of interest. And the star soloist was a delight.

title: JAMES STEWART STARS IN A CHRISTMAS TALE
description: ''MR. KRUEGER'S CHRISTMAS'' is a sentimental curio, produced for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and interesting mostly because it stars James Stewart. Another point of interest is that occasionally we hear the Mormon Tabernacle Choir. The 30-minute film will be seen on Channel 11 at 10:30 tonight.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
UNEXPECTED SNOWSTORMS
description: Sudden blizzards may strike as often as six times a year. Here, with quotes from The New York Times, are accounts of some of them.

title: HRUDEY LEADS ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders, with Kelly Hrudey's superior goaltending and a revitalized power play, beat the Hartford Whalers, 6-3, tonight at the Civic Center.

title: Steve Cauthen Spending Quiet Holiday at Home
description: It seems that everyone wants to visit the Cauthen farm in Walton, Ky., this holiday season. The Cauthens, however, are not receiving right now.

title: Topics;   Truth in Packaging Troublesome Toys
description: A label on a box of Tinker Toys, the popular building set to be found under countless Christmas trees, says it is for ''3 1/2 years and up.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, was hospitalized over the weekend in Santa Monica, Calif., where he will undergo corrective heart-bypass surgery. . . . Ken Riley, defensive backfield coach for the Green Bay Packers, has agreed to become Florida A&M's football coach, The Tallahassee Democrat reported yesterday. He would replace the dismissed Rudy Hubbard, who coached Riley when he was a quarterback at the school. . . . Terry Bowden, coach at Salem College in West Virginia and son of the Florida State coach, Bobby Bowden, resigned to become an assistant coach for Gerry Faust at Akron. . . . Doug Altenberger, the senior guard for the Illinois basketball team, will sit out the rest of the season as a medical redshirt because of a knee injury. . . . Tom McGraw, who had a career .246 average with the White Sox, Senators, Indians and Angels from 1962-75, was named the Mets' minor-league hitting instructor. . . . The Knicks' Bill Cartwright, sidelined with a broken foot, was re-examined and permitted to begin jumping exercises. He is expected to resume playing in three to four weeks, a team official said. . . . Brownell Combs 2d announced his resignation as chairman, chief executive officer and a director of Spendthrift Farm Inc., one of the largest thoroughbred operations in the world.

title: The Conscience Fund
description: The Conscience Fund had an off year in the fiscal year 1985, gathering in from a guilty public only $255,690.77, which is about $21,000 short of the previous year's donations. The number of people sending in money also dropped, to about 100, from 125 for the previous fiscal year.

title: JUDGE RIDICULES MESSENGER SPY CHARGES
description: A Federal magistrate said today that the sworn statement of the Federal Bureau of Investigation supporting espionage charges against a Washington messenger was ''as thin an affidavit as it has been my misfortune to see in many years.''

title: Cincinnati's Top Dog
description: We first met Schottzie when her owner, Marge Schott, brought her to the news conference announcing Mrs. Schott's purchase of the Cincinnati Reds. Schottzie, a Saint Bernard, wore a Reds cap and sat on Pete Rose's foot.

title: Gas Attendants Charged in Fraud
description: Sixteen gas attendants at Mobil stations along the Garden State Parkway have been charged with defrauding motorists, authorities said today.

title: Odds for Heart Patient Diminish, Doctors Say
description: Doctors said today that the chances of survival for an artificial heart recipient had dropped to less than 50-50. They cited her recent inability to respond to commands and her malfunctioning kidneys as reasons for their fears.

title: FIRST AMERICAN HEALTH CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Real Estate;   Rebuilding Downtown Jamaica
description: IN 1970, the city designated 10 acres of old buildings, abandoned movie houses and a 19th-century abattoir in the center of downtown Jamaica, Queens, as a new Office Development District. The property was purchased, the buildings razed, and the land split into four large sites on which the city hoped major office projects would be built.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
description: b-Net income.

title: Bonds Off in Light Trading
description: Treasury bond prices eased yesterday in light pre-holiday trading, while Treasury bill rates moved up slightly in anticipation of the results of the weekly auctions of Treasury bills.

title: Photographic Travels With the President
description: President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, met for the first time last month outside a villa in Versoix, Switzerland, where the President had his headquarters for the summit meeting.

title: Article 247457 -- No Title
description: A surprising number of high-priced books are selling unusually well this Christmas season, according to booksellers, but the most successful of all is the posthumous autobiography of Ansel Adams. It is the first best seller for Mr. Adams, the noted photographer, and, with a retail price of $50, it may be the the most expensive book ever to make it onto the list.

title: R.P. CONDIE, CHOIR HEAD, DIES
description: Richard P. Condie, the conductor of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir from 1957 to 1974, died Sunday in Salt Lake City. He was 87 years old and lived in Salt Lake City.

title: SALLY GANNETT McADAM
description: Sally Gannett McAdam, a trustee of the Gannett Foundation and the daughter of its founder, Frank E. Gannett, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 62 years old.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE'S CURB ON BONDS IS ASSAILED BY THE ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration today severely criticized the Federal Reserve Board's proposal to limit the use of low-grade bonds in corporate takeovers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about the AIDS epidemic's effect on Bellevue Hospital Center misidentified a psychiatrist who is a member of the hospital's AIDS task force. She is Dr. Sharon Sageman.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Ruth Warrick Returns To Roots as a Singer
description: Ruth Warrick, the 70-year-old actress who plays Phoebe Tyler on the daytime drama ''All My Children,'' is no newcomer to popular song, having been a radio vocalist before making her screen debut as Kane's first wife in the movie ''Citizen Kane.'' The most interesting moments in her cabaret act, which plays at the Park Ten Supper Club, at Park Avenue and 34th Street, through next Sunday, are the actress's memories of the young Orson Welles.

title: Chess: World Team Championship Won Easily by Soviet Union
description: The Soviet Union decisively won first place in the first World Team Championship, which was held in Lucerne, Switzerland.

title: RETAILING RIVALRY IN WASHINGTON
description: Amid a dramatic urban revival, Woodward & Lothrop and the Hecht Company, the two grand dames of retailing here, have intensified their old rivalry for the downtown shopper.

title: NICARAGUAN PILOT IS SAID TO DEFECT
description: A Nicaraguan Army pilot deserted during a routine mission today and flew to neighboring Honduras where he asked for asylum, a military official said.

title: HOW CRAZY EDDIE'S DOES IT
description: It's lunchtime just days before Christmas, and Crazy Eddie's is insane.

title: STUDENTS IN PEKING PROTEST ATOM ARMS TESTS
description: Another student protest has been carried into the heart of the Chinese capital despite official efforts to bar a repetition of earlier demonstrations.

title: Penn Central
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had taken actions to recoup about $70 million of surplus assets from a number of its overfunded pension plans. The surplus will revert to the company on receipt of regulatory approvals, expected in the next three to nine months. Penn Central said the effects of this action on its earnings would be determined by new guidelines for pension accounting that are expected to be issued within the next week.

title: Snow, Ice and Fog Chill Holiday Travel
description: Holiday travelers found the going rough yesterday with up to six inches of snow in the Northeast and fog shrouding parts of the West.

title: INTERTRANS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Drinking and Driving
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-ESM Officer's Plea
description: The former president of the bankrupt ESM Government Securities Inc. pleaded innocent today to charges of theft and other crimes related to ESM. Ronnie Ewton had been indicted by a special grand jury on 40 counts. An arrest warrant was issued for George Mead, co-founder of ESM, who was scheduled to appear for arraignment today.

title: Bert Lance Suit Survives
description: A judge has denied the Government's request to dismiss a lawsuit by the former Federal budget director, Bert Lance, that accuses bank regulators of violating his right to privacy by leaking a report on the bank he heads. In a ruling disclosed today, Federal District Judge Harold L. Murphy said the Government's motion to dismiss the case was invalid.

title: POLL SEES LANDSLIDE FOR SANTA: OF U.S. CHILDREN, 87% BELIEVE
description: In an age when children seem to grow up at an alarming pace that leaves little time for simple beliefs, at least one tradition holds: 87 percent of American children between 3 and 10 believe in Santa Claus, according to The New York Times Poll.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Chairman Oversees James River's Growth
description: Brenton S. Halsey, chairman of the James River Corporation, has seen the Richmond-based paper products concern grow from a minor player to ninth largest in the industry in the 15 years since he helped found the company. Now, he hopes to leapfrog to fourth place through the company's recent agreement to acquire virtually all of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation.

title: Reagan and Bureaucrats
description: When he sees a good target, President Reagan moves readily into action as Parodist in Chief. The other day, he spoke of ''bureaucratese - that's a language peculiar to Washington.'' And he drew laughs, adding: ''One day early in my first term a native bureaucrat stood in front of my desk and said, 'Action-oriented orchestration of meaningful indigenous decision-making dialogue, focusing on multi-linked problem complexes, can minimize the vital thrust toward non-alienated and viable urban infrastructure.' ''

title: People
description: David L. Wibbelsman, president of Nynex Information Resources, elected president of the National Yellow Pages Service Association.

title: St. Nick of Old
description: Although separated by 3,639 miles of ocean, New Yorkers and Netherlanders were together in spirit recently, as members of the New-York Historical Society recalled their Dutch heritage at a St. Nicholas Day celebration.

title: Sale of Pirates Clears a Hurdle
description: Pittsburgh's Urban Redevelopment Authority today approved a $25 million loan to a public-private coalition that is buying the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Doyle Dane Names Head of Specialty Units
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group has promoted Richard M. Victor to general manager of domestic subsidiaries, five companies that are expert in advertising specialties and one regional agency, Cargill, Wilson & Acree in Atlanta.

title: SCHUBERT IS READY NOT TO KICK AGAIN
description: The betting line for the wild-card game here Sunday favors the San Francisco 49ers over the Giants by 3 points. Theoretically, that means that one field goal by Eric Schubert of the Giants would make the teams even and two would win the game for the Giants.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: Marc Buoniconti's bedroom at home is empty now except for the sports and rock posters and the high-school plaques that adorn the walls, the box of letters, a few footballs, and the big tin button on the night table. ''Hug A Miracle,'' the button reads. ''His friend Jose gave him that button,'' Marc's mother, Terry, was saying. ''When they were at Columbus High School together, Jose ran away from home for a while. When he came home and returned to school, he told us Marc was the only one who hugged him. When this happened, Jose brought the button to Marc in the hospital.''

title: ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
SUSPECT ACCUSED OF GIVING SOVIET DATA ON MILITARY
description: Federal prosecutors today accused a messenger employed by a court reporting company here of giving Soviet operatives portions of a transcript of a top secret Congressional hearing on military communications.

title: With the Smokers
description: The word from Havana is that Fidel Castro has given up cigars. ''I wasn't surprised,'' said Norman F. Sharp, president of the Cigar Association of America, ''because the quality of Cuban cigars is not what it used to be.''

title: VECTOR FILES FOR PROTECTION
description: Vector Graphic Inc., a maker of desktop microcomputers and software, said today that it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: NORTH AMERICAN HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books of The Times;   How '60 Minutes' Ticks
description: Don Hewitt, who had the idea in the late 1960's of giving television viewers a program of short, lively pieces instead of the then prevalent one-subject shows that were overwhelming audiences with edification, has written a very personal and pithy history of ''60 Minutes.'' The CBS program was conceived in 1967 and born, a lusty, contentious and entertaining baby, a year later, and Mr. Hewitt, its executive producer, has written such a chatty book about its life and times that one is reluctant to appear pompous by calling it a memoir. Instead, ''Minute by Minute'' is the literary equivalent of spending the night in a bar listening to the yarns of an old-time newsman.

title: CROSSES DOT GREENWICH IN PROTEST OF BAN BY JUDGE
description: Crosses have been placed on lawns, telephone poles and roofs here in protest of a court decision banning the display of a cross on a local firehouse for Christmas.

title: Pennzoil Stock Rises Sharply
description: The Pennzoil Company's stock price rose sharply again yesterday as the oil concern continued to negotiate with Texaco Inc. to settle their high-stakes legal dispute. Pennzoil's shares closed at $65.875, up $1.375 a share, in consolidated trading yesterday, after rising 87.5 cents on Monday and $1.875 Friday.

title: Gavilan Still Winner
description: The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday upheld Kid Gavilan's disputed split-decision victory over Billy Graham in their 1951 welterweight title bout. The commission was persuaded to investigate the bout after a reported ''deathbed'' confession by Arthur Schwartz, one of the judges, who scored the fight 9-6 for Gavilan.

title: CUOMO OPPOSES CAJOLERY TO FIND FOE TO D'AMATO
description: With some Democrats suggesting that he intervene in the search for an opponent to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and others criticizing his actions so far, Governor Cuomo has said that ''it is not my place to pressure anybody into it.''

title: IN HIGH-TECH SILICON VALLEY, ENTREPRENEURS TURN TO TOYS
description: Throughout Silicon Valley, the homeland of the nation's electronics industry, thoughts are turning to toys - and not only because it's Christmas.

title: 20 Poles on a Tourist Visit Ask Asylum in West Germany
description: Twenty Poles who were on a vacation trip defected here today and asked for asylum, a police spokesman said.

title: 0.3 OF AN INCH KEEPS ENSIGN OFF PILOT SEAT
description: A Vietnamese refugee who finished in the top 10 of his class at the United States Navy officer school is three-tenths of an inch short of his dream of becoming a naval aviator.

title: CABARET: BARBARA COOK SINGS AT MICHAEL'S PUB
description: Barbara Cook began her current nightclub career more than 10 years ago after establishing herself as the ideal leading lady of Broadway musicals in the 1950's and 60's. She brought with her a trained voice and a sensitivity to popular songs that eludes most such voices. During the last decade, working with her musical director and pianist, Wally Harper, she has refined that sensitivity and now, making her first appearance in a New York club in almost three years - at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, through Jan. 18 - she is using the supple range of her voice with an unusual mixture of easy relaxation and finely shaded control.

title: PRESENTS OUT OF A HAT
Parents' Role
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: L.I. Developer Pays Bail to Free 9
