description: Nine prisoners who had been arrested on minor offenses were released today when a real-estate executive paid bail totaling $4,000 for them, a tradition of his for 15 years.

title: Uganda Airlines Is Grounded
description: The last serviceable plane in the Uganda Airlines fleet has been impounded at London's Gatwick Airport, stranding travelers there, because of non-payment of maintenance bills, an official said today. The three other planes in the Government-owned airline's fleet are grounded in Kenya and Uganda, awaiting money for repairs, the official said.

title: 4 KILLED AND 88 INJURED AS PLANE HITS COAST MALL
description: A plane crash showered debris and burning fuel into a shopping mall crowded with children waiting to see Santa Claus here Monday night, killing 4 people and injuring 88.

title: CORRECTION
description: A history of unexpected snowstorms in Science Times yesterday incorrectly recalled the political fate of Mayor John V. Lindsay after he drew criticism for slow snow removal in the winter of 1969. He lost the Republican primary in June 1969 but was re-elected.

title: SPIRIT OF HOLIDAY MOVES DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: The spirit of Christmas, the warmth that comes from being together with family and friends to exchange gifts and holiday greetings, is expressed by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: With the Foreigners
description: At another place, it was known that the Christmas party would attract children from many foreign embassies, so the Santa Claus, Chip Brienza, was prepared in several languages. Mr. Brienza is an interpreter as well as an entertainer, and he wished the children a merry Christmas in many of their languages: ''Feliz Navidad'' in Spanish, for example, and ''Frohe Weihnachten'' in German.

title: Domestic Help
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: SPAIN OFFERS NICARAGUA A PEACE PLAN
description: Nicaraguan Government leaders have been meeting privately with prominent opposition figures as part of a new peace initiative sponsored by Spain's Socialist Government, participants in the talks said this week.

title: THE BID FOR MIDCON INTENSIFIES
description: The struggle between the Midcon Corporation and the partnership of Wagner & Brown and Freeport-McMoran Inc., which wants to acquire it, intensified yesterday, as Midcon sought to derail the takeover attempt in court.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT was almost Christmas as she waited in the rush-hour crowd on the platform of the Lexington Avenue IRT, downtown side. Her arms were heavy with last-minute presents, her head was light from too much Scotch at the office party. As the uptown train rumbled into the station on the other side of the tracks, she found herself idly studying the faces of straphangers framed in the windows and thinking how gray and lifeless they looked against the glass.

title: Manila to Permit Group To Observe Elections
description: The Government elections commission today granted an American-backed civic organization the right to station observers at the country's 90,000 polling stations during the presidential election scheduled for Feb. 7.

title: SEISCOM DELTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain on the sale of property of $57,000 for the quarter, a loss on the sale of property of $1,812,000 for the year, an extraordinary gain of $6,695,000 for the year on debt restructuring and a nonrecurring charge of $5.9 million for the year. c-Including gains on the sale of property of $37,000 for the quarter and $620,000 for the year, a writeoff in intangible assets of $43,454,000 for the quarter and year and other nonrecurring charges of $3.3 million for the quarter and $3,550,000 for the year.

title: RESIGNED TRAVELERS ENDURE EIGHT DAYS OF FOG IN SEATTLE
description: Kurt Peterson, a reactor operator on a Trident nuclear submarine based in Bremerton, Wash., spent Monday night sleeping on a bunk in the U.S.O. at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. His midnight plane to his home in Chicago had been canceled by the fog that has hung over Seattle for most of the last eight days.

title: U.S. AGENCY RENEWS ITS REQUEST FOR CURBS ON USE OF ASBESTOS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency confirmed Monday that it had refiled a proposed rule to curb the production and use of asbestos despite efforts by White House budget officers to transfer its regulatory power to other agencies.

title: Blacks Renew a Boycott In Suburb of Detroit
description: The Detroit branch of the N.A.A.C.P. has called a boycott against Dearborn businesses because the mostly white Detroit suburb reneged on an agreement that would have permitted nonresidents to use its parks.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1985
description: International

title: MORE FUNDS GIVEN A.M.C. BY RENAULT
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that it had received another injection of cash from its French parent, Renault, in the form of a sale of $50 million in debentures.

title: CITIES AND STATES STRIVE TO MEET WINTER NEEDS OF THE HOMELESS
description: Around the nation, municipal and state governments say they are working harder than ever to shelter and help the thousands of homeless men, women and children in their midst. Still, advocates for the homeless say, the response is not keeping pace with the demand.

title: KNICKS WINNING WITH TEAM EFFORT
description: Hubie Brown was smiling. Patrick Ewing was talking. The cause? The Knicks had fashioned a modest two-game winning streak against Detroit and Washington that raised them from the depths of a 7-19 record, their low point of the season.

title: Aide Kills Himself At Jersey Hospital
description: A medical technician shot and wounded his former girlfriend today before killing himself during an argument at a hospital where both were employed, the police said.

title: Kuwait Ends Company
description: Kuwait plans to liquidate a state-run company managing investments in downstream oil projects overseas because of uncertainty in world oil markets, the Arabic daily Al-Anba said today. Kuwait's official stock market last month suspended trading in shares of the Kuwait International Petroleum Investment Company, set up in 1980 by the state oil company, the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation.

title: STUDENTS TURNING TO SPIRITUAL LIFE AT CAMPUSES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: College students in the New York metropolitan area are returning to churches and synagogues, enrolling in religion courses and volunteering for charity work in numbers that many chaplains believe suggest a spiritual renaissance on campus.

title: Coast Prosecutors Weighing Charges in Killing of Father
description: Prosecutors said today that they had not decided whether to file murder charges against a man accused of holding a nurse hostage until his comatose father was taken off a life-support system and allowed to die.

title: Visitors for Inmates
description: With Christmas come crowds at Rockefeller Center and Bloomingdale's.

title: He's Come a Long Way
description: Coach Dick Motta of the Dallas Mavericks reminisces about his childhood days in Midvale, Utah: ''My hometown was so small we didn't even have a village idiot. Me and my brother had to take turns.''

title: TO BANISH THE MOSCOW BLAHS, FINNS SAY 'TRY US'
description: For Westerners living in Moscow, and Russians permitted to travel abroad, this intimate city on the Gulf of Finland is no ordinary European capital. It is the great escape. As the closest outpost of Western culture and consumer goods, Helsinki serves as a giant playground, shopping mall, medical center and psychological safety valve for Western diplomats, business folk and journalists based in Moscow and for Russians seeking a taste of the West.

title: Alaska Oil Leasing Challenged
description: Environmentalists, Eskimos and fishermen have lined up with the state Government in suits to stop an auction of oil tracts off the coast of southwest Alaska scheduled by Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel.

title: Military Contracts
description: The System Development Corporation, a Burroughs Corporation subsidiary, was awarded two military contracts totaling $77.6 million, the Defense Department said. One $70 million contract is for the upgrading and automation of the Royal Thai Air Force's air defense system and is expected to be completed in 1989, the department said. The other contract is for work on the P-3C aircraft operational software program.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available due to Christmas holiday.* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Crossland Unit Offering Shares
description: The Crossland New York Funding Corporation, a subsidiary of Crossland Savings, is offering 750 shares of Dutch auction rate transferrable securities, or Darts, an acronym for money market preferred stock, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Meals for the Elderly
description: Every day is Christmas, in the giving sense of the day, for the Encore-at-St. Malachy's luncheon club. The program, at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, at 239 West 49th Street, provides hot meals for 80 elderly people homebound in midtown.

title: STOCKING FULL OF FORECASTS
description: HERE'S a stocking full of predictions, on Christmas morning, for the reader who has everything else.

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago results are pro forma. Share earnings have been restated to give effect to a 10 percent stock dividend declared after Oct. 31, 1985.

title: The Torch Beside the Golden Door Burns Anew
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFLICT IN SOUTH AFRICA: NEW MOOD
description: A few days ago, South Africa's Government-run radio had two events to report: the killing of six whites in a land-mine explosion near the border of Zimbabwe and the deaths of several blacks in a bus accident.

title: Don't Call a Hansom
description: To the Editor:

title: TREASURY SECURITIES PRICES UP
description: Prices of short- and long-term Treasury securities closed moderately higher in an abreviated pre-Christmas trading session that ended at 1 P.M., New York time. Dealers attributed most of the buying to short-covering of long-term bonds as well as seasonal factors. The gains erased most of Monday's declines.

title: Now Doug Williams Takes On His Alma Mater
description: If that big, stout coach on the sideline looked familiar, there was every reason why he should have. It was none other than Doug Williams, pro quarterback. But what in the name of Grambling was he doing on that sideline, the one occupied by the team from Southern University?

title: NANKIN EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AMID RANGER ROMP, SOME UNEASINESS
description: At the end of the Rangers' easiest night of the season, Ron Greschner said that this was an example of how the team could play ''once everything clicks.'' Mark Osborne talked about the camaraderie that was built up ''by performing in sync.'' In general, there was none of the introspection that a half-season of inconsistency had lent to this Ranger team.

title: O'BRIEN IS THE MOST VALUABLE JET
description: Ken O'Brien, who is in his first full season as starting quarterback, was voted the Jets' most valuable player today by his teammates. It was an honor that neither Joe Namath nor Richard Todd achieved until much later in their careers.

title: Homelessness Is Not a Ploy to Get an Apartment
description: To the Editor:

title: Kelley's Fate Weighed
description: Earl Kelley, the high-scoring guard of the University of Connecticut basketball team, will learn tomorrow whether he will be permitted to finish his final season. Kelley, who has led the Huskies in scoring for the last three seasons, was found guilty of three student-code violations in a nine-and-a-half-hour hearing yesterday by a school discipinary committee, although the panel dismissed charges that Kelley had kept a gun and knives on campus.

title: EX-GENERAL FOODS CHAIRMAN
description: Clarence Francis, a former chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, died Sunday in Logansport, Ind., where he was visiting relatives. He was 97 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Couple Convicted In Death of Child
description: A state court jury Tuesday rejected prosecutors' contentions that a Neptune couple murdered their 2-year-old foster child, Rosa Swain, but found the woman guilty of manslaughter and convicted her husband of endangering the welfare of the girl.

title: McCracken Plans To Retire in 1986
description: Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the first Nixon Administration, has announced that he will retire next May from the faculty of the University of Michigan, officially ending an academic career there that has spanned nearly 40 years.

title: Ingram to Acquire Shares of Micro D
description: Micro D Inc. said Lorraine Mecca, who holds about half the company's outstanding shares, had agreed to sell her shares to Ingram Industries.

title: AS SKI SEASON TAKES OFF, COLORADO HOLDS ITS BREATH
description: The World War II ski troops who practiced on the slopes above this valley included what were probably the only soldiers who so enjoyed their training that they came back here after the war.

title: FIVE CHEFS CONFRONT WHAT'S LEFT
description: ALMOST every family has to come to grips with leftovers during the holiday season.

title: SNAILS' EGGS: A: NEW RIVAL FOR CAVIAR?
description: SNAILS have been eaten by human beings at least since the days of Aristotle, the first person to record exact details about the mollusk. In France for centuries snails, or escargots, have been grilled alive, flambeed, stuffed, folded into omelets, candied, boiled down to syrup and prescribed for burns, nose bleeds and constipation. But all this time nobody has thought of eating their eggs. Now, Alain Chatillon, a 45-year-old Frenchman, has put snails' eggs on the market, with great fanfare.

title: Charles Dickens's Christmas Visit
description: On Christmas Day 1867, Charles Dickens, ill with catarrh, rode a slow, bumpy train from Boston to New York.

title: SMITH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Greetings, to The Political One and All
description: To be a politician is to have, perforce, many friends. So Christmas card lists grow long in the nation's capital.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 10:16 A.M. today and set at 10:17 P.M. tonight.

title: Zondervan Publisher Appoints a Chairman
description: The Zondervan Corporation, one of the nation's largest publishers of Bibles and religious texts, yesterday named Gordon H. Buter, a former trucking company executive, as Zondervan's chairman.

title: Answers for a Young Girl
description: How does the other jolly old elf enter City Hall?

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TV: A DETROIT CHORALE SINGS OUT 'MESSIAH'
description: ''Miracle on Fort Street'' is modest - a 30-minute documentary film that dispenses with a narrator, looks at people in an intimate, but not at all prying, way and manages to be wonderfully warming without being the slightest sentimental. It is a lovely piece of work, and Christmas is a fine time to see it. It will be shown on Channel 13 at 7 o'clock tonight.

title: SPACE MICROWAVE LABS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: The World's Best Shots
description: What seemed an implausible idea last December has somehow crept into the tents of power and refuses to be denied. Most of the world's children, it appears, can be immunized by 1990 against their deadliest enemies: measles, tetanus, whooping cough, polio, diphtheria and tuberculosis. What better day to agitate for the money and goodwill that this project requires? What better place than the cradle for the United Nations to redeem some of its promise?

title: SAVORING THE LAST OF THE WINE
description: ''DEAR SIR: My wife and I enjoy wine and from time to time we open a bottle with our dinner. The trouble is, we simply can't finish a bottle between us, which means we have wine left over. My question is, will it keep and how long?''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Harry Usher, the 46-year-old commissioner of the United States Football League, is listed in good condition in a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., where he is awaiting heart-bypass surgery. . . . Jack Harkness, the former Clemson assistant strength coach who was charged with illegally dispensing drugs to athletes, was returned to South Carolina after being arrested in Pittsburgh.

title: Crocker Merger Ruling Upheld
description: The Crocker National Corporation said the Delaware Supreme Court had affirmed the May 22 ruling by the Delaware Chancery Court that cleared the way for Crocker's merger into Midland Bank P.L.C. on May 24.

title: Jury Selection Works In Mysterious Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: MORALITY PLAY BECOMES A JOYOUS MEXICAN RITE
description: Four centuries ago, when the Roman Catholic missionaries of Spain sought to teach the Indians of Mexico about the birth of Jesus, they resorted to the theater to make their point, staging a version of the morality play depicting the shepherds' trek to the baby Jesus.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $70,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $571,000 for the quarter and $597,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss.

title: DOW DROPS BY 9.63 AS VOLUME PLUNGES
description: Investors abandoned the stock market early yesterday, leaving a vacuum in which stock prices fell sharply for the second consecutive session.

title: Eagleton's Brother Dies
description: Dr. Mark Eagleton, a brother of Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, died today after a long illness. He was 58 years old. Dr. Eagleton, a prominent St. Louis physician and radiologist, died at Mari DeVilla Retirement Center in suburban Ballwin. Dr. Eagleton was disabled by a stroke and retired from practice in 1973.

title: Reforms at Unesco Were Underreported
description: To the Editor:

title: Strict Rule to Curb Smoking Imposed at U.C.L.A. Hospital
description: The Medical Center of the University of California at Los Angeles has decided to ban smoking next year in all indoor parts of its hospital and clinics, officials said.

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS REFLECT ON CHRISTMAS AND THEME OF GIVING
description: On a day of brightly wrapped packages and bountiful dinners, many religious leaders find themselves occupied with the more thoughtful facets of Christmas, wondering if the compassionate message of the holiday has seeped in.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Results for the latest year reflect an extraordinary tax credit equal to 2 cents a share.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
FOOD NOTES
description: Camembert From Maine Although it is a little late for Christmas giving, the Camembert cheese produced by the Donald Brothers Cheese Company in Brooksville, Me., is nonetheless appropriate for the new year - maybe for all those you left off your gift list who surprised you with a last-minute bottle of brandy.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 23
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1985.

title: UNIVERSAL MONEY CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $470,100 for the quarter and $399,100 for the 9 months.

title: AMARCO RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Way Out of the Homeless Hotels
description: Leonard Stern has built a fortune manufacturing Hartz Mountain pet products and has launched a career as a land developer. Now he offers to turn those entrepreneurial skills to benefit New York City's homeless. He proposes to raise $100 million in private funds to construct new, temporary shelters for 2,000 families. All can join in hoping for his success.

title: U.N. REPORTS 50 VIETNAMESE SLAIN AND 10 RAPED BY PIRATES
description: Fifty Vietnamese refugees were slain and 10 women were raped last week when their boat was intercepted by pirates in the South China Sea, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: Letter: On Foreign Aid;   Securing Democracy in Central America
description: To the Editor:

title: Drunken-Driving Law Ruled Invalid by Judge
description: Judge Norman Buzaid of Superior Court has ruled that people convicted of drunken driving are not subject to penalties in a new state law designed to impose an automatic jail term.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: DEVISING inventive meals with holiday leftovers is always a challenge for the home cook. But before one puts his or her creative talents to work on this task, there is a far bigger problem to solve: where to store leftovers.

title: Postman Admits Discarding Mail
description: Overwhelmed by Christmas-season mail, a newly hired letter carrier says he threw about 1,000 pieces of mail into a trash container.

title: JUNIOR TENNIS ON A LARGE SCALE
description: Success can be inconveniencing at times. The last thing that 78-year-old Hy Zausner probably wanted to do on a cold, breezy day last week was traverse the grounds at his Port Washington Tennis Academy with technicians from a cable television network, trying to find the proper location for a satellite receiving dish. Well, it wasn't so bad, Zausner decided. Next year - atmospheric conditions permitting - he will know exactly where this space-age gadgetry should be placed.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Average Rate Up On Citicorp Paper
description: At its weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday, Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.809 percent, up from an average of 7.620 percent last week. A total of $450 million in bids was submitted, of which $50 million was accepted.

title: THE TORCH BESIDE THE GOLDEN DOOR BURNS ANEW
description: To the Editor:

title: A PERENNIAL LOSER WINS $10 MILLION LOTTERY PRIZE
description: Lloyd and Nilva Christie were arguing - as they often do on Saturday nights, when the winning tickets in the New York State Lottery are announced on television. Mr. Christie, a mail sorter in a bank who says he spends $50 to $60 a week on Lotto and the Daily Numbers, had come up with six losing Lotto tickets.

title: Chemical Plant Assessed $49 Million in Damages
description: Jurors who assessed more than $49 million in damages against a chemical company had ''no question'' that emissions from the company's plant had poisoned 31 residents of Sedalia, Mo., the jury foreman said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Birdview Satellite Communications Inc., Overland Park, Kan., said it had reduced its work force by about 40 percent, or 280 employees.

title: COPY OF DISPUTED POEM FOUND AT YALE
description: A copy of the poem recently found in England and attributed to Shakespeare, and said by its discoverer not to exist at any major American library, is contained in a rare book collection at Yale, according to a curator at the university. The Yale copy attributes no authorship to the poem.

title: Revenues Decline For Holiday Bowl
description: A drop in attendance at Sunday's Holiday Bowl was enough to cost Arkansas and Arizona State as much as $100,000 apiece, it was reported today.

title: ARCO OFFERS TO SETTLE U.S. CASE
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company has offered to pay $225 million to settle Energy Department charges that the oil company violated Federal price controls from the early 1970's to January 1981, the company disclosed today.

title: JAPAN BUDGET PLAN CALLED INADEQUATE
description: The Government began to piece together a budget for next year that is partly intended to blunt foreign criticism of Japan's trade surpluses and its level of military spending.

title: Dollar Off, Gold Mixed In Lackluster Trading
description: The dollar fell slightly in lackluster Christmas Eve trading. Gold was mixed, ending a half-day of trading at the Republic Bank of New York at $326.25 an ounce, up 75 cents from Monday.

title: Be Jolly? Bah! Humbug!
description: Tis the season to be jolly. Right? Wrong. Statistics tell us that Christmas Day actually makes more people miserable than merry. I'm not talking about lonely people with no place to go but about the traditional family fiascos. On this day, disasters proliferate and taut nerves snap like guy wires in a tornado.

title: Withholding Plan
description: Denny Stolz, the new San Diego State football coach, will have part of his salary withheld every year as an incentive to keep his program free of National Collegiate Athletic Association sanctions. The agreement, which was one of the conditions all job applicants had to agree to, calls for placing of $10,000 in wages in an interest-bearing bank acount.

title: SAHLEN & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $53,000. c-Net loss.

title: DANCE: AILEY TROUPE IN JAMISON'S 'DIVINING'
description: Some dances consist of fascinating bits that never quite add up. One such work is Judith Jamison's ''Divining,'' which the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented Saturday afternoon at the City Center.

title: RESTRICTING SMOKING IN THE WORKPLACE
description: AS the Surgeon General's annual report on smoking and health, issued last week, so aptly shows, a smoke-free work environment is being encouraged. A review of both legislation and individual company policies shows that restrictions on smoking at work are becoming more common nationwide.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Washington Watch column in Business Day on Monday incorrectly described the Internal Revenue Service's backlog of unprocessed tax returns. They are from the 1984 tax year.

title: Day of Holly, Day of Halley
description: Fir, holly and mistletoe are evergreens that celebrate the continuity of the Christmas festival. This year, however, also brings a reminder of change - a rare visit of Halley's comet. Scholars have resumed the debate as to whether the Star of Bethlehem, which appeared at the birth of Jesus, was an earlier passage of the comet.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Share earnings restated to reflect the 5-for-4 stock split of June 20, 1985.

title: LONG LIVE THE ENGLISH SWEET (REVISED VRSION)
description: KING GEORGE I enjoyed holiday puddings so often, it is said, his subjects immortalized his passion for them in the nursery rhyme ''Georgie Porgie, pudding and pie.'' Queen Victoria relished sweet custards and insisted that one always be served at her Windsor Yule feasts. And Samuel Pepys was so delighted with his Christmas mince pie that he fondly described it in his renowned diary.

title: KEY RULING DUE ON EX-WIFE SEEKING A SHARE OF A MEDICAL LICENSE'S VALUE
description: When their nine-year marriage ended in 1980, Michael and Loretta O'Brien only had one thing to show for it, besides some furniture, a set of dishes and a battered Volkswagen with no heater: his license to practice medicine.

title: 3 Said to Be Guardian Angels Are Held in Robbery in Boston
description: The police have arrested three men who they say are members of the crime-fighting Guardian Angels group and charged them with a robbery in a subway station, officials said.

title: THERMWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ADAMS GIVES DEVILS SCORING AND SPEED
description: The Devils have found success with their first choices in the last three drafts, John MacLean, Kirk Muller and Craig Wolanin. But they have also found success from an unexpected source in Greg Adams.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE LONG VIEW Christmas Day. A quiet day when most enterprises close their doors. What never closes, however, is the spectacle of New York, a vision that was always best from the great harbor. The view can be duplicated any day, for the price of a quarter, from the Staten Island ferry, which plies its 5.2-mile route from Manhattan's southern tip, South Ferry. Today, two boats will run on holiday schedule, every half-hour from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: Bomb Found in Tel Aviv
description: A small bomb concealed in a loaf of bread was found at a bus stop near Tel Aviv University today, the police said.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
IMPLANT TEAM REGRETS DELAY
description: A woman given less than a 50-50 chance to survive since receiving an artificial heart last week should have had the operation sooner, her doctors said today.

title: India to Purchase 21 British Copters
description: India decided to buy 21 Westland helicopters worth $130 million. After months of uncertainty, the Civil Aviation Minister, Jagdish Tytler, said India was satisfied with modifications made by the British helicopter maker to the Westland WG-30 and would buy the aircraft.

title: Bridge: Tradition Ends as Regionals Finish at a Manhattan Hotels
description: The end of the Winter Regionals of the Greater New York Bridge Association on Monday night at the Sheraton Centre in New York City also ended a tradition lasting more than half a century.

title: Protesters Disrupt Rites For a Spanish General
description: Protesters threw coins and shouted insults at the police today after the funeral of a retired Civil Guard general slain by suspected Basque separatists.

title: In From the Cold
description: We take you, this holiday season, to the Pied de Cochon, the suddenly famous Washington restaurant where the Central Intelligence Agency entertains such distinguished defectors at Vitaly Yurchenko. Corks are popping as we arrive. This is the spot, the Pied de Cochon, Where Christmas is spooky, but everything's bon. The spies and defectors have surfaced to rally, And everyone's here but that yo-yo Vitaly, Who, slipping his tether, went over the hill Leaving master-spy Casey stuck with the bill. So what do spies do when they've laid off eavesdropping? They love to talk shop. Hear the stories they're swapping: Chancellor Kohl was a merry old soul, Yes, a sporty old soul was he:

title: Severance Pay At Shaklee
description: The Shaklee Corporation's former chairman, J. Gary Shansby, who resigned last week in a policy dispute with directors, said he would receive about $3 million in severance pay.

title: PEKING CATHOLICS CROWD REBUILT CHURCH
description: Chinese Catholics of all ages crowded shoulder to shoulder here today for a Latin mass that marked the reopening of the Beitang Church, possibly the most historic structure of Christianity in China.

title: GORBACHEV REMOVES A POLITBURO VETERAN FROM MOSCOW POST
description: A longtime member of the ruling Politburo was ousted today from his job as head of the Communist Party in the city of Moscow, the Tass press agency announced.

title: PROSECUTOR WINS DEATH SENTENCES
description: Two Lumberton men were sentenced Friday to die for two murders, bringing to 37 the number of death sentences obtained by Joe Freeman Britt in 12 years as District Attorney.

title: Bears, Payton Dominated
description: The Chicago Bears set a number of records in compiling a 15-1 mark this season.

title: GARCIA ASKS FOR CHANGE AND PERUVIANS SAY SI!
description: From a balcony of the Government Palace, President Alan Garcia Perez first reprimanded the 20,000 slum-dwellers gathered in Lima's main plaza for being noisy and disorderly.

title: Leucadia to Raise Stake in Minstar
description: The Leucadia National Corporation, an investment company that specializes in takeovers, said it plans to increase its stake in Minstar Inc. to 11 percent, from 9.2 percent. It was not immediately clear, however, if Minstar, which is controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, will become the object of a takeover bid itself.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SALVADORANS GET A HOLIDAY TRUCE
description: The Salvadoran Government agreed today to a holiday cease-fire through Jan. 2. The cease-fire was previously approved by the leftist rebels.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1985
description: Companies

title: No First Amendment Rights for Cigarette Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO TEAMS FACING HISTORY
description: This has been a time of jinx-chasing for the Patriots and the Jets -a pair of teams who often finish first in preseason polls, then see the Miami Dolphins win the American Conference's Eastern Division title.

title: Kozo Sasaki of Japan, Former Leftist Leader
description: Kozo Sasaki, a veteran politician and onetime chairman of the main opposition Japan Socialist Party, died of heart failure at a hospital today, party officials said. He was 84 years old.

title: REBELS REPORT FOILING ATTACK
description: A spokesman for the African National Congress said today that a suspected South African agent was shot dead as he tried to kidnap a member of the group last weekend.

title: Top Sinn Fein Member Is Arrested in Ulster
description: A prominent member of Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's legal political wing, and another man were ordered held in custody today on weapons charges.

title: ARMY'S RESERVES SHOW NEW VIGOR
description: The Army's reserve forces are showing new vigor after years of neglect, according to Army officials. But in the next breath the officials acknowledge that the reserves have far to go before they would be ready for wartime missions.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review yesterday of Handel's ''Messiah'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Saturday night misidentified the soprano soloist. She was Julianne Baird, not Gail Dobish.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Israeli Reporter Is Convicted For Making a Visit to Jordan
description: An Israeli journalist who visited Jordan was convicted here today of violating laws prohibiting Israelis from visiting countries at war with Israel.

title: Singapore Stock Market
description: Singapore says plans to tighten control over its stock market, delayed after initial resistance from brokers, will go ahead soon following a financial crisis sparked by a major firm's debt problems.

title: CONDEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After a loss loss of $2.8 million on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $2,572,000, a net loss of $30,123,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $2,677,000.

title: PITTSBURGH FIGHTS TO RETAIN CLARK BAR PLANT
description: Clark Bars, a chocolate candy that has been part of this city's scene for 100 years, may become a Chicago product to save money for its new makers.

title: DR. FRANCES E. HENNE
description: Dr. Frances E. Henne, an authority on children's libraries and a professor emeritus at the Columbia University School of Library Service, died Saturday in Greenfield, Mass. She was 79 years old and lived in the Buckley Nursing Home in Greenfield.

title: MANUEL AND WATTS DO WELL IN PRACTICE
description: The Giants began practice today for Sunday's wild-card playoff game here against the San Francisco 49ers and received encouraging performances from Lionel Manuel and Ted Watts.

title: MINDEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLORIDA FACES FALLING PRICES
description: The Florida citrus industry, already reeling from setbacks due to freezes and disease, is now seeing the price of orange juice fall.

title: CONCERT: JANET BAKER, SOLOIST AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: To judge from their ovations and their departure after her last number, a goodly number of those in the audience for the Orchestra of St. Luke's concert Monday night at Carnegie Hall had come for the soloist, Janet Baker, making her only New York appearance of the season.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHOEVER created the word offal (it is a word used primarily by the British nowadays) did an awful - pardon the pun - thing to some of the best eating I know.

title: REAGAN, IN A LETTER TO GORBACHEV, ASKS TECHNICAL TALKS ON A-TESTS
description: President Reagan has written to Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposing that experts meet to discuss improving the verification of agreements on underground nuclear tests, a senior Administration official said today.

title: SOVIET AIRLINER REPORTEDLY HIJACKED TO CHINA
description: Chinese officials said today that a Soviet jetliner with about 50 people aboard was hijacked to China over the weekend. There was no word on whether the plane was still in the country or on the fate of the passengers.

title: Ferhat Abbas Is Dead; A Key Algerian Figure
description: Ferhat Abbas, who helped lead Algeria to independence from France, died today, the Government said. He was 86 years old.

title: EXORCISING THE GHOSTS OF LEFTOVERS PRESENT
description: TURKEY sandwiches. Turkey sandwiches with cranberry sauce. Mashed turnip sandwiches, candied yam sandwiches, stuffing sandwiches. Mince pie sandwiches, with or without hard sauce. All to go.

title: Wilkes Retires
description: After 12 seasons and more than 14,000 points, Jamaal Wilkes of the Los Angeles Clippers has retired from pro basketball. Wilkes, who is 32 years old, played on four National Basketball Association championship teams, with the Los Angeles Lakers (1980, 1982 and 1985) and with the Golden State Warriors (1975).

title: TRILLIUM TELEPHONE SYSTEMS reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 22
description: b-After extraordinary items. c-Net loss All figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE SCREEN: 1770'S EPIC, 'REVOLUTION'
description: The citizens are revolting. They're roistering around the streets - wearing funny hats, drinking, laughing, dancing, toppling statues and saying rude things to rich people in carriages.

title: MOTHER TERESA GAINS RELEASE OF 3 PRISONERS
description: A Christmas Eve request from Mother Teresa brought about the release yesterday of three state prisoners who are suffering from AIDS. They are to be cared for at a hospice the Roman Catholic nun opened last night in the West Village.

title: NORMANDY'S CIDER IS ITS CHAMPAGNE
description: THE champagne of Normandy is not a wine; it's not even a grape product, but cider.

title: CARNEGIE HALL DEBUT FOR KID CREOLE
description: Kid Creole and the Coconuts are a band without honor in their native country. The group's Carnegie Hall debut tomorrow night is a rare chance to see Kid Creole, alias August Darnell, on his home turf.

title: Falcon Coach Retained
description: The Atlanta Falcons yesterday extended the contract of Coach Dan Henning and hired Marion Campbell. the former Philadelphia Eagles' head coach, as defensive coordinator. ''Although the record was not what we desired, we feel Dan has handled an adverse situation as well as possible,'' the team's owner, Rankin Smith Sr., said.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $373,000 for the quarter and 6 months and tax credits of $147,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $235,000, or 14 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and $46,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $410,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and $590,000, or 46 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When you think of 10,000 persons, including pregnant women and children, with no place to stay, the parallel to Christmas is so obvious.

title: Surplus of Talent
description: The Vitalis/United States Olympic Invitational indoor track meet is celebrated for fast miles, and not without good reason. The 10-lap track at the Meadowlands has been the site of six of the eight fastest indoor miles in history, including the very best, Eamonn Coghlan's 1983 clocking of 3 minutes 49.78 seconds.

title: ANGLICAN QUITS BEIRUT AGAIN FOR LONDON
description: The latest effort by the Anglican Church to win the release of a group of American hostages in Lebanon ended without success today.

title: SAN FRANCISCO BACKS PLAN TO SAFEGUARD REFUGEES
description: The Board of Supervisors has voted 8 to 3 Monday to adopt a resolution declaring the city a sanctuary for refugees from Central American countries.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Boston Celtics, at Madison Square Garden, 3:30 P.M. The Knicks have been playing a Christmas Day game almost every year since they met the Providence Steamrollers in 1947.

title: MEGATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A TALE OF TWO CITRUS BELTS
description: Oranges by the million swirl through the Redland Heights Citrus Company, from rooms of ethylene gas that give the oranges color to conveyer belts where each fruit is waxed to shine like a new car.

title: FOREIGN ENVOYS EXPECTED TO GET U.S. BODYGUARDS
description: The Reagan Administration will seek funds next month to provide full-time bodyguards for certain foreign ambassadors stationed in Washington, a senior State Department official said today.

title: CORTLAND ANDERSON, DIRECTOR OF JOURNALISM SCHOOL IN OHIO
description: Cortland Anderson, director of the E. W. Scripps School of Journalism at Ohio University in Athens, died today at Riverside Hospital here.

title: UNIOIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: With the Homeless
description: As usual, the capital's impoverished street people are being remembered by the Community for Creative Nonviolence, but this year with something more lasting than free food. A crechelike statue of a family of three street people, complete with a sidewalk heat grate designed to produce a cloud of realistic steam, was unveiled on the Ellipse south of the White House.

title: Oil-Slicked Birds Treated In Port Angeles, Wash.
description: Dozens of volunteers were spending tonight in a makeshift rescue center caring for hundreds of ailing sea birds caught in an oil spill in Port Angeles Harbor.

title: KEVLIN MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
STATE RESTRICTS MEDICAL SCHOOL FROM GRENADA
description: The State Education Commissioner ruled today that students from the St. George's University School of Medicine in Grenada could not do their clinical training in New York State hospitals.

title: TV: CAROLS FROM ENGLAND
description: I doubt if we shall ever celebrate a space-age Christmas with any enthusiasm. It is a season for nostalgia and tradition, and both are conveyed with taste and dignity in ''Carols for Christmas'' tonight at 6 on Channel 13.

title: HOT-SELLING SMALL APPLIANCES
description: In houseware departments across the country this Christmas season, the message is that small - or at least space-saving - is beautiful.

title: GROUP W CABLE SOLD TO 5 BUYERS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has signed a definitive agreement to sell its Group W Cable subsidiary to five cable operators, the parties said yesterday. The announcement follows several months of negotiations with various bidders.

title: REAGANS TO SPEND HOLIDAY IN CAPITAL
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, plan to spend a quiet Christmas in Washington with friends and relatives before flying to California on Friday to spend the New Year's holiday, according to White House officials.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Capital Corp., Miami, has named to its board Dr. Charles A. Nickerson, dean of the College of Business Administration at Florida International University.

title: Iraq Reports Attacking 'Large Naval Target'
description: Iraq said tonight that its planes had hit a very large naval target in the Persian Gulf and had set fire to Iran's main oil export terminal on Kharg Island.

title: Carbide Pact On Severance
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that the ''golden parachute'' severance protection that 42 of its executives were given back in October is worth about $28 million.

title: A LEADER OF ANTI-IMMIGRANT RADICALS TAKES OFFICE IN ASSAM
description: A 32-year-old former student agitator who served a prison term and was once in hiding from the police was sworn in today as the new Chief Minister of the troubled northeastern state of Assam.

title: GEORGIA CITY WINS RACIAL UNITY IN KLAN FIGHT
description: The Ku Klux Klan's attempt to join in a civic celebration of Christmas appears to have brought more racial unity than division to this small city in northeastern Georgia after the City Council canceled a parade rather than let the Klan enter a float.

title: A CORRECTION
description: An editorial yesterday misidentified the Suffolk County shopping mall in volved in a decision of the New York Court of Appeals. The correct name is Smith Haven Mall.

title: With the Arts
description: Since joining the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts last year as director of the American National Theater, Peter Sellars has shown a propensity for extremes - big flops, bigger hits. A production of Shakespeare's ''Henry IV, Part 1'' was so poorly received that it closed early.

title: Miser's Fast Change
description: Ihave met Ebenezer Scrooge on the printed page and the radio waves, in darkened movie theaters sweet with the smell of Mary Jane bars and in the dancing electrical dots of television, the very same place I encountered him Sunday night. This was a superior Ebenezer Scrooge, probably because the actor in charge of him was George C. Scott and the budgeting power behind him was I.B.M.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLES UP 0.9%
description: Orders to factories for durable goods, spurred by a rebound in military hardware, gained nine-tenths of 1 percent in November, their first increase in three months, the Government reported today.

title: 'NEW LOVE AMERICAN STYLE,' ON ABC
description: DOWN in the ratings dumps these days, ABC is understandably eager to get a friendly pat of encouragement for new projects. This doubtless explains the effort to hail ''New Love American Style'' as a breakthrough form for daytime television, a departure from the game shows and serials. In fact, the anthology series of half hours, available weekday mornings at 11:30, is pretty stale stuff, inspired by the original ''Love, American Style'' show that made its prime-time debut on ABC 16 years ago and then went on to years of daytime syndication. The only thing new about this resurrection is the absence of a comma in the title.

title: IN FROM THE COLD
description: The Nebraska football team spent a good part of Christmas Day flying to Arizona for its Fiesta Bowl meeting New Year's Day against Michigan.

title: 2 Engineers Replaced For Role in Hyatt Case
description: Two engineers accused of misconduct for their role in a hotel skywalk collapse that killed 114 people in 1981 have been formally relieved of engineering duties at their company, officials say.

title: A Homeless Woman Dies In Grand Central Terminal
description: A homeless woman in her 60s, who had been staying on and off for more than a year in Grand Central Terminal, was found dead on a bench in the terminal waiting room yesterday afternoon.

title: TUITION AT COLLEGE FREE FOR FARMERS
description: A small college founded by Mennonite immigrants is offering a year of free tuition for farmers forced to abandon their livelihood because of the ailing farm economy.

title: ETNA ERUPTS, KILLING MAN IN RESORT HOTEL
description: Mount Etna erupted early today, setting off earthquakes and sending four rivers of red lava streaming down its sides. The quakes destroyed a resort hotel, killing one man and injuring 12 other guests, officials said.

title: NORTH BEATS SOUTH, 27-20
description: Mike Norseth of Kansas connected with Steve Griffin of Purdue for the winning touchdown as the North defeated the South, 27-20, today in the Blue-Gray all-star game.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Detroit Pistons, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. The Nets take a four-game winning streak into the game. (Television - SportsChannel, 11:45 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Bulls, at Chicago, 8:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) College: Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival, opening round, at Madison Square Garden. Iona vs. St. Bonaventure, 7 P.M., and St. John's vs. James Madison, 9 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M. Radio - WFAS-FM 103.9, 7 P.M., and WCBS 880, 9 P.M.). St. John's is the defending champion. The final will be held Saturday night. High Schools: Eighth annual Doc Turner East Coast Classic at Nat Holman Gymnasium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue. Teams featuring some of the best schoolboy and schoolgirl players in the country begin play with the first of three five-game schedules. At 12:30 P.M., two Bronx boys teams meet, John F. Kennedy and Samuel Gompers, followed by the Manhattan Center for Math and Science vs. Westinghouse (boys) at 2:30 P.M.; Math and Science vs. August Martin, defending state champion (girls), at 4:30 P.M.; North Babylon vs. Christopher Columbus (boys) at 6:30 P.M., and Oak Hill Academy of Virginia vs. Rice at 8:30 P.M. The tournament concludes Sunday. Hockey Islanders vs. Hartford Whalers, at Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 8 P.M.) Rangers vs. Sabres, at Buffalo, 7:35 P.M. (Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) Los Angeles Kings vs.

title: Let Floating Rates Continue to Float
description: Recently, there's been a lot of talk about abolishing floating exchange rates and replacing them with some type of fixed-rate scheme. I think that's wrong. The system of floating exchange rates is working, although not perfectly, and its performance can only be worsened by countries trying to manipulate it. The finance ministers of the Group of Five major trading countries are behaving very unwisely by intervening in the market.

title: CHIPPING AWAY AT DEBT
description: It is time for the annual report from South Sunny Slope Road in New Berlin, Wis., where Kay M. Fishburn says she had another productive year in her citizen's campaign to reduce the national debt, dollar by dollar. Mrs. Fishburn, a nurse by profession, is the dedicated coordinator of Citizens for a Debt-Free America, a band of penny-and-pound-wise optimists who chip away at the debt despite the fact that, like the universe, it seems ever expanding. In the past year it has grown to $1,903,728,000,000, an increase of $258,251,000,000.

title: 7 Hurt in Trolley Car Crash
description: A trolley car carrying 25 people sideswiped an empty trolley Tuesday morning, and seven passengers were injured, according to the authorities.

title: Fire Still Burns in Naples
description: Firefighters today continued battling a fire in a storage tank at an oil depot on the outskirts of Naples that exploded Saturday, fire officials said. Four people died and 170 were injured when the depot, owned by the Italian state oil company Agip, exploded, setting off a fire in 27 giant storage tanks.

title: Burglary at Council of Blind
description: Burglars who broke into the American Council of the Blind's headquarters stole most of the electronic equipment the national organization depends on for day-to-day operations, council officials said Tuesday. Among the $2,500 worth of equipment stolen were several heavy-duty tape recorders and two tape-answering machines the council uses for a toll-free number for its members. The weekend burglary was discovered Monday morning.

title: NEW CAMERA ACCOUNT EVEN BEATS MISTLETOE
description: The added joy at Tuesday's Christmas party at Gianettino & Meredith in Mountainside, N.J., came from the news that the agency has been tapped to be the first agency of record for Chinon of America, Springfield, N.J. Billings will be at least $1 million. Chinon is a marketer of cameras made by Chinon Industries of Japan, which among other things this year signed an agreement to make some 35-millimeter cameras for the Eastman Kodak Company.

title: 1680 GARDEN IS DISCOVERED IN THE SOUTH
description: Archeologists working here have discovered an English-style Renaissance garden dating from 1680 with a central broad walk of sand, the earliest documented formal garden in America.

title: MAGAZINE FOR AMBITIOUS MARIJUANA GROWERS
description: The seeds for Sinsemilla Tips magazine were planted six years ago, when the authorities arrested Tom Alexander and seized his crop of 1,324 marijuana plants.

title: Reagan's Dark Side
description: Two years ago, against the advice of his Chief of Staff, his legal counsel and his Secretary of State, President Reagan signed National Security Decision Directive 84, stripping over a hundred thousand Americans of their right to privacy by forcing them to undergo so-called ''lie detector'' tests.

title: N.B.A. TO RETAIN ITS LOTTERY-TYPE DRAFT
description: The lottery will be back, at least for one more year, after a vote by the National Basketball Association Board of Governors.

title: Oregonian Gets New Heart
description: Daniel V. Acker, 25 years old, of Hillsboro, who doctors said would not have lived another 48 hours, received a new heart for Christmas at the Oregon Health Sciences University Hospital. Mr. Acker was listed today as in critical but stable condition. The identity of the donor was not disclosed.

title: Last escendant of Lincoln, 81 Years Old, Dies in Virginia
description: Robert Todd Lincoln Beckwith, the last surviving descendant of Lincoln, died Tuesday. He was 81 years old.

title: New York State's Voter-Registration Order Is Good Government
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSTILE RECEPTION IS EXPECTED FOR PENSION RULE
description: Capping a decade of study and some of the most acerbic debate the accounting profession has ever seen, the Financial Accounting Standards Board will issue today its long-awaited rule on accounting by employers for pensions.

title: CALENDAR: WINTER BIRD COUNT
description: Christmas Bird Count, Wave Hill, 675 West 252d Street, Riverdale, the Bronx, 212-549-3200.

title: CHINA AND SOVIET CONFIRM HIJACKING
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry confirmed today that a twin-engine Antonov-24 airliner belonging to the Soviet civil carrier Aeroflot was hijacked to China last Thursday. But it said that ''crew members and all the passengers'' were returned to the Soviet Union two days later.

title: AFTER THE FIRE, A FOREST BEGINS ANEW
description: ''Right here,'' said Gene Yahvah, the forester, ''is where it started.'' And he looked out across the snow-covered mountainside, empty and silent in the wan afternoon sun.

title: Peter Duchin Weds Brooke Hayward
description: Peter Duchin, the orchestra leader, and Brooke Hayward, the writer, were married Tuesday at a private home in Stowe, Vt. The Rev. Peter Jacobs, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: JAZZ: DOROUGH AND TAKAS
description: BOB DOROUGH, the pianist, singer and songwriter, and his partner, the bassist Bill Takas, are holding what amount to Charlie Parker devotionals during their performances at Gregory's, First Avenue at 63d Street, where they began a series of Sunday and Monday appearances last weekend.

title: EVERYBODY'S SUING
description: Of all the cases of the Supreme Court's new term, few have so intriguing a title as No. 85-675: Four Million, Two Hundred Fifty-Five Thousand, Six Hundred Twenty-Five Dollars and Thirty-Nine Cents, etc., et al., petitioners v.

title: CONFORMITY: COOL STYLE FOR YOUNG
description: THE 29th Gold and Silver Ball was no stereotypical teen-age get-together.

title: CBS Said to Plan Film On Plight of Homeless
description: Mitch Snyder, who heads the Community for Creative Non-Violence and who fasted for 51 days to draw attention to the plight of the homeless, has said he has completed a contract agreement with CBS Entertainment for a movie based on his efforts.

title: POPE CALLS WORLD SUFFERING A SCANDAL
description: Pope John Paul II delivered his Christmas message today to a world he described as ''scandalously'' marked by human rights violations, starvation, oppression and mass suffering.

title: PROJECT SEEKS TO AVERT DEARTH OF COLLEGE TEACHERS
description: The Ford Foundation has set up a $4.75 million fund to be used by universities to develop projects to head off a shortage of professors that is expected to start in the 1990's when many current professors retire.

title: 53 REPORTED DEAD IN TRIBAL FIGHTING IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: At least 53 people were reported today to have been killed when 2,000 Zulus clashed with 3,000 members of the Pondo tribe in what police officers called the worst factional fighting in years between tribes in South Africa.

title: FIGHT OVER WHO SETS PRIORITIES
description: The National Institutes of Health is arguably the most important biomedical research institution in the world, its sprawling campus in suburban Maryland the home for many of the nation's leading medical researchers.

title: Police in Peru Seize 1,000 After Rebel Deeds
description: The Peruvian police arrested 1,000 people today in a sweep through Lima suburbs after Maoist guerrillas blacked out an Andean city, blew up seven vehicles and dynamited a statue, the police said.

title: HEART UNIT STAFF DOES EXTRA DUTY
description: Nurses on the staff caring for the first woman to receive an artificial heart have been volunteering to work extra shifts because of concern over her slow recovery, hospital officials said.

title: CITIBANK JAPAN BID DISCLOSED
description: In a bold bid to expand its presence in Japan, Citibank is seeking to acquire a Japanese bank, according to Citibank officials here. If the bank's bid succeeds, it would be the first foreign financial institution to take over a Japanese bank.

title: AN ENTREPRENEUR'S PASSION FOR FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT
description: THE round conference table in Tom Monaghan's roomy office is covered with books about Frank Lloyd Wright, and a $12,000 model of the master architect's Robie House in Chicago sits across the room. Outside the office door - a copy of one Wright designed - are two busts of the architect that Mr. Monaghan's secretaries sometimes crown with Mickey Mouse ears.

title: CHURCH REACHING OUT AT CHRISTMAS TO RETURN LAPSED CATHOLICS TO FOLD
description: Among the 150 worshipers at the 11 A.M. mass yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church on the Upper East Side were two women who were not scriptural readers or communion servers but were nonetheless important to the church this Christmas.

title: TAIWAN CHIEF RULES OUT CHANCE FAMILY MEMBER WILL SUCCEED HIM
description: President Chiang Ching-kuo today ruled out the possibility that he will be succeeded by a member of his family or a military government.

title: Goizueta's Gamble
description: Roberto C. Goizueta is the man who tried in 1985 to take away the world's favorite soft drink - a symbol of America in 155 countries - but was forced by a surge of protests to give it back.

title: Cetus Seeking Foreign Deal
description: The Cetus Corporation, a leading biotechnology concern based in Emeryville, Calif., said that it was negotiating marketing agreements with European and Japanese pharmaceutical manufacturers.

title: BASES TO MAKE TABLES IN ALL SHAPES AND SIZES
description: TABLE bases to put under a slab of marble or glass can be found at many places around town. Bon Marche sells white or black cast-iron bases. A base for a 24-inch round top costs $58; for 30-inch or 36-inch tops the cost is $77. A base for a rectangular table 34 by 15 1/2 inches is $89.

title: TAKING ON THE RISK
description: For a $291 annual premium, the Coastal Insurance Company will insure you against getting AIDS. The policy, which pays for certain medical costs, was approved for sale in California last January and is now selling in Nevada, Arizona and Washington State as well.

title: North Carolina State 80 Nevada-Las Vegas 73
description: Ernie Myers of North Carolina State played excellent defense against Anthony Jones and helped key a second-half spree as the Wolfpack won the Chaminade Classic championship game.

title: Prostitute's Death Tied to 10 Killings
description: The stabbing death of a prostitute has been linked to 10 other killings in Los Angeles County, the police say.

title: HONEYMOON IS OVER
description: When Jeff and Johnna Tupper were married last Saturday their plans called for a short honeymoon.

title: Ohio Man Wins Car He Lived in a Month
description: An unemployed construction worker has won a 1986 Ford he had lived in a month.

title: GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTING FAULTY, AGENCY SAYS
description: Congressional investigators have found that billions of dollars are lost or mismanaged through the failure of more than half the Government's 427 accounting systems to meet Federal requirements.

title: Dr. Marion Barnhart Is Dead; Researched Blood Disorders
description: Dr. Marion I. Barnhart, a researcher of blood disorders, has died of injuries suffered in a traffic accident. She was 64 years old.

title: Veliotis, From Athens, Fed Data on Dynamics
description: From his lavish villa in a wealthy suburb of Athens, P. Takis Veliotis remains a key, though distant, player in the debate over fraudulent military procurement practices.

title: Hartley Defied Pickens In Struggle for Unocal
description: Fred L. Hartley, tough as a prairie wildcatter, was the force that deflected T. Boone Pickens in 1985. When Mr. Pickens, the canny Texas oilman, attempted a takeover of the Unocal Corporation, which Mr. Hartley has headed since 1964, the fight came to symbolize the frenzied pyrotechnics of modern takeover battles.

title: MIEKO HARADA, JAPAN'S UNKNOWN STAR
description: In Akira Kurosawa's latest film, ''Ran,'' or ''Chaos,'' a character named Lady Kaede appears only a few times. But when she does, she fills the screen in astonishing bursts of blood and lust.

title: JAZZ: BUCKY PIZZARELLI AND SON
description: IN the 15 years since he was part of a notable guitar duo with George Barnes, Bucky Pizzarelli has usually performed as an unaccompanied guitar soloist or as leader of a trio with piano and bass. He is now part of a duo again, this time with his son, John, appearing Monday nights at the Greene Street Cafe, 101 Greene Street, a pairing that offers more opportunities for variety than his earlier association with Mr. Barnes.

title: SCENES OF CRIMES BROUGHT TO COURT
description: Don Eppinette's office looks like an elite toy store cluttered with intricate, colorful models including an oil rig, service station and airplane.

title: 3 Die in Blast in Jamaica
description: Three people were killed and 22 injured when a cylinder used for blowing up balloons exploded in a shopping center here Tuesday night, the police said today. The cylinder had apparently been filled by an unauthorized operator, and it was not known what type of gas it contained, they said. The center was crowded with last-minute Christmas shoppers at the time.

title: QUESTIONS LINGER FOR ST. JOHN'S
description: After winning 10 of its first 11 games, St. John's has made the point that it will survive the loss of three key seniors: Chris Mullin, Bill Wennington and Mike Moses.

title: Playoff Menu
description: Frank Minnifield of the 8-8 Cleveland Browns exudes confidence over the playoff game against the 12-4 Miami Dolphins: ''There's nothing I enjoy more than fresh seafood.''

title: A CROWDED DOWNTOWN MARKS ST. LOUIS REVIVAL
description: Five years ago, this was among the emptiest of American downtowns.

title: DOCTORS AND LAWYERS SQUARE OFF ON LAWSUITS
description: A lawyers' group, infuriated by a service that warns doctors about patients who have sued frequently, is planning to let people find out if their doctors have been sued.

title: I.R.S. SENDING OUT TAX FORMS WITH APOLOGY
description: Taxpayers get their annual greeting from Uncle Sam on Thursday, along with a rare apology from the Government, as the Postal Service begins to deliver 87 million 1985 income tax forms and instruction packets.

title: 10 FREED IN TURKISH AGCA CASE
description: A military court acquitted 10 defendants and sentenced an 11th to three years in prison today on charges of helping Mehmet Ali Agca in the 1979 murder of a Turkish newspaper editor.

title: NEO-MACABRE
description: The World Future Society is proposing some new bureaucratese for the New Year on the subject of death: ''neomort'' and ''neomortia.'' They relate to the state of brain-death, more specifically the proposal of Walter J. Daly, dean of the Indiana University School of Medicine, and Harold G. Shane, a professor of education, that the ''usable organs of newly dead people be kept in their owner's bodies'' as a form of storage. As they envision the nation's increasing reliance on organ transplant, the brain-dead - ''neomorts'' - would be kept on life support systems in a state of ''neomortia'' until the parts were needed.

title: MOVE BY YUKICA
description: David Nixon, the lawyer who won a round in Joe Yukica's lawsuit to get his football coaching job back from Dartmouth, wants a college panel to discuss the dispute in an open meeting.

title: SURVIVORS OF 1984 SHOOTING COLLECT $500,000 SETTLEMENT
description: Survivors of the 1984 massacre of 21 people at a McDonald's restaurant have begun picking up checks after a judge approved a settlement that freed $500,000 that had been held up in a disagreement over how money from a special fund was to be distributed.

title: MCELROY IS USED TO TRENCHES
description: Reggie McElroy will have no backups when the Jets face the New England Patriots in their wild-card game on Saturday.

title: 700 WRITERS TO ATTEND PEN INTERNATIONAL CONGRESS
description: At a dinner meeting in London in 1921, John Galsworthy was named the first president of a budding international organization of writers called PEN. Galsworthy, normally a retiring person, remained president of PEN for the rest of his life, and when he died in 1933 he left the money from his Nobel Prize for Literature in a trust fund for the organization.

title: A Trying Year for Anderson
description: In 1985, Warren M. Anderson faced a year of virtually unending turmoil.

title: TUNNEL IS A BAD DREAM TO ENGLAND'S CHANNEL PORTS
description: The outlook here under the fabled white cliffs is as gloomy as the English Channel in a lashing rain, for the notion is sinking in that this time the engineers are going to realize a dream they have kept alive since Napoleon's day.

title: Diablo Canyon Nuclear Plant Unexpectedly Halts in a Test
description: The Unit 2 reactor at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant unexpectedly shut down today while it was being tested, officials said.

title: Police Arrest Couple Sought in Slayings
description: The police arrested a couple today who were wanted in the slayings of three employees of pizza restaurants in Los Angeles and South Carolina.

title: THE STAGE: 'STARCOCK,' BY APPLE VAIL
description: THE disparity between a striking visual design and an artless dramatic text is demonstrated in ''Starcock,'' a play written and ''painted'' by Apple Vail, an artist who specializes in ceramics and murals. Staged by Frederick Neumann at the Westbeth Theater Center, the play is a Mabou Mines production.

title: Queen Elizabeth Offers Praise To Those Who Help Humanity
description: In her annual message beamed to millions of people around the world on Christmas Day, Queen Elizabeth said the tragic events of 1985 should not obscure the ''bravery and self-sacrifice'' of people who help humanity every day.

title: Who Cares Who Established the Cause of AIDS?
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIBANK SAYS DATA STOLEN
description: Four former Citibank employees and the brokerage firm of Bear, Stearns & Company have been charged by Citibank with having stolen proprietary information and trade secrets from the bank.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1985
description: Companies

title: U.S. Has a Continuing Interest in the Philippines
description: To the Editor:

title: Hit-and-Run Car Kills Woman
description: A woman was killed and her husband was injured yesterday by a hit-and-run vehicle in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: KNICKS, TRAILING BY 25, RALLY TO WIN IN OVERTIME
description: On rare occasions, an individual can inspire an entire group with the magnificence of his efforts. Yesterday afternoon, before a national television audience and a joyous crowd at Madison Square Garden, was one of those special times.

title: Top Player Gains In Junior Tennis
description: Nicklas Kulti of Sweden, the top-seeded player, defeated Flavio Romani of Canada, 6-0, 6-0, today in the opening round of the boys 14-and-under division of the ninth annual Rolex International Junior Tennis Championships at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Murray Perahia to Play In Moscow Tomorrow
description: Murray Perahia will become the first American pianist of international standing to perform in the Soviet Union in recent years when he performs, at the invitation of the Soviet pianist Sviatoslav Richter, an all-Chopin program at the Pushkin Museum in Moscow tomorrow night.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE DAY AFTER The day after Christmas inaugurates the interlude that runs through New Year's Eve, a week that may be fraught with dizzy social whirls or a mood that meditates on what to do. The Brooklyn Museum, that wonderful storehouse of art across the river from Manhattan, at 200 Eastern Parkway, near Prospect Park's north end and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, may help you catch up on things you have missed during the year.

title: Singer Arraigned in Assault
description: The country singer Johnny Paycheck was arraigned Monday on a charge of felonious assault stemming from a shooting at a Hillsboro tavern last week. Judge Jon C. Hapner of Hillsboro Municipal Court set a preliminary hearing for Friday. Mr. Paycheck, 44 years old, was arrested Friday in the shooting Thursday night of Larry Wise. Mr. Wise was released from a hospital after treatment for a head wound. Witnesses said the two men had argued about a band.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST POINT TO CHILDREN'S PLIGHT
description: The plight of children who are ill or homeless and alone in the world is remembered during the holiday season by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: VETERANS OF VIETNAM GAINING NEW AID TO FIGHT ADDICTION
description: In a yellow clapboard house here on West Main Street, a group of veterans gathers each week to discuss the horrors of their service in Vietnam and the drugs and alcohol they have consumed in the 15 wild and angry years since they returned home.

title: Man Who Kidnapped Infant Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: A man convicted of kidnapping a 19-month-old girl from a California park and taking her to live in Alaska has been sentenced to life in prison and ordered to pay the girl's family $18,500 in restitution.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Evening Hours column last Friday misidentified a guest at a party for the movie ''The Color Purple.'' She was Phylicia Ayers-Allen.

title: Topics;   White House Turnabouts Reportorial License
description: The power to grant a license is, of course, also the ability to deny a license. That power is appropriate for government in such matters as certifying drivers or nuclear power plant operators.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The 20th reunion of the Class of '65 at Public School 6 in Manhattan, which goes up to the sixth grade, turned up mostly doctors and lawyers - plus one acupuncturist and a masseuse.

title: 'ANOTHER AMERICAN,' HISPANIC CULTURE IN U.S.
description: ''ANOTHER AMERICAN'' says it will celebrate the Hispanic culture in the United States, and that's exactly what it does. The half-hour special, presented by WNBC-TV, is lush, sentimental and, for the most part, awfully good looking. It can be seen on Channel 4 at 9:30 tonight.

title: GOING ALL OUT TO GAIN SPACE IN TWO CITY APARTMENTS
description: WHEN it comes to coping with the nearly universal need of city apartment dwellers to make the most of their space, architects who are doing their own places produce some of the most ingenious solutions. They go all out - bartering with the neighbors for a few extra square feet or using every ounce of technical skill to squeeze a bedroom or a bathroom into available space.

title: Suffolk Man Is Killed in a Fire As Four Other Adults Escape
description: A Tuesday night fire killed a Suffolk County man, but four other adults in the same house escaped unscathed, the police said today.

title: VISIONS OF SANTA IN SPORTS WORLD
description: It's official: Santa Claus exists, at least for a resounding majority of kids in this country. As if it needed affirmation at all! But, just checking, The New York Times conducted a highly sophisticated telephone poll of children between the ages of 3 and 10 and learned that 87 percent believe.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IF a beautifully finished hardwood floor is properly maintained it will not need refinishing for many years. Sooner or later, however, most wood floors get so badly scratched, worn looking and discolored that simple cleaning and waxing is no longer enough - the whole floor must be sanded down to the raw wood and completely refinished in order to restore it.

title: Second Thoughts on Local Taxes
description: A key component of President Reagan's campaign for Federal income tax revision was repeal of the deductibility of state and local taxes. As this page argued from the start, the proposal had ominous implications for state and local governments, particularly those burdened by large obligations to the poor. A coalition of distressed governors and mayors persuaded the House to preserve the deduction, but the issue will rise again in the Senate.

title: MUSIC: SEILERS, PIANISTS
description: THE duo pianists Ernst and Kazuko Seiler drew a large audience at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night for a complete traversal of Bach's monumental valedictory work, ''The Art of the Fugue,'' in Bruno Seidlhofer's four-hand arrangement. (Bach did not specify instrumentation, and the different fugues have different numbers of contrapuntal voices.) All arrangements are interpretations, and Seidlhofer's interpretation, with which the Seilers seemed in concord, is that ''The Art of the Fugue'' is a work whose grandeur should be expressed through powerful, resonant sonorities. Two-voiced sections, thus, were not played by one pianist or another but by both, with each line doubled in octaves or even 15ths. At one point, unless my ears misled me (I could not see their hands) the theme thundered forth in six octaves - in other words, both hands of the secondo player and the left hand of the primo player in one grand unison. Many pieces ended with a series of enormous fortissimo chords, and with big rallentandos (in these Mrs. Seiler sometimes tended to follow a slight distance behind her husband).

title: Man in Motion
description: Mike McEwen, acquired by the Rangers again the other day, owns a couple of singular distinctions. First, he is, at age 29, the youngest man ever to have played for as many as six teams in the National Hockey League.

title: LANFORD WILSON ENJOYS A TRIUMP OVER TIME
description: If it had been a bad play, or badly reviewed, then ''Lemon Sky'' would not seem so enigmatic in its long absence from the New York stage. But Lanford Wilson's father-and-son drama opened in 1970 with everything arguing for success - a cast featuring Christopher Walken and Charles Durning, a successful tryout at Buffalo's Studio Arena and rave notices when it bowed here at the Playhouse.

title: MAKING THE MOST OUT OF GREENHOUSES
description: IF you have recently added a sun space or greenhouse to your home, filling it with healthy plants is probably one of your first ideas. Indeed some varieties will flourish, as the more light they have indoors the better they will grow.

title: American Aid for Irish Peace
description: The time has come for the United States to contribute to peace and stability in Northern Ireland as it has done so generously and often elsewhere in the world.

title: MAGAZINE AD PAGES OFF
description: The member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau, who are the major force in the industry, were down 3.9 percent in ad pages in November compared with the same month last year, to 15,634, but they were up 2.2 percent in ad revenues, to $519.9 million. The 11-month figure shows a decline of 3.4 percent in pages, to 138,860 and an increase of 4 percent in revenues, to $4.4 billion.

title: MACLELLAN: BULK AND GRACE
description: The blue seats still hate the red seats. Everyone has it in for Denis Potvin. Willie Huber plays well and they still don't like him. And it doesn't really matter how well the Rangers play occasionally. There is always a skeptical undertone to the cheering that years of failed expectations have created.

title: AN AGENCY OUTGROWS A BEDROOM
description: AFTER seven years operating out of Diane Casper's bedroom, the Young/Casper agency has moved into commercial space at 136 East 57th Street.

title: Haitian Opposition Chief Is Reported Assaulted
description: Family members said Tuesday that 10 men, some in uniform, entered the home of the opposition leader Sylvio Claude and beat him with ''clubs, gun butts and fists'' and that he had gone into hiding.

title: RISE AND FALL OF MUSICAL HUMORISTS
description: PETER SCHICKELE'S alter ego, the last and least of the Bachs, is poised to pounce upon us once again for his annual visitation. In other words, there will be four P. D. Q. Bach shows at Carnegie Hall this weekend. For those who missed out, what Mr. Schickele does is to compose all manner of musical parodies, many - but by no means all of them - inspired by Johann Sebastian Bach, and then string them together with patter and sight gags. Not to preclude the possibility that this year's installment may be a funereal bore, but in the past, old P. D. Q. has put on a pretty funny show.

title: MAYOR ORDERS AN AUDIT OF BELLAMY'S STAFF DATA
description: Mayor Koch has come up with an unusual farewell present for Carol Bellamy, whose 13 years as an elected official are about to come to an end: he is going have her staff records audited.

title: MEXICO HOMELESS SCORNING SHELTERS
description: Living in tents and makeshift shelters of plywood and plastic sheets, about 12,000 people left homeless by the September earthquakes are eking out an existence on Mexico City's streets, generally scorning more comfortable accommodations in Government-run shelters.

title: RATE OF NEW STOCK OFFERINGS SURGES
description: Companies eager to take advantage of rising stock prices are surging into the market with new offerings of common stock at the fastest pace since the record-breaking year of 1983.

title: PANEL REPORTS SEX DISPARITY IN ENGINEERING
description: Not only are women who are scientists and engineers paid less and receive fewer promotions than their male counterparts, but they are also discouraged from taking such jobs in the first place, a Congressional survey says.

title: WHETHER DOCTOR SHOULD ATTEND PATIENT'S FUNERAL IS DEBATED
