description: An assertion that doctors should attend their patients' funerals has touched off an outpouring of support and some dissent in Thursday's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1985
description: International

title: Franklin L. Gregory, Reporter And Columnist of Star-Ledger
description: Franklin Long Gregory, a reporter and columnist for The Star-Ledger of Newark for 25 years, died Tuesday at New York University Hospital.

title: MORE INSURERS SCREEN APPLICANTS FOR AIDS
description: Andrew, a Los Angeles businessman in his 40's, received some bad news last week: His application for health insurance had been turned down by a major California insurance company. According to his independent insurance broker, Brent O. Nance, the company feared that Andrew might contract AIDS.

title: RUSSIAN SAID TO PREDICT ISRAELI TIES AND INCREASED JEWISH EMIGRATION
description: A Soviet diplomat was reported today to have told a representative here of an American Jewish organization that he believes Moscow will restore diplomatic relations with Israel in February and dramatically increase the number of Jews permitted to emigrate to Israel.

title: Florida Police Identify Man Who Stabbed Boy to Death
description: The police have identified Lester Mizell Green, 29 years old, as the the man who went on a crazed rampage Saturday in which he fatally stabbed a 14-year-old and was later shot to death.

title: THEATER: 'LIPPE,' TALE OF A BOXING MANAGER
description: IF Off Broadway were as strictly regulated as boxing, ''Lippe'' (pronounced LIP-pee), the fight-game play now occupying the Quaigh Theater, would never have been allowed in the ring. The tale is purportedly based on the career of a manager named Lippe Breidbart, who almost had a winner in the 1950's.

title: Topics;   White House Turnabouts Polygraph Wiggle
description: In extricating himself from the lie detector controversy, President Reagan resorted to, well, the time-honored device of a face-saving prevarication. Not a lie, exactly, and hardly a wiggle on a polygraph chart, but noteworthy.

title: WINFRED O. PERRY
description: Winfred O. Perry, a former councilman in Verona, N.J., and executive secretary of the Conservative Party of New Jersey, died Monday of pneumonia at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. Mr. Perry was 92 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: CHURCH OF SUBGENIUS SPOOFS CULT MENTALITY
description: The police at San Francisco's Central Station are still talking about a recent Church of the SubGenius Devival meeting, but they call it the M-16 caper.

title: GROWING SUCCESS ON THE TANGLED TRAIL OF SPIES
description: The office is nondescript, furnished with strictly Government-issue furniture and tucked away in the corner of a building with corridors of faded institutional green.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We should live sober, upright and godly lives.'' - Pope John Paul II. [A3:1.]

title: CARL GROSSBERG
description: Carl Grossberg, a former president of the Riverside Memorial Chapels in New York City, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: RETAILERS POST MIXED RESULTS
description: The 1985 Christmas shopping season had its expected final sales surge but over all generally failed to produce strong gains over 1984. The highly mixed results around the country ranged from disappointment for some retailers to increases of as much as 15 percent over last year.

title: White House Clerk Charged
description: A White House clerk who purportedly pulled a pistol and held a man who was trying to break into the clerk's automobile is facing a weapons-possession charge, the Secret Service said Monday. The clerk was identified as Ramon S. Pineda, 28 years old. Mr. Pineda was charged with carrying an unlicensed pistol and unregistered ammunition in violation of Washington's gun-control law, the authorities said.

title: GAF'S BID FOR CARBIDE SWEETENED
description: The GAF Corporation yesterday raised its bid to buy the Union Carbide Corporation to $74 a share in cash from $68.

title: Law on Silent Moment Held Unconstitutional
description: A divided Federal appeals court has ruled that New Jersey's moment-of-silence law for public schools violates the Constitutional requirement of separation of church and state.

title: Just Warming Up For Gooden Pact
description: There was nothing magic about the number the Mets put in the contract they sent to Dwight Gooden last Friday, the day by which clubs had to tender contracts to their players. The number, that is, the salary the Mets were offering their star pitcher, had no resemblance to the salary for which Gooden will pitch next season.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TRUMAN. The Rise to Power. By Richard Lawrence Miller. 536 pages. McGraw-Hill. $19.95. THIS much everyone knows about Harry Truman: He made his way up in Missouri politics, and so into the White House, by courtesy of Tom Pendergast's machine. But even while consorting with some of the less wholesome elements of Kansas City, he managed to stay clear of the sort of activities that in time sent the boss and several of his cronies to jail. Richard Lawrence Miller's new book is not likely to change that assessment. What it does do, in rather more detail than the general reader may find absorbing or care to absorb, is to describe the future President's business and political dealings before anybody outside Missouri or many people in his own state had heard of him.

title: Prostitute Seized in Chicago Is Said to Have Spread AIDS
description: A prostitute who is believed to be spreading AIDS and has been sought for several weeks has been arrested, the Chicago police say.

title: The Quality of Mercy
description: One of America's glories is its tradition of welcome to the victims of war and persecution in the world. From Jews fleeing czarist pogroms to Vietnamese boat people, this country has opened its arms to refugee groups and individuals seeking political asylum: the ''tempest-tossed,'' in Emma Lazarus's words on the Statue of Liberty.

title: READER'S DIGEST LEAVES JAPAN
description: While operating a subsidiary here for 24 years, the Reader's Digest, a quintessential American institution, has had to adapt many times to the Japanese method of doing business. But when it decided recently to close the unprofitable unit, the company chose a traditionally American way to go about it, touching off a bitter dispute that underscores the sharp differences in labor practices in the two countries.

title: KEY CITY LANDFILL IS FORCED TO CLOSE, ADDING PRESSURE TO FIND ALTERNATIVES
description: The closing next week of one of the city's last major dump sites, the Fountain Avenue Landfill on Jamaica Bay, will raise the price of dumping garbage and increase the pressure to find alternatives for the 22,000 tons of garbage removed by the City Department of Sanitation each day, sanitation officials said.

title: BURKINA FASO SAYS MALI RAIDED BORDER AREAS
description: Burkina Faso said today that troops and planes from the neighboring West African country of Mali had attacked a border village and two towns, killing four people, and that its own troops had killed 10 Malians.

title: A PHENOMENON IN METALLURGY
description: It looks like an ordinary brass spring. But when dropped into a cup of boiling water, it instantly uncoils to five times its length, pinning itself against the cup's walls. When the water is poured out, the spring responds to the cooler air by instantly recoiling to its original shape.

title: Six More Seoul Lawmakers Are Put Under Investigation
description: South Korea's national police booked six more opposition lawmakers today for investigation in connection with a brawl at a meeting called by the governing party to approve the national budget.

title: ROYAL REVISIONISM
description: To herald the opening of ''The Treasure Houses of Britain'' at the National Gallery of Art, the British Tourist Authority and others sponsored a handsome magazine delivered free to subscribers of The Washington Post. It included ''A Royal Message,'' signed by the Prince and Princess of Wales, that began, ''Two hundred years ago, John Adams, later to be the United States's third President, was appointed Ambassador to the Court of St. James's.''

title: CHRISTMAS GREETINGS WITH A TOUCH OF GLOOM
description: One delight of the Christmas season for those lucky enough to be on the mailing list of John Paul Itta Inc., is their annual greeting card.

title: BODY OF JEW FOUND IN BEIRUT
description: The body of a kidnapped Lebanese Jew was found in a bomb-shattered district of West Beirut hours after a militant Moslem group announced it had killed him, the police said today.

title: FOR '86, CAUTION AND THE DOW
description: NOW, in the closing days of December, after an unexpectedly good year for many investors, what advice do brokerage firm market letters and advisory services have to offer?

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Parking-Ticket Champ
description: Glen Bolofsky's search for the world's greatest parking-law violator is over. The winner is a professional clown from Granada Hills, Calif., who has racked up more than 250 parking tickets.

title: Blast at Israeli Plant
description: A man was killed and two others were seriously hurt in a blast today at an Israeli power station that plant officials said was an accident, the state television reported. It quoted the officials as saying that guerrillas were not responsible for the blast at the plant north of Tel Aviv and that the cause was under investigation.

title: Tennessee Reducing Crowding in Prisons
description: Tennessee prisons, faced with a Federal judge's order to reduce crowding by Dec. 31, had room to spare today with 6,963 adults behind bars, a spokesman said. Federal District Judge Thomas A. Higgins has ordered the state to reduce the number of inmates in its 15 facilities to 7,019.

title: GETTING FANNIE MAE IN SHAPE
description: The news that the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, relayed in May 1981 could not have been more disturbing to David O. Maxwell, the new chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association. During their introductory lunch, Mr. Volcker said that Fannie Mae, as Mr. Maxwell's institution is known, was fast losing the confidence of big investors in its new debt issues.

title: THEATER AND RADIO PRODUCER
description: George Kondolf, the director of the Federal Theater Project in New York in the late 1930's and a radio and theater producer, died of a stroke yesterday at his home in Locust, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: Holiday Closings
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas. Government offices, banks, most businesses and foreign stock exchanges were also closed.

title: PROBLEMS OF CLARITY IN THE INSTRUCTIONS
description: UNPACKING a new stereo rig or video cassette recorder, the hopeful owner usually encounters a stern warning such as: ''Do not operate this equipment before carefully reading instructions.''

title: An Agreement for World's Oil Producers and Buyers
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR SOWETO, THE HOLIDAY IS A MEMORY
description: At around noon today, on the Emmarentia Dam in Johannesburg's white northern suburbs, the wind stiffened a little and the windsurfers took to the water, to be carried some way by its embrace.

title: JETS WILL BE TRYING TO CONTIN EASON
description: As he trudged onto the snow-whipped practice field today, wearing his Maine hunting boots and North Pole parka, Bud Carson had a slight edge of concern in his voice.

title: Iraq Again Tells Of Hitting 'Naval Target'
description: Iraqi warplanes struck a shipping target today, an Iraqi communique said.

title: Engineering Students With the Souls of Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Little Science Displayed by Either Side'
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY IS FACING DEFICITS DESPITE FARE RISE
description: Despite the recently voted 10-cent fare increase for New York City subways and buses, the Transit Authority faces financial trouble for 1987 and is expecting worse times ahead.

title: Deals Kept Crumbling For Turner
description: For Ted Turner, the mercurial television and sports entrepreneur, 1985 has been marked mainly by unfinished deals.

title: OGYGIAN WILL MISS DERBY
description: Ogygian, the leading contender for top 2-year-old colt of 1985, will miss the Kentucky Derby and the other Triple Crown races next spring after undergoing surgery Monday to remove a bone chip from his right hind ankle. The colt injured the ankle while kicking a rail during training earlier this month.

title: A Target for New York Schools
description: With effusive praise, New York City's Board of Education has given Chancellor Nathan Quinones another year's lease on his job, extending his contract to June 30, 1987. That action recalls two of the things wrong with the school system: The board and the Chancellor.

title: THE 'IN' COLORS OF '87 ARE BEING PICKED IN '85
description: In a small, brick-walled office on Lexington Avenue it is already the winter of 1987.

title: SECRET RADIO AND DOCTORS KEEP MOVING
description: The day starts early at a guerrilla radio station hidden in the mountains of Chalatenango Province.

title: In the Edwardian Way
description: Bob McAndrews wore buffalo-hide chaps to the Edwardian Christmas party of the Preservation League of Staten Island. ''They're Edwardian - from a different part of the country,'' he said of his legwear.

title: MOSCOW BACKS SYRIA IN MISSILE FEUD WITH ISREAL
description: The Soviet Union has assured Syria of support in its dispute with Israel over the deployment of antiaircraft missiles along the border with Lebanon, and Moscow has accused the Israelis of carrying out underground nuclear tests in the Negev, according to reports published here today.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IF nothing else, the group show Home Work, at the Holly Solomon Gallery points up the diversity of expression when artists create home furnishings. ''I wanted people to make connections between the work of art and the furniture,'' said Mrs. Solomon. The show, that continues to Jan. 4 at 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, includes a lacquer table by Robert Mapplethorpe, left, $6,000; a chest by Richard Artschwager, above, $20,000; and a lamp by Thomas Lanigan-Schmidt, right, $5,000.

title: SPECIAL RING GIVEN SIGNATURE THAT THE DISABLED MIGHT USE
description: To the casual observer, Robert H. Burroughs's ring is a handsome piece of jewelry. But to American Express and the Massachusetts Probate Court, it is something unique.

title: THE NEW CLASH WITH VOLCKER
description: The Reagan Administration's extraordinary criticism of the Federal Reserve Board earlier this week demonstrated anew that the old differences between the White House and the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, still simmer.

title: AGENCY HELPS RURAL ALASKANS ADAPT TO CITIES
description: An agency that for three years has helped Alaskans from rural areas ease into city life is reporting fewer of its clients are falling prey to crimes.

title: Bridge: Expert From Connecticut Gets Gift From Opponent
description: Christmas came early last weekend for an expert from Connecticut.

title: CARPENTER STANDOUT IN BLOCKING ROLE
description: For the sixth time in his nine years as a National Football League running back, Rob Carpenter spent Christmas Day on the practice field. And that, he said, is fine with him. ''That means I've been in the playoffs six times,'' he said, ''three years with the Houston Oilers and now three years with the Giants. I don't mind. I think you'd mind if you were sitting home instead, with the season gone and no playoffs for you.''

title: FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN SUFFER
description: Families with children are sharing a smaller portion of the nation's economic pie despite a recent trend of mothers' going back to work, according to a new study commissioned by Congress.

title: SLOW BREAK FOR JASPERS' NEW COACH
description: Tom Sullivan says all he needs to be able to compete in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference is players. ''Not good players,'' the first-year basketball coach at Manhattan College said. ''This isn't the Big East. Just players.''

title: ISSUE OF SECURITY SPLITS RESIDENTS OF CITY PROJECT
description: A year after a group of tenants launched a campaign to install intercoms and locks at Redfern Houses, a collection of nine brick buildings in Far Rockaway, Queens, the doors are still without locks and some entryways have no doors at all.

title: MALL PLANE CRASH WAS LONG FEARED
description: While many people were saddened by the crash of a small plane into a thronged shopping mall here Monday that killed four people, many residents said they had expected an accident.

title: HERS
description: THE other day my old classmate Allen and I were discussing who would be the next editor in chief of the influential magazine whose staff he had recently joined. I proposed Rosemary, the deputy editor: She had seniority, she was extremely able, she was practically doing the job already. Allen looked at me as though I had suggested sending out a spacecraft for the editor of The Neptune Gazette. Come on, he said patronizingly, you know they'd never give it to a woman. So who do you think it will be? I asked innocently. Well, he replied with a modest blush, actually, me.

title: WEEKS OF FRANTIC BUSTLE END IN FAMILIAR JOYS OF CHRISTMAS
description: There were many Christmas days in New York City: the glamorous Christmas of promenaders at Rockefeller Center, the ecstatic Christmas of a 12-year-old boy on his first 10-speed bicycle, the frenetic Christmas of the last of the last-minute shoppers, and the Jewish Christmas of old friends eating smoked salmon and bagels on the Upper West Side.

title: 200 SEIZED AT PAKISTAN MARCHES
description: The police arrested about 200 political dissidents and used tear gas and riot sticks to break up opposition marches today in the Punjab provincial capital of Lahore, opposition sources said.

title: Police Find Newborn In Cold Parking Lot
description: An abandoned newborn infant was discovered in a laundry parking lot this morning in 13-degree weather.

title: BAR PANEL GIVES HOPE TO ANTIOCH LAW SCHOOL
description: An American Bar Association panel has given new hope to those trying to retain the professional accreditation of the Antioch Law School here.

title: SHORHAM NUCLEAR PLANT OPPONENTS PRESSING FOR STATE TAKEOVER OF LILCO
description: The most vehement opponents of the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear power plant have launched an attack from a new direction: they want the state government to take over the utility.

title: CONCERT: NEW YORK STRING ORCHESTRA
description: ALEXANDER SCHNEIDER, the veteran violinist who came to this country as a member of the Budapest Quartet in the 1930's, has long dedicated his career to the development of string-playing talent in America. Among much else, he devotes the Christmas holidays each year to the New York String Orchestra seminar, in which young players come from all over the country for a concentrated 11 days of study and workshops.

title: HOW REBELS RULE IN THEIR CORNER OF SALVADOR
description: With his small blue backpack, white cowboy hat and hip-high son tagging along behind him, Evaristo Lopez makes an unlikely looking senior political official.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Jimmy Howard, who set the United States indoor and outdoor high jump records this year, will compete in the 79th Wanamaker Millrose Games Feb. 14 at Madison Square Garden, according to a spokesman for the Games. Howard surpassed Dwight Stones's indoor mark of 7 feet, 8 inches by one-half inch in the USA-Mobil Indoor Grand Prix. He equaled the mark of 7-8 1/2 for the best outdoor mark. . . . Pete Rose was named Man of the Year by The Sporting News.

title: ARCHIVES ON BLACK HISTORY
description: Carefully held behind the thick walls of the old United States Mint here, where money once was coined and used to purchase slaves, there is a letter from a small African boy named Kali, who had passed from freedom into slavery and out again, to John Quincy Adams.

title: Supermarket Unionists Voting on Coast Pact
description: Meat cutters and drivers involved in a violent eight-week strike against 1,000 Southern California supermarkets voted on new contracts today and indications were that the drivers approved their pact while the meatcutters rejected theirs.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Yankees named Eddie Lopat, their former pitching star, as a major league scout. He has spent the last 18 years as a special assignment scout with the Montreal Expos. . . . The Pittsburgh Penguins have sent the right wing Jim McGeough to Baltimore of the A.H.L. for conditioning purposes. McGeough, who sprained his left knee against the Washington Capitals Nov. 6, has missed 22 games.

title: 2d Round of Talks Seen For Texaco, Pennzoil
description: Representatives of Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company are expected to start a second round of negotiations today in their efforts to reach a settlement of their multibillion-dollar legal dispute.

title: Farewell Performance
description: He entered the loft with a suitcase, sprinkling anise and other spices until a sweet aroma filled the air. ''This has been a good place, where good work has been done,'' he said gently.

title: Topics;   Moral Bookkeeping Dial L for Liberty
description: Harrods, the tony London department store, sells almost every imaginable luxury, and now it's trying harder to reach American shoppers with its annual post-Christmas sale bargains. For one week, starting Sunday, it will have a toll-free trans-Atlantic telephone line.

title: MONTANA A THREAT FOR LONG SCRAMBLES
description: If the Giants hope to beat the San Francisco 49ers in their wild-card playoff game here Sunday, they must contain Joe Montana, the 49ers' quarterback. Not only his passing, but his scrambling.

title: PRE-COLOMBIAN ARTIFACTS STOLEN FROM MEXICAN NATIONAL MUSEUM
description: Some of Mexico's most treasured pre-Columbian artifacts were stolen from the National Museum of Anthropology on Christmas Eve, authorities said today.

title: Bridge: A Marathon in Rotterdam Has 234 Deals in 35 Hours
description: In the organization of major international events open to all comers, the Dutch have no equals. They broke new ground last month in Rotterdam with the Minihouse Bridgemarathon: 234 deals in 35 hours.

title: FILM: 'JE TU IL ELLE,' FROM AKERMAN
description: CHANTAL AKERMAN is a triple threat in her 1974 film ''Je Tu Il Elle,'' serving as screenwriter, director and star. In the film's first section, she is seen posing alone in a near-empty room, and heard on the sound track making isolated comments about rearranging the furniture. She takes off her clothes. She eats sugar from a brown paper bag. She writes a long letter, then spreads the pages on the floor, scatters sugar over them and curls up in a ball. A man walks by outside the window. After a while, she puts her clothes back on and goes outside.

title: Ogden to Post Loss in Quarter
description: The Ogden Corporation said yesterday that it will report a loss in the fourth quarter of about $15 million to cover one-time costs and write-offs arising primarily from the consolidation of its food operations.

title: Health Officials in California Say 6 More Dolls Are Tainted
description: County health officials who discovered thousands of dolls laced with pesticide last week said today that they have turned up six more soft toys containing toxic material reeking of kerosene.

title: 6 YEARS OF AFGHAN WAR: RUSSIANS AND FOES MIRED
description: Six years to the day after Soviet forces swept into Afghanistan, more than 100,000 Soviet soldiers and airmen confront a stubborn and elusive guerrilla army in a war with no end in sight.

title: Article 252245 -- No Title
description: The Education Department said today that in six months ending Sept. 30 it recovered $11.8 million in misused school aid, and netted 98 indictments in schemes ranging from theft by bank and college officials to a ring that arranged marriages between foreign students and prostitutes.

title: Rain Forests Are the Lungs of the Earth
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell moderately for the week ended Wednesday, dropping $379.6 million, to $208.41 billion, the Investment Company Institiute said yesterday. Leading the decline, assets of the 87 broker-dealer funds dropped $472.7 million, to $94.02 billion. Assets of the 192 general purpose funds fell $152.2 million, to $60.34 billion, while assets of the 73 institutional funds rose $245.3 million, to $54.05 billion.

title: Come Blow Your Saxhorn
description: When ''The Daughter of the Regiment'' opens tomorrow night at the Washington Opera, Robert Hazen is slated to play the cadenza with a soprano E flat circular saxhorn, an instrument that was popular in the Civil War era but that Mr. Hazen says has not been seen on the opera stage for perhaps 100 years.

title: E-Z-M INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AFTER 3,854 GRAVES, NO MORE AT SHILOH NATIONAL CEMETERY
description: Veterans of at least seven wars are interred here, where Union and Confederate troops fought for two bloody days in 1862, but room has run out.

title: APARTHEID BURDENING DOMESTICS
description: For 47 years Maude DeBruin has made beds for whites, cooked their meals, cleaned their houses and reared their children.

title: Ruth Warrick
description: The actress and singer Ruth Warrick will perform this weekend at Park Ten, Park Avenue and 34th Street.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''ARE there really very few parties this week, or have I been dropped?'' Dick Kagan wanted to know. The group of guests at Pamela Murdock's nursery party the other evening assured Mr. Kagan, who is editor of Pan Am Clipper magazine, that no, he hadn't been dropped and yes, there indeed seemed to be a scarcity of social events.

title: FORD MATCHES 7.9% G.M. RATE
description: The General Motors Corporation opened a new round of automobile pricing competition today by announcing 7.9 percent financing on some of its cars and trucks, and the Ford Motor Company quickly followed suit with the same incentives.

title: ENCORE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
EARTHQUAKES WORRY RESIDENTS NEAR YELLOWSTONE
description: Since Oct. 1, the town of West Yellowstone, a gateway to Yellowstone National Park, has had more than 300 earthquakes.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ARCADIA update: One of the most talked about and solidly booked restaurants of 1985 is the ''new American'' Arcadia on 62d Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues that received a two-star review on Jan. 18. This final weekend of the year seems a fitting time to revisit and see how it has held up under the pressure.

title: COCA-COLA LEADER
description: J. Paul Austin, the retired chairman of the Coca-Cola Company, who introduced Coke to mainland China in 1978, died yesterday at his home in Atlanta, Ga., after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: WALL TO WALL SOUND & VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
In the No-Candy Lane
description: The Giant Food chain, which sells more food than any other in the Washington area, has installed a no-candy checkout lane in every one of its 134 supermarkets.

title: ART: STONE CARVINGS IN 2 SCULPTURE SHOWS
description: SCULPTURE has been getting so much critical attention lately that to bring it up again is to risk overkill. On the other hand, the displays of stone carvings now at the Robert Schoelkopf and Edward Thorp Galleries can scarcely be ignored.

title: Strong Finish
description: Flushed by the comeback that had just brought a wildly improbable victory over the Boston Celtics, Hubie Brown allowed on Wednesday evening that the only thing he was not proud of was that the Knicks' huge early deficit had cost CBS much of its national television audience. Actually, no apologies were necessary.

title: ROCK VIDEOS SHAPE FASHION FOR THE YOUNG
description: It is 4 P.M. on the fourth floor of Macy's Herald Square and nine television monitors are spewing rock videos into the store's junior fashion department. They loudly demonstrate that the mating of rock music and video is changing the face of the fashion industry.

title: INDIA SHOWS IMPATIENCE WITH SRI LANKA PEACE TALKS
description: After five months of on-and-off talks to end a violent insurgency in the nearby island nation of Sri Lanka, Indian officials have begun expressing impatience with the resistance of the warring parties to accepting a compromise.

title: AUTHORITIES NOW SAY A SLAIN MAFIA AIDE WAS A MAJOR TARGET
description: After a week of intelligence analysis of the slayings of Paul Castellano and Thomas Bilotti, law-enforcement officials now say that Mr. Bilotti was a primary target and possibly the main one, because he had emerged as the underboss of the Gambino crime family.

title: 2 Johnson Units To Share Product
description: Johnson & Johnson said two of its pharmaceutical companies would co-market a non-narcotic analgesic prescription drug that had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. - Not available due to Christmas holiday. * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Man Held in Father's Killing
description: A 36-year-old man was arrested and charged with shooting to death his ailing 83-year-old father as he lay in his hospital bed, the authorities said today. According to the police, witnesses said that after John Forrest left the hospital room of his father, Clyde, Tuesday, he said, ''Now he won't suffer anymore.'' Members of Mr. Forrest's family called the killing an act of love. Mr. Forrest was being in jail without bail, the police said today.

title: AQUINO IN ASSURANCE ON BASES
description: The opposition presidential candidate, Corazon Aquino, said today to thousands of cheering people who live near the Subic Bay Naval Base that she would allow the United States to use Philippine military bases at least until 1991.

title: FOR BIG APPLE AERIALIST, A LIFETIME IN THE CIRCUS
description: Dolly Jacobs is afraid to cross the street in New York. That apprehension is not uncommon in a city where chaos reigns past the curb and is particularly acute in the tangled tangents that converge outside Lincoln Center, where Miss Jacobs is working these days.

title: Chairman Resigns At Coast Exchange
description: Charles E. Rickershauser Jr. has resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Pacific Stock Exchange to open an office in Los Angeles for Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, the Wall Street law firm that specializes in mergers and acquisitions.

title: Greek Paper Charged With Printing Secrets
description: A pro-Government Greek paper was prosecuted today for publishing two documents on an espionage case that the public prosecutor said revealed The editor of the newspaper, Eleftherotypia, was charged with publishing two top secret documents that the newspaper said were sent by the head of Greek intelligence, Lieut. Gen. George Politis, to judicial authorities investigating the spy case.

title: Look Back To Look Ahead
description: A disturbing new French film by Agnes Varda is a reminder of how much has changed in the Western world since 1968. Titled ''Without a Roof or a Law,'' the film is the story of the degradation and death of a pretty, stubborn girl with but one thought on her mind: to live by and for herself alone.

title: MUGGED MINISTER OFFERS ASSISTANCE
description: An elderly minister who was mugged and robbed on Christmas Eve invited his assailants today ''to come up to the church for help.''

title: Sniper in San Jose Field Eludes Capture
description: A sniper hidden in fog fired dozens of shots near a highway and eluded more than 50 officers who looked for him all day, the authorities said.

title: 6 MORE BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The police said today that at least six more black people had been killed in political violence in South Africa, bringing the death toll from four days of tribal and other bloodshed to 71, the worst Christmastime toll in years.

title: CONNECTICUT RIVER CULTURE AT WADSWORTH ATHENEUM
description: Flowing 410 miles past clapboard villages and farm meadows, the Connecticut River has always symbolized the heart of New England. For lovers of this white-picket-fence New England, a rare event is taking place at the Wadsworth Atheneum: ''The Great River: Art and Society of the Connecticut Valley, 1635-1820.''

title: RADIOS OF MALI AND BURKINA FASO REPORT CLASHES ARE IN SECOND DAY
description: The West African nations of Mali and Burkina Faso said Thursday that they were in the second day of border clashes that the United States says apparently started over a census.

title: STAGE: COMEDY FESTIVAL PRESENTS FIVE ONE-ACTS
description: PLAYWRIGHTS, actors and directors are allied in the pursuit of frivolity at the Manhattan Punch Line for that theater's festival of one-act comedies. In the second of two alternating evenings, there are three sketches and two longer playlets. The three are short, sharp and pithy. The two try to be a bit more serious - and their wick flickers. However, all of the efforts are marked by the talent they reveal. Most of them are variations on the subject of interrogation -peevish questions followed by quixotic answers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1985
description: International Syria has moved missiles back into eastern Lebanon, Prime Minister Shimon Peres told Israeli newspaper editors. The Syrian action raised concern that the redeployment of the Soviet-built antiaircraft missiles might pose a new challenge to Israeli planes flying over Lebanon. The missiles were withdrawn two weeks ago after the United States had told Syria, on Israel's behalf, that the weapons unnecessarily raised tension in the area. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $245,000. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $732,000.

title: Foreign Investment in the U.S. Is Too Secret
description: To the Editor:

title: REMINGTON, THE ARTIST OF THE WEST, UP NORTH
description: FREDERIC REMINGTON spent his life making art and scouring the world looking for action. He played football, built a tennis court near his studio on Ingleneuk Island in the St. Lawrence River and ate and drank excessively. He traveled to Cuba, Mexico and Europe and was about to embark on a canoe trip down the Volga when Russian authorities smashed his canoes, escorted him to the border and told him to get lost. To the public, he is probably the best known of the many artists to be lured by the romance of the American West, and he remains something of a cult figure for the way he mythologized its conflicts, individualism and pioneer spirit.

title: THEATER: SCHECHNER'S 'PROMETHEUS PROJECT'
description: RICHARD SCHECHNER, who has drawn on Shakespeare, Brecht and Greek mythology for his experiments in theater, returns to the ancients for his new offering at the Performing Garage. The central figures of ''The Prometheus Project'' are those two sufferers of myth, Prometheus, who spent 30 or 30,000 years having his liver pecked at by a vulture because he had stolen fire from heaven, and Io, who was changed into a cow by the lustful Zeus and wandered the world tormented by the stings of a gadfly. In Mr. Schechner's work, Prometheus becomes the unwitting contributor of the atom bomb to mankind and Io becomes a prototype of the sexually abused woman. That, at least, is what I gather is intended in these ''four movements and coda,'' since Mr. Schechner is not a teller of tales, but an evoker of moods.

title: Article 253231 -- No Title
description: An estimated $3 million worth of antique jewelry and silver and gold coins was stolen from two East Side antique shops over the Christmas holiday, the police said.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Net income.

title: A Penchant For Winning
description: To be sure, winning was nothing new to Michael Parker when he arrived at the University of North Carolina-Greensboro two soccer seasons ago. With Parker as coach, Lock Haven (Pa.) State had captured three N.C.A.A. national championships in eight seasons - Division III titles in 1977 and 1978, and a Division II crown in 1980. Then, earlier this month, he added another Division III title to a rapidly growing list of credits, this one as Greensboro blew away Washington University, 5-0, on the losers' home field in St. Louis. Aggregate for the tournament: 16 goals by the Spartans, only 1 by their opponents.

title: Judge Postpones Citibank Case
description: A New York State judge yesterday postponed until early January a decision on whether to grant Citibank a preliminary injunction to block four former employees from using information that Citibank said they had taken from the bank. Judge Thomas J. Hughes, who is hearing the case on a temporary basis, put off a decision so that one judge could be assigned permanently.

title: Pakistan Orders the Release Of 260 Political Dissidents
description: Pakistani authorities today ordered more than 260 political dissidents released in the province of Punjab as the country awaited an expected lifting of martial law in the next few days, official sources said.

title: A War Scribes Monument?
description: Representative Mary Rose Oakar thinks the Washington area should have a monument dedicated to journalists killed while covering ''wars and other armed conflicts.''

title: New Turkish Exchange
description: Turkey's first stock exchange in more than 60 years was opened here today by Deputy Prime Minister Kaya Erdem.

title: State Court Voids Group Home Law
description: Laws that bar unrelated people from living together in areas zoned for single-family homes violate the New York Constitution, the state's top court ruled today.

title: EG & G Contract
description: EG & G Inc. said its Florida subsidiary had been awarded a three-year, $360 million extension to its existing prime contract for base operations management and services for NASA's John F. Kennedy Space Center.

title: HOMELESS SEEK SHELTER FOR COLD, WINTRY NIGHTS
description: Green and red crepe paper still hung from the ceiling, and paper snowmen decorated the door, but for the homeless men and women at the East Side church center yesterday, these emblems of the holiday held little cheer.

title: Reagan Doctrine, Angola and Nonpartisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credit of $25,000.

title: Advertising;   Tracy-Locke Wins Curtis Mathis Account
description: Tracy-Locke, the Dallas subsidiary of BBDO International, has been designated its agency by the Curtis Mathis Corporation, also of Dallas, which manufactures and retails an array of home entertainment products.

title: No Sales-Tax Penny Too Small for Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising;   Chelsea's Sponsored Videotapes
description: THERE will be a special four-minute piece serving as a wrapper on Jan. 26 for the NBC-TV telecast of the Super Bowl that will not be advertising although there will be advertiser involvement. It is the kind of work that the guys at Chelsea Communications - Jeffrey Lawenda and Michael Yudin - like to do.

title: JAMES CARRIES BALL AND PATRIOT HOPES
description: The season was plodding along, and so was Craig James: Two victories and three losses for the New England Patriots; 228 yards on 61 carries for James. Finally, he blew up. ''I was frustrated,'' he said yesterday. ''I knew I could help the team, but I can't get into the flow or get any rhythm by carrying the ball 10 times, spread out over four quarters. So what I said was, if I'm going to be in the game, give me a chance.''

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Fazio Joins Notre Dame
description: Foge Fazio, dismissed as the University of Pittsburgh's head football coach last month, and Pete Cordelli, an assistant at Minnesota, were hired as assistant coaches yesterday by the new head man at Notre Dame, Lou Holtz. The 46-year-old Fazio, whose teams compiled a 25-18-3 mark in his four years at Pitt, will serve as Holtz's defensive coordinator, a job he held at Pittsburgh before becoming head coach.

title: TARRED BY MAFIA BRUSH
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY FACE DEATH IN AFRICA, U.N. SAYS
description: United Nations officials say that despite the easing of the agricultural situation in Ethiopia and other drought-afflicted countries, many thousands of Africans may die of starvation or related diseases next year if aid efforts prove inadequate.

title: Pet Unit Bought By Challer Foods
description: Pet Inc. said it had sold its dairy division to Challer Foods Inc., a subsidiary of Finevest Dairy Holdings Inc. While terms were not disclosed, industry sources estimated the deal, which includes all of Pet's refrigerated and fresh dairy products, to be worth about $55 million. Pet, a St. Louis-based subsidiary of IC Industries, said its evaporated milk business was not included in the sale.

title: FIVE-DAY COUNTDOWN TO NEW YEAR'S EVE
description: FROM carols, creches and the rustle of Christmas wrappings to clinking glasses and the rustle of evening dresses. The grown-ups have taken over the holidays with a weekend warmup before the New Year's Eve exhilaration. The countdown is on!

title: RESISTANCE BY CARBIDE EXPECTED
description: The Union Carbide Corporation's investment bankers held meetings yesterday to decide on a countermove to the GAF Corporation's increased $5.1 billion takeover bid for the chemical manufacturer, according to sources familiar with the situation.

title: Market Place;   Speculators And Bankrupts
description: THE trouble with speculating in bankrupt companies, an investment adviser once observed, is that most people buy the stocks before the companies enter bankruptcy proceedings. The trick is to ferret out potential winners after a company files for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: A Rossini Spectacular With Caballe and Horne
description: The kind of singing known as bel canto is currently at the top of the classical music hit parade, and a television program acknowledging this is certainly in order - especially during a holiday season when fancifulness and decoration are all about us. For much of bel canto singing is nothing if not decorative, and the subjects of bel canto operas are apt to be very fanciful.

title: Georgetown Bonanza
description: Georgetown University profited by more than $12 million during the four years Patrick Ewing played center at the school, according to a report published in next month's Regardie's, a Washington business magazine. The story pointed out that Georgetown's revenues had soared because of the near-tripling of attendance at home basketball games, the sharp rise in applications to the school, the team's three appearances in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four and its 18 national television appearances during the Ewing years. A series of figures, several based on broad assumptions, placed the bottom line on Ewing's four years at $12,337,258, the magazine said, for the $48,600 the school invested in him with an athletic scholarship.

title: THE SPARKS OF RENEWAL ARE GLIMMERING IN CAMDEN
description: After 30 years of decline, there is a perception that this city's slide has stopped and that those who hold power are filled with a vision.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: CAN photography be an art form, or is a camera simply an instrument that records reality, rather than a medium that interprets it?

title: Lukens Sees Loss In Fourth Quarter
description: Depressed oil and gas drilling activity and low prices for foreign steel plates will cause a fourth-quarter loss for Lukens Inc., the company's president, W.R. Wilson, said. During the first 12 months of President Reagan's steel trade restraint program, imported plate accounted for a record 30.9 percent of United States sales, Mr. Wilson said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. Court Postpones a Rule On Obscene Phone Services
description: A Federal appeals court has delayed new rules intended to make it more difficult for children to call telephone services offering sexually explicit sounds, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.

title: FIRE HARMS MILLION BOOKS
description: The staff of the Jenkins Publishing Company today began an inventory of rare books, including the world's largest collection of books on Texas history, and of antiques damaged or destroyed in a fire Tuesday.

title: FED DELAYS DATE FOR JUNK BOND RULE
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that it would postpone the effective date of its proposed restriction on the use of low-quality bonds to finance corporate takeovers.

title: EGYPTIAN OPPOSITION LIONIZES GUARD WHO KILLED 7 ISRAELIS
description: An Egyptian border policeman who shot and killed seven Israelis in October in an apparently mad rampage has emerged as a folk hero of the political opposition here.

title: Refugees Deserve Better;   CAPTIVE AFGHANISTAN, 6 YEARS LATER
description: As the Soviet Union's occupation of Afghanistan heads into its seventh year, the Immigration and Naturalization Service is putting our country in the embarrassing and inconsistent position of jailing some of the Afghan refugees whose cause we support, both politically and financially.

title: NETS COAST BY PISTONS
description: As the evening wore on, Dave Wohl began to seethe. He threw a clipboard, kicked an imaginary object, clenched his fists. In the end, the Nets' rookie coach laughed about it, calling himself a perfectionist. What he had hoped to see tonight was a blowout. What he got was a relatively easy Net victory, 124-116, over the Detroit Pistons at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: GUATEMALA VOTE HEARTENS NICARAGUA PARTIES
description: The prospect of a return to civilian rule in Guatemala has given new hope to non-Sandinista political parties in Nicaragua, according to opposition activists here.

title: Otis in Bid for Saxby
description: The Otis Elevator Company of the United States, which already owns 81.35 percent of Saxby, the French handling equipment company, has proposed making a public offer for the remaining shares, the Stockbrokers' Association said today. The association gave no details of the offer but said it was open until Jan. 27.

title: POSTCARDS FROM 1985
description: The awesome events of last weekend - Giants and Jets Both Win Big Games - set up the two-day Springsteen Bowl this weekend and raised the inevitable football question: What have the Giants and the Jets done for us lately?

title: Military Contracts
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation was awarded a $73 million Air Force contract for work on the F-16 aircraft's fire control radar, the Defense Department said.

title: 94 Ethnic Albanians Held in Yugoslavia
description: The Yugoslav police have arrested 94 ethnic Albanians who purportedly belong to clandestine groups advocating separatism and nationalism in the southern province of Kosovo, a senior police official said today.

title: After the Disability Nightmare
description: After four years of confusion and cruelty, Social Security's $18.7 billion disability program is finally being reordered. The campaign for improvement, begun in the Carter years, became a nightmare when zealous Reagan cost-cutters took charge. Now, severely chastened by the courts and Congress, the Administration is on a constructive track - with a greater obligation than ever to stay there.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the Exodus from Egypt misidentified Dr. Hans Goedicke. He is a professor in the Near Eastern studies department at Johns Hopkins University.

title: Japanese Airline Gives Boeing Order
description: All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-largest airline, decided today to buy 25 Boeing B767-300 airplanes worth $1.85 billion. The decision ended a fierce battle for the orders between Boeing and Airbus Industrie, the European airline consortium.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''AUNT DAN AND LEMON,'' the Wallace Shawn play that Joseph Papp imported from the Royal Court Theater in London in October, has already been given two extensions by American Equity. The latest runs to Jan. 26, and Max Stafford-Clark, the director, has been, and is, working on a complete recasting of the production so it can continue when the extensions run out. The original cast, including Linda Hunt, Kathryn Pogson and Mr. Shawn, is just finishing off a week's vacation, granted because the British members wanted to spend Christmas at home, but they'll be on hand for tomorrow night's performance and continue on to the 26th.

title: Oldest British General Dies at 98
description: Sir James Marshall-Cornwall, once Britain's youngest general, was its oldest when he died Christmas Day at the age of 98, his family said today.

title: BOSTON NEWSPAPER WAR TURNS SERIOUS ON COMICS
description: Pow! Zap! Kayo! The Boston newspapers are slugging it out on the comics pages.

title: HOME INTENSIVE CARE reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: The company changed from a fiscal year end from Dec. 31 one ending Sept. 30. Results for the latest period are for the 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1985. Year-ago results are for the full year ended Dec. 31, 1984.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American District Telegraph Co., which supplies electronic security systems, has elected Edward M. Liddy executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Federal Court Backs Use of Female Guards
description: Female guards at San Quentin Prison can conduct searches of clothed male convicts and watch them using shower and toilet facilities without violating inmate rights to privacy, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 10:04 A.M. today and set at 10:01 P.M. tonight.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ''WHERE are the sun-dried tomatoes?'' a diner at my table asked our waiter after tasting a sauce supposedly made with this distinctive and expensive delicacy, but detecting none.

title: 2 Force Open Exit of Jetliner After Seeing Fire in Engine
description: Two airline passengers forced open an emergency exit and slid to the ground on a chute when they saw flames shoot from an engine as the plane prepared for takeoff, United Airlines said today.

title: 2 PHYSICIANS ASSERT BABY POWDER CAN ENDANGER INFANTS' BREATHING
description: Two doctors urged parents today not to use baby powder, saying it was unsafe for infants to inhale, particularly those in whom tracheotomy tubes had been inserted.

title: U.S. HEALTH CARE FOR VETERANS CUT IN BUDGET DRAFT
description: President Reagan's draft budget for the fiscal year 1987 would cut spending on veterans' health care benefits by reducing the number of people treated and, for the first time, by requiring insurance companies to help pay the costs.

title: Dining Out Guide: With Children
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: ANXIETY IN FRANCE
description: With legislative elections less than three months away, a deep political uncertainty has settled over France, often summed up by a widespread, if unproved, feeling that the country faces what is being called ''la fin de regne,'' the end of the era of the Socialists, who have governed since 1981.

title: Required Reading;   Touchy About Taxes
description: Excerpt from ''The Promise of Tax Reform,'' edited by Joseph A. Pechman. (Prentice-Hall) One of the fundamental causes of the American War for Independence was the rebellion of British colonists against taxes that were perceived as inequitable.

title: That Gorbachev Account
description: Last spring, the Cartier's jewelry store in London put on a stiff upper lip and declined to confirm that Raisa Gorbachev, wife of the Soviet leader, had visited the store and paid for a pair of earrings with that ubiquitous symbol of Western life, a credit card.

title: OLD SPECTER FOR ETHIOPIA'S NEW YEAR: FAMINE
description: Here in Harerge Province, the Ethiopian famine of 1986 is about to begin.

title: 2 Ex-Miami Officers Held in Cocaine Theft
description: Two former Miami police officers were arrested today and charged with stealing part of a half-ton cocaine seizure, bringing to 11 the number of officers arrested or relieved of duty this year in an internal inquiry into police corruption.

title: Service for Kranz
description: Gary Kranz's three month sentence for his part in a drug and gambling scandal at Tulane University won't be spent behind bars, a sheriff in New Orleans said Thursday. Starting Jan. 2, Kranz will more likely spend his time pushing a broom, working with children or elderly people or cleaning police dogs' kennels, Orleans Parish Criminal Sheriff Charles Foti said.

title: New Builders in Town, With 10-Gallon Hard Hats
description: The Texas developers have come to town, and they are building Texas style, using Texas flair and big Texas dollars.

title: Free Music and Dance
description: The Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association will celebrate its 20th anniversary with a free performance of music and dance tonight at 7:30 at Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 67th Street.

title: SOVIET ABUSES IN WAR REPORTED
description: A human rights group has asserted that abuses by Soviet troops in Afghanistan have increased over the last year.

title: WELFARE HOTELS SUED OVER TAXES
description: The Koch administration has begun foreclosure proceedings against 11 of the 55 welfare hotels, which collect millions of dollars from the city to house homeless families, because of nonpayment of property taxes, city officials said yesterday.

title: Cities Can't Make Immigration Law
description: San Francisco and half a dozen other cities are declaring themselves to be sanctuaries for illegal immigrants from Central America. Inspired by the religiously-based sanctuary movement, they propose to shelter these assertedly persecuted aliens in a variety of ways, from ignoring immigration rules to outright defiance of Federal agents. No matter how humanely motivated, these actions are misguided.

title: RUSSIANS WITH KIN IN U.S. ARE LEAVING
description: The Soviet Union has begun approving exit visas for Russians with links to the United States who were on a list made public by the State Department last month, American diplomats said Thursday.

title: Youth Program Is Victim of Shelters Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Nikko Acquisition
description: The Nikko International Capital Management Company, an investment unit of Japan's Nikko Securities Company, has acquired 51 percent of Fraser Green Ltd., a British investment advisory firm, a Nikko official said. The acquisition, valued at $579,360, is significant because it gives a Japanese company access to new areas of investment advice, industry sources said. Nikko wants to strengthen its ability to advise clients in Europe, the United States and Japan on investment in worldwide markets.

title: FOOTPATHS FOR CITY DWELLERS
description: It is fitting that the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, 40 percent of whose members live in New York City, is engaged in helping to maintain footpaths in city parks.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CELEBRATING WITH 'IOLANTHE' A byzantine Gilbertian plot that revolves around mistaken identities and romantic entanglements viewed from the perspective of political and social satire, characters who range from a fairy queen to an Arcadian shepherd to the Lord Chancellor, and of course a Sullivan score - they all add up to a high-spirited holiday entertainment from the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players, who bring their production of ''Iolanthe'' to Symphony Space this weekend. John Reed, long the principal comedian at the now-defunct D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, stars as the Lord Chancellor, with Albert Bergeret serving as artistic director and conductor. Performances are Friday at 8 P.M., Saturday at 3 and 8 and Sunday at 3 at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Tickets are $11 to $22; $9 to $18 for children and the elderly. Information: 864-5400.

title: LIABILITY FOR DEMOLITION
description: The evidence appeared irrefutable and stark: four buildings on West 44th Street that were intact one evening last January had been reduced overnight by a wrecking crew to a scarred and rubble-choked ruin.

title: DR. PAUL V. HORN
description: Dr. Paul V. Horn, a retired professor of international trade at New York University, died at North Ridge Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Monday. He was 89 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: KNICKS 113, BULLS 96
description: Just one day after their most improbable and important victory of the season, the Knicks were without the player whose magnificent efforts inspired that achievement. Patrick Ewing suffered a sprained right knee during the Knicks' stirring Christmas Day comeback triumph over the Boston Celtics, and did not accompany the team here this morning for its game tonight against the Chicago Bulls.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Local College Tournaments: Dolphin Christmas Classic at College of Staten Island. Opening round: State University-Buffalo vs. Jersey City State, 7 P.M., and Cortland State vs. Staten Island, 9 P.M. Ends tomorrow. Hunter Christmas Tournament, men and women, at Hunter College's Subterranean Sportsplex, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue. Opening round: Women - Newark-Rutgers vs. Upsala, 1 P.M., and Hunter vs. Jersey City State, 6 P.M. Men - Ramapo vs. State University-New Paltz, 3 P.M., and Hunter vs. Pratt, 8 P.M. Ends tomorrow. Chase Manhattan Holiday Tournament, at New York University Cole Sports Center, 181 Mercer Street, at Bleecker Street. Opening round: Brandeis vs. Rose-Hulman Institute, 7 P.M., and N.Y.U. vs. Johns Hopkins, 9 P.M. Ends tomorrow. Other Local Teams: York at Lehman, 8 P.M. Stevens Tech at Kean, 8 P.M. Other Tournaments: Merrill Lynch Classic at Dayton, Ohio. Opening round: Dayton vs. Columbia, 6:30 P.M. (Radio - WKCR-FM 89.9, 6:30 P.M.) and California vs. Drake, 8:30 P.M. Ends tomorrow. Orange Bowl Tournament, at Miami. Opening round: Manhattan vs. North Carolina and Miami vs. Brown.

title: Economic Scene;   To Change The Future
description: THE end of the year inevitably brings on a spell of nostalgia and a fit of futurism. Nostalgia has its pleasures, but is the effort to peer into the dark future worth the candle?

title: CONCORD COMPUTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: First and Goal for Police Safety
description: The vote in the House was a lopsided 400 to 21 -for who dares oppose a bill that protects police officers? Yet the ban on hard-alloy bullets capable of penetrating police vests came to a vote only after a bitter six-year struggle against the gun lobby. Its fate now depends on how the Senate's leaders deal with diehard opposition.

title: Peru Warns Oil Concerns
description: Peru's President, Alan Garcia Perez, has threatened to take over the operations of three American oil companies unless they agree to invest more and pay higher taxes.

title: Of Lawyers' Work, There Is No End
description: The United States licenses more lawyers in one year than the total number of lawyers in Japan. We now employ more than 625,000 lawyers.

title: CHICAGO GANG SUES TO BE RECOGNIZED AS RELIGION
description: El Rukn is a name that sends shivers up the spines of many Chicagoans, who associate it with robbery, murder, extortion and narcotics.

title: A CRUCIAL TIME FOR THE COMEX
description: New York's Commodity Exchange Inc. has had its share of troubles in the last year, with some of the worst coming from an unexpected quarter.

title: MIDTOWN PIED-A-TERRE CONDOMINIUMS
description: A burst of construction on Seventh Avenue is nearing completion, and emerging from the chaos are an office building - the blocklong Equitable Tower - and, straddling it, two residential condominiums.

title: Scientists Say Lava From Etna Has Stopped
description: Lava stopped spewing from Mount Etna today, but security forces remained on alert as earthquakes continued around the volcano, officials said.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN;   WHALERS 4, ISLANDERS 3
description: From the Whalers' point of view, their 4-3 victory over the New York Islanders tonight at Nassau Coliseum was virtually inevitable.

title: Reagan Doctrine, Angola and Nonpartisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Growth Index Up in 7 Nations
description: Leading economic indexes in seven of the world's nine major industrialized countries are strengthening, a signal that growth forecasts may have to be revised upward, a business research organization said yesterday.

title: Japan G.N.P. Estimate
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd. said Japan's gross national product will grow a real 2.5 percent in 1986-87, beginning April 1, the smallest expansion rate since 1974-75. Its forecast, which compares with a projected 4 percent rise for 1985-86, reflects an estimated real 1.6 percent rise for the United States gross national product in the calendar year 1986 and deflationary effects of the yen's appreciation on the Japanese economy.

title: Chile Debt Request
description: Chile's Finance Minister, Hernan Buchi, has sent foreign bank creditors a formal request for another 180-day rollover of foreign debt repayments, according to a decree published in the official Gazette. Rescheduling contracts, which have been agreed to in principle, have not yet been signed.

title: INJURIES CALLED LEADING KILLER OF YOUNG PEOPLE IN AMERICA
description: Injuries are the leading cause of death for people under the age of 44 in the United States and account for more than half the deaths of males under 24, researchers have reported.

title: Who Needs a Lieutenant Governor Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN;   SABRES 6, RANGERS 1
description: Traveling through a winter's day, the Rangers could claim a victory: They made it to Buffalo.

title: $60.3 Million Issue For Hospital
description: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency is offering $60.3 million of bonds on behalf of St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester.

title: A REPUTED MOB FIGURE WINS BID FOR NEW JUDGE
description: A reputed member of the Mafia today chose to remain in jail rather than have his case heard by a judge whom his lawyers and family have accused of bias.

title: Israeli Leader Refuses to Halt Building of Mormon Center
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres today rejected demands by Orthodox Jews to halt construction of a new center for Brigham Young University now rising in Jerusalem.

title: BUSINESS ECONOMISTS FACE A BLEAKET OUTLOOK
description: For business economists, one area of the economy that may appear the bleakest is their own profession.

title: RAPID-AMERICAN TO BUY T.G.& Y. STORE CHAIN
description: The Rapid-American Corporation said it had agreed to buy the T.G.& Y. unit of Household International Inc. for more than $300 million.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE NEEDIEST IS ANNUAL TRADITION FOR MANY
description: Many families and individuals have made an annual tradition of contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,311,000 for the quarter and $8,622,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $5,126,000 for the quarter and $12,174,000 for the year.

title: IN REMAINS OF CHRISTMAS PAST, BARGAIN HUNTERS LOOK TO CHRISTMAS FUTURE
description: The floor of Holiday Lane, on the eighth floor of Macy's, was strewn with the wreckage of Christmas just past - broken ornaments, rolls of wrapping paper, boxes of cards. Tireless bargain hunters waited in long lines, clutching purchases that would be squirreled away until next year.

title: SULTRY SIREN OF 'DROOD'
description: SHE snarls like a tigress, baring her teeth and raking the air with blood-red talons; she slithers like a snake, lasciviously darting her tongue in and out with reptilian speed.

title: Ideas Reagan Has Considered
description: Invariably, in the 10 weeks before a President submits a budget to Congress, there are reports about what he intends to propose.

title: STUDY CITES DECLINING INJURIES
description: Disabling spinal injuries to football players in college, high school and recreational programs have declined by 85 percent since 1977, the year after rule changes outlawed spearing and other headfirst tackling, a new medical study concluded.

title: UConn Lets Kelley Play
description: The senior guard Earl Kelley will not miss any basketball games or classes under terms of punishment the University of Connecticut handed down yesterday for his role in a harassment incident, officials said.

title: Avon Debt Rating Cut
description: The rating on Avon Products Inc. senior long-term debt and that of its Avon Capital and Avon International Finance subsidiaries has been lowered to A-2 from A-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. About $410 million of debt securities are affected.

title: Oldfield Suit Rejected
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit rejected the shot-putter Brian Oldfield's lawsuit against the United States Olympic Committee for failing to allow him to compete in the 1984 Olympic trials. The San Francisco court ruled that the 1978 Amateur Sports Act, which reorganized amateur athletics in the United States, authorized the U.S.O.C. to determine its own eligibility standards and did not permit an athlete to sue over deniable of eligibility.

title: Philippine Rebels Release 7
description: Communist rebels have released the last 7 of 14 Government workers kidnapped in the southern Philippines three weeks ago, a senior local official said today.

title: New Day Dawns for Think Tanks
description: Earlier this month, the president of the American Enterprise Institute gathered his employees together and announced what had long been rumored here: The 42-year-old study group was entering a period of belt-tightening that would include staff layoffs of 15 to 20 percent.

title: Number to Call If Heat Is Off
description: Tenants in unheated buildings may call a special New York City hot line, (212) 960-4800, to register complaints.

title: REVLON SAYS UNIT'S SALE IS OFF
description: A simmering battle over Revlon Inc.'s beauty products division erupted yesterday when Revlon said its agreement to sell the division to a New York investment concern had been terminated.

title: BOMB EXPLODES IN TEL AVIV
description: A guerrilla bomb went off today opposite city hall. The Israeli police force said a woman was taken to a hospital for shock in the sidewalk blast, which shattered the windows of a fast-food restaurant.

title: JETS, PATRIOTS TO TEST THEIR PROGRESS
description: There are smiles again in the locker rooms of the Jets and the Patriots. Winning makes players suddenly discover wonderful qualities in teammates that are lost in defeat.

title: November Thrift Unit Deposits Up
description: Deposits at federally insured savings and loan associations grew by $4.33 billion in November, up sharply from the October increase of $1.74 billion, the Government said today.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Colorado Copter Crash Under Inquiry by U.S.
description: Federal officials began an investigation today into a helicopter crash that injured three members of a medical emergency team.

title: Topics;   Moral Bookkeeping Looking Backward
description: While New York's Mayor Koch would always rather be right, he seldom seems to care about being righteous. Only Charles Dickens, therefore, may be able to explain why Mr. Koch should suddenly have picked the holiday season to demonstrate moral superiority.

title: Long Road
description: And should the Jets and the Giants win this weekend, then what? Nothing much, especially for the Giants, if history is any guide. Particularly in the National Conference, wild-card winners have had a hard time the rest of the way ever since the game was added to the playoff format in 1978. Here is how each of those winners has fared, on a scale of 1 to 4, with (1) being a loss in the next game, the divisional round; (2) a victory in the divisional round but a loss in the conference championship; (3) a conference victory but a loss in the Super Bowl, and (4) a Super Bowl triumph, achieved by a wild-card winner only once. AMERICAN CONFERENCE 1978 - Houston Oilers2 1979 - Houston Oilers2 1980 - Oakland Raiders4 1981 - Buffalo Bills1 1982 - Strike season, seeding format. 1983 - Seattle Seahawks2 1984 - Seattle Seahawks1 NATIONAL CONFERENCE 1978 - Atlanta Falcons1 1979 - Philadelphia Eagles1 1980 - Dallas Cowboys2 1981 - Giants1 1982 - Strike season, seeding format. 1983 - Los Angeles Rams1 1984 - Giants1

title: Standoff Near London Ends
description: Police officers threw stun grenades and stormed an apartment house near London tonight to end a 32-hour siege in which a woman was killed and a 4-year-old girl held at knifepoint.

title: BEIRUT MILITIAS REPORTED IN PACT TO END THE WAR
description: A Shiite militia leader said today that Lebanon's warring militias had reached agreement on a Syrian-mediated pact to end ten years of civil war.

title: THE INCITEFUL MUSIC OF P.D.Q. BACH RETURNS
description: Alas for the fine acoustics of Carnegie Hall. If the merest gasp of an oboist can be heard from the balcony, what chance is there to miss the sounds of the dill piccolo, the shoe horn and the left-handed sewer flute?

title: Bronx's Polar Expert
description: As new light is shed on the story of Mene Wallace, an Eskimo who grew up in the Bronx at the turn of the century, the mystery grows deeper.

title: Antitrust Cases Settled by MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said that it had reached out-of-court settlements with United Telecommunications Inc. and the United States Telephone Association, the two remaining defendants from its 1979 antitrust suit.

title: Midcon Suing Chemical Bank
description: The Midcon Corporation said yesterday that it had obtained a temporary restraining order in a suit against Chemical Bank of New York to prevent the bank from disclosing confidential financial information about Midcon to WB Partners, the partnership that is making a hostile takeover offer for Midcon.

title: Inquiry on Drew
description: With the Washington Bullets having expressed interest in signing John Drew, the National Basketball Association has undertaken an investigation as to whether the high-scoring free-agent small forward, is eligible to return to the league. ''I've discussed the matter with the Bullets,'' Gary Bettman, the N.B.A.'s general counsel, said yesterday, ''and we are in the process of investigating his status under our drug policy, which could result in his being banned from the N.B.A. if he has been found to be a multiple drug user.''

title: A SCAR FROM THE CYPRIOT WAR: THE MISSING
description: More than a decade after the Turkish invasion of this Mediterranean island, some Cypriot families still suffer from the grief of uncertainty, trying to discover what happened to relatives whose fate remains unknown and pressing for an answer that is likely to be painful.

title: NORTH KOREA JOINS PACT TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: North Korea has joined the 1968 nuclear nonproliferation treaty, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Dow Advances 7.34 As Volume Shrinks
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in the slowest trading of the year as the Dow Jones industrial average recovered some of the 24 points it lost in the two days before Christmas.

title: AUCTIONS
description: WHILE the giants of the auction industry were reporting record sales for 1985, several of New York's smaller auction houses were experiencing financial and legal problems ranging from a modest sales decline to bankruptcy.

title: Power Fails at Atom Plant
description: Power failed in the control room of the Rancho Seco nuclear power plant today, and as employees worked to fix the problem a small amount of radioactive gas was released into the atmosphere, officials said. The amount of radioactive gas that escaped was not enough to harm anybody, they said.

title: Nikolais-Louis Benefit
description: Alumni of the Nikolais-Louis Dance Lab will appear at a benefit performance tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Nikolais-Louis Dance Space, 33 East 18th Street.

title: KOCH WRITES DEVELOPERS ON HOUSING
description: Mayor Koch yesterday released copies of a letter he has sent to 33 developers and real-estate executives, asking their thoughts on making a dent in the shortage of housing for middle-income New Yorkers.

title: PLAN FOR FUNERAL HOME AT SITE OF NOTED CEMETERY DEBATED
description: Some of Chicago's best-known people are on opposite sides of a fight over Rosehill Cemetery, one of the largest, oldest and most elegant in the city.

title: Gannon Chief Considers St. Louis Globe Revival
description: William E. Franke, chairman and president of the Gannon Companies, had been a lifetime reader of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. And the news of its closing earlier this month distressed him so much that he took steps to try to acquire the bankrupt newspaper's assets with the goal of resuming publication.

title: COURT RULES EX-SPOUSE IS ENTITLED TO PART OF MEDICAL-LICENSE VALUE
description: Medical licenses obtained during a marriage are ''marital property'' whose value must be divided equitably at the time of a divorce, the state's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: New Ford Cars In Low Supply
description: The Ford Motor Company yesterday officially introduced its new, highly publicized midsized automobiles, the Ford Taurus and the Mercury Sable, but the models are already in tight supply at the dealerships.

title: Bonds Climb in Light Trading
description: Long-term Treasury bond prices climbed yesterday, despite a flurry of late selling, after an unexpected infusion of funds into the banking system by the Federal Reserve. Discount rates on Treasury bills fell moderately for the same reason.

title: Advertising;   Mandelbaum-Remco
description: Mandelbaum, Wolf, Wiskowski, which deserted New York for a reconditioned warehouse on the water in Jersey City, has been doing the creative work for Remco Toys, a subsidairy of the Azrak-Hamway Company, while the Botway/Libov Associates, has been planning and buying the media. Yesterday, Mandelbaum, Wolf announced that it had been given the additional responsibility for the media.

title: JURORS GET CASE OF 'SKIMMING' AT RESTAURANTS
description: A jury heard the prosecution's final summation yesterday before beginning deliberations in the trial of 10 men charged with operating bars and restaurants in a ''pattern of racketeering.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Ethiopia unfortunately is a country that is facing a crisis in 1986.

title: APPLIED INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $100,000.

title: 2d Rebel Refuses Food In Northern Ireland
description: A second Irish nationalist guerrilla refused breakfast today and joined a hunger striker who has threatened to fast until he dies at Northern Ireland's Maze Prison, a Government spokesman said.

title: 2 Upstate Towns Get Cleanup Aid
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation has agreed to spend about $3.5 million to help the towns of Fort Edward and Kingsbury clean up two hazardous-waste dumps.

title: JETS POLISH THEIR LINE FOR TIMING
description: The Jets' offensive line should be basking in the limelight of an 11-5 record and the playoff game Saturday. Instead, there are serious questions about the line, which will be facing the extremely aggressive defense of the New England Patriots in the American Conference wild-card game at Giants Stadium.

title: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIA RETURNED MISSILES TO EAST LEBANON
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that Syria had moved batteries of mobile antiaircraft missiles back into eastern Lebanon.

title: ST. JONH'S TESTED IN 79-57 VICTORY
description: After slicing through a succession of weak opponents and vaporous defenses, St. John's met some unexpected resistance last night.

title: EXPERTS TELL OF MARKET IN STOLEN PRE-COLOMBIAN ART
description: The international trade in stolen pre-Columbian artifacts is among the most active of the illegal art markets, several experts said yesterday. They added that previous known thefts of such objects suggest several possible explanations for the Christmas Eve robbery at the National Museum of Anthropology and History in Mexico City.

title: ASAT Vs. Star Wars
description: The Air Force ''won't do anything in direct violation'' of a new Congressional ban on the testing of anti-satellite weapons against objects in space. But, a Defense Department official told Walter Pincus of the Washington Post, ''We will find a way to go ahead.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1985
description: Companies

title: BRIEFS
description: * Electronic Data Systems Corp., Dallas, a subsidiary of General Motors Corp., said it would not attempt a hostile takeover of Logica P.L.C., a British software company. Logica's board has said it does not favor a combination.

title: DOUBTS ON DROP IN THE DOLLAR
description: When the United States, Japan, Britain, France and West Germany decided last September to drive the price of the dollar down, foreign exchange markets were prepared for a long siege. The Group of Five's goal was to correct international trade imbalances by making American goods more competitive.

title: MID PACIFIC AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Art of Sign Language
description: Sign language is usually thought of as the means of communication for the deaf.

title: FIREWORKS, CHAMPAGNE AND JAZZ FOR NEW YEAR
description: Laughter, wonder, color and excitement are all particularly welcome on New Year's Eve - which is not an easy night for many. If you don't plan on hunkering down at home with loved ones or the tube or a good book, the city is just outside your window, offering a cornucopia of celebrations.

title: YIELDS ON SIX-MONTH C.D.'S FALL
description: The average yield for six-month certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds fell from one to four basis points for the week ended Tuesday.

title: Dramatic Move
description: Jim Valvano, North Carolina State's basketball coach, reflects on the fainting spell he suffered Wednesday during the victory over Nevada-Las Vegas: ''When I went down for the mandatory 8-count, we were up by 7. When I woke up, we were up by 10. Maybe I'll save that again for later.''

title: Bellamy to Pay Cost Of Disputed Holiday
