description: City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday that she would make good a pledge to repay personally the costs of an unauthorized holiday she gave her staff in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday.

title: Fighters Need U.S. Aid
description: Six years ago, Soviet armed forces invaded Afghanistan, killed the president and installed a puppet regime. Since then, the occupation has grown in size and brutality. Supported by tanks, artillery and air power, Soviet troops have increased to about 120,000; Soviet losses already exceed 30,000. Yet the conflict shows no sign of abating. Indeed, recent reports indicate that Moscow is preparing for a protracted war of attrition.

title: Headed for the Golden Gate
description: As headmaster of the Trinity School, Dr. Robin Lester runs an institution that is 67 years older than the United States. He is going to take charge of a school that is barely older than his 11-year term at Trinity.

title: Tanker Is Moved After Leak
description: The Arco Anchorage, a tanker that leaked an estimated 123,900 gallons of Alaska crude oil into Port Angeles Harbor, killing more than 200 birds, was moved 60 miles under Coast Guard escort to a company refinery today. Volunteers have brought more than 1,200 oil-coated birds into a makeshift rescue center at Port Angeles High School. The birds are bathed, dried and put on a special diet.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MCCALL PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN everyday speech, ''pandemonium'' has come to signify bedlam, cacophony, chaos. But the creation of the original Pandaemonium, the ''palace of all the devils'' in ''Paradise Lost,'' was anything but disorganized. On the contrary, it represented a heroic feat of mining and metallurgy, engineering and large-scale planning. What Milton shows us, as we watch the huge fabric take shape, is the Devil's energy being harnessed to audaciously constructive ends - although we are never allowed to forget that the result, however magnificent, is still the Devil's handiwork.

title: HEAD OF STATE GUARD IS RETIRING
description: The head of the New York National Guard announced yesterday that he would retire next month after 10 years as the state government's top military official.

title: KENNEDY CENTER PAYS TRIBUTE TO 6 IN THE ARTS
description: CONSIDER this for a fail-safe entertainment recipe: Open the show with the National Anthem and the voice of John F. Kennedy declaring, ''I look forward to an America that will reward achievement in the arts as it rewards achievement in business''; cut to shots of President Reagan sitting in his Kennedy Center box with Mrs. Reagan, while Walter Cronkite walks out on stage to serve as narrator; then, for a finale two hours later, bring on several military choral groups to sing a rousing medley of ''The Army Goes Rolling Along,'' ''The Marine Corps Hymn'' and ''Anchors Aweigh.'' There is more than one way, obviously, to get an audience to stand up and salute.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Deck the studio halls with baskets of muffins, Courvoisier cakes and chocolate records.

title: JUDGE'S RULING STOPS DEFENSE IN ABUSE CASE
description: Having held a preliminary hearing for the last 20 months, the judge in the McMartin Preschool sex abuse case surprised both defense and prosecution lawyers by resting the defense's case Tuesday.

title: Advertising;   People
description: Philip C. Sievers is rejoining Doremus & Co. as senior vice president and head of the bank marketing group.

title: NEW DAM ON BORNEO DISPLACES MORE THAN WATER
description: The helicopter swings around for a better view of Sarawak's first big hydroelectric project: there is the dam that catches a valley of water, the dramatic spillway, the bright new building with its humming turbines.

title: FISHERMEN STRIKE IN NEW BEDFORD
description: About 750 fishermen, rejecting boat owners' demands for a greater share of the profits from their catch, went on strike today, setting up picket lines on the waterfront in the nation's richest fishing port.

title: ECONOMIC GLOW FADING BESIDE MAJESTIC ROCKIES
description: For better than a decade, Colorado's front range cities have enjoyed the beauty of their natural setting with the comforts of a robust economy, and nowhere in the state were these benefits as happily married as in this university town north of Denver.

title: How Little Westerners Know About African Cultural Practices
description: To the Editor:

title: LET THE SELLER BEWARE
description: Among the latest Government properties President Reagan's budget advisers recommend selling to private buyers are the Federal Housing Administration and the Bonneville Power Administration.

title: CALIFORNIA MEAT CUTTERS TO VOTE AGAIN ON PACT
description: Meat cutters from the United Food and Commercial Workers union, who rejected a contract offer Thursday, will vote again on the same contract Sunday, a union official said tonight.

title: Living With Alzheimer's
description: ''Memory loss, intellectual impairment, decreased attention span, confusion and depression are not a normal part of aging. They are symptoms of a disease - dementia. The causes vary.'' So reads a booklet that accompanies ''There Were Times, Dear,'' a film about living with Alzheimer's disease. Using actors, the film shows how one family copes, until the victim can no longer remain at home.

title: PRICES FOR DURGS VARYT WIDELY, STUDY FINDS
description: Some New York City pharmacies, especially those in neighborhoods with many elderly residents, charge more than twice as much as others to fill the same prescription, according to an 11-month study of prescription-drug prices by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Washington Bullets signed Freeman Williams, who has not played in the National Basketball Association since the 1982-83 season, to a 10-day contract. The 6-foot-4-inch, 29-year-old Williams, who for the last two seasons played for the Tampa Thrillers of the Continental Basketball Association, led the nation in scoring in 1977 at Portland State.

title: Gulf Canada Sale
description: The Canadian Government approved the previously announced sale of Gulf Canada Ltd.'s refining and marketing assets in eastern Canada to Ultramar Canada Inc., according to Sinclair Stevens, the minister responsible for investment in Canada.

title: MURDER CHARGES FILED AGAINST 3 ON MIAMI FORCE
description: Three members of the Miami police force were charged today with first-degree murder in the drownings of three men thought to have been dealing in drugs, the latest in a series of scandals to hit the beleaguered department.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Mutual Funds table in Business Day yesterday mistakenly carried results of Tuesday's trading. Any reader wishing a copy of the table for Thursday's quotations may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: 150 Prisoners in Carolina To Get an Early Release
description: Gov. Richard W. Riley today declared an emergency in South Carolina's overcrowded prisons and ordered a sentence rollback of 90 days that could mean freedom for about 150 inmates.

title: Baylor, Yankees At Odds
description: The Yankees filed a grievance against Don Baylor yesterday, contending that he has effectively waived the no-trade provision in his contract and that the club should be able to trade him to the Chicago White Sox. Baylor and the Players Association, with which the grievance was filed, promptly disagreed with the Yankees' contention.

title: Finland Expanding Its Air-Defense Systems
description: Finland has expanded its air defenses in the far north since a stray Soviet missile crashed there a year ago, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: UNIVERSITY GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rumors Spur Teledyne Shares
description: Shares of Teledyne Inc. soared yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, amid rumors that the conglomerate is planning another stock buyback. Teledyne closed at $336, up $17 a share from Thursday.

title: Arafat Is Reported Ill And in Need of Rest
description: The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, is recovering from an illness, and his doctor said he required ''many days of rest,'' according to the Palestinian press agency Wafa.

title: SAVING MONEY ON PRESCRIPTIONS
description: There are many ways for a consumer to save money on prescription drugs. In general, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs suggests planning ahead by buying in quantity and comparison-shopping. The department also makes the following more specific suggestions:

title: WHERE H-BOMBS FELL, SPANIARDS STILL WORRY
description: Antonia Flores remembers the day her brother saw fire falling from the sky.

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Coach's Criticism
description: Earle Bruce, the Ohio State coach, yesterday criticized Dr. William Muse, the Akron president, for replacing Jim Dennison as coach. Bruce, whose team plays Brigham Young today in the Florida Citrus Bowl, said of Dennison's dismissal: ''That's terrible, just terrible.

title: OWNERS OF GARDEN SAID TO WEIGHT BUILDING NEW ARENA FARTHER WEST
description: The owner of Madison Square Garden has expressed ''serious interest'' in closing the Garden and building a new arena over a storage yard being built by the Long Island Rail Road on the West Side of Manhattan, the city's top planning official said yesterday.

title: HOMELESS MEN REKINDLE HOPE AT FRIARS' MOUNTAINSIDE REFUGE
description: John, an articulate 37-year-old man with a handsome face roughened by four years of drifting, lost his low-paying job as a baker at a Catskills resort hotel in November.

title: Ewing Status Is Undecided
description: Patrick Ewing underwent heat treatment yesterday afternoon in an effort to speed the healing of his sprained right knee.

title: There Is No Windfall In Bottle Deposits
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Banks Cut Rate
description: Japan's long-term credit bank and trust banks said today that they have decided to lower the long-term prime lending rate to 7.2 percent, from 7.5 percent, effective Saturday.

title: Surgery Is Done
description: Two veterinarians performed delicate surgery today to give Stephan's Odyssey, the Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes runner-up, a chance to survive, and a spokesman at Hialeah Park said things were ''going well.''

title: Giants' Tickets Sold Out
description: At 8 o'clock this morning, the Giants placed on sale the remaining 3,596 tickets for Sunday's wild-card playoff game here against the San Francisco 49ers. At 10:57 A.M., the last four tickets were sold to a man wearing a Jet jersey.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH SEAT BELTS ON SCHOOL BUSES
description: To the Editor:

title: RIDING OUT THE COLD
description: A winter's walk, at least for some of the city's smaller inhabitants, means never having your paws touch the cold pavement.

title: CONTINUING CARE ASSOC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $11,400 for the quarter and $19,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1985
description: Airport Terror

title: AIRPORT TERRORISTS KILL 13 AND WOUND 113 AT ISRAELI COUNTERS IN ROME AND VIENNA
description: Terrorists hurled grenades and fired submachine guns at crowds of holiday travelers at airports in Rome and Vienna today in attacks on check-in counters of El Al Israel Airlines.

title: Fire at Drug Supply Company In East Bronx Leaves 3 Dead
description: Three people were killed last night in a two-alarm fire at a wholesale pharmaceutical supply company in the eastern part of the Bronx, the police and fire officials reported.

title: Texaco Gets Political Lift
description: Several politicians filed briefs in a Federal court in White Plains yesterday expressing support for Texaco Inc.'s efforts to appeal a multibillion-dollar Texas court verdict against it.

title: Political Football
description: The tinge of elegy lately discernible on the capital's streets may have more to do with the demise of the Redskins football team than with the familiar syndrome of holiday melancholia. The hunger of the city's power trippers to fawn, beg or be gifted with entry to the owner's box at a Redskins game has finally ceased for the year, with the team failing to make the playoffs that begin today.

title: Jersey Judge, Declared Unfit, Is Removed From the Bench
description: A veteran Monmouth County judge who berated witnesses, lawyers and litigants in his courtroom and was said to have exploited his position for personal gain was removed from the bench today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: ISRAEL, BLAMING P.L.O., ISSUES A WARNING
description: Although the Palestine Liberation Organization denied involvement in the attacks in Rome and Vienna, Israeli officials blamed the guerrilla group today and made it clear that Israel would respond at the appropriate time and place.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was an inferno - they started throwing hand grenades and firing with submachines guns.

title: TERRORISM: A DEADLY YEAR
description: The attacks on the Rome and Vienna airports yesterday were among a total of about 690 terrorist attacks so far this year, according to State Department figures. Here are some of the major terrorist attacks this year: March 8 - Car bomb explodes outside an apartment building in Beirut, killing 80 people. Reports in Washington say later that the bombing was the work of people who had been hired by a Lebanese counterterrorist team that had been working with the C.I.A. June 14 - Trans World Airlines Flight 847, carrying 145 passengers and 8 crew members, is commandeered by Shiite Moslem hijackers after it takes off from Athens. It is forced to fly to Beirut after several flights across the Mediterranean. One passenger, an American Navy diver, is slain. The rest of the captives are released in stages, with the last group, all Americans, freed June 30.

title: STATE LETS CITY INCREASE SPACE FOR SHELTER USE
description: State officials, acting on what they called a ''desperate plea'' from the city, gave the city permission yesterday to reopen a shelter for the homeless at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx and to expand the shelter for homeless men at the Harlem Armory.

title: Oil Spill in Northwest Affecting More Beaches
description: One of the largest oil spills in Washington State's history, now even bigger than originally believed, was coating more beaches today along the Dungeness Spit.

title: A NEW CEASE-FIRE IS ANNOUNCED IN MALI-BURKINA FASO BORDER WAR
description: Mali and Burkina Faso, at war over a border dispute, have agreed to a cease-fire at the request of other West African nations, according to a radio report today in Dakar, Senegal.

title: PRESIDENT NEARS AIM ON '87 BUDGET
description: President Reagan virtually wrapped up his 1987 budget proposal before heading for California today. A top aide said Mr. Reagan had managed to pare the deficit to ''close to $145 billion,'' still more than the mandatory limit.

title: ROAD REPAIRS TO SNARL TRAFFIC ON BOTH SIDES OF EAST RIVER
description: A section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway near the Williamsburg Bridge will be closed in January for reconstruction, and the work is expected to cause heavy traffic on the Brooklyn and Manhattan ends of the bridge for more than a year.

title: UNITED SERVICES ADVISORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Failure to Success in 3 Days
description: On Dec. 16, Mitchell A. Hecht learned that he had failed the July state bar examination.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FLIGHT PLAN It's never too wintry for a dyed-in-the-feather birdwatcher, according to those who love gazing at nature's live, winged artistry. Tomorrow, from 1 to 4 P.M., devotees may test the full measure of their devotion in the Bronx, where Wave Hill will, for the 61st year, participate in the Christmas bird count for the borough and for lower Westchester.

title: REACTION OF TRAVELERS IS RESIGNATION
description: Travelers, tour operators and travel agents reacted with resignation yesterday to the latest terrorist attacks on civilian travelers.

title: Z & Z FASHIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CHICAGO OFFICIAL SAYS U.S. INQUIRY IS DESIGNED TO EMBARRASS MAYOR
description: A Federal investigation into the awarding of city contracts is a politically motivated attempt to embarrass Mayor Harold Washington, a City Council member has charged.

title: 5 Die in Argentine Crash
description: A passenger train slammed into a freight train early today, killing 5 people and injuring 23 others. The police said the accident, about 60 miles north of Buenos Aires, might have been because of the failure of train personnel to throw a switch. The train was on its way to Buenos Aires from the northern city of Concordia when it hit the freight train at a railroad switching area.

title: TEMPLE HONORS WQXR
description: A scroll marking 40 years of broadcasting the Friday evening service at Temple Emanu-El has been presented to the radio stations WQXR-AM and FM. It was presented to Warren G. Bodow, president and general manager of the radio station, by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel and Edwin A. Malloy, president of the temple, at a ceremony Dec. 20 at the temple. During the ceremony, which was also heard live over the radio, Mr. Bodow presented a vintage microphone to the temple officials. The Friday evening program is usually heard from 5:30 to 6 P.M.

title: U.S. JUDGE BACKS MINORITIES ON NEW CHICAGO WARD MAP
description: A Federal judge today approved redistricting of seven of the city's 50 wards to increase their minority population in a move that could shift the balance of power in the City Council.

title: SURVIVORS TEL OF ATTACKS AT 2 AIRPORTS
description: It was a familiar scene at Rome's Leonardo da Vinci Airport: lines of holiday travelers, inching forward with drowsy children, luggage and Christmas presents, awaiting check-in for flights home or to exotic destinations.

title: CALIFORNIA'S AGRICULTURE, LIKE THE MIDWEST'S IS ENCOUNTERING HARD TIMES
description: For as long as anyone can remember, growers in the bountiful San Joaquin Valley have said that farming in the United States can be divided into two parts: California and the rest of the nation.

title: CITY DISMISSES AIDE WHO CRITICIZED POLICE EXAM
description: A city personnel official was dismissed yesterday, five months after testifying that the passing grade on the most recent written examination for police officers was so low that a functional illiterate might pass.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FIELD-GOAL KICKERS MAY PROVE KEY TO JET-PATRIOT OUTCOME
description: In a game bringing together many of football's most noted offensive and defensive stars, today's wild-card playoff contest between the Jets and the Patriots could hinge on the right instep of a slightly built place-kicker.

title: HOW LITTLE WESTERNERS KNOW ABOUT AFRICAN CULTURAL PRACTICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Price Jump For Retail Coffee Seen
description: The severe drought in Brazil is leading to sharply higher coffee prices in the United States. And this week's wholesale-level increase - of 60 to 65 cents a pound - probably will reach the retail level soon.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:58 A.M. today and set at 9:53 P.M. tonight.

title: GAF PLAN ON CARBIDE NOTE ISSUE
description: In an attempt to strip away part of the Union Carbide Corporation's antitakeover shield, the GAF Corporation disclosed yesterday that it would try to undo the restrictions that Carbide will attach to corporate obligations it will soon issue.

title: COURT RESTORES CASES OF SEVEN, DESPITE DELAYS
description: The state's highest court has ruled that seven men whose charges had been thrown out by lower courts because of delays, should stand trial. One of the defendants is a Brooklyn man accused of raping four women and trying to rape a fifth.

title: Manhattan's Worst Loss
description: Avoiding any gimmicks that would reduce the margin of an inevitable defeat to the top-ranked team in the nation, Manhattan College tonight suffered the most one-sided loss in its basketball history.

title: PIZZA AND POTATOES HOAGIES AND HEROES
description: Replies to correspondence from readers in this last column of 1985, a task that is almost impossible to do on an individual basis, is an especially appropriate way to tie up the loose ends of the year. There have been a number of questions, many suggestions and addenda, not to mention the usual complaints.

title: WOLF, HOWARD B. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Jakarta Courting Timber Group
description: When a high-level group of Indonesians and Americans met in closed sessions in Bali recently to assess the state of relations between the two countries, it did not take long to get to the economic issues.

title: Upper Limits Of Wrestling
description: When Lyle Burrell was a baby, he was so small and cuddly that his mother nicknamed him Pooh. Soon enough, though, Pooh grew. Indulging a fondness for fried chicken and macaroni, he was gradually transformed into a 6-foot-1-inch, 339-pound all-county defensive tackle as a senior this season at Mount Clemens High School, outside Detroit.

title: LIGHT RAIL LINE IS ENVISIONED FOR WEST SIDE
description: New York State and New York City are studying the possibility of building a light rail line -perhaps a monorail - on the West Side of Manhattan as part of an extensive change in transportation patterns being planned for the area.

title: TECHNICAL COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q&A: Solicitor General Charles Fried;   Of Power and the Law
description: Solicitor General Charles Fried, the top Supreme Court advocate of an Administration that has been more critical of the Court than any in recent history, tasted controversy even before his Senate confirmation in October.

title: BIRDFINDER CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
NOT YET A NAUTICAL MUSEUM
description: Although some of the merchants in New York's handsome South Street Seaport complain about sales, and a few have left, the redevelopment on the East River summons crowds, offers them interesting goods and feeds them well. The ultimate success of the enterprise, however, depends on making South Street the thrilling, partly open-air nautical museum it should be.

title: Telex Unit Adds
description: The Telex Corporation's Telex Computer Products unit said it had agreed to acquire substantially all of the assets of the telecommunications business of the United Technologies Corporation's United Technologies Communications Company. It said the transaction involves payment of about $30 million, with 30 percent in cash and the balance in notes payable over about two years.

title: Carter Will Start for Jets
description: Russell Carter's new season began today, but Bobby Jackson's ended suddenly.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last Sunday, with an article about Santa's helpers in New York City, appeared erroneously. Chuck Bishkoff, the volunteer shown, was not holding a youngster's Christmas list; the picture with the list was not published.

title: A METAPHOR FOR DECAY
description: THE BUILDING. By Thomas Glynn. 371 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. As many New Yorkers know all too well, apartment living can seem like a series of never-ending hassles: no water, not enough heat, broken radiators, temperamental elevators, noisy, obnoxious neighbors and irresponsible management. And if that weren't enough, the city often seems to add to all the frustrations with its own intractable conditions: dangerous subways, random violence, filthy streets, roving bands of nut cases, rip-off artists and con men. What Thomas Glynn has done in his first novel, ''The Building,'' is take all the grotesqueries of life in New York and reflect them through a fun-house mirror that distorts and magnifies all that is ugly and perverse. The result is a particularly nasty novel that strives to be taken as a hallucinatory epic about modern civilization - a novel that reads like a tabloid newspaper written by an assiduous student of Swift, Kafka and Marquez.

title: COLUMBIA LOSES TO DAYTON, 57-46
description: Ed Young scored 23 points and Dave Colbert and Damon Goodwin each added 12 tonight to lead Dayton to a 57-46 victory over Columbia in the first round of the Dayton Invitational tournament.

title: Japan Penalizes Ciba Geigy Unit
description: The Ministry of Health and Welfare ordered Ciba Geigy Japan Ltd. to close two factories and suspend sales operations for 20 days from Jan. 6 because it falsified drug data, a ministry official said. The subsidiary of the Swiss-based pharmaceutical company has been submitting false data on stability testing of 46 new products since 1980, the official said.

title: TYSON WINS AGAIN ON EARLY KNOCKOUT
description: The heavyweight Mike Tyson ran his unbeaten streak to 15-0 with a first-round knockout of wild-swinging Mark Young at the Colisium Theatre tonight.

title: Safety Control Valve For Artificial Heart
description: A safety control valve for an artificial heart, invented by residents of Berlin, was patented this week for the Thoratec Laboratories Corporation of Berkeley, Calif.

title: AIRPORT ATTACKS WIDELY DEPLORED
description: The terrorist assaults at airports in Rome and Vienna were condemned worldwide yesterday as the extent of the carnage became apparent.

title: GAY BUTTENHEIM BRIDE OF JAMES E. MAXWELL
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Gay Buttenheim, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Marion Buttenheim of Princeton, N.J., to James Edward Maxwell, an actor, took place yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, N.Y. The Rev. Paul F. M. Zahl performed the ceremony.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. The flag is upside down. 2. Peking. 3. To get cities to designate themselves as sanctuaries for illegal aliens. San Francisco is the latest to adopt such a resolution. 4. 1990. 5.

title: LUCILLE BAHNSEN WED TO EDWARD WINGFIELD
description: Lucille Ginter Bahnsen and Edward Christian Wingfield were married yesterday at the Congregational Church of South Glastonbury, Conn. The Rev. Michael B. Stevens, assisted by the Rev. Barry Stipp, performed the ceremony.

title: U.S.-SOVIET ARTS EXCHANGE PLANNED
description: Negotiations are under way for at least 10 major performing arts groups from the Soviet Union and an equal number from the United States to participate in an exchange program. The proposed exchange, it was disclosed yesterday, is part of the cultural agreement signed at the Geneva summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: TEXAS-EL PASO UPSETS HOYAS
description: Quintan Gates scored 12 of his 18 points after halftime as Texas-El Paso stunned Georgetown, 78-64, tonight.

title: FOR FAMILIES OF 2 AMERICANS, SUDDEN SORROW
description: Natasha Simpson, the 11-year-old daughter of a foreign correspondent in Rome, was on her way to New York with her family for a three-week vacation with friends and relatives. John Buonocore 3d, a 20-year-old student, was on his way home to Wilmington, Del., after a semester in Rome, just in time for his father's 50th birthday.

title: BUILDERS ACCUSED OF ACTIONG AS FRONTS TO WIN CONTRACTS
description: Six construction companies used their ownership by minorities and women to help white, male-dominated associates get state contracts from a program to aid disadvantaged groups, the State Department of Transportation has charged.

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Unitas Upset
description: A full page is devoted to Johnny Unitas in the Indianapolis Colts' media guide. He is mentioned 68 times in the statistical charts.

title: OCCIDENTAL IN ACCORD WITH PERU
description: President Alan Garcia Perez said late today that he had reached an agreement with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation under which the Los Angeles-based company would give up its lucrative tax breaks in that country for 22 years and make a major investment in a new oilfield in return for the right to continue operating.

title: POP: RICHARD LLOYD AND FEELIES AT THE RITZ
description: The late-1970's New York guitar underground returned Thursday night to the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street, in a bill featuring the Feelies and the Richard Lloyd band.

title: SMALL CONCERNS BATTLE CANCER
description: When researchers at Oncogene Science Inc. reported in the New England Journal of Medicine earlier this month that they had found a key to what causes certain cancers, they focused attention on a small company that is one of the multitude of foot soldiers in the war against cancer.

title: FURTHER GROWTH IN THE ECONOMY FORECAST FOR '86
description: The United States economy seems headed for a fourth consecutive year of expansion in 1986, but its course will be marred by gradually rising inflation and stubbornly high unemployment, according to a consensus of business and academic forecasters.

title: HAVING MORE THAN ONE
description: The distributors of beer have convinced legislators in 27 states to condone - even enforce - territorial monopolies that let a single wholesaler control sales of a given brand. Consumers probably can't do much about these costly arrangements except grin and pay up. But it isn't too late to protect the rest of the country against the beer distributors' newest assault: legislation that would effectively prevent Federal antitrust suits against exclusive distribution agreements.

title: CLOSED-CAPTIONING FOR BOSTON NEWS
description: Two Boston television stations will begin offering closed-captioning for hearing-impaired people on their local evening news programs next year, becoming the first stations in the country to offer the service for such programs, the stations said.

title: 235 Poles Leave Ships In West Germany
description: Some 235 Polish tourists have failed to return to three ships docked at a West German port over the Christmas holidays, officials said today.

title: IN VIENNA, PANIC IN MIDDLE OF SHOOTING AND GRENADES
description: Panic broke out in the check-in lounge at the airport here when three gunmen stormed in, spraying the hall with submachine-gun fire and rolling grenades along the floor.

title: JAZZ: JACK MAHEU AND TRIO
description: Since the clarinet virtually disappeared from jazz 40 years ago, the few clarinet-led small groups that have surfaced have, with the exception of Bob Wilber's recollections of Sidney Bechet, tended to sound like warmed-over Benny Goodman.

title: 38 on Bellamy's Staff Took King's Day Off
description: An audit has found that 38 of 53 people on City Council President Carol Bellamy's staff took a day off last January in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, at a cost of $4,012.03.

title: MEXICAN OFFICIALS SEARCH FOR THIEVES
description: Mexico's National Museum of Anthropology remained closed today as investigators searched for clues to the identity of thieves who stole some of the nation's most prized archeological artifacts on Christmas Eve.

title: ETRUSCAN INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money;   I.R.S. Seeking More Detail
description: FEDERAL income tax forms and schedules now being distributed contain a number of changes from last year, reflecting both new laws and an effort by the Internal Revenue Service to obtain more information more efficiently.

title: Simmons in Filing On Sea-Land Bid
description: Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, has asked the Sea-Land Corporation's board to approve his ownership of more than 35 percent of the company's total shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons said he had formally requested the company's approval in an effort to avoid triggering restrictive covenants in Sea-Land debt agreements.

title: Drugs Tested to Aid Treatment of Tumors
description: A laboratory procedure that can ascertain the drug sensitivities of tumors has been patented by Prof. M. Boris Rotman of Brown University in Providence, R.I. A license under patent 4,559,299 has been granted to the Analytical Biosystems Corporation in Providence, which plans to commercialize the invention.

title: Bears Take Practice South
description: The Chicago Bears will head south to Suwanee, Ga., to practice for the playoffs, the team announced today.

title: WAR TURNS ANGOLAN BREADBASKET INTO LAND OF HUNGER
description: In what may be Africa's most expensive but least known emergency food program, airplanes of the International Committee of the Red Cross are flying about 400 tons of food weekly into Angola's fertile central highlands.

title: 49ERS AIMING TO STOP MORRIS
description: There is one main difference between the Giants who lost two playoff games in the four previous seasons to the San Francisco 49ers and the Giants who will meet the 49ers in a wild-card playoff game here Sunday. His name is Joe Morris, and if he runs as well against the 49ers as he has run in recent games, the Giants will have a good chance to win.

title: Stringed Instrument Lessons Facilitated
description: Myron Weiss, a New York professional guitarist, plans to license production of a musical teaching device that was patented this week.

title: Help from Russell
description: Coach Don Chaney of the Los Angeles Clippers has called on a former Boston Celtic teammate for help, and Bill Russell has responded. Russell, the Hall of Fame center, has agreed to tutor Benoit Benjamin, the Clipper center, who was the third player selected in the National Basketball Association college draft last June.

title: BUYOUT BID COMPLICATES KAISER COMEBACK EFFORT
description: Battered by forces ranging from the weather to the world economy, the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's third-largest aluminum producer, has racked up losses in the last five years totaling $294.2 million. Most analysts, however, agree with the company that a restructuring begun in 1980 is beginning to reverse Kaiser's fortunes.

title: REAGAN TO TRADE TELEVISION TALKS WITH GORBACHEV
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev have agreed to exchange videotaped New Year's Day greetings that are intended for broadcast in the United States and the Soviet Union, the White House announced today.

title: ST. JOHN'S TO FACE TOUGH FOE IN FINAL
description: After St. John's defeated James Madison to gain a berth in today's Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival championship game against St. Bonaventure, Lou Carnesecca was asked about last season's meeting between the teams. Carnesecca, the coach of St. John's, winced at the memory.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS TO GET BRITT
description: People Express Inc. yesterday announced a binding agreement to acquire Britt Airways Inc., the nation's third-largest commuter airline, with major hubs in Chicago and St. Louis. The terms were not given. The acquisition comes on the heels of People's November takeover of Frontier Airlines, a major carrier based in Denver, which catapulted People from the nation's 12th-largest airline in terms of passengers carried to No. 5.

title: Rohatyn Urged For M.T.A. Seat
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that Governor Cuomo appoint Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to a vacancy on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: REMEMBER THE MALPRACTICE VICTIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: British Steel-Slater
description: The Slater Steel Corporation said the British Steel Corporation had entered into negotiations to sell its 50.1 percent interest in Slater to a joint venture formed by a New York investment firm, Peterson, Jacobs & Harding, and the Toronto investors Paul and Deavid Fingold. It said if the transaction proceeded, the investors would offer $11.50 in cash and debentures worth $3 for each Slater share.

title: GORBACHEV CAUTIOUSLY UPBEAT ON U.S.
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev offered a cautiously upbeat assessment of relations between the Soviet Union and the United States today, saying points of ''potential convergence'' had emerged in arms talks.

title: CONSUMER GROUP ASSAILS U.S.
description: A national consumer group today criticized Congress and the Administration for ''a year of virtual inaction'' on consumer issues, including health care, financial services and food and drug safety.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN TROOPS REPORTEDLY VIOLATE SWAZILAND'S BORDERS
description: Swazi villagers said today that South African troops crossed into the southeastern corner of the country this week and threatened to attack them if they gave shelter to guerrillas.

title: TRADE THE INDIAN MUSEUM FOR THE DALLAS COWBOYS
description: Maybe Robert Abrams, New York State's Attorney General, is making a big mistake in trying to block the transfer of the Museum of the American Indian, in upper Manhattan, to Dallas, where financier Ross Perot has offered more than $70 million for a grand new building and installation. As New Yorkers, we should look at this offer as an opportunity, not another sign of our waning economic power.

title: 20 More of Dead in Air Crash In Newfoundland Sent Home
description: Twenty more bodies of the 256 soldiers and crew members killed in a plane crash in Newfoundland Dec. 12 were shipped to their families today for burial.

title: KEY QUESTION REMAINS: WHO ORDERED ATTACKS?
description: There was no immediate, clear assertion of responsibility tonight for the virtually simultaneous terrorist assaults on the Rome and Vienna airports. But diplomats and others said that apparently the choice of the Israeli airline El Al as a target, and the pattern of rising violence in the Middle East, suggested that the attacks might well have been the work of Palestinian militants.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. To honor the United Nations General Assembly's 40th session, an American mountaineering team climbed to within 800 feet of the summit of Mount Everest and planted this United Nations flag, which they photographed. What went wrong? 2. Despite official objections, a student protest against testing nuclear weapons took place in what major capital? 3. Federal officials say a spreading campaign by religious groups has stimulated a new flow of immigrants from Central America. What is the campaign? 4. Despite the 10-cent fare increase for New York City buses and subways that starts next week, projections from the Transit Authority show that continuing deficits would translate into $1.40 fares by (1987/1988/1990). 5. The Jets and the Giants have both won wild-card spots in the N.F.L. playoffs this weekend. How many times before have both teams been in the playoffs in the same year? 6. A Federal advisory panel recommended that experiments to implant permanent artificial hearts be (continued/discontinued). 7. The Reagan Administration and the Federal Reserve Board are at odds over a plan to slow the pace of corporate takeovers. What is the plan? 8. Loretta O'Brien is ''ecstatic'' about a historic decision from New York State's highest court. Why? 9. President Reagan's budget for 1987 proposes the sale of four agencies that provide service to millions of consumers. What are the agencies and what is the service? 10.

title: Red Army 6, Oilers 3
description: Vyacheslav Bykov scored on a power play and while his team was short-handed to spark the Central Red Army's three-goal second period.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of entertainment events in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect time for tomorrow's performance of ''The Nutcracker'' by the New York City Ballet at the State Theater in Lincoln Center. It is 5 P.M.

title: Patents
description: A HEAT pipe for a fast breeder reactor, invented for the Department of Energy, is one of several nuclear energy power improvements patented this week. Others relate to nuclear fuel, such as uranium dioxide.

title: WHEN HORROR BECOMES FREQUENT
description: The terror that has already given somber resonance this year to the names Athens, Cairo and Malta now has spread to Rome and Vienna. Even while Christmas prayers for peace still echoed, gunmen sprayed machine gun bullets at air travelers in both cities. In the showers of blood, a dozen or more innocent people died, a hundred or more fell wounded. The world has learned how to count terror's casualties. What is the larger lesson to be learned this time? What is there to be done?

title: Computer Maker Expects a Deficit
description: Computer Memories Inc., a disk-drive maker based in Chatsworth, Calif., said today that it expects to report a loss for the third quarter ending Dec. 31 because of weakness in the microcomputer industry, overcapacity and competition Irwin Rubin, chairman and chief executive, also announced the resignation of Gary Streuter, president and director, and Abraham Brand, corporate secretary and co-founder of the company, effective Dec. 31. Mr. Rubin said that both executives would remain on as consultants. Mr. Streuter and Mr. Brand could not be reached for comment. Mr. Brand had resigned as president in May after 11 months in that position, and was succeeded by Mr. Streuter. Mr. Streuter joined the company from Altos Computer Systems, where he was vice president of manufacturing. Mr. Rubin said that the company was negotiating for new business with several companies, but declined to discus the talks further.

title: The Burger Wait
description: However slowly the wheels of justice may grind, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger is discovering that Congress is no slouch either in the all-deliberate-speed department.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
BAYLOR TOPS L.S.U. IN THE LIBERTY BOWL
description: Cody Carlson, the Baylor quarterback, tossed scoring passes of 5 and 15 yards to lead the Bears to a 21-7 upset of Louisiana State University in the 27th annual Liberty Bowl tonight.

title: Nigeria Names Officers Arrested in Coup Plot
description: The Nigerian Government today named 14 officers, including Gen. Mamman Vatsa, a member of the Armed Forces Ruling Council, who it said were behind an unsuccessful coup to overthrow President Ibrahim Babangida.

title: 7 YOUTHS INJURED IN CONCERT FIGHTS
description: At least one youth was shot and six suffered stab wounds during and after a ''rap'' music concert at Madison Square Garden last night, the police said.

title: SALVADOR REBELS ALTER TRUCE TERMS
description: Leftist rebels today modified their conditions for continuing a Christmastime truce, saying that they ''no longer consider ourselves obligated to keep our forces in a passive position.''

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Football Jets vs. New England Patriots, at Giants Stadium, 4 P.M. These 11-5 teams will duel for the American Football Conference wild-card playoff berth and the right to face the Los Angeles Raiders next Sunday. The contest is the clubs' first playoff meeting. (Television -Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC, 4 P.M.) College Football Sun Bowl, at El Paso, Tex., 12:30 P.M. Arizona vs. Georgia. (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M.) Florida Citrus Bowl at Orlando, 12:30 P.M. Ohio State vs. Brigham Young University. Robbie Bosco, B.Y.U.'s quarterback, puts his 23-2 career record as a starter on the line in his college finale. In the 1982 Holiday Bowl, the teams' last meeting, the Buckeyes defeated the Cougars, 47-17. (Television -Channel 4, 12:30 P.M.) Aloha Bowl, at Honolulu, 8 P.M. Alabama vs. University of Southern California. (Television -Channel 9, 8 P.M.) Basketball Professional: Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WPAT, 7:20 P.M.); Nets vs. Washington Bullets, Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 9:30 P.M. The Jets' playoff game necessitated the change in starting time from 7:30 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 11:15 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 9:20 P.M.) College: Eastern College Athletic Association Holiday Festival, consolation and final rounds, at Madison Square Garden. Iona vs. James Madison and St. John's vs. St. Bonaventure, 12:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 12:30. Radio - WCBS 880, 2:15 P.M.); Louisville vs. Kentucky, Rupp Arena, Lexington, Ky., 4 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) High school: Doc Turner East Coast Classic, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue. Today's concluding five-game schedule begins at 12:30 P.M. and ends with the boys' championship game at 8:30 P.M.) Hockey Rangers at Minnesota North Stars, 2:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, WOR, 2:30 P.M.) Islanders at Pittsburgh Penguins, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WOR, 7:30 P.M.) Devils at Montreal Canadiens, 8:05 P.M. (Radio - WMCA 570, 8 P.M.) Other Events TENNIS: Rolex International Junior Championships, for boys and girls 18 years and under, 16 and under, 14 and under and 12 and under, at the Port Washington Tennis Academy, 100 Harbor Road, Port Washington, L.I., 8 A.M. Admission is free.

title: DOW JUMPS 16.51 POINTS AS VOLUME RECOVERS
description: Stock prices advanced across a broad front yesterday, but traders said the day's modest trading volume gave an exaggerated lift to prices.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Daewoo Heavy Industries, Seoul, has agreed to provide Northrop Corp. with frame assemblies for stretched upper decks for 100 Boeing 747 airplanes for which Northrop is building the fuselages.

title: A SMALL PRICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Modest Aim
description: Harry Neale, dropped by the Vancouver Canucks after last season and now trying to rally the stumbling and bumbling Detroit Red Wings: ''I don't want to be coach of the year. I just want to be coach for the year.''

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Part II: Can We Talk?
description: The General Accounting Office, Congress's watchdog over executive agencies, has just produced one of the slimmest inquiry reports on record, taking less than three pages to say that the Central Intelligence Agency declined to discuss a charge that it had directed leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels to lobby Congress for funds.

title: THE APPARATCHIK IS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: Perhaps the most interesting political development in the Soviet Union since the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev in November 1982 involves major changes in the relationship between the Communist Party leaders and the party apparatus - that is, the managers in the bureaucracy.

title: Hong Kong Bank Loss
description: A Hong Kong bank that was saved from collapse by the Government in June said today that it lost $385 million in the year to June and predicted further deficits in the future.

title: MUSIC: ZAMIR CHORALE IN 'MUSIC CONTRASTS'
description: Something new in special offerings for New York's holiday season has been added by the Hebrew Arts School with the presentation of a five-concert Winter Festival of Jewish Music at Merkin Concert Hall. The first event was given last Sunday and the festival will end Monday with a klezmer concert.

title: FOR EL AL, VIGILANCE AGAINST VIOLENCE
description: El Al Israel Airlines maintains the tightest security of any airline in the Western world, most security specialists agree.

title: Bridge;   New Book Offers Solutions For Those Memory Lapses
description: Hundreds of books have been written aiming to close the gap between the technique of the beginner and the technique of the expert. But the beginner has a different problem that is hardly ever addressed: he forgets the meaning of a bid, or the number of trumps that have been played, or a vital discard. Even good players can have memory lapses, and experts are not totally immune.

title: Bond Yields Up; Bill Rates Off
description: Yields on long term treasury bonds fell yesterday to their lowest level since September 1979, before rebounding in light trading after the Federal Reserve issued its holiday-delayed weekly money supply report.

title: PUT POLITICS ASIDE AND HELP THE 'HEAD START' PROGRAM
description: Everybody likes Head Start, the Federal Government's preschool program for low-income children. In 1980, President Jimmy Carter praised it as ''a program that works.'' President Reagan included Head Start in the ''safety net'' and presided over a 30 percent increase in funding. Now 20 years old, it serves about 450,000 children, at an annual cost of more than $1 billion.

title: Sports of The Times;   Strange View
description: Viewing a postseason professional football game upside down and between his legs in the Meadowlands - a position unlike that of most of the other 70,000 or so folks in attendance - is not new for Bart Oates.

title: A Fast 300
description: When the Celtics beat Chicago at Boston Garden a while back, they gave K. C. Jones the 300th victory of his career as a head coach in the National Basketball Association. In terms of total games coached, Jones reached that plateau with remarkable speed. Here is the list of the 10 fastest 300-game winners among all coaches in N.B.A. history, ranked according to the number of games it took them: Billy Cunningham430 K. C. Jones434 Larry Costello445 John Kundla452 Tom Heinsohn470 Red Auerbach491 Bill Sharman503 Al Cervi507 Dick Motta520 Joe Lapchick521

title: Wendy's Stock
description: Wendy's International Inc., the hamburger restaurant chain, said yesterday that it had acquired Restaurant Systems Inc. of Atlanta, which owns 36 Wendy's franchises in Georgia and Alabama. The acquisition involved the swap of 2.75 million shares of Wendy's for Restaurant Systems stock. Wendy's stock closed yesterday at $16.75 a share, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange, making the transaction worth about $45 million.

title: Syracuse Sues Two Airlines
description: The city is suing Piedmont and Empire airlines for $96 million for failing to bring a headquarters with 1,000 jobs to Hancock International Airport in North Syracuse.

title: Federal Reserve
description: All data in millions of dollars LatestPreviousYear WeekWeekAgo Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Dec. 16 $622,600 R $623,200 #550,900 Adj. Mon.Base (St.Louis Fed) *(12/25)#235,100 #234,300 #215,800 Reserve Position, Eight New York BanksDaily averages for two weeks ended Dec. 18 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover)#4 (8) (64) Borrowings at Federal Reserve#0 #210 #175 Net Federal Funds PurchasesR 8,268 #7,425 #8,193 Basic Reserve Surplus (Deficit)R (8,264)(7,643)(8,432) Federal Reserve CreditDaily averages, week ended Dec. 25 Gov'ts. and Agencies Held Outright#186,114 #186,101 #169,224 Gov'ts. and Agencies Under Repurchase#1,500 #427 #0 Float#1,347 R 1,137 #1,227 Other Assets#14,667 R 14,454 #11,709 Other Factors Affecting ReservesDaily averages, week ended Dec. 25 Gold Stock#11,090 #11,090 #11,096 Special Drawing Rights#4,718 #4,718 #4,618 Currency in Circulation#195,964 #194,760 #182,813 Treasury Deposits#3,577 #3,776 #3,669 Other Items Gov't.

title: Algeria Rules Out Multiparty System
description: Algeria's National Liberation Front ruled out a multiparty system for the country and strongly denounced opposition groups in a resolution published here today.

title: INTERPOL REPORTED WARNED OF RAIDS ON AIRPORTS
description: A warning of possible terrorist attacks on airports and airlines was issued two weeks ago by Interpol, the international police agency, a Dutch police spokesman said in Amsterdam today.

title: U.S., Turkey Sign Pact
description: Turkey and the United States signed an economic aid agreement today totaling $100 million, the semiofficial Anatolia press agency reported.

title: DESIRE TO EASE SUFFERING CITED IN DONATIONS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Easing the suffering of the very old and the very young in need is a motivation frequently cited for gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: CANADIENS SURGE PAST DEVILS
description: The Devils' losing streak was extended to four games tonight as New Jersey dropped a 7-3 decision to the Montreal Canadiens at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: SIZING UP SCHOOLBOY TALENT
description: Steward Barnett's mother, Annie, would never make it as a basketball coach. ''My mother's funny,'' said Barnett, a guard for Kennedy High School in the Bronx. ''She says to me, 'Poppy' - she calls me Poppy - 'you're a good player, but you play too hard.' She doesn't understand what I've got to do. I have to play hard. Because, man, they aren't going to believe I can play when I walk on the court.''

title: Marcia Henderson Is Wed To Stephen John Murphy
description: Marcia Sue Henderson, an investment analyst with Rockefeller & Company, and Stephen John Murphy, an associate in the municipal-bond department of Goldman, Sachs & Company, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. David E. Mulford performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Chatham Township in Chatham, N.J.

title: Art From Debris
description: Over a curbstone miniature of the art galleries that speckle SoHo, Lisa Werenko sells tiny bits of the city, small items she has found to transform into earrings and cufflinks.

title: 4 Hurt in Boston Subway
description: A trolley car rammed another that had stopped in a tunnel today, throwing passengers from their seats and injuring four people.

title: Hearing for Cooney
description: Gerry Cooney, who was in training in Lancaster, Pa., for a possible heavyweight bout against Michael Spinks, and four companions face a Jan. 13 hearing on charges stemming from a Dec. 5 fight at a hotel bar nearby, according to Molly Dorman, a clerk for District Court Justice Michael A. Stewart. Cooney, who is charged with disorderly conduct, and the others have entered not-guilty pleas through an attorney.

title: Zoning Must Recognize the One-Person Home
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRAIL OF AIRPORT VIOLENCE
description: The attacks in Rome and Vienna yesterday were not the first terrorist incidents in which many civilians were killed and wounded at international airports.

title: CLAVELL BOOK AUCTION TO BEGIN AT $3 MILLION
description: A new novel by James Clavell is scheduled to be auctioned early next month, and Mr. Clavell has established a minimum bid, or ''floor,'' of $3 million - three times the advance that he has received for any previous book.

title: U.S. ASSERTS THE KILLERS ARE 'BEYOND THE PALE'
description: The United States said today that those who carried out the terrorist attacks in Rome and Vienna were ''beyond the pale of civilization'' and that all nations must join in ''bringing to justice those responsible.''

title: FOR LOYAL GIANTS FANS, A 'CRAZY WAIT FOR SEATS
description: ''It was hell out there,'' Walter A. Pitcher said, pointing out his car window to the place where, only hours earlier, hundreds of cars had been wrapped around the Brendan Byrne Arena, small bonfires had burned and an occasional fistfight had broken out.

title: Part I: Can We Talk?
description: There is a sense of honest sighing about the last words of Congress, the real last words that come after the final session's flourish of Claghornish encomiums from one lawmaker to another.

title: F.A.A. PROPOSES NEW RULES FOR JET ENGINES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today proposed new regulations that would require domestic airlines to visually inspect and eventually replace a key component in thousands of Pratt & Whitney jet engines.

title: LEBANESE REACH A NEW ACCORD
description: Amid all the tension in the Middle East came a welcome - though still tentative - note of detente from the religious and ethnic factions that have been carrying on a civil war in Lebanon for 10 years.

title: True Virtue
description: Praise to Joseph Epstein's ''True Virtue.'' I'd make another point about his ''virtucrats'': scratch the surface of a virtucrat and you find a victim.

title: ALABAMA TROUNCES SOUTHERN CAL, 24-3
description: Craig Turner, Clay Whitehurst and Albert Bell scored on consecutive second-half possessions tonight to lead Alabama to a 24-3 victory over Southern California in the Aloha Bowl.

title: A RADICAL LEADER FOR ASSAM
description: Not so long ago, Prafulla Kumar Mahanta was leading student agitators in the Indian state of Assam, when he was not hiding from the police or languishing in jail. Last week, at the age of 32, Mr. Mahanta was sworn in as Chief Minister of Assam to the dismay of the central Government in New Delhi and of the hundreds of thousands of Moslems hanging on for dear life in the troubled northeastern state.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Huberman Festival Program 4: Shlomo Mintz and Isaac Stern, performing with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Zubin Mehta Pacific Arts Video 40 minutes. $39.95 This is the fourth in a series of eight releases devoted to the Huberman Festival - a weeklong extravaganza of concerts held in Tel Aviv three years ago and featuring seven world-class violinists, the Israel Philharmonic and its conductor Zubin Mehta.

title: True Virtue
description: The most hilarious example of self-declared virtue is Philip Roth's Sophie Portnoy (mother of the beleaguered Alexander in ''Portnoy's Complaint'') who laments: ''Do you know what my worst fault is? I'm too good.'' RHODA NATHAN New York City

title: SURVIVAL PROJECT OFFERS FRESH START TO TROUBLED YOUTH
description: AN intensive program combining wilderness experience with education and community service is giving troubled teen-agers a chance for a fresh start in life.

title: WOULD-BE AUTHORS TELL OF STRUGGLES
description: WHEN Charles M. Williams of Orange decided three years ago to become a published author, he had visions, he admits, of glory as well as golden rewards.

title: From Cupboards To Braided Wheat
description: The Painted Cupboard in Bedford Village is a source for antiques and modern and folk items crafted by Swedish artisans of 200 years ago, artisans working in Sweden or Swedish artisans duplicating their traditional wares in America. Some dates are discernible on the old pine and birch painted pieces, and there are well-used kitchen and farm tools - for example, a vast wheat sieve that looks like a woven basket, once priced here at $195 and now $130.

title: PURIFYING WATER: NATURE'S WAY
description: USING common marsh plants, Southold Town is tackling the problem of removing contaminants from road runoff with a natural purification system developed in West Germany.

title: PAKISTAN IS BELIEVED NEAR END OF MARTIAL LAW
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who has promised to abolish martial law by the end of this year, is keeping people guessing until the last minute about how much democracy he will allow under civilian rule.

title: ABDUCTORS IN BEIRUT ISSUE THREAT TO KILL 3 JEWS HELD HOSTAGE
description: A Moslem fundamentalist group that has said it killed a Jewish hostage has threatened to kill three Lebanese Jews it is holding and to strike at others ''on whom we may lay our hands.''

title: OUR REFUGEE POLICY IS ON TRIAL IN SANCTUARY CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: DELMORE SCHWARTZ: The Life of an American Poet, by James Atlas. (Harvest/HBJ, $10.95.) A critical biography of the poet, novelist, critic and professor who dazzled the American literary community in his youth but died alone, penniless and insane, at 53. Delmore Schwartz (1913-1966) counted among his friends the leading lights of the New York literati, and Leonard Michaels wrote in The Book Review in 1977 that ''whatever the intrinsic value of his work . . . Schwartz will continue as a presence in the work of writers better than himself.'' This ''fascinating'' portrait, he added, ''suggests that Schwartz too was better than himself.'' THE GREEN HOUSE, by Mario Vargas Llosa. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) An ill-famed bordello in the slums of a provincial city on the upper Amazon forms a principal setting for Mario Vargas Llosa's novel, first published in Spanish in 1965.

title: WINNERS OF INDIVIDUAL AND TEAM CHAMPIONSHIPS DURING 1985
description: Archery U.S. Champions Men - Richard McKinney, Glendale, Ariz. Women - Terri Pesho, Tempe, Ariz. Crossbow Men - Ervin Myers, York, Pa. Women - Carol Pelosi, Greenbelt, Md. Auto Racing World - Alain Prost, France. Grand Prix (Detroit) - Keke Rosberg, Finland. U.S.A.C. Silver Crown - Rick Hood, Memphis. U.S.A.C. Sprint - Rick Hood. U.S.A.C. Midget - Mel Kenyon, Lebanon, Ind. I.M.S.A. Camel - Al Holbert, Warrington, Pa. Can-Am - Rick Miakiewicz, Littletown, Colo.

title: BOSTON POPS' DATE ON JULY 4 STIRS PRIDE AND DISMAY
description: The organizers of the Statue of Liberty rededication are planning their event as the perfect American celebration, a resplendent statue presiding over a harbor of tall ships on the Fourth of July next year, as the Boston Pops plays ''The Stars and Stripes Forever.''

title: Psychological Mysteries
description: To the Editor:

title: HONG KONG SAVORS ITS INTERLUDE
description: IT was lunchtime in one of this British colony's finest Chinese restaurants, a plushly carpeted aerie overlooking Victoria Harbor. Clear skies in the wake of the annual typhoons made for a picture-postcard view of junks and freighters and Navy frigates from the United States; behind them, grey-green mountains stretched into China.

title: Grandparents' Visits: Gains and Losses
description: Grandparents who have been denied visitation with their grandchildren should receive our understanding and support. The vitriolic generalizations of Barbara Lewandowski (''Grandparents, Grandchildren and The Law,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 1) lend heat but not light to a discussion of this complex problem.

title: BELLAMY PROFESSESNOT BITTERNES AFTER 8 YEARS AT CITY HALL
description: Carol Bellamy was relating a conversation she had just had with a friend about what it would be like to be out of government for the first time in 13 years. ''She said to me, 'I know you. You'll be depressed for one day, and then you'll repress it,' '' Miss Bellamy recalled. Her friend was no doubt right, she said. ''I guess,'' she suggested, ''I'm just not an extraordinarily reflective person.''

title: FOR ONCE, NO MESS
description: New Yorkers usually don't think much about their Sanitation Department unless it does something wrong. That's good reason to point out how it did something right.

title: TOPICS
description: THEY never told me it would be like this!

title: CONQUERING A SOFTWARE LAN
description: THE promise of the new zero-slot LAN's, or local area networks, is economy.

title: SOUTH AFRICA AND TV: THE COVERAGE CHANGES
description: Two months after the South African Government imposed sweeping restrictions on the press, the vivid television images of protest and violent suppression that many believe helped galvanize American sentiment on South Africa have become increasingly scarce.

title: Seeking a Slogan For Providence
description: WHAT can you say to capture the essence of a city that is America's costume jewelry center, has a seafaring history and may be the headquarters of organized crime in New England? In six words or less. That is the challenge posed by the Greater Providence Convention and Visitors Bureau, whose ''Put Providence in a Nutshell'' slogan contest has drawn nearly 7,000 entries.

title: Photo of William O. Douglas, Hugo L. Black, Earl Warren, Felix Frankfurter, Harold H. Burton, William J. Brennon Jr., Tom C. Clark, John M. Harlan and Charles E. Whittaker the members of the Supreme Court in 1957 (AP);   THE ARGUMENT MATTERED MOST
description: THE UNPUBLISHED OPINIONS OF THE WARREN COURT By Bernard Schwartz. 470 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: HOME FOR THE DISTURBED APPROVED DESPITE VILLAGE OPPOSITION
description: THE New York State Office of Mental Health has approved an agency's plan to house 10 mentally disturbed adults in Rockville Centre in spite of stiff opposition from village officials and senior citizens who live next door to the proposed site.

title: BIG PLAYERS IN 1985
description: THE elements were all there in '85 - big companies, big money and big changes. But as the takeover dramas unfolded, the spotlight centered on the cast of characters making the deals. And what a cast it was: a knight from Britain going after an American Crown; a bitter C.E.O. defeated by junk bonds; an oil-patch raider turned writer; a public-relations man so well-connected that his people sit on both sides of the negotiating table in the megadeals. And there were others. Here is a primer of big players from the Takeover Tales of '85.

title: BIG AND SMALL GIFTS FROM NEAR AND FAR SENT TO AID NEEDIEST
description: With gifts both large and small, New Yorkers and out-of-towners alike have contributed to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: THE SHUTTLE SEEMS SET TO DECLARE DIVIDENDS
description: Sometime late next summer or in early fall, if all goes well, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will launch a shuttle mission that could rank as the greatest scientific achievement thus far in the age of space travel. With the first large optical telescope to be sent into orbit, astronomers on the ground will look where no one has seen before, close to the edge of the universe, where things are as they were close to the beginning of time.

title: Mailbox;   Head Mightier Than the Fist
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SOLID JOURNALISM OUTSHONE TECHNICAL WIZARDRY
description: The news wasn't different in 1985; television was.

title: Raif Denktash Dies in Crash; Son of Turkish Cypriot Chief
description: Raif Denktash, son of the Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash, died Thursday night in Ankara, Turkey, of injuries sustained in a traffic accident, the official Turkish Cypriot radio reported Friday. He was 34 years old.

title: Tough Way To Finish
description: THIS is what the wild-card round is for: It makes money for the league, it gives people something to do during the holidays and it protects teams with good records who do not win their division title.

title: FRUIT OF THE SEA AND SAND
description: RELAXED after a holiday dinner, we have gathered before the living room hearth for a cordial. The firelight gives the translucent liquid in our glasses a festive glow of garnet tinted with orange. Although reminiscent of cherries, the tang of the liqueur is distinctive. As far as I know, this after-dinner treat cannot be bought in any store; it is a home brew made of beach plums.

title: RIVER BENEFITS
description: ''We seek applications and ideas which expand river access, public facilities and habitat repair,'' said Ross Sandler, executive director of the Hudson River Foundation, inviting applicants to apply for grants through the foundation's newest endowed program, the Hudson River Improvement Fund.

title: POUND AT 100: WEIGHING THE ART AND THE EVIL
description: THE date of this writing, 1985, is the 100th anniversary of Ezra Pound's birth.

title: HEARTBREAKER ON WHEELS
description: THE AMER-ican checking out of the Graf Zeppelin Hotel in Stuttgart was in his late 40's or early 50's and expensively dressed. He slid his American Express Gold Card back into his billfold, then turned and ran down the steps to the hotel's garage making ''Vroom, vroom, vroom!'' noises, pretending to shift gears at each landing. ''He's been out to pick up his Mercedes,'' said the cashier.

title: SOUP KITCHEN DISPUTE IS CALLED UNFORTUNATE
description: In reference to the Nov. 24 article ''Trenton Soup Kitchen a Focus of Controversy,'' I note the following:

title: NORTH CAROLINA (12-0) BREEZES PAST BROWN, 115-63
description: North Carolina's Brad Daugherty hit 11 of 16 field goal attempts and scored 26 points tonight as the Tar Heels romped past Brown, 115-63, to win the Orange Bowl basketball tournament. In the consolation game, Miami beat Manhattan, 79-61.

title: STARS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 3-1
description: The Rangers lost to the North Stars, 3-1, at the Met Center today, showing no offense early on and none late. And then after yet another of his new line formations and other innovations had failed, Ted Sator suggested what other Ranger head coaches before have said: that this hockey team does not do what hockey teams still have to do to win. That is, they do not play it rough and tough enough.

title: FACES THAT MOVE MOUNTAINS
description: Names make news, says the old saw, but a striking fact about the waning year is how often concern for private individuals determined the course of public events. Consider how much the world cared about the plight of ordinary, vulnerable people - people like Leon Klinghoffer, Yelena Bonner, Winnie Mandela.

title: SIX FOR '86: PICKING BLUE CHIP WINNERS
description: THIS has been a rewarding year for investors in blue-chip stocks. A prosaic strategy of buying the 30 issues in the Dow Jones industrial average brought a total return - appreciation plus dividends - of about 32 percent. Not surprisingly after such a performance, a number of analysts and fund managers who follow the bigger companies are finding reasons why the good times should continue to roll in 1986.

title: THE PROSPECT OF BIGGER TOWERS CAST A SHADOW
description: It has been a year in architecture filled less with the pleasure of built buildings than with the debate over unbuilt ones. If 1985 will be remembered for anything, it will be as the year in which a remarkable number of plans to alter the shape of New York were announced, almost all of which sparked considerable controversy. The most dramatic, surely, was the developer Donald Trump's plan to build a 150-story tower by the architect Helmut Jahn on the site of the Pennsylvania Railroad yards on the Upper West Side, part of a project called Television City that would also include six 76-story apartment towers, an office tower and television production facilities.

title: CAPTURING THE BEAUTY OF CAMERA
description: WINTER turns the mundane into high drama, making something out of nothing. After a snowfall, a tree stump wears a high white hat, and common objects turn into mysterious sculpture. Frost etches windows like a master artist.

title: Ethnic Strife
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel, Britain and Fortune
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LIGHT RETURNS TO AN OLD GARDEN
description: Archaeologists working near a 17th-century manor house in the Tidewater region of Virginia earlier this year thought they were excavating a 19th-century garden. But their test holes yielded shards of pottery and fragments of wine bottles more than 300 years old.

title: BUDGET AIDES URGE VARIOUS CUTBACKS AT PENTAGON IN '87
description: White House budget officials, under pressure from a new antideficit law, have urged President Reagan to cut back a scheduled military pay increase, payments to weapons companies for basic research and other Pentagon spending plans in the budget he will send Congress in February, Pentagon and other Administration officials say.

title: Texaco's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: THOSE WHO BREAK THE LAW BY BREAKING THEIR SILENCE
description: WHEN she left the courtroom last week after being charged with breaking official restrictions on her movements and behavior, Winnie Mandela procceded to violate another part of her ban. She talked to reporters.

title: Spring Wedding For Miss Cheney
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. Cheney of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Mitchell Cheney to Russell Lamont Creighton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Lamont Creighton of Delmar, N.Y. The wedding is planned for April.

title: TROUBLE WITH ARMENIANS
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, whose Brooklyn district contains more Jews than probably any other in the nation, says he is naturally sympathetic to the plight of persecuted people.

title: MARTHA VON BULOW'S CHILDREN TO RAISE MONEY FOR VICTIMS
description: Eleven friends of Martha (Sunny) von Bulow have joined her two children in raising money for a Providence organization to aid crime victims.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SCRAMBLE: A Narrative History of the Battle of Britain. By Norman Gelb. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) In July 1940, Nazi Germany, fresh from its conquest of France, sent the Luftwaffe into the skies of Britain.

title: TV HAS 'DISCOVERED' THEIR CITY, AND BOSTONIANS AREN'T SURE WHY
description: James Spinney was looking out of his office window the other day at the elegant 19th-century townhouses along Commonwealth Avenue when he saw two men with guns running down the street.

title: CABARET: RONNIE WHYTE
description: RONNIE WHYTE, the singer and pianist, is celebrating his 25th year in show business by making a rare appearance in New York with a drummer at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street. Although Mr. Whyte uses a drummer on his concert tours, New Yorkers have usually found him alone at the piano or with only the assistance of his bassist, Frank Tate.

title: THE BEST CHARITY: GIVE OF YOURSELF AND YOUR WALLET
description: IT was one of those dreary rainy afternoons that seem hours longer than they actually are.

title: OTHER CENTERS PLANNED
description: State health officials said last week that they planned to create 10 to 15 hospital-based AIDS centers, most of them in New York City, to emphasize hospice care and home services rather than heroic measures and long hospital stays. New regulations, to be proposed to the State Hospital Review and Planning Council next month, would offer financial incentives to the hospitals and would allow terminally ill AIDS victims to die with as much dignity as possible. The council, an independent advisory body within the State Health Department, was expected to adopt the proposal.

title: PARLAY VOO ANYTHING?
description: It's easy to feel stupid in a foreign country, even when you speak the language.

title: GROUP SEEKS ORDER FOR HOTELS TO PROVIDE ROOMS FOR HOMELESS
description: The Partnership for the Homeless has asked Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo to exercise emergency powers and order all non-luxury hotels in New York City to make rooms available to the city to shelter homeless families temporarily.

title: United Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANON: 10 YEARS OF WAR
description: The agreement today among Lebanese militia leaders came after 10 years of civil war. Here are some of the major events in a decade of fighting: 1975 - Fighting erupts in April after Christian gunmen ambush a busload of Palestinians in a Beirut suburb, killing 30 people. Cabinet resigns as fighting between Christians and Moslem-Palestinian alliance increases. 1976 - Christian forces overrun Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut in January, and Syrian troops intervene.

title: DEUS EX MACHINA? A SOBERING BARROOM VISITOR
description: The customers are mainly regulars who love that old bar across the street from the Belmont race track. But they don't all love that new machine in the bar.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Stranger Starring Orson Welles, Loretta Young, Edward G. Robinson, Richard Long; directed by Orson Welles, 1946 Prism Entertainment 95 minutes. $19.95 Curiously, many recent eulogies to Orson Welles bypassed this film - his brilliant Gothic thriller about a fugitive key Nazi posing as a college teacher in a New England village during World War II.

title: Retton an Adult
description: She was a gold-medal winner at the 1984 Summer Olympics and one of the most visible athletes in the country, but before Friday, Mary Lou Retton was legally a minor. Then a family district judge, Herman Gordon, granted adult status to the 17-year-old gymnast, giving her the right to make her own investments.

title: LEBANESE MILITIA CHIEFS SIGN PEACE PACT IN SYRIA
description: Leaders of Lebanon's rival militia forces signed a pact today designed to end a decade of sectarian warfare that has left tens of thousands of people dead and devastated a country that was once among the most prosperous in the Middle East.

title: Kathryn Mazzini To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Mazzini of San Anselmo, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn M. Mazzini to William D. Kerr 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kerr Jr. of Winnetka, Ill. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Arson Victims
description: JUST before Christmas last year, Mayor Koch read a newspaper account of a black couple who were living in a one-room studio in Harlem after a fire, attributed by the police to racially motivated arson, damaged a two-family home they had just purchased in the Morris Park section of the Bronx.

title: Condos For Flushing
description: The Union Terrace Condominium Residence, a 57-unit apartment building near the Main Street stop of the No. 7 IRT subway line in Flushing, Queens, is a new addition to a neighborhood of much larger and older projects.

title: WHOEVER DREAMED THAT UP?
description: His genius he was quite content In one brief sentence to define: Of inspiration one percent, Of perspiration, ninety-nine.

title: A LOCAL SOURCE FOR BROADWAY
description: WHETHER the state's regional theaters are actually Broadway tryout houses is by now a moot point. Broadway, with its ever-escalating costs, diminishing profits and paucity of product, can no longer be looked to as the Mecca of theater. And Off Broadway is not so far ahead in quality or behind in prices.

title: DO THEY KNOW IT'S CHRISTMAS?
description: OLD hatreds, and even older ones, made for a particularly bloody week in South Africa.

title: WIRING COMMUNITY ESTHETICS INTO CON ED SUBSTATIONS
description: AMONG the car dealerships and warehouses along 11th Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets is a structure with alternating brown and beige square bricks that give it the appearance of an open box of dipped chocolates. In fact, it is a $50 million addition to an existing Consolidated Edison substation - an example of the utility's efforts to blend its neighborhood power substations into their surroundings.

title: PHILADELPHIA FACING BIAS SUIT
description: The city underpays workers in occupations historically held by women, according to a lawsuit filed by a public employees' union in Federal District Court.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MOZART, WESTMORELAND, AND ME. By Marilyn Krysl. (Thunder's Mouth Press, Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95.) In a fictional preface to this collection, a couple in a dining car order artichokes but are brought instead ''the purple head of Quetzalcoatl on a tray.''

title: Western Samoa Leader Quits in Budget Impasse
description: Prime Minister Tofilau Eti Alesana resigned Friday after his Government's budget proposal for 1986 was rejected by Parliament.

title: JETS ROUTED FROM PLAYOFFS BY PATRIOTS, 26-14
description: The sure hands that helped carry the Jets to the American Conference wild-card playoff game were not so sure today.

title: HOUSTON HOTEL SALE SIGNIFIES FADING OF OIL WEALTH
description: Older Houstonians still talk about the dazzling night of March 17, 1949, when Glenn McCarthy, the wealthy wildcatter, threw a blowout party to open his new Shamrock Hotel.

title: SCHOOL BOARD CHIDED IN NEWSPAPER CASE
