description: Re the article ''Paper in a Dispute With School Board'' [Nov. 24] : I must take exception to Professor Jasen's designation of The South Shore Record's attitude as ''unreasonable'' for a local weekly. Would it be more reasonable if the paper were The Washington Post or any other prominent newspaper?

title: 2 in Critical Condition After Concert Clashes
description: Two men remained in critical condition at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday after eight incidents of shooting and stabbing during and after a ''rap'' music concert Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: BOARD CUTS TAX RISE IN BUDGET TO 8.8%
description: THe Westchester County Board of Legislators fulfilled its pledge to taxpayers last week, trimming County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed 1986 budget from an 11.1 percent increase to ''single digits,'' 8.8 percent in fact. The only argument among Board members was how severely to cut the spending plan.

title: WHY PEACE WAS HELL
description: PATTON The Man Behind the Legend 1885-1945. By Martin Blumenson. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: PRESIDENT MARCOS IS JUDGE AND JURY TOO
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos likes to refer to Abraham Lincoln when he talks about the extra-judicial powers of arrest and detention he has arrogated to himself. ''After Fort Sumter, he arrested some people,'' Mr. Marcos remarked the other day.

title: Parking Tickets By Computer
description: SIX years ago, Lester Shafran wrote an article for a law journal suggesting the idea of a hand-held, computerized parking-summons machine. If all goes well, come May Mr. Shafran, now director of the city's Parking Violations Bureau, will introduce the first models of the Summons Issuing Device of New York - Sidny for short.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE LIQUOR BUSINESS
description: FOR years, the liquor business has suffered the slings and arrows of critics who blame society's ills on Demon Rum. But it is only recently that drinkers have seemed to agree. The Distilled Spirits Council of the United States says that combined wholesale and retail sales of liquor fell 1.2 percent in 1984, the third straight year of decline.

title: O'NEILL MAY HAVE HIS HANDS FULL
description: THE 1986 elections in Connecticut may finally tell whether the sweeping gains scored by the state's Republicans in 1984 were just a fluke or signaled the beginning of a major realignment of political power.

title: CELEBRATING THE BIRTH OF A DANCE PIONEER
description: Annabelle Gamson is a choreographer in her own right. But she has become known as a solo dancer who brought back to life the works of the modern dance pioneers Mary Wigman and Isadora Duncan. And she will begin the new year by celebrating Wigman's birth with a program that opens on Wednesday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: ENVIRONMENT: ASSESSMENTS OF YEAR VARY FROM B+ to C-
description: FOR Robert E. Hughey, the outgoing Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, ''The Year of the Environment'' was ''a very good year.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Theology of Nakedness Medieval theologians took an almost sinful pleasure in fine distinctions and classificatory lists. In ''Monuments & Maidens: The Allegory of the Female Form'' (Atheneum), Marina Warner gives a medieval reading of the nakedness of the legendary Lady Godiva.

title: OUR REFUGEE POLICY IS ON TRIAL IN SANCTUARY CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: The Perils of Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: WORKS OF AMERICAN FOLK ART ARE SHOWN IN STAMFORD
description: AN exhibit of folk art, considered to be one of the largest assembled in the state in recent years and ranging from portraits of 34 Presidents to quilts and wooden decoys, is on display in Stamford.

title: I. M. Pei's Pyramid
description: The controversy over I. M. Pei's pyramid brings to mind another famous fuss in Paris.

title: U.S. TESTS A LASER DRIVEN BY H-BOMB
description: The Federal Government, despite objections from 30 members of Congress, yesterday carried out a major nuclear weapon test related to President Reagan's antimissile defense program.

title: A DEGREE OF IRONY
description: In one respect tournament bridge in the United States differs from the rest of the world: There are no corporate sponsors. In Europe major events usually have one or more such contributors, providing cash prizes and paying other expenses, and it is not uncommon for expert teams to be sponsored. On this side of the Atlantic the American Contract Bridge League succeeds in financing its tournaments from entry fees and master-point income. Sponsorship is limited to the hiring of professionals by individuals.

title: AGREEMENT SOUGHT IN YONKERS
description: LAWYERS for the Federal Government, the city of Yonkers and its Board of Education plan to meet tomorrow to discuss ways to desegregate the city's public schools and public housing. It will be the first time in more than a year that the parties involved in the landmark civil rights case have met in an attempt to reach an accord on the housing and school-desegregation issue.

title: TONI MORRISON TRIES HER HAND AT PLAYWRITING
description: When Toni Morrison, author of the best seller ''Tar Baby'' and winner of a National Book Critics award for ''Song of Solomon,'' accepted the Albert Schweitzer Professorship of the Humanities at the State University of New York at Albany, she expected to lead the proverbially quiet life of an academic - teaching writing and writing fiction. Instead she found herself deeply involved in the theater, as a playwright.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SURVEY OF MODERN ART A survey of American modern art telescoped into 50 works will be on exhibit until Jan. 12 at the Yale University Art Gallery, 111 Chapel Street, New Haven. The items are from the collection of Richard Brown Baker, a 1935 Yale alumnus whose career was in the United States State Department but whose avocation was in the purchasing of art by ''the living, the young and the unestablished,'' according to the gallery publicity.

title: Miss Sias Bride Of Eric C. Witte
description: Helena Thorpe Sias, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barnes Sias of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Eric Crosman Witte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Turner Witte of Ottawa Hills, Ohio. The Rev. Theodore Hoskins and Justice of the Peace Edwin Kingsley Dimes performed the ceremony at the Saugatuck Congregational Church.

title: Surgeons Reattach Toes of 5-Year-Old
description: Rebecca Glasper, 5 years old, lost two right toes after her foot became stuck in a department store escalator, but doctors reattached them, officials said today.

title: Sarah White Engaged to W. M. Merck
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Mattocks White Jr. of Manchester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Knox White to Wilhelm Morgan Merck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Wall Merck of Mendham, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Corporate Role In Health Care
description: The Dec. 1 article [''New Effort Seeks to Insure Quality of Psychiatric Care''] by David Hechler describing the cost-containment efforts of companies such as Preferred Health Care is important in that it brings to the attention of the consumer the inherent pressures being placed on physicians in their care of patients. Physicians are treading an ever-more tenuous line between maintaining proper care of their patients and responding to powerful economic incentives to cut costs.

title: Susan Marder to Wed David S. Zelouf in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Barbara Sand Marder of Scarsdale, N.Y., and John G. Marder of New York and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Beth Marder to David S. Zelouf, the son of Betty Zelouf of East Northport, L.I., and Victor Zelouf of Manila. The wedding is planned for November.

title: BRINGING SCULPTURE TO THE OFFICE SETTING
description: THE nights grow long, the air grows cold, but all is not desolate in the landscape. Corporate country, in the past often bleak and sterile, is now peopled and bright. Christmas lights sparkle in the trees along Westchester Avenue, and in the Schulman company's office parks, groups of bronzed and silent figures evoke a sense of human warmth long after the last vice-president has gone home to his fireside.

title: TOPICS
description: WHEN I picked up the phone, the operator asked the now familiar question:

title: VIOLINIST TO PLAY IN SYMPHONY SERIES
description: FOR ITS first series of the new year, Saturday through Jan. 19, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will have as its soloist the violinist Elmar Oliveira.

title: ICE DRIVING SHARPENS SKILLS
description: Winter is the time of year when most auto racers go into hibernation, retiring to heated workshops to tinker with their cars while waiting impatiently for the spring thaw that signals the start of the next racing season. But in the frost belt, from New England through upstate New York and into the upper Middle West, there is one hardy breed of motor sports enthusiasts - the ice racer - that greets the plunging thermometer with an almost perversely eager enthusiasm.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Legal Notes column last Sunday about a robbery case misattributed a quotation from Shakespeare. It was Iago in ''Othello,'' not Polonius in ''Hamlet,'' who said, ''Who steals my purse steals trash.''

title: KOREAN BUSINESS GAINING IN STATE
description: KOREANS are relative newcomers among foreign companies with subsidiaries in New Jersey.

title: CALLER'S CHOICE
description: Outfits like Chargit and Telecharge that sell theater tickets by phone are a boon to New Yorkers who hate waiting on lines, but to reserve by phone is to take one's chances on seat location. The phone services offer only the vague promise of ''best available seats'' in each price category.

title: PARTYING
description: THE girl wants in. She skulks on the edges, hovers on the stairs, lingers just outside the door of the club.

title: I. M. Pei's Pyramid
description: There are two significant points regarding the I. M. Pei pyramid for the Louvre that were not mentioned in Richard Bernstein's article (''I. M. Pei's Pyramid,'' Nov. 24). Whether one rejoices at Mr. Pei's simple, bold design solution or deprecates his high-tech intrusion amid historic architecture, there is indeed an underlying link.

title: COMMUNITY CARE FOR MENTALLY ILL HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LOVES OF HARRY DANCER. By Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, Paper, $3.95.) The admirers of Lawrence Sanders' ''Deadly Sin'' novels, featuring that estimable retired chief of detectives Edward X. Delaney, are in for a surprise.

title: Floridians to Vote On Casino Gambling
description: Florida voters will decide next November if casino gambling will be permitted in the state.

title: PLAYING WITH APOCALYPSE
description: THE DAY STARTED like most days at the National Security Council. I first scanned the intelligence reports for any urgent items: coups d'etat, major military actions, unexpected crises. Next, I searched for odd signs and portents, the cloud on the horizon. There it was: Russian military advisers were being sent to Argentina - our hemisphere, our sphere of influence. The act had to be challenged. The Soviet reply was swift and unsatisfactory. A stiff response was essential. In the next move, I blew up the world.

title: Learning Winter Camping Skills
description: ONE need not - although the temptation may be substantial - retreat from woods and mountains when they are in winter's harsh embrace.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:53 A.M. today and set at 9:46 P.M. tonight.

title: THE GREENING OF AN AD MAN-ARTIST
description: ''RIGHT now,'' said David S. Terrell of West Babylon, ''we are at our busiest time of the year because a large number of our clients are involved in audio and loudspeakers. A massive consumer electronics show is coming up in Las Vegas Jan. 4.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WRITING FOR KIDS By Carol Lea Benjamin. Illustrated. 102 pp. Harper & Row.

title: RATS AT POND VEX 2 VILLAGES
description: WILLOW POND - which attracts Canada geese, mallard ducks and occasional egrets - is also enticing Norway rats. And local officials say the infestation of rats and other small animals has become a problem all over Nassau County.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MERRY GENTLEMEN (AND ONE LADY). By J. Bryan 3d. (Atheneum, $17.95.) J. Bryan 3d, a writer and former magazine editor, is surely one of the luckiest of mortals, for the doings of some of his friends from the 1920's through the 70's reads like an informal history of 20th-century American humor.

title: CHAMBER GROUP BRANCHES OUT
description: THE Fairfield Chamber Orchestra, which has been enjoying such popularity that it now has two subscription series, has recently added another office, too.

title: CHINESE STUDENTS PROTEST ANEW
description: China in the 80's may not be much like America in the 60's, but it is proving far different from China in the 70's. Last weekend, for example, Peking witnessed its third student protest since mid-September.

title: Lynette Perlman Is the Bride of Steven C. Koppel
description: Lynette Perlman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Perlman of Mobile, Ala., was married yesterday to Steven C. Koppel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Koppel of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York.

title: Q and A
description: Question:If weather conditions are normal, in which week in April are the cherry trees in Japan likely to be in full flower? We will be in Tokyo, Nikko, Kamakura, Hakone, Atami and Kyoto. - J. M. D., Milwaukee Answer:The cherry blossoms in the Tokyo area are generally at their peak during the first week in April. The cherry blossom festival events held at the city's Yasukuni Shrine usually continue until the middle of the month. Many Tokyo families pack a picnic lunch for visits to the Ueno and Meiji parks and Shinjuku Gyoen Garden in Tokyo during blossom time. Going to these places at night when the trees are illuminated is also popular. A cherry blossom report for various parts of the country, in English, can be obtained by telephoning the Tourist Information Center in Tokyo (502-1461).

title: ''NIGHT, MOTHER': UNIVERSAL TRUTHS
description: THE Studio Theater in Lindenhurst has developed a reputation for producing contemporary plays with challenging themes. This is the theater that provided us with the controversial ''Bent'' and the sterling production of ''Agnes of God.'' Although its last few productions have missed the mark, its choice of plays has continued to enhance the Studio's excellent reputation.

title: HOTEL NEAR TIMES SQUARE CLOSES ROOMS FOR HOMELESS TO CATER TO TOURISTS
description: The Hotel Carter near Times Square - a welfare hotel at war with the city inspectors - has sharply reduced the number of homeless families it shelters and is making attempts to attract tourists once again.

title: TEAM FINDS FREEDOM, LIMITS IN THE N.A.I.A.
description: JAMES Carter laughs when he thinks of his first weeks at St. Thomas Aquinas College. Though only 20 minutes north of the George Washington Bridge, the school may as well have been in Nebraska to a young man who grew up in Jamaica, Queens.

title: TRUST TERRITORIES
description: The Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia and Palau are names with which United States collectors will want to become familiar. Each is part of the United States Trust Territory of the Pacific administered under United Nations auspices since 1947. For collectors, each territory issues stamps that fall within the sphere of the ''back-of-the-book.'' This is the section of United States catalogues and albums that follows the regular, commemorative and airmail issues.

title: Mums on Yukica
description: Joe Yukica, the Dartmouth football coach whose dismissal was overturned by a judge last week, met for nearly an hour yesterday with the school's athletic council. But the council voted not to tell the public anything about what happened during the seven-and-a-half-hour session, leaving Yukica's status uncertain, said Alex Huppe, a college spokesman.

title: Pop Music
description: Clifton Chenier, the king of zydeco music, returns Sunday and Monday nights to the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue at 13th Street. After three decades of making records, he is still the unparalleled master of zydeco, the hottest dance music on the ''crawfish circuit'' along the Gulf Coast of Texas and Louisiana. Zydeco (the name is probably derived from ''haricots,'' or snap beans) is a hybrid of blues, country, rhythm-and-blues, rock and, of course, Cajun waltzes and two-steps; it rolls as much as it rocks, and its tootling beat will be familiar to anyone who's heard the Talking Heads' ''Road to Nowhere'' or Dire Straits' ''The Walk of Life.''

title: LIGHTS OUT
description: When Christmas trees were made by nature and decorated by loving parents, they remained in an urban home until their needles fell.

title: VILLAGE SCENES FROM THE PAST
description: IF you are looking for something to do with the children between now and the reopening of school, Johnsonville, a restored Victorian village in the heart of East Haddam, offers glimpses of the holidays as they were celebrated in the 19th century.

title: MR. TRUMP: BUILD IN NEWARK
description: MR. DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, THE TRUMP ORGANIZATION, NEW YORK, N.Y. DEAR MR. TRUMP: Your plan to develop almost 100 acres on Manhattan's Upper West Side has stirred the imagination of urban aficionados everywhere. Its proposed shopping centers, television studios, parks and housing exemplify New York's preeminence and your role as ''the master builder.''

title: BELLAMY'S BILL FOR STAFF'S LOST TIME
description: Carol Bellamy may not have intended to leave a scorched trail on her departure from city government, but last week Mayor Koch seemed determined to scorch it for her. The Mayor said on Christmas Eve that he planned an audit to determine how much the city was owed for the unauthorized day off the City Council President gave some of her staff members last January in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday.

title: NAME THAT CAR
description: In a letter in the current issue of Smithsonian magazine, William B. Farnsworth of Wellesley Hills, Mass., suggests that car makers could be a bit more imaginative in naming their models. His proposals include the Lincoln Nebraska, the Chevy Chase, the Pontiac Pilate and, perhaps the best, the Saab Sister.

title: WEALTH OF OFFERINGS STARTS '86
description: HONORS for the earliest concert of the new year would seem to go to Westport's Friends of Music.

title: POST-PARTY PAIN CAN BE AVOIDED
description: HOLIDAYS are a time for merriment, but for some people, it is also the season for throbbing headaches, said a Greenwich expert on head pain.

title: DEMOCRATS HOPE TO HAVE BETTER ANSWERS THIS TIME
description: One year after their triumph in the 1984 elections, President Reagan and Congressional Republicans appear to have lost much of the strategic high ground from which they had kept Democrats pinned down. Republicans, says Kevin Phillips, a highly regarded G.O.P. analyst, have entered a period ''where they are going to be managing the political down side of Reaganomics.''

title: A LEADING THEATRICAL AGENT
description: Audrey Wood, the doyenne of theatrical agents, who represented many of America's leading playwrights, died Friday at the Carrolton Nursing Home in Fairfield, Conn. She was 80 years old and had been in a coma since suffering a stroke in 1981.

title: MUSSELS
description: MUSSELS ARE, TO MY TASTE, ONE OF THE grandest-flavored morsels to come from the sea. And yet in the books that line my reference shelves, they seem to occupy a curious position in the modern history of food in Britain and America. I own a facsimile of the first edition of ''The Boston Cooking-School Cook Book,'' published in 1896, that subsequently became the bible of home cooks in this country. There is one brief mention of mussels: ''Mussels, eaten in England and other parts of Europe, are similar to oysters, though of inferior quality.'' I also own a 1930 edition of that masterpiece, edited, of course, by Fannie Merritt Farmer, and mussels are omitted altogether. I own a facsimile of the first edition of Mrs. Beeton's remarkable English work, ''The Book of Household Management,'' with hundreds of recipes, not one of which mentions mussels. The good news is that time has altered these concepts, and mussels are found in abundance in American waters. Now, they are prized as one of the ultimate seafoods, both in this country and in England, and they are in such demand they are now imported from Irish and New Zealand waters.

title: GETTING RID OF THE BURDEN OF SENSE
description: SELECTED POEMS By John Ashbery. 349 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $22.95.

title: FREE TRADE AND THE CANADIAN PSYCHE
description: ONE of the most contentious subjects in Canadian history, this country's economic relations with the United States, has re-emerged as a major issue as a result of Ottawa's attempt to open negotiations with Washington on free trade. Earlier this month, President Reagan responded to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's initiative by asking Congress to approve talks with Canada, a process likely to last more than two years and touch on every phase of one of the world's most developed and complicated economic relationships.

title: 49ERS ROGER CRAIG: A HARD-WORKING RECORD BREAKER
description: IT was a typical Roger Craig moment. Late in the third quarter of last Sunday's game against Dallas, Craig took a short pass from Joe Montana at the left sideline, turned upfield, gained 15 yards, tossed the ball aside and jogged back to the 49ers' huddle without the slightest show of emotion.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany has been named World Player of the Year by Golf Digest magazine. The 28-year-old won tournaments on four continents in 1985, including the Masters, the German Open, the Australian Masters, the European Open, and the Million Dollar Challenge in Africa. . . . The owner of the Atlanta Falcons, Rankin Smith Sr., will not seek an outside replacement for Eddie LeBaron, who was let go last Monday as the club's chief operating officer and executive vice president.

title: A SHAKESPEAREAN MYSTERY DEEPENS
description: Gary Taylor, the Elizabethan scholar who last month found a poem attributed to William Shakespeare in a library at Oxford University, may have been correct in his identification of the author, but he erred when he said no copy of the work existed in any major American library. Last week, a curator of rare manuscripts at Yale University said he had found the poem in a collection of verse from the 1630's.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 29, 1985 Fiction

title: A CORRECTION
description: In an article last week about health care for Newark's homeless, the name of the director of the city's Department of Health and Welfare was misspelled and the amount of a state grant to Newark was misstated.

title: CASINO TO OFFER'HIGH ROLLER' PRIVILEGES TO ALL
description: The Claridge, an unprofitable casino that needs business, is extending to all table players the complimentary rooms, food, drinks and theater tickets that casinos regularly offer big bettors.

title: Margit Susan Kildahl Weds William L. Burmeister
description: At the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Margit Susan Kildahl, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Kildahl of Scarsdale, was married to William Lewis Burmeister, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Burmeister of Naugatuck, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Gerard R. Gaeta, assisted by the Rev. Jane Gaeta, his wife, performed the ceremony.

title: Mailbox;   The Jets' Fans Are Different
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BROADCAST BRINGS FLORIDIANS NEWS OF SON'S DEATH
description: Einar R. Maland, a retired Brooklyn bank executive, his wife and his sister were watching a television newscast on Friday in the den of their white bungalow outside Tampa, Fla.

title: A. Steven Leondis Marries Lynn Palone, Law Student
description: Lynn A. Palone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent A. Palone of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to A. Steven Leondis, a son of Agnese Leondis of Massapequa, L.I., and the late Anthony Leondis.

title: BIG BROTHER AND ANTI-DRINKING LAWS
description: AS a Long Island parent of teen-age children, I resent the untoward turn our zeal to reduce drunken driving appears to be taking. While I understand and sympathize with the motivation for the restrictions confronting our children, it offends me to see their rights so summarily curtailed.

title: GRATEFUL SKIPPER TO RENAME BOAT
description: Richard Konkolski defected from Czechoslovakia in 1982 to join the BOC Challenge, a singlehanded sailboat race around the world. He finished the race in the spring of 1983, third in his class. Now he wants to do it again. But this time, much has changed.

title: WHEN MOVIEW BEGAN AND NO ONE CAME
description: Ninety years ago, Auguste and Louis Lumiere's father, Antoine, erected a wooden sign marked ''cinematographe'' with an arrow pointing down to the basement of Paris's Grand Cafe, 14 Boulevard des Capucines.

title: LAWYERS FOR POOR SEEK MORE WELFARE FUNDS
description: AS HOMELESS people here began taking the first halting steps toward organizing themselves, lawyers representing poor families across New Jersey filed petitions with the state's Department of Human Services earlier this month in the hope of acquiring significant increases in welfare benefits.

title: WELFARE HOTELS DUNNED FOR TAXES
description: Caught in a roundup of New York City landlords who allegedly have failed to pay bills they owe the city were 16 of the 55 hotels that collect millions of public dollars to house homeless families, city officials disclosed last week.

title: Ellen Koloski Marries Russell Edward Boyle
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., yesterday Ellen Joyce Koloski, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Koloski of Poughkeepsie, was married to Russell Edward Boyle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher G. Boyle of Tucson, Ariz. The Rev. John T. Kearney performed the ceremony.

title: THE PUNISHING COSTS OF FIXING OIL PRICES
description: AS 1986 rolls in, we all have something to be thankful for: OPEC is history. And as the cartel crumbles, it is becoming clear that it never really controlled the world crude oil market. Rather, market forces were the dominant factor all along, although this was obscured by events.

title: SKIING IN MAINE, TAKING THE TRAIN IN BRITAIN
description: On the Slopes At Sugarloaf While Sun Valley in Idaho is celebrating its 50th anniversary as a ski resort this winter, the East will be doing a little celebrating, too, as 35 years of skiing are marked at Sugarloaf Mountain in the town of Carrabassett Valley in Maine. Among the highlights of festivities at the complex (55 trails covering 40 miles) will be White, White World Week, a carnival scheduled for Jan. 26 to 31.

title: CAN SEX SELL LIQUOR? SURE SEEMS SO
description: IN one magazine ad for Hennessey cognac, a woman in the briefest of bikinis dips her toe into the corner of a swimming pool, almost brushing up against a man, in a similarly scanty costume, who is sitting cross-legged by the pool. Behind them is pitch blackness, the only light coming from the pool. Both are holding brandy snifters of amber liquid. In the lower righthand corner of the ad is a small bottle of Hennessey beside a snifter of cognac on the rocks.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Football San Francisco 49ers vs. Giants, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. The Giants, in their first home playoff game in 23 years, are hosts to the defending Super Bowl champions in the National Conference wild-card playoff game.

title: CLASSICS TOOK ON NEW LIFE IN NEW FORMATS
description: The year in records was as much a story of business and marketing as of music. This was a year of reissues - not just of more and more analog recordings onto compact disk, most notably the Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer, Fritz Reiner and Ernest Ansermet series, but of endless recyclings of analog material onto inexpensive budget labels. Sometimes, it seemed that the companies were so busy squeezing their catalogues, extracting the last possible juice from their analog warehouses, that they had relatively less time for new releases.

title: NEW PACKAGING FOR OLD PRODUCTS
description: EVER since the mid-1950's, when Hiram Walker Inc. began shipping Canadian Club whiskey trussed up for Christmas, makers and marketers of distilled spirits have felt obligated to gift-wrap their products for the holidays. ''Actually, the industry would like not to have to do it,'' said George Hanover, packaging coordinator for National Distillers Products Company, ''but everybody's afraid not to.''

title: True Virtue
description: At first, I quite enjoyed Joseph Epstein's attack on the ''virtucrats'' (''True Virtue,'' Nov. 24).

title: TRANSIT AGENCY PREPARES FOR NEW YEAR
description: Reduced fares - but no free rides - will be offered New Year's Eve by NJ Transit, which also will put on extra buses and trains to handle the expected throngs of party-goers.

title: THE POINT OF THE PRIZE
description: To The Editor:

title: True Virtue
description: Joseph Epstein's discomfort with the idealistic orientation of the 1960's generation and his intense dislike of their political favorite, Senator Gary Hart, is understandable. Mr. Hart's popular appeal lay precisely in his fidelity to the spirit of pragmatic idealism and affirmative national stewardship manifested by past Democratic statesmen, such as Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy.

title: KEAN TELS TEACHERS CHANGE WILL COME
description: ''YOU'RE going to hear back some of the things that went on today,'' Governor Kean promised as he ended the formal portion of an unusual meeting at Kean College that brought him together with the state's educational-policy leaders and 15 teachers to discuss a wide-ranging array of issues.

title: Canadiens Crush Devils Again, 8-3
description: Mike McPhee had up a hat trick and an assist tonight to lead the surging Montreal Canadiens to an 8-3 victory over the Devils.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STORMY GENIUS: The Life of Aviation's Maverick, Bill Lear. By Richard Rashke. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) At 24 years of age, William P. Lear was broke.

title: FICTION ON NEWSPRINT
description: THE AVAILABLE PRESS/PEN SHORT STORY COLLECTION With an introduction by Anne Tyler. 502 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $8.95.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE long debate over where to store low-level radioactive waste has only seven more years to run, thanks to an act of Congress. Shortly before its Christmas adjournment, the Senate passed and sent to President Reagan legislation extending until Jan. 1, 1993, the deadline for establishing disposal facilities. The deadline under the current law, enacted in 1980, was this Wednesday.

title: MODERN MASTERS AND VIEWS OF WAR HELD CENTER STAGE
description: The major figure of 1985 in photography was Andre Kertesz, whose seven decades of picture taking ended just as his achievements were being amply celebrated with a major museum show. Having insisted for years that his work had never received its due, Kertesz died while the exhibition, ''Andre Kertesz: Of Paris and New York,'' was wending its way from the Art Institute of Chicago to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The show opened here two weeks ago and, like many an Oscar-winning movie, it arrived just in time to garner honors as the year's best.

title: ROCKVILLE CENTRE AND ITS HOMES
description: Writing from the exquisitely intimate and knowledgeable perspective as a homeowner of 41 years in Rockville Centre, I should like to provide some very cogent and additional insights as to the rationale behind ''Rockville Centre Proposing an Owner-Occupancy Rule'' [Dec. 8] .

title: Sun Guard Sues
description: The Phoenix Suns guard Walter Davis has filed suit against two Los Angeles Laker team physicians and the clinic they work for, charging he received negligent treatment when injured in a 1984 exhibition game. The suit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court, cites negligence and medical malpractice by an unnamed representative of the clinic who diagnosed and treated the injury.

title: A FULL YEAR'S WORTH OF ART
description: TWO calendars that have become well known for being more than just ways to mark the passage of time will be celebrating milestones of their own with their 1986 issues.

title: Afghans Free 2 Australians Seized by Baluchi Tribesmen
description: The Afghan Government has released an Australian couple kidnapped by Baluchi tribesmen in Pakistan last May and taken to Afghanistan, the Australian Embassy said here today.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: JOHN F. BOYNE is looking for people with a special gift to give: a gift for parenting certain kinds of children.

title: IT'S A BIRD, A PLANE -- NO, IT'S A DEAL MAKER
description: ''What would you like to do when you graduate?'' I ask one of my best students.

title: YEAR AHEAD: PROSPECTS AND PROBLEMS
description: AS the end of 1985 approached, the Long Island Weekly section asked a random selection of prominent Long Island residents to look ahead to the new year and to offer their hopes and expectations for the Island in 1986. Here are their replies:

title: WHAT DO I HEAR FOR THESE FOUR POWER PLANTS?
description: The Reagan Administration's philosophical bent and its budgetary needs are coming together again in a proposal, reported last week, to sell the Bonneville Power Administration and three similar agencies.

title: Philadelphians Plan a Renovation
description: PRIVATE investors are planning to develop a major black cultural district in a blighted section of northern Philadelphia.

title: COLLECTION OF TAVERN SIGNS ON VIEW
description: ABOUT 1920, when he began searching for early tavern signs, Morgan B. Brainard did not do it because he wanted to collect a particular kind of antique or folk art - a descriptive term not in use then. The signs were important for their historical value, Mr. Brainard believed - they were tangible reminders of a way of life that had ended.

title: BRINGING THE GOSPEL TO BOHEMIA
description: BLOOMSBURY/FREUD The Letters of James and Alix Strachey 1924-1925. Edited by Perry Meisel and Walter Kendrick. Illustrated. 360 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95.

title: QUALITY AND RARITY SET THE TONE
description: Exotic and extraordinary works - medieval and tribal jewelry, Cartier mystery clocks and a rare copy of the Statue of Liberty - were among the antiques and 20th-century decorative arts that were shown in museums and galleries and pursued by collectors throughout 1985.

title: BREAKING THEIR SILENCE
description: THE DREAM BOOK An Anthology of Writings by Italian American Women. Edited with an introduction by Helen Barolini. 397 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $19.95.

title: FLY AMANITA
description: Amanita muscaria Size: Cap, three to eight inches wide; stalk, two to seven inches tall.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: VANES IN GREENWICH A trotting horse has taken up residence in the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., and so have an Indian, a grasshopper, a fish, an eagle on a ball and other images in metal or wood.

title: THE YEAR'S BEST EATING
description: DURING this season of hearty eating, it seems somewhat self-destructive to be recapitulating (and savoring in absentia) the best dining experiences of the past year. One should, instead, be thinking sober thoughts about diet spas, exercise programs and similar wholesome things.

title: EDWARD F. LEVY
description: Edward F. Levy, a lawyer and past president of the Society of American Magicians, died of a heart attack Friday in his home in Yonkers.

title: 3 Westchester Youths Arrested in Vandalism
description: Three teen-agers have been arrested in connection with a rash of vandalism in the Westchester County town of Greenburgh since November.

title: 35 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 35 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: MIDEAST ATTACK AND REPLY
description: A note carried by one of the gunmen in the airport attack in Rome indicated that the assault and the one at the Vienna airport were part of a cycle of attack and reprisal in the Middle East in recent months. Here are the key events in this string of attacks: Sept. 25 - A Briton and two Palestinians commandeer a yacht moored in the harbor of Larnaca, Cyprus, and kill the three Israelis aboard.

title: Miranda Spivack Engaged to Wed
description: Miranda Sheila Spivack, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Hartford Courant covering legal and regulatory issues, and Stephen Robert Herm, director of the field organizing/support department of the National Federation of Federal Employees in Washington, plan to be married Feb. 16.

title: THOREAU LEGACY: 3 'WALDEN' HOUSES
description: CONCORD, Mass. - ''The future inhabitants of this region,'' wrote Henry David Thoreau in ''Walden,'' ''wherever they may place their houses, may be sure that they have been anticipated.''

title: ONCE AGAIN, THEATER WAS A PLACE FOR WONDER
description: After feasting on Sam Shepard's new play, ''A Lie of the Mind,'' one may find it difficult to be pessimistic about the American theater of 1985.

title: CASINO CUTTING ITS COSTS
description: BUSINESS at the Atlantis Hotel-Casino here has been so slow at some hours lately that a visitor encounters more employees than gamblers.

title: Hormel Pact Rejected In Unofficial Balloting
description: Union meatpackers at Geo. A. Hormel & Company rejected a proposed contract that would end their four-month walkout, union officials said Friday after two days of unofficial balloting.

title: Winds Lash Great Lakes; Midwest Travel Snarled
description: Rescuers on Lake Michigan braved the wind and cold yesterday to search for three men presumed drowned after a fishing boat sank, and drifting snow continued to make travel hazardous throughout the Middle West.

title: AUSTRIA WILL TRY 2 GUNMEN FOR MURDER
description: Two gunmen who were involved in the attack on passengers waiting to board an El Al airliner at the Vienna airport on Friday will be tried on murder charges, Austrian officials said today.

title: The Famine Workers
description: Clifford May's article was informative in pointing out some of the errors made by African governments, but it did not tell the whole story. He might also have mentioned such factors as: the planting of cash crops instead of food crops (for export to the United States and European markets); ill-planned development schemes concocted by economic ''advisers'' for East and West; and huge-scale dam projects promoted by international development organizations (and, in particular, the World Bank) that have contributed to degradation of the environment and the spread of water-borne diseases.

title: Woman Slain in Shop; Her Husband Is Sought
description: A 26-year-old woman was shot to death yesterday at the West Side thrift shop where she worked, the police said. A co-worker who came to her aid was wounded.

title: Marcie Jacobs Married To John S. Pregulman
description: Marcie Ann Jacobs, the daughter of Mrs. Martin Loeb of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Spencer Pregulman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin Pregulman of Chattanooga, Tenn. Rabbi Maurice Denis performed the ceremony at the Fenway Country Club in White Plains.

title: FRENCH FINESSE IN GREAT NECK
description: ONE glance at the pastries on display in the retail area of Gourmandise, a new restaurant, cafe and catering shop in Great Neck, and you could be in some arrondissement instead of on Middle Neck Road.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: MILK. Written and illustrated by Donald Carrick. Greenwillow. $11.75. (Ages 3 to 6) The title may be laconic, but this is a very elegant picture book about dairy farming and how milk gets from cow to cup.

title: Christina Dillenbeck to Marry in May
description: The engagement of Christina Voth Dillenbeck and Richard Sands Wood has been announced by her parents, Suzanne V. Dillenbeck of Locust Valley, L.I., and Richard R. Dillenbeck of Summit, N.J. Her fiance is a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Hubert S. Wood Jr. of Johnson City, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: WHEN LOW AIR FARES PLAY HARD TO GET
description: Perhaps the greatest fare war in American aviation history is in progress on certain highly competitive routes. It can involve considerable annoyance for travelers, however, and substantial penalties for changing one's mind.

title: KEY WEST
description: Key West is suffering from growing pains, and there are some who fear that continued development will turn it into a sea of expensive condominiums that blot out the sunsets and cut off access to public beaches.

title: 9 Tanzanians Get Life For Roles in Failed Coup
description: Eight army officers and one civilian were sentenced today to life imprisonment for conspiring to overthrow President Julius K. Nyerere in December 1982.

title: Lauren I. Facher Engaged to Wed Harold N. Iselin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin L. Facher of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lauren Ilene Facher to Harold N. Iselin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan V. Iselin of Albany. A March wedding is planned.

title: OUR REFUGEE POLICY IS ON TRIAL IN SANCTUARY CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: EGYPTIAN OFFICER IS GIVEN LIFE TERM
description: An Egyptian border policeman who ran amok in Sinai, shooting and killing seven Israeli tourists, four of them children, was sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labor today.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HENNY AND PATTI The comedian Henny Youngman and the singer Patti Page will give two shows New Year's Eve at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: THE MERITS OF RARITY
description: Logic suggests that rare coins should be worth more than common ones. In today's market, though, that is not always the case. Emphasis on quality tends to overlook rarity.

title: REAGAN ON THE RADIO
description: Every Saturday, President Reagan sits down and addresses those in the nation who care to listen over the radio. Data suggest that, in the eyes of advertisers, the Great Communicator is getting a Great Bargain.

title: DRESSING THE LONG ISLAND BODY
description: WHEN it comes to selling their clothes, New York's fashion designers are in search of one thing: the Long Island body. The body of Eileen Smith of Brookville, to be precise.

title: A YEAR'S WORTH OF TRAVEL WISHES
description: Some want romance, others a simple respite from the pace of their lives.

title: ENCOUNTERS WITH TOYNBEE
description: A GREAT virtue of the Cornell University graduate program in history before the war was its informality. I was thus able to follow the dictates of my own spirit, and to an amazing degree. This was the situation into which ''A Study of History'' by Arnold J. Toynbee intruded. I well remember first catching sight of those three volumes, bound in bright green, nestling at eye level in one of the bays of the White Library. It was a completely random encounter: the books still smelled of fresh print, and had never been used before. Nor did I have the slightest idea of the experience that lay before me when I took them down from the shelves. What could be more noncommittal than ''A Study of History,'' with an unknown name on the spine? But I was soon engrossed. An easy chair adorned the central bay of the White Library, some 15 feet from the place in the shelves where I stumbled on the ''Study,'' and there I planted myself for the next two or three days to read Toynbee's three volumes through in one gulp. That was all that was then available. Volumes Four to Six had been published in England in September 1939, but they had not yet reached the shelves of Cornell's library.

title: The Perils of Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FEAR OF LEAVING THE GAME
description: IT was August of '62, the year I left baseball (the phrase I always use). I had returned home to Fairfield, Conn., and promptly failed at the first real job I had ever had: mason laborer. The mason who had hired me reluctantly, said, ''Athletes are too soft for this job,'' and I guess I proved him right.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'FIRST FRUITS'

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Richard Thompson: Across a Crowded Room With the Richard Thompson Band Sony Video 84 minutes. $29.95 Richard Thompson has created a one-man genre of Celtic rock.

title: Hemingway's Biographers
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL THE COURTS MAKE CONGRESS VOTE?
description: Congress has gone home without completing its work on this year's budget, and its most significant legislation on the deficit is headed for the Supreme Court. The dubious new law that Congress fashioned to the President's applause creates a new process of deficit reduction by automatic spending cuts. Not the least of that law's faults is its questionable constitutionality.

title: Nancy Ellen Trommer Married in Forest Hills
description: Nancy Ellen Trommer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Trommer of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Lawrence Jay Thaul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Thaul of East Hills, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein performed the ceremony at the Forest Hills Jewish Center.

title: CRITICISM GROWS ON AMENDMENT TO STATE OPEN MEETINGS LAW
description: GOVERNMENT officials, legislative groups and the media on Long Island and around the state are strongly attacking the passage of an amendment they say waters down the state's Open Meetings Law.

title: THE DONOVAN TRIAL MOVES FORWARD
description: A ruling by a New York State judge in the Bronx last week may clear the way for the larceny and fraud trial of Raymond J. Donovan, the former Labor Secretary, and nine other men. Justice John P. Collins of State Supreme Court ruled that tapes secretly recorded by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1979 could be admitted as evidence. With the key hurdle delaying the proceeding resolved, the judge said that next week he would set a date to begin the trial.

title: ISRAEL WEIGHING RESPONSE TO RAIDS
description: Israel is still considering how to react to the terrorist attacks on Friday against El Al Israel Airlines counters in Vienna and Rome, but senior Israeli officials said that if the past was any indication Israel would find a way to retaliate at a time and place of its own choosing.

title: SOME COMPOSE MUSIC, OTHERS COMPOSE PROGRAM NOTES
description: I used to think, when I was young, that John Burk, who wrote the Boston Symphony Orchestra's program notes from the 1930's to the 1960's, had the best job in the world, with an office in Symphony Hall, daily access to the great Serge Koussevitzky and to privileged information on the orchestra's plans. I sometimes wrote for a couple of the Boston daily papers back then, and eventually I got to publish articles in learned journals, too. But when I decided to make a profession of program-note writing, it was late in life.

title: A HIT ENDS O'BRIEN'S SEASON
description: For a brief moment before he peeled off his uniform pants, Ken O'Brien sat on the stool before his locker, motionless, with his head in his hands. If ever a picture told a story. ''Physically,'' he would say later, ''I feel fine.''

title: TOBACCO COMPANIES BREATHE A BIT EASIER
description: TO the jury, the arguments were new, but to the defendant, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, they were the same issues that had been tried in dozens of suits: Should Reynolds, the nation's second largest cigarette manufacturer, be held responsible for the death of John M. Galbraith, a chain smoker who died of lung cancer in 1982? After deliberating nine hours, the jurors - one smoker, some nonsmokers and some former smokers - found in favor of the company. But they went out of their way to say that they had done so reluctantly.

title: Four Suspended
description: For four Georgia Tech football players, the season will not end in the All-American Bowl against Michigan State on New Year's Eve. The four, including the starting quarterback, John Dewberry, it ended yesterday, when they were suspended by Bill Curry, their coach, for missing curfew on their first night in Birmingham, Ala., where the bowl game will take place.

title: County Seal Ruled Unlawful
description: The official seal of a New Mexico county, bearing a cross and a Latin phrase meaning ''With This We Conquer,'' was ruled unconstitutional Friday by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit. The full court, voting 5 to 2, reversed a decision by a three-judge appeals panel, which had ruled that the Bernalillo County seal met the constitutional tests of separation of church and state.

title: Data Bank; December 29, 1985
...AND A LOOK AT THE BOND MARKET
description: While the stock market garnered the lion's share of investor attention in 1985, the bond market did a little roaring of its own. And some experts see the dual rally continuing into 1986, fueled by stable, or declining, interest rates.

title: SUICIDE FOR A FARMERS' BANKER
description: A man who had worked in a local bank for a decade moved to a new job in Wisconsin when it became too hard for him to tell his farmer friends that they were in financial trouble.

title: PHILIPPINE REBEL CALLS VOTE IRRELEVANT
description: Presidential elections scheduled for February are largely irrelevant to the problems of the Philippines and are likely to ripen the conditions for a popular uprising, an underground Communist organizer has said.

title: GUNMEN'S TIES, AND THE MOTIVE NOT YET CLEAR
description: The identities and affiliation of the assailants who mounted the attacks at airports in Rome and Vienna have not been established, and so the motivation behind the terrorism is still obscure.

title: TRIP TO NICARAGUA HAILED AND ASSAILED
description: As a taxpayer who helps pay Professor Sensiba's salary, I resent his intellectual con job of the students in his care. Why doesn't he recruit them for harvest duty in Afghanistan, or is he afraid that the Communists there would blow up the young people as they have young Afghanis?

title: ANOTHER CHANGE ON THE KOCH TEAM
description: Is the Koch Administration tilting toward real-estate developers? Some civic and planning groups think so. As evidence, they point to the fate of Martin Gallent, the vice chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, who has repeatedly criticized high-density Manhattan office developments, arguing that they cut off light, fresh air and open space.

title: LASER BEAMS ETCHED THE SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME
description: The year's end invites reflection and reminds us that looking back is a good way to see where we are heading. In the field of audio, the overriding event has been the CD's acquisition of a new identity. It has changed from an esoteric extravagance into a mass medium.

title: TOPICS
description: THE bills used to be enormous. Just the cost of keeping our teen-age son in fruit juice sent tremors through our checkbook. A week's load of groceries lasted four days. It seemed I was cooking for a small army.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: COXEY'S ARMY: An American Odyssey. By Carlos A. Schwantes. (University of Nebraska, $22.95.) Heeding the call of Jacob S. Coxey, a wealthy Ohio businessman, thousands of men and women left without jobs by the 1893 depression converged on Washington on May Day 1894 to dramatize the need for a public works program.

title: 'LIE DETECTORS' CAN'T BE TRUSTED
description: In my opinion, based on my service as a criminal prosecutor for the Justice Department and later as a defense lawyer, ''lie-detector'' tests are not worth a damn.

title: DR. EDWARD E. SHELDON
description: Dr. Edward E. Sheldon, a radiologist and inventor of medical diagnostic equipment, died last Sunday at University Hospital in Manhattan after a heart attack.

title: NEW CASTLE NOW MANDATES ITS ESTHETICS
description: THE Town of New Castle has given itself sweeping new powers to mandate the kind of architectural style, lighting, landscaping, building and paving materials and commerical signs in renovations and new construction - even before a builder comes along with plans for a property.

title: CONCERN ABOUT INSURANCE IS SPREADING
description: ALTHOUGH the current worry about the cost and availability of liability insurance has centered on municipalities, many Connecticut businesses also are having problems.

title: TRANSIT SYSTEM STILL STRAPPED
description: If there is anything more distressing for New York City bus and subway riders than having to pay $1 a ride starting Wednesday, it must be knowing that the extra dime is not really going to help.

title: Photography
description: Two current one-man shows of color photographs focus on seasons and change, but with a different emphasis. Joel Meyerowitz's ''A Summer's Day,'' at the Brooklyn Museum through Jan. 13, celebrates the season when city people flock to seaside resorts.

title: The Muse's Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: RICHARDSON ABSENT
description: With Micheal Ray Richardson mysteriously absent, the Washington Bullets put at end to the Nets' five-game winning streak, 98-93, tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: As a specialist in the Czech language and an ardent worshiper of Prague (11 visits), I welcomed the articles on that glorious city published in the Oct. 6 Travel section. They provided much useful information that may inspire more Americans to move beyond their Western European haunts and visit Prague and other parts of Bohemia.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ARE YOU TOUGH ENOUGH? By Anne Burford with John Greenya. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) Of all the ambitious conservatives drawn to the Administration of Ronald Reagan in 1980, it would seem that Anne Burford, the former Environmental Protection Agency administrator, would have one of the most fascinating tales to tell.

title: Progress On 45th St.
description: Feldman Equities Corporation, a Lake Success, L.I., development company, plans to build a 35-story office building at 120 West 45th Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Broadway. It will replace the old Knickerbocker Hotel.

title: SOLARZ NOW SEES SENIORITY AND SAYS IT WORKS
description: Could it be that Stephen J. Solarz is mellowing?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: F.N.G. By Donald Bodey. (Viking, $15.95.) In 1969, at the height of our involvement in Vietnam, Gabe Sauers, a Cincinnati house painter, begins his tour of duty in the central highlands province of Kontum, in the mountainous jungles near the Cambodian border.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE INTERNATIONAL FILM POSTER (Salem House, Cloth, $24.95, Paper, $14.95) gives pleasure to the nostalgic eye, if not always to the mind. The writing is dull, and Gregory J. Edwards frequently offers a lengthy plot summary to provide background for a one-line comment on the film's poster.

title: THE NATIONU.S. TO PROTECT FOREIGN ENVOYS
description: The diplomatic game is not all cocktail parties and polite conversation, at least not since terrorism has become a frequent part of international relations. Last week, the State Department, which has had to pay close attention to the safety of its staffs abroad, let it be known that it will shortly start furnishing protection to some foreign ambassadors in this country as well.

title: Miss Rader Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Donald Rader of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Sperry Rader to Kevin Kenway Edwards, a son of Mrs. A. Porter Waterman of Naples, Fla., and the late Duncan Edwards Jr. of Greenwich. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Anne S. Brockie To Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Brockie of Mountain Lakes, N.J., of the engagement of his daughter, Anne Simmons Brockie, to Michael F. Wright, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Wright of Armonk, N.Y. The future bride is also a daughter of Sarah K. O'Hara of Old Lyme, Conn.

title: CALLED TO THE BAR IN SOMERVILLE
description: SOMERVILLE, which is more a working city than a residential one, has relatively few restaurants, and so it's reason to rejoice when a new one opens.

title: AUSCHWITZ EXHIBITION OPENS AT UN
description: The image etches itself into the memory, a stark black and white photograph of huddled prisoners arriving at Auschwitz.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN REGO PARK
description: AQUEENS apartment-house developer once wooed prospective tenants with the slogan, ''If you lived here, you would be home by now.''

title: Melissa J. Horton Weds C. S. Banks
description: Melissa Jane Horton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John P. Horton of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Scott Banks, a son of Mrs. Daniel T. Kingsley of Potomac, Md., and the late Robert Banks of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Drs.

title: CAN THEY PICK UP WHERE THEY LEFT OFF?
description: ALTHOUGH it has been only five weeks since President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev met in Geneva, aides are starting the climb to the next summit - the Soviet leader's visit to Washington, which may be as early as next June. ''The Geneva meeting was important,'' a State Department official said, ''but the Washington summit will be crucial if we are going to stabilize Soviet-American relations.''

title: INDIVIDUAL PERFORMANCES DOMINATED THE SCENE
description: Call it the year of the dancer. True, there were a few brilliant new works, startling revivals and a noticeable number of oddities that fit into no ready-made category. But it is the specific dance performance by an individual that sticks in the mind first and foremost. And that includes all of the 15 dancing individuals in ''tango terrific,'' otherwise known as ''Tango Argentino.''

title: Tenants As Cosponsors
description: To the Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's like taking drugs. People are getting hooked on incentives.''

title: THE FIRST KREMLINOLOGIST
description: RUSSIAN STATECRAFT An Analysis and translation of Iurii Krizhanich's ''Politika.'' By John M. Letiche and Basil Dmytryshyn. 283 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $29.95.

title: ADDING CLASS TO PRE-MIXED DRINKS
description: A LOT of soul searching went on last year at the Chicago headquarters of the James B. Beam Distilling Company. The question was, would putting the 190-year-old distiller's flagship brand, Jim Beam bourbon, into a canned, pre-mixed cocktail do violence to the product's image?

title: Court Confession
description: IN May 1984, Cecil Haynes, a 30-year-old nurse's aide at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens, was indicted on charges of strangling a mentally ill patient. He was charged with manslaughter, criminal negligence and reckless endangerment of an incompetent person.

title: Priscilla Kidder To Wed in May
description: The engagement of Priscilla Hunnewell Kidder to Josiah West Ellis has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George H. Kidder of Concord, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Ellis Jr. of Lincoln, Mass.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SAFEKEEPING. By Gregory Mcdonald. (Penzler Books, $15.95.) If Charles Dickens and Nathanael West had collaborated on ''Oliver Twist,'' they might have produced as wise and entertaining a book as ''Safekeeping.''

title: CABLE TV
description: Picturesque backgrounds enhance some quality film fare on cable this week, starting with the Big Apple itself. ''Breakfast at Tiffany's'' (1961) - Monday at 12:05 A.M. on WTBS - is a brilliant bauble derived from Truman Capote's novella about a captivating, eccentric girl, with Audrey Hepburn, George Peppard and Patricia Neal.

title: R.Z. GREENE, PHILANTHROPIST AND VENDING-MACHINE MAKER
description: Robert Zemon Greene, a Florida philanthropist recognized as one of the founders of the American vending-machine industry, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach from complications after a swimming accident last June. He was 87 years old.

title: THE PERIL BEHIND THE TAKEOVER BOOM
description: THE biggest wave of corporate acquisitions and buyouts in American history is beginning to cause widespread alarm. The merger mania has sent stock prices to levels no one ever envisioned for 1985. But in the process, American business has gone heavily into debt to pay for its multi-billion dollar takeovers. And this boom in corporate debt, particularly with its use of high-yielding, less-than-investment grade ''junk bonds,'' is bringing warnings even from those involved in financing the megadeals.

title: PHILADELPHIA PARADE REQUEST RUFFLES MUMMERS' FEATHERS
description: For 85 years, Philadelphia's Mummers have strutted their feathered costumes and banjos up Broad Street in a New Year's Day parade.

title: Adele DeBiasi and Sanford Pelz, Educators, Wed
description: Adele DeBiasi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. DeBiasi of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Sanford Millington Pelz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Pelz of New York and Berlin, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Cardone performed the ceremony at St. Raymond Roman Catholic Church in East Rockaway, L.I.

title: Robin Campbell And Brian Leach To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Robin Lynn Campbell to Brian Robert Leach has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Campbell of McLean, Va. A June wedding is planned.

title: ISRAEL AND THE U.S. STAY ON SPEAKING TERMS
description: By all indications, the United States was inclined last week to forgive, if not quite forget, Israel's recent spy caper against the United States. Administration officials willing to talk about the Israeli-American relationship were reaching for metaphors of diminution, calling the episode of espionage ''a bruise'' on a healthy body, or ''a blip'' on a graph of rising cooperation.

title: Brett Douglas Long Weds Elizabeth Helen Goddard
description: At St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., yesterday Elizabeth Helen Goddard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Goddard of Ridgewood, N.J., was married to Brett Douglas Long, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett G. Long of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: VIVID JOYS AMONG THE VAST ARRAY OF FAILURES
description: It was not a good year. Though more films have been put into release in the last 12 months than in any other year of this decade, the quantity did not increase the chances for quality, as is usually the case. Instead, as films failed, they were replaced by worse films, which failed even faster, until, by the end of the year, reviewing movies had become about as rewarding as - if somewhat safer than - tagging pigeons in Bryant Park.

title: Dance
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's three weeks at City Center has flown by and on Sunday the company presents the last two performances of its winter season. For those who have missed out, these performances offer a fairly broad sample of the company at its best.

title: Miss Rubenstein Is Bride Of Stephen Edward Shear
description: Robyn Ann Rubenstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Robert Rubenstein of North Woodmere, L.I., was married there last evening to Stephen Edward Shear, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Shear of Green Acres, L.I. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel.

title: PALESTINIAN LINKS
description: One surviving terrorist of the gunmen who killed 12 people in an attack at a Rome airport Friday has identified himself as a Palestinian born in Lebanon and a member of a renegade Palestinian group, Italian justice officials said today.

title: ENDING THE YEAR-END MONEY FIGHTS
description: YOUR husband blew his year-end bonus on a sports car when the kitchen needs remodeling. Or your wife splurged her bonus money on a fur coat while tuition bills loom. Or perhaps the problem goes across generations: You are smarting because your parents gave your younger brother and his family another four-digit Christmas gift because he is always short of money - while your children again made do with $25 savings bonds from Grandma and Grandpa because you are doing so well you do not need any help.

title: MISSILES ALSO WORRY ISRAEL
description: Besides the terrorism in Europe, Israel and the United States were also concerned by some news last week from Lebanon. Prime Minister Shimon Peres said that Syria had moved surface-to-air missiles back into Lebanon after having withdrawn them two weeks ago at the request of the United States, which was interceding at Israel's behest.

title: KNICKS' STREAK IS SNAPPED AT 4
description: Just when the Knicks were beginning to show a glimmer of how well they can play, they reminded their fans of how awful they can be, too. In an exhibition that was surely one of their worst of the season, the Knicks saw their four-game winning streak come to an ingracious end last night when they were pummeled by the Atlanta Hawks, 100-80, at Madison Square Garden.

title: LESS (AND MORE) THAN MEETS THE EYE
description: ADA A Life and a Legacy. By Dorothy Stein. Illustrated. 321 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $19.95.

title: WHITE COATS AND BLACK HATS
description: MYTHS OF GENDER Biological Theories About Women and Men. By Anne Fausto-Sterling. Illustrated. 258 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.95.

title: TALENTED PERFORMERS BROUGHT SPARKLE TO OLD FORMULAS
description: For commercial television, this was a year in which grossly inflated network mini-series, most notably ABC's $25 million costume romp ''North and South,'' were overshadowed by more humble weekly forms. The situation comedy, reinvigorated by the success of ''The Cosby Show'' on NBC, squelched premature reports of its demise with at least two new lively entries: NBC's ''Golden Girls'' and CBS's ''Mary.'' At the same time, demonstrating that the private-detective genre could still work up a touch of class, ABC came forth with ''Moonlighting.'' Over on public television, budget juggling continued to place a heavy accent on imported programs, primarily British, but ''American Playhouse,'' the single domestic jewel in PBS's drama crown, managed to put together an impressive package of quality presentations, including the best American television film of the year: ''Go Tell It on the Mountain.'' And on cable, a commercially sponsored service like the Arts & Entertainment Network focused on bringing even more British fare to viewers, while pay cable set about expanding its special niche in offbeat comedy with shows such as ''The Last Polka'' and ''The Max Headroom Show.''

title: 18 Arrested in Ulster In Sinn Fein Crackdown
description: Eighteen people were arrested today in Northern Ireland for questioning under Britain's antiterrorist legislation.

title: SWEDEN'S CUSTOM, PREFAB 'HUS' IS GAINING A FOOTHOLD
description: THE spot, deep in the Hamptons, looked like any other building site. Torn earth and mud surrounded the appealing two-story wood house, which did not appear unusual or out of place.

title: REPRESENTATIVE SCHROEDER: AN IDEA THAT IS LONG OVERDUE
description: WITH rrrecord numbers of women in the work force, more and more employees are asking employers to clarify their policies on maternity leave. Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat, has introduced a bill that would require employers to provide at least four months of leave for a father or mother who chooses to stay home with a newborn infant, a newly adopted child or one who is seriously ill. Under existing law, a disability related to pregnancy must be treated like other short-term disabilities that might affect a person's ability to work. But there is great variation in the amount and terms of disability leave employers provide. Representative Schroeder and James A. Klein, manager of pension and employee benefits at the United States Chamber of Commerce, discussed the proposal in interviews with Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times. Question. Why make parental leave mandatory? Answer. We don't make it absolutely mandatory in the sense that every single person is ordered to stay home for four months without pay. What we are saying is that if a parent requests it, it can't be denied.

title: CAUGHT IN REVOLUTION'S REVOLVING DOOR
description: TO THE STORM The Odyssey of a Revolutionary Chinese Woman. By Yue Daiyun and Carolyn Wakeman. Illustrated. 405 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $17.95.

title: True Virtue
description: I find it odd that Joseph Epstein has a deaf ear for the nation's most prominent virtucrat - Ronald Reagan. Is this because the President is a virtublican? ROBERT T. REILLY JR. Fresh Meadows, Queens

title: On Language;   When Does 'Close' Count?
description: AT THE END OF THE year, I do an office-pool column for political junkies. That is one tradition I wish I could shake, because what began as a way of showing off insiderness has become an annual exercise in humility: some nit-picking readers save the columns for a year and send them in with some illuminating comment like ''And you call yourself a pundit?''

title: PLANTS THAT RETURN WITH THE HOLIDAYS
description: THE poinsettia is not the only plant that can be enjoyed at this time of year. Many others can contribute to the festive appearance of the holidays, whether to be used in the home or as gifts.

title: FRANCE WILL PAY GREENPEACE
description: To France's embarrassment at having its agents caught blowing up a ship in New Zealand was added last week some financial cost. The French Government agreed to pay Greenpeace a sum to be determined by negotiation - or, if that fails, by arbitration - for the sinking of the environmental group's Rainbow Warrior July 10 while the ship was waiting in Aukland to sail for a French atomic testing site in the Pacific to lead a protest.

title: Mailbox;   Fear of Queens Is Unfounded
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PENNSYLVANIA COMMUNITY PITCHES IN TO REBUILD BURNED-OUT THEATER
description: ROSE VALLEY, Pa. - The theater's ghosts are illustrious indeed: Sherwood Anderson, Theodore Dreiser and Edward Albee have been associated with the place, and those who have inhabited its stage range from Eva Le Gallienne to Van Heflin to Richard Basehart to Buck Henry.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: COMING BACK UP. By Suzanne Lipsett. (Atheneum, $14.95.) In her first novel, Suzanne Lipsett places her protagonist on a limb and then pulls out the saw.

title: A HAVEN FOR CENTRAL AMERICANS?
description: SAN FRANCISCO last week took the first formal step toward declaring itself a sanctuary for illegal aliens from El Salvador and Guatemala. In doing so, it joined a growing list of communities, including New York, offering symbolic opposition to Federal policies in Central America.

title: CONSUMER RATES
DRINKING TEEN-AGERS TO GET RIDES HOME ON NEW YEAR'S EVE
description: Teen-agers in many communities in the metropolitan area will be able to get free rides home on New Year's Eve if they have drunk too much to make it safely on their own.

title: Susan M. Oelerich to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Oelerich Jr. of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Mary Oelerich to Rem V. Myers Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myers of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The future bride, an account controller for the State Street Bank in Boston, graduated from the University of Colorado. Mr. Myers, a media planner with Kenyon & Eckhardt, an advertising agency in New York, graduated from the Brooks School and Denison University.

title: DECOLLETAGE DOES ABOUT-FACE
description: NECKLINES may not be plunging very much these days -at least not in high fashion circles - but the same can hardly be said for backlines. At several prestigious parties recently, stylish women have shown up in dresses with backs that drop practically out of sight.

title: AIDS FEARS CUT BLOOD DONATIONS
description: WHILE the need for blood donations on Long Island has increased steadily, officials report that the amount of blood donated has declined recently because of what they say is an unwarranted fear of contracting AIDS.

title: STUTZ LOOKS BACK ON RENT BOARD TENURE
description: ALAN STUTZ, the chairman of the Rent Guidelines Board in the county who recently resigned after two and a half years on the board, says he has a new view of tenants and landlords: ''I have disdain for both sides.''

title: SPY-CATCHERS DILEMMA: WHEN TO POUNCE?
description: One of the trickier questions in a criminal investigation is the timing of an arrest. Move too soon or without proper attention to Constitutional safeguards, and a case may collapse in the courtroom. Wait too long, and the suspect may commit another crime or flee.

title: Joys of the Season From Connecticut
description: CORPORATIONS send Christmas cards for many of the same reasons that individuals do: to keep in touch, or simply because the company feels it ought to reciprocate when it receives a card. But because companies usually shy away from overtly religious themes, their choices are more limited than an individual's.

title: YES, VIRGINIA, THERE IS STILL SOME MORE
description: THE week between Christmas and New Year's is usually a musical timeout in Westchester - the choirs have finished their holiday concerts, the orchestras are off on mid-season breaks and most of us are too busy with family and friends to worry about recital programs or ticket reservations.

title: EFFORTS GROW TO COMBAT ALCOHOLISM AMONG EMPLOYEES
description: NEW Year's Eve, bringing with it the remembrance of things past, is among the hardest times of the year for the recovered alcoholic. Holiday seasons are always difficult, according to two specialists who deal with the problems of alcoholism in the workplace, because work slows down and parties increase.

title: VICTORIAN UPDATE
description: THE NARROW PROCESSION OF FRONT AND BACK rooms - articulated only by clunky Victorian woodwork - in this Brooklyn brownstone is similar to others in the scores of turn-of-the-century homes in the area. These houses have a special character and each one has a visual history of the generations of owners who have added their own ''modern'' tastes.

title: 'FINISHING TOUCHES'
description: According to the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, the President's budget blueprint for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 needs only ''some finishing touches'' to pare its projected deficit, ''close to $145 billion,'' to the $144 billion target set by the new budget-balancing law. As for protests from Cabinet members and agency heads about the cuts required to bring the deficit down from $200 billion levels, a White House official maintained that there had been ''no more than the number that you can count on one hand.''

title: COACHES NEED TO WIN, BUT ALSO NEED TIME TO BUILE
description: IT'S the nature of our society to press for results. Everybody does. Our society is a competitive one. That is certainly the theory that applies in college football, the game I have coached for 33 years. If you have all the resources to win, then, ultimately, you should win. That's a fact of life, particularly at the Division I level.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WINTER SPORT SCENE Westchester, with or without snow, is a winter festival. Except for days when sleet, deep snow or heavy frost prevail, golfers equipped with handwarmers and earmuffs always have a place to tee off. Saxon Woods course in Scarsdale is open through Feb. 16, seven days a week from 7 or 8 A.M. (depending upon when it's light enough to see the ball), until 5 P.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Such acts can never lead to a solution to the Palestinian problem.'' -Foreign Minister Beji Caid Essebsi of Tunisia. [12:2.]

title: JAPANESE ABSTRACTIONS: LOOKING WEST
description: IN the mid-1960's, when the Museum of Modern Art's International Council circulated a sizable exhibition titled ''The New Japanese Painting and Sculpture,'' the American art audience was largely ignorant of recent trends in nontraditional Japanese art.

title: OUR REFUGEE POLICY IS ON TRIAL IN SANCTUARY CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: TECHNOLOGICAL SURPRISES ABOUNDED
description: Video is still too young to have become set in its ways, and one would hardly expect a staid and predictable course of development. But even allowing for adolescent Sturm und Drang, the onrush of events within the past year borders on turbulence and has been full of surprises.

title: 'Star Wars' Mania
description: NOW AT LAST ''STAR Wars'' can be yours.

title: DISPUTE OF CAMPUS RADIO
description: PLANS by a Long Island radio station to broadcast National Public Radio programs to its East End audience have created a dispute with a Connecticut station that already provides the programs to the area.

title: Debra Ann Gfeller Weds M. S. Giaimo
description: The marriage of Debra Ann Gfeller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert John Gfeller of West Hartford, Conn., and Michael Steven Giaimo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario B. Giaimo of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter Claver in West Hartford. The Rev. John Kiely performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: COMET. By Carl Sagan and Ann Druyan. (Random House, $27.50.) ''Comets may act as the creators, the preservers, and the destroyers of life on Earth,'' according to the authors of this thorough exploration of what are probably leftovers from the creation of the solar system.

title: HEARTY SOUPS
description: IF champagne is the traditional drink for celebrating New Year's Eve, then soup is the right drink on New Year's Day. I don't mean a thin broth that is sipped from a delicate little cup before the fish course, but a nourishing peasant soup that comes in a large bowl and acts like medicine.

title: SHAKING UP PHILIPP BROTHERS
description: MARTIN N. KAUFMAN can hardly remember a time when commodities were not part of his life. The newly appointed chairman of Philipp Brothers, the commodities trading subsidiary of Phibro-Salomon Inc., grew up in Pittsburgh, where his father processed and traded scrap steel. Even as a small boy, he recalls, he was fascinated by ''the nuts and bolts, twists and turns'' of trading.

title: INTRODUCING A CHILD TO THE WONDERS OF THE LIBRARY
description: THREE years ago, I began taking my daughter to the library. I was not in a hurry to start her reading, but I wanted her to get the feel of the place. I hoped that she would like the library and look forward to our visits. Now, three years later, I can safely say that the experiment has worked for both of us.

title: The Famine Workers
description: In ''The Famine Workers'' (Dec. 1), Clifford D. May accurately portrays many aspects of the complex situation facing relief and recovery personnel in Africa. However, when he writes that ''Most development efforts so far have failed,'' the reader is left with an impression of development work as misguided and development workers as inept.
