title: BUILDING IN WETLANDS OPPOSED
description: A DEVELOPER'S plan to build 112 condominium units on 22 acres of virgin freshwater wetlands in Glen Head has run into opposition.

title: Heidi Dexheimer, A Teacher, Weds
description: At the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J., yesterday, Heidi Lynn Dexheimer, the daughter of Mrs. John Russell Bridgeman of Summit and Spring Lake, N.J., and the late Robert Graves Dexheimer, was married to Thomas Patrick Dulany, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bevard Dulany of Westminster, Md. The Rev. Ray Downs performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. William DeAlton White, an Episcopal priest.

title: Outsider Inside at Los Alamos
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Jean McFarland Is Engaged To Marry John S. Symington In Spring
description: Margaret Jean McFarland, a doctoral candidate in primate behavior at Princeton University, and John Sante Symington, a fourth-year student at the St. Louis University Medical School, plan to be married in May, the future bride's mother, Mrs. J. Malcolm McFarland of Cranbury, N. J., has announced.

title: 4,000, Led by Bishop, Protest At Hempstead Abortion Clinic
description: Bishop John McGann of the Rockville Centre Roman Catholic Diocese led more than 4,000 protesters in a demonstration outside an abortion clinic here today.

title: COLUMBIA LOSES CLOSE ONE
description: David Miller and Glenn Martin scored baskets in the final 2 minutes 23 seconds to help Drake overcome a game-long deficit and defeat Columbia, 58-56, tonight in the consolation game of the Merrill Lynch Classic college basketball tournament.

title: Harry Hopman Is Dead
description: Harry Hopman, the Australian coach who developed such tennis players as John McEnroe, Rod Laver and John Newcombe, died of a heart attack Friday. An obituary appears in Section I, Page 22.

title: Kim F. Albertson Becomes Bride of David M. K. Ruth
description: Kim Faith Albertson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Albertson of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to David Marion Kennison Ruth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. David Ruth of Maggie Valley, N.C. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: PROGRESS MADE IN PROTECTIVE-DEFENSE RESEARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: FACING UP TO THE HOUSING-SUPPLY ISSUE
description: IN the last decade, the Federal Government committed as much as $2.3 billion a year to sheltering low- and moderate-income people in New York City. In the same period, however, almost as many housing units were abandoned as were created. This year, Federal commitments amounted to only $789 million and, in the next decade, further reductions seem likely as Congress struggles to rein in the Federal deficit.

title: FEASTIN ON DUNGENESS CRAB
description: There is a bright side to Seattle's winter weather, besides the occasional sunny day. In October, armies of small skiffs head out into the choppy waters of Washington State's bays and estuaries to pull up large metal mesh crab pots teeming with Dungeness crabs.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Film View column in most copies of the Arts and Leisure section today carries an incomplete listing of Vincent Canby's 10 best films for 1985. It should have included ''Young Sherlock Holmes.'' The list of runners-up also omitted a name: ''Return of the Soldier.'' Mr. Canby will discuss both films in his column next Sunday.

title: AN OPTIMISTIC BRIDGETOWN TURNS 300
description: WHEN this city along the Cohansey River in Cumberland County begins its tricentennial festivities New Year's Eve with 300 rounds of fireworks and a 300-pound birthday cake, it also will be celebrating a rebirth that has been under way for roughly four years.

title: GORBACHEV OUSTS ANOTHER RIVAL IN THE KREMLIN
description: In power a little over nine months, Mikhail S. Gorbachev appears still to be concerned with consolidating his position as the undisputed Soviet leader. Last week, after a press campaign that turned on such things as tomatoes and plumbing, Mr. Gorbachev took another big step in that direction by retiring Viktor V. Grishin from his post as head of the Moscow Communist Party. Mr. Grishin, 71 years old, seemed likely to be removed as well from the ruling Politburo, where he has been a member for almost 25 years.

title: BENEFITS IN BUYING AN OFFICE
description: IN the last few years owners of small businesses have been offered a new kind of opportunity - the chance to purchase rather than rent office space in a growing number of commercial condominiums now being created in both city and suburbs.

title: HOSPITALS PRESS ISSUE OF LIABILITY
description: WARNING that their ability to provide care is threatened, directors of 18 acute-care hospitals in the county are pressing Governor Cuomo to resolve the crisis in medical malpractice insurance.

title: REMOVING THOSE STUBBORN STAINS: SPEED IS OF THE ESSENCE
description: REMOVING spots and stains from fabric - whether clothing, upholstered furniture, curtains or other fabrics - can often be accomplished with simple home methods.

title: RESPONSIBILITY
description: 'We no longer warehouse our suffering, so we have to climb over them on the sidewalk and ask whose responsibility they are.' Dr. William Lazareth pastor of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and 65th Street.

title: NAKASONE GIVES CABINET A NEW LOOK
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone reorganized his Government tonight, replacing most of his Cabinet but retaining his Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Defense and Finance.

title: Deborah Morelli And John Wygal Are Wed in Rye
description: Deborah Anne Morelli, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ondino A. Morelli of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Horsely Wygal, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hugh Wygal of Wilmington, Del. and Hilton Head, S.C. Msgr. Donald J. Pryor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Peter V. Letsou Engaged To Marry Felicity Harper
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Harper of New York and Locust, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Felicity Harper to Peter Vasilios Letsou, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Vasilios Letsou of Lowell, Mass. The wedding is planned for June.

title: NONVENTURE CAPITAL
description: THE GOLDEN DONORS A New Anatomy of the Great Foundations. By Waldemar A. Nielsen. 468 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/E. P. Dutton. $25.

title: Mailbox;   There's Noise For a Reason
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SHARED-LIVING FOR AGED GAINS
description: ''JUST imagine this beautiful stairway decorated for the holidays,'' Ann Muller, the resident manager, said as she showed a guest through Boyd House, the recently opened shared-living quarters established here by St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: A RESTAURANT CROWDED FOR A GOOD REASON
description: I am writing this in response to the review of the Navona Italian restaurant in Great Neck on Nov. 10. Florence Fabricant was perplexed because such an unimpressive restaurant was so consistently crowded.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SHORTLY before he was slain in Memphis in 1968, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led a civil-rights rally in Paterson. Passaic County Community College, in downtown Paterson, wants Dr. King's visit remembered.

title: ASSEMBLY REALIGNED BY G.O.P.
description: ASSEMBLYMAN Charles L. Hardwick of the 21st District, who next month will become the first Republican Speaker of the Assembly since Thomas H. Kean wielded the gavel in 1972, has announced a realignment of the committees that review the thousands of bills introduced each year.

title: Alexander Dane Grace Becomes Bride Of Stephen Garfield, Magazine Official
description: The marriage of Alexandra Dane Grave and Stephen Kearny Garfield took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church-on-the-Green in New Haven. The Rev. Edwin M. Ward performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LIFE IN THE FASTER LANE CAROL GLICK of Muttontown says it makes her feel like a Dallas Cowboy scoring a touchdown. Pamela Main of Merrick said that not having to keep score helps you concentrate more on your game.

title: Inflation Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WINNING KICK
description: The weekend five- or six-round Swiss-system tournament - the staple that nurtures American players -has gone a long way to determine opening preferences. In such short, crowded events, victories are at a premium because dropping even a half-point is enough to let the first and only significant prize get away.

title: MUSIC: FANTASIAS AND FUGUES BY P.D.Q. BACH
description: LIKE ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show,'' P. D. Q. Bach cannot be explained - cannot exist, really -without his audience. Of course, he couldn't exist without his creator, Peter Schickele, either, but we knew that. What was surprising and endearing about the Friday night P. D. Q. Bach show at Carnegie Hall - the run of four has two to go, this afternoon at 3 and Monday at 8 P.M. - was the way the audience pitched in so gleefully. To be sure, they've had plenty of practice - this is the concerts' 20th year.

title: Manila Recommends Trials In Killings of 20 Protesters
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile accepted the findings of a commission and recommended today that a town mayor, a police chief and 44 soldiers and militiamen be prosecuted for the killings of 20 anti-Government demonstrators in a rally in September.

title: BLACKFACE ACT UPHELD BY U.S. APPEALS COURT
description: The Baltimore Police Department unconstitutionally banned one of its officers from performing an Al Jolson blackface impersonation that was offensive to blacks, according to a Federal appellate court.

title: THE MAN RE-ANIMATING DISNEY
description: IT IS 5 A.M. AT DISNEYLAND, five hours into the 24-hour celebration of the amusement park's 30th birthday. In the tepid dawn, half-empty boats sail the seas of Pirates of the Caribbean. The children -who should have been in bed - are asleep on the benches of New Orleans Square and on the front porches of Main Street. For one brief moment between darkness and daylight, it is too early or too late to eat, to buy, to ride. And the magic is peeling off the Magic Kingdom.

title: ASSEMBLY TO WEIGH RULE CHANGE FOR TEACHERS
description: LAST year, Joanne Ferrero, an insurance group underwriter with a bachelor's degree in economics, was slowly climbing the corporate ladder at the Cigna Companies in Hartford when she decided fulfill her long desire to become a public high school math teacher. To return to school, she had to deplete her savings account, take out a loan, and now, she is considering becoming a part-time waitress as well.

title: LATE GEORGIA RALLY TIES ARIZONA, 13-13
description: Lars Tate soared over the line of scrimmage for a 2-yard touchdown with 9 minutes 26 seconds to play today, capping a 10-point fourth-quarter rally that enabled Georgia to tie Arizona, 13-13, in the Sun Bowl.

title: HISTORIANS SEE LESSONS FOR PRESENT IN FATE OF DEAD ANTHRACITE COAL TOWN
description: To come off the mountain road and turn the corner into this old, stark mining town is to gain an understanding of economic change.

title: TURIN'S ELEGANT PIAZZAS AND PALAZZOS
description: Turin has many squares, rich in shade and statuary, ideal for loafers and lovers, for playing children and dozing pensioners; but the Piazza San Carlo is the city's drawing room, and on a pleasant afternoon, nothing is more enjoyable than sitting at one of the outside tables of the Caffe San Carlo over a glass of sparkling Prosecco and looking at the square itself. It is dominated by a large equestrian statue of Emanuele Filiberto, the king who restored the fortunes of the Savoy family in 1557. The statue (known as the caval d' brons, the bronze horse) is the work of the 19th-century sculptor Carlo Marochetti, a favorite artist of Queen Victoria (who commissioned him to do the recumbent figure of Prince Albert for the consort's grave). The beautiful, airy arcades that line the square and the plan of the square itself date from the 17th century. They seem to have set a tone for the city, because most of the center of Turin is laid out with similar elegance.

title: RECALLING A TOWN THAT HAS CHANGED
description: YOU remember ''the good old days,'' don't you? If you grew up where I did, in a small New England town in the 1940s and 50's, of course you do.

title: GRAMM-RUDMAN HITS FEDERAL RETIREES
description: To the Editor:

title: CELEBRATING THE CELEBRATED EDISON
description: THE sparkle that illuminated the world a little more than a century ago will be rekindled this afternoon in a gala three-hour celebration at the Edison Memorial Tower on Christie Street.

title: ROCK FLEXED ITS SOCIAL AND POLITICAL MUSCLES
description: Rock and roll shook up an unprepared America in 1955, and in 1963 the Beatles conquered the world with cheek and charm. In 1985, rock music -hard and soft, futurist and retro, commercial and uncompromising, and every shading in between - proved it was capable of much more than providing easy shock and outrage, new fashions and faces. At the Live Aid Concerts in Philadelphia and London, at the recording and video taping session for ''We Are the World'' in Los Angeles, at the Farm Aid Concert, and at the recording sessions that gathered Bruce Springsteen, Miles Davis and an unlikely conglomeration of other stars to make a stand against South African apartheid on the album ''Sun City'' (Manhattan/EMI ST 53019), rock proved that it is no longer mere entertainment. It is now an international social and even political force, with the ability to reach people around the world, send them a message - and get results.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE LITTLE FATHER By Gelett Burgess. Illustrated by Richard Egielski. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 6) GEORGE SHRINKS Written and illustrated by William Joyce. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $10.50. (Ages 3 to 6) MOST adults have trouble remembering how central size is to the world-view of children.

title: MOSCOW ASSAILED ON AFGHAN ROLE
description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union had inflicted ''utter hell'' on the people of Afghanistan through its 1979 intervention.

title: Harry Hopman, Tennis Teacher
description: Harry Hopman, the man in charge of Australia's Davis Cup teams during its golden age of tennis and the coach who developed such outstanding players as Rod Laver, John Newcombe and John McEnroe, died Friday night after suffering a heart attack at his home near his tennis camp here. He was 79 years old.

title: NEW SEED CATALOGUES SPUR VISIONS OF TASTY CROPS
description: The seed catalogues are starting to come. It's garden fantasy time again. For those who have always thought of gardening solely in decorative terms and plant only flowers, this may be the year to give a thought to vegetables. I did.

title: DEATH AS A PARLOR GAME
description: GERALD'S PARTY By Robert Coover. 316 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Max Frisch Receives Literature Award
description: Max Frisch, the Swiss novelist and playwright, has been named the winner of the annual Common Wealth Award for Distinguished Service in Literature. Mr. Frisch was nominated for the $16,000 prize by a jury of the Modern Language Association.

title: BEHIND THE LINES
description: Dual citizenship is evidently no defense when it comes to laws that prohibit Israelis from visiting countries that are technically still at war with Israel.

title: A SYMBOL OD CONTINUITY
description: EVERY year, part of our ready-up-for winter routine is a careful brushing-away of the leaves that have fallen on our two boxwood plants. Such careis not something we do for all our shrubs, just the boxwood. They get the same kind of special treatment after a snowfall - we make sure that heavy snow doesn't bow down the plants and perhaps break their stems. It is obvious, I guess, that the boxwood represent something special in our lives.

title: BOY SPEAKS LANGUAGE OF YIDDISH STAGE
description: IF Yiddish is a languishing language, don't tell that to James Harris, an 11-year-old from Cedarhurst.

title: FOREIGN MONEY SPREADING TO ALL WALKS OF U.S. LIFE
description: Money from around the world is pouring into the United States, pushing total foreign investment toward a record $1 trillion.

title: Seven Ineligible
description: Seven Baylor University basketball players have been declared ineligible by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, Coach Gene Iba revealed yesterday.

title: CITY'S JOBLESS RATE CONTINUES DECLINE
description: New York City's unemployment rate fell to 8.2 percent for the first 11 months of 1985, the lowest such figure in more than a decade, Federal labor officials reported yesterday.

title: OTB SPRUCES UP TO ATTRACT BETTORS
description: EVER since certain forms of gambling were legalized in Connecticut more than a decade ago, the state's off-track betting parlors have been the biggest losers in esthetics and comfort.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1985
description: Airport Terror

title: Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $267,000 52 Evergreen Row *2* 5 bedrooms, 3 baths, 24-year old brick/ frame ranch; *2* eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 2.04 acres; taxes $4,000. New Rochelle, N.Y. $143,000 71 President Street *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 61-year old colonial; *2* living-room fireplace, formal dining room, den; taxes $1,800. Scarsdale, N.Y. $318,000 25 Black Birch Lane *2* 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old frame colonial; *2* eat-in kitchen, family room, deck; taxes $6,960. Guilford, Conn. $138,000 275 State Street *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 46-year-old colonial; *2* basement family room, yard with mature trees; taxes $1,387. Killingworth, Conn. $62,500 302 Route 81 *2* 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 1880 Cape Cod; *2* needs work, tool shed in yard, 2 acres; taxes $1,034. Madison, Conn. $149,000 407 Warpas Road *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old saltbox; *2* sliders to deck, 1 acre; taxes $1,699. OTHER AREAS Medford, L.I. $76,700 2001 Waverly Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; *2* eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $1,800. Edgewater, N.J. $149,000 1077 River Road *2* 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old midrise condominium; *2* pool, tennis courts, monthly charges $210; taxes $1,700. Lake Hiawatha, N.J. $55,000 101-19 Bevwyck Road *2* 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 17-year-old garden-apartment condominium; *2* new stove and kitchen cabinets, monthly charges $83; taxes $481.

title: MORE FERMENT ON K STREET
description: The capital's main street for lawyers, lobbyists and other high-priced tenants is K Street, and things are normally so orderly there that it is a matter approaching news to report what one witness found the other day in strolling two blocks.

title: True Virtue
description: What a marvelous word Joseph Epstein came up with: virtucrat. It's not every day that one finds a term that so effectively and elegantly skewers both the Moral Majority right and the bleeding-heart left. SALLY F. URKE Albuquerque, N.M.

title: FESTIVAL ENDS YEAR IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Dec. 28 - A thousand performing, visual and media artists from New England, New York and Pennsylvania will set up shows and displays next week at 35 indoor and 17 outdoor sites here.

title: DIALING GEORGETOWN
description: Georgetown, long one of Washington's fashionable if not exclusive neighborhoods, now has a new gentry symbol: its own phone book. But some Georgetowners have complained that they were passed over in the recent distribution of the first 22,000 copies, while some people living across the border in adjacent neighborhoods received them.

title: True Virtue
description: Why does Joseph Epstein limit his examples almost entirely to the political left, when these days the ''virtucrats'' we have to take seriously - the ones with real power to affect our lives - so often seem to be on the right? It was, after all, a right-wing group that chose to name itself the Moral Majority.

title: WHIMSY INTRIGUES COMMUTERS
description: THE ringing, clanging ''thing with the marbles,'' as one commuter called it, is seen by thousands of people daily, and its aficionados say it is its sheer sense of whimsy that draws them back again and again.

title: Islanders Hold Off Penguins
description: In an important divisional game, the Islanders defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-2, tonight at the Civic Arena.

title: Bremen
description: To the Editor: Thank you for John Dornberg's excellent article about Bremen in the Dec. 1 Travel section.

title: STARTLING NORMALITY
description: THE TRANSFORMATION OF SPAIN From Franco to the Constitutional Monarchy. By David Gilmour. 332 pp. New York: Quartet Books. $19.95.

title: Reflections on Brisbane
description: To the Editor:

title: MONTCLAIR THEATER IN CHEERFUL OFFERING
description: ANYONE shopping for cheerful holiday fare might find it in Alan Ayckbourn's ''Season's Greetings,'' which is at the Whole Theatre here through next Sunday.

title: HEATING OIL PRICES CAUSE STIR ON L.I.
description: ALTHOUGH world oil prices have dropped sharply, the cost of home heating oil on Long Island has gone up this season and stayed there. The disparity has caused Governor Cuomo to seek a Federal inquiry, stirred consumer groups to action and put heating oil dealers on the defensive.

title: ST. JOHN'S HOLDS ON TO TOP BONNIES
description: After leading by 18 points at the half and seemingly headed for its eighth one-sided victory in the last nine games, St. John's had to scramble to defeat St. Bonaventure, 85-69, yesterday for the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival championship at Madison Square Garden.

title: MIDEAST TERROR ENGULFS ROME AND VIENNA AIRPORTS
description: A year of terror approached its close last week with a particularly horrifying outburst of blood and death. Shortly after 9 A.M. Friday, in what is supposed to be a season of peace, terrorists armed with grenades and automatic weapons simultaneously struck at the Rome and Vienna airports. When the shooting, which ''seemed to go on forever,'' finally ended, 18 people were dead or dying and more than 100 were wounded.

title: AFTER 200 YEARS A HANDEL TRIBUTE GETS IT STRAIGHT
description: In some ways, the ''Handel Tercentenary Concert'' is more accurate than the very tradition from which it springs. The three-hour program, produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation and given its American premiere Thursday evening at 8 on Arts and Entertainment, presents a concert given last February in honor of the 300th birthday of George Frideric Handel, which was itself a re-creation of a concert presented upon the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth. But the centenary celebrants seem to have got the date wrong: a monument to Handel in Westminster Abbey - where both concerts took place, separated by some 200 years - notes his birthday as Feb. 23, 1684, and the 100th-birthday concert was dutifully held on that day in 1784. However, subsequent scholarship has shown that the prolific composer was actually born in 1685, leaving this year's festivities to finally tidy up the chronology.

title: YANKEES GOT THE RUNS, BUT ROYALS GOT THE RICHES
description: The Kansas City Royals won the World Series and the Yankees won nothing. Yet the Yankees had the most effective platoon of run producers in the majors last season while the Royals had one of the least effective. Or, maybe George Brett really was a significantly more valuable player than Don Mattingly, who was named the American League's Most Valuable Player.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review last Sunday of a New York Philharmonic performance misidentified the conductor Christoph von Dohnanyi. He is the grandson of the composer Ernst von Dohnanyi, not his son.

title: PREJUDICE IS ONE OF ASIA'S MORE COMMON AFFLICTIONS
description: Call him Paul. He was born in Singapore about 20 years ago to a Filipino father and a Chinese mother. He has always felt ''100 percent Singaporean'' and never thought much about race, he said, until he visited India with an English friend. ''Everywhere we went,'' he said, ''they treated me like his servant. I said to them: 'My skin is brown like yours. Why do you do this to me?' ''

title: Victoria Taylor Is Wed To Ernest Griffin Allen
description: Victoria Grayson Taylor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Taylor of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Ernest Griffin Allen, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William H. Allen of Philadelphia. The Rev. William D. Eddy performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: GAF SWEETENS BID, BUT CARBIDE RESISTS
description: GAF raised its bid for Union Carbide to $74 a share in cash, from $68, and said it had the necessary financing to complete the $5.1 billion takeover. But Carbide's chairman, Warren M. Anderson, said he is ready to shore up Carbide's defenses even more.

title: WHAT IF THE HOLIDAY HOOPLA CAME ONLY EVERY OTHER YEAR?
description: REMEMBER the ''What-If'' game? I used to play it with my children all the time.

title: MR. KELIN: NO CONCERN OF GOVERNMENT
description: WITH rrrecord numbers of women in the work force, more and more employees are asking employers to clarify their policies on maternity leave. Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat, has introduced a bill that would require employers to provide at least four months of leave for a father or mother who chooses to stay home with a newborn infant, a newly adopted child or one who is seriously ill. Under existing law, a disability related to pregnancy must be treated like other short-term disabilities that might affect a person's ability to work. But there is great variation in the amount and terms of disability leave employers provide. Representative Schroeder and James A. Klein, manager of pension and employee benefits at the United States Chamber of Commerce, discussed the proposal in interviews with Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times.

title: MORE FAMILIES ARE AMONG HOMELESS
description: THOSE who have sought refuge at the rambling white shelter in Danielson include a 66-year-old woman the police found living in a U-Haul trailer behind a gas station, and a family of five.

title: About Men;   Adult Education
description: WHEN MY DAUGH-ter presented her baby son to me for the first time, I was, of course, curious to see what he looked like. I had to admit that he looked like the helpless creature he was, his eyes unfocused and his head wobbling on the thin stem of his neck. My daughter, however, was ecstatic. After all, this was her baby, who had grown inside of her as she nurtured him month after month. The father was also transfixed with joy. It was his baby, too, his son. As for me, I held the baby carefully in my arms. I wanted to feel my kinship with him, but somehow I couldn't experience the surge of joy that is supposed to engulf grandfathers; yet I will acknowledge that my wife dissolved when she first beheld her grandson. No, there was curiosity, but the infant was hardly a person one could love. Little by little, I must report, the blob of humanity began to develop more definite features and to focus his attention. He even learned to smile, and I smiled back and spoke to him, although I was sure he couldn't understand a word I said. I didn't see him every day -my daughter lives too far away for anything like that - but every time she visited, the baby revealed some new sign of progress.

title: HOW LAW HAS IMPROVED AUTO TECHNOLOGY
description: A lot has changed in the 20 years since my book ''Unsafe at Any Speed'' was published.

title: HARIET CRAWLS, LYDIA PLOTS, JUNE FLIRTS
description: BAD GIRLS By Mary Flanagan. 237 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title: WHAT'S HAPPENING TO OUR TREES?
description: MANY of our forest giants are in deep trouble.

title: AN ART THEFT IN MEXICO
description: Art thieves are among the world's most discerning criminals. That was certainly the case on Christmas Eve, when 140 pre-Columbian artifacts were stolen from the National Museum of Anthropology and History in Mexico City.

title: FOR ONCE, THE ECONOMY IS OT THE PRINCIPAL PROBLEM
description: ''I am definitely one of those people who believes the Government can walk and chew gum at the same time,'' said the deputy secretary of the Treasury, Richard G. Darman, in defending the Administration's ability to hold its own in the new year's economic policy campaigns.

title: BREAKING THE CHAIN OF CHILD ABUSE
description: FALL 1978 I was sitting in the Lincoln School cafeteria in Ashland, Ore., when I first saw Rachel. She was standing on the risers, rear row to the left, performing in a choral program with 40 other fifth graders.

title: NEW MALL FOR ROUTE 1
description: The bustling Route 1 corridor through central New Jersey will soon get another project with the construction near Princeton of a 237,000-square-foot mall with 75 retail and specialty shops and a nine-screen cinema.

title: THE PATRIOTS' BIG PLAY
description: IN preparing for yesterday's American Conference wild-card playoff game, the New England Patriots' special teams were haunted by Kurt Sohn's 46-yard punt return that had positioned the Jets' 16-13 overtime victory five weeks ago.

title: Miss Kistler Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Drew Kistler of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter Sharon Drew Kistler to Peter Dwight DeNunzio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Dwight DeNunzio of Riverside, Conn.

title: GREAT SHOWS WERE HERE, THERE AND EVERTYWHERE
description: Where art was concerned, 1985 was a great year for the airlines. To keep abreast of the times, concerned people had to catch British art in New Haven, the treasures of Liechtenstein in New York, the English country house in Washington, Christo's latest gift wrap on the Pont Neuf in Paris and Indian art in many of its guises all over the United States.

title: HORDON S. HAIGHT, 84, AUTHORITY ON GEORGE ELIOT
description: Gordon S. Haight, professor emeritus of English at Yale University and the world's leading authority on George Eliot, died yesterday at his home in Woodbridge, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: EAST END MOVING ON U.S. OPEN PLANS
description: WITH the United States Open coming to the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in June, Southampton officials and businessmen are already deeply involved in planning and preparation for what is golf's biggest event.

title: THE JEW WHO SPIED FOR TH NAZIS
description: ARROWS OF THE ALMIGHTY The Most Extraordinary True Spy Story of World War II. By Michael Bar-Zohar. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $16.95.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Dec. 29, 1985 Fiction

title: FERTILITY CENTER
description: The Australian in vitro fertilization program, considered to be one of the most successful applications of the new technology in the world today, has established a center for treatment of infertility at the United Hospital in Port Chester. The program, scheduled to begin operation in February at United, is the first base in the United States for the Australian team of doctors.

title: OFFICES FOR SOMERVILLE
description: The conversion of the towns in central New Jersey from rural to urban centers geared to the support of professional and commercial services rather than agriculture is the rationale that led to the planning for an office project in Somerville, according to its developer, Richard Ripps of Manhattan.

title: ACTIVIST MAKING SWITCH TO ACADEMIA
description: Because he is determined to ''wear out, not rust out,'' Mitchell Sviridoff is changing careers - again.

title: COLUMBIA PLANNING TO BUILD $54 MILLION HIGH-TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH CENTER
description: Columbia University is planning to build a $54 million center to house its expanding research efforts in computer science, microelectronics and telecommunications.

title: IT LOOKS GOOD ENOUGHT TO EAT
description: What looks like spaghetti Bolognese and keeps fresh on the shelf for 50 years? Japanese plastic food, the real-as-life models that restaurants in Japan use for the prosaic business of window display, and that visitors have gleefully added to the canon of pop art.

title: SCIENCE EXPERIMENT
description: THE kindergarten has squirming mealworms and there are crayfish in the sixth grade. In science classes at 12 elementary schools in northern Westchester and Putnam County, students are using thousands of these tiny creatures to test new curriculum developments in a pilot program for the state.

title: SUNSHINE IN WIGHT, SWEETSHOPS IN LONDON
description: THE SKATERS' WALTZ By Philip Norman. 331 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: LOOKING BACK AT THE BAD AND BEAUTIFUL
description: IN many sports, 1985 was a year for the bad and the beautiful.

title: ZOOLOGIST IS SLAIN IN CENTRAL AFRICA
description: Dian Fossey, an American zoologist who studied Rwanda's rare mountain gorillas for 18 years, has been killed by unknown assailants at her forest camp in this central African country, the police said today.

title: OFFICE POOL, 1986
description: Why do I put myself through this prediction purgatory every year? I never get more than four right and thereby lay myself open to guffaws of derision, a year later, from amateur pundits. However, the political office pool in this space remains one of the few traditions in columny and it shows us all How Little We Know. 1. At the summit next June, where the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting will take place in front of a wheezing air conditioner, the arms-control breakthrough will be (a) a limit on offensive missiles; (b) on-site inspection; (c) interim agreement on intermediate-force systems in Europe; (d) a pact to limit testing of ''Star Wars.'' 2. First on the agreed budgetary hit list will be (a) Interstate Commerce Commission; (b) Small Business Administration; (c) Amtrak; (d) Agricultural Extension Service. 3. A K.G.B. ''mole'' will be discovered in (a) our intelligence community; (b) the Congress; (c) the media; (d) the F.B.I.'s caterer. 4. The world leader to leave the scene in 1986 will be (a) Ferdinand Marcos; (b) Francois Mitterrand; (c) Pieter Botha. 5. The Democratic Presidential hopeful with the most money in his political action committee will be (a) Gary Hart; (b) Charles Robb; (c) Mario Cuomo; (d) Bill Bradley. 6. The person to whom Disraeli's term ''dark horse'' will be most fre-quently applied will be (a) Bill Armstrong; (b) Joseph Biden; (c) Newt Gingrich; (d) Lee Iacocca; (e) Bob Packwood; (f) Sam Nunn. 7. Wall Street will be stunned by the news of (a) the drop from the 2000 Dow; (b) the junk-bond panic; (c) the soaring dollar; (d) the lowest interest rates in a decade; (e) the S.E.C.'s scandalously late discovery of the scandal of insider trading. 8.

title: A SPECIAL THANK YOU FOR DOING THE JOB RIGHT
description: We learn from experience, but not at this season when we're getting ready to discard an old year and preparing to welcome a new one. If we had learned from past Januarys, we'd know that the good resolutions we've just made are a waste of time, that they'll disappear into the thin cold air almost as quickly as the holiday spirit. Give them a month at most. Almost as meaningless are the New Year's greetings distributed with great abandon and no discrimination. We wish health and happiness to those we like and those we love and also to people we bump into on the street, exchange a few words with on the bus, forget the moment they leave our presence and very likely will never see again. The wishes come forth as a matter of rote, hurting no one but meaning little to either giver or recipient.

title: CUTTING THE HEALTH CARE UMBILICAL TO WASHINGTON
description: If everything goes according to schedule, an unusual health clinic will open here in little more than 11 weeks, replacing an inner-city family-care center so cramped that its examining rooms were squeezed into trailers in the parking lot. But what will set the new clinic apart from Detroit's eight other public health centers is not its medical equipment or more comfortable examining rooms. What makes it different is that no Federal dollars will have been spent on it.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JEWEL OF THE MOON. By William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam, $14.95.) Over a decade has passed since Horse Badorties, the indomitable hero of William Kotzwinkle's very funny cult novel, ''The Fan Man,'' conducted his Love Chorus in ''the music of the ages,'' but his prolific creator is still waving the baton and humming away, shaping eccentric tales around gnomish heroes like Dr. Rat and E.T. Of the 15 stories here - parables mostly -only two have been previously published.

title: TRILOGY COMPANY STRIVES FOR SUCCESS
description: CAN a new regional theater succeed in the county where all too many have failed and where it doesn't even have a home base? Abbe Harkavy, a resident of Mount Vernon who is the managing director of the Trilogy Theater Company, is determined to prove that it can be done, in spite of the problems impeding the company's progress.

title: Miss Palagonia Is Wed To P. E. Truesdale 3d
description: The marriage of Barbara Catherine Palagonia, a private banking associate at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York, to Philemon Edwards Truesdale 3d, an assistant vice president at the Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York, took place yesterday. The Rev. Donald T. Driscoll performed the ceremony at SS.

title: Rome
description: To the Editor: Your answer to the query for walking-tour books of Rome (Travel, Nov. 10) surprised me with the omission of Georgina Masson's ''Companion Guide to Rome'' (Prentice-Hall).

title: TRIP TO NICARAGUA HAILED AND ASSAILED
description: It is hopeful and encouraging to read that Stockton State College students and their professor, Dr. G. William Sensiba, plan a humanitarian trip to Nicaragua [Page 1, Dec. 15] and to learn that students, especially, have a moral conscience when having one is not in high fashion.

title: Diane deCordova Wed at Princeton
description: Diane deCordova, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter deCordova of Norwich, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Monroe Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Thomas Lewis of New Orleans. The Rev. Sarah Motley performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel at Princeton University, from which the bride and bridegroom graduated cum laude.

title: LOOKING AHEAD TO 1986: A SPIRIT OF EXPECTATION
description: AS the immortal Casey Stengel once observed of oral contracts, New Year's resolutions, even those uttered with the best of intentions, all too often are not ''worth the paper they're written on.''

title: Q AND A
description: Earl Carroll's Castle Question: What can you tell me about the building at 753-59 Seventh Avenue? . . . R. S., Manhattan Answer: ''Through these portals pass the most beautiful girls in the world'' was the motto of Earl Carroll, producer of the famous ''Earl Carroll's Vanities,'' who presumably was referring to the doors of the theater he operated on this site, near 50th Street, in the 1920's and 1930's. In 1931 he had the theater rebuilt at a cost of $4.5 million in a style The New York Times called ''strictly modern.'' With 3,000 seats Mr. Carroll hoped to be able to produce large shows with popular-price tickets.

title: A TIME OF MEMORIES AND BEGINNINGS
description: LAST year, on the afternoon of New Year's eve, I called my husband at his office to ask him if he would mind if I canceled our plans to go to our friends' party. I had just got over the flu and I told him I still didn't feel up to going out.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Cease-Fire Crumbles In West African War
description: Mali said today that its air force had attacked four towns deep inside Burkina Faso as the border war between the two West African countries entered its fourth day.

title: OFFICIAL HELPS FOREIGN COMPANIES TO COPE HERE
description: WHEN foreign-based companies establish subsidiaries or trading offices in New Jersey, they are approached by Ming Hsu, director of the state's Division of International Trade, with offers of help on practical matters as site selection and dealing with red tape.

title: THE PROPER ROLE OF BILINGUAL EDUCATION
description: WHEN legislators first debated bilingual education, it was to be a transitional measure to help non-English speaking students overcome their ''language barrier'' so they could quickly be part of the mainstream of public education -and public life. That is still a good description of a sensible program.

title: OUR REFUGEE POICY IS ON TRIAL IN SANCTUARY CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ASKS RESTRAINT
description: President Reagan today sent a message to Israel saying that the terrorists who attacked airports in Rome and Vienna must ''be brought to justice,'' but asserting that ''we must not allow terrorists to deter us from pursuing our larger goal of a lasting peace.''

title: I MEANT TO CALL...
description: I MEANT to tell my daughter how proud I was of her when she invited her younger brother to join in the games with her friends, even though her friends would have preferred not to have his company. But by the time they all came inside it was dinner time and the phone began to ring incessantly, and well, I just forgot to tell her.

title: CUOMO AND D'AMATO ARE LEAVING LITTLE TO CHANCE
description: WHAT a difference a few years makes.

title: BIG LOSERS BUT GOOD SPORTS
description: Some time ago, after the pairings for the Orange Bowl basketball tournament had been confirmed and the result had instantly become inevitable, Tom Sullivan, the new coach at Manhattan College, sought some advice from Frank McGuire, the former coach at the University of North Carolina.

title: HIGH-SCHOOL CHEFS IN TRAINING AT OWN RESTAURANT
description: WHEN Barlow's, Fairfield's newest restaurant, opened to the public recently, enthusiastic young waiters escorted patrons to the dining room, where colorful table linens, classical music and an extensive menu awaited them.

title: B.Y.U. SURPRISED BY OHIO STATE, 10-7
description: The linebacker Larry Kolic had two of four interceptions of Robbie Bosco passes, returning one 14 yards for a touchdown, to lead Ohio State to a 10-7 victory over Brigham Young in the Florida Citrus Bowl today.

title: THE MOST MEMORABLE EVENTS WERE OPERATIC PERFORMANCES
description: Does anyone doubt that music, when soft voices die, vibrates in the memory? We didn't need Shelley to tell us that. So, once again we stand at that moment of the dying year when tradition demands that vibrations be measured. The strongest waves being picked up by my own quirky seismograph come from vocal performances, mostly operatic. This may or may not appear on the meter as a distortion, depending on your interest in singing. However, there does seem to be a surge of interest in musical communication by human voice as compared with the esthetically purer but less immediately accessible medium of instrumental performance. Perhaps the reason is no more complicated than that opera works better on television.

title: RESOLUTIONS KEPT (ALMOST)
description: THE year is oozing out today, as though it were the last toothpaste in the tube - that remainder that is so hard to squeeze out, even if you roll the tube tightly in hopes of getting one more brushload out. Not that a year is a tube of toothpaste, any more than life is like a glass of tea. When it is done with, a new one automatically appears on the shelf whether you remembered to buy it or not.

title: STATE AND LILCO IN CLASH ON POWER OUTLOOK FOR LONG ISLAND
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company and the New York State Energy Office are offering widely divergent assessments of the supply and demand for electricity on Long Island for the remainder of the decade.

title: WHY PEOPLE MAKE FUN OF ECONOMISTS
description: EVERY year, between Christmas and New Year's Day, the American Economic Association holds its annual convention. For three days, several thousand economists, mostly university teachers but with a substantial number of people who work for governments, banks and other corporations and consulting firms, hang around a hotel lobby listening to each other talk. Or at least talking. The official program for this year's meeting, now under way in New York, includes hundreds of formal presentations, most with prepared discussions, and there will be hours of informal conversation.

title: DOCTOR'S EX-WIFE GETS A CUT OF HIS LICENSE
description: When Loretta O'Brien's husband divorced her in 1980 after she had spent much of their nine-year marriage helping put him through medical school, she did more than steam about it. She sought ''an equitable distribution'' of the only thing of value they had to show for their marriage: his medical license.

title: 2 SPAS TO CATER TO CALORIE COUNTERS
description: SPURRED by the increasing interest in fitness, two new health spas, one that opened in April and the other scheduled to open next summer, will be offering programs to Connecticut residents who want to lose weight, tone-up their bodies or reduce the tension in their lives. The first spa offers bare-bones rusticity and the other optimum luxury.

title: Leading Indications
description: This time of year economists feel compelled to make predictions, and they may get some help tomorrow when the Government releases the November number for its closely watched forecast of economic activity - the index of leading indicators.

title: VAST CODING OF DATA IS URGED TO HAMPER ELECTRONIC SPIES
description: The National Security Agency has initiated a five-year program to encode most of the millions of electronic messages sent each year by the Federal Government and defense contractors.

title: ENOUGH, ENOUGH OF DECEMBER'S PACE -- BRING ON JANUARY
description: THE holidays startle me.

title: GETTING PAID NOT TO SCRATCH THE SURFACE
description: President Reagan signed a farm bill last week that is expected to provide about $85 billion in Federal aid over the next three years, but it also will allow some farmers to repay their debts by expanding their participation in soil and water conservation efforts. Included in the legislation's complex rules on price supports, food stamps, exports and debt restructuring was a provision that permits farmers to take advantage of an artful real estate transaction known as a conservation easement.

title: SHUNNING THE BACK-OFFICE SPINOFF
description: MAJOR leases in new office buildings are a little like old-fashioned marriages.

title: Juliet E. Faber Bride Of Christopher Moore
description: Juliet Evelyn Faber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Faber of West Tytherley, England, was married in Winchester, England, yesterday to Christopher Somers Moore, a son of Mary Somers Moore and Joseph Adrian Clairmont Moore, both of New York. The Rev. Nicholas France performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A CRITIC'S CHOICE: THE BEST OF 1985
description: THE restaurant scene in and around the county has seen some unexpected changes during 1985. Any number of factors, such as new management or a new chef, can, for better or for worse, shake up an established restaurant. Sometimes after a particularly favorable review the chef responsible for the success leaves suddenly, or, after a place becomes popular, he allows a less competent helper to do the job or, secure in its stardom, a place stops trying. One thing a restaurant cannot hide is complacentcy; it finds its way into the dining room every time.

title: Mark Andrew Butler Marries Maria Hansen
description: At St. James Episcopal Church in Boulder, Colo., yesterday Maria Wakefield Hansen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Svend Hansen Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married to Mark Andrew Butler, a son of Karen T. Butler of Rye and the late Martin Butler. The Rev. James McKeown performed the ceremony.

title: Richard Gentile Wed To Joan R. McCarthy
description: The marriage of Joan Regina McCarthy and Richard P. Gentile, who received J.D. degrees last year from the Fordham University School of Law and are associates at New York law firms, took place yesterday at SS. John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, former president of Fordham, performed the ceremony.

title: The Bluffs At Navesink
description: To the Editor:

title: Manuel, and Giants, Are Ready for 49ers
description: The last pieces fell into place today for Sunday's National Conference wild-card playoff game between the Giants and the San Francisco 49ers at Giants Stadium.

title: Terrorist Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Improvement Seen In Heart Implant Patient
description: Doctors treating the first woman to receive an artificial heart said today that although she remained in a coma her neurological state had improved slightly.

title: SOARING LIABILITY PREMIUMS THREATEN SOME BUS LINES
description: Leaders of the nation's urban bus systems say they are having growing difficulty obtaining affordable liability insurance. As a result, they say, some systems may have to shut down and others will be forced by huge rate increases to reduce services, raise fares or operate without insurance.

title: TWO-TIME LOSER
description: Joseph Savino Jr., a former New York City Councilman, had a day-and-a-half in court on Monday.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: IRAN MAY ABANDON KHARG OIL BASE
description: Iran plans to abandon battered Kharg Island as its main oil terminal because of repeated Iraqi air raids, shipping sources said today.

title: On the Campaign Trail
description: Harriett Woods came to town looking for money. And while politicians seeking funds are not news, Mrs. Woods's trip may seem a bit unusual.

title: IN TEXAS, MONKEYS GREW BIG
description: Lou Griffin of Dilley, Tex., is losing her lease and is looking for a home for 346 monkeys. Although the monkeys are from Japan - they are Japanese snow monkeys, which have lived around temples in the mountains near Kyoto for centuries - she says they are now Texan to the core.

title: UNBEATEN MICHIGAN ROUTS CLEVELAND ST.
description: Richard Rellford scored 21 points to lead undefeated Michigan to a 105-85 victory today over Cleveland State.

title: CONCERN MOUNTING OVER RICHARDSON
description: Concern over Micheal Ray Richardson's whereabouts mounted yesterday as the Nets' playmaker, who was last seen Friday night when the Nets held their annual Christmas party in New Jersey, missed practice and failed to contact the team and his closest friends.

title: WHERE AULD ACQUAINTANCE ISN'T FORGOT
description: ONCE again President and Mrs. Reagan are planning to ring in the New Year surrounded by old friends and palm trees. Every year since he became President and even before, Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, have attended the same New Year's Eve party. Always the party is held at the desert estate of Walter and Leonore Annenberg in Palm Springs, Calif., and always the guest list of about 100 names includes friends from the Reagans' Hollywood days.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was very, very hard for me to leave the motherland, but I chose to be with my husband.'' - Helle Frejus, arriving in the United States from Moscow. [A9:1.]

title: Burkina Faso Agrees To a Truce With Mali
description: Burkina Faso and Mali have agreed to a truce in their five-day-old border conflict, according to official radio reports today from both countries.

title: Phillips Norway Plan
description: The Norwegian Oil Directorate has given the Phillips Petroleum Company Norway until Feb. 3 to submit a specific plan for saving the sinking North Sea Ekofisk field, directorate officials said. The directorate, an independent state agency, said such a plan was especially pressing because Norway is to begin renegotiating Ekofisk gas sales with continental buyers in March or April.

title: WHALERS WIN, 5-2
description: Ray Ferraro scored two goals in the Hartford Whalers' 5-2 victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Connecticut Fire Destroys 4 Stores
description: A fire that officials today called the worst in this town's history destroyed a downtown block of stores Saturday evening.

title: World Bank Candidate
description: A front runner has yet to emerge in the continuing drama over the President's selection of a president of the World Bank, succeeding A. W. Clausen.

title: When the Agency Pulls The Plug on an Account
description: When Epstein, Raboy Advertising got the Julius Wile & Sons Company's advertising business in 1983 in an account-consolidation move, the billings were reportedly $10 million. Yesterday, Ephron, Raboy, Tsao & Kurnit Advertising (the new name) announced it was resigning the business of the Buckingham Wile Division of Whitbread N.A. (the new name), and an agency spokesman said it was largely because the billings had dropped to less than $2 million in 1985.

title: Hanoi Reports Chinese Raids
description: Hanoi said today that Chinese troops backed by a heavy artillery barrage had crossed into Vietnam and battled with local villagers. The official Vietnamese News Agency, monitored in Hong Kong, said that Chinese artillery fired thousands of rounds yesterday into the northern provinces of Tinh Quang Ninh, Cao Bang and Vi Xuyen.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS DECLINE 19%
description: Orders for American-made machine tools fell 19 percent in November from their October level, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said in a report to be released today. The association said orders had declined 12.2 percent from November 1984.

title: AROUND THE WORLD, STOCK EXCHANGES MARK A STRONG YEAR
description: Investors will have fond memories of the final quarter of 1985, not only in the United States where Wall Street staged a historic rally, but also in continental Europe and elsewhere where the price of equities was helped by falling interest rates, the weaker dollar and by signs that long-suffering local economies were reviving.

title: Backer of The Nation Sees Gains by Magazine
description: ''The Nation is a 120-year-old treasure that I think should be protected, sustained and expanded,'' said Arthur L. Carter. Mr. Carter is a Connecticut multimillionaire publisher who, with two previous owners, bought The Nation last week for an undisclosed sum.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Mutual Insurance Cos., Wakefield, Mass., has appointed J. John Wortman president and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: Futures/Options;   Speculating On a Freeze
description: ONE group of eager speculators is stalking a killer - a killer freeze, that is - but so far without much success. The weapon, or technique, involves buying futures contracts covering frozen Florida orange juice concentrate.

title: CHIEF AUSTRIAN INVESTIGATOR ABSOLVE TOP P.L.O. GROUP
description: Interior Minister Karl Blecha said today that he ''rules out'' any involvement by Al Fatah, Yasir Arafat's branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in Friday's terrorist attack at the Vienna airport.

title: Article 258216 -- No Title
description: In its first four-year term, Governor Kean's administration let about $1 billion in contracts without advertising for competitive bids.

title: Bennie Morton, Trombonist With Major Jazz Orchestras
description: Bennie Morton, a trombonist who worked in the legendary jazz orchestras led by Fletcher Henderson, Chick Webb and Count Basie, died of complications from pneumonia Saturday in Harlem Hospital. He was 78 years ago and lived in Harlem.

title: MERGER GAME ALTERED BY NEW RULINGS
description: When historians size up the major business strategies of 1985 they are likely to focus not only on the many billion-dollar mergers but also on several major court decisions that will help set rules for takeover battles in years to come.

title: A Trade Issue For 1986
description: THE matter of intellectual property - patents, trademarks and copyrights - looms as one of the Reagan Administration's big trade issues for 1986 and beyond.

title: Required Reading;   Growth in Illiteracy
description: Excerpts from a statement by President Reagan Dec. 9 on a joint venture by the Public Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company to use their news, educational, and entertainment programming to raise public awareness of the scope of the problem of illiteracy in the United States:

title: OUSTER OF THEATER CURATOR PROTESTED
description: Two members of the Friends of the Theater Collection of the Museum of the City of New York have resigned in protest over the ouster of the collection's curator, Dr. Mary C. Henderson.

title: Bug Killers and Pasta to Y.&R.
description: Young & Rubicam has gotten two additional assignments from American Home Products, according to a house memo circulated at the agency last week.

title: 2 Held Hostage in Kentucky
description: A man who said he had already killed two people took two teen-age boys hostage in a house today and held the police off with gunshots, the police said.

title: THE DANCE: NIKOLAIS REUNION
description: NEW YEAR'S EVE came a little early, with a celebration of the past on Saturday night at the Nikolais/Louis DanceSpace that had the warmth and good humor of an ideal end-of-the-year party. The occasion was the Nikolais/Louis Alumni Association's third annual Scholarship Fund Concert - a return to the fold by dancers who studied and performed with Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis over four decades.

title: Chief Adds Position In Whittaker Shifts
description: Joseph F. Alibrandi has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Whittaker Corporation, filling the position of chairman that had been vacant at the diversified health care, technology and chemical company since the retirement of Eaton W. Ballard in 1982.

title: ANN BEATTIE'S LIFE AFTER REAL ESTATE
description: On a cold Chelsea morning, Ann Beattie is sitting in the brownstone basement apartment of a friend, around the corner from where she used to live. A little more than a year ago, Miss Beattie decided to leave New York and move to Charlottesville, Va.

title: Hasselbeck Wants More
description: At age 30, Don Hasselbeck is playing his first season with the Giants but his ninth in the National Football League. The 6-foot-7-inch backup tight end played for the Los Angeles Raiders when they won Super Bowl XVIII, and he wants more of the same with the Giants.

title: Susan D. Alter Is Married to a Rabbi
description: Susan D. Alter, a Democratic member of the New York City Council from Brooklyn, and Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, rabbi of Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., were married at Beth Shalom yesterday by Dr. Norman Lamm, president of Yeshiva University.

title: ISRAELIS BELIEVE PRO-LIBYA GROUP RAIDED AIRPORTS
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that it was Israel's initial assessment that the shadowy, pro-Libyan Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal was responsible for the Rome and Vienna airport attacks.

title: The Test Ban Clock Nears Midnight
description: Last August, Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, announced that his country would unilaterally stop underground testing of nuclear weapons. The moratorium will expire Wednesday; the United States rejected the invitation to follow suit as soon as it was made. Is a critical chance to moderate the arms race being lost? Hardly. A nuclear test ban is no substitute for an agreement to limit nuclear arsenals.

title: FIRST WOMAN ON SOVIET EXIT LIST REACHES U.S.
description: Helle Frejus, the first of eight Soviet citizens to have been given permission by Moscow to live with their spouses in the United States, arrived at the Baltimore-Washington International Airport this afternoon.

title: 49ERS FRUSTRATED IN EFFORTS TO FIND OFFENSIVE TOUCH
description: Punt. Punt. Punt. Interception. Field goal. Punt. Fumble. Punt. Punt. Downs. Downs. Downs. That's how the San Francisco 49ers' drives ended today. That's how they lost to the Giants, 17-3, in the National Conference wild-card game. That's how they relinquished the National Football League championship they won 11 months ago, nearly 3,000 miles away in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: MEAT CUTTERS END 8-WEEK-OLD STRIKE
description: By a narrow margin, meat cutters from the United Food and Commercial Workers union voted today to end a long and bitter strike against 1,000 supermarkets across Southern California and return to their jobs immediately.

title: Baby Hippopotamus Dies
description: A baby hippopotamus was born Saturday at Audubon Zoo, surprising zoo keepers who had not known its mother was pregnant, but the 82-pound baby drowned several hours later while swimming with its mother. The baby hippo, thought to be a female, was placed in a pool with its mother and father shortly after birth, but after submerging it did not reappear. ''It was not very easy to recover it with the mother in there,'' David Anderson, the curator, said.

title: The Bride Wore a Lab Coat of Peau de Soie
description: To the Editor:

title: 'POOR KID' OF SUBURBS FIGHTS BACK
description: As the camera closes in on the face of a blonde teen-ager, a man's voice declares, ''Jane McCabe is into drugs, every day in school, in Prince Georges County.'' When the girl dons a pair of laboratory goggles and the camera rolls back to show microscopes and beakers, it becomes clear that the advertisement has nothing to do with illegal drugs but with the schools of the large Maryland county that abuts the District of Columbia.

title: DRUG ABUSERS' CHILDREN FIND OASES OF CONCERN
description: Pedro Martinez rarely initiates a conversation and often covers his pale face with his hands, peering at the world from between his fingers.

title: Polish Priest Applauded On Denouncing Leaders
description: Some 10,000 worshipers at a Warsaw church applauded a priest today who denounced Poland's Communist rulers and praised the banned Solidarity labor union.

title: MAN DIES IN A BLAZE ON WEST SIDE THAT LEAVES 93 PEOPLE HOMELESS
description: One man was killed and 93 people were left homeless by a three-alarm fire that whipped through two buildings on the Upper West Side yesterday afternoon, police and other officials reported.

title: REGAN CITES U.D.C. AS FAILING TO KEEP FILES ON PROJECT AID
description: The State Urban Development Corporation cannot accurately measure the costs or benefits of economic development projects it has assisted, the State Comptroller said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: FOLKLORE HELPS TO SOLVE MISS LIBERTY'S MYSTERY
description: The solution to one of the Statue of Liberty's last remaining mysteries, the source of its green copper skin, has been found at the end of a trail that led from Staten Island to a defunct copper mine on a Norwegian island in the North Sea.

title: ORDINARY PEOPLE DDBATE ON U.S.-SOVIET TV LINK
description: About 175 Americans from the Seattle area confronted a similar number of Russians in Leningrad today in a 2 1/2-hour telecast that linked the two countries by satellite.

title: Venezuelan Oil Sales Off
description: Venezuela's oil revenues dropped almost 19 percent in 1985 over the previous year while export volumes fell 10 percent, industry officials said Friday.

title: SOLAR POWER'S FUTURE UNCLEAR AS TAX CREDIT FACES END
description: After eight years of benefiting from a heavy Federal subsidy, homeowners who want to replace natural gas, oil or electricity with energy from the sun are likely to be shoved out into the cold of the open market on Jan. 1.

title: WHISTLE BLOWS FOR A COMPANY TOWN
description: When the Northern Pacific Railroad laid its steel ribbons across Montana in 1882, it reserved 300 acres along the Yellowstone River near here for one of the largest locomotive repair yards in the country.

title: DEBATE WIDENS ON PLANS TO RESTRICT PIT BULL DOGS
description: When the dogs finished with her, Angie Hands's right leg was gnawed to the bone. Flesh and muscle had been gouged from her upper arms, and her ear was torn in half.

title: Holiday Truce Is Broken, Salvador Prelate Says
description: The Archbishop of San Salvador said today that there were reports that both the army and leftist guerrillas had violated a Christmas truce.

title: Honolulu Voters Elect Democrats to Council
description: Three Democrats scored landslide victories in a special election Saturday to fill City Council seats left vacant by the recall of three members who had switched to the Republican Party.

title: GREAT KICKERS, TO BOOT
description: While sentiment is growing among coaches to have college football rules changed to make it more difficult to get field goals, there is a good chance the 1985 season may end with one or more of the five New Year's Day bowl games decided by a place-kicker. Even the final No. 1 ranking could be settled by a kicker in the Orange Bowl - Penn State's Massimo Manca or Oklahoma's Tim Lashar.

title: TREATING FACIAL PARALYSIS: SUCCESS IN SOME CASES
description: For 30 minutes each week, Bonnie, a Manhattan travel agent, sits in front of a computer and diligently works on perfecting her smile. She is not a contender for the Miss America pageant. Nor does she aspire to model for toothpaste advertisements. What she wants to do is straighten out her slightly crooked smile, a consequence of brain surgery five years ago that left her face partly paralyzed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WHAT TO WEAR The United Nations may be the center of the most diverse world dress that we have in New York. Visitors and those who have business there often, but not always, wear garments of the sort most people sport back home. There are saris and burnooses, cardigans and dashikis along First Avenue, and one may sometimes be curious enough to learn more about how other folks dress and what their attire is made of.

title: FOR FEAR-DRIVEN MOZAMBICANS, A NIGHTMARE TREK
description: The name of this forlorn village means ''We came to this place by foot.''

title: The Wrong Way to Treat Mexico
description: Last year, Americans expected too much of Mexico. Now they expect too little. Such swings are dangerous and produce complacency or despair. Both exacerbate Mexico's problems. Until it nearly defaulted on its debt in August 1982, Mexico was one of the most stable countries in the hemisphere. That political stability has gone hand-in-hand with economic growth. To assure continued stability, the United States should support Mexico's efforts to open its economy and reduce the role of the state.

title: POPULATION OF U.S. ROSE 5.4% SINCE '80
description: The population of the United States rose to 238,740,000 as of July 1, a growth rate of 5.4 percent over the last five years, the Census Bureau reported today. Southern and Western states accounted for more than 90 percent of the population increase of 12.2 million people, the bureau said.

title: Catching Up
description: At their meetings in Phoenix last March, a majority of owners decided that the National Football League should try to reduce the length of league games.

title: Boy's Life Aims to Do Its Best on Ad Pages
description: J. Warren Young, publisher of Boy's Life, and Robert E. Hood, editor, were in town from their Irving, Tex., headquarters recently, anxious to stimulate advertising in the 75th anniversary issue of their magazine due out in March.

title: New Lease for Kodak
description: Long a part of the Grand Central Terminal tableau, the Kodak Colorama is now destined to be part of it for at least two years longer.

title: 2 Officers Injured At Triborough
description: A driver who could not pay the $1.50 toll at the Triborough Bridge slammed a car door on one officer's hand and dragged another officer about 30 feet with his car as he fled, authorities said yesterday.

title: SCHOOLCHILDREN INSPIRED TO HELP THE NEEDIEST
description: Schoolchildren are among the many contributors moved by the plight of the city's poor to donate to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: LEMIEUX EQUAL TO CHALLENGE
description: Mario Lemieux, the player responsible for the future of the Pittsburgh Penguins, tightened his thin lips into a grimace as he pondered their recent past. On Saturday night, in front of a sellout crowd in a city just beginning to place its faith and wages in the team, the Penguins had a chance to move into third place in the Patrick Division, but failed.

title: HANGAR PLAQUE HONORS C.I.A.'S AIR OPERATIVE
description: The anonymity that George A. Doole Jr. cultivated in life very nearly followed him to the grave.

title: High Pay for Federal Workers
description: Federal law requires that the Government pay its workers what their counterparts in industry are paid. But according to the National Bureau of Economic Research, an assistant professor at Dartmouth has produced a study for the bureau contending that the wages of men in Government jobs are 4 percent more than for men in the private sector and the wages of women Government workers are 22 percent higher than private-sector women.

title: Bridge: Defensive Move Thwarted By Uncooperative Partner
description: A defender can often say to himself: ''If only I could gain the lead I would have the rest of the tricks.''

title: STRAINS ON PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS
description: In 1962, a young venture capitalist named Robert L. Green bought a psychiatric hospital south of San Francisco, intending to use the site for an apartment complex. But after studying his acquisition, Mr. Green stuck with the hospital.

title: It's a Snap
description: In an era when college football linemen average 250 pounds or so, Terry Theodore is something special as well as some specialist: a 220-pound center who has been on scholarship for four years at U.C.L.A. merely to be the snapper on field goals and extra points. And because he snaps for John Lee, who by the end of the regular season this fall had set an N.C.A.A. career record with 79 field goals, he now calls himself ''the most highly publicized long-snapper ever.''

title: FOREIGNERS' POLITICAL ROLES IN U.S. GROW BY INVESTING
description: Japanese business executives warned that they would curtail their investments in the United States if Congress ended the favorable tax treatment they have received.

title: DIVING TO ANDREA DOREA
description: EVERY man is entitled to pursue his heart's desire. And if Peter Gimbel had the money, time and skills to lead an expedition to raise a safe from the Andrea Doria, who is to say him nay? But it does not follow that he had to make a television program about it.

title: WIDER BAN ON FORCED RETIREMENT BEGINS IN STATE OF NEW YEAR'S DAY
description: Mandatory retirement of most employees will be barred in New York State under a law that takes full effect on New Year's Day.

title: Tax Package Lobbying
description: Business lobbyists are already descending on the Senate, the next arena in the drive to overhaul the income tax system.

title: RANGERS WIN, 6-5, ON RALLY
description: When the night begins with the news that your best player will be lost for a few weeks and the opposition grabs the lead when the puck plops in off the back of your goaltender's head, you know you have troubles. But that, after all, is what life with the Rangers has been like of late.

title: Talks Sought on Midcon Bid
description: The partnership formed by Wagner & Brown and Freeport-McMoran Inc. to acquire the Midcon Corporation offered yesterday to discuss raising its bid of $62.50 a share for Midcon's 41.5 million shares.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Doesn't Lefty O'Doul deserve to be ranked among the baseball hitters with career averages above .320 who are not in the Hall of Fame? Does he hold any batting records?

title: Assad Meets Leaders Of Lebanese Factions
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today with leaders of three Lebanese factions and offered assurances that Syria would help carry out an agreement designed to end Lebanon's 10-year-old civil war.

title: Of Ducks and Mules
description: If it looks like a duck, quacks like a duck and walks with a limp, it must be a lame duck. But not always, as a healthy duck named Reagan has just demonstrated.

title: Dixon Takes 800-Meter Race
description: Diane Dixon, despite suffering from a cold that made ''every lap tough,'' won the 800-meter run in 2 minutes 14.8 seconds today in the Metropolitan Athletics Congress Adidas Holiday Invitational track and field meet in Army's fieldhouse.

title: SAVVY 7-YEAR-OLD TAKES MODELING TO HEART
description: The actress -49 inches tall, 7 years old and missing three teeth - stood in the center of her den and patiently explained the difference between television commercials and real life.

title: O'BRIEN AGAIN BOUNCES BACK
description: WHEN the Jets voted Ken O'Brien their most valuable player last week, many of them talked about the way the young quarterback could recover immediately from being hit. O'Brien said he could bounce back because ''my mind's not on my body.''

title: Deborah Burns Is the Bride of Bjorn Eric Nielsen
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Burns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Burns of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., to Bjorn Eric Nielsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Egon B. Nielsen of Leatherhead, Surrey, England, took place yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Martin performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Yorktown Heights.

title: Knicks' Tucker Sidelined
description: The injury-plagued Knicks, who have problems scoring points, have lost Trent Tucker, their best pure shooter, for a week to 10 days with an injured right shoulder. The 6-foot-5-inch guard aggrevated the injury in a fall with 6 minutes and 9 seconds remaining in the, 100-80, loss to the Atlanta Hawks, which ended the Knicks' four-game winning streak Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: PENN STATE PASSER: UNSPECTACULAR SUCCESS
description: THE numbers do not ever seem to go away. It is one thing for John Shaffer to be reminded of them on Saturday afternoons in the fall, when he takes the field as the quarterback at Penn State. It is understandable that those who make a living searching for imperfections would look at the numbers next to Shaffer's name, circle them with red ink, and wonder why they are so.

title: U.S. Reports Rise in Attacks On Its Border Patrol Agents
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service says violence against its agents along the Mexican border around San Diego rose 37.5 percent this year.

title: Boston School of Ballet Cleared of Discrimination
description: The Massachusetts Commission against Discrimination has ruled that the Boston School of Ballet did not discriminate against a black student in not promoting her to a preprofessional class.

title: Roberta Ann Steinfeld Weds Jonathan V. Jacobson
description: Roberta Ann Steinfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Steinfeld of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Jonathan V. Jacobson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton R. Jacobson of Hicksville, L.I. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York.

title: MILITANCY SAID TO GROW FOR YOUNG PALESTINIANS
description: Growing militancy among young Palestinians is pumping new life into extremist guerrilla factions, according to sources here who are close to the Palestinians.

title: South Africa Project
description: After the first of the year, J. Douglas Holladay, who is now with the White House office of public liaison, will become the director of the State Department's working group on Southern Africa. Mr. Holladay will hold the rank of ambassador and will be working in the United States with members of Congress, corporations and higher education and religious groups; in Europe especially with the British and West Germans, South Africa's biggest trading partners; and in South Africa itself.

title: What Nelson Saw
description: To the Editor:

title: SOONERS PUT TOGETHER WINNING BLEND ON DEFENSE
description: AT nose guard, the winner of the Lombardi Award as the best college football lineman of 1985 was once not thrilled about the idea of subjecting his body to pain during each autumn weekend. At strong-side linebacker, the winner of the first Butkus Award as the best linebacker in the nation hardened an already intense appearance by shaving the hair on the sides of his head, dyeing the top yellow, and allowing a small tail to grow down his neck. His look threatens to revolutionize the hair-cutting industry in the state of Oklahoma.

title: Frank K. Greenwall, 89, Dies; Ex-Chief of Chemical Concern
description: Frank K. Greenwall, the former president and chairman of the National Starch and Chemical Corporation, died of heart failure at his weekend residence in Holmdel, N.J., Saturday. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BURGER SAYS VACANCIES ADD TO 'JUDICIAL DEFICIT'
description: In his annual report on the judiciary, Chief Justice of the United States Warren E. Burger complains of a ''judicial deficit'' created by a shortage of judges and a backlog of cases.

title: Democrats' Economic Vacuum
description: Democratic Party leaders will not produce a coherent alternative to President Reagan's economic policies until they challenge his fundamental notion of how the economy works. Unwilling to make that challenge, Democrats in Congress have diverted themselves with a search for unoffending new ideas to make marginal changes in taxes, deficits and trade.

title: NEW ZEALAND SEIZES ARMS ON SHIP
description: Customs officials raided a French freighter tonight and confiscated 25 packages of automatic weapons and ammunition, the authorities said.

title: Plant Worker Hurt In a 5-Alarm Fire
description: A five-alarm fire at a plastics factory injured a worker and sent a large black cloud of smoke into the air today, forcing the temporary evacuation of 500 residents of a nearby condominium development, officials said.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Knicks, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. When these teams met on Dec. 12, New Jersey triumphed for the ninth consecutive time, winning by 108-85.

title: 11.26% Stake In Mercury
description: Mercury Securities said today that Reliance Group Holding Inc. of the United States, which is controlled by the financier Saul P. Steinberg, had raised its stake in Mercury to 11.26 percent, through the purchase of an additional 250,000 shares.

title: Bond Prices Rose Last Week
description: Despite the seasonal slowdown in fixed-income market activity, or perhaps because of it, investors continued to snap up Treasury and tax-exempt debt issues last week.

title: LEGAL CHIEF, ONCE A JUDGE, WIELDS WIDE INFLUENCE
description: Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department's legal adviser, was well prepared for his recent efforts to enlist Israel's help in an investigation of charges of espionage by a Navy employee on behalf of a small Israeli intelligence agency.

title: FOR OREGON DRUNKEN DRIVERS, A CLOSE-UP LOOK AT SKID ROW
description: The alcoholics who spend the nights on the damp sidewalks of Old Town were beginning to look for their first drink at 8:30 on a recent Saturday morning. In a 24-hour restaurant on the first floor of a rundown hotel, six outsiders were ordering breakfast.

title: DEFENSE IS THE KEY
