description: What made the difference for the Giants against the San Francisco 49ers today was the New York pass rush up the middle that came chiefly from Jim Burt, Leonard Marshall and George Martin, the key defensive linemen.

title: PRACTICALITIES OF NUCLEAR-FREE ZONES
description: Last year this small city on the Hudson River declared itself the first nuclear-free zone in New Jersey.

title: STAGE: GORKY'S 'CHILDREN OF THE SUN'
description: IN recent years, through the efforts of the Royal Shakespeare Company, we have come to realize that Maxim Gorky is a playwright of great humanity, as well as revolutionary fervor. The Royal Shakespeare rediscovery continued last summer with a production at Stratford-on-Avon of ''Philistines.'' Now, 80 years after the play was written, the Mirror Repertory Company is offering New York audiences an opportunity to see another Gorky, ''Children of the Sun,'' in a translation by Ariadne Nicolaeff.

title: FED TO CURB BANKS' FUNDS TRANSFERS
description: Concerned about the electronic payment systems that banks use to send money around the nation, the Federal Reserve Board is moving to introduce a sweeping change in how the systems are operated.

title: ISLANDERS AND POWER FAIL, 4-3
description: It was hockey in the gloom, something akin to the pond hockey these athletes played before ascending to the National Hockey League, and the Buffalo Sabres responded with vigor tonight at Memorial Auditorium where a second-period power failure extinguished the scoreboard, time clocks and overhead lights. It also defused the Islanders, who lost, 4-3.

title: PERU TAKES CONTROL OF BELCO'S ASSETS
description: Police with submachine guns surrounded the headquarters here of the New York-based Belco Petroleum Corporation on Saturday after the Government nationalized the company, froze its bank accounts and took control of its local assets.

title: River Ice Menaces Towns In Michigan and Oregon
description: Ice chunks blocking the Snake River on the Oregon-Idaho border yesterday pushed flood waters over the banks and threatened one city's water supply as the National Guard moved in to help evacuate residents near the river.

title: The Bride Wore a Lab Coat of Peau de Soie
description: To the Editor:

title: The Vatican Must Earn the Moral Recognition of the Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: WALTON PRAISES JETS AND LOOKS TO FUTURE
description: Coach Joe Walton told his players today, the day after they were eliminated from the National Football League playoffs, that he was proud of them. His praise indicated not only how far the team had come, but how far Walton had, too.

title: BUFFALO MEETS RECORD SNOW WITH A SHRUG
description: About midway through the weekend, the National Weather Service announced that 5 feet 2 1/2 inches of snow had fallen on Buffalo this month - more than during any other December in recorded history.

title: JETS RISKING FINES OVER DRUG TESTS
description: All the Jets who refused today to take a drug test as part of the season-ending physical - and apparently most declined - will be fined $1,000 each, said Jim Kensil, the team president.

title: Gandhi Asks His Party To Strengthen India
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi called on Indians today to shun foreign goods and catch up with developed countries in technology.

title: Sudanese Will Vote On April 1, Rulers Say
description: The Sudan's military rulers, who have promised to restore democracy, announced today that the country's first general elections in nearly two decades would be held over 12 days starting April 1.

title: A Time to Reach Out For a Phone Company
description: On New Year's Day the 100-year-old New England Telephone will break its very first brand awareness campaign, something it never needed when there was no alternative to its services except silence.

title: LESOTHO BURIES 6 SLAIN IN BORDER RAID
description: Six South African exiles shot dead in a border raid that Lesotho ascribes to South African troops were buried with state and guerrilla honors today in a funeral attended by American and foreign envoys.

title: TERRORISTS REPORTEDLY TRAINED IN IRAN
description: The head of Italian military intelligence said in a newspaper interview published today that four terrorists who killed 12 people at the Rome Airport on Friday had been trained in Iran and entered Italy by way of Syria.

title: Storm-Hit Towns Get Lilco Credits
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced yesterday that $96,000 in credits had been given to municipalities where street and traffic lights were interrupted by Hurricane Gloria in September.

title: DINESON A BIG SELLER AGAIN WITH FILM TIE-IN
description: The film ''Out of Africa,'' starring Meryl Streep and Robert Redford, has spurred a revival of interest in Isak Dinesen's works. A half-dozen books by or about her have been published to coincide with the release of the movie, with the result that the life and times of a writer who died in 1962 are suddenly big news in the bookstores.

title: TERROR IN 1985: BRUTAL ATTACKS, TOUGH RESPONSE
description: As a year of hijackings, kidnappings, car bombings and murder draws to a close, reports from correspondents of The New York Times around the world indicate that governments have hardened their attitudes and toughened security measures against a growing plague of terrorism.

title: Trial Witness Dead in Wreck
description: A woman killed in a car crash Saturday was identified today as a prosecution witness in the espionage trial of Richard W. Miller, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent.

title: Pakistani Leader Names Four to Governor Posts
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq named three retired army officers and one civilian today as governors for Pakistan's four provinces.

title: Democracy Undermines Democracy
description: The new National Endowment for Democracy is a useful agency that has strayed from its mission, strengthening free institutions in third-world countries. Could anyone who favored its creation in 1983 have expected that it would siphon off funds to an opposition group in France? Yet a grant of $575,000 flowed to a right-wing student group.

title: What Garment Makers Can Do About Knockoffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Shakes Caribbean
description: A moderate earthquake shook the eastern Dominican Republic Saturday, the Federal Geological Survey said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1985
description: International Israel's initial assessment of blame for the terrorist attacks at the Rome and Vienna airports Friday is that the shadowy, pro-Libyan Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal was reponsible. At a meeting with an American delegation, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said ''I cannot say for sure, but that is our impression.'' [Page A1, Col. 6.]

title: Egypt and France Talk
description: Presidents Francois Mitterrand and Hosni Mubarak discussed Middle East problems and relations between their two countries today over a working dinner, officials said.

title: SOVIET TEAMS LOSE
description: The Flames scored a 4-3 victory over Moscow Dynamo in Calgary and the Nordiques defeated the Central Red Army Team, 5-1, in Quebec last night.

title: IN COLORADO, THE BREATHTAKING VISTAS NOW INCLUDE TRAFFIC JAMS
description: Colorado's tourist promoters unveiled a new ''Guess I'd Rather Be in Colorado'' campaign a while back. It was built around pictures of mountain vistas empty of all but solitary hikers and picturesque wildlife.

title: Narrowing the Search
description: Congressional Quarterly, the Washington research service, offers a computerized information bank called Washington Alert that keeps its clients up to date on the status of bills in Congress. In the process, it has accumulated personal statistics about each senator and representative so it can tell clients in a flash how many legislators are farmers or Lutherans or parents of teen-aged children, the kind of information that any lobbyist needs to build a constituency for his cause.

title: ERNEST A. BAMMAN
description: Ernest A. Bamman, a retired official of the New York State Public Service Commission, died of cancer Friday at Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital in Dobbs Ferry. He was 80 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: U.S. TRIES TO CLARIFY STAND ON AN ISRAELI RESPONSE
description: The Reagan Administration, seeking to clarify its policy on whether Israel should retaliate for the attacks at the Rome and Vienna airports, said today that Israel's response should be ''measured'' so as not to provoke a new round of Middle East fighting.

title: DISSIDENTS CLAIMING CONTROL OF CAMBODIA GUERRILLA GROUP
description: A breakaway group trying to seize control of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, the larger of two non-Communist groups fighting to oust the Vietnamese from Cambodia, says it now controls the organization's civilian border camps as well as its army.

title: Head of Kroch's Selling Book Chain to Its Staff
description: After 33 years as the president of Kroch's & Brentano's, Chicago's oldest and largest bookstore chain, Carl A. Kroch has decided that it is time he slowed down and worked only 60 hours a week.

title: OUTSIDERS RAISING STAKES TO BREAK STALEMATE IN ANGOLA
description: Ten years after Angola's birth by civil war, the fighting rages on and neither side seems close to victory.

title: China Issues Patents
description: China issued its first patents since the Communist takeover in 1949 and promised to observe patent law, the New China News Agency said. It said 143 patent certificates were issued, 27 of them to concerns from Denmark, West Germany, Holland, Japan, Norway, Switzerland and the United States. The patents bureau has received more than 14,000 applications, a third of them from abroad, since April, the news agency said.

title: 2 FOES OF APARTHEID KILLED IN CAR CRASH
description: Molly Blackburn, one of South Africa's most prominent white campaigners against apartheid, and a fellow activist, Brian Bishop, were killed in a car accident Saturday night, the police said today.

title: Making Head Lines
description: Several weeks ago, skiing's world governing body adopted a rule change that for the first time allows the sport's competitors to place sponsorship logos on their attire and headgear. With that change, the International Ski Federation has created what may be, inch for inch, the most expensive advertising space in sports history. Some of the leading World Cup racers are talking of selling space on their heads for as much as $50,000. Or even more. Doug Lewis, the leading downhiller on the United States Ski Team, is said to be negotiating for $60,000.

title: Union of Concerned Scientists Is Pro Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Closes Year With Bill Sale
description: The United States Treasury will close its 1985 regular bill auctions today with the sale of $5.2 billion of 90- and 180-day bills, and will start its 1986 funding program by auctioning $6.5 billion of seven-year notes on Thursday.

title: DRY DATA ON LAND AND POWER MAKE FOR BEST SELLER IN HAWAII
description: A privately printed book crammed full of the driest of data from real estate records and legislative dockets has become a local best seller here in only two months.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:47 A.M. today and set at 9:38 P.M. tonight.

title: WESTERN EUROPEANS, SOME WITH DOUBTS, SUPPORT 'STAR WARS'
description: The United States space-based missile defense program has steadily gained grudging support among America's major allies in Western Europe.

title: Terrorism Is a Matter Of Ends and Means
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN ALMANAC
description: ROGER MUDD wrestles tonight, sort of, with Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, on NBC's ''American Almanac.'' It's an interesting example of a peculiar genre of television interviewing. Meanwhile, the rest of the program, on Channel 4 at 10, is pretty good.

title: Outdoors: Revolutionary Style in Nordic Skiing
description: EARLIER this month, when Marjo Matikainen of Finland won the first women's race of the 1985-1986 World Cup cross-country ski season, at Labrador City, Newfoundland, she did not put kick wax on her skis, she did not do one step of the diagonal stride, she did not even ski in the tracks except to go downhill. Miss Matikainen skated the entire 5-kilometer course, as did every other participant in this international field.

title: Spain Supports VW Venture
description: Spain's Socialist Cabinet agreed Friday on a $1.1 billion financial package to enable Volkswagen to take 51 percent ownership of the ailing state car maker, SEAT, a Government spokesman said.

title: More Cocaine Bags Found
description: Three more duffel bags filled with cocaine, believed to have been dropped by a drug smuggler who fell to his death parachuting from a plane, have been found hanging in a tree near this northwest Georgia town. The discovery Saturday in the Chattahoochee National Forest brought to eight the number of duffel bags, containing a total of about 520 pounds of cocaine, found in north Georgia since the parachutist's death Sept. 11, the authorities said.

title: B.B.D.O. Wins Line Of Polaroid
description: BATTEN, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, which has been doing direct marketing work for Polaroid, has now won the corporation's entire domestic consumer account, which covers both its amateur photographic equipment and half-inch videotape.

title: ON NEW YEAR'S DAY, A SCRAMBLE TO BE NO.1
description: If Penn State, undefeated and ranked No. 1, wins the Orange Bowl Wednesday night, the issue of who is No. 1 for this season will be settled. But if the Nittany Lions lose to heavily favored Oklahoma, there will be a scramble for the final top ranking in the news-agency polls that will become public midday Thursday.

title: BLACKS URGE END TO SCHOOL PROTEST IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A national conference of black parents, students and teachers urged radical black high school students of South Africa today to lift a boycott of classes that has crippled the nation's segregated educational system for months.

title: MICHAEL BLAKEMORE TALKS ABOUT HIS 2D FRAYN PLAY
description: When Michael Blakemore first read the script of Michael Frayn's ''Noises Off,'' a fast-paced, insanely complicated farce, he quailed at the thought of staging it. The prospect ''made me want to go lie down at once,'' Mr. Blakemore said.

title: How Many Tennial?
description: Perhaps on the theory that it is never too soon to start worrying about some things, the question is put: What is the word to denote a 500th anniversary?

title: GIANTS STOP 49ERS IN WILD-CARD PLAYOFF, 17-3
description: Bring on the Chicago Bears.

title: The Way Out
description: Jim Dennison couldn't have known that his successful tenure at the University of Akron and Gerry Faust's unsuccessful tenure at Notre Dame would combine to help put him out of a job. But that's what happened, and now Dennison, at age 47 and after 13 years as head coach at Akron, is trying to find someplace else to teach football.

title: 2 SEA LIONS IMPERIL STEELHEAD TROUT RUN IN WEST
description: The steelhead trout that fight their way up the fish ladders at the Lake Washington ship canal on their way to spawn have run into a pair of voracious predators, two California sea lions that have become something of a local tourist attraction.

title: Agency Search Leaves No Stone Unturned
description: If you have always wanted to known what ''left no stone unturned'' meant and were too embarrassed to ask, a recent agency search by the Coleman Company of Wichita, Kan., is a good demonstration.

title: Alienating the Future
description: The U.S. Ambassador to South Africa, Herman W. Nickel, has taken issue with a statement of mine in a recent column. I wrote that many black South Africans, offended by Reagan Administration policies toward their country, now refuse even to attend embassy functions. Ambassador Nickel says that his embassy hosts more black community leaders than any other diplomatic mission.

title: BOOKINGS DOWN, TOUR AGENTS SAY
description: Americans are apparently becoming more wary of overseas travel as a result of hijackings and other terrorist acts, according to a sampling of travel agents. They report that bookings to Rome, Athens and the Middle East have declined in recent months.

title: 'STRICTLY BUSINESS'
description: IN dethroning the San Francisco 49ers as Super Bowl champions, the Giants not only won a big game, but they won it in a big way. With a pass-rush that had Joe Montana ''throwing off his back foot,'' as Coach Bill Parcells said, they held the 49ers without a touchdown for the first time in two years. Phil Simms threw for 181 yards and both touchdowns while Joe Morris rushed for 141 yards with virtually no turnovers - no fumbles and one interception that occurred as time expired in the first half.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Plight of the Boomers
description: According to the ads, the toughest problem before young, working Americans is whether to order the Saab Turbo in traditional metallic silver or chic new platinum blue. But according to researchers at the Urban Institute, the economic choices confronting most Americans under 40 should be colored Debit Gray. As two public-policy analysts, Profs. Frank Levy and Richard Michel, make clear, the baby boomers are inheriting a disproportionate share of the burden of the nation's demographic instability and economic mismanagement.

title: School Bus Belts Need a State Law
description: New York's Suffolk County has abandoned a law to require seat belts in school buses, but mainly to make its point: If the state's schoolchildren are to have the protection they need, the Legislature will have to give it to them. The county abandoned its law in a consent decree settling a suit brought by three school districts. They charged that the Suffolk law, enacted last year, usurped the authority of the state and local school boards.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LIKE the daring Italian directors of the neorealistic films of the late 1940's and early 1950's who opened the aperture of freedom after the darkness of the Fascist era, Alberto Moravia emerged from the postwar years a liberated writer. While not as active politically in World War II Italy as such novelists as Carlo Levi, Giorgio Bassani, Italo Calvino or Elio Vittorini (or Ignazio Silone, who was in Swiss exile), Moravia and his wife, Elsa Morante, were also on the run toward the end of the war because of his anti-Fascist polemics. In his novels, Moravia's breakout from the strictures of the past took a different turn: rebellion against middle-class convention and sexual puritanism.

title: COMMENTS CLOUD BOXER'S COMEBACK
description: The story seemed a remarkable tale of one man's determination to overcome. In a high school gym in Palos Heights, Ill., on Dec. 14, Craig Bod zianowski, a 24-year-old cruiserweight, had knocked out Francis Sargent in two rounds in his first fight since part of his right leg was amputated following a motorcycle accident in June 1984.

title: Fund Manager Is Optimistic
description: IN the autumn of last year, James S. Martin was asked to characterize prospects for the stock market in 1985. ''It will be a period,'' he replied, ''of waiting for the clouds to pass and for the sun to shine through.''

title: Mr. G.J.G. Posts Aqueduct Upset
description: Kerry Nagle's Mr. G. J. G. led all the way to post a half-length upset victory yesterday in the $73,500 Alex M. Robb stakes for New York-breds 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct.

title: AS MAJORS RETURNS TO TENNESSEE, SO DOES SUCCESS
description: WHEN the call came from the familiar Smoky Mountains of Tennessee in 1976, Johnny Majors was sitting on top of another kind of peak as the coach of the top-ranked team in college football, the University of Pittsburgh. Tim McGee, Tennessee's all-America wide receiver, was just a youngster then, a fan wondering why a coach would leave a successful program for the ordeal of starting over. It would be another six years before McGee's question was answered.

title: More Plans, More Study
description: The Colorama is not the only illuminated display at Grand Central in which Kodak will be involved.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1985
description: Companies

title: Seeking Castellano's Killers
description: ''The New York City Police Department Requests Your Help,'' the flier begins. ''On Monday, December 16, 1985, at about 5:25 P.M., two men were shot and killed in front of Sparks Steak House at 210 E. 46th St., just east of 3rd Ave.''

title: HONG KONG EXPORTERS ADJUST TO U.S. RULES
description: On the first floor of Kenneth Fang's garment factory stand dozens of sleek new machines, automatically knitting bright spools of yarn into sweater parts. The machines, purchased last year for $6.4 million, represent one cost of American textile restrictions here.

title: 2 NEW AGENCIES FOR HOUSING AID PROPOSED IN CITY
description: New York City should establish two new agencies to build, rehabilitate and finance housing for low- and middle-income people, according to a nonprofit group that specializes in housing issues.

title: Manila Court Orders An Aquino Estate Seized
description: A court has ordered the Government to seize the sugar plantation owned by the family of Corazon C. Aquino, the opposition presidential candidate, for purported failure to comply with land regulations, family sources said today.

title: SOVIET SAYS IT DIDN'T BREAK ARMS ACCORDS BUT U.S. DID
description: The Soviet Union today rejected Washington's charges that Moscow had failed to comply with arms control agreements and said the United States was itself guilty of violations.

title: SOVIET SPOKESMAN ON AMERICAN TV
description: Since Vladimir Posner first appeared on American television in 1978 speaking flawless English with a Brooklyn accent, he has become one of the most visible spokesmen the Soviet Union ever put in front of a microphone.

title: COMPLEX CARBIDE CHESS GAME
description: A $5 billion battle of wits to take over the Union Carbide Corporation that began in early December continued over the weekend, with Carbide and its unfriendly suitor, the GAF Corporation, fighting to determine the future of the giant chemical company.

title: IMPORTANT MEETING FOR TEXACO
description: Executives from Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company are scheduled to meet again today in a negotiating session that could be crucial in determining whether the two oil companies can reach a settlement in their high-stakes legal dispute, sources said yesterday.

title: Dr. H. Warren Dunham Dead; Studied Urban Schizophrenia
description: Dr. H. Warren Dunham, a sociologist known for his research in the epidemiology of mental disorders in cities, died Dec. 16 after a long illness at his home in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: DISCIPLINE RULING AT AUTISM FACILITY
description: A Massachusetts state agency agreed yesterday to reconsider its order barring a school for autistic children from using a program of physical punishments as treatment.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Colonial Penn Group Inc., an insurance company based in Philadelphia, said its shareholders had approved a previously announced plan to be acquired by FPL Group Inc.

title: 'JUNK BOND' CURB: MIXED VIEW
description: A substantial part of the nation's business and financial establishment supports the Federal Reserve Board's effort to limit corporate takeovers financed by ''junk bonds,'' according to publicly available comments filed with the central bank.

title: Sampling of the Best 1985 Products
description: HUNDREDS of new computer products were introduced in 1985, and it is fitting that we pause at this time to sort through the pile. Several organizations name ''Products of the Year,'' and following is a sampling.

title: Topics;   Questions of Image Cartoon for Kids
description: ''We are the world, we are the children.'' Those words, when sung by Michael Jackson, Bruce Springsteen, Tina Turner and 40 other rock stars, helped open hearts and wallets to the plight of starving children in Ethiopia.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Dec 14
Venture for Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, taking another step into biotechnology, said it was joining the Nutrisearch Company, a venture begun in 1982 by the Corning Glass Works and the Kroger Company. The venture will be reorganized and incorporated as the Nutrisearch International Corporation, with each partner holding a one-third interest. The biotechnology concern is involved in the production of commercial food products from dairy byproducts.

title: Article 261210 -- No Title
description: Norstar Bancorp Inc. has agreed to pay a $269,904 fine for the failure of three of its subsidiaries to report currency transactions, the Treasury Department said today. The department said the subsidiaries, Norstar Bank of Albany, Liberty Norstar of Buffalo and Norstar Bank of Bangor, Me., failed to report transactions from 1980 to 1985 as required by the Bank Secrecy Act. The Treasury said it had no evidence the banks ''knowingly engaged in money laundering.''

title: FOR KOCH, 1985 WAS A YEAR OF PROMISES, WITH SOME UNFULFILLED
description: Election years always present incumbents with an opportunity to make promises, and 1985 was no exception for Mayor Koch.

title: Of Embassy Art
description: The State Department has decided to widen its program of brightening its foreign embassies with the works of American artists. The intention is to provide enough art to permit displays in the embassies' chanceries, or business offices, as well as in the ambassadorial residences, which now get most of the art that is available.

title: Why Question Loyalty Only of the Chinese?
description: To the Editor:

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST NOTE CONCERN FOR THE UNFORTUNATE
description: Concern for those in need during a time of prosperity is expressed by many contributors to the 74th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: TERRORISTS LINKED TO BEIRUT DISTRICTS
description: Italian investigators believe the terrorist attacks on the airports here and in Vienna were planned in Beirut and partly coordinated in Switzerland.

title: Macy's to Sell 12 of Its Stores
description: R. H. Macy & Company, the nation's 10th-largest retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 12 of its stores in Missouri and Kansas to Dillard Department Stores Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Duke Rolls On, 78-55
description: Johnny Dawkins had 21 points and Mark Alarie added 15 tonight as Duke (11-0) scored a 78-55 victory over Northwestern.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1985
description: International Washington accused Libya of aiding the terrorists who carried out airport attacks in Rome and Vienna last Friday and said the United States was ready to work with other governments to ''exert pressure'' on the Qaddafi Government to halt its export of terrorism. The attacks killed 18 people, including 5 Americans, and wounded more than 110 people. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: A Lot of Travail For a Little Bit of Travel
description: From the look on the face that emerged from the motorman's cab of an M train stuck in a tunnel in Brooklyn one morning, it was not a good day.

title: Bus-Stop Exhibition
description: The M-5 bus stop on Broadway at 65th Street was wrapped up in plastic a while ago, so people could not sit on its bright red bench or stand under its polished aluminium roof.

title: 550 More British Soldiers Being Sent to Ulster
description: The British Army said today that 550 additional soldiers would be sent to Northern Ireland this week to reinforce border security and protect police stations.

title: Careers;   A Trend To Older Workers
description: AS the year ends, there is a relatively new phenomenon in the labor area: help wanted signs that apparently are not drawing the young people who usually take these low-level jobs. This could mean that the person serving a hamburger in a fast-food restaurant or wrapping a book in a bookstore will be older in the future, upsetting a tradition.

title: PIER 1 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $414,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $148,000. c-After a loss of $875,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $487,000.

title: Bridge: Interpretation of a Double Brings an Unhappy Result
description: An old conundrum, modified for bridge players, inquires, ''When is a double not a double?'' The effort to separate penalty doubles from take-out doubles has become more difficult in recent years, as experts have developed special agreements about some low-level situations.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
FOREIGN MONEY CHANGING U.S. SOCIAL-CULTURAL LIFE
description: Michael Almond noticed a greater variety of wines showing up on store shelves in Charlotte, N.C. In Nashville, this year's United Way campaign was the city's most successful in history. At a new industrial park in Hibbing, Minn., 80 Americans will soon be manufacturing chopsticks by the hundreds of millions.

title: FOR THE RESORTS, SOME POLKA DOTS
description: Navy and white polka dots set the classic tone for resort fashions. As the first batch of warm-weather clothes arrive in the stores, displacing heavy fall clothes and holiday glitter, the new navy and white styles presage a cool, calm season.

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $225,000 for the quarter and $1,790,000 for the year. c-Net losses including an extraordinary credit of $9,662,000 for the quarter and year.

title: NAFCO FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics;   Questions of Image Fidel's Final Puff
description: ''I haven't really missed it that much,'' says Fidel Castro, explaining that he decided months ago that ''the one last sacrifice I must make for public health is to stop smoking.''

title: END OF CLEVELAND NEWSPAPER PROMPTS U.S. INQUIRY
description: For more than a year a Federal grand jury in Cleveland has been investigating to determine whether one of the city's two daily newspapers paid the other to go out of business in 1982.

title: Honored Police Officer Held in Miami Killings
description: A former ''officer of the month'' today became the sixth Miami police officer arrested in connection with the drowning of three men thought to have been smuggling drugs.

title: FOR ZIA, MUCH OF THE POWER REMAINS
description: By lifting martial law in Pakistan, President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq has enhanced the power of the new civilian Government while retaining his and the Army's ability to curb dissent and jail political opponents.

title: SUNBELT NURSERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bad to Worse
description: Bill Fitch recalls coaching the Cleveland Cavaliers in their formative days: ''We were the only team in history that could lose nine straight games and then go into a slump.''

title: LARGER ROLE LOOMS FOR AUBURN PASSER
description: Pat Washington, the Auburn quarterback, overslept this morning. Such a move just two days before his final game as a collegian would probably have irked most coaches. But not Jack Crowe, the Tigers' offensive coordinator. Indeed, he believes it might have been the best thing that could have happened to the player.

title: VOLCANOES' RISKS TO JETS SPUR SEARCH FOR SIGNS
description: AS avalanches of mud raced down the Nevado del Ruiz volcano in Colombia Nov. 13, killing more than 20,000 people, a lesser drama was developing overhead. A Caribbean Airlines cargo plane had accidentally flown into the erupting plume of ash, pumice balls and noxious gas.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION UNIT SET
description: HARVARD has established a special center dedicated to the proposition that reliable health information is vital to the public's intelligent pursuit of good health.

title: Advertising;   Radio City Account To Grey Entertainment
description: Grey Entertainment and Media, a division of Grey Advertising, has gotten the first sizable piece of new business since it was created in November.

title: NEW QUARTERBACK AT U.C.L.A.
description: Stability at quarterback is a coach's desire and often a team's necessity for success. But U.C.L.A., playing in its fifth consecutive bowl game, will be starting its fourth bowl quarterback in five years when the Bruins face Iowa in the 72d Rose Bowl on Wednesday. And it won't even be the Bruins' first-string quarterback.

title: U.S. ACCUSES LIBYA OF AIDING GUNMEN IN AIRPORT RAIDS
description: The Reagan Administration accused Libya today of aiding terrorists who staged attacks at the Rome and Vienna airports and said it was prepared to work with other Governments to ''exert pressure'' on Libya to halt the export of terrorism.

title: Citicorp's New York Leap
description: The decision of Citicorp to leap across the East River and plant a new 45-story headquarters building in Queens should enhance New York's future as an office center. It will also hearten New Yorkers outside Mahattan, who would finally benefit directly from the office explosion.

title: Advertising;   New Publication For Business Planned
description: Investment Management World is the name of a new controlled-circulation business publication that will be sent six times a year to 20,000 top investment professionals including the 15,700 members of the Financial Analysts Federation, sponsor of the publication.

title: RINGING IN THE NEW YOU AT HEALTH SPAS
description: Most people tend to think of the onset of the New Year as a time of commitment or recommitment, of wishes wished, of promises made that this year, this time, will surely be kept. And nowhere, it seems in these times when fitness is often akin to godliness, are such resolves more earnest than at America's spas.

title: Battle of the Floppies, With I.B.M. as Referee
description: THE first time I saw a floppy disk for a personal computer was back in the days when cassette tapes briefly dominated the micromemory market. The disk was eight inches in diameter, and the drive that used it, a Helios manufactured by the long-since-defunct Processor Technology, was the size of a filing cabinet drawer and quite literally required a hand truck to move it.

title: Park Named Coach
description: The former Ranger and Bruin defenseman, Brad Park, was named head coach yesterday of the struggling Detroit Red Wings, replacing Harry Neale, who had been on the job only six months. Their 8-23-4 record is the worst in the National Hockey League, and the Red Wings have lost 10 of their last 11 games, provoking speculation about the dismissal of Neale or General Manager Jimmy Devellano. Yesterday the club extended Devellano's contract for two years, through 1988, and gave him the title of vice president, but also announced that the two-and-a-half-year contract signed by Park makes him the director of player personnel as well as coach.

title: AIRLINES SAY THEY HAD WARNING ABOUT POSSIBLE MOVE BY TERRORISTS
description: Three days before the attacks on airports in Rome and Vienna, airlines were warned that ''Libyan-backed terrorists'' were planning actions over the holidays.

title: DENVER DREAMS OF A SUMMER GAME
description: Denver sends its greetings to the rest of the country and boasts that the weather here today is sunny with temperatures in the 50's.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1985
description: Companies

title: Florida St. Romps, 34-23
description: Chip Ferguson passed for 338 yards and two touchdowns and ran for another score tonight to lead Florida State to a 34-23 victory over Oklahoma State in the Gator Bowl.

title: 1985: A YEAR OF TALK BUT LITTLE ACTION
description: HAS the school reform engine run out of steam? In 1985 there were fewer headline-grabbing reports calling for reforms. Earlier clarion calls for an educational New Deal were not followed by a rush to action.

title: SALICK HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DR. G. C. PAFFENBARGER
description: Dr. George C. Paffenbarger, senior research associate of the American Dental Association Research Laboratory at the National Bureau of Standards in Gaithersburg, Md., died Dec. 14 at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 83 years old.

title: Agent in Contact With Richardson
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, a basketball player with dazzling skill and a troubled personal history, surfaced yesterday after a three-day disappearance that prompted concern among basketball executives, teammates and friends that he had relapsed into the cocaine addiction that disrupted his career two and a half years ago.

title: Advertising;   Ad Session Returning To the U.S.
description: VARIOUS committees are at work preparing for the International Advertising Association's World Congress which is returning to the United States after a 20-year absence.

title: Daniels Group Is Active In Key Cable-TV Deals
description: It seems that whenever a major cable television deal is announced, the name Bill Daniels almost always comes into the picture.

title: SOVIET BARS A DAUGHTER'S EMIGRATION
description: Soviet authorities have approved an exit visa for Irina McClellan, who has not seen her American husband for 11 years, but will not allow her daughter to emigrate, Mrs. McClellan said today.

title: IN TIMES SQ., CREATING HOPE FOR YOUNG LIVES
description: Out of the hospital where he was treated for tuberculosis and severe psychiatric problems, Victor is back in Times Square, freebasing cocaine and threatening to kill himself at age 16. Nicole's baby is due any day now; Nicole is 15. From 16-year-old Wanda, enrolled in a residential drug treatment program upstate, comes a hopeful letter. ''If I lived through 42d Street, I can make it through this,'' she wrote. ''I love you, Trudee. I've been drug-free 25 days.''

title: DELAY-PLAGUED SEWAGE PLANT ON HUDSON STARTED UP
description: Thirteen years after the first pilings were driven into the Hudson River to support the platform upon which it rests, one of the huge diesel engines at the North River Water Pollution Control Plant was revved up yesterday to begin treating much of the sewage the city dumps into the river each day.

title: Homosexual Judge Is Named By Koch to a 3d Interim Term
description: Mayor Koch yesterday appointed William J. Thom to his third interim term as a judge of the Civil Court.

title: 7 COLOMBIANS ARRESTED IN QUEENS IN SALE OF 120 POUNDS OF COCAINE
description: Six men and one woman, all Colombian nationals, were arrested in Queens Sunday as they delivered 120 pounds of cocaine to undercover agents, drug-enforcement officials announced yesterday.

title: FORMER PATIENT IS SOUGHT
description: A 47-year-old Brooklyn man with a complaint about past surgery fatally shot a doctor at Kings County Hospital Center yesterday afternoon and walked away from the scene, the police said. He remained at large last evening.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TELEFILE COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a net gain from debt restructuring of $154,145 and a tax credit. c-Net income.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Kid Creole and Band In Homecoming Concert
description: From the Marx Brothers to James Brown, so many pop cultural references swirl together in the music of the Caribbean-funk ensemble, Kid Creole and the Coconuts, that watching one of its shows is like entering a surrealistic time capsule. One is besieged with comic multiple exposures of iconography adapted from four decades of popular culture - a melange of Ricky Ricardo, calypso, go-go girls and break-dancing.

title: JUST ANOTHER FOOTBALL GAME NOW
description: Ever since its bold beginning in 1970, ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' has been billed as more than a game. The claim that it was something special was technically true because virtually all other games were played on Sunday afternoons before the hometown crowd and often a restricted television audience. This one would stand alone, a monopoly of sorts.

title: Leaflets in Shopping Malls, America's New Main St.
description: To the Editor:

title: Commodities Case Advances
description: Customers of the Volume Investors Corporation, a commodities broker that collapsed last March, are a step closer to receiving full reimbursement after an agreement was reached on terms to settle a key lawsuit in the case.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Michael Ventresca, 38, Dead; Worked in '80 Kennedy Drive
description: Michael A. Ventresca, a political organizer and lobbyist who had worked with two generations of the Kennedy family, was killed when his car was struck at a red light by a motorist later charged with driving under the influence of narcotics.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE LIFE AND DEATH OF AN AGENT
description: The last act of Audrey Wood's life was long, ambiguous and wholly dissatisfying, the sort of thing the legendary agent never would have countenanced in a play. But life did not imitate art in Audrey Wood's case and her death last Friday at the age of 80, after more than four years in a coma, left friends, colleagues and clients with a mixture of relief and unfocused rage.

title: Citicorp Paper Sale
description: At its weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday, Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.720 percent, down from 7.809 percent last week. A total of $450 million in bids was submitted, and $50 million was accepted. The bank holding company also sold $50 million of 182-day commercial paper, from $450 million in bids, at an average rate of 7.580 percent, down from 7.606 percent at the previous auction.

title: KING HUSSEIN AND ASSAD HOLD FIRST TALK SINCE '79
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Syria today for talks with an old enemy, President Hafez al-Assad, against whom he almost went to war five years ago. Diplomats said they believed the talks could have major implications for Middle East politics.

title: BIG DROP NOTED IN NEW YORK AREA DRINKING
description: The patterns of social drinking in the New York metropolitan area are changing markedly, according to people who run the region's taverns, restaurants and liquor stores.

title: DEFICIT LAW FAILS CONSTITUTION TEST, U.S. ADVISES COURT
description: The Reagan Administration told a Federal court today that a key provision of a new budget-balancing law was unconstitutional.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an art review in the Critics' Choices column of The Guide on Dec. 22 misidentified the site of Augustus Saint-Gaudens's monument to General Sherman. It is in Manhattan, at Grand Army Plaza on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street.

title: ISRAELIS DENY U.S. HAS ASKED THEM FOR RESTRAINT
description: Israeli leaders insisted today that the United States had not asked them to show restraint in responding to the terrorist attacks staged last Friday.

title: Anderson, Clayton Move
description: T. J. Barlow, who has been taking a gradual leave from the top management of Anderson, Clayton & Company, the Houston-based food products concern, will take early retirement at the start of the new year, the company has announced. However, it said he would continue as chairman ''on an interim basis'' until a successor was named.

title: DITKA HAPPY TO FACE GIANTS
description: Shortly before his Bears escaped the chilly weather here today for several days practice in more temperate Suwanee, Ga., Coach Mike Ditka remembered a conversation he had with Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants at the National Football League meetings in Phoenix last March.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: DAVID EWEN
description: David Ewen, the author of dozens of books about music, died of heart disease Saturday in Miami. He was 78 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $50,000 for the quarter and $97,500 for the year. c-Net losses.

title: TOM STOPPARD TV FILM ON SHELF AFTER 2 YEARS
description: ''Squaring the Circle,'' a television film about the Solidarity movement in Poland that was written by Tom Stoppard, won considerable acclaim when shown on Britain's Channel 4 in May rector and its American co-producer became involved in a dispute over its content, and two years after it was finished, it has still not been seen in this country.

title: Sharing the Spoils of Divorce
description: New York's highest court has sent a message of fairness across the country to lawyers, judges, husbands - and especially wives. By ruling that a doctor's medical license is marital property, the Court of Appeals lends powerful weight to the proposition that when marriages crash, the pieces must be divided reasonably, not just ritually.

title: LATE SPURT SENDS DOW TO GAIN OF 7.46
description: A sleepy stock market awoke in the last half-hour of trading yesterday to produce Wall Street's third consecutive impressive gain as volume recovered somewhat from recent holiday-depressed levels.

title: 6,032 WAR DEAD IN '85, NICARAGUA ANNOUNCES
description: Nicaragua's Defense Minister said today that rebel forces had killed 1,143 Government soldiers during 1985 while suffering 4,608 dead.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage, has named Rolf H. Towe chief financial officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: NUMEROUS TAX CHANGES TAKE EFFECT TOMORROW
description: The new year brings forth a variety of changes in the Federal income tax system, regardless of whether Congress overhauls tax policy.

title: Fathers, Sons And Daughter
description: He's the typical in-betweener, a 6-foot-3-inch freshman trying to make the transition from high school power forward to college guard. Maybe late this season, or early next, the kid will make the traveling squad. But when his team, St. Francis of Pennsylvania, played in a tournament in Connecticut last weekend, Elvin Hayes Jr. was back in Houston, spending the holidays with his family and trying to get a game of one-on-one with his father. It was something of a mismatch: Elvin Sr., besides being seven inches taller, retired as the third-leading scorer in the history of the National Basketball Association.

title: Frederic D. Starrett Jr. Dies; Frozen Potato Skin Vendor
description: Frederic D. Starrett Jr., who pioneered the marketing of frozen potato skins, died Saturday in a hospital here. He was 64 years old.

title: RISE IN FEDERAL GRAZING FEES IS SOUGHT BY WILDLIFE GROUP
description: The National Wildlife Federation has charged that artificially low fees paid by Western ranchers for grazing their cattle on public lands have cost taxpayers $500 million in the last seven years.

title: The Tax Bill in Mid-Season
description: The year of the Great Tax Revision ends with much uncertainty about what, if anything, will finally be changed. The House has produced a good bill, but it passed only after Mr. Reagan mollified Republicans with a hurried promise to hold out for significant further alterations in the Senate. The word from the Senate, however, is that major alterations are unlikely. So will the President end up having to veto his own initiative?

title: What's Right in The World
description: Winston Churchill said in the worst of times, ''I'm an optimist because there's not much point in anything else.''

title: Charlotte Curtis;   '85 Style Was Substance
description: IT wasn't such a bad year. The President traveled a lot. The First Lady got a more fashionable dog. Raiders, merger moguls and other millionaires eyed one another's companies hungrily, slipped into the limelight, liked it and stayed around to be photographed. They didn't have to wait long. Big money still matters in New York, and it showed up everywhere. Milton Petrie gave $10 million to Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Mortimer Zuckerman paid $8.5 million for a Fifth Avenue apartment. Saul P. Steinberg smiled up at us from the increasingly indispensable Manhattan, inc. magazine and paid for the installation of the Metropolitan Museum's beloved Christmas tree and creche.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising;   Interpublic Group Adds To Low Howard Stake
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies has completed its previously disclosed plans to increase its equity in Low Howard-Spink, a British holding company, to 38 percent from 30 percent.

title: FOR 2 QUARTERBACKS, A WORTHWHILE WAIT
description: There were days when both felt as if they had made a mistake and were waiting for an opportunity that would never come. It has been well chronicled how Vinny Testaverde, the University of Miami quarterback, sat and watched Bernie Kosar for two seasons when there was a feeling among some of the coaches that he was probably the better quarterback. At Tennessee, however, no one implied that Daryl Dickey should be playing ahead of Tony Robinson.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are a number of ways that the United States can take action to discourage terrorism.

title: Rival Rejects Bid
description: The Rival Manufacturing Company said it had terminated talks with the Newell Company regarding Newell's unsolicited proposal to buy Rival for $18.50 a share, or a total of about $116 million. Rival, a housewares company, said discussions were continuing between it and the New York investment firm of Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen regarding a buyout of Rival for $17.50 a share, or about $110 million. Rival did not say why the talks were ended.

title: THE EUROBOND MARKET BOOM
description: Sports cars, mink coats and ski trips were hot items this year on holiday shopping lists of the well-heeled players in the Eurobond market. With higher salaries and hefty bonuses spread liberally throughout London's version of Wall Street such pricey purchases are just one indication of the boom in the international capital markets.

title: 3 Fireworks Diplays Part of Celebrations
description: Besides gathering in Times Square, New Yorkers will ring in the new year tonight with fireworks displays and other activities in Central Park, Prospect Park in Brooklyn and the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan.

title: Lakes on Mars
description: Photographs taken of Mars from oribiting Viking spacecraft have revealed that lakes as large as the Great Lakes and as much as three miles deep existed early in that planet's history, two researchers have concluded. If Mars was as cold as it is today, the lakes would have been perpetually covered with ice.

title: Paradyne Barred From U.S. Work
description: The Paradyne Corporation has been suspended from receiving further United States Government contracts because of Federal fraud allegations involving a $115 million computer system for the Social Security Administration, a company official said.

title: Old Contract Settled
description: The former National Football League quarterback, Pat Thomas, has settled an old debt. Yesterday in Washington, Thomas won a $200,000 grievance settlement for breach of contract from both the Los Angeles Raiders and the Los Angeles Rams. In a ruling Dec. 26, arbitrator Sam Kagel ruled that each club owes Thomas $100,000 for breaching Thomas's 1983 contract.

title: ARMY AND ILLINOIS: AN OFFENSIVE MATCH
description: The Peach Bowl is the name of the game, but for Army and Illinois, the compromise bowl would be more fitting.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Islanders vs. Red Wings, at Detroit, 7:35 P.M. This is the Islanders' first meeting of the season with the Red Wings, who have a new coach.

title: MCNEIL SLUMPS LATE IN YEAR
description: In a pensive moment at the end of the 1982-83 season, thinking about the Jets' future after they had lost the American Conference championship game, Richard Todd said, ''We can go as far as Freeman McNeil carries us.''

title: Truth Is Just Another Victim of 'Contras'
description: To the Editor:

title: COMET IS ENTERING PRIME VIEWING PERIOD
description: ALTHOUGH Halley's comet has yet to put on its brightest show, the next two weeks will probably be the best opportunity to view the famous comet in most parts of North America. After that, it will be necessary to travel far to the south, preferably to the Southern Hemisphere, to see it.

title: 2 Georgia Girls Return; Police Seek Abductors
description: Two 12-year-old girls who vanished more than a week ago while riding their bicycles were released blindfolded on a dirt road today and told the police they had been kidnapped and raped by two masked men.

title: Other Subway Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ENERGY IDEAS EMERGE AS OIL RESERVES DWINDLE
description: MEMORIES of 1979's gasoline station lines have been dimmed by today's seeming abundance of cheaper oil, and the dash to exploit alternative energy sources has slowed to a crawl.

title: PREMIER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $835,000 and an estimated loss of $2,675,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,608,000.

title: Utah Supreme Court Upholds Conviction in a 1978 Murder
description: The Utah Supreme Court tody unanimously upheld the murder conviction of Marc Schreuder, who said his mother, prominent in fashionable society, sent him to kill her millionaire father out of fear she was losing her inheritance.

title: THE OFFICE GLUT IN DALLAS
description: This city of big ambitions is suffering growing pains. By some estimates, unrented office space in Dallas will exceed 40 million square feet next year, for a vacancy rate of close to 30 percent.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEE 4% GROWTH IN '86
description: The Reagan Administration predicted today that the nation's economy will pull out of this year's languid performance and grow by a brisk 4 percent in 1986.

title: Battery Park City Housing-Bond Plan Would Aid the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess: Jan Timman Now Qualified For the Candidates Matches
description: Jan Timman, the Dutch grandmaster, has qualified for the candidates matches that will produce a challenger for the world championship.

title: WINNIE MANDELA HELD FOR SECOND TIME
description: Winnie Mandela was arrested for the second time in eight days today for breaking government restrictions on her movements.

title: Leading Indicators Up by Only 0.1%
description: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge last month posted its poorest performance since June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SCIENTISTS FIND CITY IS A SERIES OF VARYING PERCEPTIONS
description: IN a sense, social scientists find, the city does not exist. There is no such single entity, but rather many cities, as many as there are people to experience them. And researchers now believe that the subjective reality is every bit as important to understanding and fostering successful urban life as the concrete and asphalt of objective measurement.

title: Bill Rates Increase Slightly
description: The Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday resulted in slightly higher average discount rates. The average rate on the 90-day bills rose to 7.04 percent, from 7.02 percent the previous week, while that on the companion six-month bills rose to 7.07 percent from 7.05 percent.

title: Setback for CBS In Ziff-Davis Suit
description: A New York State Supreme Court judge has said that CBS Inc. cannot charge the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company with fraud in its $40 million lawsuit against the publisher. But Judge Martin Evans, in an opinion filed Dec. 24, said CBS could still proceed on its breach-of-contract charge.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins recalled the defenseman Chris Dahlquist from the Baltimore Skipjacks to replace Rod Buskas, who is suffering from bruised ribs. . . . Howard (Moe) Ankney, assistant football coach at the University of Arizona, was appointed head coach at his alma mater, Bowling Green State University. He replaces Denny Stolz, who resigned Dec. 11 to become head coach at San Diego State University. . . . Billy Olson, the defending pole-vault champion, set a world best indoor mark at 19 feet 2 3/4 inches Saturday night at a meet in Saskatchewan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend on Nov. 15 about Hoboken misstated the history of early electric train service. While such service began in Hoboken in 1930, it was not the world's first; electric trains had previously operated in other cities.

title: HOSTAGES SOUGHT, VIENNA GUNMEN SAY
description: The two terrorists who attacked an airport check-in lounge here Friday have told investigators that they had planned to take Israeli hostages and fly them out of the country aboard an El Al Israel Airlines plane, the Austrian Interior Minister said today.

title: ROYAL BALLET'S 'ROMEO AND JULIET'
description: AS television gears up for the usual assortment of midnight revelries to welcome in the new year, one of the more elegant vehicles for seeing out the old is being made available on Channel 5 from 7:30 to 10 tonight. Manufacturers Hanover is sponsoring the complete Royal Ballet version of ''Romeo and Juliet.'' The production, which had its premiere in 1965, is choreographed by Kenneth MacMillan to the score by Prokofiev. The young lovers are danced by Alessandra Ferri and Wayne Eagling.

title: Westland Seeks Revised Aid Plan
description: Westland, the British helicopter maker courted with rival American and European offers of aid, asked a European consortium to submit a simplified version of a package intended to save it from closing.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
SHANKER ASSESSES EDUCATION
description: TOMORROW, after 21 years in office, Albert Shanker will step down as president of the United Federation of Teachers, the largest union local in the United States. Mr. Shanker announced his resignation Dec. 14, saying he wanted to devote more time to his duties as president of the American Federation of Teachers, the parent organization of the New York City local. In an interview earlier this month, Mr. Shanker discussed the impending change and other questions concerning education. Following are excerpts from that dialogue.

title: HIGH U.S.-HANOI PARLEY NEXT WEEK ON MISSING
description: The United States and Vietnam will hold talks on the highest level in nine years next Monday in Hanoi, the State Department announced today.

title: 2 BOEING DEALS TOTAL $2 BILLION
description: The Boeing Company received orders for up to $2 billion worth of planes yesterday from Japan Air Lines and the United Parcel Service.

title: NEW SOBRIETY EMPTYING AL'S CAFE
description: Silver tinsel decked the halls and a pop version of ''Silent Night'' boomed from the jukebox, but at Al's Cafe, 14 tables were empty.

title: Talking Business with Plaskett of American Airlines
description: American Airlines on Dec. 20 announced new discounts on its fares of up to 75 percent throughout its system. The discounts, which carry some restrictions, were due to expire Feb. 10. That same day United Airlines said that it was matching the cuts and extending them to March 20. Most of the major airlines have followed the reductions, some reluctantly. Thomas G. Plaskett, the senior vice president of marketing at American, who played a major role in the decision to put in the discounts, talks about the reasons for the step and some of its consequences.

title: Averting Nuclear Disaster
description: As the year ends, words of encouragement seem to rise from everywhere, including the local office of the Age of Enlightenment News Service, an affiliate of the organization of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, whose adepts teach meditation and operate a university in downtown Washington.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,236,000 for the quarter and year and an extraordinay gains of $1,527,000 for the quarter and $4,452,000 for the year from the exchange of debentures. c-Net losses after charges of $1,578,000 for the quarter and $2,902,000 for the year from the closing of facilities.

title: MIGRATORY PATTERNS TRACED IN SERENGETI
description: From the window of Dr. Markus Borner's office, one looks south across an expanse of thinning acacia trees where gazelles and wildebeest roam in the hundreds of thousands. Here the great Serengeti plains begin, a seemingly endless landscape virtually void of vegetation taller than a bush. Across this plain, perhaps the greatest migration of animals in the world occurs each year as nearly 1.5 million wildebeest and more than 200,000 zebras move in search of food along routes defined in large measure by the pattern of rainfall that sweeps across eastern Central Africa.

title: 9 OF 10 FOUND GUILTY IN SKIMMING TRIAL
description: A reputed Mafia leader, his business partner and seven associates were convicted yesterday in a racketeering case that involved skimming more than $2 million from bars and restaurants.

title: 2 Abortion Clinics Attacked in Cincinnati
description: Arsonists attacked two city abortion clinics this morning, causing $75,000 damage to each and forcing both to close.

title: Cuba Cutting Back On Military Spending
description: Cuba will reduce its outlays for the military and public security next year after failing to meet production goals for sugar and other leading exports this year, according to newly published figures.

title: M.T.A. MAY LET COMPANIES BID FOR BUS ROUTES
description: Under pressure from the Reagan Administration, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it was studying the possibility of letting private companies bid against its agencies to operate some of the city's bus routes.

title: Coloring the Coast Guard
description: Semper Paratus, or ''Always Prepared,'' is still the Coast Guard motto, and the editor of the Commandant's Bulletin, a magazine published every two weeks by the service, seemed ready for some reader complaints about its current issue.

title: Strip Searches of Infants Upheld in Prison Visits
description: The need for security during visits with prison inmates outweighs an infant's right to privacy, a Federal appeals court has ruled in rejecting a prisoner's complaint about the strip search of his diapered son.

title: An Angolan Guest
description: The American Conservative Union expects to have Jonas Savimbi, the leader of anti-government forces in Angola, as a guest of honor at its three-day Conservative Political Action Conference that starts Jan. 30 in Washington.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 9:41 A.M. today and set at 9:31 P.M. tonight.

title: Playoff Standings
description: New England's victory over the Jets last Saturday marked the first time that the Patriot franchise had won a postseason game since routing Buffalo, 26-8, in a playoff that determined first place in the Eastern Division of the old American Football League 22 years ago. Over all, the Patriots have won just two playoff games in their history, and only five franchises in the National Football League - Atlanta, Detroit, New Orleans, St. Louis and Tampa Bay -have achieved lesser totals since the A.F.L. was formed in 1960.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AN 11-YEAR-OLD AMERICAN SLAIN IN ATTACK IS BURIED
description: Natasha Simpson, an 11-year-old American slain in the terrorist attack at the Rome airport last Friday, was buried today after a emotional funeral mass attended by her classmates and several hundred other people.

title: A New Rule on Terminating Pensions
description: Companies terminating pension plans to siphon off excess cash will be able to report the excess immediately as profit under a new accounting rule issued yesterday. The rule changes the longstanding practice under which companies had to amortize, or spread, the profit over many years.

title: Green Bay Dismissal
description: Bob Schnelker has been dismissed as offensive coordinator of the Green Bay Packers, Coach Forrest Gregg confirmed yesterday.

title: STAGE: 'I HAVE A DREAM,' MUSIC-DRAMA ON DR. KING
description: THE Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was one of the great orators of modern times. The civil rights leader and apostle of nonviolent protest developed a style of public address that fused the sacred and the secular, the musical and the prosaic into a passionate inspirational rhetoric invoking a mystical faith in the triumph of humanity's nobler instincts. Dr. King's was a Christian philosophy that insisted, ''You must love your enemies - you must meet hate with love.''

title: Sooner Goes From Starter To Spare Part
description: He has been considered the most talented passing quarterback in the history of a university where the precise execution of a sideways toss has taken priority over the forward pass.

title: Victim of Mall Crash Dies
description: A 14-month-old boy who was injured when a plane crashed into a crowded shopping mall has died, becoming the fifth victim of the Dec. 23 accident. Alexander Luong, of Concord, who suffered burns over 35 percent of his body, died Saturday night in Children's Hospital, the nursing supervisor's office reported. Investigators have narrowed the cause of the crash to poor weather or pilot error, said experts of the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: 'GENERIC NEWS,' A ONE-MAN TEAM
description: THERE'S good news tonight.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SCIENTIFICALLY speaking, Marvin Harris tells us, human beings are omnivores - between us we manage to consume an enormous number of different substances, animal, vegetable and mineral. But that doesn't mean that we all eat everything that is edible. Some of us eat some things, some of us eat other things, and one man's delicacy is quite likely to be another man's aversion.

title: 54 INJURED AS TRAIN CRASHES AT END OF TRACK IN HOBOKEN TERMINAL
description: Fifty-four people on a rush-hour commuter train were injured this morning when the train failed to stop as it entered the N. J. Transit terminal here and slammed into a concrete bumper at the end of the track.

title: Dissidents Deserve Dr. Chazov's Nobel
description: The controversy surrounding the Soviet doctor Yevgeny I. Chazov, a co-recipient of this year's Nobel Peace Prize, has much discredited him throughout the West as a stooge of the Kremlin with little real concern for either peace or human rights. Yet, for all the fuss, few Westerners have given much thought to the real nature and status of the peace movement -or movements, as the case may be -in the Soviet Union.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: NOW that the season to be jolly is past, the real fun for fashion fans - the season of post-Christmas markdowns - begins.

title: Jobs's Apple Stake
description: Steven P. Jobs, the former chairman of Apple Computer Inc., has reduced his stake in Apple from 7.2 percent of its shares outstanding to 5.6 percent. Mr. Jobs did not disclose details on the sale of one million Apple common shares in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Jobs resigned in September after a dispute with Apple's board.

title: Mutual Fund Sales Triple
description: Net sales of all mutual funds climbed to $78.5 billion in 1985, tripling the record of $26.0 billion set last year, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS ELECTIONS FOR 7 CHICAGO COUNCIL SEATS
description: A Federal judge ordered today that special City Council elections be held in March in seven predominantly black and Hispanic wards.

title: PROJECTS FILL FORD'S OLD JERSEY COMPLEX
description: Quiet and inactive for nearly four years, the sprawling auto assembly complex that the Ford Motor Company had operated for more than 25 years at the foot of the Ramapo Mountains in Mahwah, N.J., sprang into life about a year ago. That was when construction started there on the North American headquarters for Japan's Sharp Corporation and workers began dismantling the old plant in preparation for a new office and hotel development.

title: Lebanon Militia Chiefs Announce Cease-Fire
description: Christian and Moslem militia leaders called today for a cease-fire beginning Tuesday as part of the Syrian-sponsored armistice.

title: The Arab-American Counts His Stereotypes
description: A Washington real estate advertisement pictures an excited Arab sheik with dollar signs on his dark glasses. The message reads: ''Is Washington For Sale?''

title: U.N. COUNCIL CONDEMNS ATTACKS
description: The Security Council today condemned the recent terrorist attacks at Rome and Vienna airports. The condemnation took the form of a statement issued by the council's president.

title: Italian Film Series
description: A screening of Federico Fellini's ''8 1/2'' on Jan. 31 will open a seven-part series devoted to Italian films at Columbia University's Casa Italiana, Amsterdam Avenue and 116th Street. The films have English subtitles and will be shown Fridays at 7 P.M. Admission to each is $5 ($3 for students).

title: Marcos Says Rival Trifles With U.S. Bases
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today accused his challenger, Corazon C. Aquino, of playing ''political football'' with United States military installations in the Philippines, and he vowed to maintain the bases.

title: PAUL S. UNDERWOOD, EX-TIMES REPORTER, AND WIFE DIE IN FIRE
description: Paul Staats Underwood, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times, and his wife, Mary, died early yesterday in a fire at the home of friends they were visiting in Randolph Township, N.J.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $28,943 for the quarter and $111,875 for the year. c-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $38,078 for the quarter and $1,683,689 for the year. Hubbard Real Estate Investment Trust said it will change its name to HRE Properties when the trust become self-administered on Feb. 1, 1986.

title: WAYNE J. HOLMAN Jr.
description: Wayne J. Holman Jr., a retired executive of Johnson & Johnson, died Friday at Middlesex General-University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J., after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Plainfield, N.J.

title: NETS' SUBSTITUTES EXCEL IN VICTORY
description: The Nets put the ball in the hands of Darwin Cook and Kelvin Ransey tonight in the absence of Micheal Ray Richardson, and the substitute guards accounted for 33 points in a 123-111 victory over the Knicks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: A BIT OF VIETNAM IS PLANTED IN CHINA
description: In a clearing between rice paddies, a shirtless youth pedals rhythmically on a threshing machine. Close by, an old woman with a bun of silver hair cries across the paddies to summon an idling water buffalo. Crickets chatter in the trees.

title: R.A.F. BOMBS MAY HAVE DOWNED GLENN MILLER PLANE
description: Two members of a Royal Air Force bomber crew in World War II believe they can explain one of the unsolved mysteries of the war: the disappearance of the band leader Glenn Miller. The two say they fear the band leader's plane was downed over the English Channel by bombs jettisoned from their own plane as they returned from an aborted mission.

title: 3 BISON WANDER FROM YELLOWSTONE AND ARE KILLED IN MONTANA HUNT
description: Just after daybreak today, two Montana hunters raised their rifles and shot two bison that had wandered out of Yellowstone National Park.

title: Phillips Appoints Head of New Unit
description: Kenneth L. Smalley, who first joined the Phillips Petroleum Company in 1954, was named yesterday to head a newly combined natural gas and gas liquids subsidiary at Phillips headquarters in Bartlesville, Okla.

title: THOMAS N. TARLEAU
description: Thomas N. Tarleau, a Manhattan lawyer and former legislative counsel to the Department of the Treasury, died Thursday at Venice (Fla.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Englewood, Fla.

title: TRW Acquires Circle
description: TRW Inc. has announced it has acquired Circle Computer Services Inc., an Illinois company that provides technical services to leasing companies and users of International Business Machines Corporation computer equipment.

title: GAF LOSES A ROUND IN COURT
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to grant the GAF Corporation a preliminary injunction that would have prevented the Union Carbide Corporation from defending itself against an unwanted takeover by GAF.

title: To Party or Not on New Year's Eve
description: How do the newsmakers in the nation's capital mark the passage of the old year into the new? The answers are as different as the newsmakers themselves.

title: Mexico Cuts Oil Prices
description: Mexico announced today that it was lowering its crude oil prices by an average of 90 cents a barrel, retroactive to Dec. 1.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,977,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: For a One-Term, Six-Year Presidency
description: Once again, thanks to President Reagan's observations about the 22d Amendment, the nation is turning its attention to the Presidential term. How long can - or should - a chief executive run the country? Does re-election enhance or diminish a President's ability to govern effectively?

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Wynton Marsalis At the Joyce Theater
description: The trumpeter Wynton Marsalis is breaking in a new quartet with his engagement through next Sunday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. Mr. Marsalis's quiet assurance and restless lyricism continue to grow, but if a lackluster early show Friday was indicative, his new quartet is still finding its feet.

title: European Steel Gets Quotas
description: The United States today imposed unilateral quotas on European Economic Community exports of semifinished steel products, and the Common Market immediately vowed retaliation in the latest round of the steel trade war.

title: Campaign for the Far East
description: There is a lull in election fever in the city now, no banners, bumper stickers or bustling volunteers - except in a small apartment in midtown.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is currently in reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws.

title: SIGNMAKER GOES TO WORK AGAIN
description: A day ago, it was the San Francisco 49ers. Next Sunday, it will be the Chicago Bears. After that, who knows?

title: Market Place;   G.M. May Lag Behind Rivals
description: AS Detroit's Big Three auto makers head into 1986, stock market prospects for Chrysler and Ford are running ahead of those for General Motors, according to most Wall Street analysts. Reflecting these judgments, shares of both Ford and Chrysler traded recently at record prices on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: WELLINGTON MARA LOOKS BACK
description: The Giants and the Bears - the nicknames alone symbolize their storied stature as the two cornerstone teams of the National Football League's formative years. Over the N.F.L.'s first four decades, the Giants and the Bears played for the championship six times, with the Giants winning three. And on Sunday, in the Super Bowl XX divisional playoffs, the Giants and the Bears will be opponents in a post-season game for the first time since the 1963 title game in 10-degree cold at Wrigley Field.

title: Other Subway Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VIEWS FROM ON HIGH On New Year's Eve, many feel the need for sociability, for the press of bodies, as in Times Square, for reassurance in the path of time's inexorable advance. Others want to get away and above the crowd to contemplate past and future with a special perspective of the present.

title: Indian Copter Crash Kills 4
description: All four crew members of an air force helicopter were killed when it crashed on a routine mission in eastern India today, the Press Trust of India reported. The news agency did not say exactly where the Chetak helicopter crashed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the history of terrorism in 1985 incorrectly described a June attack in San Salvador. The 13 deaths there occurred not in an explosion but in firing by gunmen at a cafe.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects a $2 million reserve for potential writeoffs for the company's medical products inventories and other expenses. c-Net income including a tax benefit of $305,000 for the quarter and 9 months related to the company's Domestic International Sales Corp.

title: POLICE KILL GUNMAN HOLDING 2 BOYS HOSTAGE
description: A heroin addict who was holding two teen-age brothers hostage was shot to death today by a police sniper after a 30-hour siege in which the addict demanded $50,000 and plane tickets for himself and the boys.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE APPROVES SALE OF ST. LOUIS GLOBE-DEMOCRAT
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today approved the proposed sale of The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, which has stopped publishing, to a group headed by two local business executives.

title: Cray Research
description: Cray Research Inc. said the University of Texas had ordered a Cray X-MP/24 computer system, including a 32-million-word solid-state storage device, valued at about $14.5 million.

title: For New York State's Toxic-Materials Fire Test
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 RACISTS ARE CONVICTED ON RACKETEERING CHARGES BY SEATTLE JURY
description: Nine men and a woman accused of conspiring to bring about a racist revolution were convicted today on racketeering charges based on a cross-country crime spree by a white supremacy sect called the Order.

title: BREAKING THE NEWS ABOUT AIDS TO THE FAMILY
description: Earlier this year, Kenneth Meeks and Jack Steinhebel drove an hour from Manhattan to Kenneth's parents' condominium here in the suburbs for lunch. Ken Meeks had something to say to his mother and father.

title: Confusion in West Africa Over Cease-Fire Plans
description: Mali and Burkina Faso, which fought a five-day border war, have agreed to cease-fires worked out by two separate parties, and the result today was confusion over which was the operative pact.

title: For New York State's Toxic-Materials Fire Test
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Workers Contaminated In Leak at 3 Mile Island
description: Six workers were slightly contaminated today when radioactive water sprayed from a broken pump seal for 10 minutes at the Unit 1 reactor of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, plant officials said.

title: DEBT STUDY IN CABLE BID
description: The debt of Time Inc., Tele-Communications Inc. and the Comcast Corporation has been placed under review for possible downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday. About $790 million of debt is affected.

title: GEN. WERNER FLEISSNER
description: Gen. Werner Fleissner, an East German Deputy Defense Minister since 1963, died Friday after a serious illness, the East German press agency said today. He was 63 years old. General Fleissner was in charge of weaponry and military technology.

title: Lotus Buys Isys
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, in its fourth acquisition this year, said it would buy the Isys Corporation, a small software house, in a merger that would give Lotus rights to a series of financial data bases and programs that Isys sells to large companies.
